column2: Notices are Being sent out to the more than 30,000 members of the Army's Organized Reserve Corps in the New York-New Jersey Military District, it was announced yesterday, of the first mass assembly of the area's entire Reserve Corps ever to be held.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Department store sales in the week ended Nov. 5 were 2 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Control of poliomyelitis "within the foreseeable future" was confidently predicted today by Dr. Harry M. Weaver, research director of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, as the final session of the organizations' annual conference of state advisers.

How those New York Bulldogs have perked up! Enthused by their upset victory over the Giants, on the heels of an almost equally surprising tie with the Redskins, Charley Ewart's once down-trodden charges are actually snarling defiance at the Chicago Cardinals, their opponent of Sunday at the Polo Grounds.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Testimony taken at the hospital bedside of the Bolivian pilot of the P-38 fighter plane that collided Nov. 1 with an Eastern Air Lines DC-4 over National Airport was heard today by officials investigating the crash, which took the lives of all fifty-five persons aboard the airliner.

Dorothy Shaver, president of Lord Taylor, and William M. Holmes, chairman of the board of Jacqueline Cochran Cosmetics, have been designated New York co-chairmen of the 1949 Arthritis and Rheumatism Campaign, it was announced yesterday by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, national campaign chairman.

The resignation of Edward E. (Hook) Mylin as head coach of football at New York University, effective at the expiration of his three-year contract next February, was announced yesterday through the university publicity office.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- President Truman said today that he had not given any consideration to appointing John Foster Dulles as a member of the United States delegation to the United Nations.

Maurice Levin, who resigned last week as chairman of the board of directors of Hearn Department Stores, Inc., announced yesterday that he was retiring from business to direct a drive to raise a $15,000,000 endowment fund for the Jewish Theological Seminary of America.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- The Truman Administration has far-reaching economic aims which, if achieved, will replace the collective judgment of free consumers as to what they need and can have with the judgments of Government officials, Harold G. Moulton, president of the Brookings Institution, said today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 10 -- The Soviet Union replied here today to Yugoslav reports of the concentration of Soviet troops on the borders of the erstwhile satellite state, characterizing the reports as "nothing else but provocatory acts initiated by the intelligence services of various Western powers."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- President Truman agreed today to relieve Maj. Gen. Frank R. McCoy, retired, as United States representative on the Far Eastern Commission. The release will be effective on Nov. 30.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 11 -Navy's football team finds itself in a strange position on the eve of its game tomorrow with Columbia at Thompson Field.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 11 -- Let no would-be aggressor expect to capitalize on what may appear to be dissension within the armed forces of the United States, Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson warned, this Armistice Day.

BOSTON, Nov. 11 -- Boston College's football team, largely on the strength of its Ed Songin, who leads the passers in the East, has been rated a one-touchdown edge over once-beaten Fordham when they meet in the first daylight football game of the year at Braves Field tomorrow.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Nov. 11 -- Sailing today on the Holland America Line's motorship Westerdam, after two months as Netherlands delegate to the United Nations General Assembly, Dr. Bert V. A. Roling predicted that a lasting peace could be achieved through the United Nations.
Twenty-seven persons were injured yesterday when an Astoria-bound BMT local rammed a bumper block at the Whitehall Street station.

It should not have been necessary for .t l'elident to. have to deny,as he dida 'his weekly pre conference, repo:that the.C, overnment was planning to. raise the price of gold (which is'another way-of saying to devalue the d$11ar). Since, however, he did find it necsary, to take .cognizance of these rumors, he is to be commended warmly fen:the,finA]ity with which he disposed of.them.

Warned that he was too tall to embark on a career of crime, an 18-year-old youth who stood six feet eight inches, was held in $2,500 bail yesterday in the youth part of Felony Court for hearing on Tuesday on a burglary charge.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Nov. 11 -- The results of the "completely harmonious and entirely successful" meeting of the United States, British and French Foreign Ministers in Paris will not be apparent for "weeks and months," Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared on his arrival here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- President Truman accepted today the resignation, effective Dec. 1, of J. A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, and announced that he had appointed Oscar L. Chapman, Under-Secretary, to succeed him.

Only ten Manhattan properties figured in forced conveyances last month, according to the Real Estate Board of New York, which in its monthly market analysis yesterday described the number of transfers as the lowest thus far this year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -The submarine Tusk was so little damaged in collision with a Navy supply ship that she could have remained in maneuvers with the task force off Labrador, the Navy said tonight.

With diamond prices here ruling firm to higher since the devaluation of sterling, advices from London are that the sights (sales) to be held by the Diamond Trading Company, Ltd., on Monday will be featured by offerings far under world demand, it was reported yesterday by Louis Frankel, general counsel of the Diamond Manufacturers and Importers Association of America.

Displaying a superior passing attack, the Curtis High School football team defeated the visitors from Mexico City, Normal High, 26 to 0, before 3,000 fans at Braybrooks Stadium, Port Richmond, S. I., yesterday.

Today's events: Little Orchestra Young People's Concert, Thomas K. Scherman, conductor; Milton Cross, narrator; Suzari Marionettes, Hunter College Auditorium, 11 o'clock; repeat performance at the Brooklyn Academy, 3; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Charles Munch, conductor; E. Power Biggs, organ, Carnegie Hall, 2:30.

A bus-load of white Vermont residents arrived at 7 P. M. yesterday at the Abyssinian Baptist Church, 132 West 138th Street, to spend the week-end as guests of Negro families. The idea was the outgrowth of a project known as the "Vermont Plan for Action" in interracial relations.

IN the three novels we are reviewing this morning the course of love -- false or fleeting or true -- is rugged. "Venus, the LonelyGoddess,"* finds John Erskine up to his old tricks again, spoofing the morality of the immortals, and writing his best book since "The Private Life of Helen of Troy." In "The Tunnel," Baynard Kendrick presents a pretty and distracted young woman torn between love for the living and the dead.

The Alleghany Corporation reported yesterday that its offer to exchange various dividend-bearing stocks in its portfolio for shares of Alleghany preferred had resulted, up to Oct. 31, in 9,332 shares of Alleghany prior preferred and 14,581 shares of the Series A preferred stock being exchanged.

More patients with advanced heart diseases are admitted to the Beekman Downtown Hospital than to any others of the eighty-six voluntary hospitals that are members of the United Hospital Fund, according to fund records.

Following is the text of an address by President Truman at a luncheon of the National Conference of Christians and Jews in Washington yesterday, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES from a radio broadcast:

Congress was asked to strengthen the Taft-Hartley law to bar industry-wide bargaining in a resolution adopted yesterday at closing sessions of the fifty-first annual meeting of the National Foundry Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. In another resolution, foundrymen were told it is the policy of their national organization to "enlighten employes in every detail of the Labor Management Act of 1947."

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 11 -- Directors of the Aetna Life Insurance Company recommended today an increase in its capital stock from $15,000,000 to $20,000,000 by the declaration of a stock dividend of one new share for each three shares held.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- United States Air Force witnesses testified today that a B-25 bomber's practice approach to National Airport could not possibly have figured in the mid-air collision that occurred shortly afterwards between a Bolivian piloted P-38 fighter plane and a DC-4 passenger transport.

OTTAWA, Nov. 11 -- Since any attack on Canada could be made only by air or by sea, Defense Minister Brooke Claxton told the House of Commons today, radar equipment and a communications system backed by interceptor planes with a relatively small mobile brigade group are the first essentials for defense.

Asserting that the Liberal party won three of its four objectives in last Tuesday's election, David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, served notice yesterday on Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, that the Democratic party next year must nominate liberal and progressive candidates on its state ticket to get the support of the Liberal party.

The thirty-one-story Governor Clinton Hotel, Seventh Avenue and West Thirty-first Street, opposite Penn Station, was added to the Carter chain yesterday when H. B. Cantor, president of the Carter Hotels Operating Corporation of New York, announced the purchase of a controlling interest in the Governor Clinton from the Robert Meyer estate.

An exhibit of Persian treasures from famous collections in this country is being prepared at the Asia Institute, 7 East Seventieth Street, and will be opened on Nov. 23 by Mohammed Reza Pahlevi, the Shah of Iran.
Three-year-old Barbara Collins received another chance for life yesterday, thanks to the cooperation of the Police Department. But, stricken with leukemia nearly a year ago, she is seriously ill.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -Eric Johnston said tonight that the time had come to tell Western Europe it must do its part in order to receive continued Marshall Plan aid. Mr. Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, recently returned from a mission for the Economic Cooperation Administration.

Plans for participation of church leaders in the United States in world-wide studies of church life under auspices of the World Council of Churches were made at a two-day meeting of thirty representatives in this country of denominational affiliates of the council, which ended yesterday at the Holiday Hills Branch of the New York City Young Men's Christian Association in Pawling.
The subway alumni will pour out of the subterranean interstices today in all their glory.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Following the traditional custom for the observance of Armistice Day in the national capital, President Truman placed a wreath of yellow chrysanthemums on the Tomb of the Unknown soldier in the Arlington National Cemetery today.

SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Guy G. Gabrielson, chairman of the Republican National Committee, said tonight that the Truman Administration was seeking to turn the Federal Government into a vast "give-away" program. In a speech prepared for a dinner sponsored by the Republican State Central Committee of Utah, Mr. Gabrielson declared:
Three current exhibitions of paintings by contemporary Americans show several of the varied aspects under which art today manifests itself.

BERLIN, Nov. 11 -- Gen. Vassily I. Chuikov, Soviet Control Commissioner, delivered to the Eastern German Cabinet today a statement of policy that repeatedly emphasized the Grotewohl Government's commitment to the observance of the four-power decisions implementing the Potsdam pact.
The widely acclaimed "natural" method of childbirth is a definite step backward in obstetrics, according to a study made public yesterday by the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center.

A request to hotel guests here for the Notre Dame-North Carolina football game to help New York City overcome its water shortage by "going easy" on demands for ice water and buckets of ice for "setups" in hotel rooms was passed out yesterday by the city's hotels.

The National Retail Furniture Association has gone on record as opposing excise taxes on major household appliances and is asking its more than 8,000 member stores to communicate with Congress asking for their repeal, Frederick S. Hubert, Eastern managing director, reported yesterday.

Twelve hundred persons attended the thirtieth anniversary dinner of the Italian Dressmakers Union, Local 89, of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union last night at the Commodore Hotel. Luigi Antonini, a founder of the local and now general secretary, was the guest of honor.

AKRON, Ohio, Nov. 11 -- A new departure in education, a retail store within a classroom, complete with display windows, counters, shelves and merchandise, opened in the commerce department of the University of Akron here today. The store, a laboratory for sales, advertising and merchandising students, is said to be the first of its kind in the country.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -Plans are being drawn to move the seat of government from Washington if this capital ever becomes a target in a future war, Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson disclosed today.

The new one-story building containing about 5,000 square feet of space at the northwest corner of Fifty-fourth Road and Forty-third Street in Long Island City, Queens, has been leased by the Richmond Asbestos Company from the Wilkins Lumber Company, Inc.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 11 -- Vikings settled in Virginia almost 500 years before Columbus, in the opinion of two scientists who presented their evidence to archaeologists here today.

VIENNA, Nov. 7 -- Destruction of the cultural standards of about 70,000,000 people and alteration of their history have emerged as Russia's pattern for the satellite countries. According to some who attended the recent conference in London of United States envoys to the "People's Democracies," this was one of the most striking facts disclosed by their exchange of experiences.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 11 -The mounting interest which attends a Yale-Princeton football contest will be intensified for some 45,000 persons in Palmer Stadium tomorrow when the Tigers, 33-13 conquerors of Harvard, make a serious bid for their third successive Big Three title.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 -Pennsylvania beaten in its last two starts this season, and the high-geared Army team, will meet on Franklin Field tomorrow before capacity crowd of 75,000, including 2,500 members of the cadet corps.

John L. Lewis denied yesterday that he was unwilling to mediate the soft coal dispute and declared he would meet at any time with Cyrus S. Ching, Federal mediation chief, or "anybody else" who might produce a constructive solution.

Cables arriving almost daily from distribution centers abroad are pleading with War Relief Services of the National Catholic Welfare Conference for clothing and soap. The pleas come not only from Europe but also from the Near Eastern and Far Eastern countries where once again roads are jammed with helpless civilians seeking new homes.

DETROIT, Nov. 11 -- Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink of New York, national chairman of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, declared here today that prolonged emphasis on Jewish overseas needs had led American Jews to neglect the needs of Jewish welfare and civic agencies in this country.

MARIETTA, Ohio, Nov. 11 (AP) -- This Ohio River town, oldest seat of organized government west of the original thirteen colonies, would like to have the historic Poughkeepsie regatta shifted to its doorstep.
CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Cook County (Chicago) Rent Advisory Board for the second time has voted against a general rent increase.

The United Nations has learned one crucial lesson in its efforts for world peace and that is "never to give up," Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, president of the United Nations General Assembly, declared yesterday. It was the spirit of this lesson, he said, that inspired the organization's peace efforts in Palestine and Indonesia.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Nov. 11 -A paraplegic veteran of World War I reverently marked Armistice Day by taking part in ground breaking ceremonies for his $22,000 home, which is to be built here with the aid of a $10,000 Government grant.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies declined 6.6 per cent in October, compared with the corresponding month last rear, according to a compilation covering forty-two companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- The International Harvester Company today offered two unions, representing 50,000 of its 62,000 hourly-rated employes, noncontributory pensions and a welfare plan in which the workers would contribute.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Nov. 11 -- Three devoted listeners to the State Department's Voice of America were punished with prison terms and confiscation of property today for having spread "unfounded rumors" that Hungary would devalue 100-forint notes.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- The National Republican Roundup Committee ended a two-day meeting here today with the unanimous adoption of a nineteen-point statement of "Republican fundamental principles" that advocated nearly everything President Truman's Fair Deal opposes and opposed nearly everything the Administration advocates.

Lumber production for the week ended Nov. 5 was 7 per cent above the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by trade associations. Orders were up 48 per cent and shipments 29.5 per cent.

The North Pole never has been reached on foot, the Rev. Bernard R. Hubbard declared here yesterday. Father Hubbard, known as "the glacier priest," based this opinion on twenty-three years he has lived in the land of arctic ice and wind.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 11 (AP) -Violence broke out today in the struggle between right and left wing elements of the 13,700-member United Electrical Workers local at East Pittsburgh.

We have noted with some dissatisfaction both the pronouncement of Erwin N. Griswold, dean of the Harvard Law School, and your commendatory editorial of Oct. 11. An analysis of the premises (on which you favor the admission of women) appears to turn them into hasty and, we submit, erroneous judgments; and if not erroneous, then those premises are at least quite "old hat" indeed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -Harry M. Blackmer is free to do as he likes with millions of longfrozen assets in American banks, the Government disclosed today. An official of the Justice Department's Alien Property Office said today that "blocks" against the funds were removed even before he returned from his long exile in Europe.

The visualizing of paint and furnishing colors as they will look in relation to the other accessories in a room is often a mystifying task for the homemaker. Two color selection guides now available, however, simplify the problem, and at the same time make a game of the paint-picking business.

Your issue of Oct. 28 has an article and an editorial dealing with the reported incident in which Gen. Robert E. Lee shocked the Virginia church-goers in June, 1865, by kneeling beside a well-dressed Negro during communion service at the St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Richmond, Va.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- The American people will be captives of their own Government within five years "unless the march of state socialism is halted," Clem Whitaker, director of the American Medical Association's campaign against socialized medicine, warned members of the National Editorial Association today.

HONG KONG, Nov. 11 -- A distinct cleavage is apparent in the fraternity of more than fifty United States pilots who have been flying for the China National Aviation Corporation and the Central Air Transport Corporation.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 11 -- Premier Marshal Tito said today that Russia had no chance of breaking the unity of Yugoslavia, and asserted that he was winning recruits from all over the world to his type of communism.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -The employment picture in the nation's industrial centers brightened somewhat during late September and October, the Labor Department reported today.

With prayers for peace and admonitions that the United States must gird to fight still another war if necessary, Government leaders and veterans commemorated yesterday throughout the nation the thirty-first anniversary of the armistice that ended World War I.

"The First Front," a Soviet drama dealing with the strategy behind the battle of Stalingrad, will open an engagement today at the Stanley. Nikolai Cherkassov is starred in the picture which was directed by Vladimir Petroff for Mosfilm. English titles translate the Russian dialogue.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 11 -- Yugoslavia gave a detailed account today of her charge that the Soviet Union had organized 3,000 Soviet nationals in the Yugoslav civil service and 3,000 other Russian refugees into a terroristic, counter-revolutionary "network."

The authorship of the "Junius Letters" -- long in literary and historical controversy -- has at last been definitively uncovered, according to Dr. Francesco Cordasco, Associate Professor of English at Long Island University.

Metal traders are expecting lower prices on tin next week, and yesterday envisaged reductions of as much as 5 cents a pound by Tuesday, spokesmen revealed here yesterday. Sales of tin here have been slow and some traders have been disappointed that larger orders did not follow settlement of the steel strikes, it was learned.

The Manhattan Chamber Orchestra, under Charles Schiff, which began its career with three concerts last season in this city, appeared last night at Times Hall. Julius Baker, flutist, was the assisting artist in an interesting and well-contrived program which was performed in the meritorious manner that marked the organization's work when previously heard.

A "realistic, competitive opportunity" for American-flag vessels in the foreign trades cannot exist unless the operators are compensated for the substantially higher standards and costs that are imposed upon them, Frazer A. Bailey, president of the National Federation of American Shipping, declared last night.

At 2 o'clock tomorrow morning, when most Staten Islanders are sound asleep, a group of specially trained technicians will receive a signal that will set them feverishly to work in the New York Telephone Company's new soft-hued buff brick central office building in West Brighton, Staten Island.
PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 11 -Persons fearful of death or serious disease as a result of ordinary city smogs were reassured today by air-pollution scientists.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 11 -France and Britain bitterly assailed today United Nations action in relation to colonial territories, but the Trusteeship Committee of the General Assembly overruled their protests. It approved a joint United States-Mexican resolution calling for a United Nations investigation of educational conditions among the 200,000,000 peoples in dependencies.

A snappy line of patter may land home economics students part-time and summer jobs that will pay off in cash as well as experience, eighty-nine girls learned yesterday at a workshop sponsored by the American Home Economics Association.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 11 -- The creation of a five-member United Nations commission to take an on-the-spot sounding of the desires of the Eritrean people on their own national future was recommended today by the Assembly's Political and Security Committee.
The New York Community Trust, 120 Broadway, spent $470,580 for charitable purposes during the first three-quarters of the year, it was reported yesterday.

Notre Dame's first New York appearance in three years, against North Carolina at Yankee Stadium, Army's engagement with Pennsylvania at Franklin Field and the Big Three clash between Princeton and Yale at Palmer Stadium will attract the big crowds today.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Nov. 11 -- Kenneth McFarland, Superintendent of Schools at Topeka, Kan., urged educators tonight "to take off the cellophane wrappers and come out where the people live."
GREENVILLE, N. C., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Secretary of the Army Gordon Gray today urged retention of the peacetime draft law and inauguration of universal military training.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 11 -The Maryland Court of Appeals ruled today that radio and television broadcasting rights were separate and distinct, and that the radio rights to an attraction did not, as a matter of course, cover television rights.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina waved reluctant farewell to several thousand unread and unanswered letters yesterday afternoon, softly closed the door of his office on the twenty-second floor of the Federal Courthouse and walked away from the mixed memories of the nine-month Communist trial over which he had presided.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Three United States Government survey teams will arrive in London tomorrow to make a study of the Atlantic pact powers' needs for military equipment from the United States under the mutual defense assistance program.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 11 -- Widespread confusion and hints of ballot-box tampering were prevalent in this state today as the result of a seesawing election involving the traditional cleavage between rural and city voters in the new and expanding South.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- In October, the first full month after devaluation, British exports to North America earned about 27 per cent more than in September, Harold Wilson, President of the Board of Trade, announced tonight.

The Canadiens of Montreal Will be back on the Madison Square Garden ice tonight to engage the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League game. The game will mark the second appearance of the Week for the Habitants at the Rangers' home rink.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The National Labor Relations Board set aside today an election held at the Stern Brothers store in New York because the union which polled the most votes had gone "far beyond the limits of legitimate electioneering." The three board members participating were unanimous in the decision.

All traffic -- pedestrian and vehicular -- and business came to a sharp halt in Times Square at 11 A. M. yesterday as the notes of taps floated from the marquee of the Astor Hotel. For a full minute Broadway took on the stillness of a photograph, while pedestrians bared their heads and traffic policemen stood at salute.

TOKYO, Nov. 11 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida told the Diet today that Japan should accept a separate peace treaty with the Western Allies "if such a treaty will eventually lead to an all-around settlement."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Secretary of the Navy Francis P. Matthews said tonight that unification of the armed forces already had produced "enormous savings" and increased efficiency.

A record attendance of 132,000 for the five-day session of the thirty-fourth National Hotel Exposition at Grand Central Palace was announced here last night after closing of the exposition. This exceeded the 1948 mark by more than 7,500, according to Arthur Lee, general manager.

WHEATLEY HILLS, L. I., Nov. 11 -- A field of more than 100 members of the Meadow Brook Hunt met at Groton, the estate of Robert Winthrop, MFH, this morning, for the traditional Armistice Day fox hunt over North Shore woodland.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 11 (AP) -Here is a comparison of what the CIO United Steelworkers (1) asked for originally with (2) their modified demands and (3) what they finally got:

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Timely intervention by the Government's broker brought a dramatic rebound in Government stocks on the Stock Exchange here today. Some judicious buying at low levels touched after four days of falling prices caught bears short, and as they rushed to buy back, prices shot ahead.

Record temperatures yesterday again made autumn's topcoats and fur pieces unexpected encumbrances. By 2:55 P. M., when official thermometers recorded the day's high of 74 degrees, many midtown strollers plainly felt the heat.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 11 -- William C. Brinkley of Vanderbilt University, former editor of The Journal of Southern History, was elected president of the Southern Historical Association here today. He succeeds Dr. Lester J. Cappon, archivist for Colonial Williamsburg.

Thomas Coulter, Newtown senior, closed out a successful cross-country season yesterday when he captured first place in the Public Schools Athletic League championships at Van Cortlandt Park. Brooklyn Automotive was the surprise team victor with 126 points.

It is eighty-three years ago today that Dr. Sun Yat-sen was born at Hsiang Shan, on the Canton delta. The Chinese Communists have now overrun his birthplace and we may not know if it is to be the scene of any commemorative ceremonies because of their blackout of reporting.

Mickey Colmer, who used to be one of the better hard-driving backs with the old Brooklyn Dodgers, yesterday was re-signed by Red Strader, coach and general manager of the All-America football operation at the Yankee Stadium.

"We are razing mountains, we are irrigating deserts, we are cutting through the jungle and the tundra, we are spreading life, happiness, prosperity and welfare in places where the human footstep has not been seen for a thousand years," exclaims Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union in a dithyrambic outburst.

MANILA, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Evidently defeated in his bid for the Philippines Presidency, Jose P. Laurel said today he was considering retirement from politics. But first, he said, "I want to find out what actually happened in this election."

In the expansive mood of election night, President Truman spoke at length of the considerations that prompted him to propose his "bold new program" for the development of the backward areas of the world. This program allots a noble function to the frequently maligned American capital.

"The Soviet state determines the behavior and activity of Soviet citizens in various ways. It educates the Soviet people in a spirit of Communist morality of the system which introduces a series of legal norms regulating the life of the population, imposing interdictions, establishing encouragements, naming of punishment for the violation of these norms.

Manitose N-Nin, Delaware Indian from Independence, Mo., the home town of the Great White Chief in Washington, foresook the tomtom and smoke signals of his ancestors yesterday to rely on the magic of police radio to inform the tribes of Red men and whites of his great loss.

The two-day meeting of the British, French and American Foreign Ministers ended about where it began, with an agreement to turn back to the High Commissioners the questions regarding the future of Western Germany which their chiefs were unable to settle among themselves.

Herman Shumlin confirmed a report yesterday that he is about to acquire a new play by Horton Foote called "The Chase," which he hopes will be ready in time for a Broadway presentation this season. The script, says Mr. Shumlin, is now being rewritten in Pennsylvania by the author and its action takes place in the South.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UP) -Edgar F. Kaiser, president of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, today accused Cyrus Eaton, Cleveland financier, of "inspiring" a barrage of highly critical questions about the automobile concern's affairs.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11 -- Jews are fleeing to Israel from Arab countries because there is no future except death and desolation for their children in the Arab lands, Moshe Kol of Jerusalem, director of the Youth Aliyah Department of the Jewish Agency for Palestine declared today.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Seventeen men were convicted today on charges of contempt of court resulting from a mass parade of some 500 unionists through the Bell Aircraft Corporation plant during a strike that finally was ended last Oct. 17.

Medallions honoring five women for "outstanding achievement" were presented last evening at a ceremony at the Women's International Exposition in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- Speaking at Sarrebourg in Lorraine today, Foreign Minister Robert Schuman said that in planning the "new methods of action" in Germany the three big Western powers "did not abandon the rights and principles on which they had agreed in the past."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Herbert H. Lehman is a United States Senator from New York with pay and privileges and John Foster Dulles no longer has Senatorial status or privileges, Capitol experts insisted today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 11 -- The authority of the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations to convene international conferences was defended successfully today in the face of a determined attack by the Soviet Union.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 11 -- John D. Hickerson, Assistant Secretary of State, said today that Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky had confirmed yesterday the United States position that Soviet atomic proposals would be "wholly ineffective as a means of control."

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 11 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district last week showed little change from the relatively low levels prevailing in late October, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. There was a moderate increase in the volume of trade, but the gain was offset by small declines in industrial production and in originating freight shipments.

Looking ahead to holiday parties and Christmas giving, some stores gave children's fashion shows this week, others filled up their racks with winter-coats, snow and party togs. In all there was a gamut of youngsters' fashions to be seen.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 11 -- The United States Steel Corporation and the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, came to terms here tonight, ending a tie-up which started Oct. 1 and had seriously threatened the nation's economy.

LENINGRAD, Nov. 5 -- The great maroon and gold curtain of the Marinsky Theatre, named after Sergei Kirov, assassinated Leningrad Communist leader, rises on a spectacular new Soviet ballet, "The Bronze Horseman."

Retail Sales Dropped in Week Retail sales here dropped during the week despite two partial holidays when all stores remained open. Department store sales were estimated as about 8 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were 5 per cent below last year.

Ray Lev, whose Carnegie Hall recitals are annual features of her tours throughout the country, played there last night. Before a large and friendly audience she displayed the high spirits and perceptive musicianship that are her prominent characteristics.

Lilyette Foundations Co, through Leonard J. Beck, floor, in 842 Broadway; Guardian Electronics Co, floor, in 614 W 51st St; Spectrum Litho Co, floor, in 80 Washington St; E. J. Bloomfield, Inc, floor, in 702 Broadway; Cinderella Flower Co, floor, in 599 Broadway -- Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton Inc, brokers.
Following is the United Mine Workers' transcript of the statement made yesterday by John L. Lewis at a press conference in the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in New York:

FRANKFORT, Germany, Nov. 11 For the third day in a row the Socialist Opposition denounced today the reported "concessions" made by Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of the Bonn Government, to the Western Allies.

DETROIT, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Settlement of the strike against the United States Steel Corporation tonight offered no hope of an early return to work for 43,400 idle auto ndustry employes. Industry spokesmen agreed that it would take several weeks before supplies could return auto plants to full production.

ROME, Nov. 11 -- Severe restrictions on the use of electric power were announced today in Rome and in general throughout central and southern Italy. Similar restrictions have been in force in northern Italy for some months.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 11 -- A panel of experts on food, land use and population agreed today that conservation of natural resources was basically a moral and social problem. They held that science could not be written off, but must be only a partner rather than the solution.

Charley Fusari scored a thrilling knockout victory over Terry Young of the East Side in the feature bout, scheduled for ten rounds, at Madison Square Garden last night. The Irvington (N. J.) welterweight put his game foe out of action in 1:13 of the eighth round when Referee Eddie Joseph signaled it was all over as Young lay unconscious on the canvas.

Charging that newspapers and radio stations were not adequately informing the American people of the significant events of today, Erwin D. Canham, editor of The Christian Science Monitor and alternate delegate to the United Nations, said yesterday that the public distrusts "what they read in newspapers and hear on the radio."
Myron Kahn has been named promotion manager of Marcus Breier Sons, Inc., manufacturers of Bantamac jackets. He formerly was director of National Fashion Previews, Inc.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Navy Capt. John G. Crommelin soft-pedaled his previous criticism of national defense policies today, but told an Armistice Day crowd it was the people's "patriotic duty to keep informed and interested in the organization and administration" of the armed forces. He added:

Ever since Bethlehem Steel broke the solid front of the industry in the pension dispute ten days ago by agreeing to a plan even more generous than the one recommended by the President's fact-finding, board it has been merely a question of time before the other companies would have to fall in line.

WESTBROOK, Conn., Nov. 11 -- There are more things between a lot of ducks and a duck dinner than the average wildfowler realizes, but the shooter in this area who is willing to take his ducks as they come usually has little trouble in obtaining something for the oven.

Delightfully "chocolatey" in flavor, Burton's creamed cake frosting comes ready to use in a fifteen-ounce jar. Tasters who sampled it yesterday in THE TIMES' test kitchen scored it high on two important points -- spreadability and smoothness of texture.

SAN FRANCISCO,, Nov. 11 -The executive board of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union charged today that two "avowed enemies" of the ILWU were on the committee named to try the union on charges submitted at the recent Congress of Industrial Organizations convention in Cleveland.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 11 -Screen, television and radio rights to the life story of Harry Houdini, famous escape artist who died in 1926, have been purchased from the Houdini estate by a new Hollywood motion picture company, Film Producers, Inc., according to an announcement made here today. The price was reported to have been $50,000.

Tomorrow morning at St. Patrick's Cathedral Cardinal Spellman will celebrate a solemn pontifical mass of thanksgiving to mark the 100th anniversary of the founding St. Vincent's Hospital by four Sisters of Charity of Mount St. Vincent.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 11 -- The sum of $850,000 was approved today by the Administrative and Budgetary Committee of the United Nations to continue the Special Committee on the Balkans next year. Against solid opposition from the Eastern European nations, the committee voted 35 to 6 for the appropriation.

A bronze plaque of achievement and a special citation will be awarded to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, by the Advertising Club of New York at a special luncheon next Wednesday, it was announced yesterday.

After twelve years as a member of the Columbia Broadcasting System's news staff, John Daly has joined the American Broadcasting Company's news staff. Mr. Daly will become editor of the network's Sunday afternoon broadcasts of "This Week Around the World" at 2 P. M. and will act as correspondent for the "Headline Edition" broadcasts on Monday through Friday at 7 P. M.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- President Truman asserted today that the language of the Constitution and the fundamental faith of the American people demanded enactment of laws to reduce discrimination based on prejudice. He recalled that he had asked the Federal Government to take active steps to achieve "greater justice."

The award in this city of the Russell Colgate Distinguished Service Citation for outstanding for outstanding work in Christian education will go this year to William Webster Hall, member of the North American Committee of the World Council of Christian Education.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 11 (UP) -- Raymond M. Foley, head of the Federal Housing and Home Finance Agency, said tonight that "more and more houses" are being built in the lower-price brackets.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Diplomatic observers here found today that the communique of the Paris conference on the German question was an extremely vague and meatless document, even more ambiguous than most such communiques. The London Times called it "cryptic and barely intelligible."
James R. Hastie's Erosion had to win two decisions to take the money in the $7,500 Armistice Purse at the Jamaica galloping grounds yesterday.

The Photo-Engravers Associates, Union No. 1, AFL, charged yesterday that the Photo-Engravers Board of Trade had attempted, through the Children's Aid Society, to hire replacements for white collar workers in the seventy-seven struck photo-engraving shops.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 11 (UP) -- The Liberal majority in the Colombian Congress defied today the order of President Mariano Ospina Perez dissolving the Legislature. The action was a major challenge to his all-inclusive powers under the state of siege he declared two days ago.

Designed to add charm to the theatre suit or short dinner frock and not to obstruct anyone's view were the charming small hats offered yesterday at Jay Thorpe in a collection of custom-made designs by Robert Galer. Satin and maline were the two fabrics figuring importantly in this presentation, which was given further interest by the novel point of view that detail should be centered at the crown rather than front of the hat.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 11 -- A spectacular end-zone catch by Joe Fortunato gave Upsala the decisive touchdown tonight in a 7-0 victory over City College of New York before 2,000 fans in Ashland Stadium.
BROWNSBURG, Ind., Nov. 11 (UP) -- A B-29 bomber exploded during an Armistice Day Air Force training flight and crashed in flames on a farm today.

We venture to hope that the great address of Nehru given at Columbia University on the evening of Oct. 17 will be recognized widely as of vast importance. Is it indeed conceivable that a voice from Asia, the home of the majority of mankind and the cradle of religion and philosophy followed by millions of people in Europe and America, can be heard without the deepest respect and concern?

EPHRATA, Wash., Nov. 11 -Difficult financial problems face the state of Washington, several of its county governments and thousands of potential settlers on its Columbia Basin project before the Federal Bureau of Reclamation's biggest single irrigation undertaking is fully developed.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Nov. 11 -- The International College of Surgeons conferred tonight its highest honor -- Master of Surgery -- upon 72-year-old Dr. Hans Finsterer, Professor of Surgery at the University of Vienna and one of the great teachers in that medical center.

BOSTON, Nov. 11 -- Frank H. Jackson, test engineer for the Federal Bureau of Public Roads, urged today construction" in this country of concrete roads and airstrips similar to these in England and Germany.

BUFFALO, Nov. 11 -- The Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad's new $1,500,000 Diesel streamliner Phoebe Snow made a fast demonstration run from Buffalo to Binghamton and back today after being christened with a bottle of champagne in the Lackawanna depot.

Today we read impassioned appeals for the so-called DP's of a dozen or more European nations, for whom we are asked to make ourselves responsible. Before loading these new obligations on the breaking back of the American taxpayer it might be well to consider our duties toward the North American Indians.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The United States has been advised of the likelihood that Great Britain will recognize the Communist regime in China possibly before the end of this year, it became known today.

One of the knottiest of all post-war problems -- what to do with the former Italian colonies in Africa -- is at last on the verge of solution. The Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly is on the point of agreeing on proposals, and the presumption is that the General Assembly itself will accept the plans after a more or less heated debate.

The Burroughs Adding Machine Company had a net profit of $6,015,352, equal to $1.20 a common share, for the first nine months of 1949, compared with a net profit of $9,896,358, or $1.98 a share, for the same period last year, John S. Coleman, president, reported yesterday.

PATERSON, N. J., Nov. 11 -- A court action designed to test the constitutionality of a New Jersey statute that requires the reading of verses from the Old Testament in public schools is scheduled to begin here Monday in Superior Court before Judge Robert H. Davidson.

Every effort will be made early next week to reach a settlement in a contractual dispute between the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots of America, and Atlantic and Gulf Coast employers, representatives of both sides said yesterday.

The Sterod Manufacturing Company has leased the first and second floors of the building at 442 Frelinghuysen Avenue in Newark, N. J., from the Noble Realty Corporation. The premises, containing about 15,000 square feet of space, will be used as a general sheet metal plant, which will include welding and stamping.

More than a thousand shipping men, freight forwarders and others connected with the maritime industry thronged the decks of the Israel America Line's newly acquired freighter, the Yaffo, yesterday afternoon. The occasion, sponsored by the American Israeli Shipping Company, agents for the line, celebrated the vessel's forthcoming maiden voyage under the Israeli flag on Nov. 18, when she sails for Haifa and Tel Aviv.

In a hard-fought football contest, Evander Childs defeated Monroe, 13 to 12, on the victor's field yesterday. Monroe scored in the second period on a pass from William Mann to Danny Fox from the 3-yard line, but the try for the extra point was missed.

To the early Greeks the elements were four: earth, air, fire and water. We classify them differently today -- and take them very much for granted. Water, for example, is as simple and almost as available as air.

YOUR review by Artur Rubinstein on Andre Gide's "Notes on Chopin" (Book Review, Oct. 16) arouses curiosity, surprise and no end of mirth. To anyone having read these notes as they were made to be read -- that is, as an integral part of Gide's Journal, and in the original French -- it is hardly necessary to protest against Mr. Rubinstein's obtuse and evidently bilious attitude towards these notes, and more pointedly toward their author.

At the foot of narrow Petrovka Street, where it debouches into the broad expanse of Sverdlovsk Square with the huge bulk of the glamorous Bolshoi Theatre looming on one side and the trim yellow daintiness of the Maly Theatre on the other, stands a six-story graystone building of neo-Gothic design.

With the national steel strike all but over, there was widespread speculation yesterday that the price of steel might rise after the first of the year. This indication came as steel mills the country over went back in production with workers in eager mood everywhere.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Bolivian-piloted P-38 that crashed into an Eastern Air Lines transport Nov. 1, killing all fifty-five occupants of the passenger ship, was registered with the Civil Aeronautics Administration as an experimental craft, it was disclosed today.

THAT least academic of professors, John Erskine, who once laid bare "The Private Life of Helen of Troy," now looks into the activities of another lady of widely advertised charms. His subject this time is Venus, the goddess of love.

THE personal tragedy of Miss Anna Louise Strong, who was expelled from the Soviet Union as a "spy" after years of devotion to the Soviet cause, is again highlighted by her latest work in praise of the "People's China."

CHATTANOOGA, Nov. 12 -- A major drive to bring back prohibition to Chattanooga was headed off by a small majority in a referendum last Tuesday which attracted more than 30,000 voters and held national attention.

Import figures covering American products reaching Manila during the first three quarters of this year reveal sharp increases in shipments of certain types of building materials, tools and varied household items, while declines were noted in steel, aluminum and allied materials, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by C. E. Mauchenheim, spokesman for Robot Statistics, 24 Stone Street.

Under ordinary circumstances it costs a hospital patient $33 a day for twenty-four-hour private nursing service. To offset this high cost, and yet maintain adequate care for private and semi-private patients who are not critically ill, St. Vincent's Hospital has inaugurated a "share-the-nurse" plan which reduces the daily cost for special nursing to $11.

THEATRICAL biographies for young people are rare; really good ones are rarer still. This life story of Lotta Crabtree is one of the best. It is not biography alone, but theatre history. Rollicking little Lotta was the first American song-and-dance comedienne, spiritual ancestress of the Duncan Sisters and Judy Garland.
THE chief trouble in compiling any list of favorites is elimination. Shrubs are no exception, although confining the choice to deciduous kinds that may be planted now is a slight help.

The people of the United States were the real victors in Tuesday's elections because of the freedom of voters to ballot for candidates of their choice, declared Rabbi Israel Goldstein in his sermon yesterday morning at the temple of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, Eighty-eighth Street, West of Broadway.

Mrs. Basil Harris Jr. heads the committee in charge of the arrangements for the New Decade dinner dance, to be held on Dec. 11 in the Carnaval and Chanteclair rooms of the Sherry-Netherland in behalf of the School of Social Service of Fordham University.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The National Labor Relations Board held unanimously today that an employer who relied on an opinion of a state court in discharging an employe was still liable if the discharge was illegal under the Taft-Hartley Act.

The second free lecture on art and allied subjects in the fall series sponsored by the New York Public Library will be presented at 6 P. M. Tuesday, at the main library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. Kim Hoffman, designer of interiors, will discuss "Modern Lighting in Contemporary Designing."

For three years the British tourist business has outstripped every other industry in dollar-earning capacity, John G. Bridges, director-general of the British Travel Association, declared yesterday as he sailed for home after a business visit here.

NEXT on the schedule of this extraordinarily active dance season is the engagement of the New York City Ballet Company at the City Center, opening on Nov. 23 for a series of sixteen performances spread somewhat irregularly over three weeks.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12 -- The Matson Navigation Company is going ahead to explore with the Maritime Commission "some indefinite phases" of the commission's offer to advance $5,635,555 toward completing the reconversion of the liner Mariposa, it was disclosed today by John E. Cushing, Matson's president.

WHAT the lovely, young heiress is hanging is pictures -- fourteen of them. According to the terms of her wealthy, elderly, deceased husband's will, she has to hang fourteen likenesses of his visage in fourteen different busi ness enterprises of his, and complete the job within one month.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The State Department today disclosed new failures in the efforts to get information from Chinese Communists about Angus Ward, United States Consul General, in jail at Mukden.

THIS is the amazing true life story of Phillis Wheatley, the young poet who delighted London court circles as much as she impressed George Washington and Tom Paine. Phillis was brought from her African home and sold in the Boston slave market at the age of 6.

THE extent of the financial loss suffered by England's largest motion-picture combine, the J. Arthur Rank Organization, for the year ended last June 25, and announced last Monday, may well be regarded as a major setback for British film production as a whole.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- The proposed draft of an international agreement designed to stimulate the flow of educational materials by freeing them from import duties has been sent for comment to the governments of the United Nations and to the members of the Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

WHEN Nathan Milstein made his American debut, twenty years ago, he was acclaimed as a violinist who could play with brilliance of technique, richness of tone and fiery temperament. There was no doubt that he had an immense gift for the fiddle and that he could stir an audience.

Representatives of all segments of the maritime industry have served notice of intention to appear at the public hearing on tramp shipping scheduled by the United States Maritime Commission for Wednesday in Washington.

EXHIBITIONS newly opened ring many of the changes in contemporary art, from sheer painting to heavy preoccupation with subject matter, from romanticism to semi-abstraction, from realism to violent expressionism.

A PRIVATE detective down to his last dollar, no case to work on, and the office rent coming due, then a big, remunerative case in the nick of time. This is one of the standardized openings for private-eye mysteries. The scene this time is Los Angeles, the detective is Neal Cotten, and the case starts out by being an inquiry into the reasons why a young copper heiress suddenly finds her generous allowance inadequate.

SOMETIMES it is helpful (and consoling) to remind ourselves that many of the difficulties we encounter in bringing up children result from the pressures of city living which are not present in the life of the country dweller.

Making light of a two-goal deficit before the, game was half over, the Canadiens of Montreal flashed a strong third-period attack to beat the New York Rangers, 5 to 3, in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.
ALBANY, Nov. 12 -- It is doubtful if honeymooning voters are eligible to use absentee ballots, the state Attorney General said today. He believes they are not "unavoidably absent."

CALIFORNIA is making ready for a busy season with a heavy schedule of fall and pre-winter events merging with the Christmas holiday weeks in a continuous stretch of merry-making. On Saturday, at El Cajon, a town inland from San Diego, a parade of animated floats depicting Mother Goose characters will herald the pre-Christmas season.

HALFWAY between Southampton and London by motor road, there is a pleasant little inn surrounded by fields and flowers, where passengers from liners that dock at Southampton frequently stop for morning coffee or afternoon tea en route to or from a transatlantic crossing.
WASHINGTON -- The need for new roads throughout the country and for replacement of thousands of miles of well worn routes has aroused a universal demand to keep highway building out of politics.

WHEN the Old Woman set out in the two-wheeled cart to find a new home, she had no idea that her donkey, Arthur, and Bossy, the cow, and her two cats would prove so inconveniently strong-minded. Each pet had a personal requirement, and of three new homes, not one pleased everybody.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 12 -- Improved trade was reported last week in the various outlying areas in the Eighth Federal Reserve District, now that two weeks have passed since resumption of service by the strike-bound Missouri Pacific Railroad.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 12 -- Believing that the period of training of doctors can be shortened without lowering standards, Dr. C. N. Hugh Long, dean of the Yale School of Medicine, proposed today that the medical education system be revised so that doctors would not have to wait until they were 28 or 30 years old before they could start practice.

LONDON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Pandit Jwaharlal iehru plumped for independence for Malaya today.

BOSTON, Nov. 12 -- A single wabbly pass from center gave Maryland's tough Terrapins a 14-to-13 victory today and apparently shattered the chances of a bowl bid for Boston University's hitherto unbeaten football team.

THE collector of these eleven folk tales heard them told at tive "sings" when she lived in rural Haiti. The reader needs but little imagination to catch the humming and chanting that accompany the tales, and to see moonlight shining through mango trees on a circle of dark faces.

THE questions that come up when you talk to Carl Carmer are based on the fact that he writes for adults and for children both. In fact, he's split, or nearly split, down the middle: about eight grown-up books under his belt, and about six juveniles.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Interest in the Central West centered overwhelmingly this week on the probable political consequence of the New York Senatorial election, although there had been little interest in the campaigning.

THIS book, thanks to the wide knowledge of the authors, manages to cover many angles of life in the theatre. The two young heroines and their good angel, the great actress, Kartini Yorke, are shown in summer theatres, plays in New York and London, television and movie studios, and casting agencies.
BERLIN, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Russians followed the Western example today and renounced their military government in Eastern Berlin.

THE daily televising of the proceedings of the United Nations General Assembly, which started last week over the Columbia Broadcasting System's network, undoubtedly ranks as the most extensive public service series yet undertaken by video.
THIS is Children's Book Week and a check-up on the juvenile trade reveals two trends of current interest, both involving large numbers.

The forty-first annual dinner dance under the auspices of the New York Auxiliary of the Blue Ridge School in Bristol, Va., will take place on Jan. 27 at the Pierre. Proceeds will be applied to the maintenance of the school, which provides educational opportunities for underprivileged children of the mountain districts of Virginia.

THE first trip to America as guest conductor of Jerinym Rafael Kubelik, son of the former violinist and conductor of international reputation and achievement, will be watched with interest. The twelve years of Mr. Kubelik's conductorship of the Prague Philharmonic Orchestra were years in which that organization achieved a rare quality of performance which excited the warmest praise from informed American listeners who attended the Prague international music festival of two seasons ago.
LONDON -- Autumn travel to Europe has plenty of advantages to compensate for the calculated weather risk any ocean traveler has to accept when he chooses a post-summer voyage.

They tell how animals familiar to the Western forests -- Coyote, Grizzly, Fox, Elk, Beaver and others -- prepared the earth for the coming of the Indians.

CHICAGO, Now. 12 -- Corporations own only about 2 per cent of the farm land -- roughly about 10,000,000 acres -- in thirteen leading Midwest states. BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 12 (UP) -- Yugoslavia took the diplomatic offensive against the countries of the Communist Information Bureau today by canceling her treaty of friendship and mutual assistance with Albania. This was the last major treaty link between Marshal Tito's Government and his former Cominform allies.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The National Federation of Life Insurance Agents said today that it had reached a new contract agreement with the Prudential Life Insurance Company covering 16,000 agents.

THERE are a few, a very few, bridge players so effete and so saturated with the technique of the game that to them the celebrated "squeeze" is just another play in their repertory. But to the rest of the bridge players, including the top ranks, it remains the supreme thrill that the game affords.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Eddie Arcaro made the prize mistake of his career today when he pulled up Brookmeade Stable's Blue Hills a mile before the finish of the two and one-half mile Pimlico Cup. After leading by two lengths, he lost by eight.

In the background of labor's fourth-round drive there has been a struggle for leadership among three powerful union leaders. They are Philip Murray, president of the CIO and the United Steelworkers; Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Auto Workers, and John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers.

PENN YAN, N. Y., Nov. 12 (AP) -- The wartime chief of the Waves, Dr. Mildred McAfee Horton, tonight called on women to participate "in every aspect of church life for which they are fitted by temperamen and training."

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12 -- The West Coast was not surprised by such Democratic victories as that of former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman in the New York Senatorial contest and of John F. Shelley, president of the California State Federation of Labor, in the Fifth Congressional District battle in San Francisco.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 12 -- Archaeologists meeting here today were skeptical over the theory that Norsemen settled Virginia nearly 500 years before Columbus, but sponsors of the theory held their ground.

Adults in the New York City area want education on a long-term rather than a short-term basis and are willing to travel as far as fifty miles an evening to attend classes, according to a five-year study of 37,495 students recently completed by the City College Adult Education Program.

BOSTON, Nov. 12 -- His fellow trustees of Norwich University tonight honored Dr. Godfrey L. Cabot for his role in the development of aviation. He was guest in a dinner at the University Club and heard John F. Victory of Washington, executive secretary of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, praise "his vision, courage, leadership and example."

THE New York City Opera Company's out-of-town junket will be more of a tour than at first it appeared. Besides visiting Chicago and Milwaukee, it is going to St. Louis. It will play in Chicago from Nov. 23 to Dec. 14, going up to Milwaukee for the Thursdays of Dec. 1, 8 and 15.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- France's gravest concern in the international field now is how to retain the leadership in the formation of the continental union that has been proposed as the sole solution of Europe's problems.

An armistice in the coal dispute and settlement of the steel strike had little immediate effect on stock prices last week. As part of the Military Aid Program, Congress has appropriated $75,000,000 to be used at the discretion of the President "in the general area of China." Will this amount be used? If so, how?

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 12 -- Improved markets for fine cottons are credited here for the prospect of a steadily increased production schedule in Rhode Island cotton mills for the remainder of this year.

WARSAW, Nov. 12 -- A scathing attack against Poland's former Deputy Premier Wladyslaw Gomulka, today, gave rise to widespread, rumors that Poland would soon witness a trial similar to that recently held in Budapest.

With the formal presentation of a charter by the Propeller Club of the United States, the Student Port of City College has become the organization's thirtieth chapter in educational institutions the world over.

Manhattan College, second oldest Roman Catholic college in New York State, started last night its first large scale public drive to obtain funds for needed additions to buildings on its Riverdale campus.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 12 -- Princeton's sound and solid football team fought off the mighty challenge of an aroused Yale squad today to capture the Big Three title for the third straight year -- a feat without precedent in the gridiron history of Old Nassau.

JONEL PERLEA, latest addition to the Metropolitan Opera's conducting staff, comes from a non-musical family. He considers this a "beneficial" fact, he said the other day." Otherwise he might never have been born.

Communism and its ideology must be rejected by Jews in this country, Rabbi Philip S. Bernstein of Rochester, former, adviser on Jewish Affairs to the United States Army in Germany, warned last night in an address at the Biennial National Convention of the American Jewish Congress in the Hotel New Yorker.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 12 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky said today that if there were any doubts about the Soviet Union's intentions to use atomic energy for peace, the inspectors of the proposed international control agency could cross the Soviet's borders and "smell the materials, touch them, feel them, do anything they want or desire."

A varied entertainment, to be known as a cabaret concert, will be given under the auspices of the New York Alumnae of Bennett Junior College on Tuesday afternoon and early evening at the Colony Club. Proceeds will augment the building fund of the college, located in Millbrook, N. Y. Well-known professional entertainers will appear at the event.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Privately taken testimony designed to link the Polish Consulate in New York and the Gdynia-American Line, Inc., with the stowaway escape to Europe last May of Gerhart Eisler, No. 1 Russian agent in the United States, was released today by a Senate subcommittee investigating subversive aliens.

Smoother operation and additional safety were cited yesterday among the more important factors in the 1950 Ford lines by Walker A. Williams, sales manager of the Ford division of the Ford Motor Company. This rating of appeal to motorists was based on a countrywide analysis of the opinions of dealers who have attended previews of the new line, Mr. Williams said.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UP) -- Dr. Carlton J. H. Hayes, former Ambassador to Spain under President Roosevelt, warned tonight that human liberty was being undermined by its friends as well as its enemies and said the "New Deals" and "Fair Deals" represent a trend toward state socialism.
ONE of New York's most enthusiastic little theatre groups, the Lighthouse Players, will open its twenty-sixth season here on Thursday evening with the presentation of Rachel Crothers' "Old Lady 31."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Current strikes have set in movement tides of emotion whose sweep and surge may have important repercussions on the internal organization of the trade unions and may shift the balance of power held by some leaders.

Dr. Robert B. Black, a dentist of Corpus Christi, Tex., comes forward with a method of drilling teeth which he originated in 1942 but which he has now greatly improved. The new process reduces and eliminates heat, pressure, vibration and the noise associated with cutting a tooth and preparing it for a filling.

AS an admirer of the highly individual screen works of Preston Sturges, it was with pleasure that I read your reappraisal of two of his finest film satires, "The Great McGinty" and "Sullivan's Travels." How fortunate were audiences of half a dozen years ago when a new Sturges film could be anticipated every six months or so!

Recognizing that the war's devastation had made the demands of poverty and sickness the most acute of the many needs of 60,000,000 European children, representatives of twenty-six nations, meeting at Lake Success nearly two years ago, said, "Before we try to teach the children of the world about brotherhood and the rights of man, we must feed, clothe and care for them.

The forty-first annual Thanksgiving card party of the New York Society of Kentucky Women will be held on Tuesday afternoon, Nov. 15, in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza. The proceeds will be devoted to the maintenance of scholarships for pupils in seven schools in the Kentucky mountains, including Berea College, the Hindman Settlement School, Caney Creek School and Oneida School.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra, under Charles Munch, gave superb performances of Bach's "Art of the Fugue" and Strauss' "Symphonia Domestica" at its concert yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. Special interest centered in the monumental work of Bach, which was presented in an orchestral arrangement by Ernest Munch, the conductor's cousin, and made an unforgettably deep impression.

ARSLEY - ON - HUDSON, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- Mike Turnesa of White Plains, N. Y., won the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship today, defeating Al Brosch of Garden City, L. I., 2 up, in an 18-hole playoff.

Orders for spring lines now open were fairly light in the local markets last week, although an increase was noted in the number of out-of-town buyers here, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.
NATCHEZ, Miss., Nov. 12 (AP) -George W. Armstrong Sr. is determined to make his money talk against "racial mongrelization."

Young Women of society headed by Miss Lela Lounsbery are serving on the junior committee for the opening performance of the Ice Follies on Thursday night at Madison Square Garden which has been taken over to raise funds for the Federation of Protestant Welfare agencies.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 12 (UP) -- Michigan's shock troops wore down a fighting but outmanned Indiana team today and then rolled easily to a 20-to-7 victory which put the Wolverines within a single game of their third straight Big Ten title.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Nov. 12 -- The nation's high schools must attempt to meet the needs of students who will not finish high school, Earl J. McGrath, United States Commissioner of Education said here today.

BOSTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Detroits league-leading Wings tonight pinned a 7-5 defeat on the last place Boston Bruins, who have gone through eight games without a victory. A Boston Garden crowd of 11,113 saw the Bruins lose their sixth game in their last eight contests. Two were tied.

WHEN Jeff White was 17 he forsook the city and went back to the-Maine woods where he was born and where his father, a game warden, had met a mysterious death. There he found real friends and some genuine enemies, one a killer bear and the other an outlaw.

In upholding a decision of the highest court of the State of Washington, the United States Supreme Court has put the seal of approval on a principle that may well have profound influence on the future well-being of this country. It affirmed the constitutionality of a Washington law that requires proprietors of land used for commercial logging to provide for its reforestation.

HANOVER, N. H., Nov. 12 -- While more than 17,000 spectators, the largest crowd ever to see a football game at Memorial Field, cheered themselves into a state of hysteria, Tuss McLaughry's Dartmouth players carried him off on their shoulders today -- and small wonder!

The annual luncheon and sale for the benefit of St. Luke's Home for Aged Women will be held on Wednesday and Thursday at the institution, Broadway and 114th Street, with the luncheon on the former day and a tea on the latter. The proceeds from the sale of a wide variety of articles suitable for Christmas gifts will be devoted to the support of the home, which was founded in 1852.

An audience of 2,200, most of whom were children, filled the Hunter College Assembly Hall yesterday morning when the Little Orchestra Society opened its second season of orchestral concerts for young people. Thomas K. Scherman conducted and explained what was happening.

THE charge that triple and quadruple competition authorized by the Civil Aeronautics Board had been the "major flaw" in the competitive expansion of the domestic airline system in the United States was made in a study completed recently at the Harvard Business School.

VARIETY marks the current week's dance fare, with lectures, movies, ethnologic subjects and the works of young choreographers in the modern idiom, pretty well dividing up the schedule. The only performance in the Broadway sector is Mariemma's second and last recital of Spanish dances tonight at the Ziegfeld, when she will present a change of program from last Sunday's performance.

Miss Marilyn E. Milton heads the debutante committee for the performance of "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes" on the night of Dec. 15 at the Ziegfeld Theatre which has been taken over to raise funds for the homemaker service of the Children's Aid Society. Proceeds will further the work of the beneficiary which provides homemakers to care for children whose mothers are ill.

THE cultural and historical background of "Gloriana's" reign, accurately portrayed with many scintillating personages of that golden age of literature and exploration, forms the framework of this exciting and spellbinding adventure story.
EASTON, Pa., Nov. 12 -- Bob Albert scored three touchdowns as Bucknell defeated Lafayette College, 21 -- 14, today before 6,000 spectators.

IT is amazing that one tiny, frightened baby spider with a baby-blue bow tie could start so much trouble! But when Phoebe the Spider loses the Magic Hat that makes its wearer invisible, Barnac the Cat, who is Johnny Longfoot's teacher, thinks that Johnny should find it and thereby prove that his education has been a success.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Whatever comes of Paul G. Hoffman's ambitious plan for the economic integration of Western Europe, there can be no doubt that he stated at Paris the issue on which a third Marshall Plan appropriation may be lost or won.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 12 -- This steel-making area took on something of a carnival atmosphere today as all sections prepared to repair the ravages of a forty-two-day steel strike complicated by a companion coal walkout.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 12 -- The managing editor of Ohio State University's student daily was shot to death early today by a fraternity brother. The shooting followed a cocktail party and dance at the Delta Tau Delta fraternity house, celebrating a homecoming.
EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Northwestern, the faded 1949 Rose Bowl champions, leaped out of the shadows of a three-game losing streak today to maul outmanned Colgate, 39 -- 20.

THE adventures of Cocolo, the Italian donkey, and his boy-master, Lucio, are exciting but so well paced that children have a chance to savor and enjoy each incident. First comes the sailing to New York on the S. S. Hopeful.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- In the foreground of the conference of the Foreign Ministers of Great Britain, France and the United States in Paris this week was the desire to give the Bonn Government of Western Germany an international status and to relieve it of economic burdens.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was comparatively steady yesterday and closed 2 to 10 points net lower.

FRANCE has issued semi-postals with "Famous Men of the XVIII Century" as the theme. Added to phillately's gallery re portraits of the following: George Louis Leclerc Buffon (1707-1788), naturalist, on 12 francs plus 4fr; Joseph Francois Dupleix (1697-1763), colonial administrator, on 15fr plus 5fr; Baron Montesquieu, otherwise Charles Louis de Secondat (1689-1755), philosopher, on 5fr plus 1fr; Anne Robert Jacques Turgot (1727-1781), statesman, on 25fr plus 10fr; Francoise Watteau (1684-1721), painter, on 10fr plus 3fr.

THE fifth annual drive for the "Seeds of Friendship" Collection for Western Europe has been launched by the All-America Friendship League. The goal for the spring planting of 1950 is 1,000,000 packets of flower and vegetable seeds.

IF Bartholomew Cubbins doesn't become King Bartholomew of Didd when he outgrows his role as page boy, the citizens of Didd will miss a fine bet. For Bartholomew, he of the Five Hundred Hats, is the only astute person in the whole tale of what happened when the oobleck descended.

The annual autumn festival in behalf of the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street, will be held on Thursday. Luncheon, tea and dinner will be served. Various articles suitable for holiday gifts will be offered for sale, including books, aprons, toys, flowers and food.

FOR sheer adventure it would be difficult to imagine a more absorbing yarn than this "Bring 'Em Back Alive" tale of the Amazon. John Hunt, in the business of procuring live animals for zoos, travels down an unexplored Amazon tributary with his sons, Hal and Roger.

Racial and religious discrimination by colleges is preventing many qualified students from entering the schools of their choice, the American Council on Education charged last week. The statement was carried in a pamphlet -- "Religion and Race: Barriers to College?" -- published jointly by the Public Affairs Committee and the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith.
I found the statues which Prof. Charles Seymour Jr. discusses in his article on sculpture in the National Gallery ("Our Tradition in Sculpture") somewhat disappointing.

MOSCOW, Oct. 27 -- Thousands of Soviet young persons are receiving their initial training this fall in stenography under a broadscale expansion of Soviet stenographic training launched by the Ministry of Higher Education.

ROANOKE, Va., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Roused from his sleep at a hotel, Jimmy Dorsey, the bandleader, today posted $100 bond for his appearance in Richmond, Va., Monday morning to answer a warrant charging him with assault.

A unique management school has been set up at plants of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, it was announced yesterday in Pittsburgh. The school is enrolling supervisors, from foremen to managers, to study the latest principles of successful management at various Westinghousse plants.

THERE is a memorable scene in the famous Ben Hecht-Charles MacArthur play of the late Twenties, "The Front Page." Hildy Johnson, the hero, is in the press room of the Criminal Courts Building of Chicago. He has dropped in to say good-bye to the boys and has stumbled on a scoop.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12 -- The eleveri westernmost states took two significant steps this week in regional collaboration on common problems.

FALSELY accused of loose talk against the King, Ronald Whitelaw and his younger brother, Jan, were seized, jailed and sent to the colony of Maryland. For Ronald, a master craftsman in wood, leaving England was almost the equivalent of a death sentence; but for Jan, it was the fulfillment of a dream.
