In the opinion of the Office of the Housing Expediter, the recently enacted Sharkey rent law conflicts with Federal housing regulations and is therefore "unconstitutional," it was learned yesterday. The local rent law faces its first test tomorrow in the Court of Appeals in Albany.

SEED growers and nurserymen follow the formula of sowing seeds the same season that they are produced. This method is especially true of herbs, many of which benefit particularly from fall sowing of the fresh, ripe seed.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Alabama's star halfback, Eddie Salem, gladdened the hearts of a hometown crowd of 43,000 today as he paced his team to a 20-to-7 win from arch-rival Georgia Tech.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 12 -- Rutgers proved too powerful for New York University today as the Scarlet registered a 33-9 football victory before a shivering crowd of approximately 7,000.

WHATEVER its mainspring, the trait of collecting, classifying, showing and patronizing the arts, crafts, books and other objects is a strong instinct of civilized man. Democracy has robbed it of any possible menace to society by making the public its inevitable residuary legatee.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -- Two points short of the season's biggest upset and one away from a tie which, had it been achieved, would have been as great a surprise, the underdog University of Pennsylvania football team nevertheless scored a moral victory over the mighty and undefeated Army today at Franklin Field.

The earliest recorded letter of Thomas Jefferson has been frequently published, but the original manuscript has long since disappeared from sight. There is every reason to suppose the manuscript is extant, and the editors of The Papers of Thomas Jefferson, now in progress at Princeton University, are eager to learn of its whereabouts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The coal operators said today that another strike Dec. 1 was "unthinkable." They counseled John L. Lewis that his own men were "willing and eager" to dig coal -- and so were a lot of others.

BOB ALLEN is one of the most accomplished scolds in contemporary American journalism. As a member of the original team of [Drew] Pearson and Allen (Washington Merry - Go - Round columnists and authors of "The Nine Old Men"), he has had abundant opportunity to sharpen his talents.

HERE are stories of ducks, dogs, cats, kangaroos, bears, birds and bugs to delight the 3-to-6-year-olds who have a constant hunger for more and more stories. Parents, teachers and others who are constantly with young children have brought together in this one volume long-popular stories so that others may have a ready source of good reading for these ages.

LADY JANE GREY, studious, gentle daughter of an ambitious father, is the pathetic heroine of this beautifully written novel for older girls. The story starts as young Edward VI lies dying; and as the net of intrigue and circumstance begins to close more tightly around her Jane becomes the unwilling figure in a drama of ambition.

Mayor O'Dwyer's victory in the city election last Tuesday was sweeping. The 308,000 margin he obtained over his nearest competitor was larger than observers had believed possible, in view of the intensity of the attack leveled at him by both his opponents, Newbold Morris and Vito Marcantonio.

OTTAWA, Nov. 12 -- When he presented his $380,000,000 budget estimates for all three armed services in the House of Commons yesterday, Brooke Claxton, the Minister of Defense, said frankly that Canada, with a population of 13,500,000, could not expect and could not be expected to defend her immense territory alone.

SPOKANE, Wash., Nov. 12 -- It will be seven months on Monday since Representative Hugh B. Mitchell, Democrat, of Washington, introduced a bill, approved by President Truman, providing for establishment of a Columbia Valley Administration, but the intervening period has given great momentum to the Pacific Northwest's debate over a CVA.

If more foreign countries were to follow the example of the Netherlands and grant a dollar incentive to their exporters this would mean a great impetus to imports into the United States, Henri Stakgold, president of Corneliussen Stakgold, Inc., and the Block International Corporation, said in an interview here yesterday.

The rate of Quartermaster purchasing in the first four months of the current fiscal year (July through October) shows a decline of 50 per cent, it was learned last week. If carried through at such a rate for the entire fiscal year which ends June 30, 1950, it was estimated by suppliers that buying of clothing, equippage and subsistence items for the Armed Forces will show a reduction of $200,000,000.

LISBON, Nov. 5 -- Portugal goes to the polls on Nov. 13 to elect the 120 Deputies of the National Assembly who will hold office for the next five years. They represent thirty divisions, comprising not only metropolitan Portugal and the Azores and Madeira but the Portuguese possessions in Africa, India, Asia and Australasia.

Revival of the international market for transferable sterling, with the British pound quoted almost uniformly at $2.58 to $2.62, is causing official concern in British Government circles, it was learned here. The fact that transactions in the United States -- mostly in New York -- have now reached a figure approximating $2,800,000 a week accounts for the uneasiness in Britain.

BERLIN, Nov. 12 -- Dejection was manifest in official circles hero today as the news circulated that the State Finance Ministers, meeting yesterday in Koenigstein, had reduced drastically the relief allocations for the city.

FORTY boys to whom this book was read clapped wildly at the end of this story. They loved the pioneer who set out to find meat with only one load for his gun, an axe and a bird-net. They loved it when the wild geese, trapped in the net, carried great-grandfather into the sky, then dropped him in a honey tree, where he met and killed a bear.

BOSTON, Nov. 12 -- While department store sales in Boston are 1.3 per cent above the corresponding week of last year, a recent survey of department store executives indicates they are somewhat less optimistic about the outlook for the next six months.

DESIGNED for young readers seeking a good story, this volume of familiar myths is both readable and attractive. By skillful choice, spirited retelling and convenient grouping of the stories, the author provides a happy introduction to classical mythology.

WHAT young children want to read can be determined with not much more finality than what they want to eat. Without standards of comparison and without formed tastes, they must generally depend upon the table set by their elders. I remember asking one of my daughters, when she was 3 or 4, what she would like to have for dinner on her birthday.

It may seem odd to inquire, in the second year of the European Recovery Program, whether the United States has done and is doing all it can for Europe. For many years we have consistently sent to the Marshall Plan countries much more than they, directly or indirectly, have sent back.

Should you saunter by the entrance doors to the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington one of these days, don't be surprised to hear a loud but easy-on-the-ears baritone voice giving vent to some operatic aria. That's the new chairman of the SEC just warming up.
An encouraging upturn in the volume of American export advertising is indicated next-year, it was learned here last week.
AMES, Iowa, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Little Harry Meginnis darted 70 yards on a punt return today to give Nebraska a 7-0 victory over Iowa State.

WITH a humor and familiarity reminiscent of the medieval story tellers, Mary Mian recounts a typical folk tale of central France. The pious ladies of a small town near Limoges, having decided that the saints in paradise need a change, have opened up a rest house for tired saints.

IN their newest Broadway success, S. N. Behrman's "I Know My Love," adapted from a French play by Marcel Achard, the Lunts celebrate their twenty-fifth anniversary as an acting team by appearing as a Boston couple who have triumphantly reached their fiftieth wedding anniversary.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Although it will be another year before the Census Bureau will collect a full new set of statistics and be absolutely sure where it stands, it made public this week some provisional 1949 population figures supporting the notion that the West Coast states have been gaining rapidly in residents at the expense of the rest of the country.

In 1941 a group of outstanding French scholars in exile created the Ecole Libre des Hautes Etudes -- the French University of New York. Until two years ago the institution was connected with the New School for Social Research. It is now an independent permanent graduate school chartered by the Board of Regents.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 12 -- The President of the United Nations General Assembly took time out this week from such global issues as atomic energy control and disposition of Italy's former colonies in North Africa to assure a sixth-grade class in Silverdale, Wash., that the international diplomats were holding things down securely until the Washington youngsters could take over the job of world peace for themselves.

ONE of the passengers on the world's first transatlantic cruise aboard the steamship Quaker City, bound for the Holy Land in 1867, was a young man of 31. He had a shock of hair like a cockatoo's and a russet handlebar mustache.

The marked curtailment of banking activities resulting from the double holiday last week has focused the attention of bank managements on the problem of "bankless days." Unusually acute because of the incidence of Election and Armistice Days, in the same week, the general problem has been one of continuing concern since the nation-wide trend in recent years toward Saturday closings.
RALEIGH, N. C., Nov. 12 (AP) -- An aroused North Carolina State football team scored a stunning 27-to-14 upset victory over Wake Forest in a Southern Conference game today.

CADMUS HENRY entered the Confederate Army with equipage that ranged from a beautiful, blooded mare to made-to-order boots, and with the de sire to play a gallant and spectacular role. He was, unfortunately for his ambitions, an excellent penman, and so found himself assigned to duty as a clerk.

PARENTS may differ, one from the other, from nation to nation, but children in France, they'll be happy to learn, are just like children in America and probably just like children in China. They like the same things in books, although here children say skoot for scout, Blanche Neige for Snow White and Meekay for Mickey Mouse.

WHEN a neat honeymoon cottage with simple, square contemporary lines was recently completed in Scarsdale, curious neighbors were astounded to learn that the "young" couple for whom it had been planned and built were grandparents, both over 70.

CAIRO, Nov. 5 -- Egypt is in the midst of an educational crisis. It is publicly discussed as a national disgrace by everyone from the Minister of Education on down. Masses of children as well as adult illiterates are demanding schooling.

NONE of the major Victorian novelists has been more emphatically dead than George Eliot -- she, perhaps, more so than any other. But even she is becoming the beneficiary of our returning respect for the great writers of that age. For many years she

FRESH stacks of children's books, splashing the shops with all the colors of a painter's palette, announce the peak of another season in producing books for the junior generation. There are lively pictures to catch the eye of beginning readers and a multitude of stories contrived to lure youngsters, year by year, along the path that lends to learning and possibly even to wisdom.

HONG KONG, Nov. 12 -- National Government agents threatened court action here today in a counter-move against the personnel of the two Nationalist airlines who are seeking to switch operations of the airlines to the Communist areas of China.

BOSTON, Nov. 12 -- Friends of Framingham, a voluntary group that was organized hastily ten months ago in support of Dr. Miriam Van Waters, superintendent of the Massachusetts Women's Reformatory, was working today on legislation aimed at modernizing the Commonwealth's 70-year-old indenture law.

To read a first-hand account of life in the Soviet Union these days is always a frightening experience. No thoughtful person who follows Gen. Bedell Smith's memoirs from day to day can feel anything but a sense of dread. The discussion of the police state and forced labor in yesterday's and today's installments is calculated to give anyone the shivers.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Chinese Communists drove ahead today in their campaign to split the Nationalist holdings on the mainland.

THESE two titles are fifth and sixth in the "Land of the Free" series, an extensive project designed to show the entrance of various nationality groups upon the American scene. Intended for the 12-and-upward group, they are full-length junior novels, well-planned and skillfully executed.

The final draft of a new $100,000 executive development and appraisal program, said to be the first personnel project where techniques used can be applied with equal success to companies in any type of business activity, will be submitted to sixty diversified organizations this week, Dr. Francis F. Bradshaw, president of Richardson, Bellows, Henry Co., management consultant concern, said last week.

DETROIT, Nov. 12 -- Officials of the automotive industry today estimated that it would take from four to six weeks for closed automobile plants to resume normal production after steel is again available.

MR. SHIPTON'S volume is the second in the Printer's Valhalla series. It is devoted to the publishing and printing career of one of the most colorful personalities in this field -- Isaiah Thomas. As the author has pointed out, Thomas "spread his products over the entire nation, catered to every taste, and established himself in every field of printing.

The Scholarship Fund for the boys at Bonnie Brae Farm in Millington, N. J., will be augmented by the proceeds from the performance of the Ice Follies of 1950 at the Madison Square Garden on the night of Nov. 29. A large subscription has been reported for the event. Many dinner parties will be given before the performance.

The performance of "That Lady," with Katharine Cornell in the leading role, on the night of Dec. 6 at the Martin Beck Theatre has been taken over to raise funds for the Children's Health Service of the New York Diet Kitchen Association. Mrs. Walter Reid Wolf is chairman of the benefit committee, and Mrs. Henry P. Davison is honorary chairman.

ANOTHER layer of leaves will soon be added to the floor of humus in the forest. But on the lawn, autumn leaves will be scattered to the winds or else carefully raked away. No layer of humus will remain to hold moisture, or enrich the soil and feed shade trees next year.

Last week, which some merchants expected to be one of the best of the season here, appears now to have brought only the familiar comparative decline with sales of last year. On the other hand, business was not too bad and sales on a dollar-for-dollar basis climbed about 3 per cent above the previous week.

New alignment of top responsibilities in Packard Motor Car Company's distributing organization was announced yesterday in Detroit. Am immediate apparent result will be an even closer relationship between field and factory than has heretofore existed, it was said by Karl M. Greiner, vice president and general sales manager.

IN this straightforward narrative Carl Carmer has drawn a warmly alive picture of life of the fisher folk on an island off Florida in the Gulf of Mexico. The central character is Peter Tebo, 11 years old, who helps his father fish and who goes to school in a boat.

SELDEN, L. I., Nov. 12 -- Overlooked when her parents gathered up her seven brothers and sisters after an oil stove had exploded, 4-year-old Cecilia Castaldo died shortly before 8 A. M. today, when fire swept through the Castaldo home at 317 Tuscala Street.

THE child of today is confronted with the product of thirty years of experimentation, investigation, exploration and grim determination that he should read what is good for him. Some thinkers have even held that what he likes to read is what is good for him.

GEORGE PRESTON MARSHALL probably never would admit that he's an excitable individual who dies a slow and agonizing death whenever his Washington Redskins lose a ball game -- which is much too often these days. The enemies of the Magnificent Marshall insist that the impetuous owner of the Capital Braves can't resist telephoning instructions to his coach on the field, ordering plays, substitutions and what-not.

THIS is a story about a lion who leaves the merry-go-round to find his rightful place in the forest. His adventures there are shared by Ned and Ed, the twins, who follow the lion's progress to popularity. The lion helps a squirrel gather nuts, saves a baby tiger, cuts the bear's hair, paints stripes on a zebra, and makes a coconut cake.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 12 -- Williams defeated Amherst, 19 -- 13, today to win the Little Three championship for the first time since the war. Scoring twice in the first period, the Purple went on to clinch the hard-fought battle despite fierce Amherst attacks in the second half.

PET owners will recognize in Mr. Tim the same virtues and foibles of their own pups, while youngsters who are not well acquainted with dogs will surely warm up to this winsome cocker spaniel. Mr. Tim is proud, alert and helpful, and so brave he is not even afraid of a cat now and them.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Temple University's football forces put over a touchdown against Penn State for the first time in five years today but the Nittany Lions quadrupled that production for a 28-7 victory.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- A. B. Davis High School of Mount Vernon handed New Rochelle High School's consolidated eleven its first defeat today, upsetting the previously unscored-on Hugenots, 20 -- 12, before 6,000 surprised fans at Memorial Field today.

The two fourteen-foot nudes in polished aluminum, on the facade of the new Parka-Barnet Galleries on Madison Avenue, were described by Wheeler Williams, the sculptor, as "Venus awakening Manhattan to the importance of art from overseas." -- News item.

THE long-nosed Pinocchio has always been the unchallenged favorite of Italian children, including not a few grown-up ones, ever since its first appearance in 1880. "The Adventures of Pinocchio, Story of a Puppet" by Carlo Collodi is still a best-seller, and hardly a year passes without a reprint or a new illustrated edition.
JAPANESE movies, which have staged a surprisingly rapid recovery, re beginning to reflect to increasing measure the ways of democracy and already are looking toward expansion into the foreign market.

ATLANTA, Nov. 12 -- Results of German experiences with several thousand patients have raised scientists' hopes that the new drug named TB-1 will become an important addition to the currently available agents used in the treatment of tuberculosis, medical specialists declared at a conference here today.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Nov. 12 (UP) -- Oklahoma's prairie powerhouse smashed game but outclassed Missouri in a Big Seven football showdown today, 27 to 7, to remain unbeaten this year and high among the nation's very best.

ALBUQUERQUE, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat, of New Mexico, said today "there's no question that Julius A. Krug was let out [as secretary of the Interior] because he kept pressing for reclamation projects."

NOW that 1950 is round the corner, it is high time to take stock of what has happened in twentieth century art so far. No other half century has revealed such a succession of apparently conflicting schools but, as they recede into the past, one begins to see that their divergent contributions fit, after all, into a single pattern.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- More than 8,000,000 families and single individuals in the United States received less than $1,000 cash income in 1948, according to a report made public today by the Subcommittee on Low-Income Families of the Joint Committee on the Economic Report.

BEAR MOUNTAIN -- While this is generally the slack period for outdoor holidayers in this latitude, there seems to be no off-season for the hikers who use the trails of Palisades Interstate Park. Week-ends the Bear Mountain Park trails are filled with New Yorkers getting close to nature.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 12 (AP) -- The chest and toe of Stan McGuire and the long legs of Ken Carpenter carried the Oregon State Beavers to a spectacular 25-20 football victory today over the mighty Spartans of Michigan State College.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Nov. 12 -- A pioneering move toward specialized training in safety and proper handling of children will start here next Friday at the first session of a school bus drivers' school.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Tired of waiting for Congress to act, Hawaii sets out next week on a short cut approach to statehood.

James Dickson Phillips, 58 years old, of Laurinburg, N. C., secretary of the Morgan Cotton Mills, Inc., Laurel Hill, N. C., died of a heart attack yesterday afternoon while witnessing the Notre Dame-North Carolina University football game at Yankee Stadium. He collapsed shortly before the close of the first half of the game.

Sylvia Porter's "Lessons for '49 in the Crash of '29" was a good article. But the writer declared that one of the lessons to be drawn was that there cannot be prosperity for the few. Had she forgotten that people in the Nineteen Twenties prided themselves on the fact that never before were the so-called working classes of this country so well off?

WARSAW, Nov. 12 -- The appointment of Soviet Marshal Konstantin K. Rokossovsky as Poland's Minister of Defense this week provided an unexpected and abrupt climax to the "Month for Deepening Polish-Soviet Friendship." Some non-Marxian Poles felt that too much was being done in the name of friendship.

CLIMAXING "National Stamp Collecting Week," beginning tomorrow, a National Postage Stamp Show will be held on Friday, Saturday and Sunday, from 11 A. M. to 9:30 P. M., at the 71st Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, under the sponsorship of the American Stamp Dealers Association with the support of the major national philatelic societies.

EXETER, N. H., Nov. 12 -- Exploding for 21 points in the second period, the favored Andover Academy football team beat its traditional foes from Exeter, 34 -- 21, today. It was the sixty-ninth contest of this ancient rivalry and drew a crowd of 6,000 spectators.

THE starting-off pace of "Snipe Hunt" is leisurely, but that is all right. It is always entertaining to read an account of how little it takes to make a man go wrong. The man in question is an engraver down on his luck, now specializing in that portion of United States currency which is not printed by the government.

One of the recent trends in American higher education has been the development of two-year "community" colleges. These institutions, designed to meet the needs of students who are unable to attend the regular four-year colleges, have won the support of many educational leaders and organizations.

BASLE, Switzerland Nov. 12 -- Dismantlement of economic controls and formation of a nucleus of countries following liberal economic policies are proceeding much more rapidly than is generally realized in Europe.

TOKYO, Nov. 12 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida, before the House of Councillors today, was again questioned closely regarding potential peace treaty terms based on a series of reports from abroad that a draft agreeable to the Western Allies was approaching completion.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Fleet Billy Bye popped like a wraith from a giant Minnesota forward wall before 42,515 fans today to lead the Gophers to a 24-7 victory over the University of Pittsburgh.

Jokes circtdatinl in Europe today iclude a low that ar mply "a taugk lot a laugl'a sae," but most o! them serve as ideoIogical and lolititl toeapons. Many ar recognizbh aa new vrn$ of old tandtjs. This aeecou is lrora Times correspondents.
BOSTON, Nov. 12 -- The whole New England region expressed interest this week in the downfall of Boston's 74-year-old political boss, Mayor James Michael Curley.
ACAPULCO, Mexico, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Corsair, once the luxury yacht of the late J. Pierpont Morgan, had a midnight harbor shipwreck here with forty-six passengers aboard.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 12 -- Clear-cut approval of a three-part plan for the future of Italy's former empire in East Africa was voted today by the Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly.

A three-day bus trip for thirty-four young people of high school age and of many races will end at 10:30 P. M. today on their return here from Cortland County where they have been entertained by civic leaders of many faiths and have been guests of farm and village householders.

TAM DIAMOND is a big Scottish truckdriver who won a medal as a Commando in the war and uses his fists too quickly in the peace. He is a product of Glasgow slums, the son of a drunken shipyard worker and a despairing mother, and his violence can be traced to days of the dole.

THE field of science-fiction has had many honorable practitioners, and while Frederic Brown is no H. G. Wells, he has dreamed up an amusing and inventive story. The time is 1954 and the hero is one Keith Winton, editor of a magazine known as "Surprising Stories."

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- In Peking, Paris, London, half way around the world from each other, decisions in the unceasing diplomatic and economic contest for the allegiance of the people of Asia were being made this week.

The "Ice Follies of 1950" will open a thirteen-day run at the Madison Square Garden Thursday. This skating revue set to music will have an international cast under the guidance of Eddie Shipstad and Oscar Johnson, co-owners with Roy Shipstad.

Serious inter-agency public-power squabbles have broken out in Nebraska, the only all-public power state in the nation, and fear has been expressed that the Federal Government may take over the electric facilities in that state.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- "Truman and who in '52?"

Mrs. Evelyn L. Hopkins' Three Rings, $19.10-for-$2 sixth choice in the field of eleven, did the job in the $29,250 Westchester Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. It was a front-running job, with Hedley Woodhouse getting credit for the assist.

HADDONFIELD, N. J., Nov. 12 (UP) -- Alfred E. Driscoll, newly reelected Governor of New Jersey, said today that the Republican party must stop being the "party of expediency." It must stop improvising as it goes along, he said, and it must get rid of the reputation of always being "against," and start being "for" its own philosophy of Government.

With financial markets again enveloped by easy money, investors of large means are exploiting the prevailing low short-term interest structure to achieve high current yields on certain fixed-income investments -- returns running beyond 10 per cent and exempt, moreover, from all Federal taxation.
MANILA, Sunday, Nov. 13 (AP) -- President Elpidio Quirino appeared today to have carried his candidates for Congress along with him in a sweeping victory in last Tuesday's general election.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 12 -- Navy's midshipmen, expected by many to give Army a tussle two weeks hence, indicated today they have their heavy guns greased and ready for action.

NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 12 -- The recommendation by a newly organized coalition of Democratic leaders in New Jersey that former Attorney General David T. Wilentz of Middlesex County replace former Mayor Frank Hague as national committeeman from New Jersey was viewed by politicians here today as the opening round of a serious contest over leadership and patronage.

THIS is an exasperating book because there is so much in it that is funny and appealing and so much that is flagrantly sentimental. It is the story of two bantam hens, both of whom "longed to be mothers." Flossie, gentle, dowdy, is an outrageously patient Griselda.

IT is an unusually good year which produces three volumes of new poetry for children as good as these. It would be invidious as well as unnecessary to try to choose a favorite from among them. Each collection has its special flavor and its individual rhythms.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 12 -- The past seven weeks have deepened the initial pessimism that was produced here by President Truman's laconic announcement that "an atomic explosion" had recently occurred in the Soviet Union.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 12 -- The first, concrete step toward a customs union of the countries in the Organization for European Economic Cooperation will be taken in Brussels next week at a meeting of the experts composing the group that has been studying the possibility of such a union since 1947.

In promotions here last week retailers stressed hand beaded bags, misses' and women's coats, upholstered chairs and tables, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

A drug (adenosine-5-monophosphate) appears to be just as effective in the treatment of arthritis as cortisone, ACTH or the sex hormones, and this without producing any dangerous side effects associated with Cushing's disease (growth of hair where it is not wanted, rounding of the face, tumors of the pituitary gland).

President Truman's "positive" assurance late last week that the United States does not intend to raise the dollar price of gold, which would be equivalent to devaluing the dollar, should quiet rumors both here and abroad which have increased uncertainty in foreign trade quarters.

ALBERT SCHWEITZER, the frail son of a poor clergyman in Alsace, grew to robust manhood and achieved wide fame in several fields. This book tells the story of his boyhood, student years, and early success as an organist, student of Bach, and theologian.

VALUABLE for its social slant, this story about the recreational problems of a group of city children of working mothers has meaning for children everywhere. Voluntarily sacrificing their summer plans and moving to a less expensive apartment to help their doctor mother, the five young Bennetts face a long and lonely vacation.

IT'S hard to imagine any reader from 8 to 12 who wouldn't get a lot of excitement and fun from reading this book. "Dig for a Treasure" has all the ingredients for a magic summer, built on the foundations laid in the seventeenth century when Indians attacked the town of Anchorage, Conn., leaving behind burned houses -- but also treasure, buried by the fleeing townspeople.

Andor Foldes, Hungarian-born pianist, has built up a considerable following in his annual recitals, undoubtedly because of his unusual dexterity and ability to project effects of brilliance and color. Yesterday afternoon at Town Hall his audience was unexpectedly small, perhaps due to football games.

Prior to 1935 annuity payments were not taxable until the cost thereof had been fully recovered. Since then, on the theory that each payment is in part a return of capital (measured by the cost to the annuitant) and partly income, a portion of each payment is taxable as income.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- If the synthetic liquid-fuel program that carried Germany through five years of war were applied to the coal reserves of Wyoming it would yield enough gasoline to power the nation's 38,000,000 automobiles for 2,743 years, on the basis of present consumption.

MOSCOW, Nov. 12 -- The newspaper Soviet Art today criticized Lillian Hellman's play, "Another Part of the Forest," which is being presented by the Moscow Drama Theatre under the title, "Ladies and Gentlemen," for failing to present "a merciless and scornful expose of the awful capitalist reality."

LAFCADIO HEARN has become something of a corpus vile, a state that he himself would have envisaged with horror. His contorted life of wanderlust, his emotional maladjustments and his literary oddities have furnished rich material for biographical and critical studies.

IT might be an excellent idea, if the pressure of work would permit, for the justices of the United States Supreme Court to follow the example of their brethren on the British Appeal Court, and write individual opinions in all of the cases before them.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 12 (UP) -- Tulane finally regained its early season power and mauled Vanderbilt, 41 to 14, today in a game that started rough and got rougher, with a platoon of police restoring order on the final play.

CHARLESTON, S. C., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Admiral Daniel V. Gallery said today he considered "it too dangerous to express an opinion" on the testimony of Admiral Louis E. Denfeld, ousted Chief of Naval Operations.

CAIRO, Nov. 7 -- Pilgrims returning from Mecca report that traffic lights are being installed in Islam's Holy City. The appurtenances of modern life are slowly creeping into the city in spite of those who feel that things should remain as they were in the days of the Prophet.

THE Italian chestnut growers of "Deep Grow the Roots," Miss Tomasi's first novel, and the transplanted Vermont granite workers of this equally effective second novel are vivid, moistly human paesanos who are in love with their trees and their rocks, and who accept the hazards of this love as freely as they accept the pleasures of sunshine and red wine.

THE latest 1950-model trailers -- totaling 275 units -- will be displayed by about fifty-three of the nation's leading manufacturers at the fourteenth annual National Trailer Coach Show which opens Tuesday at the National Guard Armory in Washington, D. C.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 5 -- Recalling, that Florence Nightingale began her famous work ac a nurse in this city ninety-five years ago today, United States Ambassador George Wadsworth laid the cornerstone of the new building for the School of Nursing of the Admiral Bristol Hospital here this afternoon. Mr. Wadsworth described the occasion as another sign of American-Turkish cooperation.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 12 -- Dr. Abraham Katznelson of Israel told the United Nations Assembly's Social Committee today that it was not International Refugee Organization aid to European displaced persons for resettlement in Palestine that had created the Arab refugee problem but the attack on the Jews there and the subsequent invasion of the country by Arab states.

WHEN the Metropolitan Opera season is imminent, the record makers put a spate of new operatic recordings on the market. Thus far three full operas and excerpts from others have arrived, and no doubt there will be other disks devoted to the repertory of the lyric stage.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 3. -- Relays of dispatch riders on horseback will converge on this capital next month for the dedication of a monument to the Voortrekkers (Boer Pioneers) of the last century. Those from distant parts of the Union have set out already.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 12 -- Soviet Ambassador Alexander S. Panyushkin declined today as "beneath my dignity" to reply to Yugoslav charges that the Soviet Union refused to settle on its own terms the refugee incident that led to a rupture in Soviet-Yugoslav relations.

REALITY has actually very little to do with truth; there is no necessary connection between the two. Truth may be as unreal as fiction. The real world, the world we live in, is a place of form and color, of "seas and sunsets, trees and flowers, men and women, kings and Popes, and Members of Parliament."

WITHIN these ten little story books, for boys and girls of 7 to 10, is almost everything children ask for except, perhaps, horses and fairy tales. No doubt those will come later. Each book in this new Golden Story Book series has been written by a different author.

A completely new pricing and quotation basis is being introduced by members of the gray iron foundry industry and quotations applying these new standards are already being used by individual foundries. R. L. Collier, executive vice president of the Gray Iron Founders Society, Cleveland, disclosed here last week that the terms and conditions of sale have been approved by the National Association of Purchasing Agents, including revisions made as recently as September.

After a day-long investigation into a purported plot on the life of Federal Judge Harold R. Medina, who presided here at the trial of the eleven Communist leaders, the police late last night dismissed the episode as an attempt by two youths and two young girls to impress one another.

THIS book has practically nothing to do with Paul Revere's horse. It is true that the mare is mentioned in the title essay as belonging to Deacon Larkin; but the book is not about her. Far from it. The book is a series of historical anecdotes, told with accuracy in a racy Journalistic style.

THIS is a book with not just one point of view but four. That is because four mice, the main characters of the story, live in different parts of the barn and have different views of the other animals who live in the barn. High Mouse sees only the tops of the animals while Back Mouse sees the backs from his nest in the back of the barn.

JUST as Scrooge eventually comes around to accepting Christmas, so J. B. Priestley has come around to issuing an anthology called "Delight." This analogy is instigated by the author, who is, he says, a grumbler born and reared, although with a fiercer bark than bite.

Local professional football fans again will have their choice of two attractions today. The Bulldogs oppose the Chicago Cardinals at the Polo Grounds in a National League contest, while the Yankees are paired with the Chicago Hornets in an All-America Conference game at the Stadium. The Giants are on the road, at Green Bay.

ANNOUNCEMENT by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer the other day of a forthcoming film based on Sir Walter Scott's "Ivanhoe" revived interest in a screen project which, since 1946, was planned and dropped by two other studios.

VIENNA, Nov. 12 -- Senator Elmer Thomas, Democrat, of Oklahoma, threatened today to block future United States aid to a country that, he said, had ignored his Armed Forces Subcommittee of the Senate Appropriations Committee.

MARISTAN CHAPMAN is the pen name of Mary and Santon Chapman, joint authors of some eighteen books, including regional tales of southern mountaineers, children's adventure stories, and one biography, "Imperial Brother."

Sylvia F. Porter's "Lessons for '49 in the Crash of '29" appears to follow President Truman's gospel when she quotes him, "Our own people insist upon the maintenance of prosperity and will not tolerate a depression." Simple, isn't it?
Miss Annette Simons, formerly buyer of blouses and accessories for Saks Fifth Avenue, has opened her own fashion consulting service at 30 West Fifty-fourth Street.

IT is one of the curious features of our contemporary culture that while in most fields the dividing line between what is appropriate for children and for adults has been blurred, in literature it has been sharpened. Children are no longer enjoined to be seen but not heard, nor are they excluded from participation in the conversation and activities of their elders.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 12 -- The Communist Government announced today that church marriages would not be recognized in this country after Jan. 1.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 12 -- With hundreds of miles and thousands of words behind him, Robert A. Taft, Ohio's senior Senator, is entering the final lap of his 100-day "non-political" tour of the Buckeye state in a favorable position.

THE winter holiday of Walt Mason and his two companions is interrupted when a stranger arrives at their snowbound cabin high in Mount Ranier National Park. This stranger is Fred Baker, an unfortunate boy who is involved with two criminals in a robbery. And the two criminals are tracking him up the mountain.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Retailers are buying warily, a spokesman for the Chicago wholesale district midseason market week said here. The mild autumn and the effect of labor troubles on buying power have resulted in a cautious attitude.

A clearing house for the exchange of technical information between mental hospitals will be established soon, Dr. George S. Stevenson, president of the American Psychiatric Association announced yesterday.

Cotton has taken Horace Greeley's advice and "gone west." As a result the center of the nation's cotton production has shifted from the Old South to the arid and semi-arid areas of the West and Southwest. Based on the latest forecast of the Department of Agriculture, Texas, New Mexico, Arizona and California this year will produce 7,636,000 bales of cotton, or almost 50 per cent of this country's total estimated crop of 15,524,000 bales.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP) -- A "black market" in television sets appeared in the making this week. Manufacturers in the Chicago area, who produce more than a third of the country's output, revealed that some retail dealers in various parts of the country were getting prices at $20 to $40 or more over list on the more popular sets.

ILLUSTRATED books for children are something like museums on wheels. They give a youngster some of his first esthetic experiences. In this early encounter with man-made images the child's eye and imagination are stimulated -- and just as unconsciously, his taste begins to be defined.

MANHASSET BAY, L. I. -- Only the sturdiest sailors on Long Island Sound can go in for frostbite racing, but for the spectator it's a snap. In the warm comfort of any one of a dozen good restaurants along the shores of Manhasset Bay, on a Sunday afternoon, the frostbite spectator can enjoy the easy pleasure of a family dinner on Long Island while seeing a thrilling sport.

KENT, Conn., Nov, 12 -- Scoring two touchdowns and one extra point in the second quarter, Kent today beat its traditional rival, Loomis, 13 to 12, in the season's finale for both teams before a large Alumni Day gathering. The margin of victory was the game's only successful conversion after touchdown, a neat boot by Tom Ritchey after Kent's second tally.

" TO the Gags * * * drawing was one of the inevitable things of life." It is clear in this biography that to the eldest daughter of that family drawing was life itself. Here a friend of many years tells the story of that brilliant printmaker who also was the creator of "Millions of Cats" and other wonderful books for children.

OUT of the welter of new films that arrived on Broadway this past week, at least two stand out in rugged profile to challenge real interest and regard. One is a stunning war picture from Metro, called "Battleground," and the other is a roaring social drama from Columbia, called "All the King's Men."
MOSCOW, Oct. 28 -- The Soviet Army newspaper, Red Star, has taken to task officers who have neglected the importance of the Army cook in their units.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -- The average Philadelphia voter, engrossed in the bitter municipal election in which the scandal-scarred Republican machine was jolted out of domination of City Hall, gave only passing notice to the returns from other states.

ADMIRERS will welcome this small English boy's return to the sea as second ship's boy on the S. S. Fidelity. Tim manages to emulate in miniature all the virtues of a British sailor without being in the least bit stuffy. It is naughty Ginger, the first ship's boy, who gets into dire trouble as the result of trying out the mate's too-effective hair tonic.
OTTAWA, Nov. 12 (Canadian Press) -- The government was urged this week to consider repealing the 8 per cent sales tax on newsprint used by weekly newspapers.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Nov. 12 -- Left Halfback Walt Hollister of Rye, N. Y., sophomore sensation, led Middlebury College to a 14-6 upset victory over the University of Vermont to give the Panthers their fourth consecutive Vermont Conference football championship before a crowd of 7,000 spectators at Porter Field.

An explosion blew down walls of two apartments in the Terrace Gardens apartment house at 1819 Avenue L, between East Eighteenth and Nineteenth Streets, Brooklyn, yesterday at 2:45 P. M., after a man employed as a floor refinisher had dumped a bag of wood shavings impregnated with shellac down an incinerator shaft.

It is often said that the surest cure for our "Fabulous Invalid" is a resounding hit. If, however, a hit is accompanied by such abuses to the public as conjured up by the Playwrights Company, I wonder.

It is rarely that a chemical compound for utilization in disease is as rapidly acclaimed and accepted as cortisone was. No physician questions its efficacy in cases of arthritis, rheumatic fever, gout, some mental and degenerative diseases. But cortisone also presents a problem that only chemists can solve.

The irregular and too infrequent removal of soot and ash accumulations from the rooftops of factories, apartment houses and other buildings throughout the city is an unnecessary contributing factor to air pollution, William H. Byrne, director of the Bureau of Smoke Control, said yesterday.

On Oct. 12 the Presidential candidacy of Laureano Gomez was proclaimed in Bogota. Gomez had returned only a few weeks before from Spain where for several months the "Caudillo" had shown him the greatest cordiality. Gomes was the founder and is the owner of the newspaper "El Siglo," for several years ardent defender of Hitler and Mussolini, and always, unfailingly, the most outstanding pro-Franco newspaper in South America.

DIVISIONAL histories of World War II are as varied in styles and make-up as the characters of the divisions they portray. They range from pictorial collections loosely held together by a minimum of prose to detailed written accounts that are, quite often, tiresome reading.

NEWARK, N. J., Nov., 12 -Someone once said that chance is just another name for providence. Certainly it would seem that it was something more than chance that directed Freddy Beggs' eyes to an appeal in a Newark paper in 1945 for shaving mirrors for Army hospital patients.

LONDON, Nov. 12 (Reuters) -- Tottenham Hotspur, far outpacing all rivals for the second division lead in the English Football League, captured the spotlight in today's play with a sweeping 7-0 victory over Sheffield United. Fast and clever despite a slippery pitch, the Spurs scored five goals in the first thirty minutes.
These broad conclusions emerged from the off-year elections held last Tuesday:
Miss Annette Simons, formerly buyer of blouses and accessories for Saks Fifth Avenue, has opened her own fashion consulting service at 30 West Fifty-fourth Street.

IT is one of the curious features of our contemporary culture that while in most fields the dividing line between what is appropriate for children and for adults has been blurred, in literature it has been sharpened. Children are no longer enjoined to be seen but not heard, nor are they excluded from participation in the conversation and activities of their elders.

LONDON, Nov. 12 (Reuters) -- Tottenham Hotspur, far outpacing all rivals for the second division lead in the English Football League, captured the spotlight in today's play with a sweeping 7-0 victory over Sheffield United. Fast and clever despite a slippery pitch, the Spurs scored five goals in the first thirty minutes.
These broad conclusions emerged from the off-year elections held last Tuesday:

Hofstra College emerged with its first victory of the season yesterday by defeating Brooklyn College, 13 to 7, in a hard fought game at the Flatbush field before 5,000 spectators. Though behind in almost all statistical departments, the Flying Dutchmen had enough to stop Brooklyn drives throughout the affair.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Feed grains eased on the Board of Trade today, corn dropping around a cent a bushel at one time before staging a mild rally. The downturn in part represented profit-taking following advances earlier this week.
BERLIN (By Wireless). "THERE will be no real stability in Europe until Germany's problems are settled," the late Jan Masaryk remarked to this writer late in the war.

BOSTON, Nov. 12 -- A hard driving and passing Boston College eleven blasted Fordham's hopes today before a chilled crowd of 15,798 at Braves Field, winning by 20 -- 12 after holding the Rams scoreless for three periods.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Undefeated and untied Trinity College, heading for its first perfect season in fifteen years, halted Wesleyan, 7 to 6, today in a football thriller before 8,000 chilled fans.
A policeman, a customer and a bandit were wounded during a pistol fight at 10:30 o'clock last night when the police halted a hold-up by two men in a liquor store at 103 West Eighty-second Street.

THOSE who have been viewing with alarm as well as a touch of cynicism the difficulties being encountered by Maurice Evans in his drive to arrange a theatre season for the City Center this winter are hereby assured that Mr. Evans himself is far from daunted.

THE Phoebe Snow, the Lackawanna Railroad's long-awaited streamliner, will start daily service between Hoboken and Buffalo on Tuesday. Supplanting the Lackawanna Limited, the new Diesel-powered train will make the 396-mile run in 8 hours 15 minutes, leaving Hoboken at 10:30 A. M., and Buffalo at 10:15 A. M.

A SOURCE of wonderment to this reviewer is the number of anthologies that manage to get published every season. This one is, in the editors' words, a volume designed to reach a reading body that prefers "literary genius, enriched, enlarged and elevated by a Christian habit of mind."

THESE pieces by Mr. Perry were first published in The Saturday Evening Post and Country Gentleman. Whether they were worth preserving between covers is somewhat debatable. As studies of nine fairly typical contemporary American families they are unhappily slight both in concept and impact.

It now seems apparent that for a period of time, at least, there will be some divergence between British and United States policies in the Far East. British recognition of the Chinese Communists is now said to be probable by early next year. United States recognition, in spite of support for it in some State Department quarters, will not be so precipitate -- or so sure.

A supper dance at Sherry's on Thanksgiving Eve, Nov. 23, will be the first in a series of three Gotham Dances for the 1949-50 season. The parties are arranged in separate classifications for sub-debutantes, debutantes and young men of prep school and early college years.

Story book characters "come to life" will be a feature of THE NEW YORK TIMES third annual Boys' and Girls' Book Fair, which will open on Friday for a four-day stay at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and Seventy-seventh Street.

QUINCY HOWE, who has moved from journalism to broadcasting and is now devoting himself to television, is a man who has moved with the times and yet always has tried to observe and to interpret them. The eighteen years which Mr. Howe discusses in the first volume of a work to which two further volumes are to be added, are the years of his childhood and early youth.

IN these days when drought is news, the fact that Americans annually consume in excess of 33,000,000,000 gallons of all kinds of liquids is arresting. In displacement tons of water, we drink enough to float most of the navies, fighting and freighting, of the world.
KINGS POINT, L. I., NOV. 12 -- The United States Merchant Marine Academy eleven captured the Long Island "Little Three" crown by upsetting Adelphi College, 41 -- 13, at Tomb Memorial Field today.

Radio executives agreed at a national convention here yesterday that by placing the accent in news broadcasts on local names and events, radio stations would assure themselves of greater good-will in the community and enhance their chances for profitable operation.

The Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers last week honored George G. Sharp, naval architect of New York, with the David W. Taylor Medal for "notable achievement" in his field. Mr. Sharp is the eleventh recipient of the Taylor Medal, the highest award of the society.

THE Philippine Islands were brought close to this country by recent world war history. An introduction to their folklore is both valuable and timely. These stories are long and short, simple and elaborate. Some are akin to our American Indian mythology, other stories follow familiar folktale patterns and reflect influences from Europe and the Western Hemisphere.

THE current trend here in children's books -- not a very decided trend -- is away from fantasies and fairies toward a more realistic and more adult type of reading. This has been blamed rather improbably on the war, its accent on techniques and gadgets and its dampening impact on childish imagination.

A preview performance of the comedy "Clutterbuck," by Benn W. Levy, on Dec. 1 at the Biltmore Theatre, has been taken over for the benefit of the West Side Day Nursery. The funds raised will be devoted to the work of the beneficiary, founded fifty years ago, in caring for young children of working mothers on the lower West Side.
BERLIN, Nov. 12 -- Two-year compulsory service in the "people's police" in the East zone will be introduced in March, 1950, according to today's edition of the Western- licensed Sozialdemocrat.

MR. HARAP'S thesis is that creative activity (painting, writing, film-making, etc.) has always directly reflected the prevailing issues in the class struggle, and that modern artists must find and embrace their own creative roles in the present crisis.

THE question of children's literature in the Soviet Union has been a subject of considerable discussion in the press since the publication several weeks ago of a sharp criticism of children's publications by the influential journal Culture and Life.

The St. Regis Paper Company has begun a multiple-use perpetual-yield forest operation in a 220,000-acre dense stand of long-leaf yellow pine near Fargo, Ga., it was announced last week. This means that, barring a catastrophe, a variety of wood products, pulp wood, poles and saw timber will be harvested from the forest forever, it was said.

MAROONED in the dusty attic, Miss Flora McFlimsey sat remembering those brighter years when she had been the cherished doll of a little girl in high, red, buttoned shoes. It took her one friend, Timothy Mouse, to rouse Miss Flora by describing a decorated tree downstairs.
IN his review of Elmer Rice's "The Show Must Go On," (Book Review, Oct. 9) A. C. Spectorsky refers to Mr. Rice's "Imperial City" as a "Hollywood novel."

LONDON (By Wireless). THIS is not the first time I have been concerned with one of these Sunday Times book exhibitions. I believe that on the last occasion I also received a gold medal. I shall put them both side by side and derive dual encouragement.

SQUEEZED into Babar's old car, Zephir and Arthur, Pom, Flora and Alexander started off on a picnic. Later, while Zephir and Arthur played chess, the three little elephants put on their Indian costumes and went exploring.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 12 -- Brown ended an eleven-year victory famine in Harvard Stadium today by rolling up its greatest scoring total in the history of the series, a 28-14 triumph over the Crimson before 23,000 fans.
It was indeed heartening to read Pearl Buck's "Our Dangerous Myths About China," which contained the gratifying information that China is practically bursting with food.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 12 -- Partly as a result of internal political considerations, the Indian Government has been unable to meet the position of the United States on a proposed treaty of friendship, commerce and navigation.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 12 -- The Soil Conservation Society of America called upon Congress today to undertake a comprehensive inventory of land and water resources and their condition.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Shah of Iran, due to arrive here Wednesday as the first Oriental monarch to make a state visit to the United States, will use his talks with United States officials to express his country's need for greater military and economic assistance, it was indicated today.

The decision as to whether to plant roses this fall or next spring cannot be delayed much longer. The many advantages of fall planting seem to me to warrant the addition of this task to the list for November.

MY initial indignation upon reading Mr. Robert W. Luce's letter (Book Review, (Oct. 9) was quickly followed by imagining how Jane Austen would have disposed of Mr. Luce as a minor character in one of her novels.

A Christmas bazaar for the Generosity Thrift Shop will be held at the shop's quarters at 1237 Third Avenue commencing Nov. 21 with a "Parcel Post Sale." Friends of the shop will send articles through the mails to the shop and they may be purchased, sight unseen, at a small fee by customers at the bazaar.

IN a family like Maidie's in which the children are cooperative and unselfish and the parents are understanding and sympathetic it is possible for a 12-year-old girl's day-dreams to come true -- whether they be about a house on a hilltop, a pony or a best friend.

MRS. KERNODLE traces the history of the Red Cross nurses through sixty-six years of operation as public health nurses, instructors of nurse's aides, educators in foreign lands and administrators. She has collected an impressive array of facts, drawing on original documents, newspaper reports, correspondence and memories of persons still living and has woven them together in readable form.

The Parke-Bernet Galleries will hold the first auction sale tomorrow in their new galleries at 980 Madison Avenue. The first week on the new premises will be heavy, with four sales scheduled. The books, paintings, jewelry, gold and enamel boxes and period furniture that will go under the hammer are now on exhibition throughout the ten galleries.

The shock of mighty Notre Dame trailing by 6 -- 0 as the result of a blocked kick in the first three minutes of play threw 67,000 persons into an uproar at the Yankee Stadium yesterday, but the speed, passing and blocking of the Fighting Irish resulted in the customary rout as they defeated North Carolina by 42 -- 6 in their first New York appearance since 1946.

November nights are long and chill and full of stars and the crisp whisper of fallen leaves skittering in the wind. November nights are good for walking down a country road, when the world is close about you, a world drawn in bold charcoal strokes against the sky.
The B-36 long-range bomber, largest in the world, was the center of the recent inter-service controversy in Washington, repercussions from which were still occurring last week.

The whole recovery of Europe will be greatly retarded if the problem of the German expellees is not solved, the most Rev. Bryan J. McEntegart, Roman Catholic Bishop of Ogdensburg, N. Y., said yesterday on his arrival here from Italy aboard the liner Saturnia.
Army, which has dominated Heptagonal cross-country since joining the group, won the eleventh annual run at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx yesterday.

BOSTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Endorsement of the drive by the Congress of Industrial Organizations to purge left-wing unions was voiced today by delegates to a conference representing some 30,000 members of the Textile Workers of America, CIO.

Establishment of a twenty-man permanent advertising advisory committee to cooperate in a new service unit of the Department of Commerce should result in providing more Government - compiled data for and on the advertising industry, it was suggested yesterday by advertising trade sources.

The Federal Republic of Germany, sponsored by the Western powers, has been functioning for sixty-seven days. The German Democratic Republic, sponsored by Soviet Russia, has been in existence thirty-seven days. These two states are the field on which a duel is being fought for supremacy -- a duel that is a dramatic symbol of the world-encompassing struggle between Russia and the West and probably the most critical engagement of that struggle.

HIGHTSTOWN, N. J., Nov. 12 -- Blair Academy defeated the Peddie School eleven, 25 -- 13, today before a fall homecoming crowd of 2,500. This was the season's final for both teams and the record shows Blair with three victories, three losses and one tie and Peddle with two triumphs against five defeats.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -- Charles D. Cline's sound little California Boston terrier, Champion Payson's Miss Patricia G. G., went to best in show tonight in the fifty-fifth exhibition of the Kennel Club of Philadelphia, first big one of the indoor season. It drew 1,078 dogs to Convention Hall, under last year's 1,214, and a decline also reflected in the entry at Camden tomorrow.

HARTFORD, Conn. BEFORE any election votes were cast last Tuesday, or tallied, you or I could have predicted that, with the rarest exceptions, the winning candidates would be either Democrats or Republicans. For whatever we think of it -- and I happen to think very highly of it -- the two-party system is the inescapable fact of American political life.

FOR the Sunday night supper party, the cocktail gathering where the guests stay on or the "little luncheon" for four, this department recommends the zwiebelkuchen. This onion and bacon pie, German in origin, was introduced to us at Chicago's Bismarck Hotel; it is the most delicious reason we know for visiting that establishment.
Dr. Richard H. Barnes has been appointed to the new post of assistant director of research of Sharp Dohme, Inc., pharmaceuticals. He was formerly director of biochemical research.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13 -President Truman expressed hope of Point Four aid to Israel in a message to the opening session here tonight of the thirty-fifth annual convention of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America.

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 13 -- An imported greyhound, Mrs. Harding Mason's Boughten Blue Lad of Little Andely from Cross River, N. Y., went to best in show today in the 724-dog eighteenth all-breed event of the Camden County Kennel Club.
HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 13 -- Two national concerns will open big units here on Wednesday.

The "traditional right" of a steamship company to select its officer personnel will be insisted upon in negotiations, between the Committee for the Companies and Agents -- Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, and the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, a spokesman for the owners' group said yesterday.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Aubrey S. Eban received awards last night at Yeshiva University's annual Charter Day dinner for their contributions to world peace.
Thanksgiving to God for St. Vincent's Hospital's first hundred years of service was offered yesterday by Cardinal Spellman when he celebrated solemn pontifical mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

A group of thirty-eight white visitors from a dozen Vermont communities ended a week-end bus trip to Harlem yesterday by attending the morning service at the Abyssinian Baptist Church, 132 West 138th Street. They then had dinner and attended Sunday School and a special afternoon assembly program in which two Vermont women ministers participated.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- Industrial inventories of raw materials in the Chicago area decreased steadily in October, largely because of the steel strike, the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago said today. Production of manufactured goods rose for the third consecutive month and prices remained virtually unchanged.

Benno Moiseiwitsch, the celebrated pianist, gave an all-Chopin program last night at Carnegie Hall. Again, as last year when he appeared in the same auditorium after an interim of fourteen years, he was rapturously received by a large gathering come to pay homage to one of the great artists of the time.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The giant-killer Buffalo Bills fought the champion Cleveland Browns to a 7-7 stalemate in an All-America Football Conference game today.

HONG KONG, Nov. 13 (UP) -- The Nationalist Central News Agency reported today that the Provincial Government had abandoned Kweiyang, capital Kweichow Province, as Communist armies nearing that city drove a wedge between the remaining Nationalist armies.

A "Big Brother'' plan to aid sixty new synagogues organized or in process of formation in the last two years was adopted yesterday by the New York Federation of Reform Synagogues. The federation met in the Community House of Temple Emanu-El, 1 East Sixtyfifth Street.
LONDON, Nov. 13 -- War Secretary Emanuel Shinwell charged Dr. Cyril Garbett, Archbishop of York, tonight with "deplorable" political bias in his criticism last week of the Labor Government.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Chuckin' Charley Conerly pitched four touchdown passes to give the New York Giants a 30-10 victory over Green Bay today in a National Football League game at City Stadium.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- Army raincoats and battle jackets in lustrous satins are the theme of after-dark ensembles at Jacques Fath's brilliant midseason opening, held in the presence of Princess de Rethy, wife of King Leopold of Belgium.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The head of the Federal Reserve System told Congress today that an increase in the price of gold would have the same effect as an arbitrary issue of "greenbacks" and would "expose the economy to great inflationary dangers."

Mary-Ellen Thompson, New York soprano, gave her first local recital yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall, with Johannes Smit at the piano. The program included the arias, "Divinites de Styx," from Gluck's "Alceste," and "Plus grand dans son obscurite," from Gounod's "La Reine de Saba."

" Whirlwind," by Stephen Clissold, an account of Marshal Tito's rise to power, will be published in January by the Philosophical Library. The story is pieced together from original sources and supplemented by the author's observations and acquaintance with "the chief actors in the Yugoslav drama."

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 13 -- Neomycin and aureomycin, the drugs that early laboratory work had indicated might be of value in treatment of tuberculosis, were discounted here today by specialists at the eighth Streptomycin Conference sponsored by the Veterans Administration.
Rabbi Irving Miller of Woodmere, L. I., was elected president of the American Jewish Congress yesterday to succeed the late Dr. Stephen S. Wise.

City College today will begin a week-long celebration in memory of Morris Raphael Cohen. It will open an exhibit of his books, letters and original manuscripts in the Lincoln Corridor of the College's Main Building, 139th Street and Convent Avenue.

Voting precipitated by the recent action of the Congress of Industrial Organizations in ousting the United Electrical, Radio and Machineworkers from the CIO resulted yesterday in a decision by four locals to remain with the expelled union. Two locals, including No. 201 of Lynn, Mass., the largest in the union, voted to disaffiliate and to join the newly formed International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machineworkers, CIO.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- A B-17 Air Force plane carrying Vice President Alben W. Barkley narrowly missed a collision Thursday night with a blimp near the National Airport, it was announced tonight by Bolling Air Force base.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 13 -- Five more steel companies, employing a total of 26,000 production workers, signed agreements with the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, today, leaving a total of about 74,000 of the original 530,000 still on strike in the steel and aluminum industries.
Three men who have temporarily deserted their wives for a 40-foot ketch were in town yesterday sporting beards, spinning sea stories and preparing for an uncomfortable vacation.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- France has attained third ranking among steel exporting countries, according to French industrial producers. She follows only the United States and the Benelux group, having passed the United Kingdom.

Natural limitations make it unlikely that television news programs ever will replace those on the radio, Elmer Davis, news analyst of the American Broadacasting Company, told the fourth annual convention of the National Association of Radio News Directors at the Commodore Hotel yesterday.

The municipal transit system, despite the higher fares in effect since July 1, 1948, appeared yesterday to be facing the threat of an operating deficit for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1950. The total revenue of the city system for July, the opening month of the second fiscal year of higher fare operation, fell $1,324,614 short of meeting operating costs.

To coordinate efforts to improve health care for the nation, six national associations representing doctors, nurses, dentists and hospital, health and welfare officials, have formed a joint committee, it was made known yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 13 -- The United States and Britain have agreed upon a counter-proposal to the Soviet resolution calling for a Big Five non-aggression pact and they plan to introduce it tomorrow in the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The apparent failure of John L. Lewis to re-establish negotiations with the mine operators over the weekend to prevent a resumption of the soft-coal strike heightened a belief tonight that the Federal Government would propose putting the dispute before an extralegal board of inquiry.
Mrs. Francis H. McAdoo and Mrs. Douglas L. Elliman have been named co-chairmen of the women's division of the Salvation Army's seventieth anniversary appeal, it was announced yesterday.

Ramon Vinay and Rise Stevens as "Samson et Dalila" will be starred in the first Metropolitan Opera broadcast of the new season over the American Broadcasting Company radio network Saturday, Nov. 26. The official announcement of the opera series, which had been expected for several weeks, was made yesterday by George A. Sloan, board chairman of the Metropolitan Opera;

After the Revolution, when the new United States of America, under Washington and Hamilton, had assumed the debts of the colonies and funded the continental currency at one cent on the dollar, our national debt was about $17.60 per capita.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -Rises granted by Congress increased the Federal payroll to a scheduled $10,200,000,000-plus for this fiscal year ending June 30, an Associated Press survey showed today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- Imports of home furnishings, accelerated by currency devaluations in more than thirty foreign countries, have started to provide competition for domestic producers but have not reached large scale proportions yet, Lawrence H. Whiting, president of the American Furniture Mart, said today.

Erna Berger, German soprano, will make her American debut with the Metropolitan Opera Company when it opens its sixty-fifth season next Monday evening, it was announced yesterday. She will sing the role of Sophie in "Der Rosenkavalier," presented in memory of its late composer, Richard Strauss.
The privately owned portion of the American merchant marine could not carry 50 per cent of the nation's current export volume if Government-owned vessels were withdrawn from the seas.

The old reductio ad absurdem -"what's the price of coffee in Brazil"? -- like many old saws these days, has temporarily lost its meaning. Many a housewife is scanning the spot and futures quotations of coffee, wondering where the current price rises will stop. After several seasons of drought and flood in Central and South American areas, the coffee bean is scarcer.

BERLIN, Nov. 13 (AP) -- An official of the Communist-led East German Republic was quoted tonight as saying that the Soviet Union planned to close its prison camps in Eastern Germany and turn all political prisoners over to the East German state.

WARSAW, Nov. 14 -- Deep secrecy surrounded today's closing session of the plenary meeting of the Central Committee of the Polish United Workers (Communist party). The Posh press and radio still had not announced that such an important meeting, which undoubtedly is shaping the policy of the Government as well as its composition, was in progress.

Activity in the coat and suit market increased considerably last week as a result of special sales promotions, according to a report on the wholesale apparel market here prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

The constructive force of Christianity was emphasized yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Elmer A. Fridell, foreign secretary for the American Baptist Foreign Mission Society, in one of nearly 200 exchange services throughout the country between the Northern Baptist Convention and the Disciples of Christ.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 13 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson, paying a state visit to the capital and Government of the Western German Federal Republic today, promised "every assistance" to the state and expressed his hopes that the coming talks between the Allied High Commission and the Germans "will contribute mightily to the development and recovery of Germany."

Plans for a new taxpayer building near two lower East Side housing developments have been announced in connection with the sale of 51 and 53 Avenue D, southwest corner of East Fifth Street, by Mollie Weiss to the Irving M. Gross Company, builders.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Y. W. C. A. was termed today an effective means of combating communism on college campuses by Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell of New York's Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, addressing the Y. W. C. A. annual World Fellowship Service at Washington Cathedral.

The volume of business done by men's and boys' wear stores during October dropped 17 per cent compared with the corresponding month of last year, it was announced last week in Washington by the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers.

Some folk singers stand still in their art, but not Richard Dyer-Bennet, as he demonstrated again Saturday night when he gave his annual New York recital before an audience of almost 1,300 at Town Hall. Clearly, he has been working on both his singing and his guitar playing.

CHESTER, N. J., Nov. 13 -- One man was killed, another was injured critically and two more were hurt at 7:30 P. M. today when a four-passenger private airplane in which they were flying through rain and mist crashed on a farm here.

Having categorically and finally rejected the plan for atomic bomb control approved by the great majority of the United Nations, Soviet Foreign Minister Vishinsky has now launched a double-barreled propaganda drive to deflect attention from the grave responsibility his country has assumed.

Demonstrators led by four Protestant ministers, who were dressed in black ecclesiastical robes, participated yesterday in a protest against alleged police brutality involved in the shooting last week of Herminion Miranda, 20 years old, of 129 Columbus Avenue.

Returned from abroad after an absence of twelve years from this country, Winifred Cecil, soprano, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. That the gifted artist, who had made her mark in the realm of musical comedy and on the air as well as in serious song, had not lost her hold on the local public was attested by the large and fervently enthusiastic audience which welcomed her at this reappearance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -Senator Kenneth S. Wherry of Nebraska, Republican floor leader, predicted today that the people would reject President Truman's Fair Deal program in the 1950 Congressional elections.

LONDON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Mr. Shinwell's attack on the second ranking prelate in the Established Church was the first reply by a high Government official to recent comments by ecclesiastical dignitaries on Britain's economic plight.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Columbus detectives still sought today a possible motive for an Ohio State University freshman's desire to arm himself a few minutes before he shot and killed a fraternity brother.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The San Francisco Forty-Niners encountered a stiff duel for the first half today but gathered momentum and rolled on to hand the Los Angeles Dons a 41-to-24 defeat in an All-America Conference football game before a slim gathering of 17,880 fans.
The American Association for the United Nations renewed yesterday its appeal to the world organization to set up a second atomic energy commission to deal with the peacetime uses of nuclear power.

PLEASANTVILLE N. Y., Nov. 13 -- A new dining hall, recreational hall and field house, constructed at a cost of $400,000, were dedicated this afternoon at the Jewish Child Care Association's Pleasantville Cottage School on Broadway.

Forthcoming distribution of the $2,800,000,000 G.I. insurance dividend and realization that there is no likelihood of any notable break in prices are making for fairly strong sentiment in the men's clothing industry, according to the "open letter" issued for publication today by Jerome I. Udell, president of Max Udell Sons Co., Inc., maker of Gramercy Park Clothes.

ALBANY, Nov. 13 -- A broad, impartial investigation of state finances and of the efficiency of state administration was urged today in a report by the board of directors of the Empire State Association of Commerce. The report recommended the creation of a bipartisan commission to undertake such a study.

Support of the Park Department's 1950-1952 program providing for construction of sixty-one neighborhood playgrounds was announced yesterday by the Park Association of New York City, Inc. A public hearing on the plan is to be held tomorrow by the Board of Estimate.

Warren R. Austin, chief United States delegate to the United Nations, yesterday told an audience of 800 persons, including scores of foreign diplomats, that this session of the General Assembly was witnessing a new "consultative approach" to international problems.

Plans for an extensive advertising campaign, concentrated in newspapers of major cities, to promote transatlantic travel of Catholic groups for the 1950 Holy Year of Jubilee were announced yesterday by the American Express-Catholic Travel League.

A black pit terrier bit one boy, tore the clothes of three others and scattered the late Mass crowd before the Roman Catholic Church of St. Peter and St. Paul at Brook Avenue and 159th Street, the Bronx, shortly before noon yesterday.

A low-cost dishwasher -- that is, one that is less expensive than the regular electric models -- is being introduced by General Electric. The machine, which moves on wheels, requires no permanent plumbing or electrical connections and thus involves no installation charges.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- Foreign Minister Robert Schuman, in the course of several speeches today in the region of Metz, tried to calm French uneasiness with regard to the general understandings reached among the three Western Foreign Ministers at their meeting here on the subject of Germany.

BOSTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins gained their first victory in their last nine National Hockey League games by outskating the Toronto Maple Leafs by a 4-2 margin tonight before 10,895 fans at the Boston Garden. It was a costly triumph, for Center Eddie Sandford suffered a severed left Achilles tendon during the opening period.

SEATTLE, Nov. 13 (UP) -- The successful firing "of scores" of rocket-propelled, guided missiles, designed to seek out and destroy enemy aircraft, was disclosed here today by the Air Force after two years of secrecy.
