It gave out some of the data pertaining to the pilotless, supersonic aircraft developed by the Boeing Aircraft Company.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13 -- The third major attempt of the Federal Government to send Harry R. Bridges, West Coast longshore leader, back to his native Australia as an alleged Communist gets under way here tomorrow.

We welcome, as we have in three previous years, the Regional Plan Conference, which will bring together officials and citizens of many of the 550 municipalities of the New Jersey-New York-Connecticut metropolitan region. This all-day meeting, to be held tomorrow at the Hotel Roosevelt; is unique in the opportunity provided for sitting down with our neighbors and discussing present and future problems.
LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Prince Charles, the future King of Britain, was tucked into bed early tonight to rest up for a gay party celebrating his first birthday tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UP) -An atomic energy expert challenged today a naval officer's contention that an atomic bomb explosion would not seriously injure a person standing about a mile away.

WHEN Carl Carmer wrote "Listen for a Lonesome Drum," thirteen years ago, he scratched only the surface of New York State folk history. That amusing book was about the strange religious cults and ideal communes which sprouted all across the state in the nineteenth century. But a lot of other cranks and eccentrics have flourished between the Niagara

Not with one of their better performances but with one that sufficed, the Brooklyn-New York Yankees tallied twice early and then hung on long enough to defeat the Chicago Hornets, 14 -- 10, at the Stadium yesterday. The victory, more a credit to the defense than the attack, clinched an All-America Football Conference play-off berth for the Yankees.

The future of Jerusalem has been placed on the agenda of the United Nations by the recent report of the Palestine Conciliation Commission. To us as Christian ministers and laymen the status of Jerusalem and its future are a source of anxiety.

The world's problems can be solved only by "making use of Jesus Christ," the Rt. Rev.Dr. Howard E. Rondthaler, Bishop of the Southern Province of the American Moravian Church, declared yesterday at the morning service of the First Moravian Episcopal Church, Lexington Avenue at Thirtieth Street.

An audience of almost 1,500 persons filled Town Hall last night for Jennie Tourel's first recital of the season. The mezzo-soprano was greeted with enthusiasm and in return rewarded her admirers with a substantial program sung as only she could sing it.

The main problem of Protestant welfare in New York is to take care of the dependent and neglected children under 16 years old, W. Noel Hudson, executive vice president of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Shipment of radioisotopes for peacetime uses has reached a rate more than triple that of two years ago, the Atomic Energy Commission said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The United States Government is now developing several new themes about the "integration" of Europe. But even in the highest levels of the Government there is no agreement about what "integration" means or what the United States should do to bring it about.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 13 -- The nation's refrigeration and air-conditioning industry will do approximately two billion dollars' worth of business this year -- the highest in history -- K. B. Thorndike of Detroit, president of the Refrigeration Equipment Manufacturers Association, said today.

Last night at 11:07 o'clock sharp a slight, trim man in a neat blue serge suit alighted from the Twentieth Century Limited at Syracuse. Although he looked as fresh as any other passenger, he was completing a 4,500,000-mile journey on the New York Central, a ride that became a career.
BERGENFIELD, N. J., Nov. 13 -- It was just one of those days for the volunteer firemen of this community. Everything happened.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- The Westchester Heart Home, the prize in a nail-guessing contest sponsored by the Westchester Heart Committee and the Civic and Business Federation of White Plains, will not have to be divided between the tying winners, it was made known today.
MANILA, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Official election returns today reached the point where there was no more chance for the opposition to unseat President Elpidio Quirino.

AT the end of the first half the press box experts who had seen Notre Dame in previous games were buttonholing those neighbors getting their first glimpse of the Fighting Irish. "This isn't the same team we've been watching," they were saying. "Notre Dame has lost its sharpness and is in a slump." They were still apologizing when the game ended in the Yankee Stadium with Frank Leahy's heroes winning.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UP) -Trial Examiner William E. Spencer of the National Labor Relations Board held today that a local of the United Steelworkers, CIO, violated the Taft-Hartley Act by causing the dismissal of an employe who refused to pay his union dues but was still technically a union member.

MOSCOW, Nov. 13 -- Soviet circus posters and certain theatrical advertisements drew criticism today from the newspaper Soviet Art, organ of the Film Ministry and the Central Committee on Arts. The newspaper directed theatrical administrators to take to their own hearts the admonition, "Watch the advertisements."

The domestic cotton market showed no reaction last week to the Government's crop forecast at a higher level than had been anticipated. Active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange showed only minor changes, ranging from a decline of 11 to an advance of 4 points, compared with a week earlier.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -Tommy Thompson threw four touchdown passes today to lead the Philadelphia Eagles to an easy 44-21 victory over the Washington Redskins. The Eagles had such complete command of the game that not once were they forced to punt.

Three shots were fired at 5 A. M. yesterday in the emergency ward of Roosevelt Hospital in the course of a melee involving policemen and a husky seaman who had come to the hospital to be attended for injuries suffered in a fight.

A two and one-half-mile extension of the Southern State Parkway from Deer Park Avenue, north of Babylon, L. I., to Bay Shore Road, at the intersection of the proposed Sagtikos, Heckscher and Captree State Parkways, will be opened to traffic this morning, it was announced yesterday by the Long Island State Park Commission.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 13 -Rather than an exchange of surplus United States wheat for Indian manganese and mica over a period of years, India would prefer to obtain wheat on an arrangement resembling wartime lend-lease, Dr. John Matthai, Finance Minister, said in an interview today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -The United States Treasury Department announced today that it will redeem $1,962,687,300 in seven-year-old bonds on next March 15, two years before their maturity date.

Mariemma and her little Spanish ensemble gave their second and last performance at the Ziegfeld Theatre last night in an almost entirely different program of dances. It was in many ways superior to last week's performance, partly because the two boys who dance with the star gave a better account of themselves and partly because Mariemma's own dances were better programmed.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Driving into a first-period lead and building it up most of the way, the Syracuse Nationals downed the New York Knickerbockers, 80 to 66, in a ruggedly-played National Basketball Association game which drew an all-time local high attendance of 8,005 to the State Fair Coliseum tonight.
An all-day conference on New York's traffic problems will be held at the Roosevelt Hotel tomorrow, the Regional Plan Association, Inc. announced yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- The nineteenth annual exhibition of the Westchester Arts and Crafts Guild will be opened at 2 P. M. tomorrow in the Westchester County Center here, under the sponsorship of the Westchester County Recreation Commission.
The congregation of the Morrisania Presbyterian Church, Washington Avenue and 168th Street, the Bronx, observed yesterday the 100th anniversary of its organization.

DETROIT, Nov. 13 -- George N. Craig, national commander of the American Legion, warned today that subversive groups in this country were seeking to destroy national unity "through largescale cunning campaigns to aggravate racial, religious and ethnic bigotry and tensions."
Every girl, no matter what her age or size, wants to be in step with fashion. This winter it's the blouse that is in the style limelight. A pretty blouse can give an air of dressiness to any costume.

After a somewhat acrimonious discussion of the two-platoon system in football, the talk swung around to the overpopulation of the world. This was not as grave a non sequitur as it may seem, since numbers are involved, and the course from one to the other was not too difficult to follow at that time of night.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The heavily favored Los Angeles Rams avoided a stunning upset today by pushing over a touchdown with twenty-four seconds left to gain a 7-7 tie with the Pittsburgh Steelers before 20,510 on rain-soaked Forbes Field.

Tallying nine touchdowns, eight extra points and one field goal, the explosive Chicago Cardinals rolled up a record National Football League score in swamping the New York Bulldogs, 65 to 20, before 9,072 spectators in the dark and dreary Polo Grounds yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- The stock markets continue to reflect a feeling of uneasiness and apprehension regarding Britain's economic outlook in the belief that the Government's measures are inadequate to meet the situation.
Six new films, including importations from England and Sweden, are slated to open in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

Net income of Pullman, Inc., for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 was $4,973,885, equal to $2.07 a common share, compared with $4,416,093, or $1.72 a share, in the same period of 1948, D. A. Crawford, president, announced yesterday.

A program of interest was presented in Carnegie Hall late yesterday afternoon by Bela Urban, Hungarian-born violinist. With the assistance of Simeon Bellison, formerly the Philharmonic-Symphony's first clarinetist, and Virginia Urban, the violinist's wife, at the piano, he played the first New York performance of Khatchaturian's Trio (1932) and also Walter Piston's Sonata.

It takes little study of the election figures to show what a great campaign Senator Dulles put on, and that the Republicans and many independent Democrats of the State of New York are going to support a man who is willing to stand up against federal usurpation and the welfare state.

Frequently the words "sectional" and "regional" are used in a derogatory sense. Unconsciously we think of them as indicating a withdrawal from a larger unit or as perpetuating barriers to wider understanding. It is a pleasure, therefore, to observe a case in which a "regional" concept represents an expansion of horizons and a breaking of barriers.

The Zionist Organization of America announced yesterday an agreement with the Jewish Agency for Palestine and the World Confederation of Zionists providing for the allocation of $1,250,000 to be used for ZOA projects in Israel.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13 -- After a decade or so of agitation, the question of whether a port authority for San Francisco Bay should be created is about to be subjected to serious study.
ILFRACOMBE, England, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A Spanish freighter exploded and sank in a gale near Lundy Island today, leaving six of her crew dead and six missing.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 13 (UP) -- A majority of the Supreme Court has denounced President Mariano Ospina Perez's interference with its procedure as unlawful and "unacceptable," the court made known today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 13 -- An urgent plea on behalf of the Palestine Arab refugee population has been made to Secretary General Trygve Lie by the American Friends Service Committee, it was announced here today. The committee is one of several relief organizations that have been helping to administer the United Nations Relief for Palestine Refugees program in the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The General Services Administration has allocated $18,657,471 in Federal loans among the states for planning public works to be constructed in the event of an economic decline warranting pump priming.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 13 -- Although Farley Granger's contract with Samuel Goldwyn would not have expired for another two years, the producer today gave his 24-year-old star a new one that will keep him under Goldwyn's management for five more years.

The Sisters of Charity of St. Vincent de Paul of New York deserved the warm congratulations they received yesterday on the occasion of the 100th anniversary of the founding by their order of St. Vincent's Hospital. Not only was St. Vincent's the first Catholic hospital to be established in New York City; it also was the first voluntary hospital in this city founded for the care of the sick poor.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 13 -- Selling of Netherlands 3 per cent dollar bonds has ended. At one time the price fell to 91 -- about 6 points below the price of corresponding guilder debentures -- but a slight rally now has lifted the price to 94.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears shook off the effects of three touchdown pitches by Frank Tripucka -- two of them in the last period -- to beat the Detroit Lions, 27 -- 24, in a National Football League aerial battle today.
Frank M. Rivera has moved his real estate office to 949 Columbus Avenue.

Plans for polling trade-mark owners and trade-mark bar associations on the kind of amendments to the Lanham Trade-Mark Act they wish to see presented to the next Congress were announced over the week-end by the United States Trade-Mark Association.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 13 -- The United States is seeking broad support in the United Nations General Assembly for a proposal asking the International Court of Justice to rule on the legality of South Africa's continued refusal to place the former mandated territory of Southwest Africa under international control, an authoritative source confirmed today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- Trading in soybeans on the Board of Trade was active last week, but general buying was discouraged by liberal deliveries, by the indifferent demand for oil and meal and by fairly liberal receipts.

GENEVA, Oct. 27 -- The problem of stateless persons will be as great as it was during the period 1918-1939, and probably greater, if and when all displaced persons uprooted by the recent war are re-established in new homes.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- The corn market had the limelight most of last week on the Board of Trade, with the oats futures also on the up grade, largely in sympathy with corn. All corn futures except the December made new highs for the season, and the December was the highest since last February. Oats registered new high seasonal marks for all deliveries.

HONG KONG, Nov. 13 -- The turn-over movement gained momentum here today with the announcement by local staff members of the National Resources Commission that the Hong Kong branch of the commission had gone over to the Communist regime.

Encouraged by the audience reaction, Brock Pemberton, producer of "Love Me Long," made a sudden decision over the week-end to prolong the run of the newly opened comedy at the Forty-eighth Street. The Doris Frankel play was supposed to have ended a week's engagement there Saturday night.

One of the busiest weeks in New York's art season starts off today with several one-man shows by well known artists. The sole museum opening of the week, on Wednesday at the Museum of Modern Art, is a design show, "For Modern Living."

A memorial service for 733 officers and men who died on the battlefields in two World Wars was held yesterday in St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street. The service was arranged by Seventh Regiment Post 107, American Legion.

The New York Rangers had to wait until the third period before scoring a goal against the Detroit Red Wings in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The tally, contrived by Don Raleigh, proved to be an important one, for it enabled the Blue Shirts to finish in a 1-to-1 tie with the league-leading Detroit outfit.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 13 -India's impending recognition of Israel is expected here to be the turning point in Israeli relations with Asiatic countries. The step that Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India forecast in London last week was expected to be a signal for a stream of recognitions, with Iran, Ceylon, Nepal and possibly Pakistan among the first to follow India.

Although its outward form has changed many times, the issue of "sound money" runs like a single continuous thread through the fabric of American history. That thread, if one traces it to its origin, will be found to run, indeed, all the way back to pre-Revolutionary times.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin expressed hope tonight that the results of the three-power Paris conference on Germany would be the "beginning of the ending of the age-long feud between the French and the Germans" and would bring unity and peace to Europe.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Several Swedish papers slapped back editorially today at Senator Elmer Thomas, Democrat, of Oklahoma, for his criticisms yesterday in Vienna of a Marshall Plan country that his colleagues indentified as Sweden.

The resignation of Maj. Gen. Frank McCoy as United States representative on the Far Eastern Commission brings to a close four years of hard work under often trying conditions. It was expected, of course, that when a person of General McCoy's talents and experience was put on the commission the United States would be most ably represented, and that has been the case.

A uniformity of poverty is being created across the vast Soviet-dominated areas of Eastern Europe and Asia. The Kremlin is milking the satellite states and demanding ever greater efforts from the long-suffering Russian people as it pushes forward a new series of five-year plans.

One hundred and fifty young men and women, volunteer members of the New York Catholic Charities Youth Counseling Service, were praised for their work in the city at a reception yesterday in St. Helena's Residence, Sisters of the Good Shepherd, 341 East Seventeenth Street.

CARLSTADT, N. J., Nov. 13 -Hundreds of square dancers and folk dancers from New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania, Connecticut and Massachusetts danced from noon until midnight at the second annual Garden State Country Dancers Association jamboree at Blome Hall here today.
Making educational history, the people of Connecticut are organizing into local committees to study their school needs and decide on the best way to improve their schools and colleges.

The Rev. Daniel A. Lord, preacher of the Society of Jesus, suggests this week in his column, "Along the Way," that a "pew poll" be undertaken by "some brave pastors" on the effectiveness of Roman Catholic preaching.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- The Rev. Dr. W. Harold Weigle announced this morning his resignation as rector of historic St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church, Eastchester, here. He has accepted an appointment from the Diocese of Albany as rector of the Church of Our Savior, Lebanon Springs, and also will serve as adviser to the Bishop on rural affairs.

MOSCOW, Nov. 13 (UP) -- Pravda and Izvestia, the two leading Communist newspapers, said today the Foreign Ministers of the United States, Britain and France had decided at their Paris meeting to turn West Germany into a base for attacking Russia.

Celebrating Children's Book Week, an exhibit of "Children's Books Suggested as Holiday Gifts" will open tomorrow in the Central Children's Room of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

More than 11,000 volunteer workers in the five boroughs of the city are serving in the 1949 campaign of the United Hospital Fund. This year the goal of the fund is $3,367,513 to help defray the 1948 costs of its eighty-six member hospitals in free or less-than-cost care given to 1,020,000 patients.

The 1949-50 season of the Metropolitan Opera Association will open next Monday night, Nov. 21, with the presentation of Richard Strauss' "Der Rosenkavalier." Heavy demand for boxes and orchestra seats was noted by the association, which has released the list of season boxholders.

HONG KONG, Nov. 13 -- American money guidance is making possible a province-wide program of land rent reduction in the tenantry ridden farm areas of Szechwan, the Nationalist province of which Chungking is the center.

In all the United States there are only five college football teams playing major schedules that remain undefeated as the season heads into the final week for most of the elevens in the East, the Middle West and the Pacific Coast.

New processes of metal casting now being perfected under a research contract with the Navy may eventually require preparedness planning of whole regions of America's industrial economy, to provide record-breaking output of war materials in any future war.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., announced here yesterday that it had asked the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company yesterday to borrow $20,000,000 on thirty-five-year sinking fund bonds at public bidding instead of by direct negotiation with insurance company investors.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- A tie-up of East Coast and Gulf shipping seems probable at midnight tomorrow, according to the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 14 -- Commander of the Syrian Army, Brig. Gen. Sami Hinnawi, issued orders again today to all officers to refrain from any kind of intervention in the elections tomorrow. He said he had been informed of reports that some officers had been using their influence in favor of friends.

Apparently no brass band was on the scene, no ticker tape was tossed from windows, no cheering thousands lined the streets and the key to the city had been mislaid when Senator Thomas of Oklahoma and his fellow-members of a Senate Appropriations Committee subcommittee recently arrived in Stockholm.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 14 (UP) -- The Communist Czechoslovak Government has confiscated the homes of several thousand middle-class business and professional men arrested here in a mass round-up last month, diplomatic quarters said today.

From the west bank of the Hudson to the east bank of the Delaware, from the hills at High Point to the sands of Cape May, the smoke of battle is clearing from New Jersey's electoral skies. Now the casualties are being counted, the forces regrouped, the post-mortems held; and plans laid for the next round.

Prosecution and defense in the forthcoming second perjury trial of Alger Hiss broke about even yesterday in pre-trial skirmishes in which the defense, over strong Government objections, is seeking to examine Government-held evidence.

The American Federation of Labor will sponsor a five-times-a-week radio series of news commentary over WOR and the Mutual Broadcasting System beginning Jan. 2. With Frank Edwards as the commentator, the program will be broadcast Mondays through Fridays from 10 to 10:15 P. M.

The dispatch from Moscow on the celebration of the Thirty-second Anniversary of the Soviet Revolution speaks of "one million men, women and children" who paraded through Red Square, behind a procession of Soviet fighting units.
This is the 196th and last day of the New York racing season. Jamaica's children have just eight more races in which to try to get even.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Speculation on early steps toward conclusion of a peace treaty with Japan was discouraged today by the Foreign Office. China seemed to be taking precedence over Japan because the Western powers must first decide whether the Chinese Communist regime is to be recognized and therefore invited to participate in making a treaty with Japan.

BOSTON, Nov. 14 -- Six major cities were mentioned today by Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, as having slum conditions that "should cause real indignation."

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Harry Reeves, Detroit policeman, and Charles Logie of East Grand Rapids, Mich., were the main winners as the International Shooting Union passed out medals yesterday for high finishes in the recent world championship competition.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Nov. 14 -- Ruby Thaw and Hla Sein, the two Burmese student nurses at the Margaret Hague Maternity Hospital here, who face possible deportation, will receive aid from Mayor John V. Kenny in their efforts to remain in this country, it was indicated today at City Hall.

Five clergymen representing the International Council of Christian Churches left New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, at 4:15 P. M. yesterday on a Pan American World Airways plane, en route to Bangkok, Thailand, "to oppose efforts of the World Council of Churches to dominate the Christian Churches of Southeast Asia."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- President Truman will not sit back and wait for the country's coal miners to go on strike again Dec. 1 when the three - week, union - declared truce ends.
LONDON, Nov. 14 (Reuters) -- The resolution passed by the Central Committee of the Polish Workers party, as reported by the Warsaw radio today, said:

The commerce and industry committee of the 1949 drive of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York reported yesterday at a luncheon meeting that it had received contributions of $10,000. The meeting was held in the dining hall of the building of THE NEW YORK TIMES at 229 West Forty-third Street, with Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger, committee chairman and vice president of the council, in the chair.

The visit of Secretary of State Acheson to Germany and his conference last week with Mr. Bevin and M. Schuman are proving more important than was realized. Such developments have a crystallizing effect if only because they bring problems out into the open and make it necessary to take action.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 14 -- The sixth annual all-industry refrigeration and air-conditioning exposition opened here today in Convention Hall with more than $5,000,000 worth of new and improved units, equipment and parts on display.

The demotion of two Fordham regulars by Coach Ed Danowski yesterday resulted in changes at four positions in the Rams' two platoons as drills for Saturday's contest with Rutgers at New Brunswick got under way with a heavy scrimmage.

Although northbound air traffic between South America and the United States is falling off, largely because of currency problems, Pan American-Grace Airways (Panagra) expects an over-all 15 to 20 per cent volume increase in the next three years, Andrew B. Shea, who became president last July, said yesterday.

BERLIN, Nov. 14 -- Russian interference with the freedom and liberty of nations outside the Soviet bloc must be met where it occurs, Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared today. The senior member of the Cabinet of the United States flew to Berlin through fog and rain this morning to bring to the people of the city's Western sectors a message of hope and encouragement for "the continuing struggle" in Germany.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Because farm prices were lower, total personal income of Americans dipped in September despite the first appreciable gain in factory payrolls this year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Irving Potash, one of the eleven Communist party leaders convicted in New York recently, lost a battle today to bypass a Court of Appeals and have deportation proceedings against him discussed by the Supreme Court at once.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- John L. Lewis' mine workers welfare and retirement fund announced tonight a "drastic reduction" in its administrative staff, effective immediately.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 14 -- Following are excerpts from speeches today in the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee by Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister; Warren R. Austin, permanent United States delegate, and Jean Chauvel, French delegate:

In an effort to pierce the fog of Soviet propaganda, the United States and Britain submitted yesterday to the United Nations a twelve-point resolution outlining their idea of the essential conditions for the preservation of peace and security. This resolution is their answer to a Soviet resolution accusing them of plotting aggressive war and presenting the Soviet idea of "strengthening the peace."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Secretary of the Treasury announced tonight that it had accepted bids for $1,000,580,000 of ninety-one-day Treasury bills to be dated Nov. 17, 1949, and to mature on Feb. 16, 1950.

Although the precious diamond and pearl outlast any fashion, their settings change with the mode of the day, keeping in step with both dress and hair styling. It Was Cartier that brought a new style note to the attention of the press at a preview of an exhibit held last evening in the shop at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-second Street.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, N. Y., Nov. 14 -- Ferdie Catropa of Peninsula and Joe Katz, Cold Spring Country Club, carded a 34, 31 -- 65 to win the Long Island Professional Golfers' Association one-day pro-amateur golf tournament at the Rockville Country Club today.

The forthcoming visit of the Shah of Persia to the United States is a historic event of more than ordinary proportions. Save for the informal trip of the King of Siam, this is the first time that an Oriental monarch has set foot in the New World.

Mrs. Jennie Winchell, 77-year-old mother of Walter Winchell, jumped or fell to her death at 5:45 P. M. yesterday from the tenth floor of Doctors Hospital, East End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, where she had been a patient since Oct. 25.

A new study that provides a yardstick for men's wear retailers in checking performance figures with the aim of improving newspaper advertising investments was announced yesterday by the retail division of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- An Egyptian purchasing mission that recently visited Britain placed a substantial order for jet fighter planes of the latest and swiftest model. This contract will be formally announced tomorrow by the De Haviland Aircraft Company, Ltd., which accepted it with the approval of the British Government.

TRENTON, N. J., Nov. 14 -- Five New Jersey Democratic leaders from communities outside Hudson opened a state headquarters in Trenton today and invited all party supporters to join them in building a new Democratic organization.
By an overwhelming voice vote, 500 high school editors agreed yesterday that there is no freedom of the press for student newspapers in city schools.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that he was planning a series of radio broadcasts, starting in January, to report directly to the people on matters affecting city government. He made it clear that he still was bitter against most of the city's newspapers, because of what he considered their unfair treatment of him in the recent campaign.

The double-header idea, which won popularity in professional circles elsewhere last year, will be reintroduced at Madison Square Garden tonight. A National Basketball Association twin bill there will send the Washington Capitols against the Chicago Stags in the 7:30 opener, after which the New York Knickerbockers will be host to the Syracuse Nationals. Some 14,00 fans are expected.

Schenley Industries, Inc., in its fiscal year ended Aug. 31, last, increased sales to $461,852,504 from $459,783,948 the year before, according to the annual report issued yesterday by Lewis S. Rosenstiel, chairman and president.

The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it will receive bids on Nov. 22 on an issue of $31,935,000 of temporary loan notes for the financing of three state-aided low-rent housing projects. The notes will be dated Dec. 15, 1949 and

Joseph Martin and Neal Patterson, reporters for The New York Daily News, and William Wallace, News photographer, received the annual award of the Society of the Silurians last night for distinguished editorial achievement in 1949.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Capt. Erick Rios Bridoux, Bolivian air ace, had no right to be flying the P-38 fighter plane that collided with an Eastern Air Lines DC-4, killing fifty-five persons, a Civil Aeronautics Board official asserted today.
Coffee futures dropped sharply yesterday in the early trading, with some positions falling as much as 200 points, the limit set by the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

While the railroads in the East are pleased that the Interstate Commerce Commission has granted their request of last June for a 12 1/2 per cent increase in passenger rates, some of their executives fear that the increase will not result in as great a gain in revenues as originally was anticipated.

There are approximately a thousand employes at the French Ministry of the Interior, which is situated on Rue Faubourg St. Honore, Paris. One morning a few weeks ago Jules Moch, as Interior Minister, arrived at the Ministry at 9 A. M. and ordered shut the gate that closes the Ministry's courtyard to the street.

A civil suit to prevent the merger of the Congregational Christian Churches with the Evangelical and Reformed Church was brought to trial yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court before Justice Meier Steinbrink.

I read with genuine approval, in your issue of Nov. 8, the letter of my old friend and teacher at Fordham University School of Law, Professor I. Maurice Wormser, on the admission to bail of the eleven convicted Communists tried before Judge Harold R. Medina. I agree with the professor's views in wondering why the prosecution conceded that a "substantial question" was involved in the appeal of these defendants.

The Treasury's relationship to the money market will reach a "crucial point" in the two-year period beginning next year, when $44,000,000,000 of marketable bank-eligible bonds come up for refunding, Aubrey G. Lanston Co., Inc., specialists in Government securities, declared yesterday in a special study of the market for Government bonds.
Nine Swiss tourist association executives arrived here yesterday on the first leg of a two-month tour of the United States to study American methods of dealing with tourists.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 14 -- Boll weevil infestation and excessive rainfall have blighted Southern cotton farms this year to the extent that in recent days some districts have been designated as "disaster areas" eligible for emergency loans from the Federal Government.

LONDON, Nov. l4 -- The British Government began a national recruiting drive today for its new volunteer civil defense organization. The drive was announced here by Chuter Ede, Home Secretary, who emphasized that "this does not mean war is likely."

ROME, Nov. 14 -- Pope Pius yesterday termed the totalitarian anti-Christian state a tyranny and predicted that the leaders of Communist Governments eventually would end their lives as did those of Nazi Germany, many of whom were sentenced to capital punishment at the Nuremberg trials.

Judith Coplon and Valentin A. Gubitchev sat yesterday at far ends of a defense table in the Federal Court House at Foley Square as Judge Sylvester Ryan began hearing pre-trial testimony on the former Government employe's attempt to be freed of the necessity of standing trial with the Russian engineer for conspiracy and espionage.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 14 -- The Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation signed a contract tonight with the CIO United Steelworkers ending a strike which began Nov. 1.

Ponderous motor vehicles built for arduous tasks on rugged roads made their debut against backgrounds of delicate plush and shimmery silks at a special showing of the G. M. C. truck and coach division of General Motors at the Essex House yesterday.

Election of Justice Justine Wise Polier of Domestic Relations Court as president of the Women's Division of the American Jewish Congress was voted yesterday afternoon at the closing session of its three-day biennial convention in the New Yorker Hotel.

Dr. Kenneth Holland, United States Counselor on United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization affairs at Paris, was elected president of the Institute of International Education at the annual meeting of the board of trustees last night at the Biltmore Hotel.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 14 -- A Canadian-French plan, backed by the United States, to have the big powers and Canada continue their private talks in an attempt to break the four-year deadlock on an international atomic control plan was overwhelmingly approved today in the Special Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Charging that the Israeli Government was not cooperating with the United Nations Conciliation Commission in its efforts to solve the Palestine problem, the representatives of seven Arab states asked the United States today to join them in calling on the Tel Aviv Government to do so.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission by a 6-to-4 decision granted Eastern railroads today their third post-war increase, 12.5 per cent, in passenger fares. The action brings coach fares to about 3.375 cents a mile and parlor and sleeping-car fares to 4.5 cents a mile.

The story of an altruistic retired school teacher who, despite poor health, has toured the nation since 1947 in an effort to promote the American merchant marine was unfolded yesterday when the envoy of good-will announced plans for another trip.

A 16-year-old boy who had spent four years behind the barbed wire of German and Italian concentration camps, used the Voice of America yesterday to explain to the people of France what living in a democracy has come to mean to him.

ROYALTON, Ill., Nov. 14 -- Nearly 500 United Mine Workers in this southern Illinois coal town struck today. They objected because they were not getting first choice of coal to fill their own home bins, the president of the local said.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 14 -- A formula for adapting wage rates to rising productivity, believed to contribute greatly to stability, was proposed today by John C. Davis and Thomas K. Hitch, Government economists.
ATHENS, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Two United States Senators today attacked Sweden for her alleged ignoring of a Senate subcommittee now touring Europe on a fact-finding mission.

The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation, operator of the Big Inch and Little Big Inch pipe line system, announced yesterday that it had filed with the Federal Power Commission in Washington an application for permission to construct additional pipe lines for transmission of natural gas into the New England area.

Six years ago it occurred to the Rev. A. Ritchie Low, pastor of the Federated Church of Johnson, Vt., that children in Harlem needed country vacations and that church people in Vermont could see to it that some of them had them. The plan worked well and led to friendships between the children's parents and the Vermont sponsors. Now a group of Vermonters make an annual pilgrimage to Harlem.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 14 -- The Screen Actors Guild took one more step last night toward an open breach with the other entertainment unions of the American Federation of Labor over television acting jurisdiction at a meeting attended by 1,500 members of the guild.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Banthine, a new, synthetic, nerve-control drug, is healing bad peptic ulcers. The results were exhibited for the first time to the Southern Medical Association, which began a four-day annual meeting today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 14 -- The United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission formally replied today to widespread criticism both here and abroad of its draft statute for the internationalization of Jerusalem.

The two-platoon system in football, which, it appears, has developed into a controversy between the "haves" and the "have-nots," was the principal topic of discussion at the weekly luncheon-meeting of the Football Writers Association at Toots Shor's yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Prince Charles, second in the line of succession to the throne of Great Britain, was one year old today. As birthday greetings arrived from all parts of the world, the event was celebrated with a little tea party given by his mother, Princess Elizabeth, in the Prince's nursery at their home, Clarence House.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 14 -- The United States and Britain replied today to the Soviet proposal for a Big Five non-aggression pact by introducing a resolution calling on all members of the United Nations to cooperate in settling outstanding problems, including the regulation of armaments and international atomic control.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- It is apparent that the Soviet Union, in an effort to accelerate the accomplishment of its new East European policy based on the integration of the East German "democratic" Government with those of the other satellite states, is applying a new-squeeze on Poland.

Verdicts of guilty were returned in Federal Court yesterday against three men charged with possession and sale of $10,000 of counterfeit $10 and $20 bills. The jury returned a verdict about an hour after it had been charged by Judge Sylvester J. Ryan.

DETROIT, Nov. 14 -- What happens in Western Europe in the next five years may determine what happens in the United Status in the next five decades, Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, declared here today in an address to the Detroit Economic Club in the Hotel Book-Cadillac.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 14 -- Nassau County's tax rate for 1950 will remain the same as it has been for the last seven years, it was indicated in the proposed budget filed with the County Board of Supervisors here today by County Executive J. Russel Sprague.
Firm to higher prices on new-season mink are expected as the new season opens, it was reported in the trade here yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 14 -- Following is the text of a resolution on the "essentials of peace," introduced today in the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee by the United States and the United Kingdom:

HONG KONG, Nov. 14 -- Gen. Shen Teh-hsueh and Col. Tai Ankuo were appointed here today as new managing directors of the China National Aviation Corporation and Central Air Transport Corporation. The appointments were announced by the Nationalist Minister of Communications, Tuanmu No-chieh, who said at the same time that the former managing directors, who flew to Peiping last week with twelve planes of the two airlines, had been dismissed.

An audience of thousands attended the farewell New York recital of Efrem Zimbalist last night in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Zimbalist played first familiar classics -- the Beethoven C minor violin and piano sonata, and the G major romanza.

The annual meeting of the Metropolitan section of the P. G. A. was held at the Park Sheraton Hotel last night to discuss resolutions to be presented to the P. G. A. convention at Pinehurst on Nov. 28. Also on the agenda was the election of two delegates to represent the local group.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UP) -- Research balloons soaring 110,000 feet (20 miles) in the stratosphere above northern Canada have collected new cosmic ray data that may force scientists to revise their theories about the sun, the National Geographic Society reported today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14 -- Two women and four men were tentatively accepted as jurors today as the perjury and conspiracy trial of Harry R. Bridges and two labor union colleagues opened before Federal Judge George B. Harris.

BUFFALO, Nov. 14 -- In order to help juvenile delinquents, workers in the correctional field do not have to be "junior psychiatrists," Dr. Walter C. Reckless of the School of Social Service Administration, Ohio State University, declared today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Red Cross Board of Governors today reaffirmed its policy of not joining with other organizations in fund-raising; but permitting, with safeguards, a single solicitation in industrial plants where the employer permitted only one canvass a year.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Sharp rises in British Government securities were recorded in the stock markets here today as "bears," caught by Friday's upswing, sought to buy back early. When "bear" coverings were satisfied prices fell, although most issues closed a quarter point to 1 1/2 points higher than on Friday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- The expanding Federal Government is "fast creating a load that may well break our financial back and impair the moral fiber of the American people," Cloud Wampler, president of the Carrier Corporation said here today.

Police Commissioner William P. O'Brien said yesterday that District Attorney Frank Hogan's office has investigated the shooting of Heminion Miranda in East Harlem last Thursday and had found no reason for criminal action against Patrolman Samuel Rubenfeld, who fired the shot.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 14 -- A nice blend of furnishings and decorations for the eighteenth century decor, heavily accented by the simple and "primitive" types, made the opening here today of the twenty-ninth Eastern States Antiques Fair a happy hunting ground for fanciers of antiques.
PARIS, Nov. 14 -- The Cabinet is expected to give its approval tomorrow to a record - breaking budget that will require higher taxes and loans to help bring it into balance.

Likening the structure of the American standards of living to that of a cake, former President Herbert C. Hoover, last night praised the advertising profession for creating the top layers. He spoke at a dinner marking the unveiling and dedication ceremonies of the Advertising Hall of Fame at the Advertising Club of New York, where he received the club's Plaque of Achievement.

The first official figures on this fiscal year show the New York City transit system with an operating loss of $1,324,614 for one month, July, 1949. Since it is informally reported that any later improvement that has occurred does not remove the threat of an operating deficit for the fiscal year, we believe a time has come to reconsider the whole fare structure.

ALBANY, Nov. 14 -- Governor Dewey announced today the appointment of George Sylvester, of New York City, to a nine-year term as a judge of the State Court of Claims. The salary for the office is $15,000 a year.

Although Brad Rowland failed to pick up a point for Little McMurry College of Abilene, Tex., in Friday's 27-6 victory over Howard Payne, the hustling halfback remains the top individual scorer of college football.

" The Fallen Idol," British-made drama starring Sir Ralph Richardson, Michele Morgan and the child actor, Bobby Henrey, and produced and directed by Carol Reed, will have its local premiere today at the Sutton Theatre. Graham Greene wrote the screen play, with additional dialogue supplied by Lesley Storm and William Templeton.

The stock market received yesterday the severest setback in about a month under successive, though moderate, waves of profit-taking. Losses ranged from fractions to 3 points, with chemicals, motors and golds the softest. Activity in low-price stocks accounted for an increase in volume on the Stock Exchange to 1,250,000 shares, against 1,170,000 on last Friday, while the composite rate sagged 1.32 points.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The American Gas and Electric Company of New York received permission today from the Securities and Exchange Commission to make cash advances from time to time to its subsidiary, the Appalachian Electric Power Company of Roanoke, Va., so long as the total does not exceed $15,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Russia shipped the United States an increased trickle of manganese and chrome -- vital war materials -- and a lot more fur in September, the Census Bureau reported today.

ROME, Nov. 14 -- Widespread unauthorized occupations of untilled estates by landless peasants took place in Sicily yesterday. Many thousands of peasants participated in the seizures, accompanied by their wives, children and oxen. They carried their tools and in many cases started plowing as soon as they had taken possession.

The real exodus is now on, for the Catskill deer season opens this morning, and last night found hundreds of hunters sleeping in cars, barns, tents and other shelters throughout most of the counties included in the zone.

Another solution of the ills of the modern world is offered in a new book by Benjamin A. Javits author of books on our domestic economy and its effect on international affairs. "Peace by Investment," which Funk Wagnalls will publish in January, presents a program to insure our peace and prosperity by investing in or lending to those countries who wish to stay out of the Soviet bloc.

HONG KONG, Nov. 14 (UP) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek returned to the mainland today in an attempt to stall off collapse of the Government as the Communist armies split Nationalist China into two parts and drove on Chungking.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Robert Bready, chairman of the Baltimore Slum Clearance Committee said any city could clean up its slums in fifteen years by adopting the Baltimore plan.

M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., textile manufacturer, reported yesterday improvement in sales for the September quarter over the 1948 period. Leon Lowenstein, board chairman, noted that the number of units sold in each quarter of 1949 exceeded those in the 1948 quarters.

ALBANY, Nov. 14 -- Attorneys for the Federal Government told the Court of Appeals today that New York City's Sharkey Rent Law was invalid, and that it was in "head-on collision" with the major provisions of the Federal Rent Law.

Mrs. John T. Lawless of Greenwich was re-elected president of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield County Golf Association at the annual meeting at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday. Other officers and the board of directors also were renamed with the exception of the secretary, Mrs. Leo Dwyer of Siwanoy replacing Mrs. William B. Miller of Greenwich.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Several changes in baseball rules will be up for acceptance or rejection here Wednesday at a meeting of organized baseball's rules committee.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 14 -- Peter W. Brown, 20-year-old junior at Princeton University, died early this morning in his room at Henry Hall, on the campus. His death was caused by a wound in the head, which the police said was self-inflicted. A target pistol was found near the body.
BOMBAY, India, Nov. 14 -- An audience of 500,000 today heard Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru speak two hours after his return from his tour of the United States, Canada and Britain.

The Department of Public Works has declined to make formal submission of its plans for reconstruction of the Brooklyn Bridge to the Art Commission and has been upheld in the refusal by Corporation Counsel John P. McGrath, it was learned yesterday.

Intercollegiate football puts on its last full program of the season this week and by Saturday night the champions of the Southern, Big Nine and the Pacific Coast Conferences will be established, as well as the teams in line for the Rose Bowl.

The awarding of a fellowship to Gudger Bart Leiper of Signal Mountain, Tenn., by the Eugene F. Saxton Memorial Trust was announced yesterday by Harper Bros. Mr. Leiper, a graduate of the University of Chattanooga, did graduate work at the University of Minnesota, where he was a member of Robert Penn Warren's seminar in writing.

The report that Steve Owen, coach of the New York Football Giants since 1931, will resign at the conclusion of the current season and move into a front-office job was denied yesterday by the club's publicity director, Bill Abbott.
LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Despite a continuing leakage and depreciation of the pound sterling abroad below the offcial rate of $2.80, the British Government is not worried, a Treasury official said today.

John Langstaff, young American baritone, gave a recital at Times Hall last night in which a strong and sound musical instinct triumphed over an undependable vocal method. His taste, intelligence and feeling for music of various schools were fine enough to make him worth listening to, even if the way he produced his voice made for inconsistency of sound.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:Referring to your editorial, "Colombia in Travail," your statements that there are possibilities of disturbances throughout the inter-American world but that there is little or nothing outsiders can do for them, I wish to inform you I cabled Nov. 8 the Organization of American States in Washington suggesting that they offer Colombian parties the mediation of the Inter-American Peace Commission as a contribution to pacification of the country.
LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Britain's Socialist Cabinet met today and decided, according to well-authenticated reports, to make haste slowly in nationalizing the steel industry.

An attempt to rob the home of former Representative Bruce Barton at 117 East Fifty-fifth Street was balked yesterday by the family cook, who ran screaming from the kitchen after two intruders had mauled her. One was captured after a three-block chase by Patrolman Michael Wasko.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- In a step rarely taken Louisiana today begged the Supreme Court to grant a jury trial in case the highest tribunal refused to dismiss the Federal Government's underwater oil-lands case.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and prices at the close were 6 to 13 points net lower than on Saturday.
BOSTON, Nov. (AP) -- Business at Boston's $60,000,000 Logan Airport broke all records during the first three-quarters of 1949, the State Airport Management Board said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Dividing 5 to 3, the Supreme Court sustained today an Interstate Commerce Commission order prescribing joint bus fares between the District of Columbia and points in Arlington County, Va., including the Pentagon and National Airport.

ONCE upon a time Stout Steve Owen was known far and wide as a "defensive coach." His Giants would force the breaks, kick a couple of field goals and defy the opposition to score on them. But now the Giants yield touchdowns by the gross and win -- when they do -- by piling up more points than the opposition in free-scoring, wild-and-wooly thrillers.
The Stonehill Construction Company has purchased 108 lots in Rego Park, Queens, from Shampan Shampan, architects. Advance Realty Company was the broker. Goodman Mabel were attorneys for the sellers.

Th especialty division of General Electric Company's electronics department yesterday introduced three television alignment units at a total cost of $1,054. The units featured opening of the department's week-long demonstration of new industrial electronic laboratory and testing instruments in offices and showrooms of its metropolitan area distributor, Sun Radio and Electronics Company, Inc., 124 Duane Street.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Manchac and Laran crossed the wire on even terms and the judges ruled a dead heat in the featured $3,500 Omar Khayyam Purse at a mile and a sixteenth as Pimlico's four final racing days opened this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Sweden was granted $410,000 in new Marshall Plan aid today. The Economic Cooperation Administration earmarked the additional sum for Sweden among $8,328,000 of recovery grants announced for seven European countries.
WALHALLA, S. C., Nov. 14 (AP) -- An aroused public spurred police today in a search for two white slayers of a respected Negro farmer.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov. 14 (AP) -- A revolt against Commissioner Abe J. Greene of the National Boxing Association faded today and Greene received a unanimous vote of confidence.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Nov. 14 -- The West German Government officially and the German press generally hailed today the visit of Secretary of State Dean Acheson and the decisions of the tripartite conference as the turning point in post-war German history.

TOKYO, Nov. 14 -- Informed Japanese today are expressing some anxiety over the re-election of Elpidio Quirino as President of the Philippines. Fears are expressed that this means the maintenance, even the intensification, of a "tough" policy by the Philippines toward Japan to which the United States might be compelled to give some measure of consideration.

Failure of retailers to show adequate stocks of fall merchandise when most needed indicates the lack of planning among both retailers and manufacturers in working out efficient production and delivery schedules, according to Jay D. Runkle, vice president and general manager of Crowley, Milner Co., Detroit.

WHEN Monica Martin was 20 years old she sailed for India with her restless, impetuous young husband and her 9-month-old daughter. That was in 1923. Mrs. Martin stayed in India for the next sixteen years with only a few trips home to England and no annual leaves in the Himalayan hills during the hot season.

More than 200 persons who in 1948 would have had to undergo serious operations requiring several weeks of hospitalization have been cured of thyroid conditions by treatments as simple as drinking water.

HONOLULU, Nov. 14 -- Hawaii's determined campaign to become a state gained new and official impetus today as the Territorial Governor, Ingram M. Stainback, signed a proclamation calling an election to name delegates to a constitutional convention.

The Police Athletic League has lined up an attractive program of fall and winter activities that should have a wide appeal for boys and girls throughout the city. The program, which has room for 100,000 youngsters, will be carried out in seventy-five P. A. L. youth centers in scattered neighborhoods and in indoor and outdoor recreational facilities, including parks and armories.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 3 per cent last week compared with the corresponding week last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The drop for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 8 per cent.

A new era, one that augurs well for harmony between the vast utility industry in this state and the Public Service Commission, was ushered in yesterday afternoon by Benjamin F. Feinberg, chairman of the state regulatory body.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 14 -- The Soviet-controlled Danube River Commission has taken the first steps to eliminate Yugoslavia, one of the principal Danubian states, from direct participation in the management of Europe's greatest international waterway, according to reports published here today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 14 -- A ceremony will be held in Port Rjeka (formerly Flume) next Wednesday in honor of the late Fiorello H. La Guardia, who served as United States Vice Counsel in that Adriatic port more than forty years ago.

Tremendous progress made by business during the first half of this century in mass producing and marketing must be supplemented by a "third front" of public understanding in the last half of the century, Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Belated tidings from Pennsylvania to this department indicate that more bad news than the loss to the Democrats of the fiscal offices in Philadelphia's city hall came to the Republicans of that state on election day, Nov. 8, 1949. Either a water-tight alibi must be forthcoming, or the political portents in the great Keystone State cast an ominous shadow for the Republicans in 1950.
About 20 per cent of the reforms recommended in the Hoover Report have been adopted at a saving of more than a billion dollars a year, the Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- Grain markets failed to develop a definite trend on the Board of Trade here today. Trade was largely of a professional character and the markets fluctuated in an irregular manner. Wheat finished at about the low of the day, with losses of 1/2 to 7/8 cent a bushel, while corn was firm and unchanged to 1/4 cent higher than on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. l4 -- The International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, today filed a petition with the National Labor Relations Board requesting an election to determine the legal collective bargaining unit in all plants of the General Electric, General Motors, Westinghouse and five other companies.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- A State Department spokesman said today that there was no foundation to Soviet charges that the United States was acquiring air bases in Spain.

The formation of The Lambs' Workshop, a medium through which younger members of the noted theatrical organization can practice their arts, was described yesterday by Bert Lytell, shepherd of the Lambs. Under the guidance of Mr. Lytell and other veteran members, some of the less experienced Lambs are training in drama, music, choreography and other theatre fields.
CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- The Chicago Corporation announced today the purchase of the refining and pipeline facilities of Atlas Oil and Refining Corporation, Shreveport, La. The price was not disclosed.

Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, president of the United Nations General Assembly, praised Mayor O'Dwyer and his Advisory Committee on Atomic Energy yesterday for helping to educate people concerning the peaceful uses to which atomic energy can be put.

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- To reassure the French pending publication of the decisions of the Foreign Ministers of Britain, France and the United States in Paris last week, Foreign Minister Robert Schuman declared today that there had never been any question of rearming Western Germany or of admitting her into the North Atlantic defense pact.
MANCHESTER, England, Nov. 14 (UP) -- English soccer professionals today adopted a "closed shop policy" and threatened to refuse to play with men who are not members of the players' union.
SALEM, N. H., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Edward Siravo's Assassinator won the Dublin Allowance for 2-year-olds, feature of the all-claiming program at Rockingham Park today.

More and more parents are accepting the mental hygiene approach to the problems of family living, Mrs. Jean Schick Grossman said yesterday, but "strong pendulum swings" of opinion still confuse their thinking on certain phases of the topic.

Plans for making the youth of Brooklyn "bait" for a bigger adult attendance aboard the New York State Freedom Train were discussed yesterday at a meeting in the Brooklyn Public Library, which will serve as a clearing point for arranging group trips to the train.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 14 -- They Pakistan jute industry in eastern Bengal, where 70 per cent of the world's output is produced, is encountering an exceptionally dull market in a critical period, according to a report to the Government of India by an official observer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- President Truman became the nation's Number 1 "Quiz Whiz" today by the unanimous vote of national officers of the League of Women Voters after he had answered satisfactorily a series of questions put to him about voting laws in his home State of Missouri.
The Sanitation Department, experimenting with new street-sweeping techniques, has just begun testing its own version of the household vacuum cleaner.

The New York City Young Men's Christian Association will undertake to raise $432,789 during 1950, it was announced last night at the organization's ninety-seventh annual dinner at the Roosevelt Hotel.

Six craftsmen with the combined skills of first-rate potters and artists have created a group of non-commercial one-of-a-kind ceramics at pleasantly commercial prices. A collection of their work is being shown at the Bertha Schaefer Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14 -- The raising of $9,443,186 in the last twelve months for the work of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, was reported today to its annual convention by Mrs. Abraham Tulin of New York, national treasurer.
A 61-year-old Swedish-American butler was flying to Stockholm yesterday minus $350 to $400 that a stranger in midtown Manhattan had snatched from the butler's hands while he was counting the money.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, who still is being mentioned as a potential candidate for President or for Governor of New York, has declined to designate his political party affiliation, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- President Truman became the nation's Number 1 "Quiz Whiz" today by the unanimous vote of national officers of the League of Women Voters after he had answered satisfactorily a series of questions put to him about voting laws in his home State of Missouri.
The Sanitation Department, experimenting with new street-sweeping techniques, has just begun testing its own version of the household vacuum cleaner.

The New York City Young Men's Christian Association will undertake to raise $432,789 during 1950, it was announced last night at the organization's ninety-seventh annual dinner at the Roosevelt Hotel.

Hortense Monath, whose New York appearances recently have been with orchestras or chamber-music groups, returned to Town Hall last night to give her first local recital since January, 1947. Perhaps an evening of music would be a better phrase for it than a recital.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 14 -- A proposed 1950 Westchester gross budget of $27,563,066, representing an increase of $1,955,330 over this year's, was submitted to the Board of Supervisors this afternoon by County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14 -- The raising of $9,443,186 in the last twelve months for the work of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, was reported today to its annual convention by Mrs. Abraham Tulin of New York, national treasurer.
A 61-year-old Swedish-American butler was flying to Stockholm yesterday minus $350 to $400 that a stranger in midtown Manhattan had snatched from the butler's hands while he was counting the money.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, who still is being mentioned as a potential candidate for President or for Governor of New York, has declined to designate his political party affiliation, it was disclosed yesterday.

Despite an authorization from the Interstate Commerce Commission to resume full service, announced in Washington yesterday, many railroads plan only a limited restoration until the future of their coal supplies is determined, it was indicated in New York.

Despite the reduced sales and earnings reported yesterday by the B. F. Goodrich Company for the first nine months of 1949, compared with those of the previous year, directors yesterday voted a special dividend of $1.50 to be distributed to common stockholders on Dec. 31 in addition to a quarterly payment of $1 a share.

The K. A. B. Homes Corporation, of which Sam Auster is president, has purchased twenty-six lots in Jamaica, Queens, from Hermine and Bertha Weber, executrixes of the estate of Charles Weber, and plan to improve them with thirteen bungalows.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, Nov. 16 -- The Soviet-controlled North Korean radio yesterday for the first time confirmed the presence in North Korea of two kidnapped United States employes of the Economic Cooperation Administration. They were aboard the Korean merchant ship Kimball Smith when she was taken at sea by North Korean Communists on Sept. 21.

The stock market sank yesterday to the lowest mark in about three weeks in a continuation of profit taking in issues that recently have been strong. It was the second set-back for the list this week and produced a loss of 0.76 point in the composite rate although inroads of much larger proportions studded the major sections.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 15 -- Mrs. Maria Augusta Trapp of Stowe, Vt., principal contralto of the Trapp Family Singers, received here today from the Most Rev. Edward Ryan, Roman Catholic Bishop of Burlington, the Benemerenti Medal, a pontifical decoration for "distinguished service," conferred by Pope Pius XII.

The premiere performance of the Metropolitan Opera's new season, plus all the activities which are traditionally a part of opening night, will be televised next Monday evening by the American Broadcasting Company, beginning at 7:45 o'clock. The opera to be presented is "Der Rosenkavalier," with the principal roles being filled by Eleanor Steber, Rise Stevens, Erna Berger and Emanuel List.

The three largest food chains will continue to lose business to the regional and small food stores, Lansing P. Shield, president of the Grand Union Company, predicted yesterday at the annual convention of the Grocery Manufacturers of America in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Five leading New York decorators have designed room settings showing the different applications possible for lace net curtains in contemporary homes.

August Strindberg, a confirmed misogynist, gave vent to his feelings against the so-called weaker sex in his play, "The Father," which is to be revived this evening at the Cort. It tells how an intelligent man allows himself to go to pieces by the machinations of a calculating wife.

The tenth anniversary dinner of the Motion Picture Pioneers, an organization composed of persons actively associated with the film industry for twenty-five years, will be held tonight at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Highlight of the evening will be the presentation of an award to Cecil B. De Mille as the "pioneer of the year" in recognition of his thirty-eight years of "pioneering service to the motion - picture industry."
CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Two Montreal Canadien players today were exonerated of charges they used their hockey sticks as "deadly weapons" in a melee with four fans at Chicago Stadium Nov. 2.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- A committee of preference shareholders in Central-Illinois Securities Corporation has decided to abandon its pending suit in the United States District Court in Wilmington, Del., asking that the investment concern be liquidated or reorganized, it was learned today.

ROME, Nov. 15--The Cabinet Council this morning approved the bill for redistributing land in those parts of Calabria where the problem of landless peasants is particularly acute. The bill will be submited to Parliament immediately.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Right Rev. Msgr. James H. Griffiths, Chancellor of the Military Ordinariate, which embraces all Roman Catholics in the armed services, has been named Titular Bishop of Gaza and Auxiliary to Francis Cardinal Spellman of New York in his capacity as military vicar.

Heeding protests from West Coast college athletic directors that televising of football games reduces attendance, the Radio Manufacturers Association yesterday set up a special committee to cooperate with the National Association of Broadcasters and the Television Broadcasters Association in arriving at "a policy which will be satisfactory to all interests."
A nation-wide program of "preventive" law, administered through a system of lawyer reference plans, will be set in operation soon by the American Bar Association, it was announced yesterday.

HANOVER, N. H., Nov. 15 -- The Dartmouth College Interfraternity Council announced today that it had urged twelve Northeastern colleges and universities to support "a real step" at the meetings of the National Interfraternity Conference Nov. 24 in Washington, to eliminate restrictive clauses in college fraternity charters which bar membership on the basis of race or religion.
HONG KONG, Nov. 15 -- Acting President Li Tsung-jen so far has not responded to a call by Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek to fly to Chungking for a conference.

Breaking of the log jam in international trade will require the imaginative and informed thinking of business men on both sides of the Atlantic, H. J. Heinz 2d, president of the H. J. Heinz Company, and chairman of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce, said here yesterday.
TRENTON, N. J., Nov. 15 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll looked ahead today to his new four-year term and saw economy before new taxes and labor-management peace as problems demanding prompt attention.
Trading in rubber futures was easy yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. Prices closed 16 to 23 points off, reflecting declines in both the London and Singapore markets.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 15 -- The Soviet Government has followed up the elimination of the Yugoslavs from participation in direct management of the newly constituted Danube Commission by emasculating the commission itself.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15 -- In answer to repeated pleas, the City Council today unanimously voted the financially harassed Philadelphia Orchestra a grant of $100,000 for 1950.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 15 -James Roosevelt, eldest son of the late President and a Democratic National Committeeman, announced today that he would be a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor of California in 1950. He also will run in the Republican primary under the state's cross-filing system.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Liquidation developed in December wheat on the Board of Trade today and at one time the delivery was 1 cent a bushel under May compared with a premium of 5 cents recently. Closing trades were about at the bottom, with losses of 1/8 to 1 5/8 cents.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 15 (UP) -- Government sources said tonight that Czechoslovakia was expelling all anti-Communist foreigners, except diplomats, accredited journalists and students.

In recognition of outstanding volunteer community service, the first Lane Bryant Annual Award of $1,000 was presented yesterday to the Citizens Schools Committee of Chicago, which was credited with freeing the public school system of that city from political domination.

The very light neutrals, natural straw and cream felt, accented by such tones as red, white and green, scored a smashing color victory yesterday in the spring millinery parade offered by the Millinery Creators Guild at the St. Regis Hotel. Other colors glimpsed for the coming season were Golden Haze, a greenish gold, and the combinations of pink and navy, and Cabana Blue, a lighter tone than navy, with Grenadine red.

Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan delivered a stern warding yesterday to Archibald Palmer, defense attorney, against "trying to make a farce" out of the pre-trial hearing of his motion to dismiss conspiracy and espionage charges against Judith Coplon, former Department of Justice analyst.

ABOARD THE S. S FLYING CLOUD, off Shanghai, Nov. 15 -The guns of a Chinese Nationalist warship today damaged this American merchantman home - bound from Shanghai as she broke away from the blockading warship that had detained and boarded her.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 15 -- Leading executives in the commercial refrigeration and air-conditioning industry believe that sales in their fields during the first six months of 1950 may reach as high as 25 per cent above the 1949 level for the same period.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15 -- The question, "Does the use of the word communism in this case prejudice you?" was put to prospective jurors time after time today as the work of selecting a jury in the Harry Bridges perjury and conspiracy trial went slowly ahead.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Material advance toward economic recovery continues in Western Europe but Marshall Plan countries must take further, decisive steps, including price-cutting, to get much more of their exports into American markets and improve their dollar position, President Truman reported to Congress today.

Some of the results of the recent Three-Power conference in Paris have now been made known by German Chancellor Adenauer and French Foreign Minister Schuman. These results still depend on the negotiations under way between the West-German Government and the Western High Commissioners.

Handprinted casement fabrics from California, embodying the light airy translucency so ideal for large expanses of window drapery and fabric room dividers, are an outstanding feature of the decorators' showroom that John C. Milne recently opened at 18 East Fifty-third Street.
If visitors to Fordham's football headquarters these days expect to find an aurora of gloom they will be sadly disappointed.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, Nov. 15 (UP) -- The Government declared today a state of siege, or modified martial law, throughout Haiti dissolved three political parties, closed seven newspapers and set up news censorship.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Wheeling Lake Erie Railway Company's directors declared today an extra dividend of $3 a share payable Nov. 30 on common stock of record of Nov. 25. The declaration of the extra dividend, from surplus earnings, precedes by two days the effective date of the lease of the Wheeling by the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad.

When a horse cracks a world record, even for such a rarely run distance as two miles and a sixteenth, he rates a bit of applause. But when the victory of the King Ranch's Flying Missel, 13-to-20 favorite, was declared official ten minutes or so after the running of the $22,300 Daingerfield Handicap at Empire City-at-Jamaica yesterday, there were jeers, not cheers, from many in the crowd of 27,064.

The several hundred municipal officials and others who attended the Fourth Regional Plan Conference yesterday must have been impressed, we believe, by the opportunities and challenges that lie immediately ahead for planning in the metropolitan area. Earl B. Schwulst, president of the Bowery Savings Bank, pointed out that more than half of the regional developments which were only "paper plans" twenty years ago have now become reality.

The Loewenguth Quartet of Paris gave the first of three subscription concerts of quartet music last night in Times Hall before a deeply impressed audience. The program was a hefty one in its length and in its contents. It began with three fugues and the chorale from Bach's "Art of the Fugue," and continued with three quartets of Mozart.

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- The Cabinet will meet again tomorrow to try to decide on a budget to submit to Parliament for 1950. The budget is now tentatively fixed at 2,275,000,000,000 francs and will necessitate greater taxation.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 15 -- Syria's citizens demonstrated a striking lack of interest today in what appeared probably the freest elections ever held in the Republic. Although polling places were kept open for three extra hours, most of the electoral districts, including the cities of Damascus, Aleppo and Homs, will have to keep the polls open an extra day tomorrow.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Nov. 15 -- Charles R. Cox, president of Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, said here today that the momentum immediately in prospect for our economy does not appear to be enough to satisfy a nation that has witnessed full employment and a complete scale of production.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15 -- A treatment which has cut drastically the death rate of babies suffering from RH disease, the jaundice of the newborn, was reported here today to a meeting of the American Academy of Pediatrics by Drs. Louis K. Diamond and Fred H. Allen Jr. of Boston.

Four hundred tire dealers and distributors of the New York metropolitan area attended a showing of the new "scuff-proof" white sidewall tire of the United States Rubber Company yesterday at the New Yorker Hotel.
