Among factors emphasized by company officials were increased traction and safety and a special tread that limits the need for chains in winter driving.

CAMP KILMER, N. J., Nov. 15 -- A detachment of fifty-five men was sent to Fort Dix, N. J., from this vast Army installation today to begin setting up a personnel center similar to the one that processed 5,000,000 soldiers at Camp Kilmer since it was activated in June, 1942.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, returned from a week-long policymaking visit to Europe this afternoon with assurances that his talks with the leaders of Britain, France and Western Germany had been agreeable, harmonious and personally satisfying.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Development at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology of a new process for sterilizing penicillin and many other pharmaceuticals by means of high-voltage cathode rays was announced here tonight by Dr. James R. Killian Jr., president of the Cambridge, Mass., school.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Federal Judge Emerich B. Freed heard five hours of argument today and then asked for briefs in a government suit charging The Lorain Journal with violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Act by restricting sale of its advertising space.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- A registration statement covering $5,500,000 of sinking-fund debentures due in 1974 was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Central Power and Light Company, Corpus Christi, Tex.

Long before the first snow of winter designers are planning bonnets for the Easter parade. The first crop was shown to store buyers yesterday by the Millinery Designers League at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The league includes many of the milliners whose hats range in price from $6 to $20.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 15 -- Election of a Republican Congress next year was called for tonight by Guy G. Gabrielson, the party's national chairman, to end "the give-away program" of the Federal Government and "stop this march toward national bankruptcy and ruin."
The private utilities in the six-state area of New England started yesterday a preliminary attack a short time in advance of the Administration's all-out propaganda drive for public power there.

The Hassoldt Davis Expedition departed last night from Greenpoint, Brooklyn, aboard the steamship Bilma of the French freight line Chargeurs Reunis, Jean Malgrin, master. It is headed for one of the least known parts of Africa's western bulge to record on film and sound machine the tribal and ethnic customs from the Ivory Coast to Lake Chad, the borderland where the Arab and the Negro meet in France's overseas empire.

Glamour and glitter comprised the keynote for the second Bal de Tete held last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The fabulous Hope diamond and the comparably famous diamond, Star of the East, were among the priceless gems displayed by women of society who participated in a tableau arranged especially for the occasion by Lester Gaba, industrial designer.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- The Eastman Kodak Company's board of directors today voted a wage dividend estimated at $15,500,000 for about 48,000 employes in the Western Hemisphere.

In an attempt to revive primitive arts for modern functional uses, an artist and a ceramist have joined forces to produce a group of ceramic wall-plates, wall-masks, decorative tiles, bowls, vases and lamps.
Counsel for Alger Hiss failed yesterday in an attempt to examine the Immigration and Naturalization Service files on Mrs. Hedda Massing, first wife of the Communist fugitive, Gerhart Eisler.

The six-story building at 955 Sheridan Avenue, the Bronx, containing ninety-two suites, has been purchased by Seymour Goldberg from Brown Furtch, who built it about a year ago. The property, assessed at $1,000,000, was acquired subject to a first mortgage of $550,000.
TORONTO, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Mexican Army jumping team tonight scored its first victory of the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show when it took the military two-and-two event with a clean performance.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 15 -- The use of inter-county consolidated high schools as one solution for the problem of furnishing equal educational facilities for whites and Negroes in the South appeared threatened today by a Federal court ruling.

The public must be aroused to the vital need for legislation regulating the placement of children for adoption before the current bad situation can be improved, speakers agreed at a conference held yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel under auspices of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and final prices were 5 to 7 points lower.

A new book by Carlo Levi, author of "Christ Stopped at Eboli," has been scheduled for Jan. 19 publication by Farrar, Straus. "Of Fear and Freedom" contains the author's beliefs and reflections on things Mr. Levi calls "the gods of ambiguity."

On its 311th anniversary today, the Collegiate School for Boys at 241 West Seventy-seventh Street will open a fund-raising drive for $1,250,000 for a new school building in the East Eighties, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, told Congress today that "the general economic welfare of the country," rather than any compulsion to live within its income, must determine whether the Federal budget should be balanced or show a deficit in any particular year.

Volunteer workers in hospitals are important not only in alleviating the shortage of nurses but also in the psychologically beneficial effect their presence has upon the patients, according to officials of the United Hospital Fund.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week-ended yesterday numbered 2,016, compared with 1,632 last week and 2,170 in the similar week of last year, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 1,109 arrivals yesterday against 852 last Tuesday.

A civil anti-trust suit by the Glasfloss Corporation of Stratford, Conn., asking $9,000,000 in damages from the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation of Toledo, Ohio, and New York, was on file in Federal Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The State Department made public today reports that the American merchant ship Flying Cloud had been fired upon and damaged by a Chinese Nationalist warship at the mouth of the Yangtze River.

Bronislav Gimpel, violinist, who played three concertos with a conductorless orchestra at his Carnegie Hall appearance in April, returned to that auditorium last night to give a more conventional recital with Anthony Kooiker, pianist, as his accompanist.

The need for new schools in the city has become so urgent that the Board of Education may recommend that the city seek legislation from the state permitting it to borrow up to $780,000,000 to meet future school needs, Charles J. Bensley, chairman of the committee on buildings and sites of the Board of Education, told the Board of Estimate yesterday.
In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 7 a letter from Rex D. Drilon discusses the Philippine Presidential election.

Plans for the Thanksgiving clothing and soap collection of the War Relief Services of the National Catholic Welfare Conference were announced yesterday at the chancery office of the New York Archdiocese, 451 Madison Avenue.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 15 -- The 1950 international service project of the Girl Scouts of the U. S. A. was announced here tonight as the assembling of school supplies for the children of twenty-eight foreign countries. This country's 65,000 Girl Scout troops will participate in the campaign.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The St. Louis Browns announced today that Zack Taylor will be retained as manager of the club next year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- President Truman is planning a vacation of about three weeks at Key West, Fla., the White House announced today. He is expected to fly from Washington on Nov. 28.

A gift of $100,000 was received by the New York Public Library yesterday from the Carnegie Corporation, a trust that was set up by the late Andrew Carnegie in 1911 for the advancement and diffusion of knowledge.
The new Yugoslav freighter Srbija will come here the latter part of this week from Philadelphia, according to Capt. Teodor Tijan, New York representative of the Yugoslav Ministry of Merchant Marine.

The Rangers will take the ice tonight at Madison Square Garden with the Boston Bruins as their foe in a National Hockey League skirmish. The contest, one between teams deadlocked for the cellar in the circuit, is the finale of a four-game home stand for the Blue Shirts.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Quarterback George Ratterman of the Buffalo Bills of the All-America Football Conference confirmed today that he would play for the New York Bulldogs in the rival National League next year.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 15 -- Conservative forces in the Screen Writers Guild were victorious in the guild's annual election, results of which were made public today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Maritime labor unions disagreed today as to the advisability of continuing the Maritime War Emergency Board and its functions at the first meeting of the board in more than four years. Representatives of management, however, indicated a willingness to go along with the present system of war bonuses and risk insurance as regulated by the MWEB.
ALBANY, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Railroad fares between points within New York State are not affected by the fare increase granted yesterday by the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington.

Fifteen hundred toys, Christmas presents for youngsters overseas, were taken into the Pierre Hotel yesterday as the price of admission to a party sponsored by the Foster Parents Plan for War Children.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The relationship between cancer and hormones will be further explored as a result of grants to universities and hospitals in twenty-one states made today by the Public Health Service. The rants totaled $907,212.

BOSTON, Nov. 15 -- The nation's housing officials were charged today with the task of developing the "greatest housing program in the history of the world" in face of a real estate lobby that had transferred its efforts from Vashington to local communities.

VIENNA, Nov. 15 -- A difference of opinion between representatives of the United States and the Austrian Government concerning the true exchange value of the Austrian schilling has delayed the devaluation of that currency and is still unreconciled.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 15 -Chancellor Konrad Adenauer informed the Bundestag or Lower House of Parliament today that the Western occupying powers had agreed to slow down the dismantling of German factories and study revision of the dismantling program.
The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power borrowed yesterday $20,000,000 on serial water works revenue bonds maturing on Nov. 1, 1950, to Nov. 1, 1989, at an interest cost of 2.332307 per cent.

SALEM, N. H., Nov. 15 (AP) -- R. N. Webster's Crystal Boot, ridden by Albert Treptor, came with a rush on the outside in the stretch to defeat Flag Drill by half a length at Rockingham Park today. Kandycal was third in the feature.

When the Eastern railroads put into effect the 12.5 per cent increase in fares granted them on Monday by the Interstate Commerce Commission, the traveler between New York and Chicago, Cleveland and Detroit, will find it cheaper to go by commercial airline coach than by railway coach.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- In a Parliamentary move to hasten completion of its nationalization program, the British Government introduced today amendments to the iron and steel bill that would defer its operation until after the pending general election.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Nov. 15 -- An avowed German black-marketeer told a court martial here today of his extensive operations said to have been carried on with the full knowledge of bribed United States Army criminal investigation agents.

BERLIN, Nov. 15 -- Staff officers of a number of Western European armies have been discussing the difference that the raising of even five German divisions would make to the defense of Western Europe against a possible attack from the East.

ATHENS, Nov. 15 -- Senator Denis Chavez, Democrat, of New Mexico, today warned Greek business men that if they defaulted on taxes and declined to invest in their country's post-war recovery, the United States taxpayers could not be expected to continue their present aid.
JERSEY CITY, Nov. 15 (UP) -- William S. Sternkopf, city auditor, today recommended that the New York baseball Giants be forced to pay more money for use of municipally-owned Roosevelt Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Slumped in a wheelchair, Herbert J. Burgman, 53 years old, former clerk in the United States Embassy in Berlin, was convicted today of thirteen acts of treason for broadcasting Nazi propaganda during World War II.
OTTAWA, Nov. 15 -- The Federal Government is considering a proposal to construct a $3,000,000 steamer for use as a ferry to United States points on Canada's east coast, it was learned tonight.
Turkeys are 14 to 16 cents a pound cheaper than Thanksgiving birds last year, Anthony Masciarelli, City Commissioner of Markets, reported yesterday. He also denied rumors that coffee was scarce.
Group medical practice and expansion of regional hospital cooperation are discussed in the annual report of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, published yesterday.

As a start toward solving New York's traffic problem, the zoning law should be amended to require new commercial and residential developments to provide off-street parking for their needs, the Regional Plan Association was told yesterday.

The East-West debate in the United Nations entered a new phase with Ambassador Austin's hard-hitting speech in the Political and Security Committee. Until now the Western Powers have been rather gingerly in using the United Nations platform for propaganda.

Having rid themselves of a lot of bad basketball, which had dropped them into an 18-point deficit in the fourth period, the New York Knickerbockers belatedly caught fire against the Syracuse Nationals last night at Madison Square Garden and with twenty-five seconds to go trailed by only one point.

CAMBRIDGE, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- The turnout for the opening day of the deer season in the Catskills is rivaled only by the number of anglers who throng the streams of this area for the first day of trout fishing, but of the two, the hunters are a more colorful lot.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Federal and state revenues collected from alcoholic beverages in 1948 rose to $2,962,895,000, topping the industry's $2,700,000,000 payroll, members of the Associated Tavern Owners of America were told today at their convention.

The New York City Ski Council, at a meeting last night in the Dartmouth Club, announced it has been designated by the National Ski Association of America to serve as the official reception committee to welcome all foreign skiers for the world championships to be held at Lake Placid, N. Y., and Aspen, Col., this winter.

The formation of a committee with a paid "port manager" to stimulate and coordinate the efforts of various organizations to improve the flow of commerce through New York and stop the diversion of cargo to outports, was urged yesterday by Paul G. Boise, president of the Foreign Commerce Club of New York.

The mathematical equivalent of a slow-motion picture of the splitting of the uranium atom, which takes place in a trillionth of a second, has been obtained by two Princeton University physicists with the aid of the giant electronic calculating machine.

As of this writing, the food position throughout the Soviet Union as a whole still is precarious. The last three crop years have been good, but this is exceptional in the Soviet Union, which is lucky to get two good crop years out of five. However, the 250,000 collective farms, the cornerstone of Soviet agriculture, are insurance against positive famine, even if there are several bad years.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 15 -- Thirty- three members of the immediate families and one other will be the only guests at the wedding of Mrs. Carleton S. Hadley and Vice President Alben W. Barkley on Friday in the Singleton Memorial Chapel of St. John's Methodist Church here.
Public utility companies raised $16,000,000 yesterday by the sale of new issues of bonds and preferred stock to investment banking syndicates. The awards were as follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- A strike of 2,000 AFL deck officers operating from Gulf and Atlantic Coast ports, which had threatened to tie up all shipping in the region, was postponed tonight on the plea of Government mediators. The strike had been called for midnight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Declaring that the best opportunity for little business "lies in the horizons opened for them by the basic new developments offered by big business," Crawford H. Greenewalt, president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., disclosed today that his company would spend $35,000,000 for research in 1950.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 15 -- Canada politely invited Poland today to take to the Canadian courts the three-year-old battle for possession of the ancient coronation sword of the Polish kings and other treasures out of Poland's past.

MOSCOW, Nov. 15 -- The All- Union art exhibit of 1949 opened this week at the Tretyakov Galleries with 600 works by Soviet artists and sculptors on view. Next year's Stalin prize winners will be selected from this collection, which represents the Soviet republics.

The wide regional variations in consumption of soft drinks make a local advertising medium like newspapers ideal for advertising, members of the American Bottlers of Carbonated Beverages were told yesterday at their convention in Detroit.

A six-and-a-half-pound, blue-eyed baby girl was born at 12:55 A. M. yesterday to Mrs. Leokadia Rolbiecki, a Polish displaced person, aboard a Scandinavian Airlines plane about 1,000 miles west of Prestwick, Scotland, en route to this country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The Government waited and watched for signs of life today in the suspended soft-coal negotiations but nothing happened to indicate a change in plans for White House intervention within the next couple of days.

Well-known women of society are active in the sale of tickets for the performance of "I Know My Love," with Lynn Fontanne and Alfred Lunt in the leading roles, on the night of Nov. 28 at the Shubert Theatre which has been taken over to raise funds for the Institute of Fine Arts of New York University.

Comic books are here to stay, so let's make them socially useful. That's the suggestion of Prof. Harvey W. Zorbaugh of New York University, a leading sociologist who is pioneering in the nation's first college course on how to create comics that stress education and information rather than murder, mayhem and malevolence.

Rising prices of leather and sheepskin will be reflected in heavy outerwear prices next year, according to manufacturers at the annual meeting of the National Heavy Outerwear Association in the Waldor-Astoria Hotel. With leather up 3 cents a foot and sheepskin 7 cents a foot, coats made of these materials will be increased from 50 cents to $2 a garment at the wholesale level, manufacturers said yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 15 -Milovan Djilas, Yugoslav representative to the United Nations, said today that the Soviet proposals for a Big Five non-aggression pact "sound rather ironical" when contrasted with the Soviet Union's pressure against the Tito Government.
Mexico's leading psychiatrist suggested yesterday that American movies be judged by a committee of mental hygiene experts before they are released to the public.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Alabama, Georgia, South Carolina, Mississippi and twenty counties in Arkansas have now been declared cotton disaster areas as a result of boll weevil infestations, the Department of Agriculture said today.

LONDON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Randolph Turpin, a compact little Negro, stopped Pete Mead of Grand Rapids, Mich., after four rounds of their scheduled ten-round fight at Harringay Arena tonight. Mead, who had taken a beating from the start, toppled over from his stool in the corner of the ring as Referee Teddy Waltham awarded a knockout to Turpin.

TODAY'S space must be shared by two books which have nothing in common save their excellence and the fact that neither is the kind which attracts as much public attention as it deserves. They are "Thesaurus of Book Digests,''* edited by Hiram Haydn and Edmund Fuller, a magnificently planned and executed reference book, and "A Treasury of American Homes," by Richard Pratt, one of the most beautiful and fascinating picture books I have ever seen.

Jack I. Straus, president of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., expressed the belief at yesterday's annual meeting of stockholders, which lasted four hours, that the outlook for retail business is showing improvement.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Mayor Thomas A. Burke revealed today city officials were talking over a new contract on stadium rent with prospective new owners of the Indians.

The Metropolitan Opera Association's new roster, issued yesterday, revealed that the personnel of the company will be largely unchanged for the new season, which will be Edward Johnson's fifteenth and final one as general manager and the sixty-fifth to be given at the Metropolitan Opera House.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 15 -- The Nassau Transit Commission declared today that an analysis of a study of the Long Island Rail Road made by the J. G. White Engineering Corporation corroborated the commission's contention that substantial amounts of revenue belonging to the Long Island had been withheld by the Pennsylvania Railroad, the parent company.

BUFFALO, Nov. 15 -- Referring to the "rising war of words over the phrase 'welfare state,'" Governor Dewey tonight asked people not to confuse a controversy in semantics with one over political philosophy, "as some would like to have us do."

The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit reserved decision yesterday on a motion by counsel for the eleven convicted Communists to restrain the Government from levying against the defendants' assets to provide bonds to secure their fines.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Attorney General J. Howard McGrath told a group of executives of finance companies today that "the public is entitled to secure its finance in an unrestricted market." He said the Department of Justice is trying to enforce anti-trust laws to protect "those business men who desire to bring the advantages of cheaper financing to the borrower."

MONTREAL, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Goal keepers shudder when Detroit's line of Ted Lindsay, Sid Abel and Gordie Howe are on the ice and the statistics show why. The trio, highest scoring forward line in the National Hockey League, dominated the circuit's individual scoring race today.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad will be asked to approve the following fiscal transactions at their annual meeting here next Monday:

The United States needs oil imports to supplement its domestic production, S. A. Swensrud, president of the Gulf Oil Corporation, yesterday told a Congressional subcommittee holding hearings here on the effects of oil imports on the domestic economy.

GLEN RIDGE, N. J., Nov. 15 -- A team captained by Danny Williams Sr. of The Knoll defeated Bill Glancy's combine, 13 -- 9, today as the New Jersey P. G. A. revived its colorful Ed Gaffney matches at the Glen Ridge Country Club.
Stressing ground attack plays, the New York University football team engaged in a scrimmage yesterday in preparation for Saturday's encounter with City College.

WARSAW, Nov. 15 -- The Polish United Workers (Communist) party will undergo a thorough purge to make it truly a workers' party capable of implementing Marxist-Leninist ideology, President Boleslaw Bierut told the nation today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- A $2,000,000 compromise settlement for the Government's wartime use of the Detroit Cleveland Navigation Company's steamer Greater Buffalo was announced today.

THE TIMES on Nov. 9, in an editorial on the defeat of Councilman Benjamin Davis in the Twenty-first Senatorial District, stated, "The bullet voting of PR was an ideal weapon of the Communists in putting Mr. Davis into office."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The first really detailed report on the Western Big Three Foreign Ministers' meeting in Paris came, not from the Foreign Ministers of the United States, Britain, or France, but from the Chancellor of the West German Federal Republic in Bonn.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The Displaced Persons Commission has hit upon a new device, it became known today, that may make it possible to fulfill this nation's commitment to provide a home here for 205,000 of Europe's displaced persons by June 30, 1950.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Homer P. Hargrave was nominated today for the chairmanship of the new Midwest Stock Exchange. Mr. Hargrave, who took an important part in the formation of the consolidated market, is Chicago partner of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane and chairman of the Chicago Stock Exchange.

The Long Island State Park Commission has lengthened the Southern State Parkway by opening a two and one-half mile extension north of Babylon. This makes a total of eighty-eight miles of parkway with 121 grade separation bridges to be completed in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Under a hustling ride by Johnny Gilbert, Brookmeade Stable's Pilayya got up by a head in the final strides to defeat Isle of Mist in the North Star III Purse at Pimlico today.

Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, CIO, made it plain yesterday that it believed its support for Mayor O'Dwyer in his successful re-election campaign should be followed by establishment of a forty-hour week, wage increases of 21 cents an hour and other concessions for 40,000 workers on the municipal subway, elevated and bus lines.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The citizens of this country are awakened, as never before, to the true meaning of equality, President Truman told the annual meeting of the National Council of Negro Women here tonight.

A national drive to adapt modern merchandising methods to the sale of "packaged ice" made by ice manufacturers throughout the country, was started yesterday by more than 300 members at the thirty-second annual convention of the National Association of Ice Industries at the Commodore Hotel.

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- A sharp improvement in France's foreign trade balance for October, with 80 per cent of imports covered by exports was noted in a statistical report issued today. In October, 1948, only 48 per cent of imports was covered by exports, the report said.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- British Government stocks continued to improve in the stock markets here today. After rising steadily and slowly all day, prices closed at the top, with gains up to three-quarters point.
LONDON, Nov. 15 -- An early agreement by Britain, France and the United States to allow the Germans to resume the building of fast transoceanic freighters was forecast here today.
Brought into War Emergency Court yesterday in a wheel chair, a 38-year-old woman, victim of a polio attack in childhood, signed a summons charging a real estate concern with illegal eviction.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Officials of the Farm Equipment Workers local at International Harvester Company here today declared "a state of strike without the stoppage of work."

Events today: Lorne Munroe, 'cello, Town Hall, 3 P. M.; New York Youth Concert, Wheeler Backett, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 3:15; Offenbach's "The Tales of Hoffmann," City Opera Company, City Center, 8:15; Frances Magnes, violin, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Helen Thigpen, soprano, Town Hall, 8:30; Robbie Masterson, piano, and Gosta Englund, baritone, Times Hall, 8:30; Budapest String Quartet, assisted by Milton Katims, viola, Lexington Avenue Y.M. and Y.W.H.A., 8:40.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 15 -- The late Robert E. Hannegan, former Postmaster General and chairman of the Democratic party, left an estate of $526,820, but lawyers familiar with his holdings estimated that it might run to $1,500,000.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 15 (UP) -- Westinghouse Electric Corporation, one of the big three of the industry, today asked the National Labor Relations Board to deter-existing contracts with UE it will continue to bargain with that union "on all matters of a company-wide concern as long as the contract is in force."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -Agents of the Senate Committee on Expenditures in the Executive Departments have been quietly probing into Austrian Government transactions under the Marshall Plan in this country to determine the extent of irregularities that caused the Economic Cooperation Administration recently to demand a $926,858 refund.

A delay in the proposed merger of the Congregational Christian churches and the Evangelical and Reformed Church loomed as a possibility yesterday when Justice Meier Steinbrink in Brooklyn Supreme Court ordered a halt to further planning for a uniting convention, now scheduled to he held in Cleveland next June.

Hans J. Isbrandtsen, president of Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., operators of the Flying Cloud, made public here yesterday a telegram to Secretary of State Dean Acheson stating that the line had asked the Navy for any aid needed by the freighter and urging appropriate Government action.

The airlines of the United States are continually improving their safety records and 1949 probably will not be an exception, despite the recent crash in Washington that took fifty-five lives, a Federal official said yesterday.

The Communist advance in continental China brings into increasingly sharper focus the problem of what is to be done about Formosa. It seems likely now that Chiang Kai-shek will attempt to hold the island as the last bastion of free China. How successful he can be with his present resources is problematical.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission of Maryland declined today to interfere with a plan of the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore for private sale of $20,000,000 in refunding bonds.

Rising production costs have blighted hopes for any general decreases in prices of automobiles, Harry J. Klingler, general manager of the Pontiac division of the General Motors Corporation, said yesterday. Lack of manufacturing material, particularly cold-rolled steel, may bring about a midwinter shortage of vehicles, he added.

Columbia's defensive platoon received its first taste of Brown's winged-T attack, yesterday, when the Lions engaged in a light contact workout at Baker Field in preparation for their final game of the season on Saturday.

The United Nations General Assembly rejected yesterday a resolution calling upon administering powers to submit detailed blue-prints on how they proposed to lead 15,000,000 natives in African and Pacific trust territories to independence.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 15 -- Moshe Sharett, Israeli Foreign Minister, left tonight for Lake Success on what he hoped to be a mission of peace. Nevertheless it was considered here that the situation politically and diplomatically was extremely delicate.

Live lobsters and clams for shipment to mail order customers are the "crops" of Saltwater Farm in Damariscotta, Me. Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Myers, who started this business only last May, already are sending their products to people in the Midwest and in Philadelphia as well as in this city.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 15 -China's Communist regime has served notice on the United Nations that the Nationalist Government delegation to the General Assembly "cannot represent China and has no right to speak for the Chinese people in the United Nations Organization."

The Interstate Commerce Commission has just authorized a third postwar fare increase for the railroads of the so-called Eastern territory. Some sixty carriers this side of the Mississippi and north of the Ohio and Potomac Rivers are affected by the ruling, which would establish the rate for coach travel at 3.375 cents a mile and the Pullman rate at 4.5 cents.
Notre Dame, Oklahoma, California and Army continue to be the only "regulars" in college football's first ten.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 15 -- An appeal for a thorough inventory of all "conventional armaments" (that is, non-atomic weapons) and the war manpower potential of the fifty-nine members of the United Nations was made today by France and Norway.
LONDON, Nov. 15 -- Current ferment in the Balkans is creating a new political pattern for the world.
LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 15 -- Israel told the United Nations today that an international regime for Jerusalem would "convulse the city in widespread discontent and confusion."

The whole problem of Russia's relations with the West can be stated in two sentences -- and was so stated by our delegate to the United Nations, Mr. Austin, in his reply to Mr. Vishinsky at Lake Success on Monday. Said Mr. Austin to Mr. Vishinsky: "Let your people meet with our people and discuss together our common problems.
LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 15 -- Over strenuous United States objections, the Social Committee of the General Assembly tonight passed a new United Nations program for aid to refugees.

The British Labor party leaders have nothing to lose by postponing the "vesting day" for nationalization of the iron and steel industry until after the general elections. It may be cynical to say that is why they did it, because there has been a difference of opinion within the Socialist ranks on the wisdom of nationalizing the steel industry at all.

ALBANY, Nov. 15 -- Governor Dewey appointed a ten-member committee today to draft a bill to accomplish the directives of Amendment 5, providing for a point system of veterans' preference in civil service. The amendment was approved by the voters Nov. 8.

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 16 -- Two merchant vessels easing through an almost impenetrable "pea soup" fog blanketing most of England, collided in the mouth of the Thames River off Holehaven early today.

It was a dreary week, that last one. Not that the weather was unacceptable, for it was not, and the longer New York can cling to the temperature of Miami, the easier it will be on fuel oil. Not that the elections turned out badly, since statistics show they turned out well for more persons than found them ill.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The United States refused today to recognize Eastern Europe's new Control Commission for Danube Shipping, terming it a device to assure the Soviet Union "a monopoly of Danubian commerce."

Christmas shoppers who would like to have their gifts pre-selected by a board of experts should be particularly enthusiastic about "Design Show: Christmas 1949," which opens today at the Museum of Modern Art. This year's annual display of approved miscellaneous objects has been screened by the staffs of two museums.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The nation's top military strategists will have within a few weeks the "answers" on the performance of the Air Force's long-range B-36 bomber.

The unflagging accumulation of the public's savings in the hands of insurance companies and other trust institutions against a dwindling supply of publicly marketed corporate bonds was reflected tellingly yesterday in the bidding of investment bankers for a small issue of AA-rated bonds of a Wisconsin public utility enterprise -- the Madison Gas and Electric Company.

Isidore Ginsberg, the Queens attorney accused of using the mails to defraud prospective purchasers of building materials of $15,000, admitted yesterday that he had bribed officers and salesmen of gypsum products concerns to obtain priorities.

Plans for the expansion of the Boys Clubs of America were made on Tuesday evening at a meeting of the national board at the Union Club, the organization announced yesterday. Former President Herbert Hoover, chairman of the board, presided.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The return of Secretary of State Acheson yesterday from his conference in Paris and Western Germany yielded no more important news than that the President was at the airport to congratulate the premier of his Cabinet and was informed by Mr. Acheson that he believed "we did what you told us to do."

CLEVELAND, Nov. 16 -- With Gov. Frank J. Lausche out of the picture as a potential candidate to oppose Senator Robert A. Taft in the 1950 Ohio Senatorial race, Mayor Thomas A. Burke of Cleveland becomes the big hope of the Democratic party and organized labor.
Attendance was up 15 per cent and betting increased 7.9 per cent at New York State harness racing tracks this year, the United States Trotting Association reported yesterday.

Three new films will open in first-run theatres this morning. At the Capitol the attraction is "She Wore a Yellow Ribbon," featuring John Wayne, Joanne Dru, John Agar, Ben Johnson and Harry Carey Jr. John Ford directed the Western, which was filmed in Technicolor and is being released by RKO from a screen play by Frank S. Nugent and Laurance Stallings and a story by James Warner Bellah.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 16 -- The misfortune which has dogged the Bulldog all season struck again late today almost on the eve of Yale's final and objective game with Harvard in the Bowl Saturday.
Rich, glowing colors were featured yesterday at a fashion show for dogs held in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre Hotel, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-first Street.

A new experiment in parent education was begun last night with the performance at Finch College, 52 East Seventy-eighth Street, of the first of three new plays dramatizing the knowledge of experts on problems of child rearing.
TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Nationalist China was reported today to have ordered the bombing of all foreign shipping in the Strait of Formosa.

A decrease last week of 680,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end total supplies were 103,577,000 barrels, against 104,257,000 a week earlier and 91,795,000 a year ago.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 16 (AP) -- -- The Aluminum Company of America has signed contracts with its AFL union granting company-paid, non-contributory pensoins and insurance, to 10,000 workers in five plants.
ITHACA, N. Y., Nov. 16 (AP) -- Cornell's gridiron coach, George K. (Lefty) James, took a slap today at coaches who favor repeal of the two-platoon system in college football.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Now that parents and educators are wisely beginning to remove sex instruction from the street corners and place it in the schools, we are allowing the study of history, economics and literature to be pushed into hidden alleys of thought. The Feinberg Law, which seals the lips and minds of teachers, and the increasing banning of books and periodicals are marking off whole areas of knowledge as "Forbidden."

We have read with interest what Mayor O'Dwyer has had to say, before and after the election, about New York City newspapers. Although he has not always been specific as to the reasons, it is obvious that he has been angry. We assume that this was prompted in part by disappointment over his failure, in rather sobering unanimity, to win important newspaper editorial support for re-election.

Lloyd H. Skouger of the Material Handling Equipment Company of New York has bought a new rambling home of seven rooms and two baths with a two-car garage in the Suburban Unit project at Forest and Green Avenues, in the Milton Point section of Rye, N. Y., from Edward J. Bergen, builder.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The leasing of a fifty-acre tract in the Maritime Commission's, North Carolina shipyard at Wilmington, N. C., to the North Carolina Port Authority for fifty years at a nominal rental of $1 a year was announced today by the commission.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Printing Industry of America convention advocated yesterday that the Federal Government insure an adequate retirement system for all elderly workers.

BATTENVILLE, N. Y., Nov. 16 -- If the rest of the Catskill deer hunters did as well as those from this hilly and wooded corner of Washington County, there will be new opening day record for this area.
Poland asked the United Nations General Assembly yesterday to protect immigrant workers, particularly refugees, from alleged "exploitation" by the Western powers.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 16 -- New economy shortcuts and unspent surpluses added up today to the pleasant surprise of a $6,813,412 reduction in member-nation contributions next year to the budget of the United Nations.

A preview of the Hallmark Art Award paintings will be held on the night of Dec. 7 at the Wildenstein Galleries, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street, in the interests of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross. Tickets for the special showing will include a buffet champagne supper.

Tension in the National Maritime Union, CIO, running high for years because of rightist-leftist conflict, burst into near-rioting yesterday as 200 "left wing" demonstrators stormed the union hall at 346 West Seventeenth Street and seized control of the building.

As one who has watched in anger and dismay the events which, starting with the "grand design" of Communist appeasement during the late war, have led to the outrages perpetrated against American citizens behind the Iron Curtain, I want to thank you for the editorial about "our Micawber Far Eastern policy."

Bishop Loughlin made a clean sweep of all cross-country honors this season yesterday when it captured the team title in the twenty-eighth annual Athletic Association of Private Schools championships at Van Cortlandt Park. Al Ray, Loughlin harrier who took the CHSAA crown Saturday, was the individual winner.
The Columbia football team spent another day studying Brown's winged-T attack at Baker Field yesterday, as Coach Lou Little sent his charges through a light contact practice session.

A collection of chairs and tables whose trim, delicate look belies their ability to take any amount of hard wear and tear was presented yesterday by William Armbruster, an architect, in the showrooms of the Edgewood Furniture Company, 208 East Twenty-seventh Street.

An order, defining conditions under which bonds may be posted by the eleven convicted Communists to secure fines, was handed down by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second District yesterday.

DURHAM, N. C., Nov. 16 -- Twenty American literary works described as representing the country's best were recommended here today for inclusion in the world's great classics now being compiled by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 16 -- Charles C. E. Harris of Arlington, Mass., was re-elected president of the International Refrigeration Service Engineers Society at the closing session of their twelfth annual convention at the Ambassador Hotel here today.

Helen Thigpen, soprano from Washington, D. C., gave a recital of real quality at Town Hall last night. There was quality in the purity of vocal sound, in all the material presented and in the dignity, style and musical integrity of its delivery.

Chairman Thomas B. McCabe of the Federal Reserve Board has added his voice to those of the President and the Secretary of the Treasury in deploring rumors of a mark-up in the official price of gold. He has also taken occasion to reply to the argument frequently heard that the United States should restore the so-called "full gold standard" with gold coinage and free interconvertibility of all forms of currency.

In support of Strindberg's thesis, Mady Christians is the more powerful of the two principal actors in "The Father," which was intelligently acted at the Cort last evening. She is playing this mad and shattering tragedy in company with Raymond Massey, who has also directed the performance.

The forgotten commuter was remembered yesterday when the Hudson Manhattan Railroad promised the 200,000 daily New Jersey-New York "tube" passengers a completely revamped service, including on-time trains, doors that won't jam, escalators, the "light to read by."

With only four left-wing unions dissenting, the state executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations approved yesterday a constitutional amendment barring Communists from holding office in the State CIO Council.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 16 -- The Syrian elections were completed today after the second day of voting with relatively few incidents. Indications are that the People's party, which has predominant positions in the present caretaker Government, is not doing as well as expected, while Conservative forces, despite the boycott of the elections by former President Shukral Kuwatly's one-time National Bloc party is doing better than has been expected.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Major league baseball men swarmed on Cincinnati tonight, getting set for the annual player draft tomorrow.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- British Government stocks continued to make good progress in the stock markets here today. A further increase in demand in a market none too well supplied with stock caused another general advance, in which most of the long-term issues gained about a point. One or two gained as much as 1 1/2 points.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The National Cancer Institute today awarded $2,174,900 to fourteen hospitals, universities and other institutions for construction of cancer research facilities.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- Negotiations on demands of the Independent Progressive Steel Workers Union for non-contributory pensions and welfare benefits for 4,000 employes of the Wisconsin steel works of the International Harvester Company will be continued tomorrow in an effort to avert a strike.

Continuing his quest for the best possible scoring unit, Coach Ed Danowski yesterday returned Stan Bloomer to left halfback in the offensive backfield as Fordham continued its drills for the Rutgers game at New Brunswick, N. J., Saturday, with offensive and defensive scrimmage sessions against the freshman team.

ALBANY, Nov. 16 -- Governor Dewey commuted to life imprisonment today the death sentence of Samuel T. Williams, 20 years old, of Brooklyn, who was scheduled to die in the electric chair tomorrow night for the murder of Selma Graff, 15, who died from injuries received on April 19, 1947, while her home was being burglarized.
A pair of goals in the second period proved just enough for the New York Rangers in their National Hockey League game with the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden last night.

Addressing a group of 160 parents of Colgate University students last night at the Columbia University Club (the Columbia-Colgate Club), 4 West Forty-third Street, Dr. Everett N. Case, president of Colgate, reported that increased medical facilities were urgently needed for the students and for residents of the community surrounding Hamilton, N. Y., where the university is situated.
LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 16 -- Britain warned Russia today that the time for agreement was steadily running out and then added a direct appeal to the Kremlin to remove the barriers to world cooperation.

BERLIN, Nov. 16 -- Moved by conscience, seven Czechoslovak officials in Western Germany have repudiated the Communist Government in their homeland and sought and received political asylum from British authorities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- President Truman today accepted the first copy of a report on the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund with a comment that lasting peace depended on the care now being given child victims of the last war.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 16 -- Gov. Frank J. Lausche today said definitely that he did not seek the Democratic nomination for the Senate seat now held by Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican. Mr. Taft will come up for re-election next year.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 16 -- Arthur Barry, notorious jewel thief released yesterday from Attica State Prison after serving twenty-one years, pleaded guilty in Nassau County Court here today to six indictments found against him in 1927 and 1929.

The speed with which burning planes can be entered and trapped passengers reached by highly trained fire rescue personnel was demonstrated yesterday at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. Two hundred airport managers and city officials from thirteen states who attended the two-day airport fire protection conference were spectators.

Britain has, as is reasonably well known, a Labor Government (which, sticking to the old ways, calls itself a Labour Government); the pound has been devalued; austerity literally rules, and mainly rules out, the roast; the old City of London, once symbol of a power on which the sun never set, has been bombed and burned in merciless war and dethroned of its old mastery of the world's exchange.

Despite all efforts it has made thus far, the Puerto Rican educational system is woefully inadequate and in need of an immediate drastic overhauling. Half the children of Puerto Rico do not go to school at all, while the rest attend on the average only two to four years.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- The discussions now taking place in Western Germany between Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of the Bonn Republic, and the three Western High Commissioners are of an extremely delicate nature. They are not, despite Dr. Adenauer's speech, "negotiations" in the usual sense of that word, which implies equality among those participating.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- Delegates to the fourth annual convention of the Associated Tavern Owners of America were urged today to fight for repeal of the wartime liquor tax and to conduct a concerted campaign to educate the public to the plight of the retail liquor dealers who "are singled out to bear the heaviest tax load in all industry."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 9:

RAHWAY, N. J., Nov. 16 -- Lieut. (jg) Richard Marsh Golden, USN, 25 years old, of 490 West Lake Avenue, was washed overboard and drowned in heavy seas Saturday while on maneuvers aboard the destroyer Holden in Davis Strait, off the west coast of Greenland, according to word received yesterday by his wife from the Navy Department.

There are all sorts of ways of propagating doctrines, ideas and systems, and the Russians have not been teaching the world anything new in the way of methods. The differences between propaganda in Soviet Russia today and in Nazi Germany or Fascist Italy before the war would be hard to discover, except in matters of degree and effectiveness.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service passed the soft coal dispute to President Truman today, giving him two weeks to head off another strike. The White House staff, prepared for Presidential action, has tentatively selected three men to serve on a board of inquiry, it was learned authoritatively.

A petition for an order directing trustees of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road to disclose certain information to the public was filed yesterday in United States District Court, Brooklyn, by Orrin G. Judd, special counsel to Nassau County.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- The Government bill to nationalize the iron and steel industry went through the House of Commons today without a vote. The bill needs only the almost certain acceptance by the House of Lords and royal assent, which is automatic, to make it the law of the land.

The Radio Manufacturers Association yesterday authorized its television committee to present to the Federal Communications Commission a plan for the immediate establishment of an industry-wide National Television System Committee to formulate color television standards acceptable to all manufacturers.

JUST before the baseball season ended, the rumors were flying around that Joe McCarthy was through as the manager of the Red Sox. Marse Joe was understandingly caustic when the question was bluntly put to him.

In an expansion move that will give them 40 per cent more space and consolidate their executive and subsidiary offices under one roof, Doubleday Co., book publishers, have leased the fifteenth, sixteenth and seventeenth floors in the twenty-five-story building at 575 Madison Avenue under construction by the Uris Brothers, owners and builders.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Justice Department today accused Judge Ben H. Rice Jr. of the United States District Court at San Antonio, Tex., of "abuse of judicial power and abnegation of judicial duty" in handling a Government anti-trust case.

Dr. Oliver C. Carmichael, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, proposed yesterday the creation of a "science of society" able to enunciate principles of human conduct as universally acceptable as the scientific doctrines of Newton and Galileo.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- President Truman and two members of the White House staff are engaged in a weight-reducing contest to end Thanksgiving Day, and the President already has received five turkeys for the holiday feast.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Maritime industry management and labor joined today in urging before the Maritime Commission the extension of Government subsidies to American-flag tramp shipping. Their pleas were made at a public hearing on a report by its tramp shipping committee.

Charles F. Kettering, noted inventor, told 1,700 members of the Economic Club and hundreds of their wives and friends at the Astor Hotel last night that "socialism is the hardening of the arteries of stupidity."

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 16 -- A tremor of shock has run through Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg in reaction to Secretary of State Dean Acheson's visit to Western Germany. It has shaken even high Government officials who, while eager to do business with the Germans, believe the Secretary's overt gesture of friendliness went too far.

The United Nations General Assembly, in plenary session at Flushing Meadow, adopted unanimously and without abstentions yesterday four resolutions launching two programs for technical assistance to underdeveloped countries for their economic development.
ROME, Nov. 16 -- The Communist - dominated peasants' unions have called off land seizures pending the outcome of government efforts to provide land for farmers and farm laborers who have none.

Pre-trial testimony and arguments ended yesterday on the first of three grounds upon which Judith Coplon is seeking to avoid trial here as a co-defendant with Valentin A. Gubitchev, Russian engineer, on conspiracy and espionage charges.

Manufacturers of furniture, upholstery and drapery fabrics may find themselves with merchandise backing up next spring owing to a slower pace of business at the retail level, Charles S. Shaughnessey, vice president and merchandise manager of furniture, R. H. Macy Co., warned yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16 -- Three major Eastern railroads, the Pennsylvania, Reading, and Baltimore Ohio lines, filed today with Federal and state authorities a general increase in commuter fares averaging 22 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- A warning that "persistent tendencies toward inflation" may require a decline in Federal security levels to siphon off excessive bank credit, marked the opening of Congressional hearings today on Administration monetary, credit and fiscal policy.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (UP) -- Attorneys for the E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., in a petition filed today with Federal Judge Walter J. Labuy, reiterated a plea that the case be moved to the East, because its home offices are at Wilmington, Del.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The United Corporation, New York public utility holding company, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a "comprehensive plan" designed to transform it into an investment company.

More than half the 1,281 Department of Sanitation employes who took part in a union "sick" demonstration last Oct. 17 have pleaded guilty to disciplinary charges, it was announced yesterday. The demonstration, outside department headquarters at 125 Worth Street and in front of City Hall, was denounced by Mayor O'Dwyer as a political maneuver but defended by union leaders as part of the fight against working conditions.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 16 -- Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister, said at a press conference here today that mediation in the Kashmir dispute should be carried on through the United Nations.

The New York City Center of Music and Drama yesterday announced the formation of a new branch of its producing activities to be called the New York City Dance Theatre. It will concern itself with the presentation of the modern American dance in repertory seasons comparable to the repertory seasons of the New York City Ballet Company in the classic dance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Devaluation of the British pound sterling has created for American exporters specializing in Latin-American markets a host of problems with which they are still grappling. This was the gist of opinions voiced here today at a panel discussion of international exchange and trade matters.

More than 1,000 members of the New York Athletic Club last night paid tribute to the athletes who have worn the Winged Foot with distinction in competition during the past year. The occasion was the organization's fourteenth all-sports dinner, held in the gymnasium of the city clubhouse.

Consolidated net income of the Greyhound Corporation for the first nine months of this year amounted to $9,116,162, after taxes and all charges, equal to 96 cents each on 9,330,090 common shares, it was reported yesterday. Net income for the same period last year was $12,440,721, or $1.31 a common share.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 16 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer will meet with Robert Schuman, Foreign Minister of France, in the near future to work out policies on Franco-German relations, an authoritative source said tonight.

Importance to the United States of maintaining strategic reserves of oil in Latin America, despite the efforts of oil producers to obtain cheaper oil in the East, was emphasized yesterday by Senor Antonio Davila Delgado, new consul general of Venezuela in this city.

The election of Dr. Donald H. McLaughlin of San Francisco as president of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers for 1950 was announced here yesterday after a meeting of the board of directors at the organization's office, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Additional income tax exemptions for parents with sons or daughters, or both, in college was urged today by Senator Harley M. Kilgore, Democrat, of West Virginia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD) today reopened hearings on complaints brought against Otis Co. of Cleveland after the crack-up of 1947 plans for a $10,000,000 offering of stock of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation.

ATLANTA, Nov. 16 (UP) -- Hugh D. Gravitt, a taxi-driver whose private car ran down and killed Margaret Mitchell, author of "Gone With the Wind," was convicted of involuntary manslaughter today by a jury which fixed his sentence at one year to eighteen months in jail.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, told a Congressional subcommittee today that small business was stalled in its tracks as a result of "high taxes and the inability of small business men to obtain adequate capital."

HONG KONG, Nov. 16 (UP) -- Four Communist columns converged on Chungking from the north, east and south today, and harried Nationalist leaders braced themselves for an early attack on the threatened city.

Frances Magnes, violinist, who played at Carnegie Hall last night, deserves the respect and admiration of those who care about the music of our own time. In the choicest place on her program, the culmination of the first half, she played Stefan Wolpe's Sonata 1949 in its first performance. Mr. Wolpe's music does not make easy listening, and it is not designed for a virtuoso's easy success.

A health museum exhibiting ingenious models of the human body will be opened next March on the Bronx campus of Hunter College, it was announced yesterday by Basil O'Connor, president of the American Museum of Health, Inc.

Benjamin H. Griswold 3d, a partner in Alex. Brown Sons, Baltimore, was elected yesterday president of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms at the annual meeting of the board of governors. He succeeds Harold P. Goodbody of Goodbody Co.

Tuzo (Kid) Portuguez, Central American middleweight and welterweight champion, made his American debut last night with a last-round knockout over Bobby Mann of Trenton, N. J., in one of the two ten-round features at the St. Nicholas Arena.

The Bankers Trust Company has been appointed New York agent of the Detroit Edison Company to accept subscriptions to capital stock upon exercise of warrants and to transfer such warrants during the subscription period ending Dec. 5, 1949.

In my capacity as teacher and underwriter in the field of life insurance I have considered life insurance as the greatest method of meeting financial needs. Insurance, as such, is a public service that should be available to all eligible applicants of insurable age.

The Standard Oil Company of California expects to import 30,000 barrels a day of petroleum in the first six months of 1950, R. G. Follis, its vice president, yesterday told a House subcommittee studying the impact of oil imports on the nation's economy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson protested to the Chinese Nationalist Government at Chungking today for endangering American lives in the shelling of the United States merchant vessel Flying Cloud.

The director of the New York State Hospital Study criticized yesterday as "foolish and impractical" a number of views widely held by psychiatrists with regard to the establishment of additional mental health clinics and services.

Not very many people have had the dubious distinction of being used to start a peace offensive in the middle of a cold war, with the Soviet Foreign Office mobilizing all its resources in a full-scale propaganda campaign designed to disrupt the diplomatic unity of the West.

From north of the border comes a Canadian cheddar aged to a discreetly sharp ripeness. It's made by the Ingersoll Cheese Company, Ltd., in Ontario's Oxford County, a region's that been largely devoted to the production of fine cheeses since the mid-Eighteen Eighties. The concern offers the cheddar by mail order.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan today announced the 1950 price-support program for potatoes at the lowest point allowable under law, 60 per cent of parity, a level which cost the Department of Agriculture $230,000,000 to support grower prices for 1948. Potato acreage was further cut.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- College enrollments went up this fall, despite the continuing decline in veteran students under the GI Bill of Rights, the annual Office of Education survey disclosed today.

Schapiro's Kosher Wines, whose last advertising campaign is said to have been the largest for promotion of its beverages, has appropriated $100,000 for a larger drive preceding the coming Passover holiday season, it was announced yesterday by Jack Schapiro, president.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 16 -- A somber warning to the United Nations that it may soon be well advised to abandon its three-year search for an effective control of the world's armaments as something futile, wasteful and even dangerous was sounded here today by spokesmen for the United States and Britain.

After hearing a dozen speakers plead for additional appropriations for schools and libraries, the Board of Estimate completed yesterday its public hearing on the proposed 1950 capital budget of $223,432,673. The board has until Dec. 2 to act on the budget and to submit it to the City Council.

DETROIT, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings took advantage of Chicago penalties to score a 4-1 decision over the Black Hawks tonight before 10,711 fans. Three Detroit scores came while Chicago was shorthanded.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Examiner Ralph L. Wiser recommended today that the Civil Aeronautics Board authorize United Airlines to fly between Los Angeles and Hawaii.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- Management should exert every effort to make collective bargaining effective because a breakdown in such negotiations may result in unsatisfactory compulsory arbitration, Herman W. Steinkraus of Bridgeport, Conn., president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, warned today.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Nov. 16 -- After a stormy public hearing that began last evening and continued far into the night, Mayor Edward Ingalls and four Scarsdale village trustees voted unanimously at 3 A. M. today to sustain a ban against construction of houses on radiant-heated concrete slabs that lack air space underneath.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 16 -- Dr. T. F. Tsiang, head of the Chinese delegation to the United Nations General Assembly, today proposed the formation of a new Liberal party to fight for China's independence both at home and overseas.

Robbie Masterson, pianist, and Gosta Englund, baritone, gave a joint recital last night at Times Hall. Miss Masterson was heard in the Schubert-Tausig Andantino with Variations, Chopin's Scherzo in B minor, Brahms' Rhapsody in G minor, Liszt's "Dance of the Gnomes," Liapunoff's "Carillon" and briefer pieces.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration today ruled all combat-type air-craft off National Airport in a move aimed at preventing a recurrence of the recent mid-air collision here that took fifty-five lives.
Presentation of the Cygnet Cup, 104 years old, was made last night at the annual cruise dinner of the New York Yacht Club in the clubhouse at 37 West Forty-fourth Street.

Establishment of a new union organization to represent performers in television, known as Television Authority, was voted yesterday by the Associated Actors and Artistes of America, AFL parent of all actor groups. The Four A's board met at the Hotel Astor.

The factory property at 1875-1879 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, for many years the manufacturing headquarters of the McCurrach Neckwear Company, has been purchased by the A. P. Realty Corporation, of which Joseph Silver is president, for occupancy by the Silver Refrigeration Manufacturing Corporation.

Free form mirrors may act as a contrast to the straight lines of some contemporary furniture, Sebet Silverman, mirror designer for the Nurre Company, Inc., said at a luncheon for interior decorating editors at the Park Lane Hotel yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- A three-judge special court today ruled 2 to 1 against Colonial Airlines in its fight to stop parallel service by Canadian planes on its Montreal-New York flight.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The text of President Truman's toast at a state dinner honoring the Shah of Iran follows:

For dress or play, country or town, the selection of clothes presented yesterday afternoon by Casual Clothes at a luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel would fill the bill for the most discriminating woman.
Public utility companies went ahead yesterday with the raising of equity capital through the offering of new common stock to holders of outstanding company stock.

BERLIN, Nov. 16 -- Russian hopes of balancing the new stature of the Western Republic resulting from the Paris meeting of the Western Big Three foreign ministers by renewed agitation for German unity were set back today when Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Western Chancellor, forbade a meeting of the Communist-sponsored Nauheim Circle in Western Germany.

The House Committee on Un-American Activities disclosed last night in Washington that it was looking into the validity of non-Communist affidavits filed by officers of the left-wing United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers.

Within a short while Coach E. E. (Hook) Mylin will bid his N. Y. U. squad adieu and move to a new football post. What he intends doing at the end of the season has not been revealed, but at the moment he is busy as ever concentrating on a much desired victory for the Violets.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 16 -- Following are excerpts from a speech given today by Hector McNeil, British Minister of State, in the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee debate on the Russian proposal for a Big Five pact:

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower deplored yesterday what he called "too great a pessimism and sense of defeatism" on world affairs in this country and said that with the nation's great resources it should adopt a spirit of optimism.

LONDON. Nov. 16 -- Ignoring an appeal by the important Trades Union Council to suspend all wage negotiations pending its report on the effects of devaluation on the cost of living, the representatives of 2,500,000 British workers reaffirmed their determination today to press their demand for general wage increases.

With international stars studding the cast, the Ice Follies of 1950 opens tonight at Madison Square Garden. The Follies will run nightly through Tuesday, Nov. 29, with matinees also slated for next Sunday and Sunday, Nov. 27.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Public Housing Administration took the first major step today toward carrying out the Housing Act of 1949 in announcing loans to 108 communities to cover the cost of plans for 134,500 units of low rent housing.

A United States Air Force B-29 bomber carrying twenty men went down in the Atlantic somewhere near Bermuda at about 10:50 A. M. yesterday. By last night the biggest peacetime air-sea rescue search in history was under way.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16 -- The Philadelphia Orchestra repeated tonight at a special anniversary concert in the Academy of Music the program of its first concert played by Fritz Scheel and his musicians fifty seasons ago on Nov. 16, 1900.

Coin-operated ice-vending machines now being installed throughout the country pay as high as 23 per cent profit annually on capital investment, and installations are due to more than double next year, it was learned yesterday.

Terms of the forthcoming offering of bonds and preferred stock of the Connecticut Light and Power Company became known in underwriting circles yesterday following official state authorization of the company's proposed sale of the bonds by negotiation.
A new technique that makes it possible for the first time to view the interior of cancer cells by means of the electron microscope, which can magnify up to 200,000 times, was announced yesterday.

The Cities Service Company placed its common stock on a $4 annual basis yesterday with declaration of a quarterly dividend of $1 a share. Directors also declared a special dividend of $1 a share. Both payments will be made on Dec. 19 to stockholders of record of Nov. 25.

CULPEPER, Va., Nov. 16 -- The will of the late Edward R. Stettinius Jr., former Secretary of State, was admitted to probate today in the Culpeper County Court here. The entire estate, valued at $320,000, was left to his widow, the former Virginia Wallace.
TORONTO, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Hatuey of the Mexican Army team, ridden by Capt. Ruben Uriza, tonight won the military handy course event at the Royal Winter Fair horse show after two exciting jump-offs.
A dozen seniors at Queens College are taking a practical lesson in sociology this week.

Executives of the food industry joined last night in ceremonies officially starting the Food Law Institute, Inc., formed to develop post-graduate instruction and research in food law at schools of law throughout the country.

Yesterday morning the fashion press had a preview of the new Jay Thorpe fifth floor. In this attractive setting the bridal and boudoir attire departments will be located. The decor, handled in delightful taste, provides a pleasing setting for the exquisite merchandise presented to yesterday's audience. The floor will be opened to the public today.
The inexorable advance of the Communist armies in China has closed another phase in the checkered history of United States policy in the Orient.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange failed to develop any trend yesterday and closed 2 points lower to 4 points higher.

BOSTON, Nov. 16 -- The National Association of Housing Officials authorized its board of governors today to appoint a committee to study the "problem of tenant selection and displacement of minority groups" in public housing and redevelopment projects.

Provision of educational opportunity is unique among the responsibilities of government. When government fails to provide proper facilities on schedule, as the arrival of children at the school door creates demand, the children -- and our democratic society -- suffer a loss that cannot be fully repaired at any later time.

A substantial recovery was negotiated yesterday by the stock market, which wiped out Tuesday's losses and part of Monday's. The motor issues provided the spark for the rally and were joined later by the chemical, film, construction and rail groups.

Ever since China first opened her door to international trade, each of the big powers in Europe has sought to secure a preferred or dominant position in trade and investment or a special privilege of exploitation and political control. The American people and the Chinese people have always fought jointly against this, and the cold war against single big-power sphere of influence in China is now raging.

BUFFALO, Nov. 16 -- No one group and no one political party deserves all the credit for the social legislation that has contributed to public welfare development in New York State, Robert T. Lansdale, state commissioner of social welfare, declared tonight.
Richard A. Rice Jr. has been named research analyst of the Greyhound Corporation, Chicago. He succeeds Dr. Richard R. Mead, who has resigned to return to the teaching profession in California.

ST. LOIUS, Nov. 16 -- Mrs. Carleton S. Hadley paused long enough in preparations today for her wedding to Vice President Alben W. Barkley on Friday to display part of her wedding trousseau to friends.

The increasing responsibility of unions in company administration will continue, it was predicted last night by Prof. Neil W. Chamber lain of Yale, at a meeting of the Office Executives Association of New York, Inc., in the Belmont-Plaza Hotel.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin conceded today that there was no reason to continue recognizing the Nationalist Government in China but he said the British Government had not yet decided to recognize the rival Communist regime.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 16 (UP) -- Britain's Minister of State Hector McNeil and Russia's Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky fought a "battle of fables" today and their listeners in the United Nations Political Committee adjudged it a diplomatic stand-off.

The merger of the Congregational Christian churches and the Evangelical Reformed Church would "jeopardize the freedom of expression" now enjoyed by Congregational ministers, it was testified yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court, where the proposed union is being contested in a civil action.
Robert Frost, New England poet, recited three of his poems in expressing appreciation yesterday for the gold medal awarded to him by the Limited Editions Club.

From Philadelphia, where "Signor Chicago" is being tried out at the Locust Street Theatre, Joseph M. Hyman sent word yesterday of the indefinite postponement of the play's Broadway opening. The Edward Chorodov comedy, adapted from the Granville Barker version of the Quintero brothers' Spanish play, "The Women Have Their Way," was to have opened next Wednesday evening at the Lyceum Theatre.

BOSTON, Nov. 16 -- The National Association of Housing Officials authorized its board of governors today to appoint a committee to study the "problem of tenant selection and displacement of minority groups" in public housing and redevelopment projects.

The merger of the Congregational Christian churches and the Evangelical Reformed Church would "jeopardize the freedom of expression" now enjoyed by Congregational ministers, it was testified yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court, where the proposed union is being contested in a civil action.
Robert Frost, New England poet, recited three of his poems in expressing appreciation yesterday for the gold medal awarded to him by the Limited Editions Club.

From Philadelphia, where "Signor Chicago" is being tried out at the Locust Street Theatre, Joseph M. Hyman sent word yesterday of the indefinite postponement of the play's Broadway opening. The Edward Chorodov comedy, adapted from the Granville Barker version of the Quintero brothers' Spanish play, "The Women Have Their Way," was to have opened next Wednesday evening at the Lyceum Theatre.
ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 16 -- The Turkish Government announced tonight it had smashed a plot to assassinate President Ismet Inonu.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 16 -- Plans by the national Girl Scout movement for increased work in the rural sections of the nation were outlined here to the thirtieth annual convention of the organization.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson reported optimistically today on last week's three-power talks in Paris, paying tribute at the same time to he West German leaders for the unity, vigor and seriousness of heir efforts to rehabilitate their country.

The Washington Suburban Sanitary District, Md., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Dec. 1 on $7,000,000 of water and general construction and drainage bonds dated Dec. 1, 1949, and due on Dec. 1, 1950 to 1989.
The 1950 Ford models will go on display in dealer showrooms here tomorrow, C. J. Seyffer, Northeastern regional manager of the Ford Motor Company, announced yesterday. Prices are unchanged.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The General Executive Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union today made an initial allotment of $100,000 for the new ILGWU officers' training school.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Council of the Organization of American States today overwhelmingly elected Dr. Luis Quintanilla of Mexico as chairman and Dr. Hector David Castro of El Salvador as vice chairman.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Noble Impulse won at first asking for his new owner, Justin Funkhouser of Charleston, W. Va., when he sped to a three-length victory over the heavily favored Imacomin in the Brown Prince II Purse at Pimlico today.

Further depletion of New York's water reserves caused the city to appeal again to the public yesterday to cut down as much as possible on the use of water. Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, said public cooperation had been "disappointing" in recent weeks.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (UP) -- The season's first heavy snow spread over the Midwest today.

WARSAW, Nov. 16 -- The ousted leaders of the central committee of the Polish United Workers (Communist) party -- former Vice Premier Wladyslaw Gomulka and his associates -- have gone through their trials and tribulations unrepentant of their ideological sins. President Boleslaw Beirut reported today.
