HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 16 -- Warner Brothers has acquired "The Feature Syndicate Story," a screen yarn by Charles Grayson, and has engaged Grayson to expand it into a photoplay, the studio announced today. The story is described as a composite treatment of the careers of several chieftains of the great newspaper syndicates of the United States.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 16 -- The Rev. Dr. Nelson M. Burroughs of Cincinnati was consecrated today as Bishop Coadjutor of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Ohio, with the right of succession to Bishop Beverley D. Tucker.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The threat of a strike of West Coast seamen developed today while the Government was still busy trying to keep shipping labor peace on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts.
New issues of first mortgage bonds and $100 par value preferred stock of the Missouri Power and Light Company will be placed on the market today by investment bankers.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 16 -- Hector McNeil of Britain informed Russia today that the British Broadcasting Corporation's programs were breaking through Soviet jammings and could be heard regularly in the Moscow area, mornings, afternoons, and evenings.

After advancing into new high ground in early trading, coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday met general selling late in the session and prices declined approximately 100 points from the high levels for the session.

One of the most difficult problems facing the armed services of the United States in development of long-range guided missiles is an accurate guidance and control system, Capt. Ralph S. Barnaby, USN, retired, declared yesterday.

TORONTO, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 1 -- 0, tonight in a National Hockey League game marked by a brilliant goal tending duel between Turk Broda and Bill Durnan.

A book by Sir John Boyd Orr, who recently received the Nobel Peace Prize, will be published by the Public Affairs Press of Washington early next year. Tentatively titled "Toward a New World Order,'' it will present the author's views on international affairs dealing especially with the relationship of science, health and food to peace.

The United States Trust Company of New York, trustee of the Eugene Higgins Estate, has sold the "fee" under the ten-story and penthouse apartment building on a plot 102.2 by 47 feet at 2242-46 Broadway, northeast corner of West Eightieth Street, to the Varuna Investing Company, it was announced yesterday.

The five-story building on lot 19 by 100 feet at 127 East Sixty-first Street containing a three-room apartment and eight suites of two rooms each was purchased by an investor from Mrs. Ann N. McMillan in a deal negotiated by Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers.

Advocates of voluntary "fair trade" as a protective device for the small retailer against price-cutting competition of larger organizations were assailed yesterday for indirectly branding the smaller merchandiser as inefficient and in need of a "special subsidy at expense of the public."
MONTREAL, Nov. 16 (Canadian Press) -- British shipowner Edmund Watts threw the rule book into the briny deep when he decided to build the Wanstead, a freighter with luxury-liner trimmings.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- Preston Tucker assigned the job of building transmissions for the Tucker car to his mother's machine-tool company, although it was not equipped for the job, Herbert Morley, former vice president of the Tucker Corporation, told a Federal District Court jury today.

Annie Birnback sold the five-story fifty-four-family apartment house at 1524-1530 Longfellow Avenue, the Bronx, to Hugh K. McGovern, operator. The property, on a plot 100 by 100 feet at the northeast corner of 172d Street, is assessed at $142,000.

The war memorial committee of the State Medical Society announced yesterday award of the first ten of a series of scholarships for children of thirty-four members of the society who gave their lives while medical officers in the last war.

A warning that the electric and gas companies of the nation were overloading the debt end of their capital structures was given yesterday before the Society of Security Analysts by Harry Miller, president of the National Association of Railroad and Utility Commissioners.

WE went out to Lake Success yesterday to look at the United Nations in action as a prelude to reviewing "Peace on Earth,"* a challenging new book with chapters by Eleanor Roosevelt, Hebert V. Evatt, Ralph Bunche, Benjamin Cohen, Carlos Romulo, Charles Malik, Sir John Boyd-Orr and others, and an introduction by Robert E. Sherwood.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16 -- Resolutions condemning a United Nations proposal to internationalize Jerusalem and supporting the United Nations declaration on human rights and the anti-genocide convention were adopted today by the annual convention of Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization of America.

The more healthy babies brought to St. Luke's Hospital on Monday mornings the fewer sick children seek treatment in the pediatric clinic. That is because the sessions are held in a Well Baby clinic to detect and prevent disease.

Emil Schram, chairman of the March of Dimes campaign for the Greater New York Chapter of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, announced yesterday that $122,000 had been raised by the initial gifts committee toward a committee goal of $1,000,000.

Wallace Ford, veteran stage and screen actor, has been engaged for a featured role in Hal Wallis' "The Furies," which Anthony Mann is directing for Paramount release. . . . Also from Paramount comes news that Jimmy Lydon will be seen in a supporting role in "September," the Hal Wallis production starring Joan Fontaine and Joseph Cotten.

With a display of harmony too rare in its history thus far, the General Assembly of the United Nations has adopted unanimously and without any abstentions a program for world-wide economic development which Assembly President Romulo rightly hails as one of its most constructive acts of international statesmanship.
ROME, Nov. 17 -- Pope Pius XII implicitly supported today the United States arms program for Western Europe as the most effective weapon under present circumstances to preserve peace.

Longer-term Government bonds continued to register fractional advances yesterday, taking eleven of the Treasury issues to new high price levels for the year. At the present levels, the longest-term bonds ineligible for commercial bank ownership are at a yield basis of 2.29 per cent to maturity in 1972 and of 2.25 per cent to call in 1967.
LONDON, Nov. 17 (UP) -- The King and Queen and the two Princesses drew more attention tonight than the Hollywood stars assembled for the yearly command performance of a hit film.

Moses A. Leavitt, executive vice chairman of the Joint Distribution Committee, returned yesterday on the French liner Ile de France from a two-month survey of conditions in Europe and Israel to report that about 146,000 Jewish survivors of European concentration camps still need aid from his organization to establish new homes in Israel and elsewhere.

The one-story building at 61136117 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, containin five stores, has been sold by Alfred Barr to David Kaplan, Charles Schultz was the broker. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Nov. 17 -A spectacular fire, which raged for nearly five hours, caused damage estimated at $500,000 today to a six-story dehydrating plant here of the General Foods Corporation at 319 Barrow Street, at Railroad Avenue.

In a move based on opposition to the single salary schedule, which provides equal pay for teachers on all levels of the city's public school system, the High School Teachers Association has withdrawn from the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations.
In six of the present exhibitions of painting here the opposing teams of realists and fantasists are about evenly matched, with the latter having slightly shorter odds.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17 -The Federal Government advised a jury of eight men and four women today that it would produce witnesses to "prove" that Harry R. Bridges, the West Coast longshoremen's leader, was "not only a member of the Communist party but a party-disciplined Communist" at the time of his naturalization in September, 1945.

Columbia, which has experienced naught but adversity since the first two weeks of this disastrous football season, may be without the services of two defensive mainstays in its finale against Brown at Baker Field tomorrow.
The versatility and decorative interest of wallpaper murals for rooms -- be they traditional or modern -- is demonstrated once again by James Seeman, who has just introduced a new collection.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The entire Cabinet and at least twelve Governors will attend the $100-a-plate Democratic fund-raising dinner in New York Dec. 2. The occasion will honor Vice President Alben W. Barkley and Speaker Sam Rayburn.
BERLIN, Nov. 17 -- Walter Ulbricht, Deputy Premier of the Eastern German Government, announced today the integration of that administration into the Soviet-dominated economic area of Eastern Europe.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -Government mediators were working today to avert shipping strikes on both the East and West Coasts next Tuesday.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- In another of his periodic press conferences Sir Stafford Cripps expressed limited optimism today on Britain's economic progress since devaluation. The Chancellor of the Exchequer painted a picture of steady, if slow, improvement of the nation's situation.
MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 17 (UP) -An Air Force C-74 Globemaster took off for England at 3:35 P. M. today with 103 persons on board, the largest number ever to fly the Atlantic in a heavier-than-air craft.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 17 -- Syria's election has created a situation that appears to make inevitable a moderate progressive policy as long as the newly elected Constituent Assembly is the basis of authority.

BUFFALO, Nov. 17 -- A compresensive survey of the people in New York State who make up the home relief caseload is being undertaken by the State Department of Social Welfare, Alden E. Bevier, administrative staff officer of the department, made known today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 -Thirteen Pennsylvanians tonight became members of the national board of directors of Yeshiva University, New York, the first liberal arts college in American under Jewish auspices.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The United Steelworkers of America, CIO, today rejected a strike settlement proposal offered by the Aluminum Company of America for about 16,000 employes in nine plants in nine states.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Nov. 17 -- Msgr. John O'Grady warned here today that amendments to the Social Security Act now pending in the Senate would cap a series of moves that "threaten the very foundation of the whole social security system as originally planned."

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 17 -- Although improvement shows only to a small extent in the indexes, business in the Pittsburgh district last week began the upward march from the low levels prevailing in October, according to the Bureau of Business Research.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -The Federal Power Commission today scheduled for Dec. 7 a consolidated hearing in this city on applications for expanded natural gas service in the New York-New Jersey area. The applications are from Transcontinental Gas Pipeline Corporation, Houston, Tex., and South Jersey Gas Company, Atlantic City.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 17 (AP) -Twenty minor leaguers, including four bonus players, headed for the majors today as fourteen clubs picked up talent in baseball's annual draft at a cost of $182,500.

Coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange dropped precipitously again yesterday. Trading was moderately active, with contract S closing the day 105 to 141 points under Wednesday's levels. Sales for the day amounted to 35,250 bags, compared with 35,000 in the previous session.

Dollar volume of retail housewares for the final quarter of the year in most outlets is exceeding expectations so far, buyers reported yesterday. In the period from Oct. 1 to the present-dollar sales are running from 5 to 10 per cent ahead of the comparable period last year, they reported.

PROVIDENCE, Nov. 17 -- A single-celled animal with three sexes has been discovered by Prof. Paul B. Weisz in the Arnold Biological Laboratory of Brown University. Professor Weisz said he found "three sexes in the blepharisma [the single cell], all equivalent. They fuse together and exchange nuclei."
LONDON, Nov. 17 -- A small increase in buying, much of it attributable to the recent revival in Government stocks, imparted more cheerful tone to the stock markets here today.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 17 -The season's battle of the anti-climax is scheduled for Palmer Stadium here Saturday and likely will draw the largest crowd to see Princeton play Dartmouth since the episode of the twelfth man in their 1935 snow fight.

WINFIELD, N. J., Nov. 17 -- The Winfield Mutual Corporation has authorized the board of trustees to purchase this Federally owned municipality of 700 homes at a Government-set price of $1,400,000, Delmore Brickman, executive director of the corporation, announced today.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Nov. 17 -- The churches of America were challenged here today by Miss Katharine F. Lenroot, chief of the Children's Bureau of the Federal Security Agency, to shoulder their share of responsibility in assuring a "fair chance in life" to every American child "regardless of race, creed, color, geographic location, or economic circumstance."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Nov. 12 were 635,823 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

By a vote of stockhoMers, the name of Van Diver Carlyle, Inc., New York, has been changed to Van Diver Crowe, Inc., it was announced yesterday. Philip K. Crowe, who recently returned from the Far East where he served the Economic Cooperation Administration as special representative of its China mission, is now chairman of the board.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Nov. 17 (AP) -- Delegates to the fifty-fifth annual convention of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs headed home today after choosing Buffalo as the site of their convention next November.

Dictatorship has been thrust upon Colombia. Congress has been closed, the Supreme Court discarded and the press delivered over to the complete mercy of the group of Falangists who proclaimed the candidacy of Laureano Gomez for President.

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 17 -- His Good Samaritan act in obtaining the release of a Camden citizen from a Philadelphia prison last summer may cost Camden's Mayor George E. Brunner $948. That is the amount for which he was sued today in Camden County District Court in behalf of the City of Philadelphia.

Despite new attacks on the Federal "fair trade" law, "there is no considerable thought in Congress that is advocating its repeal," it was declared yesterday by Senator Millard E. Tydings, Democrat, of Maryland. He spoke at a luncheon of the American Fair Trade Council in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

There is "new evidence that injury and death rates among mothers and infants are often lessened as much as 50 per cent when the mothers' diets are good," Dr. Charles Glen King, scientific director of the Nutrition Foundation, Inc., reported at the annual luncheon meeting of the foundation yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Discovery of the formula for stability at high levels of employment is "the major unfinished business" facing the Committee for Economic Development, Thomas B. McCabe, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board of Governors, declared yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- The mission to Washington of Prince Buu Loc and N'Guyen Dac Khe, personal envoys of former Emperor Bao Dai of Annam, was described in Viet Namese circles here tonight as the "supreme hope" for the constitution of a democratic regime in war-torn Indo-China.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Atomic Energy Commission called attention today to the country's lack of a civilian defense policy at a time of mounting fears over the possibility of atomic warfare.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission today announced an inquiry into the operations and ownership of five international radio stations which regularly handle Voice of America broadcasts for the State Department.

Two squadrons of the New York Air National Guard, suddenly mobilized by newspapers, radio, television and telephone, took to the air last night and successfully bombed mock invading forces driving on New York City.

Ninety-nine more Department of Sanitation employes pleaded guilty yesterday before a department trial Commissioner to being "absent without authority" on Oct. 17 when 1,281 drivers and sweepers feigned illness and demonstrated for better working conditions. Previously 648 workers had pleaded guilty.

When the Industrial Home for the Blind at 520 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn 16, began its work fifty-five years ago, scarcely one blind man in one hundred achieved economic independence. Today, one out of every four of the employable blind reaches that goal. This achievement has been made possible because the people of the metropolitan area have shown a steadily increasing interest in the welfare of their blind fellow-citizens.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 17 -The wireless message in which the Chinese Communist regime disowned the Chinese Nationalist delegation to the United Nations General Assembly will not be circulated to delegates as an official document.

MOSCOW, Nov. 17 -- Mrs. Paul Robeson, United States delegate to the Council of the International Democratic Federation of Women, told the opening session today, attended by delegates of nearly fifty countries, that powerful United States forces had led the nation to "the very brink of war."

The proposed merger of the Congregational Christian churches and the Evangelical and Reformed Church was attacked yesterday by witnesses in Brooklyn Supreme Court as a "step backward" for Congregational churches.

The city committed itself officially to the construction of a new lift bridge between Long Island City, Queens, and Welfare Island yesterday when the Board of Estimate made available $136,000 for the preparation of plans for the project.
Two holdups within a week by the same pair of youths proved too much last night for Max Schomer, 47-year-old proprietor of a liquor store at 297 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn.

The United States, Britain, France and Australia urged the United Nations General Assembly yesterday to adopt a resolution that would extend the life of the special Balkan investigating committee, and would call on Albania and Bulgaria to stop helping the Greek guerrillas.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 17 -- The Philippine Republic told the United Nations today that the small countries would not accept the role of "kibitzers" passively watching the great powers decide the issue of war or peace.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 17 (UP) -- Premier Enver Hoxha of Albania, worried by the growing restiveness of his people and army, is in Moscow to plead for more aid from the Soviet Union, an Albanian Government source said tonight.
Coordinated efforts by public and private agencies can do much to help Puerto Ricans adjust themselves in New York.

The Eastern Air Lines, Inc., has leased the third floor having about 17,000 square feet of space in the twelve-story office building at 565 Fifth Avenue, according to Walter Oertly Associates, Inc., brokers. The airline firm will take possession of the quarters after May of next year when alterations are completed.

Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday that he "was never more proud of New York City" than on Oct. 21, when the American Social Hygiene Association "came out flatfootedly and denied before the world" that the city was "rife with prostitution."

A change in New York's unemployment insurance law that would deny benefits to wage earners who quit their jobs voluntarily or who are not dependent upon their wages for a livelihood is being considered by a special joint legislative committee headed by Senator John H. Hughes of Syracuse.

Because the relief caseload has already exceeded the anticipated peak, the Board of Estimate approved yesterday an additional expenditure of $391,000 to increase the Welfare Department's staff by 269. The sum included $78,200 from the city's general accrual funds, with the state to provide $207,230 and the Federal Government $105,570.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 17 -- Pilaster, 5-year-old Pilate gelding that runs best when the frost is on the pumpkin, hustled off with first money of $12,850 in the mile-and-a-half Riggs Handicap today as Pimlico ended its twenty-one-day fall meeting.

Another grim picture of once quaintly rural Manhattanville was presented yesterday in a report on a two-year survey by City College of the area between 122d and 135th Streets, Eighth Avenue and the Hudson River.

Upon completion of vessels of 1,000 tons and over now under construction or on order, the oceangoing merchant fleet of the world will total over 89,000,000 deadweight tons, or nearly 13 per cent more than 1939, according to the National Federation of American Shipping.
LONDON, Nov. 17 -- The first important offer from the British labor unions to cooperate with the Government and the Trades Union Congress in restraining wage claims came today from the steelworkers.
John David Provoo, 33-year-old former staff sergeant in the Army, was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges of treason.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 17 -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley arrived this afternoon by plane and hurried to a wedding rehearsal with Mrs. Carleton S. Hadley, the 38-year-old widow he will wed tomorrow.
DON'T look now, but the football season is almost over. Tomorrow provides the grand finale for most of the collegiate teams and by nightfall next Saturday there will be only a few stragglers left.

Evidence of serious air pollution on Staten Island ha been found by a special committee that has been studying the condition for three months, it was reported yesterday by Dr. Natale Colosi, chairman of the group.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 17 -- Declaring that the cost of a compulsory government health insurance program might create a tax burden jeopardizing the country's standard of living, Adolph Schmidt, vice president of T. Mellon Sons, an investment supervision firm, said today that further study of voluntary and state health plans was desirable before the Federal Government committed itself to such a program.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 17 -- Mrs. C. Vaughan Ferguson of Schenectady, N. Y., was elected today to her third term as president of the Girl Scouts of the United States of America at the organization's thirtieth annual convention here.

Tin prices of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation were reported shaded yesterday in private deals. While the RFC price continues at 95 cents per pound, late November arrivals of tin were reported traded at 88 1/2 cents. Some metal market analysts predicted prices soon would go even lower.

Removal of restrictions on Japanese textiles will make it necessary for American manufacturers and exporters to compete with goods priced from 30 to 40 per cent under comparable merchandise produced here, according to William C. Planz, vice president of Neuss, Hesslein Co., textile merchants.

BOSTON, Nov. 17 -- President Truman, in a message to the twenty-fifth New England Conference today, expressed his belief that it was "safe to assume" the nation had weathered the worst of an inevitable readjustment following the inflationary boom of 1948.

On the wings of imagination the audience yesterday at the Plaza Hotel was transported to southern climes by a parade of attractive resort fashions styled of Erin Mills denim by several leading sportswear and pattern houses and an array of hats by Don Marshall of 53 East Fifty-fourth Street.

Ohrbach's, Inc., which operates ladies' specialty stores, transacted a larger volume of sales in its fiscal year ended on July 31, 1949 than in the preceding year, but earnings declined because of higher operating costs, the annual report showed yesterday.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 17 -- The opening session of the national convention of Young Democratic Clubs of America was split wide open today by the civil rights controversy.

ALBANY, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals unanimously upheld today the death penalty for Frank Bruno, 33 years old, of Brooklyn, who had requested the sentencing judge to omit the traditional: "May God have mercy on your soul."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Joint Committee on Reduction of Nonessential Federal Expenditures reported today that for a fourth consecutive month net reductions in Federal payroll costs had been effected by the Government.

Eight women and four men were chosen yesterday as the jury in the second perjury trial of Alger Hiss, former State Department official, which opened in United States District Court before Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard.

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- The French plan to make a great effort to start negotiations for regional freer trade blocs between now and January. The Economic Cooperation Administration will begin its report to Congress in January on what the Europeans have done toward the "integration" of their economies that Administrator Paul G. Hoffman has urged.

As of yesterday, the aggregate of Theatre Guild subscribers in twenty-one cities, including New York, was 105,243, a gain of 4,663 in comparison with last year's 100,580, according to official figures obtained from the Guild. Those devotees of the theatre crave acceptable fare.

Most of us are perfectly willing and glad to pay our taxes, knowing that without them our Government could not function. There is, however, one little item in the Government budge which your and my taxes help to pay that I, in particular, resent no end, as it helps to keep alive a hangover of superstition six thousand and more years old.

The defense in the third first-degree murder trial of Benjamin Feldman, the Brooklyn druggist accused of poisoning his wife, rested yesterday in Kings County Court after presenting the testimony of only two witnesses. Feldman, as in his previous trials, failed to take the stand in his own behalf.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 17 -Gov. Chester Bowles declared today that the special session of the General Assembly should consider restoration of cuts in the state education budget to maintain the rural supervisory school service.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 17 -- The Soviet Union demonstrated today that it was not prepared to yield one inch of ground on its stand to make a census of the world's armaments conditional upon an inventory of atomic energy. In effect, this means there can be no hope for the control or reduction of arms at this time.

ATLANTA, Nov. 17 (UP) -- Hugh Gravitt, taxi driver convicted of involuntary manslaughter in the traffic death of Margaret Mitchell, author of "Gone With the Wind," was slightly injured here tonight when his automobile crashed into a truck.

ALBANY, Nov. 27 -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein ruled in an opinion today that despite alleged illegal acts by public officials in Hamilton County, scene of a state and grand jury investigation, the state must pay the county its 1948 tax bill of $446,171.

The Department of Justice was ordered yesterday to give back to Judith Coplon, a former employe, her lipstick and other personal miscellany but was permitted to keep and use as evidence the prize items taken from her handbag last spring when she was arrested and charged with conspiracy and espionage.

The automotive issues sparked yesterday a further recovery in the stock market and, in the heaviest trading of a week, prices of some prime industrials advanced as much as 3 points. The increase of 1.49 points in the composite rate was the widest in almost two months and at no time during the session was the list under any pressure.

George (Barney) Poole, the traveling man from the famous football family, has been promoted and will be the starting right end on offense for the Football Yankees. This was announced yesterday by Coach Red Strader, who said he planned to use the wingman when his charges take on the Cleveland Browns at the Stadium Sunday.

The municipal transit system will have to find $30,000,000 a year in extra revenue if it is to meet the demand of Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, CIO, for a forty-hour week on the city-owned subway, elevated and bus lines.

LUCKNOW, India, Oct. 30 -- The abolition of feudal landlordism in the United Provinces of Agra and Oudh, a program that amounts virtually to a peaceful agrarian revolution, appears on examination, here in the capital of the province, to be going slowly and raising new social and economic problems in its wake.

ALBANY, Nov. 17 -- The board of directors of the Empire State Association of Commerce recommended today to Governor Dewey and the Legislature repeal of all permissive taxes except the county and city sales tax.

Mrs. Mary C. Rentschler, widow of Gordon S. Rentschler, former chairman of the board of the National City Bank of New York, has sold her estate property of more than fifty acres on Duck Pond Road in Matinecock, L. I., to Arnold A. Salkaln, builder, who plans to develop it with ranch-style homes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- President Truman said today that if he took action in the soft-coal dispute it would be based on Taft-Hartley procedures, but that he would use those only in an emergency. The President would give no indication of when he thought emergency action would be warranted. The dispute seems to be headed for another strike on Dec. 1.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 17 -Gov. James H. Duff and Harold E. Stassen agree that the Republican party must start appealing to the "average guy" if it is to win elections.

Arthur W. Wallander, former police commissioner, said yesterday that he never knew a Boy Scout who came into "serious trouble" with the police. Mr. Wallander spoke at a conference of Boy Scout finance committemen at the Roosevelt Hotel, at which plans to raise $2,000,000 for the Greater New York Council of the Boy Scouts of America were discussed.

Siegfried P. Brusack, operator, has purchased for investment from Rector Homes, Inc., the three attached two-family dwellings at 39-27 and 39-84 Forty-fifth Street and 39-04 Forty-seventh Street in Sunnyside Gardens, Long Island City, Queens.

Carlos P. Romulo, Philippine statesman, said last night that the newly adopted United Nations resolution to advance technical assistance to underdeveloped areas represented a special challenge to American business men and technical experts.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Fifteen members of the now - outlawed National Socialist party -- the party of the late Eduard Benes -- were disclosed tonight to have been arrested in the Communist-led Government's campaign to wipe out political opposition.
ROME, Nov. 17 (AP) -- There is disagreement among some United States Senate fact-finders about the facts of their reception in Sweden.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -Two Government agencies launched a move today to reduce the time air travelers must spend going between the downtown areas of cities and airports.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 17 -- Appearing in the unconventional role of pedagogue, Gen. George C. Marshall told a Princeton University audience tonight that no national policy could be "thoroughly realistic and continuing" without a better understanding of the lessons of history.

One listened to the strange melange of music new and old offered by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra -- Leopold Stokowski, conductor, and Wanda Landowska, harpischord soloist -- last night in Carnegie Hall, and is inclined in the retrospect of the concert to place a disproportionate value upon competent mediocrity.

Heretofore regarded by Government officials as a minor Communist party functionary, Mrs. Beatrice Siskind Johnson now is listed as one of the three top women Communist leaders in this country. Her talents were employed in the preparation of the defense of the eleven convicted Communist leaders.

LAKEWOOD, N. J., Nov. 17 -- A century of progress was shown here today as 10,000 residents and visitors jammed the main streets for the grand march opening the ten-day parade of progress in this winter resort.

Offerings of more than $23,000,000 of new common stock of the Northern States Power Company of Minnesota and the New England Electric System to stockholders of the two public utility companies are being made today, under standby underwriting contracts in which 218 investment houses in all parts of the nation are participating.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 17 (AP) -- Capt. Levi Jackson and Ferd Nadherny, both reported injured in practice scrimmages this week, will be ready for duty in the Yale backfield in Saturday's climactic game against Harvard.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Dr. Hazel K. Stiebeling, chief of the Bureau of Human Nutrition and Home Economics of the Department of Agriculture, today told the School Food Service Association that long-range dietary trends in this country, "gratifying to the nutritionist," were partly the result of the school lunch program.

In the intense struggle between Jew and Arab in the Holy Land the Christian Arab communities tend to be forgotten. These people, Christian for centuries, formed a notable quota in the New Jerusalem. They built a considerable new residential section in the now Israeli-held city.

The 65 East 76th Street Corporation obtained a mortgage loan of $850,000 at 4 1/2 per cent for twenty years from the Prudential Insurance Company of America on the ten and twelve-story and penthouse apartment building on a plot about 100 by 102 feet at 59-65 East Seventy-sixth Street, according to Title Guarantee and Trust Company, which insured title.
HAVANA, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Abe Greene of Paterson, N. J., was re-elected commissioner of the National Boxing Association over his own protests today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -Relations between the Democratic Administration and the powerful American Farm Bureau Federation, once warm and cooperative, have turned cold, and the political consequences may be far reaching.

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony, Leopold Stokowski, conductor, Wanda Landowska, harpsichord, Women's Chorus of Schola Cantorum, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 o'clock; Simon Barere, piano, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; "Don Giovanni," City Opera, City Center, 8:15; Madeline Foley, 'cello, Town Hall, 8:30; Loewenguth Quartet of Paris, Times Hall, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Unanimous industry approval was given today to a proposed United States Maritime Commission information, education and promotion program at a meeting of the joint committee for the American Merchant Marine.

Fordham received some offensive "insurance" yesterday with the return to regular duty of Tom Flanagan at right halfback as the Rams ran through a dummy scrimmage for the contest with Rutgers at New Brunswick tomorrow.

Directors of the Mathieson Chemical Corporation increased the quarterly dividend with the declaration yesterday of 62 1/2 cents a share on the common stock for payment on Dec. 23. This places the stock on an annual dividend basis of $2.50 a share, compared with the previous yearly rate of $2.

Unidentified for three days, the body of Allan Lincoln Langley, prominent viola player and composer, was claimed yesterday at the Bellevue Morgue by Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians. Identification was made on Monday through the discovery of a union card among his meager possessions.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 17 -- Two out of three machine tool users surveyed recently confirmed the view that present Internal Revenue Department depreciation policies have been putting a brake on new capital expenditures for production equipment, it was stated here today by Lloyd D. McDonald, president of the National Machine Tool Builders Association.

Five utilities in this state received permission from the Public Service Commission yesterday to issue a total of $23,575,000 of debt and equity securities. In each case, Commissioner Francis T. Mylott authorized the financing as necessary for the corporate purpose cited in the application for such approval.

Five years ago last Aug. 29 Edgar Cigelman, a 15-year-old student at the Bronx High School of Science, died of leukemia after a brief illness. He was the only son of Abraham and Mary Cigelman, who live at 75 East 190th Street in the Bronx.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned slightly easier yesterday, and final prices were 6 points lower to 1 point higher than on Wednesday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- A sustained demand for small homes for several years at least was forecast today by leading brokers from various parts of the country as the National Association of Real Estate Boards opened its forty-second annual convention here.

The Dail Eireann, the Irish Parliament was urged last night to issue an ultimatum, backed by a newly raised force of 100,000 armed men, demanding the withdrawal of all British forces and administrative personnel from the six countries of Northern Ireland.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The plan of the Long Island Lighting Company of Mineola, N. Y., for consolidation with its subsidiaries, the Queens Borough Gas and Electric Company and the Nassau and Suffolk Lighting Company, and re-capitalization of the surviving company was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

If he decides to intervene in the soft coal strike, Mr. Truman says, he will act under the Taft-Hartley Law. Although that is as much as he would reveal yesterday, it narrows substantially the field of speculation as to the future course of events in this area of labor strife.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- Free buying of December corn by cash and export interests featured the activity on the Board of Trade today, with December and March advancing 1 cent and closing at the top, the near-by delivery being at a new high since last February.
I cannot help but express my grave doubts about the "discovery" by Prof. Francesco Cardasco of the "real" author of the "Letters of Junius," as reported on Nov. 12.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Representatives of the State Department have been in conference with Latin-American Governments concerning the possibility of concluding bilateral "investment treaties" to aid their economies, it was disclosed here today.

Each of the various aspects of China's present case has its own complications. There are contradictions and cross-purposes at work that make decisions difficult. There is a conflict between what should be done and what can be done. There is no easy and ready-made solution at hand.

Gen. Hark W. Clark, Chief of the Army Field Forces, has made arrangements with Harper Brothers for the publication of his book of war memoirs. As yet untitled, it will cover his experiences from his work as General Eisenhower's deputy in preparing plans for the North African invasion through the Italian campaign to dealing with the Russians when he was American High Commissioner and Commander in Austria.
For lack of beds, more than 400 homeless men are obliged to sleep on benches and floors in Municipal Shelter 2 at 8 East Third Street, it was learned from the Department of Welfare yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- An irate former officer and director of the Tucker Corporation testified in angry phrases today that Preston Tucker concealed expense records from him, then used abusive language to him and tried to dismiss him.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Department store sales in the week ended Nov. 12 were 9 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:

TUPPER LAKE, N. Y., Nov. 17 (AP) -- State Police reported tonight that four hunters were drowned yesterday when an aluminum rowboat overturned as they tried to cross Lake Eden in northern Hamilton County.

ENDICOTT, N. Y., Nov. 17 -The range of the human mind can be increased to unimaginable proportions by multiplying a little ingenuity with the tremendous factors of electronic speed and accuracy, according to leading mathematicians here today.
CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Today's report of the markets in the Union Stockyards by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

A banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., submitted the best bid yesterday for $3,415,000 of improvement bonds of Milford, Conn., due Oct. 1, 1950 to 1969. The bid was 100.329 for interest of 1.70 per cent. Subject to award, the bonds were reoffered at tax-exempt yields ranging from 0.70 per cent to 1.90 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- President Truman today described the imprisonment of Angus Ward by Chinese Communists as an outrage.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Shah of Iran was elected honorary captain of the George Washington, University football team today.

Fashions are not foisted on the public. In fact, designers actually work to flatter the American woman. In general, this was the information gleaned at the New-Horizons-in-Fashion luncheon held at the Brooklyn Museum and sponsored by the Community Committee of the Design Laboratory there.

The General Assembly of the United Nations yesterday defeated without the formality of a vote a Polish move to condemn the Western powers for alleged exploitation and mistreatment of foreign workers, particularly refugees.

Net income of the North American Company in the twelve months to Sept. 30 was $12,828,649, equal to $1.50 a share, compared with $11,335,303, or $1.32 a share in the preceding twelve months, Herbert C. Freeman, president of the utility holding company, announced yesterday.

A record post-war total of more than $383,500 was pledged yesterday for the 1950 promotional campaign of the manufactured ice industary, during the third day of national convention sessions at the Commodore Hotel. More than 525 companies pledged the fund out of about 1,800 which are members of the National Association of Ice Industries, trade organization sponsoring the national merchandising and advertising program.

Prices of large and medium Grade A eggs and of several cuts of meat are lower today than they were a week ago. Broilers and fryers, roasters and small turkeys, as well as a variety of vegetables, are up in price since last Friday. These are the changes that the City Department of Markets noted yesterday in its weekly survey of retail food costs.

The pathetic but illegal spectacle of landless Sicilian peasants moving to occupy and till uncultivated land in their inhospitable island calls attention to a very old problem that still remains to be solved. A few weeks ago the same thing happened in Calabria, the mountainous toe of the mainland, and that agitation was accompanied by bloodshed.

In an effort to iron out major defects in the New York University football team's blocking patterns, Coach Hook Mylin devoted most of yesterday's practice to work on dummy and sled equipment. The remainder of the drill took the form of a scrimmage between the varsity and the scrubs.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Shah of Iran appealed frankly for United States military and economic aid today, linking the security of his country directly with the peace and prosperity of the world.

The pattern of intervention followed by the United Nations, which has proved effective in the missions to Palestine, Indonesia and Korea, should provide confidence for the solution of impending disputes, including those "between the East and the West," Dr. Ralph Bunche, who was acting mediator in Palestine, declared yesterday.

A proposal to create a joint committee to study methods of reducing frozen food warehouse costs was approved yesterday by William M. Walsh, president of the National Association of Frozen Food Distributors, Inc., at an industry luncheon in the Statler Hotel.

Holders of the 4 per cent first mortgage bonds of the Western Maryland Railroad Company due on Oct. 1, 1952, were invited yesterday to assent to an exchange of their bonds for new general mortgage obligations to mature in 1969, to bear 4 1/2 per cent interest until 1952 and 4 per cent interest thereafter, and to have a sinking fund intended to retire annually 1 per cent of the outstanding bonds.
The first airline version of the Douglas Aircraft Company's new Super DC-3 made a round-trip demonstration flight between La Guardia Airport and Montreal yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- The Illinois Agricultural Association, representing 167,000 Illinois farmers, accused Secretary of Agriculture Brannan today of misusing his authority. The organization demanded a curb on his activities in connection with the formulation of agricultural policies.

A two-story taxpayer building will be erected on lot 18 by 100.5 at 40 East Fifty-third Street, between Madison and Park Avenues, as the result of the sale of the five-story structure now on the site, by Frederick Brown, to a syndicate represented by Edward L. Lane, broker, and Culver Hollyday Co., co-brokers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UP) -- Secretary of the Army, Gordon Gray, today announced the appointment of a board of generals to review Army Negro manpower policies.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is scheduled to speak at the first mass assembly of metropolitan area Army Reservists in the Kingsbridge Armory, Kingsbridge Road and Jerome Avenue, the Bronx, Sunday at 3 P. M.

Mayor O'Dwyer and Miss Sloan Simpson, fashion stylist, were in Saratoga Springs late yesterday afternoon as weekend guests of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Sweeny at the Gideon Putnam Hotel. Miss Joan O'Dwyer, the Mayor's niece, will join them today.

Even those individuals with no immediate or even future prospects of owning a $5,000 pair of boule and counter partie cabinets may enjoy spending a leisurely half hour wandering through the rooms of Sloane's House in Town, which will be open to the public on Monday.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The Communists continued to edge closer to Chungking today.
Reappearance of the Ice Follies at Madison Square Garden last night testified once more to the popularity of such skating shows.

The 1949 Lasker awards of the National Committee for Mental Hygiene were presented yesterday to Miss Mildred C. Scoville, executive associate of the Commonwealth Fund, and Albert Deutsch, newspaper columnist and author, at the committee's fortieth annual meeting at the Statler Hotel.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) announced yesterday the formation of a new subsidiary, Esso Shipping Company, to centralize marine transport operations that have been handled in the past by the concern's marine department.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- J. Hayden Alldredge, a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission, said today that American railroads were approaching the limit on passenger transportation charges. He warned Congress that it might have to consider Federal subsidy of the railroads if losses in passenger revenue continue.

THE surviving Indian tribes of the Southwest, says John Collier, are "the mountain peaks of a submerged social continent." And, although he does not make the comparison himself, it is plain that to Mr. Collier that continent is much like lost Atlantis. Its culture, its "cosmic soul," as Mr. Collier likes to call it, is spiritually superior to that of white, Western civilization.

For an American to appreciate the volume and effect of Soviet propaganda, it is necessary for him to remember that the government owns and controls all media of information -- newspapers, books, magazines, radio, ballet, theatres, motion pictures, and, just recently, television, since video broadcasts were started last January in Moscow and Leningrad, and television sets can be purchased in both cities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- A proposal to withdraw Federal Reserve support of the Government bond market was attacked before the Congressional Economic Inquiry today as a "breach of faith" with the banking community that would impair the deposits of every man, woman and child in the United States.

Bernard M. Baruch, financier and adviser to Presidents, disclosed yesterday he plans to will his entire estate for the promotion of physical medicine and rehabilitation, two subjects long close to his heart.

Your editorial on "Philosophy in the Soviet Style" in THE TIMES of Nov. 5 raises a number of interesting questions of general importance. I think it is incorrect to say that "the Stalinists go back to a straightforward, old-fashioned materialism," however modified.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 17 -- The Allied High Commission announced today that the Western Federal Republic would be permitted to join the International Patent Institute at The Hague and the European customs union study group in Brussels.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 17 -Announcement of an alleged plot to assassinate President Ismet Inonu and Celal Bayar, leader of the Democratic party, principal Opposition group, was received today with astonishment bordering on incredulity.
TORONTO, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Mexico tonight captured the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show fault-and-out stake with a flawless performance by Capt. Ruben Uriza, riding Hatuey.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Anton Preisinger, the man who has been chosen to play the role of Jesus Christ in next year's Passion Play at Oberammergau, confirmed today that he had been a Nazi.
In your issue of Oct. 16 I read in Arthur Krock's column a most revealing quotation from a letter sent by Thomas Jefferson to John Jay in 1785:

A raucous and violent meeting of the National Maritime Union at St. Nicholas Arena on West Sixty-sixth Street last night marked the opening move in an attempt by union incumbent officers to stem a wildfire revolt.
Stanley M. Isaacs, the only non-Democrat in the new City Council, said yesterday that the results of the last election proved that abolishing proportional representation was a "tragedy."

BERLIN, Nov. 10 -- Along one segment of the boundary dividing the Soviet and French sectors the border runs down the middle of the Bernauerstrass. Shops on the Soviet side of the street have a deserted air, and only sparse wares in their show-windows.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin and Winston Churchill, who usually think so much alike on British foreign policy, disagreed sharply in the House of Commons today on the dismantling of German industrial plants for reparations.

STOCKTON, Calif., Nov. 17 -Two B-29 Superfortresses on a mass training flight of thirteen planes over the Far West collided 27,000 feet above this city just before last midnight, and only three of the twenty-one crew members had been found alive by tonight.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -The Maritime Commission proposed today a way in which Hoboken, N. J., might recover piers taken over by the Federal Government during World War I.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 17 (AP) -Combined shots of liquid radioactive gold and the new war gas, nitrogen mustard, are healing 82 per cent of rat and mice cancers at the Medical College of Virginia, Richmond.

KATONAH, N. Y., Nov. 17 -Three simultaneous fires today in St. Luke's Episcopal Church here caused $2,000 damage and the police arrested a 15-year-old boy from Lackawanna, N. Y., on charges of having started them for a thrill.

The instinct for building, each after his fashion, is common to beavers, birds and bees. It is also strongly entrenched in the featherless biped, known (for reasons which at the moment are not too evident) as homo sapiens.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 17 -- Twentieth Century-Fox today purchased screen rights to George Howe's new novel, "Call It Treason," for a price reported to be slightly under $50,000. The deal was negotiated by Ned Brown of the Famous Artists agency.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The public will see for the first time next Sunday the valuable collection of Austrian art treasures recently brought here. The exhibits will be on view at 5 P. M., in the National Gallery of Art and will continue through Sunday, Jan. 22.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Two red flares spotted in the ocean 240 miles northeast of Bermuda and faint radio signals spurred the search tonight for survivors of a B-29 that crash-landed off his island with twenty men aboard.

Consolidated net earnings of $8,200,013 for the thirty-nine weeks ended on Sept. 24, last, were reported yesterday by the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and all its subsidiaries including the National Theatres Corporation and Roxy Theatre, Inc.

PARIS, Nov. 17 (UP) -- Garry Davis, who renounced his United States citizenship to become a "citizen of the world," said today that he might try to get it back so that he could fight racial prejudice in the United States.

William H. Byrne, director of the Smoke Control Bureau, points out that not all of New York's smoke nuisance springs from the immediate processes of furnace combustion of fuel and refuse. There are many other causes of air pollution from fuel burning, ranging all the way from practices followed in the operation of heating plants to simple cleaning and care of property.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Nov. 17 -- Steel output at the Republic Steel Corporation's open-hearth plant here was halted today, when eleven open-hearth charging machine operators walked out.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., Nov. 7 -Since the death last week of Senator Clyde M. Reed of Kansas speculation has been brisk as to his successor. No comment has come from Gov. Frank Carlson regarding a selection.

Station WNEW, one of the country's most successful independent stations, is being sold by Arde Bulova and Milton Biow for a sum "substantially more than $2,000,000," it was made known yesterday. The sale is subject to approval by the Federal Communications Commission.

LONDON, Nov. 17 (UP) -- Winston Churchill warned in today's debate that Albania, completely under Russia's thumb and lying just off the Mediterranean, was a new world danger spot -- with Russians running its big submarine base.

The United States must remain militarily and economically strong if she wants to triumph in the East-West struggle, Dr. George S. Counts, Professor of Education at Columbia University's Teachers College, declared yesterday at a press conference.

Backless sundresses, functionally cut hunting clothes, such smart touches on formal gowns as pieces of eagle down in sockets of mallard duck and a striking hat of moose hair were features of the American Indian fashion show presented yesterday at the Twenty-One Club, 21 West Fifty-second Street.

ARLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 17 -- The hunters in this valley, who have to climb the hills to hunt, insist that their shooting is much better after the New Yorkers have shouted in the hills a few days and driven the deer across the line.

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- Although the Cabinet has been working for a week to make good its promises to labor, two of the largest labor federations today expressed dissatisfaction and announced a one-day protest strike next Thursday.
CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks scored five goals in the second period tonight to cinch an 8-to-3 victory over the Boston Bruins fru a National Hockey League game before 12,681 fans.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- During the week ended Nov. 16, member bank reserve balances increased $287,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

In seeking possible new sources of automotive motor fuels some researchers are contemplating solar rays in terms of horsepower, according to data presented yesterday by the research laboratories division of General Motors.

Edward Seymour Hidden, suave promotor and fast-talking salesman whose business activities have been the subject of considerable shop talk among authorities of at least two nations, yesterday was being held here in $10,000 bond on a Federal charge of using the mails to defraud.
Currier Lang, president of the Norwalk, Conn., Hospital, has been elected a director of Sidney Blumenthal Co., it was announced yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 17 -- Opposition within the Democratic party to the announced candidacy of James Roosevelt for the Governorship of California began taking shape today.
" I will support to the limit any move to abolish the two-platoon and free substitution system in college football," Bob Neyland, the veteran Tennessee coach, said yesterday.

When the forces of the MacAsphalt Construction Company knocked off work yesterday afternoon, the project for resurfacing and improving Forty-second Street was 88 per cent completed, Borough President Hugo E. Rogers announced last night.

Throughout the greater part of its history, and until comparatively recent years, there prevailed in this country an unchallenged tradition that, except in time of war, the national budget should be balanced annually. So long as that tradition was respected a rough ceiling was imposed on spending, since for every dollar spent it was necessary to levy a dollar in taxes.

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony Young People's Concert, Dean Dixon, conductor; Paul Tripp, narrator, Carnegie Hall, 11 o'clock; Frank Glazer, piano, Carnegie Hall, 3; Dorothy Dring Smutz, piano, Town Hall, 3; Yi-Kwei Sze, bass-baritone, Carnegie Hall, 5:30; "Love for Three Oranges," City Opera, City Center, 2:30.

An eleventh-hour announcement by Valentin A. Gubitchev that he wanted a lawyer caused a new postponement yesterday of his trial with Judith Coplon, former Department of Justice employe, on conspiracy and espionage charges.
LaGuardia Airport and the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, were closed last night at 9:30 o'clock to all fighter type aircraft by the Port of New York Authority.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- In a swift series of talks lasting a single day Sir Stafford Cripps; British Chancellor of the Exchequer, and Paul van Zeeland, Belgian Foreign Minister, came to an agreement today that will reduce the drain of gold dollars from the British Treasury to Belgium.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Nov. 18 (AP) -- The romance of Mayor O'Dwyer of New York and Miss Sloan Simpson was a mystery again tonight after both spent the day at this resort denying wedding rumors.

Poly Prep defeated St. Paul's School of Garden City, 26 -- 19, in the nation's second oldest prep school football rivalry on the Poly Prep gridiron yesterday. It was their forty-eighth meeting, with Poly Prep now ahead in victories, twenty-four to twenty-three. There was one tie. Only the Exeter-Andover series is older.

A charge that "the revised deal" under which Pan American Airways would take over American Overseas Airlines was "even worse than the first" will be made today by Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., when it files a supplemental brief with the Civil Aeronautics Board in Washington.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 8 -- The fifth regional congress of the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine, opening here today, was told by Bishop Edwin V. O'Hara of Kansas City, ethat the confraternity's responsibility was to fit all adult Roman Catholics for intelligent discussion of the principles of their faith.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 18 -- Reuven Rubin, statesman-artist who was appointed Minister to Rumania less than a year ago, will relinquish that post next month and return to Israel "at his own request," according to an official announcement here.

Albania breaks into the news with increasing frequency since the Yugoslav schism. One of the latest items is that Premier Enver Hoxha, Moscow's clumsy and frightened proconsul to that now isolated Soviet outpost, has flown to Russia in a Soviet plane accompanied by a Red Army general.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 18 -- The Girl Scout movement in 1950-51 will emphasize spiritual values, Dr. Mary H. S. Hayes of New York, chairman of the executive committee, told 6,000 adult volunteer leaders at the closing session of the Girl Scouts' National Council today.

Six months is the most frequently accepted rate-protection period in television, according to a comprehensive study of television-station rate practices that will be released this week-end by the Broadcast Advertising Bureau. Analysis of the medium's developing-rate structure was made by BAB at request of its television standardization group, which has been drawing up standard rate card and contract forms to recommend to TV stations.
New York University will be favored by six touchdowns today when it meets City College in Lewisohn Stadium. The game is a renewal of New York's oldest football rivalry that began in 1889.

SYDNEY, Australia, Saturday, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Immigration Minister Arthur Calwell said today he will not permit the Japanese to compete in the 1956 Olympic Games in Australia, even if it costs him his job.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- A Federal district court jury today heard testimony that Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican, of Michigan, was "hell bent" on jailing Preston Tucker and that a Internal Revenue Department official in this city told an agent to get incriminating evidence "any way possible."

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Two leading members of the Agrarian party have been expelled for insincerity and "rude careerism," the Agrarian party organ Zemedelsko Zname reported today. They are Stefan Tonchev, former Transport Minister, and Yani Yanev, one of the secretaries of the Fatherland Front's National Council.
The boiling revolt within the National Maritime Union, CIO, subsided to the simmering stage yesterday as the union set plans to bring the rebellious leaders to trial.
As the result of recent price declines, the Department of Welfare will reduce monthly relief payment s somewhat less than $2 a person on the average, effective Jan. 16, it became known yesterday.
ALBANY, Nov. 18 -- Governor Dewey, in a proclamation designating Thursday, Nov. 24, as Thanksgiving Day, urged today that the people devote at least a part of the holiday to religious observance.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 18 -- Mrs. Carleton S. Hadley became the Second Lady of the land today as she exchanged marriage vows with Alben William Barkley, Vice President of the United States.

Your editorial on Nov. 6 entitled "Financing Higher Education" is a good summary of the fiscal problems facing American higher education today. It cannot be overemphasized that it is financially impossible for our colleges and universities, private or public, to exist many more years on their present basis.

Although the B-29 Superfor-tresses were the backbone of the aerial attack on Japan and are the first and only bombers to deliver atomic bombs to an enemy, they were always considered underpowered and had "bugs" in them as late as June, 1948, when a heavy modification program was ordered.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Nov. 18 -- Car owners who for two months prior to the Nov. 8 election enjoyed comparative freedom from summonses for parking violations in this city, have learned in the past ten days that there are plenty of ticket-happy policemen now.

Harbor Hospital, which acquired the Half Moon Hotel at Coney Island last March to extend its facilities, was ordered yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Charles E. Murphy in Brooklyn to pay $1,190 to eight tenants still living in the building and to continue to render hotel services.

An editorial dealing with the question of the former Italian colonies appeared in your paper of Nov. 12. In this editorial you stated that the Russians, after being defeated in the United Nations, "have had their little triumph in winning over the Somali Youth to communism."

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Nov. 18 -- Following the semi-annual meeting of its thirty-six members from all sections of the country, the Board of Christian Education of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. reported today that several new records had been set thus far this year.

The article by Tania Long from London which appeared in your issue of Nov. 6 on the subject of allegedly secret uranium mines in Soviet Central Asia seems to have confused rather than illuminated the question of Russian resources of uranium. It tended to give the impression that uranium deposits were not known of abroad until the discovery of some old geological journals in the British Museum.

"When God and the community have been so good to a man, isn't it natural that he should try to make some repayment?" As a patriot, unofficial adviser to the Government, and philanthropist Bernard M. Baruch has already cleared the mortgage on his debt to society. However, he does not consider the books closed, and has announced that he intends to bequeath his entire estate to the promotion of physical medicine.

The United States Attorney's office here announced yesterday an important step toward smashing an American Railway Express check counterfeiting ring with the indictment of five persons charged with having planned the printing and circulation of $1,000,000 in worthless travelers' checks.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 18 (UP) -- Crucible Steel Corporation tonight signed a $100-a-month pension agreement with the United Steel. workers, CIO, to end the forty-nine-day-old strike of its 12,500 employes at plants in Pennsylvania, New York and New Jersey.

Continuing acute shortages in wanted brands of television receivers has resulted in pushing of tie-in sales of automatic record changers by a major manufacturer whose video line is in great demand, retailers reported yesterday. They said distributors of the line have notified dealers that television receiver deliveries will be held up indefinitely unless record-changers are ordered in quantity.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Soft-coal operators were disappointed today with President Truman's decision against prompt intervention in the deadlock with the United Mine Workers over contract terms.

"CUNNINGHAME-GRAHAM, Robert Bontine (1852-1936), of Ardoch," the dependably useful new edition of "Chambers' Biographical Dictionary" observes "Liberal M.P., Socialist, Nationalist, wrote vivid tales, sketches, and travel books, about Menteith, Spain, South America, Morocco, conquistadors and horses."

The homemaker who is suddenly faced on a blue Monday morning with a faucet that won't stop leaking, a toaster that's spitting sparks, and a blown-out electric fuse won't give up in despair -- or even call her husband -- if she has tucked away in a corner of the kitchen two handy items.
Jackie Hyatt scored two touchdowns to lead Fordham's freshmen to a 13-7 victory over Columbia yesterday at Baker Field.

The Greek Government will "contribute significantly over the next ten years toward the establishment of a center of Greek studies" at Columbia University, Constantine Tsaldaris, Deputy Premier and Minister of Foreign Affairs of Greece, announced yesterday at the university.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Guy G. Gabrielson, the Republican National chairman, said tonight that "the alumni of the Pendergast machine are not going to be dislodged from their deep freezers in Washington by anything except an avalanche of votes."

TOKYO, Nov. 18 -- Foreign business men here are trying to persuade the Japanese Government its aims will not be realized by taxing non-yen income at the same rates it taxes yen income. The American Chamber of Commerce committee has been interviewing economic leaders and these are reported friendly.

TRENTON, N. J., Nov. 18 -- Rutgers University today asked New Jersey to appropriate $1,500,000 next year to enable the university to reduce tuition from an average of $385 to $175 a year and thus place public higher education in the state on a more democratic basis.

The Bethlehem Steel Company which has been negotiating with the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, since last May, has offered a pension plan, and executive boards and committees of the locals that cover the company's eight East Coast shipyards are to meet "immediately" to discuss the proposal, M. H. Goldstein, union counsel, said yesterday.

Token packages of the final consignment of CARE holiday packages for France, scheduled to reach there in time for Christmas were presented yesterday afternoon to Capt. Joseph Cailloce of the French liner Ile de France by Renee Jeanmaire, Roland Petit and other members of the cast of the Balletes de Paris in a brief ceremony aboard the liner.

OTTAWA, Nov. 18 -- A step in the development of a warning system against air attack across the Arctic through Canadian - United States cooperation has come to light here by the publication in an official paper of a map prosaically captioned: "Points in Canada served by the communications facilities of the Department of National Defense."

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- Reports from Bonn that M. Schuman had agreed to meet Dr. Adenauer soon after next Tuesday's Assembly debate on Germany were flatly denied by officials of the French Foreign Ministry today.

The long-term capital needs of public enterprises will figure largely in the marketing of new issues of securities next week. On Tuesday, the state of Delaware will take bids on $28,369,000 of bonds and the Loup River Public Power District, Neb., will offer an issue of $14,700,000 of revenue obligations. Corporate financing will include more offerings of new common stock to stockholders of public utility companies.

WARSAW, Nov. 18 -- Premier Joseph Cyrankiewicz has joined President Boleslaw Bierut in an attack against the Premier's former Socialist colleagues as opportunists and liberals unworthy of sharing the rule in Poland.

BERLIN, Nov. 18 -- The favorable impression the new stature accorded to the Western German Federal Republic by the Western powers in Communist-ruled Eastern Germany was revealed today by the Russians. They launched a bitter attack on Prof. Hugo Hickmann, Christian Democratic Union leader in Saxony-Anhalt, for "defending" the Western regime.

For the first time in its 100-year history, the manufactured ice industry was given a complete description yesterday of operations of a standard cost accounting system applied to a typical plant in that business. More than 400 members of the National Association of Ice Industries, in closing sessions of their thirty-second annual convention, held at the Commodore Hotel, heard Paul H. Andres, of Southwest Ice Dairy Products Co., Oklahoma City.

The statements issued this week by the U. N.'s Palestine Conciliation Commission, by the Israeli delegation to the U. N. and by the Arab League can all be viewed as part of the preliminaries to the forthcoming debate over Jerusalem in the Special Committee of the General Assembly.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange showed no trend yesterday and closed 2 points higher to 3 points lower than the day before.

Liberal democracy in the Western world appears to be losing one of its most respected members as the Colombian tragedy approaches the climax of the Nov. 27 Presidential elections. Final judgment must be reserved, but the unhappy signs of approaching dictatorship and perhaps totalitarianism are so clear that they cannot be ignored.
LONDON, Saturday, Nov. 19 -- The Soviet Union demanded the recall yesterday of the Yugoslav Charge d'Affaires in Moscow for spying against the Soviet Union, the Moscow radio announced early today.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 18 -- Secretary of the Army Gordon Gray said today that there was now "general agreement" among the joint chiefs of staff that "only in united and effective action by all our military forces" could ultimate victory in any future war be achieved.

The New York City Housing Authority has under consideration plans for issuing $41,400,000 of tax-exempt bonds for the long-term financing of four projects in the city's non-cash-subsidy building program.

Princeton's intriguing match with Dartmouth at Palmer Stadium and the sixty-sixth meeting between Yale and Harvard are the most notable of the many traditional pairings that mark the East's final heavy program of college football today.

A new burst of enthusiasm yesterday enabled the share market on the New York Stock Exchange to penetrate the highs of last year and then push ahead to the peak levels for three years. Additions ranged as high as 3 points, with the chemicals and motors again providing the impetus for the fresh rally.

Eight taxpayers obtained an order from Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter yesterday directing the city to show cause on Monday why a "summary inquiry" should not be made into alleged tax liens irregularities.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 18. -- The Presidential Palace announced today that 100 persons had been arrested in connection with a plot to burn the city of Armenia. One European of unrevealed nationality in the group was detained, the announcement added.

Nearly 30,000 children, parents and teachers flocked to THE NEW YORK TIMES third annual Boys' and Girls' Book Fair which opened yesterday for four days of festivities in the American Museum of Natural History.

Jackie Robinson, first Negro ever to play baseball in the major leagues, not to mention appearing in a world series, yesterday gained the added distinction of becoming the first of his race to win a most valuable player award.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- The Cabinet of Premier Georges Bidault, which is under the fire of attacks in party meetings, appeared tonight to have attained a breathing space providing it could survive the critical debate on Germany to be held Tuesday.

Man's first glimpse of fire, unrecorded except in the Promethean myth, must have been an instant of rare excitement. Some of the thrill of that moment stirred the other night when we came upon a group of whooping urchins just off West Side Highway swinging fire-cans against a November backdrop of crepuscular blues and purples.

Faced with the vast Soviet array of propaganda mechanisms, all designed to make the people of the world hate and mistrust America and the generosity of its post-war assistance programs, our government was confronted with the countermeasures it could adopt to tell our own positive story abroad.
Puerto Ricans in New York are confused and disturbed by the question of skin color, for the "color problem" is not a part of their culture heritage, a City College anthropologist reported yesterday.

Retail sales declined here during the week, according to estimates made yesterday. Department store sales were estimated to be about 7 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were 3 per cent lower than last year.
Three one-man shows and two group exhibitions round out the interesting attractions of painting and sculpture to be seen in New York this week.

An ample supply of chrysanthemums for Thanksgiving was predicted in the wholesale flower market yesterday. For another week at least the traditional autumn flower will probably be more abundant than any other in the florist shops.

MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L. I., Nov. 18 -- The retirement of Brig. Gen. Michael Gerard Healy, air surgeon of the nation-wide Continental Air Command for the last nine months, and the appointment of Brig. Gen. John M. Hargreaves as his successor, were announced here today.
TORONTO, Ont., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Chilean Army riders won the first two places tonight in the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show's military stake.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Representatives of Stuyvesant Town, the $90,000,000 housing project in the heart of Manhattan, told the Supreme Court today that as a private landlord the corporation had the right to select tenants of its own choice.

LONDON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- L. Hennig Co., Ltd., well-known diamond brokerage concern, was charged today with the illegal export of diamonds from London to the United States by way of Tangier to evade currency rules.

Chanting, "We've had enough! We want big time football," 800 students of the University Heights division of New York University marched on the Athletic Association Office yesterday afternoon. The demonstration was a culmination of action by various student organizations to protest school policy.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Taft-Hartley fact-finding boards created to investigate labor disputes should have authority to recommend terms for settlement and not merely report the facts, Prof. Carroll R. Daugherty, chairman of President Truman's steel strike board, declared today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The State Department today expressed its gratitude to Representative James G. Fulton, Republican, of Pennsylvania, for his offer to be a hostage for the return of Consul General Angus Ward, imprisoned by the Chinese Communists in Mukden, but declined on the grounds that the exchange would be "impracticable at this time" and probably "unproductive of the desired results."

In a letter published on this page yesterday Mrs. Gertrude C. Hornbostel called attention to some of the inconsistencies in the classification and handling of the Carville (La.) Marine Hospital operated by the United States Public Health Service. This is a segregation hospital for patients suffering from Hansen's disease (leprosy) and its operation involves extra cost for staffing, discriminatory liabilities against patients such as war veterans, and treatment of the disease in an unsuitable climate.

HONG KONG, Nov. 14 -- United States officials of the Economic Cooperation Administration's aid program in rural areas of China believe a pattern of action has been developed that could be applied effectively in solving the agrarian problems of other Asiatic countries.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 18 -- The Indian decision on recognition of the Communist Government in China will be delayed until the Government consults other Commonwealth Governments.

Two new films will have local premieres today. "Bride For Sale," a comedy-romance starring Claudette Colbert, Robert Young and George Brent, will be presented at the Criterion by RKO Radio Pictures. . . . Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will be represented at the Globe with "Border Incident," which includes among its principals Ricardo Montalban, George Murphy, Howard da Silva, James Mitchell and Arnold Moss.

Publicker Industries, Inc., and its consolidated subsidiaries, including Paco Tankers, Inc., reported yesterday a net loss of $1,487,577 for the first nine months of this year after giving effect to a $1,356,000 Federal tax credit.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 18 -- Archaeologists at the American School of Classical Studies in Athens are engaging in the restoration of the Grecian Stoa of Attalos as a museum to house the 50,000 antiquities that the school has unearthed in the last two decades.

An evening of music for the cello can often become oppressive, the instrument being a cumbersome one, and audiences usually stay away in large numbers. Both situations were happily reversed last night when Madeline Foley made her recital debut in Town Hall.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Emphasizing the serious decline in railroad revenues, Ralph Budd, chairman of the Chicago Transit Authority, tonight suggested means for bolstering the railroads so they could continue their vital position in the country's transportation. He spoke before 1,100 members and guests of the Railway Business Association.

The fifty-nine members of the United Nations were officially asked by the General Assembly yesterday to impose a complete arms embargo against Albania and Bulgaria as long as the two Balkan countries send aid to the Greek guerrillas.

Pianism in its highest estate was heard from Simon Barere, who enthralled his large audience with a display of overwhelming artistry at his recital last night in Carnegie Hall. Truly a giant of the keyboard, Mr. Barere provided a series of performances which were not only marvels of technical skill, but equally remarkable from the standpoint of tone color and poetry.
