PUSAN, Korea, Nov. 18 -- As the United States merchantman Flying Cloud, fired upon by a Chinese Nationalist warship in the mouth of the Yangtze last Tuesday, arrived here today, a representative of the United States Department of State boarded the ship to obtain a first-hand account of the incident.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 18 -- Moisture content of hides and leather, important in buying and tanning hides and manufacturing leather goods and up to now matter of rule-of-thumb guess work, can be determined scientifically with an electronic moisture meter developed in the tanners' Council of America research laboratory at the University of Cincinnati.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- Pierre Balmain achieves simple elegance, suffused with youthful charm, in a collection of spring models emphasizing sleeve importance. The rose is the chosen spring flower, rose pink and black, or black and navy being the predominating color combinations.

There are only two books published today. A revised and enlarged edition of David Ewen's "Men and Women Who Make Music," a collection of biographical sketches of singers, pianists, violinists, 'cellists and of the "harmonica virtuoso," Larry Adler, is issued by the Merlin Press, 545 Fifth Avenue, at $3. Crown is publishing at $5 the first American edition of "Music of the World: A History," by Kurt Pahlen.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Council of the North Atlantic treaty created a top-level defense Financial and Economic Committee today to keep military costs under the mutual assistance program in line with the economies and recovery goals of the twelve-member nations.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Mrs. Esther du Pont Weir's Royal Governor heads a field of fifteen tomorrow in the $10,000 added Thomas K. Lynch Memorial Handicap, opening feature of a thirteen-day meeting.
CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Velo-King Velocipede Co. announced today it would discontinue production next Wednesday, but hoped to reopen after the first of the year.

WASHINGTON, Nov, 18 -- A leading New York banker told Congress' Joint Subcommittee on the Economic Report today that depression dangers had given way to threatening inflation under pressure of government deficit spending and the planned distribution of $2,500,000,000 of veterans' dividends next year.

A possible cigarette price war between leading tobacco retailers loomed yesterday when the A. Schulte chain cut prices on standard brands of cigarettes by 2 cents a pack. The reductions, effective in several of its downtown stores only, brought prices down to 18 cents a pack or two packs for 35 cents.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 18 -- The time was when a Harvard-Yale game was football's crowning glory and everybody else was an upstart who couldn't get the time of day from Walter Camp when he picked his All-American teams.
TORONTO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- United States players dominate Eastern Canada's Big Four Football Union all-star team, it was disclosed today with publication of the 1949 mythical squad.

TOKYO, Nov. 19 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, intimated today that the United States contemplated no relaxation of its policy of "austerity," budget balancing and tax reform for Japan. Mr. Snyder made his views known at a conference with United States and Japanese press representatives.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- Spokesmen for France's major non-Communist trade union federations told United States Ambassador David K. E. Bruce, who was the guest of honor at the meeting tonight, that workers in French factories and colleries were largely unaware of how the Marshall Plan benefited them.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 18 -- Joseph Kaufman, independent producer, has signed George Raft to play the leading role in "I'll Get You for This," a melodrama by James Hadley Chase which Kaufman expects to produce next spring in Europe.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 18 -- South Africa accused the United Nations today of fomenting dangerous racial strife throughout much of Africa by "misrepresenting" the Union's policy of rigid native segregation.

Many scholarly projects and necessary undertakings are being suspended in universities because of lack of funds, Dean Paul H. Buck, Provost of Harvard University, told a group of alumni at a dinner meeting last night in the University Club, Fifth Avenue at Fifty-fourth Street.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 18 -- Marshal Tito indicated today in an interview granted to a delegation of the One World Award Committee that Archbishop Aloysius Stepinatz, Roman Catholic prelate of Croatia, would not be released from prison because of his activities against the state.
Columbia will end its least successful season in five years at Baker Field when it plays host to Brown today. Kick-off time is at 1:30 P. M.

The special report of the United Nations Commission for Indonesia was accepted by the Security Council yesterday at Flushing Meadow. Debate on the question was postponed until next month pending receipt of voluminous annexes covering the recent round-table conference at The Hague.

Customs duties, internal revenue and other taxes collected as the result of shipping activities in the Port of New York last month amounted to $19,327,248, a drop of $366,333 in receipts from the same month last year, according to the monthly report made public yesterday by Harry M. Durning, Collector of Custom.
LONDON, Nov. 18 -- Nearly all sections of the Stock Exchange ended the week on a rising note today.

Thanksgiving dinner wouldn't be complete without at least one or two side dishes of relish to pique the appetite. But these sweet-sour condiments needn't be reserved for holiday occasions. Everyday meals, too, are more interesting and palatable if a tangy accompaniment is served with them.
MARHAM, England, Nov. 18 -- A United States Air Force C-74 Globemaster landed today with 103 persons aboard, the largest number ever to fly the Atlantic in a heavier-than-air craft.

Convalescent hours for patients forced to lie flat on their backs are less tedious now at Presbyterian Hospital, where a book projector flashes each page on the ceiling above the patient's head, enabling him to read.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 18 -- The Long Island Women's Field Hockey Association's first team swept to a 4-1 victory over the Mohawk varsity from Albany today as the Northeast field hockey tournament got under way at Hofstra College.

An appeal to the State Department to intervene with the Cuban Government in the controversy over assignment of wave lengths in the standard broadcast band was voiced yesterday by the board of directors of the National Association of Broadcasters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- George M. Harrison, president of the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks, AFL, called on President Truman today and invited him to address the fiftieth anniversary dinner celebration of the union's founding on Dec. 29. The celebration will be held in Cincinnati, home office of the union.
CHICAGO. Nov. 18 (AP) -- Today's report of the markets in the Union Stockyards by the United States Department of Agriculture follows

Counsel for Alger Hiss unveiled a new defense yesterday at his second Federal perjury trial by contending that Henry Julian Wadleigh, rather than Mr. Hiss, was the individual who gave State Department secret papers to Communist agents in Washington.
Governor Dewey and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, joined yesterday in warning against further centralization of power in the Federal Government.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Shah of Iran Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, appealed for increased private American investment in his country today after a forty-minute conference with President Truman during which they discussed increased United States aid for the Middle East nation.
The annual gun dog championship of the Jockey Hollow Field Trail Club will open its preliminary trials tomorrow, with the finals to be held later at the Amwell Shoating Preserve at Amwell, N. J.

Jack Kramer continued his mastery over Pancho Gonzales in their professional tennis tour by topping the national amateur titleholder, 9 -- 11, 8 -- 6, 7 -- 5, while a crowd of 2,060 looked on last night at the Jamaica Armory in Queens.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The National Guard has reached a new high in peacetime strength as a result of a two-month recruiting campaign, Maj. Gen. Kenneth F. Cramer, Chief of the National Guard Bureau, announced today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Johnny Bratton, shifty Chicago youngster blossoming into a full-fledged welterweight, tonight scored a two-round technical knockout over Gaby (Frenchy) Ferland of Montreal in the Chicago Stadium.

BUFFALO, Nov. 18 -- Little basic difference exists between a criminal and a mentally disturbed person, Dr. David Abrahamsen, research associate in the Department of Psychiatry of Columbia University, declared today.

ATHENS, Nov. 18 -- Speaking in Salonika tonight, United States Ambassador Henry T. Grady stressed the need of full cooperation in the effort toward economic and social rehabilitation now made possible in Greece as a result of the greater security.
Thirty Navy men and women gave a pint of blood each to help save the life of the wife of a sailor who underwent a serious operation yesterday.
L. B. Taylor has been named general sales manager of the Friden Calculating Machine Company, Inc., San Leandro, Calif.

Board room austerity and the prosaic atmosphere of the counting house gave way to the bizarre last night as 1,200 leaders from the fields of politics, banking and industry good-humoredly saw themselves burlesqued in the Financial Follies, the annual "feast of the Scribes and the Pharisees," in the Astor Hotel.

No longer need homemakers suffer through two-day airing periods after painting the living room. Gone, too, is the necessity for confining any large-scale painting projects to months when the windows can be opened for ventilation.

Long after the rest of the squad had retired to the clubhouse for hot tea and bouillon, Harvey Johnson, the placement - kicking star of the New York Football Yankees worked out at the Stadium yesterday.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 18 -- Tuss McLaughry's high - flying Dartmouth eleven, seeking a possible tie for the Ivy group honors, will move into Palmer Stadium tomorrow as a favorite over Princeton's Big Three champions.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 18 -- total of 224 over-income families at Mravlag Manor and Pioneer Homes -- more than one-quarter of the present population of both Federal housing developments here -- will be served by Dec. 31 with notices to leave, the Elizabeth Housing Authority decided today.
Directors of the General Electric Company voted yesterday to pay a special dividend of 50 cents a share in addition to a regular dividend of 50 cents for distribution on Jan. 25.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 18 -- "The toughest game we will have all season" is the way Rutgers' Coach Harvey Harman has described tomorrow afternoon's meeting here with Fordham, which will be looking for its first victory over Rutgers in forty years.
TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 18 (AP) -- A B-29 off to hunt for another B-29 missing in the Atlantic crashed into the mud of Tampa Bay today, killing five of the nine-man crew. The others were injured.

Seeking to complete the bulk of spring apparel production before the end of February, women's wear manufacturers are building up worsted goods stocks at the present time, it was learned yesterday. Jobbers of wool goods reported active demand for quick delivery, particularly from cutters who cannot place direct mill orders for deliveries before the end of January.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Nov. 18 -- Government welfare plans must not be permitted to displace religious agencies from their traditional importance in the care of dependent, neglected and orphan children, the diocesan directors of Catholic charities declared today.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Czechoslovakia sent fifty-five persons to prison today on charges of spying and indicated more arrests, trials and sentences would follow in this country's mounting purge.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Average primary market prices remained unchanged in the week ending Nov. 15, according to the Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 151.5 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.4 per cent below that of four weeks ago and 7.6 per cent below the figure in the comparable week of 1948.

CHICAGO, Nov. l8 -- Residential construction has failed to keep pace with gains in post-war population and births, and work in this field should continue at a high level throughout the country at least for the next year or so, in the opinion of Dr. Harold G. Moulton, president of the Brookings Institution, Washington.

Judge Harold M. Kennedy in Federal Court, Brooklyn, refused yesterday after a hearing to broaden legally the scope of participation by Nassau County in reorganization proceedings involving the Long Island Rail Road.

ATLANTA, Nov. 18 -- Senator Walter F. George, Democrat, of Georgia, a member of the Senate since 1922, dispelled reports that he might retire at the end of his present term by announcing today his candidacy for re-election in 1950. He said a few weeks ago that he might not make the race. He will be 72 years old in January.

The Right Rev. William T. Manning, retired Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, died at 5:10 P. M. yesterday in St. Lukes Hospital, where he had been a patient since Nov. 4. He was 83 years old.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Cardinals, Archbishops and Bishops of the Roman Catholic hierarchy in the United States called today for real and effective internationalization of Jerusalem.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered an investigation into motor carrier commodity rates and those made as exceptions to the class rates between the New York area and points in New England.

Sometimes the dreaming of a youngster is abruptly transformed into sweet reality, his world expands beyond the limits of the schoolroom and the home, and, briefly, he travels on a plane that few adults know. It was so with 13-year-old Angelo Cruz of Brooklyn, whose ten-day saga carried him far afield from workaday pursuits.

Francis I. Curtis has received the finished script by Elaine Ryan of her dramatization of "Lydia Pinkham Is Her Name," the novel by Jean Burton, and hopes to place it in rehearsal in January. As it stands now, says Mr. Curtis, the dramatization requires some revision, but not enough to prevent its production this season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Capt. John G. Crommelin Jr., the Naval Air officer who helped bring to public attention the Navy's dissatisfaction with defense policies, asked today for a general court-martial unless Admiral Forrest P. Sherman, Chief of Naval Operations, withdrew the recent public rebuke of him.
One hundred and six pickets tried unsuccessfully yesterday to get a lone Bronx apartment house superintendent to join their union and were arrested for their trouble.
LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 18 -- China's Communists have demanded formally that the United Nations strip the Nationalist delegation of its right to speak for the Chinese people.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 18 -- Josip Djerdja of Yugoslavia, delivering the one calm speech in an otherwise ill-tempered debate on disarmament, called upon the United Nations today to concentrate on engendering a better psychological atmosphere among the great powers rather than waste more time on lost causes

MOSCOW, Nov. 18 -- The Soviet newspapers Pravda and Izvestia charged today that the decisions reached at Paris by Secretary of State Dean Acheson, Foreign Minister Robert Schuman of France and Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin of Britain were designed to turn Western Germany into an "American Fascist Reich."

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation yesterday withdrew its price of 95 cents a pound for Grade A tin for immediate delivery from Government - owned inventories. Meanwhile price for late November deliveries of tin traded by private metal merchants dropped 3 1/2 cents, according to New York traders.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Air Force today ordered grounding of all its B-29 bombers that have not been modernized mechanically or have been carrying "maximum operating stresses." The big ships have figured in six recent crashes in which thirty-five men were killed and twenty others are missing.

Six hundred carpenters, whose jurisdictional dispute with hod carriers had halted work on five housing projects, a bus terminal and at the United Nations site, agreed yesterday to return to their jobs on Monday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Reports that 2,000,000 bushels of corn had been sold to France and 360,000 bushels to Norway, part of which was secured here, started general buying in all grains on the Board of Trade today.

Fifty-eight heifers, accompanied by three young bulls, bound as gifts for displaced persons with small plots of land in Western Germany, embarked yesterday on the United States Lines' freighter American Importer, scheduled to leave the port early this morning.

ROME, Nov. 18 -- Italy urgently needs a Ministry of Health to unify and coordinate present public health facilities, according to the recommendations of a commission that has just completed an exhaustive survey of Italy's public health services under the coordination of the International Health Division of the Rockefeller Foundation.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- In a new attempt to win Scarsdale's approval of the "ranch" type of small house that has been built extensively on Long Island, the Colonial Ranch Corporation filed with the village Building Department today revised plans for structures it hopes to build in the Quaker Ridge neighborhood near the Hutchinson River Parkway.

Nearly four years of negotiations by the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union on a treaty for Austria are at last believed to be coming to a close. When a meeting of the deputies for the foreign ministers of these powers ended in the Waldorf-Astoria late last night, a spokesman announced:

General selling developed in the coffee futures market yesterday, depressing prices for the third successive day. At the close all delivery months of contracts S and D on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange showed declines of 200 points, the maximum daily limit.

Millions of dollars' worth of American and foreign philatelic material, including every United States issue from 1847 to date, replete with the rare error varieties and other postal classics, were placed on display at the National postage Stamp Show, which opened yesterday under the sponsorship of the American Stamp Dealers Association in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

BOSTON, Nov. 18 -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, told New England industrialists today that his department would submit to Congress next year a "scientific defense budget" indicative of "rock bottom needs."

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Nov. 18 (UP) -- The pilot of an Army search plane reported tonight that he had sighted what appeared to be parts of the wreckage of the B-29 Super-fortress that crash-landed Wednesday.

HONG KONK, Nov. 18 -- Reports here from foreign sources in North China estimate that there are now about 200 to 300 Russian advisers working in and out of Peiping and about 100 in Tientsin. There are known to be numerous Soviet experts in Manchuria but the North China sources do not know how many or what they are doing.

Two active clot-dissolving agents recently isolated from infectious bacteria have shown ability, in preliminary tests, to dissolve a protecting wall with which tuberculosis germs surround themselves, it was reported yesterday to the medical section of the National Tuberculosis Association at the Statler Hotel.
The largest mass assembly of military reservists ever held in the East will gather tomorrow at the Kingsbridge Armory, Kingsbridge Road and Jerome Avenue, the Bronx.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Production experts have supplanted scientists at the Sandia Special Weapons Base Laboratories of the Atomic Energy Commission.

Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, president of the United Nations General Assembly, sharply warned delegates yesterday that he would not permit them to continue hurling insults at each other from the rostrum at Flushing Meadow.

Lumber production for the week ended Nov. 12 was 6.7 per cent above the comparable week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by trade associations. Shipments were up 33.0 per cent and orders 42.2 per cent.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 18 -- Federal Judge George B. Harris today accused defense counsel at the Harry Bridges perjury and conspiracy trial of an attempt to "discredit all Government witnesses at one fell swoop" in advance of their testimony.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 18 -- Air pollution, with special attention to the Donora smog disaster, came in for careful scrutiny today on the closing day of the Industrial Hygiene Foundation meeting at Mellon Institute.

Governor Dewey was among the public officials and churchmen who issued statements of regret last night at the death of The Right Rev. William T. Manning, retired Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.

The opening of bids on Tuesday in the Disposal Section of the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn, probably will mean the scrapyard for the light cruiser Milwaukee, famous as the only ship of her class with a four-year "hitch" in the Russian Navy.
DEERFIELD, Mass., Nov. 18 -- Faced by a squad quick to snap up opportunities, Deerfield Academy's eleven lost to Choate, 24 -- 12, today in the season's finale for both schools.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 18 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of the Western German Republic, has agreed to accept the idea of Saar membership in the Council of Europe on an equal basis projected entry of the Bonn Republic in that organization.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Formal charges that they had not supported the policy of the Congress of Industrial Organizations but had worked for Communist party objectives have been forwarded to ten Leftist-led CIO unions and nine of their presidents.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Navy today ordered about 20 per cent of its combat planes taken out of service during the next four months and is considering whether others must be withdrawn.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 18 -- Continental members of the study group for a European customs union were convinced today that British concern for the system of imperial preferences had dashed any immediate hopes of achieving a limited single tariff among the Marshall Plan countries.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots of America, AFL, today agreed to a Government-requested truce of thirty days in its dispute with the Atlantic and Gulf ship operators.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 18 -- A new formula for weeding out obsolete machine tools in metalworking plants throughout the country was laid before machine tool makers here today. The step was recommended by L. W. Scott Alter, president of the American Tool Works Company, at the forty-eighth annual meeting of the National Machine Tool Builders' Association at the Greenbriar Hotel.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 18 -- The United Nations Economic Survey Mission for the Middle East recommended today that the General Assembly approve a $48,000,000 relief and public works program to provide for the support of 652,000 Arab refugees from Palestine during the eighteen months beginning next Jan. 1.

The thirty-fourth annual meeting of the World Alliance for International Friendship through Religion will be held in Columbus, Ohio, starting at 8 P. M. tomorrow and ending Tuesday night. An institute will also be held on "World Faith for World Peace," in which representatives of Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish faiths will take part.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 18 -- Debate over whether the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund should continue after June 30, 1950, opened today in the United Nations General Assembly's Social Committee.

ENDICOTT, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- A scientific symposium may be scheduled in the near future on the application of "thinking" machines to the solution of social problems created when the machines are used as labor-saving devices.

HONG KONG, Nov. 18 (UP) -- The Chinese Communists are trying to deal with Acting President Li Tsung-jen for his surrender of Kwangsi Province and the 100,000 to 200,000 Nationalist troops there, Chinese quarters said today.

Reconstruction of Columbus Circle to eliminate traffic congestion at that busy cross-roads is 80 per cent completed and the entire repair program will be finished about Dec. 15, it was announced yesterday by the office of the Borough President of Manhattan.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Nov. 18 -- The Methodist Church will require nearly 20,000 new full-time Christian workers during the next four years, it was disclosed today by the Rev. Harold W. Ewing of Nashville, Tenn., secretary of the denomination's Interboard Committee on Christian Vocations.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- Displaying a crushing attack on the ground, Syracuse buried Colgate 35 -- 7, today before 37,000 fans in the fiftieth game of the series in Archbold Stadium.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 19 -- Repercussions from the coal and steel strike and the drop in cash farm income were reflected in business activity in the Ninth Federal Reserve District during October, the Bank in Minneapolis reported this week.
Mr. Morgenthau's thesis seems entirely flawless. * * *

MARYLA JONAS has recorded a set of Chopin Mazurkas (Columbia, ten-inch, long-playing disk), and they emerge as little gems of performance. Not many pianists have Miss Jonas' grasp of what Chopin accomplished in this modest form, and not many could bring out the variety and scope that the composer poured into it.

The thirty-first anniversary of the founding of the Republic of Latvia, now in the Soviet orbit, was observed here last night under the auspices of local Latvian patriotic, social and church groups at Webster Hall Manor, 119 East Eleventh Street.

THERE is, or course, a constant ebb and flow of literary reputations; there always has been. Taste is not static, and doubtless never will be. But that persistent seesaw seems particularly evident in our own period, perhaps because our time is such an unsettled one, so much without a quiet center of certainty about anything.

The process of moving back into four branch libraries, vacated more than a year ago for repairs, began last week as the New York Public Library made its first delivery of books, furniture and other equipment.

THE holiday this week marks the official start of Christmas shopping. Retailers are among the most practical people in the business world and they are not forecasting any record for their highest period of sales.

KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Government of Afghanistan has been reorganized. Informed sources say it represents an attempt to coordinate and unity the administration in a time of national crisis.

THE 12.5 per cent increase in railroad passenger fares granted to fifteen Eastern railroads last week by the Interstate Commerce Commission may prove to be a considerable help to the commercial airlines in the coming winter.

Offered as a series in the lower priced bracket, the new Pacemaker cars were introduced yesterday by the Hudson Motor Car Company. Delivered prices here are to be announced when the line goes on display in dealer showrooms tomorrow.

PAUL CHAVCHAVADZE describes some of the literary efforts of his early childhood by saying, "They were all colossal in conception." No better description of his latest book could be imagined His story tells of his life in Czarist Russia from early childhood to his emigration to America and of some of his experiences in World War II.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 19 -- A fight over public power and a United States Circuit Court of Appeals decision of far-reaching implications held top interest in this region this week.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 (AP) -- A big, fast and smart Villanova football team, anxious to earn a post-season bowl bid, came back from a first-period surprise today to thump North Carolina State's courageous Wolfpack, 45 to 21.

Many young women in society are working for the success of the ninth annual Silver Spoon Cocktail Party and Tea Dance in the Stork Club on Friday for the benefit of the Spence-Chapin Adoption. Service. Miss Barbara Shuttle-worth and Miss Justine Bayard Montgomery are co-chairmen of a debutante committee, the members of which include the Misses Honor L. Banks and Madelon DeVoe. Mrs. Richard Whitall is chairman of the junior committee for the event.

RICHMOND, Nov. 19 -- New building permits in the Fifth Reserve District for ten months amounted to $261,405,396, against $240,043,060 in the same period last year. October's total of $31,242,671 was 20 per cent higher than the same 1948 month and assures the building trades peak employment through the winter.

A BRITISH community for nearly eight hundred years, this little city (population 10,000) in Leicestershire has arrived at the midpoint of the twentieth century with certain prepared defenses against the age of economic man. It is helping people escape the dull impact of the times they live in, -- baffling times, indeed, for that honored character, the man in the street.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 19 -- A proposal for a world-wide census of conventional armaments and war manpower potential, together with the necessary means of verifying these statistics, was overwhelmingly approved today by the Special Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

THIS is a stimulating book by eminent chemist who clearly does not suffer from the specialist's disease described by Sir Albert Howard as "constantly learning more and more about less and less" -- the disease which, more than any other, plagues the American education of today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- A warning that "unless American communities act with the greatest haste and determination tens of thousands of homeless men, women and children now in displaced persons' camps in Europe and eligible for admission in the United States next year would miss the opportunity to enter this country," was voiced here tonight.

Restraint and caution in advertising claims for antihistamic drugs, now allowed to be sold without a prescription as a treatment for colds, will be urged in a report to be issued this week by the National Better Business Bureau, it was learned yesterday.

IF the present trend continues, the number of students attending American colleges and universities will grow beyond 3,000,000 by 1960. Even at the current rate -- nearly 2,500,000 men and women are on the nation's campuses this fall -- the country faces an unprecedented number of college graduates within the next decade.

ONE day when Mr. Morley, the William Hazlitt of Roslyn, L. I., was tilling his "glebe" he paused to stroke his anything but "glabrous" chin, cast an "accipitrine" glance through the hedge at the next-door Cybele in her hammock -- noticing "more hummock than hammock" -- and remembered that he must clear the "plain garden salsify" off his ironing board.

THIS book is, without question, the best general work on the meaning of evolution to appear in our time. It is an unassuming book, untouted in the trade, unheralded even by the author of the dust-jacket blurb. It is perhaps natural that a creative synthesis of evolution should have been written by a student of fossils.

The general tightening up of the United States Maritime Commission is working out very well, leaving members of the commission free to pursue specialized fields suited to their backgrounds and abilities. Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, chairman of the commission, said yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 19 -- A warning to Catholics to beware of attempts to sow suspicion between the hierarchy and the laity was voiced by the Rev. John G. Schultz of Washington, at the fifth regional congress of the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine, continuing here today.

CAPABLE carvers may turn the page; this column is not for them. Rather it is addressed to the house-husbands who already are thinking of next Thursday's bird in terms of the Annual Thanksgiving Tussle.

Residents of the two-block area in Greenwich Village bounded by West Twelfth, Bank, Greenwich and Wasington Streets have formed the West Village Association to protest against the acquisition of that site for a housing development.

WASHINGTON -- The nation's highways are in such bad shape that Thomas H. MacDonald, Commissioner of Public Roads, admitted recently that Federal and state highway agencies are "seriously losing in the battle with traffic."

Mrs. Mildred McAfee Horton, former president of Wellesley College, declared yesterday that although "it is not quite nice nowadays" to think hard, women's colleges ought to assume the responsibility for making brain work a form of "intellectual good manners."

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- The American people need a change in national policies to get the full benefit of recent scientific achievements in terms of human progress and happiness, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the board of the General Motors Corporation, declared here tonight.

THE struggle between the Kremlin and Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia calls for a fresh look at the Soviet pattern of aggrandizement, because for Moscow the Yugoslav question has become critical and has created for Soviet leaders problems and obstacles they have not encountered before.

The Shah of Iran, who arrived last week on an official visit, is the heir, we are reminded, to the throne of Darius of the old Persian Empire. If the young Shah had inherited the empire instead of the empty honor of the crown he would have a domain comparable in size to the United States, which he is going to tour.

ENGLEWOOD, Calif., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Chris Spencer, a 6-to-1 shot, outlasted the favored Rodney today in winning the $50,000-added Golden West Trot at Hollywood Park. The fleet bay gelding stepped the mile and a quarter in 2:33 4/5, a new track record.

RADIO'S give-away craze apparently has about run its course. Two-fold evidence is at hand to show that the fabulous jackpots are in a slump. First, the number of such shows is on the decline and in recent months the popularity of "Stop the Music," leader of them all, has been cut to less than half of what it was formerly.

MANHATTAN, KAN. ONE of the most obvious facts about 1949 America is that a person boarding a plane in New York at 7 o'clock any morning can arrive in Kansas City, Mo., shortly after noon, there to find the citizenry listening to the same network radio shows, seeing the same movies, and buying the same mass-produced merchandise as do their Eastern counterparts.

Ten of fifteen American companies which employ Americans abroad have not made and do not contemplate any revision of their expatriate pay policies, according to a survey made by the National Industrial Conference Board on effects of the recent wave of foreign currency devaluation.

Alben William Barkley is the first Vice President of the United States to marry while in office. He has, however, another distinction. He is the first Vice President ever to become generally known as "The Veep." Mr. Barkley may be proud of having been born in a log cabin, of having worked his way through college and law school and of having risen by character and hard work to high position.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Nov. 19 (UP) -- Purdue's veterans powered to a 14 to 6 victory over Indiana before 34,000 fans in Memorial Stadium today in their traditional "Old Oaken Bucket" battle.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 19 -- Yale players hoisted 300-pound Herman Hickman to their shoulders today in celebration of their 29-6 victory over Harvard, the first Big Three triumph the Elis have gained for their coach in his two years of tenure.

UPWARD of 3,000 huge men, and a few somewhat less huge women, right about now are looking forward to their most profitable season in the last twenty years. The men are professional wrestlers scattered all over the country, and their strange occupation --' or profession or industry -- is currently undergoing a startling spurt in popularity.

May I express my deep gratitude for Carlo Levi's "Italy Fights the Battle of Illiteracy"? Mr. Levi knows so well the people and places of Lucania and Calabria, which I visited last spring as a representative of the Carrie Chapman Catt Memorial Fund. My visit brought about a contribution by this fund to the National Union for the Battle Against Illiteracy and its good results are being heard about every day.

BIXXY, a carrier pigeon of the United States Army, had been sent with a very secret and important message from a base in New Jersey to another on Long Island. If it had not been for his fondness for salted peanuts and his absent-mindedness, Bixxy would have accomplished his mission, but then there would not have been such stirring complications for Louis Slobodkin's story.

HONG KONG, Nov. 19 -- Disappointment prevails in Hong Kong over the obvious fact that British recognition of the Chinese Communist Government has been postponed at least until the meeting of the Commonwealth Foreign Ministers at Colombo, Ceylon, in January.

THIS is the third book on Cardinal Mindszenty to appear in recent months. There was the selection of the Cardinal's papers, with introduction by Akos Zombory; there was the life by Bela Fabian, and now "The Cardinal's Story."

Although Columbians had hoped for a happy ending to their football season, Brown assumed the villain's role in the final chapter of the 1949 campaign yesterday by subduing the Lions, 16 to 7, at Baker Field.

FOR THIS WEEK: Mow the lawn, new or old, if grass has grown more than three inches high. If clippings are heavy, rake them up for the compost pile. . . . Clean gladiolus corms dug within the last month, roll in 50 per cent DDT dust and store in bags or trays to be kept at a temperature of 40 to 50 degrees. . . .

The highlight of three sales to be held this week at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison, will be the auction of modern paintings, drawings, sculptures and prints and African and Asiatic sculptures that comprise the collection of Josef yon Sternberg, Hollywood director.

The European Travel Commission, 122 East Forty-second Street, reported yesterday that Americans could ride European trains this season at fare reductions that in dollars would bring the cost of tickets down 35 to 70 per cent from fares last summer.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 19 (UP) -- Vice President Albert W. Barkley and his bride arrived here tired but smiling tonight. Mr. Barkley was jovial and full of quips and his bride radiated happiness.

The president and members of the board of governors of the Metropolitan Club have arranged a novel entertainment, reminiscent of old-time customs, to be known as "An Evening in Old Vienna," which will be given on Dec. 2 at the club. The occasion will mark the sixtieth anniversary of the founding of the Metropolitan Club, of which the late J. Pierpont Morgan was a founder.

THE amateur cracksman imitators of Raffles are common in English stories, but they rarely appear in this country, with the exception of the Saint -- possibly because he's the only one of the lot with anything of the style or wit of Raffles or that later and greater gentleman burglar, Arsene Lupin.

TO be blunt, this novel is hereby nominated as the story most likely to leave its readers insensible upon the floor. Briefly, the plot concerns Tulip, "who believed," as the jacket blurb puts it, and Atwater Grant, a scientist who invents marvelous machines, lives in dizzying splendor at the Waldorf and is called Anthony for reasons known only to Tulip herself.

Viewed from the American Embassy in Moscow, the Cominform struggle to unseat Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia created visible, ever-widening political and economic repercussions throughout Eastern Europe and, indeed, among inquiring minds susceptible to Communist influence all over the world.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- Department store sales volume picked up this week with the advent of colder weather and heavier promotions of holiday merchandise. Merchants have been waiting for a drop in temperature to get winter apparel items moving.

DURHAM, N. H., Nov. 19 (UP) -- Toledo rolled over New Hampshire, 48 to 14, today for its fifth successive victory before 5,600 fans at Lewis Field. The Glass Bowl champions thus finished the season with the highest number of points scored in their history. They tallied 305 points in a nine-game schedule.

The Shah of Iran will arrive here today and remain, except for several visits in the vicinity, until Friday. He will receive numerous honors from public and private bodies. The Shah will stop at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
UNITED STATES Judge Harold Raymond Medina, a man as implacably committed to regularity as a metronome, lapsed perceptibly recently.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 19 -- Aroused over the lack of action by public officials, residents of this city and adjacent communities have started a "grass-roots" campaign to stop continued pollution of the Raritan River, which flows through more than fifteen miles of Middlesex County into Raritan Bay.

Britain's post-war interest in the development of African resources has raised serious concern among Latin-American nations, which see the development as a threat to the entire world economy within as short a time as three years.

ROBERT LORD, the producing partner of Humphrey Bogart in Santana Pictures, last week took a stand which, he said, "is probably foolish from my viewpoint as a business man but necessary from my viewpoint as a citizen."
TORONTO, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings made it look easy tonight as they skated to a 5-2 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game before a crowd of 14,422.

THERE'S a story within story of the making of "All the King's Men" which I feel should be told. It deals with the subject-matter of the picture and how it unfolded in real life before our eyes in a middle-sized California community while we were engaged in putting the make-believe version on the film.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The American Legion today called upon the United States to send troops against the Chinese Communists holding United States Consul General Angus Ward unless he was released "by an early specified date."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat, of New Mexico, expressed confidence today that the Democratic party will renominate President Truman in 1952 and that he will win another four-year term.

THAT pretty, red-headed nurse, Sue Barton, is one of the most popular heroines of present-day fiction among American girls of 11 or 12 and up. Her fame is even now spreading in England, as noted by our London correspondent in last week's issue.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 19 -- Israel and the four Arab nations bordering on Palestine have given solemn pledges to preserve holy places outside Jerusalem and to guarantee free access to them, the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission announced today.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday, but on a slight decline trade houses took cotton and prices at the close were 6 points lower to 2 points higher than the day before.
SOMEHOW or other, bridge players can play the game together for years and still get into arguments over the conventional meanings of certain bids.

THE war has not checked G. B. Stern's power to marvel at mystery of creation. In this fourth volume of recollections she is bubbling with gratitude for the benefits of freedom. Her book is topical rather than personal: things, first and last, are her subject.

In climactic Ivy League contests yesterday, a Princeton pass in the closing minutes upset Dartmouth while Yale routed Harvard. Brown's late surge beat Columbia and Rutgers trounced Fordham. Ohio State tied Michigan with a last-quarter touchdown. Scores of leading games:

WALTER FARLEY has written his fifth nicker-a-page thriller, and all Black Stallion fans had best start looking for a quiet afternoon when they can let their favorite horse breathe fire down their necks. This time the story is not only of the Black, but of his precision-built, triple-crown-winning colt, deceptively named Satan. and up.

The Veterans Administration has announced another sharp drop in the college enrollment of veterans under the GI Bill of Rights. It was inevitable, of course, that the program would taper off, and it is, in fact, surprising and gratifying that the enrollments have held up as long and as well as they have.

Reflecting a decline of $10,387,792 in sales for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 from the level of $35,505,543 for the corresponding period last year, the Georgia-Pacific Plywood and Lumber Company and subsidiaries disclosed yesterday a net profit of $22,350 after taxes.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Nebraska and Colorado fought a wild and wooly football game have today with Nebraska winning, 25 to 14, before 32,000 fans.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- A nation-wide group of Senators and Representatives has been formed to make an all-out fight against dispersal of defense plants from coastal areas.

DUBLIN, Nov. 19 -- Premier John A. Costello announced tonight that his Government proposed to repatriate much of the Republic of Ireland's 225,000,000 sterling assets in Britain to be used for capital investment in this country.
ACAPULCA, Mexico, Nov. 19 (AP) -- An insurance appraiser began examination today of the wrecked Corsair, once J. Pierpont Morgan's $3,000,000 yacht.

The excitement created by Andrei Y. Vishinsky's announcement that the Soviet Union was using atomic energy to raze mountains, irrigate deserts and make people happy has not yet subsided. Much ink has been spilled on the mountain part of the announcement. According to some translators, Vishinsky said that mountains had been moved, according to others that mountains had been razed.
Mr. Morgenthau asks us to extend our relief activities to China and the rest of the world all in the hope of building good-will for America and stemming the red tide. * * *

AS the latest member of its group of artistic enterprises, the City Center now plans a modern dance organization to be known as the New York City Dance Theatre, which is scheduled to give its first two-week season of ten performances just before Christmas.

English bone china cups and saucers, men's cable nylon socks, girls' broadcloth dresses and woolen skirts were stressed in retail promotions here last week, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

The Post Office Department plans to issue a maximum of twelve commemoratives during 1950, Joseph J. Lawler, Assistant Postmaster General, and Robert E. Fellers, his deputy, said in talks over the National Broadcasting Company's nationwide network yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- When Secretary of State Acheson described his meeting in Paris with the British and French foreign ministers as "entirely harmonious and completely successful." one of the State Department news reporters immediately recalled the old story about Matt Tighe and former Secretary of State Charles Evans Hughes.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Nov. 19 -- Eighteen United States Air Force officers and men were rescued from the sea by a Canadian destroyer tonight after they had drifted for three days in rubber life rafts following the ditching of their B-29 Superfortress in the Atlantic Ocean.

The trend toward higher fees in state-supported educational institutions was branded as "un-American" last week by Dr. Alexander G. Ruthven, president of the University of Michigan. Speaking at a campus gathering, Dr. Ruthven asserted "our country will always need all of the trained minds that can be produced, and the ability of the mind is neither directly nor indirectly related to the financial standing of the individual."

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 17 -- Conservative leadership in the Democratic party extended the olive branch this week to the party rebels of the 1948 campaign, and in doing so stirred up a hornets' nest in the liberal wing of the party.

ON Thanksgiving Day in the year 1806, in the present state of Colorado, a small party of Americans who had just climbed a lesser mountain saw before them a towering peak. The leader of the ragged little party, a young lieutenant in the army, called it "Grand Peak."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The Shah of Iran introduced the imperial whammy to collegiate football today, and his team won going away.

THE power which Chiang Kai-shek held precariously in China for two decades (1927-1948) was held before him by the Empress Dowager Tz'u Hsi for almost half a century (1861-1908). AS a matter of fact, her death preceded his rise to power by only twenty years, about the same time span as that which separated the Presidencies of T. R. and F. D. R. in this country.
Mr. Morgenthau's problem is not so much the disposal of surplus food as his inability to focus on conditions at home.

THIS book has a laudable purpose. The author, a lawyer, tries, by way of history and in a commendably readable style, to acquaint non-lawyers with the nature of our legal institutions. I heartily favor popularizations by specialists of their specialties.
ATLANTA, Nov. 19 (UP) -- Georgia Tech found the South Carolina Gamecock a tough old bird today and had to come from behind in the fourth quarter to pluck him for a 13-to-3 victory before 20,000 fans.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- American women make the best mothers in the world, the president of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs said today at the fifty-fifth annual convention of this organization.

IN the wake of the recent polio epidemic Mrs. De Angeli's new book has a timely as well as literary and artistic significance. Her first to have it medieval English setting, it is the poignant story of 10-year-old Robin de Bureford, who was suddenly stricken with paralysis of the legs.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., NOV. 19 (AP) -- Prices received by farmers are down one-fifth from the post-war peak and they may decline another 10 per cent in 1950, Charles F. Brannan, the Secretary of Agriculture, said today.
LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Who put a policeman's helmet on top of the spire of the central tower of Westminster, home of Britain's Parliament?

Russian moviegoers are learning about the United States from a new documentary film entitled "Peace Wins Over War." The theme of this drama appears to be that peace is having a rugged time of it in the United States. In the United States, the movie suggests, factories for the production of peacetime goods are closed, while long lines of unemployed wait patiently for a cup of coffee and a piece of pie.

MOSCOW, Nov. 19 -- Mrs. Muriel Draper, vice president of the International Democratic Women's Federation, said at a council meeting today that the "country of Mongolia" is far ahead of the United States in the provision of equal pay for men and women.

Japanese comment is reported to be taking a saddened view of the re-election of Elpidio Quirino as President of the Philippines. Tokyo had hoped, it seems, that the successful candidate would be Dr. Jose Laurel, former puppet President, who is more than amenable to Japan, rather than Mr. Quirino, who was imprisoned by the Japanese and who lost his wife and three children at their hands.

The question of what policy should be adopted by non-Communist governments toward Red China has many facets, and bristles with difficulties. The British Government, with its important trade and industrial interests, many of which have their headquarters in Shanghai or Hong Kong, and with the future of the latter prosperous colony at stake, appears to be disposed to favor early de facto if not de jure recognition of the Chinese Communist regime.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The United Steelworkers of America, CIO, today announced the signing of an agreement with the Armco Steel Corporation (formerly American Rolling Mill Company) ending the steel strike for 8,685 workers in five states.

WHAT is tragic about the German literary life is simply the fact that the rubble on the streets is finally disappearing, but the spiritual ruins remain. "A nation must pass through the fires of suffering and sin," Walter Rathenau once told Andre Gide (who then proceeded to quote it as if it were true), "before it is ready to search its own soul and come to know itself. * * *

ONE of the most exciting events in recent years, gardenwise, has been the introduction to this country of a new race of early flowering hybrid species tulips. They are beautifully colored, extremely hardy and most of them are low-growing.

THE theatre was Henry James' first love, and it played in his life the role of succubus to anchorite, of dream-born temptress to saint. Whenever he was faithful to a boyhood dream of play writing, he betrayed his best genius, he rebelled against his fate to be a whisperer and tried to declaim.

BERLIN, Nov. 9 -- In a boxlike basement room on the Ihnestrasse students from the new Free University are on duty each weekday from early morning until late at night. This is the headquarters of the bureau that handles calls for part-time jobs from several hundred college students, most of whom come from the Soviet zone.

RENO, Nev., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Lincoln Fitzgerald, 57 years old, a gambler, was wounded critically by a shotgun blast in a midnight ambush at his palatial home here. The charge, which entered his side and severed his spine, may cause his death.

AN announcement that the Nobel Prize Committee failed to agree on a winner for its literature award signifies a portentous development in letters. It is now possible that hundreds of small-bore committees, hunting for geniuses on the lower slopes of Mount Parnassus, can be persuaded to hold their fire.

THE Embassy Newsreel Theatre at Broadway and Forty-sixth Street, which passed out of existence this week, was the pioneer newsreel house and led to establishment of some forty similar theatres in this country and abroad.

THE hero of Ethel Hueston's novel is an ordained minister. "Red" Islip can talk an unwilling millionaire into sound-proofing a gymnasium and a couple of incipient young thieves into contributing to the very kitty that they had set out to steal.

David Low in "Clues to an Understanding of Britain" writes, "It reminds me of the boy who wrote an essay on the tortoise, saying, 'A tortoise is a red fish that walks side ways.' 'Correct,' said the teacher, 'except that a tortoise is not red, it is not a fish and it does not walk sideways.'"

Coming home from the last Sunday's concert of the New Friends of Music, I wondered why it is that in concert reviewing no interest is directed to the phenomenon of audience behavior. The audience is, I believe, a very important factor in gauging the status of musical life in a community.

With hammer and saw 7-year-olds at the Hunter College Elementary School are busily producing bridges, tunnels, trees, wigwams and sundry animals. They also exhibit a great enthusiasm for woodworking, leather tooling and ceramics.

The program of the Association of Combat Divisions to serve as a clearing house of information for members of all combat units who served in World War II was endorsed yesterday at the final session of the annual reunion of the Eighth Infantry Division, held in the New Yorker Hotel.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 19 (UP) -- Minnesota whipped Wisconsin, 14 to 6, in football today, but it probably wasn't enough to get the Gophers their desired trip to the Rose Bowl.

ALL those dissatisfied people who have been muttering for the past thirty years that the sacred art of the theatre was desecrated and despoiled by upstart films might do well to soak their heads bravely in the bath of cold and sobering facts which A. Nicholas Vardac has assembled in his scholarly "Stage to Screen."

FOURTEEN years have rushed into history since Cecil B. DeMille first started an investigation of Minoan Civilization in the interests of a motion picture biography of the Biblical muscle man, Samson. The producer-director's long struggle is now ended, and the week before Christmas will witness the Broadway premiere at the Paramount and Rivoli Theatres of his "Samson and Delilah" done up in Technicolor.

IN his article entitled "Germany Today" in your Nov. 6 issue, Mr. Harrell tells us about German opera stars, which is not exactly the same thing. Inasmuch as his report is sincere and objective I am afraid it might be misleading.

THREE of the newly opened one-man shows of paintings serve further to illustrate the wide range of interests and approaches evident in the work of our contemporary artists. In the profounder sense of the word eclecticism, toward which American art has been feeling its way, they represent interesting individual currents.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 19 -- Dr. Laureano Gomez, unopposed Conservative candidate for President in the elections of Nov. 27, declared today that the present tension in this country had not been caused by the normal interplay of political forces but by the "subversion of authority" by the Liberal party.

HEAPING bowls of fruit are a traditional part of the coming holidays. Yet the old familiar mixture of bananas, oranges, apples and grapes ought to be relegated to the kitchen, and carefully planned arrangements executed for the other rooms.

LONDON, Nov. 19 (Reuters) -- Liverpool downed Aston Villa by 2 -- 1 today to extend its unbeaten string to 17 games. The league leader thus equalled the record set up by Arsenal in the opening months of the 1947-48 season.
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 19 -- Nearly 12,000,000 "expellees" in Germany comprise a "dead weight to impede the recovery of all Western Europe," the Right Rev. Edward E. Swanstrom declared here today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- A review of twenty years of searching for "unity, clarity and order" at the University of Chicago was issued today by Dr. Robert Maynard Hutchins, covering the period he has been chief executive officer of the university.

The promise that the newest antibiotic, neomycin, may conquer tuberculosis in man, a promise based on experiments with animals, is not likely to be fulfilled, if Dr. Geoffrey Rake, director of the Squibb Institute, is right. At last week's streptomycin conference, held at Atlantic City, he said neomycin was poisonous enough to discourage its use in human tuberculosis.

THE Overseas Press Club is the world's largest organized body of foreign correspondents. The combined familiarity with the world of its 700 members probably equals that of occupants of the building in Washington which houses the Department of State.

Mayor O'Dwyer returned early yesterday afternoon to his desk at City Hall about an hour after he and Miss Sloan Simpson, fashion stylist, arrived at Westchester County Airport, Harrison, N. Y., in a Police Department plane after a flight from Saratoga Springs.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 19 -- Ohio labor leaders and Democrats suffered a serious setback this week in their fight to defeat Senator Robert A. Taft for re-election next year when Gov. Frank J. Lausche definitely removed himself as a possible candidate for the Democratic Senatorial nomination.

THE first two months of the new season have been notable for the achievements of Americans, transient and otherwise, naturalized and native born. Among the transients have been Isaac Stern, Dusolina Giannini and Erica Morini.

THE long awaited exhibition of art treasures lent by the Austrian Government opens today at the National Gallery in Washington. New York is so see it at the Metropolitan next and will probably come easily to the conclusion that it outdoes the exhibition of masterpieces from the Kaiser Friederich Museum in Berlin which toured this country last year.

PARENT education today emphasizes the importance of family living for children. If we analyze literature and lectures on the subject we find that there is a new accent on the positive elements of home relationships, the shared, happy experiences which bring parent and child closer together.

IN our corner of New Jersey, there are trees and shrubs which offer protection and food for birds. Those who are not similarly blessed can easily acquire plant material which will attract the friendly nuthatches, chickadees and tufted titmice that are now twittering and chirping in our garden.

TINY, round knobs, which will develop into flowers, may be noticeable by now on plants of Christmas cactus. An earlier-flowering variety, commonly known as Thanksgiving cactus, will open salmon-pink blossoms in late November.

TROY, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- Brooklyn College today made a valiant attempt to avenge a 47-13 setback a year ago by Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, but the effort failed, as the Kingsmen went down to a 25-20 defeat at the hands of the Engineers.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 19 -- On the wings of a 41-yard pass play from Dick Kazmaier to Captain George Sella. Princeton's Big Three champions rode to a 19-13 upset victory over Dartmouth today. The old Ivy League rivals put on a whale of a battle, one of the season's best in the East, before a chilled gathering of 40,000 in Palmer Stadium.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Missouri eleven today wasted a 20-point half-time lead and then came back in the last quarter to defeat Kansas, 34 to 28, in one of the wildest football games ever staged in the Big Seven Conference.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Southern California's Trojans, riding on the gifted southpaw pitching of a fourth-string quarterback named Dean Schneider, defeated the Bruins of U. C. L. A. today, 21 to 7, in their annual cross-town duel before 75,028.

THIS book is in reality two books. One is an extremely sensitive and intelligent attack on the naturalistic-historical school of Shakespeare studies, as exemplified by Robert Bridges, Levin L. Schucking, and Elmer Edgar Stoll; the other is an effort to present a positive and constructive critical approach to Shakespeare.

THE name of Margaret Landon is as indissolubly associated with the Siamese nation as the word "twins." Through her "Anna and the King of Siam" we met the East on as easy and comprehensible terms as a Western introduction can effect.

Andrei Yanuarivich Vishinsky, the Russian Foreign Minister, is regarded as the most colorful and dramatic personality at the present session of the U. N. General Assembly. He is certainly the hardest working delegate. Most delegates are content to familiarize themselves with the ins and outs of one or two major problems, but Mr. Vishinsky has memorized the minutiae of various countries' positions on atomic energy, disarmament, the Italian colonies, China, Korea and other questions.

THE nine or ten short novels -- what a shame it is that the publishers have only been able or seen fit to include five in this volume -- of Ronald Firbank are, for me, an absolute test. A person who dislikes them, like someone who dislikes the music of Bellini or prefers his steak well-done, may, for all I know, possess some admirable quality but I do not wish ever to see him again.
After trailing at the end of the first period, the Wagner College Seahawks struck on the air and ground to crush the Panzer College Panthers, 52-12, yesterday at Wagner Field, Staten Island.

IN law, medicine and politics we are used to son following father, and grandson following son; but this rarely happens in the historical profession; indeed, the only American instance that occurs to the reviewer is that of the two Arthur Schlesingers.

THE price of the f/3.5 Ansco Automatic Reflex has been reduced to $165, a cut of 40 per cent, according to Ansco. The camera is equipped with synchronized shutter. The same camera without synchronization, is now $145.

Sylvia F. Porter's "Lessons for '49 in the Crash of '29" is the best analysis I have seen of the case. On her Point 3, I think she takes the will for the deed. Much education remains to be done before the principles of the International Trade Organization, for example, are accepted.

IN my previous article I discussed in general terms how our museums can become more dynamic factors in our daily lives and endeavored to show some of the problems involved in the relationship between the city government and these quasi-private institutions. In this article I would like to be more specific.

Yi-Kwei Sze, Chinese bass-baritone, gave a recital late yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. The gifted artist, who came to this country in 1947, received his vocal training in his native land, where he made many appearances in concerts, operas and on the air.

A NEW emphasis in education for home efficiency seems to be aimed at getting the homemaker off her tired feet. The latest contribution to the literature intended to show her how best to accomplish this is a volume called "Mary Proctor's Ironing Book" which, in 156 profusely illustrated pages, attempts to demolish the last stand of the old-fashioned housekeeper who continues to iron on her feet.

Dean Dixon, who has conducted frequent young people's concerts with his American Youth Orchestra, gave his first with the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra yesterday morning at Carnegie Hall. The event was planned for children under 9 years of age.

The focus of American diplomacy in recent weeks has been across the Atlantic. Secretary of State Acheson himself journeyed to Europe to deal with the urgent problem of Germany and returned only last Tuesday.

Led by Ken Ademac and Marty Lewin, the Stuyvesant High School football team rolled to a 39-18 victory over its East Side rival, Seward Park, yesterday at Randalls Island in the season's finale for both. The Peglegs' deceptive attack was too much for the Red and Blue, which trailed from the start.

DETROIT, Nov. 19 -- A $100-amonth pension program for Ford Motor Company salaried employes will go into effect March 1, pending approval by the Treasury Department. Henry Ford II made this announcement today in a letter to his salaried employes.

TO all devotees of the Western, and to the many old followers of Rhodes in particular, the first sizable collection of the work of the Nebraska-born novelist of the cattle country to appear since his death in 1934 is an important event.

THIS book really embraces two aspects, which we might call "On to" and "Orthodoxy." The first is a spiritual autobiography, the second an essay in Christian doctrine. The whole is another Apologia Pro Vita Mea.

LOWELL, Mass., Nov. 19 -- A small-town volunteer fireman who has seven young children was held for a grand jury on arson charges today after police said he confessed setting thirty-five fires because he needed his $1 an hour firefighting pay to catch up with maternity bills.

Professional football's biggest attraction of the local season comes up today. It's the Yankees against the Cleveland Browns at the Stadium, a battle between the two top powers of the All-America Conference. With good weather more than 50,000 spectators are expected to be on hand for the 2:15 P. M. kick-off.

THE old play, "Charley's Aunt," is one of those dramas which in the course of time has picked up the name of hardy perennial, something like "The Mikado." When, a little over a year ago, they set out to make a musical of it, there was, of course, no reason why a perennial could not also be a musical.

THE New York Yankees have never beaten the Cleveland Browns in a football game and the opportunity for so doing is vanishing fast. Today's joust at the Stadium may be the last chance they ever will get. Local fans will be out in considerable numbers this afternoon to watch the usually dazzling Browns pit their highly geared offense against a Yankee eleven whose pride and joy is its rugged line.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Paced by corn, all grains moved upward today in heavy dealings on the Board of Trade. The yellow cereal had gains extending to 2 cents a bushel at times. Deferred contracts made new seasonal high marks.

LEADING off with the adage that "men dig their graves with their teeth," Dr. Fishbein's guidebook tells the obese and the gaunt how to avoid doing just that. The advices, rules and regimens in "Your Weight and How to Control It" are set forth in thorough scientific fashion and stem wholly from accepted clinical observations and tests.

It is written, "Next to the originator of a good sentence is the first quoter." Apparently THE TIMES Magazine believes this, too. In your Nov. 6 issue you quote ("On the Record") Mrs. Fannie Jensen, Denmark's Minister for Housewives, as likening her function to that of a lightning rod -- "Women can flash down on me, and I can direct the current to the proper sources."

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Britain's Labor party declared today that a Conservative defeat in the coming general election would spell the "final eclipse" of the country's former "ruling class." This view was see forth in a 400-page handbook prepared for Laborite speakers in the election campaign.

PREDICTIONS of record motor touring volume next year are expected to exert a strong influence on plans for the annual General Motors Show opening Jan. 19 in the Waldorf-Astoria. Announcements of the exhibition emphasize that more attention will be devoted to cars than ever before while accessories, household appliances and other products manufactured by General Motors will be relegated to the status of minor attractions.
Santa Claus and a host of characters from nursery rhyme and storyland will come to town with the twenty-third annual Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade Thursday, rain or shine.

THREE welcome titles in the "First-Book-of" series. The book on bugs is the most interesting, mainly because it opens up a new world of which few of us are aware. And what a noisy, busy world it is -- the habits, habitats, and reasons for nearly a hundred insects and bugs are told in a lively manner with excellent illustrations.

The time has long since passed when being born to wealth was a badge for a life of leisure. Today the sons of the industrial tycoons of the past generation are carving their own individual niches in the world of business and finance and with accompanying varied interests that might have taxed their forefathers.

There are not many men in American public life today who command greater esteem or fewer votes than Norman Thomas. Mr. Thomas may not get much satisfaction from that situation; for, as he repeats in his article in our Magazine today: "I have said that I would rather be right than be President, but was perfectly willing to be both."

The average Weimeraner owner is all enthusiast, and after owning one of this breed for a short time he begins to hold one shoulder a bit higher than the other, in order to balance the chip he carries on it.

The Erasmus Hall high school football team won the mythical P. S. A. L. Brooklyn championship by defeating Boys High, 34-25, on the latter's gridiron yesterday before 4,000 fans. The meeting was the forty-fifth in a series that began fifty-one years ago.

The recital given by Frank Glazer yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall offered a program of a number of the greatest works of the pianists' repertory, played at all times with high-competence and at the best moments with a sensitive art and a compelling spirit.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- The Norwegian -British-Swedish Antarctic expedition, which is sailing next week from London to the Norwegian dependency of Queen Maud Land to spend two years in scientific exploration, is the first of its kind in polar history.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 19 -- The Wesleyan Cardinals completed their season today by defeating the University of Rochester Yellow Jackets, 20 to 7. The game marked the resumption of a football rivalry interrupted by the war.

With the new Federal housing program and increased state funds, the New York City Housing Authority has set a goal of 80,000 new apartments for families in the low-income brackets within the next few years, it announced yesterday.

ADD to the writers' ranks the name of Montgomery Clift. Last week it was learned that the actor, currently at work in the lead role in "A Place in the Sun," Paramount's remake of Theodore Dreiser's "An American Tragedy," is collaborating with Mira Rosovskaya on a yarn which they hope to film in Italy.

AT the age of 71 Mr. Pitkin has written another manual of self-help, a volume amply justifying his publisher's claim that he is still a "forthright guy who packs a provocative punch." This time, however, in keeping with his ripe estate, he dedicates his cornucopia of wisdom to "all men and women young enough to crave a richer life, vigorous enough to seek it, and intelligent enough to grasp the methods of attaining it."
Robert Cobb Myers would tax those who don't vote. Why make voting compulsory? Let's treat it more as a privilege, so making it more attractive.

Correspondent I. H. Roseman protests the Playwrights' Company elimination of the Sunday matinee performances of "Lost in the Stars" at the Music Box Theatre. This play has reverted to the customary Wednesday and Saturday matinee schedule because it was felt that four performances in a period of two consecutive days (matinees and nights on Saturday and Sundays) were too much of a strain on Todd Duncan's voice.

Over-all production of synthetic resins for plastics this year may outstrip last year's record output, it was reported in the industry here yesterday. The gain may not be large, but was said to represent further expansion in important end-uses for plastic materials.

It was a great surprise to me that such vast quantities of food are being stored by our Government for such a long time. Surely, with millions on the verge of starvation, what better use could be made of our enormous surplus than Mr. Morgenthau suggests ?

MISS DRUMMOND, the English author - artist whose story "The Flying Postman" was recently published in this country, gives us another original non-sense tale for 4-to-8-year-olds. When a neighborhood feud concerning the ownership of a certain bluebell patch looms up Anna Truly sets off to London to see the King with all the superb self-confidence of a well-mannered 6-year-old.

To accommodate the rapidly growing population of Queens, the platforms of all stations of the IRT-BMT Corona-Flushing and Astoria rapid transit lines in that borough will be lengthened next year at a cost of $3,850,000, William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation, announced yesterday.

THE opening night performance of the Metropolitan Opera Company will be televised by the American Broadcasting Company network for the second successive year. Telecast time will be tomorrow at 7:45 P. M. The opera will be "Der Rosenkavalier," with curtain time scheduled for 8:10.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Dispersal of Government units and functions in case of atomic bombing, even to the point of legislating by television from scattered key points and, perhaps, a mobile capital on railroad trains, was proposed today by Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican, of Wisconsin.

THAT gesture toward the Damon Runyon Cancer Fund by the management of "South Pacific" has picked up momentum with the "me, too" announcement made by the squires of the town's other musical smash hit, "Kiss Me, Kate."

Italy moved to within one final ballot yesterday of a return to Africa as the United Nations General Assembly at Flushing Meadow began its last round of debate on the future of the former Italian empire.

HONG KONG, Nov. 19 -- Within the disintegrating Nationalist regime in China there still remain two foci of opposition to the Communist forces. One of these is the Kwangsi Army and its leaders, Gen. Pai Chung-hsi and Acting President Gen. Li Tsung-jen.

IN the foreword to the second number of his handsome new miscellany, Mr. Lehmann rather pointlessly crosses swords with a Soviet reviewer who had described the first number as "artificial," "reactionary," "useless," and "stale," and repeats his earlier declaration of principle, that "the deepest need today is to assert the lyrical and imaginative spirit against materialism and the pseudo-scientists."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Two lumbering experts from Austria will spend the next eight weeks in four Western states studying the use of modern equipment in the American industry.

A "new science of propaganda, more dangerous than the atomic bomb," has arisen and under a growing control of mass media could become a means of thought-control, Representative Walter H. Judd of Minnesota declared at the annual luncheon of the Protestant Teachers Association at the Astor Hotel yesterday afternoon.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 19 -- The First and Second World Wars gave a powerful impetus to the liberation of former colonies, and only about 215,000,000 of the 2,000,000,000 inhabitants of the globe are now completely under foreign rule.

NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Stubborn Santa Clara gave Oklahoma its toughest game of the football season today with the Sooners fortunate to extend their string of victories to nineteen with a 28-21 triumph.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Nov. 19 -- Swarthmore College today turned back Haverford, 14 -- 13, in the fortieth game of a seventy-year-old gridiron rivalry. A crowd of 7,000 watched the contest at Alumni Field.

Although all factors point to an active spring season in the apparel trades, suppliers of finished rayon fabrics indicated last week that they will take a cautious stand on forward commitments. Weavers of gray goods are exerting pressure upon converter customers, it was learned, to get orders for April, May and June delivery, but there has been no general rush to buy for delivery beyond the first quarter of 1950.

" OF all the diseases known to man, none has had a more significant effect upon the history of the world than malaria," writes Dr. Warshaw as the opening words of a fascinating chapter in his biography of malaria, titled "Great Men and Fever."

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 19 -- The Brandywine Stable's Cochise, who had been running with moderate success in Class C handicaps and allowance races on the New York circuit, bobbed up as a stakes-winner at Bowie today as the Southern Maryland Agricultural Association opened its thirteen-day session.

EVERYONE has a right to call us murderers," a horrified concentration-camp guard, who had been forced into the SS, told inmate Jeanette Wolff, a former leader of the German Social Democratic party. "Even if we win the war I won't be able to forget the screams of 65,000 people murdered in the Warsaw ghetto.

Henry Morgenthau Jr.'s proposal we're for, but we wonder if it would really help win friends for democracy. If we give food to India, for example, isn't it necessary also for us to give a positive alternative to communism ?

GREENVILLE, S. C., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Halfback Ray Mathews raced 68 yards to account for Clemson's margin in a 28-21 Southern Conference football victory over Furman today. Furman staged a smashing fourth period for 18,000 homecoming fans by punching out three touchdowns after spotting Clemson that many.

MOSCOW, Nov. 19 -- The newspaper Soviet Art declared today that melody was the key to modern Soviet music and that without melody "there is no beautiful, great, forward and clear language through which music can reveal to the listener noble human thoughts and sentiments."
