BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 19 -- Reports published today summarizing the work of the first meeting of the Danube Commission in Rumania last Thursday said the Yugoslav Government had been reduced to a purely nominal membership and complete control had been vested in the Soviet Government.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 19 -- Although retail business activity in the Twelfth District last week stood below a year ago in most areas, the district as a whole showed a favorable recovery from the previous week. Bank debits in the Twelfth District during October again fell below the corresponding month of 1948.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 19 -- Integration of the West European economy on a scale unprecedented in peacetime history is envisaged by the Western Allied High Commission and leaders of the Bonn Government. The present plans for internationalizing the Ruhr and developing international customs treaties are only part of a broader and more far-reaching ambition, they say.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Nov. 8 -- Because it took eight months to draft a constitution for the proposed Central African Federation, it seems today as if much spade work will have to be done again.

ADMIRERS of Major North will be aghast to find him, in the early pages of "Dardanelles Derelict," drunk, disorderly, and volubly disloyal to the U. S. A. in a low waterfront dive in Istanbul. Still, it's easy to guess that he will soon be starring in the search for the Soviets' plans for a multi-jet ejector unit -- "the deadliest engine of destruction ever invented."

BERLIN, Nov. 19 -- As a result of the initial post-war conference on traffic problems here yesterday among federal and state officials, several concessions benefiting the Berlin transport agencies were announced today.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 19 (UP) -- Tulane's Big Green blockbusters scored on passes, power and a punt return today to explode Virginia's dream of an unbeaten season, 28 to 14, before 30,000 thoroughly impressed fans.

NEWS of hotel rate reductions and of major improvements in facilities and service, and a warning about reservations for the coming winter season, were the twin messages brought to New Yorkers last week by officials of the Miami Beach Hotel Owners Association, in town to help start 1949-50 promotion activities.

In a metropolitan medical center in the midwest last week, a 13-year-old victim of last summer's infantile paralysis epidemic took her first steps since she was hit by the disease. In Texas a 6-year-old boy, who suffers from cerebral palsy, started rehabilitation training in a new treatment training center.

IF we are to be saved from our follies, the fishermen will probably have to do the job. Freshwater fishermen; who take the time from little worries to go off and ponder the big problems of life. They find the answers, as Mr. Van de Water ably proves in this group of essays on angling and eternity.

FOR archaeologists the pueblo peoples in the Mimbres region of southwestern New Mexico remain a mystery. Six on seven centuries ago, for reasons unknown, the Mimbrenos disappeared, leaving behind unique pottery whose decoration reveals a close study of animals, birds and insects as well as pictured legend, ritual and ceremonial.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, sailed for Europe yesterday, leaving behind the promise that the free trade unions of the world would beat back the threat of communism and totalitarianism.
A Bowery derelict was arrested last night for the murder of a 71-year-old East Side druggist whom he had beaten to death, according to the police, in an attempted robbery.

JUST ten years ago William Saroyan was the young literary man of the moment. His initial book, "The Daring Young Man on the Flying Trapeze," and several subsequent volumes of short stories had introduced him to a large, eager and sympathetic public.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 19 -- Notre Dame stretched its string of games without defeat to 36 today despite a plague of fumbles and penalties and a bitterly battling Iowa team which went down, 28 to 7, only after a struggle before 56,790 fans in the Irish stadium.

PANAMA, Nov. 19 -- This city was seething with revolt tonight as a result of a clash between President Daniel Chanis and the heads of the police, with Chief Jose Antonio Remon under arrest at the Presidential Palace. The central police station was defying the President and had deployed helmeted police armed with rifles throughout the city.

To avoid much useless experimenting research scientists now apply the theory of probability. To explain how the theory works W. L. Gore, a du Pont chemist, says that the novice at "crap-shooting" soon learns that seven turns up more frequently than any other number, and the poker player learns that drawing to an "inside straight" does not pay off as a rule.

A boxed insert in Carlo Levi's "Italy Fights the Battle of Illiteracy" mentions the aid given by the Carrie Chapman Catt Memorial Fund. It might well have been added that this fund was originated and sponsored by the League of Women Voters.

TWO New York City detectives, members of the Police Department's famed "crime laboratory," are presenting, probably for the first time, a composite picture of the vast field of crime detection in "An Introduction to Criminalistics."

HONG KONG, Nov. 19 -- A Peiping broadcast heard here tonight said that Communist troops advancing on Chungking had reached a point "east of Nanchuan." Nanchuan is about eighty miles southeast of Chungking."

Britain, France, Russia and the United States agreed four years ago at Potsdam on "the principles to govern the treatment of Germany in the initial control period." All four Powers, if we take the Potsdam Declaration at its face value, contemplated "the eventual reconstruction of German political life on a democratic basis and eventual peaceful cooperation in international life by Germany."
A driverless automobile rolled down a hill on West End Avenue to Ninety-sixth Street at 7:10 P. M. yesterday, hitting two other cars and two pedestrians. Three persons were injured severly.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The CIO News, official newspaper of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, said tonight the union's leaders were anti-Communist but were not "right-wingers."

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- In official and other highly informed quarters on this side of the Atlantic the belief is growing that the leadership of Western Europe -- which neither Britain nor France appears to be able or willing to assume -- has in effect been assumed by the United States.

DISSENTERS have played more than one role in history. At various times, at various places, and on issues big and little, they have been responsible for confusion, division and discontent. And for progress. Your true prophets have always been dissenters. Heretics have often been gravely in error.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Federal Government had $2, 680,000,000 invested in surplus farm commodities on Aug. 31, the Agricultural Department reported today.

Last summer's oriole nest hangs high in the elm, in plain sight now that the leaves are gone. The orioles too are gone, and after a frosty night the nest sways in the morning sun like a gray purse spangled with brilliants. Snow will come, in due time, and fill the woven pouch where eggs were hovered and hatched.

DALLAS, Tex., Nov. 19 (UP) -- Baylor's Bears caught the Southern Methodist Mustangs with their defenses down for the first time in thirteen years today to score a hard-earned 35-to-26 victory before a startled crowd of 63,000 in the Cotton Bowl.

BOSTON, Nov. 19 -- Although hopes for the establishment of a regional steel mill were revived this week during deliberations at the twenty-fifth New England Conference, some sources wondered how much fire there might be behind all the smoke.

Women college graduates interested in an Army career may apply for appointment as second lieutenants in the Woman's Army Corps, Regular Army, it was announced at First Army Headquarters, 90 Church Street, yesterday. The program begins next June.

Introduction of "big business" techniques into the First Army will result in an estimated saving of $2,469,530 for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1950, Col. C. R. Bathurst, Controller of the First Army, reported yesterday.

LATEST to appear in the Western Americana series edited by Dr. Robert G. Cleland and Oscar Lewis are "The Shirley Letters From the California Mines" by Louise Amelia Clappe ("Dame Shirley") and Bayard Taylor's "Eldorado."

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Nov. 19 -- Protestant churches in this country have committed themselves to a building program in excess of one billion dollars, the Rev. E. M. Conover of New York, director of the Interdenominational Bureau of Architecture, said here today.

Since the war John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers have engaged in twelve major work stoppages. Three of them have been ended by the power of the Government -- one by seizure of the mines, the other two by court injunctions (for temporarily defying the injunctions Mr. Lewis and the UMW were fined a total of $2,130,000.)

Michael A. Heilperin, in a letter published in your columns on Nov. 6, took issue with statements made in dispatches to THE NEW YORK TIMES from Paris to the effect that "integration" of European economies is a term that is new in American official utterances and represents an American doctrine that was not included in the engagements taken by recipients of Marshall Plan funds in 1947 and 1948.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- President Truman today named Irving Florman of New York as Ambassador to Bolivia. He succeeds Joseph Flack, who was transferred in June to Costa Rica.

LUCKNOW, India, Oct. 29 -- Palaces, mosques and splendid mausoleums still attest to the wealth of the one-time Kingdom of Oudh, whose distinctive character survives in Lucknow, its capital, even today, although the kingdom was abolished by the British ninety-three years ago.

THE most elaborate book for beginners ever published, Andreas Feininger's "Feininger on Photography" (Chicago: Ziff-Davis Publishing Company. $15), which was put on sale last week, is also the most expensive. Written by a photographer who is noted for his mastery of the technical as well as the artistic phases of camera work, the book is thorough, comprehensive, practical and respiring.

Two heads often are better than one when starting a new business. Miss Jane H. Todd, deputy commissioner of the New York State Department of Commerce, said yesterday at its headquarters, 342 Madison Avenue.

With Paul Miller rapping six goals off the backboard in the fourth chukker, the Squadron Regulas turned back the Ellistan trio of Far Hills, N. J., 11 -- 7, in the feature match of the Squadron A Armory's inaugural indoor polo double-header last night. In the opener, the Ramayso Club halted the Hamilton Ramblers, 11 -- 8.

The new father need not gape through glass to find his heir amid rows of babies at French Hospital. A new rooming-in unit there permits new-born babies to stay in the same room with their mothers instead of in a general nursery.

AT this time of year, when flower borders need to be cleaned up before the ground freezes, the water garden continues to require little or no care. All summer long, the waterlilies have grown and flowered, presenting no worries about weeding, watering or spraying.

UNION, N. J., Nov. 19 -- While industries seeking sites here are "screened" by the township committee to bar factories which emit heavy smoke or unpleasant odors, fifteen plants have been erected in the new industrial area along the Lehigh Valley Railroad since the section was opened three years ago, Mayor F. Edward Biertuempfel disclosed today.
Aaron Copland in "Tips to Moviegoers: Take Off Those Ear-Muffs" writes, "To take music out [of a movie scene] can at times be more effective than any use of it might be."

CAIRO, Nov. 12 -- During the coming winter a major issue of world politics is going to come increasingly into the foreground in the Middle East. The issue is whether the program for the economic and social regeneration of the Middle East is to be carried out under the auspices of the United Nations or through a partnership between the Western powers, notably the United States and Britain, and the Middle Eastern governments.

When the United States Lines freighter American Merchant berths in a far-flung port, ship factors who come aboard with mail from home are often surprised that Chief Engineer Alan S. Corbett, a good family man with a wife and two children, does not always join in the mad scramble of news-hungry seamen for letters.

DETROIT, Nov. 19 (AP) -- A big twin-engined freight plane with a cargo of Christmas gifts plunged into a two-story house today, killing three persons. An elderly woman was rescued from the flaming, gasoline-drenched wreckage of the house with serious burns.

IT is clear that had Mr. Sweeney been writing "Art and Life in America" he would have confined the epic of American art over the centuries to the story of ships' figureheads, cigar -store Indians and Grandma Moses.

Robert Cobb Myers' "A Proposal to Tax Those Who Won't Vote" reads like a parody of the intellectual mind. It has been a long time since I read Voltaire's "Candide," but I was immediately reminded of "the best of all possible worlds" in which persecution came so gracefully as to be classed as a privilege.

Debutantes of recent seasons who have assisted in the plans for previous annual benefits for the Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., are furthering the sale of tickets for the Tuesday night performance of the Ice Follies at Madison Square Garden to raise funds for the institution.

BERLIN, Nov. 19 -- The initiative in the struggle for Germany which the Soviet Union and its Communist henchmen seized and held in October through a series of cleverly contrived, seemingly important but basically empty, assurances of sovereignty for the German Democratic Republic in the East has been lost.

A Yuletide exhibit of puppet Characters, ranging from Polichinelle of seventeenth century Italy through Punch and Judy to the modern figures by Rufus Rose and Basil Milovsoroff, will be held at the Cooper Union Museum Dec. 2 through Dec. 31.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- The Baruch Committee on Physical Medicine, founded by Bernard M. Baruch of New York with a grant of $1,100,000, stated in its annual report today that conversion of atomic energy, radar and sonar -- three great physical weapons of World War II -- to peacetime applications in medicine has made significant progress.

SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 19 -- Interest in uranium mining has been greatly heightened by an AEC report that a new find of the radioactive material near Marysvale, Utah, is perhaps the richest such discovery in the nation. The Marysville ore reportedly can be developed into a sizable machine-mined operation in contrast to previous "pick-and-shovel" size beds.

THE documentary dramatic series known as "City at Midnight," which NBC is presenting at 11 o'clock on Tuesday evenings, is the first live television show to go out "on location" regularly in order to obtain authentic settings.

OMAHA, Nov. 19 -- Midwest officials who have been campaigning for a major decentralization of defense industries recognized this week that they had a hard fight ahead of them. How to advance their cause was occupying much of their attention.
NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 19 -- St. Benedict's Prep defeated Carteret School, 34 to 12, at Benedict's Field today as the two rivals completed their schedules.
As I am a daughter of one of the original founders of the Farmers' Telephone Company, John Gould's "To Alexander Graham Truman" brought back many childhood memories.

Mrs. Richard C. Bondy Jr. will hold a meeting on Tuesday in her apartment in the Plaza for members of the committee for the bazaar and tea to benefit the Washington Square Home for Friendless Girls, which will be held Dec. 6 in the home at 65 East Eighty-second Street.

I AM fully in accord with W. A. Darlington's comments regarding the inaudibility of many of our present-day actors. Much of this fault is due to direction. I am an old "ham" of some forty years' experience and when first I started acting, the principal requisite was a good voice and clear enunciation.

While the railroads in the East will put into effect a week from tomorrow the 12 1/2 per cent rise in passenger fares granted last week by the Interstate Commerce Commission, executives of many carriers are convinced that higher rates alone are not the answer to the heavy loss being incurred from passenger operations.
CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Today's report of the markets in the Union Stockyards by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

THE rumors of creeping disaster in the British film industry which were suddenly incubated by a deficit financial report from J Arthur Rank have set many people to worrying lest "all those fine British films" such as we've had in the past -- and still are getting -- may very soon come to an end.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- A new answer to the old problem of economic concentration, or "bigness" in American industry and business, is being sought these days on Capitol Hill.

IN this important book Professor Lindblom's main conclusion is that the trade unions' substitution of "producers'" authority for the rule of the consumer and the price system is bound to accelerate the decline of capitalism and even destroy it.

American engineers have started supplying "know-how" equipment and supplies for the largest-scale industrial development projects ever undertaken in Australia, it was learned here yesterday. These involve first steps in the future establishment of a completely new iron and steel industry in West Australia, undertaken by H. A. Brassert Co., New York consulting engineer concern.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 19 (UP) -- Quarterback Don Burson pitched a touchdown pass and kicked a fourth-period field goal with just three minutes to go today to spark Northwestern, to a 9-to-7 victory over Illinois.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Another boom year in construction is forecast for 1950. Two Government agencies made the joint estimate today that the total value of new construction would equal the 1949 record of more than $19,000,000,000.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 19 (UP) Old fashioned football and an ancient jinx today helped Tennessee to a 6-0 victory over Kentucky that denied the wildcats a share of the Southeastern Conference title and shattered their hopes for a major bowl bid.

The New York Quartermaster Procurement Administrative Agency has been redesignated as the New York Quartermaster Procurement Agency, it was announced yesterday by Brig. Gen. L. O. Grice, commanding officer. The redesignated agency will comprise three main divisions, he said, as follows: QM Purchasing Division (formerly procurement division, New York Quartermaster Purchasing Office); QM Industrial Mobilization Division (formerly Industrial Mobilization Planning Division, NYQMPO), and QM Inspection Service Division (formerly QMC Inspection Service).

THOUGH Mr. Spong's fiction of war in the European theatre shifts attention from the battles to the black market, he has at least tried to dignify his hero (in the convention of post-war novels, I should say his Heel) by making him a deserter who has overstayed a hard-earned pass to Paris.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 19 -- James Roosevelt's long-waited announcement this week that he would seek the nomination for Governor of California next year gave him an immediate edge in the Democratic sweepstakes.

In the wake of the 1949 elections and other current developments in this country, the thirty-second anniversary of the 1917 Russian Revolution, and the thirtieth anniversary this year of the establishment of the American Communist party, it is instructive to note that the latter party has, after thirty years of continual agitation, apparently reached its nadir, as betokened by the following:

BOSTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- A hard-hitting St. Bonaventure football crew, master-minded by versatile Chris Scaturo, ruined Boston University's bowl hopes with a smashing 19-0 triumph before a crowd of 16,657 today at Fenway Park.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Admiral Forrest P. Sherman, Chief of Naval Operations, today closed the case of the Navy's dissenting air officer, Capt. John G. Crommelin Jr.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- A record high in the number of cigarettes smoked by the American public was hit this year, figures released by the Department of Agriculture here today show. Because of population increases, more persons are expected to be smoking next year, the report also shows.
SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Bishop Loughlin High School of Brooklyn won the Eastern Interscholastic Cross-Country championship today for the fifth straight time.

An excess of redemptions of United States savings bonds over sales for two months in succession is attracting more than perfunctory notice in financial circles. In October, sales totaled $388, 000,0O0, and redemptions, $396,000,000, an experience similar to that of the month before, when sales totaled $398,000,000 and redemptions, $411,000,000.

In probably the busiest and most crowded speed-boat season in Florida's history, this winter's schedule, getting under way earlier than ever, will start Dec. 31 and continue into the third week of March.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 19 -- Fordham's Rams, who two weeks ago were perched on the dizzy heights occupied by the nation's unbeaten, received another rude jolt today. Faced by an inspired Rutgers eleven that charged and passed with determination, the Maroon was beaten by the Scarlet, 35 -- 14, before 18,000 delighted spectators at Rutgers Stadium.

PEACE must be achieved. One chosen instrument now exists to seek that goal: The United Nations. Eleven of that organization's most experienced and dedicated leaders tell us in this volume how far we have come on this urgent journey.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 19 -- The University of Chattanooga today formally dedicated its new $500,000 science building. At the same ceremony it dedicated the building's medical research laboratory established by Dr. John B. Haskins, Chattanooga physician, in memory of his son, John B. Haskins Jr.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UP) -- The admirals told Secretary of Navy Francis P. Matthews in a report released today that construction of a big carrier to launch jet-powered atomic bombers was "still entirely feasible."

WHAT is most distinctive and valuable in this book of American-Russian relations in the Far East is not the treatment of the relations themselves, which have been limited and of no particular importance until very recently, but the way in which Dr. Tompkins puts them in the larger setting of foreign policy and international politics.

IN the early morning hours of April 4, 1883, New York lost one of its most colorful citizens -- 92-year-old Peter Cooper. Although Cooper's family would have preferred a private funeral, the city ruled otherwise. Thousands of New Yorkers -- men and women, millionaires and draymen -- lined Broadway to pay their last respects; editors and clergymen extolled Cooper's merits or mourned his loss.

ATHENS, Ga., Nov. 19 -- Georgia got five touchdowns on fumbles and pass interceptions today and ran up a 40-to-0 victory over Duquesne, breaking a five-week victory famine for the Southeastern Conference champions.

" The democratic pattern of family relations" is applicable to "the family of nations in taking notice of the intrinsic worth of personality," declared Rabbi Samuel M. Segal in his sermon yesterday morning at Mount Neboh Temple, 130 West Seventy-ninth Street.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 19 -- The Lehigh Engineers tried valiantly to beat the Lafayette Leopards today and at the end of the half the overflow crowd of more than 17,000 in Bethlehem High School Stadium thought they were going to make it.

KINGS POINT, L. I., Nov. 19 -- The United States Merchant Marine Academy, winner of Long Island "Little Three" football crown, today closed its season at Tomb Memorial Field with a 20-14 victory over Hartwick College of Oneonta, N. Y.
United Nations conciliators will hold another round of conversations with countries involved in the Balkan controversy, it was announced yesterday.

MAURICE CHEVALIER has spent almost fifty of his sixty years in the theatre, its alloys, variations and corruptions, Hunger-driven, school behind him, at 11 he was an unpaid, off-key singer at the Cafe des Trois Lions in his native Menilmontant in the outskirts of Paris.

IF Congress approves President Truman's Point Four program, it might be wise for it to give a copy of "Out in the Mid-day Sun" to any wife who accompanies her husband to "undeveloped areas." Today there can be few places more undeveloped or uncomfortable than was the remote interior of India when Mrs. Martin moved there in the Nineteen Twenties.

IF the detective short story is today as literate and imaginative as it has ever been since Poe invented it, the reason is very largely the driving resolution of Editor Queen. Because of production limitations, this year's volume of Queen prize winners contains only sixteen stories, and editorial comments are restricted to a brief introduction.

THE Baroness Maria Von Trapp is a woman of simple piety. This autobiography tells how, through the will of Cod, she left the convent where she was a novitiate, near her home in Salz burg, Austria, married the baron, who already had Seven children, fled the country after Hitler's advent, and turned the family's musical pastime into a profession and made it the foundation of a new life here.

GENEVA, Switzerland -- The first sight I encountered upon emerging from my hotel here was a suit of armor clanking jauntily down the street. At the corner it hailed a taxi, hauled itself in and rode off down the Quai du Mont-Blanc.

TEL AVIV. WHAT is the future of this youngest republic of the world? What will this country of modern cities and primitive settlements, of flourishing farmlands and bare, rocky slopes, of artificial, bountiful fish ponds and desolate sand wastes look like in fifteen or twenty years?

THE Metropolitan Opera season opens tomorrow night, and the repertory and the public anticipation of the same serve to remind us of the despairing remark attributed to Giulio Gatti-Casazza in a bygone day, which was quoted widely around the country and was to the effect that "opera is dead."

HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 19 -- Expressing dissatisfaction with legitimate theatre wages and working conditions on the West Coast, a meeting of 200 members of the Actors Equity Association and its affiliate, Chorus Equity, voted unanimously last night for radical changes in their union organization.
The complex structures of the North Atlantic pact and of the somewhat parallel but separate Military Assistance Program are being erected slowly in Europe and North America.

AS diverse as these two books are in their approach to the art and craft of playwriting, they enjoy the common virtue of being uncommonly worth while. Not only worth while for the student but also for anyone sufficiently curious about both the theatre and the creative forces that the writer must harness and then turn loose.
PANAMA, Nov. 19 (AP) -- President Channis called the seizure of his officials by the police late today "an act of rebellion."

The Netherlands merchant marine is near its pre-war status, but much of the tonnage is over age and the number and tonnage of passenger ships now in operation has declined considerably in comparison to the 1939 passenger fleet, the Netherlands Information Bureau announced yesterday.

SPANNING a year in the life of the Lemmings, industrial Brahmins of the Middle West, this first novel depicts a family where love and the subtler facets of personality have been stifled. To the father love is synonymous with duty, marriage means sons for Lemming Steel and the artistic instinct is comparable with physical weakness.

Birds of many feathers flocked yesterday to the Salle Moderne of the Statler Hotel to be judged in the annual Grand National Open Show, a two-day event with prizes of ribbons, trophies, rosettes and cash for the winners.

Local liquor wholesaling operations have become the most difficult in the city's history, Morris O. Alprin, general counsel for the Greater New York Wholesale Liquor Dealers Association, Inc., declared yesterday. Unless remedial steps are soon taken, further capital may be withdrawn from this area, he warned.

WHEN I mailed to Guthrie McClintic the nth version of that dramatization of my novel, "For One Sweet Grape," which on Tuesday night Katharine Cornell offers to New York under the title, "That Lady" he cabled me: "

WARSAW, Nov. 19 -- The arrest of two French citizens, one under circumstances as mysterious as the disappearance last August of American architect Hermann Field, was followed today by strong French protests to the Polish Foreign Ministry and the internment of a Polish airliner and its crew in Paris.
AFTER a season of touring America in "I Know My Love," Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne have settled down in Forty-fourth Street, New York City, for another season or two of open house in light comedy.

The latest issue of the New York Public Library's Branch Library Book News is devoted to lists and discussion of religious books for serious readers of many faiths. Two branch library exhibitions, held in observance of Jewish Book Month, have come by some of their rarities in loans by the Jewish Institute of Religion, the Jewish Museum and by readers.

FROM time to time some man, some woman, known to the public by achievement in a specified field of activity -- literature, polities, labor, social reform and even revolution -- wins a headline in the papers and a more intimate contentment within himself by submission to the Roman Catholic Church.

CAMELLIAS can be grown in flower pots in the vicinity of New York City without hothouse facilities. This fall, three blooms have already been picked from the variety Professor Sargent that is still out in a shaded spot in my garden in Northport, L. I.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Nov. 19 -- The Mizrachi Women's Organization of America today urged President Truman, Secretary of State Dean Acheson and this country's United Nations delegation to "assist in the maintenance of peace in the Middle East by supporting the just claim of the state of Israel to Jewish Jerusalem."

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- Edouard Herriot, 17-year-old president of the French National Assembly, was re-elected head of the Radical party today at the conference in Toulouse, and the threatened break-up of the Cabinet of Premier Georges Bidault was avoided.
MEDFORD, Mass., Nov. 19 (UP) -- Trinity ended its 1949 football season as the only unbeaten New England team by defeating stubborn Tufts, 6 to 0, today before 7,000 fans at Tufts Oval.

THE quest for economic security in a terribly insecure world has become a rat race for which an appropriate motto would be sauve qui peut. This book deals with the techniques by which a large and powerful group, organized labor, is advancing its demands at the risk of destroying our economic system.

OTTAWA, Ont., Nov. 19 (UP) -- The House of Commons last night rejected by a vote of 62 to 34 a proposal that gas pipeline companies be prevented from routing their lines into American soil until Canadian needs were met.

With Britain's capital investment, and modernization of industry proceeding at a rate never before equalled in its history, the future will see sufficient production to meet the nation's export requirements, Harold Wilson, President of the Board of Trade of that nation, said yesterday.

A CENTURY-OLD postal cover that passed through the mails Jan. 18, 1846, from Portsmouth, Ohio, to Lexington, Ky., is being shown publicly in New York for the first time. The cover's owner, George W. Linn, publisher of a stamp journal in Sidney, Ohio, announced last week that the expert committee of the Philatelic Foundation, 22 East Thirty-fifth Street, had issued a certificate of opinion that the cover "is a genuine Postmaster's Provisional."
BERLIN, Nov. 19 -- Poland, largest and most nationalist of Russian satellites in Europe, is regarded as the most urgent problem within the new Russian empire by qualified Western sources here.
DURHAM, N. C., Nov. 19 (AP) -- North Carolina nosed out Duke, 21 -- 20 today, to win the Southern Conference football championship in as wild a wind-up as this ancient series has ever produced.

RICHARD STRAUSS' last two operas will be presented next year and the year after at Salzburg. The one which will be done at the 1950 festival is "Capriccio," which was composed between 1940 and 1941. It is subtitled "a conversation piece" and has a countess as its chief protagonist, a role that will be sung by Ljuba Welitsch.

The newest in football inventions is a helmet ear piece filled with ammonia gas. The invention has been patented by Dr. W. D. Hershberger of the engineering department of the University of California at Los Angeles. Purpose? To enable a player on the field to receive instructions from the bench.

Retail trade here last week responded to seasonal influences, but comparison with last year was less favorable than in the preceding week. Department store sales were estimated at about 7 per cent under 1948.

Twenty years ago last week Dr. Robert Maynard Hutchins was inaugurated as president of the University of Chicago. He acquired the title of chancellor in 1945. In the last two decades Dr. Hutchins has achieved an international reputation and has become a highly controversial figure in the field of education. During the early days of World War II he aroused considerable controversy in the political arena as well by his isolationist views.
New York University humbled the City College football team at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday. While 4,000 fans looked on, the Violet eleven tallied in every period to register a 41 to 7 triumph.

A poll taken among students of Dartmouth College discloses that the overwhelming majority favor dropping restrictive clauses in those fraternity charters which bar membership on the basis of race and religion. Of the 2.359 students participating in the poll, 1,754, or 75 per cent, voted to abolish restrictions, 375 believed they should be maintained and 230 were undecided.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- The appointment of Lieut. Col. Charles H. Bonesteel 3d as executive director in Europe for the Military Assistance Program under the North Atlantic pact is expected to be announced shortly in Washington.
Not all word welders earn their living by the pen. Occasionally, a regulatory official will turn a phrase that might delight the ear but, in retrospect, threaten his standing as a seer.

The General Assembly has voted to ask all members of the United Nations to impose an arms embargo on Bulgaria and Albania as long as those countries continue to assist the Greek guerrillas. In the case of Albania this resolution creates interesting possibilities, especially if one or more members at the request of the U. N. undertook to blockade the coast of Albania in order to enforce the embargo.

THIS reporter saw Alan Paton on the eve of his leaving for England to receive a special literary award from The London Times for his distinguished novel, "Cry. the Beloved Country." In New York he had seen the "musical tragedy" version of his novel; in London he will put the finishing touches to the screen version of it for Alexander Korda.

THIS is the story of Hannah Jackson, a girl of 28 with a firm, warm grip on her difficult but full life, who walks blindly into a tough moral crisis. Love and evil come to her wrapped in one package. Her story is absorbing, and the picture of a girl unhappily in love is painfully realistic.

FROM the art of literature Mr. Cook has endeavored to develop a philosophy of esthetics, and through esthetics a world outlook. Man searches for the wonderful through a world of probabilities, for novelty in a universe of regularity.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 -- Women's apparel shops in central Philadelphia reported last week's sales were 3 per cent below a year ago and 16 per cent below for the four-weeks period. Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings continue gradually to improve and last week they totaled 81,556, as against 132,716 a year ago, a decrease of 38.5 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The Administration's public power and conservation policy, under a new Secretary of the Interior, is likely to be the same as it has been, only more so, according to competent opinion here.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Inexorably the Soviet Union is applying the revolutionary vise ever tighter to the satellite nations of Eastern Europe. A brand-new wave of purges has set in from the Baltic to the Black Sea. National-minded Communists are being dismissed from the party ranks.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Rice used a granite goal-line defense and a couple of breaks today to squeeze past Texas Christian University, 20 -- 14, and clinch a tie for the Southwest Conference championship.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Greatly increased world food production in 1948-49 has freed the United States and Canada from their roles of emergency helpers, causing them to be confronted with imminent surpluses, the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations said today in its annual report.

MR. WALBANK, who will be remembered as the editor of "The English Scene," has done a new anthology presenting England as seen in the works of its novelists from 1837 to 1938. His selections are not snippets, one is glad to say, but long enough to produce an effect as independent pieces.

UP on the roof of the Merediths' farmhouse porch Peggy turned the apple slices so they would dry in the sun. She had learned many new things since being invited out from the orphanage for the summer. The red-headed little tomboy wished she could stay on forever.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- This city of monuments, wide avenues and flags of all nations is accustomed to visits by foreign personages, and it treats them in a manner befitting their station. But this week it had a visitor unique on two counts: he was the first Oriental monarch ever to make a state visit to the United States, and neither he nor his representatives have left any doubt as to what he was after.

MRS. LASSWELL'S three beer-drinking ladies are back again and as funny as ever. In this new entertainment, they have left their junk-pile in California to visit a niece in New York, where they can engage more freely in the reconstruction of the American scene.

College opportunities for Indians are "woefully inadequate" and much needs to be done by the Federal Government and by private organizations to alleviate this condition, according to a survey conducted by the Association on American Indian Affairs, 48 East Eighty-sixth Street.

Failure of the state Department of Mental Hygiene to call a public hearing or conferences on legislative proposals submitted to it by private agencies was criticized sharply yesterday by David N. Fields, president of the Association for the Improvement of Mental Hospitals.

Although quantities of purchases are about the same as this time last year, department stores are displaying greater selectivity in placing orders for spring lines, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office.

NEW YORK STATE shares with Pennsylvania the distinction of beginning the petroleum industry, nearly a century ago. New York production, always picayune, comes almost entirely from pools in Cattaraugus and Alleghany Counties, lying on the Pennsylvania boundary.

THIS painstaking study of the State Department by Professor Stuart, who teaches political science at Stanford University, is probably the definitive volume on the subject. It goes even a little beyond the promise of its subtitle by including a handy survey of the important policies made and carried out by the department since its creation in 1789.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Temple University's football team tallied three touchdowns in the first half and then withstood a strong aerial barrage to whip Holy Cross, 20 to 7, today at Fitton Field.

The retail boom in orders for furniture has reached its peak and manufacturers can expect substantially curtailed volume at or before the turn of the year, Manfred I. Behrens Jr., vice president and general manager, Ludwig Baumann, declared in an interview last week.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 19 -- California's Bears thundered into 1949 football history and clinched the right to represent the Coast Conference in the Rose Bowl on Jan. 2 with a 33-14 victory today over the game but outclassed Stanford Indians.

Holiday sales of variety stores will more than hold their own against larger competitors, Dr. Paul H. Nystrom, president of the Limited Price Variety Stores Association, predicted here yesterday. Variety stores originally featured merchandise selling below one dollar, but now in many cases carry major appliances and other items competitive with department stores.
The performance of "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes" on Dec. 13 at the Ziegfeld Theatre has been taken over by the New York City Hospital Visiting Committee of the State Charities Aid Association.

What is called the banthine treatment for peptic ulcer has been developed by Dr. Keith S. Grimson, Professor of Surgery at the Duke University School of Medicine, and Drs. Frank H. Longino and C. Keith Lyons, United States Public Health Service fellows at Duke.

THOUGH literacy was not essential to salvation in the Southern colonies, the colonists were not indifferent to education. They did, however, labor under severe handicaps. "Damn their souls. Make tobacco," had been the response of the King's Attorney General when urged to approve a grant for a college in Virginia.

TOKYO, Nov. 19 -- Indications have begun to appear here that the Russians again this year will not fulfill their pledge to repatriate the agreed quota of Japanese war prisoners still held in the Soviet Union for more than four years since the surrender.

The additional allowance of $1,500 a year, as an exclusion from compensation received during the war by military and naval personnel, was limited by an amendment enacted by the Eightieth Congress to such compensation received prior to Jan. 1, 1949.

No man in American history has been more successful in pushing the nation's blood pressure up and its steam pressure down than John L. Lewis. Undisputed ruler of the economic destinies of half a million coal miners in the bituminous and anthracite fields, his power rests on a record of almost legendary accomplishment in the quest for higher wages, a shorter work-week, pension and welfare benefits and other improvements in the lot of his members.

AGRA, India, Nov. 19 -- It strikes many United States travelers in India that this country is neglecting a rich source of dollar exchange in not promoting a tourist industry. Though some talking is done about encouraging visitors, the prevailing disposition is to postpone any heavy advertising campaign until facilities for tourists are improved over the present level.

Swinging like a weather-vane in a high wind, stock prices rebounded last week to the highest level in three years, recovering all the earlier losses plus those of the correction period of the last fortnight. Settlement of major strikes, however, failed to terminate the uncertainty in the minds of traders regarding the future outlook for business.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Lou (Bimbo) Cecconi, great little Pitt halfback, wound up his college football career in a blaze of glory today as he led the Panthers to a 19 -- 0 victory over traditional rival Penn State. Cecconi scored twice and pitched a pass for the third touchdown.

Having "found" themselves Friday night against the Denver Nuggets, Joe Lapchick's New York Knickerbockers continued to travel the victory road yesterday afternoon when they whipped the Philadelphia Warriors, 85 to 69, in an Eastern division game in the National Basketball Association at Madison Square Garden.

An import merchandizing plan which, if successful, may increase imports of European popular priced consumer goods into the United States by $100,000,000 a year is being sponsored by the International Banding Machine Company, 280 Madison Avenue, a subsidiary of the Consolidated Lithographic Corporation.

Thirty-seven thousand persons, the great majority of them children, crowded into THE NEW YORK TIMES third annual Boys' and Girls' Book Fair yesterday, making a record two-day total of 67,000 visitors to its activities at the American Museum of Natural History.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- After a lapse of nearly fifty years, the dogs of the Hospice of St. Bernard in the Alpine snows are being equipped again with little kegs of liquor in their rescue work. The St. Bernard dogs, famous in story and cartoon the world over, were relieved of the liquor barrels, which they formerly wore strapped to their backs, in 1900.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Nov. 19 -- The United Steelworkers of America, CIO, is opening a drive to sign new contracts with the Youngstown district fabricating and steel processing companies, which employ 20,000 to 25,000 workers, it was reported here today.

AMERICAN travelers and tourists are congenially incapable, of resisting the shortcut. Those who heed such siren calls are merely following examples set by the pioneers who wearied of the established trails. The infamous Cimarron Cut-Off on the Santa Fe Trail was a detour around Raton Pass; Death Valley would be unnamed except for a short cut taken by the Jayhawkers and the Bennett-Arcane party in 1849.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- A former Federal judge will claim a seat on Monday as a trustee of the United Mine Workers welfare and retirement fund. If he is seated, as he expects, domination of the $90,000,000-a-year fund may pass from the hands of John L. Lewis.
LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Early in the new year British voters will go to the polls to render their verdict on five years of limited Fabian Socialism.

The fifty-fifth annual meeting of the Society of Mayflower Descendants will be held tomorrow night in the auditorium of the headquarters of the society at 122 East Fifty-eighth Street. After a business meeting, there will be an address on "Russia and the Bomb," given by Maj. Gen. Frederick H. Osborn, USA, retired, Deputy United States Representative on the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission.

As a regular reader of your newspaper I was much interested in the article by Benjamin Welles from Newcastle-on-Tyne which appeared in your international edition of Nov. 5. The article, if I may say so, was an excellent one, but the part of it which refers to Winston Churchill might be misinterpreted in America if it went without explanation.

The privately owned United States merchant marine can be counted on to provide adequate tonnage for this country's foreign commerce even if the present Government-owned auxiliary fleet of chartered ships is withdrawn, Frazer A. Bailey, president of the National Federation of American Shipping, declared yesterday.

THURSDAY will start a long week-end for persons able to expand the Thanksgiving holiday to a four-day vacation. Advance reservations indicate that trains and buses leaving and entering New York, especially on Wednesday and Sunday. will carry heavy loads.

DENVER, Nov. 19 -- Albert C. Jacobs, former Columbia University provost and internationally known scholar and educator, was installed today as the eleventh chancellor of the University of Denver. He warned in his inaugural address that the United States was in greater danger of internal collapse than of foreign invasion.

IMPRESSIONISM was never a completely successful graft on to the main stem of American painting. Not that it failed to find gifted champions among the artists of the Eighties and Nineties; if anything Monet's lesson was learned too well by them.

The Eastern railways have now obtained an increase in passenger rates. Here is something I think the long-suffering passengers have a right to ask from the roads in return. The process by which these railroads sell us our tickets is so antiquated, so cum bersome and so slow that improvement is long overdue.

BOSTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Boston's last-place Bruins shaded the Montreal Canadiens, 2 -- 1, tonight in a National League Hockey game, which drew 12,025 fans to Boston Garden, largest home crowd of the young season.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Bobby Livingstone stepped 80 yards for a touchdown today to lead the Buffalo Bills to a 10-0 victory over the Chicago Hornets in an All-America Conference football game.
In another crowded week of events in the world of painting and sculpture, the art of the Near East is very much to the foreground.

Moshe Keren's letter, which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Nov. 11, is further evidence -- if evidence is indeed required -- that Zionist propaganda technique is based on continuously repeated assertions, even if these have been proved false by the most reliable sources available.

The Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York will extend its medical insurance on Jan. 1 to employes earning more than $5,000 a year or whose total family income is more than $6,500, David M. Heyman, president of the plan, announced yesterday. At the same time a rate increase will become effective.

Unless the ultimate definition of democracy is the Golden Rule as a governing principle of good citizenship, then there can be nothing but moral, economic and political slavery, Canon Edward N. West declared yesterday afternoon in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

The establishment of interracial clergy staffs by the city's churches and the welcoming of Negroes as members were suggested yesterday morning by Donald Harrington in his sermon at the Community Church, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20. -- The full effect of Government loans on farm products became more apparent as prices of grains advanced sharply on the Board of Trade last week, with the deferred deliveries of corn, and May oats selling at new highs for the year, as did December and May wheat in both Kansas City and Minneapolis.
TORONTO, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Mexico captured the Chilean Foreign Minister's Trophy for international individual officers' competition at the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show last night.

Dr. Hideki Yukawa, Japanese winner of the Nobel Prize for his prediction of the existence of the meson, asserted yesterday that it was impossible for his nation during the war to construct the atom bomb because of lack of fissionable material and technological equipment.
GENEVA, Nov. 20 -- The movement to liberalize trade in Europe, which has, considerable momentum, is already in danger of foundering on the rock of cartels.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 20 -Failure of industry, including management and labor, to observe social justice can contribute toward the gradual establishment of a "welfare state" bereft of liberty and voluntary charity. Bishop Bartholomew J. Eustace of Camden, N. J., declared here tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 -- The Delaware and Schuylkill Rivers arry more water through the Philadelphia metropolitan area, comprising five counties in Pennsylvania and three in New Jersey, than it will require for generations.

An American edition of "I Attacked Pearl Harbor," by Kazuo Sakamaki, commander of the two-man submarine that led that attack on the naval base, will be published on Dec. 7 by Association Press. The book covers his experiences from his appointment to the naval academy to his return to Japan after the war and presents a picture of the Japanese mind as trained for war.

An appropriation of nearly $3,000,000 in municipal funds is resuired to "adjust" the salaries of faculty members in the four city- owned colleges, according to the annual financial report of the Board of Higher Education.

ALBANY, Nov. 20 -- New York State's capital, which once drew its water supply from the more or less polluted Hudson River, now has a mountain source of such capacity that it has offered to share its surplus with the entire county of Albany.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Nov. 20 -- The modern church has "pigeon-holed" religion and is worshiping a "God-emeritus" who has been denied responsibility for the salvation of mankind, the Rev. Dr. W. Aiken Smart, of the Candler School of Theology, Emory University, Atlanta, Ga., said here today.

WNBT and WCBS-TV, local video outlets for the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System, respectively, will televise the twenty-third annual Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade on Thursday, beginning at 10:30 A. M. Coverage of the event also will be fed to other cities by the CBS television network.

There are a number of alumni now at large who would have expressed incredulity if a few years ago anyone had suggested to them that the time might come when they would look toward the end of the football season with relief.

By retroactive adoption of "accelerated" depreciation policies, a number of large companies increased their current depreciation charges in the last two years without departing from generally accepted accounting principles. This is one of the major conclusions of a survey of 525 such reports issued for publication today by the American Institute of Accountants, a national professional society of certified public accountants.

The existing superstructure of currency evils and speculation in exchange, together with indications that some ECA goods furnished by the United States are being diverted to Iron Curtain areas from the country they were intended to aid, accentuate weakness of some phases of the Marshall Plan as it is actually functioning in Europe, it was stated here over the week-end.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -Johnny Lujack threw three touch-down passes and Sid Luckman one to give the Chicago Bears a 31-21 victory over the Washington Redskins before 30,418 today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The United States is expected to decide tomorrow on various courses of action designed to persuade the Chinese Communists to release Angus I. Ward, the United States Consul General under arrest in Mukden, Manchuria.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 20 -- In general, the water supply situation in this area and in the Missouri River basin is considered good. A watchful eye is being kept, however, on both ground and surface water levels, which are supplied from streams in good condition.
To those of us who personally knew the late A. Ritchie Low and were inspired by his concept of tolerance your editorial drawing attention to the "Vermont Plan for Action" was particularly welcome.
OSLO, Monday, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Dutch DC-3 was given up as lost today, and fear was expressed that it had crashed in a wild forest and lake area only a mile from Oslo.

Al Parsells of the Ramapo Valley Polo Club, regarded as the game's top player indoors, has been boosted from seven to eight goals, according to the 1949-50 list of handicap changes announced yesterday by George C. Sherman Jr., president of the Indoor Polo Association of America.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 20 -Southern California generally has been keeping ahead of its water requirements over the past twenty-five years despite natural aridity and unprecedented expansion of population and industry. In a few places the situation is tight and occasional rationing has been necessary.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UP) -The Communist-dominated Hungarian Government has failed to re ply to a United States request for an investigation into the "disappearance" of Robert Vogeler, the State Department said tonight.

The bogey of top-heavy inventories has been dispelled by a drop to levels more normal than those of last spring, according to the latest "How's Business" survey conducted jointly by the New York Credit Men's Association and the Los Angeles Credit Managers Association, released for publication today.

Enrollments at the American colleges and universities are still increasing, according to reports from all sections of the country. This fall there are 1,862,465 men and women attending the nation's 790 liberal arts institutions, compared with 1,822,037 a year ago -- a gain of 2 per cent.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 20 -- Two members of the New York Field Hockey Association and six from the Long Island Association were named to the first two all-star teams as the Northeast Field Hockey tournament concluded today at Hofstra College.

A five-point program to get more students to enter the field of elementary teaching is suggested by Dr. Q. A. W. Rohrbach, president of State Teachers College, Kutztown, Pa. These proposals would probably be accepted by educators everywhere as a sound basis of action by teachers' colleges.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Rams turned a recovered fumble and a stolen pass into a pair of final-quarter touch-downs and then failed on an 11-yard, last-play field goal, to dead-lock the Chicago Cardinals, 28-28, in a National Football League thriller today.
W. S. Weismann Jr. has been named assistant to the vice president of American Airlines, in the Washington office. He was formerly district sales manager in Buffalo.

Enrollment in the nation's teachers' colleges shows a gain of 3.4 per cent, going from 189,210 in 1948-49 to 195,720 this fall. However, the entering class is just the same as last year -- 62,270. The gains in the teachers colleges are smaller than those made in the technological institutions, but not far from the average for the entire field of higher education.

A good deal of unfinished business remains to be cleaned up in this final week of the football season. But most of the important decisions were reached Saturday as Virginia was toppled by Tulane, leaving Notre Dame, Army, Oklahoma and California as the only remaining spotless powers.
Reflecting the rehabilitation of European countries, shipments of parcel post have declined almost 30 per cent from last year's figures, Albert Goldman, postmaster of New York, said yesterday.

A welcome voice was added to the swelling chorus demanding the economic integration of Western Europe when Sir Stafford Cripps, the economic "dictator" of Britain, broadcast the assurance that his country was "ready and able" to play a full part in that enterprise. Sir Stafford was obviously trying to meet the rising criticism that he was mainly responsible for British hesitations on that point, and the exact content of his pledge must still be ascertained.

ZURICH, Nov. 20 -- The effort made last Thursday by Sir Stafford Cripps to restore world confidence in the devaluated pound sterling, by claiming that Britain's production and exports are increasing, and by denying that the disagio of sterling between New York and Zurich had any great practical significance, deepened scepticism in Switzerland about the long-range future of sterling.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 20 (Reuters) -- Eric Louw, South African Minister for Economic Development, has denied he made a disparaging reference to some of the races represented at the United Nations when he returned home from the United Nations session in Paris last year.
NEWARK, Nov. 20 -- A temporary haven for teen-age girls from broken homes, to help them weather the readjustment period, has been established by the Youth Consultation Service at 237 Broadway here.

The New York Public Library's annual report gives us the statistical evidence of ever-increasing service to our city and, indeed, the whole world. The Circulation Department, which operates sixty-five branch libraries and many substations in Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island, lent to readers more than 9,000,000 books in the year ending June 30, 1949, which was nearly 1,000,000 more than in the previous year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- A 50 per cent increase in social insurance taxes will go into effect Jan. 1, raising $667,000,000 more a year.

TRENTON, Nov. 20 -- With the water reserve in North Jersey at the lowest level on record, the State Water Policy and Supply Commission warned today that rationing lay ahead unless users conserved voluntarily.

Jeanne Mitchell has nearly all of the attributes of an important violinist. She is pretty, confident, and probably can read off with virtuoso skill any music that is placed before her. Such, at least, was the impression she presented at her recital in Carnegie Hall late yesterday afternoon.

The sponsors of the Institute of World Affairs will give a dinner tomorrow at the Ritz-Carlton to mark the twenty-fifth anniversary of its founding and to honor Mrs. Alexander M. Hadden, a founder. Among the speakers will be Mary Garden, former opera singer; Sir Norman Angell, philosopher, and Charles C. Collingwood, news analyst for the Columbia Broadcasting System and a former student at the institute.
Six new films, including an importation from Ireland, are slated to arrive in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

Whether devaluation will lead to greater currency convertibility is a more important question than how much the recent devaluations by Great Britain and other nations may help those countries' exports, according to a study by the research department of the National Association of Manufacturers released for publication today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- Development of elaborate shopping centers in expanding suburban residential communities has become one of the chief features of the post-war realty market, but signs are appearing in some areas that this type of building activity may taper off in the early future, members of the National Institute of Real Estate Brokers were told today by commercial property experts.

Parishioners of St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church in the Bronx observed yesterday the 100th anniversary of their parish's founding. The church is at Franklin and Fulton Avenues and East 167th Street.

Delegates from fifty-eight nations are scheduled to foregather in Washington today for the annual conference of the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization (more familiarly known as the FAO). The average planner, someone has said, "is a man whose idea of solving an economic problem is to institutionalize it."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 20 -- News dispatches from Bucharest indicated today that the Soviet Government already had implemented its last week's success at the first session of the Danubian Commission by taking over control of Rumania's principal shipping line.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 20 -- Steel bookings reaching mills here last week were in such good volume that deliveries became somewhat extended on major steel products. It was said promises on hot-rolled and cold-rolled sheet were being made as far ahead as the second quarter of 1950.

A long-term leasehold covering the land and building at 401 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of East Thirty-seventh Street, a landmark that once served as the home of .Tiffany Co., has been sold by the Textron Company to clients of Charles G. Keller Co., brokers.

The presence in New York of Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, ruler of the ancient, undeveloped and highly potential kingdom of Iran, calls attention to another of the exposed borderlines on which the East-West contest turns. This is the main purpose of the Shah's visit to the United States.

If, as has been suggested, the Chinese Communists' imprisonment of United States Consul Angus Ward is a Machiavellian Russian plot to forestall quick United States recognition of the Peiping regime, it has been thoroughly successful. One such episode, in denigration of an American citizen, of an official of our Government, and of the United States itself, will weigh more heavily in the presumably forthcoming recognition debate than a hundred closely reasoned arguments about "expediency."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 -- On the basis of recent studies of fifty cerebral palsy patients, the University of Pennsylvania Medical School reported today that the Rh negative blood factor was a cause of deafness or impaired hearing in children.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 20 -The Motion Picture Industry Council, Hollwood's solid front public relations organization, established recently to defend the reputation of the film business, has announced creation of a new award -- "The Flagpole of the Month," for the person "who best rivals the traditional publicity-seeking flagpole-sitter," by "grabbing for headlines. * * * at the expense of Hollywood."

The Rev. Dr. William Culbertson, president of the Moody Bible Institute, Chicago, warned yesterday that it was possible to enjoy political freedom and still be in spiritual servitude. Spiritual freedom came when man realized the paternity of God and accepted full responsibility as a member of God's family, he said.

PARIS, Nov. 20 -- Jacques Griffe balances pleasing proportions of simplicity and drama in charming Christmas party gowns. The short, slim, decollete gowns are simply styled in dark, rich, pine green or garnet velvet, tones that evoke Christmas colors in a subdued version.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- Good holiday business was predicted today for the home furnishings industry, but while active demand will continue through the first half of 1950, the industry will experience sharply stepped-up competition next year.

ATHENS, Nov. 20 -- British soldiers stationed in Greece lined up today before the tomb of the Unknown Soldier facing Constitution Square. In full military pomp and with bands playing, they made their gesture of farewell.

An urgent plea in behalf of the boysenberry comes from William C. Forbes, a food broker in this city. The fruit, which was first marketed in 1935 in California, has gained great popularity on the West Coast. Even in Chicago boysenberry pie is a regular feature on many restaurant menus.
Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard reported yesterday that 320,699 persons, or 160,193 cases, received public assistance during October through the Department of Welfare.

MILWAUKEE, NOV. 20 (UP) -The passing of Joe Geri and the running Of Jerry Nuzum paced the Pittsburgh Steelers to a decisive 30-to-7 victory over the Green Bay Packers today before a crowd held to a scant 5,483 by cold, gray skies.

The striking incident of the week in the foreign exchanges was the break in forward sterling to a discount. This is the first setback since devalution in mid-September, and compared with the previous week-end showed a decline of from 1/16 cent in 30's, to 1/2 cent in 90's. Spot sterling, however, remained firm at $2.80 1/8.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The New York Rangers moved into a fourth-place tie in the National Hockey League tonight by defeating the Chicago Black Hawks before 15,206 fans, 5 to 2. The Rangers and Hawks now have thirteen points apiece in the standings.

Programs for the second week of the Metropolitan Opera, beginning next Monday, were announced yesterday, on the eve of its sixty-fifth opening night. Tonight's gala event will be a performance of Strauss' "Der Rosenkavalier," directed by Fritz Reiner and featuring the American debut of Erna Berger in the role of Sophie.

KINDLEY AIR FORCE BASE, Bermuda, Nov. 20 -- Bearded, haggard and weary, the eighteen survivors of last Wednesday's B-29 crash-landing at sea were brought ashore here today from the Canadian destroyer Haida which rescued them 334 miles northeast of Bermuda yesterday.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 20 -- The water resources of the South are good. Generally speaking, the yield of ground water (wells and springs) and surface water (streams and rivers) is plentiful. There are coastal areas with a threat of salt water intrusion due to overdrawing of ground water supplies, and in some highly industrialized sections there is a decline of water tables because of heavy pumpage and use of ground water.

ISELIN, N. J., Nov. 20 -- A thousand or more expert sidewalk superintendents watched today as the world's largest prefabricated bridge was rolled into place beneath two tracks of the Pennsylvania Railroad's four-track main line near here.

NEWARK, Nov. 20 -- State Senator Elmer H. Wene, defeated Democratic candidate for Governor of New Jersey, asserted today that he had enough votes to replace Frank Hague as leader of the State Democratic party.

PANAMA, Nov. 20 -- Vice President Roberto F. Chiari was sworn in as President of Panama today, succeeding Daniel F. Chanis Jr., who resigned early in the morning after an ultimatum from the heads of the National Police.

The steel industry will shun any pacemaker role in contract negotiations with John L. Lewis United Mine Workers, despite the reopening of the steel mills after a six-week strike and the consequent need for guaranteeing a steady supply of soft coal.

A fact-finding survey covering union hiring halls for unlicensed seagoing personnel is being conducted by a staff of a Senate subcommittee on Labor-Management Relations in preparation for the reconvening of Congress early next year, it became known yesterday.

The calamity of facial palsy usually strikes persons in the low income groups, so less-than-cost or free care is necessary to help them overcome their handicaps, according to Dr. Thomas G. Tickle, surgeon-in-charge of the Facial Palsy Clinic at Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital.
KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The establishment of an "independent nation" of Pushtunistan, on Afghanistan's eastern border, is being acclaimed here by press and radio.
The second Christopher Awards contest, "to provide better quality books, motion pictures and plays," was announced yesterday by Father James Keller, founder and director of the Christopher movement.

The New York Public Library's Composers Forum -- a showcase for aspiring young American composers -- had its second public concert Saturday night at Columbia University's McMillin Theatre. Judging from the applause from the large house, the event was a happy one for the two composers.

BILOXI, Miss., Nov. 20 -- A cooperative plan for the Southern states to correlate all higher education and research facilities in developing a regional program for social and economic improvement was submitted today to the Board of Control for Southern Regional Education.

Early in 1946 it looked as if the talents of Richard Korbel were being exploited. The 12-year-old pianist had already given four New York recitals and had appeared in a movie, "Ding Dong Williams." But someone wisely called a halt, and his recital on Saturday night at Carnegie Hall was his first here in almost four years.

Continuing an upward trend, American colleges and universities show a record enrollment of 2,510,981 students this fall, an increase of 57,347, or 2 per cent, over the previous high a year ago. However, the increase is found, for the most part, in the smaller institutions, community colleges, teachers' colleges and technological schools.

BEIRUT, Damascus, Nov. 20 -- Gordon L. Clapp and his associates of the Economic Survey Mission for the Middle East, which just presented its interim report to the United Nations, have reached the basic decision that what the Arab East needs are self-help and judicious aid on a limited scale, not great amounts of dollars.

TOKYO, Nov. 20 -- Because of measures taken at the occupation's insistence, trade is stagnating, stockpiles are mounting, employers are failing to meet payrolls and panic is waiting just around the corner, according to a document forwarded to Gen. Douglas MacArthur and the Japanese Government today by the Japan Management Association.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Eagles treated 22,165 fans to a brilliant exhibition of high - powered offensive and rock-ribbed defensive football today as the National League champions pulverized New York's Bulldogs, 42 to 0, at Shibe Park.

PARIS, Nov. 20 -- The statement of Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the British Exchequer, that the British monetary reserves are on the upgrade failed to produce a rise in the pound sterling on the foreign exchange market here. Since the beginning of November the pound has fluctuated slightly around 920 francs, although the official rate is 980.

A daily average of 8,229 visitors was recorded during the fiscal year 1948-49 in the Central Building of the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue. With uncounted thousands in the branches, they borrowed or consulted 12,000,000 books in the twelve months.

Enrollment in the nation's junior colleges dropped 3 per cent this year, but most institutions queried in THE NEW YORK TIMES survey said the decline was temporary and that they had yet to reach their record enrollment. The majority felt that the peak would come during the next few years, probably in 1953; although a few said the peak would be reached in the Nineteen Sixties, when the "war babies" reach college age.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Triple-threat George Taliaferro directed a crew of rookie Los Angeles Don backs to 21-10 victory over the Baltimore Colts in an All-American Conference football game before 19,503 in Babe Ruth Stadium today.

When the National Interfraternity conference holds its annual meeting this week, the eyes of a great many Americans -- including quite a few who can't tell one Greek letter from another -- will be watching it. For this organization, which consists of almost three-score national college fraternities, will be discussing some delicate phases of a question that touches the very fabric of democracy.
Our grandmothers wore stoles and loved them. So do we today. They came to life again as a fashion item some seasons ago and are still going strong because of their usefulness and charm.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Although the city is severely critical and distrustful of practically everything the present Socialist Government does in the financial and economic field, it does not hesitate to give praise on occasions when it thinks praise is due.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- Water resources of four central states, Illinois, Indiana, Michigan and Wis consin, are in good condition except in "critical areas." These are invariably industrial areas, where pumpage exceeds natural recharge of ground water.

The 1950 Mercury automobiles will be formally announced on Friday with large-space ads in 1,460 newspapers of 1,170 cities, it was announced over the week-end by Robert F. G. Copeland, advertising and sales promotion manager for the Lincoln-Mercury division of the Ford Motor Company.

An improvement in the administration of the Youthful Offender Law and "drastic reorganization" of New York State's reformatory system for youths were urged in a report issued yesterday by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer soon will inform the President that the Government needs a central policy body to guide all Federal transportation activities, officials reported today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Some 41,725 eager Americans, vanguard of hundreds of thousands who still await the opportunity, streamed into the National Gallery today to view a wealth of Vienna art being shown for the first time in this country.

Attendance at THE NEW YORK TIMES' third annual Boys and Girls Book Fair soared to a three-day total of 94,000 yesterday when 27,000 children and their parents leafed and gaped their way through the colorful exhibit at the American Museum of Natural History.

Bred in a theatrical atmosphere, Carroll Case, son of the late Frank Case, noted boniface of the Hotel Algonquin, is yearning to become a producer. In 1942 he made an attempt, but nothing materialized. Now Mr. Case and his partner, Henry Barsha, have scheduled for a late February presentation here "Sing to the Moon," an all-Negro play with music, set in Louisiana.

New York State, which distributed $127,000,000 in unemployment insurance tax refunds to employers with stable employment records this year, has no tax melon to cut for 1950. This was announced yesterday by Milton O. Loysen, executive director of the Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance of the State Labor Department.

NEWARK, Nov. 20 -- Father Divine, whose followers recently purchased the 270-room Riviera Hotel at High Street and Clinton Avenue here for a half-million dollars in cash, is negotiating for Temple Oheb Shalom, 672 High Street. That his offer is under consideration was verified today by the Rev. Louis M. Levitsky of East Orange, rabbi of Newark's second oldest synagogue.

Detroit's young Lions, the hard-luck team of the National Football League, finally exploded yesterday. Scoring in every period, they racked up six touchdowns and a field goal in romping to a 45-21 victory over the Giants before a Polo Grounds gathering of 21,338.

PARIS, Nov. 20 -- Franco-Polish diplomatic relations were involved tonight in a serious controversy that resulted from the arrest or disappearance of a French consular representative in Poland, missing from the plane in which he was supposed to have left Warsaw for Paris via Brussels.

Hope that Northern and Southern Ireland ultimately may be unified by the People of the Land Movement was expressed here yesterday by the Rev. John M. Hayes, Tipperary pastor who in 1937 originated the plan to check Irish emigration.

PLAINVILLE, Mass., Nov. 20 (UP) -- Patrick J. Parker, 18 years old, son of a wealthy New York family, told police today that he staged a holdup here to finance a "revenge" trip to Canada to kill the man accused of causing his father's death by putting a bomb on an airliner.

BERLIN, Nov. 20 -- Steady desertions from the "people's police," proof that Titoism is infecting the German Communist party, and a renewal of sabotage and violence against the East Zone Government are interfering seriously with Soviet policy in Germany, a senior Western official said today.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 20 (AP) -- An anonymous leaflet urging the army to rebel was distributed here today.

The Rev. Dr. Paul Austin Wolfe, minister of the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at Ninety-first Street, paid high tribute yesterday at the morning service to Dr. Clarence Dickinson, organist and choirmaster at the church for the last forty years, and Mrs. Dickinson, writer and lecturer.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -The Veterans Administration reminded ex-GI's today that there was another insurance deadline coming up Jan. 1.

IT could have been a lot worse. This has been a season of such bewildering upsets that a lot of sideline observers feared the boys would follow the same daffy script on Saturday and leave nothing but confusion behind them as most of them bade farewell to football. There were plenty of upsets, of course, but they were scattered judiciously around the premises and damaged little more than the feelings of the victims.

Albert S. Goss, head of the National Grange, in an address before the annual meeting of that organization the other day, paid his respects to the Brannan farm plan. Mr. Goss is old-fashioned enough to believe, it seems, that an economy that lives on such stimulants as government subsidies is headed in the general direction of moral and financial bankruptcy.

Enrollment in professional and technological schools reached a record high this year with a total attendance of 218,276 students. This is an increase of 17,174, or 9 per cent, over last year and a gain of 93,072 students, or 74 per cent, over 1941-42.
AMSTERDAM, Nov. 20 -- "Featherbedding" is now considered one of the main handicaps in the Dutch drive toward greater productivity.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Catholic Bishops of the United States declared today that family life at present was confronted by dangers more fearsome than the atom bomb."
