The National Association for American Composers and Conductors, Inc., gave its first free concert of the season in Times Hall last night. The evening was opened by Robert Russell Bennett, who spoke on the aims of the organization.

Since it never has been made clear by the All-America Football Conference whether the team that finishes first in the regular season or the one that prevails in the forthcoming Shaughnessy play-offs is to be the loop's champion, decision on precisely what the Cleveland Browns achieved yesterday at the Stadium will have to be suspended.

Astrologers by the hundred roamed the New Yorker Hotel yesterday, giving an astral beat to the ballroom, where the American Federation of Astrologers was holding its convention. Business, art, medicine, morals, all were scrutinized by astrologers for more than twelve hours.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 20 -- Although satisfied with the general political and international attitude of Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of the Bonn Republic, several Western Allied High Commission officials are concerned with what appears to them to be a dangerous association between the Chancellor and the leaders of the German heavy industry in the Ruhr.

NEWARK, Nov. 20 -- The grand Welsh terrier, Champion Twin Ponds Belle, made another winning stride in her distinguished show career by taking the top award today in the thirty-first all-breed event of the Newark Kennel Club.

Failure to relieve the material wants of the poor and unfortunate may lead to eternal damnation, the Rev. Michael J. Deacy declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. He is a member of the staff.

The time of deepening silence arrives and a world ready for sleep drowses through gray and brown days. The voice of the north wind is heard on the land and Earth's pulse slows to match the mood of the season. The Great Dipper hangs low in the heavens and on clear nights the stars glitter like pieces of mica scattered on a dark velvet curtain.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 20 -The water situation in the Northern Pacific states is spotty. Vast semi-arid stretches of California, North Central Oregon and South Central Washington require irrigation and the water supply, especially in California's Central Valley, is inadequate to meet the needs without lowering of the underground water level.

Another step in the Government's policy of cutting interest charges on the nation's debt, which has been increased steadily this year by deficit financing, was seen in the Treasury's announcement last week calling $2,000,000,000 of 2 per cent bonds, due 1950-52, for payment next March 15.

Ebe Stignani, Italian mezzo-soprano, was heard in a recital last night at Carnegie Hall. Backed by fame, the possessor of a genial personality and gifted by nature with a voluminous voice of wide range, Miss Stignani was fervently received by her large audience.

FAR HILLS, N. J., Nov. 20 -- Handled by his amateur owner, Hartwell Moore of Huntington, L. I., and against a field of outstanding contenders, Fellers Freckles, white and red cocker spaniel, won the open all-age stake for his breed in the feature of the New Jersey Spaniel Field Trial Club's two-day trials.

Your editorials of Nov. 12 and Nov. 14 err, I believe, in characterizing as mere "romance" and "fiction" reports by the Soviet press and Foreign Minister Vishinsky that atomic energy is being used in the Soviet Union for large-scale economic projects such as razing mountains and irrigating deserts.
LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Analysis of intelligence reports available here indicates that the Soviet Union has virtually incorporated the Polish Army into that of the U.S.S.R.

Increased ordering for spring lines, requests for holiday merchandise and colder weather last week stimulated business activity, according to a report on the wholesale apparel market here prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

VIENNA, Nov. 20 -- The Austrian Government agreed yesterday on new rates for the schilling to bring it into line with the pound sterling and other European currencies. Announcement of the new rates was to have been made at a press conference today but for a reason not stated it was postponed until Monday afternoon.

BOSTON, Nov. 20 -- Although New England is suffering from its worst drought in twenty-five years, Federal, state and private engineers attribute it to a periodic rainfall deficiency and not to a permanent lowering of the water level.

"THIS is a book on science and democracy and war and their relations to each other," says Dr. Vannevar Bush about his "Modern Arms and Free Men."* Dr. Bush, the dean of engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who became head of the wartime Office of Scientific Research and Development, is probably better qualified to write on his subject than any other man alive.
The United States faces heavy economic losses in the foreseeable future because of unplanned, excessive increases in the use of its most precious mineral resource -- water.

The total number of export credit collections paid by Latin-American countries during October rose by 656 items, in contrast with a decline of 4,237 items in September, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York will report today. The data are based on the collection experience of fifteen large banks in this city.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- The 700-ton Norwegian sealing ship Norsel, which will take members of the Norwegian - British - Swedish Antarctic Expedition to Queen Maud Land, arrived in the port of London today. The British contribution to the expedition's equipment will be put aboard at once and the Norsel will sail again Wednesday or Thursday.
OSLO, Norway, Nov. 20 -- An airliner carrying twenty-nine Jewish children from Tunisia, three women and a crew of three was missing tonight on a flight from Brussels to Oslo.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Miss Mellony Turner, 49 years old, an American Methodist missionary teacher who was interned in Bulgaria by the Nazis during the war and later named by Communists as a "contact" for churchmen charged with espionage, was fatally injured in an automobile accident today at Baldwinsville.

WARSAW, Nov. 20 -- Two French Embassy aides who were ordered to leave Poland because they were said to have engaged in espionage activities will depart for Sweden tomorrow, embassy officials disclosed today.
VIENNA, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Mrs. Robert A. Vogeler said here today that her husband told her last Wednesday by telephone that he was being followed constantly by Hungarian police.

If Panama were farther away and not bisected by an American canal we might dismiss a forcible change of government there as "just another Latin-American revolution." Panama's population is less than that of Boston or Pittsburgh. But a situation in that vicinity which permits the Chief of the State Police to compel the President to resign, as happened early yesterday morning, is of concern to us.

LAZOS, Nigeria, Africa, Nov. 20 (Reuters) -- Eighteen miners were killed and thirty-one others and several police injured in "grave disorders" in the coal mining area of Erugu about 280 miles east of here, on Friday, the Nigerian Government announced tonight.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 20 -Maj. Gen. John H. Hilldring, former Assistant United States Secretary of State, said here tonight that international supervision of Jerusalem's holy places might be achieved without involving the United Nations in disagreeable and unworkable administrative police responsibilities.

The Army transport Willard A. Holbrook, one of the oldest carriers in the service, has been retired and sent to the Federal reserve fleet anchorage in the James River, Virginia, the New York Port of Embarkation announced yesterday.

The Kremlin's answer to the Marshall Plan was the re-establishment of the Comintern in the form of the Communist Information Bureau -- the Cominform -- at a secret meeting in western Poland in September, 1947, and of the Eastern European Council for Economic Mutual Aid (CEMA) in January, 1949.

Cotton prices in the domestic market moved downward last week in a relatively quiet market. At the close on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 9 to 27 points lower than a week earlier. The nearer months were under more selling pressure than the distant positions.

VIENNA, Nov. 20 -- Robert A. Vogeler, representative of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company for southeastern Europe, has been missing since he left his hotel in Budapest for Vienna at 9 o'clock Friday morning and is believed to be in the hands of the Hungarian political police.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $54,635,395,598. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

Three transatlantic liners led by the Queen Elizabeth, a displaced persons transport and four passenger vessels from Caribbean and South American ports are due to arrive here today, providing a busy day for customs and immigration officials covering the eight ships.

The farther away officers of the Army, Navy and Air Force get from Washington, the more friendly interservice relations become, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower said yesterday at a rally of military reservists here. He was heard by 10,000 persons at the Kingsbridge Armory, Kingsbridge Road and Jerome Avenue, the Bronx.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said tonight that the recent suggestion by Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, that Western European countries should be more closely integrated economically was a "good idea."

The 30-year-old Shah of Iran received a rousing greeting on his arrival at the Pennsylvania Station yesterday for a five-day visit here. Later, at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel, he outlined a program of social reform for his ancient country.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 -- The first application of precast concrete elements for entire structures of multi-story residences has started in Heliopolis, a suburb of Cairo, Egypt, it was revealed here today by Karl P. Billner, president, Billner Vacuum Concrete, S. A.
HONG KONG, Nov. 20 -- Gen. Li Tsung-jen, Acting President of Nationalist China, arrived here by plane today and announced that he had come to receive treatment for stomach ulcers.

Army's harriers impressively, and somewhat surprisingly, romped off with top honors in the forty-first annual varsity cross-country championship of the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.
The intercollegiate football season runs its course this week, except for a curtain call to be taken by Notre Dame and Southern Methodist, along with a few other teams, Dec. 3.
Critics said on Sunday that the music of Joseph Goodman was good. Yesterday a neighbor said it was a violation of Section 181 of the Sanitary Code and detrimental to public health.

A strike of sixteen drivers failed to halt operations yesterday at the Long Island City bakery of the Hanscom Baking Corporation. Members of Local 802 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, quit work at 4:30 A. M. in a wage dispute, but Maurice K. Gott-fried, company president, said all had been replaced with supervisory employes.
California has taken over the job of chasing distant Notre Dame in The Associated Press football poll.
FRANKFORT, Nov. 21 -- Charging John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner in Germany, had broken an agreement with him, Shepard Morgan, finance adviser to the High Commissioner, resigned today.

There was a representative gathering of persons prominent in the diplomatic, military, judicial and Government worlds, as well as in society and business last night at the premiere performance of the sixty-fifth season at the Metropolitan Opera House. The gala occasion, marked by all the pomp of former openings, signalled the beginning of the formal winter social season.

A $17,500,000 welfare and rehabilitation program for 4,000 ill, aged and handicapped Jews, who are to be transported to Israel from Germany, Austria and Italy was announced yesterday by officers of the United Jewish Appeal.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 21 -- The Social Committee of the General Assembly approved tonight a "compromise" Australian proposal that urges member states to contribute to the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund.

Morris Pizer, president of the United Furniture Workers, one of the ten left-wing unions threatened with expulsion from the Congress of Industrial Organizations on the ground that they had worked for Communist party objectives, broke with the left wing yesterday and was immediately repudiated by the union's two other national leaders.

The Shah of Iran last night made a frank plea for military aid to assure survival of his nation. Avoiding mention of Russia, which borders his oil-rich country on the north, the youthful monarch of a 6,000-year-old kingdom said it would know how to use aid to repel an aggressor.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 21 -- the Mizrachi Women's Organization of America, major women's religious-Zionist group in the United States, today approved a budget in excess of $1,500,000 for operations in Israel in 1950.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 21 -- Colombia's Liberal party has pledged itself not only to abstain from the Presidential balloting Sunday, but also to withhold recognition from the regime that will stem from the vote.

The members of the Alma Trio, now in its third year as an ensemble, launched a chamber music series at Times Hall last night that should prove a high point of the season if the two programs that are to come match their first one.

The steel industry is bouncing back faster from the recent strike than it did after the last major one in 1946. The industry's operating rate this week -- less than two weeks after the backbone of the strike was broken -- will be 78.2 per cent of capacity.

Wearing British Army battle dress, with nine rows of ribbons, and his famous black beret, Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery of Alamein arrived yesterday on the Queen Elizabeth for a twelveday visit to this country. The Marshal, who is chairman of the Commanders in Chief Committee of the Western European Union, went on to Washington soon after the ship docked.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 21 -- Twenty Latin-American countries presented national flags here today to the Archbishop Stepinac Roman Catholic High School for Boys. Consuls General of the countries delivered the gifts and joined with church and school leaders in pledges of hemispheric friendship, understanding and peace.

A young man from Boston who the police said made the tactical error of stealing regularly from offering boxes in Holy Cross Church, 331 West Forty-second Street, wound up in custody at 6 o'clock last night. Holy Cross is the parish church of Msgr. Joseph A. McCaffrey, Roman Catholic chaplain of the Police Department.

MOSCOW, Nov. 21 -- A meeting arranged by the Soviet Women's Anti-Fascist Committee in honor of the International Democratic Women's Federation paid tribute tonight to Premier Joseph Stalin and, citing the words of Dolores Ibarruri, the veteran Spanish Communist leader, to "his struggle for peace."

It was a big evening for ermine, mink, flashing diamonds and floor-sweeping gowns as celebrities maneuvered their way through the crowded foyers for the opening performance last night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 21 (UP) -- A Negro who was shot after he refused to sit in the "Jim Crow" section of a Birmingham street car and the conductor who shot him were charged today with assault with intent to murder.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 21 -- Ann Sheridan today filed suit in the Federal court here against RKO Radio Pictures for $350,000 damages, alleging breach of contract and bad faith in connection with the film, "Carriage Entrance," in which she was to have played the leading role.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Although net earnings of the meat packing industry in 1949 are expected to show a further decline from preceding years, a recovery is likely in 1950, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago. However, the bank said no return to the high profits of the immediate post-war years was in sight.

Issues of new first mortgage bonds and new preferred stock of the Connecticut Light and Power Company with market value of more than $15,000,000 will be offered to investors today by an underwriting syndicate headed by Putnam Co., Charles W. Scranton Co. and Estabrook Co.
Bill Young, who sparked the Hillsdale (Mich.) team to an unbeaten, untied season, is the new leader of the country's college football scorers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- An appeal from a contempt of Congress conviction by Gerhart Eisler, the Communist leader who escaped from the United States on the Polish vessel Batory last May, was stripped From the docket by the Supreme Court today.

Too often in our very necessary concern for the needy children of New York we tend to forget the lonely old people who are living on old-age pensions. Sixty-seven dollars a month provides only meager heating, few warm clothes and only 92 cents a day for food.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 21 (AP) -- A group of Cleveland business men purchased the Cleveland Indians today and selected Hank Greenberg as club general manager for the next three years.

Reporting on operations of the Hilton Hotels Corporation for the first nine months this year, Conrad N. Hilton, president, informed shareholders yesterday that gross revenues were $30,105,502 against $30,982,451 in the corresponding period a year ago.

Some of Stravinsky's music, never performed previously in this country it is said, was played in Carnegie Hall last night by the Chamber Art Society under the direction of Robert Craft. Featured were Sara Carter, soprano; William Hess, tenor; Leon Lishner, baritone, and Vera Zorina, narrator. W. H. Auden read three of his poems and the choirs of Princeton and Bryn Mawr sang choral parts.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 21 -- At the request of the Netherlands Government, the Paris conference of French, Italian, Belgian, Luxembourg and Netherland experts to consider proposals for part integration of the five countries' economy has been postponed until early December.

GENEVA, Nov. 21 -- Next to some large, easily mined gold deposits in the British Isles the thing United States leaders in Europe would like most to uncover at this stage of the Marshall Plan is some real business statesmen in European industry.

Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, was invited yesterday to testify before the American Committee for the Investigation of the Katyn Massacre, Inc., concerning the slaying of 11,000 Polish war prisoners near Smolensk, Russia, early in World War II.

A campaign, said to be the biggest single push in recent years for rayon as an apparel material, will be started about March 1 by the E. I. du Pont de Nemours Company, Inc., with five and six-page, four-color spreads in seven major consumer, and five trade publications, it was learned yesterday.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Baltimore Ohio Railroad was doing well until the coal and steel strike began, Roy B. White, president, said at the annual stockholders meeting today.

The Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association is planning to expand its facilities in the foreign field, it was learned yesterday. To that end, the California institution, which operates a state-wide branch banking organization, has formed a new corporation to engage in international banking and financial activities.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 21 -- Eradication of racial and religious prejudice is one of the most effective means of opposing atheistic communism and preserving human liberty, Gov. Luther W. Youngdahl of Minnesota told the National Conference of Catholic Charities here today.

A. E. Matthews, already sufficiently celebrated as an actor, was preparing yesterday to become the world's most debonair octogenarian. He will assume this role today, when Lee and J. J. Shubert produce a birthday reception for him at the Astor Hotel.

VIENNA, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Hungarian Foreign Ministry in Budapest declared today that it "knows nothing about" Robert A. Vogeler, an American business man who disappeared in that Communist country four days ago.

After reaching a decision on the former Italian colonies yesterday the United Nations General Assembly decided by the close vote of 17 to 16, with 18 abstentions, not to take a vote on a Soviet resolution proposing a direct or collective United Nations trusteeship.

The television transmitter of WJZ-TV will shortly be moved from the Hotel Pierre to the top of the Empire State Building under authorization of the Federal Communications Commission, which has granted a request made by the American Broadcasting Company, owner and operator of the station.

Local professional football clubs, which last Sunday suffered through one of their worst days -- all three lost -- were none too happy yesterday. For two, at least, a break in the schedules eased the pain, since the Yankees boarded a plane for the Pacific Coast in the morning and the Bulldogs, due Sunday at Los Angeles, will entertain tonight.

GENEVA, Nov. 21 -- Rapid technological advances in the iron and steel industry are laying the basis for technological unemployment, the International Labor Office warned in a report made public today.

Your editorial of Nov. 13 on further action the United States owes both its European neighbors and its own taxpayers is a piece of clear reasoning on international affairs which should be applauded by all thoughtful citizens.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Sharp criticism of the widespread use of "ghost-writers" for speeches by public men featured a ruling today, in which the Supreme Court supported, 6 to 2, the United States Patent Office in prohibiting Vernon M. Dorsey of Washington, an 80-year-old lawyer, from practicing before it.

Woman's Hospital is having its face lifted in a-thorough Cleaning of the exterior and a complete interior renovation of the buildings at 141 West 199th Street. The hospital, one of the' eighty-six voluntary institutions for which the United; Hospital Fund-is conducting its current drive, has started a complete modernization program to keep in line with New York's high medical standards.

The report of Corporation Counsel McGrath on the city's condemnation proceedings in the latest court calendar year calls our attention to the huge task and expense almost always involved in one of the early steps of providing a new public improvement -- the acquisition of a site.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Directors of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co, today declared a year-end dividend of $1.50 a share on outstanding common stock, payable Dec. 14 to stockholders of record on Nov. 28.
Following is the text of a resolution on the former Italian colonies, which was approved yesterday by the United Nations General Assembly:

"Intruder in the Dust," a Metro Goldwyn-Mayer drama with David Brian, Claude Jarman Jr., Juano Hernandez, Will Geer, Porter Hall and Elizabeth Patterson heading the cast, will have its local premiere this morning at the Mayfair. Clarence Brown produced and directed from the novel by William Faulkner and a screen play by Ben Maddow.

HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Nov. 21 -- Barbara Pearson, 17 years old, of Central Islip, and Joseph / Shapiro, 17. of Smithtown, were fatal-! ly injured when the car in which they were riding Sunday night with four friends snapped off two! roadside poles on WheeleP Road, Hauppauge, before it overturned. Critically injured was John Tapley, 16, of Smithtown. The automobile, a complete wreck, was owned by Shapiro's mother.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The bipartisan resistance movement against the political philosophy and the cost of the federal system which President Truman is advocating as his immediate goal is now openly and powerfully led by James F. Byrnes of South Carolina, former Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, Mr. Truman's former Secretary of State, and a Senate party whip in the Roosevelt Administration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Hudson Pulp and Paper Corporation, New York, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 120,000 shares of $25 par value cumulative preferred stock Series B, to be offered at a price to be filed by amendment.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 21 -- Brig. Gen Carlos P. Romulo, President of the United Nations General Assembly, today gave instructions for distribution to all delegations of a wireless message from the Chinese Communist regime calling on the Assembly to unseat the Chinese Nationalist delegation.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 21 -- Albert S. Goss of Washington was re-elected today to his fifth consecutive two-year term as master of the National Grange.

William N. Margolis, assistant director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, arrived here yesterday from Washington to take part in the dispute between Atlantic and Gulf ship operators and the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots of America.

Tremendous improvements in shipping operation in recent decades have slashed the once lucrative and adventurous business of sea salvage, according to Rear Admiral C. H. Cotter, Civil Engineer Corps, USN, retired.
CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Savings associations are getting stiff competition from sellers of new cars, television sets, clothing, food, and vacations, and it's going to get stiffer.

Some colonies achieve independence and some have independence thrust upon them. The United Nations Assembly decided yesterday that Libya is to be united and free by Jan. 1, 1952, that Somaliland will be equally independent after ten years' trusteeship under Italy and that a commission will study the situation in Eritrea and report back by next June.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery was officially welcomed here this afternoon, but it became plain at once in official circles that by dropping in at this time the unpredictable "Monty" had created an awkward situation in military protocol.

WARSAW, Nov. 21 -- The Polish Government announced tonight that it had cracked a spy ring consisting of more than 100 persons as a result of the alleged confession of Andre Simon Robineau, an assistant at the French Consulate in Stettin (Szczecin).

The National Council of Jewish Women is closing its Council Home for Girls in Athens, Greece, on Dec. 31 because the need has been met, Mrs. Irving M. Engel, the council's new president, said yesterday at the Plaza Hotel. She spoke before 700 members of the New York section, of which she is a board member.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UP) -- Clark Griffith, owner of the Senators, celebrated his eightieth birthday today with a big party and a hope that Bucky Harris, his original "boy wonder" manager, will bring Washington another pennant.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Clark M. Clifford, President Truman's foremost policy adviser and an architect of the Fair Deal, will resign from the White House staff in January to start his own law practice here.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 21 -- The Israeli delegation to the United Nations made it clear today that the Tel Aviv Government had no intention of softening its opposition to the proposed internationalization of Jerusalem.

Zinka Milanov, former Metropolitan Opera star, arrived here and repeated denials that she had been a spy in Yugoslavia for the United States and also was a close friend of Premier Marshal Tito. The charges were made last month by a Russian newspaper.

Fashions with the magic formula of success were presented at Russeks yesterday afternoon. They were a group of Henry Rosenfeld dresses with the four qualities for which this designer is famous: good price, interesting fabrics and excellent fashion, plus that all-important matter of workmanship.
MONTREAL, Nov. 21 (UP) -- Kid Gavilan, Cuban welterweight contender, outboxed Parisian Laurent Dauthuille to win the unanimous: decision in a 10-round bout tonight.

As the last of the day's 31,000 visitors filed reluctantly out of THE NEW YORK TIMES' third annual Boys and Girls Book Fair yesterday 9-year-old Sydney Schwartz of the Bronx sat alone in an alcove immersed in the adventures of a wayward dachshund.

Municipal Court Justice Jehial M. Roeder ruled yesterday in favor of New York University in the proceedings to evict tenants on Washington Square South to make room for the university's proposed $3,000,000 law center. He held in effect that the Sharkey Rent Law did not apply in the case.

Practical reason for giving thanks this Thanksgiving is the fact the traditional feast will cost less than that of last year. This is mainly because turkeys are considerably cheaper, as much as 20 cents a pound in some stores, according to the City Department of Markets.

Boxing fans who find appeal in the appearance of Joe Louis, for competition or exhibition, will have their chance tonight in Newark. The Brown Bomber, pursuing the exhibition schedule he makes routine when the fit seizes him, is to face Joe Cheshul, young Bayonne heavyweight, in a ten-round bout at Newark's Sussex Avenue Armory.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced yesterday the arrest of three men in connection with a $100,000 loan racket operated through two former employes of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, 295 Madison Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UP) -- Federal Communication Commissioners were impressed today by the first comparative tests of color television.

PARIS, Nov. 21 -- The British invitation to President Auriol was associated with the strained relations between the British and French Governments during the last year to which British Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin alluded in Common Thursday in saying the French had no ground for questioning Britain's sincerity regarding joint defense.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the country's largest private employer, confirmed yesterday reports that it had liberalized its noncontributory pension plan to bring minimum benefits for its 600,000 employes into line with those provided under the Bethlehem Steel "formula."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The text of the State Department announcement on Secretary of State Dean Acheson's message to thirty foreign governments on the Angus Ward case follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that associates of directors of an insolvent New York corporation were entitled to a full dividend on the company's debentures that the associates bought at a discount.

In a colorful ceremony the last British military units have made their farewell to Greece. Their going is the symbol of the passing of a phase in modern Greek history. It recalls the heroic and ill-fated stand in the peninsula against the German onslaught. It recalls the return of the Britons for the campaign of liberation and the firm stand that was made to forestall a Communist coup.
Throughout a world still in the grip of an uneasy peace, Americans will ask God's blessing upon family and food as they gather Thursday for the traditional celebration of Thanksgiving.
While the stage was being set and the seats dusted for the opening of the Metropolitan Opera's sixty-fifth season, a memorial ceremony took place in the opera lounge late yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board heard arguments today in unfair labor practice cases resulting from a two-year strike of farm workers against the Di Giorgio Fruit Farm Corporation in California.

The four-story building at 532-38 West 122d Street, known as the University Garage, has been resold after a year's ownership by Herbert J. Schmitz of Chicago to a client of Nathan Immerman, attorney. The property, on a plot 100 by 90 feet, was held at $240,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner today recommended that commutation fares on the Central Railroad of New Jersey between New York City and points in New Jersey be reduced 8 per cent and that commutation fares of the Erie, Lackawanna and Lehigh Valley Railroads be brought up to the new level of the Jersey Central's fares.
New York State moved yesterday to protect a $14,000,000 claim against the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road, which is now undergoing reorganization.

The voluntary hospitals of New York State are getting into a "tolerably decent economic position" and do not need subsidies from the state, Dr. Eli Ginzberg, director of a fifteen-month hospital study just completed for the state by Columbia University, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The emergence and multiplication of big-business establishments in this country have been accompanied by an unrivaled gain in the public well-being, Herman W. Steinkraus, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, said today.

The Shah of Iran opened an exhibit of the art of his country at the Metropolitan Museum of Art last night before 3,500 members of the museum and their guests. The exhibit, consisting of 105 treasures from the imperial collections and the museums of Iran, will be open to the public, beginning today, for three months.
PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 21 (AP) -- It will be California and Ohio State in the Rose Bowl Monday, Jan. 2.

I must send in an answer to the letter from Nicholas Nessin of Washington Crossing, Pa. He compares his farm job in the United States in 1947 to farm workers on a collective in the U.S.S.R. in the years between 1934 and 1937. A more truthful comparison would be the lot of the average farm worker in the United States during those years.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Nov. 21 (UP) -- The eighteen survivors of a B-29 superfortress who were rescued after a three-day ordeal in liferafts in the stormy Atlantic are well on their way to recovery, it was made known tonight.
A compromise resolution on the disposition of the former Italian colonies was approved yesterday by the United Nations General Assembly by a vote of 48 to 1.

The forty-sixth annual championship tournament of the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League, oldest court circuit in the country, opens on Saturday, Dec. 10, with Yale facing Pennsylvania at New Haven, according to the schedule announced yesterday by Asa S. Bushnell, secretary-treasurer of the league.

Profit-taking yesterday abruptly altered the strong forward movement of last week and steady though moderate selling reduced prices fractions to slightly more than a point with a few wider losses. The weakness in du Pont, which accompanied a year-end dividend declaration smaller than had been expected by most observers, accounted for a drop of 1.25 points in the price averages.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UP) -- Attorney General J. Howard McGrath said today that millions of housewives would benefit through lower food prices if the Government wins its anti-trust suit against the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Pan American World Airways asserted today that its offer to pay cash instead of stock for American Overseas Airlines had removed two complaints raised against the proposed transaction.

The Sheffield Farms Company, Inc., has purchased the one-story factory building on the south side of Herkimer Street, 320 feet west of Brooklyn Avenue, in Brooklyn from the Enra Company. The property occupies an irregular plot about 45 by 185 feet. Alger, Peck, Andrews Rohlfe were attorneys for the buyer.

Continuing the reaction of recent days coffee futures moved sharply lower yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Trading was extremely active with prices moving erratically. Long liquidation and trade selling found buyers only on a scale down. Easiness in spot coffees helped the decline in futures prices. There was some demand from producer interests.

PANAMA, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Samuel Lewis Jr., and Education Minister Jose Isaac Fabrega resigned tonight from the Cabinet of the new President, Roberto F. Chiari. They quit because the police heads who had led a successful week-end coup were still at their posts.

Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan's much-discussed painting, "The Path of Investigation," a quick oil sketch of two pumpkin-headed figures, was sold for $75 last night at an auction sale for the Urban League.

Whittaker Chambers testified yesterday that Communist party approval was sought and obtained by Alger Hiss before he changed jobs from the Nye Senate Munitions Investigating Committee to the Department of Justice and thence to the State Department in the Nineteen Thirties.

A five-inch snowfall, a few bucks, plenty of does, a multitude of hunters and perefct field conditions in the DeBruce area made for quite a week-end, even though none of our group of four fired a shot.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- John L. Lewis today challenged the credentials of former Federal Judge Charles I. Dawson of Louisville, Ky., when the latter sought to take his seat as a member of the United Mine Workers Welfare Fund trustees.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 21 -- The United States announced today it would support a resolution to have the United Nations General Assembly ask the International Court of Justice for an advisory opinion on South Africa's legal obligation, if any, to place the former mandated territory of South-West Africa under international trusteeship.
Cardinal Spellman made a nation-wide plea yesterday afternoon for support of the Catholic Church's Thanksgiving drive for clothing and soap for families in Europe, the Near East and the Far East.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Books of the Ypsilanti (Mich.) Machine and Tool Company were altered at a hastily arranged meeting in Preston Tucker's Chicago apartment two days before they were shown to the grand jury, a witness in the Tucker fraud trial testified today.
Spot prices of tin were reduced yesterday 10 cents a pound to 85 cents by the Tin Sales Corporation, selling agency for the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
A special meeting of stockholders of Dunhill International, Inc., will be held on Dec. 5 to consider a plan to reduce the capital by 45,866 common shares, it was announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Government today filed in Federal Court here a civil anti-trust suit charging four corporations with unreasonably suppressing competition in the manufacture, sale and lease of peach pitting machines.

The United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, expelled from the Congress of Industrial Organizations on charges of Communist domination, expressed willingness yesterday to match its popularity with its new CIO rival in National Labor Relations Board elections next March 15.

A funeral service for the Right Rev. William T. Manning, retired Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, will be held at noon today in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The rites are expected to be among the most elaborate ever held in the cathedral.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 7 per cent last week in comparison with the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The drop for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 6 per cent.

BILOXI, Miss., Nov. 21 -- James F. Byrnes, former Secretary of State, declared in a speech tonight that the American people in their reliance on the Government to provide security, had reached the point where they now "seem to be more afraid of life than of death."

I did not wish to comment upon the transit controversy between Commissioner Robert Moses and Paul Windels during the heat of a political campaign. This transit problem should not become a political football, as it affects all the people of all political parties.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- Business in the London stock markets today was slow. Although lack of buying tended to depress prices, the general undertone was steady. British Government issues were quiet and after fluctuating during the day closed at Friday's levels, with the exception of a few fractional gains and losses.

The first evidence of favorable results in the meat industry from Marshall Plan aid to Denmark was reported yesterday by A. Hempel, president of Hafnia Ham Company, that country's largest meat processing establishment. Because of American grain shipments to Denmark, the first post-war shipments of premium canned hams are now on the way to this country, he said.

BERLIN, Nov. 21 (AP) -- A United States Congressional committee said here tonight it would recommend including West Germany in the Western European Union, but advised against any early withdrawal of occupation forces. The four-man group is a study mission of the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The United States made a bid today for a world-wide protest to the Chinese Communists against the ill treatment of the American consular staff at Mukden during the past year. This treatment was capped last month by the imprisonment of Angus Ward, the Consul General, and four others.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UP) -- Senator Harry F: Byrd, Democrat, of Virginia, persistent critic of President' Truman's fiscal policies, believes Federal spending can be cut $10,000,000,000 without impairing Governmental functions.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Prices of corn continued rising on the Board of Trade today, with deferred deliveries at a new high for the year and December in new ground since last February. Final trades were at gains of 1 to 1 1/2 cents on the day.

Houston will be added to the growing list of American cities that are building up their municipal fleets when a new seventeen-knot, $187,500 fireboat enters service next year. It will supplement the protection given by the 23-year-old, six-and-a-half knot craft now in service.

The Metropolitan Council of Christian Churches was organized yesterday at a meeting at the National Bible Institute, 340 West Fifty-fifth Street, by representatives of eleven Protestant congregations.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21 -- Federal Judge George B. Harris denied a defense motion for a mistrial in the Harry Bridges perjury and conspiracy case today and warned the defense that its actions, if persisted in, might lead to a citation for contempt.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Democrats who were gloomy about their own party finances not much more than a year ago took a snooty view in the White House today at Republican plans for a $1-a-plate Lincoln Day supper.

Miss Gertrude Freeman will give a cocktail party this afternoon at her home, 141 East Seventy-second Street, for the committee in charge of the sale of tickets for the performance of "That Lady," with Katharine Cornell in the leading role, on the night of Dec. 8 at the Martin Beck Theatre.

GRAND RAPIDS, March., Nov. 21 -- A move to eliminate racial segregation in Methodist educational institutions is being quietly pressed by a group of denominational youth leaders, it was learned here today.

The Hoover Commission in its report of last March gave a good deal of attention to the Government's role in national transportation. "The major weaknesses in federal transportation policy," declared the Commission, "clearly arise from a failure in practice to recognize that the primary objective must be to assure the nation the best possible system for the movement of persons and goods."

The Metropolitan Opera, opening its sixty-fifth season last night, marked the beginning of the end of an era. It was the start of Edward Johnson's fifteenth and final season as general manager, and everyone connected with America's oldest opera company was determined to make it memorable.
SEA ISLAND, Ga., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Vice President and Mrs. Alben Barkley arrived at their own Shangri-La tonight. They checked in at this luxurious resort on the Atlantic Ocean shortly after 5 P. M.

In a move that may have an important bearing on the fight of Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, CIO, for a forty-hour week on the city subways, the office of Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson agreed yesterday to recommend a reduction in the work week of employes on the municipal ferries with no cut in pay.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the Philadelphia Transportation Company may deduct in its 1940 income tax return interest of $1,787,206 paid to redeem predated coupons on its consolidated mortgage bonds.
The perspective drawing of a room setting designed around a pair of French bronze candelabra won first prize for a former Army Air Forces pilot in an interior decoration contest.

An otherwise gloomy picture in the popular price dress industry is brightened by comparatively good sales of cottons, it was learned yesterday. Southern stores are leading all others in the purchase of cottons and they are seeking early deliveries. Stores in other localities, it was said, are buying first lines of cottons also for December and January selling.

Directors of the J. I. Case Company yesterday authorized for payment on Jan. 1 a year-end dividend of $2.80 a share on the common stock. In addition, they voted an increased quarterly dividend of 75 cents a share for payment to common stockholders on April 1.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 21 (AP) -- A triple elopement of six 'teenagers from Brooklyn faded out today at Harrisburg just as a transcontinental automobile trip was fairly getting started.
Nine college football teams have completed perfect seasons and seven others are nearing that feat.

TRENTON, Nov. 21 -- Ten major railroads operating in New Jersey made a second move today to extend to intrastate travel the 12 1/2 per cent passenger rate increase allowed recently by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Treasury announced today that it had accepted bids for $1,000,861,000 of ninety-day Treasury bills to be dated Nov. 25, and to mature Feb. 23, which were offered on Nov. 18.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 21 (UP) -- The Reds followed an apparently inevitable trend today and announced they would increase the number of night baseball games they play at home next year.
TRENTON, Nov. 21 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that a husband employed by his wife could not collect workmen's compensation if he suffered an injury or disability while working.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 21 (AP) -- My Ned topped off an afternoon of upsets in the featured $3,500 Leonardtown Purse, billed as a prep for Thursday's Endurance Handicap, by speeding to a two-length victory at an $18.40 pay-off for $2 today.

Abraham L. Pomerantz, newly engaged defense counsel for Valentin A. Gubitchev, said yesterday that he would ask today for a month's delay in the trial of the Russian engineer and Judith Coplon former Department of Justice employe, on charges of conspiracy and espionage.

Thirty countries, including Russia, Czechoslovakia and Poland, have either diplomatic or consular representatives still in China. Each of those countries should be concerned, as Secretary Acheson stated in the messages to them which were made public yesterday, "over the treatment of the American consular staff in Mukden."

"I'VE been in football a very long time," admitted Lou Little, a note of wonder in his voice, "but I saw something on Saturday in the Columbia-Brown game that I don't ever remember seeing before. Here's the situation. We're tied at 7-all and Brown has to kick from deep in its own territory. The punt is good, so long that the whole Brown team tears downfield under it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The controversial International Commodity Clearing House project, uppermost at the fifth conference of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization that opened today, seemed slated for "continued study" at the session's end about two weeks hence.

The financial report of the Board of Higher Education for the year ended June 30, 1949, is an interesting document, and especially worthy of attention now in connection with the nationwide studies under way for sounder financing of higher education. A considerable broadening of the base of support of the city's four colleges is noted.

VALLEY FORGE, Pa., Nov. 21 -- The first annual Freedoms Foundation awards, consisting of 121 cash prizes amounting to $72,000, and 203 gold medals, were made here this afternoon at an impressive ceremony presided over by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University.

The tune was familiar and quickly recognized by the Football Writers Association when, at the weekly luncheon-meeting at Toots Shor's yesterday, West Point's representative declared: "Army has a lot of respect -- and should have -- for Navy."

The Boston Metropolitan District borrowed $8,350,671 yesterday on tax-exempt obligations ranging from $7,650,000 of Series B bonds, due from 1950 to 1979, to $297,671 of Series D loan notes, due Nov. 24, 1950.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today business was good in October despite the steel and coal strikes and that there are signs it will be better in the months ahead.

The report of the National Container Corporation for the first nine months of this year disclosed a decline in the net profit to $1,773,905 after all deductions from $5,124,469 in the nine months ended on Sept. 30, 1948.

New York State's squirrel hunting season closed last week, save on Long Island, where the rules are different, specialized and iconoclastic. At a little after 5 o'clock on Thursday it was possible for the first time in a month to sit down quietly without fear of an alarm, with subsequent excursion into the near-by woods.
ROME, Ga., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Whether twelve men will stand trial in United States District Court for the flogging of seven Negroes was the issue put up to Judge Frank A. Hooper tonight.

As the Atomic Age encompasses more and more of the world, the need for competent scientific investigation of the nation's ground water resources becomes increasingly vital. Wider knowledge of the sources of supply, scientists and Government officials say, would be basic to the country's conduct in the event of a national emergency.
Annual Thanksgiving services will be held Thursday in the country's churches and at many synagogues with special sermons, music, pageants and prayers for peace.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 21 -- After members had expressed concern over the growing water shortage in Westchester, the Board of Supervisors voted unanimously this afternoon to have its committee on miscellaneous affairs study the causes and effects of the drought and steps to prevent a future crisis.

Transport Workers Union drivers operating buses of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation in central Bronx have been engaged in a slowdown impairing service in that area, officials of the company charged last night.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- Britain's Labor Government refused tonight to order an inquiry into the most conspicuous financial fiasco of its administration, the East African peanut-growing project that was designed to be the biggest single colonial development enterprise in the Empire's history.

Katharine Cornell brings her starring vehicle, "That Lady," to the Martin Beck Theatre this evening at 8 o'clock. Wearing a black patch over her right eye, Miss Cornell, who is returning to Broadway after an absence of a year, will portray Ana de Mendoza, the one-eyed Spanish princess of the sixteenth century. Featured in the company are Henry Daniell, Torin Thatcher, Henry Stephenson and Joseph Wiseman.

VIENNA, Nov. 21 -- Devaluation of the Austrian schilling from the official rate of 10 to $1 to a basic rate of 14.4 and a provisional premium rate of 26 to $1 was formally announced by the Austrian Government today. Between these two extremes will be an "effective" rate of 21.36 that may turn out to be the rate at which Austria can eventually stabilize the schilling.

ROME, Nov. 21 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi returned to Rome today after acquainting himself during the course of a one-day inspection tour of Calabria with what can be done to help the landless peasants of that region.

OSLO, Norway, Nov. 21 -- Despite fog, heavy rain and strong winds, war planes and civil aircraft of Norway, Sweden, Denmark and the Netherlands searched in vain today for trace of the missing airliner with twenty-nine Jewish children and six adults aboard.

Italy is now undertaking a comprehensive drive to increase exports to the United States, Dr. Clemente Boniver, commercial counselor to the Italian Embassy in Washington, said in an interview yesterday.

Since this is the centenary of Strindberg's birth, On-Stage is beginning its third season by putting on his long one-act play, "Creditors." Although it opened for the general public last Tuesday at the Cherry Lane Theatre, it was not licensed for the reviewers until last evening. Strindberg is too uncomfortable as a writer to achieve general popularity in the theatre.

Great issues of religious freedom still are unresolved in the Soviet Union, but seen at first hand the staying power of the Russian "believer," after thirty years of anti-religious propaganda and persecution, is impressive proof that the state as of this date still has not succeeded in establishing absolute moral dominion over the masses of people outside the Communist party.
WOODBURY, N. J., Nov. 21 -- A teen-age corner for the exclusive use of high school students was dedicated here today in the Deptford Institution Free Library.

OTTAWA, Nov. 21 -- Responsibility for the loss of 118 lives in the burning of the Great Lakes steamer Noronic at Toronto on Sept. 17 has been placed heavily on the owners and master of the ship, and in a lesser measure on junior officers and crew members, in a judgment handed down today by Justice R. L. Kellock.

The gross freight revenues earned by foreign shipping in United States trading are as large, and probably larger, than before the war, according to a report by Frazer A. Bailey, president of the National Federation of American Shipping.

Any real estate purchased recently from the Long Island Rail Road remains subject to the "first and paramount" lien that New York State is claiming against the property of the bankrupt commuter line, Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (UP) -- Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer reported today that Government efforts to halt illegal exports of strategic materials is paying off.

Seems that the Yankees, or at least that part of their organization that has to do with baseball, still haven't straightened themselves out on how the rule applying to high school athletes operates and it could be that General Manager George M. Weiss is thinking seriously of getting his scouts to attend night classes to learn how it works.
Notre Dame is "champion of champions" in modern college football.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Ten members of the House of Representatives from New York appealed today to the United States delegation to the United Nations to seek a United Nations resolution "condemning the anti-Jewish policy of Iraq."
HONG KONG, Nov. 22 -- Gen. Liu Po-cheng, commander of the Communist drive into Southwest China, has issued a radio appeal for the surrender of all four southwestern provinces.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The State Department said today that the second phase of the "exploratory" talks on atomic energy policy by the United States, Great Britain and Canada will get under way here on Nov. 28.

NEWARK, Nov. 22 -- An industry-wide strike in six North Jersey counties today closed down ninety laundries servicing 300,000 families. Forty-five hundred men and women in production, sales and maintenance departments, organized in three American Federation of Labor locals, are involved.

BERLIN, Nov. 22 -- Dr. Leo Herwegen, Christian Democrat and former Minister of Labor and Social Welfare in Saxony-Anhalt, is under arrest with seven associates charged with "crimes against the people's property," Otto Grotewohl, Premier of the Eastern German Government, announced tonight.

Just as the thermometer took a nose dive, a message arrived from Grover and Bill King of the Pelican at Stuart, Fla., reporting that the weather was pleasant and the river teeming with some really nice snook.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The interstate commerce commission today affirmed earlier decisions by one of its three-member divisions that the test to be applied in determining whether or not anyone operating motor vehicles is a private carrier, is this: What is his primary business?
ALBANY, Nov. 22 -- Appointment of a citizens' council to assist the Education Department in improving high school education in New York State was announced today by the Board of Regents.

Marion B. Folsom, treasurer of Eastman Kodak Company, declared last night that unless defects in the Federal Social Security program were corrected soon, the country faced the danger of losing the plan and adopting a charity approach to the problem of old-age insurance.

HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 22 (AP) -- The appointment of Laurence G. Tighe, university treasurer, as acting athletic director and acting chairman of the Board of Athletic Control at Yale University, was announced tonight by President Charles Seymour.

Several York County, Pa., bedroom furniture manufacturers may increase prices 2 to 8 per cent at or before the January homefurnishings markets, it was learned yesterday. Producers emphasized that they are doing everything possible to hold the price line but added increased lumber and other costs cannot be absorbed much longer.

Studio audiences at television broadcasts should either be eliminated or placed in the balconies, Arthur Godfrey, radio and television star, told 700 members and guests of the Fashion Group, Inc., at a luncheon yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet but strong yesterday, closing with gains of 10 to 21 points and near the best levels of the day.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 22 -- The United Nations General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee completed its work today. It was the first of the Assembly's seven main committees to do so at this fourth regular session.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The American Council of Education asked the Veterans Administration today to ease the new "regulation 1-B" which limits the freedom of war veterans to change colleges or courses.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 22 -- India and Sweden, whose Governments thus far have fought clear of allying themselves with either the Soviet Union or the Western powers, announced today that they would vote for a United States-British resolution calling on all members of the United Nations to comply with the Charter and other international obligations.
ROME, Ga., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Imperial Wizard Samuel Roper of the Ku Klux Klan today announced "a working agreement" had been reached with the Federated Klans of Alabama.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- A concerted bipartisan Congressional effort to block all plans for a dispersal of industry as a protection against possible atomic bombing gave rise in Capitol quarters today to a charge of "scare" tactics against the military forces.

The State of Delaware borrowed yesterday $28,369,000 on issues of bonds maturing on Dec. 1, 1950 to Dec. 1, 1969, at an interest cost of about 1.34 per cent. The bonds were sold at competitive bidding to a banking syndicate headed by the Chase National Bank on a bid of 100.50 for interest of 1.40 per cent.

Televised programs may be acted out against bare curtains as backdrops as a result of a strike by set and costume designers called last night by the United Scenic Artists, AFL, against five major television companies.

The Murray Corporation of America, major steel fabricator and one of the nation's largest producers of automotive bodies and assemblies, will enter into national distribution of "moderate priced" home appliances early in 1950, it was announced yesterday in Detroit.

Now that the federal public housing program is being launched, it is important to call the Commissioner's and other public officials' attention to the fact that it is vital to include plans for building apartments to house the middle income group as well as the low income group.

Dr. Simon Bernstein, widely known Hebrew scholar and since 1922 director of the Palestine Bureau of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, was the guest of honor yesterday at a luncheon marking his retirement. He recently observed his sixty-fifth birthday.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- A fight over the estate of Dr. Joseph Whittlesey Noble, Hong Kong industrialist and financier, was bared in court here today when his widow, Mrs. Ethel Darby Noble of Bronxville, asked Surrogate Charles H. Griffiths for the appointment of a temporary administrator.
PANAMA, Nov. 22 (UP) -- Shooting also broke out near the offices of an opposition newspaper, The Panama American, the National University, police headquarters, and the "model" jail.

The one church, other than the Russian Orthodox, that benefited, at least in part, from the Kremlin shift on religion was the Apostolic Church of Armenia, one of the oldest religious bodies in Christendom and the principal custodian of Armenian nationalism.
The establishment of the first international guard force, a corps of 300 trained and uniformed persons to assist the United Nations, was approved yesterday by the General Assembly at Flushing Meadow.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 22 -- Former Haganah intelligence chief, Col. Iser Beeri, was found guilty of manslaughter today in connection with the miscarriage of justice last year when Meir Tobiansky, Haganah officer, was condemned and shot outright on the charge of treason.
New issues of bonds and common stock of New York State public utility companies, having a total value of more than $9,800,000, will be offered to investors today.

You are to be commended for the clear, fair and persistent way in which you keep the Displaced Persons problem before the public. During nearly four years I was in charge of the extensive educational, social and welfare program conducted by the World's Y. M. C. A. for Displaced Persons in Austria and Germany.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Application of the multilingual system of interpreting used at the United Nations to the teaching of languages was demonstrated here today at the Institute of Languages and Linguistics of the School of Foreign Service, Georgetown University.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 22 -- Arthur Barry, notorious Long Island jewel thief released from Attica Prison last week after serving nineteen years, went free in County Court here today. Sentence on six additional indictments dating back to the 1920's was suspended by Judge Henry J. A. Collins upon recommendation of District Attorney Frank A. Gulotta.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 22 -- The United States delegation to the General Assembly is considering the advisability of submitting a resolution calling on all members of the United Nations to respect the territorial integrity of China, lit was disclosed tonight.

TOKYO, Nov. 22 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida today for the second time warned the Diet against careless discussion of a Japanese peace treaty. Such talk, he indicated, might prejudice some of the Allied nations against Japan's aims.
The critical tuberculosis situation in New York is "the skeleton in the city's closet," it was charged yesterday by Dr. Eli Ginzberg, director of the New York State Hospital Study.

THE art of conversation, it is often held, is as extinct as the brontosaurus. It did not languish in a long decline, but was foully done to death by two accomplices in murder -- bridge and the wise crack. If it ever tries to rise from its grave it is doomed to be struck down again at once by television. That such generalizations are false seems to me to be obvious.

MANILA, Wednesday, Nov. 23 (UP) -- Twelve Philippines constabulary troopers were killed yesterday in a pitched battle with 300 Communist - led Hukbalhap rebels in Batangas Province, south of Manila, constabulary headquarters said today.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Business remained at low ebb in a somewhat lethergic stock market today. But a limited amount of buying of British Government stocks resulted in a fairly general rise of one-eighth to one-quarter point.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- The Navy team that stands between Army and its fifth undefeated football season in six years today drew the highest praise Earl Blaik has bestowed upon the midshipmen since they last defeated the cadets in 1943.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Representative Paul J. Kilday, Democrat, of Texas, today told President Truman that the proposed elimination of medical benefits for dependents of service personnel probably would shatter hopes of keeping recruitment at a safe level.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Department of Justice is preparing for speedy action on some cases referred to it by the National Labor Relations Board involving union officials who have signed non-Communist affidavits under the Taft-Hartley law.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The United States Naval Institute has decided in "the best interest of the Navy" to refrain from publishing testimony of naval and Marine Corps officers before the House Armed Services Committee.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- A new plan for reorganization of Keeshin Motor Freight Lines, Inc., was filed today in United States District Court here by the trustees, William F. Drohan and Daniel D. Carmell. The plan involves a cash offer of $1,940,000 by Pacific Intermountain Express Company, San Francisco.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 22 -- The plan of two Dutch Cabinet Ministers to leave for Batavia Friday reflects the Government's concern over implementation of the Hague conference agreements on the Indonesian sovereignty.

Nine times within the space of a half hour the General Assembly of the United Nations at Flushing Meadow yesterday voted by an overwhelming margin to ask the Security Council to reconsider the membership applications of nine countries.

As has been her holiday custom, benefactress arrived at the Eisman Day Nursery School, 304 West Eighty-eighth Street yesterday, laden with gifts and turkey dinners for the 170 children at the nursery. The children, who are left there by working mothers, represented thirty-seven nationalities.

The National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, yesterday received a week's postponement of negotiations with East and Gulf Coast steamship operators to revise their demands, William N. Margolis, assistant director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, said yesterday, after a brief joint session.

The Magnavox Company and its dealers will break their largest television and radio-phonograph Christmas sales promotion early next month, it was announced yesterday. In addition to opening magazine spreads, a comprehensive promotion kit is being distributed to dealers.

David B. Tolins, attorney for a group of ten tenants on Washington Square South, facing eviction from the site of the proposed $3,000,000 New York University law center, said yesterday that he would not appeal a Municipal Court ruling that the Sharkey rent law does not apply in the proceedings.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Phillip L. Isenberg of Hartford, Conn., first-string defensive quarterback, today was elected captain of Harvard's 1950 varsity football team. The 19-year-old junior was the Crimson's 175-pound boxing champion during his freshman and sophomore years.

Atlas Tack Corporation, for the second time this year, has been warned by the New York Stock Exchange to publish promptly its quarterly statements of earnings or face suspension of its common stock from dealings.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 22 -- The Mark Twain papers, one of the most valuable collections ever left by a major American writer, will be permanently housed eventually at the University of California, Dr. Robert G. Sproul, president, said today. The author's only living daughter, Clara Clemens Samossoud, will bequeath the papers to the university, he added.
VIENNA, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Mrs. Vogeler broke down in sobs today when she heard that the Hungarian Government had announced the arrest of her husband, but she was relieved at learning he was alive.

The annual report of Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., Canada, distillers, issued yesterday by Howard R. Walton, president, disclosed consolidated net earnings for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31, last, of $23,643,669 after all charges, including $17,606,982 taxes.
John David Provoo, former Army staff sergeant, pleaded not guilty yesterday to a grand jury indictment charging twelve acts of treason against the United States.

PARIS, Nov. 22 -- For the first time since they split after the failure of the Communist-led general strike in November, 1947, the Socialist Workers' Force Movement and the Communist General Confederation of Labor have decided to join hands in a one-day walkout throughout France on Friday.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Nov. 22 -- Hungary announced today the arrest of three communications company executives, including Robert A. Vogeler of New York, on charges of espionage and sabotage. The communique declared that the three had confessed.

Coffee futures advanced sharply in moderately active trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. In early dealings, the market, which had been extremely volatile in recent weeks, advanced about 40 to 85 points. Commission-house selling satisfied the demand temporarily but later in the day demand from producing countries found offerings light, and prices gradually advanced and reached the daily permissible limit of 200 points above the previous close.

BILOXI, Miss., Nov. 22 -- Gov. J. Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, the presidential candidate of the States Rights Democrats in 1948, was unanimously chosen today chairman of the Southern Governors Conference to succeed former Gov. Ben Laney of Arkansas.

Whittaker Chambers said he had once been "a better Communist than Stalin" as defense counsel for Alger Hiss sought yesterday to destroy his credibility under cross-examination. Claude B. Cross, defense attorney, developed his theory that Julian Wadleigh rather than Alger Hiss had given State Department documents to Mr. Chambers.

Six weekday passenger trains that had been discontinued on Oct. 26 to comply with the Interstate Commerce Commission's coal emergency order were restored yesterday by the Long Island Railroad, effective at 11:59 P. M., because coal supplies on hand and en route were sufficient for them. Two other weekday trains will be restored at 12:01 A. M. next Monday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Fifteen railway lines, including the New York Central and the Pennsylvania, pulled out of the Rail Travel Credit Agency today. Fourteen of the lines withdrawing from the "charge it" ticket system were in the East.

Gems that once bought peace for India from the Sultan of Turkey paid for a prince's life and helped a king win a woman's favor began lending $10,000,000 worth of sparkle to the United Hospital Fund last night for the benefit of eighty six voluntary hospitals.

MUROC AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Nov. 22 -- Officers of the Navy Bureau of Aeronautics repeated today that the Navy-sponsored Douglas D-558-2 Skyrocket research plane had "repeatedly" exceeded the speed of sound -- 760 miles an hour -- in tests here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Department of Commerce announced today that gross production in the United States was at an annual rate of $256,000,000,000 in the third quarter of 1949, approximately $3,500,000,000 below the rate for the second quarter and $7,000,000,000 below that of the first quarter.

Accused of using "the influence of his position" to obtain $1,000 in illegal bonuses from two apartment seekers, Ira A. Schiller, suspended chief attorney of the Lower Manhattan rent area office of the Office of the Housing Expediter, was arraigned yesterday in Special Sessions on rent-gouging charges.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 22 -- Joseph Kaufman Productions, Inc., a recently formed independent film company, has purchased screen rights to "Sudden Fear," a 1948 novel by Edna Shelly, Kaufman disclosed today. The story deals with a woman playwright who learns that her husband is conspiring with another woman to kill her.

The Rowing Coaches Organization of America held its annual meeting at the Hotel Lexington yesterday. James B. McMillan of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology was elected president to succeed Harrison Sanford of Cornell.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 22 (UP) -- Reliable sources said tonight that four high-ranking Rumanian Army officers, including the assistant intelligence chief of the general staff, had been sentenced to death as spies for an undisclosed foreign power.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 22 (AP) -- The University of Santa Clara football team, twice beaten and once tied, was named today to play in the Miami Orange Bowl classic Jan. 2.

Joseph E. Pogue, petroleum economist and vice president of the Chase National Bank of the City of New York, was elected a director of the Gulf Oil Corporation at its board meeting held yesterday in Pittsburgh. He will serve the company also in a consulting capacity.
PASCO, Wash., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Superior Judge B. B. Horrigan dissolved today an order that prevented newspaper publication of an article criticizing the construction work in a Pasco housing project.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (UP) -- President Truman will observe Thanksgiving Day with a small family dinner, the White House announced today.
Mrs. Alice Miley, a poliomyelitis victim paralyzed from the waist down, took her first steps when she was 25 years old.

PARIS, Nov. 22 -- Divergent views of Germany's role in the defense of Western Europe were thrown into sharp relief here today in connection with the French National Assembly's debate on foreign policy that began this afternoon.

TROY, N. Y., Nov. 22 (UP) -- Nearly one in every five movies put out by Hollywood was found "morally objectionable," the chairman of the Catholic Bishops' committee on Motion Pictures said today. But Hollywood's record was far better than that for foreign films, nearly half of which were found "objectionable."

The liner America, the schedule of which for the current trip has been affected once by a threatened strike of American Federation of Labor deck officers in this country, causing the line to send the ship out a day ahead of time, is affected again, this time in France, by an impending twenty-four-hour general strike of French transport workers, set for Friday, it was learned yesterday.

Although the play is perfunctory, the performance is superb. The play is Kate O'Brien's romantic drama, "That Lady," which arrived at the Martin Beck last evening. Since it brings us Katharine Cornell in a magnificent performance, we owe it a certain measure of gratitude.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Army Quartermaster Corps was accused today by Orville C. Morrison, head of the Sunroc Refrigeration Company, Glen Riddle, Pa., of "tailoring" the specifications on a recent $100,000 contract to fit only Westinghouse Electric Corporation equipment.

The blouse industry and blouse departments are due for activity that justifies large preparation, Abraham Rosenthal, president of the National Association of Blouse Manufacturers, Inc., told members at the group's annual meeting yesterday in the New Yorker Hotel.

The homemaker who goes shopping for lamps, carrying fabric samples in one hand and a floor plan of her living room in the other, will be greeted with enthusiasm rather than amazement in at least one shop in Greenwich Village.

Mayor O'Dwyer opened the door yesterday for an eight-cent fare on the private bus lines in this city by instructing his aides to prepare a report on whether a higher fare would be necessary to enable the lines to carry out an arbitrator's pension and wage award.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 22 -- Federal Judge George B. Harris today found Vincent Hallinan, chief defense attorney in the Harry Bridges perjury and conspiracy case, guilty of contempt, sentenced him to a six-month jail term and ordered his name stricken from the roll of attorneys in this judicial district.

" Leonidas LaFayette Polk: Agrarian Crusader," by Stuart Noblin, will be published by the University of North Carolina on Saturday. It is the first biography of the patent medicine manufacturer, editor, agriculturist and politician. As leader of the Southern Alliance, he made the Populist party a major third-party threat in the Presidential campaign of 1892.

ROANOKE, Va., Nov. 22 -- Those in the advertising profession should answer their critics "not only by creating a better public understanding of the purpose and function of advertising, but also by cleaning the stables where necessary."

DETROIT, Nov. 22-- Exploitation of communism in China through Russia's greed for power, and the public benefit derived by publication of unbiased news, were outlined today at the fifteenth annual luncheon given by THE NEW YORK TIMES for automotive and industrial executives here.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- Corn continued today its upward movements on the Board of Trade, closing higher for the eighth straight day with gains of 3/8 to 2 1/4 cents a bushel, with the deferred deliveries at a new seasonal high, while December went into new ground since last Feb. 2 by gaining 1 1/2 cents on May as the result of heavy buying by a commission house which sold May against it.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 22 -- Coffee, which Brazil burned by millions of bags fifteen years ago, is suffering from a disease that stunts the tree and from deplanting on a huge scale. These have reduced the Brazilian output to figures that amaze most laymen.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- The New York State Teachers Association went on record today as condemning the employment of Communists and members of other subversive groups in the schools of the state and would deny them the privilege of membership in the association.
Cornell, one of the powers of Eastern football, placed four players on the 1949 All-Ivy League team selected yesterday by The Associated Press with the aid of the loop's coaches.

Formal effectiveness of the two-year-old proposal of the Republic of Colombia to service external dollar bond debt of certain political subdivisions on an adjusted interest basis and with maturities extended to 1978 was announced here yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Israel's fast growing merchant marine has acquired three additional second-hand vessels within the past week and is in the market for new ships, possibly to be built in British yards, a representative of the new state's principal shipping line disclosed here today.

DETROIT, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Kaiser-Frazer Corporation became today the second major automotive company to agree on a pension plan, the bulk of which will be company-financed. It also agreed with the United Automobile Workers, CIO, to increase its contributions to its health and welfare plan from 5 to 7 3/4 cents an hour.
Charges that an unfinished mural in a student lounge at New York University's School of Education was "communist propaganda" became public yesterday as the result of protests by a group of students.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- The old story has it that British foreign policy is founded upon two premises: that God is an Englishman and that the road to India must be kept open. Probably both the Labor and Conservative party views are not too far from this credo today.

A Christmas candy package for children overseas is being introduced as a holiday specialty at the Schrafft stores. It includes an imposing chocolate Santa Claus surrounded by candy canes, red and white peppermint sticks, lollipops and bright-colored sour balls.
