Chief Magistrate Edgar Bromberger gathered his magistrates and ranking court attaches in a public school auditorium yesterday to tell them he would retire on Feb. 14 because of ill health.

NBC television has announced the addition of two musical programs to its Saturday evening schedule. The first -- at 8:30 P. M. -- will present Bette Chapel, song-stress, in her own program, assisted by Art Van Damme's instrumental quintet, Miss Chapel has been one of the major attractions on the Sunday show known as "Garroway At Large," starring Dave Garroway.

A year ago ground was broken for the construction of Bell Park Gardens, Bayside, Queens, first veterans' non-profit housing development in the country. Yesterday, as a gesture of appreciation to those who had helped make the project possible, the families of 400 veterans now living there staged their own Thanksgiving party and distributed a number of scrolls.

By being bold enough to decrease taxes during a downturn in business, Canada stimulated the national economy at a crucial time and vindicated the concept of the modern governmental budget as a balance wheel of The economy, Douglas Abbott, Canadian Minister of Finance, declared here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery declared today that military strength in Western Europe would guarantee peace, but he appealed at the same time for improved human relationships so that men might live in harmony.
BOWIE, Md., Nov. 22 (AP) -- In an extremely close finish Tacaro Briar, owned by Robert L. Hall Jr., got up in the last stride to nose out Flag Drill and Briar White in the feature here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The recent pension settlement in the steel industry, Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, said today, raised the question of whether the country was drifting into a problem of providing $100 a month through Government or business for all persons over 65 years of age.

VIENNA, Nov. 22 -- The appointment of a Soviet marshal to command the Polish Army may soon be followed by similar steps in other satellite countries, according to indications that have reached Vienna. The first such move probably will be in Bulgaria.
SEA ISLAND, Ga., Nov. 22 (AP) -- A beaming Vice President and his pretty bride took life easy in their honeymoon retreat today -- "doing as much of nothing as possible."

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Nov. 22 -- The public school has ceased to be an ally of the church and has become, by its attitude of "exclusion and separation," an "obstacle" in the path of adequate religious education, Bishop Fred Pierce Corson of the Philadelphia Area of the Methodist Church and chairman of the denomination's General Board of Education, said here today.

Devaluation of the Japanese yen does not appear likely at this time, David Maynard, former State Department attache to the Office of United States Political Advisor to the Supreme Command of the Allied Powers in Tokyo, said here yesterday.

IT would be simple enough to wave the flag, prate about "true Americanism" and gush over with platitudes just because Jackie Robinson of the Dodgers became the first Negro ever to win Most Valuable Player honors. But that sort of sickening hogwash belongs in the realm of politics, where race consciousness is a profitable axe to grind.
Stockholders of the Hershey Chocolate Corporation approved yesterday in Hershey, Pa., a plan to reclassify the convertible preference stock.

The shiny brass plaque bearing the name, Gardner School, still hangs beside the doorbell of the English basement brownstone thirty-two-room double house that was the former home of Bernard M. Baruch at 1055 Fifth Avenue.
Stuart Smith has been appointed product manager, sheet and plate sales of the Reynolds Metals Company, Louisville, Ky. He formerly was manager of aircraft sales with headquarters in Dayton, Ohio.
On the eve of his departure for France, Capt. Edward Molyneux, of couture fame, spoke yesterday of his plan to introduce American play fashions in Paris and London.

Voluntary hospitals, which are financed through private philanthropies, were commended yesterday by Governor Dewey as spiritually superior to institutions wholly supported and operated by government, whether Federal, state or municipal.

Everett Fritzberg, who gave his third New York recital last night at Carnegie Hall, is a puzzling pianist. When the music was gentle he played with sensibility, but when it was fast or loud he played like an automaton.

British engine makers envisage a large American market for Diesel mine locomotives of types not made here as soon as present backlogs of other orders have been filled, according to thirteen industry members interviewed yesterday at the offices of the Economic Cooperation Administration at 2 Park Avenue.
Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman reserved decision yesterday after a heated hearing on three motions stemming from last week's intra-union dispute at the National Maritime Union's headquarters.
NEWARK, Nov. 22 -- Time has taken its toll of Joe Louis' superlative fighting qualities and the decay of inactivity has left its imprint on the retired undefeated heavyweight champion.

A year ago in an address to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization President Truman touched for the first time on the idea which was to develop subsequently into the now famous "Point Four" of his Inaugural. It was natural and appropriate, therefore, that he should have come back to that theme when he again spoke before the annual conference of the same group in Washington yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Michigan and Minnesota dominate the 1949 All-Big Ten football team which includes three repeaters but lacks a unanimous choice by coaches who annually pick the honor line-up for the Associated Press.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Following is the text of a speech by President Truman today to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations:

WARSAW, Nov. 22 -- Polish authorities again refused a French Embassy request today to visit Andre Simon Robineau, a consulate employe arrested last Friday as an alleged key figure in a French spy ring. However, Polish authorities transmitted a letter to M. Robineau's father, who is president of the French Institute here, in which he asked his parents not to bother sending food to him while he was in prison.

Directors of the Republic Steel Corporation voted yesterday a special year-end dividend of $1.25 a share in addition to the regular quarterly of 25 cents payable to common stockholders on Dec. 22. These will bring the year's disbursements to $3.

The somber pomp of centuries of church ceremonial characterized the funeral service held yesterday for the Right Rev. William T. Manning, retired Protestant Episcopal Bishop of New York, in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine which his labors had carried far toward completion.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Cold facts, which usually wilt in the heat of Army-Navy football war, say just what the generals have been telling the admirals all along: the cadets should beat the midshipmen Saturday.

With regard to your editorial of Nov. 19 entitled "Colombia in Danger," I believe it is my duty to convey to you the following facts, which can be easily proven and which, in my estimation, will lead to entirely different conclusions than those arrived at by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Industrial and agricultural over-draft and pollution -- clues that show what an area does with its water supply -- are giving scientific observers a picture of the nature of America's regional and local water shortages,
ROME, Ga., Nov. 22 (AP) -- The defense accused the Government today of playing Democratic party politics by bringing to trial twelve men in the case of seven flogged Negroes.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 22 -- The Liberal party tonight called a general protest strike to begin Friday at 5 A. M. and to continue through midnight Sunday, election day. The demonstration is to be along civic rather than labor union lines, and is aimed at the entire membership of the Liberal party.
Vice Admiral Jules James, USN, and Mrs. James of Baltimore, are at the St. Regis.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 22 -- The coming three months will be crucial to success of the Federal public housing program, and Roman Catholics should participate in and spur local action in its behalf, Msgr. John O'Grady urged here today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- An attorney for the Government and an agent for the Treasury Department today denied charges of a witness in the Tucker fraud trial that they stole office records for evidence against Preston Tucker and threatened the witness with indictment.

A respite until two days after Christmas was given yesterday to Valentin A. Gubitchev, Russian engineer, and Judith Coplon, former Department of Justice analyst, who are to be tried in the Federal Court House on Foley Square on charges of espionage and conspiracy.

Regardless of the consequences, the United Nations' decision on the Italian colonies is an event of great importance; first, because it is the first step toward international responsibility for colonial rule and development, and second, because for the first time the General Assembly has superseded the Big Four by settling a problem the Great Powers were unable to solve.
Walter Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, asserted yesterday that the most effective fight against communism could be carried on by the trade union movement.

The Shah of Iran was welcomed to Princeton University yesterday by its president, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, as the representative of a people whose ancient culture had contributed to Asia and the world's civilization.

Heartened by the return to duty of three veterans who had been sidelined by injuries, Coach Edward E. (Hook) Mylin looks for his New York University eleven to play its top game of the year in the annual "Battle of the Bronx" against Fordham at the Polo Grounds Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Oscar R. Ewing, the Federal Security Administrator, will depart for Europe Dec. 1 with three high-ranking aides to make a month's study of health insurance, social security and education programs in operation there.
Anticipating the universal feminine desire to brighten up homes for the holidays, F. Schumacher Co. introduced yesterday a varied group of decorative fabrics designed and timed for just that purpose.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,134 against 2,016 last week and 1,059 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 369 arrivals yesterday compared with 1,109 last Tuesday.
TORONTO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Col. Humberto Mariles of Mexico tonight led his military jumping team to the most closely contested victory of the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 22 -- An attorney representing Ferdinand (Fred) A. Gehrhardt, president of Kings County Buick, Inc., reported in First District Court here today that his client's franchise had been canceled because of wide publicity given a drunken driving charge against him.

UVALDE, Tex., Nov. 22 (UP) -- John Nance Garner, Vice President during Franklin D. Roosevelt's first two terms, spent his eighty-first birthday quietly at his ranch home today, instead of going hunting.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- President Truman hailed advances in farm production techniques in the United States as "an agricultural revolution" today and offered other nations the benefit of this country's experience, knowledge and experts.

Four new films will arrive in first-run theatres this morning. At Loew's State, the attraction is "Holiday Affair," a romantic drama with Robert Mitchum, Janet Leigh, Wendell Corey and Gordon Gebert. The RKO release was produced and directed by Don Hartman from a screen play by Isobel Lennart and a story by John D. Weaver.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- A Chinese newspaper account of a radio broadcast in Mukden was the State Department's only source of information today on the status of Angus Ward, United States Consul General imprisoned by Chinese Communists in the Manchurian city.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 22 -- South Africa warned today that the future of the United Nations will be gravely endangered if the organization becomes a "forum for agitators and international suspicion and enmity."

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 22 -- American Quakers are suggesting United Nations sponsorship of a standstill agreement to halt atomic bomb races and provide time for a new scientific examination of the conditions necessary for international control.

It sometimes comes as a paradoxical shock to be reminded that the word "totalitarian" is a literal description of what is comprehended by the Police State. The two installments of Gen. Bedell Smith's memoirs printed in this newspaper yesterday and today, concerning the efforts to suppress religion in Russia and to oppose the great religions of the world are a reminder that, in order to succeed, communism must kill religion or provide an adequate substitute.

The recent statement by Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, asserting that he saw "no moral problem" involved in the question of gold convertibility "ignores completely the continued debasing of the purchasing power of the dollar," Philip Le Boutillier, New York State chairman of the Gold Standard League, declared yesterday.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 22 -- The three Western Allied High Commissioners and Dr. Konrad Adenauer, initialed tonight a "protocol of agreements" between the Big Three and the Bonn Republic.

In accordance with President Truman's Point 4 program, the United States Steel Corporation accepted an invitation by the Government of Pakistan to send a mission to the new nation in southeast Asia to survey the possibility of establishing steel-fabrication plants there, Lauri Shaffi, Consul General of Pakistan, announced here yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer's official plurality in the recent election was 310,392 votes, the Board of Elections reported yesterday after completing the canvass of the Mayoralty election. Mr. O'Dwyer polled 1,266,213 votes on the Democratic ticket, while Newbold Morris, his closest opponent, received 570,609 Republican votes, 273,209 Liberal party votes, and 12,063 under the emblem of the City Fusion party, for a total of 955,821.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- After two days of comparative tests, the Federal Communications Commission today urged sponsors of color television systems to place receivers in the hands of the public as soon as possible for intensive tests in homes. Requests went to the Radio Corporation of America, Columbia Broadcasting System and Color Television, Inc., of San Francisco.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 22 -- The general feeling here is that the United Nations has reached a highly unsatisfactory decision about the former Italian colonies, and has been somewhat disappointing in its first attempt to exercise supreme international legislative authority.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Nov. 22 (UP) -- Dr. R. E. Lapp, consultant to the United States Atomic Energy Commission, urged today that a $1,000,000,000 agency be created to spy on Russia.
ROME, Nov. 22 -- By a vote of 299 to 159 the Chamber of Deputies confirmed today its confidence in the policies of Premier Alcide de Gasperi's Government. Nineteen Deputies abstained.

The Metropolitan Opera, though it opened its sixty-fifth season on schedule Monday night, has no contract with the stagehands' union, one of the principal labor organizations with which it deals, it became known yesterday.

OSLO, Norway, Nov. 22 -- The wreckage of the airliner that was lost while bringing twenty-eight children, mostly orphans, from Tunisia to a rehabilitation center in Norway was found at noon today on a densely wooded hill twenty miles south of Oslo.
Benjamin Feldman's third trial as the poison murderer of his 24-year-old wife in 1943 went to the jury early last evening in Kings County Court.

The public must begin at once to consume less water if lowering of water pressure is to be avoided throughout the city, Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, warned yesterday. Reservoirs were described as down to 39 per cent of capacity.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- One of the problems that has plagued Britain as an occupying power -- the question of East German refugees in South Schleswig on the Danish border -- has been passed on to the Bonn administration.

The stock market resumed the advance yesterday after a setback on Monday due to profit taking. A good portion of the preceding day's losses was recovered in a timid but sustained rally which left final quotations higher by approximately a point.

Last June, when Irene Selznick dropped Norman Corwin's play, "Mary and the Fairy," Alfred de Liagre Jr. quickly picked it up for production -- it is still slated for this season. Yesterday it was announced that Mrs. Selznick, sponsor of "A Streetcar Named Desire," had purchased "Bell, Book and Candle," the John van Druten comedy, until recently controlled by Mr. de Liagre. That's a neat switch, and may they both profit.

New York is coming alive again. This is the time of the year when a little island becomes a place of fable. The theatres are filled with the magic of the stage. The shops set forth the finery of the world. The thinkers, the doers, the artists come together here to work, to plan and to be with each other.

The amount of discipline parents can exert over teen-agers in a crisis is apt to depend on the number of bitter words and dark faces the parents can endure, Mrs. Jean Schick Grossman, director of parent education of the Play Schools Association, admitted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Marriner S. Eccles, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today that "private banking leadership has failed" to meet the changing needs of the economy and that legislation was needed fixing uniform reserve requirements for all commercial banks.

PANAMA, Nov. 22 -- Shooting broke out in this city tonight after Dr. Daniel F. Chanis Jr. had repudiated his resignation as President and led a march on the Presidential Palace. A boy was reported killed and seven other persons were wounded, including two Deputies.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers effectively stymied the Washington Capitols' attack tonight to defeat them 89 -- 74 before 1,535 fans at Uline Arena.
BELLEVILLE, N. J., Nov. 23 -- The Navy LSM 458 finally has reached her permanent berth in Belleville after resisting the staunchest efforts of man and his machinery for over a month.
Science, industry, simple common sense and a will to conserve water can stem the depletion of America's ground water resources.

Eto nye kulturno is a phrase one hears often in Moscow, especially among earnest young Communists. Literally, the Russian phrase means "that isn't cultured," and it has a variety of applications to describe widely varying acts and objects. It is equally applicable when reference is made to the rude behavior of an uneducated person or to the poor quality of a toothbrush.

ST. SHOTTS, Nfld., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Fishermen of this south coast town early today rescued eighteen crew members of the wrecked Canadian freighter Harcourt Kent. The 1,076-ton vessel went aground during a storm yesterday on Murr Rock, about two miles west of here.

Plans for the first lowering of water pressure in the city, necessitated by the growing shortage, will be prepared by engineers of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity next Wednesday under orders issued yesterday by Commissioner Stephen J. Carney.

Arnold Schoenberg's seventy-fifth birthday occurred on Sept. 13, which is an awkward time of the year for concerts in tribute to a composer. But last night the United States Section of the International Society for Contemporary Music made good the policy inherent in its name by presenting a program in honor of Mr. Schoenberg at the Museum of Modern Art.

BERLIN, Nov. 23 -- Reports that all radio stations in Eastern Germany had been placed under the direct control of Otto Grotewohl, Premier of the Soviet zone state, were carried today by DPA Western Germany News agency. The news agency cited as authority for the reports, Hans Mahle, member of the Socialist Unity [Communist] party and general superintendent of such stations.

Directors of the Commercial Credit Company voted yesterday to increase the quarterly dividend to $1 a share and also declared a special distribution of 30 cents a share to common stockholders, both payable on Dec. 31. Shareholders have received 90 cents quarterly.

MANILA, Thursday, Nov. 24 (AP) -- A two-day truce was reported today to have halted fighting between Government forces and the rebels south of Manila. Press reports said that twenty-nine men were known to have been killed in the two-day battle.
Plans for a thirty-two-story addition to the Chrysler Building at a cost of $9,000,000 were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Nov. 23 -- Fighting extradition, John Mallone, who escaped from the London, Ohio, prison farm, said today that he was determined to stay in New Jersey to seek out the man for whom he "took the rap" on a murder charge and served 15 years of a life sentence.

American steamship lines in foreign trades are beginning to lose cargoes as a result of the threat of a strike by the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, it was reported yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 23 -Valentine Davies, author of "It Happens Every Spring" and "Miracle on Thirty-fourth Street," has written a new screen comedy, "First Sight," about a woman who believes in shaping her own life and a man who believes in surrendering to fate, it was learned today from the scenarist's agent, Ned Brown of the Famous Artists Company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The smoldering soft coal dispute, heading into another strike deadline one week hence, came to life with two developments today. One of these was an arrangement by John L. Lewis for a meeting of the United Mine Workers 200-man policy committee in New York on Monday, it was learned reliably.

An underwriting group, headed by Glore, Forgan Co. and W. C. Langley Co., yesterday received an award on competitive bidding of 276,805 additional common shares of the American Natural Gas Company. The group's bid named a compensation of $43,942 plus a commitment for the unsubscribed shares at $28.25 a share.

With Robert Q. Lewis as master of ceremonies, the Columbia Broadcasting System is planning a new weekly full-hour variety series which will be auditioned over a closed circuit next Thursday as a simultaneous radio and television presentation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -The reasons for the removal of Admiral Louis E. Denfeld as Chief of Naval Operations will not be investigated by the House Armed Services Committee, the chairman, Representative Carl Vinson, Democrat, of Georgia, said today.

Stockholders of the Columbia Pictures Corporation were informed at their annual meeting held here yesterday that gross earnings for the September quarter are expected to be about $500,000 before taxes.

Advertising in newspapers of fifty-two cities during October totaled 214,935,122 lines, 2.5 per cent less than in the comparable month of last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. For the first ten months, however, total lineage was 2 per cent ahead of the like period of last year.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- Pay raises which average 17 1/2 per cent for Chicago's 12,000 public school teachers were asked of the Board of Education today by the Chicago Teachers Union, AFL. The proposed increases range from $700 a year for grade teachers and $840 for high school teachers to $1,200 a year for high school principals.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Government announced failure today in its attempt to get a quick settlement of right-left union rivalries in the country's electrical industry.

Billy Graham, East Side welterweight, made sturdy Tony La Bua, Ozone Park, the victim of his sixth straight victory at the St. Nicholas Arena last night, in a ten-round battle that satisfied 1,364 onlookers despite the fact the East Sider entered the ring at 1 to 4 in the betting. The receipts amounted to $4,167.

A 99-year-old grandmother, said by officials of the Scandinavian Airline System to be the oldest displaced person ever to arrive here by air, landed at 11 A. M. yesterday at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, aboard a plane from Bremen, Germany.
CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The head of the American Veterans Committee said today that a new international ex-service men's organization would be formed in Paris next summer.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Nov. 23 -- The Western Allied protocol of agreement with the Western Federal Republic on the revision of the capital reparations program and German cooperation in the International Ruhr Authority was signed today by the High Commissioners and Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Bonn Chancellor.

Thanksgiving is not a holiday for the head of the house, the carver. For him, the day is a day of specialized work so strenuous as to leave him spent and all but lifeless by late afternoon. Despite the outward appearance, carving goes far beyond just what takes place in full view on the table; like everything else of moment, it needs preparation.

Defense attorneys for Alger Hiss laid the groundwork yesterday for a psychiatric attack on Whittaker Chambers' testimony as the Government's key witness in the Hiss perjury trial went through his third day of cross-examination.

Franz Rupp, pianist, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. His program was composed of Bach's Fantasy and Fugue in A minor, three pieces by Scarlatti, Mozart's Fantasy in C minor (K. 396), Beethoven's Sonata, Op. 109; Chopin's Sonata in B minor and Debussy's "Poissons d'or," "Hommage a Rameau" and "Jardins sous la pluie."

ALBANY, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that the widow of a man appointed as a New York City fireman while in the armed forces was entitled to a department death benefit. The tribunal reversed the lower courts, in a 6 to 1 decision, on an action by Mrs. Margaret Molinari against the department's life insurance fund.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 23 (UP) -- The Communist Czechoslovak Government's campaign against the middle class has extended to large farmers, who are being subjected to confiscation of their property, fines and imprisonment, diplomatic quarters said today.

Puccini's "Manon Lescaut" was revived last night at the Metropolitan with enormous success. It had not been given there for nineteen seasons. It is noteworthy that it fell on the ears of last night's audience with a sensation of freshness and of dramatic blood in the music that were surprising.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The trim gray and white sealing ship Norsel, flying the Norwegian flag, nosed out of the docks here today and started down the Thames on a voyage that will take her across the Antarctic Circle. Aboard were fourteen British, Norwegian and Swedish scientists who will spend the next two years in Queen Maud Land on the South Polar Continent.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- The grain markets were firm today in the early trading on the Board of Trade here, May and July corn selling at new highs for the year. Liberal profit - taking developed, however, and wheat closed with losses of 1/2 to 1 5/8 cents a bushel, the May contract leading.

Mohawk Carpet Mills, Inc., will increase prices of its rug and carpet lines soon because of higher wool costs, it was learned in the trade yesterday. The amount of increase has not yet been determined, but official confirmation of the forthcoming advance will be given by Howard Shuttleworth, president, in a report to stockholders on third-quarter activities which was mailed out last night.

Collectors of American Art, Inc., will hold an open house reception on Sunday afternoon from 5 to 7 o'clock. John Begg, sculptor and art director of the Oxford University Press, will speak on "The Making of an Art Book." This is the final reception of the year to be held at the gallery, 106 East Fifty-seventh Street, before the annual distribution of oils, sculpture and prints to members.
PARIS, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The French atomic energy project has produced about one milligram of plutonium, it was announced today.

The indifferent performance against Detroit last Sunday led Coach Steve Owen of the New York Giants to put his squad through a scrimmage at the Polo Grounds yesterday, something the professionals rarely undergo at this stage, and to hand some offensive assignments to players used hitherto mostly for defense.
A disputed mural at New York University that some students have charged is "communist propaganda" will be discussed at a Student Council meeting Monday night, it was announced yesterday.

A funeral service was held yesterday morning in Temple Emanu-El for the Rev. Dr. Nathan Krass, rabbi emeritus, who had served the congregation for nine years, until failing health caused his retirement in 1932.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Nov. 23 -The Interfraternity Council at Middlebury College has voted to request elimination by 1952 of discriminatory clauses from fraternity constitutions, it was announced today. Failure to "make an honest effort" to remove the clauses would result in the revocation of council membership.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The leaders of Britain's Labor party contend that it is non-Marxist. They say "there are Marxists in our party and we have some Marxist doctrines. But the Labor party was brought up more on Christ than on Marx."

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 23 -- An ambitious proposal calling for the expenditure of $78,400,000 for the establishment of agricultural settlements for new immigrants will be submitted by the Jewish Agency for Palestine to the heads of the United Jewish Appeal when they meet in Atlantic City on Friday, it was announced tonight.
Today's schoolboy holiday football program is spiced with plenty of good fare as traditional games hold forth in the metropolitan area.

After spending a month in a Chinese Communist jail, Consul General Angus Ward and his four aides have been released at last in a condition which at least enables them to be "up and about." This news will be greeted with relief not only by the United States but by the whole civilized world, and most especially, of course, by the families of the victims.
ROME, Ga., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Imperial Wizard Samuel Roper of the Ku Klux Klan, today denied his organization had a Klavern in Dade County, Georgia, scene of the beating of seven Negroes.

Many dire predictions were made during the last two months about the steel and coal strikes wrecking our whole economy. Now that the strikes are practically over, are we supposed to forget that they ever happened?

The only book published today is "World's Greatest Christmas Stories," edited by Eric Posselt. Issued at $3.50 by Ziff-Davis, the anthology contains "the best loved stories on the Christmas theme from the literature of many lands."
It's still four weeks until Santa makes his official trip down the world's chimneys, but all signs proclaim that he is already comfortably settled in this town's stores.
BOWIE, Md., Nov. 23 (AP) -- William Ziegler's Entrust, an invader from Jamaica, led a field of seven other 3-year-old sprinters home by a length in the featured $3,500 St. Mary's Purse today.

TOKYO, Nov. 23 -- Virtually the entire General Staff of Japan's crack Kwantung Army is alive and held as a unit in Siberia, it was asserted today by the All-Japan Repatriation Council here. More than four years after the end of the war, none has as yet been tried as a war criminal.

KEENE, N. H., Nov. 23 -- Elliot Community Hospital prepared a new contract today to submit to Dr. Albert C. Johnston, its radiologist, with whom it had been in disagreement over terms of employment since last March. Chester Kingsbury, president of the hospital trustees, said the contract would be submitted soon to Dr. Johnston's attorney.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -The Governments Inland Waterways Corporation, which hauls freight on the Mississippi River system, lost $1,000,065 in the last fiscal year, Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, announced today.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- On the eve of the publication of the agreement with the Bonn Government to liberalize the Western Allied occupation policy in Western Germany. public notice was given today that the occupying powers were not interested in a German proposal for foreign investment in the Ruhr industries as a security measure.

Accused of shooting Police Detective John Cox of the Flushing Precinct at 5 A.M. yesterday in front of Roesch's Tavern, 18-48 122d Street, College Point, Queens, another policeman, Matthew E. O'Connell of the East Twenty-second Street Precinct was suspended, arrested on a felonius assault charge and released in $2,500 bail.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- Earl Blaik gave every outward sign of being at ease as he sat in his office today, discussing the Navy game. The cadet coach carried on an amiable chat with friends and visitors, and frankly undertook to answer every question put to him regarding the service battle that will draw upward of 100,000 fans to Philadelphia's Municipal Stadium on Saturday.
The American Potash and Chemical Corporation, in its statement issued yesterday for the nine months ended with last September, reported a net income of $1,169,847 after taxes and all charges.
Mohammed Reza Pahlevi, the Shah of Iran, opened last night at the Asia Institute, 7 East Seventieth Street, an impressive exhibit of Persian art treasures.

HONG KONG, Nov. 23 -- Nationalist troops in many parts of Szechwan are carrying out a sweeping withdrawal southwestward toward Sikang and the rugged outer ramparts of Tibet, according to Americans evacuated here by plane from Chengtu and Chungking.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- President Truman today appointed John Forrest Floberg, 34 years old, a Chicago lawyer, as Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Air, a post vacant for several months since Dan A. Kimball was elevated to Under-Secretary of the Navy.

A lot of excellent chamber music is being offered to New York concertgoers this season, and last night another worth-while series was opened at Times Hall. It consisted of three concerts and is being given by the Paganini Quartet.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Czechoslovakia's Communist rulers started another spy trial today. Twenty Czechs were arraigned on charges of having stolen Czechoslovak industrial secrets for the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -Approval of a $10,265,000 loan to the East Kentucky Rural Electric Cooperative Corporation, Danville, Ky., was announced tonight by the Rural Electrification Administration. The loan is subject to approval by the Kentucky Public Service Commission.
OTTAWA, Nov. 23 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's foreign trade was a record $5,750,000,000 in 1948, the Trade Department announced today in its annual report for the year ending last March.

There was considerable indication on Rose Hill yesterday of a revival of the spirit of aggressiveness in the Fordham football forces, as well as the spirit of the student body, both of which had sagged badly during the losing games with Boston College and Rutgers.

Two left-wing unions of the Congress of Industrial Organizations have been ordered to answer charges that they have followed policies of the Communist party rather than those of the CIO, it was announced yesterday.

The New York City Ballet Company opened its fall season at the City Center last night with a program consisting of three of its familiar works, but with several new people in the company to supplement the old favorites, if any of the members of so young a company can be so designated.
ROME, Nov. 23 -- Communist-controlled unions that distribute newspapers to newsstands have threatened vendors with reprisals if they refuse to sell Communist newspapers, Vatican circles said today.

The United Nations General Assembly called on the Big Five and Canada yesterday to examine every possible method of breaking the deadlock on atomic control and to look carefully into all concrete plans.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Nov. 23 (AP) -- The company that builds the B-36 bomber said today it had designed a transport that could carry 100,000 pounds or 400 armed men from the East Coast to Western Europe without any strain.
The Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth sailed yesterday with 1,542 passengers bound for Cherbourg and Southampton. The vessel left her West Fiftieth Street pier shortly after 11:30 A. M.
Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter reserved decision yesterday on a motion by eight taxpayers for a writ directing a "summary inquiry" into alleged tax irregularities.

The Cunard Line turned the lounge of its Parthia, docked at Pier 56, Fourteenth Street and the Hudson River, into a toy store yesterday afternoon. Then it turned forty-five children from West Harlem between the ages of 5 and 7 loose in the place and told them all the toys were free.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 23 (AP) -A two-man Congressional committee seized control of the business offices of the three remaining independent newspapers and the Communist organ, the Hora, in Buenos Aires today.
MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 23 -- The potential hazard of over-pumping the Long Island fresh-water table has caused New York to decrease its exploitation of the Nassau watershed, it was learned here today.

Delicate, open sandals are the highlights of Delman's new evening and resort collection at their Bergdorf Goodman salon. Airy sandals of very thin straps are worked in extremely intricate designs in plain or multi-pastel colored calf for resort wear.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23 -- Pennsylvania and Cornell will meet here tomorrow for the fifty-sixth time, with the Ivy League title at stake, and a crowd of 75,000 is expected almost to fill the double-decker stadium at Franklin Field. The kick-off is set for 1:30.

MOSCOW, Nov. 23 -- The Literary Gazette declared today that All-Union Geographical Society's publication Izvestia should devote less attention to ancient themes such a Ptolemy and more to the "drastic differences between Soviet and bourgeois geographical science."

The murkiness in Panama is moral as well as political. Whether the President is now Daniel Chanis or Roberto Chiari is an important issue by itself, but what is even more important is the shocking manner in which the crisis took place. Political strife in Panama has a tradition of being rough and mock-heroic.
Socialization of American industry was deplored yesterday as in part "an accomplished fact" by Elmer L. Lindseth, spokesman for the $17,000,000,000 electric utility industry.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 23 (UP) -- The sixtl conet of the year has been discovered, of the sixteenth magnitude. The comet, labeled 1949F, can be seen only with powerful telescopes. It was spotted by Dr. Ira S. ]3owen, director of l[ount Wilson and Palomar Observatolies in California, according to word received at Harvard Observatory. The newest comet is in the constellation of Pegasus, not far from the star Gamme Pegasi.

PARIS, Nov. 23 -- The Foreign Ministers of the Benelux countries are expected to meet in the Hague tomorrow to discuss a plea by Maurice Petsche, French Finance Minister, for some action toward a regional economic union by Dec. 15. On that date the member governments are to report to the Marshall Plan Council on reduction of quotas.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 23 -- Dr. Charles A. Malik, the Lebanese delegate, said today that the "non-Communist world will be perfectly stupid, and, indeed, about to dissolve, if it does not look feverishly to its own defenses against possible Communist aggression, whether external or internal, and if it does not seek adequately to meet the challenge of the Soviet Union."

ALBANY, Nov. 23 (AP) -- New York State's stand-by residential rent-control law probably will be continued into 1951, Assemblyman D Mallory Stephens, chairman of the State Temporary Commission on Rents, predicted today He also indicated that state laws controlling business and commercial rents in New York City would be extended, and possibly modified

Borough President Hugo E. Rogers of Manhattan, who will retire from office next month, and Borough President-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr., chairman of the City Planning Commission, faced each other at a commission hearing at City Hall yesterday as Mr. Rogers argued for a proposed Manhattan zone change.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson said today that the forthcoming meeting in Paris of the North Atlantic treaty Defense Committee had been ordered to produce a military defense plan for Western Europe that would enable President Truman to release $900,000,000 voted for this purpose by Congress.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -Duties on almonds will remain unchanged as result of a Tariff Commission investigation of foreign and domestic production costs.
Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange in cotton futures was rather quiet yesterday and closing prices were irregular, 2 points lower to 6 points higher.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 23 -- The first experimental transmissions of weather maps and other data by facsimile from land bases to operating ships at sea have proved highly successful, it was reported today, as Atlantic Fleetunits returned to Hampton Roads from extensive maneuvers inside the Arctic Circle.

Existing provisions of the State Constitution permit New York City to borrow sums exceeding 20 per cent of the average of its assessed valuations for the last five years, according to a computation made by the Commerce and Industry Association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- A House Judiciary subcommittee investigating monopoly said today that the Army would receive an opportunity at a special hearing Friday to support its denial of "tailoring" specifications in a recent $100,000 procurement transaction.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Amtorg, the Russian trading corporation, was fined $10,000 in Federal District Court today for failing to register as a foreign agent, but Judge Alexander Holtzoff suspended the fine on request of the United States Government.

The stock market held its ground yesterday, but not without some difficulty. Favorable special and year-end dividends stiffened some issues, but others showed disappointment over disbursements smaller than anticipated. Such a reaction was particularly noticeable in Studebaker and Union Pacific.
Kane and Cook Counties, Ill., will receive bids on Dec. 16 for $2,500,000 of school district No. U46 bonds, dated Dec. 1, 1949 and due from Dec. 1, 1952 to 1969.

A resolution calling on the United States Public Health Service to make a comprehensive survey of air pollution on Staten Island was adopted last night by a special committee appointed in August by Richmond Borough President Cornelius Hall to investigate many complaints by Staten Islanders that they were suffering ill effects from smoke.

PARIS, Nov. 23 -- While Premier Georges Bidault in a broadcast to the nation tonight appealed to workers and Government employes not to join the twenty-four-hour strike that has been called for Friday, the executive board of the Socialist party decided to urge party members to obey the orders of the Socialist labor federation.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Brown Bears are heavy favorites to close their season with a victory over Colgate in their Thanksgiving Day clash.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- A tentative contract, its terms subject to approval of 25,000 members of the United Packing House Workers Union, CIO, employed in twenty-one plants of Armour Co., meat packers, was agreed to today between union and company negotiators.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Nov. 23 -Twenty-eight young farmers from the Netherlands sailed for home today, enthusiastic about their new concept of America and Americans gained during seven months spent studying mechanized farming methods in this country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UP) -- Consuems are not buying enough turkeys this Thanksgiving to suit officials of the Department of Agriculture. They said today the Government had to buy 723,000 pounds recently under the price-support program.

The three-story building at 167-75 Nassau Avenue, Brooklyn, containing six stores and three apartments, has been sold by Rose Zimmer to Emilia Napoletano, Milton L. Strom was the broker. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

CAIRO, Nov. 23 -- Sixteen hundred Americans, the whole American community in Egypt, will celebrate Thanksgiving Day with roast turkey instead of mutton and pumpkin pie in place of figs. Everyone will pitch in. Each family will bring food from home.

PANAMA, Nov. 23 -- National Police forces surrounded and attacked the National University here tonight, using machine guns and tear gas. The students had planned a protest meeting in Santa Ana Plaza against the recent police coup that resulted in having two rival Presidents.

West Point gave its twenty-one gun salute yesterday to the Shah of Iran, and the ruler of 17,000,000 subjects returned the compliment by obtaining release for thirty cadets at the United States Military Academy from punishment ordered for breaches of discipline.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 23 -An increase of 66.6 per cent in unemployment compensation claims, most of it attributed to layoffs resulting from the steel strike, was recorded today in the October monthly index of business of the Chamber of Commerce of eastern Union County.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday the appointment of Victor F. Condello as the city, legislative representative at an annual salary of $10,000. Mr. Condello succeeds Harold L. Herzstein, who resigned Sept. 15 to return to private law practice.
Preparations for Thanksgiving Day occupied the attention of New Yorkers yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States stepped up its campaign today for adoption of reforms proposed by the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government. It brought out a booklet entitled "A Multi-Billion Dollar Opportunity."

A total of $258,000,000 was contributed by American Jews to the United Palestine Appeal and its constituent agencies in the last twenty-four years, Magistrate Morris Rothenberg, acting national chairman of the appeal, reported last night at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- A British Government committee will be set up at once to study the question whether Tass, the Soviet news agency, or other such organizations, should continue to have immunity under British law. Legislation subsequently may be sought to remove that immunity.

All security and commodity markets throughout the United States will be closed today in observance of Thanksgiving Day. The banks also will be closed. Canadian and European exchanges and banking institutions will operate as usual.

United Nations approval of "an infamous proposal" to internationalize Jerusalem would mean trouble instead of peace, Reuven Shreibman, deputy mayor of Jerusalem and a member of the Israeli Parliament, declared yesterday at the office of the National Committee for Labor Israel (Histadrut) at 45 East Seventeenth Street.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 23 -- The solidarity of the American Continent was given added significance today by President Miguel Aleman of Mexico.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 23 -- While most delegates to the United Nations General Assembly may take issue with the views of Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky, few would dispute the fact that he is no clock-watcher and has more stamina than some of his younger opponents.

A projected Board of Transportation report on the feasibility of the forty-hour work week for 40,000 workers on the city-owned transit lines was rejected in advance yesterday by Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO.

PARIS, Nov. 23 -- The four Polish airmen who had been detained for questioning by French authorities here since Sunday in connection with the disappearance and subsequent disclosure of the arrest of Andre Simon Robineau. French Consulate employe in Warsaw, were allowed to return to Poland in their plane today.

A plea that the courts "stand as a sentinel" against invasion of civil rights through "widespread" wire-tapping was voiced yesterday before a three-judge Federal statutory court by Emil K. Ellis, counsel for the New York County Criminal Courts Bar Association.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 23 -- The defense at the Harry Bridges trial today made a bid to have all testimony concerning the longshore leader's alleged membership in the Communist party restricted to a four-month period in 1945.

Benjamin Feldman, the Brooklyn druggist who was twice sent to the Sing Sing death house for the alleged poison murder of his wife in 1943, was a free man last night. A jury in Kings County Court acquitted him in a third trial ordered after the State Court of Appeals had voided two previous convictions.

Staging a blistering attack that had the visitors on the run throughout, the New York Knickerbockers last night ran their winning streak to four straight and bounded into second place in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association by humbling the Washington Capitols, 87 to 67, at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

A decline last week of 197,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end stocks were 103,380,000 barrels, compared with 103,577,000 a week earlier and 91,244,000 a year ago.

Most people in this country today can be thankful for an abundance of food. Our national food problem is rather one of overproduction than of scarcity. But as we sit down to the table that nature and human energies have so bountifully spread for us we may remember that there are many millions in the world who rarely or never have enough to eat.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -The Justice Department says that E. V. Sittler, recently dismissed from the faculty of the Michigan College of Mining and Technology, has been told to be ready to return to Germany about Dec. 5.
The first of $10,000,000 in rice shipments to Indonesia will leave a port in the Gulf of Mexico next Tuesday in the revival of Economic Cooperation Administration grants to Holland for Indonesia.

Coffee futures continued to advance in active trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Both contracts S and D, which rose the permissible price limit of 200 points in Tuesday's trading, showed further sharp upswings in yesterday's transactions.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 23 -- A prediction that agreement would be reached on Friday between the Sailors Union of the Pacific, AFL, and the Pacific Maritime Association was voiced today by Omar Hoskins, a Federal conciliation commissioner.
R. W. Fordyce has been named general sales manager of the Bendix television and broadcast receiver division of the Bendix Aviation Corporation. He replaces E. A. Bonia, who has resigned.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 23 -- William Benton of Southport, who is expected to be appointed Senator from Connecticut next week by Gov. Chester Bowles said today that he was not affiliated with any political party. He told a reporter that he classified himself as an independent voter.
The second split season on waterfowl seems to be making up for the indifferent shooting which prevailed during the first one, according to reports from Long Island as well as up-state duck areas.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UP) -Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, Republican, of Iowa, said tonight that David E. Lilienthal's resignation from the Atomic Energy Commission would be good for the country, but some other members of Congress and scientists believed otherwise.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The uneven, but still considerable, influence in determining contests for office and national policies that has been attained and wielded by the C. I. O.'s Political Action Committee and the Americans for Democratic Action has produced the serious suggestion in many quarters that a similar nonpartisan group be formed in opposition to the programs these two generally support.
Firemen are stealing a little time from polishing brass these days to groom their Dalmatians for the special competition for New York fire dogs in the Brooklyn Kennel Club dog show on Dec. 3.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The defense ministers of five Western Union powers, Britain, France, the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg, met here today to discuss how to merge their alliance based on the Brussels treaty into the broader framework of the North Atlantic pact.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The State Department announced today that the Chinese Communists in Mukden had freed Consul General Angus Ward and ordered him to leave the country.

Dollar volume of bedding industry factories in the first half of 1950 will increase 10 per cent compared with the like period this year, J Paul Fanning, managing director of the National Association of Bedding Manufacturers, predicted yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UP) -- Following are the texts of letters exchanged by David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, and President Truman:

Your recent editorial on the Freedom Train interested many. As a "Nassovian" from a county contributing two important items in this the county's fiftieth anniversary, it seems proper to call attention to the Nicolls Code (as the Duke's Laws are known) before the days of Dongan's creation of the counties.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Wartime excise taxes designed to penalize production and consumption of certain "luxury" products and services are "an injustice to whole communities" and should be repealed, Congress was told today by Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the board of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., of New York City.

The thanksgiving celebration earlier this week in Bayside, Queens, in which veterans and their families paid tribute to the leadership that helped them become owners and occupants of good, modern housing, calls attention to a type of cooperative that is worthy of multiplication. Bell Park Gardens now has about 400 families of war veterans living in it, and 400 more families will move in soon.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 23 -- If hoopla, all-out enthusiasm and hard work can win a football game Navy should be a heavy favorite to beat Army in Philadelphia Saturday.

DETROIT, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Delayed effects of the steel strike will hit the automobile industry hard next week. With few exceptions the factories closing tonight for the Thanksgiving Day holiday will remain idle until perhaps Dec. 12 or later.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 16:

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- Dr. Morris Fishbein, editor of The Journal of the American Medical Association and center of controversy in the medical profession, will sever his affiliation with the AMA early next month, it was reported tonight.
The 1949 All-America football team, selected for The United Press by 313 football writers and football broadcasters from all sections of the country, was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The South Carolina Electric and Gas Company, Columbia, S. C., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $22,200,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds, due Dec. 1, 1979, that are to be offered publicly by underwriters.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- There was further slackening of business in the stock markets here today, and small deals were enough to dictate price changes. The movement was irregular, although the undertone was fairly steady.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Former Representative Andrew J. May of Kentucky and Henry and Murray Garsson today asked the Federal District Court to reduce their sentences for conspiracy and bribery, to suspend any sentences or to grant probation.

ARMONK, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- Development of a suburban shopping center and two motion picture theatres, one a drive-in on the sixty-seven acres of the Westchester airport here is planned by a syndicate, it was learned tonight when an application for rezoning the acreage was filed with the North Castle town board.

The present pattern of psychiatric care in the state, which centers on the construction of new buildings for mental patients, should be strengthened, not changed, as some experts have advocated, Dr. Eli Ginzberg, director of the New York State Hospital Study, declared yesterday.

IT was just the other day that Johnny Dell Isola, the fiery Dartmouth line coach, was cutting up old touches with his one-time boss, Steve Owen. What was practically an ethereal glow spread across the rugged features of Dell when Stout Steve mentioned the time that Johnny got into a fist fight with Ernie Pinckert of the Washington Redskins on the very first play of the game.

Until recently scheduled as a Christmas week offering, "Alive and Kicking," the new musical which William R. Katzell and Ray Golden are producing, will arrive on Broadway on Monday evening, Jan. 9, at a theatre to be announced later.
Many skiers will enjoy their Thanksgiving Day testing dormant legs, thanks to the unusually early snows which make limited running possible.

Thanksgiving Day, as no other feast, is on target, aiming point and bombs away for every cranberry. Undoubtedly, such single-minded predestination makes him a bit of a fanatic -- a quality which does no harm to the soul of an artist. Everything about a cranberry smacks of struggle and Sparta.
ATLANTA, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Associated Press all-Southeastern team may show why Deep South football is off key this-season.

NORTHFIELD, Vt., Nov. 23 -President Homer L. Dodge of Norwich University said today the poor showing of the Norwich football team this season was among the reasons for his decision to resign. He added that he was influenced to some extent by the pressure applied by sports-minded alumni.

Fifty-four plants in the metropolitan area were announced yesterday as winners in the seventh annual Inter-Plant Accident Reduction Contest sponsored by the Greater New York Safety Council. A total of 426 plants, with 188,126 workers, took part in this year's contest from April 1 through Sept. 30.

Dr. Robert E. Muller has purchased the dwelling at 50 Caterson Terrace in Hartsdale, N. Y., from Horatio H. Burtt. Chauncey B. Griffen was the broker. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

In its third change of ownership in about one month the Raleigh Hotel, a fifteen-story building occupying a plot 60 by 102.2 feet at 119 to 123 West Seventy-second Street was purchased yesterday by a syndicate representing hotel interests from Iran.

We have long supported New York City bus drivers in their demands for retirement pensions and are therefore gratified by the Sugerman arbitration award that extends this benefit to workers on two major private lines and probably sets a precedent for others. The five-cent hourly pay rise also awarded seems to be in line with the wage trend elsewhere.

"The Dalton Gang," a Western with Don Barry, Robert Lowery, James Millican and Betty Adams, which arrives at the Palace, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Ford Beebe directed the offering from his own screen play. The Lippert production is being released by RKO.

The Office of the Housing Expediter approved 750 petitions for rent increases and denied 445 for the week ended last Friday in the New York City Defense-Rental Area, it was announced yesterday by Regional Housing Expediter John J. Pendergast.
Members of the paper industry were urged yesterday to combat a conception of industry as selfish and harmful to public welfare created by what appears to be calculated harrying of business.
NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 23 (AP) -Excellent results were reported today by scientists who sent balloons 97,000 feet aloft to get information on nuclear energy.

The first structural steel for the new Port Authority bus terminal, a thirty-foot column on the Eighth Avenue side of the block between Fortieth and Forty-first Streets and Eighth and Ninth Avenues, was raised yesterday.

TORONTO, Nov. 23 (Canadian Press) -- The Mexican Army team tonight crowned an almost undefeated performance at the Royal Winter Fair when it took the horse show's final event -- the International Officers Team Challenge Trophy.
The Soviet Union announced publicly yesterday that it would no longer recognize the right of the Chinese National Government to be represented in the United Nations.

For far sighted and considerate hostesses approaching holiday entertaining with a resolution that no guest shall search frantically for an empty spot to lay a drained glass, small collapsible chairside tables are a welcome solution. New variations of these convenient aids, which may be stored in a closet until needed, are now available.

David E. Lilienthal's friends had foreseen his early resignation as Chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission. He had been carrying a load as heavy as that of any man in the Government. With his colleagues he had been responsible for the security of the United States to a degree not even dreamed of a few years ago.

ALBANY, Nov. 23 -- Clifford J. Fletcher, Motor Vehicle Commissioner, today warned the more than five million motorists in the state that scattered snowfalls had already brought winter driving hazards.

According to Senator Thomas of Oklahoma, Sweden is a country which "helped no one in the last 135 years." You have already denied editorially this incredible statement. Would you allow me to illustrate the case from the experience of one of the nations which did get help from Sweden?
The internal dispute in the National Maritime Union, CIO, flared up again yesterday for a few minutes, but a scheduled "march" of rightist members to clear the hall of dissidents did not take place.

DETROIT, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The league-leading Red Wings had their hands full tonight turning back the Rangers, 4 -- 3, in a thrilling game at Olympia that saw the New Yorkers drop their role of "cousins" to the Detroiters.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 23 -The Minister of Government said in a press release today that 200 grenades had been seized by authorities in the northern sector of this city two nights ago. The statement added that the grenades were of such technical and expensive manufacture as to give basis for the belief that they were the work of either native or foreign experts.

BOSTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Capt. Milt Schmidt, veteran Bruin center, came up with his first goal of the current National Hockey League season to clinch a 3-1 victory for Boston over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight before 11,744 fans at the Boston Garden.

Coach Hook Mylin had his New York University football team engage in a three-hour drill, including scrimmage, yesterday afternoon in preparation for Saturday's traditional battle with Fordham University. The return of Tackle Mike Fazio, End Frank Ambrosia and Guard Russ Girolamo has put the Violets as near top condition as they have been since the start of the season.
DETROIT, Nov. 23 (UP) -- Louis Barbaroux, head chef of the Hotel Book Cadillac, took issue with countless housewives and his counterpart in New York's Waldorf-Astoria today on how to cook a turkey.

Calling for a revision of the system of prescribing war bonuses and war risk insurance for seamen, the Pacific Maritime Association has urged the creation of a new agency along lines similar to the present Maritime War Emergency Board.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 23 -- Austria will be permitted to stoekpile certain strategic materials, notably steel and chemicals, under the terms of a state treaty now nearing the final stage of negotiation by the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The National Labor Relations Board today barred from an election an "independent" local union on the ground that it was actually a "front" for the CIO's International Fur Workers Union headed by Ben Gold, avowed Communist.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, who confesses to being baffled at the rules of football in the United States, talked his way today into a shrewd wager on Saturday's Army-Navy gridiron battle.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations rejected Spain's application for membership tonight, but accepted those of Israel, Indonesia and Korea.

PATCHOGUE, L. I., Nov. 23 -- The finishing touches are being applied to Suffolk County's newest diagonal highway -- the thirteen-mile Patchogue-Commack Road, which will become a part of the county highway system on Dec. 1.

A committee of members of the Community Church of New York, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, headed by Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, will present a five-story brownstone residence, 28 East Thirty-fifth Street, as a parish community center, in honor of John Haynes Holmes, retiring minister, at 8:30 P. M., Tuesday, at a farewell reception for him and Mrs. Holmes at the church.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Nov. 23 (UP) -- An Albanian note to Yugoslavia accused Marshal Tito today of trying to form a "major Balkan state" that would oppose Russia and that he himself would lead.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Nov. 23 (AP) -- They're going to do it again! The University of Alaska and the Ladd Air Force Base Flyers will tangle Jan. 1 in the second annual Ice Bowl game.
The life of a 2-year-old girl was saved yesterday when a mail carrier making deliveries in an uptown Manhattan apartment building smashed through a door to snatch the child from a burning crib.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- In anticipation of the coming general election Britain's Labor party considered trimming its Socialist sails today. At the same time trades union leaders, representing 8,000,000 workers who are the backbone of the party, advised their 190 affiliated unions against any action that might disturb the country's economic equilibrium with adverse political effects.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The White House announced today the resignation of David E. Lilienthal, first chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission and perhaps the most controversial figure in Washington since the end of the war.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 23 -- The Rev. Michael Guthrie Scott, a lean soft-spoken Anglican clergyman who champions the Herero tribes of South-West Africa, scored a victory here today over the determined effort of the United States, Britain, France and a dozen other countries intent upon denying him the privilege of testifying before the Trusteeship Committee of the United Nations.
PLYMOUTH, Mass., Nov. 23 (UP) -- A pageant depicting the Pilgrims going to church will be the highlight of the Thanksgiving Day observance in Plymouth tomorrow.

Baseball hasn't run out of surprises yet in the waning year. At least it has one more in store for the fans in the announcement that Ted Williams, Boston's hard clouting outfielder, has been chosen the most valuable player in the American League for 1949, and by a wide margin to boot.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 24 -- The Foreign Ministers of Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg conferred here today and reached what was described as "more or less complete agreement" on the position of the Benelux countries in the five-nation economic integration talks to be opened next week in Paris.

The football squads from St. John's Prep and Brooklyn Prep spent their Thanksgiving in their usual manner at Ebbets Field yesterday, and came up with another of those keenly waged battles that have dominated the rivalry between the schools ever since 1914.

For the forty-ninth consecutive season, the Volunteers of America will send out to the city's street corners this morning more than a score of Santa Clauses of assorted sizes and shapes, each one carefully schooled in the proper deportment of his holiday profession.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Early cessation of the dismantling of German industrial plants was foreseen in London tonight as a consequence of the agreement between the Western Allied High Commission and the West German Chancellor published in Bonn. Experts estimated that dismantling would be terminated early in the new year.
BERLIN, Nov. 24 -- Conversion of the East zone "people's police" to an army status has been ordered by Moscow, according to a report in today's edition of the Western-licensed newspaper Abend.

PARIS, Nov. 24 -- The Paris offices of the Polish Red Cross, Boy Scouts and veterans' organizations were raided today by territorial surveillance agents of the Surete Nationale, who seized files for scrutiny and detained ten Polish nationals for questioning. The Poles were later released.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Export-Import Bank announced today that it had authorized a loan of $21,000,000 to Afghanistan to aid in financing the construction of a dam, a canal and irrigation system and supplemental additional river development projects.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 24 -- The dome of the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, directly over the designated Tomb of Christ, was ablaze tonight in a fire that began at 5 P. M. yesterday. It was apparent that the entire roof would be a total loss but because of the underlying construction little fear was felt for the shrine itself.

THERE won't be enough football teams left in action after tomorrow to fill an oversized training table. To all intents and purposes this is the end of the gridiron year. So here we go for a final stare.

MITCHEL AIR BASE, L. I., Nov. 24 -- A veteran of both World Wars, Brig. Gen. Charles E. Thomas Jr. has been appointed Inspector General of the Continental Air Command, it was announced today by that national command's headquarters here. He succeeds Col. Edgar T. Selzer and was formerly assigned as Commanding General of the 1503d Air Transport Wing at Tokyo.

BONN, Germany, Friday, Nov. 25 -- Dr. Kurt Schumacher, leader of the Social Democratic party, was expelled for twenty sessions from the Bundestag, or lower house, of the Western German Parliament, at 6:15 o'clock this morning for having labeled Chancellor Konrad Adenauer as the "Chancellor of the Allies."

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The Soviet Union no longer publishes statistical information concerning its production, consumption, cost of living, health, population and unemployment because it deliberately wishes to hide such information from the world.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Nov. 24 -- Technical conditions for return to practices that would permit full development of multilateral trade among Western European countries are now as good as they are likely to be for years to come. That is the opinion of American European experts responsible for advising Marshall Plan countries on the next moves to put Europe on its feet.

Hilholme, the former home of the late Percy S. Straus in Westchester County, will be sold by the United States General Services Administration, it was announced yesterday by W. E. Reynolds, commissioner of the Public Buildings Administration.

NEWARK, Nov. 24 -- Upward of a half million persons from this city and the surrounding area lined the sidewalks on both sides of the three-mile route of L. Bamberger's Thanksgiving Day parade today. By unanimous opinion of parade officials, police and veteran observers, it was the largest, most colorful and most festive of the sixteen annual parades the company has sponsored.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The National Labor Relations Board held today that a local education board in Kentucky was a "political subdivision" of that state and that its dealings with labor unions were beyond the scope of the Taft-Hartley Act. The decision was unanimous.

WICHITA, Kan., Nov. 24 -- The University of Detroit football team smashed the University of Wichita, 33 -- 7, to win the Missouri Valley Conference title today. The Titans finished their first season in the Conference with four victories in as many games.

HONG KONG, Nov. 24 -- The development of "national liberation armies" on the pattern of the Chinese Communist armies was declared essential to the success of the struggles in Asian and Australasian countries for "national independence and a people's democracy" by Liu Shao-chi in a Peiping speech last week.
CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (UP) -- Dr. Morris Fishbein, "muzzled" editor of The Journal of the American Medical Association, today confirmed reports that he would quit his post to become a medical consultant.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The State Department reported today that O. Edmund Clubb, United States Consul General at Peiping, was working on arrangements for the departure of Consul General Angus Ward and his four associates at Mukden who have been ordered to leave China by the Communist authorities in Manchuria.

For a change in this season of prevailingly conventional programs we had last night a challenging and exciting concert, mostly of new music, when Leopold Stokowski conducted the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall. Most of the music was significant. Some of it was not.

Twenty-three debutantes were honored at the Junior League Ball for provisional members, the first of its kind, last night in the ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton. Green and white, the colors of the League, were carried out in the decorations.

Possible strike action on the seventy-six routes of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation awaited last night a survey scheduled for this morning of a slowdown in the Bronx by James Hodes, one of the three trustees managing the system.

HAVANA, Nov. 24 -- The tendency of governments to go into the insurance business is one of the most serious problems faced by private insurance companies of the Western Hemisphere, according to A. L. Kirkpatrick, secretary of the permanent committee of the Hemispheric Insurance Conference now meeting here.
ALEXANDER CITY., Ala., Nov. 24 -- Tornadoes sweeping across Alabama tonight killed thirteen persons and injured fifty-three, the Red Cross reported.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UP) -- John L. Lewis claimed Thanksgiving immunity today and refused to discuss reports that he would meet in New York on Monday with the United Mine Workers' 200-man Wage Policy Committee.

The new $6,500,000 Americana hydroelectric power plant, a part of the $125,500,000 public-utility network in Brazil of the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., has been placed in service, according to an announcement made here.
MOSCOW, Nov. 24 -- The Soviet press published today extensive reports from United States and European sources under the headline "American Plans for the Creation of an Army in Western Germany."
PARIS, Friday, Nov. 25 (UP) -- Early today the Paris subway stations closed one by one and taxis disappeared rapidly from the city's streets.

Henry Laskau, national titleholder from the Maccabi A. C., competing from scratch, captured top honors yesterday in the thirty-ninth annual City Hall to Coney Island handicap walk sponsored by the Walkers Club of America. The Staten Island Harriers annexed the team title with a low point total of 12.

The latest move in President Peron's long campaign against the free press of Argentina has a touch of the absurd about it. The business offices of Buenos Aires' two great independent newspapers -- Prensa and Nacion -- and of two others have been seized, apparently in an effort to show that they had received money from opponents of Senor Peron in the 1946 election.

PANAMA, Nov. 24 -- Dr. Arnulfo Arias, who was ousted as president of Panama in 1941, was installed in the Presidency tonight by the National Police within an hour after the Supreme Court had ruled that Dr. Daniel Chanis Jr. still was the constitutional Executive.

VIENNA, Nov. 24 -- The general expectation in Hungary is that next spring will see the beginning of a military offensive by the Communist Information Bureau countries against Yugoslavia, according to advices that have reached Vienna from a highly reliable source.
HOUSTON, Texas, Nov. 24 -- (AP) -- Lack of a healthy winter market is giving crude oil a rough time, but it seems to be affecting exploration little.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 24 (UP) -- Discovery of a vast new Mexican oil field by American oil operators was announced here late yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Failure of the South African loan temporarily jolted the stock market here today but prices generally regained yesterday's levels.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Far from standing still, the National Security Resources Board has made solid progress in "the various programs for resource development in the event of war," James H. Shoemaker, director of program adjustment for the board, said today.

I had a unique personal experience that illustrated the jealousy with which the Soviet Union guards the accomplishments of its scientists and the extent to which it eschews collaboration with the West, even in those fields that have no military or industrial implication but which, on the contrary, would only be for the benefit of mankind.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- Caught off guard by a "sleeper" pass on the first play of the game, good for 68 yards and a Hamden touchdown, the White Plains High School Tigers struck back with a vengeance before 8,500 at the high school stadium this morning and turned back the previously unbeaten Connecticut eleven, 32 to 7.

Although actual construction of the physical plant of the new New York University-Bellevue Medical Center being erected on First Avenue between East Thirtieth and Thirty-fourth Streets has only just started, the first annual report of the new medical center, issued last week, shows that it is already making a significant contribution to the health not only of this community but of many others.

H. Clay Waterman, formerly of Pettit-Waterman Company, has formed the firm of Waterman Company with offices in 12 East Forty-first Street. Associated with Mr. Waterman in the new concern are William Hanley and Eugene A. McKeever, formerly of Pettit-Waterman Company.

I view with grave concern the fact that the so-called "informed Japanese today" have expressed some anxiety over the re-election of President Quirino in anticipation of a "tough" policy by the Philippines toward Japan. "To which," your Tokyo correspondent said, "the United States might be compelled to give some measure of consideration."

For the first novelty of its season, the New York City Ballet Company at the City Center last night presented Lew Christensen's "Jinx," set to music of Benjamin Britten. The work was originally presented by the Dance Players in 1942 and was quite the most distinguished piece to be introduced by that short-lived but interesting little organization.

The Democratic State Committee fired its opening gun of the 1950 campaign for the Governorship yesterday when Paul E. Fitzpatrick, chairman, invited the public to attend and speak at a legislative program policy-making conference at the Biltmore Hotel on Dec. 12 and 13.

As part of their campaign for amendment of the Taft-Hartley act to eliminate the ban on rotary hiring in the maritime industry, the Atlantic and Gulf District of the Seafarers International Union, AFL, has invited members of the Senate and House to see at firsthand the operation of their hiring hall at 51 Beaver Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Total consumer income in the United States is 90 per cent higher than in 1939. It is off 3 per cent from the peak reached in late 1948, the year with the highest consumer income on record.
