CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Cleveland Browns, though shackled by snow and a slippery gridiron, crossed the goal line twice within the first ten minutes of play to win their final All-America Football Conference regular season game from the Chicago Hornets, 14 -- 6, before 5,031 fans in Soldier Field today.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 24 -- Walter Wozniak, 51 years old, was killed and his wife, Hedwig, and five of their eight children were injured when a fire started at 2:20 A. M. today in their apartment at 109 Elizabeth Avenue here today. Seven firemen were overcome by smoke in fighting the blaze and were treated at the scene.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 24 -- Harry M. Popkin, United Artists producer, has acquired "The Hard Pillow," a screen melodrama by Theodore Strauss and Joseph Michel, under an option, and has assigned it to his colleague, George Moskov, for production in January. Strauss and Michel were represented in the deal by Ingo Preminger, author's agent. The story deals with a perverted killer who black-mails an innocent man implicated in one of the killer's crimes.

BUFFALO, Nov. 24 -- Techniques for teaching school children skills in reading newspapers and magazines and listening to radio programs will be one of many proposals of the Commission on English Curriculum of the National Council of Teachers of English, Dr. Dora V. Smith, the commission chairman, said here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Nearly 500,000 veterans of World War II who did not complete grade school have obtained an elementary education through the G. I. Bill of Rights, the Veterans Administration reported today.

DETROIT, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears had a comparatively easy time today rolling to a 28-7 decision over the Detroit Lions before 24,385 chilled fans, who braved a snowstorm to see the National Football League game.

The churches and synagogues throughout the country were visited by thousands of worshipers yesterday morning at annual Thanksgiving services. In keeping with tradition fruits, vegetables and sheaves of grain adorned many sanctuaries and altars. Supplies of farm produce thus collected were distributed to needy families and dinners were served at missions, churches and welfare agencies, under religious auspices.

Capt. Thorbjorn Thorsen, a veteran of forty-one years at sea, will be in command of the new luxury liner Oslofjord on her maiden trip from Oslo to New York. The ship sails tomorrow and is due here on Dec. 5

MONTREAL, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens took over second place from the Toronto Maple Leafs in the National Hockey League tonight by handing the Leafs a 5-3 trimming before a record Forum crowd of 13,805. The Canadiens won with two tallies in the final period.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UP) -- The Government predicted today that new home construction will set a new record this year.

ATHENS, Nov. 24 -- Speaking at a formal dinner tonight in honor of George C. McGhee, United States Assistant Secretary of State, who is en route to a diplomatic conference in Istanbul, Premier Alexander Diomides paid tribute to the United States as a power "seeking to offer to the whole world the rule of law and peace and a life free of fear and worry."

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 24 -- The jewelry industry, which reached an all-time employment peak of 22,059 workers in Rhode Island in October, faces a series of lay-offs that may take the jobs of thousands of workers, at least temporarily.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 24 -- A library of natural law, believed to be the only one of its kind in the world, will be founded at the University of Notre Dame at the third annual Natural Law Institute to be held Dec. 9 and 10 in the College of Law at Notre Dame, it was announced today by the Rev. John J. Cavanaugh, president of Notre Dame.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 24 -- Members of the Junior Hadassah, the Young Women's Zionist Organization of America, were urged here today in a keynote address to "accept responsibilities as well as the privileges of their birthright as young Americans." The speech was made in the opening day of the twenty-sixth annual convention of the order.

Held in check for three periods, New Dorp's football machine scored twice in the last session to down Curtis High, 12--0, before 6,000 yesterday at Gabes Stadium in Port Richmond, S. I., and thus wind up the season as the lone P. S. A. L. team possessing an unbeaten record.

The Long Island Rail Road pledged yesterday through its trustees, Hunter L. Delatour and David E. Smucker, to pay taxes on railroad property in five Suffolk County communities "promptly" when the levies on current assessments become payable.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 24 -- The United States opened debate on the Palestine question here today with the recommendation that a solution could be found in a reasoned, conciliatory approach to the problem and a warning that, conversely, all would lose by continued bitterness.

Plans for a one-family ranch house with two bedrooms were announced in connection with the purchase by Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Bachmann of Brooklyn of a plot 100 by 100 feet at the southwest corner of Middlesex Avenue and Goodwith Street, Iselin, N. J., through the C. B. Snyder Realty Company, brokers. Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas H. Giesse were the sellers. Financing was arranged by the brokers.

TOKYO, Nov. 24 -- Japan plans to make long-range efforts to promote trade with Communist China amounting to 25 or 30 per cent of Japan's import - export business, Heitaro Inagaki, Minister of Trade and Industry, has told the Diet's Budget Committee.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 24 (UP) -- The National Cotton Council today renewed its battle against state and Federal margarine taxes with the appointment of a special committee "to develop plans to combat discriminatory margarine legislation."

ROME, Nov. 24 -- On the eve of the Paris meeting of experts to discuss regional economic union among Italy, France and the Benelux nations, Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza declared today that the matter was extremely important as a step toward a European union. He added that it would have to be taken up on the government level by the powers concerned if the experts should fail to reach an understanding.

The Western Powers and the West-German Government have now signed an agreement which represents a further revision of both Western occupation policy and traditional German policy, and which in lieu of a formal peace treaty will serve as the basis of their relations with each other.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., Nov. 24 -- In an English-type cottage, its mullioned windows overlooking pleasant farmlands and estates here sits a little old lady busily at work on an unusual job of needlework. Using only silks and wools, she is recreating scenes ranging from those of her childhood in Yorkshire, England, to operatic stories and glimpses of historical events.

Federated Department Stores, Inc., in the fifty-two weeks ended on Oct. 29 had a sales volume of $360,625,510, the largest for any similar period in its history, Fred Lazarus Jr., president, reported yesterday. The volume for the fifty-two weeks to Oct. 30, 1948, was $330,977,625.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UP) -- The National Federation of Independent Business warned today that increasing United States imports of oli are "seriously jeopardizing our national security" and threaten the future of small producers.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Delegates to the National Grange convention were advised officially today to continue to oppose the farm price support program advocated by the Secretary of Agriculture, Charles F. Brannan.

Thomas Jefferson Miley, executive vice president of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., complained to Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday that the Temporary City Housing Rent Commission had delayed adopting regulations strengthening the Sharkey Rent Control Law. This he said, had placed a "great hardship on owners and tenants."

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 24 -- Three touchdowns behind midway in the third period and still twelve points to the bad with less than seven minutes to go, Brown came on with an irresistible surge to beat Colgate, 41 -- 26, at Brown Field today. The delirious finish sent 18,000 spectators home to their Thanksgiving turkey in a frenzied babble of excitement.

The Ellerman Lines freighter City of New York, the first oceangoing ship to carry the name of this port since the war, is scheduled to arrive here today to begin service in the company's New York-East and South Africa run.

The city opened its larder yesterday, wider than it has in many years. With 4,000 homeless and indigent persons partaking in the customary turkey and chicken Thanksgiving Day dinners, the Department of Welfare served one- third more meals this year than last.

" Texas, Li'l Darlin," jointly sponsored by Studio Productions, Inc., and the Anthony Brady Farrell Productions, will begin its Broadway career on the stroke of 8 tonight at the Mark Hellinger. Referred to as "Hell Bent for Election," when considered by Rodgers Hammerstein two years ago, the spoofing musical is the combined product of John Whedon and Sam Moore, authors of the book; Robert Emmett Dolan, composer, and Johnny Mercer, lyricist.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat, of ]qluois, estimated today that his health insurance plan to cover only "catastrophic" illnesses would cost about two-thirds less than the Truman Administration's broader program.
A waste-recovery by-product development now in its first stages is likely to make the American paper industry a major producer of alcohol, it was learned over the holiday.
For those who have a means of warding off chilblains, do not suffer from what is lightly termed the "common cold," and are so inclined, the ice-fishing season officially opens this morning.

Tomorrow night in a tiny Lower East Side theatre thirty young men and women will fold back tenement walls for an hour or two as they play, sing and act in Mozart's comic opera, "The Abduction from the Seraglio."

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Nott Terrace of Schenectady led its closest rival, Mont Pleasant, by ten points to retain the team laurels in the high school cross country feature of the Poughkeepsie Y. M. C. A. Thanksgiving road races today.
Curtains made from the many fabulous synthetic materials developed in recent years con be used interchangeably on most windows in most localities, but each fabric actually functions differently.

Leading figures of show business, the newspaper and civic fields are volunteering their services for the staging of a testimonial all-star show for Bill (Bojangles) Robinson to be held on Monday, Dec. 5, at Bop City, Forty-eighth Street and Broadway. The dancer is a patient at Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, where he is being treated for a heart ailment.
On this day -- Nov. 25 -- in the year 1783, General Washington and his staff rode into New York to take possession of the city that had been in the hands of the British ever since 1776.

New statistics on voluntary health insurance, published for the first time in the New York State Hospital Report, give evidence that the potentialities of voluntary insurance may be as great as those offered by compulsory health insurance, Dr. Eli Ginzberg, director of the study, declared yesterday.

The plenary session of the United Nations General Assembly at Flushing Meadow adjourned almost an hour before schedule shortly after 1 P. M. yesterday when the delegates had to choose between their Thanksgiving Day dinners and listening to a debate on full employment.

SEA ISLAND, Ga., Nov. 24 -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley celebrated his birthday anniversary and Thanksgiving in seclusion with his bride today after blowing out a cluster of candles with one puff.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 24 -- Premier Kim Il Sung, head of the Communist-led North Korean regime, indicated on Monday that poor labor discipline, lassitude and anti-Communist sabotage were hampering industrial production in that region.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 24 -- Dr. George S. Counts, Professor of Education at Columbia University Teachers' College and former New York State chairman of the American Labor party, tonight castigated those liberals who unquestioningly support the Soviet Union's policies in world affairs.

PARIS, Nov. 24 -- Holding in his hand the Bonn Agreement, Foreign Minister Robert Schuman took the offensive in the debate on Germany in the National Assembly today by pointing to the results of the first negotiation with the Western German Government as a positive achievement of the policy he was urging.
The halting search for atomic security apparently is opening new chapters at Lake Success and in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- From the Presidential table at Blair House to the mess hall of the most distant military installation in the world, the traditional turkey dinner was in high official favor today.

The course of America's economy will be analyzed by leading national and international figures at the fifty-fourth annual Congress of American Industry, sponsored by the National Association of Manufacturers, which will be held for three days starting Dec. 7, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 24 -- The lowest round-trip fares yet asked for air travel between North America and Europe will become effective Jan. 1 if approved by the Governments of countries in which air lines belonging to the International Air Transport Association operate.

The sea-going labor force on the active merchant marine has fallen to a post-war low of 64,000 officers and seamen, according to figures made public yesterday by the Joint Committee for the American Merchant Marine. During the war between 200,000 and 250,000 seamen were engaged in the nation's record-size fleet.

Arthur C. Liverhant, First Secretary of the Israeli Embassy in Washington, declared last night that "the best method of arriving at an acceptable solution of all outstanding problems between Israel and the Arabs is through direct negotiations between interested parties."
BOWIE, Md., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Brandywine Stable's Greek Song, trailing at the half-mile pole, closed like an express train in the $10,000 added Endurance Handicap today and won going away.

Figs and dates stowed away today on a kitchen shelf, among the many remnants of yesterday's feast, may come to the table again in the form of simple desserts. Example: The thrifty fig bread pudding pictured today, which has cool-weather appeal when served warm.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 24 (AP) -- The left-handed passing and explosive running of Clarence Tapper gave the University of Chattanooga a 13-to-0 football victory over favored Duquesne today.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 24 -- By formal agreement with the Western Allied High Commissioners, the West German Federal Republic stood pledged today to maintain demilitarization in its territory and and to prevent the re-creation of armed forces of any kind.
HYDE PARK, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- Mohammed Reza Pahlevi, the Shah of Iran, laid a wreath of white crysanthemums on the grave of President Franklin D. Roosevelt early this afternoon.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Maryland's football team got hotter as the game progressed to rout a bewildered West Virginia eleven, 47--7, today and enhance its outlook for a post-season bowl bid.

Treatment of scoliosis, an abnormal curvature of the spine, is attracting doctors from all over the world to the Hospital for Special Surgery, one of the eighty-six voluntary hospitals of the United Hospital Fund.

George E. Allen, whose career as Presidential adviser embraces both the Roosevelt and Truman administrations, has signed a contract with Simon Schuster for the publication of his first book, "Presidents Who Have Known Me."
A city fireman was injured early yesterday while fighting a stubborn blaze that burned for four hours in the hold of the Icelandic freighter Trollafoss, tied up at pier 25, Oliver Street, East River.
LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 24 -- Britain told the Soviet Union today that the time had come for it to choose between "world peace" and aid to revolutionary movements.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican, of Wisconsin, said today it would be "a grave mistake" for Congress to fail to make an investigation of the dismissal of Admiral Louis E. Denfeld as Chief of Naval Operations.

The excellence of the screen drama made from William Faulkner's "Intruder in the Dust" points up a recent trend in movies for which that industry deserves the strongest praise. This is the group of pictures which have come along this year on the theme of anti-Negro prejudice and its cruel and inhuman effects.
SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 22 -- Despite last spring's predictions of a crisis by wishful thinkers from the West the Chinese Communists have won the first round of their battle in Shanghai.

" ELIO VITTORINI is one of the very best of the new Italian writers," says Ernest Hemingway in his introduction to Mr. Vittorini's short novel, "In Sicily."* Stephen Spender and Elizabeth Bowen are also quoted on this book's jacket to the effect that they think "In Sicily" is a profound masterpiece.

TORONTO, Nov. 24 (Canadian Press) -- Imperial Oil, Ltd., will borrow $50,000,000 to refund its outstanding debentures and provide additional working capital, the subsidiary of Standard Oil of New Jersey announced today.

WARSAW, Nov. 24 -- The Polish Government reacted swiftly tonight to the arrest of its nationals in France and promised that it would "spare no efforts in the defense of its citizens and Embassy employes who fell victims to unheared-of behavior of the French authorities."
Grateful for a year of peace and prosperity, Americans here and in other parts of the world observed Thanksgiving Day yesterday in traditional fashion -- in prayer and feasting.

The belated decision of Britain's Trades Union Congress to support the Government's plea for a wage "freeze" ought to carry the Labor party leaders into a calm general election harbor. There is no certainty, because the T. U. C. has no mandatory powers over its 190 unions with 8,000,000 members, but the decision was thoroughly threshed out in advance and the only danger will come from "unofficial strikes."

BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 24 -- With the clandestine radio urging Liberals to stage a general strike beginning at 5 A. M. tomorrow, the Government warned today that it would not tolerate interference with public services.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 24 -- As 1,600 delegates began gathering here for the opening tomorrow of the annual conference of the United Jewish Appeal, Henry Morgenthau Jr., general chairman, announced that the Appeal had raised more than $620,000,000 since its inception in 1939 to meet Jewish needs in Israel and other parts of the world.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 24 -- India's Ministry of Industry and Supply is "encouraged" by the recent influx of foreign capital, both independently and in partnership with Indian interests, a spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UP) -- Following is the text of a State Department announcement on the agreements reached between the Western Allied High Commissioners and the Chancellor of the West German Federal Republic at Bonn:

Down Central Park West and Broadway yesterday morning moved a familiar but ever-enchanting procession. Ablaze with color and rich in fantasy, Macy's annual Tanksgiving Day Parade -- the biggest in its twenty-three-year tradition -- gaily made its way to the measure of blaring trumpets and rolling drums.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 -- With an up-hill fight rarely equaled by Cornell on Franklin Field, the Big Red overcame a 21-7 half-time deficit to defeat Pennsylvania, 29 -- 21, today and keep the Ivy League championship for a second year. It was the first time since 1931 that the Ithacans had beaten their ancient Thanksgiving Day rival two years in succession, and their point total was the largest against the Red and Blue since 1937.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 24 -- As expected, business in the Pittsburgh district last week showed a further pronounced gain, according to the Bureau of Business Research, of University of Pittsburgh. Moreover, the continued rise in the current week will no doubt boost the index above levels prevailing before the coal and steel strikes.

In a letter from Blaise Cascio about insuring physically handicapped individuals, published Nov. 17, Mr. Cascio indicated that it is a practice of life insurance companies to deny the benefits of insurance to physically disabled persons. This is not true. Life insurance companies have accepted as an obligation to the public the spreading of life insurance benefits to as many people as possible at rates which will be self-supporting.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Missouri Tigers, listless and indifferent at times, beat down a high-spirited Kansas State eleven, 34 to 27, today in the final football game of the season for both teams.

Mr. Vishinsky's declaration in the United Nations that he did not recognize the validity of the Chinese delegation was both a petty and a gratuitous insult. It hardly needs to be pointed out that the Soviet delegate is not the recognizing authority in the United Nations.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Army and Navy football teams, complete with new secret weapons and defensive gimmicks, prepared today to converge on this city tomorrow for the service classic Saturday.

" Trapped," an Eagle-Lion melodrama, will open this morning at the Globe. Lloyd Bridges, Barbara ayton, John Hoyt and James Todd head the cast of the offering, which was directed by Richard Fleischer and produced by Bryan Foy from a story and screen play by Earl Felton and George Zuckerman.
COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Nov. 24 (UP) -- Fists flew today as the University of Texas notched a 42- 14 victory over Texas A. and M. in their annual grudge battle, watched by 42,000 fans.

There has been a tendency of late to tone down the dreadful effects of an atomic bomb which is detonated over a hapless city. We have the somewhat skeptical report of the Strategic Bombing Survey, Prof. P. S. Blackett's disparagement and now Dr. Vannevar Bush's almost reassuring prediction.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 24 (AP) -- World tin mine production for September, 1949, was estimated at 13,200 long tons as compared with 13,900 in August, it was announced today by the International Tin Study Group here.

The 1950 Mercury line of cars offering added comfort and styling advances was announced yesterday by the Lincoln-Mercury division of the Ford Motor Company. The new models will go on display Tuesday in dealer showrooms here and over the country with no change in prices.

HONOLULU, Nov. 24 -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder and his party, including Gov. Ernest Gruening of Alaska and Rear Admiral Merlin O'Neil, the incoming Coast Guard commandant, arrived here today on the last leg of their inspection tour of Pacific Coast Guard installations.

The Brooklyn Bureau of Social Service and Children's Aid Society has just opened its annual Community Services Campaign, seeking from the public $293,000, which represents only one-third of its annual budget. Contributors' gifts will go to support four of the most important types of personal service, administered to troubled individuals of all races and creeds.

Manufacturers of printed rayon fabrics are seriously considering a plan for design registration with the United States Patent Office, it was learned over the holiday. Endorsement of such a plan, which would tend to reduce unethical copying, can be obtained from almost all print producers provided assurance can be given that design patents can be speeded up, according to the manufacturers.

PARIS, Friday, Nov. 25 -- A one-day general strike took increasing effect early today after getting under way in advance of the midnight deadline with a shutdown of newspapers and the teleprinter service of the semi-official French News Agency at 6 o'clock last night.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 24 (UP) -- Czechoslovakia's Roman Catholic Bishops warned priests today they would be unfrocked for any collaboration with the Communist regime that violated their obedience to the church.

Of eighteen countries compared with the United States, the Soviet Union stands out as the one in which the largest number of hours and minutes of work are required on the average to buy food, the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics reports.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The New York Yankees defeated the Los Angeles Dons today, 17 -- 16, a heartbreaking setback that eliminated the Dons from a possible chance of landing in the All-America Conference championship play-offs.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The Preparatory International Trade Union Committee was preparing final details here today for next week's meeting that will set up an international non-Communist trade union organization.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Marked improvement in employment in major production areas between July and the end of September was reported today by the Labor Department.

With infants and children under 15 years old, soon to be the largest single population group in the United States, pediatricians are in a strategic spot to work with parents in a constructive program of mental hygiene that might cut down the future number of adults requiring attention for mental upsets, according to Dr. Arnold M. Gesell, founder of the Clinic of Child Development, Yale University School of Medicine.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Controversy over the question of "restrictive clauses" in Greek-letter-society constitutions and by-laws was believed likely today to arise at sessions tomorrow of the forty-first annual National Interfraternity Conference.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Senator Herbert R. O'Conor, Democrat, of Maryland, disclosed today that he had urged the Federal Power Commission to withhold any action bearing upon legislation proposing the long-contested St. Lawrence Seaway until Congress had an opportunity to pass on the project.

Two hundred of the organized vegetarians in New York had Thanksgiving dinner yesterday without turkey, mince pie, apple cider or any of the usual trimmings. They were attending the eighteenth annual holiday dinner of the Vegetarian Society of New York in Mayfield's Dairy Restaurant, Broadway near Seventy-fifth Street.

A new seven-story $1,750,000 medical and surgical building at the Israel Zion division of Maimonides Hospital, 4802 Tenth Avenue, Brooklyn, will be ready for occupancy March 1, it was announced yesterday in a joint statement issued by Edward Neimeth, president of Maimonides, and Ralph E. Samuel, president of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, with which the hospital is affiliated.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The United States rejected today as inadequate and unsound the proposal for an International Commodity Clearing House put forward by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations to handle world-wide distribution of food surpluses.

Without the heat or the tension that accompanied discussion of the subject earlier this year in the Economic and Social Council, the United Nations General Assembly opened yesterday at Flushing Meadow its debate on methods of achieving and maintaining full employment.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The New York Yankees defeated the Los Angeles Dons today, 17 -- 16, a heartbreaking setback that eliminated the Dons from a possible chance of landing in the All-America Conference championship play-offs.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The Preparatory International Trade Union Committee was preparing final details here today for next week's meeting that will set up an international non-Communist trade union organization.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The United States rejected today as inadequate and unsound the proposal for an International Commodity Clearing House put forward by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations to handle world-wide distribution of food surpluses.

Without the heat or the tension that accompanied discussion of the subject earlier this year in the Economic and Social Council, the United Nations General Assembly opened yesterday at Flushing Meadow its debate on methods of achieving and maintaining full employment.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- March wheat, March, May and July corn and December and May oats sold at new high prices for the year on the Board of Trade here today as the markets resumed their upward movement following a reaction on profit-taking Wednesday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 -- Army and Navy meet here tomorrow for the fiftieth time in football's spectacle of spectacles, with the West Point cadets, unbeaten in their last nineteen games, favored by two touchdowns.

PARIS, Saturday, Nov. 26 -- By a vote of 344 to 248 the National Assembly just before 6 o'clock this morning gave the Government a highly qualified and reluctant vote of confidence on its German policy.

FLANDERS, L. I., Nov. 25 -- Two duck hunters, members of the closely limited Flanders Club, a hunting and fishing association, drowned this afternoon when their boat overturned in Peconic Bay as they were returning from a blind.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Miss Margaret Truman, here for a concert Sunday afternoon with the National Symphony Orchestra, today told a news conference that she received a dozen favorable criticisms to two adverse ones on her current concert tour, but the adverse ones "got the national circulation."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Many small nations and independent organizations had their say today in behalf of the International Commodity Clearing House proposed by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations. The plan was killed yesterday by the big nations.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- During the week ended Nov. 23, member-bank reserve balances decreased $445,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Four teen-age boys took to two rafts, Huckleberry Finn fashion, on the Harlem River yesterday afternoon and were enjoying a pleasant if somewhat choppy voyage when they noticed a Police Department helicopter hovering over them.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Northeast first squad came from behind today to gain a 2-2 tie with the Philadelphia first team in the second day of play in the Women's United States field hockey tournament. Middle Atlantic beat Southeast, 3 -- 1.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 25 -- Major Benjamin H. Namm, former president of the National Dry Goods Association, charged today that a majority of economics professors in "too many" American colleges and universities were slanting their courses against the country's economic system.

"OUR time is like a dance of death whose uncanny rhythm is understood by few," the Countess Ballestrem-Solf wrote from Berlin not long ago. "I do not want to think of the past because it has lost its meaning. The world has learned nothing from it -- neither slaughterers nor victims nor onlookers." Yet the world can learn from her story.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 25 -- Speaking for the Western Allied High Commission, Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, British High Commissioner, declared today that the recent Bonn agreement "should not be regarded as a stepping stone for further demands."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce announced today that all controls on imports, distribution and inventories of pig tin will be dropped Dec. 1.
NUTLEY, N. J., Nov. 25 (AP) -- A plastic coating for windows that is said to prevent fading of furniture was announced today by the manufacturer.

The juvenile aspect of any typical American street scene is one that quickly causes an adult to come to the conclusion that a preponderant percentage of toys are of a war type. Kids are armed to the teeth with pistols, dummy rifles, rubber daggers, plastic sabers, tin machine guns, and what not.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 25 -- This country faces greatly increased college and university enrollment, Dr. Alvin C. Eurich, president of the State University of New York, predicted here today. By 1960, he asserted, colleges will have an enrollment "far above 3,000,000" as against the present 2,500,000.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 21 -- All property in Israel to which the Russian church or Government has clear title has been transferred to the Soviet Union. But the ownership of vast real estate holdings registered in the name of the Russian Orthodox Society or of Grand Duke Sergei who was assassinated in 1905, is still unsettled.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- The stock markets here were featureless and extremely quiet today. Gilt-edge stocks, where changed, usually showed rises of 1/8 point, this fraction being gained by most of the savings issues. However, losses of 1/4 point were shown by the Conversion 3 1/2 per cent and War Loan issues.

Cook Academy, a former Baptist preparatory school in Montour Falls, N. Y., which was recently bought by the Franciscan Friars of the Atonement, Graymoor, Garrison, N. Y., will be dedicated on Tuesday as St. John's Atonement Seminary.

The country is indeed fortunate that two of its most influential citizens, former President Herbert Hoover and J. Edgar Hoover, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, have taken an extensive interest in boys' clubs. The two Messrs. Hoover appreciate that the importance of reaching boys in their formative years cannot be overemphasized.

I am obliged to use buses every day going to and from my work and I believe that my complaint about them is shared by many of your readers. The present system whereby the driver is obliged to spend so much time with each passenger, collecting the odd amount, making change and depositing the various coins in their different receptacles, is a tremendous strain on him.

VIENNA, Nov. 25 -- Trade with the West by Soviet satellite states is to be regarded as a variant of Lenin's transitory "New Economic Policy," according to an article in the latest issue of the journal of the Communist Information Bureau.
LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 25 -- Following are excerpts from the address delivered today by Dr. T. F. Tsiang of China before the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly:

ROME, Nov. 25 -- On his return from Budapest, Hungary, where he went "on party business," Palmiro Togliatti, Communist leader, said in an interview he planned continued agitation and unrest among Italy's southern landless peasants.

St. John's basketball team, paced by its six-foot six-inch center, Bob Zawoluk, defeated John Marshall of Jersey City, 97 to 71, in De Gray Gymnasium last night. Zawoluk, collecting 37 points, set an individual scoring mark for the court, while the team total of 97 was four more than the previous record.

The five-cent cup of coffee in the large chains of low-priced cafeterias and counter restaurants in New York cannot last a month longer, it was predicted yesterday by executives of the restaurants concerned.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- Debate on organizational matters and on one phase of a proposal for an international veterans league marked the opening sessions today of the three-day annual convention of the American Veterans Committee.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Flying weather sprinted to a five-length victory and then survived a claim of foul to win the $10,000 added William P. Burch Memorial Handicap today before 9,608 spectators and pay $18.20 for $2.
BUFFALO, N. Y., Nov. 25 (AP) -- United States pottery makers planned today to carry their fight against low-price Puerto Rican pottery into the island itself.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed firm, 1 to 14 points net higher.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 25 -- In the wake of the ouster of Dr. Kurt Schumacher, Socialist leader, from the Bundestag or Lower House of Parliament, the Social Democratic party announced today the initiation of a sharp struggle against the West German administration on the ground that it was seeking to create an authoritarian state.

Fifty-four plants in the metropolitan area were announced yesterday as winners in the seventh annual inter-plant accident reduction contest sponsored by the Greater New York Safety Council. Eighteen are in Manhattan, fifteen in Brooklyn, nine in Queens and five in Westchester.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -The Federal Power Commission said today that the Central New York Power Corporation must get a Federal license before starting to build its proposed dam and storage reservoir on the Raquette River. It adopted, with modifications, an examiner's recommendation to that effect.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 22 -- In the past few weeks Nationalist planes have dropped increasingly heavy bomb loads on the seaports of China from which the Communists are expected to launch invasions of the Nationalists' last island strongholds.

A 12-year-old girl -- a Greek war orphan -- with a charming smile and captivating personality pushed a button yesterday and officially opened a bright Christmas toy exhibit on the eighty-sixth floor observatory of the Empire State Building.
ASHEVILLE, N. C., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay announced his resignation today as president of Ecusta Paper Corporation, effective as soon as a successor could be named.

Business loans made by New York City banks dropped $4,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, declining for the second successive week. The reduction, it was explained yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its weekly report is based on figures adjusted to cover the shrinkage, through mergers, of the twenty-four reporting member banks to a new total of twenty-two.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Brig. Gen. E. M. Brannon, assistant judge advocate general for army procurement, admitted today that the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's definition of electric water coolers recently was used by the Army in preparing specifications for $100,000 of such equipment.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 25 (UP) -- Gargantua, the fearsome gorilla who symbolized the savage beast for millions of circus-going youngsters, died in his $10,000 cage today a few hours after his last appearance. During his twelve years with the circus, the great ape awed 40,000,000 visitors.

Muriel Kerr, pianist, gave a recital last night at Carnegie Hall before a highly enthusiastic gathering. She was heard in the Bach-Busoni choral prelude, "Nun komm' der Heiden Heiland"; Hindemith's Sonata, No. 3; Schumann's Fantasy, Ravel's "Valses nobles et sentimentales," and a Chopin group composed of the Prelude in C sharp minor, Op. 45, Prelude in F sharp minor, Op. 28, No. 8, and "Andante Spianato and Grande Polonaise Brillante."

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- The twenty-four-hour general strike throughout France was being concluded tonight without having greatly inconvenienced the public. Its effect in getting pay rises and freedom in collective bargaining for the unions was not clear.

Department store and specialty shop trade improved seasonally this week. Percentagewise, specialty shops had the best gains of the fall season thus far and are expected to show increases of about 6 per cent. Department store sales were estimated at 2 to 3 per cent under the comparative 1948 week, an improvement over the larger decline of preceding weeks.

The only book published today is "Leonidas LaFayette Polk: Agrarian Crusader," by Stuart Noblin. It is a biography of the leader of the Southern Alliance, who made the Populist party a major third-party threat in the Presidential campaign of 1892.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UP) -- President and Mrs. Truman will be accompanied by a party of twenty-eight, including relatives, friends and White House staff members, when they attend the Army-Navy football game at Philadelphia tomorrow.

BUFFALO, Nov. 25 -- The world may stand close to "a peak in the history of mankind," if we control the use of atomic energy and employ it only for beneficent purposes, Edward Weeks of Boston, editor of the Atlantic Monthly, said tonight.
With T-square and triangle, fifty girls at the Brooklyn High School for Homemaking are learning to plot out intricate plans for furniture arrangements.

The partial failure of the one-day general strike called yesterday by the French labor confederations lends credence to the belief that there has been a considerable decline in union influence as well as membership. Whatever the reason for this development, a new chapter will soon be opening in the post-war history of labor relations in France with the expected passage of a bill restoring collective bargaining.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 25 -- Authoritative Yugoslav sources take the view today that the dangers implicit in the Belgrade-Moscow struggle have abated, at least temporarily, as a result of current political disturbances inside Communist parties and governments in he Communist Information Bureau bloc.
Varied tastes will be satisfied by diverse exhibitions of paintings and sculpture in New York this week.

HONG KONG, Nov. 25 -- United States participation in large-scale rural reform efforts in Szechwan terminated this week. With the approach of the Communist armies toward Chungking and Chengtu, all American personnel connected with the Szechwan program have withdrawn by plane.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Nov. 19 totaled 758,972 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 25 (AP) -Charles Ritz, president of the International Milling Company, reported today a consolidated net profit of $2,296,230 for the year ended on Aug. 31.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 25 -- Following are excerpts from statements today by Moshe Sharett Foreign Minister of Israel, and Kamil Abdul Rahim Bey, Egyptian Ambassador to the United States, to the Special Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly:

BREWSTER, Mass., Nov. 25 -- A sea turtle weighing 350 pounds and measuring fifty inches long by thirty-two inches wide was hauled ashore here today. Three carpenters stopped work on a Cape Cod cottage they were building to lasso it as it threshed in a losing fight against a strong incoming tide.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Magnavox Company, manufacturer of television and radio sets, made public today the terms of its proposed new financing. A stockholders' meeting has been called for Dec. 12 to vote on the proposals.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 25 -- An international Islamic conference, whose deliberations may affect the trend of thought and action in the Moslem world, opened in Karachi today.

Through arrangements just completed, WOR-TV will telecast twenty-one college basketball games during the 1949-50 season, it was announced yesterday by Robert J. O'Connor, director of sports for the station.
ALBANY, Nov. 25 -- Governor Dewey today appointed Miss Constance K. Eberhardt of 616 West 116th Street, New York City, as a confidential law assistant to his counsel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Gen. Omar N. Bradley, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, described the North Atlantic treaty organization today as potentially a greater deterrent to aggression against its members than the atomic bomb. He spoke in a radio address carried by the Voice of America, before his departure for the meeting of the organization's Military Committee in Paris.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- President Truman today named Hubert E. Howard, a Chicago coal company executive, to the long-unoccupied post of chairman of the Munitions Board of the Department of Defense. The appointment filled one of the most prominent of several vacancies that have occurred in the defense establishment.
LATROBE, Pa., Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Right Rev. Denis Omer Stritt-matter was enthroned today as Coadjutor Archabbot of St. Vincent Archabbey and College in a ceremony dating to the seventh century.

The 1,000th showing of "The Red Shoes" will go into the record this afternoon at the Bijou Theatre, where the British-produced ballet drama now is in the fifty-seventh week of its engagement and still going strong. The box-office take now is crowding the million-dollar mark, with some 539,698 tickets having been sold so far at an average admission of $1.80.

A group of foreign shipping men representing recipients of Marshall Plan cargo will meet with officials of the Economic Cooperation Administration next Thursday and Friday in an attempt to answer ECA criticism of the allocation of cargo to United States shipping lines.

Heavy advertising by television set manufacturers and their dealers have been an important factor in gains made by newspapers in retail linage, Media Records, Inc., reported yesterday. During September, television dealers placed 3,693,698 lines of advertising in newspapers of the thirty-four key television markets, an increase of 250 per cent over the 1,272,981 placed by retailers in the same newspapers for the like month of last year, it was noted.

The creation of an appeals committee within the framework of the Board of Examiners of the city's school system was urged yesterday by five teacher and supervisory groups before an open hearing at Board of Education headquarters, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn. Two organizations, however, supported the establishment of an appeals board that would be completely independent of the examiners.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The State Department, expressing "profound shock" at the police-directed coup establishing Dr. Arnulfo Arias as President of Panama, today withheld diplomatic recognition from the new Panamanian Government.

The Boston Celtics and the New York Knickerbockers will meet in a professional basketball game in Madison Square Garden this afternoon, starting at 3 o'clock. It will present Tony Lavelli, formerly of Yale, in the role of Boston basketball and accordion player.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The British cotton textile industry is very much concerned with Japanese competition, Harold Wilson, president of the British Board of Trade, said today.

WARSAW, Saturday, Nov. 26 -- The French Ambassador to Poland, Jean Baelen, personally thwarted an apparent attempt early this morning by Polish security authorities to arrest Mlle. Helen Loisel, Embassy secretary and acting French Vice Consul here.
Does not the editorial on "The Gold Coin Standard" in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 17 put THE TIMES in the position of being one of the defenders of our system of irredeemable currency?

Although Texas covers a large area, it is considerably better organized than the musical cartoon entitled "Texas, Li'l Darlin'," which opened at the Hellinger last evening. That is probably the reason why the show is the less entertaining of the two.

China's charges against the Soviet Union in the United Nations have several aspects of great gravity. The complaint goes to the root of some of the difficulties in post-war international dealing and it cannot be dismissed either as idle propaganda or as a belated attempt to win adherents to the cause of the Nationalist Government of China.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- Consolidation of two of the three large national private business school associations was proposed here today, as delegates convened for the first joint convention of the National Council of Business Schools, National Association of Accredited Commercial Schools and American Association of Commercial Colleges.

The question of what makes the Soviet mind tick is raised again by the circumstances surrounding the arrests of an American representative of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company in Budapest and a French consular employe in Warsaw. Both mysteriously disappeared, the Frenchman from a plane bound for Paris, the American after checking out of his hotel to drive to Vienna.

The Carnation Company announced yesterday an extra dividend of $2 a share and the regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents on the common stock, payable on Dec. 15. This brings payments for 1949 to $4, or double the amount distributed in 1948.

HEAMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 25 -- Hofstra College's veteran quintet inaugurated its 1949-50 campaign with a 95-to-53 triumph over San German of Puerto Rico in Calkins Gymnasium tonight. This was the first of nine games in the United States for the visitors who won the Insular championship last summer.

There's nothing like travel and no place like home, a saleswoman and stock man from Gimbel Brothers reported yesterday at a news conference they held in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel a few hours after returning from three weeks of sightseeing in six European countries.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 25 -- "Criminal Code," a 1931 prison film directed by Howard Hawks at Columbia, will be remade by the studio as a Glenn Ford vehicle if a suitable new scenario can be developed from the property, it was learned today.
Mayor O'Dwyer took action early this morning to prevent a threatened strike on buses of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation, which would affect 1,800,000 daily users of its lines.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- Indications have now been received that the "quiet purge" of the followers of the late Andrei A. Zhdanov, which has been going on in the Soviet Union during the past year, is now over.
BOONTON, N. J., Nov. 25 -- Ralph Romano, Madison pro, gave The Knoll Golf Club an unofficial course record today and he would not trade it for a dozen official standards.

Gen. Nicolae Radescu, 75-year-old former Premier of Rumania, accepted yesterday a challenge of Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, to tell the United Nations the facts about the dismissal of the general's administration in 1945.

The season for parties and gala fashions is officially open. With Thanksgiving Day past, the young people are looking ahead to Christmas, New Year's and debut parties as times when ball gowns and formal dresses will be needed.

MOSCOW, Nov. 25 -- Under the title "'learned' slanderers of THE NEW YORK TIMES," the Government organ Izvestia attacked today an article by Harry Schwartz published in THE NEW YORK TIMES Oct. 11 reporting on studies of Soviet collective agriculture made by Prof. Naum Jasny of the Stanford University Food Research Institute.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Snow forced Notre Dame's squad inside for most of its drills this week, and the usual razor sharpness honed into the team by task-master Frank Leahy for a big game may be missing when the unbeaten Irish tangle with Southern California here tomorrow.
Ranch and wild mink are almost the only strong spots in the fur season about to get under way in the local markets.

The Hour Glass Restaurant, which has occupied the five-story and basement building on lot 18 by 100.5 feet at 42 East Fifty-third Street between Madison and Park Avnues for more than fifteen years, yesterday bought the property from Frederick Brown in a deal negotiated by Douglas L. Elliman Co. and Joseph L. Gerety, brokers.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 25 -- China asked the United Nations today to find the Soviet Union guilty of jeopardizing the peace of Asia and to call on all fifty-nine members to refuse recognition and aid to the Chinese Communists.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 25 -- The conference of the heads of the United States diplomatic missions to the Middle East, opening here tomorrow, will be dominated to a great extent by the sharp difference in relations between the United States and the various countries concerned.
PARIS, Nov. 25 -- In a small collection of early spring millinery, Albouy teams helmet-like caps with wrist-length capes, both in light-weight felt.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 25 -- The Western powers, won United Nations committee approval today of their outline for peace through international cooperation. In another vote they piled up a heavy majority to reject the Soviet Union's demand for a new treaty among the Big Five.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The Southern Coal Producers Association unexpectedly made a direct offer to John L. Lewis tonight to resume wage talks with the United Mine Workers.

Today's events: "Samson et Dalila" at 2 o'clock and "Tosca" at 8:30, Metropolitan Opera; Guiomar Novaes, piano, Town Hall, 2:30; Pro Musica Antiqua, Safford Cape, conductor, Times Hall, 3; Philharmonic-Symphony, Leopold Stokowski, conductor, Jacques Abram, piano, Carnegie Hall, 8:45.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 25 (AP) -- The powerful University of Kentucky Wildcats roared back tonight and smashed a gallant University of Miami football team, 21 to 6, before 42,970 stunned spectators in the Orange Bowl.

BARNEGAT CITY, N. J., Nov. 25 -- There are a few isolated fringes along Barnegat Bay where the Sunday tripper and the bungalow tycoon have never penetrated, where the quiet is broken only by the occasional gabble of feeding waterfowl and the noise of wind in the sedge.

The one and three-story buildings at 25-09 Forty-second Road in Long Island City, Queens, have been leased by the Malan Plumbing Company from J. P. McGowan. The Roman-Caswell Company was the broker. The lessee, an industrial plumbing contracting concern, will use the buildings for executive offices and warehouse purposes.

On three different occasions this year we have urged that the salaries of the Mayor and his principal Cabinet members be increased. A salary of $25,000 is utterly inadequate and unjust for the Mayor of New York City, with the responsibilities attendant on governing a population of 8,000,000 persons.

Speaking again of those holes in the ground which accompany the continuing process of putting a modern face upon our city -- and provide convenient entertainment for the man in the street -- it has been suggested to our faithful sidewalk superintendent that watching holes in the ground being dug is probably the oldest of spectator sports.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The Navy announced today that it is reorganizing its sea training program for reservists to save $2,000,000 annually while at the same time increasing by 10,000 the number of training billets.

The State of South Dakota announced yesterday that it would receive bids Jan. 5 on an issue of $11,000,000 of war bonus bonds. Dated Jan. 15, 1950, the bonds will come due Jan. 15, 1951 to 1953. The issue will mark the state's second recent offering of war bonus bonds.

Issuance of the recent decree by Peru establishing a free market rate for the sol and making the proceeds from exports convertible at the free market rate was hailed yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council as a "forthright and realistic effort to cope with Peruvian international economic problems."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The State Department denied today that Spain had requested a loan from the United States Government, but added, at the same time, that the department had not objected "on political grounds" to such a loan.

Newspapers' retail advertising linage during the holiday month of December should top the high levels reached last year, it was estimated yesterday by John Giesen, director of the retail division of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.

Joan Field is a good violinist, as she has proved in past recitals and as she proved again last night in Town Hall. Her tone is pure, rich in colors and of accurate pitch, and she can play difficult passages with ease.

Max Gordon's first production of the season, "Metropole," starring Lee Tracy, will make its Broadway debut at the Lyceum Theatre on Tuesday evening, Dec. 6, it was announced yesterday. The William Walden play, staged by George S. Kaufman, has been undergoing revisions in Philadelphia, where it will remain through next week.

Surrogate William T. Collins eliminated yesterday all but one of the 173 claimants to the $5,000,000 fortune left by Miss Mary Bullock Powers, 72-year-old spinster, who died July 20, 1948, in her $30-a-day suite in the Seymour Hotel, and directed the remaining claimant, Horace Powers Gale, paper carton executive, to establish by Dec. 5, that he is a distributee and entitled to share in or inherit the entire estate.

The Sheffield Farms Company, Inc., has sold the two two-story factory buildings at 2241 East Sixteenth Street and 1601 Neck Road in Brooklyn to the Enra Company, Inc., represented by August Kloges, attorney. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- George Tomlinson, Minister of Education, has rejected a proposal by the Roman Catholic hierarchy of England and Wales for reducing the cost to the church of reorganizing and building Catholic schools under the 1944 Education Act.

Last night's performance by the New York City Ballet Company at the City Center had as its principal item of interest the season's first presentation of "The Guests," choreographed by Jerome Robbins to music by Marc Blitzstein. The work was done originally for this company last season, and was not especially impressive except for a brilliant pas de deux in the middle.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Under pressure of undergraduates from colleges in the Northeast, reinforced by members from the Middle West's Big Ten, the National Interfraternity Conference received reluctantly today a resolution calling for repeal of discriminatory clauses that bar fraternity membership because of race or religion.

THE NEW YORK TIMES on Nov. 6 featured on the front page a news dispatch from Tel-Aviv with the sensational headlines: "Ben-Gurion Warns Foreign Zionists -- Assails Leaders Abroad Who Try to Sway Israel Policy -- Silver Held Target."

DETROIT, Nov. 25 (UP) - Welterweight Lester Felton floored previously unbeaten Ross Virgo three times tonight to overcome the Rochester, N. Y., fighter's early advantage and win a unanimous decision in their 10-round bout before 7,181 fans.

A family of four consuming twenty-four and a half quarts of milk weekly, the amount recommended by nutritionists, can save $1.19 1/2 each week at current prices if the supply is store-derived rather than home-delivered.
A police alarm for an automobile with a broken headlight and a dented hood turned up a suspected hit-run driver who struck and killed a patrolman early yesterday

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- A "national theatre" movement, aimed at decentralizing the legitimate theatre business now concentrated in New York, and which would, it was predicted, provide more jobs for actors and actresses who cannot get to Broadway, was launched here today.
ALBANY, Nov. 25 (AP) -- A government bureau today faced failure in an attempt to give away $400,000,000. The bureau may run out of people seeking cash before it runs out of money.

Bill (Bojangles) Robinson, the dancer, died at 7:28 P. M. yesterday in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. The 71-year-old "King of Tap Dancers" had been admitted to the hospital on Nov. 14, suffering from a heart ailment.

The five-story residence of Mrs. Shepard Fabbri at 7 East Ninety-fifth Street was deeded by her yesterday as a gift to the House of the Redeemer, a corporation of the Protestant Episcopal Church, for use as a retreat haven for the New York area.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 25 -- Professor Edith Putnam Parker of the University of Chicago was the recipient tonight of the Distinguished Service Award of the National Council of Geography Teachers at the organization's thirty-fifth annual convention banquet.

The football Giants entertained two hopes as they ran through a long drill at the Polo Grounds yesterday -- one that they would beat the Washington Redskins tomorrow and the other that at the same time the Pittsburgh Steelers would outscore the champion Philadelphia Eagles.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 24 -- The Soviet Union now is encouraging openly the slogan employed by Arab refugee spokesmen of all types that if the United Nations does not repatriate the Palestinian Arab refugees they will turn Communist.

BOSTON, Nov. 25 -- Speakers and delegates at the opening session of the Massachusetts Congress of Industrial Organizations made it clear today that Communists and fellow travelers no longer would find asylum in their ranks.

EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., Nov. 25 -Mr. and Mrs. Edward Lipkin of New York lost today their $100,000 damage suit against Sheriff Alvin Kramer of Clinton County, Ill. They charged that he had falsely arrested them in 1946 and held them incomunicado for ten days in the Clinton County Jail at Carlyle, Ill.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- West Point cadets, using a B-25 bomber, an anti-aircraft searchlight and four or five remarkably loud-sounding cannons, staged a football rally at the Academy last night that alarmed this Hudson Valley community.

GENEVA, Nov. 25 -- Fourteen Western and Eastern European countries and the United States decided today to continue cooperative work through the United Nations to improve European coal and coke production and distribution despite the end of the period of acute shortages.

The stock market, which has had considerable difficulty this week in setting a definite course, encountered yesterday a sizable quantity of profit-taking on the Stock Exchange which shook prices from fractions to about 2 points lower, with a loss of 0.97 point in the composite rate.
The Ford Motor Company of Detroit reported yesterday a move designed to simplify the organization's corporate structure and to pave the way for rehabilitating its foreign associated companies.
DETROIT, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports predicted today a progressive improvement in rehiring i n the auto industry throughout December.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The State Department announced today that Willard L. Thorp, Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, would head a small group of government officials on a four-day visit to consider economic development in Puerto Rico.

BERLIN, Nov. 25 -- ADN, Soviet-licensed news agency, said tonight that a United States Air Force enlisted man of Spanish descent had renounced his citizenship and had asked for asylum in Communist-ruled Eastern Germany.

In an editorial on Nov. 17 we took occasion to applaud a statement by Thomas B. McCabe, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, in which he met and, it seemed to us, effectively disposed of the principal arguments that are advanced from time to time for a return by the United States to the full gold coin standard.

November bedroom and dining-room furniture suite bookings by the Mengel Company are running "far ahead" of the like month last year, Alvin Voit, president, reported yesterday. Up to this month, he said, retail orders for each month in 1949 lagged behind 1948.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 25 -- A "basis of settlement" that shipping men hoped would foreshadow a long period of peace in the West Coast maritime industry was reached late today in contract negotiations between the Pacific Maritime Association and the Sailors Union of the Pacific, AFL.

The Park Company, represented by Joseph Howard Katz, attorney, has purchased a taxpayer site at the northwest corner of White Plains Road and East 231st Street, the Bronx. The seller was the 4040 Carpenter Avenue Realty Corporation, of which John McNulty is president. Charles H. Hayes was the broker.

The Census Bureau estimates that there are now more than 150,000,000 of us. Those who have followed the Bureau's periodically published statistics will not be astonished, despite the decline in the birth rate which began to be noticed right after the Civil War. It was immigration that populated the country during the latter half of the nineteenth century.
A school for nursery nurses is one of the features of St. Mary's Hospital for Children, one of the eighty-six voluntary hospitals for which the United Hospital Fund is conducting a campaign.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Gen. George C. Marshall received today at the White House the Distinguished Public Service Award of the United States Conference of Mayors. The general was the first to receive the award.

The disturbances that have marked a struggle between administration forces and a so-called left-wing element for control of the CIO National Maritime Union flared out anew yesterday at union headquarters, 346 West Seventeenth Street.

A better tone in apparel sales which has been evident since the weather became cooler has had a heartening effect on millinery, according to industry spokesmen. Top line houses are almost back to full scale production, it was learned, following a period in October when manufacturing hit a low for the year.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 25 -- A strike of 360 meat cutters and food clerks in northern New Jersey against Safeway Stores, Inc., began at 8 A. M. today, and indications were this afternoon that the dispute between the grocery chain and two American Federation of Labor locals would not be settled at least till the beginning of next week. Sixty-three retail food stores in the area were closed because of the strike.

Application for a Federal order requiring the Government to show cause why the eleven convicted Communist leaders should not be permitted to travel throughout the continental United States will be argued before Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman at 11 o'clock this morning in Room 506, Federal Court House.
CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- An electrically operated wind tunnel that produces an air flow five to ten times faster than the speed of sound was described today to the American Physical Society.

The market for new capital next week will be stirred by a moderate resumption of corporate debt financing. On Tuesday the Louisville Gas and Electric Company will take bids on $41,000,000 of refunding bonds and the Gulf States Utilities Company will offer $10,000,000 of bonds.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UP) -- House Democrats today accused Republican critics of the State Department's handling of the Angus Ward incident of proposing action that would have provoked war with Communist China.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 25 -- Moshe Sharett, Foreign Minister of Israel, today rejected a compromise proposal by the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission for the establishment of an international regime in Jerusalem.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 25 -- The three constituent agencies of the United Jewish Appeal reported here today that a total of $272,455,000, described as a minimum need, would be required next year to further immigration and development in Israel, the continuation of relief and rehabilitation in Europe, and the readjustment of Jewish refugees entering the United States.

After attorneys for some of five men accused of disorderly conduct during a Harlem street rally Nov. 3 asked for additional time to produce witnesses, the hearing of the defendants was postponed yesterday until next Wednesday.

Although the Jews are ideologically a peaceful people, they are aware of the necessity for security and are prepared to meet any challenge, it was said here last night by Dr. Joseph Burstein, director of the department of culture and education of Histadrut, the General Federation of Jewish Workers in Israel.
MANILA, Nov. 25 (AP) -- International golfers, playing in the Philippines' $17,500 tourney, reached the halfway mark tonight with three American pros tied for the lead.

Fordham's multiple platoons are favored over New York University's thinly manned squad in the annual clash between these traditional rivals today. The twenty-seventh Battle of the Bronx, which closes the local collegiate season, is expected to attract 20,000 spectators to the Polo Grounds.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- The French Ministry of the Interior announced today that seventeen Polish nationals, described as undesirable because of their irregular activities in France, were expelled from the country last night.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The daily double at the Fair Grounds paid $1,173 for $2 today.

In his enlightening account of his three years in Moscow, Gen. Walter Bedell Smith remarks that the Russians always accuse us of intending to do what they themselves are doing. The observation is based on long observation of Soviet tactics, but a perfect current example is to be found in yesterday's reports on the rearming of Germany.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday his sponsorship of a local law to increase his annual salary to $40,000 starting Jan. 1. The measure would increase the salary of Controller Lazarus Joseph to $35,000 and that of Council President Vincent R. Impellitteri to $30,000. It would fix the salaries of each of the five Borough Presidents at $25,000.

OTTAWA, Nov. 25 -- The Canadian Maritime Commission has reported to the government that in its opinion "it is inadvisable as well as uneconomic for Canada to consider the construction and operation of a Canadian flag oceangoing merchant marine of sufficient dimensions to accommodate all her export trade or any fixed percentage thereof."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Six Air Force men escaped injury tonight when their B-17 plane wrecked a power line during a landing approach and put part of southeast and southwest Washington in darkness for two hours.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 25 -- Three men were killed late today when police opened fire on a group accompanying a Liberal party leader, Dario Echandia, Senator Julio Ortiz Marquez said tonight.

Plastic bags are as much a part of the good housekeeper's equipment as her broom, and almost as important. They do everything from keeping silver shiny to preventing the spread of bacteria. New varieties of these plastic bags are now being shown in the stores.

Street-corner Santa Clauses who look the part were the pride of the Volunteers of America yesterday when twenty-four Santas set up their chimneys and jingled their bells for the first time this season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- President Truman moved today to plug up national security leaks in Congress, apparently as a result of a statement by Senator Edwin C. Johnson. The Colorado Democrat said recently that considerable progress was being made on an atomic bomb 1,000 times deadlier than the one dropped on Nagasaki.

BERLIN, Nov. 25 -- The dominant reaction of Western Berliners to the Bonn protocol was that it comprised the most cheerful document of the post-war period, although there was some criticism of various phases of the accord.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Tulane lays its football reputation and an almost cinched bowl bid on the chopping block tomorrow. And sports writers think Louisiana State University has a sharp axe.

The first of the two Junior Assemblies for this season was held last night in the ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton, with many of this winter's debutantes attending. The second will take place on Dec. 22.

All divisions and bureau heads of the Fire Department have just received from Third Deputy Commissioner Nathan C. Horwitz a "reminder" of an old department rule that would ban any holiday festivities in fire quarters.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- Convinced that the drive-in branch bank has a "great future," officers of the County Trust Company opened a new one here today and said similar branches would be opened at Hastings-on-Hudson next month and in Yonkers early in 1950.

FOR THIS WEEK: Soak the soil under all evergreens and newly planted shrubs before the ground freezes for the winter. . . . Water bulbs that are being forced in either fiber or soil, if necessary. . . . Finish outdoor planting of spring-flowering bulbs as soon as possible. . . . Syringe or wipe off the foliage of house plants with water once a week. . . .

Since the city announced on Wednesday its tentative plans for lowering water pressures to conserve the precious fluid, the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity has been deluged with protests from residents of upper-floor apartments who would be first to feel the pinch, Commissioner Stephen J. Carney conceded yesterday.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 26 (UP) -- Dr. Theodor Heuss, President of the West German Federal Republic, rejected today the idea of the collective guilt of the German people for Nazi atrocities against the Jews.

BUT it appears, contrary to the contention of last Sunday's article in this place, that Richard Strauss, whose "Rosenkavalier" opened the Metropolitan last Monday night, felt that "opera, as an art form, was dead!" This from the author of some fourteen operas, of which "Rosenkavalier" was only the fifth!

John A. Lock, chief purser of the liner America and one of the best known American merchant marine officers on the Atlantic, has left the sea for two months to catch up on the accumulated social obligations of thirty-four years. He has been at sea almost continuously since 1915 and claims one of the longest records of continuous service with the United States Lines and its predecessor company.
Coal doesn't get much attention from the average citizen until John L. Lewis starts using his eyebrows to sweep his men out of the mines.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The great bulk of the papers of President Franklin D. Roosevelt will be opened for research purposes next March 17, although a small number will be kept under seal for another twenty-five years, it was announced today by Dr. Wayne C. Grover, Archivist of the United States.

EDMONTON, Alta., Nov. 26 (Canadian Press) -- Imperial Oil Ltd., which this year put $30,000,000 into oil development in Alberta, plans to match that amount next year, G. L. Stewart of Toronto, president, announced last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that three West Coast maritime unions violated the Taft-Hartley Law ban on coercion of employes by permitting picket-line assaults and the erection of barriers at the gates of a plant.

From June, 1948, to last August, the two big United States Air Forces bases at Rhine-Main and Weisbaden in Western Germany were scenes of the world's greatest air operation. Every three minutes around the clock, twenty-four hours a day, planes loaded with coal, food and other vital supplies headed East to Berlin, carrying a total of 2,309,358 tons in 275,627 flights.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 19 -- Modern divers are scouting the sea floor of Caesarea, thirty miles north of here, in the first step to restore one of the world's ancient harbors. Caesarea was developed originally by King Herod the Great thirteen years before Christ as the principal seaport of Palestine.

THIS is one of those murder-on-shipboard routines. A woman is discovered to be missing from a cargo ship bound for Rio. To the captain it is a simple case of her having been lost overboard and he wants no nonsense about an investigation.
BOSTON, Nov. 26 -- An immediate minimum pension of $100 per month for "every retired person in the United States" was urged today by Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin.

Police Commissioner William P. O'Brien issued a list of suggestions yesterday for the guidance of motorists and pedestrians in reducing traffic accidents. At the same time he urged the public to be extremely careful during the holiday shopping season.
OTTAWA, Nov. 26 -- In an effort to close the session early in December the Canadian Parliament has been sitting morning, afternoon and evening and now even on Saturdays.

Plans have been completed for the Bal Masque to be held on Dec. 5 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the pension fund of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York. Mrs. William C. Breed and Mrs. Emmerich von Jeszenszky are chairman and vice chairman, respectively, of the committee for the event, which is being sponsored jointly by the firms of Elizabeth Arden and Van Cleef Arpels.
EASTON, Pa., Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Knoxville (Tenn.) Baby Vols today won the first annual Piggy Bank Bowl football game by defeating the Easton All-Stars, 13 to 0.

The impressive declarations made to the correspondent of The United Press in Bogota by ex-President Dr. Eduardo Santos, now Vice President of the republic, and published in your edition of Nov. 18, give an exact idea of the real significance of what is now occuring in Colombia.

The fourth free art lecture in the New York Public Library's Art Education Project will be given on Tuesday at 6 P. M. at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The subject will be "The Process of Creation in the Art Form," and the speaker, Hans Jelinek, master in the field of woodcuts and wood engravings. Mr. Jelinek is on the faculty of the New School and City College.
WARSAW, Nov. 26 -- Franco-Polish relations have disintegrated "to the point where it is possible to foresee the worst," French Ambassador Jean Baelen told the Polish Government today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- That the Senate would approve Admiral Forrest P. Sherman as Chief of Naval Operations without reviving the bitter unification conflict among the armed forces was predicted today by Senator Millard E. Tydings, Democrat, of Maryland, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, which will be the first Congressional group to act on the appointment.

ALTHOUGH shattered remnants of last Thursday's festive birds still crowd many home refrigerators, the time already has arrived to look ahead for Christmas and offer the department's annual prospectus on stage fare for the Yuletide season.

HOLLYWOOD. WHEN we first started work on the film, "Guilty of Treason," in the fall of 1948, we had no intention of doing a story about Hungary. We were simply developing a story about Soviet Russia, based upon the experience of various members of the Overseas Press Club, as recorded in their book "As We See Russia."

Retail trade picked up substantially here last week. Seasonal buying gave women's specialty shops their best week of the fall season thus far with an estimated increase of around 6 per cent. Department stores cut the decrease from a year ago to about 2 or 3 per cent for the week.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Nov. 26 (Reuters) -- The Governor of Nigeria, Sir John Macpherson, today declared a state of emergency and imposed a press censorship in the eastern provinces where riots had followed the police shooting of between twenty and forty striking miners at the government-owned Enugu coal mine.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 26 -- With the passage of the deadline for posting bond for an appeal, the way is cleared for the distribution of $400,000 resulting from the Federal auction of the steamship City of Athens here in 1947. Today City of Athens here in 1947.

THE fiscal strategies of gentlemen charged with the desire to produce a play or musical show on Broadway vary in wide and baffling degree. Some approach the problem in the lofty manner of the Treasury Department floating a Government bond issue, others attack it with the delirium of a Piuts, crazed with an overdose of vanilla extract, trying to hock his blanket that he may have a last lethal swig.

RENE LEIBOWITZ, Polish-born composer living in Paris, himself a student of Schoenberg and Webern, is the latest, and in some ways the most formidable, champion the Schoenberg school has yet had. No serious musician denies the historical importance of Schoenberg's contribution, nor the fact that all contemporary music, directly or indirectly, owes something to his daring.
The annual bazzar of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity will be ]leld in St. Christopher's House, 316 EastI Eighty-eighth Street, on Thursdayl and Friday afternoons and evenings.

Events in Germany are frightening, whether they are good or bad. That is another evidence that we live in a dangerous world. A momentous week is just passed. We -- the Allies -- gave Western Germany a new start, economically and politically, but put stress on demilitarization. The Russians gave Eastern Germany a new army, and German armies are normally the best in Europe and also -- normally -- the instruments of aggression and imperialism.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 26 -- As Christmas shopping gets under way throughout this section indications are that buying will be as spirited as it was in 1948.
OMAHA, Nov. 26 -- The weather, which has been unseasonably warm, appears to hold the key to the volume of Christmas shopping that will be done in the Midwest.
