AMONG the easiest people for whom to choose Christmas gifts are those with hobbies. Gardeners are no exception. Certificates for bulbs, seeds or plants and innumerable tools for indoors or out are infallible selections that are certain to be appreciated.

" GUADALCANAL is not a name but an emotion," concludes Mr. Morison, delivering a verdict of history. It also stands as a shrouded giant among the world's decisive battles, being in the public mind what Russia is in Winston Churchill's -- a mystery cloaked in an enigma.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 26 -South Africa boycotted the fifty-nine-member Trusteeship Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today as the Rev. Michael Scott, Anglican cleric representing native groups in SouthWest Africa, made a moving plea for United Nations action to curb South Africa's rigid segregation policy in the former mandated area.

The Rh factor is a substance found in the red blood cells. It is so called because it was first discovered in the blood of rhesus monkeys. The 87 per cent of normal persons who have this Rh substance in their bloodstreams are known as Rh positives. The remaining 13 per cent are Rh negatives.

ATLANTA, Nov. 26 (UP) -- Georgia Tech's resilient Engineers absorbed Georgia's primitive punches today and stabbed out a 7-to-6 victory before 40,000 fans who shivered at every tackle in the red-eyed rivalry.

" NO Quaker book," George Bancroft wrote a century ago, "has a trace of skepticism on man's capacity for progress." "The United States and the Soviet Union" constitutes no exception to the Bancroft rule. The Quakers have long commanded the admiration and gratitude of mankind for their kindliness, their benevolence and their unstinted services in the cause of peace and philanthropy.

THE star of Cesar Franck, scarcely recognized during his lifetime except by a few fanatically devoted followers, rose high soon after his death in 1890 but has fallen considerably in recent years. Not, however, for English composer-conductor Norman Demuth, who puts Franck with Berlioz and Wagner in the trinity who founded modern music.
BERLIN, Nov. 26 -- Protest meetings in Berlin and Hanover today rallied Social Democrats to the support of Dr. Schumacher, their chairman.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 26 -- The Indian Constituent Assembly adopted a new constitution today transforming the country into a "sovereign democratic republic" under a President. The constitution as a whole becomes effective Jan. 26, the day on which India will be officially proclaimed a republic though a few clauses come into force at that time.

The domestic airline industry is expected to report modest profits this year for the first time since 1945. The factors responsible for this achievement, according to airline executives, are principally the 15 per cent increase in revenue passenger mileage over last year and the marked progress of the industry's extensive economy programs.

WEATHER is never a commonplace to the sentient person. Here, as in "White Snow, Bright Snow" and "Johnny Mapleleaf," the team of Tresselt and Duvoisin again create an evocative impression of the changing moods of wind and weather. "Sun Up" describes in fluid text and brilliant pictures the course of a summer day as seen and felt by a little farm boy.

Robert Cobb Myers (in "A Proposal to Tax Those Who Don't Vote") suggests that "unexercised rights are likely to become lost rights." This is historically doubtful and in any case carries with it an unwitting deception. A right is not a function or activity which withers away or becomes nonexistent in the abstention. It is a power which one is free to actualize or not.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- In accepting without endorsing the Bonn agreement early this morning, the French National Assembly expressed the misgivings still widely held in France regarding the policy reflected in that agreement and regarding the intentions of the United States and Britain in dealing with Germany.

THOMAS Merton's newest volume of poetry is concerned, not surprisingly, with the themes that have dominated all his published work since the conversion he described so vividly in "The Seven Storey Mountain." "In a day of blood and many beatings," Merton addresses the Immaculate Virgin:

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Huge illuminated portraits of Joseph Stalin, Mao Tze-tung and Harry Pollitt dominated the hall in Liverpool where Britain's Communist party began its twenty-first national congress today. The 400 delegates spent most of the day discussing a written report by Mr. Pollitt, general secretary of the party.

The new state of Israel is the logical focal point for textile production and distribution in the Near East but it will need American machinery and know-how to do a successful job, according to A. M. Perlman, president of the rayon converting company bearing his name.

CHARLES DE FOUCAULD, whom the subtitle of this book calls "sinner, saint, explorer, priest," was a Frenchman killed during the first World War in the Sahara Desert. He was then living alone as a hermit priest next to a small community of Mohammedan Touregs, restive at the fringe of the beleaguered French Empire.

A $29.95 Kodak Pony 828 Camera, especially designed for convenience and efficiency in taking color pictures with the eight-exposure 828 film, is announced by Kodak for release next month. The new miniature is equipped with a Lumenized three-element Kodak Anaston 51mm f/4.5 lens, focusing from 2 1/2 feet to infinity.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced his opposition yesterday to administration of Jerusalem by the United Nations. He spoke at a luncheon session of a three-day convention being held by Histadrut, the labor federation of Israel, at the Commodore Hotel.

HIGH up in No. 2 Park Avenue in New York, a young man dressed in unobtrusive gray watches silently while a dispatcher slips the last secret paper into a thick leather pouch, snaps a lock, and, as a final guarded touch, double-seals the lock with lead.

THE oddest job in the world, perhaps, is to be a juror. Unsung, unheeded, unheard -- except when the verdict comes in -- he homeward plods his weary way after hours and days of sitting and listening, and even his family often looks upon him as no more than an amiable and stationary contemplator of the universe.
A year ago at this time the Communist armies of Mao Tze-tung had begun their big drive in the Chinese civil war -- the long march of victory south from Manchuria.

What was to have been a happy reunion leading to a belated Thanksgiving dinner for an elderly Rumanian couple and their daughters resulted yesterday in another separation when the couple was ordered sent from La Guardia Airport to Ellis Island.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Government officials said today they hoped to make enough progress toward a soft coal agreement to cause postponement of another strike at midnight Wednesday.

Evidently overcome by fumes in a leaking gas connection, Miss Terry Putnam, 25 years old, described by the police as the daughter of a prominent scientist, Palmer C. Putnam of 82 Monmouth Street, Brookline, Mass., was found dead late last night in her two-room apartment at 10 Louis Street, near Clitnon Street.

THE people of New York have cause to be grateful to His Imperial Majesty, Mohammed Reza Pahlavi, Shahinsha of Iran. In connection with the young ruler's diplomatic visit, a group of Near Eastern art treasures from the imperial collection itself and from the museums in Teheran and Mashhad has been lent to the Metropolitan.

KOREA, south of the Thirty-eighth Parallel, a precarious foothold of Western political thought on the mainland of Asia, has been the subject of continuous American interest. There may be doubt as to which philosophy will prevail in our time, but there is no doubt concerning the vigorous and active position that Occidental music has developed in the tempestuous years since the end of World War II and the liberation of Korea from Japanese colonial rule.

ALTHOUGH August Strindberg is not exactly a lovable dramatist, he is being treated with great respect this year. This is the centennial of his birth in Stockholm in the gloom and chill of the long winter (Jan. 23, 1849); and no doubt the latter-day interest in his work derives from that fact.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, and Gen. Omar N. Bradley, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, took off for Europe tonight for a series of meetings expected to accelerate the rearmament of Western Europe.

Advertising and vending in New York's subways and surface lines netted the city a $4,298,561 jackpot in the fiscal year ended last June 30, Board of Transportation records showed yesterday. In the last eighteen months vending has been extended to include such popular machine-delivered commodities as soft drinks, 3-cent candy and 5-cent crackers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- The National Theatre Conference ended a two-day meeting here today with the adoption of a resolution to "support in principle" the National Theatre Assembly, a convocation proposed by the American National Theatre and Academy to be held next March in Washington "to discuss ways and means toward a National Theatre."
RACINE, Wis., Nov. 26 (AP) -- The J. I. Case Company announced today that about 11,000 employes would receive bonuses ranging from 3 to 6 per cent of their annual earnings.

In a report which they present in the Archives of Internal Medicine, Dr. James V. Neel of the University of Michigan and Dr. Frederick Snell of the Brookline Board of Health Hospital, Chestnut Hill, Mass., reach the conclusion that the blood of those who survived the atomic bombing of Hiroshima now differs little from the blood of persons in near-by Kure who were not exposed to deadly rays.

IT is an exceptional week in the New York galleries when a conscientious visitor cannot obtain a pretty wide perspective of the diversity of contemporary art. Four of the newly opened one-man shows are cases in point and one new group exhibition mirrors the contemporary scene in miniature.
ATLANTA, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Southern Bell Telephone Company today announced a new liberalized pension plan covering 51,000 employes.

WHEN Arthur Judson and F. C. Coppicus stepped down from their positions as president and senior executive vice president of Columbia Artists last year, rumors flew along Fifty-seventh Street that perhaps the men who had been in control for eighteen years had been obliged to take a back seat.

GREAT music is a psychical storm, agitating to fathomless depths the mystery of the past within us. Or we might say that it is a prodigious incantation. There are tones that call up ghosts of youth and joy and tenderness; there are tones that evoke all phantom pains of perished passion; there are tones that revive all dead sensations of majesty and might and glory -- all expired exultations, all forgotten magnanimities.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican, of New York said today "I'm not at all interested in being a candidate for Governor of New York."

ANDRE GIDE was 80 years old last week despite an exaggerated rumor to the contrary in my copy of the fifth edition of Webster's Collegiate Dictionary, which carries the following entry: "Gide, Andre, 1869-1934. Fr. novelist critic, essayist."

The Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., will continue its fight against the steamship conference system and its exclusive patronage contracts, and has asked for action by a House subcommittee on Study of Monopoly Power.
MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 26 (AP) -Auburn's brilliant Travis Tidwell scored a fourth-quarter touchdown to gain his hard-pressed team a 20-20 tie with underdog Clemson today.

A fundamental change took place last week in the relations between the Western Allies and their German protege -- the Bundesrepublik Deutschsland (Federal German Republic) that began functioning last Sept. 7. The United States, Great Britain and France relaxed important controls they had held as occupying powers in a defeated country.
THE outlook for television programming seems to be brightening, with the sports picture in particular showing a great deal of promise.

THE Canadian Government estimates that United States tourists will have spent $300,000,000 in Canada during the twelve-month period ending Dec. 31. This constitutes a new record for United States tourist expenditures in the Dominion for one year.

MR. SALTER, a New York psychologist and author of "What Is Hypnosis?", probably writes not for fellow therapists but for the vast lay audience interested in relief of emotional suffering. At all events, his manner of writing and the contents of his book are unscientific and bombastic.

THE South, according to Mr. Botkin, is "the nation's No. 1 folklore region as well as its No. 1 'economic problem.' It was inevitable that a book of Southern folklore should shape itself around Southern life and character." The framework should be "ways of life and looking at life * * * common to the Southern people as a whole throughout their history."

A Federal District Court judge at Norfolk, Va., last week ordered the United States to reimburse the owners of a Swedish merchant ship for damages suffered by the vessel in a collision off Cape Henry in November, 1945.

WHILE last year the Philharmonic season began with the climax of Leonard Bernstein's Copland, Mahler and Bartok concerts, a less conspicuous opening was made this October by Paul Paray, musical director of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra this year.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 26 -- A warning that America's freedoms are being menaced by internal forces as well as by totalitarianism outside the country was given today to a nation-wide gathering of 1,200 educators.

ON Aug. 7, 1948, the science of genetics had its throat slit by a decree of the all-powerful Central Committee of the Communist party. The decree was announced by a Russian plant breeder named Trofim D. Lysenko who had repudiated the historic principles of Gregor Mendel and Thomas Hunt Morgan.

Everybody admits slums are bad, but we often forget how terribly bad is their effect on human life. This aspect of the situation was underlined recently from two sources. Six major United States cities were listed by Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, Surgeon General of the Public Health Service, as having slum conditions that "should cause real indignation."

BOSTON, Nov. 26 -- Because of the financial condition of the industry, leaders of the CIO Textile Workers Union of America have decided not to seek wage increases and pension benefits in the first half of 1950 for 90,000 workers in New England and Middle Atlantic woolen and worsted mills.
In your editorial of Nov. 19, "Colombia in Danger," are several remarks rather astonishing to anyone well acquainted with Colombian politics and the recent history of that democracy.

FOR the first time in six years New York State will hold an examination for the position of motion picture reviewer, otherwise known as film censor. And never in the twenty-eight years that censorship has been in force in the state have the qualifications been so high.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 26 (AP) -North Carolina's Tar Heels today gained the most places on the 1949 All-Southern Conference football team of the Associated Press.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- More than two months have passed since Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, announced the revaluation of the pound in international exchange from $4.03 to $2.80. Thus far the results have been gratifying to the Government, although concern remains for the future effect on wages, prices and employment.

CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 26 -- Herbert V. Evatt, Minister for External Affairs, and United States Ambassador Peter Jarman signed an agreement today under the terms of the Fulbright Act providing for an exchange of students between the United States and Australia, to be financed by a balance of more than u1,500,000 Australian remaining from Lend-Lease reciprocal aid and surplus war property.

THE other day a select literary audience gathered to pay tribute to America's leading poet, Robert Frost. This reporter saw Mr. Frost before the ceremonies. He found the 74-year-old poet in good form -- a gracious, alert, somewhat shy man, whose powerfully sculptured head was made gentle by the softness of his deep-set eyes.

Although the credit for having discovered the anti-bacterial properties of sulfanilamide properly goes to Dr. Gerhard Domagk of the Interessengemeinschaft, the compound itself was first produced by the Austrian chemist, Dr. Paul Gelmo, in 1906. The histories of medicine and the literature on the sulfonamides all state that Gelmo disappeared about 1908, and some writers hinted that he may have been a victim of World War I.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- The outlook for Christmas shopping in the Central States this year -- except in the areas affected by the steel and coal strikes -- is about the same as that for last year, which turned out to be the highest on record. Even the effect of the strikes is not expected to be so great as would be indicated by a computation of wage losses, secondary effects and so on.

BOSTON -- A master plan for promoting New England's $870,000,000 recreation industry in much the same way that manufacturing is sold to the rest of the nation was presented to the region's vacation leaders at the twenty-fifth New England Conference held here.

ATLANTIC CITY -- The broad sandy beach that has been the fortune of this community since it was founded as a health resort ninety-five years ago, will soon feel the effects of a major operation to be performed on near-by tidal channels to keep them open to navigation and prevent erosion of the beach.

CHARLES WATERTON was a Victorian nobleman and naturalist who is chiefly remembered for his book, "Wanderings in S. America," which describes his adventures in that continent's jungles, and which contains the celebrated account of his ride on an alligator.
The New York A. C. snatched victory from defeat in the final minute of its polo game with the Squadron A Blues before 1,100 at Squadron A Armory last night.

I SHOULD like to protest against the aspersions, distortions and plain misstatements of Mr. Charles Norman's recent review of my book, "To Meet Will Shakespeare." It is of course impossible for any reader who has not read the biography to recognize the injustice of Mr. Norman's general remarks. May I comment, however, on four specific points of attack in his article?

Music of the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries received a devoted presentation yesterday afternoon in Times Hall. The performing group, Pro Musica Antiqua, comprised five singers and six instrumentalists under the direction of Safford Cape, who are making their first visit here from Belgium.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Only establishment of a Federal Union by the democracies offers real hope today of averting a disastrous third world war, Will L. Clayton, former Under-secretary of State, asserted in an interview here.

The new moon is a parenthesis in the western sky, setting off the crisp afternoon from the frosty night; and the crisp maple leaf rattling down the road in the wind is the chill-stiff hand of late autumn clinging to the memory of Indian summer. November wanes. Ice crackles in the dawn breeze on the pond.

FROM now until Christmas it is dance time at the City Center. The New York City Ballet Company, now in residence, will close on Dec. 11, to be followed three days later by the newly organized modern dance unit, the New York City Dance Theatre. This in turn will run until Christmas Eve.
GENEVA, Nov. 26 -- Obstacles to the liberalization of trade, to which Western European countries have pledged themselves, are cropping up almost every day.

BATAVIA, Java, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Four United States Senators winding up a three-day investigation of Economic Cooperation Administration spending in Indonesia expressed dissatisfaction today with the "meager facts" they were able to dig up.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today ordered Henry J. Taylor, radio commentator, to "cease and desist" from certain practices on bread wrapping devices which he had patented.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 26 -- A five-day conference of ranking United States diplomats from eleven Near and Middle Eastern countries with Assistant Secretary of State George C. McGhee began at the United States Embassy residence here today.

Gimbel Brothers, New York, will enlarge its personnel administration staff 20 per cent, effective Jan. 1, John J. McCarthy, assistant general manager, disclosed in an interview last week. One of the most important phases of the enlargement, he said, is expansion of the training staff also by 20 per cent.

DETROIT, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks broke loose for five goals in the final period as they beat the Detroit Red Wings, 7 to 2, tonight before 12,702 fans. The defeat was Detroit's first in eleven games.

THERE are many, many signs of the profound changes taking place in our understanding of children, but none, perhaps, is more significant than the recognition of the role of emotions, not only in the child's conduct but also in his health and illness.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Nov. 26 -- With a feeling of progress achieved on the economic front, Western Allied sources indicated today they would initiate a forceful program to bring about greater acceptance of democratic practices in Western Germany.

A survey and report on the feasibility of restricting automobile parking to one side of the street in many areas of the city was ordered yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer. This type of parking, the Mayor declared, would help attain the double objective of cleaner streets and less traffic congestion.

FOUR hundred and nine years ago last April Don Francisco Vasquez de Coronado, blue-blooded, 30, able and confident, set out from his rendezvous at Compostela, Mexico, for the Seven Cities of gold and turquoise in the unknown immensity to the north.

The present system of medical education should be revised so that doctors will not have to wait until they are 28 or 30 years old before they can start practice, Dr. C. N. Hugh Long, dean of the Yale School of Medicine, said last week. In his annual report the Yale dean observed that training for medical careers "now occupies from ten to twelve years after graduation from high school."

IT would seem that Margaret Webster really started something last season when she sent out her troupe to play in college and community theatres across the land. This season, besides Miss Webster's touring version of "Julius Caesar" and "The Taming of the Shrew," the University of Minnesota, with the assistance of the Theatre Guild, has had John Rust's Theatre-on-Tour going to the smaller cities and crossroads in the state in "The Hasty Heart."

The unique place that Bill Robinson occupied in the hearts of his contemporaries was not merely the result of his art, magnificent as that was. For while Bojangles the dancer elicited the highest commendation, it was Bill Robinson the man who won such uniform affection and esteem. His death takes from us not only a great performer who entertained us but a great human being who made our lives richer and happier.

TEN years ago a decorator composing a room for music and aiming primarily for a result that would please the eye was faced with the major problem of integrating into an attractive room setting either what was then considered a heavy, clumsy form of piano or radio or phonograph enclosed in a hideous "borax" box (Borax is a trade term meaning contemporary gone wrong.)

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 26 -- China pressed her charges against the Soviet Union in the United Nations today, submitting a formal resolution that calls for the condemnation of Moscow and a ban on aid to the Chinese Communists or recognition of the Peiping regime.
Mr. Lilienthal is widely regarded as one of the ablest public administrators of his time. For many of his sixteen years in the Federal Government he has also been one of the most controversial.

Mr. and Mrs. John N. Regan of 25 Sutton Place gave a tea dance yesterday in the Carlton Suite of the Ritz-Carlton for their daughter, Joan, who will be presented to society on Dec. 19 at the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball in the Waldorf-Astoria.

IN the year 1949 it would seem almost impossible for anyone to present anything new about Viscount Nelson, above all when the presentation consists of a one-volume selection from the letters that were published in seven volumes under the editorship of Sir Nicholas Nicolas.

BEING very scientifically minded, it is my purpose to trace the basic causes which have caused our present return to the fashions of the Twentys and to find out for THE NEW YORK TIMES whether or not there is going to be a return of the Flapper. And, the best way to find out is to go to the root of the matter, and concentrate on Histry.
Army and Cornell each placed two men on the 1949 All-Eastern college football team, it was announced yesterday by The Associated Press.

COLOGNE. IT was a lovely Sunday afternoon. The air was like white wine, dry and bracing, and the fine, thin sunshine of autumn slanted through the trees, burnishing the dark red leaves of the copper beeches, polishing the golden currency which dangled from the branches of the birches and the maples.

THE vogue of Geoffrey Chaucer is perhaps greater today than at any time during the last 450 years. Apart from Chaucer's literary merits, his incorrigible good humor and tough-fibered sanity are welcome to an age in which the jitters are normal, and Macbeth and Hamlet the usual leaders of nations.

In an effort to promote better inter-group relations and to prevent -- not merely curb -- racial and religious prejudice, the New York City Board of Education and the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith began last week a new program for training teachers in the techniques of combating bigotry. The program, should it prove successful, will be extended to other cities.

Many a doctor or dentist, when he needs hot water to sterilize an instrument, uses an electric immersion heater. This is merely a coil of wire which is connected with an electric outlet and immersed in a small vessel of water. In a minute or two the water boils.

Absent from the repertory since the season of 1941-42, Saint-Saens' "Samson et Dalila" was revived yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. The work had been carefully prepared and the performance moved smoothly. But the cast, headed by Rise Stevens, Ramon Vinay and Robert Merrill, found itself in deep water in this offering, which can be made viable only by the most distinguished kind of acting and vocalism.

The Damon Runyon Memorial Cancer Fund now has "passed its $3,000,000 mark and is on the way to its fourth million," Walter Winchell, treasurer, announced last night in a broadcast over the American Broadcasting Company facilities.

PARIS. THE importance and the length of political crises in France are always astonishing to a certain number of our foreign friends. They often ask us: "Why can't you succeed in limiting the number of political parties, set up a stable majority and thus avoid the crises which give the world an impression of uncertainty and weakness?"

MILLARD MITCHELL'S career is one to make other actors stand up and cheer, and to give hope to those who feel that all of Hollywood has a one - track mind. After fifty plays and nine pictures, the lanky actor with the cynical note in his voice still hasn't been type-cast.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Merchants were keeping close track of the response to record promotions this week, seeking the answer to questions regarding consumer response. There is a belief that sales during the current period and next week will reflect the consumer's decision on the extent of holiday purchases.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Firm opposition to rearmament of Western Germany now or in the near future was expressed here today by five of the six members of the Senatorial Appropriations Subcommittee who have just completed a five-week investigation of economic and military integration in Western Europe.

NEWARK, Nov. 26 -- County heads of the Democratic party in New Jersey -- including the anti-Hague factions -- welcomed today the protracted delay in the submission of former Mayor Frank Hague's resignation as National Committeeman.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 22 -- Despite Nationalist air attacks, internal transportation across the vast areas of China under the Communists now is estimated by foreign observers to be heavier and more efficient than perhaps at any time in the history of that country.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 26 -- The Government of Jordan informed the United Nations today that it would not pull its troops out of Jerusalem nor agree to any change in the present system of divided Israeli-Jordanian control over the Holy City.

LONDON, Nov. 26 (Reuters) -- Unstoppable Liverpool extended its unbeaten string to eighteen games today, holding last season's cup winners, the Wolverhampton Wanderers, to a 1-1 draw at home, to establish a modern-era record.

Guiomar Novaes yesterday afternoon joined the outstanding pianists who this season have marked the centennial of Chopin's death by devoting a whole program to his works. The event drew more than 1,600 to Town Hall, including fifty standees upstairs and another fifty listeners who sat on the stage.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration is making a nation-wide survey of alleged abuses by colleges and training institutions of the veterans educational program.

Laurence Goldstein of Lynn, Mass., 11-year-old son of an American soldier killed in the Battle of the Bulge, said yesterday at La Guardia Airport that he was ready to forgive some older boys who had beaten him and jeered him for being a Jew.

BRIDGE system-makers agree that no-trump bids must be strictly "limited": one should not make the same no-trump bid once on a weak hand, again on a strong one. This principle applies to no-trump responses and rebids as well as to opening bids.

GREATNESS in motion pictures is a controvertible thing which no one can surely determine at the time of a film's release. So many factors are intrusive above and beyond techniques -- especially the mood of the moment -- that judgment might better be delayed until the excitement is finally settled and the ad writers have had their busy fling.
PARIS, Nov. 26 -- Life returned to normal in France today after a twenty-four hour strike as workers everywhere went back to their jobs.

Insurgent forces within the National Maritime Union, CIO, opposing the administration of the union's president, Joseph Curran, served yesterday a State Supreme Court order that directs Mr. Curran and five other national officials to show cause why they should not be restrained from interfering with the membership books of the plaintiffs.

LEONIDAS L. POLK was a nineteenth - century North Carolina farmer, editor and crusader for agricultural and political reform. Almost forgotten today (and not to be confused with his kinsman Leonidas Polk, Episcopal Bishop and Confederate general), he wielded national influence in the period of Populism. His story is told interestingly and in detail by Stuart Noblin, Professor of History at North Carolina State University.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- Tension between France and Poland increased still further today after French authorities had expelled nine more Polish nationals from the country for "anti-national activities." The total number of Poles expelled now stands at twenty-six.
GENEVA, Nov. 26 -- After considerable debate, the World Health Organization of the United Nations has decided to build permanent headquarters in Geneva.

IN 1936 Merle Armitage assembled eleven commentaries on Igor Stravinsky and his music and published them in book form. Now Mr. Armitage and Edwin Corle have done a similar job, retaining five of the pieces from the earlier book and adding ten new ones.
I DENY that there were "distortions and plain misstatements" in my review of Mr. Hill's book.

ACCORDING to its publishers, "Tarry Flynn," Patrick Kavanagh's second novel, "was banned in Ireland when it first appeared." Though the ways of censors are mysterious, it is difficult to imagine what could have prompted any authority to lay a hand on Tarry Flynn's unbelievably innocent head, much less on that of his fearfully puritanical creator.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 26 -- In a private memorandum circulated today among several United Nations delegations, the Archbishop of Canterbury appealed for a return to the idea of establishing an international enclave in Jerusalem

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- The nineteenth annual exhibition of the Hudson Valley Art Association will open tomorrow with a reception and tea between 4 and 7 P. M., at the Westchester County Center. Winners among the 246 entries were announced today by a seven-man jury of awards.

In "The Independent Voter Isn't Independent," Chester Bowles assumes that such voters are split between the two major parties. However, many such voters split their vote three ways, or vote the Socialist ticket straight.
NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 26 -- Oklahoma leap-frogged over Oklahoma A. and M., 41 to 0, today into a post-season football game in the Sugar Bowl on Jan. 2.

UPON being pressed recently for an explanation of how he got tickets to "South Pacific," Edgar F. Luckenbach Jr., heir to the Luckenbach steamship fortune, replied airily: "Oh, I just swapped 'em for a couple of ships."

A REFRESHED perspective on United States policy in the Caribbean during the Cuban phase of the Spanish-American War is provided by this historical novel, which is much more challenging as history than as fiction. The curious thing about W. Adolphe Roberts' approach is that he makes you sense the possibilities without realizing them himself.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The National Interfraternity Conference struck a blow today against discrimination in college Greek-letter societies by recommending the elimination of restrictive membership provisions. This action was a reversal of its previous stand that the controversial issue was "not proper" for consideration by the conference.

Playing its twentieth straight contest without defeat and completing an all-victorious nine-game season, Army routed Navy yesterday before 102,443 spectators in Philadelphia's Municipal Stadium. The 38-point margin was the most decisive attained by either team in fifty service classics.
GAINESVILLE, Fla., Nov. 26 (UP) -- Alabama's football "team of the future," led by Sophomore James (Bimbo) Melton, humiliated the Florida 'Gators, 35 to 13, today before 25,000 fans.
Foster Hailey in "How Socialist Is Britain?" says that the prophecy of Winston Churchill in 1945 that Britain would have a Gestapo as a concomitant of socialism has not yet proved true.

OSLO, Norway, Nov. 26 -- The pride of Norway's merchant marine, the passenger liner Oslofjord, sailed today on her maiden voyage to New York. She will touch Kristiansand, Stavanger and Bergen, where receptions will take place aboard.

FOR twenty years -- ever since Haley's "The XIT Ranch of Texas" was suppressed because of real or fancied indiscretions -- historians have shied away from the story of the 3,000,000 acres of Panhandle land with which Texas paid for the construction of the State Capitol in Austin.
BERLIN, Nov. 18 -- As in every country swept by World War II, an unprecedented number of physically handicapped -- civilian as well as military -- were found in Germany.

B-12, the vitamin that controls pernicious anemia, was first isolated from liver by Dr. Karl Folkers and co-workers in the Merck research laboratories. He has now identified the structure of about one-tenth of the B-12 molecule. With this knowledge chemists are justified in thinking that B-12 can be synthesized.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said tonight that if Britain were to balance her accounts the people of the United States would have to abandon their traditional protectionism. Such a change, as well as harder work by the Britons, he declared, is "the only really businesslike way of ever solving this problem."

ALBANY, Nov. 26 -- Senator Thomas C. Desmond, Newburgh Republican, announced today that he would introduce a bill in the 1950 Legislature to end the perennial top-heavy representation of his party on the Board of Regents.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- Of all the sectors in the prevailing "cold war" between the Soviet bloc and the Western democracies, the one which is perhaps the most delicate and potentially the most significant is the Mediterranean. Russian attempts to creep down to the shores of that sea and establish an area of control have been persistent and gradual since the early eighteenth century.

THE Post Office Department's philatelic programs for 1950 contemplates a maximum of twelve stamps. Regardless of any bills which may be introduced in Congress, final decision will rest with Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson in accordance with assurance given him some months ago by the House and Senate postal committees.

BERLIN, Nov. 26 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, United States commandant in Berlin, demanded today that the Russians take immediate steps to punish the sentry who shot and killed a United States soldier last night.
LITIGATION last week provided the major news in Hollywood as three suits were filed, the trial date was set for a fourth, and actual hearing of a fifth drew toward a close.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- A dozen railroads will begin a battle on Monday to resist refunds estimated at $2,000,000,000 claimed by the Federal Government as overcharge on wartime freight rates, it was announced today. Gustav Metzman, president of the New York Central system, is one of the witnesses expected to testify before the Interstate Commerce Commission.

THE future usefulness of garden tools depends to a large degree on the care with which they are stored away for winter. Whether they are kept in garage, cellar or tool house, an assigned spot for each one is a timesaver all year around.

GALEN DRAKE, whose radio programs contain a generous amount of philosophic commentary, is sure of only one fact: He despises being known as the "friendly philosopher." He weaves wisdom and spins trivia for housewives on seventeen different broadcasts each week, a total of seven and a quarter hours, but he still insists that he is uncertain as to his exact category in radio.

With traffic steadily declining, it is becoming increasingly clear to most railroad executives that operations must be readjusted if the carriers are to be maintained on a sound financial basis. Over the years much "deadwood" has accumulated in the industry, such as branch and feeder lines, and the consensus is that this should be eliminated as promptly as possible.

Eleven gifts to the Neediest Cases Fund of THE NEW YORK TIMES were provided in the wills of persons who died in the last year and did not forget the distressed families and individuals helped by the fund.

The eleven convicted Communist leaders failed yesterday to obtain an order citing the Government to show cause why restrictions in their bail bonds should not be lifted to permit them to travel freely throughout the United States. Five of the eleven previously had been permitted to leave the Southern District of New York, where they were convicted, for their homes.

" IN SICILY" is Elio Vittorini's first novel to appear in English translation and it comes heralded by several distinguished writers, including Ernest Hemingway who provides an introduction. The author, now in his early forties, is considered one of the best of the new Italian novelists.

New York's Charley Conerly and Washington's veteran Sammy Baugh, who rank one-two in that order among the National League passers, will hook up in an aerial duel at the Polo Grounds today. For the twenty-seventh game in their torrid rivalry, the Giants and Redskins will have the local stage to themselves.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Atomic Energy Commission which David E. Lilienthal is leaving, after serving three years as its chairman, is best described in the words of one of his close associates -- he calls it "a miraculously going concern."

SAILORS, as well as baseball fans, have their hot-stove leagues so that there may be no seasonal denial of their consuming appetities. They savor what is past and anticipate what is to come; they discuss the "ifs" of last year and the "maybes" of next.

THE perennials whose foliage remains in good condition and is attractive throughout the season become more noticeable as flowers disappear. They are worth casting at this time of year for any planting list.

The nation's investment bankers are about to measure the progress they have made in the last year toward fulfilling one of their most challenging tasks -- selling to the working masses the idea of owning shares in the business concerns that keep the United States going on a private enterprise basis.

Charges that business men in some western European countries are reviving old cartel arrangements and forming new ones is causing him and other business men great concern, it was declared yesterday by Earl Bunting, managing director of the National Association of Manufacturers, in a communication of Paul Hoffman, Administrator of the Economic Cooperation Administration.

In the decade following World War I the nation's colleges and universities virtually doubled their enrollment. Even the depression of the early Thirties could not stop the trend. By the time World War II began higher education had reached its peak in this country, with a student enrollment of nearly 1,500,000. It was generally felt that the colleges could not expand much beyond that figure and still maintain adequate standards.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 26 -- Pilaster, winner of the Pimlico Cup and the Riggs Handicap earlier in the month, did some more cash-collecting at Bowie today, advancing from last place in the backstretch to first at the wire in the $12,100 Prince George Autumn Handicap. The 5-year-old gelding made it with half a length to spare.

Theatre parties continue as a popular means of raising funds for charitable enterprises. Two performances of "That Lady," a new play with Katharine Cornell in the leading role, at the Martin Beck Theatre, have been taken over to augment the funds of well-known philanthropies.

ALBANY, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Solicitor General Wendell P. Brown said today the State Attorney General's office "would look into charges" by the American Labor party of "election frauds" by the Albany Democratic organization. Daniel P. O'Connell is the Democratic leader here.

THE oratorical genius of Abba Hillel Silver has long been one of the assets of the American Jewish community. Dr. Silver matches erudition and profundity with a vivid and strikingly original style. His speeches in this volume, dealing mainly with the need for an independent Israel, belong in the highest tradition of polemics.

HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 26 (UP) -- Rice Institute's Owls won an automatic bid to oppose North Carolina in the Cotton Bowl at Dallas Jan. 2 by smashing ever-dangerous Baylor, 21 -- 7, in the Southwest Conference's game of the year today.

THE Patients' Garden Club of the Veterans Administration Hospital, Northport, N. Y., will meet in the administration building of the hospital on Monday at 7:30 P. M. Montague Free will lecture on house plants and answer questions concerning their cultivation in pots and window boxes.

ROME, Nov. 26 -- The Vatican strongly supported today the resolution submitted by the Australian delegation to the United Nations advocating the complete internationalization of Jerusalem. At the same time it criticized as inadequate the compromise plan of the Palestine Conciliation Commission.

After two years of negotiation the talks between the United States and India on a treaty of friendship, commerce and navigation have been suspended to allow the two countries to re-examine their positions. It is now quite clear that the roadblock on the path to success is not economic; it is psychological. The principal basis of the difficulty, says a dispatch to this newspaper from New Delhi, is "popular distrust of foreign enterprise."

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- The new Midwest Stock Exchange, an amalgamation of four regional exchanges, will mtart operations on Thursday with little fanfare but high hopes for steady increase in stature as a key financial market. Its headquarters will be the present Chicago Stock Exchange with which are merging the exchanges in St. Louis, Cleveland and Minneapolis-St. Paul to form the new organization. Branch offices will be maintained in the other participating cities.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- The general strike action in France on Friday was regarded by many as paradoxical, since times were fairly prosperous and the Government had already pledged itself to return to collective bargaining as the unions had demanded.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Government will issue a "new and improved edition" this week of the best-selling booklet in which it tries to explain its admittedly complicated income tax laws to confused taxpayers. George J. Schoeneman, Internal Revenue Commissioner, said today that the 138-page pamphlet, "Your Federal Income Tax," would go on sale at the Government Printing Office here Thursday.

THIS year's crop of oyster is large enough to assure plentiful supplies at moderate prices throughout the country. A. E. Kessler of the Oyster Institute of North America, from whom this information comes, also reports that the quality is high.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 26 -Hopes were still high here today that Jerusalem would not be internationalized despite United States pressure at Lake Success. There were well-founded rumors that Jordan and Israel were making an eleventh-hour attempt to reach a compromise that would avert any plan that would jeopardize the sovereignty of either.

THESE biographies are for the 8-to-11 group. Their separate authors, who long worked in collaboration, share a common gift for doing away with stuffiness and for making great musicians human and likable. In her present book Miss Wheeler completes the story begun in her last year's volume.
CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Nov. 26 -- All-America Halfback Charlie Justice teamed with End Art Weiner to lead North Carolina to a 14-7 football victory over Virginia and a Cotton Bowl trip.

The leveling influence of American democracy has brought to the masses the ancient rites of astrology, once the delight of kings. The American Federation of Astrologers, which met last Sunday in New York, got much less attention, it is true, than the American Federation of Labor, the American Federation of Musicians, or almost any other American Federation one might mention, would have got.
MANILA, Sunday, Nov. 27 (AP) About 600 rebels, who stood off the Philippines constabulary and Army and Air Force units, apparently escaped today into the jungles south of Manila.
MONTREAL, Nov. 26 -- The Montreal Canadiens consolidated their second-place position in the National Hockey League by handing the New York Rangers a 5-1 defeat tonight before a crowd of 12,769.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 26 -- Preparations are going forward to celebrate the sixth anniversary of the founding of the Communist regime in Yugoslavia in the Bosnian village of Jajce Nov. 29, 1943.

ALONG with its diplomatic cold war, the Soviet Union wages constant theatrical war against the United States. American villainy vs. Russian virtue is a staple theme on Soviet stages, developed in a dozen ways in dozens of playhouses.

IN this New England story Marty Atwater and her friend Kathleen Maclain enjoy seaside adventures which will keep readers of 9 to 12 absorbed. Without being in any way imitative the story reminds this reviewer of the works of the late Nina Rhodes, to whom she owes many pleasant hours of childhood reading.

TWO weeks ago, in the Children's Book issue, my eye was caught by a publisher's advertisement which was headed, "Once upon a time, children didn't read anything but books." There was, to be sure, Youth's Companion, or St. Nicholas, but by and large, thirty years ago, the copywriter pointed out, books held the center of the stage as entertainment for children.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- The Midshipmen have been such constant burrs under the Army saddle of recent years that the Cadets rode all over them in bareback fashion on the frozen tundra at Municipal Stadium today. Before the festival was over the joyous West Pointers were virtually shouting in glee: "Look, no hands!" It was as easy as all that.
Two men died and three other persons, one a 9-month-old baby, narrowly escaped death in a fire at 54 Moore Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning.
TORONTO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Milt Schmidt's goal midway in the third period gave the Boston Bruins a 3-3 deadlock with the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight in a National Hockey League game before 13,067 fans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Nearly $50,000,000,000 of competitive business income is escaping Federal taxation annually through exemptions in existing law and "loose and liberal" regulations, Representative Noah M. Mason, Republican, of Illinois and member of the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee, charged today.

BILOXI, Miss., Nov. 26 -- The Board of Control for Southern Regional Education has voted unanimous approval of a plan for Southern states to survey their resources and integrate them with higher education facilities in developing social and economic improvements for the region.
BOSTON, Nov. 26 -- A spirit of optimism, engendered by an upturn in the New England textile situation this week, served as a spur to early Christmas shopping.

MR. CARMER, well known as an author of adult books, can also spin a good story for younger readers. This one's about the experiences of 10-year-old Bill Bailey on a trip from the Bailey cherry farm in New York to Pittsburgh with a load of cherries. Bill goes along for the ride and to help his friend George, the farm workman.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UP) -- The Government said today that by 1975 the United States population may hit 188,500,000, a gain of 26.4 per cent.
Concluding another campaign against its traditional rival at the Polo Grounds yesterday, Fordham swept off with all the honors in beating N. Y. U. by 34 to 6.

Although it is always the first and, by a wide margin, the largest, New York's annual National Motor Boat Show, which will hold forth in Grand Central Palace on Lexington Avenue from Jan. 6 to 14, is followed by a succession of other somewhat similar expositions carrying into late April. The schedule for them follows:

FRANKFORT, Nov. 26 -- The Government of Dr. Konrad Adenauer at Bonn, responding to what seems to be an immutable law of German politics, is moving slowly to the right after ten weeks in office. The product of the coalition of center and right-of-center parties, the Government never would be considered "liberal."
Fine prints, English and French eighteenth century furniture and a wide variety of Chinese art objects will be auctioned this week in four sales at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

EXCESSIVE cleverness has spoiled what might have been a very amusing book. "Ready, Willig and Abel," the story of an immigrant's troubles in the Twenties, has the situations and people for the warmest sort of humor. But Walter Artzt's self-conscious search for the sharp phrase, the slick epigram deprive the story of much of its basic humaneness.
" Every salesman his own sales manager" is the pattern adopted by one large concern to meet the growing competition in one of the country's most competitive industries -- film and camera supplies.

IF Christine Caroll were 15 years old today, she would have been recognized as dangerously peculiar. Psychiatrists would have been called in, she would have received sympathetic treatment and either been cured of her obsessions or put away where she could do no harm. Unfortunately, the heroine of Francis Leary's "This Dark Monarchy" lived in the England of the Eighteen Fifties.

Robert Moses' "The City's Museums -- A Fresh Appraisal" brings out facts which seldom come to the attention of the average museum attender. However, what was the reason for the conspicuous omission from the article, as well as the map of museums, of that non-inconspicuous place, the Museum of Modern Art?
BEGINNING tomorrow night at 10 o'clock, WNEW will introduce a new musical program, "Rhyme and Reason," which will feature Dr. Nandor Fodor, psychoanalyst.

AS traveling inspector for the Baker Street Irregulars, lately returned from some weeks in London, may I make my brief biennial report? The anomalous situation whereby the Moriarty brothers were able to keep all Sherlock Holmes stories out of print for some years, is now relieved.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 26 -- As part of the State Department's policy to strengthen the democratic way of life, a record number of 50,000 students and teachers will have been exchanged this year between the United States and the rest of the world, it was announced today at the sixty-third annual convention of the Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools.
The immediate threat of a strike on the seventy-six lines of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation was averted yesterday following intervention by Mayor O'Dwyer.

PLANNED as an introduction to the Bible, this book presents a sequence of episodes from the Old and New Testaments told in language closely following the King James version, yet sufficiently modernized to allow young people to read the stories with interest and understanding.

BOSTON, Nov. 26 -- Legislation aimed at protecting the job security of older Massachusetts workers during the rapid expansion of pension plans was being prepared today by the State Federation of Labor.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 26 -Christmas shopping in the Southwest has been somewhat slower getting under way this year than last, but merchants seem little dismayed.

The over-all conditions reported by purchasing executives for November show no material trend changes from October, according to the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents. The steel strike settlement halted any further steep decline in industrial activity which was likely had the tie-up continued through the month.

FOR half a century stagehands have been mopping up blood between the acts at Grand Guignol. The carnage of two world wars has not satiated the public's appetite for gore in this tiny Montmartre theatre, and actors nightly continue to slash their wrists, chop off their hands and gouge out each other's eyes -- all in the interest of entertainment.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- Sales reported last week by Philadelphia women's stores were off 13 per cent from a year ago and were 11 per cent less for the four-week period. Pennsylvania railroad car-loadings last week totaled 111,021, as against 131,609 a year ago, a decrease of 15.6 per cent.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 26 (AP) -Mexico is convinced she will have lots more oil in the next few years.

Americans should take warning from the resignation of David E. Lilienthal as first chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission lest they lose "the type of men it needs most in public service," declared Rabbi William F. Rosenblum in his sermon yesterday morning at Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 26 -- The Palestine question, which in one way or another has been continuously before the United Nations for the past two and a half years, has now emerged as one of the outstanding issues at this session of the General Assembly.

STARKVILLE, Miss., Nov. 26 (UP) -- The University of Mississippi Rebels combined the running of John (Kayo) Dottley and Billy Mustin with the passing of Rocky Byrd today to defeat Mississippi State, 26 to 0, and capture the traditional "golden egg" for the third straight football season.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26 -- With official observers of Oregon and Washington present, representatives of a cross-section of California's economic life will sit down early next month to try to draft a pattern for dealing with the state's unemployment problem.

TAKE three young gypsies: a lovely violinist; her rival, a dancer; and a lad with a mind of his own, and you might reasonably expect an imitation of Carmen. But Mrs. Kahmann, who is an old friend of the gypsies, has written a romantic comedy with overtones which are serious but never burdensome.

Wider participation by students in extra-curricular activities that tend to increase their knowledge of good citizenship was advocated yesterday by students and a school official who took part in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over WQXR.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 26 -- One of the largest college building programs in history is being brought to completion at Michigan State College, where the self-liquidating loan plan, started in 1931, will save taxpayers roughly one-third of the post-war construction outlay of more than $30,000,000.
After a nine-year watch the thousands of sidewalk superintendents in the Maritime district on the southern tip of Manhattan will find themselves out of a job in about six months.

Feeling in brisk fettle over the week-end, I decided to "live dangerously" and take on two double bills consisting of "Thieves' Highway" and "Father Was a Fullback"; "Too Late for Tears" and "My Friend Irma."

The "Battle of Washington" was transferred to Municipal Stadium in Philadelphia yesterday, and except for the organized mayhem of the Army-Navy football game, the spirit of Thanksgiving seemed to pervade the services.

An immediate cause of concern in the shoe industry has been the offering in the last few weeks of Czechoslovakian women's shoes, both slip-lasted and cemented types, "at prices far below those at which similar shoes could be produced in this country," the National Shoe Manufacturers Association reported last week.

DURING the eight months following Pearl Harbor, American merchant shipping was easy prey for U-boats roaming the Atlantic seaboard. Some of the night-and-day heroics of the men who sailed these ships are told here by Captain Manolis, skipper of the freighter Caribsea, which was torpedoed and sunk in 1942. Neither history nor objective reporting, the book is a rambling personal reminiscence covering a seagoing career, with special emphasis upon the author's war experiences.

ROBERT FROST had never commemorated a Vermont breakfast at one sitting -- just a few of the components (apples, maple sugar, blueberries) -- so the breakfast commemorated Frost. It all came about when his "Complete Poems" was picked by a panel of critics as the one book published within the last five years most likely to become a classic.
PANAMA, Nov. 26 -- The Government of Dr. Arnulfo Arias struck against its opponents today and political refugees are rushing to the Canal Zone for asylum.

IN the season 1946-47 Mr. Grierson was in charge of two seaplanes on the factory ship Balaena that were used to hunt whales and do general reconnaisance work in the Antarctic. The first attempt to use a plane for this work in 1929 resulted in the loss of plane and pilot.
In a recent letter to the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES A. G. Reilly commented on the living conditions under British socialism.

AS the holiday shopping season starts there is still a good percentage of retailers who believe that they will beat last year's dollar volume. There are still more, of course, who predict that they will exceed 1948 unit sales because prices are now lower. To back up these more cheerful views it can be reported that there has been a bit more snap to retail trade in the last week.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Budget Bureau today is drafting legislation under which an estimated $250,000,000 in Federal tax money would be allotted to major cities next year.

HONGKONG, Nov. 26 -- A financial settlement that may have wide implications and hold up his departure indefinitely was ordered in the Communist court sentence passed on Mr. Ward, a Chinese language broadcast from Peiping and picked up here revealed tonight.

ALBANY, Nov. 26 -- Key leaders of the Republican-controlled Legislature frowned today on a suggestion that the state, through general taxation, assume responsibility for raising to a minimum of $100 a month payments to New York recipients of Federal social security pensions.
FRANKFORT, Nov. 26 -- United States occupation troops put on a typical American show for the Germans today -- a bowl football game complete with parades, floats and a charity benefit raffle.

The annual benefit of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association, "A Winter's Eve Dinner Dance," will be given at Sherry's, 300 Park Avenue on Dec. 9 under distinguished patronage. The sponsoring organization, which has done a great deal to make the Sharkey anti-air pollution bill a law, is promoting this winter an all-out campaign for a clean-up of the city streets.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 26 -- Interest in the Christmas season seems to be mounting earlier than ever in the Upper South this year. And every indication points to shopping volume that will approach, but probably not surpass, the records of 1948.

THE hazards of winter driving are increasing with the rise in traffic volume and deterioration of many main highways, according to a country-wide warning issued by the National Safety Council. Statistics presented by the council show that in northern states the winter death rate from road accidents is from 24 to 53 per cent higher than during the summer, while in southern areas the increase varies between 5 and 33 per cent.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Nov. 26 (UP) Underdog South Carolina took off like a ball of fire but then had to fight down Wake Forest's lastminute comeback to score a 27-to-20 victory before a shouting homecoming crowd of 20,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The State Department revealed today that William N. Stokes, United States vice consul in Mukden, had been seized by the Chinese Communist authorities there in connection with "spying charges."

" HERE in this country," says the author of the first of these volumes, "instead of palaces, temples, tombs or cathedrals, the real historical monuments are the fine old homes that tell the history of the American people."

THE Potomac is one of the great historic rivers of America. It is the river of the Piscaways and the explorations of Captain John Smith, of George Washington and the Lees of Stratford, of Washington City and Harper's Ferry. It is the river of those two early thrusts into the West -- the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad and the Cumberland Road. It is the river of John Brown.

In Robert Cobb Myers' "A Proposal to Tax Those Who Don't Vote" one point must be challenged. Mr. Myers writes: "Back in the Eighteen Sixties in Belgium only 10 per cent of the electors generally voted. Thirty years later the figures were reversed and turnouts of between 92 and 95 per cent were being recorded.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 26 -- Prime Minister David Ben Gurion, in a message to the national conference of the United Jewish Appeal here today, declared that his nation desired peace, but the Arab States, "which waged an aggressive war against us and failed, refuse our peace offers" and "their leaders are full of talk of a second round."

IN this treatise on social organization, Professor Murdock, a Yale anthropologist, labors strenuously to inject more science into social science. He approaches such human matters as kinship, marriage and culturally patterned sexual behavior with the tread of an engineer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat, of Colorado, member of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy, charged today the existence of "a nefarious plot, headed by David E. Lilienthal, to disclose to Great Britain vital and secret information regarding "the so-called super bomb."

MR. BROWN'S preceding books have brought him quite an enthusiastic following, and his current one is not going to let anyone down. It is as fast, smooth, and well-plotted as the others -- and it centers around a ripper. Mr. Brown manages to convey a goodly amount of the visceral terror an actual ripper would induce in the reader.

You probably never heard of Henry Crown, or, if you saw his name in print, it meant nothing to you. Once in a while (if you look hard) you'll find his face in newspaper photographs, but usually among those who "also attended."

It seems to me that Chester Bowles' in his provocative article, "The Independent Voter Isn't Independent," underestimated grossly the silent but none the less effective pressure that the independent voter exerts upon the two old parties, particularly in the nomination of higher-type candidates.

Twelve debutantes were formally introduced to society last night at the annual Grosvenor Ball, one of the outstanding social events of the winter season. It was held in the ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton, the Oval Room being reserved for dinners given in advance for the debutantes by their parents.

Thinking on the subject of Federal social security financing can vary according to one's attitude toward government spending. There seems to be a feeling among some supporters of the Federal plan that because one is not sympathetic to the present method of financing the retirement scheme, he is opposed to social security as an institution.

Nearly four hundred exhibits have been installed in Grand Central Palace in preparation for the opening of the Twenty-second Exposition of the Chemical Industries tomorrow at 2 P. M. for a six-day run. The entire four floors of exhibition space have been filled, officials said yesterday when they announced that a great variety of new chemical substances will be on display throughout the week.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- President Truman enjoyed the Army-Navy game today but he thought it was "a little one-sided."

Sixty per cent of 250 department stores expect to go ahead or break even in sales for the first four months of next year, according to the results of nation-wide survey announced yesterday by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office.

MOST Americans head for their family reunions at Christmas time, and with winter vacations on the increase many of them this year will be able to visit other places before joining their kinfolk at the traditional holiday dinners. Outstanding seasonal celebrations in Williamsburg, Va.; Hot Springs, Ark.; Palmer Lake, Col., and Claremont, Calif., are just four examples of the extraordinary contrasts in Christmas festivities to be staged across the nation.

ON the evening of Jan. 19, 1949, a pianist whose name meant nothing to many of us gathered in Carnegie Hall gave a recital that left an indelible impression. Her playing had maturity, style, poetic feeling, self-effacing integrity and unmistakable individuality.
The deceptive Dick McGuire, who was a veritable ball of fire in collegiate ranks while playing at St. John's, continued to indicate yesterday he is going to prove equally as deadly as a professional.

VIENNA, Nov. 26 -- A new campaign against the kulaks or richer peasants has been launched in all "people's democracies" with the end of the planting season. It seems likely to liquidate them as a class in the course of the next twelve months.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26 -- A new attempt was made today by attorneys for Harry R. Bridges to have Federal Judge George B. Harris disqualified from presiding at the perjury and conspiracy trial of the West Coast longshore leader and two union colleagues.

Nine major points for improvement in British foundries were recommended in the first official report on the tour of the industry here by the British Steel Foundry Productivity teams. The report was received here last week. In a comprehensive review of American methods, it was pointed out that employe productivity in this country is between 50 and 90 per cent higher than in similar plants in England.

QUITO, Ecuador, Nov. 26 -- The northern Andean Republic of Colombia, where a Presidential election will be held tomorrow under martial law, is being ravaged by an old political war at a time when the soaring price of coffee has ironically improved its economic prospects for the next year to the extent of $100,000,000.

THE televising of the Metropolitan Opera's opening night performance of "Der Rosenkavalier" was a decided improvement over last season's experiment with "Otello." The lively comedy of Richard Strauss was much more suitable fare for the demanding cameras, and the technical work in picking up the proceedings from West Thirty-ninth Street was consistently alert and resourceful.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 26 (UP) -- Tennessee's unpredictable football Vols edged Vanderbilt, 26 to 20, today in a wild scoring scramble. Vanderbilt's coach, Bill Edwards, got so angry with the officials that his own players had to lead him from the field.

PUNTA D'ELLA CASTELLA, Italy, Nov. 26 (Reuters) -- In the dark hours before dawn this morning Father Francesco Parise called the roll of his men in the muddy village street. He got 180 answers. Then, hitching up his frayed black cassock, he led them off on the five-mile tramp across the muddy fields.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 26 -- With a busload of Socialist party leaders in front and four elephants bringing up the rear, about 50,000 Kisans (peasants) marched through Lucknow yesterday in India's biggest political demonstration since the days of British rule.

A new conception of candy merchandising is being pioneered by Stephen F. Whitman Sons, Inc., manufacturer of boxed assortments, with installation of a specially designed refrigerated display cabinet in retail outlets, it was learned last week.

WHEN Shaw read my biography of him in 1942, he remarked: "Between ourselves your practically complete ignoring of my prefaces makes the book more readable and not intolerably long; and for my part I want people to read my prefaces and not read about them." To adapt two lines in a well-known hymn by Cowper, Shaw is his own interpreter, and he will make it plain.

MR. SNOW is a blend of sleuth, antiquarian and historian. For this, his latest book, he hiked 1,158 miles along the Atlantic Coast, with side trips by plane, train, car and boat, and he has dug up a variety of fare -shipwrecks, mutinies, hidden treasure, ghosts and murders.

TOM RAINSE returned to his native mountains after an absence of five years to learn that poachers were slaughtering the wild life and terrorizing the people. He became a game warden and with the help of sad-eyed Smoky, a dog that was half bloodhound, helped smash the poaching ring.

WINTER airline schedules are in effect now, and in New England and other regions of the snow belt a vivid method of outlining runways and marking snowbanks is expected to result in safer landings and fewer taxiing accidents.

COCO, the French poodle, had all the virtues of her kind. She was gay and clever and loving. To Rudolf, a little prince living in the lonely magnificence of a Hungarian castle, she was a great joy and his dearest friend. When Coco, in a burst of independence, slipped through the castle gates one morning, Rudolf set out on his tricycle in a desperate search.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 26 (UP)--William and Mary slugged North Carolina State College to a 33-7 defeat before 8,000 football fans today, displaying in the season's final game the kind of power and punch they were supposed to have all year.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- In the worst massacre perpetrated in the fifty-game history of their rivalry on the football field, Army defeated Navy by 38 -- 0 today as President Harry S. Truman and a host of notables looked on in the half-frozen crowd of 102,443 that filled the vast Municipal Stadium to capacity.

BOGOTA, Nov. 26 -- The whole Good-Neighbor Policy and the question of anti-democratic trends in the Western Hemisphere are inevitably involved in the present crisis in Colombia, where tomorrow, for the first time, a Presidential election will be held under martial law.

IN this useful and comprehensive handbook, which is the result of a quarter century of teaching to the students of Occidental College in California, the chief concern of the authors is to help students understand the problems which confront us in Japan, China, Indonesia and the islands of the Western Pacific.
There is no evidence that Ezra Pound is legally insane, according to Dr. Frederic Wertham, one of the country's most prominent psychiatrists in the criminal field.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- When a country is divided on any fundamental issue, its Government usually delays action or forms a committee to "study the situation," which mounts to the same thing.

Only one of the six points raised by Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc., in support of its application for resumption of an operating subsidy for its three "Good-Neighbor" passenger vessels, was approved by C. W. Robinson, Maritime Commission trail examiner, in his report to the commission. The report was made public here yesterday.

LONDON -- More Marshall Plan aid and a further freeing of exchange for tourism are the two pressing needs of the European hotel industry, it was agreed at the Third Congress of the International Hotels Association meeting here last week. The congress included 750 delegates representing twenty-eight countries.

WASHINGTON. TODAY for the first time in American history, we the people have the means of clearing up our number one national disgrace -- the slums and blighted areas that afflict most of our cities. Whether we follow through with those means will be a significant test of the ability of government -- Federal, state, and local -- and private industry to solve a major common problem.

SOCIETY exists in communication and the extent to which people can communicate with each other determines the understanding that they will have of each other. This is a thesis of "A Handbook of Human Relations." It is also the philosophy of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, of which the author is the president.
Next week will find the quail season opening in the coastal states from Virginia to Florida, and for a vast army of sportsmen the upland game season really begins when the bobwhite may be hunted.

Activity in the ready-to-wear and accessories markets was light last week with most department stores taking advantage of the cold weather to push final fall promotions of popular-priced coats and suits, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

Interrupted by the Thanksgiving Day recess, financial markets were thankful last week for the opportunity to appraise the year's progress in finance and industry. With slightly more than a month to go, the record shows a lot to be thankful for despite recent strikes and the unsettled state of affairs in the coal regions.

A BITTER civil war is raging among neuropsychiatrists who try to relieve us of our fears, frustrations and psychoneuroses. One camp, the Freudians, holds that our mental disorders have their roots largely in our infant -- and even prenatal -- sex life. Arrayed against these dismal doctors are more hopeful physicians, the organicists. To them our mental pathology is basically a chemically warped physiology, and bids fair to be chemically correctable.

BOSTON, Nov. 26 -- Boston College crushed Holy Cross today in the traditional battle between the Jesuit rivals. While a crowd of 38,775 fans watched in Braves Field, the Eagles ran up a count of 76 to 0 over their hapless opponents from Worcester.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 26 (AP) -- J. D. Rodgers' Walkie Talkie, 7-10 favorite, won the feature at the Fair Grounds today.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The junketing Congressman who was satirized in the popular movie, "A Foreign Affair," has come to be regarded as a natural part of the post-war European scene, as routine as the "cold war" and as inevitable as questions of Marshall aid, Atlantic defense, displaced persons, a Spanish loan or any of the other problems which American legislators come to Europe to study.

MOSCOW, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The management of the Soviet Composers Union, the highest musical body in the nation, today began listening to more than 220 compositions turned out this year by Russian composers.

The Soviet Government has ordered abandonment of the much-criticized method of calculating industrial production in terms of 1926-27 prices and its replacement by a new index based upon current wholesale prices.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 (UP) -- The CIO's new International Union of Electrical Workers geared itself today for its first organizational meeting here and an all-out war with an ousted left-wing union for representation of more than 400,000 workers.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Colombia's violent Presidential campaign closed tonight with strikes, shootings and a funeral holding explosive possibilities.

DENVER, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Rocky Mountain oil supplies caught up with demand in 1949 -- a situation that producers viewed with some alarm. In his annual report to the Rocky Mountain Oil and Gas Association last week, Glenn E. Neilson, president, said that when production passed market demand, producers in the mountain region were placed in a precarious position.

Prices paid by consumers for truck-hauled commodities are due for a revision. Tomorrow the Public Service Commission will begin weighing two-and-a-half years' evidence preparatory to recasting motor carrier tariff schedules on a more equitable basis.

BUFFALO, Nov. 26 -- Writing is becoming almost a lost art, according to Dr. Lou La Brant, Professor of English in the School of Education at New York University, who today addressed the thirty-ninth annual meeting of the National Council of Teachers of English.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26 -Although the Coast states have not swung into the real Christmas buying period, it already is evident among merchants that the shoppers are back to the pre-war pattern. Their buying spree will not get under way until next week and they will not buy anything without careful inspection.

SINCE their introduction to the public about fifteen or twenty years ago, the popularity of African violets has grown by tremendous strides. Florist shops all over the country now carry them, and they have a place on the window sill of small city apartments, as well as suburban homes.

PRINCE GEORGE, B. C. -Men behind the ticket windows at Grand Central some day may reserve lower berths or drawing rooms for Fairbanks, Alaska. Perhaps tourists, laden with fishing rods and high-caliber rifles, will rush through the gates at Pennsylvania Station clutching yard-long train tickets for Whitehorse or Tanana Crossing.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 26 -- Following is the text of the address made today by Fouzi Pasha el Mulki of Jordan on the Jerusalem question before the Special Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly:

As to Pearl Buck's "Our Dangerous Myths About China," when the Foreign Missions Conference wished to reproduce it, as we are doing, we asked Dr. Gerald F. Winfield, author of "China, the Land and the People" to examine it.

MOST men will argue about most things. But few will fail to agree that Winston Spencer Churchill, who next Wednesday will celebrate his seventy-fifth birthday, is the greatest fighting man among political leaders of our time. To say this is not to undervalue such men as Franklin Roosevelt; it is merely to say that they were different.
