SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 26 (AP) -- The National Grange has rejected the Brannan farm price support program as "an internal cancer that would ultimately destroy our free enterprise system."

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 26 -- Louisiana State University cracked the back of Tulane, football champion of the Southeastern Conference, today with two touchdown plays that went a total of exactly 147 yards, and rolled up a 21 to 0 victory.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Firmness in prices for cash grains, more export business and no news that margin requirements will be reduced on Monday spurred buying in grain futures on the Board of Trade today. In active dealings the market went to new high points on the current events.

A large subscription has been reported for the performance of "I Know My Love," with Lynn Fontanne and Alfred Lunt in the leading roles, on Thursday night at the Shubert Theatre, which has been taken over for the benefit of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 (AP) -A great display of individual play by Arnold Galiffa and a defensive unit that rose to its greatest heights carried Army to a shutout victory over Navy today in the opinion of Coach Blaik of the cadets.

DURING the past ten years Justice Felix Frankfurter has become a controversial and in some respects a puzzling figure on the Supreme Court. This in a measure is owing to a superficial assumption that there is a discrepancy between his judicial philosophy and his reputation made during his twenty-five years as a professor at Harvard Law School as a stanch fighter for liberal causes.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The University of San Francisco will play Fordham in New York next Oct. 28 in the first football game between the two Catholic schools, U.S.F. Coach Joe Kuharich announced today.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- Sterling Smith's Sun Beau won the open jumper class at the Boulder Brook Club horse show today and made a bid for the championship by placing ahead of Mrs. Don Ferraro's Black Watch, Roger C. Young's Quien Sabe and Leon S. Haymond's Brooks Heddie.

Something new has been added to Organized Reserve Corps procedure, Capt. Mary E. Stanton, Women's Army Corps adviser to the Senior Army Instructor of New York State, made known yesterday at the corps headquarters at 90 Church Street.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Nov. 26 (UP) -- Texas Christian University's perpetual motion man, Lindy Berry, passed Southern Methodist dizzy today to close out his collegiate career exhibition that gave T.C.U. a 21-13 victory before a capacity crowd of 33,000.

MONTICELLO, Ill., Nov. 26 -- Former President Herbert Hoover and ten leading national authorities in marketing were named this evening as recipients of the first P. D. Converse national awards conferred by the Central Illinois Chapter of the American Marketing Association.

" PAVLOV," wrote H. G. Wells in THE NEW YORK TIMES a quarter of a century ago, "is a star which lights the world, shining down a vista hitherto unexplored." Prof. John F. Fulton of Yale says that Pavlov, because of his studies of digestion and of the conditioned reflex, is one of five or six men who have influenced our thinking most in the last hundred years.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- Uniform-of-the-day for the vast majority of the 102,443 onlookers at the fiftieth service classic today was anything that would kep a lady or a gentleman warm. Though it was sunny and sparkling clear, the temperature hovered near the freezing mark through the whole long day of pomp and pageantry, plunging, passing and punting.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 1 to 6 points net lower than on Friday. It opened unchanged to 3 points up and held within a narrow range. In the early trading there was some price fixing credited to domestic mills, while most of the selling appeared to be liquidation in December and hedge selling in other months.
MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 26 -- Strikes in the shipping industry are both outmoded and unnecessary, in the opinion of Walter M. Wells of New York, president of the Isthmian Steamship Company.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Tax exempt money paid to the Boston Foundation in the last twelve months by the Edgewater Beach Hotel, which it owns and leases to an operating company, has been contributed to eighteen charities, it is stated by A. M. Sonnabend, who incorporated the foundation under Illinois laws in October, 1948, to purchase the hotel for $6,000,000.

EAST - WEST diplomacy has been marked more than once by passages in which urbane statesmen abandon statistics and Gladstonian oratory and resort to fables, folklore and proverbs. The Russians are best known for it; on many occasions they quote a pungent "old Russian saying" to point a moral or clinch an argument.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Having begun their annual convention with measures to deal with the two most persistent problems of their organization, delegates to the national convention of the American Veterans Committee considered today their annual platform.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 26 -- The Shah of Iran, accepting high academic honors from the University of Michigan at a special convocation called today for a "closer than ever" friendship between his nation and the United States in their common desire for world-wide peace.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -- The new anti-Communist electrical union set up by the Congress of Industrial Organizations lost no time today in letting electrical employers know that the CIO's ideological swing to the right did not mean the industry could look forward to an easier time in collective bargaining.

PARIS, Nov. 27 -- The general index for French stocks has reached its lowest level since last July 15. The figure now is 1,042 on the basis of 100 for the year 1938. Likewise, the index for foreign stocks has touched its lowest since July 29. It is now at 656 as compared to 100 in 1933.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UP) -- Nearly all of the 123 Government workers discharge for disloyalty during the first two and a half years of President Truman's loyalty program were Communists, it was disclosed today.

Major strides have been taken during the last four years in erasing the scars of war from the Ukraine and rebuilding its economy almost to pre-war levels, recent reports in the Soviet press indicate. This is said to be the situation:
BRISTOL, England, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Sir Stafford Cripps told his East Bristol constituents tonight that much of the British press unduly magnified Britain's economic difficulties.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina, who presided at the trial of the eleven Communist leaders, interrupted his vacation yesterday to deliver an unorthodox address to 500 guests at a reception given by the Near East Society for delegates from the Near East to the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- One of the major tasks President Truman will take with him as he travels to Florida tomorrow for a long-delayed vacation will be selection of a successor to David E. Lilienthal as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 27 -- Journalistic circles deduce from the speech by F. C. Erasmus, Minister of Defense and Posts and Telegraphs, that press censorship has begun in South Africa, at least as far as dispatches to overseas newspapers are concerned.

The Pentagon and the Navy today present a state of "watchful waiting." The cogs of the intricate defense machinery in the Pentagon are meshing -- although there are still squeaks -- and the Navy is doing its job.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 22 -- The Chinese Communists are working on a five-year plan to build 10,000 kilometers [6,250 miles] of new railroad into Northwest China and Szechwan, and to build the long talked-of bridge over the Yangtze.

Untimely though it may be to mention turkey so soon after Thanksgiving, the fact that canned whole birds now are available is news not to be postponed. Sell's Specialties produces this innovation, the first turkey-in-a-tin to be offered in retail stores.

Offerings of redeemable savings bonds should be halted under present conditions, J. Stewart Baker, chairman of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, asserts in his annual report to stockholders. The report, for the first time, is being issued in advance of the annual meeting, scheduled for Dec. 6, and will be mailed to stockholders today.

Reginald Kell, British clarinetist, was the featured performer in the New Friends of Music concert at Town Hall late yesterday afternoon, playing the Mozart Clarinet Quintet with the Hungarian String Quartet. The string players also performed Brahms' Quartet in C minor, Op. 51, No. 1, and were joined by Milton Katims, violist, and Benar Heifetz, 'cellist, in that composer's Sextet in B flat major, Op 18.
David Warfield, one of the legitimate theatre's greatest character players in years past, will be 83 years old today.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 27 -- While some steel sales officials were cautious about forecasting demand beyond the end of this year, most agreed last week that demand and production of steel would be at high levels well into the first quarter of 1950.

BOSTON, Nov. 27 -- Representative John W. McCormack of Massachusetts, Democratic leader of the national House of Representatives, told the State Congress of Industrial Organizations at its convention today that he saw no chance of repealing the Taft-Hartley Act in this Congress.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Miss Margaret Truman today capped her concert appearance with the Washington Symphony Orchestra by singing as an encore "Smilin' Through" in a way that the White House press termed "strictly for the family."
LONDON, Nov. 27 -- A commission of two Africans and two Britons was appointed today to investigate the disorders and riots in Nigeria that had begun to disturb political opinion in Britain.

The Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations, which represents sixty-seven groups with a total membership of 43,000, accused the High School Teachers Association yesterday of breaking the "solid front" of teachers in the city and endangering their welfare.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Nov. 27 (AP) -- More than 100 Sunday school children were led to safety today when fire started at the Betts Memorial Universalist Church in the heart of the business district.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Nov. 27 -- Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson insisted here today that the United States "has no intention of rearming Germany."

The theatre is something more than a business; it is a vital part of the nation's cultural pattern, is therefore touched with a public interest and should be as available to the public as is financially possible. These circumstances explain, we believe, the legitimate concern over the present unsatisfactory method of ticket distribution in New York's theatres.

Today's atheism is dynamic; it comes from the will and not the intellect, and seeks to destroy God rather than deny Him, Msgr. Fulton J. Sheen declared yesterday at the 11 A. M. solemn high mass in the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament, 152 West Seventy-first Street.

The New York State Hospital Study, in recommending that no state subsidies be given to voluntary hospitals, implies that philanthropy will continue to play a substantial role in support of these hospitals, Dr. Eli Ginzberg, director of the study, declared yesterday.

In behalf of the Elmira College Centennial Fund, members of the Elmira College Club of New York will hold a card party and fashion show on Saturday at the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street. Dr. Lewis Eldred, president of Elmira College, and Mrs. Eldred will be guests of honor at the event.
Issues of a dispute that brought a strike threat last week against the Third Avenue Transit Corporation will be placed this afternoon before Theodore W. Kheel, impartial arbiter of the bus industry.

Fred Wilt, former Indiana University harrier now representing the New York Athletic Club, captured top prize yesterday in the Senior Metropolitan A. A. U. cross-country championship at Van Cortlandt Park. The Winged Foot squad won team honors with 22 points.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -After a series of postponements, Representative J. Parnell Thomas is due to go to trial tomorrow on fraud charges.

NEWARK, Nov. 27 -- Bluing Monday, which had been in prospect tomorrow for 300,000 housewives in six New Jersey counties who normally send their laundry out, disappeared this afternoon with the announcement that four American Federation of Labor unions had settled disputes with the New Jersey Laundry and Cleaning Institute.

Leaders of two left-wing unions of the Congress of Industrial Organizations that face ouster because of their alleged adherence to Communist rather than CIO policy, denounced yesterday the trial committees named to hear their cases.

Three Arab states are interested in concluding a peace treaty with Israel but are unable to do so because of unstable internal conditions, Deputy Mayor Reuben Shreibman of Jerusalem declared yesterday afternoon at the closing session of the twenty-sixth annual convention of the National Committee for Labor Israel in the Hotel Commodore.
Worshipers at all masses in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday were urged to conserve water and to pray for "the rain necessary to replenish our water supply."

CHARLES WATERTON, an aristocratic Yorkshire gentleman descended from a half dozen royal saints, was always irascible; but nothing angered him more than to be called eccentric. Even at the age of 77 when he used to gratify his friends "by scratching the back part of his head with the big toe of his right foot" he resented the accusation.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- Michael Straight, 33-year-old editor of the New Republic, today was elected by more than a four-to-one margin as national chairman of the American Veterans Committee, a World War II veterans' organization, which adjourned its fourth annual convention here this afternoon.

Are you thinking of spring or the new resort fashions? Let us give you a tip: many of the prettiest are going to be airy as thistle down. They will be of the sheerest of materials -- organzas, chiffon, net -- rayon or nylon -- fine cotton voiles and many others.

WHEN the rabid Amy rooters finally thawed out -- if they ever thawed out -- after the Army-Navy game, they began breathing defiance and asking the inevitable question: Where could you find a better football team than Army? The obvious answer could be: At Notre Dame. But that isn't necessarily the correct answer.

The determined effort of free labor to rid itself of the pernicious influence of communism is sharply pointed up by two meetings that will be held today three thousand miles apart. The meetings, one in London and the other in Philadelphia, have a direct connection in that they both spring from belief born of bitter experience that democratic trade unionism and communism are mutually antagonistic and, in fact, incompatible.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Former Russian Prime Minister Alexandre Kerensky, broadcasting to Russia for the first time since he was deposed thirty-two years ago, told Soviet Communists tonight that they were playing with fire.

BOSTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins gained their second National Hockey League tie in twenty-four hours by coming from behind to deadlock the New York Rangers, 1 -- 1, before a crowd of 10,482 at the Boston Garden tonight. Johnny Peirson gave the home forces an even split with the Blue Shirts by scoring on a screened shot during the finale.

The city's revenue from the 2 per cent sales tax in the four months ended Oct. 31 was $59,563,673, a drop of $1,949,731, or more than 3 per cent, from the $61,513,404 collected from the same source in the comparable period last year. The implications of the decline and its bearing upon the city's current and 1950-51 budgets were being studied yesterday by the offices of Controller Lazarus Joseph and Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson.
I wish to add the following information to the forum you have been printing on the subject of playgrounds and the letters of Stanley Isaacs and Arthur Hodgkiss.
MANILA, Nov. 27 (UP) -- Ed (Porky) Oliver of Seattle today won the Philippine open tournament by shooting par 72 golf over the Wack Wack Club course for a 285 total.

The United States, according to advices from Washington at the end of last week, "has rejected, as inadequate and unsound," the proposal for an International Commodity Clearing House put forward by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations to handle world-wide distribution of food surpluses.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 27 -- By the purchase of 128,000 guilders of gold with dollars the Bank of the Netherlands has increased its gold holdings to 740,000,000 guilders. The official explanation is that in the first year of Marshall Plan aid the bank had to use part of its gold for pre-financing Economic Cooperation Administration help, but now that ECA operations are running smoothly, sufficient dollars are available.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Angus Ward, United States Consul General at Mukden, informed the State Department today that the Chinese Communists had released Vice Consul William N. Stokes and had widened their deportation order to include all non-Chinese members of the consulate staff.

In the current issue of the Consumers Union's "Reports" there is a discussion of watches, along with a few tips about how to care for them once they have been taken home. First on this list is what must be the most cynical direction ever given about anything, anywhere.

HONG KONG, Nov. 27 -- If Chinese Communist leaders by now have realized the depth and extent of feeling aroused in the United States over the detention of Consul General Angus Ward, it has come as a surprise to them, observers of Chinese affairs here believe.

Thieves wore out a set of burglars' tools yesterday in a vain attempt to open a safe in the John Mullins Sons furniture store at 1262 Broadway, Brooklyn. They damaged the safe so badly that mechanics will be called today so that the company can get the $2,400 in it.

Marvin L. Katke has been appointed manager of the Ford Motor Company's projected automatic transmission plant in Cincinnati. He was formerly superintendent of the Oldsmobile engine plant at Lansing, Mich.
Pierre Fournier, French 'cellist who made his Town Hall debut a year ago, gave his second recital there yesterday afternoon. He again proved himself a master technician and eloquent interpreter.

John Haynes Holmes, for more than forty-two years pastor of the Community Church of New York, preached his farewell sermon yesterday. He stepped down from the pulpit, he said, "to become one of the congregation."

What's the future of "The Browning Version," co-starring Maurice Evans and Edna Best? As far as your observer was able to learn yesterday, the twin bill of Terence Rattigan plays, which includes "Harlequinade," is slated to depart on Jan. 7 from the Coronet, where the $50,000 presentation opened Oct. 12.
The Maritime Commission is preparing to ask Congress for an extension of authority to sell war-built merchant vessels beyond June 30, 1950, it was learned yesterday.

Prices of cotton in the domestic market recovered moderately last week. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains of 16 to 30 points. The greatest advance was made by the May, 1951, contract.

DANBURY, Conn., Nov. 27 -- The water supply in Fairfield County communities is the lowest in fifty years and the situation has reached the critical stage in one city, Norwalk, where residents face a drastic curtailment of service unless the shortage is alleviated soon.
CHUNGKING, Nov. 27 -- The threat to Chungking increased today.
Religious modernists were accused yesterday by the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, of propagating a false faith in "a half-Christ."

ZURICH, Nov. 27 -- Without imposing any quantitative restrictions on imports or raising the customs duty or in any way infringing her traditional "open door policy" in international trade, Switzerland has found an ingenious way of sheltering one of her old-established industries by means of a new regulation.

Thousands of persons paid their respects yesterday to Bill (Bojangles) Robinson, whose body lay in state at the 369th Anti-Aircraft Armory, at Fifth Avenue and 142d Street. When the armory closed at 11 P. M., Deputy Inspector Thomas V. Boylan of the police put the number of mourners at 31,942.

WIESBADEN, Germany, Nov. 27 -- The United States Air Force is organizing an airborne rescue unit with headquarters here, able to sweep one-eighth of the earth's surface in searches for missing planes, authorities said today.

ROME, Nov. 27 -- Widespread floods have followed the severe drought that has held Italy in its grip for a whole year. It has been raining heavily and almost without a break over the greater part of Italy for the last two weeks.

Orders for holiday and winter merchandise increased slightly last week as a result of cooler weather and the advent of the holiday season, according to a report on the wholesale apparel market here prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- Improved farm equipment, from portable irrigation systems to prefabricated buildings for the housing of farm animals and storage of produce, marks the current eight-day National Farm Show being held here in conjunction with the fiftieth International Live Stock Exposition. The Farm Show opened yesterday.

ALBANY, Nov. 27 -- Public assistance in New York State this year is costing more each month than at any previous time in the history of the programs, according to a report today by the Citizens Public Expenditure Survey, Inc.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 27 (AP) -- George Ratterman today treated 16,323 Baltimore fans to their last look at him in an All-America Football Conference uniform by passing the Buffalo Bills to a 38-to-14 triumph over the Colts.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- Grain markets continued on the upgrade on the Board of Trade last week, with December, March and May wheat, all deliveries of corn except December, and December and May oats selling at new high prices for the year.

The New York City Ballet Company, at the City Center, last night presented George Balanchine's new version of Stravinsky's "Firebird," with the Marc Chagall scenery and costumes and with Maria Tallchief in the title role, and, to come to the point quickly, it was wonderful.
PRAGUE, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Czechoslovakia's Communist party announced today it would conduct a month-long purge of its membership in December to expel "hostile" elements.
Sybil Shearer, one of the most provocative of modern dancers, gave a solo recital at Carnegie Hall yesterday in the late afternoon, and let us all down considerably.

While the far Northwest battled destructive gales and Florida fought frosts, the New York area suffered little more than alarm and delay yesterday in the first real snow of the season. There may be more snow tonight, according to the Weather Bureau, which forecast a cloudy day today, followed by rain or snow.
ALBANY, Nov. 27 -- Governors, legislators and other officials of eighteen industrial states will meet in New York Dec. 15 and 16 to discuss state disability benefits programs.

Reiterating statements already made by President Truman and Secretary of State Acheson, both Defense Secretary Johnson and General Bradley have again emphasized in the most positive terms that the United States has no intention of rearming Germany and that there is no hedging or dodging about the American position on that point.

RAHWAY, N. J., Nov. 27 -- John P. Ostrom, who as an inspector and later a supervisor in the United States immigration service around New York harbor perhaps met more international celebrities than any other known man, will retire Wednesday after twenty-five years of service.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Nov. 27 -- The 222-passenger C-124, described as the largest production transport plane made for the armed services, made its maiden flight today. Looking on were the men and women who had built it.

WARSAW, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Marshal Konstantin K. Rokossovsky, Polish Defense Minister and former marshal of the Russian Army, told a merger congress of the two peasant parties today that Polish forces, "with the excellent Soviet Army, would together defend the western frontier."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Guy G. Gabrielson, Republican National Chairman, pictured the Truman Administration tonight as leading the nation down the road toward "a poorhouse state."
Three new films are slated to open in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

The National Labor Relations Board has consented to an election to determine which of two unions shall represent pursers aboard ships of the Moore-McCormack, Robin, and Farrell Lines, it was learned yesterday.

SEATTLE, Nov. 27 (UP) -- One of the worst storms in Pacific Northwest history blew into Montana tonight after killing twenty persons and causing millions of dollars of damage in Oregon, Washington and British Columbia.
"Tosca" is a mightily effective opera, intended for virtuoso artists only. The opera also requires a master hand at the baton.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 27 -Israel today celebrated the seventy-fifth birthday of President Chaim Weizmann.

In terms of hours of work required to earn the price of everyday necessities and petty luxuries such as cigarettes and beer, living costs in London are materially higher than in New York, according to a survey made for the National Industrial Conference Board immediately after the recent devaluation of British currency.

Featured among the art shows this week is an exhibition of paintings honoring Henry McBride, the dean of American writers on art. Opening today at Knoedler's, the display is made up of works of art selected by Mr. McBride. Shown also at the gallery will be a collection of drawings by the late Elie Nadelman, whose sculpture was exhibited at the Museum of Modern Art last year.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- The stock markets here have subsided into a state of comparative lethargy after the recent violent recovery in gilt-edge stocks following the Government broker's intervention to arrest a demoralizing decline in that market.

PARIS, Nov. 27 -- Arriving tonight at Orly Field from Philadelphia and Frankfort, General Bradley declared that he was sure effective measures would be taken at the meetings here this week for active planning of defense of the North Atlantic area.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 27 -- To the conference of United States diplomats in the Middle East now meeting here, all United States Embassies and Legations in the area have presented reports and data on the problem of strengthening the economy of the Middle East with minimum expenditure of United States funds.

Congressman Kenneth B. Keating of the Rochester district has, at the behest of a local patriotic organization, introduced a bill making the date of Lincoln's Gettysburg Address "a day of national observance."

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The talented right arm of Quarter back Bob Waterfield sent the Los Angeles Rams sailing closer to the Western Division title of the National Football League today as the Rams walloped the New York Bulldogs by a topheavy score of 42 to 20.

The end of the college football season found Army, Oklahoma and Notre Dame, which has a final date with S. M. U. in Dallas Saturday, all running up huge scores to establish their pre-eminence with California as the unchallenged big four for 1949.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- A twelve-year labor-management relationship that handled 30,000 grievances without a strike is analyzed in a case study made public today by the National Planning Association.

Fifty-five percent of 167 department and specialty stores of all sizes and types expect a decrease in Christmas sales compared with last year, according to a survey by the Retail News Bureau, released over the week-end. Forty per cent of the stores surveyed expect a gain over 1948 totals, while 5 per cent expect to match last year's figures.

Julius Epstein, a journalist in Europe for many years, has signed a contract with the Cima Publishing Company for a book entitled "Katyn Massacre." He served in the Office of War Information in the war and has long studied this case of the killing of 15,000 Polish war prisoners near Smolensk.

The one-story taxpayer building occupied by the Queens Borough Public Library and Rockaway Cleaners at 115-08 to 115-14 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Park, Queens, was sold by Wilbrun, Inc., to the Senft Realty Corporation for investment. It is assessed for $40,000.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Chicago Cardinals jumped into an early five-touchdown lead, mainly on Jim Hardy's passing, and coasted to a 41-21 National Football League success over the Green Bay Packers before 16,787 at Comiskey Park today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 27 -- Dr. Philip C. Jessup, United States delegate, is expected to deliver an important policy declaration tomorrow when the political committee of the United Nations General Assembly resumes debate on the Chinese charges against the Soviet Union.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 27 -- The names of twenty-four leading international scholars who will serve as an advisory committee for the publication of the private papers of James Boswell were announced today by Dr. Charles Seymour, president of Yale University.

DETROIT, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens picked up some ground in the National Hockey League race tonight by defeating the first-place Detroit Red Wings, 6 to 2, before 13,242 fans in a game marked by sixteen penalties.

Allied relations deteriorated during the first half of 1948 over the festering problem of Germany, which had not yielded to solution at the Moscow and London meetings of the Council of Foreign Ministers.

Yugoslavia's break with the Soviet Union was "just as genuine as it could be" and the "heaviest blow that has been struck against the Kremlin," Cavendish Cannon, retiring United States Ambassador to Yugoslavia, said here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Union-won wage gains were credited by the American Federation of Labor today with playing an important part in the nation's "quick recovery" from a business recession.

PANAMA, Nov. 27 -- Dr. Daniel F. Chanis Jr., who went to the Canal Zone after he had been forced out of the Presidency, reiterated today that the Supreme Court had ruled he was still constitutional President of Panama.

Goodman and Jane Ace, the husband and wife radio team who gained fame through their "Easy Aces" program, will make their television debut on Wednesday evening, Dec. 7, at 7:45 o'clock, over WABD and the DuMont network in an adaptation of the long running radio show.

PARIS, Nov. 27 -- In seeking a German policy that France can accept, the United States faces the opposition of Gaullists and others on the right as well as of the Communists. The best estimates are that together, these two groups might be followed by half the voters of France.

Postponement of the Detroit International Fair until 1951 leaves Chicago as the sole United States city to offer American and foreign manufacturers exhibition space in the First United States International Trade Fair in 1950, it was announced over the week-end.

NORTHPORT, L. I., Nov. 27 -- Two hundred and fifty persons attended the dedication of the first of three altars in the recently completed chapel of the Veterans Administration Hospital here this afternoon.

QUITO, Ecuador, Nov. 27 -- At the other end of the social level from the wealthy Colombian industrialists in the Department of Antioquia, a religious factor exists that has played a part in the violence preceding the uncontested election held in Colombia today under martial law.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 27 -- "Troubled Spring," a novel by John Brick that Farrar Strauss will publish in the spring, has been acquired for the screen by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and assigned to Robert Thomsen for production.

SCRANTON, Pa., Nov. 27 -- Thirty-four economics students from City College in New York who sought to supplement their textbook learning with first-hand observation of coal mining operations are richer in knowledge after a visit to the Hudson Coal Company here Friday.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- On the eve of the first session of the organizational meeting of the Free World Labor Conference in London, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, outlined the purposes of the new body today.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Nov. 27 -- Miss Carol Werber's Blue Jean captured the championship for children's horses in a special judges' test after Blue Jean had been tied by Miss Polly Jennings' Scout Leader at 8 1/2 points in the final session of the two-day Boulder Brook Horse Show tonight.

Dresses for the teen-ager, no longer a youngster and not yet old enough for junior or misses clothes, were modeled by members of various Girl Scout troops, at a fashion show in the Teen Age Shop of Franklin Simon, recently.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Steve Van Buren ripped to shreds a defense designed especially to stop him as he led the Philadelphia Eagles to a 34-to-17 victory over Pittsburgh today and a third straight National Football League Eastern Division championship.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UP) -- Housing Expediter Tighe E. Woods said today he believed Congress would feel it necessary to extend rent controls again next year because the housing situation "has not changed materially since last spring."

India has passed another milestone on the road to the organization of her independent status with the virtually unanimous adoption of a Constitution. This document has been in process of debate and drafting for approximately three years by the Constituent Assembly.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27 (AP) -- San Francisco's Forty-Niners defeated the New York Yankees 35 -- 14, today to take undisputed second place in the All-America Conference football race.

Puccini's "Boheme" and Bizet's "Carmen" will receive their first Metropolitan Opera performances of the season during the company's third week. In the former, Enzo Mascherini will sing his first Metropolitan Marcello and Lois Hunt her first Musetta.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 27 -- The United Jewish Appeal closed its three-day annual national conference here today as 1,600 delegates from forty-one states set its record figure of $272,455,800 to be raised next year to meet Jewish needs in Israel and throughout the world.

Chuck Conerly was an outstanding passer, Bill Swiacki a sure-fire receiver, Gene Roberts a spectacular runner and Emlen Tunnell, Frank Lo Vuolo, Moon Mullins and Dick Duden excelled on defense. Toss in some stonewall blocking by Joe Sulaitis and fine punting by Ray Mallouf, mix well and these will add up to a 23-7 victory for the Giants over the Washington Redskins yesterday at the Polo Grounds.

Major speeches at the thirty-eighth annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America in Hollywood, Fla., from next Sunday through following Friday, will be given by Sir Oliver Franks, British Ambassador to the United States, and Harry A. McDonald, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

ALBANY, N. Y., Nov. 27 (AP) -- A Pekingese English importation owned and handled by John B. Royce of Brookline, Mass., won the best-in-show award of the Albany Kennel Club today at its annual all-breed event.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 27 (AP) -- A half-dozen United States concerns have taken an option to participate in the development of Labrador iron ore deposits, it was announced today.

Encouraged by the recent statement of the State Banking Superintendent, Elliott V. Bell, that the statutory prohibition against payment of direct fees to trustees has become an "anachronism," savings bank executives are planning to establish a special committee to propose new legislation clarifying all phases of their trustees' activities.

Man's dominion ends at the doorway of his own soul, the Rev. Dr. Ellsworth Charles Reamon declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue.

Robert L. Mills, a veteran shipping man and an expert on trading between the United States and Brazil, has been named Brazilian manager of the River Plate and Brazil Steamship Conferences, it was announced here yesterday.

SANDY HOOK, N. J., Nov. 27 -- The 101-year-old Spermaceti Cove Coast Guard station, first life-saving station to be authorized by act of Congress, back in 1848, will become a Coast Guard shrine next spring.

One of the city's leading child guidance centers, the Caroline Zachry Institute of Human Development, will be forced to close within a month unless funds are raised immediately, it was learned yesterday.

In the midst of much official and unofficial discussion of plans for a Second Avenue subway, a project urgently needed, Chairman Reid of the Board of Transportation reminds us that there is much other construction work the Board of Estimate is about to undertake to keep abreast of the city's expansion.

DIXIANA, Ala., Nov. 27 (UP) -An Air Force B-25 bomber crashed into a hilly field near here today, killing two airmen, including the pilot, who was a former all-America football quarterback. A third man bailed out safely.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UP) -- An All-American Airways plane, with twenty-one persons aboard, narrowly missed hitting a small aircraft near here today.

SANDY HOOK, N. J., Nov. 27 -- The 101-year-old Spermaceti Cove Coast Guard station, first life-saving station to be authorized by act of Congress, back in 1848, will become a Coast Guard shrine next spring.

One of the city's leading child guidance centers, the Caroline Zachry Institute of Human Development, will be forced to close within a month unless funds are raised immediately, it was learned yesterday.

In the midst of much official and unofficial discussion of plans for a Second Avenue subway, a project urgently needed, Chairman Reid of the Board of Transportation reminds us that there is much other construction work the Board of Estimate is about to undertake to keep abreast of the city's expansion.

DIXIANA, Ala., Nov. 27 (UP) -An Air Force B-25 bomber crashed into a hilly field near here today, killing two airmen, including the pilot, who was a former all-America football quarterback. A third man bailed out safely.

Irene Inniss Bailey, New York pianist, presented yesterday afternoon at Times Hall in her local debut by the art guild of the Church of St. Martin, gave Beethoven's A flat Sonata, Op. 26, as her major selection. She also played a Chopin group and selections by comparatively recent composers.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 27 -- Colombia's ruling Conservatives named Laureano Gomez President today in an election that went off quietly despite acute political tension. Senor Gomez had no opposition for the four-year term. The Liberal party, the main opposition to the Conservatives, had withdrawn its candidate and called for a boycott of the election.
LAKELAND, Fla., Nov. 28 (UP) -- The first widespread frost to invade Florida this winter caused perhaps $5,000,000 damage to the state's winter vegetable crop, the weather bureau here reported today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture today added tobacco to the growing list of farm crops which will be under strict production controls next year.
Edward E. Rhatigan, former City Commissioner of Welfare, will return to welfare work in New York, this time in private welfare, as executive director of Goodwill Industries of New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Employer associations and labor unions in the vast construction industry have asked the Government for a blanket exemption from the Taft-Hartley Labor law's election requirements. Their formal appeals to the National Labor Relations Board came to light today.

Beginning Dec. 2, Ronson Art Metal Works, Inc., will begin a Christmas promotion for its lighters with ads in 133 newspapers of 125 cities, it was announced over the week-end by Alexander Harris, president. The drive, said to be Ronson's largest in newspapers, will feature the theme: "Make Santa's job lighter -- choose Ronson for every smoker on your Christmas list."

Benjamin Lubetsky purchased for investment from Louis Lieberbaum, Sidney Shurgin and Harry Chernoff the three-story business building at 1314 Avenue J., Brooklyn, and insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

Establishment of fellowships for Americans whose racial or cultural backgrounds have hampered their opportunity for personal advancement was announced yesterday by the John Hay Whitney Foundation, 30 Rockefeller Plaza. The foundation has appropriated $100,000 for the first year.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- Dr. Arthur J. Dempster of the Argonne National Laboratory reported yesterday that a small portion of mercury would change to gold if bombarded by neutrons in an atomic pile. This is the transmutation long sought by alchemists.

In London today delegates from free trade unions of fifty-five nations, including the CIO, the AFL and the UMW from the United States, are meeting to organize a non-Communist Labor International to rival the Communist-dominated World Federation of Trade Unions.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said today that the United States and Canada were turning to policies that could "establish permanently new and enlarged channels of trade between the dollar and sterling and other areas."

ALBANY, Nov. 27 -- The State Education Department said today that a survey just completed by its Bureau of Statistical Services revealed that public school enrollments were well above those of a year ago and that the trend was "steadily upward."

It was another week of desultory trading in the foreign exchanges, the net result of which, aside from the irregular lower trend in the Canadian dollar, was minor fluctuations in the few units which happened to stir.
DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Shah of Iran flew into Wright-Patterson Air Force base today and got a close look at some of the latest and most modern airplanes in the United States Air Force.

The possibility of a tri-partisan coalition to defeat Representative Vito Marcantonio for re-election to Congress next year became a matter of open discussion yesterday. It was brought to a climax by a public appeal of the Liberal party for the Democrats and the Republicans to join with them in such a move.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 27 (UP) -- The Mid - Winter Sports Association tonight picked Louisiana State University, which upset the champions of three conferences, to play undefeated Oklahoma in the 1950 Sugar Bowl football contest here on Jan. 2.

The seventeenth annual Rockefeller Center Christmas tree, which is scheduled to be set up west of the skating rink this morning, will feature a new costume, the result of spraying its 75-foot height with 200 gallons of fireproof white camouflage paint.

Merces Silva-Telles, young Brazilian pianist, gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. She was heard in a program comprising Hindemith's Sonata, No. 2; Bach's "Chromatic Fantasy and Fugue"; Brahms' Sonata in F sharp minor, Op. 2; Bartok's "Rumanian Folk Dances"; the Waltz in E flat major and the Fantasy by Chopin, and the "Valse Oubliee" in F sharp major and Etude d'Execution Transcendante in F minor by Liszt.

In a quick turnover of an East Side property acquired recently Samuel Neirenstein has resold the five-story building containing eight two-room apartments and one of three rooms at 127 East Sixty-first Street to an investor in a deal reported over the week-end by Douglas L. Elliman Co., the brokers.

Dick Kazmaier, Princeton's sophomore tailback, ran away with Ivy League honors for individual offensive play, final statistics revealed yesterday. Finishing the season with 1,155 yards gained in all, Kazmaier eclipsed his closest competitor by 356 yards.

THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial of Nov. 25 entitled "Minimizing the Bomb" couples Prof. P. S. Blackett's "disparagement" of the atomic bomb with Dr. Vannevar Bush's "almost reassuring prediction." The editorial concludes that the bomb is far more than "the skeptics would have us believe."

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- A Tucker Corporation dealer testified today in Federal District Court that he paid the corporation $4,000 in cash and gave a note for an additional $4,000 and never received an automobile or a refund of his money.

Whittaker chambers admitted yesterday that one of the forty-seven State Department documents in the second trial of Alger Hiss might have been given to him by Harry Dexter White rather than by Mr. Hiss. It was after three days of cross-examination that the defense drew this admission.

I have frequently enjoyed the Monday Financial Column of Edward H. Collins. I find myself in direct disagreement, however, with his side remark recently that the term "laborsaving machinery" ceases to have any meaning if the same number of men are employed on the job as before the installation of the machinery.

High style gloves of unusual fabrics will grace women's hands this mid-winter. With the trend toward longer length gloves, more opportunity is afforded for styling and detailing of cuffs. While the short-shorty is still available, the newer fashion is to have this type high enough only to cover the wrist.

NEWARK, Nov. 28 -- An application for a 25 per cent increase in commutation rates by the Pennsylvania Railroad was heard here today by the Interstate Commerce Commission and the New Jersey Public Utilities Commission. The increase is opposed by fifty-seven New Jersey municipalities.

The Port of New York was host yesterday to two new cargo ships in ceremonies aboard the vessels at their Brooklyn piers. The freighters, City of New York and Sirius, are making their debut here. Both are equipped with limited passenger accommodations as luxurious as any to be found on large passenger liners.

An issue of $5,200,000 of tax-exempt revenue bonds to finance the construction of buildings and parking facilities for the municipally owned Lexington Market of Baltimore will be offered to investors today by a banking syndicate headed by Alex Brown Sons. The bankers described the market as the largest revenue-secured project of its kind undertaken by a local government.

The interim report by Deputy Commissioner John J. Woods to the Board of Transportation on labor's thirty-five separate demands has to be judged against the background of the transit system's dollar position. Mr. Woods' assignment is to develop a good labor relations policy. He has reduced greatly the backlog of grievances, and he proposes to develop still better machinery for handling these.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Bob Black of Rhode Island State retained his title as king of the distance runners at the N. C. A. A. cross-country meet here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Two presidents of railroads testified today in five cases before the Interstate Commerce Commission, in which the Government asks refunds of freight charges on wartime shipments, claiming the rates paid were too high.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- A new policy designed to attract additional private investment in European recovery was announced today by the Economic Cooperation Administration. It permits United States manufacturers to include in investments on which the agency would guarantee dollar convertibility the value of unique production techniques and processes.

Three-year-old Faith Henderson played happily in the sunny, green-walled waiting room while her mother and 6-year-old brother, Lemuel, were being treated inside. It was her introduction to the dentist's office, and she was enjoying it thoroughly.

PARIS, Nov. 28 (UP) -- Lauri Miettinen, president of the Finnish Athletic Federation and a member of the Olympic organizing committee, said today the International Amateur Athletic Federation has rejected his request to reduce the number of track and field events in the 1952 games at Helsinki.

BELHAVEN, N. C., Nov. 28 -- The big Canadian honkers are not the only migrants now along the North Carolina Coast, for gunners from a score of states began arriving yesterday and will be ready for the opening gun at noon tomorrow.

The response of the adrenal glands to the stresses imposed by life situations may largely determine whether a person will remain healthy or become ill, according to studies reported yesterday to the American Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Winston Churchill proposed tonight that at the forthcoming conference of the British Commonwealth Foreign Ministers in Ceylon, the British Government should discuss with other Commonwealth countries the possibility of Britain's joining a European union.

ALBANY, Nov. 28 -- The Feinberg Law, which directed the Board of Regents to purge the public school system of Communist or fellow - traveling teachers and other employes, was held unconstitutional today by Supreme Court Justice Harry E. Schirick in a test case.

Benjamin J. Davis Jr., one of the eleven Communist leaders found guilty on Oct. 14 of conspiracy to teach and advocate the forcible overthrow of the United States Government, was formally expelled from the City Council yesterday. The members, voting 15 to 0, ruled that he had forfeited his membership upon his conviction.

In almost every office there is a man who, comes the hunting season, locks his desk under the envious eyes of his fellow workers, puts on his hat and coat and disappears for a week or two. To his colleagues, to whom vacation may be but a pleasant and expensive memory, his action appears simple enough.

A play pen should be what the name implies and not a sort of penalty box in which babies are popped to keep them from under foot, members of a discussion group at the Child Study Association, 132 East Seventy-fourth Street, decided yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Following are excerpts from the transcript of the press conference held today by David E. Lilienthal and other members of the Atomic Energy Commission:

The water has now gone through the mill in Colombia. There is now a Conservative Government with a Conservative President-elect, Laureano Gomez. The Liberals chose to abstain, but the election has to be considered a defeat for them if only because the Conservatives received more votes than the Liberals did in last June's election, when the latter claimed that their total made them the majority party.

The Columbia College Fund Committee opened a drive for $250,000 yesterday with a luncheon at the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of the university, was the main speaker.

THE greatness of Florence in the fifteenth century is so entangled with the greatness of the Medici that it is difficult to know where one leaves off and the other begins. Most of us are likely to be more than a trifle confused about the Medici anyway, remembering a few scraps of history, a few impressions left by European guide books and various museums and Robinson's immortal lines from "Miniver Cheery":

Roland LaStarza, undefeated young Bronx heavyweight, and Cesar Brion, South American contender for the title vacated by Joe Louis, yesterday passed the medical examination ordered by the State Athletic Commission in advance of their scheduled ten-round battle Friday night in Madison Square Garden.

The local law that Mayor O'Dwyer has said he was sponsoring to give salary increases to him and other members of the Board of Estimate was amended yesterday before it was introduced in the City Council to give the incoming members of that legislative body a $2,500 annual rise in the present $5,000 base pay.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- A sharp fight over the right of Christian (Roman Catholic) trade unions to join the Free World Labor Conference was foreshadowed here today as the conference began its twelve-day session.

A little engineering on the part of the American woman could do wonders for her housework, in the opinion of Dr. Lillian M. Gilbreth, noted engineer who is perhaps better known these days as the mother of the "Cheaper by the Dozen" family.

Christmas came closer yesterday as several hundred "sidewalk superintendents" braved the cold to watch the Rockefeller Center tree get into position. This year it is a seventy-six-foot Norway spruce, crowned with a star big enough to bring its height to eighty feet.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- The new National Planning Committee of the American Veterans Committee, between-conventions governing body elected at the AVC convention which ended yesterday, today took these actions at its first meeting:

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28 -- A former Communist party organizer told a Federal Court jury today that Harry R. Bridges signed a Communist party membership application in the late fall of 1933, received a membership book, paid his dues over a period of several years and urged others to the join the party.

ROME, Nov. 28 -- Floods throughout Italy showed a tendency to decrease today, but the situation was still serious in several regions, especially in the provinces of Bologna and Pisa. Meteorologists foresee no decisive improvement in the weather for another two or three days.

Irish Shipping, Ltd., has been "moderately successful" this year and looks with optimism to 1950, which will be the first full year of the line's operation of a fleet of seven new cargo-passenger vessels, according to James J. Stafford and Capt. John O'Neill, director and general manager of the company, respectively.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 28 -- The United States turned a cold shoulder today toward a resolution offered by the Chinese Nationalist Government under which the General Assembly would call on all members of the United Nations not to recognize the Chinese Communist regime.

An overwhelming din of hammers on metal, of wheels grinding and buzzing, greeted the visitor yesterday to the workshop of the William Hodson Community Center at Tremont and Third Avenues in the Bronx, where the approach of Christmas is spurring the normal activities of its members.

A resolution to provide maintenance for Isaac Allal, only survivor of twenty-eight refugee children in a plane crash near Oslo, Norway, on Nov. 20, was unanimously adopted yesterday at the opening conference session of Pioneer Women at the Henry Hudson Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, held a press conference on the sex life of the atom, in the course of which he demonstrated that even this form of sex is a difficult, delicate and maybe even a dangerous subject.

First commercial models of electronic instruments, heretofore used only by Government laboratories, were shown yesterday by the Radio Corporation of America at the opening of the twenty-second annual Exposition of the Chemical Industries at Grand Central Palace.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Labor Department reported today that 19,000,000 man-days of work were last in October because of strikes.

The Metropolitan Opera has made several brave efforts to sell Verdi's "Simon Boccanegra" to its public. The opera was done for the first time in January, 1932, and remained in the repertory for several seasons. It returned in the season of 1939-40.
Heavy buyer registration and active purchasing were reported yesterday at the Popular Price Shoe Show of America at the New Yorker and McAlpin Hotels.
" TELL me this, Greasy," asked Lou Little of Greasy Neale. "Last year you objected to the two-platoon system. Do you still feel that way about it?"

Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind reserved decision yesterday in a suit through which property owners, with the assistance of the Office of Housing Expediter, are seeking to have the Sharkey rent law declared unconstitutional on the ground that it is in hopeless conflict with the Administration's 1949 Housing Act.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- President Truman told Congress today that the first two years of the Greek-Turkish aid program helped bring about "successful containment of the Communist threat to Greek independence" and "close cooperation between Turkey and the Western world."

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28 (UP) -- Chung Sai Yat Po, oldest daily newspaper of San Francisco's Chinatown, today was bought by a group of leading Chinese business men who plan to scrap the newspaper's pro-Nationalist policy in favor of "neutrality and progressiveness."

Mayor O'Dwyer, exhausted by the twin tasks of running the city and campaigning for re-election, went to Bellevue Hospital last night for an "absolute and complete rest." The hospitalization order was issued by Dr. Edward Bernecker, former Commissioner of Hospitals, who is the Mayor's personal physician, and Dr. Clarence de la Chappelle.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 28 -- A program with substantial Christian-Moslem support for effective internationalization of Jerusalem and Nazareth in Palestine on the basis of the Palestine Conciliation Commission's report was offered today before the United Nations General Assembly's Special Political Committee.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 28 -- South Africa startled the United Nations General Assembly today by abruptly walking out of the fifty-nine-member Trusteeship Committee for the remainder of its current session.

The Communist regime of Marshal Tito celebrates today the sixth anniversary of its founding in a little village in Bosnia on Nov. 29, 1943. This regime, born amid the upheavals of the Second World War, as the Bolshevik regime itself was born amid the upheavals of the earlier war, is still communistic and therefore hostile to Western civilization.

ALBANY, Nov. 28 -- Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, the State Health Commissioner, rejected today a demand by the New York State Catholic Welfare Committee that the State Health Department cease distribution of the sex education film, "Human Growth," for permissive use in the public schools.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 28 (UP) -- Lou Boudreau, who wasn't sure he would be holding down either job next year, received a vote of confidence today as manager of the Indians and then said he was going to try to get back his old post at shortstop.

Negotiations are in progress to have the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra play as the principal attraction in a stage show at the Roxy Theatre some time after the close of the 1950 outdoor season at the Lewisohn Stadium. If arrangements are satisfactorily completed, the orchestra may play as many as five times a day.

An increase of $5 a ton in the prices of several of its products announced yesterday by the Sharon Steel Corporation of Sharon, Pa., aroused speculation in industrial quarters whether a pattern is being drawn to be followed by the rest of the steel industry, to compensate for recent increases in costs.

Led by six senior letter men, all with three years of varsity experience, Siena College of Loudonville, N. Y., will come to town with about 1,800 rooters to meet Manhattan in one of the two collegiate basketball games at Madison Square Garden Saturday night.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Britain's nationalized transport system, now operating at an annual loss of 20,000,000 applied to the House of Commons today for permission to increase charges for hauling and handling freight. Alfred Barnes, minister of transport, said he did not contemplate any rise in passenger fares.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 28 -- A strong current of feeling against the Franco regime in Spain is still running through the majority of delegations at the United Nations, it was demonstrated by debate in the Legal Committee of the General Assembly today.

The market for Government securities is pondering a current change of pace in the open-market operations of the Federal Reserve System. On top of last week's sale of $19,000,000 of long-term Treasury bonds from the Federal Reserve's portfolio came a mark-up yesterday in the yield on Treasury bills to 1.12 per cent, compared with a 1.08 per cent yield rate prevailing recently.

The stock market yesterday assumed an indifferent attitude toward the future and sagged under a minimum of pressure. Individual issues proved highly vulnerable to small sales and at only scattered interludes during the session was there any visible demand. Prices fell fractions to about a point, with the composite rate down 0.83 point on the day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- In the longest and most significant peacetime step in atomic energy, the design for a machine intended to "breed" the essential materials for creating that force has been 90 per cent completed. Preliminary construction work has begun.

GARY, Ind., Nov. 28 (UP) -- City officials today ordered a "full" investigation of a freak accident in which three persons were swept off a station platform by suction of the speeding "Twilight Limited" and hurled to their deaths against the train.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that Limpia Royalties, Inc., Midland, Tex., filed with it a registration statement covering 516,228 shares of $1 par value capital stock.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (UP) -- The weather death toll rose to thirty-four today as floods periled the Pacific Northwest in the wake of a mighty storm that spread destruction across five states and a Canadian province.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Urging "strategic revisions in Federal taxes," Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, said today that this country was in the midst of a "great economic revolution."

In your editorial of Nov. 23, "A Struggle for Men's Souls," you stated in referring to Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith's seventeenth installment of "My Three Years in Moscow," which appeared in your paper on the previous day, that "already, General Smith writes, all the orthodox churches except the Istanbul Patriarchate are controlled from Moscow."

It seems to me that the letter of Peter A. Sturgeon, published in your issue of Nov. 19, commenting on your editorial of Nov. 6 about "Financing Higher Education," falls short in his proposed remedy. He says the plight of higher education goes deeper than the fiscal problem, Agreed.
KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 28 -- The number one vacationer arrived today, and this town was happy. President Truman flew in for his seventh visit here and incidentally gave the tourist season a good start.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 28 -- Seizure of Greenwood Lake and Lake Hopatcong and diversion of their waters to the Wanaque and Boonton reservoirs in order to avert a threatened water famine in North New Jersey were urged today by Clyde Potts, civil engineer of Morristown and Newark and for twenty-five years water consultant to Jersey City and Bayonne.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 28 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan challenged today the right of the United Nations to extend its "interference mania" to this country's administration of the formerly mandated territory of South-West Africa and declared his future action would be determined by what happened after the Trusteeship Committee reported to the General Assembly.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 28 -- Gary Cooper's next film at Warner Brothers will be "Dragger Captain," which Melvyn Levy has written for the screen from a New Yorker magazine sketch by Joseph Mitchell, the studio announced today.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated within a narrow range yesterday and closed 1 point higher to 4 points lower than on Saturday.
LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Business on the stock markets here today was on the smallest scale, with no definitive trend apart from a steady demand for British Government securities.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Nov. 28 -- After revising the architectural drawings to include thirty inches of air space under each house. Sam Berger, builder of the King Ranch houses on Long Island, obtained permission today from Scarsdale to build ranch-type homes here in the Quaker Ridge neighborhood beside the Hutchinson River Parkway.

The housing shortage here and throughout the state can be "licked in two years," State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman said yesterday, if municipal authorities will support his program for non - speculative cooperative housing projects.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent in the week ended on Nov. 22, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 151.5 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.7 per cent below four weeks ago and 7.7 per cent below the comparable week in 1948.
BERLIN, Nov. 28 -- Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson declared here today that the position of the Western powers in Berlin was an integral part of their defensive position in Western Europe.

PARIS, Nov. 28 -- The Shah of Iran certainly did not plan his American tour as a gesture calculated to please the Soviet Union. Oddly enough, however, a definite shift in Moscow's policy toward Teheran seems to have set in and, while it is perhaps temporary, it is certainly soothing.
In 1949 more tourists visited Scotland than there are Scots in the country, Sir Andrew Murray, Lord Provost of Edinburgh, said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Field Marshal Sir William J. Slim, chief of the Imperial Staff of the British Army, conferred today with Stephen T. Early, Acting Secretary of Defense, as he started a six-day schedule of defense discussions and visits to military installations. He will meet tomorrow with the chiefs of staff of United States armed services.

The committee campaigning for the re-election of John Cashmore as Borough President of Brooklyn received contributions of $38,006 and spent $33,789, according to its report filed yesterday with the Board of Elections.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week dropped 2 per cent below the corresponding period a year ago, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Sales for the four weeks ended last Saturday were off 4 per cent.

The United States delegation to the United Nations introduced yesterday its resolution in respect to China. The definitive part of the resolution as well as the expository and explanatory statement that led up to it seem admirably to express sentiments of benevolence and concern and to establish us as right-minded and well-wishing. At the same time they seem somewhat remote from the realities of the situation.
Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery expressed the hope yesterday at City Hall that the flow of arms and military equipment from this country to Western Europe was "not going to end too soon."

BERLIN, Nov. 28 -- Reports in the German press indicate that an extensive movement of inmates of East Zone concentration camps to Russia has been under way for the last week. About 8,000 prisoners are reported to have been moved by train.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that industrial production dropped only 4.6 per cent in October despite the steel and coal strikes then in progress.

Recordings of major wartime broadcasts will be used by WNEW to relate the history of the Second World War in a new weekly series beginning Sunday afternoon from 5 to 5:30 o'clock. Entitled a "Radio History of the War," which has been in preparation for ten months, the program will place emphasis on documentary material, on-the-scene reports and the voices of the fighting men themselves.
ROME, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Countess Edda Ciano announced blandly today she had been born many years before her father, Benito Mussolini, and her mother, Rachele Guidi, had been married.

On page 14 of your Nov. 24 edition there appears the headline, "F. A. O. Rejects Bid by Spain to Join," which, in the light of what happened, is utterly misleading. In "World News Summarized," on page 1 of the same edition, the mistake is repeated.

ALBANY, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Commissioner Francis T. Spaulding of the State Education Department has ordered the Hempstead School District to resurvey zoning lines so that pupils may attend the schools nearest their homes.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Nov. 29 -- After many hours of debate the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations decided early this morning to establish its permanent headquarters in Italy. The vote was 30 in favor of an Italian site to 28-for one in the United States.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 28 -- Twelve White Guard Russian emigres, accused of espionage on behalf of the Soviet Government and hostile activity against Yugoslavia before, during and after World War II, will be placed on trial at Sarajevo next Thursday.

Five hundred New York City veterans last week established retirement pay rights that will bring to them as much as $100 a month or more at the age of 60 by enrolling in the Organized Reserve Corps, it was announced yesterday by Brig. Gen. Richard S. Whitcomb, commander of "Operation Maverick."

The recent inter-service squabble has left many Americans in a fog. Does a man entering our armed services lose one of his basic rights -- freedom of speech? Do the citizens of the United States expect their military leaders to broadcast military secrets and restricted information to probable enemies or to friends just because they are witnesses before a Congressional committee or have chips on their shoulders?
HONG KONG, Nov. 28 -- The fall of Chungking to the Communists appeared here tonight to be a matter of a day or two, perhaps of hours.

To the surprise of no one at all, Army's undefeated football team yesterday was named winner of the Lambert Trophy, emblematic, of Eastern college gridiron supremacy. It was the second straight year that Earl Blaik's cadets gained the honor and the fifth time they have been chosen for the award. Army retired the first Lambert Trophy in 1946.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The National Farm Committee, including two state agricultural commissioners, pleaded innocent today to charges of violating the Federal lobbyist registration law.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today that living costs in the larger cities declined in October to the July level, the lowest for 1949, largely as the result of a 1.8 per cent drop in food prices.

In the future baseball writers will announce most-valuable-player awards the day the winners are selected, it was announced yesterday. Heretofore these selections were made known to the winners and newspapers about a week before the announcement.

BERLIN, Nov. 28 -- An exclusive unconfirmed article in today's editions of the West-licensed Telegraf asserts that one of the most drastic mine disasters in history occurred Thursday at the Soviet controlled urannum mines at Johanngeorgenstadt, on the border of Czechoslovakia, in Saxony, just south of Aue.
ROME, Ga., Nov. 28 (AP) -- A lean, work-hardened Negro woman testified today of "troubles" with police after she refused to sell her home.

DETROIT, Nov. 28 -- Cyrus S. Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, advised labor and management today not to place too much reliance on private pension plans in preference to a joint effort to increase Federal old-age benefits to a point where they would be "both adequate and equitable."
BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Colombia's Liberals, who boycotted the election of a Conservative President yesterday, indicated that their hope rested in the army.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 28 -- Creation of a Westchester County Water Authority that could develop a local watershed adequate to cope with future droughts should be considered immediately, the Westchester Water Works Conference told the Board of Supervisors today.
CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Mighty Notre Dame landed four berths today to monopolize the 1949 All-Midwestern football team selected by The Associated Press.
With the ski season now under way, two fashion stories are in the news: ski and after-ski clothes. Gimbels showed a selection of each last evening in a fashion presentation on the third floor.

The producers of "Good-bye, My Fancy," Michael Kanin, Richard Aldrich and Richard Myers, have decided to advance the closing date of the Fay Kanin comedy to Saturday. The attraction, which had been advertising its last weeks, was to have quit after the performance of Dec. 17. By closing time, it will have played 438 performances at four theatres, the Morosco, Fulton, Martin Beck and Golden.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Nov. 28 (AP) -- The president of Local 2054, CIO United Steelworkers, declared today that "it looks as if we will be striking" against the American Locomotive Company.
ALBANY, N. Y., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Savings of New York State residents totaled more than $28,000,000,000 on last June 30, or about double the national average on a per capita basis.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 28 -- Charles E. Wilson returned to his adopted home town today to be honored for a half century of achievement in behalf of the General Electric Company and for service to the nation in time of emergency and war.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 28 -- Zenn Kaufman, merchandising director for Philip Morris Co., Ltd., New York, said today merchandise should be sold through vending machines with the showmanship formula used by daily newspapers.

Coffee futures were easier after early steadiness in trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. The market opened slightly higher on commission house demand and continued the advance in the first hours of trading on orders from producer interests and further commission house demand.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -- The new antibiotic drug, neomycin, has been used successfully on human beings, Dr. Garfield C. Duncan, director of the Divisions of Medicine at Pennsylvania Hospital, revealed tonight in an address before the section on general medicine at the College of Physicians here.

The Walgreen Company, which operates a chain of 410 retail drug stores throughout the country, transacted a record volume of $163,365,019 net sales in the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, it was reported yesterday. In the preceding fiscal year net sales were $163,260,827.

KINGS POINT, L. I., Nov. 28 -- New York University's basketball team opened its season with a 76-44 victory over the United States Merchant Marine Academy at O'Hara Hall tonight. The triumph marked the start of Howard Cann's twenty-seventh year as coach of the Violets.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 28 -- The police were searching here today for a youth who, interrupted early this morning while he attempted to rob a tavern, beat a crippled 71-year-old caretaker to death and struck a 67-year-old woman who tried to come to his aid.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The oft-postponed trial of Representative J. Parnell Thomas, Republican, of New Jersey, on charges of conspiring to defraud the Government through payroll padding and "kickbacks" from fictitious employes began today in Federal District Court.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Baking industry spokesmen told Senate investigators today that high costs, not profits, have kept the retail price of bread at its high post-war level.

The 200-man policy committee of John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers was scheduled to meet here with its chief yesterday afternoon, but there was a last-minute change of plans and the session was deferred until today. This means that there should be a break one way or another within the next twenty-four hours in the state of uncertainty which has enveloped the coal-mining dispute now for some three weeks.

PARIS, Tuesday, Nov. 29 -- The French Communist newspaper Humanite published this morning the texts of three resolutions said to have been adopted by the Communist Information Bureau at a meeting in an undisclosed place during the last half of November.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The National Labor Relations Board today ordered John L. Camp of Houston, Tex., counsel for the Ohio Oil Company, to show cause why he should not be barred from further practice before the board.

RALEIGH, N. C., Nov. 28 (UP) -- The United Press today announced its 1949 All-Southern Conference football team, with a line averaging 205 pounds and a backfield balanced between bone-bending runners and tricky triple-threat men.

Although the Police Department's strength is greater today than at any time in the last fifteen years, less than one-third of the force is on duty every twenty-four hours "pounding a beat." On some eight-hour tours as few as 1,100 men are available normally for the arduous and least rewarding job of foot patrol.

John C. Brent of London, representing several manufacturers of British delicacies, spent half an hour yesterday telling us about Ribena. That is the trade name of a black currant juice that is being introduced in this country from Gloucestershire.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The State Department was informed today that the steamship Sir John Franklin, of United States registry, had been shelled by Chinese Nationalist warships while going up the Yangtze River en route from Hong Kong to Shanghai.

PARIS, Nov. 28 -- The first formal move toward giving military and economic substance to the North Atlantic peace pact began here today in an atmosphere of heightened French nervousness regarding the possible participation of Germany in the defense of Western Europe.

Although the New York Football Giants will win no championship this season -- the Philadelphia Eagles have clinched the National Eastern Division crown -- second place remains to be determined, and with this in mind, Steve Owen, Giants' coach, will start preparations today for Sunday's Polo Grounds game with the Eagles.

The committee on foreign commerce of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York yesterday gave conditional approval of President Truman's Point 4 program for the development of economically backward areas.
A warning that industry must go to the financial support of higher education was sounded last night by Wallace F. Bennett, president of the National Association of Manufacturers.

The directors of the National Steel Corporation yesterday declared a year-end extra of 50 cents in addition to the usual quarterly dividend of $1.25 on the common stock, both payable Dec. 15. This brings total disbursements this year to $5.50. Last year when the stock was on a $1 quarterly basis, a year-end extra of $1 together with 10 per cent in stock were paid in December.

PANAMA, Nov. 28 -- The operation of the Panama Canal has not been hindered m any way by the absence of diplomatic relations between the United States and the present Government of Panama, Gov. Francis K. Newcomer said today. He added, in effect, that the present situation was not expected to affect future Canal operations.

Resumption of futures trading in tin on the Commodity Exchange here early next year was forecast by traders yesterday. A meeting of the exchange's special metals group is scheduled for tomorrow, at which preliminary work for drawing up a trading contract for tin transactions will be discussed.

Four members of Congress last night urged renewed aid to Nationalist China and no recognition of the Chinese Reds under any circumstances. They spoke at a Carnegie Hall meeting of the newly formed Committee to Defend America by Aiding Anti-Communist China.

Manufacturers of both men's and women's apparel have been critical of price increases for finished cottons and rayons, it was pointed out in the trade yesterday. Manufacturers of house dresses, using a larger proportion of percales and carded broadcloths than any other segment of the dress industry, have indicated that they will hold back on large-scale purchases until the end of the year because of the higher prices.
