JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Missouri and Maryland were announced as Gator Bowl football foes today.

Procedures for working out union schedule grievances against the Third Avenue Transit Corporation were agreed upon yesterday by union and management representatives at a two-hour meeting with Theodore W. Kheel, impartial arbiter for the bus industry.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- For the third time a group under the auspices of the law school of Notre Dame University is to discuss whether the need of mankind today is to be found in the doctrine which great thinkers for the past twenty-two hundred years have called "the Natural Law." The institute of that name at Notre Dame is to hold its 1949 symposium Dec. 9 and 10 on the premises of the university.
Times Square and Harlem were joined yesterday by miles of mourners as the city paid funeral homage to Bill (Bojangles) Robinson.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -- President Truman threw the prestige of his office today behind the new anti-Communist electrical union set up by the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 28 (AP) -- A disqualification marked the featured $3,000 Edgar G. Horn Purse at the Bowie track today when Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' Fleet Vixen won but was moved back to fourth by the stewards.

Dollar volume of independent home furnishings stores throughout the country in the first nine months of the year decreased 11.5 per cent compared with a year ago, the National Retail Furniture Association reported yesterday. The group emphasized, however, that unit sales were only 4.8 per cent below last year.

Foreign import restrictions, together with currency devaluation, are gradually driving American pharmaceutical concerns out of world markets, it was charged yesterday by Dr. Theodore G. Klumpp, president of the American Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association.
Removal of a disputed mural at New York University has resulted in a protest by the Student Council of the School of Education, it was learned yesterday.
Columbia University's School of Journalism has received facsimile equipment worth $40,000 from THE NEW YORK TIMES, Carl W. Ackerman, dean, announced yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 28 -- Despite denials here, it was learned tonight from an authoritative source that high level talks were taking place between Israel and Jordan with a view to settling the Jerusalem problem away from Lake Success.
MOUNT HAMILTON, Calif., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Two vast clusters of galaxies or Milky Ways, larger than any hitherto known, have been found by Lick Observatory astronomers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- December, March and May wheat, March, May and July corn and all deliveries of oats sold at new high levels for the year on the Board of Trade here in the early trading today, but the finish was irregular. Wheat closed 1/4 cent up to 1/8 cent off; corn, 1/2 cent up to 1/8 cent down.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 28 -- Two officers of the Economic Cooperation Administration mission to the Netherlands left for Indonesia last week to check on the spending of Marshall Plan aid funds, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- British armed forces can hold Hong Kong and intend to do so, "if the Chinese are foolish enough to attack it," Field Marshal Sir William J. Slim, chief of the Imperial General Staff, said here today.
BATANGAS, Philippines, Nov. 29 (UP) -- Feliciano Leviste, Governor of Batangas Province, suggested today that President Truman intervene in the Philippines to supervise new general elections.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, declared today that the Federal budget could be balanced by 1952 without an increase in taxes if certain cuts in spending, notably in foreign military and economic aid, could be put into effect.

The bitter factional struggle in the National Maritime Union, CIO, is expected to reach a climax tomorrow night in a show-down meeting at St. Nicholas Arena, on West Sixty-sixth Street, adherents of both sides reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- False reports of a coffee shortage were blamed by the chairman of a Senate investigating subcommittee today for "scare buying" that he said had driven prices up and benefited speculators.

Operating with a larger budget and a younger, more aggressive state the Federal Trade Commission will step up its activities in the realm of price discrimination and tie-in sales, James T. Welch, Washington attorney, warned yesterday. Big business, he said, must use every means possible to convince the FTC of its good faith and confer with the agency before making price policy changes that might be suspect.

Count Felix von Luckner, famed commander of a German sea raider in World War I, arrived here yesterday aboard the Swedish American liner Gripsholm for a lecture tour. It was his first visit since before the war.

DANBURY, Conn., Nov. 29 -- En route to the northlands: Before describing what's new in the ski country, this would be a fitting time to tell generally what the picture for the winter of 1949-50 looks like.
BOWIE, Md., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Harbourton, carrying the colors of the High Ground Stable, beat off repeated challenges from Arthur Pilate to take the featured Laytonsville Purse by a head today.

Establishment of a new kind of school to help men and women prepare themselves for retirement was urged yesterday by Dr. Alonzo F. Myers, chairman of the department of higher education at New York University's School of Education.

The little boy look is in fashion in high white collars but the flatchested flapper of the 1920's is not returning, according to predictions made yesterday by Bien Jolie, one of the leading corset manufacturers.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- United States labor leaders attending the Free World Labor Conference here moved swiftly today to end what had been termed a virtual Socialist veto on the admission of the Christian (Roman Catholic) trade unions of several European countries to the common fight on communism.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- Charging that left-wing forces were using the courts in an effort to keep electrical workers from ridding themselves of Communist domination, James B. Carey, chairman of the administrative committee of the new anti-Communist electrical union set up by the Congress of Industrial Organizations, called on the new union's officers and locals today to defy any court injunctions that interfered with the union's progress.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The appeal of the Communist Information Bureau for Communists the world over to help overthrow Premier Marshal Tito was seen here today as confirmation of Moscow's fears that the Yugoslav anti-Soviet Communist leader presented a genuine threat to Russian domination of Eastern Europe.

John W. Davis, former Ambassador to the Court of St. James, awarded the medal of the Hundred Year Association of New York to Dean Millicent Carey McIntosh of Barnard College at the association's seventeenth annual dinner last night at the Plaza Hotel.

New Yorkers can reduce their per capita use of water for domestic purposes from the present seventy-five gallons daily to fifty gallons "without actually depriving anyone of necessary water," it was estimated yesterday by Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.

An expected increase of 25 per cent in the city's constitutional debt-incurring and taxing power would mean "a time of crisis in 1950 for real estate investors," Harold Riegelman, counsel for the Citizens Budget Commission, declared yesterday.

John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, deferred action in the "coal war" until the last minute when he called off a meeting of his top union committee yesterday for the second straight day.

The latest in the series of flashbacks in photography at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, opens today with an exhibition, "Roots of French Photography," on loan from the George Eastman House, Inc., of Rochester, N. Y.

More than seventy racing executives from thirty-five United States tracks will gather at the Hotel Plaza today for the eighth annual membership meeting of the Thoroughbred Racing Associations. Top event of the two-day session will be a dinner tomorrow night, at which Vice President Alben W. Barkley, the nation's No. 1 bridegroom, will check in from Shangri-La to make the principal address.

Five hundred indifferent cats and a bewildered audience of twenty-five persons listened yesterday as an instructor in business law at Long Island University explained the intricate problems involved in leaving a legacy to a feline.

The sale of the choice Louisville Gas and Electric Company bonds to bankers yesterday at an interest cost of about 2.66 per cent may mark the start of another substantial era of "refunding the refundings," according to market observers.

ROME, Nov. 29 -- The Communist newspaper Unita published the text of the Communist Information Bureau's communique this morning, dedicating two pages to it. Non-Communist circles attributed comparatively little importance to it, regarding it mainly as a rehash of outworn commonplaces of Communist propaganda.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Norris E. Dodd, Director General, today asked the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations to increase contributions by member nations to cover the estimated $1,500,000 cost of the move to the newly chosen permanent headquarters in Rome.

Winston Churchill must surely be aware, today, of the stream of good will and good wishes that is flowing across the Atlantic as he rounds out three-fourths of a century of an eventful life. He must know that his millions of American friends want to wish him a happy birthday and that many of them will wish him also many happy "returns" in more senses than one.

William J. Powell, a short, rugged man who got a job in the Sanitation Department as a "white win" forty-three years ago, will retire as Commissioner of Sanitation on Jan. 1 "to take life easy," it was learned yesterday. His resignation has been accepted by Mayor O'Dwyer.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 29 -- The Communist Information Bureau's communique ordering a renewed assault on Yugoslavia was received here tonight with disdain by the Yugoslav Communist leaders.
SEATTLE, Nov. '29---1Vatthew G. KriVor, a Seattle resident, had Ia premonition that he was to die, according to an official of the !Y. IVL C. . technical school here.

Directors of the Burlington Mills Corporation yesterday elected a new director and five new vice presidents. The new director is Graham H. Anthony, chairman of the board of Colt's Manufacturing Company, Hartford.

Demand from distributors is so great for Anahist, first of the anti-histamine products for colds to be marketed, that it has been put on allocation despite a daily production of 2,000 gross of bottles, John W. Clissold, director of sales of the Anahist Company, said yesterday at the luncheon of the Sales Executives Club at the Roosevelt Hotel.
The European Recovery Program has thus far been more successful than its founders originally expected, Gen. George C. Marshall, former Secretary of State, said in an address here last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Public appeals to "buy American" were condemned today by Paul G. Hoffman, Marshall Plan administrator, as economic nonsense indulged in only to cloak an underlying demand for protection of industries from legitimate competition of fellow producers at home.
The United States went before the United Nations General Assembly yesterday to offer the "hand of cooperation" to the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The Federal Trade Commission today ordered the Bristol-Myers Company of New York to discontinue certain alleged misrepresentations as to the therapeutic value of Ipana toothpaste and the extent to which it is used or recommended by dentists.

Two hundred new books selected by the children's book committee of the Child Study Association of America went on display yesterday at the group's headquarters, 132 East Seventy-fourth Street. The public can look them over between 9:30 A. M. and 5 P. M. on weekdays until Dec. 22.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 29 -- Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer today named Keenan Wynn to appear with Fred Astaire, Red Skelton, Vera Ellen and Arlene Dahl in "Three Little Words," a musical treatment of the careers of Burt Kalmar and Harry Ruby, song writers.

For six weeks Detective Rene Mareno sauntered into various taverns throughout East Harlem seeking a possible tip to the solution of a grocery-store murder on Oct. 14. Early yesterday the tip developed and in quick succession the two alleged slayers and a married couple who had secreted the purported murder weapon were in custody.

Gilbert Miller, a stickler in casting, needn't fret any more about getting the right actors for the T. S. Eliot comedy, "The Cocktail Party," which he will present by arrangement with the Sherek Players, Ltd., of London. Yesterday he announced that six London performers of the ten-character cast to be imported as a unit had been signed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UP) -- A golden era ended for the nation's farmers today when the Agriculture Department reported that they had lost all of the so-called "price advantage" they had held since the start of the war.

More understanding by publishers and advertising agencies of each other's problems should be achieved by organized personnel-training programs, it was declared yesterday by A. L. Billingsley, president of Fuller Smith Ross, Inc.

Sixteen lustily normal 1-year-olds got together yesterday to clink their nursing bottles and drink a toast in formula at the first birthday party of the Premature Ambulance Service of the Department of Health.

The creation of an appeals unit, completely independent of the Board of Education, to review decisions of the city schools' Board of Examiners was urged yesterday by the Teachers Union, CIO, as hearings continued on the issue.

The making of oral agreements between Revlon Products Corporation, cosmetics manufacturer, and its jobber distributors to exclude handling of competitive products was denied yesterday at opening of hearings on Federal monopoly charges.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 29 -- A wide circle of friends, including President Miguel Aleman and top Government officials as well as leading persons in industry and business here, today mourned the tragic deaths of Jose de la Mora with his wife, Flora, and two daughters, Ofelia and Guadalupe, in the plane crash at Dallas, Tex.

DALLAS, Tex., Nov. 29 -- Twenty-eight persons died in the flaming, scattered wreckage of an American Airlines international plane at the north edge of Love Field, the Dallas municipal airport, at dawn today.

For housewives on a budget the United States Department of Agriculture lists foods that will be plentiful in December. Ready availability plus comparatively reasonable costs are strong points in favor of the following items:

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Tomorrow will be Winston Churchill's seventy-fifth birthday anniversary. Although no longer the King's First Minister, he still ranks in the hearts and minds of most Britons as the nation's first citizen and they still refer to him with affectionate respect as "Winston."

SOUTHERN PINES, N. C., Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Professional Golfers Association of America voted at its annual meeting today against allowing any professional to become eligible for membership after two years as a recognized tournament circuit player.

The Port of New York faces a 10 per cent reduction in experienced customs inspection personnel as a result of an order by the Civil Service Commission calling for the dismissal of fifty-two inspectors, effective Dec. 31, it became known yesterday.
Holiday hospitality at home may be "glamourized" by tables festively laid with new colored cloths -- both imported and domestic -- now being shown in local stores.

PARIS, Nov. 29 -- In a note delivered to the French Foreign Minister this afternoon, Jersy Putrament, Polish Ambassador to France, flatly rejected French protests arising out of the arrest in Warsaw Nov. 18 of Andre Robineau, secretary of the French Consulate in Szczecin [Stettin].

New fare schedules that will enable many patrons of New England railroads to avoid the 12 1/2 per cent increase in passenger tariffs recently authorized by the Interstate Commerce Commission were announced yesterday by the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad. The revisions will apply also on the Maine Central and the Boston Maine Railroad.

College basketball games scheduled for Madison Square Garden and the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street, again will be covered by WMGM this winter in a series of thirty-six broadcasts, beginning tomorrow night at 8:30 o'clock and running through the early part of March.

In an all-cash deal, the five-story residence at 133 East Seventy-ninth Street has been sold by Julian S. Myrick, former vice president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company, to an American investor residing in Monte Carlo. Douglas L. Elliman Co. were the brokers in the sale of the house, which occupies a lot 20 by 102 feet, near Lexington Avenue.

Eddie LeBaron, the magnificent faker of College of Pacific's all-conquering Tigers, once again heads the Little All-America football team -- eleven players from minor schools who probably could hold their own in any company.
For the third time in the past four years Notre Dame has been voted the nation's No. 1 football power by sports writers and sportscasters taking part in The Associated Press poll.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Great Britain today received $14,967,000 in new Marshall plan aid to make heavy purchases of industrial metals, cotton and animal hairs.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- Woodruff Randolph, president of the International Typographical Union, AFL, has dropped two former running mates from his slate of candidates seeking re-election to union office May 17. They are Larry Taylor, first vice president, and Elmer Brown, second vice president, and in their places Mr. Randolph is offering, respectively, Charles M. Lyon, of Local 121, Lynn, Mass., and Harold Clark, of Local 5, Columbus, Ohio.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 29 -- For the first time in its 147 years the United States Military Academy here will open tomorrow an undergraduate conference on American affairs to which students from civilian colleges have been invited.

A report by Kathleen McLaughlin about an agency for part-time jobs for university students in Berlin says that these "are the first German students to adopt extensively the United States custom of working their way through." This is a mistake.

Bronx County Judge Samuel Joseph used his judicial power yesterday to try to increase the jail sentences of three hoodlums convicted of an attempted attack on a Bronx girl as she sat on a park bench on the Bronx Concourse with her fiance after the party announcing their engagement.

A month before the New York Legislature acted we opposed, as blunderbuss method, the Feinberg law to rid the public schools of subversive employes. The bill was passed, by 41 to 14 in the Senate and by 122 to 25 in the Assembly, in the closing hours of the session, and quickly signed by the Governor.

ROME, Ga., Nov. 29 (UP) -- Sheriff John W. Lynch turned his back and mingled with the mob when a victim of hooded terrorists appealed to him as an officer for help, a Government witness testified today.

The demands of office and running for office have put Mayor O'Dwyer into the hospital, suffering from "almost complete nervous and physical exhaustion," accompanied by an acute respiratory infection. It seems clear now that he would have been wise to take a vacation immediately after the campaign.
The Board of Estimate approved yesterday a 1950 capital budget of $335,647,497. The second largest in the city's history, it was $1,262,277 less than the record one for 1949.

In another step in the liquidation of its realty holdings in the city, the Pinchot Estate yesterday sold the southeast corner of Broadway and West Seventy-sixth Street, a five-story building on plot 127 by 107 feet, to the Nahaba Realty Corporation for investment.

Public utility companies raised more than $73,000,000 yesterday by the sale of new issues of first-mortgage bonds and common stock. In all instances the new issues of securities were bought by investment banking syndicates on competitive bidding. The awards were as follows:

John Haynes Holmes, for forty-three years minister of the Community Church of New York, officially retired from the active pastorate last night on his seventieth birthday -- but promised his parishioners that he would "hang around for a while longer as pastor emeritus."

BALTIMORE, Nov. 29 -- Responsibility for the operation of the Arctic research laboratory at Point Barrow. Alaska, has been shifted from the Navy to Johns Hopkins University. This was announced today by Dr. Detlev W. Bronk, president of the university.

TORONTO, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Hockey's fabulous fat man, Walter (Turk) Broda, got orders today to cut his weight from 197 to 190 pounds. Until he does, someone else will tend goal for the Toronto Maple Leafs in the National Hockey League.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29 -- Testimony that Harry R. Bridges met with Earl Browder, then leader of the Communist party of the United States, in a shack in a Santa Clara County prune orchard during the 1934 maritime strike was given today to a jury in the Federal court room of Judge George B. Harris.

Federal mediators reported no change in the relative positions of the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, and a committee representing thirty-eight East and Gulf Coast steamship operators after another negotiations session yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Following are excerpts communique adopted by the Communist Information Bureau after a meeting this month in Hungary, as transcribed and translated from Russian by the Soviet Monitor from a Moscow radio broadcast:

The board of directors of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company voted yesterday to change the dates of future dividend payments on the common stock, and accordingly deferred action on the dividend normally considered at this time.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The Administration will back a bill in Congress to permit the use of an $800,000,000 to $900,000,000 fund for grants to states to encourage them to increase the amount and duration of unemployment compensation benefits under minimum Federal standards.
KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 29 -- President Truman busily, almost feverishly, relaxed today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission expects to begin proceedings on Jan. 9 to determine whether to revoke or suspend the broker-dealer registration of Otis Co., Cleveland investment banking concern, or suspend or expel the company from membership in the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc.

MORTON, Pa., Nov. 29 -- The new all-metal fuselage HRP-2 tandem rotored transport helicopter, marking another step in the Navy's long-range helicopter development program, was unveiled here today at the Piasecki Helicopter Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- This country is preparing in the utmost secrecy to conduct further tests of its atomic weapons at the isolated Central Pacific proving grounds at Eniwetok Atoll. This was announced tonight in a joint statement of the Atomic Energy Commission and the Department of Defense.
Contract demands of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, have been submitted to the American Airlines and Pan-American World Airways, it was announced last night.

PARIS, Nov. 29 -- The Soviet Union's international propaganda machine announced to the world today that a secret meeting of the Communist Information Bureau had decided to press more ruthlessly for the overthrow of Marshal Tito's regime in Yugoslavia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The United States has authorized the issuance of a visa to Li Tsung-jen, Acting President of the Chinese Nationalist Government, to enable him to get medical care in this country, it was disclosed today.

Coffee futures prices dropped sharply in moderately active trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. The market opened lower and prices receded gradually thereafter on commission house and trade hedge selling.

The American China Policy Association yesterday made public resolutions it had adopted at the annual meeting of its board of directors on Friday demanding a full investigation of the whole Far Eastern Division of the State Department by a subcommittee of the Senate Foreign Affairs Committee.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 29 -- The remark made here three weeks ago by Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky that Russia was "razing mountains" with atomic power has apparently been radically toned down for home consumption.

HAVANA, Nov. 29 -- A pro-amateur golf tournament, with prize money of around $15,000, will be held on the links of the Country Club of Havana, Dec. 14-16, inclusive, according to an announcement by the tournament committee today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A Philadelphia manufacturer, who last week accused the Army of tailoring procurement specifications to fit one company, clashed with another Government agency today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Mrs. James M. Helm, White House social secretary, announced today the finding of the earliest-known original copy of the Presidential crest on a White House engraved invitation. Its date was Feb. 19, 1880.

More than 700 votes ahead of his closest competitor, Leon Joseph Hart, giant Notre Dame end, has won the Heisman Memorial Trophy, awarded annually by the Downtown Athletic Club, Harry H. Kennedy, chairman of the award committee, announced yesterday.

A total of 138 awards was made to members of eleven Columbia athletic teams at the twenty-ninth annual Varsity C Club dinner at John Jay Hall on the college campus last night. There were 350 persons on hand.
A burly fireman headed for the basement of Hook and Ladder Company 22 yesterday with something white dangling from his right hand. At every step the thing emitted a plaintive cry: "Mama!"

Tentative plans for one-family dwellings on a tract of 520 acres in Farmingdale, L. I., were announced yesterday by Joseph J. Fischer, president of the Broad Hollow Estates, Inc., who purchased the land from Realty Associates, Inc., H. D. Burchell, vice president. David Shaw was the broker.
LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Three weaknesses in the Communist cold war strategy seemed to Western observers to have been exposed today in the resolutions of the Cominform.

HAVANA, Nov. 20 -- The accusation by the Dominican Republic that Cubans were preparing a new expedition to attempt to oust President Rafael Trujillo is completely false, according to the Ministry of State.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- The Metropolitan Opera Company opened its Philadelphia season at the Academy of Music tonight with Puccini's "Manon Lescaut," last sung here nineteen years ago and revived in commemoration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the death of the famous Italian composer.

Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, bought the vacant plot 50 by 114 feet at 2694-2696 Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx, from Elfreda and Alma M. Dettinger of Stamford, Conn. J. G. Breunich was the broker. This transaction marked the first sale of the property in forty-one years.

The chubby youngster between the ages of 6 and 16 who has the desire to be as attractively dressed as her svelte sister but finds shopping for the proper clothes a problem will welcome the new selection now available in Lane Bryant's chubby department.

Plans for a new home colony in Colonia, N. J., were revealed yesterday by Carragher Bros. Corporation, builders and developers, in connection with the announcement of thet purchase of 350 lots from Woodbridge Homes, Inc., of New York City. The property is on the westerly side of St. George's Avenue and comprises about one square mile.

OCEAN GROVE, N. J., Nov. 29 -- It was moving day here today for the "residents" of the New Jersey Methodist Home for the Aged, who officially took posession of the impressive new $1,250,000 edifice that rises five stories above its lake and sea front surroundings and could easily be mistaken for a luxury seashore hotel.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- British Government issues made another vigorous advance on the Stock Exchange here today. Buying by big investors was much heavier than it had been of late and it was quickly reflected in sharp rises of up to 1 3/4 points.

ROME, Nov. 29 -- By a vote of 172 to 89 with 9 abstentions, the Senate, following similar action by the Chamber of Deputies a week ago, confirmed today its confidence in Premier Alcide de Gasperi's Government.

TOKYO, Nov. 29 -- The lower house is expected tomorrow to give final approval to the Foreign Exchange Control Act which passed the House of Councillors yesterday. General MacArthur has indicated it will be used for private export deals from Dec. 1 and private import deals from Jan. 1.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Government reported today that sales of chain stores, mail order houses and department stores dropped in October.

Forty-five hundred transatlantic passengers arrived and departed yesterday aboard eight passenger ships in one of the busiest days along the waterfront in recent weeks. All eight vessels docked at or sailed from piers along the Hudson River.
The Crown Zellerbach Corporation, manufacturer of paper, and its subsidiaries, had a net income of $8,656,013 in the six months ended with last October, according to the report released today.
The campaign committee that worked for the re-election of Mayor O'Dwyer, Council President Vincent R. Impellitteri and Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday a deficit of about $205,000.
HONG KONG, Nov. 29 -- Chou En-lai, Premier and Foreign Minister of the Peiping Government, warned France today against permitting any Nationalist forces to retreat into Indo-China.

Buddy O'Connor and Nick Mickoski will be back in the New York Rangers line-up for tonight's game with the Montreal Canadiens in Madison Square Garden. The Rangers will be on home ice after an absence of two weeks. They'll play four of their next six games in the Garden, including tonight's.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Guy George Gabrielson, Republican National Chairman, sought advice from party ranks today on whether there should be a restatement of Republican principles in advance of the 1950 Congressional election.

The railroads of this country will be forced to submit their short-haul or commuting business to socialization in the near future as a result of increased costs and the competition of passenger automobiles, Patrick B. McGinnis, railroad official and stock broker, declared yesterday.

It is becoming increasingly clear that the highly favorable settlement of their pension demands obtained by the steel workers has opened a Pandora's box so far as that issue is concerned. Regional labor leaders have come forward in the last few days with proposals for extending the "Bethlehem plan" over wide geographical areas, and Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor, has called for pensions of $100 a month for all.

Parents of excursion-minded boys and girls were advised yesterday to put the youngsters themselves to work ferreting out ideas on what to do next. When the adult spirit of adventure begins to lag, it is time to start the children looking through newspapers for events to come, Mrs. Ruth Loud, author of "New York, New York," said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UP) -- The Government today ordered growers to cut back plantings of fire-cured and dark air-cured tobacco by 15 per cent next year. Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, proclaimed marketing quotas on the two crops and set planting allotments at 56,850 acres for fire-cured tobacco and 26,200 acres for dark air cured tobacco.

Events tonight: Saint-Saens' "Samson et Dalila," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:30; Ruggiero Ricci, violin, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Bach Aria Group, William H. Scheide, director, Town Hall, 8:30; Paganini Quartet, Times Hall, 8:30; Budapest String Quartet, Milton Katims, viola, Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A., 8:40; orchestral concert, Harris Danziger, conductor, Manhattan School of Music, 238 East 105th Street, 8:15.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner advised today against changing the present freight rate relationships among the North Atlantic ports in the handling of export grain from the Great Lakes.

Incurrence of budgetary deficits on a large scale and over a long period during peacetime is "an invitation to disaster," the Guaranty Trust Company of New York declares in the current issue of its monthly Survey. Pointing out that the Federal deficit for the current fiscal year has been officially estimated at $5,500,000,000, against the President's January budget forecast of $873,000,000, the bank asserts that "the end of deficits is not even dimly in sight."

In what is understood to be an unprecedented move the RKO theatre circuit will "guarantee" the "enjoyability" of "Everybody Does It" by offering free tickets to a future RKO show to those patrons who state that the film does not meet with their approval.
Following is the text of the address made by Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery last night at the dinner of the English-Speaking Union in the Waldorf-Astoria:

Notes on the operations of a Soviet-controlled spy ring in Washington between 1934 and 1938 were introduced by the prosecution yesterday at the second Alger Hiss perjury trial, in the form of new documentary evidence.

A non-profit organization intended to encourage the flow of American capital and industrial experience to Israel has been formed by American financiers and business leaders, it was announced here yesterday. The new group, the Industrial Institute of Israel, has completed the formalities of incorporation and will begin operations at once under the leadership of Ralph Friedman, president.
Mayor O'Dwyer, a patient at Bellevue Hospital since Monday night, was reported yesterday to have developed an acute upper respiratory infection but to be resting comfortably.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,543, compared with 1,134 last week and 1,146 in the same week of last year, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 1.069 arrivals yesterday against 369 last Tuesday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- Removal of hedges against sales of 1,000,000 sacks of flour to the domestic trade, and continued firmness in the spot wheat market sent all deliveries of that grain, other than the July, to new highs for this year on the Board of Trade here today.

The Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center has received two gifts totaling $550,000. Bernard M. Baruch gave $450,000 and the Louis J. and Mary E. Horowitz Foundation, Inc., gave $100,000, it was announced yesterday by Nevil Ford, chairman of the center's current public appeal.

1Vfrs. Reba Wadel, a former chairman of the National Women's Division of the United Jewish Appeal, was returning to her home! in Dallas from the national conference of the UJA in Atlantic City, where a special dinner was heldI in her honor on the occasion of herI retirement from the chairmanship.[

Here it is not yet Christmas and the winter is over. Indeed, it is much closer to Thanks- giving than to the more expensive holiday, and the winter already is over. This is good. It always is good to have an early winter, and as painlessly as possible, and in that regard the winter just ended was fine.

MATTAMUSKEET, N. C., Nov. 29 -- The temptation to gather in a goose dinner this morning was almost more than some shooters could resist, as the echelons of honkers flapped over the lakes, marsh and field blinds, but we did not hear a single shot until the season officially opened at noon.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Elven fleet horses were named today to run in the Inaugural Handicap, feature event on the nine-race program opening Florida's thoroughbred racing season at Tropical Park tomorrow.

PARIS, Nov. 29 -- After his arrival in Paris by plane from London tonight, Secretary Johnson issued a prepared statement to emphasize once more that, "We have no desire or plan to permit the rebuilding of the armed forces of Western Germany."

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 29 -- Consideration of the Palestine problem by a conference here of the chiefs of United States diplomatic missions in the Middle East, under the chairmanship of George C. McGhee, is dominated by evidence that King Abdullah of Jordan is determined to make a separate peace with Israel.

MADRID, Nov. 29 -- A thousand Madrid bank employes paraded in the capital's streets tonight in a demonstration unprecedented under the Franco regime. The employes demanded better pay and working conditions.

HONG KONG, Nov. 29 -- Li Li-san made public admission of his errors in the tactical leadership of the Chinese Communist movement two decades ago in a speech to the trade union conference of Asian and Australasian countries, which has been in session at Peiping for two weeks.

A silver jubilee membership drive for a minimum of 15,000 new members in Pioneer Women between Jan. 1 and Oct. 1 was approved yesterday at the national board and regional conference in the Henry Hudson Hotel.

A plan sponsored by the Amalgamated Meat Cutters Union, AFL, to construct a $2,823,000 cooperative housing development for its members in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn was approved yesterday by State Housing Commissioner, Herman T. Stichman.

A biography of the famous Norwegian-American Arctic airman, Bernt Balchen, has been scheduled for Dec. 15 publication by the Bell Publishing Company of Drexel Hill, Pa. "Hitch Your Wagon" is illustrated with photographs of many of his exploits and has a foreword by Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker.

VIENNA, Nov. 29 -- Soviet Army deserters have been committing so many outrages in Lower Austria during the past fortnight that the Austrian Cabinet, after hearing a report by the Minister of the Interior, Oskar Helmer, resolved today to take special measures to protect the people.

To the shrill tune of the bagpipe, Sir Andrew Murray, the visiting Lord Provost of Edinburgh, was entertained yesterday at a luncheon at the New Weston Hotel given by the British Travel Association, which provided a bill of fare in sharp contrast with the traditional frugality of the Scot.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Cuts in the British Government's domestic information services, which now cost ten times what they did before the war, were recommended today in a report by a committee appointed by the Government to make a study of the services.

What was described as the first concerted action by realty owners and builders to solve the problem of television antenna service for Manhattan apartment buildings was taken yesterday with the simultaneous signing of contracts for installation of master aerials in three multi-family buildings now under construction.
Since the city clean-up drive was started last May, the Sanitation Department has spent $32,303 to remove refuse from 1,453 vacant lots, a report by Commissioner William J. Powell showed yesterday.

One of the great four-engined Globemasters that recently transported 103 persons to Europe on one flight and was used in the Berlin airlift to carry enormous payloads, and a DC-4 that can be quickly converted for either cargo or passenger use, were among the planes inspected at Newark Airport yesterday by a group of engineers.

Much of the confusion which surrounds the present discussion on the internationalization of Jerusalem might be dissipated, and a rational solution arrived at, if the parties to the discussion would keep clearly in mind these fundamental ideas:

During December and January the New York Infirmary will seek from the public $2,800,000 to complete the $4,050,000 fund needed to build a new eleven-story hospital building on the present infirmary site, 321 East Fifteenth Street, facing Stuyvesant Square All told, 215 general care beds will be provided, doubling the capacity of the present structure.

IN THE year 1540 a dashing young man of 30 set out from Mexico on one of the most elaborate expeditions of discovery and conquest in the history of the Spanish conquistadores. He was the Captain General in command of nearly 350 white soldiers and several hundred Mexican Indian allies, who were actually paid to serve as scouts and herdsmen.

Roland La Starza, undefeated Bronx heavyweight, will face his most serious ring threat Friday night in Madison Square Garden before a gathering which will more closely approximate the palmier days of boxing from latest indications.

With the minor league convention slated for next week in Baltimore and the major league conclaves coming up in New York the week following, baseball affairs in local circles are beginning to perk up sharply.

David N. Lewis, a lawyer, of! New York, was one of three persons nominated last July 28 byl President Trum. an to serve as members of the War Claims Corn-i mission established last year. He had returned only a shoc time before from Germany, wher he had i worked on.civil prosecutions under the United States Attorney Gen-! eral's office.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- High officials of three railroads vigorously refuted today claims of the United States Government that rates on wartime freight were too high. Their testimony was presented during the second day of a hearing before the Interstate Commerce Commission, at which the Department of Justice is seeking refunds from the rail carriers estimated to run to $2,000,000,000.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 29 -- After four years of bitter political debate, the United Nations General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee today asked the International Court of Justice at the Hague for an advisory opinion on whether South Africa could legally absorb South-West Africa in defiance of three United Nations resolutions demanding that the former mandated territory be placed under international trusteeship.
HONG KONG, Wednesday, Nov. 30 (UP) -- A curtain of silence blacked out Chungking early today and it was believed here that Communist occupation of the Nationalists' temporary capital had begun.

Parents of teen-agers, appalled at the drastic changes in their youngsters' personalities, should remind themselves that these individuals, however strange, are not "new people" but products of all the experiences that went before, Mrs. Jean Schick Grossman said yesterday.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was somewhat irregular yesterday and closed 3 points higher to 9 points lower, with the near months relatively stronger than the far months.

Industrialists from foreign chemical industries have started buying new American equipment in record quantities, exhibitors revealed yesterday during the second day of the twenty-second Exposition of Chemical Industries at Grand Central Palace.

A stewardess of an American Airlines plane waved good-by to the last of her passengers at La Guardia Field yesterday -- and then learned that her sister, also an American Airlines stewardess, had died in the crash of a DC-6 at Dallas, Tex.

Two of the chief reasons why the Cleveland Browns dominated the All-America Football Conference in 1949 were the exceptional passing of Otto Graham and the equally brilliant receiving of Mac Speedie. The official statistics, released yesterday, reveal that Graham and Speedie retained their individual championships in their respective specialties, both with record performances.

IT'S probably very much like the hitting art. The law of averages works eventually for the good hitter and it never works for the bad one. So that's probably as reasonable an explanation as any for the incomprehensible selection of Theodore Samuel Williams as the Most Valuable Player in the American League. The Boston slugger batted a cool .406 in 1941 and didn't get it.

The New York Turn Verein will be 100 years old in a little over six months, which brought about a sort of pre-birthday celebration and oratorical kaffee-klatsch for sports, civic and newspaper figures yesterday.
LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 29 -- The United States and France have reached a compromise on the United Nations' new controversial plan for aid to refugees.

Lewis'Copeland, 60 years old,] was president of ' his own firm, [ uopeiand Lamm, Inc., of 18 I East Forty-eighth Street, an edii torial bureau that prepares book !manuscripts for publication, lie Iwas going to Maria, Texas, where ,he had a home, to attend the funeral of his brother-in-law,Mil-'ton Gillet, a cattle rancher of/Vfarfa, who died on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Representative Edwin Arthur Hall, Republican, of New York, announcing plans for a "vigorous campaign'' to win re-election, said today he was taking no chances on a possible defeat.

PANAMA, Nov. 29 -- Business returned to normal in this capital city today, and business is reported normal throughout the Republic, indicating the failure of the general protest strike called by the faculty of the National University.

The charge that American Zionists were trying to influence the Labor Government in Israel through donated funds was denounced as "false and mischievous" last night by Rabbi Abba Hillel Silver, former American chairman of the Jewish Agency for Palestine.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Sawyer said today small business needs some tax relief.

Color appeal to attract women has been added to the motor trucks produced by the International Harvester Company, J. H. Kline, New York district manager, announced yesterday. He said that the vehicles also had increased maneuverability and better load distribution.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Members of a House Judiciary subcommittee heard an insurance company executive concede today that it might be necessary to limit the size of such companies, while another asserted that a limit on size would be "highly detrimental to the American people."

A middle-of-the-road course was pursued yesterday by the stock market in trading on the New York Stock Exchange, although the selling continued heavy and on balance the list lost ground. Cross-currents ruled through the afternoon after a shaky morning with the composite rate reduced 0.12 point on the day.

Prior to the American Airlines DC-6 crash that killed twenty-eight persons at Dallas yesterday, this type of aircraft had flown 162,000,000 miles since the last time it was involved in an accident. Forty-three persons were killed when a United Air Lines DC-6 struck a power line and disintegrated in flames near Mount Carmel, Pa., June 17, 1948.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission has announced that it will start a consolidated hearing here on Dec. 8 on proposed new gas pipe line facilities for Oswego, Onondaga, Madison, Oneida, Fulton and Herkimer Counties, New York.
The Board of Transportation was called upon last night to discuss "immediately" the CIO demands of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, the union announced.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 29 -- Royal Bailey Farnum, consultant to Cooper Union Art School, New York, was re-elected president of the National Association of Schools of Design here this afternoon. The association closed a two-day annual meeting under the auspices of the University of Cincinnati and the Cincinnati Art Academy.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 29 -- Recent developments in sales tax laws indicate a trend toward lower sales tax payments by vending machine operators, members of the National Automatic Merchandising Association heard today.
Germany is fast becoming the major bulwark in Europe against communism, Mayor Max Brauer of Hamburg said on his arrival here yesterday aboard the United States Lines freighter American Merchant.

Jean Chauvel of France said yesterday in the United Nations Assembly debate at Flushing Meadow that Russia had developed a new kind of offensive in offering a pact that she knew would be turned down. He referred to the Soviet proposal for a Big Five peace pact.

Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery declared last night that the nations of the Western European Union could, with American help, secure peace. He warned, however, that the effort might fail unless every participant put it on a "one for all and all for one" basis.

The state of Louisiana sold yesterday an issue of $10,000,000 of highway bonds due from Nov. 1, 1953 to 1964, to Ira Haupt Co. and associates at a bid of 100 for interest rates of 4 per cent, 2 1/2 per cent and 2 1/4 per cent, representing an interest cost of 2.40937 per cent.

WESTVILLE, N. J., Nov. 29 -- The Texas Company formally opened today its new $60,000,000 refinery here when Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll turned a switch to put the plant in operation. Situated on the Delaware River across from Philadelphia, the plant is expected to process about 50,000 barrels daily of foreign-produced crude oil.

One hundred twenty-seven home owners in the vicinity of Seventy-sixth Avenue, Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, pledged to Magistrate Peter M. Horn yesterday that they would install a $4,500 private sewer to eliminate floods in the area.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Frederic D. Vechery, a special agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, detailed to a United States District Court jury today the alleged admissions that brought Representative J. Parnell Thomas, Republican, of New Jersey, to indictment and trial on charges of payroll padding and receiving kickbacks from fictitious employes.

Joan Hammond, the Australian soprano, was the soloist at last night's Philadelphia Orchestra concert at Carnegie Hall, and for this opportunity she owes thanks to Eugene Ormandy, the orchestra's conductor. Her singing last night helped to set at rest doubts about her capacities as an artist that other appearances in this city had raised.

Formation of a committee to help Hampartzoon Cholakian, Armenian shoemaker, to regain custody of his three children who are in two New York Catholic orphanages was announced yesterday by the Rev. Charles A. Vertanes, pastor of the Presbyterian Church of Sweet Hollow, in Farmingdale, L. I.

Prices of steelmaking - grade scrap metal declined $1 to $2 a ton in three major markets yesterday. Quotations by leading dealers were off $1 to $2 in Pittsburgh and Chicago, and down $1.50 in Philadelphia.

PARIS, Nov. 29 -- There was little press reaction and no official reaction in France today to the resolutions adopted at the recent meeting of the Cominform. The content of these resolutions added little to what the French Communist party had been saying in its press, in statements of the labor groups under its control and in the National Assembly.

LAKE SUCCESS; Nov. 29 -- The Soviet Union demanded this afternoon that the United Nations General Assembly go ahead with the plan for the international administration of the Jerusalem area contained in the Palestine partition resolution adopted two years ago today.

From an esteemed authority on home cooking comes further recognition of the practicality and increasing availability of powdered milk. The United States Department of Agriculture has just released a booklet of more than seventy recipes employing this food either in the whole or nonfat (skim) form.

Dr. F. Cyril James, principal and vice chancellor of McGill University, Montreal, advised last night that the problem of adequate hospital facilities was a community's responsibility and that the Government must act wherever the community failed to provide.

Bach always emerges as the hero in any appearance of the Bach Aria Group. And so it was again last night when the ensemble of four singers and five instrumentalists gave the first of three concerts they are presenting at Town Hall in this, their third season in New York.

The Board of Education will undertake a school construction program next year that will average better than two new projects a month, it was announced yesterday by Charles J. Bensley, chairman of the board's committee on buildings and sites.

Underwriting syndicates will place on the market today two new issues of public utility bonds totaling $51,000,000, The obligations represent refunding bonds of the Louisville Gas and Electric Company and the long-term financing of new construction by the Gulf States Utilities Company.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Scoring 13 straigth points in the first three minutes of the third period, the Minneapolis Lakers rallied to defeat the New York Knickerbockers, 102 -- 92, in the National Basketball Association tonight.

The National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, through Capt. C. F. May, national president, and Capt. E. W. Higginbotham, first vice president, yesterday accused Atlantic and Gulf Coast steamship operators with "misstatements of facts and the raising of a completely phony issue in a vain attempt to deprive deck officers of deserved security and employment."
Richmond, Va., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Dec. 14 on $5,280,000 of public improvement bonds dated Jan. 1, 1950, and due on Jan. 1, 1951 to 1970.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Continued strength of British Government issues, coupled with the overthrow of the Labor Government of New Zealand, imparted a more cheerful atmosphere to the stock markets here today.

A concerted action by the New York University Undergraduate Athletic Board and student newspapers to improve the football situation at the university culminated in the release last night of a ten-point program to strengthen athletics. It was stated at a meeting that this program was being forwarded to the Board of Athletic Control as representative of the student body's desires.

New fares, making it possible for travelers on the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad to save 15 1/2 per cent on one-day round trip coach tickets, as compared with previous coach fares, went into effect on the line yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 30 -- A dinner tonight honoring the former presidents of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards marked the opening of the thirty-third annual convention of the association.
With a long look toward the sunny South, Carolyn Schnurer drew upon her imagination for the gay array of resort fashions shown yesterday at the Pierre Hotel.
PARIS, Nov. 30 -- Can Western Europe be defended against potential Soviet aggression on a line based on the Elbe River, and if so can this be done without establishing a West German Army?

For the third day in succession John L. Lewis yesterday postponed for another twenty-four hours the meeting of the United Mine Workers policy committee originally scheduled to take place here on Monday. By the time that session convenes, even if there should be no further postponement, the deadline in the coal truce will have passed, and most of the 400,000 bituminous miners affected will have left their jobs again.

Classes in practical nursing will meet for the last time today in the Ballard School of the Central Branch of the Young Women's Christian Association, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-third Street, where the course will be discontinued after a review of the last nine months of study.

Chairman Gabrielson of the Republican National Committee is seeking advice from party ranks as to whether there should be a restatement of Republican principles in advance of next year's Congressional elections. For this purpose he is inviting all Republican Governors, state and county leaders and National Committee members to tell him whether they think such a declaration should be made, and, if so, what it should say.

The three five-story apartment houses at 2735, 2741 and 2747 Sedgwick Avenue, the Bronx, have been sold by T. Victor Searing and William Reiner to the 2735 Sedgwick Corporation. Alan Brothers were the brokers and Herman Brothers represented the purchaser. Joseph Howard Katz was attorney for the sellers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- A Senate Labor subcommittee, with a recently recruited staff, is preparing a preliminary report on experiences with the Taft-Hartley law. The purpose is to obtain a large appropriation for a full-scale investigation in 1950.

Bellevue Hospital presented service stripes yesterday to thirty "substitute mothers" who have spent between seventy-five and 1,000 hours administering large doses of "tender, loving care" to patients in the children's wards.

First exhibits of new equipment vital to atomic energy production and to commercial use of radioactive materials attracted large crowds at the third day of the 22nd Exposition of Chemical Industries at Grand Central Palace yesterday.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 30 -- The integration of Western European economy is the "single greatest threat" to Russia's plan for world conquest, Paul G. Hoffman, head of the Economic Cooperation Administration, declared here tonight.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 30 -- Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett told the United Nations today that even if his country did accept a solution for the problem of Jerusalem, it could not accept responsibility for the reaction of the populace of the city to internationalization.

HONG KONG, Nov. 30 -- Chungking fell today. Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek fled his recently established Nationalist capital a step ahead of an estimated 20,000 Chinese Communists. Reliable sources in Taipei, Formosa, the Generalissimo's island headquarters, said Chungking was lost shortly before noon (11 P. M., EST., Tuesday).

Two weeks ago a squadron of dissidents within the National Maritime Union, CIO, led by some New York port officials who had been suspended by the national office, stormed the union building and seized control. If they had legitimate cause they thus forfeited the right to plead it. As for the union leadership, there is some evidence, the validity of which cannot now be determined, that it has resorted to dictatorial procedures.

FAREWELLS to the Forties will soon fill the air. In the coming months all sorts of books will sum up, from all sorts of points of view, these ten most violent years in the history of the world. Ten spectacularly unquiet years that began with what was called a phony war and are ending in what is decidedly a phony kind of peace.

Perhaps the butcher arraigned in Mid-Manhattan Court yesterday had misapplied the advice of a British treasurer of long, long ago. What the Englishman said was that if you take care of the pennies, the pounds will take care of themselves. But he was not thinking of capons.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- An organized Democratic campaign is afoot, it became known today, to offset anti-Administration implications drawn from the recent meeting of the Southern Governors Conference at Biloxi, Miss.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The rush into public discussion of what role, if any, Western Germans should have in the defense of their state and the Continent against possible aggression from Soviet Russia was sudden but inevitable. Ever since the beginning of World War II statesmen and military leaders of the nations then arrayed or arraying against Germany, Italy and Japan have been pondering this question, which poses every complex issue of modern times.
MUNICH, Germany, Nov. 24 -- The newspapers of Bavaria, once relied upon to speed the democratization of the state, today reflect its "renazification."

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 30 -- Governors of the Missouri River Valley states set out today to find an alternative to the valley authority type of administration for the vast Federal-state development program under way in the basin.

Suspected of a series of liquor store hold-ups, two men and a woman were arraigned in Bronx Magistrate's Court yesterday afternoon before Magistrate Hyman Bushel on charges of assault and robbery in connection with the hold-up on Nov. 4 of Irving Rosen, proprietor of a liquor store at 1997 University Avenue, the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Defense Department sharply curbed today the participation of military aircraft in public air demonstrations, races and minor patriotic celebrations.
Revival of a strong market abroad for American office machines and systems equipment was reported yesterday by Marcell N. Rand, general manager of the export division of Remington Rand, Inc.
SOFIA, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Besides the accusations against Mr. Kostov and his ten co-defendants, the indictment published here today said the following nine men had been drawn into criminal activities:

Diversity marked the record of new financing here in November. Offerings of bonds fell to the lowest figure since May, while stock emissions were the heaviest since June. Compared with a year ago, the movements also were irregular, with bond flotations smaller and stock offerings larger.

Dust finally having settled on the recent controversial selection of Ted Williams as the American League's most valuable player for 1949, the Baseball Writers Association yesterday made known its vote on the year's outstanding rookie in each major league and with one of these selections the scribes doubtless stirred up another hornets' nest.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- Breaking into the American market with competing British merchandise had been given top priority "just as winning the war was," the top Cabinet Minister directing England's trade and export drive declared today.

Racing executives from the thirty-five tracks that make up the Thoroughbred Racing Associations opened their annual meeting at the Hotel Plaza yesterday. They heard an optimistic report from the T. R. A. president, Donald P. Ross of Delaware Park, reaffirmed their stand against night horse racing, elected a new director, saw a movie about the Kentucky Derby and then adjourned for cocktails.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Coast Guard is about to drop two of its weather-ship stations in the Atlantic and add a third to the two it now maintains in the Pacific.

John F. Brennan, T. A. Monroe and Giles C. Stedman have been elected vice presidents of the United States Lines at a meeting of the line's board of directors, it was announced here yesterday by John M. Franklin, president.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Nov. 30 -- John J. McCloy United States High Commissioner, attributed the rise in nationalism in Germany today to improved conditions and "a sense of well-being" since the end of the war. He carefully differentiated, however, between "healthy patriotism" and "sinister nationalism."
The first group of 108 specially designed motor coaches to take medical and dental services to 100,000 children in poor rural areas of Cuba are nearly ready for shipment, it was learned yesterday.

MENLO PARK, N. J., Nov. 30 -- New Jersey's new diagnostic center where the knowledge of medicine, psychiatry and psychology will be combined to aid the wrong-doer was dedicated here today in a ceremony presided over by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll and attended by 500 persons from all parts of the state.

The poets sat on the sidelines last night while statesmen, business leaders and writers of prose recited. The occasion was the fifteenth anniversary dinner of the Academy of American Poets, an organization devoted to assisting poets through fellowship awards.

Coming after four consecutive months of rising prices, November, although finishing on a somewhat uncertain note stock-market-wise, gave a much better account of itself than in recent years. As measured by THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks, the market had a negligible rise of only 0.73 point, the smallest change in the index since 1942.

Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan ordered the Government yesterday to show cause on Monday why he should not suppress any evidence in the Coplon-Gubitchev spy case that was obtained by wiretapping and void the indictment if it was founded on such information.

There was a slightly tense moment at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last evening when Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery faced 1,100 Americans of Scottish descent and declared, "I come from Ireland, where most of the best people come from."

Increasing concern over current social issues, with less emphasis on technical problems, is reflected in the program of the seventieth annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers at the Statler Hotel this week.

Effective today, the realty business conducted under the name of the Pettit-Waterman Company has been reorganized under the name of H. E. Pettit Co. and retains its offices at 12 East Forty-first Street. Howard E. Pettit announced yesterday. Mr. Pettit heads the mortgage department, while William A. Kaufman is in charge of sales and commercial leases.

CHICAGO, Nov 30 -- Evening-up operations combined with scattered liquidation by holders of December contracts for grains resulted in irregular grain markets on the Board of Trade here today. December and July wheat and December and May oats sold at new seasonal high prices before reacting.

An old friend appeared in new dress at a cooking demonstration yesterday in the local kitchen of General Mills at 588 Fifth Avenue That company's Bisquick was employed for the first time to produce home-baked cookies. Since the preparation was introduced in the Nineteen Thirties its main use has been in hot breads.
Salient points of Whittaker Chambers' testimony on his prewar relations with Alger Hiss were corroborated yesterday by sixteen Government witnesses who followed Mr. Chambers on the stand.

The Hundred Year Association made a happy selection in choosing to honor this year Dean Millicent Carey McIntosh of Barnard College. Mrs. McIntosh received the association's annual gold medal for achievement in the interests of the City of New York, but she amply deserved a medal also for living two lives simultaneously and well.
KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 30 -- As the deadline for resumption of the coal strike approached tonight, the White House in winter quarters here was playing its cards as closely as John L. Lewis.

Plans for twelve and fifteen-story parking garages on two mid-Manhattan sites were announced yesterday in connection with the passing of titles to the property to the Municipal Realty Corporation, which insured the titles with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

MANILA, Nov. 30 -- President Elpidio Quirino by executive order imposed a drastic tightening of import controls on luxury and semi-luxury merchandise averaging around a 90 per cent reduction on controlled items already affected by a comparatively moderate system imposed a year ago.

A. Phillip Sweet, as agent for the Lycia Realty Corporation, sold the one-story taxpayer at 290-300 Merrick Road, corner of Forest Avenue, in Lynbrook, L. I., to the Manufacturers Shoulderpad Corporation. The property was held at $125,000 and was sold subject to a first mortgage of $62,000. David Feldman was attorney for the seller and Maxwell Slote acted for the buyer.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 30 -- Plans for the United Nations delegation building, slated to be the final unit in the skyscraper capitol along the East River in Manhattan, have been indefinitely deferred, it was learned today. The plans, which had looked to a $22,500,000 structure, may be ultimately scrapped, it was indicated, for lack of prospective tenants.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- President and Mrs. Truman are going to have room for extra guests when they move back into a safe and modern White House in late 1951. There also will be space to store all those things that some people don't like to throw away.

The surprising defeat of the Labor party in the New Zealand elections has set political headquarters and chancelleries all over the world buzzing with speculation. The British Labor party has naturally had a bad shock, and the effect in Australia, where a general election is to be held on Dec. 10 and where another Labor Government is in power, must have been even greater.

The recital given by Ruggiero Ricci, the violinist, last night in Carnegie Hall testified particularly to his phenomenal equipment as an executant and the catholicity of his taste in program making. For it is seldom that a program so inclusive and so meaty is offered at a violin recital today.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 30 -- The new central research laboratory of American Optical Company was officially opened here today by the company's board of trustees and distinguished guests who participated in a luncheon and inspection tour.

Union pickets marched for three hours yesterday morning outside a Brooklyn church in protest against what they thought was a non-union painting job going on inside, only to learn that it was being done on a voluntary basis by a father and son, both painters, but long-time parishioners of the church.

Coach Earl Blaik of Army strongly endorsed use of the two-platoon system and at the same time denied that he considered the United States Military Academy a "football power," during a lengthy open forum discussion yesterday after his acceptance of the August V. Lambert Memorial Trophy.

Dr. James T. Shotwell, president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, was honored last night at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to mark the tenth anniversary of the Commission to Study the Organization of Peace.

An increase last week of 1,537.000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. Total supplies at the week-end were 104,917,000 barrels, against 103,380,000 a week earlier and 93,802,000 a year ago.

The New York State Commission Against Discrimination announced yesterday an investigation of private fee - charging employment agencies here to determine whether their policies involve discrimination because of race, creed, color or national origin.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Charges that the Air Force intends to eliminate the Air National Guard by attrition, if it cannot control it, were laid before a mixed committee of Regular and National Guard officers here today by Maj. Gen. E. A. Walsh, president of the National Guard Association.

NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 30 (AP) -- The water shortage in New Jersey reached the crisis stage today with one Monmouth County community completely dry and a Passaic County reservoir down to a sixty-day supply.

A portrait of the late Dr. Frederick Tilney, Professor of Neurology at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, and medical director of the Neurological Institute, was presented to the Neurological Institute yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UP) -- A message from President Truman calling for use of air power as a force for peace will be flown around the world in connection with ceremonies honoring the Wright brothers, founders of modern aviation.

Officials of the Textile Workers Union, CIO, decided officially yesterday not to reopen contracts covering 90,000 of its members employed in woolen and worsted mills in New England and the Middle Atlantic States.
FLEMINGTON, N. J., Nov. 30 -- Today has been a special occasion in eight one-room rural schools around here. This was marked by the daily bulletin on the blackboard at the Copper Hill School:
Arts and crafts from the workshops of Israel are now on display at the Palestine Galleries at 2 Park Avenue prior to going on sale at Abraham Straus in Brooklyn on Dec. 12.

A budget of $3,146,000 for 1950 was announced yesterday by the Advisory Council of the American Bible Society, which ended a two-day session of its thirty-first annual meeting yesterday afternoon with officers of the society at Bible House, Fifty-seventh Street and Park Avenue.

Representatives of seventeen of the country's leading law schools will complete before a "moot Supreme Court" in a two-day contest sponsored by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, opening today at the Bar Association Building at 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Army will soon take delivery on a light tank of new design that will immediately be assigned to reconnaissance units of divisions, Gen. J. Lawton Collins, Army Chief of Staff, disclosed today.
LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 30 -- An official of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund gave assurances today that the global relief agency expected to continue its welfare operations.

Prices of stocks held steady yesterday, despite the lack of news during trading hours as to a decision by John L. Lewis concerning a meeting of his organization's policy board. Although there were fears that the mine workers' leader might allow the soft-coal truce to expire, thus automatically halting production, the market on the New York Stock Exchange showed no undue concern and inched ahead or held its ground through most of the session.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Representative J. Parnell Thomas, Republican, of New Jersey, suddenly withdrew in Federal District Court here today his plea of not guilty to charges of payroll padding and receiving kick-backs from fictitious employes.

The contemplated lowering of water pressure throughout the city can be deferred until about Jan. 1 only if the public cuts consumption to less than 1,000,000,000 gallons daily, Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, said yesterday.

Prospects are now considered good this year for topping 1948's record high total of advertising expenditures, a check of key sources indicated yesterday. Last year's total is variously estimated at between $4 and $4.5 billions. It is believed that new record high ad spending will continue through 1950.

A prophetic view of fashions for resort and spring was given to an assemblage of 1,700 women at noon yesterday in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The occasion was a membership luncheon of the Women's American ORT (Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training) of the New York region.

Distributing bumps and heavy body checks with unusual vigor, the New York Rangers made their homecoming a successful one at Madison Square Garden last night. They met the Canadiens of Montreal and surprised a crowd of 12,636 fans by sending the Flying Frenchmen down to defeat by the score of 5 to 2.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 30 -- A comprehensive zoning guide to assist laymen and zoning technicians in cities of 10,000 population or less, believed by its compilers to be the first of its kind, was made public today by the Southern Association of State Planning and Development Agencies.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange inched upward in moderate trading yesterday and closed 2 to 9 points net higher.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- A three-judge Federal Court today ordered the Civil Aeronautics Board to hold up action on the request of a Canadian airline for a new route in this country.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Nov. 30 -- An indictment was published today accusing Traicho Kostov, long a leader of the Bulgarian Communist party and former Deputy Premier, of having plotted to overthrow the present regime, in association with Premier Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia and United States and British agents.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Winston Churchill sauntered into the House of Commons today -- his seventy-fifth birthday anniversary -- and interrupted a bickering interrogation of ministers by Opposition members.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- United States labor leaders representing more than 14,000,000 members of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations won the backing today of virtually the entire Free World Labor Conference in their fight to include numerous European Catholic trade unions in the common front against communism.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 30 -- The mayors of several hundred American cities, after subjecting themselves to an afternoon of critical self-analysis, demanded today a greater share of highway revenues to end what they called "the present gross inequities" that discriminated against municipalities.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30 -- The defense tried to show a Federal Court jury today that "instructions" were borne from Communist party leaders to Harry R. Bridges in the Nineteen Thirties by John H. Schomaker not because Mr. Bridges was a Communist but because Mr. Schomaker, the "messenger," was both a Communist and a longshore union member.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- The air-transportation industry has emerged from its post-war doldrums, is completing its first year of universally sound and profitable business since the end of World War II, and through broad application of lower-fare air-coach travel in 1950 it expects to offer the greatest mass service in history.

The State of Israel can become "a true bastion of Western civilization" only if it manages to avoid the "nationalist impulses" that have marred the history of Europe in the last two centuries, Sir Norman Angell, British author and Nobel Peace Prize winner in 1933, declared here yesterday.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Prague's Municipal Council announced today that no new labor would be allowed to private enterprise.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 30 (AP) -- Five Northern stars and one Southerner were added to Blue-Gray rolls today. This leaves four vacancies for the annual all-star football game Dec. 31.

New York State moved yesterday to dissolve a local "mail-order diploma mill" charged with having peddled hundreds of higher education degrees in the last two years to "students" in this country, Puerto Rico and Mexico.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 30 -- Varied college programs, more emphasis on citizenship training and experience and more personal contact between student and teacher were called for today at the annual Conference on Higher Education of the University of Michigan.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Thursday, Dec. 1 -- The defeat of the New Zealand Labor Government is not helpful to Australia's Labor forces, political observers here remarked today. Although the Ministers here insisted the Nationalists' victory in New Zealand has no significance for Australia, the Labor party has always conceded that a Labor reverse in New Zealand would diminish its prospect of success in the Australia elections of Dec. 10.

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 30 -- Camden's Mayor, George E. Brunner, slapped back at the city of Philadelphia with a $1,000 libel action today as a counter claim to the Quaker City's suit against him for $948 growing out of the controversial George Ross "wage tax martyr" case.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Erie Railroad announced today that a leave of absence had been given to Harold D. Barber and that he would be replaced by Raymond C. Randall as vice president for operations and maintenance. Paul W. Johnston, new president of the railroad, made the announcement.
Traffic congestion costs New York "upwards of $300,000,000 yearly," Harold Riegelman, counsel of the Citizens Budget Commission, estimated yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 -- The new anti-Communist electrical union set up by the Congress of Industrial Organizations carried forward its campaign of resistance to judicial "harassment" today by demanding that the courts stop allowing Communists to "avail themselves of the protection of a government and legal system which they openly despise."

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Nov. 30 -- Mrs. Fannie P. Dudgeon, 50 years old, an active social, civic, and political worker who was convicted of bookmaking in Nassau County Court at Mineola in 1945, was arrested on a similar charge again today.

A taxpayer site on Nostrand Avenue near the Nostrand and Sheepshead housing developments in Brooklyn has been assembled for the Herbor Realty Corporation of which Sam Borden is president.
