The buyer, which owned the adjoining plot of 200 feet on Nostrand Avenue by 110 feet on Avenue U. acquired a parcel fronting 130 feet on Nostrand Avenue and 105 feet deep from Oliver Bello through Slomka Brothers, Inc., brokers.

WELLINGTON, N. Z., Nov. 30 -- Speaking after the result of the poll had become clear, Prime Minister Fraser said today that Labor had always believed in democracy and that it accepted the decision with good grace. Labor in opposition, he said, will cooperate with the Government in internal and external policy to protect the welfare of the people.

Christmas and the circus, normally some four months apart, were neatly tied together by Gimbels last night at a reception for toy manufacturers in the midst of a children's wonderland on its newly designed sixth floor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Treasury today offered four-and-a-quarter-year notes paying 1 3/8 per cent interest in exchange for $4,694,253,150 in debt certificates and bonds falling due on Dec. 15.
The United States is headed "straight down that road to British ruin" unless more believers in private enterprise take an interest in politics, Governor Dewey declared yesterday.

MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L. I., Nov. 30 -- A speed-up in all phases of air defense has been accomplished by the Air Force's Air Continental Command since its establishment on Dec. 1, 1948, it was reported today at the command's headquarters here. The aniversary of the founding wil be celebrated tomorrow.

New orders booked by furniture factories in October decreased 14 per cent compared with the preceding month but increased 15 per cent as against the like month last year, according to the monthly report issued yesterday by Seidman Seidman, accountants for many leading furniture manufacturers.

Two new films will open in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Criterion, the attraction is "The Story of Molly X," starring June Havoc, John Russell and Dorothy Hart. The Universal-International melodrama, which was written and directed by Crane Wilbur and produced by Aaron Rosenberg, features Connie Gilchrist, Cathy Lewis, Charles McGraw and Sara Berner.

PARIS, Nov. 30 -- The abolition of the French Commissariat of Supplies by the end of the year and the immediate freeing of the last remaining supplies on the ration list was approved at a Cabinet meeting late tonight.

Joint action by British and American producers of textiles must be taken to assure markets for surplus output of the two countries, according to Sir Raymond Streat, chairman, British Cotton Board. Textile sellers, he said, should guard against commercial upheavals that will destroy buyer confidence in world markets.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- A recommendation that the United States assume no more than 25 per cent of the total contributions by countries to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations was placed before FAO delegates here today.

The sixteenth consecutive collegiate basketball season at Madison Square Garden will be ushered in tonight, with Texas A. and M. of the Southwestern Conference facing Long Island University, and Vanderbilt, Southeastern representative, meeting New York University.
Gene Burton, Harlem contender for the welterweight title, knocked out Roy Carter, the Bronx, in the seventh round of their scheduled ten-round battle last night at the St. Nicholas Arena.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The sixteenth National Conference on Labor Legislation today recommended "an over-all Federal temporary disability insurance law."

PARIS, Nov. 30 -- The general plan drafted in Washington for an "integrated" collective defense of the area covered by the North Atlantic treaty -- slightly modified as a result of the meetings here Monday and Tuesday of the Chiefs of Staff of the member nations -- is expected to be finally approved by the Defense Committee under the pact here tomorrow.
ROME, Ga., Nov. 30 (UP) -- A former Ku Klux Klansman today supported the testimony of Negro flogging victims that Sheriff John W. Lynch of Dade County helped a hooded mob abduct the Negroes.

Confident of Mayor O'Dwyer's complete recovery, Deputy Mayor John J. Bennett and William J. Donoghue, executive secretary to the Mayor, began yesterday to lay plans for an inaugural ceremony on Jan. 2 to mark the start of his second administration.
The controversial "One World" mural at New York University's School of Education has been returned to the student lounge from which it was removed last Wednesday, it was learned yesterday.

The Labor party in New Zealand has been in power since 1935, when the Labor Government took over under the Premiership of M. J. Savage after having defeated a coalition government headed by George W. Forbes.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Nov. 30 (AP) -- Tropical Park today launched South Florida's colorful 122-day winter racing season before a crowd of 11,201.

Mayor O'Dwyer's physicians announced yesterday that his condition was "somewhat worse than we thought," showing "a very definite heart strain" in addition to an upper respiratory infection and a fever. A bulletin issued at 1:45 P. M. by Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, his personal physician, after consultation with Dr. Clarence de la Chapelle, heart specialist, indicated that the Mayor would have to remain in Bellevue Hospital for at least two more weeks.

Arthur Imerman, treasurer of Tammany, and Charles D. Gilbert, treasurer of the Queens County Democratic organization, are the opposing candidates for president of the National Democratic Club. The election will be held from 5 to 10 P. M. next Tuesday.
Currency inflation and other factors are aiding communism in Japan, Joseph C. Grew, former Ambassador to Japan, said in an address here last night.

WARSAW, Nov. 30 -- One of the chief functions of Andre Simon Robineau, former assistant at the French consulate in Szczecin [Stettin], was gathering and reporting information about Soviet troop movements in Szczecin Province, the Polish Government declared today.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- J. Arthur Rank, Britain's leading film producer and exhibitor, reiterated today that regular, systematic production of motion pictures in this country might cease unless the industry received some relief from the entertainment tax.

ROME, Nov. 30 -- A twenty-four-hour national general strike has been proclaimed for tomorrow by the Communist-dominated Italian Confederation of Labor to protest against the death of three workers in a clash with the police in the Province of Foggia yesterday.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

The Seaboard Western Airlines, Inc., have leased for their main offices in New York City the fourth floor of 80 Broad Street with more than 10,000 square feet of space, according to Schlang Bros. Co., brokers, who said the lease is for ten years.
For the first time since development of nuclear fission, metallic uranium will be stocked and sold in New York at a standard price of $50 a pound, beginning this month.

A series of gigantic jig-saw puzzles in the form of fragments of fifth century B.C. Egyptian papyri that have taken months to piece together were shown yesterday in the final stages of completion in a laboratory of the Brooklyn Museum.
HONG KONG, Nov. 30 -- In assuming the administration of conquered Szechwan, the Communists are taking on the toughest job they have tackled anywhere in China.
ALBANY, Nov. 30 -- The State Health Department revealed today that nearly 1,250,000 babies will have been born in the state during the four post-war years, 1946 through 1949.

The latest product from the drafting board of one of the most famous of contemporary chair makers, Alvar Aalto, has arrived from Finland and was unpacked just in time for the opening of the new Finsven showroom at 870 Madison Avenue yesterday.

OTTAWA, Thursday, Dec. 1 -- Colonial Airlines, which operates between Montreal and New York, will be notified today of an order to appear before the Air Transport Board of Canada in Ottawa Dec. 12 to show cause why its license should not be suspended.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 30 -- John C. Ross, United States representative, announced today that the United States would contribute "a fair share" toward a $54,900,000 fund under which a new United Nations agency would provide jobs on public works projects and direct relief for Arabs who have fled from Israeli territory.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared today that the firing on United States merchant ships by Chinese Nationalist warships off Shanghai was a violation of the legal rights of the United States. He added, however, that vessels entering those waters did so at their own risk.
There has been a great deal of talk in recent months about alleviating the traffic situation in New York. Like the weather, everyone talks about it, but nobody does anything about it.

A jury in Federal Court, Brooklyn, disagreed last night in the case of Isadore Ginsberg, Queens attorney and alleged post-war "gray marketeer" in building materials, charged with using the mails to defraud prospective purchasers of building materials. The seven women and five men, who began deliberating at 11 A. M., returned to the court room at 8:30 P. M. to inform Judge Leo Rayfiel that they could not reach a verdict.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 30 -- Gov. Chester Bowles and Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat, of Connecticut, reached a "complete agreement" today on the proposed appointment of William Benton of Southport to the Senate.
In a newly installed and streamlined system, the New York Public Library will process 1,000 new books a day for its branches, eliminating a week's wait for readers, it was announced yesterday.

Lenin's theory that it is impossible for communism and capitalism to exist side by side for any length of time in the same world, that sooner or later one or the other must go down, and that before that end supervenes the most frightful collisions will occur between the two systems still is the cardinal principle of Soviet political doctrine.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in November fell somewhat below that of October as a result of the holidays, but the turnover was the smallest for a corresponding month since 1947.

The New York Central and the New York, New Haven Hartford railroads announced yesterday that they had agreed to make a new twenty-five year lease for the South Station in Boston, subject to the approval of the Interstate Commerce Commission and the Federal courts. Under the proposed plan, the claim of the bondholders of the present Boston Terminal Company would be liquidated and a new terminal company formed.

The New York Philharmonic Orchestra may appear at the Edinburgh Festival in 1950, Sir Andrew Murray, Lord Provost of Edinburgh, announced yesterday in his capacity as chairman of the Edinburgh Festival Society. Sir Andrew, who is on a good-will tour of the United States, has invited the orchestra to perform at the festival and said that it would participate if success attends negotiations already initiated.

Consolidated net income of the Liquid Carbonic Corporation for the fiscal year ended with last September was $1,224,062, or $1.09 each on 888,505 common shares outstanding, the annual report revealed yesterday. Net income for the preceding year was $2,747,906 or $3.01 a share on 828,100 common shares then outstanding.

Jackie Robinson and Roy Campanella, Brooklyn Dodgers baseball stars, were among 230 persons present last night at the ninth annual dinner of the Century Club of the Harlem Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, 180 West 135th Street.
LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The possibility of increasing Italy's military production through the use of United States military aid funds is being explored by officials of both countries.
TRENTON, N. J., Nov. 30 (AP) -- Governor Driscoll was informed today that it was his duty to call a special election if a vacancy occurred in the Congressional post now held by Representative Thomas.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- The news of Labor's defeat in New Zealand was hailed here this afternoon by Lord Beaverbrook's Evening Standard with the headline "New Zealand Leads Way: Throws the Socialists Out."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Declaring that the United States needed "the combined contributions of both big and small business," Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company, warned today that it would be "a most serious, catastrophic error" for the Government to limit the area in which these units exist.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- A spokesman for the Department of Agriculture testified today that farmers had been bearing the brunt of lower food prices while profits of middlemen remained about constant.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30 (AP) -- San Francisco's pro football Forty-Niners today threatened to strike unless guaranteed a $500 bonus per player for meeting the New York Yankees in an All-America Conference play-off game here Sunday.
Twenty-nine persons were injured yesterday at 7:40 A. M. when two interurban buses crashed at Thirty-fifth Street and Dyer Avenue, near the Lincoln Tunnel exit.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Justice Department today pressed the Supreme Court for a decision on the Government's suits against Texas and Louisiana over submerged oil lands.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 30 -- The conference of United States Middle Eastern diplomats, which closed here today, has approved for relations with the Arab nations the policy worked out by Gordon Clapp, chairman of the board of the Tennessee Valley Authority, and his associates in the United Nations Middle Eastern Survey Mission.

The first American biography of Marshal Tito, "Whirlwind: Tito's Rise to Power," is planned for publication by the Philosophical Library on Jan. 31 to commemorate the fourth anniversary of Yugoslavia's becoming a federated republic. The author is Stephen Clissold, British press attache in Belgrade.
Three seamen were arrested yesterday in an altercation arising out of the two-week rebellion that has split the National Maritime Union, CIO, into two factions.

TORONTO, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Manager Conny Smythe of the Toronto Maple Leafs of the National Hockey League today announced the purchase of goaltender Al Rollins from the Cleveland Barons of the American Hockey League, just a day after he benched Leaf goalie Turk Broda for being overweight.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 30 -- The waning fortunes of Belgium's Communists have led the party to abandon some of its separate trade union organizations, according to evidence now available here. A new tactic of attempting to infiltrate the Socialist trade union movement has apparently begun.
C. Duffield Clarke has been named manager of national accounts and head of a newly organized vending machine division of the Charles E. Hires Company.

The women's handbag industry is becoming concerned over the possibility of a flood of foreign imports, it was reported here yesterday by A. Mittenthal, co-director of the National Authority for the Ladies' Handbag Industry.

BUFFALO, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers lost one round and won another today in two legal skirmishes with the new International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO.

After three weeks of deliberation and laboratory tests in Boston and New York, the jury of experts appointed by the Metropolitan Museum to rule on the authenticity of the controversial painting "Study by Candlelight," attributed to Vincent van Gogh, submitted a signed report, it became known yesterday, refusing to accept the painting as an original.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Army will start to release tomorrow the first of 30,000 men who were inducted or recruited under the Selective Service Act of 1948. First to be released will be the men who were drafted or volunteered in the Army's first call for 10,000 men m November, 1948.

In a setting of Union Jacks, American flags and Christmas gift merchandise, Lady Franks, wife of the British Ambassador to the United States, opened yesterday the twenty-ninth annual bazaar of the Daughters of the British Empire in the ballroom of the Biltmore Hotel.

All employers subject to the new state disability benefits law are being warned by the Workmen's Compensation Board that, starting Jan. 1, a new payroll deduction must be made to establish a special insurance fund for benefits to disabled unemployed wage earners.

Daniel Frisch, president of the Zionist Organization of America, charged yesterday that anti-Zionists in this country were advocating "regimentation rather than Americansim" in their efforts to prevent aid for the economic reconstruction of Israel and the revival of Jewish culture here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- A spokesman for thirty-eight shipper, industrial and agricultural organizations today joined the railroads in opposition to Government demands that the rail carriers refund about $2,000,000,000 on income from wartime shipments.

When John Haynes Holmes retired as pastor of the Community Church on the eve of his seventieth birthday, he brought to a close forty-two years in the ministry that have been distinguished by idealism, humanitarianism and courage. With zest Mr. Holmes has entered into the controversies of the day; and it was natural that his outspoken views -- particularly his uncompromising pacifism -- should have aroused sharp antagonism.

Resumption of trading in tin and lead at an "early date" was recommended to the board of governors of the Commodity Exchange yesterday by the organization's metals group committee. If approved by the board of governors, that body will fix the dates upon which futures trading in the two metals will be revived.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 23:
Yugoslavia used the rostrum of the United Nations General Assembly yesterday to defy the Communist Information Bureau and accuse it of threatening the peace and independence of small countries.
Notre Dame's all - conquering football legions placed three men on The Associated Press 1949 All-America, a domination surpassed in recent years only by Army's contribution of five in 1945.

TOKYO, Nov. 30 -- The Netherland reparations account with Japan has been closed. The final shipments have been loaded aboard the Dutch ship Tjimenteng, which is scheduled to depart before the week-end.

CORNWALL, Conn., Nov. 30 -- Back in the late Nineteen Twenties and early Thirties, Connecticut, oddly enough, was one of the leading states in the field of skiing. The popularity and fame of such areas as Salisbury, Winsted and Norfolk spread far and wide as pioneers, like the Satre brothers, the Holtvedts, Sorensens and Torrissens, labored uncermoniously at the comparatively unknown activity.

A group approach to instruction in child care will be used to supplement the present methods employed at child health centers conducted by the Health Department, according to Dr. Samuel Wishik, director of this service.

A request by the Amateur Fencers League of America that Columbia University's two Negro fencers be kept from A.F.L.A. competition led to the withdrawal yesterday of Columbia's fencing team from all future competition in the league.
HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 30 (AP) -- Negro colleges and schools of the South, for the first time, sought membership today in the Southern Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 30 -- Dr. James R. Killian Jr., president of Massachusetts Institute of Technology, announced today that the Standard Oil Company of California had made a grant-in-aid totaling $250,000 to support the institute's research program.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, declared last night that too much emphasis was being placed on personal security at the expense of individual liberty, and said the current definition of a "liberal" seemed to be "a man in Washington who wants to play the Almighty with your money."

SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia, Nov. 30 -- The trial of twelve White Russian emigres accused of espionage on behalf of the Soviet intelligence service and acts of hostility against Yugoslavia is scheduled to begin tomorrow at 8 A. M. before the People's Court in this city. This is the capital of the People's Republic of Bosnia-Herzegovina, one of the constituent republics of the Yugoslav federation.

Coffee futures prices rallied yesterday in early dealings on demand from local trade and producing interests, but the support was not strong enough to maintain the market advance. Later in the day commission house selling and trade hedging found support on a scale down and most of the early gains were lost.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Consumers Cooperative Association, Kansas City, Mo., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $2,000,000 of five-year, 3 1/2 per cent certificates of indebtedness and $3,000,000 of ten-year, 4 1/2 per cent certificates of indebtedness.

Allow me to express my congratulations to you for the sincere and sentimental article which appeared in Topics of The Times for Nov. 23. I have read it with delight, especially as a newcomer to this wonderful city, in which I will stay a few months.

The Hercules Powder Company announced yesterday a year-end dividend of $1.25 on the common stock, payable on Dec. 21. This increases the 1949 disbursements to $2.60 a share from last year's payments of $2.25.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- A survey by the National Education Association of the status of public schools in the current year, published today, showed two basic shortages -- too few grade school teachers and too few schoolhouses.

Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company is sold up for three months in wanted patterns of wide width twist and Wilton carpeting, C. C. Denebrink, vice president for sales, reported yesterday. He attributed the situation to heavy retail orders received between Nov. 11, when the company announced that its mill prices would be increased, and Nov. 21, when the increases became effective.

The Citizens Housing and Planning Council of New York announced yesterday that it had urged Mayor O'Dwyer to appoint a "courageous, experienced administrator" as chairman of the City Planning Commission on Jan. 1, when Robert F. Wagner Jr., present chairman, becomes Borough President of Manhattan.

The fourth stoppage in the nation's soft coal industry in 1949 became effective at 12:01 A. M. today as 400,000 miners struck after the expiration of a three-week truce in their walkout first begun last Sept. 19.

Harry Berse of the Louis Silverman Company has been elected president of the National Notion Association, it was announced yesterday. Also elected were: Aaron Traum of the David Traum Company, first vice president; A. J. Donahue Jr. of the Donahue Sales Corporation, second vice president; Charles F. Pitt of Poirier Lindeman Company, treasurer; and Arthur I. Mellin of the Notion and Novelty Review, executive secretary.

BERLIN, Nov. 30 -- The conscription of young Germans into the Soviet zone "people's police" began four weeks ago, according to residents of that area who have visited Berlin during the last few days. The campaign was integrated with a wave of dismissals of such youths from employment, they say.

Allow me to express my congratulations to you for the sincere and sentimental article which appeared in Topics of The Times for Nov. 23. I have read it with delight, especially as a newcomer to this wonderful city, in which I will stay a few months.

The Hercules Powder Company announced yesterday a year-end dividend of $1.25 on the common stock, payable on Dec. 21. This increases the 1949 disbursements to $2.60 a share from last year's payments of $2.25.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- A survey by the National Education Association of the status of public schools in the current year, published today, showed two basic shortages -- too few grade school teachers and too few schoolhouses.

Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company is sold up for three months in wanted patterns of wide width twist and Wilton carpeting, C. C. Denebrink, vice president for sales, reported yesterday. He attributed the situation to heavy retail orders received between Nov. 11, when the company announced that its mill prices would be increased, and Nov. 21, when the increases became effective.

The Citizens Housing and Planning Council of New York announced yesterday that it had urged Mayor O'Dwyer to appoint a "courageous, experienced administrator" as chairman of the City Planning Commission on Jan. 1, when Robert F. Wagner Jr., present chairman, becomes Borough President of Manhattan.

The fourth stoppage in the nation's soft coal industry in 1949 became effective at 12:01 A. M. today as 400,000 miners struck after the expiration of a three-week truce in their walkout first begun last Sept. 19.

Harry Berse of the Louis Silverman Company has been elected president of the National Notion Association, it was announced yesterday. Also elected were: Aaron Traum of the David Traum Company, first vice president; A. J. Donahue Jr. of the Donahue Sales Corporation, second vice president; Charles F. Pitt of Poirier Lindeman Company, treasurer; and Arthur I. Mellin of the Notion and Novelty Review, executive secretary.

BERLIN, Nov. 30 -- The conscription of young Germans into the Soviet zone "people's police" began four weeks ago, according to residents of that area who have visited Berlin during the last few days. The campaign was integrated with a wave of dismissals of such youths from employment, they say.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 30 (Reuters) -- The American Conference of Shipping Lines has decided to suspend for ninety days from tomorrow a surcharge of 25 per cent levied by them on freight to Bombay, according to information received by the Indian Ministry of Transport today.

MATTAMUSKEET, N. C., Nov. 30 -- This area lived up to its reputation as the "goose-shooting center of the East" on opening day, for although there were a handful of hunters who failed to get their honker limit, most of those lost out because they failed to shoot where they were looking.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today that, because of recent changes in its membership, thirty defendants charged with violations of laws administered by the commission will have opportunities to reargue their cases. Final arguments have been heard in the cases involved but no decisions reached by the commission.

As it enters its 106th consecutive year of service the Prison Association of New York again appeals for funds to be distributed during the Christmas season to the children, wives and mothers of men in prison. As has always been the case, these funds are allocated on the basis of real need, and not a penny is deducted for administrative purposes.
SOUTHERN PINES, N. C., Nov. 30 (AP) -- Harmony was the keynote today at the annual meeting of the Professional Golfers Association of America.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 1 -The Harvard Teachers Union adopted a resolution today terming the loyalty pledge required of members of the Harvard Naval Reserve Officers Training Corps "contrary to the principles of academic freedom."

Spurred by pressure from business and civic groups to ease "intolerable" curb parking conditions, the Mayor's top advisers have asked the City Council to act on a proposed local law to establish a parking meter program on an experimental basis.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The election of Yugoslavia to the eighteen-member Council of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization brought a strong protest today from the delegate of Czechoslovakia.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 1 -- The Dutch proposals for regional economic integration now being discussed in Paris call for the progressive lifting of quantitative restrictions to free 75 per cent of the trade within the participating group by January, 1951, and with certain exceptions 100 per cent by July 1, 1951.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Loading of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 26 were 664,555 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. There was 94,417 cars or 12.4 per cent fewer than in the preceding week, 58,381 cars or 8.1 per cent fewer than in the corresponding week last year and 127,776 cars or 16.1 per cent fewer than in the corresponding week in 1947.
Former President Herbert Hoover declared last night that excessive governmental expenditures and excessive taxation are threatening the continued existence of the American republic.

We cannot agree with the cries of grief, alarm and for shame! that have followed the proposals to raise the salaries of the city's elected high officials. Except in the case of the rather modest $2,500 suggested for the City Council members, there is nothing sudden about the proposal, nor, so far as we can see, is there any failure to give ample opportunity for public discussion.

VIENNA, Dec. 1 -- The Parliamentary Commission that will investigate alleged scandals in connection with the purchase of American goods by Austria under Economic Cooperation Administration allocations asked the Austrian Government today to acquaint it with the results so far of the inquiry being made in the United States by the Senate "watchdog" committee.

Winners of the 1949 Travel Journalism Awards were announced last night at a dinner of the American Society of Travel Agents in the Roosevelt Hotel. Selected from among hundreds of newspaper, syndicate and magazine writers who entered the competition, the winners received savings bonds and plaques from Irwin Robinson, public relations director of the American Society of Travel Agents, Inc.

Continuing their downward trend for the third successive week, business loans made by banks in this area declined $23,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that a substantial majority of the reporting New York City member banks experienced reductions in these loans but there we no large items among the repayments.

Paul G. Hoffman, ECA Administrator, told several hundred men and women yesterday that the Chinese people would never stand for the sort of ruthless slavery to which they would be subjected under communism.

In marked contrast to the pessimism of last spring, business continues good and the severe economic setback forecast by many for the last quarter of this year has failed to materialize, the National City Bank of New York asserts in its December Monthly Bank Letter. The unknown factor in the picture at present, it adds, is the uncertainty concerning the duration of the coal strike.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Transportation officials of the Economic Cooperation Administration began a two-day discussion today with foreign shipping representatives about the allocation of ECA cargo to United States flag lines, but they reported no conclusions.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- Three of the defendants in the Tucker case are in serious financial circumstances, defense attorneys said today during trial of eight former executives of the Tucker Corporation on charges of violating the Mail Fraud Statute and the Securities Act.

BERLIN, Dec. 1 -- Western Berlin went festive today in celebration of the reopening of the power station at Spandau. This at least partly liberates the area from dependence on current from plants under the Soviet control.

The board of directors of the Midland Steel Products Company, at a meeting held yesterday in Cleveland, increased the quarterly rate to 50 cents a common share and also declared a special dividend of $3.50, both payable on Dec. 22.

The Pennsylvania State Highway and Bridge Authority borrowed $15,000,000 yesterday on tax-exempt bonds maturing serially over twelve years at an interest cost of 1.2534 per cent. The obligations are not backed by the full-faith-and-credit pledge of the Pennsylvania state taxing power, but by the revenues to be paid to the authority by the commonwealth on lease contracts.
Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, said yesterday that Federal aid to higher education would be enacted eventually by Congress.
Technological developments in the atomic-bomb race are fast out-pacing man's political capacity to cope with them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- A recommendation that the United States send troops into Formosa to occupy it indefinitely was made today by a Republican member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Senator H. Alexander Smith of New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The chairman of a Senate Agriculture subcommittee accused speculators today of inspiring false reports that the panel had called off its investigation of spiraling coffee prices.

Collection of waste was halted yesterday at numerous commercial establishments in the Bronx when 225 drivers and helpers went on strike against member concerns of the Bronx Trade Waste Removers Association.

Unless the winter is abnormally cold, New York will be able to "squeeze by" without a fuel shortage at the present rate of coal production, Brig. Gen. Brice P. Disque, president of the Coal Consumers Protective Association, a dealer organization, estimated yesterday.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 1 -- The special session of the General Assembly adjourned at 7:15 P. M. tonight after approving thirty-one bills, including a compromise measure to provide state aid for local school construction.

The first three volumes of a new series, "The Twentieth Century Library," under the general editorship of Hiram Haydn, editor-in-chief of The American Scholar and of Crown Publishers, which will deal individually with the great thinkers of the last 100 years, will be issued in February by Scribners.

Preservation of the American two-party system may depend on the Republicans' ability to develop and advance a positive program, Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. asserted yesterday. The Republican from Massachusetts spoke at a luncheon of the New York Young Republican Club at 56 Broad Street.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 1 (AP) -- The richest university in the world waved good-by today to 'big time' football and at the same time prepared to underwrite an athletic program "good for everybody."

Transferable British pounds sterling were quoted in the unofficial market here yesterday at $2.43 to $2.46, against the official price of $2.80 3/16. Two or three weeks ago the lowest quotation in the unofficial market was $2.56.

A tested formula for reducing labor disputes, improving productivity, increasing wages and profits was presented yesterday before more than 300 executives representing industries with more than $3,500,000,000 annual sales and more than 240,000 employes.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 1 -- The real estate and building industry was taken to task here today for its "failure" to provide an adequate answer to the post-war housing problem.

Valentin A. Gubitchev, facing trial here on spy charges, asserted yesterday that he was still third secretary of the Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The Soviet Embassy gave support to his claim by saying that he had not given up his Ministry post when he entered the employ of the United Nations Secretariat, three years ago, as an engineer.

Mrs. William Hockenjos' Jr. of Baltusrol was re-elected president of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association yesterday at its annual meeting in the Hotel Shelburne. Mrs. Caryl Sayer of The Creek was chosen first vice president and Mrs. E. M. Alexander of Siwanoy second vice president.

SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia, Dec. 1 -- The trial of the Sarajevo group alleged to have been in a Soviet espionage network in Yugoslavia began this morning in People's Court here with an unexpected coup de theatre.
Students from seventeen law schools became lawyers and lawyers assumed the guise of learned judges in Moot Supreme Court yesterday at the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 1 -Betty Hutton has agreed to star in two more films for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer after her appearance in the studio's "Annie Get You Gun," it was learned today. The films will be made under the clause in the actress' contract with Paramount permitting her to do one picture annually away from her own company, and will not be loan-outs.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 1 -Police measures were put in force today to forbid political meetings unless police permission was granted. The reason, police officials declare, is to prevent the so-called democratic fronts, which are alleged to be Communist organizations, from spreading the anti-Brazilian doctrines of a foreign country.

A new combination sink, clothes washer and dishwasher featured an open house for dealers given yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by Mayflower Industries to introduce 1950 products of several manufacturers whom it represents in the metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Edward J. Brown, former president of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, AFL, petitioned the United States District Court today to restrain the union temporarily from making effective a ruling that bans him from attending union meetings or taking part in union affairs.

The Republicans, led by their national chairman, Mr. Gabrielson, have announced that they are going out to "the grass roots" to take a poll and find out what's wrong with the Republican party and what can be done about it.

Mrs. Alicia Grajales Baker of 737 Park Avenue agreed to accept a $50,000 cash settlement in lieu of all interests in the $1,178,000 estate left by her husband, Grenville Kane Baker, son of the late George F. Baker, New York financier, who was mysteriously killed on Jan. 17, last on the family's 13,000 acre estate, near Tallahassee, Fla.

GUATEMALA CITY, Dec. 1 -Congress, after four hours debate in its closing session late last night, approved an export tax of 15 per cent of the value of each hundred pounds of coffee leaving Guatemalan ports. The tax becomes effective after the law is approved by President Juan Jose Arevalo and officially promulgated.

BEN LUCIEN BURMAN, who hails from Covington, Ky., is a Southerner who has spent much of his life about as far from the South as he could get, sojourning at various times in North Africa, Baghdad, Avignon, Locarno, Paris and New York City. But all his better books have been about the South and his best ones have been about the Mississippi River.

PARIS, Dec. 1 -- The resignation of Pierre Pflimlin, a Popular Republican, as Minister of Agriculture was announced today. This is the first crack in the Cabinet of Premier Georges Bidault -- a Cabinet that had been based on a fragile coalition from the start.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 1 -Through the admitted use of "a trick," Vincent Hallinan, chief defense attorney in the Harry Bridges perjury trial, claimed today in Federal court to have impeached the testimony of John H. Schomaker, a former Communist who had sworn he recruited Mr. Bridges into the Communist party.

No one could quarrel with the Catholic Bishops of the United States in their desire to improve family life, as reported in your issue of Nov. 21. But your account might lead readers to suppose that the Bishops, when inveighing against planned parenthood in general, as an advocate of the "use of unnatural and morally degrading means," were also damning family planning by any means.

Barely had the three weeks' truce in the coal mines ended on Wednesday and the 400,000 bituminous miners walked off the job -- for the fourth time this year -- when Mr. Lewis, adhering to his adopted role as a sort of super drill sergeant, ordered them back yesterday on a three-day week.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Britain's Consul General in Peiping, W. G. C. Graham, who has had some contact with Chinese Communist authorities, has been instructed to intercede with them on behalf of Angus Ward, United States Consul General at Mukden, and his staff.
The John W. McGrath Corporation of 29 Broadway has leased Pier B, Jersey City, after being balked in efforts to rent a New York pier since early this year.

The Audit Bureau of Circulations was lauded yesterday for thirty-five years of service to advertising and publishing. The tribute was paid by more than 800 executives of these fields at a "birthday party" luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
New horizons in interior design -- from textiles to complete interiors -- were forecast for members of the Brooklyn Museum at a luncheon-forum there yesterday.
In the installment of his memoirs entitled "Men of the Kremlin" General Smith said:

ALBANY, Dec. 1 -- A boycott by civic and women's organizations against concerns that erect unsightly or dangerous billboards along the highways was urged today by Senator Thomas C. Desmond, Newburgh Republican.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- President Truman was told today that the success of the first Federal pump-priming efforts justified continuation of the program "on a vigorous basis" wherever unemployment remained a problem.

The Germans are being scrutinized these days with eyes that are far from tender. The survival of Nazism, the persistence and even growth of nationalism, militarism and "cartellism," are all proving worrisome.

The one and incomparable "Tristan und Isolde" received its first performance of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The cast was a familiar one; its virtues and percentages of excellence, etc., do not need to be extensively retailed here.
Vice President Alben W. Barkley and his bride were welcomed to the city yesterday morning with a huge barrage of flashing cameras -- and they thoroughly enjoyed it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- State Department officials are studying plans to educate Congress and the public with the necessity of increasing United States imports if foreign economic aid is not to be prolonged.

Rubber prices advanced strongly in futures trading on the Commodity Exchange yesterday under aggressive commission house buying in all active 1950 deliveries. Buying interest centered on March delivery, which sold at the close at 17.05 cents a pound, up 34 points from Wednesday's close.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Federal Power Commission today authorized the Central Hudson Gas and Electric Corporation of Poughkeepsie, N. Y., to build a forty-mile pipeline to distribute natural gas in Dutchess, Orange and Ulster Counties. The estimated cost is $1,700,000. Central Hudson now supplies manufactured gas.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The coal and steel strikes cut down manufacturing business during October, a month when manufacturing usually gains.

Wall Street's traditional tickertape welcome to visiting celebrities was missing yesterday when Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery paid a call on the financial district. Instead of the usual shower of paper streamers from office windows, however, he was accorded the rare distinction of seeing the message, "Greetings, Field Marshal Montgomery," interrupt the pro saic reporting of stock and bond quotations by the ticker machines.

An important group of sixty-six Japanese prints of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, recently purchased from the Louis V. Ledoux collection, goes on exhibition today at the Metropolitan Museum. By supplementing this group with a number of examples of work by these masters already in the collections, the museum has assembled a display that handsomely illustrates Japan's school of popular art.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 1 (AP) -- Palatine Stable's Selenite today won the featured fifth race at Tropical Park's second day today before a slim crowd of 5,619.

Mayor O'Dwyer's condition showed some improvement yesterday, according to bulletins issued from Bellevue Hospital at 12:20 P. M. and 5 P. M. by Dr. Edward R. Bernecker, his personal physician, after consultation with Dr. Clarence de la Chapelle, heart specialist.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UP) -The United States will not help Marshall Plan nations build enough oil refineries to injure American oil exports, a House small business sub-committee was assured yesterday.

An evening of earnest music-making was presented in Times Hall last night when Luigi Silva played the 'cello with the able assistance of Artur Balsam at the piano. Mr. Silva is not only a sincere soloist but also a musician of parts. He has appeared as an ensemble player and has made arrangements, several of which he played last night.

The Board of Higher Education has asked State Commissioner of Education Francis T. Spaulding to dismiss an appeal from the board's findings in the matter of charges of anti-Semitism against Prof. William E. Knickerbocker, chairman of the Department of Romance Languages at City College, it was learned yesterday.

Ted Malone, poet and story teller, will have a late evening radio series on the American Broadcasting Company, effective Dec. 12; he will be heard Mondays through Fridays at 11:15 o'clock. The program, consisting of interviews, poetry and tales from distant lands, will replace Joe Hasel's sports round-up.

J. J. Slater introduced their new collection to the press at a showing in their Madison Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street store last evening. Foot fashions for fair weather or foul, designed exclusively for Slater, included items from chic fleece-lined boots to sandals of the barest strippings.

The report of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., issued yesterday for publication today, discloses combined net retail sales for the six department store divisions of $77,496,000 for the thirteen weeks ended on Oct. 29, against $77,646,000 reported for the corresponding quarter of 1948.

Women of society headed by Mrs. C. Berwind Harjes are serving on the committee furthering the success of the preview of the Hallmark Art Award in the Franco-American competition of Christmas paintings to be held Wednesday night at the Wildenstein Galleries for the benefit of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Organzed manufacturers and farmers joined today in demanding that Congress free the Federal Reserve System from domination by the Treasury Department and restore its control over the volume of bank credit as a weapon against business booms and depressions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The United States has assigned "minimum immigration quotas" of 100 persons a year each to the new states of Israel and Hashimite Jordan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had approved a plan of integration and simplification filed by the National Gas and Electric Corporation of New York.

NEWARK, Dec. 1 -- An apparent attempt last midnight to murder Detective John Schultz of the Prosecutor's office, who has been among the directors of hundreds of gambling raids in Hudson County, was followed today by a strong appeal from Prosecutor Duane E. Minard for "public support for an all-out war against the gambler and his ilk."

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- The new Midwest Stock Exchange got off to a flying start today with brisk trading that pushed the day's share turnover 40 per cent above the combined total for its four predecessor exchanges yesterday. The volume was 53,000 shares -- more than double the average daily turnover of the Chicago Stock Exchange in 1949.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board announced today that the "reckless conduct" of a Navy pilot caused the death of fifteen passengers and crew members of an Eastern Air Lines DC-3 near Chesterfield, N J., last July 30.

ROME, Dec. 1 -- The nation-wide general strike called for today by the Communist-dominated Italian Confederation of Labor was the most resounding failure that has been registered by any similar manifestation since the end of the war.

Some nine years after Erskine Caldwell wrote his novel about the Georgia back roads, "Trouble in July," The Troupers, a semi-professional group, are getting around to presenting an adaptation of it in a brownstone house at 6 Fifth Avenue.

Having completed their two-day business session, executives of the thirty-five tracks that make up the Thoroughbred Racing Associations held their annual dinner at the Hotel Plaza last night, at which Vice President Alben W. Barkley was the chief speaker.

The Federal Government began putting in the documentary evidence of its perjury case against Alger Hiss yesterday with a secret high-level cablegram from France to the State Department forming the highlight of the documentary exhibits.

Barring a radical physical defect, the average human being should be able to live as long as he desires, according to Dr. Maurice Ernest, British longevity specialist, who arrived here yesterday on the United States liner America.

The order issued by John L. Lewis to the coal miners to resume work on a three-day basis was seized upon yesterday as a logical excuse for fresh bidding for shares on the New York Stock Exchange. A major upward surge in prices took place in the final hour when a rally in the rails created a sympathetic move by some of the other sections.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UP) -Oscar L. Chapman of Colorado took the oath as Secretary of the Interior today with a promise to work "for all the people, not against any group or against any concept of business or industry."
GREENVILLE, S. C., Dec. 1 (AP) -- Former Secretary of State James F. Byrnes declared today that he would not be a candidate for the Presidency or Vice Presidency in 1952.
MUNICH, Germany, Nov. 25 -In 1945 about 12,000 teachers were dismissed from their jobs in Bavaria because of Nazi affiliations. Today about 11,000 of them are back.

The Navy's controversy with the other branches of the Department of Defense was revived last night by Admiral W. H. P. Blandy, commander in chief of the Atlantic and the Atlantic Fleet. Admiral Blandy spoke at the annual dinner of the New York Commandery of the Naval Order of the United States at the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street.

Roland La Starza, Bronx heavyweight who has yet to meet defeat n the professional ranks, will appear in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. His opponent will be Cesar Brion, hard-hitting warrior from Cordoba, Argentina.

Nearly a thousand men and women, supporters of the missions of the Society of Jesus, heard Senator Herbert R. O'Conor, Democrat, of Maryland, declare last night that communism was the false democracy.
Tourism is Britain's "top dollar-earning trade," J. Harold Wilson, president of the British Board of Trade, declared yesterday at the British Travel Association, 336 Madison Avenue.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 1 -- President Truman received the news of the miners' return to work with considerable gratification. Today's development in New York pleased him on two grounds. He saw a crisis-breeding strike averted and the need for invoking the Taft-Hartley Act eliminated.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 1 (UP) -- A grim band of San Francisco Forty-Niners turned out for practice at Menlo Park today, determined that the slightly ruffled feelings caused by their abortive strike would not interfere with their plans for winning the All-America Football Conference championship.

The finance and economic ministries of the new Western German Government have "heartily endorsed" the move just made by major banks here to protect the interests of legitimate holders of pre-war dollar bonds of German industrial enterprises, the Committee of American Trustees for German Dollar Bonds reported here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The resolution adopted unanimously by the new, anti-Communist union of electrical workers at Philadelphia yesterday would deny the processes and protections of law in this country to petitioners who "openly despise" and would do away with the system which establishes them.
Plans for the consolidation of the Atlantic Avenue and East Rockaway stations on the Long Beach division of the Long Island Rail Road were submitted to the Public Service Commission yesterday.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 1 -- The United Textile Workers of America, AFL, will seek in its new contract demands a $100-a-month pension plan that would be financed from an industry-wide pool, it was announced here tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UP) -Consumer credit has risen sharply in the past year to an all-time high of $17,187,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 1 -- The American Municipal Association today asked the Federal Government to withdraw from the field of taxation of admissions and amusements in favor of local levies on the same source of revenue.

In a 500-word statement signed by its officers, the Eastern Association of Intercollegiate Football Officials hit back hard yesterday at the recent assertion by William R. Crowley, a retired official, that present officials worked under an "almost impossible situation."
Sales of New and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 2.5 per cent in November compared with the corresponding month last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The spectacle of two nationalized industries recouping part of their losses by raising prices against each other was presented in the House of Commons tonight.

Eighteen performances which better or equal listed world records are among the 134 marks which will come up for approval at the sixty-first convention of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States in San Francisco on Dec. 8-11.

Four new pictures will open in first-run theatres today. At the Roxy, the attraction is "Dancing in the Dark," a Twentieth Century-Fox romantic drama with music featuring William Powell, Betsy Drake and Mark Stevens. Irving Reis directed and George Jessel produced the Technicolor offering from a Mary C. McCall Jr., an adaptation by Marion Turk and the play.
Leaders of the two-week revolt in the National Maritime Union, CIO, which reached near-riot proportions, have been found guilty of disruptive tactics and violation of the organization's constitution.
The United Nations General Assembly adopted as its own yesterday a Western pronouncement listing a dozen forms of international cooperation as the essentials to peace.

Paul P. Milling, president of Local 9 of the Retail Clerks International Association, AFL, announced yesterday the ratification of an amended contract with John Wanameker giving 1,900 employes weekly wage increases of $3 to $5.
OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 1 -- Water rights, an old question that has produced gunplay and bitter legal tangles in the West, stirred up stinging debate in the Missouri Basin Inter-Agency Committee today.
The Swedish American liner Gripsholm, commanded by Capt. Sigfrid Ericson, will sail at noon tomorrow on her final voyage this year.

Vice President Alben W. Barkley predicted yesterday that the Democrats would gain seats in both the Senate and House of Representatives in next year's Congressional elections, and thereby continue in control.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Moscow radio today accused "Anglo-American ideologists and their yes men" of trying to knock down the idea that peaceful cooperations is possible between the Soviet Union and capitalist countries.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 1 (AP) -- John L. Lewis and other mine union officials were sued today for $500,000 damages by operators of a non-union mine, scene of a gun battle in September. The action was filed in Federal District Court by the six Preskitt brothers, owners of a small strip mine near Jasper, Ala.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Dec. 1 -A 147-year tradition at the United States Military Academy here was broken today and every one, from plebe to colonel, appeared to be delighted about it.

Admitting a number of vulnerable spots in the Giants' present set-up, which include a hurling corps that needs at least "one good, solid pitcher," and an infield that appears a total blank, Manager Leo Durocher none the less, expressed confidence yesterday that if he could swing at least two of the player deals he had pending the Polo Grounders would be set to run a strong race in 1950.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The American Newspaper Publishers Association asked the National Labor Relations Board today to seek prompt court enforcement of its order against the International Typographical Union. The ANPA said the union had "determined to ignore the board's orders" until they were enforced by a court.

TOKYO, Dec. 1 -- The Japanese Diet has enacted a long-awaited Fisheries Redistribution Law, which has been characterized by Occupation officials as a major step toward ending the pre-war feudal economy comparable to the abolition of "Zaibatsu" capital concentrations and the Allied land reform program.

That a mother's love is a child's legal right was the principle under which two boys, 13 and 11 years old, were removed from the custody of their mother yesterday by Justice Jacob Panken of the Domestic Relations Court. The case was heard in Child Court, the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The rapidly expanding welfare plans of the labor unions are having "harmful effects" on the national welfare program as a whole, Dr. Eveline M. Burns of the New York School of Social Work, Columbia University, declared today.

William Goetz, owner of the painting "Study by Candlelight" that a board of experts, appointed by the Metropolitan Museum, refused to authenticate as an original Van Gogh, had not received the official report in California late yesterday, according to his attorney, Arnold Grant.

YARMOUTH, N. S., Dec. 1 (UP) -- All seven crew members and a ship's cat were safe here today after their small American fishing vessel was pounded to pieces by raging seas yesterday against Nova Scotia's rocky southwest coast.

Criticizing the proposed salary increases for top city officials as excessive, the Citizens Union said last night that the inclusion of members of the City Council in the pay-rise bill now before that legislative body was bound to leave the impression that they had "horned in" on a "salary grab" in return for their support.

The nation's larger banks will be required to provide $358,236,000 under a call on War Loan accounts with the Class B institutions issued yesterday by the United States Treasury. The call, for 15 per cent of such deposits on the close of business on Nov. 30, is payable in equal instalments on Dec. 6, 7 and 8.
I have read Prof. Walter Spahr's letter to THE TIMES, which is persuasive, but merely adds to the general confusion on the subject of gold.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 1 -- Dr. T. F. Tsiang, the Chinese Nationalist representative, served notice today that, despite the refusal of the Western powers to support him, he would not withdraw his resolution calling on members of the United Nations not to accord diplomatic recognition to the Chinese Communist regime.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The National Labor Relations Board tightened its regulations on non-Communist affidavits today to discourage attempted evasions of the filing requirements in the Taft-Hartley Law.

Pork has been holding at the lowest levels at wholesale since price controls were removed about three years ago, Joseph Santora, market reporter of the local office of the United States Department of Agriculture, said yesterday. And at retail, according to the City Department of Markets, pork loins are down again, this time to 47 cents a pound, which is 6 cents less than a week ago.

The General Electric Company suspended yesterday a contract offer it made on Oct. 20 to the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers until such time as the National Labor Relations Board clears up a "serious legal problem" involving the union's right to represent 125,000 G. E. employes.

MOSCOW, Dec. 1 -- The journal New Times charged today that the United States and Britain were collaborating in a "dirty adventure" to detach Tibet from China and establish it as a "colony and military base" directed against the new Chinese Government.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- A British proposal that would in effect sharply reduce United States participation in the leadership of the new non-Communist international labor organization being created here was proposed today during a meeting of the committee considering the draft of a constitution for the new body.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UP) -Laurence Myers, chief of the Agriculture Department's sugar branch, today ordered the nation's softdrink makers to explain why some of them are spreading reports of a threatened shortage of sugar. He said he had been unable to dig up any facts to confirm the reports and that he wanted an explanation.
HONG KONG, Dec. 1 -- The Communists appeared today to have ahead of them little more than a major mopping-up operation against the Nationalists on the Chinese mainland now that Chungking has fallen.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The sixteenth National Conference on Labor Legislation today called upon the various states to increase weekly maximum workmen's compensation benefits to a minimum of $40.

Charging "mismanagement and neglect" by top officers of the National Enameling and Stamping Company of Milwaukee, Arthur Keating, the corporation's largest stockholder and one of its directors, announced here yesterday plans to form a committee of common stockholders in an effort to oust certain officers and directors.

PARIS, Dec. 1 -- The French balked at inviting Western Germany into the proposed trade bloc composed of France, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg when the question arose in the negotiations of experts of these five countries here today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- During the week ended Nov. 30, member bank reserve balances increased $51,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Federal Government's tax and monetary policy "has been driving the thrifty people of the country into the arms of the insurance companies,'' Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, New York, said today.

The New York City Ballet up at the City Center is really going places these days, turning out premieres one after another and putting a high percentage of them into the hit category. The latest of them, George Balanchine's "Bourre Fantasque," which made its bow last night, is clearly going to be in the repertoire for a long time giving considerable pleasure to the majority of the customers.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 1 -- The conception of an international zone for the Jerusalem area embracing the Holy Places sacred to three faiths won open support in a vote of the United Nations here today. It was the first time this had happened during the current session of the General Assembly.
An air of holiday festivity prevailed in the Terrace Room of the Plaza Hotel yesterday noon, so far as the fashions shown were concerned. The exhibitor was Russeks Fifth Avenue.

The campaign for conservation of water in hotels and restaurants went into high gear yesterday, as patrons of dining rooms serving the public began to discover that drinking water was no longer being provided with their meals unless they specifically asked for it.

Alexander Knox is the author of "The Closing Door," in which he and his wife, Doris Nolan appeared at the Empire last evening. If anybody else were the author, Mr. and Mrs. Knox would have grounds for serious complaint. For there have not been two more monotonous parts played on Broadway for a fortnight, and there has not been any busier acting.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday, and final prices were 3 points lower to 5 points higher.

Leopold Stokowski's eighth and final week with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony until the spring began last night at Carnegie Hall with a program that followed fairly conventional lines. There was a distinguished soloist, Isaac Stern, who played the Brahms Violin Concerto.

An industry-wide campaign in Great Britain for lower cost production and simplification of output has been recommended to trade organizations throughout the country, it was disclosed here yesterday through the Economic Cooperation Administration, 2 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Representatives of about 150 national organizations ended today a two-day meeting in which they recommended topics for discussion at the Mid-Century White House Conference on Children and Youth to be held the week of Dec. 3, 1950.
ALBANY, Dec. 1 -- Motor vehicle license plates for next year -- just one plate for each vehicle -- will go on sale Monday at all Motor Vehicle Bureau offices and most County Clerks' offices.

Edward Larrigan, a puckish exbartender whose regard for others was just about 33 1/3 per cent as strong as his regard for himself, was being held under $10,000 bail in Seal Beach, Calif., yesterday for return here to face a ten-count indictment of possessing and passing counterfeit American Express travelers checks.

A hidden threat to use Government funds for investment abroad if private enterprise does not supply the capital lies behind official exhortations to American business to invest money in under-developed areas abroad, August Maffry, vice president of the Irving Trust Company said yesterday.

A new brand of cough drops, known as Elmets, is being produced by Nyrope, Inc., manufacturers of pharmaceuticals, it was announced yesterday. Maury, Lee and Marshall designed the package and will direct all promotional activities.
John L. Lewis yesterday ordered 400,000 striking soft-coal miners back to work next Monday and decreed a three-day work week for the country's entire coal industry, effective at the same time.
PARIS, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Following is the text of today's North Atlantic Defense Committee communique:

An unexpected switch of directors has been made in "Caesar and Cleopatra," starring such luminaries as Sir Cedric Hardwicke and Lilli Palmer. Sam Wanamaker, who had been directing the Bernard Shaw revival since Nov. 14, quit Wednesday afternoon, saying "Tm through," after differences with Sir Cedric.
The Board of Education will save at least $400,000 a year on future purchases of school furniture by accepting bids from "assembly-line" manufacturers, it was made known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dee. 1 -- Department store sales in the week ended Nov. 26 were 5 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:
CLEVELAND, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Indians cut a big slice from their expensive coaching staff today by releasing two former big league baseball managers -- Bill McKechnie and Steve O'Neill.

ROME, Ga., Dec. 1 (UP) -- The Government rested its flogging case against a Georgia Sheriff and eleven others today after a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent testified that the Sheriff gave him the impression he was in league with the Ku Klux Klan.
Your article, "Israel Turns Over Russian Property," which appeared in your paper under date of Nov. 26, needs clarification.

Thomas F. Morgan, 72-year-old supervisor of inspectors in the Bureau of Weights and Measures of the Department of Markets, who recently completed fifty years' service, received a certificate of distinguished service yesterday from Acting Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri.

Accused of bilking a score of persons out of upwards of $500,000, Edward Rashkin, 47-year-old certified public accountant, was arraigned in Felony Court yesterday on a grand larceny charge and released in $5,000 bail.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Judge Henry A. Schweinhaut refused in Federal District Court here today to lighten the eight months to two years wartime conspiracy and bribery sentences of former Representative Andrew Jackson May, Democrat, of Kentucky, and Murray and Henry Garsson, munitions makers.

Stockholders of E. R. Squibb Sons have approved a plan to offer not more than 100,000 shares of the corporation's common stock to employes for purchase on an installment basis, it was announced yesterday. The shares will be from the corporation's authorized but unissued stock.

PARIS, Dec. 1 -- The organization of the common defense of the twelve nations in the North Atlantic treaty moved a stage further here today. The Defense Committee formed under the pact, composed of the defense ministers of the twelve nations, announced it had agreed unanimously on a "strategic concept," an armament production program and the coordination of planning among the five regional groups of nations.

New York University lost to Vanderbilt, 65 to 59, in an overtime thriller after Long Island University had romped to a 66-52 triumph over Texas A. and M. last night in the opening double-header of Madison Square Garden's sixteenth season of intercollegiate basketball.

In contrast to the lethargic attitude of the United States the principal maritime countries of Europe are pressing their shipping programs to the fullest possible extent, Warren G. Magnuson, Democratic Senator from Washington, declared yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 1 -- The second Alger Hiss trial has brought to public attention the possibility that an extensive Soviet intelligence service, including respectable United States citizens among its agents -- some perhaps unknowingly -- has not only been functioning for some years, both in the United States and abroad, but has managed to penetrate the United States' own network of intelligence agencies.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 1 -- A formal request by the West German Federal Republic for membership in the International Authority for the Ruhr was transmitted directly to the Authority by the Western Allied High Commission at a meeting at commission headquarters in Petersberg today.

A member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Representative John Davis Lodge, Connecticut Republican, declared here yesterday that recognition of the Communist regime in China by the United States "would consecrate Soviet imperialism" and "strike a heavy blow at the security of our own nation."

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The stock markets here were buoyant again today under the influence of persistent strength in British Government issues and the defeat of the Labor Government in New Zealand. Although the pace of the advance has slackened, gilt-edge issues have risen 6 to 8 points, almost without pause, since Nov. 10.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations' new anti-Communist electrical workers union ended its four-day founding convention today with a three-hour session in which only one of a number of issues encountered debate before being passed by the 400 delegates.

SWANQUARTER, N. C., Dec. 1 -- This little hamlet was well named, for there probably are more swans here than there were when the name was established, but the December visitors on hand now are interested in ducks and geese.

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony, Leopold Stokowski, conductor, Isaac Stern, violin, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 o'clock; "Lucia di Lammermoor," Metropolitan Opera, 8:30; Rudolf Serkin, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Ethel Elfenbein, piano, Town Hall, 8:30; Margaret Ferguson, piano. Times Hall, 8:30; Benefit concert for French Children, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

Marshall Plan and Point 4 aid for the development of the African colonies of European nations may represent a "substantial threat" to the economies of Latin-American countries producing similar products, particularly coffee. Ambassador Cyro de Freitas-Valle, head of the Brazilian delegation to the General Assembly of the United Nations, warned yesterday.
A move to keep the Northern soft-coal mines closed rather than submit to the three-day week decreed by John L. Lewis almost prevailed at a meeting of leading coal producers in Pittsburgh yesterday.
Hector McNeil, British Minister of State, announced yesterday that Britain would refuse to supply information on political conditions in her colonies to the United Nations. Speaking at the...

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 1 (AP) -- United States officials disclosed today that Germans had been authorized for the first time since the war to take jobs guiding airplane traffic at civilian airports.

Evelynn Corvello, soprano from California, gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. Her program was composed of early classics by Rosa, Cavalli and Scarlatti; French lyrics by Debussy and Poulenc; the Mad Scene from Thomas' "Hamlet"; a group of Spanish and Portuguese songs, and a final dispensation devoted to songs in English.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Department of Defense announced today that 13,000 to 17,000 Reserve and non-Regular officers are expected to be dropped from active duty under the personnel reduction program announced earlier by Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson.

Miss Dorothy Darling, formerly with Franklin Simon Co., has been appointed managing director of the Institute for Hand Knitting, it was announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the National Hand Knitting Yarn Association in the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- December wheat sold at a new high for the year in the early trading on the Board of Trade today but turned reactionary later and the market closed 3/8 cent higher to 1/8 lower.

A $175,714 damage suit against the Government has been filed in the United States Southern District Court by Mrs. Ruth Parker of South Salem, Westchester County, who charged that her 23-year-old husband died as a result of an infusion of jaundiced blood plasma given to a state hospital by the War Assets Administration.
TOKYO, Dec. 1 -- Japan proposes to punish trading concerns that dump abroad by temporarily banning their foreign trade activities, Premier Shigeru Yoshida announced today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- Brooks Brothers, 131-year-old manufacturer and retailer of men's, boys' and women's clothing, with headquarters in New York City, will open a major branch store in Chicago next September, Winthrop H. Brooks, chairman, and John C. Wood, president, said today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 1 -- A $2,600,000 supersonic wind tunnel for testing scale models of aircraft and high-speed missiles was dedicated today at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

TORONTO, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Goalie Harry Lumley scored his fourth shut-out of the National Hockey League season and his second in two nights as the Detroit Red Wings downed the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2 -- 0, tonight before 14,015 fans.

A transcontinental rocket liner, capable of crossing the nation in less than an hour, was described yesterday to the fourth annual national convention of the American Rocket Society at the Statler Hotel.

A host of organists and choirmasters must have read with pleasure that news item the other day describing the tribute paid to Dr. Clarence Dickinson and his wife by the Rev. Dr. Paul Austin Wolfe, minister of the Brick Presbyterian Church at Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street.
Though Harry Jones Lester's letter which you published a few days ago suggests an attempt at some sort of propaganda, a native's comment on farm conditions near Harrisburg, Pa., might be pertinent.

Abels-Wasserberg Co., Inc., one of the city's top lamp manufacturers, has stopped accepting business and is working overtime to make holiday deliveries on orders already on the books, Walter Abels, president, reported yesterday. Retailers said some other factories of comparable stature are in the same position, although producers' holiday deliveries usually end Dec. 1.

City College's basketball team, rated the top local quintet, will make its seasonal Madison Square Garden debut tonight, opposing Lafayette College in the second game of a double-header on the Eight Avenue floor. Manhattan College and Siena will clash in the 8 o'clock curtain raiser and some 17,000 fans are expected.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 2 (AP) -- The University of Maryland Terrapins displayed bowl caliber football tonight in defeating the stubborn University of Miami Hurricanes, 13 to 0, in the Orange Bowl before 34,886 spectators.
Stockholders of the American Air Filter Company and of the Herman Nelson, Corporation will meet on Dec. 20 to consider a proposal to merge the two concerns, it was revealed yesterday.

Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery sailed for home yesterday after a twelve-day visit here and in Washington into which he crammed a number of speeches, talks with military men, tours of industrial plants and saw his first American-style football game.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 29 -- Although China's Communists are nearing complete frontal victory, in their rear they still face resistance, liquidation of which probably will be deferred until the Communists achieve nation-wide political conquest.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- David T. Bofinger, president of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, was threatened today with service of a subpoena to force his appearance before a Senate agriculture subcommittee.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Dec. 2 (AP) -- The fourth in a series of atomic production units will be built here at a cost of about $162,000,000.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 2 -- Princeton University's Theatre Intime, campus dramatic group, presented tonight in the Murray Theatre the American premiere of Jean Cocteau's "The Typewriter," a psychological mystery drama.
KINGS POINT, L. I., Dec. 2 -- Columbia's basketball team opened its season tonight by crushing the United States Merchant Marine Academy, 97 to 44, at O'Hara Hall.

SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia, Dec. 2 -- Father Alexej Krishkov, Russian Orthodox priest of Sarajevo, confessed today to political and economic espionage in behalf of the Soviet intelligence service. He also confessed in part to collaboration with Gestapo chiefs in Sarajevo during the occupation of Yugoslavia by the German armies.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Dec. 2 -- Mrs. T. W. Hawes of Baltusrol was re-elected president of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at the annual meeting of the organization at the Montclair Golf Club today. Also re-elected were Mrs. Edward E. Alley Jr., Ridgewood, secretary, and Mrs. Edwin Sargent, Forest Hill Field Club, treasurer.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- General Carl A. Spaatz, former Chief of State of the Air Force, was appointed today to head a board that will recommend to Congress the site for a proposed Air Force Academy.

CAMP KILMER, N. J., Dec. 2 -- Col. James D. Brown, commanding officer of this First Army installation for six months, has been transferred to the command of the personnel center at Fort Dix, it was announced here today. He has been succeeded by Col. Louis B. Rapp, former executive officer.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 2 -- The American Municipal Association, in the closing session of its 1949 conference, laid the groundwork today for a war on syndicated crime.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Reduced fare "air coach" service between New York and Los Angeles will be started Dec. 27 by two of the nation's largest airlines under an authorization issued today by the Civil Aeronautics Board. The one-way fare will be $110 plus Federal tax of 15 per cent.

BRADENTON, Fla., Dec 2 (AP) -- Deacon Bill McKechnie, veteran baseball coach and former manager, is retiring from baseball to become a farmer. The Indians announced yesterday they were releasing McKechnie and Steve O'Neill from their coaching staff.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- W. Randolph Burgess, chairman of the executive committee of the National City Bank of New York, today pleaded for Federal "monetary sanity, and for honest money -- and that means balanced budgets."
