Fordham launched its basketball season successfully last night by turning back an aggressive John Marshall quintet, 71 -- 55, before a crowd of 2,300 at the Rams' gymnasium. Four Fordham players registered double figures in scoring, with Tommy Breslin's 18 high for the game.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Government today ordered deportation of E. V. Sittler, a native born American who became a German citizen and broadcast from "Station Debunk" in Berlin during the war.
A Queens boy came back from Paris yesterday with a report on how a French family enjoyed an American Thanksgiving dinner that he had carried there.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 2 -- Dr. Kurt Schumacher, leader of the Social Democratic party, took his seat in the Bundestag or Lower House of Parliament today after the suspension order against him had been withdrawn.

After two years of intensive research, steel containers have been developed to open an entire new market in the transportation of chemicals, N. A. Evans, vice president, Pressed Steel Tank Company, Milwaukee, Wis., declared yesterday in an interview at the twenty-second Exposition of Chemical Industries at Grand Central Palace. Officials estimated record attendance this year will exceed 45,000 by the time the show closes today.

A set of early English silver apostle spoons, with the master spoon, were sold yesterday to the Boston Museum of Fine Arts for $5,000 in an auction sale at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue. The set came from the collection of Mrs. Howard Eric of Stamford, Conn., and previously was in that of the late Marsden J. Perry.

The market for new capital is facing a week of varied transactions. The offering of 1,144,000 shares of the Ohio Edison Company's new common stock will be priced today for subscription by stockholders until Dec. 19. Railroad equipment-trust financing will include the sale on Tuesday of $10,350,000 of certificates by the Great Northern Railway and $9,600,000 on Wednesday by the New York Central.

A debutante committee, under the chairmanship of Miss Dita Douglas, has been holding frequent meetings at Place Elegante to further plans for performances of the 102d annual musical production of the Hasty Pudding Club of Harvard University.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 2 -- The Special Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly approved today a new $54,900,000 program for the relief of Palestine Arab refugees during the eighteen months beginning Jan. 1. The program would be administered by a new agency, the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees.

Although figures released yesterday by the Distilled Spirits Institute show liquor sales for the first nine months of the year to be .7 per cent ahead of the corresponding period in 1948, indicated consumption during September was lower than last year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UP) -- Commissioner O. O. Kessing of the All-America Conference today forbade the hard-pressed Baltimore Colts to discuss any settlement of the professional football war with the neighboring Washington Redskins of the rival National League.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 2 (UP) Harvard Athletic Director William J. (Bill) Bingham, the Ivy League's most influential sports figure, was buffeted on all sides tonight.

CAZENOVIA, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- A flexible program of higher education that would meet the individual needs of students rather than concentrate upon either intellectual or vocational training was urged today by Governor Dewey.
KEY WEST Fla., Dec. 2 -- President Truman went fishing today and all he got was a tossing by wind and wave. The denizens of the Gulf Stream completely ignored him.

Rejecting proposed British amendments that would have excluded non-self governing territories from the scope of the proposal, the United Nations General Assembly adopted yesterday a resolution approving a draft convention for prostitution control.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent in the week ended on Nov. 29, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The index was 151.4 per cent of the 1926 average, the same as four weeks ago, and 7.6 per cent below the comparable week in 1948.

STEUBENVILLE, Ohio, Dec. 2 -- In recognition of outstanding service to humanity, the College of Steubenville will present its first annual award of the Poverello Medal of St. Francis of Assisi to Alcoholics Anonymous next Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The working party considering a substitute for the defeated International Commodity Clearing House voted today to recommend to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization the formation of a "Committee on Commodity Problems" under the eighteen-nation FAO Council.
The Postoffice Department has banned a proposed postmark advertisement for the Hoover Report on Government reorganization, it was disclosed yesterday.

Ethel Elfenbein's playing throughout her piano recital last night at Town Hall was serious, sane and intelligent. If her work never became particularly brilliant or glowing, it had sensitivity and taste, being especially satisfying when tender lyricism was demanded, as in the opening and closing divisions of the Franck-Bauer "Prelude, Fugue and Variation," which were delivered with appealing expressiveness and meaningful huances of delicate, singing tone.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The first shipments of United States arms to Western Europe in the $1,000,000,000 Military Assistance Program for this country's North Atlantic treaty partners will go forward next month, if all goes well.

Leaders in Protestant churches in ten Southeastern states will attend the second convocation for them Tuesday through Thursday at St. Mark's Methodist Church in Atlanta, Ga. The first was held in January, 1948. A cooperative program covering many areas of church life will be considered.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- A decision was handed down today by the Securities and Exchange Commission granting the request of Frederick N. Goldsmith, doing business as F. N. Goldsmith Financial Service, New York, to withdraw from registration as an investment adviser.

There is a disturbing element about the haste with which recognition of the Communist regime in China is being pushed in some circles in this country, in the United Kingdom and some of the British Commonwealths. Quite apart from sentiments of repugnance toward a new Asiatic dictatorship that has managed to be conspicuously unfriendly toward us, there are several cogent reasons why we should act with more than usual deliberation.

With new product introduction next year, the Revlon Products Corporation, cosmetics, will expand its 1950 advertising budget to nearly $2,000,000, it will be announced today at a sales meeting in the Savoy-Plaza Hotel. Martin Revson, vice president in charge of sales, will disclose the nature of three new products, an aquamarine luxury soap planned for January release; a one-dollar liquid powder base, February, and an eye make-up line, March.

Retail sales here remained slightly below last year's figures this week as heavy Christmas promotions began to appear. Department store sales were estimated to be about 5 per cent under the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were 2 per cent below last year.

"Lost Boundaries" will be the feature at the Plaza, today through Tuesday. . . . The Trans-Lux Eighty-fifth Street will show "One Woman's Story," tomorrow through Wednesday. Also beginning tomorrow, the Schuyler will offer "Come to the Stable" and "Massacre River" and the Carlton will show "Madame Bovary" and "Outpost in Morocco."

In seven of the New York exhibitions of painting and sculpture there are more than 400 objects. They represent as broad a cross-section of what is being done by 1949 American and European artists as could be desired. For they range from academic realism through varying degrees of fantasy to extreme abstraction.
Slender, sandy-haired John Joe Barry, whose foot-racing exploits in Ireland have earned him the nickname of "The Ballincurry Hare," yesterday experienced what he described as "the thrill of my life."

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 2 -- The United States is leading the way in search of a solution to the problem of Jerusalem that will not offend either Israel or Jordan too deeply and that will win enough votes for approval in the United Nations General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UP) -- Navy Capt. John G. Crommelin, who blew the lid off the service unification row, said tonight the present United States military set-up followed that of Hitler Germany "much too closely."
ROME, Dec. 2 -- The extreme left-wing press declared today that yesterday's nation-wide general strike had been successful, but it did so in a distinctly minor key.
LONDON, Nov. 2 -- The terms of the new British Government conversion loan, as announced by Chancellor of the Exchequer Sir Stafford Cripps, were well received in the stock markets here today.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Anthony Eden, Deputy Conservative leader, defended the British press tonight against recent attacks made by Labor Ministers. He referred especially to the charge of Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, that the majority of the press had set out to "mislead and confuse" the people.

A recent shopping tour, induced by the somewhat painful realization that less than a month remains before Christmas, showed unmistakably that foreign countries are making a special effort this year to be represented on American yule lists.
ATLANTA, Dec. 2 (UP) -- Southern building leaders today denounced the Government decision to bar FHA insurance for segregated housing as a measure that would not possibly work in this section.

BERLIN, Dec. 2 -- Nearly thirty pounds lighter than when he disappeared in May, 1947, from his unit in Luneburg, a British soldier told today of his escape after tweny-eight months in Soviet prisons in Eastern Germany. He returned to Berlin last night and reported to his headquarters.

At a luncheon given in the John Wanamaker store here yesterday, John E. Raasch, president, honored the two newest members to the store's fifty-year club. Attended by other members of the club and store executives, the luncheon was used as the occasion to present the two employes with gold watches in commemoration of their service.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Harry Darby, Republican National Committeeman for five years, was named Kansas' new United States Senator today. The 54-year-old Kansas City steel manufacturer was chosen by Gov. Frank Carlson to fill the unexpired term of the late Republican Senator Clyde M. Reed.
Luxurious furs designed by Dein-Bacher were shown yesterday during the weekly televised luncheon in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The program is carried by the Dumont network.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Communist Information Bureau journal quoted a Soviet spokesman today as saying that Premier Stalin's 1934 statement that capitalism and communism could exist peacefully side by side "forms the basis of Soviet Russia's foreign policy."

Convinced that the City of Hoboken does not intend to participate in the Port of New York Authority's program for the development of the city piers, the authority yesterday informed Mayor Fred M. De Sapio of Hoboken that it would proceed with plans for a joint state-authority development program.

It would be easy to write off "Lucia di Lammermoor" as old-hat opera fit only for simple souls who never tire of the Sextet or the coloratura warbling of the Mad Scene. But that would be ignoring a fact that cannot be blinked: the Donizetti opera has a tenacity that keeps it in the repertory.

Asserting that constantly changing conditions had made governmental regulation increasingly necessary to maintain the rights of the American people ever since the founding of the Republic, Vice President Alben W. Barkley declared last night that the Republican charge that President Truman's Fair Deal was leading to "statism" was merely an attempt to scare the voters.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- After two days of heated debate behind closed doors United States labor leaders were reported tonight to have won a key position in determining the policy of the new non-Communist international labor congress being created here.

Tom Lanphier Jr., World War II fighter pilot who is credited with destroying the plane that carried Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto, commander of the Japanese fleet, to his death, left La Guardia Airport at 12:30 P. M. yesterday on the first leg of a round-the-world flight by commercial airlines.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 2 -- Political pressure for more public housing is inspired largely by the "misconception" that most of the people support the idea of subsidized shelter, the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards was told today by several speakers.

Demands of professional investors for inside information concerning operations of companies in which they hold an interest were described as unreasonable in a spirited exchange yesterday between company executives and spokesmen for insurance companies, banks and investment companies.

HONG KONG, Dec. 2 -- Efforts by the Chinese Nationalists to repossess two aviation companies that they used to operate here have bogged down in a maze of legal technicalities. Prospects now are dim that the Nationalists will ever get their planes airborne again.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 2 (UP) -- Admiral Forrest P. Sherman, Chief of Naval Operations, tonight urged the Navy's "future admirals" to bury any interservice squabbles and cooperate wholeheartedly with the Army and Air Force.
BERLIN, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Russian Col. Alexei Yelisarov said today he was sorry that one of his sentries had shot and killed a United States service man in Berlin last week.

Roland La Starza's record of consecutive ring victories went through its thirty-seventh chapter last night in Madison Square Garden, where the ex-collegian pounded out a decision over eager, but crude Cesar Brion of South America, in a ten-round battle witnessed by 12,035 fans paying receipts of $40,092.

The New York State Committee on Discrimination in Housing passed two resolutions yesterday calling for the Federal Government and state and local legislative bodies to enact legislation to prevent discrimination and segregation in housing constructed with public assistance.

Giving employes "a stake in the business" has "paid off" for Willoughby Camera Stores, Inc., New York merchants, by a thirtyfold expansion in business since profit-sharing was first started in 1926, J. G. Dombroff, president, told more than 400 industrial executives yesterday.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 2 -- The Western Allied High Commission issued a statment of policy tonight warning the Western German state governments to limit closely the strength, policies and affiliations of the state police forces.

Several of the rneumatoid and allergic illnesses, generally ascribed to environmental strain, colds or infections, have their origin in some cases in a deranged activity of the adrenal cortex which produces an unbalance of hormones, the Association for Research in Nervous and Mental Disease was told yesterday.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Pennon, 10-1 shot, owned by H. W. Fincher of Miami, thundered to a surprising victory in the Blakestown Purse before a crowd of 5,562 at Tropical Park today.

In an account of the settlement of the estate of Grenville Baker, in yesterday's paper, it was incorrectly reported that his widow, Mrs. Alicia Grajales Baker, had agreed to accept a $50,000 cash settlement in lieu of all interests in the $1,178,000 estate.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 2 -- Twentieth Century-Fox today announced the purchase of two new film properties, "The Harry Lick Story," written for the screen by Boris Ingster and Laszlo Vadnay, and "Take Care of My Little Girl," an unpublished novel by Peggy Goodin.

In a drive to eliminate all possible waste of water during the current acute shortage, the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, assisted by other city departments, moved yesterday to augment and "tighten up" its inspectional services.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- Because of continued strong demand for membership on the new Midwest Stock Exchange, the board of governors has made seventeen more seats available at the initial price of $2,500, James E. Day, president, announced today.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Dec. 2 -- Snows were falling in the mountains today and the spirits of the natives in Berkshire County, comprising almost 1,000 square miles in the western Massachusetts uplands, were rising high. For, with a deep frost in the ground, portents are for an old-fashioned winter with lots of snow and cold weather.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange suddenly became active yesterday but closed somewhat irregular, 13 points higher to 5 points lower than the day before.

I think that the appeal for conservation of water would be more effective if a few practical suggestions were offered. Anyone who has lived where water is scarce is appalled by the frightful waste of water here.

Making his first report on the state of the Yankees since the Bombers completed their year of spectacular surprises by annexing the world championship, General Manager George M. Weiss yesterday revealed that he has drafted a dual platform by which he hopes to keep the Yanks on top through 1950.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 2 -- The Administrative and Budgetary Committee of the United Nations General Assembly lopped off another $69,790 from next year's expenses for the world organization during the final reading of the budget today, leaving the net total of $34,839,668 to be paid out by member nations in 1950.

Establishment of a national organization of independent television producers is expected to result from meetings of officials of the Independent Television Producers Association of New York and the Television Producers Association of Hollywood.
A trend away from direct foreign relief and toward reconstruction of war afflicted areas was described yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Friends Service Committee.

It took seventy French midshipmen from the French Naval training ship Jeanne D'Arc exactly forty-two minutes yesterday morning to consume 200 cups of coffee and eighteen dozen les beignets (French crullers) on a tour of New York, Harbor as guests of the Port of New York Authority on the tug Grace M. Moran.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 -- A longshore walking boss and former Communist told a Federal Court jury at the Harry Bridges perjury trial today that Communists during the 1934 maritime strike "gave us help with a mortgage on our union which was to pay dearly in later years."

CAMDEN, N. J., Dec. 2 -- Four thousand day shift workers at the New York Shipbuilding Corporation's yard here staged a spontaneous four-hour walkout today in protest over a Chancery Court ruling ordering them to quit an American Federation of Labor union, which they had joined in September, 1948.
MADRID, Dec. 2 -- Students of the Madrid University School of Industrial Experts announced tonight they were going on strike for better premises for their classes.

Robert E. Sherwood, four times Pulitzer Prize winner, was elected to membership in the American Academy of Arts and Letters, 633 West 155th Street, at its annual meeting yesterday. He was the sole new member chosen.

Miss Renee Cohen, 24-year-old bookkeeper, of 848 Glenmore Avenue, Brooklyn exercised the age-old feminine prerogative yesterday afternoon -- with good results. That change of mind at the last minute saved her employer a $1,205 payroll, and later led to the capture of youthful robber suspects.
"Dear Ethel: Here is a recipe for a steak, picked up on fishing trips to the Wisconsin woods."

Led by the rail group the stock market yesterday extended its gains to around the best levels for the present movement. Trading was heavy and the volume of business crossed the 2,000,000-share mark for the first time this year. Key stocks were up fractions to more than 2 points.

The city's attempt to test in state courts its right to forfeit the Third Avenue Transit Corporation's franchise was blocked, at least temporarily, in a decision handed down yesterday by Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman.
Rejection of the proposed local law to increase the salaries of Mayor O'Dwyer, his Board of Estimate colleagues and the members of the City Council was urged yesterday by Newbold Morris.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 2 -- Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia has sent a personal warning to the United Nations that the setting up of a ten-year trusteeship over Somaliland under Italy's administration created a "certain, inevitable and overwhelming" danger to his country.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Ignoring warnings by employers and unions that any change in the present Pacific Coast longshoremen's contract affecting hiring halls might disrupt industrial peace, a trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board today ruled that these halls were operated in violation of the Taft-Hartley Law.
PORTSMOUTH, England, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Four explosive charges blew the bottom out of the 152-year-old French-built warship Implacable today and sank her in thirty-six fathoms of the English Channel.

Fundamental research combined with commercial experimentation will produce in five years synthetic fabrics possessing all the warmth and durability of wool plus features that will make them washable at home, A. E. Buchanan Jr., of the E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., declared yesterday. Certain experimental suiting fabrics already produced, he said, surpass wool in its "wooliness" and have proven many times stronger than the natural fiber in abrasion tests.

The preliminary report of R. Hoe Co., Inc., for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 disclosed yesterday a net profit of $1,997,163 after all charges on sales of $18,512,237. Net profit for the preceding fiscal year was $1,702,384 on sales of $17,230,844.

Within the memory of man it has been the rare exception when anything favorable was said about the Sanitation Department. If the shock will not be too great we should like to wave a sympathetic farewell to a former $12-a-week whitewing who is known affectionately in the department as "the old man." Commissioner William J. Powell has served the department and the city for forty-three years.
BOSTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- University of Pennsylvania President Harold E. Stassen today denounced any implication that Penn's "state scholarships" were given for athletic ability.

TRENTON, Dec. 2 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll intervened in New Jersey's critical water shortage today to order conservation of 10,000,000 gallons of water daily for North Jersey municipalities by closing a reservoir outflow.

Tuberculosis has been well named "the unnecessary disease" -- unnecessary because its cause is known, it can be cured, it can be prevented, and, eventually, it can be wiped out. Yet in this city alone there were 7,000 new cases reported in the first nine months of the year -- 9 per cent more than in the corresponding period of 1948.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- John L. Lewis refused again today to recognize Charles I. Dawson as the coal operators' trustee for the United Mine Workers' welfare and retirement fund.
LONDON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- A battle between the Roman Catholic Church and Britain's Labor Government has broken out over the issue of government aid for church schools.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- As part of its drive to enforce civil rights, the Truman Administration suddenly announced today that financing by the Federal Housing Administration would be refused for any new houses or apartments where occupancy or use was restricted on the basis of race, creed or color.

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- The replacement of Pierre Pflimlin, who resigned yesterday as Minister of Agriculture, by Gabriel Valay, another member of the Popular Republican party, failed today to restore full confidence in the future of Georges Bidault's Cabinet, which has been facing a deadlock brought on by the passive resistance of the coalition political parties.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 2 -- President Juan Peron tonight made one of the strongest anti-Communist speeches of his career. He said that the Communists, in cooperation with "opposition politicians" and the "imperialist press" of the Continent, had fomented a sugar strike that had dragged for more than a month.

At least $2,000,000 will be needed to finance Republican Congressional and Senate campaigns next fall and to carry on the functions of the National Committee, it was estimated at a Republican finance meeting this week.

For the third successive week, roses have been the most abundant cut flower in New York City. Altogether 511,338 were received during the first four days of the present week, and by today the number probably will equal last week's 722,172.

There are perhaps few pianists, even among the leading figures in this field, who would dare to go before a public in Carnegie Hall with the predominantly classic and unpyrotechnical list of compositions which Rudolf Serkin presented yesterday evening.

ATHENS, Dec. 2 -- Deputy Premier Constantin Tsaldaris, Populist party leader, and Minister of State Sophocles Venzelos, the Liberal leader, announced today that Greece would hold general elections April 9 or 16, 1950.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Transportation has been provided for Consul General Angus Ward, his staff and their families, and they have been ordered to leave Mukden by Wednesday morning, China time, or Tuesday night, Eastern standard time.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Secretaries of the Army and Air Force tonight ordered a full investigation of the bitter struggle for power that has been going on over the National Guard and the Air National Guard.

YOU may have noticed that the gentle art of nature writing sometimes breeds ferociously pugnacious authors. The better to praise their leafy paradises they damn the pleasures of civilization to hell. A townsman who buys their books to get a few vicarious hours in the quiet solitudes may find, instead, that he is being loudly lectured as an ignoramus, a knave and a fool.

An old realty holding in Times Square passed to new control with the sale yesterday of the four-story building on a lot 21 by 70 feet at 1565 Broadway, near the southwest corner of West Forty-seventh Street, by the family of Strother J. Murphy to the 1565 Broadway Realty Company.

The United Nations General Assembly appealed yesterday for further contributions to the International Children's Emergency Fund and lauded the agency's "great humanitarian effort," but evaded the crucial issue of when the organization is to come to an end.

Paul Hoffman has been devoting a good deal of his time recently to telling Europeans how to make the most of Marshall Plan assistance while it lasts, and telling Americans what the alternatives are to a permanent subsidy of Europe. Just as he has inevitably had to disregard some European special interests in his demand for integration, so he has had to offend some American special interests in his plea for more imports.

Today's events: Young People's Concert, Little Orchestra, conducted by Thomas K. Scherman; Beverly Lane, Eleanor Knapp, Ruth Kobart, Norman Kelley, Frank Robier, singers; Max Leavitt, narrator, Hunter College Auditorium, 11 o'clock, and Brooklyn Academy, 3.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Army today announced a 1950 football schedule which includes games with Stanford and Michigan and the election of End Dan Foldberg as captain of the team.

ALBANY, Dec. 2 -- Henry Root Stern, chairman of the State Board of Social Welfare, said today that declining juvenile delinquency in New York State had reduced to pre-war levels the rate of court commitments to state training schools.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan today ordered the nation's twenty cotton - growing states to cut their 1950 plantings enough to remain within a national goal of 21,000,000 acres. He issued the order in announcing state cotton acreage allotments for next year in an effort to prevent costly surpluses under the Government price-support program. Some 26,380,350 acres of cotton were under cultivation last July 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Truman's Point Four plan, if not accompanied by social welfare objectives, may "lead to more conflict rather than to more peace," Dr. Alva Myrdal, principal director of the Department of Social Affairs of the United Nations, declared tonight.
Overruling the bitter protests of Britain and France, the United Nations General Assembly acted yesterday to extend permanent international supervision over the world's 200,000,000 dependent peoples.
Acting Detective Lieut. John H. F. Cordes, the only man in Police Department history to receive the Medal of Honor twice, will retire formally on Jan. 1, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, maintains that there is no insuperable barrier to unity with the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Marriner S. Eccles, member of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, told Congress today that the Truman Administration was inviting economic disaster by its "easy money bias" and was making the Federal Reserve System "an engine of inflation."
CHENGTU, China, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Chinese Communists almost caught Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, No. 1 on their "war criminals list," at Chungking.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UP) -- Representatives of railroad labor said today the Government's $2,000,000,000 suit for refunds of freight charges will lead to "social and political upheavals" and perhaps Government ownership of the railroads.

"Clutterbuck," a comedy by Benn W. Levy, who holds the unique distinction of serving as a member of the British House of Commons while practicing as a playwright, will open this evening at the Biltmore Theatre. Irving L. Jacobs is sponsor of the project in association with David Merrick.

The Port of New York Authority moved yesterday to put $54,000,000 of its outstanding 3 per cent general bonds on a lower interest-cost basis. Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Authority, said the port enterprise would offer on Tuesday, Dec. 20, an issue of $54,000,000 of Fourteenth and Fifteenth Series bonds at competitive bidding.

The Federal prosecution completed presentation of the bulk of its documentary evidence in the Alger Hiss perjury trial at 3:12 o'clock yesterday to show that Mr. Hiss had primary access to all but a few of the State Department documents.
A special public relations school, designed to increase promotional activities by savings and loan associations is being planned by the New York State Savings and Loan League.

DALLAS, Tex., Dec. 2 (AP) -- A consolidation of oil and gas properties of five companies appraised at more than $40,000,000 is in final stages of negotiation here, A. W. Smith, president of the Texmass Petroleum Corporation of Dallas, has announced. The properties will be merged into Texmaas Petroleum.

Debate on a resolution that would establish a United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to provide protection for refugees and stateless persons after the International Refugee Organization finishes its work, opened yesterday in the plenary session of the General Assembly at Flushing Meadow.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner recommended today that Trans-Canada Air Lines receive a permit for operations between Montreal and New York.

I was surprised and disturbed by your recent editorial suggestion that a "modest tuition fee" be charged at the city colleges -- surprised because THE TIMES has been in the vanguard of educational reform in America, and disturbed because the suggestion indicates a serious lack of information concerning the meaning of a "free" education here in New York.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., Dec. 2 -- The ninth annual national championship retriever trials began on the faded fields and leaden waters of this area today with eighteen dogs, mostly Labradors, competing and with all of them still in the running when three frigid series had been completed.
Directors of the Radio Corporation of America authorized yesterday for payment on Jan. 23 a dividend of 50 cents a share on its outstanding common stock, or a total of $6,928,600 on this issue.

NAGS HEAD, N. C., Dec. 2 -- Although the hunter on Kitty Hawk Bay does not see as many geese as he does at Mattamuskeet, there were a number of limit bags taken today in the places we hunted, as well as near-limits of ducks.

Your editorial comment of Dec. 2 expressing "concern over South Africa" follows, unwittingly one hopes, the well-worn pattern established by the Union's detractors by highlighting innuendoes and half-truths to present the country and its affairs in an unfavorable light without saying anything on the credit side.

The New York regional office of the National Labor Relations Board announced yesterday that it would start preliminary hearings next Wednesday on the claims of two rival unions to represent workers in the electrical industry.

Marked expansion of the use of color in the fur industry is now under way, with leading dyers and processors bringing out new hues marking a notable departure from the traditional blacks, browns and grays used for major pelts, it was reported here yesterday.

J. K. Gillenwater has been named purchasing agent of the Tennessee Eastman Corporation, subsidiary of Eastman Kodak Company in Kingsport, Tenn., to succeed D. V. Hammock, retired. W. J. Jackson succeeds Mr. Gillenwater as assistant purchasing agent.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 2 -- Faced with the prospect of a diplomatic defeat China's delegation today obtained a three-day postponement of the vote on its resolution calling on the United Nations to adopt a non-recognition policy toward the Chinese Communists.

A three-man team from Yale University's Law School captured the fourth annual Moot Supreme Court competition last night, scoring in the final round over a University of Chicago team. The winners received as a prize possession of the Samuel Seabury sterling Silver Revere bowl for one year.

Three readily available chemicals that show promise as fuels or aids in propelling the rockets of the future were described yesterday to members of the American Rocket Society and the American Society of Mechanical Engineers as they ended their joint convention at the Statler Hotel.

Two papers by the late Lord Keynes, which he expressly desired to be published after his death, are issued today by Augustus M. Kelley, 31 East Tenth Street, in a small book, entitled "Two Memoirs." The first, "Dr. Melchior: A Defeated Enemy," is the inside story of the breaking of the blockade of Germany after the 1914-18 war, in which Keynes played a leading part.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 2 -- Returning to this country after a three-month trip to Germany, Austria, Italy and Switzerland, Ugo Carusi, chairman of the United States Displaced Persons Commission, reported today considerable progress in the movement of displaced persons to the United States, Australia, Canada and South American countries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Magnavox Company, Fort Wayne, Ind., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 100,000 shares of Class A (preference) stock, $15 par value, that is to be offered publicly.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 2 -- Faced with the prospect of a diplomatic defeat China's delegation today obtained a three-day postponement of the vote on its resolution calling on the United Nations to adopt a non-recognition policy toward the Chinese Communists.

OUR own enterprising City Ballet has, at this writing, presented only half of its scheduled novelties at the City Center, but in one of them it has already scored a resounding success, for which we are all appropriately thankful.

TARPON SPRINGS, Fla. -- The string of little resort towns that runs south from this colorful town of Greek sponge fishermen thirty miles to St. Petersburg is already bustling with early winter activity. North of here towns are few and far between, but to compensate for the barren stretch of Gulf Coast there a numerous fresh-water lakes inland with "the world's best bass fishing," and natural springs which attract thousands of winter visitors.
DALLAS, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Frank Leahy said the Notre Dame football team that scored a hair-raising 27-20 victory today over Southern Methodist was the greatest he ever coached.

THE curious neglect that has befallen the reputation of Edmund Burke is the first of many puzzles and paradoxes remarked by Mr. Copeland, Associate Professor of English at the University of Chicago, in this stimulating book.

This newspaper begins today its thirty-eighth annual appeal for the Hundred Neediest Cases. Since 1912 THE TIMES has asked the leading private charitable agencies to select these cases and allow us to present them to our readers. Every cent received is immediately turned over to the proper agency so that it may be put to work at once.

Joint surveys and action by trade groups here and abroad to increase imports into the United States, in place of apparently "unending discussion," was urged here yesterday by Saul Cohn, vice chairman of the City Stores Company.

BOSTON, Dec. 3 (UP) -- Scores of minor accidents and a toll of six dead were reported today after the Northeastern states' heaviest storm of the season left from one to ten inches of snow in the area.

The nation-wide wild mouse hunt by thousands of high school students interested in studying the little rodents for cancer research has been balked temporarily in New York by the game laws of the city Parks Department.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The State Department's Voice of America set out to tell the Russian people today how their Communist party newspaper, Pravda, is fooling them, especially by editing the speeches of their own Foreign Minister.

SINCE duty, duty must be done and the rule applies to everyone, it is necessary to point out that Katharine Cornell has returned to town in a phlegmatic play. Kate O'Brien's "That Lady" is a heavy-footed historical romance about kings, counselors, princesses and other literary bric-a-brac in sixteenth century Spain.

THE highest efforts of genius, in every walk of art, can never be properly understood by the generality of mankind: There are numberless beauties and truths which lie far beyond their comprehension. It is only as refinement and sublimity are blended with other qualities of a more obvious and glosser nature, that they pass current with the world.

HAD Charles Kingsley and his wife been more likable human beings the story of their love and marriage might have captured the public imagination. As it was, Charles Kingsley's approval of the wedded state expressed itself in a rabid hatred of celibacy and, consequently, of the Catholic Church for advocating it.

SALT LAKE CITY -- At this season every Utahan is on skis -- with the sole exception of folks hobbling in plaster casts as a result of last week's spills. Institutions such as the University of Utah and Brigham Young University list ski classes in their curricula.

OF course, it was sure to happen. Sooner or later, the success of Milton Berle as a cut-up on television -- which our colleagues assure us he has been -- was bound to entice some movie company into making a picture starring him.

Emergence of new fields of industry -- from television to three-dimensional subway advertising -has broadened the opportunities for young people in the sphere of commercial art, Paul Lang, art director of the Ketterlinus Lithographic Company, told 1,000 art students and parents yesterday.
John E. O'Hora has been appointed acting assistant to the president of the United States Brewers Foundation. He formerly was assistant director of the foundation's legal department.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 3 -- The United Nations has been asked by the American Federation of Labor to establish the forty-hour week as an early practical goal for all the workers of the world and to look into a thirty-hour week as an international long-range labor policy.

" The Woman in Fashion" by a British writer, Doris Langley Moore, is to be published here next month by B. T. Batsford, Ltd. The book is an analysis of style, illustrated by photographs of costumes from Mrs. Langley Moore's extensive private collection. These are modeled by a galaxy of women famous on the British stage and screen, in couture, the arts and letters and the world of fashion.

Gov. James E. Folsom of Alabama declared yesterday that, despite some indications to the contrary, the split in the Democratic party in the South caused by the 1948 revolt of the States' Rights party had been healed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Thomas B. McCabe, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, minimized policy conflicts between the board and Treasury today in assuring Congress that continued cooperation between the agencies would make a redefinition of their powers unnecessary at least for the immediate future.

HANCOCK, Mass., Dec. 3 -- Ski fever was running at a record high for this time of the year in the Berkshires today, as the second snowstorm of the season left in its wake a white mantle that reached eight inches in places.

I WAS much disappointed when I read the review by Bucklin Moon of Lillian Smith's new book, "Killers of the Dream." This book ought to be read by as many Americans as possible. An understanding review or even a just review in your pages would have presented the book more clearly for what it is.
HONG KONG, Dec. 3 (AP) -- China's Acting President, Li Tsungjen, completed arrangements today to leave by plane Monday for the United States.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Dec. 3 -- Field Marshal Sir William J. Slim, chief of the Imperial Staff of the British Army, characterized Germany today as both "the most valuable and the most dangerous" nation in Continental Europe.

Eighteen children of Toledo, Ohio, left fatherless by World War II, will receive scholarships to the University of Toledo through a war memorial fund now being set up. The effort to provide full tuition for the children of every former student killed in the war was started four years ago by a group of veterans who chose this project in preference to a monument or similar memorial.

NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 3 -- The captain of an oyster boat rescued three Norwalk duck hunters this morning about half a mile off Calf Pasture Beach, after they had been tossed into the icy waters of the harbor from their boat. Rescued were Robert T. Douglas Jr., 30 years old, Joseph Morris, 21, and Arthur Bowers, 22. All were treated at the hospital and Douglas remained there.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 3 -- Rutgers received its first basketball setback of the season tonight at the hands of a fast, shifty, superior Yale quintet, 73 -- 60, before 3,200 spectators. It was the Bulldogs' first game of their campaign, but the Scarlet had opened its season last week with a victory over Rutgers of Newark.

VERSAILLES, France, Nov. 29 -- Amid landscaped gardens in the outskirts of this Paris suburb, the Chateau de la Maye stands as an ideal retreat from the world and its problems. As such it has been used by royalty, including the Duke of Windsor, King Peter of Yugoslavia and King Zog of Albania.
NOW, when there is an exciting bustle about the house, with mysterious comings and goings and the hiding of packages begins, the only stories that really match the mood are Christmas stories.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Despite British protestations that it is difficult to sell British products on the United States market, the recent experience of one small company shows that there is a great demand in the United States for British goods if they are well advertised and offered at a reasonable price.

Battling to hold second place in the National Football League's Eastern Division, the New York Giants will close their home campaign today against the Philadelphia Eagles, who already have clinched the sectional title. Kickoff time at the Polo Grounds will be 2:05 P. M.

It was no mere "impulse" of John McCaull of the McCaull Opera Comique Company at Thanksgiving in 1882 to have his banquet menu printed on a handkerchief, as Doris Greenberg reports in "Invitation to the Feast." He had a more substantial interest.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 3 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, President of the United Nations General Assembly, said tonight that he had been encouraged by the replies of the six permanent members of the Atomic Energy Commission -- the Big Five and Canada -- to his appeal for a fresh examination of the question of international atomic control.

PETER NEAGOE'S story concerns his childhood among the peasants of Transylvania, and one can only envy him the experience. The people he writes of are interesting and entertaining; they had an affinity for life and the soil, and Mr. Neagoe has written a beautiful book about them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- One of the major problems facing the world today is the distribution of food. For the past two weeks this and other food problems have been under study by the Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations which is holding its fifth annual conference here.

TOKYO, Dec. 3 -- The Russians are holding about 10,000 Japanese as war criminals, including the remnants of one entire Japanese Army division, according to members of the latest group of repatriates returned from the Soviet Union.

THIS anthology is planned "to show how close the connection is between religion and that very vital human need -- humor" and to do this with selections from recent humorous writings by Roman Catholic authors. Another volume by the same editor, "With a Merry Heart," had a similar aim but drew on material from the earlier decades of this century.

The safety of United States Government officials and other American citizens in East Asia has been much in the news and much in the American mind during the past week. The "deportation" of an entire consular staff from Manchuria has been ordered after the consul has spent many months (one of them in jail) trying to leave the country.

FORT JEFFERSON, Fla. -This remote national monument is located on the tiny island of the Dry Tortugas, some sixty-eight miles west of Key West, Fla., in the Gulf of Mexico. As there is no regular travel service to the Tortugas, the fort is almost inaccessible to the average tourist.

DALE PONTIUS' review of Jose Rizal's life, "The Pride of the Malay Race" (Book Review, Oct. 23), was a fresh reminder of how somehow heartening it always is to learn of an individual -- in any land, in any period -- who has believed in true freedom enough not only to live and work for it but to die for it.

THIS is a book written with wide learning, humor and clarity. Dr. Binger undertakes to acquaint the reader with psychosomatic medicine, classical psychoanalysis, various psychological concomitants, contributing causes and effects of disease, and several kindred topics.

TORONTO, Dec. 3 -- Turk Broda, a stylish 189-pounder, returned to the National Hockey League wars tonight and scored a 2-0 shut-out over the New York Rangers before a highly partisan crowd of 13,359. Turk received a tremendous hand from the fans as the final whistle signalized his fourth shut-out of the season for the Maple Leafs.

Political action for peace is urgent because of threats of a possible economic collapse, Dr. Harry F. Ward, professor emeritus of Union Theological Seminary, declared yesterday at the opening of a three-day conference sponsored by the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship, Inc.

MEXICO CITY -- Tourists, in their stampede to snap up this city's quaint pottery, brightly colored baskets, huaraches and other typical souvenirs, often overlook the numerous shops in the European tradition which offer high-quality, hand-made merchandise without "national" characteristics at moderate prices.

In Paris last week the military chieftains of Western Europe and the United States held a series of significant meetings. Out of the meetings there came agreement on important aspects of the defense of Western Europe. But there was left unsettled a question which overhung the deliberations -- the question of whether Germany should be rearmed to participate in Europe's defense.

THE American premiere of Prokofieff's Sixth symphony was perhaps the outstanding event of Mr. Stokowski's first eight weeks with the Philharmonic-Symphony. There were of course conflicting opinions of the worth of this symphony, compared with Prokofieff's Fifth, which had preceded it by two years.

WARSAW, Dec. 3 -- Spy fever, the most contagious of Eastern European national diseases, now has Poland in its grip. The arrest last week of Andre-Simon Robineau, 25-year-old French consular assistant, and the expulsion of two French diplomats, all as members of an alleged French spy ring, served as a warning to Poles that contacts with foreigners are extremely dangerous.

BEAR MOUNTAIN -- There were only fourteen days of skiing at this state park last year, the winter of almost no snow, whereas the year before ninety-six successive days of winter sports were enjoyed by more than 210,000 persons.

BOOKS on photography covering a broad field of interests that range from manuals to picture collections are available this season in considerable quantity. Of the ten recently published volumes under review here, more than half are concerned with technical information, the remainder teach through the study of pictures only.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Grants by the Public Health Service to aid medical research to an amount of $835,700 were announced today by Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator. Similar grants to a total of $2,056,426 were announced last August.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 3 -- Reports from London that a conference of the Southeast Asian nations would be held in February, with India as the leader, came as a surprise to the Government here,

NEW on the housewares market is a dishwasher-on-wheels that has the capacity and performance of permanently plumbed-in models, but is less expensive, partly because no installation (which can cost as much as $50) is necessary. New, too, is a chest-shaped refrigerator, the top of which provides a working surface, and whose storage area is contained in pull-out drawers.

Ruben Varga, young Palestinian violinist, who was blinded shortly after he began music lessons as a boy, made his New York debut yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The program, sponsored by the Lighthouse of the New York Association for the Blind, attracted an audience of 1,000 persons.

OVER at Kitty Cornell's flat, up against the river East, there she was the other fine day: Kate O'Brien. No, it wasn't anything like that. Miss O'Brien, though she was born in Limerick fifty-one years ago, and educated in Dublin, has only the subtlest trace of an Irish brogue.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 3 -- Israel and the Kingdom of Jordan are still at war, technically, although they are becoming friendly enemies. Paradoxically, one of the things that is bringing them closer together is their mutual dislike of anything resembling internationalization of Jerusalem.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 3 -Nineteen member nations of the Interallied Reparations Agency are to divide up the German industrial equipment originally destined for Russia that had been stored in Western Germany for almost two years pending final decision on reparations.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 3 -- President Juan D. Peron announced this morning that he was bringing legal action against the newspapers Prensa and Nacion for printing a story that charged the President with enriching himself through his office.

THE TIMES of Nov. 20 carried an item to the effect that the violinist, Louis Kaufman, had recently discovered eight "lost" violin concerti from Antonio Vivaldi's Opus 8 in the library of the Brussels Conservatory. With all due respect for Mr. Kaufman's zeal on behalf of Vivaldi's music, it must be said that his efforts were quite misguided.

LOS ANGELES -- Although Southern California, after last winter's celebrated "deep freeze" is one place that is not hoping for a white Christmas -- outside of its mountain areas -- preparations for a festive Noel have been proceeding with a gusto that would do credit to the most snow-clad regions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Franklin D. Richards, commissioner of the Federal Housing Administration, stated today that the newly-announced policy against financing those developments that have restrictive covenants would have a minimum effect on his agency's activities.
PERTH, Scotland, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Earl of Strathmore, bachelor nephew of Queen Elizabeth, was charged in court today with driving a jeep while drunk. He pleaded innocent.
CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- Expulsion of seven "active members" for violation of the so-called "Sanity Code" today was recommended to the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

In a unique "know-how laboratory" operated by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation in Pittsburgh, engineers are "painting" with molten steel, cutting brass with abrasive rubber wheels that look like giant typewriter erasers and drilling holes in metal at speeds ten times faster than ever before.

THE remaining threat to industry over the near term was removed last week when Mr. Lewis decided to return his "cat and mouse" act to the boards. His soft-coal miners will return to work under their "willing and able" clause for three days a week.

THIS volume is the first to appear although the fifth in sequence of the five-volume Studies in Prejudice prepared by the Institute of Social Research -- with which the authors are associated -- for the American Jewish Committee.

THE International Court of Justice has come out of the doldrums. With work being completed on its first case and several more issues coming up, the world tribunal faces the busiest period of its three-and-a-half-year history.

Young women of society headed by the Misses Louise Wheeler and Phyllis Hoffman are serving on the debutante committee for the card party and Christmas sale in behalf of the National Cathedral Association to be held tomorrow afternoon in the ballroom of the Colony Club under the auspices of the New York Committee of the association.

THE urgent task of meeting the health and welfare needs of the community cannot be performed by the public welfare agencies alone. It requires the assistance of all members of the Community. It demands the use of the city's total social welfare resources, particularly the special skills, services and facilities of the volunteer agencies!

Critics of the "activity," or "learn-boy-doing" program in the New York public school system were challenged yesterday to prove their charges that pupils were not learning the fundamentals of the three R's.

Paul G. Hoffman ("We Must Do Our Part") should be congratulated for insisting on the urgent need for heightened imports into this country. Very few people in authority have the courage to champion this goal in the face of possible disadvantage to particular pressure groups.

Evidence that osteo - arthritis may be the product of personality traits developed during a mal-adjusted childhood, an aggressive adolescence and an unstable adult life was presented yesterday to the twenty-ninth annual meeting of the Association for Research in Nervous and Mental Disease at the New Yorker Hotel.
St. John's basketball team, paced by Captain Gerry Calabrese and Bob Zawoluk, rolled to its fifth victory in a row this season by defeating Fort Monmouth, 96 to 50, at De Gray Gymnasium last night.

Partly as the result of its poor work in analyzing the current problems of capitalist countries, the Institute of Economics of the Soviet Union has undergone a major purge and reorganization, recent Soviet publications indicate.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday was active, and closing prices were 1 to 9 points net higher than the day before.

The United Jewish Appeal announced yesterday that 5,600 Jewish communities throughout the country had been requested to begin preparations to meet needs in Israel and other parts of the world through their 1950 campaigns for the appeal.

AFTER several literary seasons given over, mostly, to the frisky antics of kids, precociously knowing and singularly charming, but not to be counted on for those gifts that arrive by no other way than the experience and contemplation of a truly adult mind, now is obviously a perfect time for a writer with such a mind to engage our attention.

The report of a Working Party on American-Soviet Relations prepared for the American Friends Service Committee and recently revised was analyzed last night by Prof. Cornelius Kruse of Wesleyan University, Middletown, Conn., at the closing session of two days of meetings.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Philadelphia made a clean sweep of a collegiate double - header tonight at Convention Hall when Temple University soundly trounced Vanderbilt, 55 -- 35, in the second game after St. Joseph's triumphed over Louisiana State, 61 -- 59, in the opener.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 3 -- Pierre Montel, chairman of the Committee of National Defense of the French General Assembly, said today that France and other countries of Western Europe, as a result of the development of the atomic bomb by the Soviet Union, would need between sixty and eighty divisions to defend themselves against Soviet attack.

The approaching holidays are bringing a heavy schedule of sales to the city's auction galleries. In four sales this week the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, are offering rare books, English period furniture, Oriental rugs, old masters and a variety of decorative objects that will go on the block in both day and evening sessions.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3 -- Business firms, financial houses and labor officials joined individuals today in the strong protests against the City Council's plan to increase the municipal tax on wages and extend it to all forms of income.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Oil experts in London indicated today that British-owned oil refineries in Haifa, which have been running at about one-tenth of capacity on crude oil from Venezuela, might have to close down again unless oil could be obtained from Arab sources nearer at hand.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 3 -Harvard's football fortunes are at the lowest ebb in seventy-five years, but 90 per cent of 3,000 undergraduates polled by The Crimson, undergraduate daily, are opposed to the university subsidizing future gridiron stars.

The Rev. Laurence J. McGinley, president of Fordham University, declared last night that the American business structure would collapse if its operators "continue to ignore the social implications of the industrial civilization they have created."

BOSTON, Dec. 3 -- Adrenal hormones, including the anti-arthritic cortisone, can be produced by feeding abundant and cheap raw materials to the glands of slaughterhouse animals kept alive in laboratory test tubes, it was reported here this afternoon by scientists from the Worcester Foundation for Experimental Biology.

" Opportunities for economic advancement under the guidance of free enterprise appear greater than ever before in our history," said Edward H. Foley Jr., Under-Secretary of the Treasury, speaking yesterday at the annual convention of the National Council of Salesmen's Organizations in the Astor Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Yale led the way today at the halfway mark of the two-day "frostbite" regatta, annual classic for collegiate skippers who like their sailing cold and rough.
ATLANTA, Dec. 3 -- The stepped-up campaign of the South's State's Rights movement provided top interest this week throughout the area.

A ring of car thieves, responsible for the theft of between 300 and 400 late-model automobiles that were marketed in South America and Europe, was brought to light yesterday by the Police Department's Automobile Squad.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 3 -- Communist organs in Trieste have been doing everything possible to revive racial bitterness, Maj. Gen. T. S. Airey, commander of the British-United States zone, reported to the United Nations Security Council today.
IN whatever direction the winter tourist may travel from New York, he will find generally improved equipment on through trains, but fares will be a little higher than last year.

WITH camera prices lower than they were last year and with more inexpensive equipment on dealer shelves, cameras should be high on Christmas gift-shopping lists. In spite of added improvements, many of the prices are close to, if not equal, pre-war levels, and the choice is much wider.

Champion Senta, 4-year-old Great Dane owned by Mrs. Herta Schroeder of Dunellen, N. J., gained the most important victory in her show ring career yesterday when she was named best in the second annual all-breed fixture of the Brooklyn Kennel Club at the spacious 106th Infantry Armory.

MEXICO CITY -- By driving down the Pan American highway, the only paved road reaching deep into Mexico, a vacation in that country can begin the moment the border is crossed. The 748 miles between Laredo, Tex., and Mexico City are dotted with interesting towns and villages that are missed when traveling by train or plane.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 22 -- After seven troubled months, starting from Col. Husni Zayim's overthrow of the first Syrian Republic at the end of March, the fate of the country has been placed in the hands of Syria's first genuine political party.

SARASOTA, Fla. -- The winter tourist business along the lower Florida west coast from Bradenton to Fort Myers has taken a spurt since the end of the war. To keep pace with the uptrend, new construction of tourist accommodations is under way.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Federal Government has asked the Supreme Court to review Michigan's strike regulation law, contending that the statute deals with issues pre-emptied by Congress in the Taft-Hartley Law.
