SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 3 -- With a dozen western Senate seats in contest in 1950, the fight over the Brannan farm program is expected to get considerably hotter.

The generous effort of the good American women to combat illiteracy in Italy (Carlo Levi's "Italy Fights the Battle of Illiteracy") would be funny if it were not so tragic. Have they compared the statistics on our own illiteracy, as reported by the U. S. military authorities?

QUEBEC -- Snow resorts in the Montreal and Quebec City areas expect to be filled to capacity this winter, judging by advance bookings. By mid-November most resorts were booked for the Christmas and New Year's week-ends, and a number of resorts were booking winter vacationists by the week only for January and February.

PARIS, Dec. 3 -- Negotiations for a trade bloc comprising France, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg have struck snags, and heads of the Belgian and Netherlands delegations asked today for new instructions from their Governments.

WHILE business men and others who use the airlines regularly throughout the year continue to fly abroad and around the country in all directions, the winter vacationers who take to the air after the season's first snowfall travel in definite patterns, following general east-west and north-south courses.
The Vassar Club of New York will hold its twenty-eighth annual benefit at the Metropolitan Opera House Jan. 28, when "Le Nozze di Figaro" will be sung, it was announced yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS -- About the time most Easterners and Midwesterners are getting used to winter, what is loosely called the fall season is beginning in the New Orleans area. At this time a stream of tourists starts to flow into the Crescent City by train, bus and airplane, not only to escape wintry blasts elsewhere, but also because New Orleans is easy and inexpensive to get to.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3 -- Pope Talbot, Inc., which operates cargo vessels over three routs and carries on large lumber operations, celebrated its 100th anniversary this week. It is one of the few West Coast companies dating to the gold rush era.

Without any thought of criticizing the magnificent performance of the Schoenberg Serenade under Dimitri Mitropoulos' leadership, at the last concert of the I. S. C. M., I think it historically necessary to correct a misinformation. The program bore the mention, "first New York performance."

Swiss control of the millions of dollars held in that country and through Swiss banks here, but owned by the thousands of persons who were deported to Germany in the war years, is being challenged in courts of this country. A legal action, involving Dr. Jorg T. Heyd, now in Germany, against the American Express Company, Inc., was brought last week in the Supreme Court, New York County.

BOSTON, Dec. 3 -- Massachusetts old age recipients became eligible this week for an extra $4 monthly allowance for "leisure time activities," voted to them in the closing hours of the legislative session in September.

MIAMI BEACH -- This city's oceanfront area has become swimming-pool-conscious, although the city's eastern boundary is a solid eight-mile strip of bathing beaches. Almost $10,000,000 has been invested in the construction of pools and cabana clubs along the fabulous "Gold Coast" during the past few years.

A "COUP" in bridge is any play that appears to sacrifice a trick only to win back two or more tricks in exchange. Most of the plays known as coups have extravagant names -- Deschappelles Coup, Vienna Coup, Pitt Coup -- and extreme scarcity of occurrence.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Departments of Commerce and Labor said today that a record number of dollars spent for new construction was "virtually assured" for 1949.

Concerning Wright Morris' "Summer Encore," no one in Indiana during the first two weeks of November, 1949, would have had to depend on "old-timers gathered around a cracker barrel" to believe in Indian summer. * * *

The New York State Association for Crippled Children, 257 Fourth Avenue, announced yesterday reorganization and expansion of its medical advisory board into a state-wide professional advisory committee.

DENVER, Col. -- The advance guard of an expected quarter-million skiers is breaking out the trails and spruce-lined slopes of Colorado's high country already and filling the white silences with an unusual amount of cheer.

Since its opening in 1931 as the first municipal hospital in the United States devoted exclusively to chronic disease, Goldwater Memorial Hospital has continuously been identified with pioneer programs in the care of patients with long - term illnesses.

MR. BURMAN, who has done very well with his folksy, good-natured novels depicting life on the Mississippi and other rivers ("Steamboat Round the Bend," "Rooster Crows for Day," etc.), moves ashore for "Everywhere I Roam" and chronicles the cross-country wanderings of a nomadic, back-country Kentuckian and his three teen-age children.

MORE than most art seasons, this one so far as it has gone has presented evidence in the one-man shows that our artists do not stand still. Many of the shows have indicated a gratifying advance on the part of the exhibitor; a few have come in the nature of veritable sea changes; hardly any have denoted a decline and few have marked time.

SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia, Dec. 3 -- Three more defendants in the trial of Russian emigres pleaded guilty today to charges of collaboration with the Gestapo during the Nazi occupation of Yugoslavia and espionage on behalf of the Soviet intelligence service. They were Vladimir Ogniev, Anatoli Polyakov and Ilya Zherebkov.

THIS book is a collection of interrelated stories about certain people in Lafayetteville, Pa., somewhere between Pittsburgh and Philadelphia, "set on a hill and in a valley, beside a dirty, yellow river." In 1927, when the stories begin, the population was 22,767.
LONDON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, told Britons today he would "rather have the United States as a welfare state than a Wall Street state."

PEOPLE who love all kinds of maps, who like to pore over atlases, historical geographies and various projections of the sphere, will find a kind of excitement in the publication of a new geographical dictionary. Yet this book is not precisely for them, but rather for use as a quick and convenient reference book by those who read the daily papers, the Bible and ancient or modern history.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., Dec. 3 -- The great guessing game of who would win the national retriever championship continued today as three more series, one providing a notably formidable test in Moriches Bay, were held. If none but the judges knew for sure which dog was most likely to reach the highest peak in retriever field work, the identities of eight that definitely would not were established as concrete fact.
Aid to the world's underdeveloped areas should be channeled through the United Nations, speakers at a meeting of the Middle Atlantic States Philosophy of Education Conference declared yesterday.
DALLAS, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Three Notre Dame all-Americas today accepted invitations to play in the East-West football game at San Francisco Dec. 31, Managing Director William M. Coffman announced today.

NORMAN, Okla., Dec. 3 -- Three bodies were removed today from the ruins of a wooden dormitory that housed 349 University of Oklahoma students after an early morning fire destroyed the five-wing two-story structure.

THE viburnums are an exceptionally hardy group of shrubs that are well suited to large - scale, naturalistic plantings. They require no regular pruning and, left to develop in their own way, they make sturdy specimens for the shrub border.

Lambert Fairchild, who wrote in your letters column his opinion that citizens who fail to vote should be compelled to give a good excuse or be deprived of the privilege at the next election, should have mentioned New Jersey's practice.

IT is regrettable that two acts of violence, essential to the plot, puts "Rosa" in the classification of a murder story. The book deserves a better fate, a wider audience. Based on the life and sudden death of an Austrian refugee, the story presents the unusual personification of what was once known as "character" amid an amoral group of associates.

THE winter tourist, whose holiday season is just about getting started with the Northeast suffering -- or enjoying -- the first touches of wintry weather, will benefit this year from a three-way appeal for his interest and patronage. Normally, the winter holidayers divide about 65-35 between those who follow the sun south and the smaller group of snowbirds who travel in the other direction in search of weather and snow suitable for skiing.

Theophylactus of Simocatta, Eastern Roman historian, who lived toward the end of the sixth century A. D. and wrote "A Universal History," has recorded the first appearance of the Slavs on the stage of world diplomacy -- a stage where they now play so great a part, often to the confusion of the other actors and the amazement of the audience.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3 -- The CIO is running into lawyer trouble in its effort to establish a new anti-Communist union in place of the old United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3 -- How Harry Bridges, the CIO long-shoremen's leader, would fare in his present perjury trial after escaping deportation following two hearings and a Supreme Court decision, was a matter of wide speculation this week on the West Coast as the third week of the proceeding ended.
Christmas cards and parcels should be mailed now without further delay to assure punctual arrival, Postmaster Albert Goldman of New York warned yesterday.

MASTERPIECES of man's building, like the Pyramids, the Taj Mahal and the spire of Salisbury Cathedral, are usually to be found on level landscapes where they can be features of the skyline. This second of Mr. Parker's fine albums devoted to scenery in the national parks of the United States reveals the overpowering competition of nature's majesty which man's prudent architecture likes to keep at a safe distance.
OMAHA, Dec. 3 -- Neighboring Midwest states were showing unusual interest this week in the political storm that is brewing in Iowa around Republican Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper.
" THANKS very much for sending those tickets to my brother," said Greasy Neale appreciatively, "It was most generous of you."

HAVANA -- Two things generally strike first - time visitors to Cuba as soon as they disembark from their planes at Rancho Boyeros Airport, or from their ships in Havana harbor: the simplicity of entrance requirements, and the delightful weather.

ON Nov. 26 1764, the little city of Hartford, Conn. (population about 4,000), had a new newspaper. It was issued by Thomas Green, who had previously managed a printing office in Hartford, from rooms over James Mookler's barber shop.

NOW and again, as some more than usually dramatic trial catches the attention of the public, and the activities of prosecutors and defense attorneys are described at length in the daily papers, widespread interest is aroused in the manners and methods of trial lawyers.

BELHAVEN, N. C., Dec. 3 -- For the hunter who really likes a mixed bag this area is one of the few spots along the East Coast that is capable of providing it, for you may hunt deer, quail and waterfowl with an excellent chance of taking limits in all three categories.

LONDON, Dec. 3 (UP) -- The British film industry faces some sort of government control unless Hollywood agrees to send in more films for the same amount of dollars it now is permitted to draw, it was reported today by an informed source.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, rejected today the demands of two accused unions that outside panels be chosen to hear charges of Communist - domination against ten CIO unions.

TAHOE CITY, Calif. -- The Far West's newest ski resort is ready for its first winter Boasting "the world's largest ski lift," which parallels the old emigrant trail over which California pioneers pound their way through the Sierra Nevada barrier, Squaw Valley is bidding for a place on the nation's sports map.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 3 -- The fiery crosses of the Ku Klux Klan continue to light up countrysides over the South, and waves of violence and intimidation are reported here and there. But a growing army of persons and organizations opposed to the principles and practices of the hooded order is fighting back with increasing vigor and gaining some ground in the struggle.

TO his many volumes on European history, Mr. Schevill -- retired from the duties of Professor of Modern History at the University of Chicago -- has now added one devoted to that family which has remained for centuries among the most continuously fascinating and discussed of all famous families, the Medici.

The Port of New York Authority, in a brief filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington last week renewed its fight to force the railroads to abandon a surcharge applied on produce delivered to, and unloaded at, Manhattan pier stations, it was announced by Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the bi-state agency.

International understanding is definitely aided through the study of foreign languages, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, declared yesterday. He emphasized that "technological 'know-how' is not enough when the expert is required to translate the 'know-how' into the foreigner's native tongue."

Economists generally agree that flexibility in the main source of Federal revenues -- the tax upon income of individuals and corporations -- is essential as a fiscal policy in order to attain economic stability over a long period of time.

IN a sense, of course, any book that one wants is a good book for Christmas. I once knew, for instance, a young writer who asked for and got Kempf's "Psychopathology" -- a peculiarly burdensome work with gruesome pictures -- and that was all right, too, even though it did look a bit queer -- emerging from tissue paper and red ribbons.

With water consumption continuing at almost the "normal" rate and no substantial rainfall in sight for the next few weeks, New York now has only one chance in five of filling its reservoirs by next June, Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, said yesterday.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Vast patches of scorched earth scarred the Gulf coastal region today and hundreds of forest fires still burned.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- The season outlook here, most resort owners believe, boils down to this: More tourists spending less money and demanding more return for what they do spend. St. Petersburg is still engaged in a hectic building boom which got under way in 1946 and shows little sign of slackening.

Having held themselves in firm restraint as long as anyone could reasonably expect, baseball's bigwigs are about to move into the open again, and for the next week and a half there should be some intensive wind-jamming up and down the Atlantic seaboard.

LONDON. THE brain is a mystery -- it has been -- and still will be. Not that we do not know many facts about it. The facts we know have indeed greatly multiplied in recent years, but they all fail to give us a key to the mystery of how it creates -- if it does create -- our thoughts and feelings; that is, said more concisely though less concretely, our mind.

TAMPA, Fla. -- This city is making a special bid for tourists who enjoy fishing. Along the waters of Old Tampa Bay, on the causeway to Clearwater, concrete pavilions provide outdoor tables for picnickers, while fishermen cast into the water off the sandy beaches.

TO Bess Streeter Aldrich, Christmas signifies children coming home to mother, gay family reunions with presents, doughnuts, traditional oyster supper, Christmas trees strung with popcorn, and celebration by the whole community with the absence or temporary breakdown of class distinctions.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 3 -Auburn, winner of only one game all season, scored the easy way, added another touchdown on sheer power and hung on like the Tigers they are called to outplay and upset mighty Alabama today, 14 -- 13.

BILOXI, Miss. -- Fully recovered, after some setbacks, from the disastrous hurricane of two years ago, the Gulf Coast of Mississippi and near by states is again being called "the Riviera of America." Recent months have brought a sharp increase in the thousands of visitors crowding the shores, drives and resort centers of this balmy area that offers year-round rest and recreation.

EVERYBODY talks about California, but few people do anything about it -- such as delving beneath the surface to find out the causes of its manifold enormities. Industrially, commercially, scientifically, California has become an entity and a force to be reckoned with.

I have recently returned from a month's visit to England, my native land, where I had opportunities for frank discussions with all classes of people about the distressing financial situation of "the old country."
Administration candidates have swept to victory over a "rank and file" opposition slate in an election held among members of Local 100, Transport Workers Union, CIO, it was announced yesterday.

A KOOLITE head containing a fluorescent grid cold light lamp is now available for the DeJur Versatile line of enlargers. The new head is interchangeable with the standard condenser unit when a diffusion type of light is needed.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 3 -- The most comprehensive scrutiny ever given by a conference of business men to the problem of promoting wider ownership of shares in American private enterprise, among masses of people unacquainted with the financial markets, is going forward at the Hollywood Beach Hotel here today and tomorrow.

Foreign boat builders from England and Canada and a British Diesel engine manufacturer will launch a keen competition against American firms at the Fortieth Annual National Motor Boat Show, which will open Jan. 6 at Grand Central Palace.

JAMES THURBER, whose compassionate satires and timely fables (both drawn and written) have made him America's most subtle and gifted humorist, will celebrate his fifty-fifth birthday on Thursday. He is completely philosophical about it.
TWENTY-FIVE years ago, when I first made pictures in Italy, Vesuvius erupted on schedule for a sce in "Romola" and Prince Umberto consented to play an extra in "The White Sister."
CHARLESTON, S. C., Dec. 3 (AP) -- Scoring in every quarter, the University of South Carolina Gamecocks ran and passed to a 42-0 football victory over The Citadel Bulldogs today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 3 -- Dr. T. F. Tsiang, Chinese Nationalist representative to the United Nations, today asked for an appointment over the week-end with Dr. Philip C. Jessup, United States Ambassador at Large, to discuss a compromise resolution on the Chinese Communists.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Dec. 3 (AP) -- Justice Jesse E. Kingsley of the state Supreme Court said today he wanted James B. Carey, acting leader of the CIO's new Electrical Workers Union, "to know that he will obey the order of this court."

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 3 (UP) -- The country's Roman Catholic Bishops reported today that Premier Antonin Zapotocky had replied to their request for a revision of the new church control laws with a blazing letter of rejection that sounded as though it were addressed to "criminals."

At the U. N. the Russian-American struggle -- which has run through most of the 520 meetings of the present session of the General Assembly -- has headed up in debates on adoption of a "peace plan." Early in the session Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky introduced a resolution denouncing the United States and Britain as warmongers and calling for a Big Five pact to assure peace.

DETROIT, Dec. 3 -- The automobile industry, anxious to "ring out the old" with a production record in 1949 of more than 6,000,000 trucks and cars, sent out urgent calls and telegrams today to thousands of workers whose jobs were restored ahead of schedule by the alleviation of steel and coal shortages.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Grain markets threw off early hesitancy and moved up briskly in late dealings on the Board of Trade today. The advance was led by wheat, which jumped more than 2 cents a bushel at times. All old-crop wheat contracts made new seasonal highs.

LONDON. AMERICA and America's virtues, responsibilities and stupidities form much of the daily substance of the average Englishman's newspaper reading, but still he has a picture of America that is at best blurred and colored by legend, and at worst viciously distorted.

CRUGERS, N. Y., Dec. 3 -- A city of thirty-six spacious brick buildings, connected by a maze of covered corridors and subterranean tunnels, has risen in three years on 383 acres of scenic plateau and roiling woodland here beside the Hudson River.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Dec. 3 -- Intensified political action to defeat "the remaining reactionary" members of Congress in 1950 was set in motion here today at the eleventh biennial convention of the New Jersey CIO industrial union council.

NEWARK, Dec. 3 -- A nine-day strike of 360 clerks and meat cutters against Safeway Stores, Inc., in Northern New Jersey ended this evening when a tentative agreement between the two parties was rached in the office of the State Mediation Board here.

PARIS, Dec. 3 -- The North Atlantic treaty that was initialed in the auditorium of the State Department in Washington last April 4 became a military reality in Paris this week. The military and civilian defense heads of the twelve treaty countries met here to discuss and to approve the broad strategies and the program for mutual defense for which the treaty provides.

Benefitting from an upturn in earnings of the nation's industrial manufacturers in the third quarter of this year, the combined net income of 496 manufacturing companies for the three quarters came to $3,591,157,967. In the corresponding period last year they chalked up $3,978,485,798.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 3 -- The Toledo Rockets met their first Glass Bowl defeat today from Cincinnati's Bearcats, 33 -- 13, before a crowd of 8,500.
The increasingly acute water shortage was brought home to New Yorkers last week. These were some of the effects:

Long Island University's quintet easily turned back the touring Puerto Rican San German Olympics, 73 to 38, at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy Gymnasium last night. The losers were returning a visit the Blackbird had made to Puerto Rico early this season.

" THE cowpaths lead to mysterious fields," wrote William T. Davis in "Natural History Notes," the journal he kept for fifty-six years, seven bulky volumes written in longhand on both sides of the paper. As with Henry Thoreau of Concord and Gilbert White of Selbourne, Willie Davis. "Bug" Davis and "One" Davis -- he answered to all three -- found what he sought almost at his doorstep.

ALLEGAN, Mich., Dec. 3 (AP) -- Representative Clare E. Hoffman, Republican, of Michigan, filed a $50,000 libel suit today against a fellow member of Congress, a newspaper publisher, three union officials and a news dealer here. The suit stemmed from remarks which Mr. Hoffman said Representative John Lesinski, Democrat, of Michigan, made at a CIO steelworkers' strike rally at Kalamazoo a year ago.

PARIS, Dec. 3 -- Following the resignation of Minister of Agriculture Pierre Pflimlin over a question of fixing prices, the Peasants' group in the National Assembly voted today to withdraw their minister from the Government on a basis of if and when.

THE radio listener undoubtedly is today's forgotten man. The networks and the sponsors of programs have become so preoccupied with the glamour of television that they have virtually forsaken the individual who, either through choice or geographic location, can only listen and not look. It is time that the non-looker got a break.
EVELYN EATON gives a cool ironic account of herself in a memoir that is quite unlike the usual run of humorous travel diaries.

WARSAW, Sunday, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Foreign Ministry has made a "very sharp protest" to France over alleged mistreatment of Polish Vice Consul Jozef Szczerbinski, the Polish Press Agency said early today.
A gala welcome will be extended to the new Norwegian motorship Oslofjord when the streamlined luxury liner arrives here tomorrow morning on her maiden voyage from Norway.

THE ingenious and indefatigable Frank J. Sheed has again hit upon a happy idea in this compilation of sketches of the lives of forty saints from St. Paul to St. Teresa of Lisieux, written by various modern authors, mostly English or Irish. He makes this observation:

Andre Berry, French pianist, gave her first New York recital late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. She was presented by Raymond Duncan as the winner of his Prix de New York 1949. The recital was free and almost 1,000 persons came to hear the 75-year-old philosopher's new protege.

IT looks like a good winter for the birds -- from the food standpoint. More and more people who have been forced indoors by snow or cold are finding a new interest by enticing the feathered clan into their backyards with winter feeding stations.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Northerners seeking the comfort of a Florida winter without the crowds, excitement and glamour of Miami and Miami Beach can find many other cities along the state's east coast that make tourism their business.

CEDARHURST, L. I., Dec. 3 -- Diehl Mateer of Philadelphia, winner of the Gold Racquet last year, was eliminated from the annual invitation squash racquets tournament of the Rockaway Hunting Club today in the second round.

READERS familiar with the novels of Rumer Godden, with their intrinsic imagination, will not be surprised that her latest work is a story in verse. "In Noah's Ark" the legend of the Flood is retold with an enchanting difference.

FORT MYERS, Fla. -- This west coast resort city celebrates its 100th birthday this winter and is giving itself a winter-long birthday party culminating with a Centennial Week and the Edison Pageant of Light in February.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- An electronic selector that can scan a coded library catalogue at the rate of 120,000 entries a minute, or about 10,000 times as fast as a human worker, is under development by the Department of Agriculture and the Atomic Energy Commission.

VIENNA -- The big news of the 1949-50 Austrian winter sport season is the devaluation of the Austrian schilling in terms of the dollar and other foreign currencies. Because a general election was in prospect the Austrian Government waited two months after the devaluation of the pound to bring its currency into line.

THOSE who believe that a designer, in order to be considered "contemporary," must confine himself to square lines, unornamented surfaces and stridently functional materials, like stainless steel and plywood, may be surprised by present evidences of a luxury look in modern decor.

THIS powerful work on Jewrylaw in medieval Germany -that is, on the portion of Christian law specifically affecting the social and economic behavior of the Jewish community -- beyond doubt will remain the definitive source of information in this field for many years to come.

CALL it a new movie merchandizing approach if you will, but the RKO circuit last week made history by offering free admissions to its houses to customers who might not enjoy "Everybody Does It." The Twentieth Century-Fox comedy will begin stands on Wednesday at RKO neighborhood houses in Manhattan, the Bronx and Westchester.

Ten newspaper editors will interview spokesmen for American industry in an open, unrehearsed free-style interview Thursday afternoon before the fifty-fourth annual Congress of American Industry in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

BOULDER CITY, Nev., Dec. 3 -Another step in the vast program of harnessing the Colorado River will get under way in a few days when engineers begin impounding water behind Davis Dam, sixty-seven miles down river from Hoover Dam here.

Winifred Young, pianist, gave a long recital in Carnegie Hall late yesterday afternoon. She is an experienced performer who has definite opinions about the music she plays and often succeeds in giving apt impressions of its contours.

PIKEVILLE, Ky., Dec. 3 (AP) -- The first crack in a solid operator front against John L. Lewis and his United Mine Workers appeared here today. A union official announced that thirty-four truck mine coal companies of the Big Sandy area were considering a contract which might put them back on a five-day work week basis after next week.
LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Officially Britain's political campaign will not start until after the New Year. Unofficially, it is well under way.

A traveling business show will be opened in Detroit tomorrow by the International Business Machines Corporation, it was announced yesterday. The snow will feature electronic working set-ups to demonstrate the operation of electronic tubes in performing calculations in I. B. M. computing units at such speeds as 2,174 additions and subtractions a second.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Ewan Clague, Commissioner of Labor Statistics, said today that pensions for everybody seemed assured with "the old and the near-old" making up half the voting population.

THIS will be more than just another winter to the 4,000,000 ski enthusiasts throughout the United States. This year, for the first time, the world ski championships of the Federation Internationale de Ski (FIS) are to be held in this country -- at Lake Placid and at Aspen, Colo.

AT the quaint, worn little bookshops along Charing Cross Road one may get the impression that Londoners are planning to start now to escape the season's equally inevitable fogs and crises by determinedly settling down to a long winter's reading. Some little shops are as crowded as subways.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 3 -- The New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards went on record today as favoring a constitutional amendment limiting Federal taxation to 15 per cent of national income.

THE Federation Internationale de Ski (FIS), the world ruling body for the sport of skiing, was founded on Feb. 2, 1924, at Chamonix, France, about one generation after the start of international ski competitions. Ski meets had been held, generally speaking, since 1890 and by 1910 competitive skiing had become widepread, not only in the northern countries, where it had long flourished, but also in Central Europe.

As the result of another trip through Amazon jungles, Dr. Paul Kosok, chairman of Long Island University's history department, is applying the final touches to an "Andean Rhapsody" -- a work based on songs and dance music of descendants of the Incas.

WHILE the bags were being packed and the car greased for a looking-and-listening trip around these United States, this traveler's attention was called to a complaint from New Brunswick, N. J. Dr. Richard P. McCormick, Assistant Professor of History at Rutgers University, said that New Jersey lacked state pride and had no economic, political or cultural unity.

SAN JUAN, P. R. -- A center of luxury and privilege has become a symbol of new hope for Puerto Rico's under-privileged, who see in the opening of the Caribe Hilton Hotel in San Juan, a point of leverage for their now famous "operation bootstrap."
HILLSBOROUGH, Calif., Dec. 3 -- Major Gen. George Fleming Moore, whose individual courage at Corregidor was cited by General Douglas MacArthur, killed himself with his service revolver last night.

SALEM, Ore. -- Skiers will find exercise at a minimum and downhill swoops at a maximum in the immense mountain fastnesses of the Pacific Northwest during the forthcoming winter season. New ski lifts, tows and tramways are under construction throughout the region to make it easier and speedier for the skier to get back up to the top of his run.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 3 -Rhode Island's leading woolen and worsted mills are looking ahead to steady operation through February on the basis of orders already on the books. This is a far different picture than pertained a year ago, when an adjustment at the end of the post-war boom had set in and was causing major cutbacks in production and heavy layoffs of workers.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The East Asian Christian Conference was formally opened today while a dissident missionary organization charged the conference leadership with supporting communism.

CATANIA, Italy, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Earth shocks jolted the Mt. Etna area at intervals today and flames belched from the main crater high above farm lands newly seared by its molten lava. The threat of a major disaster, however, appeared diminishing.

Jokes circulating in Europe today include a few that are simply "a laugh for a laugh's sake," but most of them serve as ideological and political weapons. Many are recognizable as new versions of old stand-bys. This selection is from Times correspondents.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Former Representative Andrew J. May, Democrat, of Kentucky, will receive a monthly Government pension of about $280 all the time he is in prison and for the rest of his life when he gets out. He is under sentence of eight months to two years for bribery and conspiracy.
DALLAS, Dec. 3 (AP) -- An early resumption of the Notre Dame-Army game was forecast today by Ed Krause, athletic director of Notre Dame.

RECORDINGS of piano music have been numerous in recent weeks, and one of the most impressive has been by Rudolf Firkusny, who is not so widely represented in the gramophone repertory as some of the more glamorized names.

Christmas buying got under way actively here last week. Department store sales were estimated at about 5 per cent under the comparative week of last year. Retailers reported strong emphasis on medium price brackets, with a return to the normal buying pattern.

Last week the retiring chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, David E. Lilienthal, told the newspaper men and women who attended what may well have been his last press conference that under the direction of Dr. Lawrence Hafstad new "reactors" were to be built to determine the possibilities and impossibilities of atomic power.

AN Italian film which won the grand prize at the Brussels Film Festival, and which seems likely to take further honors, opens in New York Dec. 12. The movie tells no rounded story; rather it relates an incident in the life of a worker's family -- the theft of the bicycle which is vital to the father's new job, and the subsequent search for it.

ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands -- Within a year, on the lush hillside where the legendary Bluebeard's Castle commands a panoramic view of the Caribbean and looks down on the storybook-like town of Charlotte Amalie, there will be a new, modern guest house -- the major item in a half-million-dollar improvement program at Bluebeard's Castle Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Joint Senate-House Atomic Energy Committee will investigate the story told by a former Army captain that shipments of uranium, atomic information and other secrets went to Russia during the war in lend-lease planes.

AN electric atmosphere is generated at the Buchholz Gallery, where Alexander Calder's latest mobiles and stabiles are on view. For these consummately clever wire and metal constructions are almost surcharged with potential energy.
Unless something radical is done strikes will continue; strikes disastrous to labor, industry and the general public.
CAMP KILMER, N. J., Dec. 3 (UP) -- This Army camp, built in a feverish rush when World War II began, sent its last soldier overseas today and quietly closed its gates.

" LET'S have a 'Be Kind to Daddy' Week" was the enthusiastic suggestion a few weeks ago from the youngest in our home. We were reminded of it several times as we reviewed the pre-Christmas toy problem.

The Cominform (Information Bureau of the Communist and Workers Parties) was founded in the town of Miszlawkowice in Poland, in September, 1947. The chairman of the Cominform's "constitutional convention'' was the late Andrei Zhdanov of the Soviet Union's Politburo.

ANYBODY can plant a terrarium, but a certain amount of skill and patience is needed to produce one that will last. A miniature woodland scene that is confined to a glass bowl would be an excellent type to establish at this time of year.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 29 -- Although last July the Communist Government in Shanghai set as one of its goals the moving of a large part of the city's industry into the interior, only four of its thousands of plants are known to have been moved so far.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 2 -- With the election only nine days away, Prime Minister Joseph B. Chifley and the leader of the Opposition, Robert Gordon Menzies were equally confident of success. Both were chary, however, of attempting to forecast probable party strength in the new Parliament, but both think that the voting will be close.

WITH highway regulations reportedly being enforced more rigidly this year than heretofore below the snow line, motorists driving to Florida and other southern areas are advised by the Automobile Club of New York to study in advance the traffic and speed laws in the states through which they will pass.

IN this book a student of trees and forestry pleads eloquently in behalf of our living heritage -- the forest. Mr. Baker has ranged the world to look at forests; he has seen the results of reckless timber-cutting and exhaustive cultivation -- erosion, rivers charged with good earth, aridity in place of fertility.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Labor circles here were exceedingly skeptical today of the effects of the "compromise" under which the door has been opened to inclusion of Christian (Catholic) trade unions in the new Free World Labor Federation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The big question among economists today is this: What effect will labor's fourth-round gains have on prices and on the national economy generally?

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- From the moment it became apparent that the Chinese Communists soon would be in effective control of most of China, opinion in Whitehall was that British recognition of the new regime was inevitable. In due course the British Government decided upon recognition but did not fix the time.

DESPITE reports that the British soon will recognize the Chinese Communist regime, this British crown colony continues to live a life of high tension, uncertainty and contradictions. Throughout the colony, from Gov. Sir Alexander Grantham down, there is sentiment for recognition of the Peiping regime to make Hong Kong safe from invasion from the north, if for nothing else.

IN "Volume Two" Jose Garcia Villa has presented a pure, startling and resounding body of poetry remarkably consistent in its devotion to spiritual reality. His style, while new, is readily assimilable and provokes enjoyment in its assimilation. But the subject-matter is formidable in that the author is a God-driven poet who writes interminably about God.

Theatre parties for current Broadway productions continue as a popular means of augmenting the funds of various charitable organizations. The performance of "I Know My Love," with Lynn Fontanne and Alfred Lunt in the leading roles, on Thursday night at the Shubert Theatre has been taken over to benefit the Viewpoint School Scholarship Fund.

PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti -- The remains of Henri Christophe's Queen and his Princess daughter, who fled Haiti to die tragically in Pisa, Italy, after the now-legendary Emperor blew his brains out with a silver bullet in his mountain fortress, will be officially transferred to Haiti by the Italian Government in one of the inaugural ceremonies of the Bicentenary Exposition of Port au Prince this Thursday.

MR. PEATTIE launches this book with the thesis that "out of our tradition of forest abundance has come much of our political philosophy, much of our careless generosity, our sense of immense range and possibility." From there he pokes into our history and examines the "heartwood" of American ideas and ideals.

The second perjury trial of Alger Hiss is, in a way, like a mystery novel read a second time. The surprises are no longer surprises; the drama that attended even minor details is gone. Nevertheless, there is an intense interest in the denouement of a case which seems certain to go down in history as one of the great trials of the period.

DALLAS, Dec. 3 -- Notre Dame thundered fifty-seven magnificent yards to a touchdown in the last minutes today to beat Southern Methodist University, 27 -- 20, and finish four full consecutive seasons without defeat, the first time the South Benders have accomplished such a glittering feat.

HAMBURG, Germany, Dec. 3 (AP) -- A Frenchman newly expelled by Poland was killed while on his way home by train through the United States zone of Germany today. French officials said they believed he threw himself off the train.

ALL the cruise-ship operators want now is a crisp spell of what is nostalgically known as "old-fashioned winter weather." It looks like a good season for the cruise fleet. There are more ships available and more varied accommodations and itineraries.

BEFORE the present music season started there were some who predicted there would be almost 10 per cent fewer concerts than in the previous season. A slow September, with only thirteen events, seemed to bear them out.

Before and after every popular election somebody is sure to come up with the proposal that those citizens who don't vote be taxed, fined or otherwise penalized. (See Robert Cobb Myers' "A Proposal to Tax Those Who Don't Vote.")
The role of Italy in the defense of the West began to assume new importance last week.

ZERMATT, Switzerland -Zermatt is developing so fast, inspired by the great number of winter sports fans expected this winter, that the old-timers are afraid it will lose its flavor. The tiny cow hamlet huddled at the foot of 12,000-foot peaks known to Whymper, Mommery, Rev and other pioneers of modern alpinism, is no more.

I ONCE amused myself by asking persons on the street, in stores and on street cars what they most desired out of life. This was before the polls of Mr. Gallup or of the inquiring reporter, or the stratified sample. I expected those questioned to place foremost good health, which Herbert Spencer ranked first.

THE thirty-eighth annual appeal for the Hundred Neediest Cases is made in these pages today. The need is as great as ever, even greater. The response, we are confident, will be as full and as spontaneous as always.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 3 (AP) -- Jamison (Jam) Handy, one of the founders of the American crawl swimming stroke, today called for a radical revision of the crawl to match the new slower beat Japanese free-style technique.
Motion pictures have a definite influence on the youth of today, much of it good, it was decided yesterday by a panel of six junior high school students and members of an audience of 600 youngsters.

MR. MAUGHAM, nephew of the novelist, was wounded during the Libyan campaign and later served as a British intelligence officer in the Near East, where he became interested in Arab problems. His book "Approach to Palestine" has been described in the scholarly Middle-East Journal as reflecting the opinions of the Arab League and marked by clear anti-Jewish bias.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- The overthrow of the Labor Government in New Zealand by the Conservative party this week after an election campaign in which the issues bore a broad superficial resemblance to those on which the coming general election will be fought here was a cause for public rejoicing among British Conservatives.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 3 -- Football fans in the European Command still don't know how today's Notre Dame-Southern Methodist game came out.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Dec. 3 -- Emboldened by its own amazing recovery and by the success of the Bonn Government in achieving the end of dismantling, the Ruhr is seething with agitation for the removal of Western Allied "restrictions'' and recompensation for what is called these "arbitrary acts" by the Western powers since the defeat of the Third Reich.

MOSCOW, Dec. 3 -- The Soviet press announced today the formation of a seventy-five-member committee under the chairmanship of Nikolai Shvernik, President of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet to organize the celebration of the seventieth birthday of Generalissimo Joseph Stalin Dec. 21.

Decorative and useful articles, many of which are products of the Women's Workshops of the Pestalozzi Foundation of America, may be purchased for holiday gifts at the annual Christmas sale under the auspices of the foundation to be held Wednesday afternoon and early evening at Sherry's.

The Soviet union spurned yesterday -- calling it a "Goebbels-like concoction" -- a British invitation to investigate on the scene with complete freedom the truth of Soviet charges that refugees in Britain were used as "cheap" or "slave" labor.

ALBANY, Dec. 3 -- A report urging amendment of the New York estate tax law to permit a marital deduction was approved today by the Executive Committee of the Section on Taxation of the State Bar Association.

FOR its final week at the City Center the New York City Ballet Company has still another premiere up its sleeve. This is William Dollar's version of "Ondine," set to the music of Vivaldi's "Four Seasons," but still basing the story on the scenario of the Perrot-Cerito ballet of 1843.

WHEN the usual methods of increasing plants by seeds, cuttings and layers are not practical, the age-old art of grafting is employed. But there are other reasons for grafting. Roots that are resistant to disease may be substituted for those that are susceptible, and plants whose roots fail to thrive in certain soils may be given another root system.

The two-day Institute on Local and State Health Councils just held at Princeton under the auspices of the National Health Council should help to focus attention on what these voluntary groups are doing to set a pattern of cooperation in the distribution of medical care.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The United States has formally warned the Chinese Nationalist Government to cease "immediately" its attacks on United States ships in attempting to enforce the so-called blockade of the Chinese ports.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Three factors, age and fatigue, the economic lure of outside employment and the hazards of public life, have been making it increasingly difficult for President Truman to keep together his essential high policy staff.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Dec. 3 (UP) -- Canisius College's powerful basketball team raced to its third triumph of the season tonight, defeating Oregon State, 58 to 45, before 10,331 fans in Buffalo's Memorial Auditorium. Niagara University came from behind to edge Texas A. and M., 53 -- 50, in the opening game of the double-header.

THE Dramatic Editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES thought it might intreege people to hear about the trials and tribulations that 'Gentlemen Prefer Blondes' went through before it finally became a musical show.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 3 -- The Government's decision to enforce an anti-discrimination policy for all Federally aided housing will "raise havoc" with future building projects in all parts of the country just at a time when private builders were hitting their stride with a production rate of a million residential units annually, leaders in the industry warned today.

MIAMI, Fla. -- Competition among associations promoting the three main highways which lead to south Florida may mean a new deal for winter visitors who drive to Florida this winter. Chances are good that there will not be any serious detours on U. S. 1, at least not as bad as the one which three years ago practically closed the highway along the east coast.

Christmas shopping spurred the demand for main floor gift items in the wholesale garment and accessories market here last week, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Following is the text of the United States protest to Nationalist China over the shelling of the Sir John, Franklin in Chinese waters Nov. 28:

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 3 -- The new rector of St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church at Grand and Van Vorst Streets and the new president of St. Peter's College at Hudson Boulevard and Montgomery Street here were announced tonight at the rectory in letters of authorization.

TWENTY-ONE young Negroes of the Howard University Players returned this week from a three-month tour of four European countries exhausted and a little breathless, but none the less ready and eager to talk about an unusual and stimulating theatrical experience.
I OFFER you my comments, this time, on the book "Mary," by Sholem Asch:

ALBANY -- Lake Placid is to be host to the world Nordic championships, Jan. 30-Feb. 5, and the state-sponsored Belleayre Mountain Ski Center in the Catskills will operate as soon as sufficient snow covers the trails and slopes.

The United Hospital Fund will benefit from the proceeds of the premiere of the Twentieth Century-Fox motion picture, "Prince of Foxes," on the night of Dec. 22 in the Roxy Theatre. The film, made in Italy from the novel of the same name by Samuel Shellabarger, was directed by Henry King and stars Tyrone Power, Orson Welles and Wanda Hendrix.

FOR centuries Santa Claus has been nothing but a Teutonic tourist here in France and strictly for kids. For skeptical and unsentimental French adults New Year's Day has been put aside as the occasion for exchanging gifts, name cards and best wishes.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Dec. 3 (AP) -Supreme Court Justice Frank P. Malpass today dismissed a $2,450,000 suit brought by Merwin K. Hart of New Hartford against E. P. Button Co., Inc., New York City book-publishing concern.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 3 -- British hopes for nationalization of German industries and French security demands regarding deconcentration of the German economy have conflicted with United States views on anti-trust policies in Germany and held up the entire program, it was learned today.
BOWIE, Md., Dec. 3 -- There was a bit of a surprise, to say the least, in the main act of Bowie's final racing show of the year today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 3 -- The Special Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today formally commended Indonesia and the Netherlands for settling their dispute and expressed satisfaction over the agreement to set up the Republic of the United States of Indonesia as an independent, sovereign state.

NEXT door to each other on Fifty-seventh Street at the Knoedler and Durand-Ruel galleries are two exhibitions which should be seen together. Each contains several superior paintings; both focus attention on the subject of art criticism.
HONG KONG, Dec. 3 (AP) -- A rapid Communist advance through China's Far West raised the prospect today that Chiang Kai-shek soon might abandon the mainland for his island fortress of Formosa.

MR. BENTLEY'S various publications as arbiter of the modern theatre have been strongly marked by his personal tastes and convictions, and none more strongly than the present collection of ten plays "from the modern repertoire."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The National Coal Association today accused the Truman Administration of "playing politics of the cheapest sort" in John L. Lewis' deadlocked coal negotiations with the soft coal industry.
Vito J. Cirello of 14 Washington Place, 31-year-old executive of a paper stock company, was found shot to death early yesterday morning in an alley between 112 and 114 Leroy Street.

Coming to life in the second period after having trailed at 5 -- 1, the Long Island Stars turned back the 17-goal Squadron A Stars, 12 to 7, in the feature match of the indoor polo double-header at the Squadron A Armory last night.

The chance to serve not only the poor but also those persons who can afford to pay for services they need will be provided through the $50,000,000 building fund campaign being conducted by the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York.

ALBANY, Dec. 3 -- Senator George T. Manning of Rochester, chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Highways, Canals and Revenues, said today that the committee would conduct a public hearing in Albany Dec. 12 and 13 on the controversial question of charging tolls on the barge canal and of imposing special taxes on commercial users of the highways.

December is the shortest month of the year. No argument will be accepted, if it is to the contrary; and those who point to February are merely making gestures. True, December does have thirty-one days, such as they are. But can you really call days those hurried little spans that come zipping past, once Thanksgiving is behind and Christmas lies just ahead?

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 3 -- Senator Robert A. Taft has completed for this year his "Report to the People" tour of Ohio and his associates assert that he has made "remarkable progress" and "gained ground immeasurably" in preparation for his campaign for re-election next year.

BOSTON, Dec. 3 -- The country's hospital requirements would cost an estimated $12,572,000,000 for construction alone, Isadore Rosenfield, a New York hospital consultant, told the first regional seminar on hospital design today.

THERE has been only one contemporary writer in English who, so far as style is concerned, has set his mark perceptibly on the prose fiction of our period. His name, of course, is Hemingway. There was a time, not so long ago, when a good many of the younger novelists -- and some who were not so young -- were aiming to write in the Hemingway manner.

Dr. Carl C. Pfeiffer, Dr. Elizabeth Hemmens, Elizabeth Jenney and Robert E. Lee of the University of Illinois have found that aspirin performs some of the functions of cortisone, the anti-arthritic hormone about which we have been hearing so much. Other mild pain-killing drugs, such as aminopyrine and cinchophen, also stimulate the adrenal cortex and so cause the release of cortisone from the adrenal gland.
LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Across the Thames from the "Mother of Parliaments" a new non-Communist international labor organization is quickly taking shape in the massive London County Hall.

WHILE the colleague on the left spends the morning praising Katharine Cornell, if not "That Lady," it should also be interesting to Cornell rooters that exploratory talks have been going on concerning an invitation she has received to appear next summer at the Edinburgh Festival of the arts.

Is it not time for the public to awaken to a realization that the bald eagle, our national emblem and one of our largest and most magnificent native birds, has already approached nearer to the danger line of extinction than is safe?

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3 (UP) -- Anxious to prove that their abortive strike is strictly a thing of the past, the San Francisco Forty-Niners are set to battle the powerful Brooklyn-New York Yankees in a semi-final play-off game of the All-America Conference race tomorrow.

OCALA, Fla. -- Tourist cities from here southward along the scenic Orange-Belt ridge of central Florida are preparing for what they hope will be their greatest winter season in history. Visitors really haven't seen Florida, many Floridians contend, until they have viewed the thousands of square miles of orange and grapefruit groves, the rolling highways and scenic lakes which are typical of the central section of the state.
PIERRE MONTEUX'S name stands out in great, bold letters on San Francisco's music calendar for this winter season.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Seeming contradictions notwithstanding, Communist China wants to trade with the United States.

HONG KONG, Dec. 3 -- The Communist Peiping Government today officially recognized a critical financial situation in Communist China and announced an issue of "peoples' victory bonds" in an effort to cope with it.

Action of Supreme Court Justice Harry E. Schirick in declaring the Feinberg law unconstitutional was hailed yesterday by Rabbi Edward E. Klein of the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 West Sixty-eighth Street, as an indication that the "undemocratic hysteria now sweeping our country will soon abate."

CHRISTMAS anthologies come only once a year -- but inevitably they do come, as Eric Posselt proves this season with his collection of thirty-nine tales, "World's Greatest Christmas Stories." Along with a number of classic Christmas pieces, the collection includes a number of little known, but interesting, tales, fourteen translated especially for this volume.

In promotions here last week retailers stressed handbags, rhinestone jewelry, men's nylon hose, chairs and cotton print brunch coats, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

Debutantes of this season headed by Miss Anne Whitman are aiding members of the executive committee in furthering the success of the showing of fashions, gifts and accessories to be known as a "Holiday Preview," which will be held on Wednesday during the luncheon hor in the Carnaval Room of the Sherry-Ntherland for the benefit of the Nearly New Shop.

DANBURY, Conn., Dec. 3 -- In a finding returned today by Fairfield County Coroner Theodore E. Steiber, the Danbury Hospital was held negligent in the death Oct. 13, of William Silinski, 68 years old, of this city, who suffered first, second and third degree burns four days earlier while a patient in the institution.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla. -- Visitors to Miami Beach this winter will find new glamour at their favorite sunning and sitting spots as the result of an $85,000 beautification and improvement program for recreation parks and street-end areas.

ALBANY, Dec. 3 (AP) -- A group of war veterans threatened today to quit the State Civil Service Employes Association and form a new organization if the association did not abandon what the group termed "anti-veteran policies."

ONLY the title is likely to give the uninformed reader of this excellent history any trouble. The book devotes just sixteen pages to the immense story of Naval Air in World War II and no pages at all to contacts with the enemy, tactical doctrine, or the current controversy over the role of naval aviation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The talks of the United States, British and Canadian atomic energy commissions, which began here in September, are still jogging along comfortably, with little news and no great decisions being made at the present time.

ONE of our favorite historical novelists, P. G. Wodehouse, is writing about Bertie Wooster and Jeeves again. The England of the richly idle that he has so long and lovingly lampooned in his meticulously scatterbrained comedies has gone with the wind, but he still seems to feel entertainingly breezy about it.

Pleasant but not talkative, Foma Trebin, Soviet ambassador to Venezuela, disposed of questions put to him before he sailed for Europe yesterday, by replying, "I don't want to make any statement about my voyage, myself, or anything."

MOSCOW, Dec. 3 -- The biggest continuing story in the Soviet press during the past month has been the United Nations meeting at Lake Success and particularly the series of addresses in which Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky has outlined the Soviet position.
ATLANTA -- Nowhere in the Southeast is the region's growing tourist industry more manifest than at Jekyll Island, Georgia's romantically rich playground on the Atlantic.

During World War II most college fraternities suspended activities because most of their members were in uniform. Many informed persons believed the fraternities' days were numbered, that they had outlived their usefulness. They said that when the GI's returned to school they would not be interested in "kid stuff" associated with the Greek-letter organizations.

PRAGUE, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Communist persuading committees roamed the Czechoslovak countryside today to goad backsliding farmers into delivering their prescribed crop quotas to government depots. The drive against farmers accused of being in arrears was nationwide.

A new basis for purchasing steel which may eliminate as much as 75 per cent of past rejections due to "off heats" has been developed through twelve years of research, it was revealed here yesterday by Ralph Richardson, manager, technical data section, Research Laboratories Division, General Motors Corporation, Detroit.

FROM another Soviet satellite state, this time Rumania, information reached New York dealers last week that the "Societe d'Etat pour le Commerce Exterieur" (State Company for Foreign Trade), otherwise Romanoexport, has been made sole exporter of stamps from that "People's Democratic Republic."

New developments in chemical preparation and electronic and mechanical measuring and control devices have aided textile manufacturers to cut production costs, it was pointed out last week at the annual meeting of the Textile Research Institute.

THE prospect that Mary Pickford might evict Samuel Goldwyn from the Goldwyn Studio at the corner of Santa Monica and Formosa Boulevards, where Mr. Goldwyn has made his headquarters for twenty-three years and has held undisputed sway for the last decade, titillated Hollywood mightily last week.

DETROIT, Dec. 3 -- Slender Frederick Wilt, a fleet-footed FBI agent, outsped a field of seventy starters to capture the National Amateur Athletic Union cross-country championship today. The Indiana University graduate, running under the auspices of the New York Athletic Club, covered the Warren Valley Country Club course in 30 minutes 31 seconds.

Notre Dame completed its fourth straight full season and thirty-eighth game in a row without defeat by downing Southern Methodist, 27 -- 20, at Dallas yesterday. Bill Barrett, who had scored in the third period, smashed 6 yards for the winning touchdown to culminate a 57-yard march in the final quarter.

CERTAIN steps can and should be taken now to lessen the effects of this year's drought, as well as guard against possible damage next year. Selection of drought-resistant material is possible, but more practical and immediate are ways to maintain existing plantings.

An assortment of useful and colorful articles suitable for gifts at the forthcoming holiday season will be offered for sale at the annual bazaar in behalf of the Cenacle of St. Regis to be held Tuesday afternoon and evening in the main ballroom of the Plaza.
CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- Ashton Stevens, dean of American drama critics, was honored tonight as "Press Veteran of the Year" at the eleventh annual dinner of the Chicago Press Veterans Association.

The person who acquires a doctorate spends an average of $10,000 to earn the degree. Last week, however, the State Attorney General's office disclosed that a local "mail-order diploma mill" had sold hundreds of advanced degrees at fees ranging from $1 to $75.

NASSAU, Bahamas -- A unique, year-round resort catering to tourists in the middle-income group is nearing completion on Grand Bahama, a British island sixty-five miles off the Florida coast. This new resort has been planned as a means of providing an inexpensive winter resort where working people may spend their holidays at small cost.

Some day next month a cargo of military goods, probably including artillery and ammunition, will leave some port in the United States for some port in Western Europe. This is in accordance with the principles of the North Atlantic Pact, with the terms of our Military Assistance Program and with the decisions arrived at last week by the North Atlantic Defense Committee, representing twelve nations, meeting in Paris.

Reminiscent of the snake charmer, whose subjects danced to the tune of the piper, was the attitude of John L. Lewis and his miners last week. And the movement of stocks reflected the air of uncertainty that prevailed, although prices closed higher on balance.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3 -- Philadelphia women's wear shops last week had 3 per cent less sales than a year ago and their four-weeks' sales were off 6 per cent from last year. Pennsylvania railroad carloadings last week totaled 102,175, as against 114,050 a year ago, a decrease of 10.4 per cent. For this year to date Pennsylvania railroad loadings totaled 4,781,782, to compare with 6,138,126 last year, a decrease of 22.1 per cent.

PHOENIX, Ariz. -- What to wear on that trip West? Informality is the keynote in the sun-lazing country. Dress is practical and comfortable. The men wear levis, the blue jeans of the working cowhand, and slacks, sports shirts and coats.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- Illinoisans are watching with increasing interest pre-primary jockeying in the state's 1950 Senatorial election, an activity which finds Democratic Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson and Democratic Mayor Martin H. Kennelly of Chicago apparently interested in different candidates for the Democratic nomination.

Baltimore obligingly rolled over and played dead, so the New York Knickerbockers fashioned the ninth triumph in their last ten starts with the greatest of ease yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden.

FOR THIS WEEK: Winter coverings placed too early on flower borders may do more harm than good. Postpone mulching until the ground remains frozen for more than a day or two. . . . Mulch strawberry beds two inches deep with material that tends to become compact, as will leaves or sawdust, or four to eight inches with fluffy salt hay. Spread between rows and over plants. . . .

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 3 -American vocational educators must extend their cooperation with the top levels of industry, labor, agriculture and business to plan for occupational adjustments on a national basis, E. L. Williams, president of the American Vocational Association, said here today.

WHEN the truculent young Scotsman of John Patrick's comedy drama remarks that "sorrow is born in the hasty heart," he is quoting one of the youngest old adages on record. It may come as a relief to the editors of Bartlett's Quotations and a surprise to the pundits who sagely attributed it to bygone centuries to learn the source of this particular old adage.

THE eighteenth course for flower show exhibitors and judges will be presented by the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State next month, from Jan. 24 to 27. The sessions will be held in the Colonnades Ballroom of the Essex House, 160 Central Park South, New York City.
LONDON, Dec. 3 (Reuters) -- Liverpool was held to a 2-2 tie by Portsmouth in a feature match on today's soccer card.
THE Hiram Percy Maxim Award for the year's top achievement in amateur movie-making has been won by Glen H. Turner, a Springville, Utah, art teacher, for his 8mm Kodachrome film, "One Summer Day."

TOKYO, Dec. 3 -- By the end of March, 1954, Japan's economy should be in balance again, according to a report of the Economic Stabilization Board here. The board expects mining and manufacturing to rise 80.9 per cent, and an increase in agricultural, forest and equatic production of 20.5 per cent to bring this country's foreign trade into balance without further American aid.

BOSTON -- Skiing will continue to be the major attraction in New England this winter for travelers who have made the sport a multimillion-dollar industry. Notable among the new winter sport ventures in the country's northeast corner is the expansion program of the Mount Mansfield Hotel Corporation at Stowe, Vt.

NO SOONER does a cruise ship stand away from the parachute jump at Coney Island and point out to sea than some passengers begin searching the horizon for the Gulf Stream. All the travel literature they have studied for days and days has spoken glowingly of the warm blue exotic Gulf Stream that brings the tropics to within a short sail of the Statue of Liberty.

A FLASH-BACK to photography's beginnings in France was displayed last week at the Museum of Modern Art with the opening of a new exhibition, "Roots of French Photography.'' On loan from the Cromer collection of George Eastman House in Rochester, the new show was assembled by Edward Steichen and covers the first thirty years of photography in France.

IN the Museum of Modern Art's garden, against a dramatic backdrop of the Renaissance-palace-like University Club and the brownstone houses of West Fifty-fourth Street, stands the small modern exhibition house designed by Marcel Breuer.

With the exception of rainfall on Friday, last week was regarded by most retailers as the first in the early holiday shopping season with no unfavorable conditions. For the most part, they viewed results as the first true indication of what the holiday season will bring in the way of sales.

THE last months of the War of 1812 come alive in this story of New Orleans and the pirates of Barataria. Wade Thayer, aboard his father's ship, which is running the blockade, sights an enemy sail on the horizon. It is the British frigate Cerberus in pursuit.

ALTHOUGH it would not seem apparent to New Yorkers who have seven television stations from which to choose, the video industry is suffering from an acute lack of network facilities which is affecting program schedules.

Holman, having promised to experiment with a two-platoon system, went a step further, employing three combinations and no matter which group was in action, Lafayette found itself overmatched. Actually, it was no contest.

CHRISTMAS is a time of year when window decorators do a Maypole dance around their merchandise, swaddling it in tissue paper and ribbons. The calculated effect of this is to lure shoppers into the store by partly concealing what is offered for sale.

Several performances of "That Lady," with Katharine Cornell in the leading role, at the Martin Beck Theatre have been taken over to raise funds for philanthropies. The Children's Health Service of the New York Diet Kitchen Association will be aided by the performance on Tuesday night.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 3 (AP) -- Grandview Stable's Artist Life surprised the majority of a throng of 9,005 at Tropical Park today when he held on gamely to win the E. R. Bradley Memorial Purse by an invisible nose from Bobanet Stable's favored King Midas.
Rededication of the sanctuary at the Congregational Church of North New York, 411 East 143d Street, the Bronx, indicated yesterday that the widow's mite had increased since biblical times.

Iva Kitchell paid us her annual visit last night with a program of her ridiculous dance burlesques at Carnegie Hall and had the rafters ringing with laughter most of the time. It would seem by any calculation than an entire evening on the single note of clowning, and pretty low comedy clowning at that, might be wearisome, but the amazing thing is that it is not.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 4 -- The 1949 session of the United Nations General Assembly, which convened last September amid cautious hopes that the "cold war" was gradually coming to a halt and that the Assembly could do something to help, is expected to adjourn Friday or Saturday on a very subdued note.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- Harry Stuart, United States Assistant Secretary of Air, arrived here today by plane from the United States for conferences with Royal Air Force officials regarding the development of the air reserve in the United States.

Maximilian Moss, president of the New York City Board of Education, addressing 2,000 delegates and alternates at the tenth annual convention of the Brooklyn Jewish Community Council, called yesterday on the United Nations and the United States Government to repudiate the plan calling for the internationalization of Jerusalem.

Two of the Metropolitan Opera's major acquisitions -- the new conductor, Jonel Perlea, and the soprano, Erna Berger -- acquitted themselves admirably last night in the season's first performance of "Rigoletto," which was presented for the benefit of Yeshiva University Women's Organization.

If the actors, director and playwright were all of the same mind, "Clutterbuck," which opened at the Biltmore Saturday evening, might be a very funny escapade. Benn W. Levy, who wrote "Springtime for Henry" has written this one in a deliberately artificial style that always becomes the theatre when it is well done.

Back on home ice after an extended eight-game tour, Phil Watson's New York Rovers bagged their third game in as many starts at Madison Square Garden this season by halting the hapless Atlantic City Sea Gulls, 5 to 3, in an Eastern Hockey League game before 8,238 yesterday afternoon.

PARIS, Dec. 4 -- An atmosphere of impending crisis was gathering tonight around the Cabinet of Premier Georges Bidault with the resignation of Paul Ribeyre, Under-Secretary of Health, who was the second member of the Ministry to withdraw within a week.

Two conferences meeting in New York on Friday and Saturday heard discussions of some of the objectives of the Point Four program for aid to the peoples of underdeveloped areas. It was agreed by several speakers that concentration on economic objectives must not lead to an exclusion of consideration of cultural, humanitarian and social projects.

One hundred and sixty firemen were summoned to Wall Street yesterday morning to fight a three-alarm blaze on Pier 13, East River. It was confined to underpinnings and pilings. They burned three hours while firemen used pneumatic drills to cut through timber and concrete flooring to reach the blaze.

Business taxes now account for a "vasty enlarged part" of the total of state tax collections, according to an analysis of state taxes on business, released over the week-end by the National Industrial Conference Board.

There has been a steady and increasing improvement in the sale of British products in the United States during recent months, J. W. Hobson, member of the advertising committee of the British Dollar Exports Board, said in an interview here last week.
PARIS, Dec. 4 -- The three principal events of interest to financial and economic circles here at present are:

Communities throughout the country will be watching Connecticut's examination and evaluation of its school systems with intense interest. For a long time now citizens in every state have been troubled by the sight of schools physically inadequate to meet today's needs and by the realization that too few good teachers are being drawn into the public school systems, especially at the important elementary level.
The Metropolitan Opera is engaged in paying tribute to Puccini, and on Saturday night it honored him in a fitting way. It gave its first "Madama Butterfly" of the season a glowing performance.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Government's present farm-price support program, rather than helping the farmer, is "pricing his best potential customers out of his market," the Congress of Industrial Organizations charged today in calling for enactment of the Brannan Plan.
BERLIN, Dec. 4 -- Winds that ranged up to eighty miles an hour ripped across northern Germany today, killing ten persons and injuring sixteen. The death toll in Berlin was five.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4 -- Pacific Coast shipping during the last week neared its goal in a drive started last December for long-term no-strike, no-lockout contracts covering all maritime unions.

ZURICH, Dec. 4 -- Negotiations between Switzerland and France of prime importance to intra-European trade which began in Paris on Nov. 21, aiming to simplify monetary relations between these two countries and abolish at least partly quantitative restrictions on imports, as recommended by the Organization for European Economic Cooperation, are expected soon to end.

YONKERS, Dec. 4 -- The Neustadter Home for Convalescents, a branch of Mount Sinai Hospital, was reopened formally here this afternoon after completion of a year-long $700,000 modernization program that included addition of a new wing, the Moses Weinman Memorial Building.

This dispatch is by a correspondent who recently left Communist China, where transmission facilities have been denied Western newspaper men. SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 29 -- A network of huge, monopolistic trading companies is spreading across China as the Communist armies complete their conquest of the mainland. Agents of these organs are even now moving into the smaller villages.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 4 -- Czechoslovakia's Roman Catholic Bishops have solemnly warned the Communist Government they cannot submit to church control laws that destroy religious freedom in this country. They even went so far as to suggest the possibility of a religious fight.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Richmond Rebels, with Quarterback Paul Rickards throwing three touchdown passes, overpowered the Paterson Panthers today, 35 -- 14, to win the championship of the American Football League. A crowd of 8,600 fans watched the game.

HONG KONG, Dec. 4 -- Communist China's economic difficulties cannot be solved until Formosa is captured and the Nationalist blockade is eliminated, Jao Sze-shin, political commissar of the Communist East China regional area, told a meeting of the Government Council in Peiping Friday.

DETROIT, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Joe Klukay of the Toronto Maple Leafs drove in a pair of goads tonight to beat the Detroit Red Wings, 2 -- 1, in an action-packed National Hockey League game before 14,403 fans.

My complaint is about special privileges -- special privileges in the way of: Private cars with special police authority which can park in restricted areas without fear of fines; city employes who ride free on transit lines; city officials who park in restricted areas without fear of getting a ticket.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Scoring a touchdown in the final second of the game, the Chicago Cardinals blasted the Los Angeles Rams' hopes of clinching the Western Division title of the National Football League today with a 31-27 triumph.
John L. Lewis will turn from soft to hard coal tomorrow in his six-month effort to cut an improved contract pattern for the 480,000 members of the United Mine Workers.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4 -- The value of the estate left by A. Atwater Kent is placed at $9,130,971.11 in the first accounting submitted by the two executors and approved in Superior Court.

Champion Dah-Lyn Kai Jin of Caversham, the handsome Pekingese brought here from England last May by his owner, John B. Royce of Brookline, Mass., yesterday continued to indicate he is going to be a pretty tough toy dog to beat.

WHIPPANY, N. J., Dec. 4 -- Accused of the fatal shooting of a young married couple in a crowded tavern near Hanover Township Police Headquarters here late last night, a former man friend of the woman was held without bail today in Morris County jail on charges of murder and atrocious assault.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 4 -- German sources disclosed today that the Western German Federal Government had been balking at Signing a bilateral treaty with the Economic Cooperation Administration because it would be required to assume the huge financial obligations created by the overdraft on credits by the Allied Military Government.

BERLIN, Dec. 4 -- Confirmation of rumors that two Soviet-sponsored newspapers would disappear from the Berlin scene at the end of this year was provided last night by ADN, the Soviet news agency. They are Vorwaerts, which will be absorbed by Neues Deutschland, the official organ of the Socialist Unity (Communist) party, and Tribuene, published by Free German Trade Unions.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 4 -- Efforts on the part of the Yankees to swing one of the several player deals General Manager George M.
