Weiss is understood to be brewing, commanded chief interest tonight as the baseball clans from all sectors of the nation came trooping in for the annual minor league conclaves which get under way tomorrow.
CHENGTU, China, Dec. 4 -- Chiang Kai-shek said in an interview today that the fight on the Chinese mainland would be continued at all costs and sacrifices.

The traditional pre-Christmas slump in receipts wasn't entirely unexpected last week. But no one dreamed there would be such a precipitate decline. Consequently, the departure of "The Browning Version," co-starring Maurice Evans and Edna Best, had to be advanced four weeks, from Jan. 7 to Saturday night, at the Coronet.

The recognized freedom of the seas and the right of American merchant vessels to ply these waters in the orderly, lawful pursuit of commerce are principles that Hans J. Isbrandtsen will not surrender for the cause of international politics or diplomacy.

Leon Temerson is a musician's violinist. Lest that be a damning sentence, it must be quickly added that he, and his talented pianist, Artur Balsam, pleased an audience that was far too large to be all colleagues in Town Hall last night.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Ike Williams risks his lightweight boxing title for the fifth time tomorrow in Convention Hall -- and some folks think it may be the slugger's last defense of the crown, win or lose.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- Outside markets continue to outbid Chicago for cash corn in the Central West, with the result that local arrivals last week were less than a third of those in the corresponding period last year. At one time arrivals here were smaller than at any of the five other leading markets.
SCHWEINFURT, Germany, Dec. 4 -- The German ball-bearing industry, on which virtually all West German manufacturing is directly dependent, cannot fill half the demands on it.

From babyhood to old age emotional factors play an important part in the health of teeth, dentists attending two meetings here yesterday were told. In childhood emotional disturbances may cause habits that can impair the teeth, they were advised, while in old age teeth may fall out because of neglect resulting from fatalistic attitudes.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 -- Three hundred and twenty contract bridge players began play at the Bellevue-Stratford Hotel here today for the National Open Individual Championship in the twenty-third winter tournament of the American Contract Bridge League.

As Christmas aproaches, activity in the art galleries and museums intensifies. Opening on Thursday at Wildenstein's is an exhibition of 100 French and American paintings selected from works submitted in the Hallmark contest. Proceeds from the sales of the paintings will go to the American Red Cross.

Schools of nursing in the nation admitted 43,612 first-year students this year, the largest class in any peacetime year, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Theresa J. Lynch, chairman of the national Committee on Careers in Nursing, 1790 Broadway, and director of the Department of Nursing Education at the University of Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- A positive approach to the prevention of monopoly and restraint of trade through an educational and promotional program will be explored by Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer at the request of President Truman.

In the strongest protest addressed to a Soviet puppet regime thus far, the Roman Catholic Bishops of Czechoslovakia have notified their Government that they will not obey its recent church control laws. They call on the Communist masters of their country to revise these laws or face an open religious conflict in which the Church is willing to endure new martyrdom.

If communism would "profess God" and if Christianity would come to realize that the world is "always changing," the two ideologies would have "much in common," Henry A. Wallace declared last night at a weekly forum in the Community Church, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street.

Aubrey S. Eban, permanent delegate of Israeli to the United Nations, declared yesterday that the economy of Israel was basically sound, otherwise it never could have sustained the simultaneous burdens of military defense and mass immigration.

IF we are to believe the history books, there once was a fellow named Alexander. He used to wander about in search of new worlds to conquer. Perhaps Bill Veeck is not a lineal descendant of Alexander the Great but he has the same restless conqueror's zeal. The flamboyant William transformed the moribund Cleveland franchise into a huge winner in both the league standings and the box office.

ROME, Dec. 4 -- The long-awaited Congress of Socialist Unification was inaugurated this morning in Florence. Its purpose is to create a third Socialist party standing halfway between Pietro Nenni's Left-wing Socialists, who are pro-Communist and anti-American, and Giuseppe Saragat's Right-wing Socialists, who are anti-Communist, pro-American and favorable to the North Atlantic Pact and collaboration with Premier Alcide de Gasperi.

TOKYO, Dec. 4 -- Joseph M. Dodge, General Douglas MacArthur's financial adviser, indicated today that the Occupation looked with disfavor upon "discriminatory" tax rates that imposed a lesser taxation on the foreign business community here than on the Japanese themselves.

VIENNA, Dec. 4 -- The Russification of the "people's democracies," which has proceeded at a feverish pace since the outbreak of the Titoist heresy, will reach a crescendo on Dec. 21, when Premier Stalin's seventieth birthday will be celebrated with semi-religious ceremony.
AMSTERDAM, Dec. 4 -- Important Amsterdam stockbrokers, van der Werff Hubrecht, disagree with the pessimistic views on Indonesia held by Dutch financial and trade quarters.

Better and medium price suits were selling very well in the wholesale garment market here last week and zip-out lining coats were heavily re-ordered, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

For every group of New Yorkers with a foreign background, there's a food store providing the delicacies of "the old country." Some of these establishments offer Italian specialties; in others the wares may be Syrian, French or Mexican.
Bergdorf Goodman has converted the "visions of sugar plums" seen in dreams the night before Christmas into hundreds of gifts, from a jeweled comb case to silver-blue mink ascots.
Three new films, all of which will open on Thursday, arrive this week in midtown theatres. The pictures follow:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (UP) -- The grain storage "problem" that was so troublesome last year has disappeared completely, officials of the Department of Agriculture revealed today.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 4 -- Duncan Stewart, Governor of Sarawak, was stabbed yesterday while on a visit to Sibu on the Rejang River in Sarawak. He was brought to Singapore today in a Royal Air Force flying boat.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 4 -- Bankers meeting here for the thirty-eighth annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America are convinced that the job of spreading the ownership of corporate securities among the people must be done "from the bottom up," -- that is, not by exhortation from top national trade association levels, but by selling common stocks at the local, or "grass roots," level.

The city's reservoirs, depleted to 37 per cent of their capacity, now hold only enough water to supply the needs of its 8,000,000 inhabitants for sixty days at the present rate of consumption. This warning was sounded yesterday by Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, in a radio broadcast from station WNBC appealing to the public to take every possible step to cut down water consumption and prevent leakage.
TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 4 (AP) -- Bill Schindler, one-legged driver from Freeport, N. Y., won the ten-mile feature A. A. A. automobile race today from some of the country's top drivers.
MADRID, Dec. 4 -- Anti-British feeling, which has been simmering in official circles here, boiled over today in a violent editorial attack by the Falange party newspaper Arriba.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Dec. 4 -- Carl Holderman of Rutherford was re-elected president of the New Jersey Council of the Congress of Industrial Organizations here today at the closing session of its eleventh biannual convention.

Seven men, five automobiles and a number of engraved plates were seized by the police late Saturday night and early yesterday morning in two related "Italian lottery" raids. The round-up, they said, should result in the complete break-up of a ring that has been operating in Brooklyn.
Like mother, like daughter is the theme of our pattern feature this week. During the holidays, when daughters and mothers go to parties together, they enjoy dressing alike.
Mayor O'Dwyer's tentative slate of transfers and appointments affecting key posts in his second administration calls for an extensive shake-up in his official family, it was indicated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The American Iron and Steel Institute and nearly 100 member steel companies have offered to accept a Government consent order directed against pricing practices in the sale of some eighty steel products ranging from ingots to nails.

The National Committee of the Progressive party, at a week-end meeting here, called upon the United States Government to take the initiative in a move for peace and understanding with Soviet Russia, C. B. Baldwin, national secretary, announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- Grain markets continued on the upgrade on the Board of Trade last week. All deliveries of wheat and oats and the deferred months in corn sold at new high prices for the year as the result of enlarged professional and public buying.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- George Washington University won the third annual Potomac "frostbite" regatta today, coming from behind to beat Yale by four points.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- The United States Military Academy, steeped in the traditions of 147 years, fiercely proud of the "long gray line" from which have sprung so many of this country's military leaders, is undergoing a change.

Medicine is in the midst of a new transition, going beyond the "scientific" stage reached in the last half century, the Commonwealth Fund reported yesterday in a summary of its activities in the last year. The fund, established in 1918 with a bequest from Mrs. Stephen V. Harkness, appropriated $2,135,000 for various medical purposes during the year.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 4 -- Rabbi Maurice N. Eisendrath, president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, New York, warned today that salvation from impending atomic destruction could not be found in the sharpening of international tensions but in a spiritual renaissance in daily lives.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 4 -- Concerned over revival of cartels in Europe, United States authorities have made clear their opposition to the proposals of French Finance Minister Maurice Petsche for a seriese of investment agreements by the industries of France, Belgium, the Netherlands, Luxembourg and Italy.

Dr. Jacob Bart de la Faille, Van Gogh authority, disagreed last night with the committee that reported to the Metropolitan Museum of Art that the painting, "Study by Candlelight," was not an original Van Gogh.
CEDARHURST, L. I., Dec. 4 -- Calvin McCracken of the Princeton Club won the Gold Racquet today for the first time.

Textron, Inc., to Harry Serwer, Inc., for the Textron drapery fabrics division. James Serwer is account executive. Merchandising Consultants, Inc., has been appointed merchandising counselor for the division.

Years ago, while snowbound for a few days in the mountain town of Cettinje, capital of Montenegro, the writer encountered a group of emigres from Czarist Russia which included shabby remnants of Wrangel's army, priests of the Orthodox Church and others of the old regime who had fled from the Bolsheviks and found refuge in Yugoslavia.

BOSTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Pete Horeck drilled home a pair of goals tonight as the Boston Bruins downed the Montreal Canadiens in a game, 4 -- 2, before 11,276 Boston Garden fans. It was Boston's sixth home game without defeat.
ALBANY, Dec. 4 -- The State Motor Vehicle Commissioner, Clifford J. Fletcher, estimated today that New York's 1949 motor vehicle death toll would approximate 1,960, compared with 1,484 a year ago.

In a Christmas Sermon Robert Louis Stevenson wrote: "There is an idea abroad among moral people that they should make their neighbors good. One person I have to make good: myself. But my duty to my neighbor is much more nearly expressed by saying that I have to make him happy -- if I may."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Gulf States Utilities Company, Beaumont, Tex., has received from the Federal Power Commission authority to issue $10,000,000 in thirty-year first mortgage bonds. The commission approved a bid of the Stone Webster Securities Corporation to buy the bonds at 102.1499, with a coupon rate of 2 3/4 per cent a year and an initial offering price to the public of 102.58 per cent of the principal amount.

For those who listened to the Colombian election returns last Sunday evening, as broadcast by the Government station in Bogota, the farce had ended, and, for better -- as few could hope -- or for worse -- as many feared, Laureano Gomez was the newly elected Conservative President, elected in a shameful example of force and democratic mockery.

From hamlets and cities in all parts of the United States 189 contributors sent gifts totaling $24,628.07 as THE NEW YORK TIMES Neediest Cases Fund yesterday opened its thirty-eighth annual Christmas appeal.

The Federal budget for 1950-51, which makes its appearance early next month, is expected to introduce one of the most striking procedural innovations in many years. That innovation will stem from the recommendations of the Hoover Commission.

Sixty-five fellowships, with a total value of $42,850, have been awarded to college graduates here and abroad for study at the New York School of Social Work, a division of Columbia University, Dean Kenneth D. Johnson announced yesterday.

HEARTWELLVILLE, Vt., Dec. 4 -- Given another eight inches of cover and Dutch Hill, popular ski development just eleven miles north of North Adams, Mass., and 165 from Times Square, will roll into action. At the present time five inches of ideal snow surfaces four inches of frost.
PARIS, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Europe has spent nearly $3,000,000,000 of its own money under the Marshall Plan, a United States Government survey showed today.

The first general book in English since 1674 about Lapland will be published next Monday by the Princeton University Press in cooperation with the American-Scandinavian Foundation. "The Lapps," by Bjorn Collinder, presents the history of the region stretching across Norway, Sweden and Finland into Russia and of its people, as well as information on their reindeer economy, customs, family life, literature, music and art.

The American people are being "de-Christianized" to a point where the "values by which we live are as materialistic as Russia's," the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken, pastor of the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, said yesterday in his sermon.

VIENNA, Dec. 4 (Reuters) -- Four "hooded men" who had been hunted for days in the mountains of central Austria were arrested early this morning by a gendarmerie patrol near Weyer, Upper Austria, the Ministry of the Interior announced tonight.

President Truman is reported to be having trouble in finding a successor to Chairman David E. Lilienthal of the Atomic Energy Commission, whose resignation takes effect at the end of this month. This is a good sign. Mr. Lilienthal's job is not one to be lightly dealt with. It is intimately related to the security of the nation and to our future peaceful progress.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 4 -- Apparel plants have become an expanding industry in Rhode Island in the face of a general decline in all maufacturig in the state during October.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4 (UP) -- -- The rugged San Francisco 49ers, beating New York at its own defensive game, battled their way into the final of the All-America Conference play-offs today with a 17-7 victory over the Yankees before 41,393 fans at Kezar Stadium.

The left-wing United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers issued a statement last night denouncing the General Electric Company for its refusal to negotiate contract improvements with the union until its right to represent the 125,000 GE production workers had been verified by the National Labor Relations Board.

Cedric Adams, newspaper columnist and radio commentator in Minneapolis, will begin his coast-to-coast series of informal commentary over the Columbia Broadcasting System radio network on Jan. 3. The series, originating in the Minnesota city, will be heard Mondays through Fridays from 3:55 to 4 P. M.

Harry L. Bialock has been appointed sales manager of the tubing specifications division of the United States Steel Corporation in Gary, Ind. He succeeds David T. Marvel, resigned. Charles J. Lundvall succeeds Mr. Bialock as sales manager of the National Tube Company, Atlanta.

DETROIT, Dec. 4 (UP) -- Detroit's victory-hungry Lions roared from behind to edge the New York Bulldogs, 28 to 27, today and soared out of the National Football League Western Division cellar for the first time in four years.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- A suggestion that banks expand their operations to include commercial factoring was made here today by Dunwoody-O'Bryan Co., Inc., large commercial factoring concern in Chicago, after a study of the financial problems of 428 companies in the fields of shoes, textiles (infant and children's wear, work clothing, knit goods), furniture, mattresses and bedsprings, chemicals, food (manufacturing and wholesale), and hardware and tools.

Out of the cross-currents which developed in the foreign exchange l market last week the hardening of sterling forwards was the most! significant_ Elsewhere, the poor demand for the Canadian dollar even in the face of light offerings continued to depress that unit, while m/d week irregn!2rity in the Sviss franc was altered later when foreign buying turned it higher.

MOSCOW, Dec. 4 -- The Soviet press reported today that, in connection with the approach of Generalissimo Joseph Stalin's seventieth birthday, all branches of the Soviet national economy were setting themselves special production tasks to be fulfilled by his birthday, Dec. 21.
ATHENS, Dec. 4 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration mission's report titled "The Marshall Plan in Greece Through 1949," published here today, cites a number of achievements.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The private capitalistic system is being threatened seriously by a lack of venture capital, and it cannot exist unless there is a steady flow of private capital into the economy in terms of ownership as well as in terms of debt, Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat, of Wyoming, told a news conference today.

SINGAPORE, Monday, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Governor passed a fair night, a bulletin from the Singapore General Hospital said today. The bulletin said that the Governor "appears now to have gotten over the immediate danger of the initial phase. He is still seriously ill."

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- The stock markets here developed a distinctly brighter tone last week under stimulus of New Zealand elections showing Socialists defeated after fourteen years. Industrial equities revived and business showed a noticeable increase.

The most powerful propeller-turbine airplane engine ever built has successfully completed its ground tests and will be flight-tested some time next month, it was announced yesterday by the Allison Division of General Motors.

Maj. Gen. John H. Hilldring, former member of the United States delegation to the United Nations, speaking at a dinner of the Brooklyn Jewish National Fund at the St. George Hotel last night, declared that the United Nations could not assume control over the Jews who desired to be Israelis and the Arabs who wished to be citizens of Arab Palestine.

Perhaps of all human gifts, imagination, charm and sympathy are the ones most impervious to time. And because Frieda Hempel has them in such abundance her recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall was a singularly touching experience, even though old-time admirers had to admit her voice was not at the best.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Air Force said today it was checking its records for any report from a former Army captain about evidence of wartime air shipments of atomic materials to Russia. None has been found so far, an official said.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 4 -- Israel's problem at the moment is not the internationalization of Jerusalem but what to do to appease Egypt. No one here believes sincerely that the United Nations General Assembly will get enough votes to internationalize the city, although the import of the threat is not discounted, but the attitude of Egypt is seen as the principal factor in the issue.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 4 -- A new plan for internationalization of Jerusalem will be presented tomorrow to the United Nations General Assembly in still another attempt to determine the future fate of the city.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., Dec. 4 -- The greatest distinction a field trial retriever can win in this country went to F. T. C. Marvadel Black Gum, a 4-year-old black Labrador owned by Mr. and Mrs. Paul Bakewell 3d of St. Louis today at the conclusion of the three-day competition of the National Retriever Field Tidal Club.
Dorothy Gordon, pianist, and Arlene Stone, soprano, gave a joint recital in Times Hall Saturday night. Both young women showed themselves performers of promise before a large and friendly audience.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- Unemployment in Britain's shipbuilding and ship repairing industries has risen since last March to 15 per cent of the total labor force and may eventually affect 75,000 men, E. J. Hill, general secretary of the Boilermakers Union, declared today.
PANAMA, Dec. 4 -- Tension is growing between the Government of Honduras and the Revolutionary Council now ruling El Salvador over a boundary dispute, it was learned here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Dick Poillon kicked three field goals and Sammy Baugh turned into a scat runner today as the Washington Redskins walloped the Green Bay Packers, 30 -- 0, in a National Football League game before 23,200 fans.

When the water shortage has reached such a critical state that the city finds it necessary to appeal to restaurants and hotels not to serve water with meals unless it is requested by the patron, the full import of the emergency should be brought home to Mr. and Mrs. New York.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Cleveland's Browns moved within a game of their fourth straight All-America Conference championship tday as they twice battled from behind to subdue a stubborn Buffalo Bill team, 31 to 21, in a play-off tilt before 17,270 fans.

Municipal issues scheduled for sale this week aggregate $30,968,049, compared with $72,228,017, which included $8,288,000 of short term notes, last week, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. For the year to date, the weekly average of offerings stands at $68,994,453.
Failing to score a touchdown for the first time this season, the New York Football Giants succumbed, 24 -- 3, to the champion Philadelphia Eagles before 25,446 fans at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

Condemning the sex education film "Human Growth" as "unmoral, rank, bad sex education" for school children, Auxiliary Bishop Joseph F. Flannelly, administrator of St. Patrick's Cathedral, yesterday criticized Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Health Commissioner, for permitting use of the film in public schools.

The three-story office and showroom building on lot 30x100 feet at 204 Fifth Avenue, facing Madison Square and running through to Broadway, was sold by Francis J. Kleban to investing clients of Hyman Lindenauer. It formerly was occupied by the Chase National Bank and now is used by Sleepwear, Inc., Neisner Bros., Inc., and the Toy Guidance Council, Inc.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- The fact that security prices in Wall Street have now virtually reached their highest level in three years has prompted The Financial Times to devote a leading article to re-examination of the American business situation to see whether this optimism of Wall Street is justified.
It seems to me that your editorial "Minimizing the Bomb" is exactly right, and it is heartening to see that a paper not given to hysterical judgments continues to respect the size of the bomb.

The New Friends of Music began the program of their late afternoon concert of chamber music yesterday at Town Hall with the Stefan George cycle of the Schoenberg songs, Op. 15, "Das Buch der Haengenden Gaerten," in honor of the composer's seventy-fifth birthday.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt received last night a gold key from the women's fashion division of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York. The award was made at a dinner held at the Plaza Hotel.
Vice President Albert W. Barkley and his bride, the former Mrs. Carleton Hadley, left yesterday by train for Washington for what Mr. Barkley described as "a continuation of our honeymoon."

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- Diplomatic quarters declined comment today here on reports that India was considering an early recognition of Israel and was suggesting a similar course to the Arab Governments in the Middle East.

Nine hundred cadets marched yesterday in the eighty-fifth military review of the Reserve Officers Training Corps Regiment of Xavier High School, which was held in the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory at Lexington Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street.

Robert C. Mai bought the two-story frame dwelling on lot 40 by 116 feet at 94-29 Springfield Boulevard, Queens Village, from Edward G. Mayer and Louise Wissel and insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, which also insured title in the sale of the two-story dwelling on lot 20 by 90 feet at 135-06 Ninety-first Avenue, Richmond Hill, by William Raedel to Harry Newberger through Robert L. Thornton, broker.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 4 -- Memorial of West New York, undefeated and untied this season, downed Lincoln High of Jersey City at Roosevelt Stadium today, 19 -- 0, in the third annual Hudson County Interscholastic A. A. invitation bowl game before a crowd of 22,000.

The Rev. Albert A. Chambers, formerly of St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church in Auburn, N. Y. was installed yesterday as rector of the Church of the Resurrection, 115 East Seventy-fourth Street, by the Right Rev. Robert E. Campbell, Superior of the Order of the Holy Cross.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 4 -- Ambassador-at-Large Philip C. Jessup and Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, former United Nations Mediator for Palestine were named today by the United States for the permanent panel that is to provide the world organization with top-drawer persons to investigate and conciliate international controversies.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- Trade in lard futures remained unusually light on the Board of Trade last week in striking contrast to the big turnover in cottonseed oil. The action of the latter market had considerable influence on lard, the price of which was depressed by a continued liberal movement of hogs, with prices the lowest of the year, and a large make of lard.
FLAGSTAFF, Me., Dec. 4 -- Only twelve native residents remained today in this backroads village, which lies in the path of a projected power company storage lake in Dead River valley.
CHENGTU, China, Dec. 4 (UP) -- Generalissimo Chiang virtually took over as President today as non - essential Government personnel began fleeing this temporary Nationalist capital.

Tii Niemela, Finnish soprano, made her American debut yesterday afternoon in Times Hall with the assistance of her husband, Pentti Koskimies, at the piano. The singer was sponsored by the American-European Artistic Exchange, founded by the late Hans Kindler.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 4 -- The national steel ingot rate last week moved up to 88 per cent of rated capacity. This was an increase of 9 points from the week before, and was about 2 1/2 points above the rate prevailing before the steel strike.

PARIS, Dec. 4 (AP) -- French officials said today that Guy Auffrey, French national expelled from Poland, had been found allive near the German-Swiss border. A previous report of his death in a plunge from a train was termed a mistake.

Maria Augusta Menezes de Oliva is a name you will probably hear again, because she is in the way of being a first rate pianist. Hailing from Brazil, she made her New York debut late yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 4 -- President Truman witnessed the baptizing of two babies today and heard a "wonderful sermon" on how to draw inspiration from the Scriptures on how to overcome one's own doubts of faith.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 4 -- Gerard Fairlie, self-confessed prototype of Bulldog Drummond, who took over the authorship of the novels when Cyril (Sapper) McNeile, literary creator of the character died in 1937, has come to Hollywood to write a new Bulldog Drummond film for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 4 -- Fleeting glimpses of an underground jungle in post-war Eastern Europe emerged today in the testimony of Arseney Boremovitch, one of the ten Russian emigres on trial in Sarejevo for alleged espionage on behalf of the Soviet intelligence service and for war-time collaboration with the Germans.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Dr. Kurt Schumacher, the fiery German Socialist leader, delivered his first political speech tonight since his reinstatement to the West German Parliament -- and his target was again Chancellor Konrad Adenauer.
Aided by funds from the Federal Government and private industry, American colleges and universities are engaged in the most extensive research program in the history of higher education.

In an investment deal in the Dyckman area of upper Manhattan, two six-story apartment buildings occupying the blockfront on the south side of West 207th Street, between Shermah and Post Avenues, have been sold by the Sherpost Realty Corporation to a syndicate for cash over mortgages amounting to $435,000.

There was a fire yesterday in the three-room Bellevue Hospital suite occupied by Mayor O'Dwyer. But the Mayor, undergoing a rest treatment, slept through it, for the firemen were not permitted to disturb him.

As parishioners of St. Martin's Protestant Episcopal Church, Lenox Avenue and 122d Street, listened yesterday as usual to the largest carillon in the world across Morningside Heights, they could be confident that two weeks later the sound of the seventy-two bells of Riverside Church would be mingled with the ringing of the next largest number in the city -- their own.

Columbia's basketball team, which set a new Lion high-scoring mark in its 97-44 conquest of Kings Point last Friday, will face sterner opposition tonight when it opens its home campaign against Rutgers at the University Hall gym. The game will start at 8:30.

Tossy Spivakovsky, who played at Carnegie Hall last night, is a violinist who makes you sit up and listen hard, no matter what he does. You may not see eye to eye with him on details, but his violin playing is invariably compelling. His is a real affinity for the instrument.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- In generally subdued stock markets British Government securities lost some of their recent buoyancy today. After some initial firmness in short dated issues, the gilt edged securities drifted in idleness and closed one-eighth to three-eighths lower than Friday's prices.

HONG KONG, Dec. 5 -- The financial and economic difficulties that the Chinese Communists have acknowledged through public statements and decisions of the Central Government Council in Peiping may have important effects on Communist policies for the immediate future. Possible consequences of the stringent conditions are seen as:

BINGHAMTON, Dec. 5 -- The Broome County Board of Supervisors voted today to give $1,000,000 to help pay the cost of establishing a state four-year liberal-arts college in the triple cities of Binghamton, Johnson City and Endicott.
The annual meeting of the Eastern College Athletic Conference gets under way here today with the biggest problem confronting the 150 athletic officials: what to do about television.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week were 7 per cent below the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 5 per cent.

A Department of Justice civil anti-trust suit charging Celanese Corporation of America, 180 Madison Avenue, with unreasonable restraint of competition in the manufacture and sale of rayon warp-knit fabrics through its merger with Tubize Rayon Corporation, was filed yesterday in Federal Court.
THE NEW YORK TIMES is to be commended for its editorial position in opposing the proposals of Walter Spahr and others that unlimited gold redemption be resumed.

The one-story taxpayer containing four stores at 120 East Post Road in White Plains, N. Y., has been sold by the B. C. Posner Construction Company to a client of Charles Port. Pearce and Mayer were the brokers. The building, on an irregular plot about 65 by 131 feet, was erected two years ago.

Contributions from a child of 10, a Brazilian delegate to the United Nations and an employe of the Bank of China were among the 169 gifts received on the second day of the thirty-eighth annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which opened on Sunday.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Dec. 5 -- Nicholas Dicovitsky of 731 Floral Avenue who was an Army translator at Great Falls, Mont., for nearly three years, serving both the accuser and a key Russian figure in the reported flying of atomic-bomb materials and information from this country to Russia, declared today that during that time he never heard the word uranium mentioned, in Russian or in English.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 5 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion declared in the Knesset [Parliament] today that Israel considered the United Nations partition resolution of Nov. 29, 1947, as null and void. He said Jews would sacrifice themselves for Jerusalem just as Americans would fight for Washington or Russians for Moscow.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 5 -- Thirty-seven debutantes, including several from New York and Connecticut, were presented to society tonight at the Bachelors Cotillon.

If you enjoy the best in chamber music, don't miss the concerts of the Musician's Guild, whose fourth season began in Town Hall last night. Both in quality of performance and in thoughtful selection of programs this organization is a delight.

ALBANY, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Dwight S. Perrin, executive editor of the Syracuse Herald-Journal, today was elected president of the New York State Associated Press Association. He succeeds Joseph T. Adams, managing editor of The Rochester Times-Union.

A Polish charge that Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, military chief of the Western Union high command, said in one of his off-the-record conferences in New York that Western Germany must be rearmed enlivened debate yesterday on arms reduction at the United Nations General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- George Racey Jordan, a former Air Force major, insisted under oath before the House Committee on Un-American Activities today that atomic bomb materials and information were expedited to Russia by planes in 1943-44 with the aid of the late Harry L. Hopkins, adviser to President Roosevelt.

" Metropole," a new comedy by William Walden, starring Lee Tracy, will make its local debut this evening at 8 o'clock at the Lyceum Theatre. Max Gordon is sponsor of the project, which will serve as his first offering of the season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- A special motion picture for women's clubs -- to show women how to examine themselves for possible signs of breast cancer -- is planned as part of a campaign to reduce deaths from this type of cancer by more than 50 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- While Southern soft coal operators today condemned the three-day work week "imposed upon the industry by John L. Lewis," it was learned that one of their leading figures would take part in an important conference tomorrow morning looking toward settlement of the dispute which has curtailed coal production for five months.

The position of the United States with regard to maritime matters is much the same now that it was after World War I -- the nation cannot seem to make up its mind whether it wants to be a world maritime power -- in the view of Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Washington Democrat.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- A working party substituting a fourteen-nation committee on commodity problems for the international commodity clearing house plan was accepted today by a commission of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UP) -Arthur Leff, a National Labor Relations Board trial examiner, today recommended dismissal of secondary boycott charges against a union that held up delivery of New York newspapers to subway stands last summer.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Wheat led the way to higher prices for grains today on the Board of Trade here, all deliveries selling at new highs for the year to date, with the old-crop months showing the most strength. The finish was unchanged to 1 1/8 cents up, the December position going to 6 cents over the May.

Add to the list of films opening this week "A Dangerous Profession," an RKO melodrama starring George Raft, Ella Raines and Pat O'Brien, which will arrive at the Criterion on Saturday. Ted Tetzlaff directed and Sid Rogell produced from a story by Martin Rackin and Warren Duff.

With two million Christmas trees en route from Canada and Santa Claus taking root and shape on every corner, in every store, now is the time for the reign of the shopping list. No dictator was ever more benevolent -- or absolute. The list never contracts, rarely stays fixed, almost always swells like raisins in the rain.

John L. Collyer, president of the B. F. Goodrich Company, yesterday urged British and Far Eastern rubber growers to improve the quality and uniformity of crude rubber. He expressed the foregoing opinion in commenting on an announcement that the growers would spend $1,000,000 in the United States in 1950 to promote increased use of crude rubber.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5 -- One hundred and twelve pairs entered the masters contract mixed pair championship play at the winter national tournament of the American Contract Bridge League here tonight at the Bellevue Stratford Hotel.
In your edition of Nov. 29 is printed a letter from Franco's Agricultural Attache, who tries to correct your story about the defeat of Franco's movement to be admitted into the FAO.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 5 -- Cuba, Ecuador and Peru, in a surprise move, today introduced a resolution under which Nationalist China's charges against the Soviet Union would be referred to the United Nations Little Assembly, with instruction's to report to the 1950 session of the General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 - The United States Court of Claims handed down a decision today declaring that the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway, and the Drug and Chemical Club, 85 John Street, both of New York, are subject to tax as "social clubs" under the Internal Revenue Act.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Department of Defense created today an appeals board to hear disputed cases involving the loyalty of industrial workers or contractors employed on secret defense production.
Lorenzo Robba pulled out of his coat pockets yesterday two small jars filled with the fruits of his triumph as a truffle hunter.

Robert A. Barnet, president of the Irving Savings Bank of New York, was elected president of the Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York at the organization's annual meeting yesterday at Fraunces Tavern. Broad and Pearl Streets.
A policemen's sharp eye was responsible yesterday for bringing about the arrest of three 16-year-old boys who are alleged to have stolen thirteen automobiles in recent weeks.

The Government of Mexico, through its Finance Minister, Ramon Beteta, and the International Committee of Bankers on Mexico, announced yesterday that a modified version of the agreement of Feb. 20, 1946, for adjusting the debt of the National Railways of Mexico will be declared operative shortly.

FORT MASON, Calif., Dec. 5 -The Army transport Gen. Hugh J. Gaffe3' arrived today with 1,419 passengers from Yokohama, it was nounced by the local port of embarkatiorL The next scheduled transport arrival will be that of the Gen. C. G. 1%forton, due Monday from Okinawa
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 5 -- The form of economy being set up in Communist China is "very far from communism," Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared today.

ALBANY, Dec. 5 -- The State Civil Service Commission announced today a new procedure designed to eliminate a possible source of discrimination against candidates for Civil Service positions because of their national origin.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- There was no official comment here on the announcement by Britain today that work was being stopped on a large atomic pile because of "possible developments in the near future."

Encouraged by the success of its West Coast affiliate, the Sailors Union of the Pacific, AFL, the Atlantic and Gulf District of the Seafarers International Union has notified the fifty steamship companies with which it holds contracts that it, too, is seeking a company-financed welfare plan for its 20,000 members, it was reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled by 6 to 2 today that the old Wagner Act permitted the dismissal of workers who tried -- despite a closed shop contract -- to have their union replaced by a rival labor organization. The Taft-Hartley Act bans such discharges.
Christmas belongs traditionally to the children of the house. In addition to selectng toys and goodies for the holidays, parents will find new furnishings designed especially for the junior set.

ROME, Dec. 5 -- In an obvious allusion to the anti-religious campaign being carried out by Communist - dominated governments, Pope Pius today told a group of United States members of Congress that dictators through centuries had attempted to deprive man of his spiritual freedom.
Vigorous disapproval of the dental program in Great Britain's national health service was voiced last evening by Dr. Harold Hillenbrand, secretary of the American Dental Association.

Forty persons stationed around the swimming pool in Far Rockaway High School were privileged last night to witness a young man's victory over polio after seventeen years of subjection to its crippling effect.
NEWMARKET, England, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Two mares were bought for export to the United States at the first session of the Newmarket December thoroughbred horse sales today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Arguments in the now famous controversy over ownership of oil-bearing lands beneath the marginal sea, off the Texas and Louisiana coasts, will be heard in the Supreme Court Feb. 6, under an order issued today.
PARIS, Dec. 5 -- Premier Georges Bidault appeared confident tonight that he could win back support after two resignations from the Government.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Doak Walker and Charlie Justice, most publicized All-America backs since the war, will be football opponents for the first time in the Senior Bowl here on Jan. 7.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- In an unanimous ruling, the Supreme Court today sustained the constitutionality of the Arkansas "right-to-work" law.

It is indeed regrettable that THE NEW YORK TIMES finds it necessary to resort to unrealistic arguments in its editorial of Nov. 30 in an effort to discredit a proposal that was intended to promote a national rather than a sectional solution to the pension problem.

The Newell-Emmett Company, a partnership, will be dissolved as of Dec. 31, it was announced yesterday. A corporation is now being formed to carry on the business, and will be known as Cunningham Walsh, Inc. Incorporating stockholders will be John P. Cunningham, Fred H. Walsh, George S. Fowler, William Reydel, Richard L. Strobridge, present Newell-Emmett partners, and also Earl H. Ellis, G. Everett Hoyt and Robert R. Newell.

Elaborate divertissements were presented at the Bal Masque, given in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria last night for the benefit of the Pension Fund of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York. A fashion extravaganza was a feature of the party, which was sponsored by the firms of Elizabeth Arden and Van Cleef Arpels.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 5 -- A report that Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of the Bonn Republic, had suggested Germany might receive a role in the Western European defense program by contributing German units in an army under a combined West European command produced quick reaction throughout Western Germany today.

An interesting recent development in Germany has passed almost unnoticed here. When Germans drove out Slavs from the Berlin area centuries ago, one group, the Wends, stayed behind in the marshes southwest of Berlin, and they have maintained their Slavic tongue there ever since.

LONDON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Government officials reported today the projected African federation of Southern Rhodesia, Northern Rhodesia and Nyasaland, with 5.650,000 persons and 477,000 square miles, had foundered on Britain's insistence that Negroes receive direct representation in the central parliament.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Shirley Temple won a divorce today, testifying that her husband, John Agar, actor, drank to excess, romanced with other women and even drove her to thinking of suicide.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 5 -- As the minor leagues, with a record total of 59 circuits, launched their annual convention today by holding their first group of draft sessions, club owners and managers of the majors redoubled their efforts to pry things loose in the all important trading mart.

Trouble that had been brewing aboard the 7,200-ton vessel Nathaniel B. Palmer since she left Honolulu last month with a cargo of raw sugar erupted last night in New York Harbor. The ship's radio operator was wounded in the back by a bullet during an altercation when the captain tried to arrest four crew members.
The new rotary traffic plan to speed motorists through Columbus Circle went into operation yesterday on a trial basis and was hailed as a success.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Dec. 5 (AP) -- All but one of Colonial Airline's employes stationed here have received a two-week notice of "indefinite furlough" if a Canadian court rules against Colonial's operation in Canada. An official of the company said the notice was signed by B. T. Dykes, vice president in charge of operations.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- The withdrawal from Rumania of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund mission was requested by the Rumanian Government on Nov. 29, the agency's European headquarters announced here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- James K. Vardaman Jr., member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, came out today for a tax increase at the next session of Congress of "whatever amount" was needed to cover current expenditures and those that might be added.
A six-count criminal information charging conspiracy and illegal placement of babies for adoption was returned yesterday in Special Sessions against two lawyers and a housewife.

The United Nations General Assembly adopted yesterday without objection or discussion a resolution proposed by Ecuador that Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, Assembly President, "ascertain the views of the representatives of the Government of Greece concerning the suspension of death sentences passed by military courts" against nine Greek nationals.

It is disturbing to realize that this city which boasts of a police force known the world over as "the finest" admittedly lacks numerical strength to protect its 8,000,000 inhabitants properly at all times. Officials recognize that in emphasizing mobility they have of necessity sacrificed the foot patrolman, who, thoroughly familiar with local conditions, not only enforces the law but in many instances prevents it from being breached.

We confess that we are mystified by the failure of all efforts over the last decade to pass a law at Albany to revise the system of selecting top personnel in the Bureau of Attendance of the New York City School System. The three highest supervisory positions in that important bureau are now vacant, and have been for periods varying from one to six years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -Charles A. Lindbergh will receive the 1949 Wright Brothers Memorial Trophy for outstanding public service in aviation over the past twenty-two years, the National Aeronautic Association announced today.
Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, did not know last night whether, beginning tomorrow, he would be knocked down in public by a member of his faculty or just have to fall down.

Connecticut's new Senator, William Benton, is a former partner of Governor Bowles, who yesterday appointed him to take Senator Raymond E. Baldwin's place. However, his wide experience, not only in business but in education and public service, makes this fact a coincidence rather than an act of favoritism.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5 -- In a lightweight championship battle which contrasted sharply with the popular conception of what such events should be. Ike Williams, doughty little Trenton, N. J., Negro battler, retained his title tonight against Chicago's Negro challenger for the crown, Freddy Dawson, at Convention Hall, before a crowd of 10,389 fans who paid receipts of $46,652.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 5 -- In the past two decades, since the South was termed the nation's No. 1 economic problem by a Presidential committee named to report on the economic state of the union, the South has made rapid strides in business and industry, Dean Lee Bidgood of the School of Commerce and Business Administration, University of Alabama, said today at the University of Cincinnati.

Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen of the Department of Public Works will be the guest speaker at the luncheon meeting of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects today in the Architectural League Building at 115 East Fortieth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UP) -The Interstate Commerce Commission adjourned today until March 20 its hearings on the Government's claim for more than $2,000,000,000 in alleged wartime freight rate overcharges by 900 railroads.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 5 (AP) -The Midwest chapter of the Football Writers Association of America tonight named George Thomas of Oklahoma as the outstanding backfield player of 1949 in the Big Seven - Missouri Valley Conference area.

An American first-prize winner who was selected yesterday in the 1949 Hallmark art contest and the French first-prize winner who was selected in Paris in June split the international award of $3,500 when the jury could not choose between them.
LONDON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The top man in President Truman's welfare program is gathering information here for planning civilian defense against atomic bomb attacks.

William Rosen, a witness whose name has been linked by the prosecution to Alger Hiss through an automobile transfer, refused to answer key questions at the Hiss perjury trial yesterday on the ground that the answers might incriminate him.

Present import duties on iron and steel products coming into the United States are merely "nominal" and afford "negligible protection to the domestic producers," the American Iron and Steel Institute asserted yesterday.

Since the week ended on Oct. 8, New York's consumption of water has fallen off by 75,000,000 gallons a day, according to figures made public yesterday by Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 5 -- The appointment of William Benton of Southport, Conn., a former Assistant Secretary of State, as the new United States Senator from Connecticut was announced today by Gov. Chester Bowles at a special press conference.

Benjamin J. Davis Jr., convicted Communist leader, obtained an order from Supreme Court Justice Thomas A. Aurelio yesterday directing city officials to show cause next Monday why his ouster from the City Council should not be set aside.

Strategic bombing did not come into existence as the result of the ideas of any one man or any group of men. Trenchard, of the RAF; Mitchell, of our Air Corps; Douhet, of the Italian Air Force; Goering, of the German Air Force; the Japanese, with the Pearl Harbor raid; all added their bit before the modern RAF and our United States Air Forces completed the picture.

G. T. Baker, president of National Airlines, acclaimed yesterday the development of low-cost coach service by the airlines as a step toward making the industry "a profitable business, independent of Government subsidy support."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Federal Housing Authority for the last few days has been assuring private building interests that the new anti-discrimination policy on government loans for home financing, announced at a New York City meeting by Solicitor-General Perlman, will neither prevent a property owner from selecting the tenants he desires nor affect his choice of a buyer if he wants to sell.

The Norwegian America liner Oslofjord, a trim gray-and-white ship equipped with the latest in passenger accommodations and cargo-handling facilities, slipped proudly into New York on her maiden run from Norway yesterday amid the raucous salutes of harbor craft.

Poland's permanent delegate to the United Nations, Dr. Juliusz Katz-Suchy, declared last night that the Soviet Union still was willing to work out a plan for peaceful uses of atomic energy, one that simultaneously would outlaw the bomb and permit inspection.

Bob Morgan, Montreal's crack infielder, who is slated for a trial with the Dodgers next spring, was the International League's champion batsman for 1949 with an average of .337, according to the official figures announced yesterday.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia Unversity, received harsh criticism yesterday from the university's student newspaper, The Columbia Daily Spectator. In an editorial entitled "Security and Hot Dogs," the publication attacked the General for "several remarkable statements" before the St. Andrew's Society at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last Wednesday night.
LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Delegates attending the world labor conference here virtually cleared the way today for transformation of the conference into an international confederation of free trade unions.

Low-cost electric power and the creation of a new industrial and agricultural section in Brazil were foreseen yesterday with the announcement of a vast hydroelectric project on the Sao Francisco River in the northeastern part of the country.

Plans were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings for the store and office structure to be erected at the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, where the 77-year-old Gothic edifice of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas is now being razed.

First serious shortages of standard steel pipe have appeared in the New York and New England areas and scarcities are not expected to be relieved before early in January, industrial purchasing sources revealed yesterday. Large requirements of some big building contractors are being met by "pick-up" deliveries from a number of local jobbing warehouses, instead of by carload shipments from mills, it was learned.

DALLAS, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Notre Dame's gridiron champions today are on the way home boasting the greatest four-year record in Fighting Irish history -- but take it from Coach Frank Leahy, they accomplished it in the nick of time.

The Teachers Union, CIO, urged the Board of Higher Education yesterday to grant an immediate pay rise of $1,200 each a year to teaching, administrative and custodial employes of the four city colleges. The action came at an open budget hearing of the board's committee on finance and facilities, held at Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue.
CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Federal District Judge Walter J. LaBuy admitted to evidence in the Tucker fraud trial today a letter dated Aug. 22, 1947, which asserted that the Tucker car was "a reality."

MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L. I., Dec. 5 -- The retirement of Col. William M. Talbot, a West Point graduate who spent more than twenty years in military service, was announced today by the Continental Air Command's Eastern air defense force.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 5 -- A special United Nations committee was set up today with a membership of sixteen countries to examine broad data on non-self-governing territories but there were clear signs that at least three colonial powers might boycott the new group.
Automobile license plates for 1950 went on sale yesterday at offices of the State Bureau of Motor Vehicles.
SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 5 (UP) -- Lieut. Gen. Leslie R. Groves denied tonight that he ever had cleared shipment of atomic materials to Russia.

Just a little over a century ago -- in November, 1847 -- the Communist League held a congress in London and commissioned Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels to write "a detailed theoretical and practical program of the party." The result was the Communist Manifesto.
TRENTON, Dec. 5 -- With one exception, all sections of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority Act were upheld today by the New Jersey Supreme Court.
Mayor O'Dwyer denied yesterday published reports that Police Commissioner William P. O'Brien might retire after Jan. 1. He said Mr. O'Brien had told him he had no intention of retiring.

The stock market may become the principal competitor of mutual savings banks in the next decade, August Ihlefeld, president of the Savings Banks Trust Company, declared yesterday. A speaker at the annual mid-year meeting of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, attended by some 600 banking executives, at the Commodore Hotel, Mr. Ihlefeld said that "growing competition" for savings already had developed in the buying of corporate securities.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 5 -- The continuing migration to California, along with the natural increase in its established population, confronts the state with the task of creating 10,000 new jobs every month to maintain the employment balance, Gov. Earl Warren declared today.

Dutton announced yesterday the publication on Jan. 27 of "Combat Command: The American Aircraft Carriers in the Pacific War," by Admiral Frederick C. Sherman, who commanded the carrier Lexington in the Battle of the Coral Sea and later was in command of the Fifth Fleet.
ASHLAND, Ky., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Andrew J. May gave up his pearl gray hat and his business suit with the white piping on the vest today for the garb of a prisoner of the Federal Government.

A bid for the Bronx as a site for a proposed international world trade exposition was entered yesterday by Borough President James J. Lyons. He announced that he had written to Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administration head, and would also confer with city officials to press his borough's offer.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UP) -The Government today offered to sell to private dealers 725,000 pounds of turkey bought under the farm price support program in recent months.

The Southern fishing, and we mean "deep" South, seems to be getting off to an early start this season, for reports from both Stuart and Palm Beach on the Florida East Coast indicate that there is much to be said for the proverbial "early bird" theory.

The importance of opening community centers to older persons was stressed yesterday at the first meeting of the Mayor's Central Committee on the Aged in the Welfare Department Training Institute, Ninth Street and Avenue B.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 5 Appropriation of $29,000,000 by the Federal Government in the next fiscal year for vocational education was urged today by the National Association of State Directors of Vocational Education at its annual meeting in the Traymore Hotel.

The negotiation here of a state treaty for Austria bogged down completely last night. A spokesman for the Soviet Union informed representatives of the United States, Britain and France that no more decisions could be expected pending the outcome of current talks between Moscow and Vienna.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5 -- "Great hatred" dating back a dozen years was suggested in questioning today by the defense as a basis for the testimony of Henry Schrimpf, a longshore walking boss, placing Harry R. Bridges, leader of his union, in secret meetings with high Communists during the 1934 strike.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 5--The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development will call in its $100,000,000 issue of 2 1/4 per cent bonds early in January, and will replace them with an issue of like amount that will mature serially in three to twelve years at the rate of $10,000,000 annually. The new issue is to be sold at competitive bidding. Bonds to be cashed would otherwise mature in 1957.

A new day care center for the aged, named for the late Dr. William I. Sirovich, member of Congress and physician, is now being set up at 203 Second Avenue, the site where he served as superintendent of the People's Hospital from 1910 to 1927, it was reported yesterday.

MOSCOW, Dec. 2 -- Ivan Alexandrovich Pavlenko, director of Moscow Boys School 315, told a group of foreign correspondents who visited his school this week that at the foundation of Soviet education was the objective of inculcating in a child a love of his own country.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 5 -- A new blending of earlier Dutch and Swedish proposals for the creation of a moderate international authority in Jerusalem received the strong support of the United States today in the Special Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.
DALLAS, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Kyle Rote, Southern Methodist's mighty man, and Lindy Berry, Texas Christian's "busiest man in football," were double champions in the Southwest Conference this season.

Slats Gill, whose Oregon State Beavers roll into Madison Square Garden tonight to tackle New York University in the feature battle of the collegiate double-header, addressed the metropolitan basketball writers at their weekly get-together at Leone's yesterday.

The tapping of wires by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which has been ruled illegal by the United States Supreme Court, was denounced yesterday by defense attorneys who sought dismissal of the indictment in the CoplonGubitchev spy case.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 5 (AP) -American farm surpluses cannot be solved, except by drastic production cutting, unless European recovery is realized, a Government economist said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Library of Congress researchers today reported to the special House committee investigating lobbying that lobbyists here outnumbered members of Congress three to one during 1947 and 1948.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Under a Supreme Court order issued today, permission to file briefs was denied to several organizations critical of exclusion of Negroes from the Stuyvesant Town housing development in New York.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 5 -- Cancer of the stomach, a disease that strikes almost 50,000 Americans a year, is an ailment that lends itself to improved techniques of surgery, Dr. Carl A. Moyer of Dallas, Tex., said today at the opening of the annual meeting of the Radiological Society of North America.

A two-month postponement on a hearing of an appeal brought by the six Communist conspiracy trial lawyers against their contempt of court convictions was granted yesterday by the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Hopes for a ruling on the legality of a Los Angeles County "employe-loyalty test" were upset when the Supreme Court today unanimously held that the constitutional questions that brought the case to Washington were "not ripe for decision."

NEWARK, Dec. 5 -- Public Works Director Leo P. Carlin said today that unless Newark's householders and manufacturers cooperate to a greater degree in cutting consumption of water, he will ask the city's Law Department to explore the possibiilty of adopting an ordinance calling for mandatory restrictions.

Little change in the volume of business during the first quarter of 1950 and a moderate rise to an annual rate of gross output of $265,000,000,000 by the second quarter was foreseen yesterday by Sumner H. Slichter, Lamont Professor at Harvard University.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- A visitor these days to the United States Military Academy here might be lucky enough to find himself eavesdropping on a meeting of the Soviet Union's Politburo, a Four-Power Foreign Ministers Conference or a session of the United Nations General Assembly.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration has the right to enforce its requirements for war veterans wishing to take flight training, the Federal Court of Appeals ruled today.

A hearing started yesterday in Bronx Surrogates Court to determine which of two wills filed for probate is valid in the $750,000 estate of William Lauro, real estate dealer, who died last June 2 at his home, 2457 Hoffman Street, the Bronx. He was 57 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today refused to consider a Government complaint that Federal Judge Ben H. Rice Jr. of San Antonio, Tex., had shown "an abuse of judicial power" in his handling of an anti-trust case.

Keener competition in the popular price cigar field was seen here yesterday with the announcement by H. A. Kent, president of the P. Lorillard Company of the creation of a new cigar division headed by Frank Hopewell, vice president. As vice president in charge of sales, Mr. Hopewell has been a key figure in the steady rise of Old Gold sales to an all-time sales high.

The left-wing United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, ousted from the Congress of Industrial Organizations on charges of Communist domination, was suspended yesterday by the Canadian Congress of Labor, the CIO's Canadian counterpart.

DANBURY, Conn., Dec. 4 -- Connecticut's volunteer firemen, particularly those in Fairfield County, expressed anger today at being "left out in the cold" by the special session of the General Assembly, which adjourned last Thursday.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- A cryptic announcement from the Ministry of Supply stirred speculation here today on possible new advances in the development of atomic energy and changes in Britain's atomic research program.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 5 -- President Truman's brain trust was fully assembled here tonight and ready to assist him in drafting the three major messages he will present to the second session of the Eighty-first Congress next month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The United States Government is informing other governments privately that it will not consider recognizing the Chinese Communists as long as there is any effective organized resistance by the Chinese Nationalists on the mainland of China.

A LITTLE more than a fortnight ago Princeton achieved the unprecedented feat of winning the Big Three championship for the third straight year and vast was the pride of every Son of Old Nassau at such an accomplishment. Yet it is to be doubted if this exploit generated even a fraction of the excitement that followed precipitately in the wake of Princeton's second successive victory over Yale just fifty years ago last month.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Dec. 5 (UP) -- Some 250 workers building a new plant which will produce uranium-235 for atomic bombs walked off the job today, protesting the use of non-union labor on another Oak Ridge project.

Young women of society are serving on the committee for the Bachelors Ball to be held on the night of Dec. 17 in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The event, to which only debutantes of recent seasons and bachelors under 35 years of age may subscribe, has been arranged under the direction of Mrs. W. Montgomery Wilcox, assisted by Mrs. Wilmerding Satterlee.
Emil Schram, 56 years old, president of the New York Stock Exchange since July 1, 1941, has been a patient at St. Luke's Hospital here since Nov. 29, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The question as to whether the Pan American Coffee Bureau constitutes a cartel was raised at the Senate Agricultural subcommittee hearing on food prices today by Paul E. Hadlick, committee counsel.
With the upward spiraling of coffee prices in the last two months under investigation by Congress, the coffee futures market took a sharp drop yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

WARSAW, Dec. 5 -- Polish coal miners were told yesterday by President Boleslaw Bierut they faced great tasks in increasing their extraction rate by 36 per cent during the next six years. Efficiency in the coal industry, which is the only important one not yet to have completed its three-year plan quota, must simultaneously rise 35 per cent.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 5 -- Dr. Vannevar Bush, one of the foremost authorities on atomic energy, warned today that a growing trend toward federally sponsored "soft security" was a greater threat to the nation than Russian armaments.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- Prix Goncourt, the most important literary prize a French novelist can win, was awarded today to Robert Merle, 41-year-old former teacher of English here, for his war novel "Week-End at Zuydcoote."

Public and private home building in this country will probably proceed about as it has been doing in spite of the teapot tempest caused by Solicitor General Perlman's announcement that Federal Housing Administration financing would be refused on new housing in which occupancy or use was restricted on account of race, creed or color.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 5 -- The United Nations Social Commission opened a two-week session today by starting to map a work program for agencies of the peace organization in the fields of housing, crime prevention, child welfare, rehabilitation of the handicapped and other branches of social work.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UP) -- The Supreme Court today refused to decide whether a state can compel an employer to deal with a union that has lost its bargaining status under Federal law.

The First Boston Corporation; Lazard Freres Co.; Union Securities Corporation, and Wertheim Co. headed a nation-wide group of 154 underwriters which yesterday offered an aggregate of 1,136,537 shares of common stock, $8 par value, of Ohio Edison Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Treasury Department announced today that it had accepted bids for $1,002,321,000 of 91-day bills to be dated Dec. 8, 1949, and to mature on March 9, 1950, which were offered on Dec. 2, 1949.

In one way at least, the meat-packing industry is a peculiar one, unique. Like other industries it is subject to labor negotiations, suits about restraint of trade, the law of supply and demand, and the quitclaim that anything unforeseen by the attorneys is a simple Act of God.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Registration for Miami's twenty-sixth annual $10,000 open invitational golf tournament closed at noon today, with 201 professional and amateur golfers entered.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- According to the latest available information on Yugoslavia, the Cominform's economic blockade of that country has had serious repercussions, but the strength of Marshal Tito's military dispositions would seem to have delayed indefinitely any threat of actual invasion by the forces of the Soviet Union and its puppet satellites.

HONG KONG, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Chinese Communist troops were reported today to be only 100 miles from Chengtu, temporary Nationalist capital in China. A defense line was thrown up thirty to fifty miles from the city.

CHARLEMONT, Mass., Dec. 5 -- While one of the oldest ski developments in the East, the Chickley Alp ski center here in the heart of the Mohawk Trail country is little known, especially to metropolitan New Yorkers, simply because it hasn't "merchandized" its qualities.

Factory dollar volume of the domestic glassware industry this year will decrease approximately 12 per cent compared with last year, Herman L. Dillingham, secretary of the American Glassware Association, revealed yesterday. A sharp pickup in order volume during the latter part of the year has failed to offset the serious slump last winter and spring, he said.
A demonstration of a radar speed meter for use in planning to ease traffic congestion will be staged at 11 A. M. today by the Department of Traffic Engineering on Park Row opposite Beekman Street.

A plea for a balanced sharing of the nation's economy was made last night by Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer at the second annual dinner of the Public Relations Society at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

UPTON, L. I., Dec. 5 -- Leland J. Haworth, director of the Brookhaven National Laboratory, a subsidiary of the Atomic Energy Commission, today announced the resignation of his executive assistant, Dr. Lincoln R. Thiesmeyer, effective at the end of the year.

WALTER WILLIAMS, a dull, ordinary man of 46, heard the sound of weeping outside the door of his apartment in a Westchester suburb. It was no business of his. It might even be a trick, a ruse whereby a criminal could get inside the apartment for no one knew what nefarious purpose. Mabel shouted to him not to open the door; to put the chain on it any way.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Charges that the Yellow Cab Company and a group of affiliates had violated the Sherman Anti-Trust Act were rejected by the Supreme Court in a 5-to-2 ruling today. Justice Robert H. Jackson wrote the majority opinion, from which Justices Hugo L. Black and Stanley Reed dissented.

Twelve plum puddings and twelve fruit cakes won high ratings in the third annual tasting conducted by this department. The sampling was done recently in THE NEW YORK TIMES' test kitchen by three judges, who scored twenty-two of the puddings and twenty-three of the cakes that are being offered in stores here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Air Force disclosed today that it had diverted $50,000,000 from other projects to start immediate construction, most of it in the vital Alaska defense area, of a radar aircraft warning network designed to protect the country from enemy air attack.

A donation of $11,084 for the scholarship fund of the Fashion Institute of Technology, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street, has been given by THE NEW YORK TIMES, it was announced yesterday by Samuel L. Deitsch, chairman of the fashion committee of the Educational Foundation for the Apparel Industry.

After tonight's performance, Milton Berle will take a vacation from his television program on the National Broadcast Company network for two weeks, which he will spend in Florida. The program will continue as usual on Tuesday evenings, with guest masters of ceremonies filling in for the star on Dec. 13 and 20.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Mrs. John Marsch's Marina, a winner here last week, turned in another sparkling performace as she drubbed seven other juveniles in the sixth and best race on the stakeless card this afternoon at Tropical Park.

PIKEVILLE, Ky., Dec. 5 (AP) -Two members of a three-man operators committee scheduled to meet with the United Mine Workers in Washington tomorrow resigned tonight, charging that the UMW wanted them to sign a "blank check" for a new contract.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Obrana Lidu, Czechoslovak Army newspaper, tonight denounced the country's Roman Catholic Bishops as "enemies of our state."

Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner, urged yesterday a far-reaching revision of New York's minimum wage law that would affect the earnings of 1,600,000 employes, including 200,000 domestics, not subject to the Federal minimum wage law.

In his recent articles in this newspaper, former Ambassador Bedell Smith characterized the present Soviet system as the offspring of a marriage between Great Russian imperialism and Communist ideology. How much Communism there is in Russia (besides state ownership of the means of production and the use of Communist terminology for other ends) is subject to dispute.

Three-out of four of the business executives interviewed during the last six days of November expect their first quarter 1950 sales volume to equal or exceed the first quarter 1949 level, according to preliminary results of a survey released for publication today by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Forty-five per cent expect a larger sales volume, 29 per cent foresee no change and only 26 per cent expect a lower sales volume.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 5 -- The last four defendants in the Sarajevo trial of ten Russian emigres accused of espionage on behalf of the Soviet Intelligence Service and of collaboration with the Germans during the war pleaded guilty tonight.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 5 (AP) -- In an unprecedented draft meeting the alert operators of the Cardinals' extensive farm system dominated proceedings today as members of the top seven circuits in the national association's spralwing fifty-nine-league structure, took turns dipping talent from the reserve lists.

MARIETTA, Ohio, Dec. 5 (AP) -The Marietta rowing committee -- which wants the traditional Poughkeepsie regatta shifted from the Hudson to the Ohio River -- today invited the American Intercollegiate Rowing Association stewards to look over the Marietta site before their annual meeting Dec. 9.

The first use of "direct truck distribution" in the frozen food industry was extended yesterday to all New England states, according to Howard C. Boerner, national sales manager of Minute Maid Corporation. Four weeks ago the first trial of this form of distribution was begun in the greater metropolitan area and has resulted in a 40 per cent sales jump, he disclosed.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The materials shipped to Russia in 1943 included relatively small amounts of the two basic ingredients of a chain-reacting atomic pile.

BERLIN, Dec. 5 -- Gerhard Eisler, chief of the Public Information Bureau of the Eastern Germany Government, asserted today that Chancellor Adenauer would be brought to trial one day on charges of treason and "Petainism."

American production methods on men's and boys' clothing offer the basis for speeding up output of similar items in Great Britain, according to members of a British productivity team which has completed a six weeks' tour of Eastern and Midwestern clothing factories.
Michael J. Quill let New York straphangers know yesterday that his enforced absence in London was not abridging his customary solicitude for their traveling comfort.

Promenaded to the music of Dimitri Mitropoulos, a showing in dance pantomine of gowns created by Castillo was unfolded last night at the Bal Masque at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Elizabeth Arden and Van Cleef Arpels were sponsors of the ball, which was for the benefit of the pension fund of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York.

Stocks were moderately firmer on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Rail Issues, which recently led the list upward, moved into the background as other groups rotated in taking the lead. Despite increasing activity at the opening, when large blocks of stock changed hands, sales dropped to 1,820,000 shares.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 5 -Compulsory competitive bidding for the purchase of corporate securities was denounced here today by Hal H. Dewar, Texan president of the Investment Bankers Association, as a "fallacious extension of government fiat which is not destructive of monopolistic practice but is creating new monopolies."
