Louis J. Glickman, operator, has contracted for the purchase of the nine-story thirty-six-family apartment house at 147-151 West Seventy-fourth Street for $240,000. The property, on a plot 65 by 100 feet, is assessed at $220,000. The building contains suites of three to six rooms.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 5 -Albert J. Cohen, independent producer, has purchased "I Dive for Treasure," by Harry E. Reiseberg to provide the basis for a prospective Cinecolor film.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- An agreement which will assure a minimum of 300,000,000 cubic feet of natural gas daily from the Texas Gulf Coast fields for Chicago and other centers was announced today by James F. Oates Jr., chairman of the Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 5 -Princeton University will renew football relations with Williams College, Colgate University, and seven of the nine rivals that the Tigers faced during the past fall, according to the 1950 varsity football schedule released today by R. Kenneth Fairman, director of athletics.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Greatly magnified television presentations of surgical procedures will be shown for the first time at the interim clinical session of the American Medical Association, which opens here tomorrow morning.
ALBANY, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Sportsmen's organizations are taking their fight to prevent construction of the Panther Mountain Dam to the Court of Appeals.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and final prices were 2 to 14 points net higher than on Saturday.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Ont., Dec. 5 (Canadian Press) -- The Algoma Steel Corporation, Ltd., had net profit of $4,035,956 in the year ended April 30, or $2,016,657 more than in the preceding year. This is equivalent to $9.78 a common share, compared with $4.79.

The most important habit for children to form today is the habit of being able to form an appropriate new habit quickly, Dr. Margaret Mead declared yesterday. She spoke at a luncheon meeting of the Women's City Club at the New Weston Hotel, Madison Avenue and Fiftieth Street, on the topic, "Rearing Unknown Children for an Unknown World."

Astute parents can learn a lot from watching their children play, Mrs. Jean Schick Grossman, director of parent education for the Play Schools Association, told a group of mothers yesterday at a meeting sponsored by the association at 44 East Seventy-third Street.

Technical considerations were charged yesterday with halting the advance in stock prices, as well as with causing a sharp decline in trading volume. The market closed mixed, with the composite index up 0.02 on the day.

A decision to send a textile mission to Japan has been reached by the Anglo-American cotton textile conference which has been in session for the last week, it was announced yesterday by Robert T. Stevens of J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., chairman.
KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 6 -- President Truman today proclaimed United Nations Human Rights Day and called for its observance on Saturday and on Dec. 10 of each succeeding year.
BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., Dec. 6 -- The Town Council last night capitulated to its superiors, the people of Block Island, and as a result the islanders will not lose their only doctor.

NEWMARKET, England, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Mrs. Elizabeth N. Graham's Maine Chance Farm paid $29.400 today for a 2-year-old. Pagen Worship, at the thoroughbred sales. The filly, by Hyperion-Participation and bought by the British Bloodstock Agency for Mrs. Graham, will be shipped to the United States.

Coffee futures declined the permissible limit of 200 points on yesterday's trading in contract S on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The only exception was the trading in the S spot December deliveries, which closed 152 points lower than the previous day's levels.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- A glimpse into the foreseeable future when scheduled airlines, military planes and many big executive transports are expected to have special electronic equipment in their cockpits, was given here today. The new equipment is designed to give crews complete visual dispatching directions from the ground to prevent collisions, to speed up landings and to direct all plane movements in the air.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The United States imported $28,700,000 more goods in October than in September. This apparently reflected some initial effects of lowered prices for many foreign goods as a result of the mid-September foreign currency devaluations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A House committee was told today that fear of a Communist-directed work stoppage prompted the Atomic Energy Commission to order recognition withheld from the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers Union at two atomic energy projects.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 -- Business is booming in the Oriental market being opened up to West Coast structural steel, according to testimony presented today as the Maritime Commission opened a hearing on subsidy applications filed by Pacific Far East Lines, Inc., and Pacific Transport Lines, Inc.

Television cameras will be moved directly into the home of a Chicago family by the National Broadcasting Company tomorrow night at 8 o'clock, when it launches a new series, "Portrait of America," designed to stress the ideal that the family is the foundation of democracy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Small Business Advisory Committee of the Department of Commerce urged Congress today to consider a plan under which the Government would insure private bank loans to small business.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 6 -- Supervoltage radiation in the treatment of malignant tumors has become an established procedure, Dr. Milford D. Schulz of the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston declared today at a meeting of the Radiological Society of North America.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UP) -- The Communist-controlled Government of North Korea today offered to release two captive United States officials as Consul General Angus Ward and his party presumably began their arduous exit from Communist China.
LONDON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The chairman of Leach's Argentine Estates proposed today that this British-owned company be transferred to Argentina to evade double taxation.

Contradicting the contention of Alger Hiss that he had never seen Whittaker Chambers after Jan. 1, 1937, Mrs. Esther Chambers testified yesterday that she and her husband had entertained the Hisses at a wedding party in the middle of December, 1937.

American business managers in increasing numbers are becoming aware of the need for doing something more than they have done to secure better cooperation from employes in meeting competition and in preserving the American economic system, Ralph A. Lind, head of the labor relations department of Stevenson, Jordan Harrison, Inc., said yesterday at the annual convention of the Toy Manufacturers of the U. S. A. at the New Yorker Hotel.

The market discount from the book value of bank stocks reflects the public's fear of government control in the banking field, J. Stewart Baker, chairman of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, said yesterday while presiding at the 151st annual stockholders meeting, at the bank's main office, 40 Wall Street.

The largest project approved under the state's limited dividend housing law and the first such development in fifteen years will rise in the Whitestone section of Queens, State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman announced yesterday.

A 39-year-old former head of a now defunct publishing company was arraigned yesterday in General Sessions and charged with stealing $104,250 from five business men on fraudulent representations that he could obtain profits in scarce newsprint for them.
Ingalls Snyder announce that Philip F. MacGuire, member of the New York Stock Exchange, is with the firm in its investment department.
GENEVA, Dec. 6 -- The Swiss Government has agreed to turn over to the Polish Government funds placed in Swiss banks and other institutions by Polish Jews who died heirless during World War II.

The task of getting through the Legislature a satisfactory constitutional amendment designed to ease the present jam of litigation in the Supreme Court here has been assumed by the State Judicial Council, it was announced yesterday.

With the peak of the holiday season approaching and many formal affairs in the offing, the evening shoe will play an important part in completing the formal attire. Dressy pumps and sandals of gold or silver kid, satins and brocades will peek from beneath many long gowns or show off to their utmost with the new shorter length cocktail and evening dresses.

Monthly pensions for 150,000 of the nation's clothing workers will be increased $20 a month soon after the first of the year as the result of a new agreement reached yesterday between the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, CIO, and the Clothing Manufacturers Association.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Students of form were jolted when the Jerry McCarthy Stables even-money favorite. Air Patrol, was nipped at the post by D. G. Neuman's Warship in the Spike Island Purse at Tropical Park today.

Despite the dismissal by Magistrate David P. McKean of third-degree assault charges brought against them as the result of an altercation Monday night aboard the converted cargo ship Nathaniel B. Palmer, four seamen will be brought up on charges by their union today.

The Committee on Research of the National Association of Cost Accountants, 505 Park Avenue, today released the results of a national research study on "The Analysis of Cost-Volume-Profit Relationships." This is the second in a series presenting conclusions drawn from a study of the variation of costs with volume.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Maryland's racing commission today dropped a plan to have the state's four major race tracks run their 100 days of racing in continuous meets instead of splitting them between spring and fall.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 6 -- Following are the texts of two resolutions on the Chinese question approved today by the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly. The first was sponsored by Cuba, Ecuador and Peru; the second was introduced by the United States, Australia, Mexico, Pakistan and the Philippines.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 6 -- The movement of freight by rail in Europe reached the pre-war level of 1937 last year as a result of a spurt in its recovery, according to data released today by the Statistical Office of the United Nations. The figures did not include Soviet freight movement.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 6 -- Broad outlines of a joint trade association program intended to promote the interests of all branches of the investment securities business were suggested here today in the second main session of the convention of the Investment Bankers Association.

Georgi N. Zarubin, Soviet deputy, denied yesterday that his country was stalling in the Austrian treaty negotiations. At a meeting of the Big Four deputies in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel the Russian described a report of the collapse of the negotiations as "nonsense" and declared that such things were likely to wreck the discussions.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 6 -- A new basic policy directive by the United States has been sent to John J. McCloy, High Commissioneer in Germany, calling for the concentration of his efforts in helping to nuture a democratic government in Western Germany, an authoritative source disclosed today.
DETROIT, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A proposed settlement of the multi-million - dollar stockholders' suits against officials of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation was challenged in Federal court here today.

Not overlooking the place that fine antiques have in today's homes, Gimbels has opened a department featuring a collection of eighteenth and nineteenth century china and silver in the fifth-floor gift shop.

About half of 262 industrial companies, replying to a national survey on year-end bonus policies by the National Foremen's Institute, will give bonuses for Christmas this year, it was announced yesterday in New London, Conn. The institute, which recently moved to expanded headquarters in New London, is a thirty-year-old organization.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,752, against 1,543 last week and 1,350 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 737 arrivals yesterday, compared with 1,069 last Tuesday.

Small-scale, delicately fashioned furniture, flexible enough to be adapted to the change desired by apartment dwellers who move about frequently, was introduced yesterday at the opening of the new shop of Edith Hernandez at 136 East Seventy-fourth Street.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Sandy Saddler, ex - featherweight champion, tonight won the National Boxing Association's junior lightweight boxing title by taking a split decision from Orlando Zulueta of Havana, Cuba.
Governor Dewey asked New York City yesterday "to catch up with the actual cost" in its payment to the voluntary hospitals (non-profit institutions supported by private funds) for indigent patients.

The editorial "Point Four's Human Goals," in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 5, was an excellent treatment of the two conferences that met in New York on Dec. 2 and 3. The planning committee of the Philosophy of Education Conference that met at New York University, would underscore the fact that the social as well as technical phases "must be indissolubly wedded if the large goals of the project are to be achieved."
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Dec. 6 -- The Atomic Energy Commission put in a quick call for Federal help today to end a wildcat walkout that has made idle 2,000 construction workers on AEC projects here.

The present session of the U. N. General Assembly, now nearing a close, has devoted much of its time to arguing the relative merits of two plans for peace -- the Soviet proposal for a Five Power non-aggression pact and the American resolution reaffirming the pledges taken by all the member nations when they signed the Charter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- "Satisfactory" progress in the preliminary investigation into accusations by George Racey Jordan, a former Army Air Forces major, that atomic materials and information were sent by planes to Russia with the aid of the late Harry Hopkins was reported today by Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat, of Connecticut, chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy.

Another book of Amy war memoirs is planned for publication by Doubleday on Jan. 5. It is Lieut. Gen. Sir Frederick Morgan's "Overture to Overlord," an account of the planning of the invasion of Europe. The author did the preliminary work for Operation Overlord, prior to the appointment of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and served under him as Chief of Staff.

Hope for a treaty for Austria has bogged down again because Moscow, holding that country for ransom, has once more raised its price. At a moment when negotiations seemed to promise success, mainly because the Western Powers had conceded so much to Russia, the Soviet representative blandly announced that no final agreement could be reached until completely unrelated negotiations between Moscow and Vienna were completed.

Eight years ago today the Japanese attacked at Pearl Harbor. Out of that attack came many things both in the United States and in the whole Pacific area. The immediate result was to crystallize opinion and sentiment in this country and to make possible a concerted effort whose end was victory.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UP) -- Customs Collector Michael J. Bradley of Philadelphia today was elected president of the newly organized Association of Collectors of Customs.

George Racey Jordan, who told the House Committee on Un-American Activities on Monday that Harry Hopkins helped the Soviet Union get atomic secrets, said here yesterday that a Soviet general had flown to Russia with a radar-equipped plane when radar was a military secret.

Holders of common stock of the White Sewing Machine Corporation will receive a year-end dividend of $1.25 a share on Dec. 28, making total disbursements for 1949 $3 a share. Last year the company paid an initial of 25 cents in November and a year-end special of 50 cents in December, or a total of 75 cents a share.

The Old Grad, who had been somnambulently digesting his excellent repast -- even foregoing, in the political discussion that swirled about him, his cherished denunciations of what the country was coming to -- stirred fitfully as the words "political football" fluttered about the room and landed on his consciousness.
Sparked by Bob Reiss, a sophomore, Columbia's basketball team opened its 1949-50 home campaign last night by halting a sluggish Rutgers quintet, 59 to 45, in University Hall gymnasium.

Child labor in the United States -- that is, the employment of children under 18 -- has dropped since the bad old days and since the high-pressure times of the Second World War. In 1945 three million youngsters were at work. According to the current report of the National Child Labor Committee the total is now about two million, of whom 700,000 are in the 14-and-15-year-old age group.

A ban on the appearance of student bands at the intercollegiate basketball games in Madison Square Garden has been put into effect by Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, it became known yesterday.

An attempt to test the New York State Constitution's clauses permitting wiretapping was sidetracked yesterday when a Federal statutory court dismissed for lack of jurisdiction an action to enjoin city and state authorities from intercepting private communications.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Selection of a sculptor to execute a memorial bust of James Forrestal, first Secretary of Defense, will be announced later this month, Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, said today.

Salary increases for the heads of many city departments and agencies and for aides of Mayor O'Dwyer will be considered by the Board of Estimate at an executive session this afternoon, it was learned yesterday. The proposed rises, ranging from $1,000 to $10,000, would cost the city $73,100 a year.

Speaking as an industrialist who has not fared too well under the Marshall Plan, Dr. Walker C. Boveri, chairman of Brown, Boveri Co., Ltd., of Switzerland, criticized the plan yesterday, saying, among other things, that he was "a little bit afraid of it."

Four inspectors of the Department of Sanitation pleaded not guilty yesterday before Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz in Kings County Court to charges stemming from an alleged extortion case. Each was held in $1,000 bail for trial, no date for which was fixed.

State Senator Thomas C. Desmond, chairman of the New York State Joint Legislative Committee on the Problems of the Aging, warned employers last night to ease the practice of arbitrary discrimination against older job seekers. Unless such a policy was curbed, the Newburgh legislator said, laws barring age limits for job applicants would be sought.

The Bankers Trust Company has been appointed trustee, paying agent and registrar for $10,000,000 of Connecticut Light and Power Company first and refunding mortgage 2 3/4 per cent bonds, Series L, due Nov. 1, 1984.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had approved Part II of a plan of liquidation filed by Bartholomew A. Brickley, trustee of the International Hydro-Electric System, for the purpose of retiring Hydro-Electric's 6 per cent debentures.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Charles M. La Follette, national director of Americans for Democratic Action, proposed today to James F. Byrnes, former Secretary of State, that he establish and head "something like ADA" for Northern and Southern conservatives.

BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Dec. 6 -- Since 1922, this thriving New England industrial community has been a pioneer in skiing, its high jumping hill rating with the best in the country. Thrice it was the locale of national championships. Today, the natives point proudly to the vast recreational ski development carved out on the ridge of Hogback Mountain, fourteen miles west over the famous Molly Stark Trail to Bennington.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UP) -- Representative Sam Hobbs, Democrat, of Alabama, asked the Supreme Court today to uphold the policy of racial segregation in railroad dining cars.
Canada's Trade Minister, who is in charge of atomic research in that country, said yesterday that he knew of no shipments of uranium from Canada to Russia in 1943.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations today voted final endorsement of a fourteen-nation Committee on Commodity Problems and of plans for a greatly increased technical assistance program.

Twelve babies will move into the new premature nursery of Presbyterian Hospital on Friday. They will be the first tenants of the first premature infant unit built in New York with funds from the Federal, state and city governments supplementing money provided by a hospital.

Huddie Ledbetter (Lead Belly), the Negro minstrel from the deep South who attained international fame as an interpreter of his people's folk songs, died of a bone infection yesterday in Bellevue Hospital. He was 60 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, vice president and general manager of THE NEW YORK TIMES, urged the Federal Communications Commission today to "minimize the harmful effects" of new international telegraph regulations.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 6 -- Three new political parties have announced their formation in the last few days, following by about a week the withdrawal of licensing restrictions in the United States zone. At least two of them appear to have nationalist tendencies.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Two exhibits important to the Government's case were admitted in evidence today in Federal District Court by Judge Walter J. LaBuy in the trial of eight past and present Tucker Corporation executives on charges of violating the mail fraud statute and the Securities Act.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 6 -- Britain's failure to increase her Belgian franc earnings since devaluation has aggravated the difficulties in the way of the United Kingdom's participation in Western European regional economic integration.

Appealing to women to make a place for politics in their time and money budgets, Mrs. Preston Davie, chairman of the women's auxiliary of the New York County Republican Committee, yesterday opened the auxiliary's 1950 fund drive.

Brimming with the effervescent chit-chat for which he is noted, Noel Coward is in town renewing old acquaintances. Next Tuesday he'll leave for his winter home in Jamaica, B. W. I., for a couple of months' rest. Around mid-February the personification of "Present Indicative" will be back here to attend the world premiere of his picture, "The Astonished Heart."

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Grain prices turned sharply downward on the board of trade today after wheat had opened about steady with the close of the previous day. Scattered liquidation developed in December contracts as the result of tenders of 325,000 bushels of corn, 30,000 bushels of oats and 284,000 bushels of rye on future contracts and with talk of likely tenders of a liberal amount of cash wheat in the immediate future.

Whether or not a taxpayer suit upsets the arrangement, the truce effected by Governor Carvel of Delaware to end an eighteen-day bus and street car strike in Wilmington offers several points of interest, and possibly some lessons applicable in New York City. Union demands for a 35-cent hourly increase in wages had been rejected by the Delaware Coach Company.

A "strange package" aroused the fears of Mrs. George Racey Jordan yesterday that someone had sent her a bomb in reprisal for her husband's testimony on Monday before the House Committee on Un-American Activities. He said atomic bomb materials and data had been sent to Russia in 1943-44.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Consul General Angus Ward and nineteen members of the consulate general were scheduled to leave Mukden for Tientsin and eventual return to their homeland, at 2:45 P. M. today, Eastern standard time, or 3:45 A. M. Wednesday, China time.

The 1949-50 season may well set a record for chamber music. No sooner does one ensemble complete a series than another one begins. The latest to enter the picture is the Mannes Trio, which last night presented the first of three concerts it is giving at Times Hall.

Midland Beach Park on the south shore of Staten Island, for many years a prosperous summer resort, will be placed on the auction block in a tax lien sale today by the city. The sale will be held at 10:30 A. M. in the annex to Chelsea Vocational High School, 250 West Houston Street, Manhattan, and will be conducted by the Tax Department.
Because the officials failed to see Bill Harper of Oregon State step out of bounds, N. Y. U. suffered its second straight setback last night at Madison Square Garden.

The City Stores Company and its subsidiaries set new records for sales in the three, nine and twelve months periods ended on Oct. 31, but earnings were lower than in the preceding year, the report of the department and specialty store chain revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Communication Workers of America, CIO, today filed thirty-four separate unfair labor practice charges against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and nineteen affiliated companies.

The thirteenth annual schedule-making convention of the Eastern College Athletic Conference, a five-day parley that will bring to town the athletic officials of nearly 150 institutions, opened yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore with meetings of five affiliated leagues and associations.

Awards in an essay contest for non-ambulatory veterans in metropolitan area hospitals will be presented at a dinner at the Commodore Hotel on Dec. 15, it was announced yesterday by Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, chairman of the judges' panel, and William C. Hope, commander of Crossroads of the World Post 310, Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States.

From a Pan American World Airways Stratocruiser yesterday afternoon stepped Pierce Courtney White, who is the living answer to a question: "What manner of man will use four years savings for a flight to Ireland and back, then spend as little time as possible looking at the green little isle?"

The Rangers will seek their second straight victory in four nights against the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden tonight and attempt to climb from sixth place to within two points of second in the standing. Last Sunday, with Chuck Rayner getting his first shut-out of the season, the Blue Shirts beat Chicago, 4 to 0.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- After an eight-year delay, the Irish can now look forward to getting a statue of John Barry that the United States has promised.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UP) -- The volume of unemployment-insurance claims filed with state agencies increased "moderately" between October and November. the Labor Department reported tonight.

Traders in tax exempt and Government bonds have recovered from the pessimism that attended their anticipation of the Treasury's Dec. 15 exchange offer to holders of its obligations called or maturing on that date. Since the department's terms were disclosed last Wednesday, the trading pace has become livelier.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board issued today a new transatlantic air travel policy that will permit thousands of Americans to visit Europe next summer at sharply reduced fares. In a move that brought immediate opposition in some quarters, the board invited both scheduled and nonscheduled air carriers to conduct charter service to Europe between June 1 and Sept. 30.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UP) -- The Government's ban on mortgage insurance for housing under restrictive racial covenants may go into effect March 1, Federal housing officials said today. Under the new policy insurance will be denied for private loans on any housing project on which "there has been recorded a covenant racially restricting the use or occupancy of the property."

A hundred neediest? A thousand neediest? Can the numbers be measured? The children who do not laugh; the youths whose lives are twisted; the men and women struck down by accident or disease or sudden poverty; the aged who know no peace. These are the Neediest.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Dec. 6 -- The future of the Methodist Church in Communist China was viewed here today with guarded optimism by one of the denomination's leading mission officials. There are some 200,000 Methodist Church members in China and 150 missionaries.
NEWBURYPORT, Mass., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Andrew J. "Bossy" Gillis bounced back from twelve years of political obscurity today to win a fourth term as Mayor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The State Department said tonight that the suspension of the New York-to-Montreal operating license of Colonial Airlines, Inc., threatened by the Canadian Air Transport Board, would be "inconsistent" with the terms of an air agreement signed by the two countries on June 4.

Greeting cards and posters, toys and other objects made by youngsters in nineteen countries were shown yesterday at a preview of an exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History by the Committee on World Friendship Among Children.
A drive for funds for more research on the new "miracle cures" for arthritis was opened yesterday at a luncheon in the Commodore Hotel attended by 600 persons.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 -- An announced intention by defense counsel to show that a Government witness in the Harry Bridges perjury case was "a liar" caused a court room flurry today and led Federal Judge George B. Harris to admonish the jury against paying heed to statements of the attorney, James M. MacInnis.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The International Council of Christian Churches decided tonight against further efforts at seeking participation in the East Asian Christian Conference.

As the first of the major studios to divorce production from theatre operations beginning Jan. 1, Paramount is prepared to set cameras turning on eighteen features during the first eight months of 1950, it was announced by the company yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 6 -- A cautious debate today in the special political committee of the United Nations General Assembly moved the question of international control in Jerusalem toward a critical vote, probably tomorrow afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Max Brauer, Lord Mayor of Hamburg, urged today the retention of United States troops in Western Germany even if the Soviet Union withdrew its forces from the Eastern zone.

The largest educational drive in the history of the $250,000,000 materials handling equipment industry was started yesterday by the Materials Handling Institute, Inc., a national trade association. The industry-wide program was undertaken at the fourth annual meeting at the Commodore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Two men accused of illegally flying aliens into the United States from Havana have been arrested, and with their apprehension an alien-smuggling plot has been broken up, the Department of Justice announced today.

A total of $12,250,000 has been raised thus far in the record $50,500,000 building fund and maintenance campaign now being waged by the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, it was announced yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 6 -- Beating down United States opposition, the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly approved today a resolution under which the Assembly would refer Nationalist China's complaint against the Soviet Union to its Interim Committee, the Little Assembly, "for continuous examination and study."

ATLANTA, Dec. 6 -- A suggestion that President Truman deliver before a joint session of Congress a "bold proclamation" of Far Eastern policy that would warn the people of Asia against the "dangers of a permanent totalitarianism" was approved today by the executive committee of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America.
With the Northern upland game and waterfowl shooting about over and most of the deer hunters winding up the season, the foxhunting is due to get into full cry any day.

With South Africa again participating in the debate, the United Nations General Assembly voted overwhelmingly yesterday to ask the International Court of Justice for an advisory ruling on whether South Africa could legally defy four Assembly resolutions calling on her to place the former mandated territory of South-West Africa under international trusteeship.

The new Norwegian America liner Oslofjord, like her predecessor of the same name that was sunk by a mine in Allied troop service in the last war, will be at the disposal of the United States in any future emergency, Hans C. Henriksen, managing director of the company, declared yesterday.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Earnings of the Kelsey-Hayes Wheel Company for the first quarter of its new fiscal year, starting Sept. 1, were adversely affected by the recent steel strike, Vice President Lester R. Downie said today.

Nathan Milstein's annual New York recital, given last night in Carnegie Hall, signalized his twentieth year on the concert platform. Some virtuosos might not even like to be reminded of that fact. But Mr. Milstein's playing, by a violinist still in his youth, was the thing that made the occasion worthy of special note.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Dr. Austin Smith, who today officially succeeded Dr. Morris Fishbein as editor of the Journal of the American Medical Association and the association's nine other technical journals, amplified a recent warning issued by the association's council on pharmacy and chemistry against the indiscriminate use of the so-called anti-cold tablets.

Open your mouth and some knowing dentist is likely to tell you your troubles. Especially if he dabbles in psychiatry will he be able to tell the story of your emotional conflicts from tell-tale signs and symptoms of your gums and teeth.

The news spread like wildfire yesterday through the House of the Holy Comforter at 196th Street and Grand Concurse, the Bronx. Mrs. Amelia Marie Propper, its oldest guest -- 101 years old on Nov. 10 -- had received a letter from the Lonely Hearts Club.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Reports of a drought in Brazil, world's largest coffee producer, were cited today as a factor in soaring United States coffee prices.

Africa will offer many promising markets to United States exporters when exchange and trade restrictions become more normal, Frederick H. Jewell, export manager of the Davis Lawrence Company, Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., yesterday told the luncheon meeting of the Export Managers Club at the Statler Hotel.

The dramatic change in the world's atomic energy picture since last September indicates the need for a fresh approach to the problem of international control and a new concept for the extension of the rule of law.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Economic Cooperation Administration today earmarked $7,792,000 to finance purchase of Marshall Plan goods by seven Western European countries.

The annual report of the General Shoe Corporation showed yesterday that net sales in pairs were 6 per cent above the previous year, but in dollars they were 1 per cent lower, and net profit declined 8 per cent.

The nationalization of the steel industry in England may be a determining factor in the British general electtions next fall, Capt. Arthur Marsden, Conservative member of Parliament from Surrey, declared yesterday in addressing members of the Town Hall Club at luncheon at 123 West Forty-third Street.

Assistant Attorney General Herbert A. Bergson denied yesterday that the Government's anti-trust enforcement program was attacking bigness in industry. He said that the Justice Department rather was fighting "monopoly power" in suits against the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company and E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co.

THE professional basketball folks have just suggested three rules changes which are to be adopted almost immediately and the football people are yowling long and loudly about the two-platoon system on the eve of the meeting of their Rules Committee. It seems that someone is always yelling "There oughter be a law," and the tinkerers are forever juggling the code in these two major sports.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed barely steady, 4 points higher to 16 points lower.

Attempts by advertisers to inject more novelty into contests were cited yesterday by F. Harvey Morse, account executive of the Reuben H. Donnelly Corporation, as among the pitfalls in the use of this promotional device. He spoke at a meeting of American Marketing Association members in the Shelton Hotel.

Governor Dewey warned last night against the establishment of an authority to operate the Long Island Rail Road, now in the process of reorganization in the Federal Court. He addressed 900 at the thirty-seventh annual dinner of the Queens Chamber of Commerce in the Commodore Hotel Manhattan.

HONG KONG, Dec. 6 (UP) -- The Chinese Nationalist Government today rejected a strong United States protest against the shelling of United States merchant vessels that try to run its blockade of Chinese Communist ports.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration has ordered seven Marshall Plan countries to refund about $30,000,000 spent for recovery goods in this country that failed to move by the so-called 50-50 shipping rule.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 6 -- A Communist demand for an explanation of his statements on German rearmament may force Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of the Bonn Republic, to make an official statement of policy at the next session of the lower house of Parliament.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Dec. 6 -- A torpedo that hit the port of Monaco five years ago had a distant echo tonight when it indirectly brought about the downfall of the Government of the world's smallest monarchy.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 6 -- Collectors and Christmas shoppers in search of the unusual mingled today at the opening of the fifteenth annual show sponsored by the Antique Club of New Jersey at the suburban hotel here. It will be continued through Friday.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- The suspension of work on a third atomic pile at Great Britain's Sellafield plutonium production plant was ordered "as a matter of expediency" rather than as a result of any basic change in the country's atomic energy program, a spokesman for the Ministry of Supply said today.

The letter in THE TIMES of Nov. 25, in which a correspondent inquires why you omitted Vermont in a recent listing of states requiring the poll tax as a voting prerequisite, penetrates a chink in the armor of not only THE TIMES but the whole national press.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Directors of the National Enameling and Stamping Company today elected Stevens A. Bennett president, defeating for the time being the efforts of Arthur Keating to unhorse the present management. Mr. Keating, president and chairman of the Ekco Products Company and a director of National Enameling (NESCO), said he would wage a full-scale proxy battle to replace the management at the annual stockholders' meeting in April.

Thanks to the wonders of aviation, epicures who can afford it may roll fresh foie gras truffe on their palates this holiday season within ten days after its having been prepared in Strasbourg, France. And that, we hardly need add, is the world capital for foie gras.

In permitting John L. Lewis to dictate how much coal is to be mined, and where and when, the coal operators have tacitly handed over to the union leader one of the most important responsibilities of management. It is reassuring to note that the operators are showing an increasing awareness of this fact.

A family in Queens, whose "beloved son and brother" once suffered from an incurable disease, sent its contribution yesterday to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to help a mother among the neediest who is watching her daughter die of a rare blood disease.

"He was one of those pure artists through whom the deepest urgencies of their age and their country become articulate. * * * He was one of America's five or six major artists, who happened to work with ideas instead of with poems or novels." A major artistic thinker? Jefferson is the first name which would come to many minds.

The Greater New York Council for Foreign Students, composed of thirty-three colleges and organizations interested in extending aid to foreign students in this country, released its annual report yesterday to mark the first full year of operation. The report outlined the council's efforts to provide employment, financial aid, housing and over-all guidance to visiting students.

As the level of New York's Catskill and Croton reservoirs sank to 35.3 per cent of capacity, Mayor O'Dwyer from his sickbed at Bellevue Hospital yesterday took personal charge of the city's efforts to combat its growing water shortage.

Directors of North American Aviation, Inc., voted yesterday a 75-cent dividend at the conclusion of a two-day meeting in Los Angeles, at which they were informed of the net income of $7,306,409 for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, last.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- A Government-appointed committee proposed a measure today to introduce more competition in the distribution and exhibition of films while retaining the largely monopolistic structure of the British movie industry.

Dr. Joshua Starr, 42 years old, an analyst in the program evaluation branch of the State Department's international broadcasting division (the Voice of America), was found dead of gas poisoning at 11:10 A. M. yesterday in his apartment in Peter Cooper Village, 350 First Avenue.

Matthew Guinan, president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, issued a warning last night that a slowdown on the city's transit lines was imminent unless the Board of Transportation "acts very promptly" on the local's demands.

New Yorkers will welcome the announced plans of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity to install new street and park lighting costing $2,025,000 next year. Some of this work, of course, will be done in new sections of the city, such as some parts of Queens, where new housing developments have sprung up.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- British Treasury officials confirmed today that, as a direct result of a United States demand for the greater economic integration of Western Europe, Britain had made proposals to three Scandinavian countries for closer economic collaboration.

Johnson-Carper Furniture Company, Inc., one of the lage producers of medium price furniture, yesterday announced price increases averaging approximately 5 per cent on five of its seven three-piece bedroom suites. Harden Hill, vice president, said the increases are necessary because of higher lumber and plywood costs resulting from changes in minimum wage legislation.

MONTREAL, Dec. 6 (AP) -- For the fourth straight week, Detroit's Ted Lindsay holds the individual scoring lead in the National Hockey League. The 24-year-old left wing, a veteran of six seasons, has scored 13 goals and 17 assists for 30 points, league statistics showed today.
Announcements of the presentation of six new plays were made yesterday by various off-Broadway theatre groups.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 6 -- Responsible Yugoslav opinion considers the trial of the Bulgarian Communist leader, Traicho Kostov, former Vice Premier, and his ten co-defendants, which is scheduled to begin in Sofia tomorrow, as a diversion by the Soviet Government to justify the next stage of its campaign to overthrow the Tito regime.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman of New York, putting in his first appearance at the Capital since his election Nov. 8, announced today he planned to sit as a Democrat-Liberal.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 6 -- Sharman Douglas received a wall-bred Harvard hint today that there may be "more pep and flavor" in certain young Americans -- Harvard men, of course -- than in the British lords she has been dating.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 6 -- Although the minor leagues, swinging through the second day of their annual National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues convention, plumed themselves on the record high of fifty-nine circuits which operated in 1949, one of the bulwarks of onetime minor league greatness today was crumbling fast and within another day or two should be reduced to little more than rubble.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- Four public school boys, who wrecked the interior of a fifteen-car commuter train over Saturday and Sunday in a storage yard of the Harlem division of the New York Central Railroad to get material to build a fort, were arrested today and charged with juvenile delinquency.

The probable nature of any future war, and the fact that the Government estimates military needs at $15,000,000,000 a year, illustrate the necessity of planning civil defense measures now, speakers agreed yesterday at a hearing of the State Joint Legislative Committee on Military Law.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- British Government stocks continued to drift lower on the Stock Exchange here today as buyers apparently re-adopted the wait-and-see policy. Losses up to about a half-point were suffered by undated and long-term issues but short-dated stocks were strong.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 6 -- Far-reaching proposals for innovations in California's economic and administrative structure were advanced today on the second day of a two-day conference of 1,500 industry, labor and public officials called by Gov. Earl Warren to study the problem of fuller employment.

Angus Ward, United States Consul General, his wife and members of his staff were scheduled to leave Mukden yesterday for Tientsin and the American ship that is to transport them on the first stage of their journey home. They leave Manchuria not after a few weeks' adventure in a Communist jail but after a period of virtual imprisonment that has lasted nearly a year.

A move to insure the continuance of mandatory liquor price-fixing in this state was made by Daniel J. Scotti, executive director of the Veteran Affiliated Package Store Owners Association, yesterday. Mr. Scotti, working with three specialists on constitutional law, disclosed the completion of the final draft of a bill to be introduced at the next session of the State Legislature.

Supreme Court Justice Morris Eder denied yesterday an injunction that would have tied Local 450 and its funds to the left-wing United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America (UE), expelled on Nov. 2 by the Congress of Industrial Organizations as Communist-controlled.

Paper-hatted and ice cream-stuffed, 100 children celebrated the centenary of St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday at a special party in the nurses' dining room at Seventh Avenue and Twelfth Street. Judging by the din and demolition at the refreshment tables, the party was a success.

A suggestion that a "stockpile" of green coffee sufficient to meet normal demands for at least six months be set up as a stabilizing factor for coffee prices was advanced here yesterday by Angus Mackey, member of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange and head of Angus Mackey Co., coffee brokers.
HONG KONG, Dec. 6 -- Disintegration of Nationalist resistance to the Communists on the China mainland is proceeding rapidly, reports here from many sources made plain today.

College training opportunities for those already in business are helping the average food merchant to compete with and even beat the large chains, it was declared last night by Harry E. Cohen, supervisor of distributive education at the City College of New York School of Business, Evening and Extension Division.

Memories of some of Queens County's most notorious crimes, including the Guldensuppe and Snyder murders, will flare briefly today when several tons of legal papers are pushed into the furnace of the seventy - seven - year - old County Court House in Long Island City.

VIENNA, Dec. 6 -- Despite the apparent urgency of the Soviet claim for compensation for supplies and services to Austria, the Russians refuse to state any final sum as the extent of their claims, Austrian sources said today. The sum of 45,000,000 schillings [$2,736,000] has been mentioned but not as definitive and it is suspected that the total might grow to a much larger amount.

John L. Lewis set his own "pattern" yesterday for a new coal agreement, complete to the choice of trustees to "represent" the operators and the public in the United Mine Workers Pension and Welfare Fund.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 -- A contract bridge team from Canada and Boston led a field of twenty-nine men's teams-of-four in the national tournament of the American Contract Bridge League here today, while Philadelphia players dominated the contest among fifty-seven women's teams-of-four.

Anyone who wishes to see the McGraw-Hill president's horrendous full-page blast at "labor union monopoly" reduced to a puff of smoke can do so by reading "That Labor 'Octopus'" in the Oct. 29 issue of The Nation.

Pointing out that mills will no longer stockpile textile products, Ralph Allaire of Taylor, Pinkham Co., Inc., yesterday urged store buyers to plan on carrying a supply of sheets and pillowcases for sixty to ninety days. Such a buying policy, he said, would prevent loss of retail business as a result of inadequate stocks.

PARIS, Dec. 6 -- Statements published today by Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, and by his Deputy, William C. Foster, were interpreted here as supporting the stand of the Benelux group -- Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg -- for a trade bloc embracing those countries and France and Italy.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 (UP) -- Lightweight champion Ike Williams and his manager, Blinky Palermo, were summoned today to testify before the Pennsylvania Athletic Commission at noon tomorrow concerning the champion's fears about a "fix" of last night's title bout.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- A quiet anniversary of the day that President Roosevelt said would "live in infamy" will be observed tomorrow. The date was Dec. 7, 1941.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 6 -- The International Labor Organization today warned members of the United Nations that the disappointing and slow economic recovery of many Asiatic countries had pointed up the need for an early start on the peace organization's program for technical aid to backward areas.

MINEOLA, L. I., Dec, 6 -- Frank A. Gulotta, Nassau County District Attorney, today launched an investigation into complaints that local fight promoters had taken potential Golden Gloves young contenders out of the state and had entered them in professional matches for which their remuneration averaged $10.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- While India has not yet recognized the Government of Israel, overtures have been made for scientific relations between the two countries, Meyer W. Weisgal, chairman of the Executive Council of the Weizmann Institute of Rehovoth Israel, disclosed here today.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- While India has not yet recognized the Government of Israel, overtures have been made for scientific relations between the two countries, Meyer W. Weisgal, chairman of the Executive Council of the Weizmann Institute of Rehovoth Israel, disclosed here today.

DUBLIN, Dec. 6 -- County Kerryborn Michael J. Quill paid a flying visit from London to this city today. Before leaving he met the press at Leinster House where the Dail was in session and spoke on partition.

Directors of the National Association of Manufacturers proposed yesterday, on the eve of the opening of its fifty-fourth annual Congress of American Industry, the substitution of a uniform manufacturers' excise tax for all existing excises except those on liquor and tobacco.

ROME, Dec. 6 -- Land seizures by peasants occurred on a considerable scale today throughout the Province of Rome. Several thousand men, women and children under Communist leadership participated in the occupation of privately owned properties.

Now that the Northern huntng season is drawing to a close, except for those who hunt rabbits and foxes, the letters are flowing in with stories of assorted freak shots, mishaps and close calls, with most of the writers expressing the hope that through the publication of their experiences others will take warning.

Leonard Bernstein, serving as guest conductor of the visiting Boston Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night, put on a show that revealed some of his best and worst points. On the one hand he conducted with taste, refinement and an awareness of the music's proportions; on the other, he did violence to the spirit of a composition.

As thousands of civilians were mobilized by the Police Department yesterday to alert residents and property owners on the necessity for saving water, the city ordered all automobile washing "completely stopped." The police are to cooperate in enforcing the order, which was issued by Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.
SEBRING, Fla., Dec. 7 (AP) -- Rex Beach, whose books of robust men in robust times sold into the millions, killed himself at his lakeside retreat this morning with a pistol shot in the head.

The annual meeting of the National Association of Manufacturers yesterday heard vigorous denunciation of the "welfare state" and "statism," with the charge that the Truman Administration was endeavoring to impose both in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- A greatly modified substitute for the Administration's compulsory health insurance bill was proposed today by an Administration Democratic Senator, Paul H. Douglas of Illinois.

An issue of $2,500,000 of school bonds has been purchased by the Chase National Bank of New York and asociates from Arlington County, Va., on a bid of 100.049 for a combination of 5s, 1 1/2s and 1 3/4s for a net interest cost of 1.8624 per cent. The issue, dated Dec. 15, 1949, will come due from Dec. 15, 1950, through 1974.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 (AP) -- For yelling "fix" and then admitting he didn't know the source of the charge, Ike Williams, the lightweight champion, today was fined $500 by the Pennsylvania Athletic Commission for actions "detrimental to boxing."

Scarf-trimmed necklines and softly full sleeves gathered into cuffs provided pleasing detail yesterday at the Pierre Hotel in the showing of fur fashions by Ben W. Cohen of Finefur, Inc., 6 West Forty-eighth Street.

Harvard College's 110-piece band -- resplendent in flaming red blazers and white trousers with red stripe -- came to town yesterday morning for one formal concert and ended by giving several of the informal variety. The inspiration, impartial observers agreed, came from the approaching Yuletide.

The first "Boheme" of the season was given last night at the Metropolitan Opera House in a week of a year that marks the twenty-fifth anniversary of the composer's death and a forthnight at the Metropolitan that has seen the performances of all four of his greatest operas from "Manon Lescaut" to "Madama Butterfly," inclusive.
Whether entertaining at home or giving a gift, the news that fine crystal can be found again in sets complete with all the luxury pieces should be welcome.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The eighteen-nation Council of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations convened today in closed session and selected members for the Committee on Commodity Problems. The committee was created yesterday by the sixty-three-nation Food and Agriculture Organization conference.

OTTAWA, Dec. 7 -- If the St. Lawrence seaway and power project is not approved soon by the United States Congress, Canada will have to give serious consideration to abandoning the navigation features of the project and starting on the power side alone, Lester B. Pearson, Secretary of State for External Affairs, told the House of Commons today in reply to a question by T. L. Church, member for Toronto.

MARK TWAIN destroyed the literary reputation of James Fenimore Cooper. It declined, however, to remain destroyed. After all, in any age, attacks on the author of the Leather-Stocking Tales are necessary teething-rings for rising critics and satirists. But who else ever gave us in our youth such wonderful stories of wildly philosophical white hunters and distinguished Indians stealing stealthily through the twig-snapping wilderness of America's long, bright and adventurous morning?

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- The American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations joined today in the organization of a new non-Communist trades union international. In closing the Free World Labor Conference the delegates of 48,000,000 workers constituted International Confederation of Free Trade Unions as a rival to the Communist-led World Federation of Trade Unions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Protests by members of Congress -- thus far only Republicans -- against the plan of the Census Bureau to include in its forthcoming questionnaire an inquiry as to personal incomes assert that this exceeds any authority granted by the Constitution or bestowed, explicitly or implicitly, by any statute.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 7 (AP) -- Mrs. J. Purpura's My Freedom, a recent arrival from New England, came tearing down the short Tropical Park stretch like a jet-job as she got up in time to win the fifth race by a nose at the handsome odds of $47.30 for $2.

Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, which on Tuesday barred student bands from appearing at college basketball games in Madison Square Garden, announced yesterday that it would "next turn its attention to the use of amateur bands at Yankee Stadium, Ebbets Field and the Polo Grounds."
Li Tsung-jen, acting President of Nationalist China, arrived at the overseas air base at La Guardia airport yesterday for an indefinite stay here.
A mother of five children testified in General Sessions yesterday against her husband, being tried for first-degree murder.

The Federal Government brought its perjury charges closer to Alger Hiss yesterday with expert testimony that his Woodstock typewriter was the machine used to copy forty-one State Department documents.

The legal representatives of the United States, Britain and France are to meet next year to discuss the desirability and practicality of ending the still existing state of war with Germany. The new meeting was agreed upon by the Foreign Ministers at their last conference in Paris, and its probable result has been foreshadowed in the protocol concluded between the Western Powers and the Bonn Government.

Millard F. Tompkins Jr., president of the New York University Alumni Federation, Inc., issued a formal statement yesterday in answer to requests for comment on a petition by an independent group of alumni for the return of "big time" football to N. Y. U.

BOSTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The pacesetting Detroit Red Wings protected their National Hockey League undefeated road game string by eking out a 2-1 victory over Boston tonight before 10,103 at the Boston Garden. While the Bruins were bowing for the first time in seven home games, they lost two, Pete Horeck and Dave Creighton, with leg injuries.

Fruit cakes are stacked in stores from a profusion of bakers, as this column attempted to show earlier in the week. Excellent as many of them are, some households apparently still like to bake for themselves the most famous of Christmas confections.

The Lee Higginson Corporation heads an underwriting group of seventeen investment banking firms that will offer today 120,000 shares of new 5.12 per cent cumulative preferred stock of the Hudson Pulp and Paper Corporation. The offering price will be $25 a share, plus accrued dividends.

Brig. Gen. David Sarnoff, chairman of the board of Radio Corporation of America, has signed a contract with Cima Publishing Company for a book entitled "Science for Life or Death." Scheduled for April publication, the book presents the author's views on the latest developments of science as instruments for peace.

LONDON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- British school teachers are free to be Communists or hold any other political views so long as they mind their P's and Q's in the classroom, a British Government spokesman said today.

Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, said yesterday that economies he had put into effect would keep military expenditures for the current fiscal year down to $13,000,000,000, or $1,500,000,000 less than the figure used last month by President Truman in predicting a $5,500,000,000 Federal deficit for the year.

Samuel Reichmann, pianist, who made his debut here in 1926 and has given only one recital in the intervening thirteen years, returned to Town Hall last night for his third program in New York. It included two transcriptions of his own from organ works.

Donations in memory of an officer killed in action in France and of a private of the Seventy-seventh Division were among the 403 contributions sent yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES Neediest Cases Fund.

" The panel urged the maintenance of protective tariffs, noting particularly growing foreign competition in the tuna fishing industry, which employs 10,000 persons. * * * Promotion of foreign trade, to which was ascribed the employment of 200,000 Californians, was recommended. * * *" Thus runs a dispatch from Sacramento to yesterday's TIMES, describing proposals drawn up at a state-wide conference studying California's unemployment problem.

The Soviet Union is more vitally concerned with the internal economy of the United States than the atomic bomb or our outward military force, Gov. Sid McMath of Arkansas declared yesterday at a luncheon at the Advertising Club of New Work, 23 Park Avenue.

A revised bill to increase the annual salaries of members of the Board of Estimate and the City Council by amounts ranging from $2,000 to $15,000 was approved yesterday by the Council's Finance Committee. The Strict party vote was 6 to 3.
PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 7 -- Pearl Harbor was remembered here today, just as it has been on each Dec. 7 for the last eight years. With the passing of time the ceremonies have become simple and brief.

After a public hearing on a proposed local law to establish parking meter zones in the city, the City Council's General Welfare Committee decided yesterday not to report the bill out to the full Council until a study was made of recommendations by a number of speakers.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 7 -- Vladimir Dedijer, Director of Information, issued a statement today on behalf of the Yugoslav Government denouncing the Sofia trial of Traicho Kostov and his ten co-defendants as a threat to Yugoslavia's independence.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 7 to 9 points net higher yesterday under a moderate volume of business.

PARIS, Dec. 7 -- Ever since the first Soviet purge trials in the Nineteen Thirties the monolithic system of communism has found it convenient to explain its own mistakes and shortcomings by discovering traitors, enemies and saboteurs in its own ranks who wrecked plans that otherwise might have been perfect.

The American Civil Liberties Union offored yesterday a program that it said would enable any community to prevent, without suppression of civil rights, situations such as led to mob violence at the Paul Robeson concerts near Peekskill last summer.
Please allow me to thank you for your editorial of Dec. 3 entitled "Imports Are Necessary."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The State Department announced today that the United States and Canada would begin preliminary talks tomorrow on a new treaty governing the use of the Niagara River for development of power and preservation of the "natural beauties" of the falls and rapids.

Spring orders for men's sportswear are running about 20 per cent ahead of last year at this time, it was reported yesterday by Benjamin Gluckman, vice president and sales manager of Revere Sportswear. He has just returned from a six weeks' trip throughout the country and reported increased confidence on the part of merchants.

PATERSON, N. J., Dec. 7 -- A new system of high speed fabric dyeing, utilizing atomic energy compounds, was demonstrated today to members of the press at the plant of the Shamrock Textile Processing Company of this city.

Prospects for Italian shipping in the coming year, particularly on the trade routes between Italy and the United States, were described yesterday as "excellent" by Capt. Giuseppe Cosulich European general agent of the Home Lines.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Dec. 7 -- Back in the early days of skiing in 1934, this historic Taconic and Green Mountain area, long famous as a summer resort, began to realize its potentialities as a winter wonderland.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 7 -- The Yale University Glee Club, one of the oldest collegiate singing groups, will go on a Christmas concert tour of the Midwest and South, it was announced here today.

We measure our words with care when we say that the time has come when our people must get down to business on saving water. Surely no one who has reached the age of discretion and is not an unwashed hermit can fail to be aware that there is a water shortage.

Using only regular scheduled airline service, Tom Lanphier Jr., World War II fighter pilot, landed at La Guardia Airport at 11:55 A. M. yesterday to set a new record of 4 days 23 hours 47 minutes for round-the-world airline travel.

PARIS, Dec. 7 -- In a sweeping shake-up in the High Command of the French Army ordered by the Cabinet at its meeting this morning, Maj. Gen. Clement Blanc was promoted to lieutenant general and appointed Chief of the Army General Staff, replacing Gen. Georges Revers.

ROME, Dec. 7 -- A new major Socialist party came into being today when the Congress of Socialist Unification in Florence decided to found a Congress of the Socialist party. It will be known as the PSU, from the initials of its Italian name, Partito Socialista Unitario.

BOSTON, Dec. 7 -- Laurence F. Whittemore, president of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad for sixteen months, resigned today. He asked that the resignation be effective on Dec. 21 in order to accept "another position."

Neighborhood cats of various ages and descriptions, which heretofore have been entered in local pet shows sponsored by the Police Athletic League, will face more serious competition in conjunction with the Empire Cat Club show opening today in the McAlpin Hotel.

Seventeen, a magazine for teenagers and a subsidiary of the Triangle Publications, Inc., of which Walter Annenberg is president, has leased the entire tenth floor containing 19,500 square feet of space in the office building being erected by Uris Brothers at 488 Madison Avenue.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 7 -- Billy Southworth arrived backstage today as the minors got around to opening formally their annual National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues convention and no county fair barker could have drawn a bigger crowd of spellbound listeners

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- A second hormone from the cortex (outer layer) of the adrenal gland has shown promise, similar to cortisone and ACTH, as an agent capable of bringing about striking remissions in rheumatoid arthritis, according to a report presented here today before the interins clinical session of the American Medical Association.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7 -- "Flabbergasted" and "shocked," Mrs. Irene Harris, 63-year-old wife of a longshoreman, heard Harry R. Bridges tell a group in 1938 that he was a member of the Communist party, she testified before a Federal court jury today.

IN all the excitement and hullabaloo which followed the departure of Bill Veeck from the Cleveland Indians, so much attention was concentrated on the flamboyant strawberry blond that not many noticed the black-haired, determined and capable chap he left in the general manager's chair when he slammed the door behind him.

There is no better clue to the problems that beset the Neediest among New York's millions than their own words. The tragedies that have reduced them to their misery wring from them outbursts of pain, fear, grief, loneliness -- all the bleak and bitter emotions that well up from suffering hearts.

Leading figures in the banking world yesterday told approximately 300 frozen food men that their industry has passed the promotional stage and is financially sound from an investment viewpoint. They addressed a luncheon of the Eastern Frosted Foods Association in the Biltmore Hotel.

City Councilman Eugene P. Connolly, Manhattan Laborite, resigned yesterday in protest against the recent expulsion of Councilman Benjamin J. Davis, Manhattan Communist who was one of the eleven Communist leaders convicted of conspiracy charges.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 7 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of the Bonn Republic, reiterated today his apparent belief that Western Germany might be called upon by the Western Allies to provide manpower for a defense of Europe.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Moshe Sharett, Foreign Minister of Israel, concluded a conference with Secretary of State Dean Acheson today with a pessimistic report on further conciliation efforts in the Middle East.

PATERSON, N. J., Dec. 7 -- Hugh R. Johnston, foreman of the May term Passaic County grand jury, was in critical condition in Barnert Memorial Hospital tonight after shooting himself last night with a 12-gauge shotgun after returning from a hunting trip.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 7 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's ill-starred production of Henry Sienkiewicz's novel, "Quo Vadis," received a new setback today when Arthur Hornblow Jr. and John Huston were relieved of their respective assignments as producer and director of the film at their own request.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Frank Pace Jr., director of the Bureau of the Budget, will be leaving here tomorrow with a whole catalogue of $64,000,000 questions for President Truman.

Santa Claus sent 6-year-old Eugenia a sewing machine yesterday. Jeffery, who is 2, and Joey, aged 3, got xylophones from the North Pole, where the Jolly Gentleman also made dolls for Joan and Gloria, both 8, Marion and Marlene, both 10, and other toys for about twenty more patients in the children's cardiac ward of Bellevue Hospital.

The executive committee of the Eastern Intercollegiate Football Association, meeting yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore in connection with the thirteenth annual schedule-making convention of the Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference, endorsed the present method of assigning officials for college games.
The Interstate Commerce Commission resumed hearings yesterday on the petition of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad for further increases in commutation fare rates within New York State.

Much has been said and written, with little import, by leading economists, statisticians, politicians and industrialists, in behalf of the growing ranks of unemployed "oldsters." As real Americans, perhaps these thinkers and theorists could set aside their political differences and accusations, at least temporarily, and work together to rid this land of three vexing problems in our midst of plenty:
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 7 -- California authorities took stock today of the state's machinery for preventing sex crimes and found many ways in which it could be tightened and improved.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 7 -- A California peach grower who got rich during a Democratic Administration has willed his $750,000 estate to his brothers and sisters with the request that they become Democrats.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 7 -- In maintaining "a policy of silence" on religion the public school is not fulfilling its primary purpose of education for citizenship in American democracy, Dr. Luther A. Weigle, dean emeritus of Yale Divinity School, declared today.

EDGEWATER, N. J., Dec. 7 -- The theft of approximately $600,000 worth of parts and accessories from the Ford Motor Company plant here during the last several months was discl:osed today when six men were arrested for alleged complicity in the larcenies.

HONG KONG, Dec. 7 -- Communist troops have driven into Yunnan at Chaotung in the northern tip of the province, 200 miles from Kunming, reports reaching the Chinese press said here tonight. The Communists pushed to Chaotung from Pichieh, Kweichow Province.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The State Department disclosed today that United States diplomatic representatives from Seoul would be sent to the border between North and South Korea to arrange for the release of two Americans held by the North Korean Communist authorities since Sept. 22.
LONDON, Dec. 7 -- British Government stocks tumbled again on the Stock Exchange here today the third day in succession.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson confirmed today that the United States, Great Britain and France would take up the vexing legal problems of ending the state of war with Western Germany in a three-power meeting some time next year.
CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Joe Louis tonight knocked out San Francisco's Pat Valentino in the eighth of their scheduled ten-round exhibition in the Chicago Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Lieut. Gen. Leslie R. Groves, who headed the project that developed the atomic bomb, denied today before the House Committee on Un-American Activities that former Vice President Henry A. Wallace or the late Harry L. Hopkins, adviser to President Roosevelt, had ever attempted to put pressure on him for the release of atomic secrets or materials to Russia.

The six-story apartment house for seventy-eight families on a plot 182 by 100 feet at 320 Wadsworth Avenue was sold by Punia Marx, Inc., of Brooklyn, to an investing client of Benjamin Duhl, attorney, for cash over mortgages amounting to $243,875.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Leroy A. Lincoln, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, New York, said today that his company would accept 90 per cent of any sound small business loan if local banks would take the remaining 10 per cent and service the loan.

Southern Methodist's strong quintet, which upset City College here last year, will be out to repeat the trick tonight when the teams clash in the feature battle of the collegiate twin bill at Madison Square Garden. Clair Bee's Long Island University tossers take on Kansas State in the opener at 8 o'clock.

Full production of home appliances will soon be achieved by the Murray Corporation of America, large producer of automobile bodies and assemblies, at a modern plant in Scranton, Pa., it was announced yesterday.

An increase of 347,000 barrels of gasoline last week in the nation's stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute As of Dec. 3, stocks were 105,264,000 barrels, compared with 104,917,000 a week: earlier and 95,235,000 a year before.
The cooperation of New York dentists to save at least 6,000,000 gallons of water daily was pledged yesterday at the twenty-fifth annual Greater New York Dental meeting at the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Admiral Forrest P. Sherman, Chief of Naval Operations, asserted today that the United States program for the rehabilitation of Europe was proving a stronger peace force than heavily built-up armed services.

OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 7 -- Col. Lawrence Varsi Castner, leader of the Alaskan combat intelligence platoon known as "Castner's cutthroats" in the recent war, died at the home of his mother here yesterday of a heart ailment that developed when he was wounded in the battle of Attu, and caused his retirement from the Army in 1944.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 7 -- The 1950 shape of the Fair Deal program began to take form today under the coconut and cork trees on the lawn of the winter White House. Under the shade of the exotic trees President Truman and sixteen aides held their first staff conference on the forthcoming State-of-the-Union message.

Women of society headed by Mrs. Louis Connick are assisting the sale of tickets for the performance of "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes" on Tuesday night at the Ziegfeld Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for the New York City Hospital Visiting Committee of the State Charities Aid Association.

" Gentlemen Prefer Blondes," the musical transformation of Anita Loos' novel of the same name, arrives tonight at 8 o'clock at the Ziegfeld Theatre. Herman Levin and Oliver Smith, who introduced to American theatregoers three years ago Jean-Paul Sartre's drama of Existentialism, "No Exit," have teamed up again as sponsors of the venture.

Four banks and allied institutions were included in the list of establishments announcing declarations of special or increased dividends yesterday. Among them were the Guaranty Trust Company, which authorized for payment on Jan. 3 an extra disbursement of $2 in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of $3.

Magistrate Morris Rothenberg, acting national chairman of the United Palestine Appeal, reported yesterday that by the end of this year the appeal and its agencies will have spent $150,000,000 in Israel for immigration, rehabilitation and resettlement.

BERLIN, Dec. 7 -- A law adopted today by the People's Chamber in the Soviet zone insures that the tenure of jurists of the Supreme and state courts will be dependent on their political fealty. They will be appointed and recalled by a vote of the People's Chamber.
The controversy over the speed of phonograph record players moved one step nearer solution yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- The utmost effort to conserve water through re-use by the air-conditioning and refrigeration industry is in order, as the industry is the fastest growing user of city water supply and disposal systems, it was agreed here today.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 7 -- Harry A. McDonald, new chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, told the nation's investment bankers today what they may expect from his administration in respect to the trade's most controversial questions.

The United States charged yesterday that the "expansionist ambitions" of the Communist Information Bureau were behind the Soviet Union's bitter attacks against the agreement to create a new United States of Indonesia by the end of the year.

STEEP ROCK LAKE, Ont., Dec. (Canadian Press) -- Steep Rock Iron Mines, Ltd., had net profit for the ten months ended on Oct. 31, of $1,267,173. This is shown in an interim financial statement which will be presented on Friday to a meeting of shareholders.

MANILA, Thursday, Dec. 8 -- President Elpidio Quirino's Liberal party in a caucus last night laid plans to circumvent Congress' refusal to ratify the results of the Nov. 8 elections and thus prevent the Presidential inauguration. The press today told of another reported plot to overthrow the Govern

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Dec. 7 -- Marvin Jaffe of Long Island City scored 19 points to pace Muhlenberg's quintet to a 73-56 victory tonight in the opening game of the season with Fordham University before 2,300 fans.

Industrial activity at the end of November was at the highest rate since late September, according to the latest survey of business conditions by the National Industrial Conference Board, released yesterday.

Paramount Pictures, Inc., conforming to the requirements of the consent judgment entered against it last March by order of the United States Supreme Court has effectuated or entered into commitments for the termination of its joint ownership with co-owners of 347 theatres, Barney Balaban, president, reported in a letter sent yesterday to stockholders.

Formation of a new advertising agency known as Willsted Shacter, at 280 Madison Avenue, was announced yesterday by Fred Shacter and Martin Willsted.
