The former previously was an account executive with Hirshon-Garfield, Inc., sales and advertising manager of Traub-Lyons-Oppenheim, Inc., textile converters, and prior to that with Morton Freund Advertising and Lord Thomas.

William du Pont Jr. of Wilmington, Del., was voted the turfman whose services to racing were outstanding in 1949 in a pool conducted by the New York Turf Writers Association, it was announced by the organization yesterday. Long active in turf circles, du Pont is a member of The Jockey Club and the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Food Fair Stores, Inc., of Philadelphia filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $8,000,000 of "sinking-fund debentures, due Jan. 1, 1965.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 7 -- The fifty-two-day-old strike of 17,000 workers in nine plants of the Aluminum Company of America was settled today, ending the last of the major walkouts that at one time involved about 530,000 members of the United Steelworkers of America in the aluminum and steel industries.

PARIS, Dec. 7 -- In a motion voted today the Foreign Affairs Committee of the National Assembly "regretted" French acceptance of the United Nations plan for former Italian colonies and asked Foreign Minister Robert Schuman for an explanation.
A snowstorm blew into town from the Northwest yesterday, dropping .7 inch of the winter whitening on the city before dawn. But rain washed it away by 6:30 A. M.

HAMPTON BAYS, L. I., Dec. 7 -- The Canoe Place Inn, a hostelry that since its founding thirty-five years before the Revolution has played host to leading figures in society, politics and sports, has been sold to a New York hotel official for about $55,000, it was learned today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 -- A New York team won the national men's team-of-four championship and the women's team-of-four contest ended in a tie during the third day's play of the American Contract Bridge League tournament at the Bellevue Stratford Hotel here this afternoon.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board today ordered its first major fact-finding hearing in the dispute of rival electrical unions. The hearing, involving some 26,000 General Motors workers, is set for Dayton, Ohio, on Dec. 19.

The International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, and local contracting stevedores have come to an agreement on closing of the time gap between the end of a longshoremen's work period and his next pay day, Joseph P. Ryan, ILA president announced yesterday.

As part of a celebration marking the eightieth birthday of Hunter College, which will be on Feb. 14, fifty members of the faculty last night turned actors and revived Augustine Daly's 1868 melodrama, "A Flash of Lightning," at the College Playhouse, 695 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The International Association of Machinists, 400,000 out of whose 600,000 members are engaged directly or indirectly in defense work, laid the groundwork today for an all-out fght in Congress by labor against dispersal of war plants from coastal areas.

ALBANY, Dec. 7 -- Senator Austin W. Erwin, chairman of the state Temporary Commission on Agriculture, announced today the appointment of a labor committee to help develop a program of reducing the coat of milk distribution in New York City.

There is a theory which no non-professional rightfully may dispute that without the north light an artist might as well set bricks. Being sunless, the north light casts no major shadows, and the artist can paint away feverishly from dawn to dusk without having to change his colors after lunch.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 7 -- Traicho Kostov, former Deputy Premier and long a member of the Politburo of the Bulgarian Communist party, repudiated in open court today the confession of treachery and spying he had made in private to the police.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Cuban Government has invited the Inter-American Peace Committee to visit Cuba to determine the truth or falsity of charges by the Dominican Republic that an armed invasion against it is being organized on Cuban soil.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 7 -- The last days of the general election campaign have been marked by a brisk exchange of charges and counter-charges between the Labor Government and the opposition without the emergence of new issues. The balloting takes place Saturday.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The National Parliament adopted by a show of hands today the Communist law declaring church marriages illegal unless preceded by civil ceremonies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities, shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 30:

For the first time since the early Nineteen Thirties steel warehouses here are worried about price-cutting as a result of lower prices offered here on French, Belgian and German steel, it was disclosed yesterday. Discussions have been held between individual warehousemen this week about effects of the increasing volume of hot-rolled steel imports upon consuming markets on the Eastern seacoast.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- A Senate Agriculture subcommittee, holding the threat of a subpoena over him, today gave the president of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company until next Monday to produce a sheaf of data on the concern's purchase, sale and supplies of coffee.

William H. Lukens has been appointed general sales manager of the R. M. Hollingshead Corporation, Camden, N. J., manufacturer of chemical products. He formerly was vice president in charge of export sales for the corporation.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 7 -- The financial experts of the Administrative and Budgetary Committee of the United Nations General Assembly took up gingerly today the $8,150,000 estimate put forth by the Secretariat as the annual cost of running an internationalized Jerusalem. The big question still unsolved tonight was: Where is the money coming from-

In your editorial of Dec. 2, "Recognition in China," you aptly quote the remarks made by Clement Attlee in March, 1939, condemning recognition of the France Government as "a gross betrayal of a friendly Government, and an announcement to the whole world that anyone who is out to use force will always have a friend in the British Prime Minister."
Classification during a television program of a government employe as being a Communist is slanderous per se, Federal Judge Edward A. Conger ruled yesterday.

Settlement of the strike by Local 829 of the United Scenic Artists against five New York television stations was announced yesterday afternoon. Under the terms of a contract running until Oct 1, 1950, the basic minimum rates for scenic designers will not be changed, but revisions in hours and working conditions are expected to result in increased "take-home" pay for the union members.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 -- With Paul Arizen in the starring role, Villanova trounced St. Francis of Brooklyn, 80 to 57, after Pennsylvania defeated Swarthmore, 71 -- 65 in the opening double-header at the Palestra tonight before 3,000 spectators.

State and municipal financing last month, $247,203,075, was the largest for that period since the present decade began. Also, for the eleven months to Nov. 30 the total of $2,721,402,416 was the highest since the beginning of the Forties with the exception of the $2,858,011,534 reported for the first eleven months of 1948.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 7 -- Theodor Heuss, President of the West German Republic, told the people of Germany today that they must never forget the Nazi persecution of Jews.
LONDON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Labor Government began distributing today 1,000,000 copies of a leaflet entitled "For Women Only" -- an appeal for housewives to fight inflation. It advises housewives:

A weight advantage of close to seven pounds, along with a confusing style and the experience he has acquired through eighty-two engagements, last night carried Tommy Yarosz, Monaca, Pa., light heavyweight, to victory over Jimmy Beau, Norwalk, Conn., Negro boxer, in the feature eight-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena.

Jan. 5 was set yesterday as the date for the resumption of tin trading on the Commodity Exchange. At a special meeting yesterday the Board of Governors, acting upon recommendations of the Exchange's metals group voted approval of the trading proposal and formally established the date.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Establishment of a single monetary exchange rate, replacing a sliding scale system, was announced tonight by the Chilean Government.

A goal by Buddy O'Connor late in the second period provided the New York Rangers' margin in their 2-1 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

The city's decree to stop washing of automobiles came as a severe blow to garages and their workers, with the expectation that many car washers would be laid off and that auto laundries would be shut down entirely.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Dec. 7 -- The Christian Church in Eastern Europe had failed to be the "conscience" of the state, and this was one of the most "tragic" aspects of the current "cold war," the Rev. Dr. Garland E. Hopkins, associate secretary of the Board of Missions and Extension of the Methodist Church, declared here today.

The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday on the activities of its Manhattan staff, mostly telephone operators, in collecting enough dolls and other Christmas toys for distribution among 6,000 underprivileged children in the city area.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Setting a goal of 2,500 Lincoln Day dinners throughout the country in 1950, Guy George Gabrielson, the Republican national chairman, urged today that the emphasis be on mass participation rather than fundraising.

Parents must correct their negative attitudes toward hearing aids, Mrs. Marie Hayes Heiner, president of the Cleveland Hearing and Speech Center, and member of the board of trustees of the American Hearing Society, declared yesterday at the Princeton Club, 39 East Thirty-ninth Street.
Governor Dewey warned yesterday that if sound measures for coping with existing social problems were not adopted unsound ones would become inevitable.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 7 -- The Special Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today voted by an impressive margin to create a permanent international regime in Jerusalem. The city and its environs would form a separate enclave under the administration of the Trusteeship Council.
GENEVA, Dec. 7 -- Socialist economists and intellectual leaders in several Western European countries are showing distinct antipathy to further experiments in nationalization of industry.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- Higher prices for automobile accessories, parts and service are likely next year as a result of the steel strike, delegates to the Motor and Equipment Wholesalers Association's business conference said today. Manufacturers' and wholesalers' inventories have been reduced from the levels at which price reductions became general throughout the industry earlier this year, they reported.
DUNKIRK, N. Y., Dec. 7 (AP) -- A locomotive-size gas turbine fueled by pulverized coal was demonstrated today to a group of railroad executives by the American Locomotive Company.

Two apartment properties in Dumont, N. J., have been sold by E. M. Spiegel. As president of Laurel Gardens, Inc., he conveyed the two-story twenty-eight-family Laurel Gardens at Knickerbacker Road and Lexington Avenue to the Knickerbacker Corporation, and as the head of Briarwood Gardens, Inc., he sold the two-story seven-teen-family Briarwood Gardens at Larch Avenue and Knickerbacker Road to the W. K. Corporation.
Leon Hart, Notre Dame's stellar end, was the recipient of the Heisman Memorial Trophy at the Downtown Athletic Club last night as "the outstanding college football player of the 1949 season."

Yesterday's statements by General Groves and Secretary Acheson dispose rather thoroughly of the sensational charges that high government officials in Washington connived at, and participated in, sending Soviet Russia important atomic materials and still more important atomic secrets during the war.

DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Dr. George Rieveschl Jr., director of research for Parke, Davis Co., Detroit pharmaceutical concern, regrets that the anti-histamine drugs have been released for over-the-counter sale.

No settlement formula has yet been reached in the dispute between the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, and a committee representing thirty-eight East and Gulf Coast steamship operators, William N. Margolis, assistant director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, said yesterday after a session with the employers' group.

Three new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Radio City Music Hall, the attraction is "On the Town," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Technicolor musical featuring Gene Kelly, Betty Garrett, Frank Sinatra, Ann Miller, Jules Munshin and Vera-Ellen. Kelly and Stanley Donen directed and Arthur Freed produced from the screen play by Adolph Green and Betty Comden and the musical play of the same name.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- Grain markets were unsettled on the Board of Trade today in trading featured by selling of December wheat and corn against purchases of May. Wheat lost 1/8 to 3/4 cent and corn was 1/8 off to 3/8 cent up, the latter on May. Oats were up 1/4 cent to 1/8 cent down; rye rose 3/4 to 1 cent, and soybeans, 3/4 cent to 1 3/4 cents.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 7 -- The Navy permitted a commercial plane to deliver a keg of beer to its Boca Chica Naval Air Station today. It was a special delivery from Milwaukee for sixteen Navy men who were observing the eighth anniversary of "the day of infamy" at Pearl Harbor.

The Bulgarian Communist leaders (those few who are left in power) evidently were not quite able even in eight months to soften the iron will of Traicho Kostov and to induce him to make the usual plea of guilty. In other respects this latest purge follows familiar patterns.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- An emphatic denial that any airplane equipped with radar left Washington for the Soviet Union during World War II was made here today by Major Bernard Green of the Military Intelligence Reserve.
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Dec. 8 (Reuters) -- S. G. Holland, whose National party defeated the Labor party by 46 seats to 34 in last month's New Zealand general election, announced his Cabinet today.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- Britain's economic situation is improving. Since the devaluation of the pound the nation's gold reserve, which had come perilously close to the bankruptcy point, has increased. So have exports and productivity in industry.

Italian small business men, artisans and farmers will now be able to purchase American equipment and machinery on generous credit terms under a procedure now perfected in Italy, it was learned here yesterday.

As possible substitutes for personal interview tests used by the city school system for fifty years, the Board of Examiners is experimenting with group interview tests for selection of supervisors and administrators, it became known yesterday.
HONG KONG, Dec. 7 (UP) -- Nationalist officials today poured into Hainan Island in a wholesale evacuation of the Chinese mainland as Communist armies swept to within forty miles of Chengtu.

Casualty insurance companies are ready to undertake the rehabilitation of injured workers but have hesitated to enter the field in New York State because of a law provision that they feel might penalize them criminally, the Joint Legislative Committee on Labor and Industry was advised yesterday.
Mayor O'Dwyer attended midnight mass last night in the Roman Catholic chapel at Bellevue Hospital It was the first time he had left his suite since entering the hospital on Nov. 28.
Medicine is in danger of becoming a trade rather than a profession in the eyes of the public, Dr. Franklin Murphy, dean of the University of Kansas Medical School, warned here yesterday.

Strong buying in the steel issues yesterday reversed a sagging stock market and left prices generally higher. The demand for the steels was fairly impressive and was considered inspired by predictions of a high operating rate in the industry for some months.

Reports that displaced persons in Europe are starving and inadequately clothed and cared for are "gross misrepresentations" of the facts, Senator Pat McCarran, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, declared yesterday.

The seventy-four little girls were beribboned and scrubbed shiny, and their brothers were out to keep them that way at the sixteenth annual Little Sister Beauty Contest yesterday at the Boys Club of New York, Avenue A and Tenth Street.

John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers rejected last night an employer request that the union call off the Lewis-decreed three-day work week for 80,000 Pennsylvania hard-coal miners. The union action strengthened the belief that Mr. Lewis wanted to exert maximum pressure on the anthracite operators in the hope of making his first major contract breakthrough in that section of the coal industry.

The United States agreed yesterday to vote for a three-nation proposal to refer Nationalist China's charges against the Soviet Union to the United Nations Little Assembly, on condition that the Little Assembly be directed also to study any future violations of a five-nation resolution upholding the territorial integrity of China.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission began today a hearing on applications to expand natural gas service in the New York-New Jersey-Philadelphia area.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Dec. 7 (AP) -- A spokesman for the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service said tonight that some 3,000 workers on a wildcat strike at atomic installations would be ordered by their unions to return to work tomorrow.

TOKYO, Dec. 7 -- A strong plea to Occupation authorities to grant him just a little more administrative freedom while retaining their general supervision over broad policy was made today by Finance Minister Hayato Ikeda in an interview.

Three merchant marine officer unions charged yesterday that Sieling Jarvis, operators of the American-flag tanker Saint Christopher, had "used subterfuge and distortion" to sign off their American seamen and officers and replace them with Chinese crewmen and later with an entirely Italian crew except for the American master.

Henry G. Waltemade, director of the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards, will be the principal speaker at the dinner meeting of the Association of Bank Women, Middle Atlantic Division, to be held at the Hotel Warwick on Dec. 13.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The United States, by official account, had not yet found the secret of the atom bomb at the time uranium shipments were going to Russia in 1943.

Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, reported yesterday that the "cold war" to prevent further expansion of Russian influence in Europe was "half won" but that the most difficult part of the task remained to be done.

The O'Dwyer Administration rejected flatly last night demands by the Transport Workers Union, CIO, for higher wages and shorter hours and warned the union not to engage in a threatened subway slowdown before Christmas.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- Twenty-five participants in the Robeson concerts have refused to sign waivers of immunity when called to testify before the Westchester County October Grand Jury that is investigating violence at the affairs, it was disclosed tonight.

Happy days are here again. The musical version of "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes," which lighted the Ziegfeld last evening, is a vastly enjoyable song-and-dance antic put on with humorous perfection. Millions of people doted on Anita Loos' comic fable when it appeared as a play in 1926 with a memorable cast and the laughs pitched fairly low in the diaphragm.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Mooler-Dee Textile Corporation, Wilmington, Del., had filed with it a registration statement covering 500,000 shares of the company's $5 par value capital stock.

A sizeable segment of Christendom is against the total internationalization of Jerusalem, Dr. Carl Herman Voss, chairman of the executive council of the American Christian Palestine Committee, said last night at a testimonial dinner to Eddie Cantor sponsored by the New York Chapter of Hadassah.

The orderly program of the Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference's thirteenth annual schedule-making convention was enlivened by a heated, but inconclusive, discussion on the two-platoon system yesterday. The subject came up in the course of the closed meeting of the Eastern Intercollegiate Football Association.

This has been a singularly rich season for chamber music, a commodity that has not the public of opera and orchestra. It is not yet mid-December, and already there has been an impressive number of ensembles in an impressive number of series. But those who value the special joys of listening to chamber music would be well advised not to overlook the Hungarian Quartet, which played last night at Town Hall.

BERLIN, Dec. 8 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, United States Commandant in Berlin, accused Russia today of having mounted an economic blockade of Berlin "in many ways more effective than the old Russian blockade."

Jonel Perlea's conception of "Carmen," presented at the Metropolitan Opera last night, was a revelation. It had not only the freshness of a first performance of the season, but a warmth and sweep that were of the conductor's own making.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 8 -- The Federal Reserve System's scanty sales of long-term Government bonds in recent months may turn out to be a market extreme, driving prices to unwarrantedly high levels and complicating both the pricing of future issues of Treasury securities and the stabilization of their market behavior after issuance, the Investment Bankers Association convention was warned here today.

Although the purposes of the National Health Service of Great Britain are to emphasize preventive medicine, thus far the project has been occupied largely in filling prescriptions and catching up with the deficit in dental and ophthalmic services and other immediate and urgent health needs of the population, Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, dean and Professor of Medical Economics, Faculty of Medicine, Columbia University, reported yesterday.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange sold off slightly yesterday on the bearish final estimate of the cotton crop by the Government, and closing prices were 9 to 17 points net lower than on Wednesday. Early in the summer there were many trade reports that the acreage was larger than the Government estimates.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 8 (UP) -- The Government has begun to arrest Communist party members because "Anglo-American intelligence agents" have infiltrated their ranks, the cultural newspaper Lidove Noviny reported tonight.

Indicating that negotiations will soon be opened between the United States and Brazil for improving the investment and commercial climate in that country for American commercial operations, the board of the American-Brazilian Trade Council yesterday approved and sent to the State Department a special memorandum urging safeguards for the United States exporter.

Tex Sullivan, manager of heavyweight Lee Oma, said yesterday that he was withdrawing his boxer from an exhibition bout with Joe Louis, scheduled for Detroit on Wednesday. Asserting that Louis' recent ring performances are real fights and not exhibitions at all, Sullivan added that he would prefer to have Oma meet the Brown Bomber in a regular contest that would draw a good gate.

ATLANTA, Dec. 8 -- Representatives of fifteen Protestant denominations in ten Southeastern states approved today an action program that called attention to "un-Christian racial attitudes" in the South and listed seventeen measures for correcting the situation.

Unusually early skiing will be enjoyed in the East this week-end as many of the popular areas report limited to excellent running. With such a booming start after last winter's snow scarcity, the 1949-50 ski season promises to be one of the best in history.

The exploitation of child labor on commercial farms in New York State is still an urgent problem despite more stringent enforcement of existing laws, the Joint Legislative Committee on Labor and Industry heard yesterday as it ended four days of hearings here on prospective legislation.

Henry Julian Wadleigh, named with Alger Hiss by Whittaker Chambers as one of his two sources of State Department documents for a pre-war Soviet spy ring, testified yesterday that he had channeled up to 500 State Department papers into Soviet hands in 1936 and 1937.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, and the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company were hosts yesterday to a group of sixty-six high school seniors, of whom half had come up from Oak Ridge, Tenn., and half down from Bronxville, N. Y.

Youngsters of Police Athletic League centers put on an exuberant cat show of their own yesterday under the sponsorship of the Empire Cat Club, which opened its thirty-third championship event at the McAlpin Hotel.
WARREN, Ark., Dec. 8 -- A small Dutch community reached across the Atlantic Ocean and deep into Arkansas tonight to express its appreciation of American aid over the last quarter century.
HONG KONG, Dec. 8 -- The capital of the depleted Nationalist Government of China shifted for the fourth time today, this time to the island of Formosa, 110 miles off the mainland.

" The Unusual in Antiques," boasts the cost of arms on the building at 22 East Fifty-fifth Street opened yesterday by Symons Galleries. That slogan is backed up by six floors filled with exquisite examples of English and French eighteenth and nineteenth century antiques.

James G. Law, vice president and general manager of the Magee Carpet Company yesterday urged the carpet industry to investigate large-scale use of substitute raw materials for Argentine wool He spoke at the annual meeting of the company's 100 distributors in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 8 -- The Geiger counter, a device that detects the presence of radioactive materials, now has been put to use to verify the existence of brain tumors, the Radiological Society of North America was told today.
As a New Zealander I am grateful for your lucid and accurate editorial on the result of the New Zealand General Election, which ended fourteen years of Labor rule.

Reprisals against David Dubinsky's International Ladies Garment Workers Union for its refusal to join other American Federation of Labor unions in seeking Mayor. O'Dwyer's re-election threatened yesterday, to cause the Dubinsky union to withdraw its 200,000 New York members from the official AFL central body in this city.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Dec. 8 -- A large and influential body of Protestant opinion in this country will support the action taken on Wednesday by the Special Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly when it approved the creation of a permanent international regime in Jerusalem, the Rev. Dr. Garland E. Hopkins of Washington, D. C., predicted here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Members of Congress of both major political parties received a gift in the mail today from the American Medical Association -- a copy of John T. Flynn's recent book, "The Road Ahead."

Business loans made by banks in this area dropped $11,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, registering their fourth successive weekly decline. Data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed that although there was some expansion of borrowing from among the reporting New York City member banks, reductions of commitments predominated.

PARIS, Dec. 8 -- The Cabinet of Premier Georges Bidault was rebuffed twice today by the National Assembly over a proposal to increase veterans' pensions. The Government obtained a compromise by only six votes after a whole day spent in debate.

A new method of treating cancer, which was said to have resulted in the relief of pain in many cases and the halting of malignant growths in others, was described last night by Dr. Emanuel Revici, scientific director of the Institute of Applied Biology in Brooklyn.
MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 8 -- Construction of a system of ground water reclaiming basins has enabled Nassau County to conserve its water resources and escape the near-famine faced by New York City.

Reports of skin reactions and toxic effects from "cold wave" solutions such as those in home permanent kits were not substantiated by tests on 1,200 women, Dr. Howard T. Behrman of the New York University College of Medicine told the Society of Cosmetic Chemists yesterday at its annual meeting at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel.

" Side-effects" from the use of the new anti-histamine drugs for the relief of colds and certain allergies have been noted in 10 to 65 per cent of the patients so treated by physicians, according to James C. Munch, research pharmacologist of Upper Darby, Pa.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UP) -- United States Consul General Angus Ward and his entire party have arrived safely at Tientsin, China, the State Department reported tonight.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 8 -- By joint informal agreement the three Western Allied High Commissioners have decided to attempt to quash all public talk of German remilitarization by keeping silent on the matter. Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of the West German Republic, who has publicly commented on some aspects of the subject, has been given to understand, also informally, that it would be a good idea for him to observe the same policy.

Dresser Industries, Inc., builders and distributors of equipment used chiefly in the petroleum and natural gas fields, had net earnings of $3,524,804 in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, last, H. N. Mallon, president, reported yesterday in a preliminary unaudited statement to stockholders.

New York City tax-anticipation notes, amounting to $60,000,000, have been awarded to twenty-six bank and trust companies, Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday. The notes, dated Dec. 9, 1949, and bearing an interest rate of 1 1/8 per cent, mature as follows: $20,000,000 payable on April 12, 1950; $20,000,000 on April 19, 1950, and $20,000,000 on April 26, 1950.

Fifty-six years old yesterday, Pierre Etchebaster held the gallery spellbound with the perfection and artistry of his performance as he opened the defense of his world court tennis championship against Ogden Phipps of Roslyn at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 8 -- King Leopold III was deterred from returning after his liberation from German captivity in 1945 by an implied threat of Allied economic sanctions, it was asserted today by Prof. Jacques Pirenne, the self-exiled monarch's chief secretary in Brussels.
Capt. John Miller, veteran pilot of Pan American-Grace Airways, Inc., was honored yesterday at the Wings Club, Biltmore Hotel, upon the completion of 25,000 flying hours as a pilot.

When Great Britain catches up with her backlog of orders, American manufacturers of wool goods will feel the real impact of competition based on devalued currency, Lord Barnby, past president of the Federation of British Industries, declared yesterday.
A total of $16,000 in fines was levied yesterday against 1,219 Sanitation Department street sweepers and truck drivers who participated in a "sick strike" on Oct. 17.

BERLIN, Dec. 8 -- The administration of the German Democratic Republic today issued an official ban against the entrance into its domain, including the Eastern sector of Berlin, of any member of the Yugoslav military mission stationed here.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 8 -- Despite further improvement in the steel industry, business in the Pittsburgh district lost ground last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The setback resulted partly from the return to a three-day work-week in the coal industry and partly to a less-than-seasonal gain in the volume of trade.

The United Nations General Assembly approved yesterday a $54,900,000 program to provide jobs on public works projects and direct relief for 652,000 Arabs who fled from Palestine during the fighting that followed the end of the British mandate.
Mr. and Mrs. Austin B. Osgood have come to the Delmonico from Washington.

VIENNA, Dec. 8 -- Chancellor Leopold Figl today sent a note to the Allied Council requesting that Austrian gendarmes be permitted to use arms against members of occupation forces caught in criminal acts of violence.

The Transport Workers Union, whose demand for a forty-hour week and a 21-cent-an-hour wage boost was rejected summarily Wednesday night by William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation, talked "tough" publicly yesterday.

A new International came into being in London Wednesday when the representatives of 48,000,000 workers adopted a constitution and elected officers for a Confederation of Free Trade Unions. This is an event of historic importance, in many respects the most significant development in the struggle for a free world.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The testimony of George Racey Jordan, a former Army Air Forces major, concerning shipments of atomic materials to Russia in 1943-44 led the House Committee on Un-American Activities into an intra-mural dispute today.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Some of Britain's foremost critics among German industrialists and financiers got a lecture in Duesseldorf yesterday from Sir Ivone Kirkpatrick, head of the German section of the Foreign Office, on the reasons for the Allied policy of restricting German industry.

Howard C. Sauer, general manager of the export division of the Timken Roller Bearing Company, Canton, Ohio, was elected president of the Overseas Automotive Club at the annual meeting yesterday at the Hotel Shelton.

A top retailer representing one of the largest store groups in England said yesterday that there is a much greater market for distribution for British goods than now exists in this country. Simon Marks, vice chairman and managing director of 240 stores in Great Britain, made this appraisal of American business yesterday in the offices of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Strong trade demand throughout the day caused the coffee futures market in contract S to turn firm on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Final prices were 200 points above the previous close, including the spot December, with sales amounting to 54,250 bags.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 8 -- The much-discussed and frequently cussed bonus rule of organized baseball, which for three years has placed severe restrictions upon major league clubs which seek to entice hitherto unsigned high school, college and sandlot players into their organizations by offering flattering inducements tat in some instances soared to $75,000, will remain in effect for another year at least.

BONN, Dec. 8 (AP) -- President Theodor Heuss declared today that current speculation over a West German army was dangerous to Germany's future. He said he was against a West German army even if the Western Allies should want one.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 -- In the labor-turbulent depression years not only Harry Bridges but the conservative wing or organized labor in California had aims similar to those of the Communist party, the defensetried to show today in four hours of cross-examination at the Bridges perjury trial.

" Arms and the Girl!" the Herbert and Dorothy Fields -- Morton Gould song and dance fabrication of "The Pursuit of Happiness," isn't coming to the Mark Hellinger after all, notwithstanding the fact that Anthony B. Farrell, owner of the Hellinger, has an investment of $100,000 in the Theatre Guild's $200,000 musical. Therefore, Mr. Farrell's presentation of "Texas, Li'l Darlin' " will remain undisturbed at the Hellinger.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Knight's Gift, owned by P.L. Grissom, marked her Tropical Park debut with an exciting triumph in the Aurelius Purse today, streaking home a length and a half clear of H. J. April's Shining Deed.

A study of the probable industrial uses of atomic power, and the effect on world economy, is planned for publication early next year by the Princeton University Press, entitled "Economic Aspects of Atomic Power." The study has just been completed by the Cowles Commission for Economic Research, a part of the University of Chicago.

Because of the increased activities provided for underprivileged families on the lower East Side, the Henry Street Settlement began yesterday its first public appeal for funds to supplement the budget formerly obtained from voluntary contributions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Truman Administration was said today to be desirous of easing Federal taxes on American business operations abroad to support the President's program for encouraging foreign investment.
Talks between anthracite operators and John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers were reported yesterday to have entered for the first time the area of genuine collective bargaining.

In the early fall of this year, when I heard the criticisms of the B-36, and of the methods of its operation, it brought a thought to my mind: What would the experts in their lines say were I to criticize battleships, destroyers, carriers and their operations?

Lieut. Gen. Leslie R. Groves, retired, said yesterday he had withheld from former Vice President Henry A. Wallace secret reports on atomic developments that normally would have gone to Mr. Wallace, The Associated Press reported.

Brazilian coffee producers, disturbed by talk in this country that Brazilian growers have purposely underestimated the probable size of the forthcoming coffee crop to create a scarcity market and drive up prices, are planning an official reply to the allegations, according to cables received in the trade here yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 8 -- On the eve of the decisive General Assembly debate on the proposed internationalization of Jerusalem, Israel gave flat warning today to the United Nations that any effort to put the city under the aegis of the world organization would be taken at considerable risk.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The House of Delegates of the American Medical Association, supreme policy-making body in American organized medicine, today voted unanimously to establish annual dues of $25 for its 142,000 active members.

The Public Service Commission disputed yesterday the contention of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad that it had lost $37,089 in its intrastate commuting operations during the "sample" month of June, 1948. Through two consulting engineers, the PSC offered testimony at an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing, purporting to show the railroad actually had gained $48,566.
A five-power resolution calling on all nations to respect the territorial integrity of China was approved yesterday morning by an overwhelming majority of the United Nations General Assembly.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 8 -- Roman Catholics prayed today in the Church of Dormition on Mount Zion for the first time in eighteen months when a solemn high mass observing the Feast of the Immaculate Conception was celebrated in the vaulted crypt.

Today's events: Philharmonic Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos, conductor and piano soloist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 o'clock; "Simon Boccanegra," Metropolitan Opera, 8:15; Metropolitan Bell Symphony, Frederic Kurzweil, conductor. Patricia Travers, violin, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 8 -- The United Nations Social Commission voted unanimously today to take the first steps toward the development of a comprehensive program to promote the rehabilitation of the physically handicapped. The commission acted after hearing recommendations by Dr. Howard A. Rusk, United Nations special consultant.
The woman today "who concerns herself with politics to me typifies the finest type of American woman," Mrs. Eugenie Anderson, Ambassador-designate to Denmark, declared yesterday at the Chatham Hotel.

BERLIN, Dec. 8 -- Premier Otto Grotewohl of the East German Democratic Republic has been hospitalized since last Sunday, it was confirmed today by both Eastern and Western German sources. Walter Ulbricht, his deputy, has temporarily assumed the duties of his office, and official announcements indicate that Herr Grotewohl will be unable to resume his post for four weeks.
The nation's leading industrialists were told yesterday that America's middle-income families comprise industry's best source of investment capital.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A rapid rise in the number of unemployed workers exhausting jobless benefit rights is causing growing concern among Government officials.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday were 693,923 cars, the Association of American Railroads reported today. This was 29,368 cars, or 4.4 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 110,249 cars, or 13.7 per cent, fewer than for the same week last year and 184,665 cars, or 21.0 per cent, fewer than for the week two years ago.

Air - conditioning on passenger ships is indispensable and no American liner of the future will receive Government construction aid unless the design calls for such a system, Joseph K. Carson Jr., a member of the Maritime Commission declared yesterday.

Three city-owned North River piers, two of which are suitable for the berthing of the largest ocean liners in the world, have been leased to the Cunard White Star Line and Baltimore Ohio Railroad, it was announced here yesterday by G. Joseph Minetti, Commissioner of the Department of Marine and Aviation.

THE beak-busting business is back in the news again, as winsome and as inspirational as ever. The impression is growing that every State Athletic Commission should order compulsory memory courses for every sterling charactor under its control. Boxers are the forgettingest guys. Ike Williams, the world lightweight champion, drew a complete blank in the recollection department the other day and had a $500 fine slapped on him by the Pennsylvania authorities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat, of Virginia, called today for a $36,000,000,000 limit on Federal spending in the 1951 fiscal year, which begins July 1, to provide a surplus and halt what he regards as a trend toward "national insolvency."
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 (UP) -- Avery Brundage, president of the American Olympic Games Committee, today said that he expected Japan to compete in the 1952 Olympics at Helsinki.

Switching operations dominated the trading yesterday on the Stock Exchange but prices reached new highs for the current movement despite a minor set-back near the close. There were some isolated charges of a point and more, but generally the list held within a fractional range, with the composite average up 0.26 point on the day.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 8 -- Scotching rumors of a prospective peace settlement with Mary Pickford in the battle of their jointly owned studio, Samuel Goldwyn has concluded a deal for rental of storage space at the Eagle-Lion studio and has begun to move his production equipment from his own plant, it was learned today from a Goldwyn representative.

VIENNA, Dec. 8 -- The Austrian Parliamentary Commission inquiring into an alleged million-dollar scandal in connection with purchases for Austria under Economic Cooperation Administration allocations in the United States heard preliminary evidence today from Sanford de Brun, Frederick Lawrence Sunley and Kurt Ullrich.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- In cold, drizzling rain the people of South Bradford, Yorkshire, a woolen textile manufacturing center, went to the polls today to vote in a by-election that, because of the approaching general election, was closely watched by leaders of all parties.

A former housepainter, who took over without investment a lower east side condemned tenement that he sought to turn into a cooperative at a possible $100,000 profit, was among eight persons arraigned yesterday in Special Sessions on rent-gouging charges.

The spotlight in the critical water shortage shifted yesterday to New Jersey where, in Trenton, Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll issued a proclamation declaring a state of emergency in the droughtstricken northern half of the state.

GALVESTON, TEE., Dec. 8 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, told a combined meeting of Galveston's luncheon clubs today that "you must not bow your necks to a centralized government."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today increased its estimate of this year's cotton crop by 510,000 bales -- a fact that added new pressure on growers to cut production in 1950 to avert a burdensome surplus. The year's final estimate put the crop at 16,034,000 bales, or 3 per cent more than the November estimate.
I would like to add a word if I may in connection with the existing water shortage.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, and Harold Wilson, President of the Board of Trade, who is just back from a visit to the United States, gave a profit-and loss statement to the nation today on devaluation of the pound. The gist of their remarks at a press conference was that Britain is doing better since devaluation but not well enough, largely because of lagging by private industry.

Clarence E. Pickett, executive secretary of the American Friends Service Committee, said yesterday that the offer by Israel to accept 100,000 Jewish refugees is a humanitarian act that should be made effective as soon as possible.

The United States Treasury is withdrawing $562,000,000 from its War Loan accounts with both Class A and Class B banks under a call issued yesterday. The call, based on balances as of the close of business on Dec. 7, must be met on Dec. 15.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Bob Hamilton, veteran professional from Landover, Md., took the lead in Miami's $10,000 open golf tournament today with a blistering six- under-par 64.

Europe's recurring dollar shortage is the result primarily of unwillingness or inability to produce for the American market the goods it demands, according to Robert R. Wason, former president of the National Association of Manufacturers.

Unmoved by the protests of spokesmen for four civic organizations, the Board of Estimate voted unanimously yesterday to increase, by $1,000 to $10,000, the annual salaries of twenty-four heads of city departments and agencies and members of Mayor O'Dwyer's City Hall staff.

George Heller has been appointed national executive secretary of the Television Authority, the new labor group established to organize performers in video, it was announced yesterday. He holds the same post with the American Federation of Radio Artists.

Those Americans across the continent who have responded to the appeal for the Neediest Cases Fund demonstrate again our people's traditional sympathy for the unfortunate. In touching notes mailed with contributions a cross-section of our vast population has shown the kindly spirit for which this nation is known.

Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan signed three orders yesterday asking the Government to show cause why diplomatic immunity should not be granted to Valentin A. Gubitchev, why his trial for espionage should not be severed from that of Judith Coplon, with whom he is co-defendant, and why the conspiracy count in his indictment should not be quashed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Expenditures by United States business on new plant and equipment probably will reach $4,400,000,000 in each of the third and fourth quarters of this year, while total capital outlays for the year are expected to be $17,900,000,000, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Department of Commerce announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 -- Forty-three teams began play last night in the open team-of-four contest in the national contract bridge tournament being conducted by the American Contract Bridge League at the Bellevue Stratford Hotel.

Willard H. Campbell, vice president and director of merchandising and sales promotion of Schuneman's, Inc., St. Paul, Minn., has been appointed chairman of the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- Liquidation was on in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today with closing trades about the bottom. Wheat declined 1/2 to 1 1/2 cents, corn 3/4 to 1 1/8 cents, oats 1/8 to 1 1/2 cents, rye 1 1/4 to 2 cents and soybeans 1 1/4 to 3 cents. Lard was unchanged to 2 cents lower per 100 pounds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Formal notice that the Amtorg Trading Corporation has registered under the Foreign Agents Registration Act was issued today by the Department of Justice. A total of 214 enterprises have signed the necessary statements, the agency said.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 8 -- Six of Traicho Kostov's ten Communist fellow-accused turned against him in court today. They joined in denouncing as a traitor the former Deputy Premier and Politburo member who yesterday repudiated his confession.
Max Greenbaum, patriarch of the Brooklyn Hebrew Home and Hospital for the Aged, Howard and Dumont Avenues, Brooklyn, died there yesterday after a brief illness. His age was 106.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- United States labor leaders representing more than 14,000,000 workers gave support today to an anti-Franco resolution adopted here by the new International Confederation of Free Trade Unions.

THE year now drawing to a close, as far as books are concerned, resembled last year and the year before in the fundamental fact that the same kinds of books were as popular as usual, books of religious inspiration and self-help, shoddy and meretricious historical romances, novels which became best-sellers because of their sexual sensationalism rather than their merit.

A major upturn in the sales of large gas and diesel engines has started throughout the country, carrying with it expanded demand for added industrial equipment of auxiliary types, it was learned here yesterday.

The Long Island Sound waterfowl shooting is holding up very well and reports from both Connecticut and Rhode Island indicate that there are plenty of red-leg blackducks and broadbill on the open water and in the coastal marshes.

Fifty years ago today a brilliant, though basically simple, idea was born. This was that the people who buy goods in stores could have a say as to the conditions under which those goods were produced. By their economic and political pressure they could fight child labor, they could shorten working hours, they could protect women against exploitation, they could make the ideal of the minimum wage a living fact.

The General Assembly of the United Nations did not come to an outright vote or an outright conclusion yesterday on China's charges against the Soviet Union. The situation in respect to China and Russia is therefore held somewhat in suspense, just as the actual situation in China is in a state of suspense and change.

Very finished and authoritative conducting, and exceptionally fine tonal quality of the orchestra signalized Dimitri Mitropoulos' first appearance this season with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony last night in Carnegie Hall. Much of the effect of admirable performances was lost, however, by a long and poorly constructed program, which included a new, quite ugly and trivial piano concerto by Ernst Krenek, which Mr. Mitropoulos both played and conducted.
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Modest buying by the Government's broker slowed down the decline in British Government bonds on the Stock Exchange here today.

Jake La Motta will make his first ring appearance since winning the middleweight championship of the world last June when he opposes Robert Villemain of France in a ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. Although the Bronx battler will not be risking his title, the fight has aroused the interest of local fans, and expectations are that it will draw a crowd of 10,000 and receipts of $40,000.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Dec. 8 -- The movement for European unity must be fought "on all fronts at the same time," Paul-Henri Spaak, former Belgian Premier and co-president of the European Movement, said here today.

A tabulation of vessel casualties from mines, which has been made public by the American Merchant Marine Institute, lists ninety-three ships sunk and thirty-one damaged between Jan. 1, 1946 and last Oct. 20. These statistics have been presented to the Maritime War Emergency Board by Walter E. Maloney, assistant general counsel of the institute.
A labor dispute between the Progressive Restaurant Owners Association and Local 89 of the Chefs, Cooks and Pastry Cooks Union, AFL, threatened to close down fifty-five restaurants today.

Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer announced yesterday in Washington the appointment of an advertising advisory committee. The first meeting of the committee will be held today at the offices of the department. Considered will be problems of organization, methods of collection and dissemination of data of importance to advertising and marketing and a program for closer liaison between the advertising industry and the Department of Commerce.
PARIS, Friday, Dec. 9 (UP) -- The National Assembly's hostile votes were on minor matters and no confidence issue was involved.

Despite the claims of modern dentifrice manufacturers, there is no panacea for tooth decay and patients would do well to heed the worlds of the fifteenth-century scientist, Giovanni di Arcoli, who warned against sweet and sticky foods, 1,000 dentists were told yesterday.

Godfrey N. Nelson cannot possibly show that taxes to pay government bonds owned by OASI are taxes to pay OASI benefits, as he again argued in THE TIMES, Oct. 30. He cannot, even though he then cited a resolution adopted by the American Bar Association as supporting his stand.

The children's world of books is a wonderful world. It has a variety of enchantment: the flashing silver skates of Hans Brinker, Jack's tall beanstalk and a crocodile with a clock ticking away inside his stomach.

A historic collection of nineteenth-century American art works owned by the Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street, will be sold after Jan. 1 and the proceeds will be used to increase the museum's funds for the purchase of contemporary American art, it was announced yesterday by the museum's trustees.

BONN, Dec. 8 -- The West German Federal Republic and the United States finally have initialed an agreement for a bilateral treaty under the Economic Cooperation Administration, it was stated here today. The agreement calls for the assumption by the Bonn Government of about 700,000,000 Deutsche marks [$166,670,000] in financial obligations that grew out of a previous ECA agreement with the Military Governments.
Christmas in New York art galleries is as usual heralded by a number of large group shows that contain pictures and sculpture especially selected to interest the Christmas buyer.

Abraham Straus became a mecca for skiers yesterday when the "Ski World" shop was opened on the second floor. For the first time, ski clothes and equipment for men, women and children are gathered together in one section of the Brooklyn store.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Department store sales in the week ended Dec. 3 were 8 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like period of 1948:

PARIS, Dec. 8 -- The first notable step toward the "integration" of the European economies on a regional basis is expected to be taken here tomorrow by France, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg. The move would be in keeping with the recommendations urged by Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator.

C. C. N. Y. was too tall and talented for Southern Methodist and Nat Holman's Beavers sped to a 67-53 victory over the Mustangs before 16,531 fans at Madison Square Garden last night. In the first game Kansas State came through with a second-half spurt to upset L. I. U. 58-51, handing the Blackbirds their first setback in eight games this season.

LAKE CHARLES, La., Dec. 8 -- The $42,000,000 refinery of the Cit-Con Oil Corporation was dedicated near here today amid tributes to the engineerng skill and competitive spirit that made the plant possble. Several thousand were at the ceremonies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UP) -- The Federal Communications Commission today scheduled hearings to begin Jan. 16 on a new type of television service designed to bring into homes first-run motion pictures, stage plays and other events.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- At the current stage of the talks among United States, Canadian and British officials on the exchange of atomic energy information, there is every disposition on the part of this country to oppose manufacture of atomic weapons in the British Isles.

ALBANY, Dec. 8 -- The State Tax Commission announced today receipt from shippers of the first lists of names and addresses of New York residents who have purchased untaxed cigarettes by mail from other states.

Exhibits on a large scale of Dutch products in American department stores and advertising campaigns in the United States devoted to various branches of industry in Holland will feature the Netherlands export drive to the dollar area.

Federal insurance should be the nation's basic form of security against need in old age, Miss Jane M. Hoey, director of the Bureau of Public Assistance of the Federal Security Agency, asserted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- President Truman has offered the job of Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs to Byron Price, former director of the Office of Censorship, and now Assistant Secretary-General of the United Nations.

Three chairs and a chest, the lines and composition of which have been kept a closely guarded secret since they won awards last January in the International Competition for Low-Cost Furniture sponsored by the Museum of Modern Art, will be revealed to the public in the spring of 1950.

For shoppers with economy in mind, the most attractive offerings this week-end are pork and poultry -- broilers, fryers, roasters, fowl. Pork loin, which has been declining steadily in the last few weeks, is down to 45 cents a pound with the latest 2-cent drop, according to the weekly price survey of the City Department of Markets.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 8 -- A mere cub reporter intruded himself among veteran White House correspondents here today during a news conference. This cub, a contributor to that obscure daily, The Federal Register, was trying to look like a journalist.

On notepaper torn from a child's school pad a carefully printed letter attached to a single $1 bill was sent yesterday to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund with the plea: "Give the money to the lame girl in Case 4."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat, of Wyoming, warned today that any witness who appears before his investment subcommittee of the Joint Committee on the Economic Report and urges a balanced budget had better come prepared with a program to support his demands.

There will be a light, very open and airy look to feet tripping South if they stop first at Saks Fifth Avenue, judging by this store's current collection of charming shoes for resort wear. Styles are pared to the minimum of coverage, composed of all manner of open work in delightfully unusual fabrics and combinations.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Dec. 8 -- Members of the Long Island Golf Association gathered at their annual meeting tonight at the Garden City Hotel and named O. M. Lamberson of the North Hempstead Country Club president for the coming year.

The Central National Bank of Cleveland yesterday announced a 10 per cent common stock dividend for payment to shareholders on Dec. 30. First of its kind in the bank's sixty-year history, the dividend will increase the $20 par common shares to 330,000 from 300,000 now outstanding, according to John C. McHannna, chairman, and Loring L. Gelbach, president.

The General Assembly of the United Nations still has time to approve a solution of the Jerusalem question that is not only "just and equitable" but also realistic and workable. We regret to state that in our view the resolution adopted Wednesday by the Special Political Committee of the Assembly was unwise, unjust and impossible of execution.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Differences of opinion on the part of some executives of the Federal Reserve Board and the Treasury Department apparently were not resolved today in a private conference held in the office of Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat, of Illinois.

In your issue of Dec. 6 you published an editorial entitled "The Untouchable Bureau." In this editorial you profess mystification at the failure of efforts over the last decade to pass a law at Albany to change the system of selecting top personnel in the Bureau of Attendance of the New York City school system. You say:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Formidable Congressional efforts for heavy reductions in the amount of money to be provided next year for the European Recovery Program were forecast today by Senators returning from inspection trips to the Continent.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- During the week ended Dec. 7 member bank reserve balances increased $253,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Ohrbach's third floor, where resort wear is gathered for display in colorful array, is conducive to thoughts of holidaying in the sun. Yesterday morning, the fashion press was invited to review the merchandise as it hung temptingly on the racks before the public was admitted to the store at noon.

We shall now see whether the city, and the people of New York, are running their transit system, or whether Michael J. Quill and the Transport Workers Union are running it. For the first time in years the chips are down on this question and the city administration gives promise of being willing to stand up and fight instead of promise, compromise and temporize.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- A three-man committee of experts to advise Secretary of State Dean Acheson on one of the knottiest reorganization recommendations before the State Department -- amalgamation of high-level department personnel with the Foreign Service "career" groups -- will be named soon and will begin its study of the problem soon after the Christmas holidays.

Rising taxes, Federal deficits and costly new Federal welfare programs are drying up venture capital and threatening the continuance of the American economic system, 3,000 business leaders were told yesterday at sessions of the fifty-fourth Congress of American Industry.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 8 -- Adrian Pelt, 57-year-old United Nations Assistant Secretary-General for Conference and General Services, was nominated tonight as United Nations Commissioner for Libya. The former Italian colony Assembly last month.

GENEVA, Dec. 8 -- Twenty-nine nations signed revised Geneva conventions governing the treatment in wartime of the sick and wounded, prisoners of war and civilians in enemy territory at a ceremony here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board disclosed today that it had urged the State Department to protest Canada's action aimed at suspending Colonial Airlines' operating rights into that country.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Premier Yen said today the breach was now growing wider between Generalissimo Chiang and Acting President Li.

Recent studies indicate that babies may begin to breathe six months before they are born, speakers declared yesterday at a panel discussion during the annual meeting of the American Society of Anesthesiologists at the New Yorker Hotel.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 8 -- Frank L. Weil of New York, chairman of President Truman's Committee on Religion and Welfare in the Armed Services, declared here tonight that the existence of American voluntary social agencies was imperative to preserve the American ideal and principle.
Contrasting textures that highlight patterns and create tone-on-tone color effects have been used by Julore in creating a new group of upholstery fabrics.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 9 -Broderick Crawford was named today by Columbia to play the district attorney in "One Way Out," a remake of the 1931 Howard Hawks film. "Criminal Code," which will go before the cameras Monday, with Henry Levin directing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor, today told the annual meeting of President Truman's committee on employing the physically handicapped that five years of organized effort had brought results in job opportunities for the disabled.

"The Browning Version," starring Maurice Evans and Edna Best, which closes its engagement this evening at the Coronet Theatre, will be heard Sunday night, Dec. 18, at 8:30 on the Theatre Guild dramatic hour over the American Broadcasting Company network.

Members of a General Sessions jury that had convicted a 30-year-old former marine of second-degree murder yesterday waived their juror's pay, amounting to $180, and turned the money over to the defendant's wife, a mother of five children.
CLIFTON, N. J., Dec. 9 -- Late hours in front of home television screens are causing poor grades in classwork, an elementary school principal told pupils' parents yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UP) -Members of the House Committee on Un-American Activities said today they "undoubtedly" would call Boris Pregel, whose New York concern sold Canadian atomic materials to Russia during the war, to try and find out what United States official approved the deal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UP) -- The man who supposedly played the biggest role in settlement of the pro football war -- George Preston Marshall of the Washington Redskins -- declined tonight to take any credit for it.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 9 -Albert T. Armitage, president of the Boston investment banking company of Coffin Burr, Inc., was elected and installed president of the Investment Bankers Association of America here today at the association's final convention session in the Hollywood Beach Hotel.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Bob Hamilton, Landover, Md., holed a spectacular 33-foot uphill putt on the eighteenth green today for a five-under-par 65 and a 36-hole total of 129 to lead the second round of Miami's $10,000 open golf tournament.
Pastel stars, plucked from a sky in fairyland, twinkled last night on the silver Christmas tree in Rockefeller Center.

"Is the human brain obsolete?" we asked our physicist friend the other day. "Every time we pick up the paper it seems we read about a new thinking machine or mechanical brain capable of wondrous feats of cerebration.
TRENTON, N. J., Dec. 9 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll prepared today to call a special election to fill the seat of Representative J. Parnell Thomas.

Secretary of Defense Johnson asserts that this country is now better prepared to defend itself than at any time since we laid down our arms in 1945, and that this result has been achieved despite a cut in defense expenditures which more than makes up for armament aid to our European allies.

ROME, Ga., Dec. 9 (UP) -- The Dade County Sheriff, John W. Lynch, swore today that he reached for his gun to stop Ku Klux Klan seizure of two Negro prisoners. But, he observed, he was too slow on the draw.
Back from foreign waters came the heavy cruiser Columbus yesterday morning with strange tales of ticklish protocol.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Dec. 9 -- The Board of Missions and Church Extension of the Methodist Church called on Congress today to earmark this country's food surpluses for impoverished areas in foreign lands.

The stock market encountered yesterday moderate resistance to any further extension of prices and the list slipped slightly. The pattern of close price movement which had prevailed through the week did not change, while the composite rate showed a loss of 0.16 point, although this did not reflect some major alterations in a large number of issues.

Sales of women's coats, which lagged badly at the wholesale level last month, has been enjoying a minor boom with the advent of continued cold weather, it was pointed out yesterday by New York manufacturers. Producers in the medium-price range are much encouraged with the activity, they said, and hope to reduce by a wide margin the net loss in units that appeared in prospect for 1949.

HONG KONG, Dec. 9 -- Two leading British shipping companies of the China coast today bowed to the Nationalist blockade of Shanghai. A high executive of one of the companies announced that its efforts to run vessels through the Nationalist naval patrols off Shanghai and all other ports south of there would be ended for the time being.

Terming television a "potential threat to the financial structure of intercollegiate athletics," the Eastern College Athletic Conference yesterday announced that it would urge the National Collegiate Athletic Association to "take prompt and definite action on this important matter."
The final novelty of the New York City Ballet Company's season at the City Center was William Dollar's "Ondine," which had its world premiere last night. It was, unhappily, not a success.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 9 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of the West German Republic demanded today that West German manpower be included in a European striking force against Russia. He said that the Western Allies must not ignore German security needs in their current military planning.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- Ending a five-day visit here as guests of Bronxville High School, and its pupils, thirty-three seniors of Oak Ridge (Tenn.) High School started home by bus this afternoon. In March an equivalent number of Bronxville pupils will visit Oak Ridge.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Dr. Vannevar Bush, president of the Carnegie Institution, said today in his annual report that a thirty-year search for rare stars, characterized by bright hydrogen lines, has been completed in the last year.

ALBANY, Dec. 9 -- Governor Dewey telegraphed the State Department in Washington today a request that representations be made to the Canadian Government urging withdrawal of proceedings leading to suspension of the authority of Colonial Airlines, Inc., to operate in Canada.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Discovery of the origin of the most disabling form of epilepsy, and a brain surgery technique to treat it, was reported today to the American Medical Association by Dr. Arthur A. Morris of Washington. He said that to his knowledge it was the first surgical technique for attacking a form of the disease usually resistant to certain drugs that had proved highly effective against other forms of the malady.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Representative W. Sterling Cole, Republican, of New York, urged his colleagues of the House Armed Services Committee today not to acquiesce supinely in the ouster of Admiral Louis E. Denfeld as Chief of Naval Operations.
As the result of increasing crime in the city's subways, the Board of Transportation began yesterday a sweeping revision of its methods of policing the transit system.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 9 -- The new International Confederation of Free Trade Unions was denounced here today as "a strike-breaking" instrument forged by "imperialist agents" to destroy the unity of the international workers' movement.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 9 -The new underwriting technique for hedging stand-by offerings or public utility common stock has grown to be a "Frankenstein monster," threatening, at odds of 25 to 1, to inflict six-figure losses on bankers overnight, the Investment Bankers Association was warned today.

Lieut. Gen. Leslie R. Groves, retired, who served as wartime head of the atomic bomb project, told business leaders yesterday that the American people will not be satisfied with a "whitewash" of recent charges that atomic secrets leaked to Russia.
Five hundred boys and girls rioted yesterday afternoon in the auditorium of their Brooklyn public school when a movie show they had paid 10 cents admission for was halted because of a stolen reel.
ROME, Dec. 9 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi estimated at a press conference today that to make 3,750,000 acres of land available to Italian peasants would cost from $1,250,000 to $1,500,000.

The largest single contribution received by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund since the thirty-eighth annual Christmas appeal opened a week ago was sent in yesterday by Mr. and Mrs. Alfred P. Sloan Jr., who donated $10,000.
LONDON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Oscar R. Ewing was asked at his news conference today whether the American health plan, like that in Britain, would supply wigs, spectacles and false teeth.

Directors of the Container Corporation of America ordered yesterday the payment of an extra dividend of $1 on the common stock, payable on Dec. 27. This raises the 1949 declarations to $4 a share, as quarterly payments were 75 cents. Total payments last year were $4.50.
Three current New York art exhibitions, two of paintings and one of sculpture, deserve special notice among the new attractions.

ALBANY, Dec. 9 -- Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Health Commissioner, said today that the 1949 polio epidemic, fourth worst in the state's history, is "essentially over" and that the number of new cases occurring each week "now approaches the usual expectancy for this time of year."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 9 -The ten Russian emigres accused of wartime collaboration with the Germans and post-war collaboration with the Soviet intelligence service were sentenced today by a district people's court at Sarajevo to terms at hard labor ranging from three to twenty years.

Joseph Barone presented two young American artists in debut with his New York Little Symphony at Times Hall yesterday evening, Gabriel Banat, a 23-year-old violinist of European background who performed Mendelssohn's Violin Concerto, and Gladys Stein, a young pupil of Clarence Adler, who was heard in Beethoven's Fourth Piano Concerto.

BERLIN, Dec. 9 -- A fourteen-hour blockade of the quarters of a Yugoslav trade mission in the Pankow area, in the Soviet sector, by "people's police" of the East German Democratic Republic was lifted shortly before 2 o'clock this afternoon.
"HOUSE IN THE SUN,"* by a mysterious Englishman who calls himself Dane Chandos, is a cheerful book that is almost as good as a passage to Mexico. It seems to be a sequel to "Village in the Sun."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Former Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers will have to stay in jail at least for another year. The District Parole Board today turned down his plea for release after serving the minimum amount of his twenty-months-to-five-years sentence No reason was given but the board said Meyers could ask for parole again after Nov. 1, 1950.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 9 -- Commercial marine radar has been installed on a municipal pier here, making this city the world's third major port with radar harbor control. The others are Liverpool, England.
If it was retributive justice Robert Villemain, the gallant son of France, sought, he got it in full measure last night in Madison Square Garden.

W. J. Kinloch Anderson is head of William Anderson Sons, tailors and kiltmakers to King George VI. Forty-two years old, medium-sized, with straight dark hair and a neat mustache, he is a polite and patient man with precise convictions abut the nomenclature of the kilt.

Many local appliance dealers yesterday prepared to ask customers to wait indefinitely for delivery of Christmas orders if a strike of trucking employes occurs on Monday as tentatively scheduled. The threatened strike would completely paralyze consumer deliveries of refrigerators and other white goods for stores using outside trucking organizations.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Increasing optimism on the business outlook in November was reflected in the increasing number of companies adopting a ninety - day buying policy, the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago said today. Association spokesmen explained adoption of a ninety-day buying policy indicates belief that business will remain sufficiently stable to justify carrying a ninety-day inventory of goods and supplies.

NOTRE DAME, Ind., Dec. 9 -- The development of English common law and American constitutional law as expressions of "natural law" was traced here today by two speakers at the Third Natural Law Institute, presented by the College of Law of the University of Notre Dame.
Reports coming in from several Catskill and Adirondack areas indicate that this is proving to be quite a season for varying hares, with some combining this hunting with ice fishing.

At a special meeting here yesterday, stockholders of the North American Rayon Corporation approved a stock reclassification plan under which Beaunit Mills, Inc., becomes the owner of more than 99 per cent of North American's common stock.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 9 -- A closer working relationship between national agencies, including the United Jewish Appeal, and American Jewish communities in the raising of funds for all Jewish causes, was a major recommendation put before 500 Jewish community leaders today as the Council for Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds opened its eighteenth annual assembly.

Congress should be well informed on the state of Europe when it reconvenes in January. All summer and fall European Governments and American embassies abroad have been kept busy showing visiting Senators and Representatives around and answering their more or less pointed questions about "conditions."

The rate at which oxygen is used up in the human brain is a direct indication of the alertness of any individual, it was reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Society of Anesthesiologists at the New Yorker Hotel.

The annual two-day Brooklyn winter horse show began last night with more than 700 entries and in a new location, spacious Squadron C armory. Since 1937, excepting the war years, it had been at Teevan's Riding Academy on Caton Place, but it had outgrown that arena and a change was in order, said Edwin R. Teevan.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 -Harry R. Bridges not only was present but presided at a Communist party "fraction meeting" in May, 1936, a Federal court jury was told today at the perjury and conspiracy trial of the West Coast longshore leader.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Saturday, Dec. 10 -- About 5,000,000 Australians went to the polls compulsorily today to choose a Commonwealth Government for the next three years. In the fifty years of the Australian federation no election has evoked deeper interest.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 9 -- The Western Allies have rejected the manner in which Chancellor Konrad Adenauer had requested membership of the Western German Government in the International Ruhr Authority, it was learned tonight.

In its first change of ownership in forty years, the five-story store and apartment building on lot 25 by 82 feet at 206 West End Avenue, near West Sixty-ninth Street, was sold by the estate of Hattie Cohen to the Rejen Realty Corporation in a deal negotiated by Dwight-Helmsley, Inc., brokers. It is assessed for $29,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Russia apparently is trying to get her propaganda magazines into American schools. This became obvious today following reports that the attempt had been blocked in more cities.

Bill Robinson, beloved entertainer and friend to countless underprivileged and handicapped people, was devoted to the work of the New York Association for the Blind.
