He was a frequent visitor to the Lighthouse, bringing cheer and good-will to many hundreds of sightless men and women of all ages, races and creeds.
The United Nations General Assembly adopted a resolution last night reaffirming its decision of two years ago that the Jerusalem area should be administered by the Trusteeship Council.

Coffee futures were easy after early steadiness on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. In early dealings prices advanced slightly on trade hedge-lifting and scattered commission house buying. Demand, however, was not sufficient to maintain these levels and prices gradually slipped off on general selling with support temporarily absent.

ALBANY, Dec. 9 -- Governor Dewey told 400 delegates to the fourteenth annual Hi-Y Assembly today that the American system of free enterprise could give its people all and more than the dictators promised, without destroying personal liberty.

The B.V.D. Corporation, fabric and men's clothing manufacturer, reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended Aug. 31 a net income of $1,272,214 after transferring to net income a contingency reserve of $655,000 and crediting a tax refund of $21,234.

Operators of forty - two auto laundries in the metropolitan area yesterday defied the city's ban on car washing and said they would continue operating despite the water shortage and in the face of warnings that their water would be cut off.

SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia, Dec. 9 (UP) -- It was the first time since the war that Soviet citizens had been tried, convicted and sentenced outside their own country. The defendants all immediately appealed.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 9 -- Over British objections, the United Nations Trusteeship Council decided today to consult representatives of political parties and other local groups in former Italian Somaliland as it began drafting a ten- year accord with Italy for placing the colony under international supervision.

Sales of pastel colored shirts, in comparison with last spring, have decreased in 64 per cent of forty stores surveyed, are unchanged in 21 per cent, and have increased in 15 per cent. These forty stores comprise the style committee group of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers.

The St. John's University five, unbeaten in six tests, will endeavor to maintain its fast pace tonight when it encounters Rhode Island State in the second game of a collegiate twin bill at Madison Square Garden. In the opener, faltering N. Y. U. will tackle Rutgers.

SAN JUAN. P. R., Dec. 9 -- Puerto Rico began today a weeklong celebration of its drive to emerge from a one-crop economy with the hope of becoming a self-sufficient industrial and agricultural area. The event was marked by the formal opening of the $6,000,000 Caribe Hilton Hotel on San Geronimo Point.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 9 -- The little mountain village of Capracotta, high up in the Appenine Range in Central Italy, was assured tonight of receiving a $20,000 snowplow to keep it from being isolated by winter storms.

The fourth regular session of the United Nations, now drawing to a close, made solid contributions toward the maintenance of world peace and the improvement of living standards, Ambassador Carlos P. Romulo of the Philippines, its president, declared last night.

Leon and Anna Marziano bought the three-story six-family apartment house at 452 Sixty-eighth Street. Brooklyn, from Lucia Nelli The Colonial Realty Company was the broker. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Reversing the trend of the last few days, British Government securities rallied strongly on the Stock Exchange here today. As buying expanded and selling eased on the feeling that the recent fall had been overdone, gilt-edged issues made a general recovery of as much as 1/2 point.
LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Labor won another by-election victory yesterday in South Bradford. The Socialist candidate won by a plurality of 4,022.

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony Young People's Concert, Leopold Stokowski, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 11 o'clock; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Leonard Bernstein, conductor; Yvonne Loriod, piano; Ginette Martenot, Ondes Martenot, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; "Manon Lescaut" at 2 and "Samson et Dalila" at 8:30, Metropolitan Opera.

BILOXI, Miss., Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Southeastern Conference reopened the gates to football bowls today and declined to increase its membership to 13 colleges. In effect, this barred the University of Miami from membership.

PARIS, Dec. 9 -- In agreeing here today on slightly closer economic relations among their countries, financial representatives of France, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg decided that Britain should be invited to join in the agreement.

As the baseball clans came trooping into New York yesterday from the Baltimore minor league convention, with hopes for a break in the trading mart's current stalemate, interest was centered upon developments in the forthcoming major league conclave.

Retail sales here remained below figures established last year, according to estimates made yesterday by trade observers. Department store sales were estimated to be about 6 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were 7 per cent below last year.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Denver, host city for the national Amateur Athletic Union championship basketball tournament for fourteen years prior to last season, will be the scene of the event March 19-25.

The blockfront parcel on the east side of Yellowstone Boulevard between Sixty-eighth Drive and Sixty-ninth Avenue in Forest Hills, Queens, containing 42,000 square feet, has been purchased by Martin Fisher Brothers from the Cord Meyer Development Company.
Stewards of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association in session at the Hotel Biltmore last night voted to inspect the site at Marietta, Ohio, proposed scene of the 1950 championship regatta.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Dec. 9 -- On the northern flank of East Mountain, seven miles from this town on the road to Brattleboro, stands Snow Valley, which has earned a large following since the Rath brothers, Dolf and Walter, and Florence Linden (now Mrs. Dolf Rath) brought the skiland into existence in 1942.

Business is confident about 1950 prospects, according to the results of a poll of 30,000 member companies made by the Research Institute of America, 292 Madison Avenue, and announced yesterday by Leo M. Cherne, executive secretary.

The American Civil Liberties Union has held an inquest on the disturbances which accompanied two attempts last summer, the later one successful, to hold a Paul Robeson concert at Lakeland Acres near Peekskill. It lays the blame where it thinks it belongs. More important in the long run, perhaps, are the recommendations which the Union makes in the hope of preventing future disturbances of the same sort and of preserving the basic liberties.

Exports from the United States dropped almost $56,000,000 in October compared with the value of merchandise shipped in the previous month, while imports showed a $28,700,000 gain in October over September, according to a report issued by the Census Bureau of the Department of Commerce.

The likelihood of all immediate slowdown on the city's subway system lessened yesterday when Mayor O'Dwyer recommended an open meeting between the Board of Transportation and the Transport Workers Union, CIO.

West Forty-second Street, once the hub of the legitimate theatre before the films and "hot dog" stands took over, may have "live" entertainment again. Plans are under way for the establishment of a policy of combined stage and film presentations at the Selwyn Theatre, 229 West Forty-second Street, formerly one of the more popular legitimate showcases.
Delicacy shops, with their imposing displays of food packages, offer ready-made solutions to the problem of what to give for Christmas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur today bespoke voluntary United States aid to the new democratic education of Japan in a message to the National Defense Conference on the Occupied Countries.

Christmas trees this year will be as gay and sparkling as ever, to judge by the assortment of trimmings and ornaments bedecking store counters, many of which indicate a return to the traditional old favorites missing for many years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The evil redskin has bitten the dust once too often in the movies, the Association on American Indian Affairs said today. It has organized a national film committee to see that American Indians get "serious new cinematic treatment."

The price-support activities of the Federal Government with respect to farm products is proving so costly that the $4,750,000,000 borrowing authority of the Commodity Credit Corporation, the agency designated for carrying out the program, soon may be exhausted.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -A jigsaw puzzle is confronting state and Westchester County engineers who are seeking new exits to the north for New York pleasure cars and trucks, but indications here today are that a soltuion will soon be found.

MANILA, Dec. 9 -- The Philippine Government resorted today to outright control of foreign exchange to halt the flight of dollars to the United States, which during the last several weeks has assumed alarming velocity.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 9 -- Four Rumanian passengers of a Soviet Rumanian Airline transport plane forced the pilot and crew at pistol point to fly the plane off its course today and land it at Zemun airport in Belgrade.
GENEVA, Dec. 1 -- In its second year, the title "European Recovery Program" has become more or less obsolete as applied to the Marshall Plan.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Professional football's four-year war was settled across a conference table today. The All-America Conference merged into the National Football League.

Decision was reserved yesterday by Judge Harold M. Kennedy in Federal Court, Brooklyn, on a motion by the trustees of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road to enjoin Nassau County officials from offering for public sale tax liens on the railroad's property.

MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 9 -- The first-degree murder trial of Dewitt Combs, 22-year-old. Marine Corps veteran of Wantagh charged with the shotgun killing of his sweetheart's father, got under way in Nassau County Court here today with the medical witnesses of the prosecution taking the stand.

The cleavage between the Soviet bloc and the rest of the world in the United Nations was illustrated sharply again in the vote of felicitation that welcomed the peaceful settlement of the Indonesian question. While most of the United Nations assembled expressed their satisfaction that an agreement had been reached, there was the usual negative vote from the Soviet bloc.

More than forty officers and directors of the National Office Furniture Association, trade association of office furniture dealers, met at the Commodore Hotel yesterday, with regional chapters throughout the country represented. Moe Turman, president of NOFA, and vice president, Metwood Office Equipment Corporation, 64 West Twenty-third Street, presided.

Charges that labor monopolies and Federal intervention in labor disputes were undermining free collective bargaining were made yesterday before the National Association of Manufacturers as it ended its fifty-fourth annual Congress of American Industry at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 9 -- Federal District Judge Owen M. Burns today granted the Securities and Exchange Commission permission to investigate alleged manipulations n stock of the Pittsburgh Terminal Realization Corporation.

Three books are being published today. New Directions is issuing at $1.50 Albert Cossery's "The House of Certain Death," a novel set in the slums of an Egyptian city. It has been translated from the French by Stuart B. Kaiser. Bellman Publishing Company of Boston is issuing "Scholarships, Fellowships and Loans," by S. Norman Feingold, a directory of student aids, for $6.

A sharp break between rival factions in the liquor industry became evident here earlier this week when the Veterans Affiliated Package Stores Association announced plans for introduction of a bill on mandatory fair trade at the next session of the State legislature in January.

One of the finest paintings by the Venetian master, Jacopo Tintoretto, a canvas of the late Fifteen-Fifties, entitled "Lucretia and Tarquinius," has been purchased by the Art Institute of Chicago, it was learned here yesterday.
HONG KONG, Dec. 9 -- Last-minute efforts by Nationalist leaders to keep Yunnan Province in the anti-Communist front appeared today to have slowed the trend there toward defection.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 9 -- A great disparity of opinion regarding the ultimate absorption of radioactive rays by a human being makes it "highly desirable to obtain some dependable data," Dr. Robert R. Newell of San Francisco told the closing session of the conference of the Radiological Society of North America today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 -- A team composed of Alvin Landy, Elmer Schwartz and Arthur Goldsmith of Cleveland; Jeff Glick, formerly of Cleveland but now of Miami, Fla., and Sol Mogal of New York led forty-three contract bridge teams into the third and final round of the national championship team-of-four contest in the American Contract Bridge League's twenty-third annual tournament here today.

A head mentor - for only three years, Charles (Bud) Wilkinson, whose Oklahoma University football team was one of the nation's four major undefeated college elevens this past season, has been named "1949 Coach of the Year," it was announced yesterday.

Newspaper advertising by passenger car makers during October in 106 markets cost $3,477,190 compared with $1,773,817 in the same markets in October, 1948, or an increase of 96.3 per cent, it was reported yesterday by Media Records.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy should be in possession of all vital information on this country's atomic weapons, including the size of the bomb stockpile, the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists said today.

William Burston has been appointed a merchandise manager at Nature's, Brooklyn, to supervise toiletries, stationery, notions, liqors, silverware, luggage and restaurants, in addition to several leased departments. He was formerly vice president of Frozen Food Products.

A 40 per cent cut in traveling time on the avenues and major crosstown streets of Manhattan was promised yesterday by the Traffic Commission when it adopted an ingenious new traffic signal plan devised by the Department of Traffic Engineering after months of study.
J. M. Grimes, treasurer of the State of Iowa, announced yesterday that he would receive bids on an issue of $8,750,000 of Service Compensation bonds on Jan. 5.
The New York State Maritime College, the oldest maritime institution of its kind in the country, will celebrate its seventy-fifth anniversary next week.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- A manifesto condemning all forms of totalitarian government and exalting human dignity and freedom was adopted today by the final session of the first congress of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions formed in London in recent days.

Fifty-five restaurants, chiefly kosher and dairy establishments, refused to open for business yesterday in a dispute with Local 89, Chefs, Cooks, Pastry Cooks and Assistants, AFL. Later in the day, however, the union announced it had signed contracts with eleven of the restaurants and that they had reopened.
The construction dollar volume has reached a new high this year in the area east of the Rocky Mountains, it was reported yesterday by the F. W. Dodge Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Washington Evening Star reported today that the Federal Housing Administration "evidently intends to prevent all discriminatory practices by those receiving its assistance."

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Possibility of the Western Conference relaxing its recruiting code to permit direct contact with prospective prep athletes is being thrashed out behind closed doors at the annual winter meeting.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The inside of the stomach of a living patient, as seen by the gastroscope, was projected here for the first time on a television screen and viewed by an interested audience of physicians at the closing sessions of the Interim Meeting of the American Medical Association.

Manhattan College's quintet, seeking to gain some of the prestige it lost when it bowed to Siena College last Saturday, used its superior height to full advantage at the Second Corps Artillery Armory in Brooklyn last night to register a 71-to-57 triumph over St. Francis College.

In recent months there has been a good deal of agitation for repeal of the wartime excise taxes. Nearly all existing excise taxes were enacted originally in time of war, including even those on liquor and tobacco, which go back to 1862. These taxes were expanded or increased three times in the Second World War emergency -- in 1941, 1942 and 1944.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 9 -- Testimony that as early as 1942 Premier Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia was pursuing a pro-Western anti-Soviet line was offered today in the Sofia treason trial. Some of the testimony of alleged hostility to the Soviet Union on the part of the guerrilla leader in Yugoslavia during the war came from Blagoi Ivanov Hadjipansov, one of the last four former Communist leaders, defendants in the trial, to take the stand.
BOSTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau tonight issued this report of New England winter sports conditions:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UP) -The Governmental committee recently set up at the request of President Truman to work with industry for voluntary curtailment of monopolies held its first meeting today.

"You may quote me any way you please about the merger of these football leagues," said owner Ted Collins of the National League's New York Bulldogs, who obviously was in a jovial mood about his purchase of the New York Yankees.
TOKYO, Dec. 9 -- The Japanese Government is falling behind in the vital collections of foodstuffs from farmers for distribution next year as an officially priced ration in hungry cities.

Mayor O'Dwyer confirmed yesterday the report that he would appoint Deputy Mayor John J. Bennett as Chief Justice of the Court of Special Sessions to succeed George B. De Luca, District Attorney-elect of Bronx County. The annual salary of the judicial post was increased from $16,000 to $18,000 by the Board of Estimate on Thursday.

Evening hours this season have witnessed the rise of a new fashion, charming little veiling headpieces that complement the cocktail and short dinner gown with a beguiling chic. Many are fashioned in little caps with the flash of rhinestones ensnared in their mesh, saucy little veils tipping the nose and shadowing the eyes.
HAMILTON, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- A smooth-working Columbia University basketball team successfully began its invasion of Central New York State tonight with a 64-47 victory over Colgate before 1,500 fans.

Shortages of steel in Great Britain are holding back fulfillment of the largest power equipment program ever planned in that country's history, it was pointed out yesterday by members of the United Kingdom productivity team of the electrical supply industry.

Clergymen of the Jewish, Roman Catholic and Protestant faiths will begin discussions at 2:30 P. M. Tuesday at the Woodrow Wilson Foundation, 45 East Sixty-fifth Street, in the eleventh exploratory session of the Religious and Welfare Committee of the New York Committee on Atomic Information.

Decision of the State Department granting Morocco an extension to Dec. 31 of that country's curbs on trade was attacked here yesterday by the group of American traders, represented by Robert E. Rodes, commander of the American Legion Morocco Post, most of whose members depend on Moroccan trade.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 9 -- Frank Pace, the Budget Director, discussed "important phases of the budget" with President Truman today and later told reporters that he saw no probability of balancing the 1951 fiscal year budget without additional taxes.

Getting a youngster into nightclothes before his supper and following the meal with a little quiet play and story-telling will help to get him into bed with a minimum of fuss, according to "The Baby Sitter," an educational film for girls previewed yesterday at Finch College, 52 East Seventy-eighth Street.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 9 (AP) -- J. Pelierra's Mi Preferido, the "Citation" of Cuba, today redeemed himself for his recent setback when he whirled to the front at the break and had things his own way, winning by two and a half lengths over Arilou at Tropical Park.

Federal funds totaling $240,000 will be made available to the Board of Education for the planning of four new public school projects in Brooklyn and Queens, it was announced yesterday by Charles J. Bensley, chairman of the board's committee on buildings and sites.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday, and final prices were irregular, 5 points higher to 13 points lower, with new-crop months showing relatively the greatest weakness.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Oscar R. Ewing, the United States Federal Security Administrator, declared today that most of the critics of the health insurance program proposed for the United States had "tried to mislead the American people" on facts about the British National Health Service.

MONTREAL, Dec. 9 (AP) -- A general meeting of members of the Labrador Mining and Exploration Company today unanimously approved a proposal aimed at an extensive iron-range development in the frozen wastes of Labrador and Ungava.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Dec. 9 -- Mrs. Eugenie Anderson sailed today on the East Asiatic Company's motorship Jutlandia for Copenhagen, where she will take up her duties as first United States woman Ambassador to Denmark. With Mrs. Anderson were her husband, John, a Red Wing (Minn.) artist and farmer, and their two children, Johanna, 15 years old, and Hans, 11.

Hints that the power of subpoena might be used to compel a witness to back up a statement of widespread fraud in the administration of unemployment insurance benefits were made yesterday as the Joint Legislative Committee conducted a hearing here on proposals to change the unemployment insurance laws.
BAY CITY, Mich., Dec. 9 (AP) -- The lake freighter George F. Rand stuck in a mudbank in a Saginaw Bay shipping channel, defied Coast Guard efforts to pull her free today.

The letter of the Board of Transportation, reported in THE TIMES of Dec. 8, warning the Transport Workers against a slowdown may provoke the very situation it attempts to prevent. The board appeals vigorously to the fact that the riding public are the employers of the transit workers, and seems to take it for granted that this settles the matter.

Lauritz Melchior, playing the role of Santa Claus as if he might relish it even more than Siegfried, squeezed himself through a plywood chimney yesterday at the Hospital for Special Surgery for the holiday pleasure of forty young patients, many of them wheelchair and stretcher cases.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- William M. Boyle Jr., Democratic national chairman, charged today that the American Medical Association had set up the machinery for "punitive action against any of its members who refuse to go along with its fight against the President's national health insurance proposal."

The outlook in the automobile industry is good for next year and no increases in car prices are anticipated, A. H. Belfie, assistant general sales manager, Buick motor division, General Motors Corporation, predicted yesterday.

Administration of sickness and death benefit funds of the Fur Dressers Union, Local 2, CIO, and the Fur Floor Workers Union, Local 3, CIO, will revert exclusively to the International Fur and Leather Workers Union, CIO, under a decision handed down yesterday by Federal Judge Irving R Kaufman.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Navy moved today to strengthen its Pacific Fleet. It ordered the transfer of one heavy cruiser from the Atlantic and assigned to the area an anti-aircraft cruiser that was to have been laid up.

The five-story store and apartment building at 2636 University Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company to Alvina Kogin. The property, on an irregular plot about 150 by 77 feet at the southeast corner of West Kingsbridge Road, is assessed at $120,000.
Authorization for installing water meters in New York's estimated 150,000 multiple dwellings will be sought by the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity soon after Jan. 1.
ALBANY, N. Y., Dec. 9 (AP) -- The State Commerce Department today listed good skiing at many New York sports centers.
Over vigorous defense objections Mrs. Hede Massing swore yesterday that Alger Hiss was a member of a Communist underground apparatus in Washington in 1935.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Grains made an easy start and a strong finish on the Board of Trade here today, advancing rapidly in the last few minutes of trading on general short-covering following moderate purchases by commission houses. Final sales were at about the top, with wheat up 5/6 to 1 1/4 cents a bushel, the July delivery leading.
OLDWICK, N. J., Dec. 9 -- The magic shop here in a rural section of Hunterdon County, is doing a thriving business in a 1773 colonial house which offers homemade merchandise as the chief attraction.

"A Winter's Eve Dinner Dance," the annual benefit of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association, was given last night in Sherry's. Among the features of the dance was a showing of ballroom gowns modeled by members of the debutante and junior committees and the auction of a cultured pearl necklace, a dinner hat of Indian gold and blue brocade and a case of champagne, all donated by well-known firms in this city.
John L. Lewis' financial demands on the anthracite coal industry were made public officially yesterday for the first time since expiration of industry-wide contracts last July 1.

An election of world-wide interest is to be held in Australia today. In these days when the pros and cons of socialism, the welfare state, nationalization of industry and free enterprise are issues of paramount importance in most countries, the results in Australia should provide one more straw to show which way the wind is now blowing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.3 per cent in the week ended Dec. 6, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 151 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.3 per cent lower than four weeks ago and 7.4 per cent below the comparable week in 1946.

The United Nations "has fallen victim to incredible light-mindedness," Moshe Sharett, Israeli Foreign Minister, said last night in commenting on the decision of the United Nations General Assembly to establish an international Jerusalem enclave in Palestine.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Representative J. Parnell Thomas, Republican, of New Jersey, was sentenced in Federal District Court here today to six to eighteen months in prison and to pay a fine of $10,000 for padding his Congressional payrolls.

YONKERS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- Twelve hundred irate taxpayers of this city gave a collective and vociferous heave-to early today to a proposal that Yonkers' swollen budget be balanced by the imposition of five new excise taxes.

SINGAPORE, Saturday, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Duncan George Stewart, 45, British Governor of Sarawak, died here today from stab wounds inflicted by a Malay youth last Saturday at Sibu, Sarawak, the Singapore General Hospital announced.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The present small amount of capitalraised through stock financing is more attributable to stock market conditions and management decisions than to a lack of equity capital, Robert B. Patrick, financial vice president of the Bankers Life Company, Des Moines, said today.

This letter is in response to your editorial of Nov. 21 calling for tuition fees in the city colleges. As a student of City College, I believe I am in a favorable position to question the opinions expressed.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 9 (UP) -- The official Communist newspaper Rude Pravo, confirming predictions of a December purge, announced today that 49-year-old Vilem Novy had been ousted as its editor in chief. Vladimir Koucky has replaced him.
Children of the Department of Parks playground at Seventy-fourth Street and the Hudson River chuckled with delight yesterday at an invitation to visit Japan as guests of the children of Gifu City.
I Wish to comment on your recent editorial on currencies and morals, which only adds to the present confusion on the question of money and gold.

VIENNA, Dec. 9 -- The Soviet Deputy Commissioner, Lieut. Gen. Alexei Zheltov, charged at today's Allied Council that there had been a resurgence of neo-nazism in Austria in defiance of Article 5 of the draft Austrian state treaty.

A proposal to consolidate all of this state's courts, except those for appeals, into a single court, with uniform pay for all judges, stirred controversy yesterday at a hearing on ways of breaking the backlog of cases in local courts, some of which are nearly three years in arrears.
Delegates to the United Nations General Assembly hope to wind up their work today and call an end to a session that has lasted twelve weeks and discussed almost all the world's political problems.

"WILL it be out before Christmas?" is the question being asked by those who are impatiently awaiting the appearance of the newest in flower and gardening books. This season, publishers offer a variety of subjects aimed to appeal to diversified interests.

Those who plan a Southern fishing trip prior to Jan. 15 should be able to work in some interesting shooting as well as good fresh and salt water fishing, for the latest reports indicate that the big wind did no noticeable harm to the quail situation.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 10 -- With Ohio River barge-line traffic nearing 50 million tons a year, river men here are working hard to get channel and port facilities developed for another decade of industrial growth.

THE time is at hand for parents to start thinking about that annual Yuletide headache -- what to do to entertain the youngsters. According to available data, five distinct programs, designed especially for the small fry, are being offered by the impresarios of the juvenile circuit within the metropolitan area.

The twelve members of the New York Wind Ensemble rounded up two dozen of their musical colleagues and late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall presented concert versions of two chamber operas. The first was Monteverdi's "Orfeo," which dates from 1607, and the other was Stravinsky's "Mavra" of 1922.
HAMILTON, N.Y., Dec. 10 (AP) -- College professors from throughout the state were told today they must organize to improve their economic status.

ON the evening of Sept. 21, 1945, when I last talked with Bela Bartok, he was lying in bed, quite ill. Nevertheless, on and around his bed were sheets of score and sketch manuscript papers. He was working feverishly to complete the scoring of the last few bars of his Third Piano Concerto.

HARTFORD, Conn. -- For years, the State of Connecticut has had little to offer the winter visitor. It watched, rather sadly, as the winter tourists trekked through the state en route to the established resort areas further north.

WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 10 -- Holy Cross had little trouble in defeating Fordham tonight, 75 to 48. A capacity crowd of 2,800 watched the Crusaders outmaneuver the Ram quintet all the way; their smooth ball handling and floor speed were brilliant.
Prof. Louis M. Hacker, director of Columbia University's School of General Studies, has lots of reading to do this week because he dared ask his students for advice on how to run the school.

An argument is being asserted in defense of spending social security tax money for general governmental purposes that it cannot be shown that tax receipts used "to pay Government bonds owned by OASI (Old Age and Survivors Insurance) are taxes to pay OASI benefits."
Fifth Avenue may have its holiday windows, but cobblestoned West Street has more Christmas trees.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, said tonight that Canada's move to revoke the license of Colonial Airlines "had done more to hurt good relations between our two countries than anything that has happened in a century."

The Soviet Union has achieved much more widespread dispersion of its industrial production than before the war by pushing the development of the areas east of Moscow more rapidly than originally contemplated in the fourth Five Year Plan, according to an analysis of recently published data.

AT a quaint Greenwich Village restaurant in Macdougal Alley fifty-odd novice playwrights aiming for Broadway production convene one night a week to put their unproduced manuscripts through what they term the "acid test."
IN one of New York's bridge clubs a losing player went to the club's principal expert and asked: "What should I do to improve my game"? The expert answered him in two words: "Stop overcalling."
PARIS, Dec. 10 -- Alarmed by the arrival of Chinese Communist troops at the frontier of Indo-China, the French have taken two steps designed to save that country from invasion.
CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- An advance notice of the thirty-first annual meeting of the American Farm Bureau Federation, which opens here Monday, promises "a full airing of national farm policy."

When they were first introduced, the antibiotics -- of which penicillin and streptomycin are best known to the public -- were supposed to be effective only in some cases of bacterial infection. Gradually their field of usefulness was extended. With aureomycin it was possible to treat even some virus infections.

THE Norwegian America liner Oslofjord, a 16,500-gross ton, yacht-like motorship, made her debut in the North Atlantic travel trade last week with a triumphant arrival in New York that was a tribute not only to the originality and skill of her Norwegian designers and Dutch builders but also to the tenacity and courage of the nation she represents.

MR. GALBRAITH in his review of Ludwig von Mises' "Human Action" (Book Review, Oct. 30), published by the Yale University Press, objects to the publisher's statement on the jacket that "Professor von Mises' approach bears little relation to what is usually taught in classrooms or to the hopeful, revolutionary but bankrupt 'economics' that conquered the Western World in the last decades."

FRONTIER Oregon was a pretty staid sort of a place. When a big argument got worked up in 1852 over whether a lady should lift her dress to cross a puddle, most folks said the whole thing was academic because no real lady would be seen on the streets in muddy weather, anyway.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- An anonymous government bureau one of the 1,812 sections of the Executive Branch, was praised by the Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report today for its successful voluntary efforts to achieve economy and efficiency.

The question of the strength of the British Labor party becomes increasingly insistent as Britain approaches its national elections to be held early next year. Last week two elections took place which political observers scrutinized carefully for indications of what the election outcome in Britain may be.

The Columbia swimming team opened its season by defeating Fordham in the Lions' pool yesterday, 42 to 32. Sophomore Fred Orrik starred for the winners, taking first place in the 220-yard free-style and the 100-yard free-style.

Several parties will be given in the near future for debutantes of this season. Miss Sally-Ruth Burch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Burch of 20 East Seventy-fourth Street, will be the guest of honor at a luncheon to be given by her mother on Dec. 20 in the Chanteclair Room of the Sherry-Netherland.

DR. BROWN reiterates the warning that "in a world only sixty hours large" we must learn to live together or perish. "Our failure," she says, "to treat Negroes as persons is still democracy's No. 1 failure at home and one of the nation's major embarrassments abroad."

Italy, which is the world's second largest producer of velvets, velveteens and corduroys, will have upward of a million yards of velveteens for the American market in 1950, according to Della M. Grattan, Italian trade consultant. These are priced under comparable goods produced in the United States, Miss Grattan said, but will not disturb the market because of the wide demand that can absorb American and foreign production.
THE Southern California Association for Better Radio and Television has lodged a complaint with six Los Angeles television stations and the Federal Communications Commission.

Scout House, headquarters of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, was formally dedicated yesterday with the unveiling of a plaque recording the numbers of 706 local troops that had donated $5,625 to the building fund. The building is at 133 East Sixty-second Street.

AMONG the almost evergreen ornamental plants for late fall color in the perennial border or herb garden, rue (Ruta graveolens) is one of the most striking. It can be started from seed sown directly in the ground in late November or early December.

A PIONEER in social service and the struggle for women's rights, Mary Bakewell now sets down the story of another pioneering struggle: the fight to give women equal rights with men as ministers of the Episcopal Church.

PERHAPS the admission indicates a certain obtuseness on my part, but it has only recently dawned on this department that the rereading of books which give us lasting pleasure has a quality of enjoyment quite distinct from that which came from the first encounter.

MOTHER'S caster set and her Star of Bethlehem pieced-quilt were the only two fine possessions she had to remind her, and father, and the three Brett children of another kind of life than that in the Colorado Territory.

AFTER six years and thirteen pictures Gregory Peck has worked his way out of all but two of the complex and profitable contractual commitments which established him as the hottest actor in Hollywood even before the public saw him. Now he can look ahead a bit and make plans without stopping to worry about being in conflict with his assorted employers.

Winter coats were in strong demand in the wholesale garment market here last week, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office. Orders for the coats, which were wanted for promotion, covered fur-trimmed, untrimmed and zip-out styles.

AMERICAN eating habits have changed radically in the last forty years, and this is official. Economists and other scientists of the United States Department of Agriculture are responsible for the statement and have documented it with thousands of figures assembled in a thick book, recently issued, entitled "Consumption of Food in the United States, 1909-48."

Commercial banks in this area have started a drive for social security tax accounts under the revised Treasury Department procedure, which will become effective on Jan. 1. Several large downtown banks, it was learned yesterday, have sent letters to their corporate customers pointedly reminding them that the new regulations permit such tax remittances to be paid through the bank.

Hollywood could have devised no more characteristic spectacle than Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon when the Boston Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Leonard Bernstein, gave the first performance in this city of Messiaen's "Turangalila" symphony, which takes an hour and a half in performance and is in ten movements.
The people of New York will be asked to take a "water vacation" for several hours some day this week, Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, said yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- Edward Theodore Townsend, who looks like a lumberjack and talks like a college professor, will be 70 years old on Wednesday and doesn't relish compulsory retirement as one of the state's most experienced and widely known game protectors.

Music in the branches of the New York Public Library is on its way to reaching a peak as the holidays approach. The Seventh Annual Carol Sing at 104 West 136th Street will be held on Wednesday at 8:30 P.M. Miss Catherine Van Buren will be soprano soloist with the Student Nurses Glee Clubs of the Harlem and Lincoln Hospitals.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10 -- Al Wheltle, Baltimore attorney, was nominated today to become the next president of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States. The office is for two years.

RUSSIA is today the only country in which the government tells the citizens what to read and instructs the writers what to write. The right path to follow in fiction and criticism, the criteria for evaluating works of art, general literary policy: all are laid down by the Central Committee of the Communist party.

THREE -- things will recommend this symposium on Southeast Asia to readers interested in world affairs: first, the importance and timeliness of the subject-matter; second, the high competence of Professor Mills and his colleagues in this field; and third, the skillful and lucid way this complex and difficult material has been handled.

Davidson (N.C.) College is offering financial assistance to almost one-fourth of its student body through the most extensive scholarship program in the college's 113-year history. The college reports that 208 students are receiving scholarships amounting to $43,355.

Why do some baby chicks turn somersaults and walk backward? Probably they lack vitamin E in their diet, Dr. Erwin L. Jungherr of the University of Connecticut told the last meeting of the American Veterinary Medical Association. Poultry-men call the condition "crazy chick disease."

IN reference to your article of last week, "Plea for Radio," television may excite New Yorkers, but AM radio is still in business in Boston. With only two television stations in operation and with the FCC freeze eliminating the possibility of any more in the foreseeable future, a mad fight for the radio listener has resulted.

IT may seem paradoxical that the current exhibition at Pierre Matisse's be devoted to the art of a man who, in 1920, declared that painting should be "assassinated." But such is the case and that man is none other than Joan Miro who, almost as much as Picasso, Miro's fellow Catalan, has exercised a powerful and seductive sway over twentieth century painting.

GEORGE PRESTON MARSHALL, the heap big chief of the Washington Redskins, puffed contentedly on an Indian peace pipe for the benefit of photographers the other day. That made it official. The costliest war in the history of sports had ended. No one can even begin to guess how many millions of dollars were lost by the embattled magnates of the National Football League and the All-America Conference in their four-year battle of attrition.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- Off-campus job activity of several top-ranking Big Ten athletes, including half-backs Chuck Ortmann and Leo Koceski of Michigan, has been investigated by two ex-G men working out of the commissioner's office.

Peace on the city's subway system -- for the time being at least -- appeared assured yesterday as the Board of Transportation and the Transport Workers Union, CIO, moved toward a meeting some time this week.

NEW YORK STATE'S motorists will have an opportunity this week to present their views on legislation in behalf of motorists, better highways and greater safety, to the Democratic State Committee's program conference for 1950 legislation, meeting at the Biltmore Hotel tomorrow and Tuesday. This is the first time that the state's organized motorists have been invited to submit their proposals to the platform-drafting group of a major political party.

TO assist the motorist crossing frontiers, France is establishing a series of border gateways. The first Porte de France will be ready for operation in April, according to G. Poguet, Chief of the Tourism Section of the Automobile Club of France, and originator of the gateway system.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Gridiron Club, at its winter dinner tonight, "took" its guests to Fishwheel, Alaska, to witness a Republican party gold rush.

The first World War brought an end to the old notion that American colleges and universities were academic retreats, remote from the hard realities of the world outside. World War II emphasized again the prodigious contribution that the nation's schools could make to victory.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 10 -- On the eve of the fourth and final championship play-off of the ill-fated All-America Football Conference, for which the death knell was sounded yesterday at Philadelphia, Paul Brown, general manager and coach of the Cleveland Browns, today dropped a mild bombshell smack in the middle of the peace pact.

The Federal medical services, which account for one out of every seven hospital beds in the nation and whose budget totals $1,000,000,000 yearly, are "efficient and reasonably economical" and "there is no justification whatever for the radical changes as suggested by the Hoover Commission Report," Dr. Eli Ginzberg of Columbia University, declared yesterday.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 10 -- The required capacity for the production of electric power in the Missouri River valley will be far greater in twenty years than can be developed under present Federal-state development plans and by private and other public sources, according to the Federal Power Commission.

WASHINGTON -- At the third annual clinical session of the American Medical Association in Washington last week, Dr. Andy Hall, 84-year-old Mount Vernon, Ill., physician, was named the general practitioner of the year. When the 5,000 doctors, internes and medical students present paid tribute to Dr. Hall, one of his three physician sons, Col. Wilford F. Hall, was not present to join them, as he was in South America on military duty.

CHATTANOOGA, Dec. 10 -- The controversial issue of the oil-rich tidelands off the coast of Louisiana and Texas became big news again this week in the Deep South when the United States Supreme Court set Feb. 6 for a hearing on two cases involving questions of title to these lands.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 10 -- Santa Claus parachuted into town today, got hung up in high tension wires and was rescued as hundreds of children alternately wept and cheered.

Despite high publication costs, for the second consecutive year since the war large buying groups are finding it highly rewarding to publish Christmas catalogues for the use of their individual member stores.

AMONG the minor but regrettable casualties of the war years were many children's books which, of necessity, were retired from print. During the last three or four years, however, the classics and old favorites have been reappearing in ever greater and ever brighter numbers.

BERLIN, Dec. 10 -- Although the Communist-dominated German Democratic Republic has presented a facade of unity, economic progress and general well-being, while Western Germany's Federal Republic is shaken by political turbulence, there are abundant signs from this window on the East that the latest Soviet satellite is undergoing one of those upheavals involving both politics and economics which are so frequent in the supposedly monolithic Communist countries.

The grants of practically all of the $100,000,000 from the Federal Government and the $25,000,000 from private industry to American colleges and universities are for research programs in the engineering and the physical and medical sciences. There are only very minor grants for smaller projects in the fields of psychology, chemistry, biology, biochemistry, pharmacology, geochemistry and physiology.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Eastern seaboard will have a colder December than is customary, while temperatures will be about normal in the central and southwestern states and above normal for the rest of the country -- if you can believe the United States Weather Bureau's monthly Outlook.

Although a sufferer from a heart ailment herself and required to restrict her activity, Mrs. Louise Baer has helped raise more money for research and study in heart diseases than any other individual. The New York Heart Association has therefore named her general chairman of the 1950 New York Heart Campaign.

JANE, the Herberts' granddaughter, is the youngest resident of the large house in which the prominent, indigent, and ramified Herbert family lives. As the story opens she is just beginning to suspect that she's been robbed of a large portion of her father's securities, which he'd asked her to turn over to his solicitor, and which she'd been duped into giving to a stranger.

GENERAL agreement of three speakers on the weaknesses of contemporary pictorialism but an inability on their part to satisfy the audience's request for a sure-tire remedy marked the second forum in the series of panel discussions on salon judging being conducted by The Camera Club.

Some weeks ago I applied to the visa section of the American Embassy in London for a visa to the United States, in order that I might give a lecture at Harvard University on Goethe, and a few lectures at other colleges. I was asked by the vice consul who interviewed me to declare, on oath, whether I had ever been a member of the Communist party.

IN England several of the monitors of public virtue have been shocked by what they regard as the indecency of Tennessee Williams' "A Streetcar Named Desire." With Vivien Leigh giving apparently an inspired performance as the desperate and terrified Blanche Du Bois, the play is a notable success.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Congressional inquirers disclosed today they had asked for records of the Chemical Warfare Service as they sought to run down the whole story of how the Russians were able to get atomic materials during the war.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 10 -- Yale, defending Eastern Intercollegiate League basketball champion, notched its third consecutive victory of the season and first in loop competition by defeating the University of Pennsylvania, 57 -- 51, tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10 -- In an atmosphere approaching "the judicial calm" called for by Federal Judge George B. Harris after an early period of wrangling and bellicosity, the trial of Harry R Bridges and two fellow officers of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union has concluded its fourth week.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Dec. 10 (AP) -- The College All-Stars, outplayed by Charlotte's Clippers in the first half, rallied in the last two periods today to defeat the professional eleven, 21 -- 6.

WARSAW, Dec. 10 -- An official disclosure that the Central Committee of the Polish United Workers (Communist) party contained elements that distrusted the Soviet Union and permitted faulty cooperation with the Russian Army was made today.

Because of an increase in population, which water engineers estimate at 30,000 persons a year, and because of the habit of New Yorkers to use far more water than they need, there has been an increase in water consumption here in six years from 880,000,000 gallons daily to 1,200,000,000 gallons daily.

THIS is the America of Ethan Allen: frontier Connecticut and Vermont at the time of the Revolution; Indians and Tories, Ticonderoga and the Green Mountain Boys. The youngster who loved to read, who would have gone to college had his father lived, grows to manhood -- tall, dominant, quick-tempered; a natural leader, violent in action, deeply loyal.

BESIDES the big debut of the New York City Dance Theatre, the week contains a good deal of other activity. At the Ziegfeld Theatre tonight, Sujata and Asoka present dances of India and Tibet under the distinguished patronage of Mme. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit. The New York City Ballet Company closes its most successful season to date with two performances today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10 -- In spite of the stimulus of pre-Christmas shopping, retail business activity in the Twelfth District did not show any appreciable gain during the last week, although reports from all areas showed the variation of losses from a year ago were not as extreme as those of the previous week.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- Syracuse University's basketball team waged a terrific uphill struggle at the State Fair Coliseum tonight to knock Columbia from the unbeaten ranks, 60 -- 48.

The Art Workshop will be the beneficiary of a pre-opening performance of George Bernard Shaw's comedy, "Caesar and Cleopatra," with Sir Cedric Hardwicke and Lilli Palmer in the leading roles, tomorrow night at the National Theatre.

FOR years, as a native up-state New Yorker, I have been fighting a losing battle to get straight in people's minds the variations in spelling and the proper use of the word Allegany or Alleghany or Allegheny.
A bereaved mother sent $200 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday as a memorial to her daughter, who was killed recently in an automobile accident.

AN ancient truth, that music can be a powerful ally of the living theatre, has been rediscovered on Broadway in recent years. The result has been beyond any optimist's expectations. Not only is the musical theatre being revitalized, but in its daring and originality it is becoming one of the most adventurous forces in America's cultural scheme.

Developing a strong undertone despite the cross-currents in stock trading, prices ranged to new three-year tops by a small margin on the New York Stock Exchange last week. The market reflected the quick recovery in industrial production since the steel strike ended, and seemingly ignored the demands of John L. Lewis that the hard-coal operators increase wages and royalties to settle their dispute.

ONE hundred and twenty young men began forming a chilly line in front of New York's Municipal Building at 3 A.M. some days ago. They were waiting to apply for civil service examinations for the police force.

Paced by Ed Roman's 19 points. City College gained an easy 82-to-28 triumph over the Kings Point quintet on the Beavers' court last night. Nat Holman's charges employed a two-platoon system through the first half to gain a 35-15 lead.

The week just passed has brought an end to formal warfare on the Chinese mainland. The capital has been withdrawn to Formosa and Chiang Kaishek has declared that mainland operations are being organized on a guerrilla basis. The roles of the parties to the strife have thus, in effect, been reversed.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec. 10 -- Plans for erection of Puerto Rico's first oil refinery, to be built and financed by private American capital, were revealed today by Gov. Luis Munos Marin as the latest unit in the program of industrialization of this factory-hungry island.

GEORGETOWN, Conn., Dec. 10 -- Descendants of the original settlers in this old New England village are completing the first step in the restoration of one of their cherished heritages. Men and women are at work renovating with their own hands the Methodist Church here, believed to be one of the oldest edifices in Connecticut.
GENEVA, Dec. 2 -- The outstanding lesson learned by both European and United States economic statesmen during 1949 has been that European "integration" must proceed by stages.

ON a rambling seventeen-day motor trip which my wife and I made recently up through New England and the Maritime Provinces, with the return via the St. Lawrence and the Adirondacks, a station wagon served not only as our means of transportation but also our home.

MOST reference books can be counted on to supply facts and figures in their chosen field. A few furnish good reading and stimulating comment for the general reader, as well. To this more exalted class belongs "Thesaurus of Book Digests," a collection of 2,000 summaries of the world's writings, compiled by fifteen authorities under the editorial supervision of Messrs. Haydn and Fuller.

THE evidences of archeology demonstrate that for thousands of years the human mind has been as energetic and as capable as it is today. A question is what happened to the vast mental initiative which, in our own century, is lavished on scientific research.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 10 -- The Connecticut Highway Department is proceeding with a major bypass project on the Boston Post Road at Darien despite opposition from some groups of residents in the area.

A wide divergence of opinion has developed in the rayon yarn market on the subject of prices, it was pointed out last week. With three of the leading producers of viscose filament yarn raising prices by an average of 4 per cent, the trade anticipated that all other producers would likewise make price increases.
FORTY major films, half of them in color, and many shorter pictures are scheduled for production in Soviet studios next year, according to the newspaper Soviet Art.

THERE is increasing evidence in contemporary painting of the truth of the old proverb that the first sign of a step forward is a look backward. The more reckless of our experimenters are learning -- many of them have learned -- that one cannot cut loose entirely from tradition.

ALBANY, Dec. 10 -- Youthful delegates to the fourteenth annual Hi-Y assembly representing councils throughout the state approved bills today increasing teacher salaries, providing for the licensing of "lonely hearts" clubs and requiring the hospitalization of sexual psychopaths until they are cured.

FLORHAM PARK, N.J., Dec. 10 -- Fire fighters attached to three fire companies -- one in this community, one from East Orange and one from Madison -- stood by helplessly here today as the Braidburn Country Club burned to the ground. They didn't have any water with which to fight the flames.

THE most spectacular triumph -- if not the most rewarding one -- for the Countess Origo in her work on "The Last Attachment: The Story of Byron and Teresa Guiccioli" was the pre-literary one, the actual business of getting hold of the letters themselves.

MOST popular writing about calculating machines illustrates the fact that it is easier to impress people than to share information with them. You learn that the machines take only a few hours to solve mathematical equations too complex for the human brain, and that some day they may predict weather or figure out income-tax returns.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 10 -- A twenty-day scourge of smog in the Los Angeles Basin finally ended this week, but left in its wake an equally acrid pall of public controversy.

Upholstered chairs, rhinestone jewelry and electric trains were featured in retail promotions here last week, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

LUXEMBOURG, Dec. 10 -- The United States is seeking agreement of all the North Atlantic pact nations on a coordinated policy to govern the shipment of war material or potential to any country outside the pact.

Members of the American Institute of Accountants have formally approved a program requiring a clear explanation of the auditor's position when he is unable to provide an opinion on financial statements he has examined, it was announced yesterday.

IT is unfortunate that many mothers and fathers actively engaged in the rearing of children feel so pressed for time that they cannot enjoy to its fullest the remarkable development and unfolding that is going on before their eyes.

MANY of the truly blue flowers in our plantings are supplied by the perennial anchusas. Several different ones, considered during the past growing season, will supply their satisfactory color from early spring until fall.

DR. BERGLER, a psychoanalyst, believes that serious and lasting conflicts in marriage are mainly the result of the union of two emotionally disturbed people, "neurotics." In such cases divorce is not generally recommended, for, as he says, you can divorce your husband (or wife) but not your neurosis.

The first definite step in the acquisition by the Chicago Cubs of the Yankees' Newark International League franchise was effected yesterday when the Cubs took an option until Jan. 15 on the Newark holdings.

CONSIDERING the constant hubbub prevailing in the busy Pennywink household of twelve (Mother, Father and ten boys), it is no wonder that it took them three days to find out they had accidentally kidnapped Katie Kelly.

THE still safe margin of shopping days until Christmas seems to disappear when you enter the Wildenstein Galleries. The holiday has already arrived on its elegant fifth floor. For here are 100 paintings, each based on a Christmas theme.

P.S.G. of Norwich, Vt., on Kaempffert's review of de Kruif's "Life Among the Doctors," defends the "skepticism" of conservative medicine by citing the "dangers" of premature reports (Book Review, Oct. 30).

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- Christmas travel to Bermuda is expected to carry the Colony over its goal of 60,000 tourists during 1949. The week from Dec. 26 through New Year's is fairly solidly booked, and this last-minute spurt will probably boost the year's total to 62,000 tourists.

MR. MUSSELMAN here sketches the course that led to his first and best-selling book, "Wheels in His Head," in 1946, as well as to this new one, "I Married a Redhead." When he married the redhead she was an actress who did a lot of touring, he was a radio set salesman in Chicago, and it was easier to carry a typewriter than a store from place to place.
OMAHA, Dec. 10 -- The Midwest, accustomed to regard itself as the nation's breadbasket, was discussing this week its future role as the nation's largest potential reservoir of fuel.

DURING a memorable thunderstorm which swept the area around Caen, in Normandy, in the summer of 1939 a young Frenchwoman gave birth to a son in the farmhouse where she lived for six months of each year with her English husband.

ABOUT one-half of the entries in the fourteenth annual Travel Salon sponsored by the Metropolitan Camera Club Council were selected during the judging at the Camera Club last week for exhibition throughout the United States.

BERLIN, Dec. 10 -- Announcement that an extraordinary session of the People's Chamber of the Eastern German Democratic Republic has been called for 11 A. M., Dec. 21, led Western observers here today to anticipate some significant development on the political side to mark the Communists' observance of the seventieth birthday of Premier Stalin.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 10 (AP) -- A new Iraqi Cabinet was formed today by Ali Jawdat al-Ayubi, former Premier and Foreign Minister and former Iraqi Ambassador to Washington.
WHEN misfortune strikes, most of us can count on a friend -- someone to whom we turn for comfort, for advice, for a helping hand.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- A sharp division among the five members of the National Labor Relations Board was disclosed today when the majority held that an employer had no legal obligation to bargain with a union unless it had complied with the filing and non-Communist affidavit requirements of the Taft-Hartley Act at the time it sought to bargain.

IN the pages of the Bible the role of men naturally assumes a more important place than that of women -- if only for the reason that men wrote the Bible. But the women of the Old Testament played important parts, too, as decisive as those of men in the crises of Israel's history.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 10 -- A technique in which light beams are bounced around a scale model to determine the acoustical properties of an auditorium is being worked out at Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

THIS novel is cast in a pattern that was made familiar to metropolitan moviegoers by that fine film "The Search" -- the parent-seeks-son pattern, played out against a post-war backdrop, and heavy with psychiatric overtones. Unlike the motion picture, Miss Laski's book begins with the child already found: the actual search is ended, but a tortured path must be followed in the mind of a father who cannot quite accept the responsibility of fatherhood.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 10 -- The three-day work week in the Wyoming-Colorado-Utah coal fields, plus an even more serious no-day work week at lead-zinc diggings throughout the Mountain States, are spotlighting the "captive status" of the area's economy.

Practically everything we use in our daily lives, from a cradle to a coffin, requires some specially developed exterior or interior coatings, known as industrial finishes. Without them the life of any given product would be short or often useless.

Financial insitutions specializing in the administration of pension plans are well equipped to service the recent increase in industrial retirement programs, a survey of some of the leading banks and insurance companies here indicated last week.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 (AP) -Oklahoma A. and M. had a rough time but managed to stay in front virtually all the way to hand St. Joseph's of Philadelphia a 57-46 defeat tonight in the second game of a college double-header. Temple won from Muhlenberg. 56 -- 49, in the first game.

HOUSTON, Tex. Dec. 10 -- Former President Herbert Hoover received a bronze plaque in absentia here tonight "in appreciation of his lifelong adherence to true Christian principles throughout his outstanding career as an engineer, statesman and humanitarian."

EVELYN is "a curly-haired, dimpled little girl" of 4 years and 3 months; "her ready smile makes her well-liked by adults"; she gets along well with her age-mates; she is of average intelligence, goes to nursery school, and, we gather, is in every respect a normal, happy little girl.

BECAUSE Japanese beetles and black spot are two of the most serious rose troubles, varieties that show some resistance are worth noting for future planting. This year, roses that have flowered well in spite of the hot, dry summer should also be added to the list.

A reader posed two questions in your letters columns to Chester Bowles regarding his "The Independent Voter Isn't Independent." The first question was: "How does Mr. Bowles think he got nominated to be Governor of Connecticut, instead of an inferior machine politician, except as a candidate more inviting to the floating center?"
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities is again "in the news."

HONG KONG, Dec. 10 -- During the war with Japan, American forces at one time prepared for an invasion of Formosa. Okinawa was hit instead, but in plotting the Formosa operation experts in amphibious warfare were struck by the number of good landing sites on that island.

While the Bulldogs are facing the Pittsburgh Steelers at the Polo Grounds and the Giants are tackling the Eagles at Philadelphia, the significant action today in the National Football League will be taking place far afield. The Western Division championship hinges on the results of the games between the Rams and Washington at Los Angeles and between the Bears and Cardinals at Chicago.

Legislation encouraging American corporations to export "used-but-good" mass production machinery and tools to economically backward nations was urged yesterday by Arthur Keating, president of Ekco Products Company, is a practical approach to objectives of President Truman's Point of Program.

THERE is no peace on earth this Christmas. There is no peace for the French reader, at any rate. War novels, avoided since the armistice, have outflanked the critics and invaded the best-seller lists. It has taken longer to reduce the second World War to human size, or art form, than it had for the first.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- "How tetchy are Britain's new upper classes!" The London Daily Express remarked this week. According to their opponents, politicians of the Labor party are a grim and dedicated lot of social reformers, characterized by the solemnity of their breed.

Dr. Alfred C. Kinsey made a mistake in adding the figures in his much-discussed report on the sex habits of American men, says W. Allen Wallis, chairman of the University of Chicago committee on statistics, in the Journal of the American Statistical Association.

It was unintentional but significant that the man standing at Churchill's right in the photograph for Robert Gordon Menzies' "Churchill at 75: An Intimate Portrait" is not identified. He is Ernest Bevin, then -- on VE Day -- Minister of Labor in the Coalition Government that led Britain to costly victory.

MANHASSET, L.I., Dec. 10 -- The court tennis teams of New York and Philadelphia moved into the final round of the Payne Whitney Memorial doubles tournament today in the Greentree court of John Hay (Jock) Whitney. Led by James H. Van Alen and Frank Shields, New York defeated Long Island, 2 -- 1, and Philadelphia won by the same score from Boston.
The Soviet Union used the closing ceremonies of the United Nations General Assembly yesterday to accuse the West of stirring up a "black plot" against the peace.

CONTRARY to his title "Days Beyond Recall," Roger Dooley does a very thorough job of bringing back to mind the morals and manners of the first two decades of this century in Buffalo. He concentrates on the Catholic Irish of the First Ward whose grandparents could remember their days in Ireland.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 10 -- Stanley C. Myers, president of the Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds, the national organization embracing 265 Jewish community welfare funds throughout the country, declared today that Jewish needs in Israel, overseas and on the domestic scene were "inherently interwined."

Representatives of seventy organizations will speak at the Democratic State Committee's legislative program conference at the Biltmore Hotel tomorrow and Tuesday, Paul F. Fitzpatrick, state chairman, announced yesterday. Thirty other organizations have sent in recommendations for legislation.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 10 -- Arthur A. Cahvell, Australian Immigration Minister, was returned with a large majority in a i safe Labor Melbourne constit- l uency. ] Dr. Herbert Evatt, External J Affairs Minister in the Labor Gov-] ernment, has received 19,889 votesI in the Barton, New South Wales, ] constituency. His opponent, Mrs. N. Wake, Liberal, has 17,328.

A NEW model Automatic Rolleiflex will be placed on the market Thursday, according to announcement by Burleigh Brooks Company, Eastern distributors of Rolleiflex cameras. Simultaneously, fair trade act regulations will be put into effect on these cameras, although the agreement will apply only to the new models.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 10 -- A vital factor in the conservation of the Long Island ground water table is the reuse of water used in air conditioning and the refrigeration industry and for other industrial purposes.

"THE deepest rift that is at present dividing the edifice of science is the cleavage between natural science and the humanistic disciplines." These words announce their author's endeavor to see things whole. He is a distinguished physicist in the Department of Social Thought at the University of Chicago.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 10 -- The pressures of an inflated post-war enrollment have made Princeton University's eating-club system the center of a heated controversy between members of the sophomore class and graduate and undergraduate members of the seventeen Prospect Street eating clubs.

Hustling Dick McGuire carried off the honors at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. The former St. John's star, plugging all the way, drove in from underneath on a feed from Bill Van Breda Kolff as the buzzer sounded for the end of the five-minute overtime period to give the New York Knickerbackers a 93-91 decision over the rugged Chicago Stags.

The $15,000,000 CARE book program -- to bring the latest available knowledge to technical and professional workers and students overseas to help them in the reconstruction of their own countries -- is expected to reach its peak activity by next spring, it was announced yesterday at CARE headquarters, 20 Broad Street.

The fourth regular session of the United Nations General Assembly, after more than 540 plenary and committee meetings, yesterday completed its work. For eighty days of the session the Assembly had been dominated by the familiar East-West debates and accusations -- and few hard decisions had been taken.

A GIFT of a pair of English hollies started my interest in these evergreens over thirty years ago. This year, both native and exotic kinds growing in my garden in New Jersey are laden with a particularly fine and heavy crop of berries that I can use for holiday decorations.

ARTHUR MILLER, a man who obviously believes that a writer's function is to write, is hard at work these days fashioning a film script. Last week the author of "Death of a Salesman" revealed that he had "finished the first fifty pages" and still had "about 100 pages to go" on the as yet untitled work.

A NUMBER of influential people have to be interested in a composer's work before it reaches the public ear. Since the composer is obliged to live in the meantime, it generally means that people with money have to furnish a commission in the first place.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 10 -- With traditional ceremony, Nobel Prizes for 1949 were presented to winners today in Stockholm's Symphony Hall. The delicate health of King Gustaf, who is 91, prevented his attending, and Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf handed diplomas and checks for about $30,000 to each of the winners.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 10 -- On the leadership of the United States may rest the main hope of a number of member states in the United Nations eager to find a solution to the baffling problem posed by its own decision yesterday to establish an international Jerusalem zone in Palestine against the wishes of Israel and Jordan.

Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, president of the United Nations General Assembly, discarded his prepared speech before an assembly of young people yesterday and made instead an impassioned plea for human beings to respect each other.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 10 (AP) -- A four-engine Navy plane, with four United States Senators and their party aboard was brought down safely with the help of radar in poor visibility here today.

LUXEMBOURG, Dec. 10 -- The International Ruhr Authority has requested the Western Allied High Commissioners in Germany and the Bonn Government to abandon the double pricing system now applied to coal and coke products, in efforts to facilitate the integration of Western Germany into the economy of Western Europe.
IT may be said, and so I'll say it, that there are four basic types of Christmas shopper:

Employment opportunities for college graduates are less favorable now than they were a year ago, Dr. Frank S. Endicott, director of Northwestern University's Bureau of Placement, reported last week on the basis of a survey conducted by the bureau.

TOKYO, Dec. 10 -- The Japanese Government is again facing an explosive labor situation which has been held in abeyance since the Conservative regime dismissed thousands of surplus public workers earlier this year. Some observers believe it will provide the hardest test thus far for the administration of Premier Shigeru Yoshida, and in connection with other developments it may even cause a Cabinet shake-up early next year.

THE boys in the local film business are scratching their heads again. It seems that they're up against something which they find most discouraging. For the past several weeks general business in the big Broadway theatres has been "off," while a mild boom has been progressing in some of the smaller show shops off Broadway.
Officials of college bands in the local area went on record yesterday avowing their right to appear in conjunction with athletic teams at events sponsored by their colleges and universities.

Although two members were unable to be present, the eight others on the 1949 All-America lacrosse team were guests of honor last night at the annual dinner of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association at the Hotel Statler.

Jet transport planes will not be carrying passengers on United States scheduled airways much before 1955, despite the current availability of British and Canadian models, says Carlos Wood, designing engineer of the Douglas Aircraft Company.

THE letters and autobiographies of great artists, together with their diaries and journals, often tell us more of the artistic movements of an age than do all of the pages of endless criticism these artists have themselves evoked. Delacroix's "Journal," Van Gogh's "Letters" to his brother Theodore, the sonnets of Michelangelo bear witness to the inner life and acceptance or rejection of the world in which the artist lived.

A panel of six senior high school students agreed yesterday that the German people needed re-education in the ways and means of democracy but split sharply over the question of rebuilding Germany industrially and militarily.

Declaring that there could be no substitute for vigorous enforcement of the anti-trust laws, Herbert A. Bergson, Assistant United States Attorney General, warned yesterday that it was up to business to do everything possible to carry out the philosophy of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

The steel industry expects to have within the next few months a settlement of its long-standing controversy with the Government over pricing practices. When the situation is clarified, it is said, many leading companies will adopt quickly a program involving absorption of freight charges of a limited character.
AN informative fragment from a recent seminar in the House of Commons concerning American fiction, freely adapted from a report in The Bookseller, London:

THOMAS ELPHINSTONE HAMBLEDON was the brightest creation of modern espionage fiction -- the most audacious and inventive adventurer since Arsene Lupin. No reader will forget his long career as chief of the Berlin police, actively prosecuting a search for himself, nor his more recent masquerade as a top Nazi scientist.

EASTON, Pa., Dec. 10 -- Lafayette did not give Princeton a field goal in the first 19 minutes and 40 seconds of the first half and then had to thwart a Tiger second-half rally to win, 48 -- 35, tonight. George Davidson and Oliver Smith paced the Lafayette attack with 14 and 13 points, respectively, while Mike Kearns led the Tigers with 7.

According to a report in THE TIMES on Nov. 30 Andrei Vishinsky's boast before the U.N. that Russia was already "razing mountains" with atomic energy has already been toned down in Moscow for home consumption. Evidently they were aware at home that it was just a bluff to throw a scare into the United States.

Sought for eight years for violating parole, a former New York patrolman convicted of attempted kidnapping was almost caught Friday night in Los Angeles, it was reported here yesterday. The fugitive slipped out the back door of his home while his wife barred the front entrance to local sheriff's deputies.

KINGS POINT, L.I., Dec. 10 -- Warrant Officer Charles Williamsen, who left his native Denmark forty-six years ago to ship to America as a foremast hand on the sailing yacht Alhoa, rose to his present rank in the merchant service by way of the hawse pipe.

The earth's atmosphere is somewhat like an onion in that it has several layers. Near the earth lies the troposphere, which is about six miles thick; above that lies the stratosphere, which extends to an indefinite height without any sharp boundary. There are also the ozone layer and the ionosphere.
