STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 10 -- A "Little Hoover Commission," consisting of a volunteer seventeen-man task force, is making a survey of Stamford's new consolidated city government, which has been beset with difficulties even greater than those encountered in the merger of two business establishments.

The first anniversary of the adoption of a Universal Declaration of Human Rights by the United Nations General Assembly was observed here yesterday with words and music glorifying the brotherhood of man.

Storm clouds are rumbling across the regulatory horizon. With unprecedented vigor, two of the nation's state public utility commissions have charged that the Federal Government is trying to extend its control to intrastate matters.

The Carpet Institute, Inc., will train between 5,000 and 6,000 retail carpet salesmen in the principles of scientific selling as part of its 1950 marketing program, Merrill A. Watson, president, disclosed last week. In 1949, the institute trained 2,300 retail salesmen in twenty-five cities following adoption last April of its sales training course after more than a year and a half of preparation.

The United Nations General Assembly is not, except in limited special cases, a legislature. It is not a representative body. It is not a body with great power of any kind -- except the power of influencing world public opinion. This can be and, during the session that ended yesterday, has been a very considerable power.

BETHLEHEM, Pa. -- This manufacturing community of 69,000 people last week made its annual change of character, being transformed into the Christmas capital of America. The change started with the lighting last week-end of an eighty-one-foot star atop South Mountain.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 10 (UP) -- The Communist district chairman of Kiel and three other party officials were ousted today, the latest moves in a continuing purge of the West German Communist party.

MADRID, Dec. 10 -- Under the pressure of increasing economic difficulties and of growing domestic discontent caused by these difficulties, the Spanish Government is watching closely the trend of opinion in the United States and hoping a big loan will be forthcoming to bolster Spain's economy.

ROME -- Americans who plan to go skiing in Italy this winter will do well to make their reservations as soon as possible. This is particularly advisable if they want to make their headquarters in either of the two rival capitals of the country's snowy mountains: Sestriere or Cortina d'Ampezzo.

To some people, Thomas Foppiani is just the soda jerk who works behind the luncheon counter at Friedgen's Pharmacy at 1220 Amsterdam Avenue. But to the students and faculty of Teachers College, Columbia University, Tom is better known for his views on higher education and psychology than for his dispensing of strawberry floats and marshmallow sundaes.

MOST amateur photographers love to play with gadgets and they are inclined to try every new device that reaches the market. The average darkroom indicates this weakness and raises the question: How much of all this paraphernalia is necessary for the making of good pictures by the amateur?
ALONG with the holiday season comes the annual round of gala entertaining. At this time the dining table, around which much of this festive activity occurs, becomes a center of interest in the home.

Possible development next year by the United States of an aid program for the Far East, including India, was seen here yesterday as a logical development by Charles S. Morgenthau, vice president of Stern, Morgenthau Co., foreign traders, who has just returned from a two and a half months' survey of India, Ceylon and Pakistan.

FOR quite some time I have been attracted by the work of a group of thinkers and writers carrying on a labor of enlightenment, so necessary in times of growing darkness such as ours. I speak of the Institute of Social Research, formerly of Frankfort on the Main, now of New York, and directed by Prof. Max Horkheimer.

Debutantes of this season, headed by Miss Edwina Shea, are aiding Mrs. Harold Ruckman Mixsell and members of the executive committee in furthering the sale of tickets for the performance of "The Enchanted," a new play by Jean Girardoux, on the night of Jan. 20, at the Lyceum Theatre, for the benefit of the New York Botanical Garden.
A 12-year-old boy who tried yesterday to rescue a 14-year-old boy from a Central Park lake was himself saved by a policeman who dived into the icy water after him.
IT may well be asked why no opera has appeared in the quarter century since Giacomo Puccini died. Nov. 29, 1924, to equal any one of his best or second-best works for the lyric stage?

A new trade salesmen's kit that opens like an unsealed folding box into a graphic, three-dimensional display of an advertiser's coming premium or other special sales promotion is being developed on a large scale by the Container Corporation of America, it was learned last week.
TORONTO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs scored their fourth straight National Hockey League victory tonight, beating the Boston Bruins, 2 to 1, before 13,134 fans.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 10 -- Officials of the wartime pro-Nazi government in Bulgaria testified today that the life of Traicho Kostov, former Deputy Premier, had been spared in 1942 only because he betrayed his fellow-Communists and turned police informer.

A PRIMER of intellectual freedom is badly needed. That spirit of free inquiry, which the nineteenth century assumed to be the essence of intellectual life, has been increasingly under totalitarian assault in the stormy twentieth century.

It would seem that Santa Claus is just a bourgeois capitalist, after all. In the Soviet Zone of Germany, according to a dispatch to this newspaper, the customary holidays are not to be celebrated this year.

Whether faculty members should be required to take a special loyalty oath is creating a sharp controversy at the University of California and has brought charges of "cold war hysteria" against the administration. A pamphlet recently issued by the American Civil Liberties Union of Northern California, entitled "Crisis at the University of California," accused the university of violating the principles of academic freedom.

Registering falls in the first two events on the program, the Rutgers wrestling team conquered Columbia on the latter's strips yesterday, 24 to 7. The Lions were able to win only one bout, Gene Manfrini, blind Columbia sophomore, throwing Tom Dierauf in the 155-pound class bout. The losers other two points came from a contest that ended in a draw.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 10 -- The United Nations General Assembly's vote to internationalize Jerusalem came as a shock to the Israelis. After the stunning effect had passed, the popular consensus seemed to be: "Well, let's see them do it."

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Australia has followed New Zealand's lead and rejected the Labor Government -- at least for the present. The big question in British minds is, Can it happen here? The Conservatives, naturally, are saying that it can and will, but the British Socialists are holding their peace.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Senator William E. Jenner, Republican, of Indiana, said today that a trip around the world had convinced him "Stalin is winning the cold war." He called for an end to the bipartisan foreign policy and the discontinuance of foreign aid.

The appointment of Mario Geminiani, former assistant marine superintendent to the post of assistant passenger traffic manager, was announced yesterday by Guy de Berc, general manager of the French Line in the United States and Canada.
LONDON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Two American plays are wearing down Vivien Leigh and Paul Muni.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 10 -- International governmental loans and grants of an unprecedented magnitude, on which trade among countries largely depends today, afford only a temporary solution to international commercial and financial problems, United Nations specialists warned this week.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 -- The national team-of-four championship contest in the American Contract Bridge League's twenty-third annual tournament here ended in a three-way tie, it was announced in the early hours of this morning. It was the first time three teams had tied for this title.

A strong upturn in demand for five basic kinds of durable goods appeared throughout Eastern states last week, it was reported by equipment manufacturers. In a few lines, large backlogs are reappearing and price rises have been studied in anticipation of announcements to be made soon.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Dec. 10 -- The third anniversary of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund, which is being observed on Sunday, finds 18,500,000 children and young adults tested and 8,500,000 vaccinated against tuberculosis in all parts of the world.
Black Watch took the jumper championship and Sombrero the title among working hunters as the two-day Brooklyn winter horse show ended in Squadron C Armory last night.
CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- Steps aimed at the establishment of a permanent commission on the preparation of college teachers were taken here today.

PARIS -- More tourists visited France in the first nine months of 1949 than in any other comparable period in her history, according to figures released at a recent press conference by Christian Pineau, Minister of Public Works, Transport and Tourism.

ANOTHER school term begins next month when several courses for gardeners are being offered. At the New York Botanical Garden, Bronx Park, a series of lectures on "Outdoor Flower Gardening" starts Jan. 5. Classes will meet from 8 to 10 P.M. on six alternate Thursdays, through March 16. Arthur King will conduct the course.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 -- The Interstate Commission on the Delaware River Basin announced today that it was preparing a plan to eliminate for fifty to 100 years the possibility of water famines such as now threaten New York City and northeastern New Jersey.

News comes from Paris that Sidonie Gabrielle Claudine Colette Gauthier-Villars de Jouvenel Goudeket, known to France and the world as "Colette," has been elected the first woman president of the Goncourt Academy. This honor is a tribute, not only from the distinguished "Ten" but from the French people to their outstanding femme de letters -- the lady with the mop of hair and the passion for cats.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The emergence in the United States zone of Germany of strong "protective" organizations bent on wrecking occupation plans to return property to the victims of Nazi persecution or to the heirs of such victims was reported today to Secretary of the Army Gordon Gray.

AVRO MANHATTAN presents his own version of "inside Europe." Wherever social or political reaction has threatened liberal thought and democratic government, he says, look for the hidden hand of the Vatican. To be sure, he disavows a belief that Roman Catholicism can be held responsible for all the upheavals of the past forty years.

Mrs. Charles V. Hickox heads a group of women of society who are sponsoring a ball for debutantes of recent seasons to be held on Dec. 21 in the main ballroom of the Plaza, in behalf of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service. A feature of the forthcoming event will be a Cavalcade of the Dance, illustrative of the various dance steps that have been popular for the last twenty years.
PARIS, Dec. 10 (AP) --Europeans still are suspicious of United States motives in flooding their countries with Marshall Plan dollars, a public opinion poll disclosed today.

THE National Association of Manufacturers calls its annual convention the Congress of American Industry. Last week in sessions here the speeches and discussions followed the usual vein with emphasis upon condemnation of the "Welfare State" and the "Fair Deal."
NEWARK, Dec. 10 -- The New Jersey State Bar Association approved today two resolutions aimed at eliminating alleged racial discrimination in the American Bar Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The National Labor Relations Board is preparing for an avalanche of union-shop elections that not only will be costly but also will strain its staff resources and compel the hiring of many temporary employes.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 10 -- Brig. Gen. Wallace H. Graham, the White House physician, said today that President Truman was probably the busiest President in American history and should take short vacations at more frequent intervals.
Following is a summary of the major decisions taken at the fourth regular session of the United Nations General Assembly:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Indications that President Truman would submit another unbalanced budget next year were received at the Capitol without surprise today, and there was little hope that Congress would effect sufficient economies to bring it into balance.

WHETHER France is in or out of the headlines, there is one story that has received little play in the press: the constant battle being waged for the mind of the French people, particularly the French worker. This battle is being waged with every trick in the book of propaganda warfare.

VIENNA, Dec. 10 -- The struggle between communism and the Catholic Church, which has been waged in all the "people's democracies," has become sharper in Czechoslovakia this week. The protest by the Catholic hierarchy against new laws designed to subject the Church to control of the Communist state has been answered by an official brochure accusing Archbishop Joseph Beran of high treason committed on Vatican orders.

FIRST signs are visible here that the spirit of European cooperation is beginning to filter into music. The Holland Festival Foundation is planning to invite representatives of the Salzburg and Edinburgh festivals to a meeting here in January to discuss the possibilities for coordination among them.

BOSTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- A veteran New York squash racquets team swept all seven matches from Philadelphia today in the first round of the twenty-first Lockett Cup tri-city competition at the Harvard Club.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 10 -- Republican party leaders throughout Connecticut were called upon today by Clarence F. Baldwin, state Republican chairman, to submit suggestions for a party platform in 1950 to oppose Gov. Chester Bowles, Democrat.

NORTH BALDWIN, L.I., Dec. 10 -- With the aid of volunteers, William F. Kramer, a 31-year-old paraplegic veteran of the recent war, may move with his family into their "dream house" on or before Christmas Day.

Partly recovered from the stunning effects of defeat in last year's Presidential election, Republican leaders began yesterday to take definite steps to replenish the nearly exhausted treasury of the National Committee and to agree on a party program to present to the voters in next year's Congressional elections.

A total of $1,700 was realized in contributions earned by members of the Sabbath School of the Washington Avenue Seventh Day Adventist Church, Brooklyn, last night, when reports of investments of 100 one-dollar bills were made at a rally of the school at the Bedford Young Men's Christian Association, 1121 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn.

The United Nations may run into "embarrassing complications" in carrying out the decision of its General Assembly that Jerusalem should be placed "under a permanent international regime," Rabbi Zev Zahevy declared in a sermon yesterday morning before Congregation Ohab Zedek, at 118 West Ninety-fifth Street.

HOLY Year starts on Christmas Eve. In commemoration, both Vatican City and Italy will shortly release postal paper. For Vatican City there will be eight values, the designs to include "the four patriarchal basilicas of Rome": St. Peter, St. John Lateran, St. Paul, St. Mary Major.

Efforts of Soviet scientists to apply energy from the sun for industrial and domestic uses, including power, refrigeration, air conditioning, and household heating, are emphasized in the latest issue of the official organ of the Soviet Academy of Sciences.

The last part of the late Alfred Stieglitz' collection of 850 modern paintings, both European and American, plus uncounted photographs, has finally been placed in museums. Recently Fisk University in Nashville, Tenn., formally accepted 101 paintings, photographs and photoengravings.

THE trouble with "I Can Hear It Now," Vol. II, is that you can You can hear a lot of it now without the benefit of the recording. The 1948 Presidential campaign is over, but the same voices may be heard speaking along the same lines. Certain phases of the cold war are over, but the cold war itself continues.

A RECENT journey through the Middle West after many surveys of post-war Europe convinced this reporter that the contrast between the United States and Europe is greater today than it was before the war. From the heart of America it is easy to see that today's antithesis lies less in outward circumstance than in the workings of the mind.

DETROIT, Dec. 10 -- Goalie Chuck Rayner of the New York Rangers turned in a super-duper performance tonight as he blanked the Detroit Red Wings, 1 -- 0. It was the first shutout suffered by the Wings in this National Hockey League season.
Crime in public and private housing projects is virtually non-existent, owing in large measure to the special patrol forces that are an integral part of the developments, a survey showed yesterday.

BRUSSELS. ON May 28, 1940, the Commander in Chief of the Belgian Army surrendered himself and his remaining half-million men to the advancing Germans. Whenever two politically conscious Belgians have met since then; Topic A has been "La Question Royale." Several books have been written on the matter.

Tonight will be a rare occasion for Father Dante Del Fiorentino, the shy, gentle pastor of St. Lucy's Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn. He will be one of the guests of honor at the Puccini Memorial Concert at the Metropolitan Opera House, marking the twenty-fifth anniversary of the composer's death.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company is an industrial giant that some people consider a shining monument to the uniquely American institution of free enterprise and others consider a monopolistic octopus which has achieved unparalleled power by crushing its competitors in ruthless disregard of the anti-trust laws.

ROANOKE, Va., Dec. 10 (UP) -- Southern Conference officials today adjourned their annual meeting but planned another session after action by the National Collegiate Athletic Association on its request for softening of the "sanity code."

MONTREAL, Dec. 10 (AP) -- A brilliant goal-tending exhibition by Frankie Brimsek tonight earned the Chicago Black Hawks a 1-1 National Hockey League tie with the Montreal Canadiens before 13,894 fans.

WHEN shall we learn that logic, mathematics and physical theory are merely man's inventions for succinctly stating what he already knows? When shall we realize that his only hope for exploring the unknown with these inventions lies in the fact that he has sometimes been lucky enough to advance a little by acquired momentum?

LONDON. IN THE game of cricket it is the custom of the crowd to give sustained applause to a batter when he reaches the score of 50, officially known as a half century. But if he eventually reaches his full century the applause is even louder and more sustained. One might almost say that on such an occasion the calm English air is vibrant with something akin to excitement.

A seven-goal, second-half outburst enabled the No. 1 Squadron A team to overcome the West Orange riders, 11 -- 8, in the featured match of an indoor polo double-header at the Squadron A Armory last night. The Squadron A triumph followed the Squadron A Blues 14-to-4 setback by the Brooklyn Polo Club.

Two great "clouds" of galaxies or extra-galactic nebulae larger than any heretofore known have been discovered at Lick Observatory of the University of California. The discovery may lead to a new concept of the distribution of "island universes."

DETROIT, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The auto industry's record-breaking vehicle output this year will have a wholesale value of about $8,000,000,000. This figure is based by the Automobile Manufacturers Association on an indicated production of 6,200,000 cars and trucks.
BOSTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau tonight issued this report of winter sports conditions in New England:

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10 -- What to do about unemployment in the face of unslackened westward migration was an uppermost topic of discussion on the West Coast this week. California, at an employment conference called by Gov. Earl Warren, offered a laboratory in which the other Coast States, as well as the Federal Government, took a deep interest.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Canisius rattled through the first half tonight but regained its poise in time to trip Kansas State, 54 -- 51. In the second game of a college basketball double-header before 11.127 spectators in Memorial Auditorium.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 10 -- Tight Squeeze, winner of the Inaugural Handicap, made it two in a row at Tropical Park today when he easily annexed the De Soto purse, streaking home four lengths clear of Windsor Farms' Loriot.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 10 -- Australia swung to the right today and deposed her Labor Government. After eight years of Socialist rule the country elected a coalition of the Liberal and Country parties.

American colleges in Near Eastern countries will be aided by the proceeds from "Lucia di Lammermoor," with Lily Pons, Jan Peerce, Francesco Valentino, Jerome Hines, Felix Knight and Leslie Chabay in the leading roles on the afternoon of Dec. 27 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- A 27-page pamphlet entitled "Essentials of Adoption Law and Procedure" has issued today by the Children's Bureau of the Federal Security Agency. The bureau has made a close study of adoptions for more than twenty years.

TO give teen-aged boys this fast-moving post-war cloak-and-dagger yarn, the author has brought together two former members of the O.S.S., ex-lieutenant "Dutch Kane and ex-master sergeant Sam Marusaki, a Japanese-American who is an old friend of Kane's.
A new "spy investigation" attracted national attention last week and shed light on some of the psychological aspects of the present American scene.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 -- Sweeping changes to modernize the 46-year-old American Power Boat Association, ruling body for the sport of speed boating, were adopted today at a special meeting of the National Council, followed by a session of delegates from many boating centers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The American Legion announced today it would sponsor an "All-America Conference" of 100 national organizations in New York City next month with the aim of solidifying public knowledge and support of the constitutional form of government.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., Dec. 10 -- New Jersey's six-day season for modern Robin Hoods ended at sunset today with the archers setting a new Garden State record for killing deer by the ancient method.

STOWE, Vt., Dec. 10 -- Brilliant sunshine, crisp, freezing weather and snows from twenty to thirty inches blanketing the huge network of slopes and trails today provided an ideal setting for the third week-end of skiing at Mount Mansfield, Vermont's highest peak at 4,500 feet. The symbol of the ski flutters throughout this peaceful New England winterland, whose diversity of facilities and deep snows lure thousands to Stowe for recreation each winter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- With the skill of men who have fought many times over the same terrain, the pro and anti-civil-rights forces now draw themselves up for a great Senate struggle early in the new year.
HONG KONG, Dec. 10 -- The Province of Yunnan appeared today to have turned against the Nationalists and lined itself up with the Communists.

MORTON DOWNEY, once introduced by Bing Crosby as the world's oldest choir boy, commands the unique position of a veteran radio tenor who has survived the age of the baritones. In recent years the boys with the tonsil tones have ripped the air waves like an armada of locusts, but all the while Downey has weathered the onslaught, even making a comeback.

ANTHOLOGIES, a matter of taste like neckties and wives, are the most difficult of books to criticize. Often they seem to have no real reason for being beyond the reason that validates, say, a memory-book or a private collection of one's favorite pieces.

LONDON, Dec. 10 (Reuters) -- Liverpool's unbeaten string was snapped at nineteen games today on a slippery field at Huddersfield. The league soccer leader bowed for the first time this season after setting the pace at halftime, 2--1.

Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, president of the United Nations General Assembly, Mrs. Romulo, and several Assembly delegates were special guests of the Metropolitan Opera Guild yesterday at the matinee performance of "Manon Lescaut."

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 6 -- About one-fifth of the world's population is now within the jurisdiction of the newly established "People's Courts" of Communist China. So far there is no legal code by which to determine cases.

Yesterday's announcement in Washington that this country will entertain Liaqat Ali Khan, Prime Minister of Pakistan, in the spring is gratifying. The visit itself is a good idea and it fits in admirably with our plans to make and keep friends. Our relations with the Indo-Pakistan subcontinent in the past have not been close.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report will present to Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson on Tuesday an award for "courageous" efforts to unify the military establishment and cut defense costs.

A SMALL man, eyes wide with excitement, darted out of the basement of L Building in Bellevue Hospital and clambered up the fire-escape to the roof nine stories above, hotly pursued by a grim-visaged detective with gun in hand.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- In that considerable stretch of territory from China's coast to the African Gold Coast, the United States, Britain and France seem to be finding considerable room for disagreement.

Pennsylvania's Republican Senator said in an address here last night that the Government was on a "spending spree" but his Democratic colleague, speaking from the same platform, said that it was easier to inveigh against spending than to indicate where cuts should be made.

HERE is a book which invites the reader to think about the problem of personal existence in our time. The author, who teaches at McCormick Theological Seminary, Chicago, believes that modern man is driven by the apparently indefinite power he may hope to pyramid and the number of goods he may accumulate.

THIS is a rather innocent-looking book with a title that puts one off, but before we are done with it, we have recognized in Sir Osbert a strong, subdued poetic fire, a hatred of injustice, and at times an almost savagely ironic understanding.

The unusual experience of a concert devoted entirely to the literature of piano and strings was offered yesterday afternoon at Times Hall by Emma Boynet and the Loewenguth Quartet of Paris The nearest thing to a standard work on the program was the Franck Quintet, for the other two works.

World opinion, acting through the United Nations General Assembly, is exerting steady and persistent pressure upon the great powers to settle their disputes through "conciliation and accommodation," Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, President of the Assembly, said yesterday as the 1949 session closed.

DALLAS, Tex., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Declaring "the coaches must assume responsibility for preventing dirty play," the Southwest Conference faculty committee censured coaches and players of the University of Arkansas for what occurred in the Arkansas-Texas Christian football game last fall.

NOTRE DAME, Ind., Dec. 10 -- Four years of work of the United Nations have taught the lesson that lasting world peace is unattainable without the establishment of a universally accepted system of law deriving its sanction ultimately from God, Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, President of the United Nations General Assembly, said here today.

The United Nations General Assembly yesterday at Flushing Meadow approved Adrian Pelt, United Nations Assistant Secretary General for conferences and general services, as Commissioner for Libya to administer the former Italian colony until it becomes independent on Jan. 1, 1952.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 10 -- Confidential sources here today named A. Mihailov, a Soviet representative in Sofia, as the man behind the trial of Traicho Kostov and the party purge that has been going on in Bulgaria.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- George F. Kennan, Counselor of the State Department, plans to give up public life for a year or two, starting next summer, it was learned from friends today. He was spending the week-end at his farm in Pennsylvania and could not be reached for comment.

Leaders of the manifold and often conflicting parts of the investment securities business have just taken time out for a good look at where the private financial markets are heading. They hope to chart realistically the future place of the securities business in the nation's economic life and the best means of getting there.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 10 (UP) -- A speedy Little Rock football squad scored in every period today to defeat Santa Ana, 25 to 19, and capture the national junior college championship in the fourth annual Little Rose Bowl game.

JEFFREY PINE on Sentinel Dome is one of twenty-four full page photographs by Ansel Adams appearing in his album, "My Camera in Yosemite Valley" (Boston: Houghton, Mifflin Company, $10). Mr. Adams' artistry with the camera is revealed in scenes of the Valley's great rock formations, its forests, waterfalls and less familiar by-ways.

AN international contest second in intensity only to the atomic race is the struggle for supremacy in jet planes. American spokesmen have said this country equals or surpasses any other nation in jet engine development; Britain has claimed record after record; Russia, through Lieut. Gen. Vassily Stalin, has said Soviet pilots fly "farther, faster and higher" than any others in the world.

MADRID, Dec. 10 -- Heavy rains in the last days of November saved Spain from a disastrous grain shortage in the coming year, according to experts here. After having suffered the worst of a long succession of dry years, Spain faced a complete failure of the next harvest when sudden rains saved the day.

IN the past few years, more and more people have been buying "living" Christmas trees which may be planted outdoors after the holidays to become a permanent part of the property. Cut trees, of course, are still most in demand with this year's crop for New York City expected to total around 675,000.

THE American frontiersman, that hardy fellow, half horse and half alligator, would be the last to admit it, but much of the humor he thought up and was amused by acted as a kind of defensive armament. Most of it was based on exaggeration of an elemental sort, and some of it was based on simulated igno

St. John's University, off to a flying start this season and determined to maintain its high estate in basketball, gave another impressive performance last night. Opposed by a Rhode Island State team that proved troublesome in the first half, the Redmen none the less registered a 75-54 triumph before 18,000 persons at Madison Square Garden.
I am delighted to note the storm of criticism that has broken over the temporarily thoughtless head of Chester Bowles anent his article, "The Independent Voter Isn't Independent." * * *

The names of fifty-two additional patronesses for the annual luncheon of the Salvation Army Association on Wednesday in the Waldorf-Astoria were announced yesterday by Mrs. Oscar M. Burke, chairman of the event.

THE American Men of Letters Series, an editorial venture undertaken but two years ago by four distinguished American scholars and critics, is a series of which this country should be vastly proud. Four volumes have already appeared, on Cooper, Hawthorne, E.A. Robinson and Thoreau; seventeen more are on the way.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- New York City's wholesale marketing facilities for perishable foods were described by a House Agriculture subcommittee today as "probably the most antiquated, crowded and inefficient" in the United States.

Pension demands of labor over the last several weeks highlighted by the recent steel strike, have reached a point where no finance officer of a major corporation can afford to ignore the subject, according to views expressed here last week at the two-day conference on financial problems, sponsored by the American Management Association.

RUDYARD KIPLING'S "Kim," which has been on and off the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer production schedule for twelve years, finally went before the cameras last week in Lucknow with the blessing of the new Indian Government, which has apparently decided that British imperialism is now a matter of history.

America's colleges face a breakdown of morale and a lowering of academic standards because of a lack of cooperation among administrators, faculty, students and trustees, Prof. Alonzo F. Myers, chairman of New York University's Department of Higher Education, declared yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Grains climbed steadily higher on the Board of Trade today in a fairly active market. The December contracts, aided by a good deal of short covering, led the advance. Corn contracts came close to their seasonal high marks.

Books in handsome bindings, Egyptian and other antiquities, modern paintings and French period furniture and decorations will be auctioned this week at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, in four sales.

FAITHFUL readers of the late Mrs. Hill's seventy-nine religious romances will be comforted and inspired by this post-humous appearance of her short stories. They will find here the same starry world which she created for them over the years with regularity of purpose and execution.

The second in the series of three dances for young people, known as the Gotham Juniors, will be a tea dance on Dec. 22 at the Cosmopolitan Club for preparatory school students. The party at the club has been arranged through the courtesy of Mrs. Hildreth Meiere.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange experienced a rather quiet session yesterday and prices at the close were 1 to 5 points net lower.
BOSTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Navy's cool basketball forces fended off a hard-driving Harvard finish tonight to emerge victorious, 70 -- 68 at the Boston Garden.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- Cicero, where Al Capone once set up headquarters, today was again in the crime spotlight following the gang-land-style assassination last night of Frank J. Christenson, 44 years old, former Cook County assistant state's attorney and militant foe of gambling while he served as an official of the suburb.

THIS excellent translation of a book recently awarded the Stalin prize makes available in English the Soviet version of the U.S.S.R.'s economic history before 1917. Written by a scholar who first achieved academic reputation before Lenin seized power, this work is representative of the finest kind of social science scholarship that can probably be achieved under Soviet conditions.

FUNDAMENTALLY, man is not a rational animal. It is this that makes fiction so difficult to write; for the reader, or the spectator of a play, demands, at all events today, that he should behave as if he were. We feel dissatisfied when the persons of a story do not act from motives that we accept as sufficient.

When Larry MacPhail stepped out of the Yankee baseball picture, taking with him his million dollars in "capital gains," that marked the day of decision for the club to pull out of professional football.
I have read with great interest the two lively and challenging articles by Robert Moses, "The City's Museums -- A Fresh Appraisal" and "Some Prescriptions."

Ways and means of streamlining the program of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. indoor championship, which have become somewhat unwieldy as a result of swollen entry lists in the last few years, will be considered at a games committee meeting here on Dec. 28, it was disclosed yesterday.

AFTER the premiere of Kay Kyser's "College of Musical Knowledge" it is not likely that even the Russians will claim they invented television. The band leader's first show on NBC video (9 P. M. Thursday) turned out to be a gala excursion in tedium, consisting of about equal parts of questionable quiz and corny charade.

IN America Edith Sitwell's collected poems have long been out of print, and the first step toward rectifying that lapse in recognition of her gifts is made with the publication of her present volume, a new selection of her poems.

CHILDREN come first at Christmas; the day is second to none in their calendar, not even the happy one in June on which school closes. As gifts for children to give to playmates, or for oldsters to present to youngsters, this column suggests the popcorn dolls pictured today.
Duncan A. Brownlie has been appointed industry manager of the Reynolds Metals Company's metal products division, with offices in Louisville, Ky.

I ACCEPT Mr. Davidson's plea that the jacket sought only to condense Professor Mises' views. I must still chide him for making the reader wait for the above letter to learn of the fact and also for the somewhat florid character of his condensations.

"With such evidence of an augmenting and multiplying wealth and population * * * that she be to this country what London is to England, it must be a matter of profound regret that she is destitute of a supply of good and wholesome water * * *."

A record budget of $49,641,773 to run the United Nations, including a special increase of $8,000,000 to internationalize Jerusalem, was approved yesterday by the General Assembly at Flushing Meadow with no country opposed, but with Israel voting "no" on the specific item for the Holy City.

WARSAW, Dec. 10 -- After a week's lull French-Polish relations again took a turn for the worse tonight when the French announced that the Poles had ordered the expulsion of another member of the French diplomatic colony.

THE duty of a conscientious reviewer is, surely, to report on what a book contains, permitting himself an occasional note of mild surprise about what it does not contain, and to say, as objectively as may be, whether he thinks the author has done his job well or ill. But Andre Malraux forces his reader into an exceptional frame of mind which the reviewer must perforce take into account.

The Norwegian America Line's new flagship, the Oslofjord, left here yesterday afternoon on the return leg of her maiden voyage. She was bedecked for the approaching holiday season, the decorations including large lighted Norwegian spruce trees lashed to her two masts.

St. Barnabas House will be the beneficiary of the performance of "La Traviata," with Licia Albanese, Ferruccio Tagliavini and Leonard Warren, on the night of Jan. 24 at the Metropolitan Opera House. Mrs. Kelly Muir is chairman and Mrs. John McMaster and Mrs. William Raymond, co-chairmen, of the executive committee in charge of the sale of boxes and seats.

WHEN Lincoln Steffens investigated Boston shortly after the turn of the century everyone told him that one of the worst politicians in that politics-ridden city was Martin Lomasney, undisputed boss of old Ward Eight, which took in the impoverished and teeming North End.
Christmas trade forged ahead last week, but dollar volume ran under last year. Department store sales were estimated at about 6 per cent under those of the comparative 1948 week.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 10 -- An exhibition of thirty outstanding drawings from the collection of the Fogg Art Museum at Harvard University marks the publication of a new art book, "One Hundred Master Drawings," edited by Miss Agnes Mongan, it was announced today.

"J. V. Stalin, Military Genius of Our Time," is one of the many roles the great dictator in Moscow will fill next week on his seventieth birthday, when a paean of idolatrous praise swells from a carefully coached chorus behind the Iron Curtain.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 10 -- The Sarajevo trial of ten Russian emigres accused of wartime collaboration with the Germans and post-war collaboration with the Soviet Intelligence Service contained all the elements of a good case history of court procedure and the application of the principles of justice in Communist states of Eastern Europe.

Urging motorists and pedestrians to take special care this month, usually one of the worst in motor accidents, the Greater New York Safety Council reported yesterday that traffic accidents were the only mishaps killing more New Yorkers this year than last.

TWO weeks from now two of the major scheduled airlines of the nation will start air coach service from coast to coast. The two lines are American Airlines and Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., and the fare will be 4.5 cents a mile.

Immediate Federal attention and support are needed to restore adequate port facilities here and in other United States harbors that suffered from heavy wartime use when the Federal Government commandeered all facilities without making repairs or improvements.

Construction of a superliner for the United States Lines, a project now under way at the yards of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, might well be the "spark" urgently needed to rekindle this country's interest in its merchant marine, according to Rear Admiral Paul F. Lee, USN, retired, vice president of Gibbs Cox, Inc., naval architects who designed the vessel.

The Rev. Angelo Volpicella, who was one of the twenty Italian priests brought to this country in June by Cardinal Spellman to serve in understaffed parishes, said yesterday he wanted to learn the English language as soon as possible, become an American citizen and live in this country for the rest of his life.

When the clock strikes twelve tonight, it will be St. Lucy's Day, celebrated in Sweden as a feast that ushers in the Christmas season with all the excitement we Americans associate with Christmas Eve. But the gustatory delights that go along with the holiday won't be confined to Sweden.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- British and United States experts on the Middle East, who have recently examined plans for economic development in the Arab League states, have estimated that a total outlay of 140,000,000 in foreign capital would be needed for projects now contemplated.

Sujata and Asoko, dancers from India, gave a program of dances last night at the Ziegfeld Theatre under the patronage of Mme. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, Ambassador of India, and R. R. Saksena, Indian Consul General.
Sales of dwellings formed the bulk of realty deals reported in Brooklyn over the week-end.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 11 -- A golden jubilee reception was held today for John F. Moors of Brookline, a trustee of Radcliffe College for fifty years.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Twenty-three Republican members of Congress today assailed the Census Bureau.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. has given securities valued at $500,000, his second gift of this size to the New York University - Bellevue Medical Center, it was announced yesterday by Nevil Ford, chairman of the public appeal for the center.

Changing a pile of mixed greens into a salad seems to bring out hidden dramatic talents in many persons. To set the "stage" for such occasions there are interesting new serving accessories in unusual woods.

Professional football bowed out of the local scene for 1949 quietly yesterday as the Pittsburgh Steelers, keeping their National League date with the Bulldogs, humbled the New York eleven, 27 -- 0, at the Polo Grounds. Only a handful of spectators -- the official figures of 4.028 appeared way out of line -- turned out to watch the proceedings.

AMSTERDAM, Dec. 11 -- Figures just published on the distribution of the occupational population between 1930 and 1947 reflect a reduction of productive elements among the Dutch population for purely administrative purposes.

A group of six buildings occupying a plot 190 by 100 feet at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and East Eighty-ninth Street was sold by Chisholm Realty Corporation to an investing client of Max A. Gulack, attorney, in a deal reported over the week-end by Hugo Taenzer, the broker. The property is assessed for $448,000, of which $398,500 is land value.

ZURICH, Dec. 11 -- Swiss-owned British Government sterling bonds deposited in Britain were changing hands here last week at a disagio 40 per cent below the new sterling rate, thus reaching the lowest level since sterling was devalued. First-class sterling securities were obtainable in Zurich at 7 Swiss francs to the pound price in Britain -- sterling parity being 12.25 francs.

BOSTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Jack Gelineau, the National Hockey League's rookie goalie, turned in his second shut-out of the season to give the Boston Bruins a 2-0 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight before 11,053 at the Boston Garden.

Almost all of the interest in the foreign exchange market last week centered in the slowly ebbing value of the Canadian free dollar which on Friday sold down to 87.82 cents, a new low since devaluation in mid-September; the close was 88 cents, a loss of 1 1/8 cents from the previous week. Monday's rate was 89.25 cents.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Dec. 11 (UP) -- A coal range, overheated by wood being burned in it, was blamed tentatively today for the fire at midnight which caused the death of eight children. Through a freak accident, Mr. and Mrs. Bert Edkins were outside the frame house in the snow while their children perished in the blaze.

In a ceremony in front of the Park Avenue entrance to the Seventh Regiment Armory at Sixty-sixth Street, the Christmas trees along Park Avenue were lit last night and dedicated as a memorial to the men of the United States armed forces who died in World War II.

Central Park South will undergo an improvement next spring somewhat similar to the more ambitious job just carried out at Forty-second Street, Borough President Hugo E. Rogers of Manhattan announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Compliance with the non-Communist affidavit requirements of the Taft-Hartley Law has reached a peak with 108,345 union officials and 11,345 local labor organizations having filed the necessary papers.

ROME, Dec. 11 -- Pope Pius will proclaim as a dogma the assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary to heaven at a solemn ceremony in St. Peter's, probably during the forthcoming Holy Year, Vatican circles said today.

The Mergenthaler Linotype Company has announced that net sales in the twelve months to Sept. 30, 1949, were $23,124,530, or $2,927,366 more than in the preceding twelve months. Net income was $3,354,103, a rise of $1,174,471 over the $2,179,632 cleared a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- A collection of several thousand scientific and medical books was presented tonight to the Hebrew University at Jerusalem as "the gift of the American people."

A very pleasant debut recital was offered yesterday in the Carnegie Hall "Twilight Series" by the lyric soprano Costanza Pillori. This young artist, who studied here and in Italy, already has made a number of appearances in concert and opera.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Rams blasted their way into the Western Division title of the National Football League today, walloping the Washington Redskins in merciless fashion, 53 to 27, to earn the right to battle the Philadelphia Eagles here for the loop championship next Sunday.
Most of the country's 400,000 soft-coal miners may be out on a new strike Jan. 1.

Blanche Thebom sang the role of Dalila for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera House on Saturday night, when the association presented Saint-Saens "Samson et Dalila" for the second time this season. Her conception of the role was original and lent conviction to the opera.

Spotting their rivals a lead of three goals in the opening period, the Grand Rapids Rockets responded with a strong offensive in the succeeding sessions to defeat the New York Rovers in the Eastern Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden yesterday, 5 to 3.

City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses attacked yesterday State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman's program for the construction of tax-exempt housing projects under the state's limited dividend housing law as a too generous "waiving" of city taxes without the approval of appropriate city authorities.

Gounod's "Faust," which has not been done at the Metropolitan Opera for the last two seasons, will be restored to the repertoire on Dec. 23 with a new Faust in the person of Giuseppe Di Stefano and a new Mephistopheles in Italo Tajo.

Vladimir Padwa, a musician with a distinguished European background at present with the New York College of Music, appeared at Town Hall yesterday in the dual role of pianist and composer. A group of Mr. Padwa's compositions occupied the central place on the program,

The Sydney Sun suggests that the Australian vote reflected "the rebellion of Mrs. Australia, the housewife, fed up with restrictions, shortages and controls." The Sun, an anti-Labor paper, found support for this statement in the fight of Mrs. Nancy Wake, who campaigned in behalf of housewives against Dr. Herbert Evatt, one of the most prominent figures in international as well as domestic policies, and cut down his former two-to-one majority to something over 2,000.

Leaving the gravy city of New York yesterday in search of Florida sunshine, Mayor O'Dwyer described himself as "a refugee from a hospital." He is, in fact, a victim of one of the world's hardest jobs. His most active political opponents would never deny that he works at that job with a soldierly devotion to duty and gives it the last ounce of his strength.

MOSCOW, Dec. 11 -- The All-Union Soviet Book Chamber reported today that the circulation of Premier Joseph Stalin's writings in the Soviet Union had now reached 539,000,000 copies in 101 languages, making the Soviet leader the most widely read author in the world.

Three years ago, on Dec. 11, 1946, the General Assembly created the International Children's Emergency Fund, to carry on the child-rescue phase of UNRRA operations, then closing down. Shortly after, the Fund determined that at least 20,000,000 European children and many more millions in the Near and Far East were in direst need of foods to counteract malnutrition and disease; the yearly cost was put at $20 a child.

Furniture retailers will pass along to the consumers all wholesale price increases put into effect by manufacturers, Manfred I. Behrens Jr., vice president and general manager of Ludwig Baumann, declared over the week-end. The steady reduction in retailer gross margins and net profits in the last several years makes absorption of the latest wave of wholesale price increases a "physical impossibility," he said.

Retailers emphasizing price appeal on cashmere sweaters are doing themselves and their resources a great disservice, according to Sidney S. Korzenik, executive director and counsel of the National Knitted Outerwear Association.

The ban on fresh Christmas decorations in places of public assembly has been liberalized slightly, it was disclosed yesterday when the Fire Department issued its annual warning on the fire hazards involved in the use of Christmas trees.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 11 -- Just like it started, the All-America Football Conference ended today with the Cleveland Browns monarchs of all they surveyed in the ill-fated field. It ended after four long years of trials, tribulations and costly experiments, but behind the disappointments, the disillusionments and financial setbacks involving millions of dollars, remained the unshaken conviction of the powers-that-were that because of their efforts the standards of the professional gridiron sport were raised.

Sales of municipal bond issues scheduled this week total $87,013,423, a rise of $52,109,374 over the $34,904,049 of municipal bonds sold last week. The weekly average of offerings for the year to date is $68,298,730, according to the Daily Bond Buyer.

An American edition of Robert Merle's novel, "Week-End at Zuydcoote," which last week won the Prix Goncourt, the most important French literary award, is planned for publication next year by Knopf. It deals with a group of French soldiers in the fighting in the Dunkerque area.
J. C. Penney, honorary chairman of the board of directors of the J. C. Penney Company, looked back yesterday to his boyhood days as a hog raiser to illustrate the Golden Rule in business dealings.

A study of the life and works of Rex Beach, deceased novelist, impels the Catholic Writers Guild of America to express its appreciation of the man and the writer. He has ever been intolerant of morbid or erotic ideas.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 11 -- There was no let-up last week in demand for steel, nor is one expected for some months to come, according to late reports here, except for a dip this month under holiday influences. During this period, however, some plants may pay overtime to keep production going.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11 (AP) -- James A. Rhodes, outgoing president of the Amateur Athletic Union, took sharp issue today with Avery Brundage, head of the United States Olympic Association over the subject of athletic scholarships vs. amateurism.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- An easier undertone developed in the grain markets on the Board of Trade last week, wheat and corn being off around 3 cents a bushel from the close of the previous week at one time, but a strong rally came later and the greater part of the loss was recovered.

Edward J. Shaughnessy, director of the New York District of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service, asserted yesterday that if a bill in Congress to admit 137,000 additional displaced persons were adopted the problem of such persons as known in this country would be solved.

Thousands of Protestant congregations throughout the country attended services yesterday at which emphasis was put upon reading the Bible. The day had been set aside as Universal Bible Sunday under a project of the American Bible Society, which annually provides reading lists for use daily from Thanksgiving until Christmas.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Dec. 11- Lifting of the morning fog and the stir of a breeze meant dinghy racing today at the Larchmont Yacht Club. The breeze, east by north, was easy.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Playing his finest game in two years as a Chicago Bear quarterback, Johnny Lujack flipped six touchdown passes and set a National Football League record with an aerial gain of 468 yards as his team routed the Chicago Cardinals, 52 -- 21.

RONKONKOMA, L. I., Dec. 11 -- With only two weeks left before Christmas, the family of John Kilgore, 67 years old, was not surprised last night when he disappeared for the evening into his hobby shop behind his home on Hawkins Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Department of Commerce reported today that publicly reported cash dividends of United States corporations in October aggregated $463,500,000. This was 2 per cent less than the $474,600,000 distributed in October, 1948. Publicly reported dividends are 60 to 65 per cent of all cash dividends paid.

Good planning and the gumption to carry it out have paid off in Nassau County's water supply, and while the method is not applicable to all areas the general principle is certainly worth study everywhere. This principle is to conserve run-off water instead of letting it drain into streams or ocean.

The growth of college lacrosse was reflected yesterday as the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association, at its sixty-seventh annual meeting at the Hotel Statler, added five colleges to the rolls to bring the total membership to thirty-eight, an all-time high and double what it was at the end of World War II.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UP) -- Officials of the Department of Agriculture said today that many farmers apparently have cut down wheat plantings this fall for fear the bottom may drop out of the market next summer.
Bellevue Hospital had an unexpected patient yesterday -- a small brown and white dog, breed, age and address undetermined, but destined to answer henceforth to the name of Whitey.
CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks fell into the National Hockey League cellar before 15,754 fans tonight when they lost to the Montreal Canadiens, 3 to 0.

NEW RICHMOND, Ohio, Dec. 11 -- Judge John W. Haussermann, president of the Benguet Consolidated Mining Company in the Philippine Islands, said tonight at his home here that American business interests in the Philippines need not be alarmed by the foreign exchange control just placed in effect there.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 11 (Reuters) -- A conference here representing 15,000,000 Protestants in East Asia declared today that the conflict between Christianity and communism was "fundamental."

At odd intervals, Joshua Logan, an important cog in any attraction, has been billed as co-producer. With "The Wisteria Trees," his own variation of "The Cherry Orchard," laid in a Louisiana locale at the turn of the century, Mr. Logan will step out as an independent producer.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Tons of the most modern photographic paraphernalia were loaded aboard the Ras al Ardh of the Marine Transport Line today in preparation for the embarking of the first expedition of the American Foundation for the Study of Man.

Midwinter is the season when many social and sports events take place for the young people. The skating ponds in town and country are show places for colorful twirling skirts. So-called after-ski clothes are the fashions for ski lodges.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 11 -- Leading personalities of the big German banks during the Nazi period are making their way back into banking institutions in Western Germany and initiating practices that appear to be developing monopolies, it was reported by a high German source today.

MANHASSET, L. I., Dec. 11 -- Despite one of the most extraordinary rallies ever seen on a court, Philadelphia was beaten by New York, 2-1, today in the final of the Payne Whitney Memorial court tennis doubles tournament. It was the third successive triumph for New York in this annual fixture held in honor of the memory of one of the famous patrons of the sport of kings.

A radio description of the historical ceremonies attendant to Pope Pius XII's proclamation of the start of the new Holy Year will be carried by the National Broadcasting Company in an hour-long program on Christmas Day. The broadcast from Vatican City will be sent by shortwave to NBC here, where it will be transcribed and played back on the air at 2 P. M.
MADRID, Dec. 11 -- Tennessee Williams has aroused a minor storm among theatregoers here by refusing to permit his play, "A Streetcar Named Desire," to be produced in Spain.

Fighting their league - leading rivals gamely all the way to the final whistle, the New York Rangers scored a 2-to-1 victory over the Detroit Red Wings in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The tussle was a torrid one and thrilled a crowd of 15,035 fans, who followed the play intently until the final whistle.

The first military craft to be designed and built for cycloidal propulsion is undergoing sea trials off the South Carolina coast, according to officials of the Army Transportation Corps Board who have just returned from Charleston. The experimental vessel is the Army mine planter Truman O. Olson.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Officials of A. M. Byers Company, manufacturer of wrought iron, charged today that a New York group is trying to obtain control of the concern and has incorrectly stated certain facts in a "solicitation letter to Byers' stockholders."

Official state approval of the new graduate program at Adelphi College for training psychiatric personnel in the fields of nursing, teaching, social work and psychology has just been received, Dr. Paul Dawson Eddy, president of the college, announced yesterday.

The nineteen women and eighteen men of the Fleur-De-Lis Choral Ensemble celebrated their third anniversary as a group yesterday afternoon by giving their first downtown concert at Times Hall. They were led by Clyde S. Turner, who also made most of their arrangements.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 11 -- When counting of ballots in the Australian general election ceased tonight the triumphant Liberal - Country party coalition held an apparent majority of thirteen seats in the House of Representatives. Counting will continue tomorrow.

The burning last week by the Queens District Attorney's office of several tons of old legal papers has been criticized as "unnecessary" by Miss Rebecca B. Rankin, chairman of the Mayor's Municipal Archives Committee, it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- Dr. Walter Stevenson of Quincy, president of the Illinois State Medical Society, said today that Oscar Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, was "dishonest and deliberately deceptive" when he said in London Friday that the British socialized-medicine program would be "good for" the United States.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 11 -- A move is under way to shift next month's session of the United Nations Trusteeship Council from Geneva to New York during the critical period of setting up an international regime over Jerusalem.

STOWE, Vt., Dec. 11 -- Extraordinary skiing for this time of the year was enjoyed today by some 1,500 enthusiasts, including a large group of winter sports reporters from New England, New York State and Montreal, at the diversified and comprehensive set-up at Mount Mansfield, where the 4,395-foot peak was shrouded in clouds most of the day.
Five new films, including importations from Italy, Sweden and Australia, are scheduled to open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 11 -- Thirty-two Rhodes scholars-elect for 1950 have been chosen from 412 competitors, it was announced today by Dr. Frank Aydelotte, director of the Institute for Advanced Study here and American secretary to the Rhodes trustees.
Support of science by "the church, the Government and the people of the country" was urged yesterday by Dr. James A. Reyniers, director of the Lobund Laboratories of the University of Notre Dame.

Mayor O'Dwyer's choice of William Reid to be Deputy Mayor in his second term, beginning Jan. 1, can be applauded heartily and without reservation. Mr. Reid is a civil servant of more than thirty years' experience in city employ, much of it in intimate relation to financial problems.

Mayor O'Dwyer left the city yesterday at 2:43 P. M. aboard the Atlantic Coast Line Champion for Fort Lauderdale, Fla. There he will seek recuperation from the illness that on Nov. 28 forced him to enter Bellevue Hospital.

ABOARD THE S.S. LAKELAND VICTORY, off Tientsin, China. Monday, Dec. 12 -- Angus Ward and his party of nineteen members of the United States Consulate staff at Mukden were freed from Communist China to this ship of haven today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The famed Third Infantry Regiment, the oldest in the Army, with 165 years of service, has turned to entirely new duties -- one of which requires greeting friends instead of meeting foes.

The German Federal Republic set up in cooperation with Western Allied occupation forces has begun the tedious task of establishing legal ownership of $5,000,000,000 to $6,000,000,000 worth of securities issued by corporations in Western Germany before and during the war.

A baby girl was burned to death at 4 P. M. yesterday in a fire in a two-room rear ground-floor apartment in a six-story brick tenement at 215 Eldridge Street, near Stanton Street, on the lower East Side.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Bob Hamilton and Fred Haas Jr. tied at the end of Miami's $10,000 open golf tournament today with record shattering 264s. They will meet in an eighteen-hole play-off tomorrow.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 11 -- Irving Allen, producing partner in Allen-Dembow productions, recently formed independent company, has concluded a deal with Lew Ayres for the actor to star in and co-direct "New Mexico," a photoplay by Max Trell, which will be photographed in Ansco Color in January at the Motion Picture Center.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 11 (UP) -- The announcement that Prime Minister Liaquat Ali Khan has accepted President Truman's invitation to visit him in Washington was received coldly today by the Pakistani press.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Department of Defense has dropped about 116,000 civilian workers since the start of its economy program last summer, officials said today.

PARIS, Dec. 11 -- Some of the highest officials in France have said that the most important problem at the present moment is the question of returning to free competition. They say that competition alone can result in specialization of industries and in reduction of production costs and increase the chances of developing exports in such a way as to bring in enough hard currencies to balance accounts when the Marshall Plan is ended.

An increasing indifference of Christians to charitable causes soon may force the state to take over this fundamental obligation of the church and its worshipers, the Rev. Albert L. Neibacher, pastor of St. Luke's Evangelical Lutheran Church, 308 West Forty-sixth Street, declared in a sermon yesterday morning.

PACIFIC GROVE, Calif., Dec. 11 -- Vigorous demands for aid to the Chinese Nationalists by Senator William F. Knowland, Republican, of California, and equally emphatic opposition to it by John M. Cabot, former United States Consul General in Shanghai, marked a three-day "China conference" at near-by Asilomar this week-end.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- William M. Boyle Jr., Democratic national chairman, announced today that Charles Luckman, president of the Lever Brothers Company, would be national chairman of the Jefferson-Jackson dinner of 1950.

The New York Foundling Home at 175 East Sixty-eighth Street was tremulous with Christmas happiness yesterday. The city's firemen gave a party for 150 children there with presents for all and singing and clowning. Later there were ice cream and cookies -- everything to bring joy to a young child's heart.

With a sharp rise in sales of women's coats at the retail level, buyers made heavy purchases of coats in the wholesale apparel market here last week, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. The increased demand may enable coat manufacturers to substantially reduce the net loss in units that appeared to be in prospect for 1949, it was said.
The Stalinist interpretation of war apparently has altered since pre-war days, if recent writings of the great dictator are an accurate clue.

The Swiss F. C. gained the verdict over Hakoah, 3 to 1, in a National Challenge Cup match sponsored by the United States Soccer Football Association at Hawthorne Field yesterday. At the change of ends, the victors led, 2 -- 1.

There is, and always has been, a basic cleavage in the field of monetary policy between the central banking authorities (which in the case of this country means the Federal Reserve system) and the Treasury. It is the function of the central bank to regulate the supply and cost of money (credit) in the general interest of national financial and economic stability.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 11 -- After several hours' precarious negotiations, that at times seemed on the verge of collapse, two United States merchant marine officials on duty with the American Economic Cooperation Administration in Korea, Albert E. Willis, 40, of Brooklyn, N. Y., and Alfred T. Meschler, 28, of Kinderhook, N. Y., were released this afternoon by the North Korean (Communist-directed) Government.

Rayon yarn and staple shipments in November totaled 99,700,000 pounds, an increase of 9 per cent above November, 1948, according to a report issued for publication today by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc. For the first eleven months of 1949 shipments totaled 871,300,000 pounds, 13 per cent below shipments in the corresponding period last year.

People who conduct surveys are fond of recording the results of their studies in fractions. A case in point is the survey of undergraduate habits made the other day by Observation Post, a student newspaper published at City College.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 11 -- The main evidence at the Sofia spy trial today dealt with alleged Yugoslav activities against Bulgaria and was only indirectly linked with former Deputy Premier Traicho Kostov, chief defendant of the eleven accused of treason and spying.
DETROIT, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Bob Mann and Bill Dudley led the Detroit Lions to a 21-7 victory over the Green Bay Packers today in a National Football League game before 12,576 fans at Briggs Stadium.

Reconsideration of traditional methods of accounting where foreign exchange is involved has been forced by recent currency devaluation by about twenty-five countries, it was pointed out over the week-end by the American Institute of Accountants.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Minor changes in the scouting and playing structure of Big Ten football and expansion of conference basketball schedules were considered today by league officials at their annual winter meeting.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 11 -- In the second installment of disclosures in connection with the trial of Traicho Kostov, Borba, official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party, has cast serious dubts on the circumstances under which Georgi Dimitrov left Bulgaria for the last time to die near Moscow last July 2.

CRAB ORCHARD LAKE, Ill., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Davellis Wager, owned by David B. Silberman of Chicago, won the third annual national English springer spaniel trials today. The dog was handled by 76-year-old Martin J. Hogan, also of Chicago.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 -- Leading the field of 126 pairs going today into the final sessions of the national open pairs championship, was the team of Mr. and Mrs. Morrie Ellis of New York with a score of 525 1/2 points. In second position, 10 points behind, were Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Fleischer of Atlantic City.

ROME, Dec. 11 -- The Italian Government has decided to authorize one Italian airline to organize service between Rome and New York. The Government's choice is the Linee Aeree Italiane, Italian Air Lines, or LAI, in which Trans World Airlines has a financial interest and which got a loan of $4,500,000 from the Economic Cooperation Administration for the purchase of flying equipment in the United States.

The National Association of Engine Boat Manufacturers will open an extensive campaign on Wednesday for its fortieth annual Motor Boat Show, scheduled to be held Jan. 6 to 14 at Grand Central Palace. Media includes forty-four suburban and twenty-five daily newspapers, with emphasis on New York City newspapers, boating and entertainment magazines and spot commercials over six New York radio stations.
VICTORVILLE, Calif., Dec. 11 (AP) -- A 70-ton slab of rock broke off from Dead Man's Point and crashed into Lucerne Valley today, killing four picnickers and seriously injuring two.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 11 -- A conference possibly involving critical decisions on 1950 fiscal policy -- the mounting deficit, the new taxes that will be demanded, and national income -- was held here this afternoon by President Truman, John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, and Frank Pace Jr., Budget Director.
The city's dwindling water supply dropped still more yesterday despite light rains in the upstate watershed area.

Solicitor General Perlman, in a speech Dec. 2, announced that the Federal Housing Administration would shortly adopt rules under which it would "refuse to aid the financing of any properties the occupancy or use of which is restricted on the basis of race or creed or color."
Tornadoes killed nine persons in Missouri and Arkansas yesterday, increasing to thirty-eight the number of lives lost through violent week-end weather.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- A committee of thirteen leading retailers was announced here today by the National Appliance and Radio Dealers Association to spearhead a fair-trade pricing test program in Greater Chicago. First products to be tested under the program will be refrigerators and television receivers, according to Clif Simpson, managing director of the association, who made the announcement.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 -- Steve Van Buren went on a one-man rampage in the final period today to snuff out the Giants' last hope of bagging second place in the National Football League's Eastern division.

The decisive victory for the "conservatives" in the Australian general election is an event of major world importance, coming as it does immediately after a similar defeat for the Laborites in New Zealand. The latter elections taken by themselves could have been the result of a swing of the pendulum after fourteen years.

The salvation of the free world will come through social reform engendered by a renewal of faith and not through material power, Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, president of the United Nations General Assembly, declared last night.

Hospitals and cemeteries "were not part of God's plan for the world," the Very Rev. John Shields, pastor of St. Alphonsus Roman Catholic Church, Manhattan, declared yesterday in his second Advent sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 11 -- Present resistance to the Communist regime in Bulgaria has reached such proportions that more than 1,0O0,000 acres of fertile land in that small country have remained unplanted with winter crops, according to a survey of agricultural and industrial conditions published today in the Yugoslav newspaper Glas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer indicated today he would ask President Truman to recommend repeal of high wartime excise taxes next year. He also said that business should be good in 1950, although profits might be lower.
China's sorrows have struck hard at a Chinese-American family in Brooklyn, it was brought home to the police here yesterday.

YONKERS, N. Y., Dec. 11 -- Organized labor and many taxpayers oppose the plan of City Manager Donald C. Wagner to discontinue the fifty-year-old system of having city sanitation workers collect garbage and refuse from basements, it was learned today.

Escapism has no place in Christian concepts concerning a future life, the Very Rev. Hughell E. W. Fosbroke, dean emeritus of the General Theological Seminary, declared yesterday morning in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
A group of children representing all grades in St. John's School at Mountain Lakes, N. J., made up a purse of $25, which they sent yesterday to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

Faced with increasing fleet inactivity, the private tankship industry is renewing its efforts to persuade the Navy to relinquish control of fifty-seven tankers it has operated since the 1947 oil famine, according to John W. Bancker, vice president of the American Merchant Marine Institute.

HANOVER, Germany, Dec. 2 -- The most powerful, overt challenge that neo-fascism offers to democracy in Germany is the steadily growing connection among three radical right-wing organizations in the British and United States zones of occupation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- A subcommittee of the Joint Committee on the Economic Report will spend the next ten days considering the situation of the 10,000,000 American families with an income of less than $2,000 a year.

PATERSON, N. J., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Local 669 of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, today rejected a proposed contract clause that provided for the dismissal of workers belonging to a subversive organization. The local, representing 5,000 production workers at the Wright Aeronautical Corporation, said the specific clause would infringe on their basic civil liberties.

The current dispute on industry pensions has implications which go much beyond the question of pensions itself. As THE TIMES states in its editorial "Perspective on Pensions" of Nov. 30, "* * * the pension issue must be approached at the national policy level." And the editorial goes on to second Robert Taft's proposal that the problem "should receive the most careful study from the Senate Finance Committee when it meets in January."

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Argentina claimed the world polo championship today after easily defeating the Meadow Brook team from the United States, 11 -- 5, in the final of an international tournament.

Kirsten Flagstad opened her fourth post-war season in New York last night with a recital at Carnegie Hall. The event gave evidence that old animosities are dying and that the Norwegian soprano is succeeding in singing her way back into the graces of the American public.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- Unity against the Brannan Plan for agriculture prevailed, at least among top leaders of the American Farm Bureau Federation, on the eve of the opening of the federation's thirty-first annual meeting.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The National Labor Relations Board has ruled that the secondary-boycott ban of the Taft-Hartley labor law is not violated when a union of truck drivers pickets an employer's truck at the premises of a customer.

Rains late last summer not only delayed potatoes from maturing, but are the reason now for their turning dark after cooking, according to Dr. E. V. Hardenburg of Cornell University's vegetable crops department. As a remedy he suggests:

HONG KONG, Dec. 11 -- Gen. Lu Han, Governor of Yunnan, who turned the province over to the Communists in a week-end coup, also sought to have Chiang Kaishek captured and held for the Communists in Chengtu, a spokesman for Governor Lu told Chinese newsmen here today.

BOSTON, Dec. 11 -- The impact of Federal policies on the economy of New England will be studied by the National Planning Association and the New England Council, it was announced today by Council President James C. Richdale.

Affirming belief in a significant relationship between the dollar crisis and the soul of man, the Right Rev. Dr. J. Hutchison Cockburn, former Moderator of the Church of Scotland, declared in a sermon here yesterday morning that the world religious community must apply its Christian principles to international problems or be bound by the "iron ties of an authoritarian dictatorship."
The Zionist Organization of America pledged full support yesterday to Premier David Ben-Gurion of Israel in any action he might take to prevent the internationalization of Jerusalem.

Kirsten Flagstad opened her fourth post-war season in New York last night with a recital at Carnegie Hall. The event gave evidence that old animosities are dying and that the Norwegian soprano is succeeding in singing her way back into the graces of the American public.

BOSTON, Dec. 11 -- The impact of Federal policies on the economy of New England will be studied by the National Planning Association and the New England Council, it was announced today by Council President James C. Richdale.

Affirming belief in a significant relationship between the dollar crisis and the soul of man, the Right Rev. Dr. J. Hutchison Cockburn, former Moderator of the Church of Scotland, declared in a sermon here yesterday morning that the world religious community must apply its Christian principles to international problems or be bound by the "iron ties of an authoritarian dictatorship."
