The Zionist Organization of America pledged full support yesterday to Premier David Ben-Gurion of Israel in any action he might take to prevent the internationalization of Jerusalem.

It was a big week-end for Blanche Thebom. On Saturday night she sang her first Dalila at the Metropolitan Opera and yesterday afternoon she gave a recital in Town Hall. It was the fourth for the richly endowed mezzo-soprano since her debut in 1944 and was enthusiastically received by a large audience.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 11 -- The Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds, the national organization of 265 welfare funds in this country, closing its eighteenth annual general assembly here today, unanimously adopted a series of resolutions designed to strengthen national fund-raising in 1950 for Jewish needs in Israel, overseas and in communities of this country.

MOSCOW, Dec. 11 -- The United States wartime lend-lease program actually was a "weapon of American imperialism" designed to capture markets for United States capitalists, the Soviet review, Problems of Economy, declared today in a study of the wartime financing of capitalist powers.
ATLANTA, Dec. 11 (AP) -- A proposal to put cotton under a two-price system and knock out Federal subsidies was approved yesterday by Southern Agricultural Commissioners.
GENEVA, Dec. 3 -- To European eyes there is a growing disparity between doctrine and practice in the conduct of United States economic policy.

Bishop Charles K. Gilbert of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York dedicated yesterday morning a "Tree of Life" window and the Chapel of St. Peter at All Angels Church, Eighty-first Street and West End Avenue.

PARIS, Dec. 11 -- Expert opinion in this European capital of the Marshall Plan is that the projected trade bloc of France, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg will not achieve a great deal toward freeing trade within Europe, and that the proposed closer linking of Britain with Scandinavia will achieve still less.

BERLIN, Dec. 11 -- Accusations practically identical with those raised against the Yugoslav Military Mission are published today in Taegliche Rundschau, Soviet Army paper, regarding the Brazilian Military Mission, indicating that the next few days will bring a similar ban against its members entering the territory of the Eastern German Democratic Republic, including the eastern sector of Berlin.

A warm air mass from the South, moving into the metropolitan area, gave pedestrian New Yorkers relief from cold weather yesterday, but because of the fog it caused was far less kind to air travelers and motorists.

MADRID, Dec. 11 -- The most important question in Spain's relations with the United States is not what the United States is going to do about Spain but what Spain is going to do about the United States, a Congressional subcommittee announced here today as it left for Lisbon after a two-day visit.

Despite an estimated shut-in crude oil production in this country of more than a million barrels daily, virtually all United States oil companies are planning a further increase in imports into this country next year. While economic and other factors will play some part in what the increase will be, it is estimated in the industry that it will be about 25 per cent over that for 1949.

A bridegroom of four months was arrested on robber charges at 9 P. M. yesterday in the IRT Subway Station at Times Square after he had been spotted in Washington Heights and trailed downtown by a clerk who had witnessed a $4,000 payroll hold-up on Oct. 19 in the garment section.

The war against cancer got new impetus last night with the announcement that John D. Rockefeller Jr. had pledged $2,000,000 toward a $5,250,000 construction and teaching program at Memorial Hospital, 444 East Sixty-eighth Street.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 12 -- The opening of debate today on a bill to revise the ancient Hindu code on marriage, divorce, inheritance and other matters -- the most controversial and far - reaching measure ever to come before the Indian Legislature -- brought 500 angry demonstrators to Council House, the Parliament building.
Savings resulting from mechanization and continued expense control measures have enabled Western Union Telegraph Company to operate on a profitable basis for the second consecutive month this year.

A bruin that tips the scales at 558 pounds is a big b'ar, even in the Smokies, but word came via the Tar Heel grapevine that one this size had been brought in by Hack Smithdeal and his Plott hounds while hunting the swamps near Elizabethtown, N. C.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- By refusing, 5 to 3 to review a lower court decision, the Supreme Court, to all intents, sustained today an Idaho law forbidding picketing of a business establishment not directly affected in a labor dispute.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- A Congressional committee proposed tonight to limit cotton acreage cuts to individual farmers while a group of Texas growers tossed the problem into district court.
Pierre Etchebaster, 56-year-old monarch of court tennis, successfully defended yesterday the world open title he has held since 1928.

SOFIA, Dec. 12 -- The public prosecutor demanded today the death penalty for Traicho Kostov and the ten other defendants in the Sofia treason trial. In closing the state's case, he said that no mercy should be shown to a "gang of spies, traitors and saboteurs."
Beginning today, questionnaires will be sent to the 1,200 members of the American Football Coaches Association to ascertain whether the rules for college football in 1950 should be changed.

Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York, at its annual meeting last night, elected Saul F. Dribben, textile merchant, as president. He succeeds Lewis L. Strauss, member of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, who has been president since 1937.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 12 -- On the eve of the Government's debate on the policy to be followed concerning Jerusalem, the United States has advised Israel not to take any "inflammatory" steps that might endanger relations with the Arabs or the Vatican, it was learned tonight.

WAITSFIELD, Vt., Dec. 12 -- example of how skiing has created a community dedicated to the recreation -- just like the settlements in Scandinavia along the Gulbrandsdalen Valley in Norway or Jamtland in Sweden -- is to be found in Mad River Valley over which towers 3,570-foot Stark Mountain.
The city of San Francisco borrowed yesterday $21,245,000 on seven bond issues to finance miscellaneous improvements at an interest cost of 1.4099 per cent.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Sensational riding by Sammy Boulmetis of Baltimore highlighted the program at Tropical Park today. By kicking home three winners through the first five races, the apprentice became the undisputed leader for the riding honors of the meeting, stretching his total to twelve.

The State Public Service Commission will try to determine today whether it has jurisdiction to deal with the question of daily "broadcasts" being made over the public address system in Grand Central Terminal, it was learned yesterday. The meeting will be held in closed session at 233 Broadway.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Army said today that it was re-establishing its War College. The first session will be held at Fort Leavenworth, Kan., pending selection of a permanent site.

The Edward J. Neil Memorial Plaque yesterday was voted to Ezzard Charles, Cincinnati Negro heavyweight who is recognized by the National Boxing Association as world champion, at a meeting of the Boxing Writers' Association of New York, held in Al and Dick's Restaurant.

ABOARD THE S. S. LAKELAND VICTORY, off Taku Bar, China, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Consul General Ward today disclosed there actually had been an altercation in the Mukden consulate, as the Communists alleged, but his version differed far from the way the Communists told it.

For the first time since the end of World War II United States flag vessels have relinquished second place in Suez Canal traffic to Norwegian shipping. This was in September, according to statistics in the November bulletin of the Compagnie Universelle du Canal Maritime de Suez.

The first new regulations providing a basis for landlords' applications for higher rents since the enactment of the Sharkey rent law last Oct. 7 were approved yesterday by the Temporary City Housing Rent Commission. They become effective today.

MOSCOW, Dec. 12 -- Pravda today characterized the former United States Ambassador to Moscow, Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, as a "slanderer," a "warmonger," a "lying former Ambassador," a "mad general" and a "petty soul of a diplomat from the infantry."

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 12 -- Russia's ability to move important documents from the United States through the open-door "diplomatic pouch" method should be called to the attention of Congress and the American people, Col. William Goodman, Memphis attorney, declared Saturday night.
Miss Helen B. Taft has been appointed manager of the International Business Machines Corporation's systems service department.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 12 (UP) -- Foreign Minister Vladimir Poptomov said tonight that the Government had not decided whether to act against Mr. Heath and other diplomats as the result of allegations made in the current trial of eleven Bulgarians as spies.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 12 -- The five-nation commission appointed by the United Nations Security Council to iron out the Kashmir dispute between India and Pakistan reported failure today and suggested turning the task over to one person, who would have "broad authority" to settle the two-year-old quarrel.

With some pride Will Harridge, president of the American League, announced yesterday that his loop once more had reached the eight-figure mark in season's attendance, even though there was a decrease from the all-time high in 1948.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- A new trade treaty between France and Western Germany, expanding trade between them and reducing some trade barriers, probably will be signed soon, French officials in touch with the negotiations said today. The parleys will resume tomorrow at the French Foreign Office.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was barely steady yesterday and final prices were 2 to 12 points net lower than on Saturday, with far months relatively easier than near months.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Following is the text of the address by former President Herbert Hoover here tonight before the National Reorganization Conference:

ALTHOUGH there are not yet as many books about George Bernard Shaw as he has written (nearly fifty plays and thirty other books), there are probably more than were ever written before in a man's own lifetime. Shaw's eminence as a playwright, him importance as a thinker and his amusing personality are not alone responsible for this.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Insurance companies can sue the Federal Government in their own names when seeking to recover damages they have paid to insured persons who were injured through the negligence of Government employes, the Supreme Court decided today.

These are the days of the visiting firemen who descend upon the cities with a great noise like locusts upon the fields. Drawn from their habitats to places where holiday season lights glow brightly, they come like moths to the lamp to flutter for a while and then, wearied, to crawl away.

The new signal light system adopted by the city's Traffic Commission will be watched anxiously by motorists and business men alike. For the former it could mean an end to harried nerves, for the latter a substantial saving in cost of truck operations.

At the symphonic concert in Carnegie Hall last night it was Richard Korn, the conductor, who received the major billing, and Ernestina L. Crisologo, 19-year-old Filipino pianist, who made the debut. But it was Rose Bampton who carried off the honors.

A budget of $1,952,450 to finance next fall's Republican Senate and Congressional campaigns and to keep the Republican National Committee functioning throughout the year, was approved yesterday at a meeting of the Republican National Finance Committee at 11 West Forty-second Street.

The New York regional office of the Veterans Administration is processing 20,000 cases of veterans in connection with subsistence payments while they are attending school under the GI Bill of Rights, it was reported yesterday. The cases in process equal nearly a fourth of all cases of GI students in the metropolitan area.

The proposed merger of the Congregational Christian Churches and the Evangelical and Reformed Church was defended yesterday by Miss Helen Kenyon, moderator of the General Council of the Congregational Christian Churches, as "consistent with Congregational policy."

The National and American Leagues, sitting in separate sessions, opened their annual winter conclaves at the Hotel Commodore yesterday, and each chose to go its own way on a number of items that have to do with the dispensation of their commodity, professional baseball.

" Back of the gift stands the giving," as Richard Realf wrote in the early Eighteen Hundreds. Today, as then, charity is needed. The concept of need may have changed in that emotional deprivation is thought by many to be as important as economic deprivation but thousands of persons unable to cope with the struggle called life must have help to ease their burdens.

Plum Island, former site of Fort Terry in Long Island Sound, off Orient Point, is valued at $196,000 by the General Services Administration, War Assets, but the highest bid the Federal agency could get for the property yesterday was $16,000.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 12 -- United States representatives have made informal representations to the Israeli and Jordanian Governments against any precipitate action as a result of the decision by the United Nations General Assembly to reaffirm the two-year-old resolution calling for the internationalization of Jerusalem.

Proof that modern home furnishings have not really changed so much was offered yesterday when four new lamps by Greta von Nessen were presented against the background of the designer's own home, which is furnished with historic modern pieces that date from the Twenties.

American Steel Foundries reported yesterday the largest earnings in its forty-seven-year history with the net of $6,505,442, or $5.48 a share, for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30. In the previous fiscal year, the net income was $6,008,851, or $5.06 a share.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 -- Charles Whitebrook, a New York advertising executive, and Gardner Goldsmith, a Philadelphia real estate man, won the national contract bridge pair championship here in play that ended at 2:30 o'clock this morning.

WINDSOR, Ont., Dec. 12 (Canadian Press) -- The Ford Motor Company of Canada, Ltd., today offered its 11,000 auto-worker employes a company-financed pension of $55 a month at the age of 65 after thirty years' service.

As the level of water in the Catskill and Croton reservoirs dropped another three-tenths of 1 per cent yesterday, harried city officials asked 8,000,000 New Yorkers to go without water all day next Friday except for "emergency" uses.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The State Department delivered a sharp dressing down to the ranking Bulgarian envoy today for the continued attacks and "indignities" to which Donald R. Heath, United States Minister in Sofia, was being subjected.

Everybody had fun at Madison Square Garden last night and nobody got hurt. Wrestling, experiencing a rebirth as the result of television's missionary work, was served up as the main attraction at the country's leading sports palace, and the bill attracted the amazing turnout of 17,854 fans, who paid $50,639.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson is now looking for a man to replace George F. Kennan, counselor of the State Department and head of its policy planning staff, who hopes to take a year off starting next July.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- Commenting on the publication in THE NEW YORK TIMES of the main provisions in the United States draft of bilateral treaties under the Military Aid Program, officials here today said that negotiations had already changed this draft and that final agreement would contain nothing that the French Parliament could not accept.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The State Department reported today that "satisfactory progress" has been made in preliminary talks looking toward a new United States-Canada treaty governing power development of the Niagara river.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 12 -- United States High Commissioner John J. McCloy stressed tonight the need for improvement of the educational program in Western Germany. He said that better schools, new teachers, new methods of teaching and better equipment in schools were required.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 12 -- John Garfield will go to Morocco early next year with his independent film producing partner, Bob Roberts, to star in the screen version of Bernard Dryer's novel, "Port Afrique," Roberts announced today.
CAIRO, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The foundation for an Arab TVA was laid out today in recommendations by the United Nations Economic Mission to the Middle East.

There is, and should be, general rejoicing in this country over the fact that Angus Ward and his staff, detained by the Chinese Communists in Mukden, are now safely aboard an American ship and ready to come home. Likewise, two American officials of the Economic Cooperation Administration have been set at liberty by the Communists in northern Korea.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The gradual liquidation of the Marshall Plan and the substitution for it of United States Government loans directly to private enterprise in Western Europe were proposed today by Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican, of Michigan.

Following an admission by the Federal Bureau of Investigation that it had tapped the defendants' telephones and intercepted their mail, Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan ruled yesterday that the burden now lay upon the Government to prove that the conspiracy and espionage indictment of Judith Coplon and Valentin A. Gubitchev was based on information obtained in other ways.
FREDERICK, Md., Dec. 12 (AP) -- A Catholic priest from Brooklyn, N. Y., was able today to tell police how he came to be found freezing on a mountain near here Saturday.

The Carnegie Endowment for International Peace announced yesterday that it had authorized the construction of a twelve-story building for its permanent headquarters on the west side of First Avenue, between Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets, adjacent to the United Nations site.

The Board of Transportation and the Transport Workers Union, CIO, agreed yesterday to meet next Monday on the union's twelve demands, earlier rejection of which had brought the threat of a pre-holiday slowdown on the city's subways.

UNION CITY, N. J., Dec. 12 -- A small blaze, believed to have started in a table tennis room, developed into a general alarm fire at 2:30 A. M. here today, and destroyed the Playdrome, a large bowling alley, with the loss of one life and damage estimated at $500,000.

Exclusive video rights to the Opera Television Theatre, headed by Lawrence Tibbett and Henry Souvaine, have been granted to the Columbia Broadcasting System, which will offer a series of performances beginning with "Carmen" on Sunday, Jan. 1, from 5 to 6:15 P. M.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Benefit checks of almost 2,000,000 war veterans or their dependents are about to be increased, the Veterans Administration said today.
Problems related to re-employment of ex-service men have become more complicated than had been expected, Hugh W. Bradley of the United States Department of Labor said here yesterday.

DALLAS, Tex., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Capt. Laurens Claude of Fort Worth, Tex., broke down today as he told of the crash of an American Airlines plane here on Nov. 29 in which twenty-eight persons were killed. In charge of the four-engine DC-6 airliner in its flight from New York to Mexico City, he testified at a hearing by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Members of the House of Commons, scheduled to debate Britain's food problems next Thursday, warmed up today with spirited exchanges concerning dining rooms and cafeterias of the Mother of Parliaments.
An inquiry into bread prices here was begun by the city yesterday. The purpose will be to find out why a loaf still costs as much as it did a year ago even though wheat prices have declined.

The first "Walkuere" of the season last night in the Metropolitan Opera House had some action and some attention paid to scenic elements which are of utterly essential significance in this opera and which had not for some seasons had any particular degree of attention at all. The result was salutory.

OTTAWA, Dec. 12 -- Adjournment until tomorrow morning of the show cause hearing of Colonial Airlines by the Air Transport Board of Canada was granted this afternoon. This was done to permit counsel for Colonial, if they wished, to establish their position under the Logan Act, which they invoked as preventing them from taking any part in the proceedings.

The stock market emerged yesterday from the narrow trading range of the past week and pushed through to further new highs since 1946, under the sponsorship of television and automotive issues. Traders on the New York Stock Exchange shifted to these two sections to the exclusion of the steels despite the higher operating rate set this week for the industry.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Strength in the new National-American Football League will be divided equally among the two divisions, Commissioner Bert Bell said today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12 -- Mention of a letter assertedly written in 1939 by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt in defense of Harry Bridges crept into the Bridges perjury and conspiracy trial today despite Government efforts to block it.

The seventeenth annual meeting of the National Association of Stevedores, which closed last night in the Hotel Statler, was more optimistic than last year's session because of remedial Federal legislation in the summer regarding overtime on overtime.

Chief Magistrate Edgar Bromberger will preside in court for the last time this morning, and then depart on a trip to Georgia and a "terminal leave," ending his twenty years of public service. His retirement, for reasons of health, has been accepted reluctantly by Mayor O'Dwyer. It will be effective Feb. 15.

TRENTON, Dec. 12 -- A move by Democratic leaders to form a new state organization to replace that of former Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City was postponed tonight by a 27-to-10 vote of the State Committee.

ALBANY, Dec. 12 -- Governor Dewey was asked today to give his support to state aid for the establishment of a $4,000,000 college in the Southern Tier. The institution would provide four years of liberal arts instruction.

H. G. W. Woodhead thoughtfully considered some of the facets involved in the question of recognition of the Communist regime in China in your issue of Nov. 20. He admitted the disposition of the British Government to give de facto and perhaps de jure recognition for the sake of trade and retention of Hong Kong.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 12 -- Dr. Edvard Kardelj, Foreign Minister and one of the leading political theorists of Yugoslavia, today consummated another important ideological break with Soviet leaders and the Communist Information Bureau version of socialism by demanding the liberation of science from dogma and its use as an instrument of state policy.

Edith Stearns is a pianist who makes music sound no better than it should, a trait that one listener found exhilarating at her first New York recital in Times Hall last night. Her program, with a few exceptions, was of a romantic nature, and she played it with smoothness and dexterity.
DUESSELDORF, Germany, Nov. 30 -- The owners of the Ruhr gathered recently in an ornate dining room of the luxurious Breitenbacher Hof here for their first public outing since the war.

Christmas table settings for a tete-a-tete, a buffet or a formal dinner party have been devised by Carole Stupell for Richard Hudnut. The series of five settings may be seen at the Hudnut salon, 693 Fifth Avenue, until Christmas.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 12 -- Acquisition of five acres in Yonkers for a connection between Central Park Avenue and the contemplated Sprain Brook Parkway near Palmer Road was authorized unanimously this afternoon by the Westchester County Board of Supervisors, although residents had declared it would be a step toward destruction or defacement of $1,000,000 in homes.

Yesterday the 100 finalists in the Pillsbury National Recipe Contest took over the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, turning a room favored for automobile shows and debutante balls into a fragrant, friendly kitchen. Results of what Pillsbury termed "the Bake-off" will be anounced today at a luncheon on the hotel's Starlight Roof, when Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will present nine awards ranging from $500 to $50,000.

The strength of the police force was increased yesterday to 18,591 members as a Police Academy class of 290 probationary patrolmen was graduated at exercises held at the Washington Irving High School. In an address to the graduates Acting Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri said: "We still don't think that we have enough [policemen] and we plan to continue right along trying to make a bigger force."

MANILA, Dec. 12 -- Adhering to constitutional processes, the Philippine Congress met today to proclaim Elpidio Quirino President of the Republic for the next four years and Fernando Lopez Vice President over opposition party strategy that almost prevented ratification. A last-minute combination with defeated candidate Jose Avelino's Liberal splinter party provided the required majority of Senate votes and avoided a ruinous political crisis.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Dec. -- the founding of an all-European Institute of Nuclear Physics and the removal of restrictions on the flow of books and magazines among European countries were among the major recommendations adopted today by the European Cultural Conference.

Divorced parents face certain especially painful problems in rearing their children, but they need not fatalistically assume that the youngsters are "doomed" emotionally, Mrs. Sidonie Matsner Gruenberg, director of the Child Study Association of America, said yesterday.

Your brief editorial titled "No Comment" in the issue of Dec. 1, reprinting a dispatch from Atlanta about the tearing down of non-union work and its re-erection by union workers, is notable only because it caused you to take notice of it.

ABOARD THE S. S. LAKELAND VICTORY, Off Taku Bar, China, Dec. 12 (UP) -- United States Consul General Angus Ward disclosed today that the Chinese Communists had charged him and nineteen companions $7,000 in United States money for a 400-mile train ride, with their baggage, from Mukden to Tientsin.

BERLIN, Dec. 12 -- Lieut. Col. Momcilo Sibinovitch, chief of the Yugoslav Military Mission and Premier Tito's chief agent in Germany, today protested to Soviet authorities that they had dishonored Russia's agreements with the Western powers.
KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 12 -- Did President Truman partake of a $60 ostrich egg omelet?

A clubhouse where teachers of the city can meet and get to know each other better was urged yesterday by Mrs. Eudora Fletcher, principal of Public School 99, Brooklyn, and president of the Brooklyn Teachers Association.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Additional protection for political refugees was recommended today by the International Relations Committee of the International Federation of Free Journalists of Central and Eastern Europe and Baltic and Balkan Countries.

A man must be very brave or a bit "goofy" to write on such a subject as "The Probability of Another War." But with two wars in back of me I am willing to throw in my two bits' worth. My first thought is that of the death-dealing and destructive capabilities of modern war implements available to mankind, which should make us all shudder at the very thought of another war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Officials of the Pan American Coffee Bureau denied today any intent to "bull the coffee market" by the statistics, press and radio releases and advertisements recently made public by the bureau to explain soaring prices.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 12 -- On the basis of a country-by-country survey of child-welfare conditions abroad, the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund reported today that its relief programs were reaching about 10 per cent of the 60,000,000 undernourished youngsters considered to be in "urgent need of help."

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 12 -- The anti-Socialist trend in Australia's general election became more marked as late results today showed the Liberals would have 52 seats in the new House of Representatives, the Country party 21, and Labor 48, giving the coalition a majority of 24 after providing a Speaker.
LONDON, Dec. 12 -- The Labor Government declined today to disclose whether Britain is now able to make atom bombs.

On July 25 in Chicago, Federal Judge Elwyn R. Shaw ruled that the Housing and Rent Act of 1949 (the rent control law) was unconstitutional. The decision did not terminate or even interrupt the operation of the Act, however, as the Government obtained a stay of execution until the Supreme Court had had an opportunity to consider the case.

Christmas customs in Scandinavia will be featured at the annual Christmas dinner dance to be given Friday night at Sherry's under the auspices of the New York Chapter of the American-Scandinavian Foundation for the benefit of the organization's fund for the exchange of students between the United States and Scandinavian countries.

LAKE SUCCES, Dec. 12 -- Dr. Jose Arce, Argentine representative on the United Nations Security Council, stalked out of its meeting this afternoon when it insisted on meeting after 6 o'clock. Dr. Arce's proposal to adjourn was beaten 5 to 1, with 5 abstentions, and the Council did not quit until 6:40.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The constitutionality of the 1949 Federal Rent Control Law was sustained by the Supreme Court today in a brief order reversing the decision of a lower court. The ruling, unanimous and with Justice William O. Douglas not participating, upset a decision by Judge Elwyn R. Shaw in the Chicago Federal District Court.
Recommendations for including courses on family living in public school curricula were made yesterday at the annual open meeting of the National Women's Conference of the American Ethical Union.

" Undertow," a Universal-International melodrama, starring Scott Brady and Bruce, will open at the Palace on Thursday instead of "Girls' School," which originally was booked in for that date, it was announced yesterday by the management.
A block of Florida citrus-producing land, described as the largest of its kind in the state, has been purchased by Minute Maid Corporation, it was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Electric Company estimated today a possible $2,000,000 reduction in annual operating expenses if the Power Commission authorizes it to buy more natural gas from the Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Gov. Adlai Stevenson of Illinois was divorced today by his wife of twenty-one years, Ellen Borden Stevenson, on charges of extreme mental cruelty.

Sales of leading mail-order and chain-store companies declined 4.2 per cent in November, compared with the corresponding month last year, according to a compilation covering thirty - nine companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 12 -- Andrei I. Galagan, Ukrainian representative on the United Nations Security Council, launched a long attack today on the recent roundtable agreement at The Hague under which the Netherlands is to transfer sovereignty to the United States of Indonesia by the end of the year.

Thirty-five Army and Air Force recruiting booths in the metropolitan area will do double duty this week, it was announced yesterday. In addition to their regular job of signing up men for the armed forces, they will also be signing up volunteers to fight infantile paralysis.

Tom Maloney, partner of Newell-Emmett Company, will join Cecil Presbrey, Inc., on Jan. 3, 1950, as an executive officer, it was announced jointly yesterday by Mr. Maloney and James Cecil, president of Cecil Presbrey. Mr. Maloney will be joined by a number of members of his staff at Newell-Emmett.
PARIS, Dec. 12 -- Jacques Duclos, secretary of the French Communist party, termed today as "simply ridiculous" reports that there was a grave crisis within the party.

OSLO, Norway, Dec. 12 (Reuters) -- Lord Boyd Orr, 69-year-old Scottish scientist, farmer, nutrition expert and winner of this year's Nobel peace prize, declared here today that if the world's governments would give one-hundredth part of the money they were using for "war preparation" to the specialized agencies of the United Nations, obstacles to peace would vanish.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Four persons were probably killed and nineteen believed rescued in the crash of a Capital Airlines DC-3 transport plane in the Potomac River tonight. The accident took place a little after 8:30 P. M. in a heavy fog.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 12 -- Ernest A. Gross, former Assistant Secretary of State, formally took up his duties as deputy United States representative to the United Nations today at the Security Council meeting.

The National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots. AFL, and a committee representing Atlantic and Gulf Coast ship operators renewed yesterday their contract talks for the first time in more than two weeks in an effort to avert a strike threatened for Friday.
The first list of German securities to be subjected to screening by the Securities Settlement Advisory Agency of the German Federal Republic reached here yesterday.

If the late session of the United Nations General Assembly did not achieve miracles it was not the fault of its President, Gen. Carlos P. Romulo. General Romulo did more than preside. He felt that as the representative of the Philippines, a Far Eastern nation closely associated with the United States, he might be an effective mediator.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- John L. Thurston, Acting Federal Security Administrator, told a joint Congressional subcommittee as it began a study of problems of low-income families today that "perhaps three children in every average classroom of thirty pupils are destined to spend part of their lives in a mental hospital."

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- The defeat of the Socialists in the Australian election had a cheerful effect on the stock markets here today. However, apart from Australian stocks, which went ahead, buying was on a small scale and the early enthusiasm was not maintained.

The hope that the Chinese Communists will permit Presbyterian missionaries to continue their work in that country was expressed yesterday by the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

An increase of 25 per cent in sales of air-conditioning and automatic-heating equipment can be achieved next year, Harold F. Smiddy, vice president of the General Electric Company, predicted here yesterday. He told 300 distributors of the company's air-conditioning products at their annual sales conference at the Forty- eighth Street Theatre, that less than 10 per cent of the potential market has been sold.

The World Jewish Congress has sent a letter to United States High Commissioner John J. McCloy urging him to reject any demands by the Western German Government to grant freedom to German war criminals now serving prison sentences in Landsberg Prison.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week were down 4 per cent from the corresponding week last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 5 per cent.

Although neither side would admit that it had altered its position, both operators and union conferees at the anthracite talks here yesterday said they were hopeful that a contract would be negotiated.

The block of 200,000 shares of Northern States Power Company of Minnesota placed on the market yesterday by Blyth Co., a non-underwriter, marks an unapprehended new development in the distribution of public utility equity shares through stockholders' preemptive subscription rights.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Notre Dame's Fightin' Irish, unbeaten in ten games this season, will play a nine-game schedule next year.
CANTON, Ohio, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The thirty-eight-day-old strike of 10,000 Timken Roller Bearing Company production workers in five Ohio cities was settled today. The men will return to work tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Americans must stop wasting their heritage if they wish to remain free, former President Herbert Hoover declared tonight in urging immediate Government reform in eight areas that he asserted could produce savings of $2,000,000,000 annually.

Charles Lukens Huston Sr., who is nearing 94 years of age, will begin tomorrow his seventy-fifth year of continuous service with the Lukens Steel Company of Coatesville, Pa. His record is believed to be unequaled in the annals of American business.

With the purchase by the Italian Government and subsequent transfer to Italy of 123 merchant vessels from the American surplus war-built fleet completed, the Italian merchant marine is well on the road to complete recovery, Capt. Albio T. Marena of the Confederation of Italian Shipowners, said yesterday.

Intent on bagging victory No. 5, Hank Iba's Stillwater Cowboys from Oklahoma A. and M., Missouri Valley Conference rulers and finalists in the 1949 N. C. A. A. championship, make their twenty-first appearance in Madison Square Garden tonight when they face Long Island University in the feature test of a collegiate basketball double-header.

An erroneous impression by corporations that all human relations problems can be centralized in one unit often results in personnel departments causing more harm than good, it was declared last night by Glenn Gardiner, vice president of the Forstmann Woolen Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Sharp Dohme, Inc., Philadelphia drug manufacturers, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 171,815 shares of the company's cumulative preference stock of no par value.
A heavy fog covered New York and vicinity for most of the day yesterday, disrupting airline and ship traffic and slowing movements by automobile and truck. It turned into rain early in the evening.

As was to be expected, the prosecution in the Bulgarian propaganda trial against nationalist Communists has demanded the death penalty for former Deputy Premier Kostov and four other leading defendants, and the record of Communist regimes leaves them little hope of escaping with their lives.

Cecil Smith of Austin, Tex., and Stewart Iglehart of Delray, Fla., and Westbury L. I., once again share the highest rating awarded by the United States Polo Association. According to the 1950 ratings announced yesterday, Smith and Iglehart head the outdoor handicap list at ten goals.

TOKYO, Dec. 12 -- Occupation personnel in Japan are in a minor panic these days because of a rumor that authorities will shortly eliminate all currencies except the yen, thus possibly forcing foreigners to change dollar bank accounts into yen.

ALBANY, Dec. 12 -- Strong opposition to a special tax on commercial users of the state highways was expressed at a public hearing today before a joint legislative committee created to investigate possible revenues from highway and canal rise.

Mayor O'Dwyer's announcement that he intends to proceed with a career and salary survey of the city's civil service, asking the Board of Estimate to take action on Dec. 22, is a matter whose importance cannot be overrated. This action may well stand as one of the great landmarks of the present regime.

A Brooklyn man who was said by the Federal Bureau of Investigation to have been the head of a counterfeiting ring that circulated $140,000 worth of bogus American Railway Express checks and planned the distribution of a total of $1,000,000 worth of worthless checks, was arrested last night on a warrant for conspiracy.
ATLANTA, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Georgia lost today a tax suit that officials say could cost the state $10,000,000.

A refugee who found a haven here sent her annual "anonymous" contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday. She declared that "without the assistance of this great country we could easily be among the neediest."

Importers of French wool berets are now required by the Bureau of Customs, under Treasury Decision 50034, to file "anti-dumping" bonds in the equivalent value of the merchandise imported. It was confirmed at the office of the Appraiser of the Bureau of Customs, 201 Varick Street, that appraisals of this merchandise are being withheld, pending an investigation in France.

The National Jewish Hospital at Denver will celebrate its fiftieth anniversary today with the institution of an expanded children's service program that will include treatment of tuberculous infants. It will be the first time in the hospital's history that it has devoted itself to the cure of children from infancy.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Freddie Haas Jr. captured the second major tournament of his professional golfing career today by defeating Bob Hamilton two strokes in an 18-hole play-off for top prize of Miami's twenty-sixth annual $10,000 open tournament.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities will recall for more testimony Lieut. Gen. Leslie R. Groves, retired, who headed the project that developed the atomic bomb, and George Racey Jordan, former Army Air Forces major who recently started a new inquiry into alleged shipments of atomic secrets and materials to Russia in 1943-44.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- In its searches between wars for qualified citizens to fill high posts that are vacant the American Government lately has filled the air with laments that these are becoming increasingly hard to find; and it is more and more inclined to attribute this largely to the "inadequacy" of official salaries.

HONG KONG, Dec. 12 -- Gen. Chang Chun, one of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's most trusted trouble shooters, who ranks high as a "war criminal" in the Communist list, arrived in Hong Kong from Kunming via Haiphong, Indo-China, after a forty-eight-hour "guest-room arrest" by Yunnan Governor Lu Han, who deserted to the Communists on Friday.
The Soviet Union apparently has abandoned any hope of an early let-up in the "cold" trade war that has been under way between this country and Russia for the last two years.

No effort has been made on the part of anyone in the independent stockholder's group to gain control of the A. M. Byers Company as charged by officials of the wrought-iron manufacturing concern, Gerald Nielsen, investment banker of this city, and secretary of the group, declared yesterday.

I read in THE NEW YORK TIMES Senator O'Mahoney's statement at a subcommittee hearing when Devereux Josephs was on the stand, and I quote him: "It is utter nonsense, from my point of view, to urge cutting government expenses."
A cushion of space -- the vast geography of Russia -- fortifies the Soviet concept of victory in war by counter-offensive.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the Government may tax tickets to a public bathing beach.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Praise of the British national health service by Oscar R. Ewing, United States Federal Security Administrator, was described today by the British Fellowship for Freedom in Medicine as "not the result of an impartial investigation but just another item in the Truman Administration's campaign for its own national health program."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The steel and coal strikes forced personal income in the United States down to an annual rate of $208,400,000,000 in October, a decline of $2,100,000,000 from the September level, the Department of Commerce disclosed today.
BOSTON, Dec. 12 -- Robert H. Best, former newspaper man from Sumter, S. C., today denied that he ever had committed any act of treason, and that he "could have proved it if given a fair trial."

Ex-President Herbert Hoover, in his broadcast address last night in Washington, described the movement to modernize the Federal Government as "a crusade to clear the track for competency." It may be that the word competency will not stir men's souls like such words as freedom, but there is a connection between competency in government and freedom for the people who are being governed.
CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- Raymond (Buddy) Parker resigned today, leaving the Chicago Cardinals with their third coaching vacancy in a year.

Directors of the Home Insurance Company increased the annual dividend rate to $1.60 a share with the declaration yesterday of 80 cents for payment on Feb. 1. The company, which distributes its dividends semi-annually, paid $1.40 a share in the previous year.

A notice that the musical drama "Regina" will close after Saturday evening's performance was posted backstage last night at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre, where the attraction has been running since Oct. 31.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 12 -- Patrolman Francis B. McManus of the Jersey City force was charged with breaking, entering and larceny today after he had admitted committing a series of thefts while on patrol duty, according to the police.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Du Mont Laboratories, Inc., expects sales of $70,000,000 this year and possibly $80,000,000 in 1950, Dr. Allen B. Du Mont, founder, told an investment subcommittee of the Joint Committee on the Economic Report today.

With retailers seeking to clear holiday inventories before committing themselves to further purchases, manufacturers of children's dresses find themselves in the midst of a slack selling period, it was learned yesterday. Children's dress production, however, is showing activity on the basis of some early orders from retailers and substantial business from wholesalers.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan appealed to the American Farm Bureau Federation today for a full and free discussion of price supports for farm products, including his own plan, and the federation's president promptly questioned his motives in making the appeal.

Only a few weeks ago, or so it seems, we were picking our way gingerly through road construction in Times Square and climbing over dirt and rock barricades thrown up by the contractor engaged in improving Forty-second Street. It all seemed very confusing at the time, and we know there were days when traffic through this busy artery had a hard time traversing only a few blocks.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- Important progress has been made in the development of suitable substances for transferring and harnessing the enormous quantities of heat generated in a nuclear reactor (atomic furnace), it was revealed here today by David E. Lilienthal, retiring chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, at the first press conference held by the commission outside of Washington.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Treasury announced today that it had accepted bids for $903,483,000, or thereabouts, of 91-day Treasury bills to be dated Dec. 15, 1949, and to mature on March 16, 1950, which were offered on Dec. 9, 1949.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12 (AP) -- A wave of Alaskan air that got sidetracked sent Southern Californians shivering into sub-freezing cold today.
The new week in coffee futures trading opened on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday with a sharp break in prices.

St. John's University, Brooklyn, announced yesterday that John A. Coleman, a member of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange and former chairman of the board, had been named the 1949 winner of the St. Vincent de Paul Medal.
Distribution of 100,000 leaflets urging both motorists and pedestrians to "take it easy" to avoid accidents during the current holiday season will be started today by the Police Department.
NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 12 -- An SOS from a radio-equipped taxi serving as a ship's wireless office brought the Coast Guard to the rescue of a ferryboat in distress this morning.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Czechoslokavia is supplying Russia with large quantities of uranium ore from a new mine near Prague, a diplomatic source disclosed here today.

MISSING from the baseball meetings for the first time in a mighty long while is Deacon Will McKechnie, a mild-mannered, soft-spoken and kindly man. The Deacon has just terminated his employment -- or maybe it was vice versa -- with the Cleveland Indians. He had been wanting to quit for the past couple of years and it wasn't his trifling salary of $40,000 per annum which kept him going.
CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- Trading in grain futures on the Board of Trade was unusually slow today. Brokers attributed the lack of activity in part to uncertainty on the outcome of December contracts.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 12 -- The Argentine Congress, in a special session this afternoon, voted 95 to 1 to expel an opposition Deputy, Atilio Cattaneo, who had been accused of "desacato," or disrespect, to President Juan Peron. The lone negative vote was cast by the only opposition member present, Reynaldo Pastor, a Democrat.

Several large carpet mills may put a second round of price increases into effect at or prior to the January home furnishings market, it was learned yesterday. Mill spokesmen said increases made last month have failed to offset steadily advancing carpet wool costs and added another increase is inevitable unless an unforeseen drop in carpet wool prices occurs in the next few weeks.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The United States is likely to move cautiously in giving support to Chiang Kai-shek's defense of Formosa against the Chinese Communists.

Charging discrimination against manufacturers' representatives and merchant exporters by Colombia, the Commerce and Industry Association yesterday protested to the Office of International Trade in Washington the provisions of that country's executive decree No. 13,693.

Thomas Scherman seems to have a sound formula for program-making. One would guess that he looks around, sees what everybody else is doing and does something different. At this season of the year nearly every one who presents Handel is bound to do "The Messiah."

Dr. Stanley K. Hornbeck, former Ambassador to the Netherlands, testified yesterday at the second Alger Hiss perjury trial that he had heard Mr. Hiss described as "a fellow traveler" by William C. Bullitt, former Ambassador to France.

ROME, Dec. 12 -- Pope Pius today took the last preliminary step before the solemn inauguration of the Holy Year by officially appointing during a secret consistory the three Cardinals to act as his legates at ceremonies marking the opening of the holy doors of the three Roman basilicas on Dec. 24.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Scott W. Lucas of Illinois, the Senate Democratic leader, conceded today that the second session of the Eighty-first Congress, to open on Jan. 3, was not likely to repeal the Taft-Hartley Labor Act.

The Traffic Commission is exploring the possibility of unified operation of the Avenue of the Americas and the Seventh Avenue bus lines to eliminate acute bottlenecks at Central Park South, it was learned yesterday.
The Pennsylvania Electric Company raised more than $18,000,000 yesterday by the Sale of new issues of thirty-year first mortgage bonds and of $100 par value cumulative preferred stock.

Year-end investment buying made a premature appearance yesterday and enabled the stock market to score one of the most impressive gains since last month's setbacks. Although selling for both tax purposes and profit was encountered during the session, the bidding proved sufficient to overcome the obstacles and left the composite rate higher by a point. Many gains were well in excess of this amount.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 13 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion announced in a tense Knesset [Parliament] today: "We are continuing with the transfer of the Government to Jerusalem and hope to complete it as soon as possible."

ESSEN, Germany, Dec. 1 -- One of the most disturbing elements in the German picture is that at the moment when nationalism and neo-fascism are reviving, the end of dismantling has left Western Germany with a steel production capacity that British experts estimate at about 15,000,000 tons.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 (AP) -- On the record, it'll be Los Angeles' passing against Philadelphia's running in the National Football League championship game Sunday -- but it ain't necessarily so.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 13 -- The United Nations Trusteeship Council today beat down strong pleas by the United States and Britain for delay and voted overwhelmingly to begin immediately the preparation of a statute placing Jerusalem under international rule.

Announcements of plans to distribute Christmas bonuses are being made by many companies. Although business volume is generally lower than last year, a number of concerns are paying the same amount as last year, or are increasing it, their reports indicate.

In their spare time, when they are not engaged in the prosaic work of drawing up leases or making appraisals, many of New York's leading real estate men engage in a wide variety of hobbies and cultural pursuits.
John L. Lewis arrived in the city yesterday, but negotiations between the United Mine Workers and the nation's anthracite operators remained deadlocked.
Howard J. Snyder has been appointed assistant in industrial relations at L. Bamberger Co., Newark. He formerly was a labor attorney with the law firm of Root, Ballantine, Harlan, Bushby Palmer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, told President. Truman today that the Federal Government was "fostering and promoting competition" in the transportation industry" on the one hand and restricting it on the other."

The articles, "My Three Years in Moscow," by Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, which have appeared in The Saturday Evening Post and THE NEW YORK TIMES have given our citizens an opportunity to appraise Russia based on exact information from our former Ambassador to that country.

Fifty years ago yesterday Hugh S. Kelly was hired by the New York Telephone Company for "a temporary job," recharging central office batteries in the plant department on Staten Island at $3 a week. Yesterday Mr. Kelly, a tax accountant for the New York organization since 1930, observed the half-century mark of service with the company.

The frozen-food industry will establish an all-time record output this year of about 1,000,000,000 pounds and it is now virtually certain that this will be increased considerably in 1950, C. Courtney Seabrook, vice president of Seabrook Farms, predicted yesterday.

As the executive director of an organization devoted exclusively to the improvement of public personnel administration and extension of the merit system throughout government in New York State, I have read with great interest your editorial on "The Untouchable Bureau" printed on Dec. 6, and A. Mark Levien's letter commenting thereon.

OTTAWA, Dec. 13 -- Counsel for Colonial Airlines today continued to maintain the position that under the Logan Act they could not defend their case upon resumption of the hearing of the Air Transport Board's order to the company to show cause why its license to operate out of Montreal should not be suspended.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- James T. Nicholson, often called "Roving Ambassador of the Red Cross," who has been the conferee of kings and queens and who once dined with Stalin in the Kremlin, was honored today for thirty years of Red Cross service.

The slim skirt found but little favor yesterday noon in a fashion show in the Oval Room of the Ritz Carlton Hotel. Skirts swirled and twirled in resort and summer styles presented by Mary Lewis of 746 Fifth Avenue who gave the show.

ALBANY, Dec. 13 -- Suggestions ranging from transfer of the State Canal System to the Federal Government to Federal subsidies for properly run railroads were submitted to a legislative committee today as means to avoid the imposition of tolls for use of the Barge Canal.

Abe J. Greene, Paterson (N. J.) editor who is commissioner of the National Boxing Association, will be the recipient of this year's James J. Walker Memorial Award, it announced yesterday by the Boxing Writers' Association of New York.

As baseball's major leagues concluded their separate meetings in the Hotel Commodore yesterday preparatory to going into joint session before Commissioner Albert B. Chandler today, the National and American circuits still were running far apart on the bonur rule, with which they saddled themselves almost three years ago.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Two locals in Washington and Newark were notified today by the International Printing Pressmen's Union, AFL, that their charters had been revoked and awarded to new locals.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Dec. 15 -- Mrs. Olivia Murray Cutting, widow of William Bayard Cutting, financier and philanthropist, who died Nov. 15 at the age of 94, left approximately $1,000,000 in bequests and annuities to relatives, friends and employes and $195,000 to charitable and religious institutions.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 13 (UP) -- Government officials disclosed today some of the complicated plans for moving the seat of the Israeli Government from Tel Aviv to this city. The gigantic moving job already has been in progress for a year.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- The American Farm Bureau Federation will detail in a resolution its official opposition to the program proposed by Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan in addition to restating its position for flexible price supports for farm products, it was learned today.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Dec. 13 -- High on snow covered Worth Mountain, sixteen miles southeast of this tradition-steeped college town is Middlebury's Snow Bowl, one of the most compact and comprehensive collegiate ski layouts in the country.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Frank Pace Jr., Director of the Budget, assured the National Reorganization Conference today that President Truman planned to make a vigorous fight in the new year for governmental reforms that would yield "a maximum return for every dollar spent."

Interest of American business concerns in the West German consumer market is growing rapidly, and promises expanding advertising and promotion of American products as the non-Russian occupied zones speed recovery, it was learned yesterday at an exhibit of German publications and other media.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UP) -- The American Aviation Daily said today that the crash of a Capital Airlines DC-3 here last night might have been averted but for CAA "procrastination" on the question of installing high intensity approach ights at National Airport.

The aluminum gadget in the Madison Avenue shop window may not look like jolly old St. Nick, but you can walk right up to it and tell it what you want -- if you have a quarter, that is. Whether you get your order won't depend, however, on whether you're a good boy or girl but on whether you have a charge account or will pay C. O. D.
LONDON, Dec. 13 (UP) -- The secret of how many evening dresses Princess Margaret buys each year came out today. The number is twenty.

Intermittent to steady rainfall in New York's watersheds in the last forty-eight hours put millions of gallons of water into the city's Catskill and Croton reservoirs. But city officials warned that the basic situation there had been relieved by only four-tenths of 1 per cent.

WESTPORT, Conn., Dec. 13 -- Dionysia C. Skouras, 20 years old, of 2 Shore Road, Rye, N. Y., daughter of Spyros Skouras, president of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, is a patient in Hall-Brooke Sanitarium here today following a wild ride over the Post Road from Greenwich to Darien in which policemen fired five shots at her car, the authorities announced.

An American edition of a first novel by Anthony West, son of H. G. Wells, has been listed by Houghton Mifflin for Jan. 10 publication. "The Vintage" is a story about an English colonel and a Nazi general, whom the colonel prosecuted, who set out together after their deaths to explore the lives they had lived and the choices that remained.

ATLANTA, Dec. 13 -- A new chemical identified as Compound 497 has produced the best results in a series of tests in which thirty insecticides were used against adult house flies, two scientists of the United States Public Health Service's Communicable Disease Center announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission was asked today to approve the purchase by the Atlas Corporation, New York, an investment company, of 20,000 shares of Barnsdall Oil Company common stock.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 13 (UP) -- Both the Socialists and the Christian Democrats demanded today that Wolfgang Hedler, ex-Wehrmacht officer and member of the Rightist party, be deprived of his seat in Parliament for defending the Nazi anti-Jewish policy.

A bred-by-exhibitor class was substituted for the limit class as a standard event at dog shows by the delegates of the American Kennel Club at their meeting in the Hotel Commodore yesterday. There was one major deletion from the rule for the new class that previously had been approved by the board of directors.

BOSTON, Dec. 13 -- When Santa Claus stops in at the Children's Medical Center on Christmas Eve, he may be surprised to find some parents sitting up with their convalescing children awaiting his arrival.

Complex provisions of the new state disability benefits law that will go into effect on Jan. 1 were analyzed yesterday for 900 business men and representatives of the city's major industries. Insurance executives and state officials outlined its salient features at a symposium conducted by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York in the Engineering Auditorium, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

Rain over the New York City watershed was a blessing, but the relief thus far is so transient and the backlog of need so great that the net result could even be a setback for the city if it relaxed the self-discipline that has been painfully built up. The reservoir supply has been deepened by about a day's supply, and there is hope of further delayed arrival from run-off.

Inexplicable, indeed, are the ways of the theatre -- sometimes; which brings to mind a lyric of Oscar Hammerstein 2d in the song, "Some Enchanted Evening." This apparently is applicable to love as well as to the stage:

The fear and desperation that are so evident among the Neediest Cases are facets of living experienced by most of us at some time in our lives. Few may look back without the knowledge that somewhere a hand of friendship, extended at an hour of need, staved off black despair from which there seemed no return.

Marketing of new issues of corporate bonds will be at a slow pace until after the turn of the year, but competition of bidding syndicates will continue to be keen. Eight syndicates of bankers are lined up to compete today for the $12,500,000 issue of bonds of the Central Illinois Light Company, an AAA-rated credit likely to be priced along museum-piece lines despite the coolness of institutional investors to newly plunging yields.

VIENNA, Dec. 13 -- A small but significant incident in Vienna over the week-end indicated that even the tiny Austrian Communist party has split along the lines of Titoism versus the Communist Information Bureau.

Issues of new securities of Pennsylvania public utility enterprises totaling $19,013,300 in principal value will be placed on the market here today by underwriting syndicates. Included are first mortgage bonds and preferred stock of Pennsylvania Electric Company and preferred stock of the United Telephone Company of Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- An increase of 100 per cent in the average of old-age pensions now being paid under the Social Security program was recommended by Maurice J. Tobin, Secretary of Labor, today to the joint Congressional group investigating problems facing low-income families.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- High estate and inheritance taxes are slowly wiping out the nation's small businesses, a Senate-House economic committee was told today. Federal and state tax priorities are forcing estate liquidation and making it almost impossible for a business to pass from father to son, it was said.

The Eastern Interscholastic Golf Association private school tournament will be held at the Greenwich Country Club, June 13 through 18, John G. Kendall of the Hill School, association chairman, announced.

The performance of "That Lady," starring Katharine Cornell, on the night of Jan. 24 at the Martin Beck Theatre has been taken over as a benefit for the South Brooklyn Neighborhood Houses at 62 Joralemon Street in Brooklyn.

Officials of the Screen Actors Guild met here yesterday with representatives of eleven motion picture companies regarding wages and hours for actors engaged in making commercial films for television. Also discussed was the matter of additional payments for films used more than once.
The Browns announced last night the sale of third baseman, Bob Dillinger, and outfielder, Paul Lehner to the Athletics for $100,000 in cash and four players.

The Protestant Film Commission, an agency of major Protestant denominations, yesterday held a preview of "Kenji Comes Home," a motion picture dealing with the role of the Christian Church in providing guidance to the people of post-war Japan.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The United States Government is still far from an agreed policy on expanding the exchange of atomic information with Britain and Canada.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- Benoit Frachon, head of the Communist-dominated General Confederation of Labor, with 2,500,000 members, today appealed to French workers, railroaders, dockers and seamen to refuse to manufacture or transport war materials, including those sent by the United States.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- A revolutionary new type of atomic power plant that will eliminate some of the costliest and most troublesome features of nuclear reactors was described here today by Dr. Lawrence R. Hafstad, Director of Reactor Development for the Atomic Energy Commission.

More cooperation among the world's religious denominations is needed, especially a program of strategic planning to bring about greater unity, Dr. J. Hutchison Cockburn declared yesterday. He is a former moderator of the Church of Scotland and a member of the executive committee of the World Council of Churches.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 13 -- A resolution commending the Dutch and the Indonesians for reaching an agreement recently in .The Hague was vetoed twice by the Soviet Union in the United Nations Security Council today. This was considered here as evidence that the sovereign United States of Indonesia would not be accepted for membership when application is made about one year hence.

The fourteen investigations that displaced persons undergo to establish their fitness for the American way of life were cited here yesterday as evidence of the careful selection and screening that DP's undergo before leaving Europe.
WARSAW, Dec. 31 -- The Polish Government today crippled the activities of the French Institute by ordering the expulsion of eleven professors and lecturers on the institute's small staff.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Eagles headed West to defend their National Football League championship against the Los Angeles Rams Sunday, after receiving a rousing send-off today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 13 -- Victor Mature was suspended from salary today by Twentieth Century-Fox for refusing to fulfill a loan-out commitment to RKO for the film, "Alias Mike Fury," formerly "Mr. Whiskers," on which pre-production photography is in progress in New York.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Business was at exceptionally low level in the stock markets here today. Prices of issues of nearly all groups, except the rubbers, sagged.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Herbert A. Bergson, assistant attorney general in charge of anti-trust operations, today told the Senate subcommittee investigating food prices that the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company "receives as a general practice discriminatory rebates."

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13 -- The "nationalist philosophy" of Zionist Jews is a "death fixation," an abnormality, even though it can be understood and explained by the tragedies of Jewish life," Rabbi Morris S. Lazaron, professor at Rollins College, Winter Park, Fla., told the American Council of Judaism tonight.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Paul G. Hoffman expressed the belief today that United States defense costs would reach $30,000,000,000 annually if Western Europe should go Communist. Such costs now total about $15,000,000,000.
Scaring folks with spooky ways and hobgoblin faces may pay off a little, but true goodness brings far better rewards in the end, four youngsters learned here yesterday.

For the second year two Manhattan youngsters have charged their friends 2 cents each to watch their television set. This year again they sent their collection to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- A small group of financial experts from the West German national bank, the Bank Deutscher Laender, will arrive in London this week for exploratory talks with British authorities on the expansion and liberalization of trade between the two countries.

A generation ago cancer could be treated only with X-rays, radium and surgery. These are still mainstays. But with the rise of chemotherapy, the established influence of the sex hormones on the generation of tumors, the proof that genetics has something to contribute to our knowledge of cancer, the introduction of the hormones, nitrogen mustards and other chemical agents, the fields of investigation and of clinical practice have expanded.

The threat of an East Coast shipping strike, scheduled to begin Friday, was removed yesterday when the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, and a committee representing Atlantic and Gulf Coast ship operators agreed to a four-month extension of their present contract.

Formation of the All America Defense Association, a national civilian organization dedicated to increased military protection for the coastal and Great Lakes regions and Alaska and opposed to the strategic shifting of defense industries from these areas, was announced here yesterday.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 13 -- President Truman today asked his Committee on Religion and Welfare in the Armed Forces to arrange Christmas visits in homes for the many thousands of service men who cannot be with their families at the holiday season.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 13 (UP) -- Government officials charged tonight that well-organized Communists are trying to overthrow the Mexican Government and place a Communist regime over the Mexican people.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 13 -- Traicho Kostov, former Bulgarian Vice Premier, again denied in the Supreme Court in Sofia today that he was guilty of charges of espionage or treason.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- Abandonment of the "me-too" policy, which many persons believe cost the Republican party the last four Presidential elections, was urged today at a meeting here of the Republican Strategy Committee by Arthur E. Summerfield, its chairman.

The Public Service Commission will begin immediately a comprehensive investigation of the Long Island Rail Road to find "a workable solution" to the road's financial and operating problems and improve its service.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- An unexpectedly sudden crisis in the nation's coal supplies has brought the executive committee of the American Retail Coal Association to this city for an emergency meeting tomorrow, it was learned today.

John A. Dunbar of the Cushman Wakefield, Inc, through the same brokerage firm, and Scott A. Youmans, an executive of R. H. Mary Co, through Albert B. Ashforth, Inc, in Sutton Terrace on York Ave between 62d and 63d Sts -- Douglas L. Elliman Co, brokers.
CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- Officials at the college of the University of Chicago said it was "theoretically impossible."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Although more than $1,000,000 a year is being spent by the American Automobile Association to curb highway accidents, the toll continues to increase, according to Lou E. Holland, president of the organization.

Senator Herbert H. Lehman strongly criticized yesterday the decision by the United Nations to internationalize Jerusalem. He termed the United Nations action "unjust and unworkable" and called for correction of this "grievous mistake."

A syndicate headed by Joshua Sidney Shultz, which bought the six-story apartment house for twenty families at 242-46 East Fiftieth Street last June, yesterday resold it to the 252 East Fiftieth Street Corporation for cash over mortgages amounting to $79,000.

TRENTON, Dec. 13 -- Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons has written to O. John Rogge and other lawyers representing three of six Negroes awaiting trial for murder here, asserting that their charges of racial discrimination were unfounded.

DALLAS, Tex., Dec. 13 (UP) -- Civil Aeronautics Board examiners were told today that the first officer of the American Airlines plane which crashed here and killed twenty-eight persons two weeks ago "feathered" a second propeller of the crippled plane without the captain's knowledge. Feathering of a propeller puts its engine out of use.

George Mikan and the Minneapolis Lakers will oppose the New York Knickerbockers in a National Basketball Association encounter at Madison Square Garden tonight. A preliminary contest will pit St. Simon Stock of the Bronx against St. Michael's of Brooklyn in a C. H. S. A. A. engagement which will start at 7:30 P. M.
CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- One-third of a $120,000 dividend on the preferred stock of the Chicago Great Western Railroad was ordered impounded today by Federal Judge Walter J. La Buy.
The Society for Forgotten Music unearthed another interesting collection of musical curiosities for its second program of the season at Carl Fischer Hall last night.

The J. S. Gould Son's Company resold the two-story garage and loft building at 216 State Street, Brooklyn, to Dr. Bernard Stattman for investment. The Harry M. Lewis Company was the broker in the transaction, in which title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

NEWARK, N. J., Dec. 13 -- Raymond Welsh, 16 years old, was found guilty of first degree murder late this afternoon in the rifle killing of a 15-year-old friend on March 3. The jury of eight men and four women recommended a sentence of life imprisonment.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- London was threatened with a peacetime blackout tonight as outlaw strikes spread through the powerhouses of the recently nationalized electric industry. By using soldiers, sailors and airmen as replacements for the strikers the struck stations have been able to maintain output at about 75 per cent of normal.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 13 -- Sharpness in vision begins to diminish rapidly in most individuals at about 36 years of age, much sooner than they expect, members of the American Academy of Optometry were told today at the closing session of their annual convention.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- A House Foreign Affairs subcommittee returned from a mission of inquiry in Europe today with what one member termed a unanimous recommendation that no sort of West German rearmament should be allowed.

BOSTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Bob Cousy gave a masterful exhibition of ball handling, sinking 22 points and passing to at least half as many more, as the Holy Cross basketball team routed Dartmouth, 85 -- 53, tonight at the Boston Garden.

Some British M. P.'s went fishing in troubled waters on Monday and came up with a flabby red herring. The complaint was that the dining room of the House of Commons put grilled herrings on the menu but served them stewed or steamed "with one of those charity sauces that cover a multitude of sins."
Physicians, surgeons, nurses and other members of the Beth Israel Hospital staff met on a common ground yesterday that had nothing to do with hospital work or routine.

The Soviet Government has decided to give up the nine-story office building in New York now occupied by the Amtorg Trading Corporation and to move that representative of the Soviet foreign trade monopoly to smaller quarters of brownstone-house proportions. This move, which is, of course, in keeping with the Kremlin's estimate of the general world situation, foreshadows a further shrinkage in trade between the United States and the Soviet Union, already reduced to a trickle.

John D. Rockefeller Jr.'s conditional gift of $2,000,000 to the construction and teaching program at Memorial Hospital increases to more than $11,000,000 the total of his known benefactions in the last year and a half.

MIAMI, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Eight men were believed to have perished and eight others were missing tonight following an explosion and fire aboard the Dutch motorship Doros, 300 miles east of Miami. Eight were rescued.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Disorders in Eritrea resulting from a dispute over the future of that former Italian East African colony have now become an issue among the great powers.

TOKYO, Dec. 13 -- Japanese Government railway workers today called off a nation-wide wave of hunger strikes as the Cabinet gave indications of its willingness to compromise the increasingly explosive labor situation.

Making a rapid recovery in the last two weeks of the month from the effects of the steel strike, the nation's steel, mills in November turned out 4,145,294 net tons of raw steel, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This production compared with a revised figure of 926,082 tons for October, when 90 per cent of the industry was strike-bound, and with 7,797,558 tons in November, 1948.

Thomas Martin Polo, 40 years old, 20-60 Twenty-third Street, Astoria, Queens, was free on $20,000 bond last night after his earlier arraignment before United States Commissioner Edward W. McDonald as an "important link" in an alleged $1,000,000 counterfeit American Express travelers check ring.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- Robert Schuman, Foreign Minister, told the French National Assembly today that his Government would remain steadfast in its determination to defend the seventeen French nationals now being held by Poland in solitary confinement.

Four buildings containing a total of seven stores and fifty-four apartments at 3810 to 3816 Third Avenue, near Claremont Parkway, the Bronx, were leased for three years by the 3810 Third Avenue Corporation to the Joanatel Realty Corporation in a deal reported yesterday by L. H. Kahn and J. Zimmerman, the brokers.
The Hospital Council of Greater New York announced yesterday that it would accept new applications from municipal and voluntary hospitals for Federal construction grants after Jan. 1.

A survey of the water resources of the entire state will be pressed at the coming session of the Legislature, it was indicated yesterday. The aim will be a bipartisan commission to study present and potential water sources to prevent a recurrence of the water shortage.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 -- One of Senator Francis J. Myers', Democrat, of Pennsylvania, biggest non-legislative headaches is the annual Army-Navy football classic in Philadelphia.
