Higher prices for ranch and wild mink at both local and Montreal auctions have toned up the price structure on new season furs. The rise on mink, averaging some 25 per cent over the levels which marked the opening of the 1948-49 season, was in line with expectations.

Greer Garson arrived here from England yesterday to join her husband, Col. E. E. Fogelson, who is sick at New York Hospital. A spokesman for the hospital stated that early reports that Colonel Fogelson was suffering from a heart attack were untrue and that "causes of the ailment have not yet been ascertained.

Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter denied yesterday a petition by eight taxpayers for a summary inquiry into the alleged violations and neglect of duty by the City Collector's office in handling tax liens.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 13 -- Connecticut's bank commissioner, Richard Rapport, declared in his annual report today that "we are again threatened with inflation which profits a few immediately but serves no one in the long run." Commissioner Rapport's report was made to Governor Chester Bowles and covers the year ended on Sept. 30.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Winfield W. Riefler, assistant to the Federal Reserve Board chairman, said today there is every indication business will "remain strong through the first half of 1950."
LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 13 -- Following is the text of the statement made to the Israeli Parliament today by Premier David Ben-Gurion, as issued here by the Israeli delegation to the United Nations:

The United States delegation to the United Nations was urged yesterday to take the initiative to prohibit the atomic bomb as an instrument of international warfare and to back a world-wide program of general disarmament.

Possession basketball, long the chief stock in trade of Hank Iba's Oklahoma Aggies, boomeranged and blasted the Stillwater squad from the unbeaten ranks last night at Madison Square Garden. For the Blackbirds of Long Island University, rarely straying from the characteristic Oklahoma style of attack, upset the visitors, 38 -- 31, in the roughest court contest of the season.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Atilio Cattaneo, wanted by Argentine police on a charge that he insulted President Juan D. Peron, went into exile today in Uruguay.

The election of officers for Local 791 of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, will be held on Friday in the local's offices at 164 Eleventh Avenue, it was announced yesterday. Local 791, which covers the Chelsea district piers on the North River, is one of the ILA's largest units.

Dollar volume of the Northeastern lumber industry this year will come to approximately $97,000,000 at the mill level, Rand Stowell, vice president of the Northeastern Lumber Manufacturers Association reported yesterday. He said this represents a 15 per cent drop compared with 1948 in an interview following a directors meeting in the Statler Hotel.

New York City Housing Authority issued invitations yesterday for the submission of bids on Dec. 21 for $32,282,000 of temporary loan notes for financing the development cost of three state-aided projects. The notes will be dated Jan. 18, 1950, and will mature on Jan. 18, 1951.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Plans for formation of a New York State Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report were announced today by Jerome D. Barnum, former Syracuse publisher, who is attending the National Reorganization Conference here.

The Westchester County Golf Association elected a new leader last night at the annual meeting at the Hotel Biltmore. C. W. Benedict of the Whippoorwill Golf Club, Chappaqua, N. Y. was named president to succeed Ted Law, who has moved from the district to Fort Worth, Texas.

CHICAGO, Dee. 13 -- If the employe security programs spreading among American industry are to be successful, they must rest on a sound foundation and the "earning power of industry must be fostered in adequate degree" to enable it to meet its obligations, Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, declared here tonight.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., filed a petition yesterday asking permission to intervene in the application before the Civil Aeronautics Board for helicopter postal service in the New York area. A public hearing has been scheduled by the CAB in Washington for Jan. 9.

Initial testimony on how alleged export racketeers poured $500,000 worth of commodities into European and South American black markets under illegally issued licenses was submitted in Federal Court yesterday in the trial of three of thirteen men indicted last September by a Federal grand jury.

Summer training schedules for Reserve units at Pine Camp, N. Y., and Camp Edwards, Mass., were announced yesterday after commanders of Reserve divisions and representatives of the Department of the Army and the First Army met at Governors Island. The dates are as follows:

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The Strand, monthly magazine in which Sherlock Holmes and other famous characters in fiction first appeared, will cease publication at the end of February, it was announced today. The Strand first appeared in 1891 and has a circulation of more than 100,000.

HAVANA, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Gen. Genovevo Perez Damera, ousted as chief of the Cuban Army four months ago, offered his services to President Prio Socarras today if war breaks out with the Dominican Republic.

Investigation of the spring season activity in the New York selling offices of a dozen dress manufacturers reveals that the trade-marked and franchised lines are being ordered in quantities equal to or greater than those of a year ago, according to Erwin Feldman, director-counsel of the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers.
LONDON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Nasrullah, a great stallion whose progeny won thirty-three races this season, has been sold to an American syndicate for 132,000 ($369,600) -- a record export price.

Elliott V. Bell, Governor Dewey's chief adviser on domestic policy and economics for the last ten years, resigned yesterday as State Superintendent of Banks, effective as of Dec. 31, to become chairman of the executive committee of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company, Inc.

The coffee futures market recovered from Monday's weakness yesterday and at the close of trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange quotations stood 85 to 130 points above the previous day's close.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Census Bureau insisted today that the law gave it ample authority to require some 30,000,000 persons to report their personal incomes in the 1950 census.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Senator Brien McMahon of Connecticut urged the Federal Power Commission today to expedite approval of proposals to transport natural gas to Connecticut and New England. In a telegram to Chairman Nelson Lee Smith of the commission he said:
CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- December wheat and March and May corn sold at new seasonal high prices on the Board of Trade today as the result of heavy buying attributed to cash and export interests.

Gurgling and flashing a two-toothed smile, a 7-month-old baby, described only as Linda, became the fiftieth child yesterday to be placed in a foster home under the Department of Welfare's new Foster Home Program.

An additional chapter was added yesterday to a tale of violence in the Bronx when Emilia Westgate, 51 years old, of 832 East 152d Street was told that she had dodged the electric chair by informing on two Swedish seamen convicted of beating a Chinese laundryman to death in a robbery.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 13 -- Paul A. Porter, former Price Administrator, and Thurman Arnold, former Assistant Attorney General of the United States, have informed the American High Commissioner's office here that they have undertaken to act as attorneys for Baron Ernst von Weizsaecker, who is serving a seven-year prison sentence imposed by a United States War Crimes Tribunal last April.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Mrs. S. G. Steckler's Coyote, under a powerful ride by Bobby Strange, drove between the leaders in the stretch to capture the Bucksnort Purse at Tropical Park today. The gelding dropped his head in front of Brookmeade Stable's Music, the favorite, who was weakly handled.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was somewhat irregular yesterday and final prices were 2 points lower to 11 points higher than the day before.

HILLSDALE, Mich., Dec. 13 -- A total of $1,001,574,371 has been given this year by the members of fifty-two Protestant denominations for local church expenses and benevolences, it was announced here by the United Stewardship Council.

Publication of a list of possible concessions that the Board of Transportation reportedly was prepared to make at its meeting next Monday with the Transport Workers Union, CIO, was characterized yesterday by the board as "premature speculation."

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 13 -- Former City Clerk Francis X. Burke of this city lost his last hope of reinstatement today when Superior Court Judge Haydn Proctor ruled that the Congressional Medal of Honor winner did not have tenure of office.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The ballerinas of the Sadlers Wells ballet came home tonight loaded down with goodies to make the figure bulge.

An informal offering of pleasing Southern resort designs by Frances Sider, running the gamut from swim suits to sun dresses, regaled those fortunate enough to be in the sportswear department of Abraham Straus yesterday.

An inspector of the Federal Bureau of Investigation revealed yesterday in court that FBI agents had destroyed records of many of the conversations they had heard by tapping the wires of Judith Coplon and Valentin A. Gubitchev, who face trial here for conspiracy and espionage.

In the great struggle between East and West that has gone on since the war there have been various planes on which the conflict has been waged. There is, for example, the economic plane, and to win the contest in this sphere the United States has poured forth its billions through the Marshall and other foreign aid programs.

ALBANY, Dec. 13 -- Plans for a safety program in state government, covering accidents, health and fire prevention, were decided upon today at a conference of representatives of state departments and employes.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 985, compared with 1,752 last week and 886 in the similar week of last year, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 398 arrivals yesterday against 737 last Tuesday.
The Braves traded the veteran right-hander, Bill Voiselle, to the Cubs for Infielder Gone Mauch and an unannounced amount of cash late yesterday at the major league meetings here.

Edgar Bromberger performed yesterday his last official act as chief magistrate. Presiding in Brooklyn Felony Court, Magistrate Bromberger, whose retirement is effective Feb. 15, welcomed a branch of the Legal Aid Society to the court.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Investigation of the crash last night of a Capital Airlines DC-3 in the Potomac River near National Airport opened today while Navy salvage crews attempted to raise the shattered aircraft from a sandbar and transfer it to a barge.

The Foster Parents Plan for War Children, Inc., announced yesterday that it would end its relief activities in Poland on Dec. 31. At the same time CARE (Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe, Inc.), another relief agency, anounced it had ceased operations in that country.

Virginia Davis, daughter of the band leader, Meyer Davis, gave a program at Times Hall last night that she called "Portraits in Song." Using simple elements of costume, the young singer was in turn a folk singer, a monologist and a straight recitalist.

You have twice expressed your disapproval of the position the United Nations has taken with regard to the future status of Jerusalem. Your newspaper has been an outspoken supporter of the United Nations in the past. But you now take the position that this democratic body has arrived at the wrong conclusion upon an issue which can be settled justly and adequately only through reason and principle.

A new policy of running motion-picture ads in main news sections of newspapers and similar run-of-paper positions was announced yesterday by Universal-International Pictures. The innovations, it was explained by David A. Lipton, U-I's national advertising director, is the result of an experiment carried out in Chicago.

It will be a gray Christmas for thirty employes of a Manhattan photoengraving concern as a result of a fellow-worker allegedly having misappropriated Christmas Club money entrusted to him, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan revealed yesterday.

John Foster Dulles, making his first public speech since his defeat last month as the Republican candidate for Senator from New York, urged yesterday that the United States shift from the defensive to the offensive in the "cold war" with Russia.
Attorneys for Alger Hiss devoted the second day of their defense yesterday to a group of six character witnesses headed by John W. Davis, Democratic candidate for President in 1924.

Using painted beer barrels lent by a brewery, borrowed costumes and improvised scenery, the students of the city's High School of Music and Art will present, this week, an operatic production that will have at least one distinction -- it will not be "in the red."
BALTIMORE, Dec. 13 -- Baltimore, the world's third major port to experiment with radar harbor control, inaugurated its unit today with a demonstration, followed by a dinner tonight.

The great furor, known in some circles as the "deer drive," is echoing from the pine barrens, cedar swamps and bogs of Ocean County, for the New Jersey deer season is now in full swing -- or should we say cry.

TWENTY-SIX years ago in a high valley in the mountains of Northwestern Wyoming I made a discovery. In a collection of abandoned books, mostly the works of Gene Stratton Porter and Harold Bell Wright, which the former Eastern owner of a Western summer cottage had long forgotten, I stumbled upon a little green-bound volume called "Kokoro," by a writer with the strangely musical name of Lafcadio Hearn.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13 -- Demands for an immediate reduction of the Panama Canal tolls are increasing all along the West Coast. San Francisco Bay area spokesmen renewed their pleas several days ago at a meeting here under the auspices of the Bay Area Council, the fourth of its kind to be held on the coast on this subject.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- After being for two years without a legitimate theatre, the national capital will see a playhouse opened, perhaps in April, it was learned tonight.

Restoration of an unrestricted gold-coin standard would return the power over the public purse to the people "in theory only," according to a bulletin issued yesterday by Dean Rowland G. Collins, director, and Dr. Marcus Nadler, research director, of the Institute of International Finance, New York University.

Russell B. Kingman of Orange, N. J., received the award of the Lawn Tennis Writers Association of America yesterday as the one who had done the most for tennis in 1949. The award was made at the annual meeting of the writers at Leone's Restaurant.

We wish to thank you for your support of the $4,000,000 from the United States Government for financial aid to the needy Chinese students now in this country. Thanks to the good heart of the American people, the bill had been passed in Congress more than three months ago.

From Manila The Associated Press quotes an official source as saying that the Philippine Government has been informed that the United States will "take positive action to counteract the Communist threat to Formosa." This information, the source adds, is "very assuring to us."

An eleven-day Christmas music festival, in which thirty-two prominent choral groups will sing, will open today in Grand Central Terminal under the sponsorship of the New York Central and the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroads.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 13 -- The Old Dominion Electric Cooperative yesterday asked the state of Virginia for permission to bulid an electric generating and transmission system in an area now partly served by the large Virginia Electric and Power Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Plans are being pushed in the Government to name a committee of eminent private citizens to help fashion United States policy toward current world economic problems, it was learned today.

MOSCOW, Dec. 13 -- Pravda charged today that the Government of Premier Karl August Fagerholm was dragging Finland down the same "dangerous and disastrous road" that twice within ten years had led to war.

The Gardiner Realty Company has sold a vacant plot, 54 by 140 feet, at 1085-7 Elizabeth Avenue in Elizabeth, N. J., to the Penn-Jersey Auto Stores, Inc., of Philadelphia, Pa. The new owner will improve the parcel with a one-story building to be occupied in April by another in its chain of stores.
LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 13 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie received today the complicated job of drafting a future United Nations program to assist millions of needy children throughout the world.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., Dec. 13 (AP) -- This city's bid for 400 public housing units has been rejected because the City Council resolution contained a clause that would have restricted occupancy of the project to Negro families. The rejection was announced here today.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- When the Ministerial Steering Committee of the European Marshall Plan Council meets here next Tuesday it will face two major issues at what is considered a turning point in this recovery program.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Communist Government of Poland was accused today of using the Gdynia-America Line, Inc., as an "innocent-appearing medium" for propaganda in the United States.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Apparently as a result of suggestions made in the United States Congress, officials of the Economic Cooperation Administration have been studying whether some more positive use might not be made of the sterling funds that Britain sets aside as counterpart to dollar aid.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- Discords in the Government majority and a trend toward division in the Socialist party's national council today revived the tension that had been threatening the Cabinet of Premier Georges Bidault for some time.

All his life, T. Alfred Fleming has been trying to save persons from fire. From hell-fire when he was an evangelical minister in Ohio, from accidental fire on this earth, since 1917, when he became a professional fire-preventer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Department of Commerce reported today that the rise in business inventories during October was $60,000,000 below the seasonal normal. The coal and steel strikes were mentioned unofficially as probable factors.

Four windows presenting versions of the Christmas spirit were lighted up and unveiled by Lord Taylor yesterday morning at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street. Each window is done in the period of the Renaissance. Four different kinds of light associated with the feast are represented.

Two concertos, one an eighteenth-century concerto grosso by Vivaldi, the other the greatest of nineteenth-century violin concertos -- that of Brahms -- with Erica Morini as soloist, were played at the concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. Eugene Ormandy, the conductor, completed the program with the Sixth sympathy of Vaughan Williams.

The city's public school teacher organizations were united in protest yesterday against a Board of Education decision to increase the working hours of special-subject instructors assigned to high schools.

You say in your editorial of Dec. 10 on the U. N. decision to internationalize Jerusalem that now that the decision has been made, all parties should cooperate to implement the decision. This is a very shallow statement after your understanding editorial on the same subject on Dec. 9.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13 -- A former member of the American Communist hierarchy testified today that Harry R. Bridges became a member of the National Committee of the Communist party in 1936.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Harvard Alumni Bulletin has come to the defense of athletic director Bill Bingham in his stand that the Crimson must curb its so-called "big time" football.
Plans for construction of a national center for Reform Judaism moved another step forward yesterday with the announcement that Dr. Albert A. Berg had made a large gift to finance the project.

In a move which was termed a precautionary measure, the New York Rangers, enjoying a winning streak of four straight, yesterday announced that Jack Evans, defenseman, has been recalled from the New Haven Ramblers of the American Hockey League to fill in for Frank Eddolls, star defenseman.

We are all among the needy. Food, clothing, shelter -- these are not the only essentials of life, for one can be poor in understanding, poor in living one's life, no matter how well-to-do in terms of goods. We are all in need of guidance in the realm of the spirit.

Kentucky, minus its great stars of the last few years but plus a 7-foot sophomore center who has drawn rave notices, will make its annual basketball visit to Madison Square Garden tonight. The Wildcat quintet will face St. John's in the featured contest of a doubleheader that opens at 8 P. M. with a clash between City College and Brooklyn College.

TOKYO, Dec. 14 -- The Japanese Parliament today decided to seek the intervention of the United Nations in the vexed question of the repatriation of Japanese war prisoners from the Soviet Union that has dragged on for more than four years.

The negotiation of a state treaty for Austria was suspended here yesterday after the representatives of the United States, Britain and France had become convinced that the Soviet Union remained committed to a policy of non-cooperation.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 14 -- The United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund has decided to suspend further shipments of milk and food supplies to Rumania following the Bucharest Government's close-down of the agency's three-member mission Monday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today an increase in the added payments for one person occupying a compartment or drawing room southbound on Pennsylvania and New Haven Railroads.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 5 -- The resurgence of reactionary, radical nationalism with strong Nazi overtones is the most dangerous, long-term problem facing the Western powers and the Government of the Western German Federal Republic.

MANILA, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Government today banned free domestic trade in gold. Gold, in all forms but jewelry, was ordered turned into the Central Bank. The bank announced that restrictions on the removal of earnings of foreign films was under consideration.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 14 -- President Truman has fixed the ceiling on the 1951 fiscal year budget between $42,000,000,000 and $45,000,000,000, a White House source disclosed tonight, as the main outlines of the Fair Deal for 1950 began to emerge.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The October and November run on United States coffee stocks was set today at about 100,000,000 pounds by the Senate Price-Investigating Committee. The estimate was based on a special Census Bureau survey made public there.

A scene reminiscent of war days was re-enacted yesterday morning at Pier 4, Brooklyn Army Base, First Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street, when 268 soldiers, debarking from the Army transport Henry Gibbins, trooped down the vessel's gangplank and boarded a waiting five-car train, bound for Fort Dix, N. J.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Senator Robert A. Taft has hardened his conservative position after thirteen weeks of campaigning in Ohio and will take the lead in Congress in attacking the Truman Administration as a "handout state."

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Cries of distress from the impoverished British motion-picture industry elicited few, if any, signs of sympathy today from Harold Wilson, President of the Board of Trade, when he spoke in a House of Commons debate on film business.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Interior Department assured the nation today that it was not running out of water despite shortages in New York and other areas "where we don't have water where we want it when we want it."
Former President Herbert Hoover was honored yesterday for his leadership as a statesman and humanitarian by the Salvation Army Association of New York.

The United States of Indonesia, the latest of the world's free democracies, is now organizing itself as a going concern in preparation for the day -- Dec. 27 -- when it will assume among the Powers the separate and equal status of an independent and sovereign state linked with the Dutch Crown.

MIAMI, Fla., Thursday, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Coast Guard said early today five more survivors from the Dutch motorship Doros had been picked up by the Williamsburg, a merchant vessel, about thirty-five miles north of San Salvador, a little south of where the Dutch vessel exploded and burned Monday.

The city's population of nearly 5,000 hardworking horses is conserving water too, Sidney H. Coleman, executive vice president of the American Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, declared yesterday.

ALBANY, Dec. 14 -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein served notice today of an appeal to the Appellate Division at Albany from the lower court decision holding the 1949 Feinberg law unconstitutional.

Success of the modern "relaxed" approach to child rearing depends to a large extent on the personality of the mother and her reaction to the idea of self-regulation, according to Dr. Harry Bakwin of the Department of Pediatrics, College of Medicine, New York University-Bellevue Medical Center.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 14 -- Belgium's "royal question" will almost certainly come to a head at the end of next month when a "popular consultation" will be staged to sample public opinion on whether King Leopold III should return to his throne.

LANSING, Mich., Dec. 14 -- Price reductions up to $375 were announced today at a press preview of the 1950 Oldsmobile line here. The cuts included the straight reduction of cash paid in some models and the deletion of equipment from standard to optional classification in others.

Police Commissioner William P. O'Brien inspected yesterday some of the 50,000 toys that the Police Athletic League has collected for Christmas distribution to underprivileged children of the city. Then he appealed for more toys to brighten the holidays for 100,000 youngsters.

The forty-foot Douglas fir erected yesterday in Broad Street by the New York Stock Exchange will be lighted tomorrow. As in years past, recorded Christmas carols will be played from the outside gallery of the Exchange at noon and in the late afternoon commencing on Monday.

LONDON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A magistrate slapped fines totalling 281,175 ($787,290) on a London diamond firm and two of its officers today. They were convicted of avoiding customs and currency laws by sending rough stones to New York by way of Tangier.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- The stock markets here were much more cheerful today and many small gains were made. However, there was no real expansion of business.

A new gain of 1,856,000,000 gallons in water storage at the city's reservoirs in the twenty-four hours ended at 8 A. M. yesterday was credited by city officials in considerable measure to public conservation.

GENEVA, Dec. 14 -- Workers, employers and government delegates from six European countries reached agreement here today on a unified system of social security for Rhine River boatmen. The agreement, first of its kind, represents a new venture in methods of achieving European economic integration.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Trading in hogs and cattle turned active today in the major session of the week in the Union stockyards. Pork animals regained 25c to 35c a hundredweight and cattle were steady to 50c up. Declines up to 50c continued in the lamb pens, however. The report by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, N. J., Dec. l4 -- Donald Doubrava was on his way home to Fairview Park, Ohio, today to spend the Christmas holidays with his parents and to show them the "miracle" of his being able to walk and use his hands.

Museums are not always the stodgy places people think they are, where the lowered voice and discreet behavior are the rule. There was plenty of noise and merriment yesterday at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.

Increased engine power, comfort and safety were emphasized in the 1950 line of Chevrolet commercial cars and trucks announced yesterday by the Chevrolet Division, General Motors Corporation. The line includes twenty series on nine wheelbases with gross vehicle weights ranging from 4,100 to 16,000 pounds.

In the latest of a series of jewel robberies in the suites of guests of big hotels here, $36,000 worth disappeared some time between 7 P. M. Tuesday and 12:35 A. M. yesterday from the bedroom of Mrs. Doris Gershenson, known better as Doris Fisher, song writer, in the Sherry-Netherlands, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

A session of Christmas Cooky making was held in THE NEW YORK TIMES' test kitchen earlier this week. Mrs. Ruth P. Casa-Emellos, home economist, baked batches of German springerle, sugar cookies in shapes befitting the season and crunchy filbert macaroons.

There has been much emphasis of late -- and rightly so, in our opinion -- on the need for increased economic integration among the countries of Western Europe. But we think the person who scans the 30,000-word report by Secretary of Commerce Sawyer on the tangle of economic contradictions which we know as the American transportation system is likely to conclude that, like charity, integration might well begin at home.

An action for $4,860,000 damages and a permanent injunction under the Clayton Act was filed in Federal Court yesterday by the Interborough News Company, 525 West Fifty-second Street, against seventeen publishing and distributing companies and twenty of their officers.

Lis Broge, Danish soprano, came a long way to make her American debut at Town Hall last night, and it would be pleasant to report that it was worth it. But her singing was not impressive, despite the potentialities of the voice.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 14 -- Apparently unanimous condemnation by his colleagues today forced a Rightist member to withdraw from further participation in the Bundestag until charges that he had made a Nazistyle speech could be investigated.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, indicated today that he favored some cuts in excise taxes as a part of removing "inequities" in the tax system.

RUTLAND, Vt., Dec. 14 -- When two youngsters from New York, the late Brad Mead and his wife, Janet, came to this New England community in the early Nineteen Thirties and told the natives of their plans for a ski development, they were told to forget their "fanciful dream."

DETROIT, Dec. 14 (UP) -- Joel Louis, once this city's favorite boxing son, was booed lustily by a disappointed crowd of 9,252 at Olympia tonight as he shuffled through two five-round exhibitions against equally uninspired foes.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Dec. 14 -- Returning to this country after three months as musical adviser at the American Academy in Rome, Samuel Barber, American composer and Pulitzer Prize winner, announced that his first piano sonata, written for the twenty-fifth anniversary of the American League of Composers, will be played for the first time by Vladimir Horowitz at Carnegie Hall Jan. 19.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Black Hawks ended the New York Rangers' four-game winning streak and rose out of the National Hockey League basement tonight by winning, 5 to 3, before 12,139 persons at the Stadium. Chicago took fifth place, one point ahead of Boston.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- In the first of two articles published in this space last week on the legal issue raised by the decision of the Census Bureau to gather statistics on individual incomes in its 1950 inquiries as it did in 1940, this correspondent pointed out that involved were (1) a statute passed in 1929 and (2) the general question of what is a "reasonable" exercise of federal power.
The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals will open a $500,000 fund-raising campaign today for a new hospital and shelter for animals.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 14 -- Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion declared here today that "we have entered upon the greatest political struggle in the history of our people."

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- With the signing of a 133,000,000 ($372,400,000) one-year trade agreement between Britain and Sweden here today some British trade officials predicted that Britain soon would be gradually abandoning such bilateral arrangements and adopting a freer mode of trade.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Oil experts in London estimated today that foreign companies interested in the Iraq Petroleum Company and consolidated refineries in Haifa had so far lost 10,000,000 ($28,000,000) in income as a result of the inactivity of the refineries.
Buying by Russia and her satellites is affecting world futures markets in such commodities as rubber, wool tops and hides, according to traders here yesterday.
KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 14 (AP) -- The White House said tonight that President Truman had taken "no action" on a Navy selection board's recommendations for promotion from captain to rear admiral.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 14 -- Traicho Kostov, former Deputy Premier of Bulgaria and leader among eleven Communists accused of treason, was found guilty today on all charges against him and sentenced to death.
Is television of college football games keeping spectators at home and away from the stadiums?

Tonight 160 elderly residents of the Warschauer Haym Salomon Home for the Aged at 136 Second Avenue on the lower East Side will lift their wine cups high in tribute to a close friend and fellow-resident, Isaac Fishberg. For Isaac will be 100 years old and his birthday falls on the eve of Hanukkah -- the Feast of Lights.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 14 (AP) -- Elkcam Stable's Blue Zac won the Variety Club Purse at Tropical Park today in a field of six 2-year-olds.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- The world's strangest garden, where atomic "fruits" literally grow on radioactive trees and plants, was displayed here today to leaders in nuclear research attending the three-day conference called by the United States Atomic Energy Commission to discuss the commission's future program.

It is regrettable that the spokesmen of government policy in South Africa seem unable to meet criticism on its merits but must rather attribute motives of malice to those who call attention to the consequences of these policies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Dr. Harold C. Urey, an atomic scientist, asserted today that a single bomb with 1,000 times the power of the present atomic bomb could wipe out New York or Washington, but warned that it would still take ten years for a third world war to run its course.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- The American Retail Coal Association, which describes itself as representing "thousands of the retail coal merchants in the bituminous coal-consuming area of the United States and the great majority of all bituminous coal sold at retail," today demanded that the Government intervene immediately in the coal shortage.

THE Book-of-the-Month Club people did a fine day's work when they chose E. B. White's "Here Is New York" for their double-of-the-year. As you probably remember, Mr. White's tale of one city appeared first in Holiday magazine then was reprinted in enough hundreds of thousands of copies to put a carpet right around the town.

NEWTON, Mass., Dec. 14 -- Francis R. Hart Jr., a prominent New England theatrical figure and son of a former president of the United Fruit Company, killed himself with a pistol in his home here today. He was 50 years old.

Consideration of a dividend on the common stock of the American Zinc, Lead and Smelting Company was deferred by directors yesterday until a later meeting "in view of current working capital requirements."

Traicho Kostov, Bulgaria's greatest Communist leader after the late Georgi Dimitrov, is being hanged because he "kept secret from the Soviet delegation the prices of some Bulgarian products." That was not the reason given at the trial which has just ended, where he alone refused to recant and was sentenced to death while the others received prison sentences, but it must be the real reason because nothing else makes the slightest sense.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Senator Guy M Gillette, Democrat, of Iowa, accused the State Department in effect today of having kept secret the presence in this country of Herman J. Abs, a German banker with a "background" of Nazi collaboration.
The 1920 "flapper" silhouette is not completely in fashion. Newer than this is a return to the period of 1900.

As Dr. Vannevar Bush indicates in the first chapter of his recent book, "Modern Arms and Free Men," the principal purpose of the book is to stimulate public discussion and understanding of the impact of science on war, so that public opinion can determine the proper course for a great democracy in the age of scientific war.

Factory dollar volume of domestic dinnerware manufacturers this year will drop 25 to 30 per cent compared with last year, spokesmen for the United States Potters Association revealed yesterday. In interviews following Concluding sessions of the group's annual convention in the Astor Hotel, they described sales in the fourth quarter as only "fairly satisfactory" and added they do not offset the "disastrous" second and third quarters.
JERUSALEM. Dec. 14 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Ben-Gurion, in a speech here tonight, said:

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- Reports from French officials in Saigon today indicated that "several thousand" Chinese Nationalist troops had crossed into Indo-China and had there been disarmed without difficulty.

Governor Dewey declined yesterday to give his support to suggestions that the state government mission" be set up in New York State. Such a commission would attempt, on a state-wide basis, what the Commission on Organization of the Executive branch of the Government, headed by former President Herbert Hoover, has done in the nation.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 14 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo of the Philippines, President of the General Assembly, and Sir Benegal Rau, Indian representative to the United Nations, have been requested to submit formal proposals on atomic control to the six permanent members of the Atomic Energy Commission.
CASEY STENGEL was sauntering through the lobby and Mickey Cochrane stepped in front of him, a huge grin on his face and hand outstretched. "Hiya, Case?" he said.

An increase last week of 882,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 106,146,000 barrels, against 105,264,000 a week earlier, and 97,110,000 a year ago.
CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- Negotiations between the country's railroads and their 175,000 conductors and trainmen on the union's demands for wage, hour and rule concessions ended in disagreement today.

Emphasizing the need for public and private welfare agencies, Raymond M. Hilliard, Commissioner of Welfare, urged support yesterday for the $50,500,000 program of the Federation of Jewish Philanth ropies. He told 300 women at the federation's first annual conference of Bronx women's organizations in the Concourse Plaza Hotel that the fundamental problems of preventing dependency or delinquency are solved by agencies of the type of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The United States renewed diplomatic relations today with the Government of Panama, but Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared that this act did not imply approval of the manner in which the Arias regime had come to power.

Miss Joan Francke Remick, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Gould Remick of Cedarhurst, L. I., who was introduced to society in New York at the Junior Assembly on Nov. 25 at the Ritz-Carlton, will be presented also at the Debutante Cotillion and Christmass Ball to be held on Monday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the New York Infirmary.
Testimony in the Coplon-Gubitchev spy case turned unexpectedly yesterday from illegal wire tapping to illicit romance.

ABOARD S. S. LAKELAND VICTORY, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Safely out of Chinese Communist waters, Consul General Angus Ward said today the "spy trial" at Mukden that ended with his deportation order was "curiously interesting."

BERLIN, Dec. 14 -- En route to Moscow from the United Nations conference in New York, Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, paused in Berlin today for a state visit, obviously intended to counteract the favorable impression created among the populace by the recent trip to this city of Dean Acheson, United States Secretary of State.
ALBANY, Dec. 14 -- The State Senate chamber and lobby, renovated at a cost of $800,000, were opened for inspection today by Senate leaders. Work on the chamber has been carried on since last April.
MOBILE, Ala., Dec. 14 (AP) -- Eddie Stanky said today Leo Durocher was his type of manager and that he was happy to be back with his old boss.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The State Department took issue with Colonial Airlines today for using a 150-year-old law to justify its failure to take part in an aviation hearing before the Canadian Air Transport Board.

TRENTON, N. J., Dec. 14 -- In an effort to save taxpayers of the seventh Congressional District $35,000 in costs of a special primary election to choose a successor to Representative J. Parnell Thomas, the office of Attorney General Theodore Parsons is investigating means to eliminate the primary.

The national colors of the Republic of Korea will fly in New York harbor for the first time on Tuesday when the gunboat Bak Du San, latest addition to the Korean Navy, departs for her new home under the command of Admiral W. Y. Sohn.
VIENNA, Dec. 14 -- Viennese laundry owners today held a protest meeting and accused two American business men of stealing their customers.
An increasing number of business companies and executives are contributing to THE NEW YORK TIMES Neediest Cases Fund, which yesterday received 564 gifts totaling $11,092.99.

VIENNA, Dec. 14 -- Prof. Wilhelm Taucher, head of Austria's new agency to handle European Recovery Program allocations, said today that future Marshall Plan aid must not be used for any project, no matter how necessary, that does not benefit Austria's trade balance.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The biggest harvest of the tax season starts tomorrow.

VIENNA, Dec. 14 -- Mrs. Robert A. Vogeler, wife of the vice president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company who was arrested in Budapest by Hungarian political police a month ago, cabled President Truman today asking for help in freeing her husband.
LIVERPOOL, England, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The famous old transatlantic liner Aquitania is to be taken out of active service.

Every democratic government is faced, to a greater or less degree, by the problem discussed in a stimulating report published yesterday by the research and policy committee of the Committee for Economic Development. It is the problem of security vs. freedom. Under present world conditions, security is obviously a prime requisite for this and every other democracy.

A greatly expanded program for aiding employers and communities to explain the American economic system has been undertaken by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, it was announced yesterday. Known as the "American Opportunity Program," the campaign is being conducted by the chamber's committee on advertising with the view to reach 2,500 local chambers of commerce and 500 trade associations.

American industry faces higher steel prices today. The United States Steel Corporation, which as the nation's leading producer accounts for 32 per cent of domestic steel production, announced yesterday that it is preparing to publish higher quotations on some products because of increased costs.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, predicted yesterday that Governor Dewey eventually would give his "reluctant consent" to the proposal for a $500,000,000 state bond issue for new schools. The bond issue was urged at hearings on a 1950 legislative program held by Democratic members of the State Legislature on Monday and Tuesday of this week.

TORONTO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens scored in the last minute to gain a 2-2 tie with Toronto tonight before 13,533 fans at Maple Leaf Garden. The two teams remained tied for second place in the National Hockey League.

Even the gloomiest pessimist will concede, if pressed, that there are one or two things which are delightful, or charming, or whatever little-used word he can pluck from the bottom of his vocabulary. A sail at sunset deserves this word, and a purple haze following a summer's sudden rain.

Charley Brickley, who kicked thirty-five field goals for Harvard football teams between 1911 and 1915, was arrested early yesterday with a son, Charles Brickley Jr., after a brisk scrimmage at Reuben's Restaurant, 6 East Forty-eighth Street.
The fourteen-day Christmas Cruise of the liner De Grasse to the West Indies and South America, scheduled for Dec. 23, has been canceled by the French Line.

Food packers yesterday charged here that many grocers are failing to reduce retail prices on canned goods to keep them in line with replacement costs. Some grocers are maintaining prices at levels of last year despite the fact that goods are gathering dust on shelves.

As club owners of the National and American Leagues closed their annual winter conclave yesterday amid an unprecedented orgy of player deals, it remained for the Giants and Braves to grab the eleventh-hour spotlight with one of the biggest transactions in recent years.

WARSAW, Dec. 14 -- All four French defendants in the spy trial opening in Wroclaw are in poor physical condition, Gustav Martin, French Consul General in Katowice, reported today. He was the first French official permitted to see the French nationals since they were arrested last March on charges that they were working against the security of the Polish state.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Dec. 14 -- Fifteen men and a woman nurse lost their lives shortly before the noon lunch hour today in a bomb-like explosion at the Swift Co. packing plant here.

Ossy Renardy, who was heard last night at Carnegie Hall, is not yet 30, but he is already a distinguished violinist. His recital offered playing of rare quality yet it also left one wishing such gifts could have been turned to music of greater profundity.

Five, five - story apartment houses at 609 to 619 West 135th Street, which were acquired by foreclosure by the Dry Dock Savings Institution, have been resold to an investor, it was reported yesterday by David Vogel, Inc., the broker in the deal.
SOFIA, Dec. 14 -- Mr. Kostov remained seemingly calm and unmoved as he had apparently been throughout the trial as the convictions and sentences were read in court today.
ROME. Dec. 14 -- Vatican officials today expressed concern over what they called "Israel's defiant attitude" in regard to the establishment of an international regime in Jerusalem.

BOSTON, Dec. 14 -- Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam told fellow Methodists tonight that it took political leaders until 1948 to stand behind social gains that "the clear thinking of churchmen" had advocated in 1908.

Accused of the fatal shooting of his brother, a 32-year-old man was held on a homicide charge in Felony Court yesterday after hearing, with sullen unconcern, the magistrate compare the crime to the Biblical murder case of Cain and Abel.

A "public inventory" of progress made in this country during the last fifty years will keynote a wholly new program devised by the Advertising Council for its 1950 campaign to improve public understanding of the American economic system, it was learned yesterday.

Quite contrary to Paul A. Gardner's contention in his recent letter, "That Labor Octopus" in the Oct. 29 issue of The Nation does not reduce the McGraw-Hill president's so-called "blast" at labor union monopoly to a "puff of smoke." Had the McGraw-Hill president been arguing that only labor constituted a monopoly, the article in The Nation would have been an apt rejoinder.
The Community Service Society, which is beginning its 102d year as a welfare agency, yesterday adopted a yearly budget of $3,600,000.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Government laid claim today to the $30,000,000 Garrett snuff fortune as "spoils of war."

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 14 -- President Truman accepted today, on behalf of the country, a portrait of George Washington by Gilbert Stuart. It will be hung in a state room of the White House after the old mansion is reconstructed.

Fitzie Pruden, a welterweight from St. Catherine's, Ont., who punches like a perpetual-motion machine, last night knocked out Al Hersh, East Sider, in the sixth round of their scheduled ten-round feature at the St. Nicholas Arena. A crowd of 1,065, paying receipts of $2,301, saw Pruden, 146 1/2, get credit for a knockout victory when Referee Frank Fullam halted the battle in 2:59 of the sixth.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Navy said today it had trained Russian officers to operate radar-equipped submarine chasers that were lend-leased to Russia during the war.

In twelve years beginning with 1951, New York State's high school enrollment will make a phenomenal rise of more than 250,000 pupils over 1947 registration, an official of the State Board of Regents forecast yesterday.

The booking of Carson McCullers' play, "The Member of the Wedding," into the Empire Theatre, was announced yesterday by the producing firm of Robert Whitehead, Oliver Rea and Stanley Martineau. The attraction, starring Ethel Waters and featuring Julie Harris, will make its local debut on Thursday evening, Jan. 5. Next Thursday it starts an engagement of nine days at Philadelphia's Walnut Street Theatre.

Display Builders, Inc, in 109 W 64th St; Neda Foundations, Inc, in 559 6th Ave; United States Vitamin Corp, in 232 E 43d St; Sam Savitz and Harold Winnekoff, importers, in 133 W 25th St; Nu-Process Label Co, Marrow Hosiery Co of Pennsylvania, Institute Market Bureau, Inc, and Fox Birkhahan, offices and showroom for boys' and men's wear, in 1270 Broadway -- Spear Co, brokers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today that certain unresolved issues were holding up the completion of the bilateral agreements between the United States and each of the North Atlantic Treaty nations for the shipment of arms under the military-aid program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission agreed today to reconsider a claim by builders of a proposed natural gas system in the New York metropolitan area that they are not subject to jurisdiction by the commission. No date for oral argument was set.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson disclosed today that additional action was being considered by the State Department for the release of two United States service men held by the Chinese Communists.

"Undertow," a Universal-International melodrama with Scott Brady, Dorothy Hart and Bruce Bennett, which arrives at the Palace, is this morning's lone film newcomer. William Castle directed and Ralph Dietrich produced from a screen play by Arthur T. Herman and Lee Loeb. Peggy Dow, Robert Anderson and Dan Ferneil are among the featured players
HELSINKI, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A dispute which jeopardizes the Olympic Games in Helsinki in 1952 came to a crisis today when Socialists in the City Council threatened to block appropriations for the game.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- Secundo Campini, Italian jet propulsion expert and former employe of the Tucker Corporation, testified today regarding two transactions which, he said, virtually depleted his checking account the day he opened it.

A Christmas Eve program originating in Bethlehem, Pa., will be carried by NBC television from 11 to 11:45 P. M. on Dec. 24. It will include the choral service from the Cathedral Church of the Nativity, where the choir of seventy men and boys will be heard under the direction of Robert Knox Chapman.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Dec. 14 (AP) -- The General Electric Company announced today development of an improved instrument for analyzing substances with X-ray.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 14 -- Jesse L. Lasky will move to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Monday as associate producer on his long-delayed project, "The Life of Caruso," which he has been preparing since 1945, when he acquired the screen rights to Mrs. Dorothy Caruso's biography of her husband, "Enrico Caruso, His Life and Death," Metro announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The National Labor Relations Board today moved one step toward seeking court enforcement of its order directing the International Typographical Union, AFT, to refrain from violating the closed-shop ban of the Taft-Hartley Act.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 14 -- Yugoslav propaganda services accused the Soviet Government today of pursuing the same policy as the Nazis in dispersing and annihilating entire nations within its own borders. The Yugoslav assertions came close to the accusation of genocide against the Soviet Government.

The American Chemical Society, 60 East Forty-second Street, has elected as chairman of its board Dr. Charles Allen Thomas, executive vice president of the Monsanto Chemical Company, St. Louis, and one of the key figures in the development of atomic energy, it was announced yesterday.

A last-minute decision to fix up the house before the holidays need not involve a frantic rush to the upholsterer or decorator. It can be accomplished quickly, inexpensively and attractively with ready-made slipcovers. There are even some made to fit odd sizes and modern furniture shapes, as well as various sofa-bed combinations.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- There was a lack of the aggressive buying of wheat and corn by cash and export interests on the Board of Trade here today which had featured trading in futures yesterday. Liquidation developed in December wheat and it closed 2 1/4 to 2 1/2 cents a bushel lower at 5 3/4 cents over the May contract after selling at 5 cents above at one time, against 8 cents on Tuesday.

Directors of the Chase National Bank acted yesterday to transfer $10,000,000 from reserve for contingencies to undivided profits and $35,000,000 from undivided profits to surplus. The move increased the surplus account from $154,000,000 to $189,000,000, effective on Dec. 31.

The Citizens Budget Commission urged yesterday, at a public hearing before the City Council's finance committee, establishment of "a realistic, integrated master plan" on which the city's capital budget could be based.
ROME, Dec. 14 -- Ingrid Bergman today said she would marry Roberto Rosellini, Italian film director, as soon as she obtained a divorce from her husband, Peter Lindstrom.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 7:

OGDEN, Utah, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A sharp reduction in the Amalgamated Sugar Company's earnings the last year compared with the previous twelve months was reported today. H. A. Benning, president, in his report to stockholders, listed these figures:
BETHLEHEM, Conn., Dec. 14 -- The Yuletide has come again to this little community -- population 750 -- in the picturesque Litchfield County hills, which is known as "The Christmas Town."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Public housing is playing an important role in the economic rehabilitation of families of low income, Raymond M. Foley, Housing and Home Finance Administrator, told a joint Congressional investigating subcommittee today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 14 -- The Rev. Dr. Ralph L. Woodward, assistant dean of Yale Divinity School, has been named president of Central College, Fayette, Mo., it was announced today. He will assume the post in June.
HONG KONG, Dec. 14 -- Chinese Communists charged today that the French and Bao Dai in Indo-China were planning to incor porate Chinese Nationalist troops into Viet Nam anti-Communist forces.
George Lamson has been appointed manager of the automotive replacement sales division of the Thermoid Company of Trenton, N. J. He has been with the company since 1935.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- A Congressional inquiry into the availability of equity capital entered the realm of President Truman's Point Four program today when Philip D. Reed, chairman of the board of the General Electric Company, said that "difficulties and risks" associated with investment abroad were "greater today than ever before."

Out of the flurry of deals which came just as the major league meetings were on the verge of adjournment, the Detroit Tigers came up with one of the most important when they acquired Gerry Priddy from the St. Louis Browns.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 14 -- The United States replied today to a challenge by Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, by producing a letter from Constantin Visoianu, former Foreign Minister of Rumania, charging that Mr. Vishinsky had issued a two-hour ultimatum to King Michael on Feb. 28, 1945, demanding the replacement of the Rumanian regime by a Communist dictatorship.

Mr. and Mrs. William Ziegler Jr. gave a luncheon yesterday in the west ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for Dr. Robert B. Irwin, retiring executive director of the American Foundation for the Blind. Dr. Irwin has served for twenty-six years, since the founding in 1926 of the organization which has advanced the welfare of blind persons all over the world.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 14 -- Thirty-six Protestant church leaders representing seven of this country's major denominations opened a three-day conference here tonight with the avowed intention of drawing up an acceptable blueprint for the ultimate union of American Protestantism.

I have recently received a list of publications, other than farmers' bulletins, prepared for free distribution by the United States Department of Agriculture. There were some eighty-five titles on the list, including these: "If You're Thinking About a Little Place in the Country," "Mending Men's Suits," "How to Tailor a Woman's Suit," "Eat a Good Breakfast to Start a Good Day," "How to Choose and Use Your Refrigerator," "Make-Overs From Leather, Fur and Felt."

Minneapolis had George Mikan but New York had an alert, opportunistic and tightly knit team on the floor and so the Knicks, registering the twelfth victory in their last thirteen starts, defeated the Lakers, 94 to 84, before an estimated 9,500 spectators at Madison Square Garden last night.

Plans for the erection of a modern business building in Getty Square, Yonkers, N. Y., were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the old Radford Hall Building by the Samuel B. Hawley Estate to Samuel Knepper, New York operator and builder.

Trustees of the Long Island Rail Road charged last night that Nassau County had hampered their study of the specific financial and operating problems of the bankrupt carrier that the Public Service Commission now proposes to investigate at public cost.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 -- Harry R. Bridges was pictured today to a Federal Court jury as a labor leader occupying a position so strategic for the Communist party that only once did party heads dare risk permitting his attendance at a meeting of the party's national committee.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 14 (AP) -- St. Louis University, one of the oldest schools west of the Mississippi River, is dropping intercollegiate football -- chiefly because it has proved too costly. The announcement was made today by the Catholic university's president, the Very Rev. Paul C. Reinert.

ALBANY, Dec. 14 -- The State Board of Canvassers announced today, after an official tabulation of the votes cast Nov. 8, that former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate, had defeated John Foster Dulles, Republican, for Senator by 198,057 votes.

The latest unit in the City Center's family of artistic producing enterprises made its bow last night under the name of the New York City Dance Theatre, and got off to a fine start. Its field of operation is the modern dance, as differentiated from the ballet, and its personnel includes almost all the leading figures in that art form.

Jacob S. Potofsky, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, CIO, announced yesterday that the Congress of Industrial Organizations committee of which he is head will hear charges beginning Jan. 4 against the International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers, CIO, in Washington.

Sixty-five college graduates from this country and abroad are to benefit from fellowships valued at $42,850 for study at the New York School of Social Work, Columbia University. Although it is a fact that these students may otherwise not have been able to enter on a social work career, the awards have a significance beyond their monetary value.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- Farmers should speak for themselves on national agricultural policy, and other groups, including government agencies, business and labor, should not try to "call the shots" for farmers, Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat, of New Mexico, said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- In a report condemning "the present trend toward undue secrecy" in the conduct of national defense policies, the Committee for Economic Development warned today that public apathy or ignorance in such matters was dangerous to essential liberties and could lead to a "garrison-police state" here.

Declaring that a renewed attack upon the British problem is long overdue, the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce yesterday declared the first undertaking should be a constructive reorganization of the more than $9,000,000,000 in Britain's wartime blocked sterling balances.

Beset by domestic manufacturing subsidiary losses, the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's consolidated net income of $2,973,240 for the nine months to Sept. 30 showed a drop of $3,078,382 from the $6,051,622 reported in the same period in 1948.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- There were reliable indications tonight that the three-day-old unofficial strike that has spread to four big power plants serving the London area might end tomorrow. The 2,700 strikers will attend mass meetings in the morning to hear appeals from strike leaders for an immediate return to work.

Five officers of the council of organizations of the United Jewish Appeal left New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday on an Air France plane for Israel, where they will confer with that country's leaders on the participation of New York Jews in refugee resettlement.
DETROIT, Dec. 14 -- American motorists are much safer today on their highways than they were three years ago.

Many of those who took to the woods or fields with a gun last season will be surprised to learn there were only 12,534,455 others engaged in the same form of recreation, although the report just compiled by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service indicates that the 1948-49 license sales reached a new high. Wait until they get around to the 1949-50 totals.

Appointment of Dr. J. Harris Purks, director of the University Center in Georgia, as associate director of the General Education Board, 49 West Forty-ninth Street, was announced yesterday. He succeeds Dr. A. Hollis Edens, who resigned last year to become president of Duke University.

In an effort to improve retail selling methods for his company's products and at the same time learn first-hand some of the points-of-sale resistance to be overcome, Nathan I. Cummings, chairman of the board of Consolidated Grocers, world's largest food wholesalers, just completed a nation-wide study of grocery stores.

Sure lure to the southland was the Russeks' resort collection yesterday at the Pierre Hotel that afforded in turn glimpses of cloud-light fleece greatcoats in snowy white and pastels, vivid Haitian prints, frocks of fluid pleats, beachwear and street-length evening cottons to wear beneath a tropical moon.

The revised schedule of relief payments, announced by Welfare Commissioner Raymond Hilliard on Nov. 28, was interpreted and discussed yesterday at a meeting of private agency executives and officials of the Welfare Department at the Welfare Council, 44 East Twenty-third Street.

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- A rising conflict within the Government majority was threatening tonight to frustrate Premier Georges Bidault's effort to get the budget passed next week, and it has placed the Cabinet's chances of survival at the mercy of a political incident.

The New York Public Service Commission voted yesterday to hold public hearings next week to determine whether a ban should be ordered on the daily "broadcasts" over the loudspeaker system in Grand Central Terminal.

The New York City Housing Authority borrowed yesterday $41,400,000 on city-guaranteed tax-exempt bonds maturing serially until 1998 at an aggregate interest cost of $31,577,106, or about 2.622 per cent.
Testimony as to the reputation of Alger Hiss as a loyal State Department official dominated his second perjury trial yesterday as the denfense went into its third day.

It was 158 years ago today that the first ten amendments to the Constitution -- the "Bill of Rights" -- went into force. From that day to this, the American people have had to maintain constant vigilance to insure that these most fundamental of their liberties were not chipped away.

Jacob Glass Son have purchased the six-story apartment house accommodating seventy-one families at 43-34 Forty-ninth Street in Sunnyside, Queens, from Isadore Fink. The property, on a plot 135 by 100 feet, is assessed at $213,000. Benjamin Newman was the broker and Samuel Rothstein and Reuben Lesser were the attorneys.
Progress in their negotiations for a new contract was reported yesterday by spokesmen for the United Mine Workers and Pennsylvania anthracite operators.

BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A provisional constitution welding a new nation of 77,000,000 persons out of the Indonesian Islands was signed tonight by delegates of the sixteen states and territories.

The stock market put on yesterday a show of strength that was unparalleled for this time of year. In the broadest market on record on the New York Stock Exchange prices climbed to the best levels since the summer of 1946 and, while profit-taking slowed the momentum, bidding outweighed the pressure.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Serge Koussevitzky, whose direction of the Boston Symphony Orchestra for a quarter century made it one of the world's great musical organizations, today gave the Library of Congress more than $100,000 to help composers of good music.

The Feinberg Law, designed to eliminate Communist teachers from the public school system, was declared unconstitutional yesterday for the second time in a State Supreme Court test case. Also declared void was the section of the Civil Service Law which the Feinberg Law was intended to implement.

The American Association of Advertising Agencies' New York Council will hold its fourth annual examination for advertising here on Feb. 18 and 25, it was announced yesterday. The examinations are intended for students in their final year of college and for persons in business, who are under 30 years of age.

Calling the Civil Aeronautics Act of 1938 "the Magna Charta of air transportation," Carleton Putnam, chairman of the board of Chicago Southern Air Lines, Inc., declared yesterday that it was under "a well-organized and calculated attack" from several directions.

According to the records in this office, which do not go back much beyond 1492, J. M. Synge's "Deirdre of the Sorrows" has never been done professionally in New York. This is difficult to believe, because Synge was one of the supreme geniuses of dramatic poetry and "Deirdre" is a masterpiece of romantic tragedy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Navy announced today that it had placed a $24,000,000 order for an unspecified number of "rough-water" seaplanes designed for antisubmarine warfare.

The first national carbide tool educational service plan of Carboloy Company, Inc., Detroit, is now being supplied to engineering and vocational training schools throughout the country to aid tool engineering education.
WACO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Young Bob Woodruff, who rebuilt Baylor's sagging gridiron fortunes, will continue as head coach.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UP) -- The steel industry argued today against a "bitter-end" fight in the basing-point price case and urged the Federal Trade Commission to accept a settlement that would ban inter-company price fixing.

Despite the "cold war" and the indicated curtailment of the activities of the Amtorg Trading Corporation, the Soviet Union counts on a market in the United States for a heavy percentage of her furs during the coming year.

Indications of neglect of bedridden veterans of World War II are contained in essays submitted by non-ambulatory veterans to Crossroads of the World Post No. 310, Veterans of Foreign Wars, according to William Calhoun Hope, commander.

Growing evidence from motion-picture research indicates that many instructional and educational films have been "paced too fast" for the learner, Dr. C. R. Carpenter, Director of the Instructional Film Research Program at Pennsylvania State College, declared yesterday. Greater repetition of the points stressed in a teaching film is also necessary, he said.

Government subsidies have increased the cost not only of farm products but also of land, John Adikes, president of the Jamaica Savings Bank and past president of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York, told the realty conference of the New York Metropolitan Association of Real Estate Boards yesterday at the Hotel Commodore.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Stockholders of Eversharp, Inc., today went through the process of electing nine men to their fourteen-man board of directors for the second time this year. With one exception the group elected was the same as the management slate which was victorious in last July's annual meeting but was later invalidated by a decision of the Delaware Supreme Court.

A dress rehearsal of Christmas got under way in the city yesterday with parties all over town for underprivileged and orphaned children. Boys and girls began to receive good things to play with and to eat, given by many organizations and early Santa Clauses.
Twelve thousand building service workers in Manhattan loft and office structures have received a wage rise of 6 7/8 cents an hour, it was announced yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 15 -- The United Nations has been asked to turn over a corner acre of its property in midtown Manhattan as a permanent city playground for neighborhood children, as was learned today, but Secretariat officials are a little cool to the idea.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Representative Daniel A. Reed, Republican, of New York, called upon President Truman today to order Oscar R. Ewing, the Federal Security Administrator, home from Europe "to avoid further embarrassment to the United States."

Although the Norwegian merchant marine, one of that country's economic mainstays, is approaching the 5,000,000 gross ton mark and has exceeded by almost 150,000 tons her pre-war size, it is by no means comparable to the pre-war Norwegian merchant marine, a survey made public yesterday said.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15 -- An unsuccessful motion for a mistrial in the Harry Bridges perjury-conspiracy case was made today by Vincent Hallinan, chief defense counsel, in a statement that embroiled him in a bitter exchange with the prosecution.

Those who think all sterling silver has the same flat polished surface and bluish color may broaden their conception of the versatility of this metal after examining the exhibit, "Form in Handwrought Silver," opening at the Metropolitan Museum of Art today.

The tables were abundant in food last night in the Warschauer Haym Salomon Home for the Aged at 136 Second Avenue. The music blared and the wine flowed. Toast after toast was delivered in tribute to Isaac Fishberg's 100th birthday.

New, uniform editions of some of Anthony Trollope's leading novels are planned for publication by Knopf. The first will be "Orley Farm," tentatively scheduled for May, which has typography and design by W. A. Dwiggins and an introduction by Henry S. Drinker.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Southern California handed Canisius its first basketball setback of the season tonight, 69 -- 55, as Bill Sharman of the Trojans scored 27 points. Niagara remained unbeaten by topping Denver, 55 -- 54, in the first game of the Memorial Auditorium double-header before 6,415 spectators.

More than $50,000 was raised for the New York Foundling Hospital by the annual Christmas party given at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday by Cardinal Spellman. Nearly 1,000 persons, mostly women, crowded the main ballroom, paying $20 each for admission.

In 1876 the first class of the old nautical schoolship St. May's received at the foot of East Twenty-third Street their "tickets" authorizing them to practice seafaring. The famous old sloop of war served for thirty-four years and some of its graduates are still engaged in the business of shipping.

ROME, Dec. 15 -- The Government Administration was to a large extent crippled today by a twenty-four-hour strike of state employes. The strike had the support not only of the Communist-dominated unions but also of anti-Communist unions, and caused almost all the lower ranks of state employes to abandon their work.

The Regional Plan Association must be constantly on guard against the lowering of standards under the guise of so-called economy housing, Paul Windels, president of the organization, said yesterday at its twentieth annual meeting.

There is every indication that the average American hasn't the faintest conception of what the term "balanced armed forces" means. Let us take a look-see at some of the statements made recently in press reports:

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- David Low, widely known political cartoonist and creator of Colonel Blimp, the personification of British "die hardism," has resigned from The Evening Standard and will leave that Beaverbrook paper in the spring after twenty-three years on its staff.
DETROIT, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Boxing Commissioner Floyd Stevens, irked by a pair of lack-luster Joe Louis exhibitions, today banned "no decision" fights in Michigan and asked other states to follow suit.

BELGRADE, Dec. 15 (AP) -- A spokesman for Premier Marshal Tito's Government said today that the Sofia treason trial in which Mr. Kostov and ten co-defendants were convicted of plotting with Yugoslavs Britons and Americans to take over Bulgaria was a fiasco.
The world needs a "second Renaissance," to be brought about through a greater stress in the schools on the humanities, Dr. Shigeru Nambara, president of the University of Tokyo, said here yesterday.

ALBANY, Dec. 15 -- Governor Dewey declined comment today on reports that he intends to appoint is counsel and long-time associate, Charles D. Breitel, to the Supreme Court vacancy in the First Judicial District, Manhattan and the Bronx, caused by the death last Saturday of Justice Samuel Null.
Members of championship teams in professional football's rival leagues dominated The Associated Press 1949 all-pro team announced yesterday.

Plans for a new apartment house in the Bronx were revealed by the Ciampi Construction Corporation in connection with the announcement of its purchase of the property at 318 East Mosholu Parkway from the Home for Young Girls, Inc. Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., were the brokers. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
The Central Trades and Labor Council of Greater New York, AFL, accepted last night the resignation of Joseph Tuvim as a member of the council's fifteen-man executive board.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Dec. 15 -- The New York Central Railroad's Suspension Bridge passenger station, located on the 175-foot American bank of the lower Niagara Gorge, was virtually destroyed by a spectacular fire today.

The famous Lyceum Theatre, built in 1903, is on the verge of being sold at a reported price of $450,000 or on a cash basis above the first mortgage of $170,000. That much seems to be certain, despite the fact that an iron curtain surrounds the deal.

Sheikh Mohammed Abdullah, Prime Minister of Kashmir, arrived at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday to appear before the United Nations Security Council tomorrow in connection with an Indian-Pakistan dispute over his country.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Rosters were completed today for the Shrine's annual North-South college all-star football game to be played in the Orange Bowl here Dec. 26.

Thomas W. Balfe, president of the White Rock Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of the National Distillers Products Corporation, and vice president and director of sales of the parent company, has been nominated for a three-year term on the board of directors of the Broadway Association, Inc., it was announced yesterday by R. K. Christenberry, president of the association.

Suspicion is an important and often necessary part of the game warden's stock in trade, and some of their experiences would sour the outlook of the Good Samaritan, but there are circumstances in which suspicion can be detrimental to the conservation picture.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 15 -- The United States tonight expressed some dissatisfaction with the way the United Nations Social Commission had handled the problem of millions of needy children abroad who will continue to need international help.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A new milk pricing plan for the New York market which would cause the price of fluid milk, class 1-A, to change automatically in response to changes in economic conditions was recommended today by the Department of Agriculture.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- The Foreign Affairs Committee of the French National Assembly took a strong stand today against the unification of Libya and in favor of an autonomous Fezzan, Libyan province now under French administration.

Saying that there was no doubt that the United States under the Administration of President Truman was drifting toward socialism, Senator Irving M. Ives declared yesterday that "we can save our country from socialism if we can get the American people to recognize that drift."
MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Dec. 15 -- Here at its birthplace the 158th anniversary of the ratification of the Bill of Rights was observed today.

After registering four successive weekly declines, business loans made by banks in this area rose $49,000,000 during the week ended on last Wednesday. The rise, according to date covering the reporting New York City member banks, issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, mostly reflects increased borrowings on tobacco and sugar and by sales finance companies.

HOLLYW00D, Calif., Dec. 15 -- Sam Zimbalist and Mervyn Le Roy were named today by Metro-Gold-wyn-Mayer to produce and direct the long-delayed screen version of Henry Sienkiewicz's "Quo Vadis," in Italy, replacing Arthur Hornblow and John Huston, who withdrew from the project last week.
