ALBANY, Dec. 15 -- Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran announced today that the 354 candidates for state real estate brokers' and salesmen's licenses who failed the November examination will be given an opportunity to learn why they failed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended on Dec. 10 were 668,825 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 25,098 cars or 3.6 per cent fewer than in the preceding week, 114,088 cars or 14.6 per cent fewer than in the corresponding week last year and 185,334 cars or 21.7 per cent fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago. The carloadings in detail were:

Attorneys for Alger Hiss attacked yesterday the Government's contention that his wife Priscilla typed copies of State Department documents on their Woodstock typewriter as they completed the fourth defense day in United States District Court.

A proposed inter-collegiate Conference on Democrac yin Education, originally scheduled for this week-end has been canceled after refusals by Columbia and New York Universities to allow the group use of campus facilities, Alfred E. Cain, conference chairman, announced last night.
ALBANY, Dec. 15 -- New York State's pioneering program for preventing juvenile delinquency has been so successful that it will almost certainly be continued, at least for another three years.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- W. John Kenney, chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration's mission in London, said today he was not certain that in the present circumstances the most effective and beneficial use was being made of the sterling funds that Britain sets aside as counterpart to dollar aid from the United States.

TOKYO, Dec. 15 -- Measures taken by the Occupation and the Japanese to combat the severe stock market crisis have begun to have some effect. Both Tokyo and Osaka prices today recovered most of yesterday's losses.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 15 -- The joint Argentine - United States trade commission's conclusions were described as optimistic. Particular encouragement was felt over the improvement of some aspects of commerce between the nations.

To the youngster at school who finds his December allowance has surprisingly evaporated, leaving no cash for gift-shopping, the crisp bills from father come as a gay surprise. To the young couple who have budgeted not wisely but too optimistically, the generous check from the old folks solves all problems for Christmas cheer, and the sun shines again. There's nothing like money from home.

Residents of Staten Island who are far from established branches of the New York Public Library received an early Christmas present yesterday. It is a service by which they may choose books from a new library-on-wheels.

A warning that "our peril is no less today than it was during the years of World War II," was sounded last night by Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler at a dinner at the Commodore Hotel at which awards were made for essays submitted by non-ambulatory veterans.

Directors of Bendix Home Appliances, Inc., declared yesterday a dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock for payment on Jan. 10. This will be the first distribution to shareholders since 37 1/2 cents a share was paid on Jan. 11, last.

The jury of awards for the Julore Design Competition with Theodor Muller of American Institute of Decorators and American Designers Institute as chairman was set up at the group's first meeting yesterday.
Your editorial of Dec. 7 on street and park lighting omits the fact that sky-lighting unconsciously continues to be the biggest factor in the program.

The National Society for the Prevention of Blindness adopted yesterday a $500,000 budget as its 1950 objective for an intensified campaign against preventable blindness. The annual meeting of the society was held at the New York Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street.

With the prospect that Federal rent control will cease June 30 when the present law expires, landlord organizations yesterday began working for adoption of a state law that would provide for residential rent control by the state and guarantee landlords a fair return on their investment.
ROME, Dec. 15 -- Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza criticized the attitude of the Israeli Government toward the internationalization of Jerusalem at a press conference this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today it will help finance a study by the Brookings Institution to seek an answer to a question which has concerned farmers, consumers, Congress and even the President -- What effect does speculation in the commodities futures markets have on cash market prices of farm products?

PORTSMOUTH, Va., Dec. 15 -The newest submarine hunter-killer, a streamlined 390-foot destroyer named the U.S.S. Carpenter, became a unit of the Navy's active fleet this afternoon at commissioning ceremonies here that tagged her as the answer to the threat of high-speed schnorkel submarines.

One of Governor Dewey's first acts following his election in 1942 was to name a new State Superintendent of Banks. His choice was not a banker but a young editorial writer on this newspaper who had come to that post after several years of financial writing in Wall Street.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- The American Farm Bureau Federation charged today that the ultimate effect of the Brannan Plan "would be nationalization of agriculture and the distribution system" for farm products.

Washington Heights has switched from steam to electric-powered water pumps. Yesterday, Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, turned the big wheel in the new pump station at 179th Street and Amsterdam Avenue and started the electric motors that will now carry the Croton and Kensico water to 250,000 residents of the area.

MADRID, Dec. 15 -- Feeling toward the United States warmed up again in Spanish political circles tonight with the report that Secretary of State Dean Acheson had said yesterday that the question of Spanish admission to the United Nations technical organizations might be considered.
Three members of the music department of Syracuse University appeared at Times Hall yesterday evening in just such a concert as they must have often given for their university colleagues.
Stockholders of the General Foods Corporation approved yesterday the merger of Igleheart Brothers, Inc., principal flour-milling unit of General Foods since 1926, into the parent company.

In two major railroad rate decisions, the Public Service Commission approved yesterday increases in commutation fares ranging from 31 to 46 per cent on the New York Central Railroad, and denied a petition by twelve railroads operating in the state for a 12 1/2 per cent increase in basic intrastate coach and pullman fares.
ANNAPOLIS, Dec. 15 -- Was the Star-Spangled Banner made in a brewery?

There is no immediate prospect to removal by Canada of her import restrictions which are likely to continue for some time, Kenneth R. Wilson, Canadian editor, said yesterday at the first of a series of foreign trade forums sponsored by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York at 65 Liberty Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -The United States and Argentina undertook today to work out a new system of economic and commercial relations, with one aim a 75 per cent increase in trade next year.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- A new Socialist move to hamper industrial campaigns against nationalization provoked an embittered, stormy debate in the House of Commons tonight as the session of this Parliament, which comes to an end tomorrow, drew toward its close.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that department-store sales in the week ended Dec. 10 were 4 per cent below sales in the corresponding week last year. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Dec. 15 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower said today that, no matter what anyone thought, he was not a Presidential candidate and furthermore would not be talked into becoming one.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -United States imports from the Marshall Plan countries scored a $3,700,000 monthly increase in October following European devaluation.
DETROIT, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Dr. Bernard Gariepy, Royal Oak (Mich.) physician, was sentenced today to two and a halt years in Federal prison for income tax evasion.
The second performance by the newly formed New York City Dance Theatre at the City Center last night was entirely in the hands of Jose Limon and his company, and a stunning performance it was.

With mistletoe about to be hung and parties in the planning, 'teen-age date dresses are in the spotlight at the stores. Among the many dressy styles are those which reflect some of the important fashion trends of the season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Property placed under racial or religious restriction by recorded covenants after Feb. 15, 1950, will be ineligible for new Federal loan guarantees, the Federal Housing and Veterans Administrations announced today.

A vacant plot 100 by 100 feet on the west side of Forty-eighth Street, north of Fifty-fifth Drive, in Laurel Hill, Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by Stephen J. Devoe to Frank J. Oehler Jr. Seymour C. Rudges was attorney for the buyer and Burke, Morrison Green represented the seller. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

Industrial production of the Marshall Plan countries is above pre-war figures by 20 to 25 per cent, and "enormous progress in economic recovery" has been accomplished by Western Europe, W. R. Herod, president of the International General Electric Company, asserted yesterday.

The veteran Danish-flag motor-ship Erria is en route here on her "maiden" voyage in the Copenhagen-New York service of the East Asiatic Company, Ltd., and is expected to arrive on Wednesday, it was announced yesterday by the Gdynia America Line, general passenger agents for the run.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 15 -Trygve Lie is expected to announce soon that he will not be a candidate for re-election when his five-year term as Secretary General of the United Nations expires on Feb. 1, 1951, usually reliable sources said today.
DETROIT, Dec. 15 -- Safety factors and the convenience of occupants were emphasized today by K. T. Keller, president of the Chrysler Corporation, as primary necessities in car construction.

GENEVA, Dec. 15 -- Max Petitpierre of Fribourg was elected President of the Swiss Confederation today by an overwhelming majority of votes in a combined session of the National Council and the Council of States (cantons) meeting in Berne.

BUFFALO, Dec. 15 (UP) -- Justice Alger Williams of the State Supreme Court ruled today that Mary Elizabeth Marshall, 5 years old, should be raised by her white grandparents rather than her part-Negro father and white mother. He dismissed a writ of habeas corpus brought by the mother.

The city is wasting "millions of gallons of water daily" it was charged yesterday in Supreme Court by a group of nineteen employes of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity who are seeking to compel the city to employ more competent pipe caulkers.

The valuable blockfront on the east side of Park Avenue between Thirty-ninth and Fortieth Streets, owned by the city, has been ordered sold at auction by the Board of Estimate. The property is assessed at $1,715,000 and an upset or minimum price of $1,250,000 has been fixed on it.

Approximately 500 members of the Hotel Sales Management Association convened yesterday in the New Yorker Hotel to devise means to halt declining sales and rentals. According to association officials, numerous hotels throughout the country are now operating with less than 80 per cent of capacity occupancy, said to be the average break-even point at this time.

Suits for damages totaling $2,020,000 for personal injury, property damage and deprivation of civil rights, were filed yesterday in the Federal Court by Paul Robeson baritone, Howard Fast, author, the Civil Rights Congress and twenty-five others.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 15 -- President Truman stated unequivocally today that he has had only one Navy promotion list before him here, that no name had been removed from it and that no revision had been made in it.

BALDWIN, L. I., Dec. 15 -- A war veteran, too sick to work, and the Austrian-born wife whom he met while serving in Europe, are spending their first night in a new home that is theirs, rent-free, for life, and they are so happy "that it hurts."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The White House Renovation Commission does not intend to crack the wall of the mansion to uncover a plate of inscribed brass believed to mark the first stone placed on Oct. 13, 1792.

The Yale Materials Handling Clinic of The Yale Towne Manufacturing Company opened yesterday at 323 East Forty-fourth Street for a two-day showing of new mechanized materials handling devices, including gas and electric trucks, weighing devices, hoists and drum-filling machinery. Products of four companies were demonstrated in a series of cost-cutting methods newly developed for wide use by many industries, More than 100 railroad executives were among guests from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- A national argument that has been going on in the press and among visitors from this austere land to the Continent for many months reached the floor of the House of Commons today. The issue was whether people eat better under socialism or under the free economies of France, Italy and the Low Countries.

Marjorie Lawrence, Australian-born soprano, formerly of the Metropolitan Opera, gave a recital in Town Hall last night. She was cordially greeted by a sizeable audience, which continued to show its admiration for her magnificent voice and for her courage in continuing her appearances under her physical handicap.

Patrolman Martin Sheehy, for twenty years assigned to school traffic crossing duty at Public School 122, First Avenue and Ninth Street, received minor injuries yesterday morning when an auto knocked him down, but to many of the pupils the incident was a major accident.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- New programs and expansion of existing programs designed to help low-income farm families were recommended by Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan today to the joint Congressional subcommittee studying this and related problems.

The Port of New York Authority, at its monthly meeting yesterday, awarded or authorized contracts totaling $426,745 for improvements at various projects under its jurisdiction in New York State and New Jersey.
Voluntary hospitals and kindred organizations form a vital part of the bulwark against Government encroachment on private enterprise, Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey asserted yesterday.

Coffee futures opened sharply higher on trade hedge-lifting and commission-house buying on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Prices held steady for a time on a continuation of the same demand but general selling which developed later caused quotations to sag and a large part of the early gains were erased.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The fifty-two member national committee on the Mid-century White House Conference on Children and Youth today opened its second quarterly two-day session in the motion picture room of the White House's east wing.
ROME, Dec. 15 -- The Pope authorized today the celebration of a special mass for the Holy Year at midnight Dec. 31 in all the Roman Catholic Churches of the world.

The third anniversary of the acquisition of the 10,000-ton Liberty ship John W. Brown by the Board, of Education for use in training high school students as deckhand, engineers and stewards was celebrated yesterday aboard the ship at its berth at Pier 73, East River, at Twenty-fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Atomic Energy Commission said today that it was drastically reducing its program of research fellowships for the fiscal year starting next July 1, because of the opposition of many scientists and scholars to loyalty investigation of applicants in non-secret fields.
The November, 1946, grand jury that has been investigating the fatal beating three years go on election day of Joseph R. Scottoriggio was dismissed yesterday from further service.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A compromise atomic alliance under which the United States would make all atomic bombs for the West and Britain would be free to develop new atomic weapons other than bombs is now being seriously discussed in Washington.
ALBANY, Dec. 15 (AP) -- George B. Cummings of Binghamton was appointed by Governor Dewey today as vice chairman of the State Building Code Commission.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- The Order of Railway Conductors and the Brotherhood of Railway Trainmen, whose wage and hour negotiations with the railroads were broken off yesterday, announced today that a strike ballot is being distributed to members of the two unions. The voting is expected to be completed in three or four weeks.

The Nassau County Transit Commission denied yesterday that it had hampered a study by the trustees of the bankrupt long Island Rail Road of specific financial and operating problems that the Public Service Commission now intends to investigate.

The Austrian treaty talks are again suspended -- this time on a note of utter frustration on the part of the representatives of the United States, Great Britain and France. The impotence of diplomacy in the face of Soviet determination not to agree was never better exemplified than in the interminable conferences that have kept high-ranking officials of four Governments futilely employed for three years.

The name of Dr. Edward U. Condon, director of the National Bureau of Standards, was brought into yesterday's pre-trial hearing on the Coplon-Gubitchev spy case as one of the most eminent victims of all allegedly widespread Government practice of tapping telephones in violation of the law.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- A combination of a plentiful gland chemical and a vitamin may become a substitute for scarce cortisone and ACTH in treatment of arthritis.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Albania must pay Britain 843,957 ($2,363,051) for the Corfu Channel incident of Oct. 22, 1946, the International Court of Justice ruled, 12 to 2, today.

Bankers dollar acceptances outstanding in the United States during November rose to $250,686,000 from $214,713,000 at the end of October, it was announced yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The latest figure compares with $239,478,000 outstanding on Nov. 30, 1948. Seasonal influences were responsible for a large part of the increase, it was explained, for since 1925 in November there have been twenty-one increases and only four decreases.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Thousands of letters pouring into Republican national headquarters from the party's rank and file reveal overwhelming support for the proposal to restate party policy before the 1950 Congressional campaign.

Adolph Rupp's Kentucky Wildcats, shorn by graduation of the talents of Alex Groza, Ralph Beard, Wallace Jones and Cliff Barker, returned to Madison Square Garden last night and for the first time since 1944 lost to a local quintet.

The stock market on the New York Stock Exchange found difficulty yesterday in holding its ground. Stocks were under periodic pressure but a late rally in the oil division gave a strong tone to the close. The strength during earlier sessions this week had confounded the analysts, most of whom expected a setback. Therefore, they found some solace in yesterday's market action, for they felt that the sharp advance called for corrective measures.
Price increases averaging $4 a ton on a wide range of key steel products were announced yesterday by the United States Steel Corporation, the country's largest producer.

VALPARAISO, Ind., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican, of Indiana, said last night that a $37,000,000 loan by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to Lustron Corporation was made at the insistence of President Truman.

Of the more than 18,000 contracts involving more than $1,000,000 awarded during the past four years by the Armed Services Medical Procurement Agency, 36 per cent, amounting to more than $37,000,000 have gone to small business concerns (less than 500 employes).

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- No official invitation was extended to Herman J. Abs, a financial supporter of the Hitler regime, but his trip to the United States was cleared by British, French and United States Occupation authorities, the State Department said today.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 15 -- Concrete procedures to be followed in achieving the ultimate union of American Protestantism were discussed today by thirty-six official representatives of seven major denominations.
Kidder, Peabody Co. announced yesterday that they will distribute Christmas bonuses on next Wednesday to salaried employes. The bonuses will range up to 15 per cent of yearly base salary.

Caroll M. Shanks, president of the Prudential Insurance Company of Newark, was elected yesterday president of the Life Insurance Association of America at the latter's forty-third annual convention, held in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. He succeeds Asa V. Call of Los Angeles.

Congregations of Jews throughout the world attended religious devotions yesterday at sundown, beginning the annual eight-day celebration of Hanukkah, or Feast of Lights, commemorating the victory of the Maccabees in 165 B.C. in Palestine in their struggle for religious freedom against the Syrian Greeks.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 15 -- The United States High Commissioner, John J. McCloy, and Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of the West German Republic, signed the long-delayed bilateral Economic Cooperation Administration agreement today in the klieg-lighted Cabinet Room of the Chancellory Administration Building here.

Onions arrived from Czechoslovakia and Hungary earlier this week. Five thousand boxes of endive came from Belgium. California sent its first rhubarb, rather early, one would think, for this spring tonic. Strawberries and snap beans were flown in from Florida, and from the same state came the season's initial shipment of that exotic fruit, the papaya.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation of Syracuse, N. Y., had filed with it a registration statement covering $40,000,000 of general mortgage bonds, due Jan. 1, 1980, to be offered at competitive bidding.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- One word interfered with settlement today of the strike that had virtually shut down four important power stations serving the London area. The strikers at the Barking plant, the largest in Europe, returned to work this morning "in the national interest," but at the three other stations they refused to enter the gates on seeing new notices posted by the British Electricity Authority informing them that their return must be "unconditional."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Ambassador Philip C. Jessup, ranking adviser to the Government on Far Eastern policy, left for New York today on the first lap of his journey to undertake a two-month survey of the Orient.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- More and more persons are likely to be job hunting in the next few years even with continued high levels of production, a labor market expert said today.

At a time when many Americans in official positions and in private life are insisting that the United States should import more goods from countries whose economic well-being is a matter of concern, this seems an appropriate season to point out the difficulties in one field -- that of toys.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- During the week ended Dec. 14, member bank reserve balances increased $142,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
MONTREAL, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadians defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4 -- 1, tonight to take sole possession of second place in the National Hockey League.

The Columbia Pictures Corporation had a net profit of $337,000 after all charges, including $216,000 estimated provision for Federal taxes, according to the report for the thirteen weeks ended on Sept. 24, issued yesterday by Harry Cohn, president.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The President's Committee on Religion and Welfare in the Armed Services today recommended that the three branches take immediate steps to improve their information and education programs in the "war of ideas."

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 15 -- A charge that the three-day week in the coal industry was causing a shortage of coal was made late today in a statement issued by the National Bituminous Wage Conference after a meeting of Northern operators with their negotiating committee.

Early settlement of the monetary dispute between India and Pakistan appears to be remote and burlap importers are faced with the prospect of a general upheaval in the traditional method of distribution of such goods, it was pointed out yesterday by L. Shaffi, Consulate General of Pakistan.

Onondaga County, N. Y., sold yesterday $1,100,000 of sanitary trunk sewer and treatment plant bonds due front Nov. 1, 1950 to 976, to a banking syndicate headed by Phelps, Fenn Co., at a bid of 100.89 for interest of 1.70 per cent. The bonds were reoffered at tax-exempt yields ranging from 0.60 per cent to 1.80' per cent.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- A European monetary fund to facilitate freer trade and convertibility of currencies is being discussed by experts of the European Marshall Plan Council and the United States Economic Cooperation Administration.

The U. N., according to Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, is not without accomplishment looking toward peace in international relations -and this notwithstanding the persistence of the cold war and impediments created by a Soviet penchant for the use of the veto.

Three-fourths of the benefits payable under New York's new Disability Compensation Law will be financed through policies written by private insurance companies, Miss Mary Donlon, chairman of the State Workmen's Compensation Board, estimated yesterday.

While making a plea for a "super-effort" on this bathless, shaveless "Dry Friday," city officials announced yesterday that the continuing seriousness of the water shortage had forced them to increase by 50 per cent the goal originally set for reduction of the daily consumption of water.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 15 -- A balanced budget is his aim, President Truman declared today, but this was said in reiteration of his general fiscal policy and he offered no assurance that it would be a particular objective for the next fiscal year, 1951.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Judge Henry Schweinhaut of Federal Court today restrained the Printing Pressmen's Union, AFL, from taking over funds and records of the union's ousted Local No. 1.

More than 210,000 motorists in this city will benefit from a speedier two-way radio emergency road service system instituted yesterday by the Automobile Club of New York at the east midtown branch office, 109 East Fortieth Street.

C. David Reich has joined the industrial and diversified fabrics division of the Burlington Mills Corporation (N. Y.) and will be in charge of the new products department. He formerly was with American Viscose Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The economic research director of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States believes 1950 will be a relatively good business year. He sees no "great breaks" for the consumer, and thinks the Federal budget deficit may not be as inflationary, in the short run, as some have assumed.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 15 -- Despite Israel's decision to move the seat of Government to Jerusalem, there is little evidence that the city will become Israel's capital in fact for some time. The Knesset (Parliament) will reconvene there Dec. 26, but the Foreign Office and other key ministries will remain in Tel Aviv.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The nation's cotton farmers voted today to return to pre-war production controls to hold down surpluses of their crop.

Shortly after his election as president of the Metropolitan Golf Association, Earl Ross of the Winged Foot Golf Club called upon his executive committee to consider a broad program to encourage junior golf in this area.

Seven scientists in snowsuits and an occasional Howdy Doody sweater gathered in Brooklyn yesterday to perform an experiment on a rare compound. They were five young men and two young women between the ages of 4 and 6, members of the Young Scientists Club, which pokes at the secrets of the universe for a half hour weekly at the Brooklyn Children's museum.

Trustees of the State University have approved plans to enter a tripartite "partnership" with the Fashion Institute of Technology, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street, it was learned last night. The state program would make available funds equal to one-third of the total amount contributed by the Board of Education and by the Educational Foundation for the Apparel Industry, the institute's sponsoring organization.

FREEPORT, L. I., Dec. 15 -- Chester Vail, 66 years old, a local real estate dealer for many years, was killed when he fell or jumped beneath the wheels of a westbound Long Island Rail Road passenger train at the Brookside Avenue grade crossing here, at 11:46 A. M. today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Southern coal operators asked President Truman today to intervene in their six-month-old dispute with the United Mine Workers and "to bring an end to the existing crisis."
The first four patients treated with penicillin for syphilis were recently re-examined, after a lapse of six years, and found still to be entirely free of symptoms of the disease.

WARSAW, Friday, Dec. 16 (AP) -The Polish Government accused French diplomats today of hiring spies who had orders to poison the air breathed by Polish miners and to set fire to a cotton mill in Silesia. This was done, it was stated, under instructions of the British intelligence services.
Chalk up another one for the Yankees -- the baseball Yankees, that is.

ROME, Dec. 15 -- The Communist leader, Palmiro Togliatti, acknowledged that all was not well with Italian communism in his speech yesterday to the party's central committee. The Communist newspaper Unita quotes Signor Togliatti this morning as saying that some "bewilderment" and "ideological disorientation" exists among the rank and file.

During the pre-Christmas season New York art galleries cover their walls and fill their show windows with mixed displays of paintings and sculpture by gallery regulars. Such exhibitions and an exceptional group of modern sculpture at the Clay Club make this week's gallery tour rewarding.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today set Tuesday, Dec. 20, as the date on which passengers on through trains from stations on the New York, Nev. Haven Hartford and Pennsylvania Railroads north of Washington to the South will pay a premium for single occupancy of compartments or drawing rooms on pullman cars. The increases range from 60 cents to $6.68.

A committee of twelve physicians was appointed yesterday by Dr. Marcus D. Kogel "to evaluate the modernization and construction program of the Department of Hospitals and to make appropriate recommendations."

H. Lawrence Whittemore has been elected president of Alley Richards, Inc., effective Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday. He succeeds Courtland N. Smith, who is resigning as president on that date. Harry M. Billerbeck, who has been elected to succeed Mr. Whittemore as treasurer, will serve as vice president and treasurer.

The oldest part of Britain's "unwritten" Constitution, except for the Crown, will suffer another historic change today when King George VI signs the new Parliament Bill curtailing the delaying powers of the House of Lords from two years to one. This bill will be enacted only "by the King's most excellent Majesty by and with the advice and consent of the Commons."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- United States Steel Corporation's announcement of a price increase in steel drew an immediate demand today from Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat, of Wyoming, for a Congressional investigation of the matter.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 15 -- France called upon the United Nations Trusteeship Council today to warn Israel of the "very grave consequences" likely to follow the transfer of her Government to Jerusalem "in obvious contradiction" of the General Assembly decision to internationalize the city.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange Was steady yesterday and final prices were 1 to 8 points net higher.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The removal of the name of Capt. Arleigh A. Burke, the "31-Knot Burke" of World War II fame, from a naval promotion list for Rear Admiral has stirred up much comment and considerable resentment in the Navy, besides evoking some interest in Congressional circles.

Lost coins and bills found by a Brooklyn family along city streets "and set aside" for the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund were among the 437 contributions which added $9,282.53 to the fund yesterday.

Dr. Jessup, our Ambassador who is charged with directing the formulation of a Far Eastern policy, left Washington yesterday afternoon on the first leg of a journey that is to take him to various critical positions in East Asia. The climax of his trip, presumably, will be a conference with United States foreign service officers to be held in Bangkok in February.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 15 -- Yugoslavs wrote a postscript today to the trial of Traicho Kostov at Sofia by publishing data concerning Bulgaria's foreign trade in an effort to prove that country's complete subjugation to the Soviet Union. Mr. Kostov, Bulgaria's former No. 2 Communist, was sentenced to death by the Sofia court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer has given assurance that his campaign to "educate" business in voluntary anti-trust compliance means no let-up in the Government's trust-busting program. That program is carried out by the Justice Department's anti-trust division and by the Federal Trade Commission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The State Department released today a first-hand report from Consul General Angus Ward telling of the "atrocious conditions" and "perversions of justice" to which he and his staff had been subjected while imprisoned by the Chinese Communists in Mukden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The members of Congress who daily are disembarking from Government-chartered airplanes after weeks spent in "inspecting conditions" abroad include many who enjoyed the luxuriant hospitality of our new diplomatic mission to Luxembourg.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Dan Montour's Nassau, going in his best form at Tropical Park today, made every pole a winning one in the Southern Cross Purse, carrying Clarence Picou home one length and a half before Jerry McCarthy Stables' Cherish.

The International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, owner and operator of the local FM station WFDR, yesterday filed an application with the Federal Communications Commission to purchase WINS, owned by the Crosley Broadcasting Corporation.

BERLIN, Dec. 15 -- For the second time within a month, representatives of the Soviet Union and the Western occupation powers met socially tonight in an atmosphere of cordiality. The occasion was a state reception that marked the second day of Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky's visit to Berlin.

With the release of the first batch of National League figures it became official yesterday that Jackie Robinson of the Dodgers, already voted the loop's most valuable player, won the batting title with a mark of .342, just four points above that of Stan (The Man) Musial, the Cardinals' magnificent mauler and all-around star.

THE winter baseball meetings are over. They began as a conversational marathon but ended by substituting action for words. The log jam is broken at long last, a pile-up that no one has dared dynamite since before the war. There have been more major deals within the past few days than there have been in almost a decade and the indications are that others will follow.

HONG KONG, Dec. 15 -- Gen. Liu Wen-hui, Governor of Sikang Province, has followed the lead of Yunnan's Gov. Lu Han and turned over to the Communists along with two Szechwan generals who, like General Liu, were once independent warlords.

MOSCOW, Dec. 15 -- Trofim D. Lysenko, writing in Izvestia today on the contribution of Premier Stalin to Michurinist agrobiology, declared that Soviet agrobiologists in 1949 had achieved indisputable evidence of the transmutation of one biological genus into another -- in this case the transformation of wheat into rye.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Class I railroads of the United States have reported to the Interstate Commerce Commission estimates for capital expenditures for the last quarter of 1949 and the first quarter of 1950 considerably below those for the corresponding periods a year earlier.

HAVANA, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Melvin (Chick) Harbert of Detroit teamed today with Pedro Menocal, Havana amateur, to take the lead in the second annual $10,000 Havana pro-amateur invitation tournament at the Havana Country Club.

Mrs. Catherine Lemily sold the four-story eight-family building at 520 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn, to Asdghig Arifian for cash above a mortgage of $13,000 held by the Bay Ridge Savings Bank. The property is assessed at $28,000. Paul A. Bogossian Son were the brokers.

CLIFTON, N. J., Dec. 15 -- Four-year-old Boyd Richard Philip was still a candidate for a hero's award today although his parents declared that the incident that gave rise to his nomination had been greatly magnified.

Chairman McNaughton of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission has asked Gen. Carlos P. Romulo and Sir Benegal Rau, representing the Philippines and India respectively, to submit new proposals on the international control of atomic power. The Commission is acting under a United Nations Assembly resolution adopted by a 49-to-5 majority.

Beau Jack will be back in Madison Square Garden as a main bout performer tonight. The former bootblack from Augusta, Ga., who twice held the lightweight championship of the world, will oppose Tuzo Portuguez of Costa Rica in a clash listed for ten rounds.

Medical authorities at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center announced yesterday that Li Tsung-jen, acting President of Nationalist China, was suffering from an inflammatory stomach condition that will require an operation within the next few days.

It seems to us that that extraordinary person, Dimitri Mitropoulos, has seldom, if ever, done himself, or rather his ideas, more complete justice than he did when he conducted the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony last night in Carnegie Hall.

Women active in the work of the Maternity Center Association have taken over the performance of "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes" next Thursday night at the Ziegfeld Theatre to raise funds for the organization. Mrs. Edmund P. Rogers, Mrs. Edward F. Hutton, Mrs. Virgil G. Damon and Mrs. S. Maitland Goldsmith are co-chairmen of the benefit committee.

British exports to the United States have increased since devaluation, but because of a slump in the period from April through August may show a decrease of 10 per cent for 1949, compared with 1948, Neville Blond, trade adviser to the British Government, said at a conference yesterday in the offices of the British Information Service, 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

Severe new import-exchange curbs imposed by the Philippine Government can be expected to continue into 1952, bringing sizable reductions in the $400,000,000 in goods bought annually from this country in recent years, foreign traders were told here yesterday.

Under the reorganization plan of the Superior Oil Company of California which provides for the formation of two Separate companies, the holders of its capital stock will receive two shares of the stock in the new gas company and one share in the new oil company for each share now held, it was announced yesterday in the call for the special meeting to be held on Dec. 29. Superior has 423,014 capital shares outstanding.

Opens Frozen-Potato Plant A quick-frozen French fried potatoes plant was opened yesterday in Caribou, Me., by the Birds Eye-Snider division of the General Foods Corporation, it was announced yesterday. Located in the heart of Maine's famed potato-growing area, Aroostook County, the plant is equipped with the latest scientific equipment for rigid control of each step in the process.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared here yesterday that the "international unity" achieved between the AFL and the Congress of Industrial Organizations at the London meeting that set up the new International Confederation of Free Trade Unions "ought to aid in bringing about national unity" between the two groups.

ROSWELL, N. M., Dec. 15 (AP) -An Air Force B-29 crashed and burned two miles west of Walker Air Force Base today, killing five members of the crew and injuring four others. The giant plane crashed after clipping off a windmill.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 15 -- Commenting on Assistant Secretary of State George C. McGhee's statement here on President Truman's Point Four program, New Delhi newspapers today were critical of the slowness and apparently limited scope of the prospective United States aid to underdeveloped countries of Asia. They questioned the basis of United States policy in this area.

Several executive promotions in the Chase National Bank were announced yesterday by Winthrop W. Aldrich, board chairman, Charle Cain Jr., vice president and executive officer of the foreign department, and Tnomas H. McKittrick, vice president, were appointed senior vice presidents of the bank.
Wallace H. Sloat, vice president and secretary of the Brooklyn Trust Company, has been elected a member of the board of trustees, filling the vacancy created by the death of Edwin P. Maynard.

Thanks to the substantial assistance of the United States and the courage and bravery of the Greek Army and people, Greece has defeated communism and "won the greatest battle in her history," Archbishop Michael, new head of the Greek Orthodox Church in North and South America, said yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Prices continued to creep forward in virtually all principal sections of the stock markets here today as a result of a relatively few small buying orders for issues in which the supply was short.
Unlike a week ago, when good skiing was possible at many points, this week-end will find limited sport, if any, unless more snow falls.
TOKYO, Dec. 15 -- Emperor Hirohito intimated before Parliament today that he now hoped for an early peace treaty for Japan.

Virtually every non-denominational college and university in the state has eliminated questions dealing with race, color or religion from its student application blanks, Dr. William J. Wallin, Chancellor of the Board of Regents, said yesterday.

VIENNA, Dec. 15 -- Completion of the new Danubian river harbor at Linz and two-thirds of the hydroelectric power development that will bring energy from Kaprun, in Salzburg Province, to Vienna -- projects that mean much for Austria's future -- were observed with ceremonies today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UP) -- The left-wing United Electrical Workers asked the Federal court here today to stop the Government, at least for the time being, from holding hearings that might force it out of the country's biggest electrical manufacturing plants.

Reflecting inventory write-downs resulting from the continuous decline in prices of meat in the early part of the fiscal year, the Cudahy Packing Company disclosed yesterday that its net operating result for the year ended on Oct. 29 was a loss of $4,650,382 after an income tax carry-back credit of $2,630,000.

Further evidence of the lagging interest in giveaway shows came yesterday with theannouncement by Columbia Broadcasting System that it would discontinue "Hit the Jackpot" after the broadcast of Dec. 27. The present sponsor of the show, the De Soto-Plymouth Dealers, will take over the presentation of the Groucho Marx program on Jan. 4.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 16 -- One after another, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and other party leaders in the West German Bundestag took a stand today against re-establishment of a German army. There was wide variance, however, on the question whether Germans should serve in a European army under a combined high command.
PARIS, Dec. 16 -- A series of proposals for developing and freeing European trade, and notably a revised monetary plan, was passed today by the Economic Committee of the Council of Europe.

The City Council and the Board of Estimate approved unanimously yesterday a proposed local law requiring that all deeds, leases or other instruments executed by the city or any of its agencies in connection with housing construction include anti-discrimination clauses.

It is encouraging to find that the city fathers at long last agree that our faithful city employes need an immediate 60 to 100 per cent increase in their pay. We trust that public reaction to their "limited" proposal will make them apply it not to themselves but to those large groups of employes to whom such an increase is an urgent necessity.

After an ownership of a little more than two months, Louis Schleifer, operator, has resold the Bryant and the Collingwood, two midtown hotels with a total assessed valuation of $1,325,000 which he purchased from Nathan Wilson last October. The latter, in turn, had purchased the two buildings from the Knott Chain Corporation.

HAVANA, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Cary Middlecoff, national open golf champion from Ormond Beach, Fla., led 29 United States pros today in the $10,000 Havana pro-amateur invitation tournament, but the team of Melvin (Chick) Harbert, Detroit, and Havana amateur Pedro Menocal led the best-ball scores with 122.

The Maritime Commission has made "definite progress" in its efforts to overhaul the machinery of awarding subsidies for vessel construction, it was said this week by Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, chairman of the agency.
Three exhibitions of contemporary paintings, one of which contains work by five different artists, have opened in New York this week.
Directors of Seagrave Corporation yesterday approved a dividend of 50 cents on the common for payment on Jan. 17.
The Cuban-American Sugar Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit of $3,772,476 for the year ended Sept. 30. This compares with a profit of $5,098,604, a year before.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UP) -- Dewey Anderson, director of the Public Affairs Institute, resigned today from the Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report and denounced it as "no place for a liberal."
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Rev. George P. Hetenyi was convicted today of second degree murder in the fatal shooting of his 25-year-old wife.

The move by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., cutting nylon yarn allotments to hosiery knitters will have a salutary effect on hosiery prices or the first quarter of 1950, according to trade sources. Hosiery manufacturers, however, indicated that they will protest the cuts because they will be forced to curtail production with consequent increase in cost.

The well-balanced and strongly mounted New York Athletic Club trio of Herb Pennell, Johnny Pflug and Zenas Colt will meet the Ellistan team in the feature match of the indoor polo double-header at the Squadron A Armory, Madison Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street, tonight.

After three days of discussion the United States Maritime Commission decided yesterday to defer decision, subject to reconsideration by the chairman, on the application of the Mississippi Shipping Company to build an additional combination passenger-cargo vessel for the New Orleans-east coast South America service, with a construction differential subsidy.

English novels have many a grace in common. They have the local vicar who, on better-type paper, is a white-haired widower with a marriageable niece, or, on pulp, is an amateur detective. They have the curate who, on both, is tall and angular, Eton and Oxford.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 16 -- Park Commissioner Robert Moses' appetite for playground sites probably will remain unsatisfied so far as the site of the United Nations future headquarters is concerned, Secretary General Trygve Lie predicted today.

I am writing to correct an erroneous impression that may have been conveyed by an article on Page 3 of THE NEW YORE TIMES on Dec. 1, regarding action taken by the Labor-Department-sponsored conference on state labor legislation.

Anna Carnevale, mezzo-soprano who made her recital debut in Times Hall last night, has an unusually beautiful voice. It is of large dimensions, both in range and depth of quality, is inherently rich and almost contralto in color. She was cordially received by a sizable audience.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- In the name of George VI, Viscount Jowitt, as Lord Chancellor, gave royal assent today to a series of Socialist measures. They included a bill to reduce to one year the period in which the Lords may delay legislation of the House of Commons in cases of disagreement and the bill to nationalize Britain's steel industry.

Screen rights to the Mildred Cram novel, "The Promise," have been purchased by Benedict Bogeaus, independent producer releasing through United Artists. Mr. Bogeaus reports that Jane Wyman and Gary Cooper are "strongly interested" in co-starring in the film and that Cooper now is studying a screen treatment prepared by Miss Cram, who also will write the screenplay.

One seaman was injured and the 2,746-ton Swedish freighter Ekefors had "considerable" damage done to her bow when she collided at 5:57 P.M. yesterday off Quarantine with the 8,108 gross-ton freighter Seatrain Texas of the Seatrain Lines, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Republican National Committee officials said today they would start the new year with all debts paid and $150,000 in the bank.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 16 -- Humanity is still chilled by fear of atomic weapons as the atmosphere of the "cold war" persists, Secretary General Trygve Lie of the United Nations said today in a press conference.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 16 -- Traicho Kostov, former Deputy Premier, who was the principal defendant in the Sofia treason trial, was executed here today, after a last-minute appeal for mercy had been sent by Mr. Kostov top Premier Vassil Kolarov.
The magic moment when the Christmas season becomes a reality danced into town yesterday and though the lack of rainfall may mean unhappiness ahead, the winter sunshine gave it extra sparkle.

The New York State Maritime College held its seventy-fifth anniversary ceremonies yesterday in conjunction with the annual visit of alumni and the board of visitors. The school at Fort Schuyler, the Bronx, was founded in 1874 under the aegis of the Board of Education of the City of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, made public today a twenty-one-page letter to Allan B. Kline, president of the Farm Bureau Federation, blaming Mr. Kline for the cotton curtailment hardship cases which the latter had attributed earlier to Secretary Brannan.
The Yankees and Senators, who on Thursday appeared to be within one more telephone call of completing their long awaited player deal, have suddenly been swept further apart than the poles.

BERLIN, Dec. 16 -- The development of a new type of atom smasher, which allegedly represents a long step forward in the production of energy by nuclear fission, was announced today by the Soviet Army newspaper Taegliche Rundschau.
HONG KONG, Dec. 16 -- Chinese Communist regulars under Gen. Chen Keng have reached the Indo-China border in South Kwangsi, the Peiping radio announced tonight.
LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The stock markets here remained quiet and firm today, although a little irregularity crept into the closing prices.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- There is plenty of equity capital available in the country, Winthrop H. Smith, New York investment banker said today. Nevertheless, he added, stock ownership is seldom considered because many persons are ignorant of investment principles or believe that common stock investment is a sure way to lose money.

ROME, Dec. 16 -- The anti-banditry police forces in Sicily cut a very meager figure today when the weekly Oggi published an interview that three journalists had with the bandit Salvatore Giuliano in the last few days.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- French officials expect that the conquest by the Chinese Communists of Chinese territory along the frontier of Indo-China may result in the renewed smuggling of arms from China to Ho Chi Minh, Communist leader of the National Indo-Chinese army resisting the French, and perhaps in movements of Chinese troops along the frontier to keep the French in a state of disquietude.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- France is to receive an aircraft carrier under the military aid program of the North Atlantic pact, Rene Pleven, Minister of Defense, told the National Assembly's Committee on Defense today.

Plans to help solve the increasing medical problem of blindness by assembling clinical data on an unprecedented scale were announced at the end of the annual meeting of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, notified six CIO affiliates today they are "not in good standing" because of failure to pay per capita tax to the CIO.
Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, announced last night that figures compiled up to 5 P.M. indicated that "Dry Friday" had been a marked success.
WEST LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16 (AP) -- A $75,000 jewel robbery during the honeymoon with her third husband was reported today by Mrs. Susan Stephenson Schrafft Guinle Veiga.

The tricks-in-trade of New York homemakers should be the richer today from having learned yesterday the waterless way of washing dishes. To add to information picked up privately on that score, this column has quizzed authorities for their ideas on water-saving in the kitchen.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Louis E. Leverone, president of the National Aeronautic Association, today deplored the failure of aviation interests to agree even on what ails the industry. He spoke here at the seventh annual aviation forum under the auspices of the association.

BOSTON, Dec. 16 -- Fred Allen, radio comedian, met his match today in an entirely unrehearsed skit co-starring Tax Commissioner Henry F. Long of Massachusetts. The plot revolved around a $90 tax bill.

Latin-American export credit collections made by fifteen large New York City banks improved during November, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Aggregate dollar volume of outstanding draft indebtedness reported by these banks, which participate in the Federal Reserve's monthly survey, declined $4,000,000 to $177,400,000. This was the lowest level since May.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 16 -- Consolidation under one management of Mexico's two telephone systems that now operate as separate and competing companies appeared imminent with the arrival yesterday of Sosthenes Behn, chairman of the board of directors of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company, to confer with government officials and Axel Wenner-Gren, Swedish banker and industrialist, who has extensive interests in this country.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Baltimore Trotting Races, Inc., Baltimore, Md., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $1,000,000 of 5 per cent debenture bonds and 110,000 shares of its $1 par value common stock.

NEWARK, Dec. 16 -- The Board of Public Utility Commissioners of New Jersey in two decisions today approved a 12 1/2 per cent fare increase for intrastate railroad passenger traffic and sustained as "just and reasonable" the seven-cent bus and trolley fare for the Public Service Coordinated Transport, its interstate affiliate and independent line.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- John L. Lewis three-day work week has compelled coal operators to take the unusual course of going into the oil business to "protect" their customers, it was disclosed today.

Election of Charles A. Gardiner to the office of treasurer of the Hudson Wire Company, Ossining, N.Y., was announced yesterday. Mr. Gardiner joined the company twenty years ago. He has been controller.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 16 -- Charles G. Ross, President Truman's press secretary, denied today that the Chief Executive had discussed with intimates the possibility that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was seeking the Republican Presidential nomination in 1952.

Integration of the United States Testing Company, Inc., Hoboken, and the Esselen Research Corporation, Boston, two of the leading scientific laboratories in the country, was announced yesterday by Allen L. Brassell and Dr. Gustavus J. Esselen, respective presidents of the two organizations.

THE pleasure of reading Lytton Strachey generally outweighs any pain that may be caused by his gaiety. He saw no reason, apparently, why the most serious subjects in the world should not be discussed with the most felicitous precision. A rather reedy old moth-nest in real life, he managed to give an extraordinarily convincing impression of being a dandy on the printed page.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Federal Communications Commission announced today that the Western Union Telegraph Company has revised its rates to correct inequalities between messages traveling equal distances but between different points.

NEWARK, Dec. 16 -- When teenagers look forward to Christmas, it's the big dinner that the boys anticipate most. For the girls, it's tree-trimming. So far as father and mother are concerned, having the family all together is the best part of the day.
DETROIT, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Federal Judge Frank A. Picard clashed today with lawyers opposing an out-of-court settlement of more than $50,000,000 in suits by Kaiser-Frazer Corporation stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer announced today that the new inter-agency committee to deal with the question of business monopoly had agreed on three basic objectives, as follows:

Desirous of learning at first hand the experiences of civil service competition, Mrs. Esther Bromley, a Municipal Civil Service Commissioner, will take the test for clerk, Grade 2, on Feb. 4, she said yesterday.
Louis Hollander, plain-spoken president of the State Congress of Industrial Organizations, publicly chided yesterday the Transport Workers Union, CIO, for recent subway slowdown threats.

Hotel men were warned yesterday not to reduce rental rates to attract more business. Speaking at the annual convention of the Hotel Sales Management Association in the New Yorker Hotel, Warren Freeman, general manager of the McFadden Deauville Hotel, Miami, explained that in the face of current high operating costs such moves are foolhardy.

The Government of Cuba has awarded the Cross of the Order of Carlos Manuel de Cespedes, with the rank of Official, to the Rev. Dr. Edward A. Odell, who retired on Dec. 2 as secretary for church work of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. in the West Indies.

A large one-story store building will be constructed on the north blockfront of Union Turnpike between Utopia Parkway and 176th Street in Jamaica Estates, Queens, by Sam Minskoff Sons. Jerome Minskoff, vice president of the building firm, said work will be started soon on the project.
HOUSTON, Tex., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Commissioner O.O. Kessing tonight said the All-America Conference still is in existence and its future will not be determined until next month.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, has personally rebuked Miss May A. Quinn, Brooklyn public school teacher, for making "ill-considered statements" about Negroes, it was announced yesterday. He cleared her, however, of any intention "to offend the Negro people or to justify discrimination."

Evidence indicating widespread use of the telephone by individuals posing as Kinsey Report interviewers, or falsely informing victims they have won contests, was disclosed here yesterday by Edward L. Greene, head of the National Better Business Bureau.

By unanimous decision, the Appellate Part of the Court of Special Sessions upheld yesterday the vice convictions of Nancy Fletcher Choremi, Madeleine Blavier and Margaret Starr. Mrs. Choremi, the wife of an Egyptian cotton broker, and the two other women had been convicted of loitering for the purpose of prostitution after a trial last December in Women's Court.

Christmas may find some people at a loss for gift ideas, but one designer has created all manner of amusing and chic accessories. She is Clare Potter, who with her partner, Martha Stout, forms the alert, less-than-a-year-old company of Clare Potter, Inc.

Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan ordered yesterday that Dr. Edward U. Condon, director of the National Bureau of Standards, appear before him Wednesday morning for questioning in connection with the Coplon-Gubitchev spy case.

The installation of radio receivers in buses to bring music and advertisements to, passengers has been under "serious study" for several months by two major local coach companies, it was learned yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 16 -- Preparations for the Roman Catholic Holy Year, when 100,000 pilgrims are expected to tour the Holy Places in Palestine, are not affected by the resolution of the United Nations General Assembly to internationalize Jerusalem.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Administration has indicated to responsible quarters in Congress that President Truman's Point Four program for helping the world's backward areas is to have a high place this session on his "must" calendar.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Government yesterday ordered Autonator Laboratories Company (460 South State Street), Chicago, to stop selling an electric water heater without warning it is potentially dangerous unless directions for use are strictly followed.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16 -- As early as the spring of 1934, members of the Communist hierarchy were looking upon Harry Bridges as "a future leader of the party" but were talking of a need for "keeping him in the background," it was testified today at the perjury-conspiracy trial of the West Coast longshore union head.

TRENTON, Dec. 16 -- Three New York lawyers, including O. John Rogge, were barred today from further participation in the retrial of six local Negroes who were granted a new trial after being convicted of a shopkeeper's murder.

There are some aspects of the editorial "On Currencies and Morals," in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 26, in reply to the queries in my letter published in the same issue, that I should like to point out for the consideration of yourself and interested readers.

Mayor O'Dwyer and Miss Sloan Simpson, fashion consultant, will be married at Stuart, Fla., next Tuesday at 8:30 A.M., it was announced yesterday at City Hall by William J. Donoghue, the Mayor's executive secretary. The ceremony will take place at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church with the Rev. Timothy J. Geary officiating.

Being an inventive director Erwin Piscator has found an interesting way to stage "The Burning Bush," which opened in the Rooftop Theatre of the Dramatic Workshop in Houston Street last evening. Written in the tedious form of a court trial, the play is theatrical without being dramatic.
Despite a marked decline in the attendance figures of other major sports, college football crowds showed a surprising 1.3 per cent increase this year over the bumper turnouts of 1948.

Parking meters probably will be on the streets by March 1, it was indicated yesterday as the City Council and the Board of Estimate passed a local law to set up the program. The measure is slated to be signed by Acting Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri after a statutory public hearing on Friday.

Daniel Frisch, president of the Zionist Organization of America who left last night for Israel, urged the United States Government to move its embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem "as a concrete follow-up of its recognition of the justice of the Israeli case for a Jewish Jerusalem."

A special meeting of the staff and guests of St. Vincent's Hospital was called last night to hear a report that a new drug had been used with dramatic results to treat cases of severe itching from many different causes that heretofore have been difficult to halt.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- Trade in grain futures was restricted here today by the approaching holidays, and prices on the Board of Trade were irregular when the market closed. December wheat developed independent strength and closed 1 3/8 cents a bushel higher, with the deferred months up 3/8 to 3/4 cent.

David McDonald, secretary-treasurer of the United Steelworkers and a delegate to the recent conference that established the new International Confederation of Free Trade Unions in London, said yesterday that American unions must teach the labor organizations of France and Italy our idea of trade unionism.

There are folk scattered through the city who do the shopping, possibly the cooking too, or who bring cheer and news of the outside to a desolate neighbor next door or down the street. Moved only by compassion for a despairing fellow-human, they do what they can to help someone ailing, needy, someone forgotten in the bustle of a busy city.

A few months ago Communists in Western Europe were warning their countrymen that in the event of war they would fight on the side of the Soviet Union. But during the past week a note of uncertainty on this point sounds in the voices of the party spokesmen.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 16 -- A deep-water sailor for forty-eight years, Capt. William W. Kuhne, skipper of the American Export Line's 9,644-ton steamer Excambion, brought his ship into port here today to complete twenty-five years as an Export Line captain.

GENEVA, Dec. 16 -- Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary have agreed with the Western European Governments to submit data to the United Nations on railway cars held by them since the war. An international team of experts will conduct a survey in each country to verify the nationality of the Western European cars.

The largest field for water conservation by industrial and commercial users of air-conditioning apparatus is among operators of three to twenty-five-ton units, 90 per cent of whom have not so far purchased "water-savers" from contractors in the New York area, according to sales reports of contractors here yesterday.

Television advertising of Lucky Strike cigarettes has been assigned to Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., it was announced yesterday in a joint statement by Vincent Riggio, president of the American Tobacco Company, and Gerold M. Lauck, executive vice president of N.W. Ayer Son, Inc.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- Premier Georges Bidault, at a special Cabinet session tonight, asked his Ministers to endeavor to find over this week-end budget savings to permit the National Assembly to vote a balanced budget when the finance bill is acted on next week.

Because of its position of leadership in one of the nation's basic industries, any policy action by the United States Steel Corporation is a potential public issue. It is not surprising to find, therefore, that while price advances introduced earlier by a number of other companies went virtually unnoticed, this week's announcement of similar action by Big Steel promptly stirred up a political hornet's nest in Washington.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- The new Midwest Stock Exchange today made available for purchase the last twenty-five of its 400 authorized memberships, and eight were sold immediately. The transactions gave the Exchange 383 members, compared with 358 when it went into business on Dec. 1 after the merger of the Chicago Stock Exchange and three other regional markets.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Baltimore Ohio Railroad today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to approve refunding of $11,879,898 of outstanding balances under fifteen conditional sale contracts, originally underwritten by the Mellon National Bank and Trust Company of Pittsburgh and thirteen other banks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Federal Advisory Council to the Bureau of Employment Security voted today for a ban on foreign farm labor. The ban is aimed primarily at Mexicans employed in the South and Southwest. There were about 90,000 of them this year.

Centralized procedure through the projects branch of the Office of International Trade will enable business and industry to obtain a prompt statement of Government opinion on the export of unclassified technical data from the national security and defense standpoint, Newton H. Foster, chief of the projects branch, said yesterday.

The State of Washington expects to market an issue of $70,000,000 of war veterans' compensation bonds right after the turn of the year, according to reports in underwriting circles yesterday. Jan. 5 has been designated tentatively as the date for receiving bids.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 16 -- Evidence that exists in Belgrade indicates the arrest, trial and execution of Traicho Kostov have accentuated a split among Bulgarian Communist leaders over the question of whether Bulgaria is to continue as a dependency of the Soviet Union or fight to recover her independence.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Dec. 16 -- Col. Howard Caswell Smith, president of the Gen. Theodore Roosevelt Jr. Memorial Fund, turned over the keys of the Oyster Bay Free Public Library this afternoon to Dr. Dwight W. Bishop, chairman of the board of library trustees.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UP) -- Capt. John G. Crommelin Jr., out-spoken Navy flier who brought on a Congressional investigation of the service unification row, left tonight for his new Pacific Coast assignment, convinced the battle was far from over.

Year-end switching operations produced yesterday no clear-cut issue on the stock market and, although business continued at a fairly fast pace, price changes were small. Bidding in the afternoon was fairly persistent in the motion picture section but even here quotations advanced only fractionally.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 16 -- The threat of a full shut-down in the coal industry beginning Jan. 1 diminished tonight after major bituminous operators revealed that they would make the scheduled payment to the United Mine Workers' welfare fund Tuesday.
JOGJAKARTA, Java, Dec. 16 -- Dr. Sukarno was elected today the first President of the United States of Indonesia -- the independent nation for which he fought for more than twenty years.

WROCLAW (Breslau), Dec. 16 -- The Polish Government's trial of six alleged espionage agents working for the French opened today with the promise of departing from the cut-and-dried pattern set in other Eastern European countries.

In keeping with their two-decade tradition, the students of Horace Mann School for Boys sent their annual gift to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday. Their contribution of $4,825 was the largest of the day that saw 392 contributors send $14,474.73 to the fund.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Dec. 16 (AP) -- As an outgrowth of an investigation into the strangulation death of Margaret Jackson, a coed, the University of Iowa today acted to curb student drinking and gambling.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Negotiations between the United States and Great Britain on the European arms aid program have temporarily stalled over the terms of the Mutual Defense Assistance Act, the State Department disclosed today.

SOFIA, Dec. 16 (UP) -- Premier Kolarov told 100,000 cheering, singing Bulgarians in the central square of the city tonight that the Kostov trial had wrecked Anglo-American plans to "enslave" the Balkans.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 16 -- Firmly convinced that the "time has now come" for the Protestant churches of this country to unite under one banner, thirty-six official representatives of eight denominations today formally constituted a permanent Conference on Church Union.

Modernization of the Metropolitan Museum of Art came closer to reality yesterday when its request for a capital expenditure of $1,379,709 to help pay for rehabilitation, reconstruction and improvement of its building was approved by the City Council. Previously endorsed by the Board of Estimate, the expenditure now waits only for the Mayor's signature.

GUATEMALA CITY, Dec. 16 -- The Government's coffee auction here was canceled yesterday because of the unsatisfactory price offered on 15,300 bags of 100 pounds each by national and interned plantations. This last substantial lot is the only one unsold of the 1949-50 crop.

A collection of poems by modern Greek poets, from 1751 to the present, is scheduled for publication on Monday by Gaer Associates. Translated and edited by Rae Dalven, "Modern Greek Poetry" contains 148 poems by forty-three poets with their biographies, as well as twelve examples of Greek poetry and folk songs from the Roman period to the seventeenth century.

Over in Brooklyn water-saving and money-raising got all mixed up yesterday. At Willoughby Junior High School, St. Nicholas Avenue and Suydam Street, faculty and students had prepared an educational campaign. The students had decided to canvass the neighborhood getting pledges of support for the water conservation drive.

Christmas trees of every description, crates of evergreens and holiday plants give a festive air to florist shops all over the city. The buyer, intent on decorating house or apartment, may choose from an assortment of material to carry out his own ideas or from ornamental pieces and trees already trimmed by the florist.

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Greentree Farm in near-by Lincroft, one of the nation's top race horse training layouts, has been purchased by a Jersey City father-son combination that races under the name of Cee Vee Farms.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The State Department announced today the appointment of Paul H. Nitze as director of its policy planning staff, effective Jan. 1, to succeed George F. Kennan.
With the score tied at 69-all; the basketball game between Manhattan and St. Peter's, at the former's gymnasium last night, was called because of an injury to Vince Farrell, one of the referees.

A smiling little man with twinkling brown eyes and trim white moustache, by the name of Hartune Michaelyan, noted a milestone in his life yesterday. The day marked his fiftieth anniversary as a connoisseur, collector and merchant of oriental rugs. Friends and associates presented a concert in his honor at the Michaelyan Galleries, 315 Madison Avenue.

With one Connecticut Senator dissenting, representatives of eighteen industrial states, meeting yesterday at the Astor Hotel, approved a resolution declaring that enactment of sickness compensation legislation should be the subject of state rather than Federal action.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Mrs. M.F. Drinkhouse's Third Ace, seemingly beaten twenty yards from the finish, gave a burst of speed to nose out Spring Hill Farm's Master Mind in the Shanballymore Purse at Tropical Park today.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Eagles arrived today, outwardly calm and confident of whipping the Los Angeles Rams and winning their second successive championship of the National Football League.

Alexander Borovsky, pianist, played impressively last night in Carnegie Hall. His program was one of wide perspectives and exceptional demands upon the interpreter's art. Mr. Borovsky more than met its requirements. It is superfluous today to speak of his technical prowess, for he has put questions of technic far behind him.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 16 -- Faced with a continuing move by Israel to shift her capital to Jerusalem, the United Nations Trusteeship Council prepared tonight to invite the new state before it to explain its action.

The angler or hunter who has a visual block when confronted with a "No Trespassing" sign seems to have no difficulty in deciphering print on other mediums, and the Christmas shopper with last-minute problems can find a number of new books on these sports that would be very acceptable gifts.

The Metropolitan A.A.U. junior championships at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory tonight will open the indoor track season. A record total of 461 individual entries and fifty-six relay teams, including strong representation from all the local clubs and colleges, promises exciting competition.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Cotton, the South's major crop, will be grown and marketed next year under rigid Government controls.

Two novelties graced the program of the New York City Dance Theatre at the City Center last night. One was the only appearance of the delightful Katherine Litz in a pair of solos, and the other was the first New York presentation of Sophie Maslow's "Festival," which was originally produced last summer in the Connecticut Festival at New London.

Anthony M. Ryerson has been appointed assistant general manager of sales for the Inland Steel Company. He replaces Neele H. Stearns, recently elected executive vice president of the subsidiary Inland Steel Products Company of Milwaukee.

In two transactions involving the leasing of a total of 40,000 square feet of area in the same building, G. Irving Huber, broker, reported yesterday that the Gotham Lighting Corporation, maker of architectural lighting equipment, and E.J. Hayden Co., manufacturers of advertising displays, each signed for 20,000 square feet in the Palmer-Singer Building, on Thirty-seventh Avenue, between thirty-first and thirty-second Streets, Long Island City, Queens.

Coffee futures were steady yesterday in moderately active trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Opening prices were higher on commission-house buying and scattered trade hedge-lifting. Prices worked their way gradually higher as demand remained constant through the day.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 16 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration mission for Germany announced today the release of 1,036,000,000 Deutsche marks (about $246,671,600) of European Recovery Program counterpart funds "for the development of the productive capacity of Western Germany.

As the promise of a Congressional investigation of its 4 per cent price increase confronted the United States Steel Corporation, Benjamin F. Fairless, its president, said last night that the company "will welcome" the opportunity to "appear in Washington to explain the small increases in its steel prices."

ALBANY, Dec. 16 -- Assemblyman Wilson Van Duzer, Republican, of Middletown, announced today that he would ask the 1950 Legislature to urge upon Congress an amendment to the Federal Constitution placing a ceiling on Federal income taxes and turning over to the states the sole authority to impose estate taxes.

MONROVIA, Liberia, Dec. 16 -- The United States and Liberia are expected to open talks here within two weeks on the $32,000,000 plan for technical and financial assistance for the development of the natural resources of Liberia.

The local bill to increase the salaries of members of the Board of Estimate and the City Council was approved yesterday by both bodies, despite the renewed objections of business and civic organizations and individuals. The measure, which now goes to a public hearing before Acting Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri at 1 P.M. next Friday, provides increases ranging from 40 to 66 per cent and becomes effective Jan. 1.
