WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Representative Frank Buchanan, Democrat, of Pennsylvania, chairman of the new House Committee to Investigate Lobbies, appealed to the Washington press galleries today for their assistance.

Drew Pearson, radio commentator, received permission yesterday from Supreme Court Justice Thomas A. Aurelio to amend his complaints in his libel suits against Westbrook Pegler, columnist, Hearst Consolidated Publications and King Features Syndicate, increasing damages from $500,000 to $1,200,000.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was active yesterday and closed 25 to 32 points net higher.

Jean Dalrymple confirmed yesterday the report that she is negotiating for the American rights to "The First Gentleman," Norman Ginsbury's British work. If she succeeds in closing the deal, there will be a production this season, possibly in conjunction with Milton Shubert, who has been interested in the project himself for some months.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 16 -- Arrangements for a merger of two of the four major motion-picture talent and literary agencies, the Berg-Allenberg Company and the William Morris company, have been concluded, it was learned today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 16 -- The task of preparing Libya to assume her role as an independent and sovereign state not later than Jan. 1, 1952, will be started in the near future when Adrian Pelt, elected United Nations Commissioner for Libya last week, leaves to make a preliminary investigation on the spot.

The taxable bonds of the Federal Government and the tax-exempt obligations of local governments continued strong in yesterday's trading. Most of the buying in the Treasury list was among the restricted bonds, with insurance companies and savings banks prominent in the buying.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- The Illinois Central Railroad will refund an additional $8,736,000 of its early bond maturities with new consolidated mortgage bonds maturing in 1974, Wayne A. Johnston, president, said today. It recently offered to take $52,201,000 of outstanding bonds due from 1950 through 1955 in exchange for 1974 and 1979 maturities in the single consolidated mortgage issue.
One thousand labor leaders and liberals attended a testimonial dinner at the Astor Hotel last night to Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 16 -- Representatives of the Soviet Union Byelorussia and the Soviet Ukraine signed with reservations today the convention on genocide. Their signatures brought to thirty-seven the number of signers.

The principle of the synchrotron was discovered independently in 1945 by Dr. Veksler of Russia and Prof. Edwin M. McMillan of the University of California. A number of giant synchrotrons, accelerating electrons up to 300,000,000 electron volts, have been in full operation in the United States for more than a year.

The Axis Victims League, Inc., and the American Association of Former European Jurists adopted a resolution last night at a meeting in the Bar Association of the City of New York, 42 West Forty-fourth Street, calling on John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, to take action to insure the restitution of rights and interests to Axis victims.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 16 -- The views of the Economic Cooperation Administration have been requested on the possibility of United States help in financing a grandiose plan for the development of the Rhine.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 16 -- United States High Commissioner John J. McCloy declared tonight that investigation had shown that in a majority of the cases in which United States soldiers had been accused of brutality or rowdyism by Germans, the soldiers were more sinned against than sinning.
Donald Hiss, younger brother of Alger Hiss, headed eight defense witnesses who combined yesterday to deny Whittaker Chambers' testimony of his pre-war spy ring relationship with the elder Hiss.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- Despite steadily increasing taxation year by year, the British people have not measurably changed their spending habits. Nor has the crippling cigarette tax of Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, done anything to decrease the people's addiction to smoking, which grew to huge proportions during the war years.

A special "Bethlehem Appeal" committee of the Church World Service, overseas relief agency of twenty-three Protestant and Eastern Orthodox communions, has urged affiliates to collect Christmas gifts for the aid of Christian and other refugees including Moslems and Jews, in and near Bethlehem and other areas of Palestine.
LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The five-day-old power station strike, which threatened to disrupt British industries, homes and transport over Christmastide, ended here tonight.
BERLIN, Dec. 16 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky resumed his journey from New York to Moscow by plane today after a forty-eight-hour state visit to the Soviet sector of Berlin.

Alvin Johnson, who will be 75 tomorrow, has made an outstanding contribution to the educational life of this city and the nation. For the last three decades the New School for Social Research, of which he was a founder, has grown in prestige and influence, taking its place as the pioneer adult education center of the land.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 16 -- Political bitterness was set aside here today for the unveiling of a monument to pioneer Boers who trekked north into the Transvaal more than a hundred years ago to find new homes.

Five prizes totaling $3,100 were awarded yesterday to sculptors in a national competition sponsored by the Medallic Art Company, 325 East Forty-fifth Street. The contest was held in commemoration of the concern's fiftieth anniversary and the awards were made at a reception and exhibition of the entrants' work in a gallery of the company's recently completed new quarters.

Employing its reserves during a large part of the contest, Fordham University's quintet swept to a 75-37 triumph over the Merchant Marine Academy of Kings Point in the Rams' gymnasium last night. The triumph was the third for the Maroon in five starts.

MOSCOW, Dec. 16 -- Mr. Mao greeted the Soviet Union in an address at the Yaroslavl Railroad Station, where he was welcomed by high state leaders and diplomatic representatives of the "peoples democracies" of Eastern Germany, Northern Korea and Mongolia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent in the week ending Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The index was 151.1 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.2 per cent below four weeks ago and 7.1 per cent below the comparable week of 1948.
Long Island University's Blackbirds will encounter a tall Denver quintet tonight in the feature contest of a collegiate twin-bill at Madison Square Garden. In the opener, N.Y.U. will face Holy Cross.

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony Young People's concert, Leopold Stokowski, conductor; James Fassett, narrator, Town Hall, 11 o'clock; "Tristan und Isolde," at 2, and "Rigoletto," at 8:30, Metropolitan Opera; National Orchestral Association, Leon Barzin, conductor; Saul Goodman, percussion; Anita Zahn dancers; Augustin Duncan, narrator, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; "Hansel and Gretel," David Le Vita, conductor, Brooklyn Museum, 2:30.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- United States shipments to China, off sharply since Communist control spread there, dropped to $300,000 in October. This compares with $700,000 in September and $9,600,000 in October, 1948.

VIENNA, Dec. 16 -- That the Russians have decided to postpone indefinitely the granting of a state treaty to Austria and will use the alleged failure of denazification to justify it is now believed certain in Government and diplomatic circles here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Government's multi-billion-dollar farm programs have not halted poverty in agricultural areas because they have concentrated on commodities and price supports and have by-passed this "explosive" problem, Dr. Theodore W. Schultz, a University of Chicago economics professor, told a joint Congressional investigating sub-committee today.

The Government's most sweeping effort to put the finishing touches on an American Express travelers check counterfeiting ring was brought to a head yesterday with a Federal grand jury indictment of twenty persons.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- The Federal District Court trial of eight present and former executives of the Tucker Corporation on charges of violating the Mail Fraud Statute and the Securities Act was recessed today by Judge Walter J. LaBuy for two weeks for the Christmas holidays.

Two jewel thieves who had pleaded guilty to the theft of $368,500 worth of jewelry from the Brand-Chatillon Corporation in the St. Regis Hotel last July 25, were sentenced yesterday to serve from five to fifteen years each in state prison.

The pronunciamentos on Spain by wandering members of both Houses of Congress have become so frequent this autumn that an observer untutored in the ways of American politics might almost think that there was an overwhelming desire in this country to resume full and normal relations with the France dictatorship.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- A gift of 33,562 acres of land in Grand Teton National Park and Jackson Hole National Monument in Wyoming was made to the Government today by John D. Rockefeller Jr.
A crowd of 7,281 boxing fans, paying $20,282 for their seats at Madison Square Garden last night, saw the approaching finish of a fighter who was great in his time.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- The opportunities for slum clearance available to cities under the 1949 Housing Act, and the obstacles faced by many communities were discussed today at the press seminar of the Public Administration Clearing House here.
An apartment house development in Brooklyn costing $3,405,000 and a veterans' mutual housing project in Queens costing $3,000,000 were among proposed projects for which plans were filed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UP) -- Admiral Forrest P. Sherman, Chief of Naval Operations, has ordered Navy personnel in the capital to be more careful about extending proper courtesies, including salutes, to high civilian officials, it was disclosed today.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Dec. 16 (UP) -- A regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, accused anonymously of being a Communist, said today that he had been recommended to President Truman for appointment to a vacancy on the NLRB in Washington.

NEWARK, Dec. 16 -- Right wing leaders in locals of the United Electrical Workers Union won an important legal victory in New Jersey today when Superior Court Judge Alfred A. Stein ruled that locals of the old union had a right to secede from the organization and affiliate with the newly organized International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, CIO.
The Board of Regents of the University of the State of New York appointed a committee yesterday to study the advisability of training practical nurses in high school.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 16 -- The statements of the Greek Premier and Foreign Minister discouraging agitation for the union of Cyprus with Greece have been well received here. The Turks believe that it is in the interest of both Greece and Turkey that the British should retain the island as a useful foothold in the eastern Mediterranean.

Donizetti's "L'Elisir d'Amore" is a cheerful opera, and the Metropolitan Opera's production, which had its first performance of the season last night, is good, clean fun. It is well sung, and in the principal roles agreeably played. There are not many places around town where you could find such gay and agreeable musical comedy.

Government intervention will again play an important part in keeping business activity at a high level next year, Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Banking and Finance at New York University, told the eleventh annual meeting of the Institute of Life Insurance at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

A four-alarm fire of undetermined origin was sweeping through a four-story factory building at 125-27 East 129th Street, occupied by the Modern Cabinet Corporation, at 2 A.M. today. Firemen said the blaze appeared to be under control.

New York's men started roughing it yesterday. They either didn't shave, or fortified themselves with elaborate explanations of why, despite the city administration's dry- Friday plea for all-out water conservation, they were smooth-faced. Explanations were more numerous than bearded faces, but even so, many a wifely cheek was scratched by the parting kiss of a stubble-faced husband.

Retail sales last week remained about even with the corresponding period last year, according to estimates made yesterday by trade Observers. Sales were spotty, however, and although some stores showed fair gains about the same number had sales declines.

TOKYO, Dec. 16 -- Tentative plans are being discussed for exhibition in the United States of treasures of Japanese art. Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters has promised "wholehearted support" for the program.

In announcing two first mortgage loans aggregating $2,000,000, each made by a lending institution at 4 3/4 per cent for short terms, Sonnenblick-Goldman Corporation, broker, who arranged the financing, said yesterday that one of the loans was obtained by Broaduane Corporation on its eighteen-story office with stores, known as the Barclay Building, at 299 Broadway.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 17 -- Rhode Island companies producing wire and cable and parts utilized in production of electrical equipment look to a brighter future as 1949 nears its end. An upturn in orders with attendant increase in employment in the last month has helped to build this optimism from the low reached last July, when orders had slowed to a trickle.
CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Mrs. Jacobson, 34, wept when she learned of her husband's arrest.
New York City's critical water shortage has started municipal officials and water engineers thinking in terms of the community's future water needs and of the resources available to meet them.
A novel series of West Indian cruises on a luxurious new Norwegian freighter have been arranged by Tramp Trips, Inc., 353 West Fifty-seventh Street, it was announced yesterday.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 17 -Navy Capt. Winfield Scott Cunningham, hero of Wake Island, is waiting until Christmas to open a package the Japanese kept him from getting eight years ago.

ABOARD S.S. LAKELAND VICTORY, Dec. 17 (UP) -- This ship with Consul General Angus Ward and his rescued party, left Pusan, Korea, for Yokohama, Japan, this afternoon. The Italian-born radio technician Franco Cicogna, who was jailed with Mr. Ward by the Chinese Communists in Mukden, is in the group.

WHETHER your gambling is limited to penny-ante poker or three-digit bets at the race track, the chances are that Ernest Blanche will put you on guard. His easy-to-read book proves again that gambling doesn't pay.

Many things happen to soften the heart at Christmas -- even in a metropolis as large as New York. And yesterday afternoon one of the city's most beautiful and reverent celebrations of the Christmas season was presented again at Carnegie Hall under the auspices of the National Orchestral Association.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The new CIO Electrical Workers Union reported today the signing of its first major contract, with Philco Corporation covering 7,000 workers at the Philadelphia plant.

MOTORISTS in the country's snow belt are offered some timely advice by the Rubber Manufacturers Association regarding the care of tires during the winter driving season. As the association points out, precautions taken now can help to eliminate the danger of accidents on slippery pavements during the months that lie ahead and also increase the amount of mileage obtained from tubes and casings.

THOUGH the City Center is currently absorbed in its new modern dance repertory company, those activities have not yet gone on long enough to warrant any general conclusions. There is still time, accordingly, for a brief postcript here on the New York City Ballet Company.

The softwood plywood industry has a two-month order backlog amounting to more than 320,000,000 square feet and is unable to increase production sufficiently to make a "dent" in it, Harrison Clark, assistant managing director, Douglas Fir Plywood Association, disclosed last week.
MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 17 -- Sales volume was holding up well as the Christmas buying season swung toward its peak in the Ninth Federal Reserve District this week.

OFFICIALLY, winter arrives in two days. The snow shovel is ready for use again; the snow plow has replaced the cultivator on the garden tractor. It may be pleasant to hope they will not be needed, but it is more profitable to simplify their use by making a few minor changes land repairs in driveways and walks.

AFFLUENT European royalty during the Edwardian era had little trouble thinking up unusual gifts for their fortunate friends and colleagues who "really had everything." They handed the whole problem, if they had the proper entree -- and a blank check to Peter Carl Faberge of old St. Petersburg, fabricator of jeweled fantasies extraordinary to the last Czars, Alexander III and Nicholas II.

LONDON, Dec. 17 (Reuters) -Liverpool, topping the first division of the English Football League, dropped its second straight game today, bowing by 3 -- 2 at Sunderland before nearly 47,000 fans. The Merseysiders led, 2 -- 0, early in the first half, then faded.

THE 1949 annual of contemporary American painting at the Whitney Museum, it may be reported at once, includes a larger proportion of abstraction, semi-abstraction and frankly experimental work than any of its predecessors. Not all of this work is good.

Secretary General Trygve Lie's confirmation of the report that he will not seek a new term in his United Nations post reminds one of the swift passing of time and flow of events. Mr. Lie will finish his fourth year in office next February. His term will expire in February, 1951. It is not too early to consider his record and what may happen a year from February.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 17 -- President Truman is completing his winter training here this weekend. An offensive fighter, he is looking forward with keen anticipation to the 1950 battle for his Fair Deal.

THE indefatigable Miss Brown has added two more volumes to that long bookshelf which bears her name. "Two Little Trains," for 4-to-7-year-olds is probably the more enduring of the two. One little train was a streamliner, carrying a little boy; the other was a little old train carrying a girl and assorted livestock.

Louis Sachar, president of the Fabriton Corporation, textile buying office at 33 West Seventeenth Street, will retire from active participation in this and three real estate corporations on Jan. 1 to devote all of his time to Government work, he announced yesterday.

MR. GANTTS review of Babkin's biography of Pavlov (Book Review, Nov. 27) would gain much in interest if he had mentioned Bernard Shaw's famous dissection of Pavlov as a scientist in "Everybody's Political What's What."

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- Wayne Hebert of Lorain, Ohio, will leave on Jan. 16 to tour United States air bases in Europe and Africa with a series of religious-scientific films produced by the Moody Bible Institute of Science in Los Angeles, a branch of the Moody Bible Institute of Chicago.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, announced yesterday that the Democratic party would press for the establishment of a "Little Hoover Commission" for New York. It would perform the same task for the state that was done for the nation by the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government, headed by former President Herbert Hoover.

Fresh and crisp, the linens, cottons and failles are ready to take their place in the sun. They bring with them this season's story of colors. It records greens, sunny yellows, violets, honey tones, pinks and mellow blues.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Dec. 17 -- Harry C. Harper, Labor Commissioner of New Jersey, was endorsed today by the Seventh Congressional District Republican leaders as their candidate in the special primary to be held on Jan. 24.

Many big game hunters, having obtained most of the trophies in which they were interested, have turned to camera hunting in recent years and the results have provided interesting information on the characteristics of animals normally classified as "dangerous" game.

DR. HAWLEY is right when he says that the Blue Cross organization has not officially sought "Government subsidy," but I was right when I said that Blue Cross leaders have individually asked such subsidy in order "to enable their plans to expand."

Richard A. (Pancho) Gonzales, national amateur champion, is provisionally rated first in the rankings of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, released for publication today and to be passed upon by the annual meeting of the organization in this city Jan. 21.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Quantico Marines, cashing in on two enemy miscues, won their third straight All-Navy football championship today by edging out the Camp Pendleton Marines in a rugged contest, 14 to 13.

A strong finishing kick in the last forty yards carried Otto Behensky of Andrew Jackson High to a thrilling triumph in the 1,000-yard event of the open competition in the forty-third annual Stuyvesant High indoor interscholastic track and field meet at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory last night.

All over the city yesterday, from morning until night, small hearts beat faster and small eyes gleamed brighter. Saint Nicholas, the magical man who can be in a dozen places at once, was practicing up for the big day by visiting thousands of children whom he might otherwise have missed.

Steel kindergarten sets, television sets, sterling silver compacts and men's silk ties were stressed in retail promotions here last week, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

In one of New York's largest hospitals in the last few months, a 10-year-old girl severely crippled by Still's disease, a form of arthritis seen in children, has been treated alternately with two new widely publicized drugs, cortisone and ACTH.

STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 17 -- A preview of the true spirit of Christmas unselfishness was provided this morning by 2,000 youngsters attending a Yule party given by the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company in the Palace Theatre here.
JOGJAKARTA, Java, Dec. 17 (AP) -- President Sukarno of the United States of Indonesia was sworn into office under a Moslem oath today and received his first twenty-one-gun salute.
Sales will be held in many of the auction houses this week, but the volume of goods to be offered has been sharply reduced as the holiday season nears and galleries make ready for a busy new year.
CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (AP) -- A pair of sharpshooting guards led Northwestern to a 66-56 triumph over Notre Dame in a basketball game witnessed by 12,000 at the Chicago Stadium tonight.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 17 -- The Governor of Sao Paulo, Adhemar de Barros, who, it is reported, will run for the presidency next year, came to Rio de Janeiro two days ago. He visited President Eurico Gaspar Dutra and other political leaders to exchange views.

DETROIT, Dec. 17 -- Paul G. Hoffman, administrator of the Economic Cooperation Administration, has received the offer of the position of managing director of the $205,000,000 Ford Foundation, it was revealed today by Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company.

STUART, Fla., Dec. 17 -- Mayor O'Dwyer of New York will be asked to become Mayor of the Day in this little community of 2,000 persons and the high school band will play "The Sidewalks of New York" after Miss Sloan Simpson and he are married by the Rev. Timothy J. Geary in St. Joseph's Church here on Tuesday morning.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The resignation of Yen Hsi-shan as Premier of Nationalist China was reported tonight by a reliable source.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 17 (AP) -Tom Bakke, 22-year-old junior end from Denver, Colo., will captain next year's Navy football team, Capt. H. H. Caldwell, director of athletics, announced today.

" THE CHOSEN" is the story of five boys from the Bronx who went to the same college, each of whom knew by graduation exactly what he wanted to do. The novel traces their attempts to reach this chosen goal, but the background and talents of the five are varied and not equally suited to the career selected.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 17 -- St. Louis merchants expect a decline of 6 to 10 per cent below 1948 Christmas sales in dollar volume, and this sentiment probably general in is the Eighth Federal Reserve District.

Although the New York Public Library is the most faithful observer of holidays, recognizing all kinds of anniversaries and events with special notice, this is the first Yuletide since the building at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street went up in 1911 that it has been decked with greens and festive lights.

ITHACA, Dec. 17 -- Sophomores Johnny Werner and Fred Eydt paced Cornell to a 60-57 victory over Yale's basketball forces before 6,000 spectators in Barton Hall tonight. Werner, hitting with deadly accuracy from the pivot, and Eydt, tossing set shots from the corner, totaled 35 points as Cornell won its first Eastern Intercollegiate League start.

BEGINNING Jan. 1 and continuing until March 15, the air traveler will be able to fly from the United States to almost any part of Europe and return for the lowest airline fares in the history of aviation.

This long poem seeks to use story of the murder of Orpheus at the hands of the maddened bacchantes as the basis for an allegory of the artist's death and resurrection. Miss Rukeyser begins with a description of the dead Orpheus on the mountaintop, the women still fleeing from their crime.
One of the forty-five Hungarian self-exiles released from Ellis Island after almost two months of detention has offered what he says is a "modest" Christmas gift, a blood donation.
HONG KONG, Dec. 17 -- Hong Kong was treated today to the unusual spectacle of a Chinese labor force going on strike because the employer insisted on hoisting the Communist five-starred flag.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- A spokesman for coal operators said today the Government won't "face up to the plain fact that there is an emergency" in coal supplies due to John L. Lewis' three-day work week.

RUTH and Latrobe Carroll's "Pet Tale" is going to be the pet tale of any child lucky enough to read or to hear it. It is the story of a farmer whose trotting horse was his pet. The trotter had a pet, too -- a shaggy little donkey, whose pet, a lamb, had a small pig as her pet.

THE author of the new novel "One on the House," Mary Lasswell by married name, is a comely lass just past 40. She was catapulted into public life seven years ago when her first novel, "Suds in Your Eye," caught the fancy of GI's and civilians to the tune of 300,000 copies.

THE jacket shows a scared drummer boy, in all the red-and-gold splendor of the British Regulars, groping his way along the white walls of a French fort while a shell bursts neatly against a starry sky. One of Hollywood's adolescent historical fictions is indicated. But the story between the covers deserves a rather better fate than that.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 -- Half a dozen animals from the Philadelphia Zoo were paraded across the stage of the sedate Academy of Music today at the first of a series of five children's concerts by the Philadelphia Orchestra.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 17 (UP) -- A spokesman for Philip Murray, Congress of Industrial Organizations president, said today that the union would "honor its contracts" and seek no further pay increases in 1950 despite the recent rise in steel prices.

THANKS to the musical version of "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes" we have a new star on Broadway. Although the management has not given her celestial billing yet, it probably realizes, as everyone else does, that Carol Channing is the chief attraction of the production.
CONTRADICTORY as it may seem, Winter coverings are placed on plants not to keep them from freezing, but rather to make certain that they are kept frozen during the cold months.

More than half of the large metalworking companies reporting on a national survey of business trends in metal product manufacturing districts throughout the country reported yesterday that 1949 sales are below 1948 levels. In a study which included thirty-six companies in Chicago, St. Louis, Pittsburgh, Detroit, Cincinnati, New York and centers in New England, only twelve reported increases in total sales volume above 1948 levels.

No stretch of American soil has a wilder beauty or a more romantic history than the Jackson Hole country of Wyoming. Into the shadowed land beneath the majestic Grand Teton summits stalked wide-eyed John Colter, trapper and explorer, in 1807; through this valley in 1811 passed the Astoria-bound adventurers; here came trappers and Indians to outfit and rendezvous; here, finally, about 1884, arrived the first settlers, lonesome in the great silences.
THE author of the memorable story, "The Secret of the Porcelain Fish," here gives us another brightly painted picture of old China as seen by a naughty, appealing small boy.
RICHMOND, Dec. 17 -- Merchants over much of the Upper South are thankful this Christmas that television sales are doing so much to hold up a Yuletide trade that is not what it was a year ago.

THE revival that took place in American political culture between the Eighteen Nineties and the first World War is familiar to the most casual readers of American history, but a revolt that took place concurrently on another front among philosophical students of society is too little appreciated.

PARIS, Dec. 17 -- Negotiations now going on in Paris may result early in the coming year in transforming the Marshall Plan. If they succeed, the plan will become less a means of financing commodity purchases for Europe and more a means of financing a permanent monetary fund or "clearing union" to permit a freer flow of trade within Europe.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations came out with a financial report today for the first time.

Expanding Christmas shopping last week pulled sales totals for the period about even with those of the corresponding week of 1948 so far as department stores are concerned. Late buying is running heavy, following the normal pattern. Food sales ran slightly ahead of last year, while holiday liquor volume is expected to spurt this week.

If any superannuated brass hats are muttering in their beards about the curricular changes that are taking place at the United States Military Academy they have been discreet about their displeasure. No audible voice has been raised in protest against the "revolutionary" addition of more of the humanities, psychology, oral English, modern languages and other such embellishments to the rigorous course of study that has turned out our professional soldiers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- A move that apparently will ease the centralized and tight control of the Defense Secretary's office over the handling of news material by the three individual armed forces was disclosed today. News of the Army, Navy and Air Force will be controlled by the respective directors.

THOMAS BRIDGES and his son, Lucas, are among the few frontiersmen in history worth idolizing. Like the colonial pioneers of North America, they were men of exceptional courage and character. In all other respects they stand alone.
The shipping industry has held two meetings in the last few days to map action on competition posed by a declining trend in transatlantic air passenger rates, it was disclosed yesterday.
Transfer of certain governmental functions of Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem was hailed yesterday by rabbis throughout the city as a historic milestone in the development of the new Jewish state.

FOR THIS WEEK: Support newly planted trees with a stake or, if they are more than ten feet tall, with guy wires. . . . Don't forget to clean garden tools before putting them away, and to have pruning shears sharpened for winter use. . . . Cut down the chrysanthemum plants that were last to flower and any other neglected perennials. . . .

A Federal fellowship program to help subsidize the training of potential college teachers was proposed last week in the report of the first Conference on the Preparation of College Teachers. The conference was held Dec. 9-10 in Chicago under the auspices of the American Council on Education.

ROME, Dec. 17 -- For many weeks the Soviet military authorities in control of Albania have been supervising the embarkation at Albanian ports of Greek Communist guerrillas, who are being sent to Bulgaria by sea, said reports from Tirana this week.

LITERATURE, which has something for everybody sooner or later, has something for us all at this season in the form of new cookbooks. Where will any reader find a finer line than "When buying turkeys, estimate one pound per person"? (That's from "The Fireside Cook Book," by James A. Beard; Simon Schuster; $5).

" Crafts Today" will be the subject of the seventh in the current series of art lectures to be held on Tuesday at 6 P. M. in Room 213 of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. Mrs. Gladys Havre Simons will be the lecturer.

THE author has decided that planetary chaos, a world physically split by an atomic bomb, and a Nazi-like United States constitute ideal material for satire. Interwoven with heavy-handed treatments of these subjects is the story of an American and Korean who suddenly swapped residences because of the atomic blast of 1960.

THE search for peace is inherent in decent mankind. The two great world wars fought in this century have been fought for it. The first produced the League of Nations; the second the United Nations. Twentieth-century history has shown that the first impulse of mankind, after a shattering struggle, is to seek universal and permanent peace by universal and permanent machinery.

WHEN Hannah Smith, nee Merriam, was inside the True Believer Church she was proud of her lean, dark father, who led the service, and she felt a glow of affection for the brothers and sisters who joined in fervent cries of "Hallelujah," "Amen" and "Glory."
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 3 to 6 points higher, with a moderate volume of business.

Staging one of the most bullish demonstrations of the year, stock prices last week rocketed to new high levels. The upsurge was accompanied by numerous favorable news developments and predictions for the coming year. At the same time a flood of year-end dividends joined the cheerful parade of improved business statistics.

Robert Villemain, French middleweight who recently battered his way to a decision over Champion Jake LaMotta in a ten-round non-title bout at Madison Square Garden, left by plane yesterday to spend the Yuletide holidays with his family in France.

The Humane Society of New York held itS 'twenty-eighth annual Chrstm Tree pay yesterday for children and'their pets at the society's headquarters, 313 East Fifty-eighth Street, and distributed $600 worth off animal gear.

SMOKED turkey is nice to give at Christmas, but, to put it quite honestly if selfishly, even nicer to receive. Of course, the papery thin slices, dark or light, complement cocktails and hot heady punches.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 17 (UP) Navy's unbeaten basketball team, making its final appearance before playing in the Cotton Bowl, chalked up its fourth victory today by defeating the University of Maryland. 75 to 62.

Foreign traders here hope for early action next year by Congress on the program for streamlining and simplifying customs administrative procedure which has been under study by various Government agencies for a number of months.

The Alleghany Corporation yesterday offered holders of its 38,171 prior preferred and 310,525 Series A preferred shares rights to exchange their holdings for 233,785 shares of railway, utility and coal issues held in its portfolio. The invitation will remain open until Jan. 20, 1950.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- Officials of locals of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, whose 23,000 members are in five plants of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company in as many reties today received a pledge from the international union of "full support, both moral and financial, in their determination to obtain a just settlement of reasonable demands, including support of strike action if necessary.''

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 17 -- The Security Council of the United Nations resolved today to seek a short cut to a solution in the dispute between India and Pakistan over Kashmir because normal procedure had led to an impasse.

YOUTHFUL and budding naturalists will discover the essential facts about North American snakes from the large simple text and excellent black and white pictures of this compact little book. Painstakingly accurate, Dr. Zim is not content with mere recital of the habits and life cycle of snakes; he also shows how valuable some of these reptiles are in eating harmful insects, rats and mice.

THE truly remarkable staying powers demonstrated by such films as "Hamlet," "The Red Shoes" and "Quartet" in New York's smaller cinema theatres was duly noted in your perceptive essay (Dec. 11), "It's Still a Business."

AS the saga of the rise of a comedian whose egotism is unique but whose talents seem vague, "The Curtain Never Falls" is a complete guidebook to the gags, routines, stages and players of that world bounded by vaudeville, the Borscht Belt, Broadway, Radio City, Fifty-second Street and Beverly Hills.

ROSELLE, N. J., Dec. 17 -- As firemen here early today continued to wet down the ruins of the historic First Presbyterian Church, which with its attached parish house and chapel were wrecked in a $200,000 fire last night, the Rev. Robert M. MacNab announced that Sunday School sessions and worship services would be held tomorrow in Abraham Clark High School.

Re Henry Morgenthau Jr.'s "Let Us Give Food to the World's Hungry," I heartily agree to make this oversupply available for the world's needy. However, I think it outrageous to store so much powdered milk and egg powder, for which there is quite a market here for shipment abroad in food parcels.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- A decennial White House child conference next December that will result in a series of new practical and philosophical aids to all United States parents in bringing up their children was promised today by Dr. Leonard W. Mayo, chairman of the executive committee for the meeting.

MOST of radio's regularly scheduled programs will reflect the arrival of Christmas next Sunday and, in addition, the networks have made arrangements for many special shows in the spirit of the season.

ROME, Dec. 17 -- While land seizures continued this week in many parts of Central Italy, the Government was still calmly considering its agrarian reform bill, which should make land available to satisfy at least some of the demands of the peasants who have none.

About six miles up lies the stratosphere. Instruments sent into it by sounding balloons led meteorologists to believe that it was dry and virtually weatherless. Now come Earl W. Barrett, Lee R. Herndon Jr. and Howard J. Carter, University of Chicago meteorologists, with the discovery that in the stratosphere is a belt of air which is soaking wet -- 100 per cent saturation.

A 45CM (18-inch) f/5.6 telephoto lens for the Leica or Contax camera, which is only about six inches long and weighs a little more than three pounds, will be on the market next month, according to Paul Cherney, of the Alfa Photo Corporation. The lens, the Old Delft Fototel, is a Dutch product and will cost around $400.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Dec. 17 -A six-room custom built ranch style "dream home," to be used in a fund raising drive for the Long Beach Memorial Hospital, was completed here today during an eight-hour work period.
IDEAS and theories about rearing children can be found by the bookful. But facts are scarce. Ask the American farmer how to raise a good calf and he'll have the answers, or know where to find them.

Your way of figuring illiteracy in Italy and the United States is misleading, as stated in your reply to a letter concerning Carlo Levi's "Italy Fights the Battle of Illiteracy." The latest statistics on illiteracy in Italy are for 1930 and 1931.

IT is no longer safe to talk about the single record as distinguished from the album on the assumption that you will make yourself clear. The long-playing record, which contains the equivalent of an album or two, is a single disk, after all.
Last Friday Mao Tze-tung, head of a nation of 450,000,000 Chinese, met at the Kremlin with Joseph Stalin, head of a nation of 200,000,000 Russians.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Questions of national policy with respect to atomic energy are undergoing a vigorous re-examination on several fronts in Washington these days. Seldom has there been a deeper conviction that without vastly more order and discipline in the international competition for atomic development, disaster inevitably will result.

A new large-scale cost-cutting program, aimed also at mutual boosting of profit, will be carried out among retail druggists next year by the National Wholesale Druggists Association, it was learned last week.

The recent revelations of early leaks of atomic information to Russia reflect a state of mind which should fill each of us with grave concern. The general impression seems to be: "Russia has the bomb, therefore someone must have given her our secrets."

HONG KONG, Dec. 17 -- Hainan will be an early objective of Chinese Communist attack, observers here believe. It is felt certain that the big tropical island in the Gulf of Tongking will be tackled long before the Communists get around to assaulting Formosa.

The first national packaging survey of the American Supply and Machinery Manufacturers' Association, Inc., Pittsburgh, has been completed. A complete technical "methods manual," has been prepared under the direction of Robert Weir Jr., chairman of the sales methods committee of the association.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 17 -- The dollar volume of Christmas sales in stores here during the early part of this month showed a decrease of about 9 per cent as compared with the same period last year.

CHARLES LUTWIDGE DODGSON was a shy, pedantic Englishman who lectured on mathematics at Oxford from 1855 to 1881. He never really unbent except in the company of children. His one great hobby was photographing youngsters, and he was a great success with his subjects because of the fantastic stories he made up.

Seven large veterans' groups in New York State, including the American Legion, the Veterans of Foreign Wars and the Disabled American Veterans, are banding together to form a common front in fighting for legislation they feel is favorable to the veteran and the country.

The question of what effect labor's "fourth round" gains would have on prices was brought into sharp focus last week by the United States Steel Corporation (Big Steel), the nation's largest producer. Big Steel boosted its prices. It said the increase was necessitated largely by the concessions made under its new contract with Philip Murray's CIO United Steelworkers.
A local employe of the Central Trust of China sent $25 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, all her personal savings for two months.

FOR many years now the present observer has contended that Oscar Hammerstein is a better poet than most poets -- especially those who write long and semi-obscure pieces. It is also true (and this can be said of few writers of popular lyrics) that his words, are usually as well known as the music that accompanies them.
PARIS, Dec. 17 -- The United States and France have agreed on terms under which United States military aid will be supplied to France, a Foreign Office spokesman said tonight.

Two weeks hence, on New Year's Day, a new experiment in opera will be tried on television. Under the artistic direction of Lawrence Tibbett, the Metropolitan baritone, the Opera Television Theatre will make its bow on the Columbia Broadcasting System with the avowed hope of harvesting a new crop of opera enthusiasts.

HERE is a good Christmas Day book for 4-to-8-year-olds. While grown-ups bustle about, children and their guest cousins can find a quiet corner and amuse themselves by looking at and discussing the 500 illustrations which make this book so gay and colorful.

SAN BRUNO, Calif., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Huon Kid led from wire to wire today in the $15,000 added San Francisco Handicap on the getaway program at Tanforan. Nick Wall, on the comeback trail after suffering serious injuries in a spill that had him laid up nine months, was the winning jockey.
CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- Sammy Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., today officially was crowned golf's top money-winner and captor of the coveted Vardon Trophy in 1949.

BOSTON, Dec. 17 -- Inspired by Chuck Rayner's brilliant goal tending, the New York Rangers trounced the Boston Bruins, 3 -- 1, at the Boston Garden tonight before 9,474 fans, smallest National Hockey League gathering here in many years.

A depositor of the Chase National Bank might well be surprised to find Winthrop Aldrich, chairman, taking over a teller's window in the bank's main office, as a commuter on the New Haven Railroad might be taken aback to find Frederic Dumaine, chairman, punching tickets of the New Haven's commuters.

THOSE lists of books which authors draw up for the newspapers as a guide to confident giving, how reliable are they? A little yule logrolling is not unknown by writers; skeptical readers will make a distinction between logs blazing of their own combustion and those that have been sprinkled with chemical salts, the better to take a grain of in making a choice of books.

Looking back over the diplomatic events since 1945 there appears to be a danger that the United States may exhaust its post-war efforts and authority in Europe in pursuit of secondary rather than primary objectives; that American policy may come to regard certain tactical operations as fundamental diplomatic strategy.
Stephen Early's championship of industry's executives ("The Nation's Great Need -- Top Officials") for bigger and better government jobs is a one-sided proposal.

THOUGH thousands of years in time separate them, Prince Zarth Arn of the Mid-Galactic Empire contacts John Gordon, an ex-GI, by means of a complex scientific apparatus he has developed. Gordon is informed that if he is willing, an exchange of brains between them may be effected.

PARIS this autumn is musically minded. The concert halls are crowded, and there are queues at the box offices. The churches offer organ recitals and little groups like the Association des Amis de l'Orchestre de Chambre are giving programs of Bach and Handel.
Construction of a new settlement is under way in Israel for 100 blind immigrants and their families to enable them to become self-supporting within three months.

In Hal Borland's article, "Autumn Bounty in the Land," it is stated that four-fifths of America's sugar is supplied from sugar beets. This assertion is erroneous. Cane sugar provides four-fifths of our country's sugar requirements, with beet sugar taking care of the rest.

The war on tuberculosis may have another front-line weapon in para-aminosalicylic acid (abbreviated to PAS). When used with streptomycin it delivers a double-barreled attack on T. B. A report on PAS by Drs. Gwyn Roberts, James T. Duncan and Roy E. De Laney appears in the winter issue of the Stanford Medical Bulletin.

The British Industries Fair next May is expected to be the largest in its history, with more than 3,000 manufacturers, representing twenty-six groups of allied trades and ninety industries, exhibiting, according to the British Information Services.

A program of graduate studies under a group plan is under way at New York University as the result of a $50,000 grant from the Carnegie Corporation of New York, Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase announced yesterday.

Robert Moses' tastes (as revealed in his two articles on "The City's Museums") are no more authoritative than my own. And, as a twentieth century museum-goer, I would trade Mr. Moses a few dozen of his various exhibits -- as much "freshened up" as he likes -- for the one "huge, ugly, obtrusive Zeiss dumb-bell (as he called the intricate mechanism which projects the solar system on the dome of the Planetarium).

Andre Philip's "A Clue to the Maze of French Politics" seems to suffer from patriotic oversimplification. Perhaps a more basic cause of French political instability is the group of historic cleavages among the highly individualistic French people, such as peasant versus urban France and "Revolutionary" France versus those factions which opposed French Revolutionary philosophy.
Impelled by their failures, the utilities are about to take their case against alleged Government competition directly to the people.

THIS master of literary distillates has filtered into fifty- four small, tightly worded pages what countless, clumsy scribblers have not been able to convey in two-pound volumes. It is an old E. B. White trick. No matter how often you reread it, you find it hard to say how the effect is achieved. It is black magic done with printer's ink.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 17 -- Having advanced a standby total mobilization plan to a stage he deems satisfactory, President Truman is now ready to try again to end the year-long deadlock over the chairmanship of the National Security Resources Board.

THERE are some places and situations that offer you nothing but despair. Somehow you cannot be yourself in them. Everybody and everything there cancels you out. You are alone among the enemy. Anything you say or do or can even imagine yourself saying or doing would mean nothing.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 17 -- Considering a sales slump earlier in the year. West Coast merchants fairly generally are congratulating themselves on the Christmas trade to date. The situation is somewhat spotty through the Twelfth Federal Reserve District, with the district as a whole off 3 to 4 per cent compared with last year but with such metropolitan areas as widely separated Spokane, San Diego and Salt Lake City showing improvement.

TONIGHT in the Frick mansion on Fifth Avenue the strains of the Aida march, the "Pilgrim's Chorus," "Believe Me If All Those Endearing Young Charms," the "Lost Chord," and "End of a Perfect Day" will rise from the Frick family organ -- the favorite selections of Henry Clay Frick, the centenary of whose birth will occur tomorrow.

Beaten to all intents and purposes on two occasions when they trailed with only seconds remaining, the New York Knickerbockers refused to give up and came on to defeat the St. Louis Bombers, 81 -- 76, at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Charles A. Lindbergh, whose fame as pilot and airman began with his nonstop solo flight to Europe in 1927 and has continued for more than two decades, received tonight the Wright Brothers Memorial Trophy, which was awarded for his "enduring" contributions to American aviation.

Premium lists for the Westminster Kennel Club show in Madison Square Garden Feb. 13 and 14 are being distributed throughout the country now. Also bearing on the most important of America's dog shows is an event being held in Worcester, Mass., today.

KEY WEST, Dec. 17 -- President Truman declared today that the anti-submarine training going on here, with the latest type of schnorkel submarines and the vessels designed to destroy them, was "one of the great necessities of our national defense program."

The 200-inch mirror for the Hale Telescope has been aluminized, put back in the telescope and the first new test photographs made with the giant instrument, Dr. Ira S. Bowen, director of the Mount Wilson and Palomar Observatories, announces. The photographs leave no doubt that the Hale will be a great success, but not until a Ross corrector lens has been installed.

Having suffered defeat in five successive Presidential elections, the Republican high command has now decided to turn to the right and adopt a definite party program for next year's Congressional elections in opposition to the Fair Deal of President Truman as preparation for the Presidential election of 1952.

Leading educators of the city and nation will meet this afternoon at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, to honor Dr. Alvin S. Johnson, who has been a vigorous influence in American education for the last half century. Dr. Johnson, who is 75 years old today, has pioneered in the field of adult education and has helped extend educational opportunities to all, regardless of race, creed or color.

ROME -- Three symbolical taps of Pope Pius XII's golden hammer will officially open the "holy door" of St. Peter's Basilica in Rome next Saturday, thus inaugurating the Holy Year and setting off what may develop into the greatest peaceful migration of Americans to the Eternal City recorded in history.

ROBERT BUCKNER, Universal - International writer - producer, has returned from an expedition to Italy for his film "Deported" with the information, contrary to standard local myth, that work there is not only economical but efficient.

A FEW popular novels aimed primarily at the ladies' lending library trade have the gaiety and direct appeal of primitive paintings. And so it is with Mrs. Loring's latest romantic flight. Wendy Adair, courageous and beautiful, and the strong, handsome, dashing, rich and intelligent men in her life are involved in potentially exciting adventures in Washington, centering around smuggled State Department documents.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Companies must bargain about the price of meals in company-operated dining rooms if these are the only eating places convenient to some of the employes.

TEL AVIV, Dec. 17 -- There is hardly anyone in this land who expected internationalization in the form in which it was proposed to the United Nations General Assembly. As a matter of fact, few thought any degree of internationalization would be imposed especially after Foreign Minister Moshe Sharrett and other oppositionists had so clearly defined its impracticability.

MR. JOSEPH A. BARRY, writing from Paris (Book Review, Nov. 27), says that in his copy of Webster's Collegiate Dictionary, fifth edition, he finds the entry: "Gide, Andre, 1869-1934. Fr. novelist, critic essayist." I am puzzled by the fact that my own copy of that dictionary, in that same edition (1943); has this somewhat different entry: "Gide, Andre, 1860 -- Fr. novelist, critic, and essayist."

MADRID, Dec. 17 -- Spain's third National Assembly of Farmers and Stock Raisers concluded today with the presentation to Generalissimo Francisco Franco by 3,000 delegates of requests and recommendations, which, they were told in advance, probably would not be carried out.

WROCLAW (Breslau), Dec. 17 -- A purported French intelligence network in Poland was described this afternoon by Yvonne Bassaler, former secretary at the French consulate here, as she pleaded guilty to espionage charges before a Polish military court.

The announcement of a $4-a-ton net price increase by the United States Steel Corporation last week, touching off the fourth set of post-war price advances to compensate for a similar number of direct and indirect rounds of wage rises, came as no surprise to industrial observers. The timing of the action, however, and the fact that it was limited to 4 per cent were not generally expected in financial circles.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- In the wake of raids which netted thirty-one drug peddlers and users early today, Federal agents and police detectives set out tonight in a continuing drive which is aimed at wiping out the city's traffic in illegal use of narcotics.

The collapse of resistance to the Chinese Communists and the advance of the Communist armies to the borders of Southeast Asia already have had politico-military effects in Asiatic countries, according to reports reaching Washington last week.

AFTER having been included for many years in the Scott Standard Postage Stamp Catalogue as a separate political entity, the region once philatelically known as "South Bulgaria" has been subordinated by the catalogue's publishers.

COLLECTIVISM is a system of government which subordinates individual freedom and initiative to an all-powerful state in which the government supports the people rather than the people the government. But for the sake of those who wish to be academic, the Library of Congress has supplied this definition of collectivism:
HOUSTON, Tex., Dec. 17 (AP)--O. O. Kessing, commissioner of the All-America Football Conference, tonight said "big news" will develop at the league's New York City meeting next month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The United States issued its first formal warning to United States ships and ship operators today that Shanghai was a "zone of danger" to both American lives and property and "extremely hazardous to shipping."
The dollar shortage appeared last week to have deprived the United States of another important market.

" Bulky up-state New York is tinged with New England," writes Hal Borland in "48 States, 48 Personalities." But how much more tinged with Amsterdam and Flissingen (Flushing to you) and the House of Orange and the rest of the Netherlands! Architecturally, how much more elegant! For the New England "salt box" clapboard shacks, take upper New York State's stately "Greek Revival" mansions.
Six hundred junior high school students were nearly unanimously agreed yesterday that, with certain reservations, children in their age group should be allowed to participate in family decisions.

Generosity is one of the virtues of the American people. Prodigality is one of their faults. In his recent address before the National Reorganization Conference in Washington, Herbert Hoover warned that "we must stop wasting our heritage if we are to survive as a free people."

Three volumes of a monumental work that has been in the making intermittently for more than twenty years, a catalogue of the art treasures of the Frick Collection, Fifth Avenue and Seventieth Street, will be shown there at a preview inspection tonight, the eve of the centenary of the birth of Henry Clay Frick.

FOR its last six performances at the City Center, the new New York City Dance Company still has a flock of novelties. Among them are Charles Weidman's "Rose of Sharon" (formerly called "Song of Songs") in its world premiere, and his "Ata

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 17 -- It now seems unmistakable that the new line of President Juan Peron is to portray himself as beyond politics and to court, or perhaps deliberately abet the formation of a new "loyal opposition" within the framework of the peronista ideology.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Undefeated La Salle College broke loose in the second half of a Convention Hall basketball game to whip previously unbeaten Temple, 60 to 55, tonight. Southern California trounced St. Joseph's, 79 -- 65, in the opener before a crowd of 7,923.

Gracie Mansion, the large, white frame Colonial house at Eighty-seventh Street and the East River, was built in 1799 by a wealthy ship-owner named Archibald Gracie for his private residence. In 1927 the city's Park Department restored the house as a kind of museum; it was furnished by museums and private collectors.

The city's first water holiday on Friday cut 176,000,000 gallons from last week's daily average consumption. Only 798,000,000 gallons were used during the 24-hour shaveless and bathless period as compared with 879,000,000 gallons on Thursday and 937,000,000 gallons on the previous Friday.

Falling off of low-end dress sales has forced New York manufacturers to consider drastic steps to revive business, it was pointed out last week. The segment of the industry producing dresses wholesaling at $8.75 or under has undergone one of its worst seasons since before the war, manufacturers said, mainly because consumers have failed to respond to the styles that were offered.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 17 -- Without going into the merits of the case, it is now apparent that the decision of the General Assembly to set up an international regime in Jerusalem is an example of a resolution that commits the United Nations to a policy that has no chance of being carried out.

Christmas sales m the Second Federal Reserve District are giving department store owners no cause for complaint. This district, which contains the world's largest shopping areas, in and around New York City, seems assured of selling a large number of gifts this year than during the Christmas season of 1948.
For the third straight year right wing Forces in the New York Newspaper Guild, CIO, were elected to office by large margins over two opposition slates.

VISITORS from the United States, several millions of whom annually travel to the near-by countries of Canada, Cuba, Mexico, Bermuda and the Caribbean, received a real break this year from Congress. So, though to a lesser degree, did the hundreds of thousands of tourists to Europe and other climes.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 17 -- The Scandinavian and British experts who have been discussing the British proposal for removing financial restrictions and for closer economic cooperation between their countries ended their three-day talks here tonight on a note of uncertainty.

THOSE who interest themselves in art sometimes vehemently deprecate modern painting, but at least they are familiar with most of its wonderful wanderings since it left the broad road of realism sometime before the first World War.

LONDON, Dec. 17 (Reuters)--Pan American World Airways claimed to have set up a new transatlantic record today from New York to Shannon, Eire, of 7 hours 49 minutes, representing an average speed of 395 miles an hour for the 2,670 miles.

In preparation for post-Christmas and January promotions, coat and suit buyers here last week placed fill-in orders for fur trimmed and untrimmed coats, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office, Zip-in lining coats were reordered and these also will be featured in promotions.

DR. KOUSSEVITZKY'S gift to the Library of Congress of the funds and manuscripts of the Koussevitzky Music Foundation, Inc., now to be known as the Serge Koussevitzky Music Foundation in the Library of Congress, is an event properly characterized by Luther H. Evans, Librarian of Congress, as "an event assured to exert a benign and growing influence upon the history of music throughout the world."

Stephen Early in "The Nation's Great Need -- Top Officials" suggests three impediments to the attraction of working for the Government but omits a fourth and very important one. He names politics, the appointive-confirmation process, and financial inducements.

CARVED in stone across the facade of New York's Main Post Office is the oft-quoted legend: "Neither snow nor rain nor heat nor gloom of night stays these couriers from the swift completion of their appointed rounds."

LONDON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Proud architects showed off Britain's new House of Commons today, and announced that the rebuilding of the chamber, smashed by German bombs on May 10, 1941, should be completed in time for next autumn's session of Parliament.

" SIR," Stendhal once replied to a man who asked him his business. "I am an observer of the human heart." What Stendhal did not say was that he was equally busy hiding his own heart from the curiosity of others. And in both businesses -- in the one of observing and in the one of being observed -- he was pre-eminently successful.

PARIS, Dec. 17 -- Western Germany has set out to regain the world markets the Germans held before the war on a free trade basis, Baron Vollrath von Maltzan, director of foreign trade of the Bonn Republic, said today in an interview published in the French newspaper Monde. Baron Maltzan is in Paris for talks on the Franco-German trade pact that is expected to be signed next week.

IN June of 1929 blood pressures rose to record highs in the sidewalk cafes of Paris' Left Bank: Transition -- its title originally had a lower case "t" -- had just published its notorious "Revolution of the Word" proclamation, abolishing dictionaries, grammars and even readers.

A program of Korean music and dances was presented yesterday afternoon in Times Hall. Cha-Kyung Kim, soprano, sang "Batti, Batti," from Mozart's "Don Giovanni," and works by Cherubini, H. Y. Lee and Harry R. Bishop, with the assistance of Leslie Harnly, pianist, and Catherine Lewis, flutist.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Dec. 17 -- While a United States policy pushes steadily for integration of Europe to facilitate its economic recovery and strengthen its political and military position, sufficiently complex obstacles are emerging to render this difficult.

City Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard will commend twelve Queens College students, who are canvassing Queens communities to find foster homes for homeless children, at an informal meeting on Tuesday at 11:30 A.M. in the office of Dr. John J. Theobald, the college president.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Once - beaten Canisius outlasted California, 55 -- 83, for its fifth basketball victory tonight in Memorial Auditorium. Washington State overcame the University of Buffalo, 56 -- 44, in the first game of the double-header.

DALLAS, Dec. 17 -- Christmas business for this Federal Reserve district is off this year. Buying was down 9 per cent for the week ending Dec. 3, but was off only 3 per cent for the week ending Dec. 10 as against the same two periods in 1948.

MONTREAL, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Rip Riopelle's goal midway through the third period carried the Montreal Canadiens to a 4-to-3 National Hockey League victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight. The triumph advanced the secondplace Frenchmen within six points of the league-leading Wings.

JUST about the funniest show on the radio is Groucho Marx's half-hour of absurdity and sass at 9 P. M. Wednesdays over CBS. Where his colleagues in ethereal humor for the most part are still struggling with rusty situations and pedestrian

William Ogburn's "Can Science Bring Us Happiness?" dodges several of the underlying causes of unhappiness in our industrial society. How can our fears and anxieties be expected to diminish when the threat of war, the growing totality of expanding industry and science, and the utter impotence of the individual increase so rapidly? Will "more spending money" and a few suggestions about "how to choose a mate" offset these monstrous forces? * * *

POINSETTIAS will be massed in the greenhouses at the New York Botanical Garden, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden and Prospect Park throughout the holidays. The New York City Park Department will have over 1,500 plants on display in Prospect Park, at Prospect Park West and Ninth Street, Brooklyn.

Although the Giants finished nowhere near the top in the National League standings they can boast today of having the leading pitcher in that department of pitching coveted by all hurlers -- the earned-run averages.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Dec. 17 -After a slow start in which it was unable to demonstrate any positive superiority throughout the first half, Army got its basketball attack moving in high gear midway through the closing session and went on to smother St. Lawrence University, 70 to 53, before a crowd of 2,500 in the field house today.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 17 -- Afghanistan's Ambassador to India alleged today that his landlocked country's principal trade routes, which go through Pakistan, had been severed by a deliberate economic blockade.
TODD DUNCAN, the Umfundisi of Ndotsheni in the thriving musical play, "Lost in the Stars," took a long chance when he left Australia last September to come here for the role.

HOUSTON, Tex., Dec. 17 -- All-Star power and a mud-swamped field proved too big a handicap today and the All-America Conference champion Cleveland Browns lost, 12 -- 7, in the Shamrock Bowl football game for charity.

LAKE HARMONY, Pa., Dec. 17 -- Ardent metropolitan skiers who have always pointed their wooden runners northward for sports might do well to investigate the possibilities of this compact skiland south of the border, so to speak, in the beautiful Pocono Mountains. In its fourth season the Split Rock development has assumed major stature.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 17 -- The political situation in Syria has become more difficult as a result of differences in the Constituent Assembly today over the oath to be taken Monday by Hashem al-Atassi, Provisional Chief of State.
All this discussion of "security" and "retiring" at 60 and taking time off for "hobbies" amuses a youth who is about to complete seventy-three years of busy life.

RESERVATIONS are already heavy for Christmas crowds leaving the city for the holiday season. With Christmas falling on Sunday, Monday is the official Yule holiday, thus giving all hands three days for fun and feasting. Extra trains and planes will be put into service to carry merrymakers to annual celebrations far and near. The big exodus will get under way by Wednesday and reach its peak the day before Christmas.

TO an audience sitting in Carnegie Hall, the 112 men of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra present one kind of picture. It is a picture largely obscured by the commanding presence of the conductor. But to us, who face him at our desks on the other side of the proscenium, the Philharmonic is something quite different.

THE review by Michael M. Davis of Faxon's "The Hospital and the Community" (Book Review, Oct. 23) has been called to my attention. I am astounded by the outrageously false statement therein that "many of the Blue Cross leaders now ask Government subsidy to enable their plans to expand."

The oldest maritime school in the country, the New York State Maritime College at Fort Schuyler in the Bronx, passed its seventy-fifth anniversary last week, but formal celebration of the occasion was deferred until next spring. Originally set up by the New York City Board of Education as the New York Nautical School, the institution is now a full-time professional college in the State University system.

Rolling up the bulk of its score in the middle distance and distance events, Manhattan College won the team title for the fourth straight year in the Metropolitan A. A. U. junior indoor track and field championships at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night.

TOKYO, Dec. 17 -- Labor unrest spread today over a wide field of vital industries. The nation-wide strike just begun by the Japanese Seamen's Union was reported to have immobilized more than 150 vessels in principal Japanese ports, with other crews expected to join as soon as their ships reached port.

When next month's show-goer to the National Motor Boat Exposition has trudged his way in and out of every display of pleasure craft, marine motor and gadget, there will still be a heap of show for him to see. At least twelve institutional and educational exhibits have received space allotments from Joseph E. Choate, show manager. Many of them will be "musts" for the skippers.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- Leaders of Britain's Labor party, chagrined at the defeat of their comrades in Australia and New Zealand, found satisfaction closer home in the victory in the South Bradford by-election. It was the thirty-fifth that they had won.
This letter suggests that Messrs. Acheson and Hoffman and even THE TIMES may be counting too heavily on a rise of United States imports to solve Europe's dollar problems.
Staging a six-goal rally in the final period, the Brooklyn Polo Club came from behind to gain a 13-12 victory over Squadron A before a crowd of 500 at the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn last night.
This exchange was overheard at U. N. headquarters at Lake Success last week:

FRIENDS and relatives of members of the armed forces stationed in Germany may send Christmas messages overseas without charge, thanks to special arrangements made by the Airways and Air Communications Service of the Air Force at Mitchel Field, N. Y.

THAT loving connoisseur of words, Mr. Ivor Brown, has recently called attention to a peculiarity in their contemporary use so obvious that I am surprised not to have seen the fact mentioned before. Writing about "Words in Our Time" for the journal of the National Book League (London), Mr. Brown observes that one curious aspect of word-usage today is the undeclared warfare between use of the long and the short word.

Only two days after the article by Daniel L. Schorr ("World Law at Work") appeared in the Dec. 4 Magazine the United Nations General Assembly passed on another case to the International Court of Justice at The Hague.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 17 -- Artist Life, ably handled by Angel Rivera, gained his second straight victory at Tropical Park today, beating eight rivals in the Governor Warren Purse. Helen S. Reineman's Dinner Hour, closing stoutly on the inside, nosed out Cherry Oca Stable's Pellicle for second. Happy Victor, coupled with Artist Life as the Grandview Stables' entry, was fourth, another nose away.

Balked in their efforts to swing a trade with the Senators, the Yankees yesterday concentrated their efforts on Detroit and in the matter of a few hours were able to close a deal that will bring Dick Wakefield, 28-year-old "problem child" of the Tigers, to the Stadium next season.

A 2,000,000-volt X-ray machine for cancer treatment has been ordered by the city for installation in the Francis Delafield Hospital, which is nearing completion on 163d Street between Riverside Drive and Fort Washington Avenue, it was announced yesterday.

Abrupt termination of United States aid to Europe in 1952 may waste the thirty billion dollars this country has invested in European recovery and result in our defeat in the "cold war," Russell C. Leffingwell warned yesterday.

THE aim of Mr. Wilson's novel is to present the "citizen criminal" in his natural habitat, in this case a roach-ridden Alabama jail. He begins briskly with a man-hunt of an irresponsible young hothead who has stolen a farmer's Chevrolet.

Hungry New Yorkers, who for nearly four decades have been accustomed to drop nickels in a slot when they patronized a Horn Hardart restaurant, are in for a surprise when they visit the company's new unit soon to be opened in Fresh Meadows, Queens.

Eleven changes in its personnel were announced yesterday by Wamsutta Mills through its president, Joseph H. Axelrod. Fisher Abramson has been named executive vice president in addition to treasurer, while K. B. Cook has relinquished his posts as vice president and general manager of Wamsutta to devote full time to his duties as vice president and general manager of Crown Manufacturing Company and to the management of the new dye plant recently constructed by Crown.

KITTY HAWK, N. C., Dec. 17 -- Maj. Gen. Orvil A. Anderson, commandant of the Air War College, said here today that the United States could never really bargain for its security on mobilization after D-day. He said this was one of the two big lessons learned as a result of World War II.
As a West Virginian, I consider that Hal Borland in "48 States, 48 Personalities" omitted relevant material. Ever hear of John W. Davis, Richard Harding Davis, Louis Johnson or "Stonewall" Jackson?

Asserting that their clients had been "unlawfully sentenced by the same court which now seks to deny them the constitutional right to counsel of their own choosing," the four lawyers for three of the "Trenton six" defendants, three of whom were barred from the case on Friday, issued a joint statement yesterday.

The annual Groton-St. Mark s i School dance in 'behalf of the summer ,camps maintained by thei schools will b held on Wednesday night in the. Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Patrick F. Crossman of Groton and Henry F. Romaine of St. Mark's head the dance committee.

Industrial uses for radium in product testing are now up 25 per cent above previous levels on a national basis. Steel foundries, pipeline constructors and power plant equipment makers using radiography as a standard inspection practice have been responsible for this increase, it was learned here yesterday.

I happen to be a theatregoer who likes perspective when viewing a stage rather than the front rows and grease paint at close range. So, when writing for my second pair of tickets to "South Pacific" recently, I asked for the rear of the center of the orchestra and received them promptly -- for three months from now, as expected, and with the following note:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- A new drive against liquor advertising will be started soon after Congress convenes next month. The Senate Commerce Committee has set hearings for Jan. 12 and 13 on a bill to bar interstate transportation and radio broadcast of liquor advertising.

VIENNA, Dec. 17 -- Israel Jacobson, head of the American Joint Distribution Committee's Hungarian office, was arrested Thursday by the Hungarian Political Police on his return to Budapest from a six-week holiday in the United States.

UTICA, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- Colgate dealt Princeton its third straight basketball loss in Utica Free Academy gymnasium tonight, 76 -- 68. More than 1,600 fans saw the Red Raiders break on top and maintain a 5-to-10-point lead. They led at halftime, 40 -- 35, and at the three-quarters mark, 57 -- 48.

THIS has been a momentous year, a year of vast ebb and flow. The cold war, the atomic debate, the dollar gap, China, Germany, Yugoslavia -there has been turbulence everywhere. Yet within this picture of change one old tradition has remained unaltered, unshakable, in a world constantly putting tradition on trial.

PARIS, Dec. 17 -- Chinese Communist forces reached the frontier of Indo-China this week. They came in comparatively small numbers. But they symbolized what the French consider to be the danger of more massive incursion from the north, possibly in the form of Communist penetration or of Communist aid to Ho Chi Minh, the Communist-trained leader of the highly organized and well-armed force in Indo-China that so long has successfully resisted the French.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Defense Secretary Louis Johnson has told President Truman that a three-year extension of the peace-time draft law is "essential" to national security, it was learned today.

THIS entertaining account of our adolescent republic in the Jacksonian era begins with the remark that Americans believed that change meant progress. And the changes of the Eighteen Thirties, from New York City with its new Croton Reservoir to Texas with its newly established independence, were multitudinous.

The Ogden Corporation has called a special meeting of stockholders for Dec. 27 to consider a proposal to dissolve and liquidate it, it was disclosed yesterday in a notice from the New York Curb Exchange.

One hundred fifty of the nation's leaders in education, industry and public affairs will honor the Shah of Iran, Mohammed Reza Pahlevi, at a dinner tomorrow night in the Columbia University Men's Faculty Club, 400 West 117th Street.

Last September newspaper readers added a new technical term to their vocabularies. The word was "antihistamine." An antihistamine, chlortrimetron, since named coricidin for commercial reasons, was reported to stop a cold from developing when the first chill and sniffle were noticed.
