Three armed young thugs invaded the Argo Fur Company at 110 West Thirtieth Street -- about twenty feet from the entrance to the West Thirtieth Street police station -- late yesterday afternoon, gagged and bound three owners and escaped with twelve fur coats, valued at $20,000, and also $3,300 in cash.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 -- To date, Christmas sales in department stores through the Third Federal Reserve Bank District are running approximately 4 per cent below the corresponding period of last year in dollar volume.

INDIA, which is contributing its fair share to the field of contemporary history, is the subject of a feature-length documentary currently being prepared by The March of Time. Approximately 150,000 feet of film was shot by camera crews sent to the teeming sub-continent this year and in 1948, according to Richard de Rochemont, the producer.

TORONTO, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Chicago's high-geared offense broke loose with five goals in the third period tonight as the Black Hawks smothered the Toronto Maple Leafs, 7 to 1, in a National Hockey League game.
LONDON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Movies with a "basically sadistic theme" are to be banned outright in Britain under a ruling of the Board of Film Censors announced today.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- British industrialists, attacking the problem of increasing Britain's production, have been distinctly encouraged by the recent results of a productivity convention held to discuss how to improve output by the application of more efficient methods, many of them American.
ROME, Ga., Dec. 17 -- The mass civil rights trial of ten men with its tales of seven flogged Negroes and night-riding Ku Klux Klansmen ended in a mistrial today.

IT is Christmas time and New York is ablaze with light. This is the outer glow and it brings with it gutter and cheer. But there is another kind of light that brings something deeper and more lasting. It is the glow that is between friend and friend, between neighbor and neighbor.

In the face of the cutthroat bidding of banking syndicates for underwriting contracts, alert investment banking capital is still finding it possible to earn substantial returns for executing its basic job of distributing new public-utility stock now coming to market.
MOSCOW, Dec. 17 -- In the new oratorio by Dmitri Shostakovich, called "Song of the Forests" are these words written by the poet Eugene Dolmatovsky:

PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 17 -- Gwilym I. Jones, anthropologist of Cambridge University, completed today several months of investigation into ritual murders (voodoo) in the British protectorate of Basutoland. He declared that in his view police action alone was powerless to end such crimes.

CLEVELAND. Dec. 17 -- Department store Christmas sales in the Fourth Federal Reserve District have shown appreciable gains in the last four weeks, but have a long way to go to yield an ultimate outcome satisfactory to merchants.

CARNEGIE HALL, which has nurtured so much art in New York, is now sheltering the city's latest cultural nursery. Down in the sub-basement level of the old red building, between a locker room and telephone booths, hundreds of youngsters studying virtually every art have established headquarters in a tiny lunchroom.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 17 -- Dr. Walter Eytan, Director General of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said tonight that there was no intention of moving the Foreign Ministry to Jerusalem "at the present time." This more or less rules out the current belief that Jerusalem would suddenly be transformed into the capital of the new state.

FOR the fourth time in history -- and the first time in twenty-five years -- Bernard Shaw's "Caesar and Cleopatra" will appear on the Broadway stage. Sir Cedric Hardwicke and Lilli Palmer will star in the production opening soon at the National Theatre.

ONCE upon a time George Halas hired a calliope to advertise his Chicago Bears but he soon abandoned the project because the Papa Bear just couldn't afford the $15 a week it cost. Newspapers dismissed pro football games with a one-sentence story and Halas was thrilled to tears when one early account of a Bear battle carried the additional line: "It was a very fine game."
ATLANTA. Dec. 17 -- Christmas business is moving along in substantial volume in the Sixth Federal District.

WILLA CATHER had nothing of the literary lioness about, her. Her reticence concerning her personal history has left her admirers with little to satisfy them beyond her creative writings, which by themselves, of course, are as good as a feast.

FOR the fourth time in history -- and the first time in twenty-five years -- Bernard Shaw's "Caesar and Cleopatra" will appear on the Broadway stage. Sir Cedric Hardwicke and Lilli Palmer will star in the production opening soon at the National Theatre.

ONCE upon a time George Halas hired a calliope to advertise his Chicago Bears but he soon abandoned the project because the Papa Bear just couldn't afford the $15 a week it cost. Newspapers dismissed pro football games with a one-sentence story and Halas was thrilled to tears when one early account of a Bear battle carried the additional line: "It was a very fine game."
ATLANTA. Dec. 17 -- Christmas business is moving along in substantial volume in the Sixth Federal District.

WILLA CATHER had nothing of the literary lioness about, her. Her reticence concerning her personal history has left her admirers with little to satisfy them beyond her creative writings, which by themselves, of course, are as good as a feast.

THE use of documentary photography as the principal medium for telling about a primitive people's rise from poverty to independence provides the amateur with a valuable object lesson in "The Awakening Valley" by John Collier Jr. and Anibal Buitron (Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. $6), just published.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 17 -- The Government campaign to harass the independent newspapers Nacion and Prensa has entered a new phase. The municipality of Buenos Aires is invoking all the technicalities on the books to hamper, without halting, day-to-day operation of the plants of both dailies.

THE thing about the Norwegians, as a nation or individuals, is their downright usefulness. Nansen, Amundsen, Riiser-Larsen -- strip any of them of their glamour and glory and the hard nugget of utility is there.

In observance of the season and in observance of something else -no less than the genius of Richard Wagner -- Toscanini devoted himself to a program of that master's works, beginning with two excerpts from "Parsifal," when he conducted the NBC Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Radio City.
Five generations of the Metchik family and several hundred friends will gather today to celebrate the 100th birthday of its oldest member, Isaac Wolf Metchik.

SAN JUAN, P. R. -- The first results of the recognition by Puerto Rico and her neighboring West Indies islands of tourism as a major industry were evident here last week after the Hollywoodian opening of the Caribe-Hilton Hotel. Nearly four hundred people came down here by plane and ship from the States for the opening parties.
It is disappointing to find Paul Hoffman ("We Must Do Our Part") held at fault for "lacking the courage" to demand tariff cuts, as charged by a writer in your letters columns.

For the second time within three weeks Zenas Colt, belting No. 2, came through with last - period goals to bring victory to the New York Athletic Club indoor polo team in the second match of a double-header at the Squadron A Armory last night.
HISTORY is notorious for repeating itself in bridge, and the experienced player will often have the comfortable feeling that he has seen his hand before and knows precisely how to play it.

ONCE again, in a thirteenth-floor courtroom in Manhattan's skyscraper Federal Building, on Foley Square, Alger Hiss and Whittaker Chambers are at grips in the contest which in the past year has dominated and changed the lives of both men. It is a contest which has been fought before a committee of Congress, before a grand jury, before a trial jury which could not agree where the truth lay, and now before a second trial jury.

WASHINGTON. FEW industries depend so much on good public relations as the motion picture industry. Last week, meeting in Washington, twenty top officials from all branches of the industry decided relations with the public -- the all-important ticket-buying public -- were badly in need of repair.

FOR some time the readers of the literary magazine Horizon have been hearing rumors that Cyril Connolly, its editor and founder, was going to suspend publication temporarily or close shop for good. Now the rumor has come true, though in its least distressing form.

Residents of the metropolitan area will have more packages under their trees next Sunday than they had a year ago. Sales in department stores and United Parcel Service deliveries combine to show that 5 to 10 per cent more gifts than last year will be purchased by Christmas Eve.

OF primary interest to nurses, this book tells the story of the Bellevue School of Nursing, which is more than seventy-five years old, and which seems to have authentic claim to being the first training school for nurses in the United States.

HOLLYWOOD. THE epic battle between Samuel Goldwyn and Mary Pickford over the 16-acre film studio they own jointly on Santa Monica Boulevard developed last week into a Chinese puzzle as Mr. Goldwyn's organization continued filming the current "Edge of Doom" in the studio while movable studio equipment was shuttling back and forth across the street in a legal gambit of inspired ingenuity.

Long Island University was expected to rout Denver and did, 58 -- 43, and Holy Cross figured to outscore N. Y. U. and did, 49 -- 34, last night in the closing basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley said tonight it was his "candid judgment" that the American people would continue to support the Democratic party "throughout the years of the future."

THOSE engaged in promoting music, either for love or money, are always thinking up new ideas. One of the ideas that has proved most successful has been that of getting members of the community to cooperate with commercial managements in presenting subscription series.

The rear part of a five-story factory building at 1072 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, was wrecked at 10:30 A. M. yesterday when the roof collapsed apparently under the weight of a 10,000-gallon corrugated metal water tank, the police reported.

HONOLULU, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Quarterback Eddie Lebaron and College of the Pacific -- a school ignored by bowl promoters -- closed an undefeated, untied football season with a crushing 75-0 victory over the University of Hawaii last night.

HAVANA, Dec. 17 -- Melvin (Chick) Harbert, long-driving golf star from Detroit, and Havana Amateur Pedro Menocal today won the best ball 54-hole contest of the $10,000 Havana invitational pro-amateur tournament with a total score of 184.

Gray Iron Founders have started studying selling methods used by the industry, for the first time. First reports received on a national analysis of methods show that there is little uniformity in practices followed, according to a preliminary tabulation. The Gray Iron Founders' Society, Inc., of Cleveland, indicated that complete details of results of compilation of information from 256 foundries will be sent to all members within the next week.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (AP) -- While grains showed little change in prices today on the Board of Trade, lard spurted under aggressive buying for a Saturday session. May and July contracts, in which dealings most recently started, reached new seasonal peaks, but the best gain was made by December.

CHICAGO. Dec. 17 -- Christmas business in the Seventh Federal Reserve District this week was about 5 per cent below the record level set last year, in dollar volume. But this year's Christmas business here may equal that of last year for these reasons:

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 18 (UP) -- All - American Doak Walker, Southern Methodist's sparkplug, was declared out of the West line-up for the Shrine game today when the knee that kept him out of the S. M. U.-Notre Dame game and crippled the Mustangs throughout the season failed to respond to treatment.

LONDON, Dec. l7 -- Defense plans for the Scandinavian sector of the North Atlantic pact are now well along, it was learned today. These plans are being drawn up rapidly by military experts of Britain, Norway and Denmark, which make up the Northern European Group -- one of the five geographic groups in the pact.

While a huge amount of American dollars for rehabilitation has been flowing into the Philippines, many commodities are being purchased in Japan and other countries which have been previously bought in the United States, according to a survey especially prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by C. E. Mauchenheim, spokesman for Robot Statistics, 24 Stone Street.

While intolerance cannot be eradicated by law, civil rights measures can clear the way for the gradual disappearance of prejudice, Attorney General J. Howard McGrath declared here last night in an address before the Hudson County (N. J.) Bar Association at the Statler Hotel.

That famous old "agrarian reformer," Mao Tze-tung, has now gone officially to Moscow to celebrate his reforms and incidentally to pay his homage to his spiritual chieftain, Stalin. He has not lost much time on the second score, since he was in full oratorical flight before he ever left the ceremonious greeting at the railway station.

WOLVERHAMPTON, England, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Juno, the elephant who has been on a sitdown strike in a railway car for a week, was lured out today by an old friend who came all the way from Dublin to chat with her.

EARLY along at the outset of the new film, "The Bicycle Thief," which the brilliant Vittorio De Sica has sent us from Italy, the principal character in it -- an humble bill-poster in Rome -- has pathetic occasion to make an appeal to the police.

A recent conference of the Metropolitan School Study Council, a research affiliate of Teachers College, Columbia University, concluded that college entrance requirements are more of a hindrance than a help to high school programs. Dr. Paul R. Mort, council secretary, observed that in making plans for changing their curriculum, high school administrators often wonder, "How about the Regents?" and "Will the certification law permit us to do this?"
MILWAUKEE, Dec. 17 (AP) -Frank J. Murray, Marquette University's head football coach, resigned today. He will be succeeded by Lisle Blackbourn Sr., line coach.

I NEVER met the late Philip Barry, but I knew that he was a gentle man and a sincerely religious one. He had a great affection for whimsy, a deep, abiding love of laughter and a healthy respect for the gymnastics of a keen intellect.

Increased volume of container business during the last half of the year, offsetting an earlier decline, should bring the total for 1949 close to that of last year in the $8,000,000,000 packaging industry, it is concluded in an advance copy of a Department of Commerce report made available here yesterday through its regional office.

CHESTNUTS always bring to mind James Thurber's story of his granduncle who died of the chestnut blight. He was the only human being ever to do so and the only one who, to the family's embarrassment. needed the attention of a tree surgeon!
REFERENCE "Lincoln Finds a General" by Kenneth P. Williams reviewed by Douglas South-all Freeman (Book Review, Nov. 6):

BONN, Germany, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Franz Bluecher, Deputy Chancellor and Marshall Plan Minister in the West German Government, was appointed by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer today as West Germany's representative on the International Ruhr Control Authority.

The Trapp Family Singers celebrated their tenth anniversary yesterday afternoon with the first of a pair of Christmas concerts in Town Hall. A near-capacity audience applauded the annual presentation of informal music, speaking and pageantry.

IT seemed that whatever Allen did, Bailey, the new boy in the community, could do better -- including fighting. And as a final insult, Bailey had a pure-bred Hereford calf that he was raising for the 4-H contest. Allen loved calves and wanted to enter that contest in the worst way.

STUART, Fla., Dec. 18 -- Final plans for the wedding of Mayor O'Dwyer and Sloan Simpson on Tuesday were being worked out today. Though both the bridegroom and bride met reporters and photographers, they did not meet each other. Indications were that they would not meet until shortly before the ceremony, which is scheduled to begin at 8:30 A. M. at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church here.

LONDON, Dec. 18 (UP) -- The chief significance of the election of Mr. Khrushchev as a member of the secretariat of the Central Committee of the Russian All-Union Communist party apparently is that Mr. Popov has been eliminated, diplomatic quarter's in London suggested tonight.

In a rough-and-tumble contest that was marked by a riotous third period, the New York Rovers blanked the Boston Olympics, 7 to 0, in an Eastern Hockey League battle before 8,132 fans at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

SOFIA, Dec. 18 (AP) -- First scattered official returns tonight from Bulgaria's parliamentary election indicated a vote of 97 to 100 per cent for the only ticket offered, that of the Fatherland Front.

Shortly before 11 o'clock yesterday morning two warmly clad gentlemen in their mid-sixties strode briskly across Fifth Avenue into Central Park. They were on their way to preserve a tradition that began one December Sunday in 1894 when a pair of young New Yorkers skipped church for a hike in the Westchester hills.

BERLIN, Dec. 18 (AP) -- German Communists who side with Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia in his struggle with the Soviet Union formed a new party today and their leader said they would fight both East and West in the event of war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UP) -- The Federal Mediation Director, Cyrus S. Ching, said today that employers could spare themselves a lot of "labor trouble" by sending more capable representatives to the collective-bargaining table.

ALBANY, Dec. 18 -- Dr. Francis T. Spaulding, State Commissioner of Education, said today in a report to the public on "Education in New York State, 1949" that while many gains were made this year, 150,000 children still faced the possibility of substandard education because of the lack of school buildings.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- Fog, a drizzle and an outstanding lack of wind cut short the sailing dinghy racing today at the Larchmont Yacht Club. After one race, or rather a drift, it was called a day.

Town Hall was filled almost to capacity on Saturday night to hear Hindemith's song cycle "Das Marienleben." The performance by Jennie Tourel and her accompanist, Erich Itor Kahn, was of an artistic devotion and integrity beyond praise, and received a warm reception from a distinguished audience.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 18 -- Having cleared up virtually all the work he had planned to do here, President Truman spent a restful day today. His main activities were attendance at church and a swim in the Atlantic.

The only two undefeated major collegiate quintets in the metropolitan sector, City College and St. John's risk their records tonight against powerful rivals from out of the West. Nat Holman's Beavers tangle with a veteran Oklahoma University five at the Garden after the Redmen tackle tall Washington State in the opener at 8 o'clock.

Wagner's "Lohengrin" will return to the repertory of the Metropolitan Opera in the sixth week of its season, beginning Dec. 26, it was announced yesterday. Fritz Stiedry will conduct it for the first time with the company.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The American Retail Federation, claiming to speak for 500,000 retail stores, announced today it would fight any attempt to impose a general manufacturers' excise tax.

Donald Harrington, pastor of the Community Church. 40 East Thirty-fifth Street, challenged the United States Government in his sermon yesterday to espouse a "new idealism" and to offer to Russia dollar credit along with friendship and good-will.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- Short covering in December lard and the need of the actual commodity to deliver on future contracts caused a rapid advance in lard prices on the Board of Trade late last week. May and July sold at a new high for the year, while December at the top showed $1.65 a 100 pounds above the recent low.

A program of industrial and commercial cooperation between the United States and the Marshall Plan countries was outlined here last week by Dr. Werner Feilchenfeld, former president of the Export Organization for Israel and now vice president of Service for Palestine, Inc.

The Christmas mail rush has begun earlier than usual this year. Normally Sunday is a quiet day with perhaps 100 on the job in the big gray building at Thirty-third Street and Eighth Avenue. Yesterday was different. Seven hundred and sixty men and women operated chutes, filled bags and sorted packages.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 18 (UP) -- Americans for Democratic Action asserted today that James F. Byrnes and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower had joined forces with "advocates of the jungle state."
Dr. Alvin Johnson, president emeritus of the New School for Social Research, was honored on his seventy-fifth birthday in ceremonies last night at the school.

Mrs. Margaret Osborne du Pont of Wilmington, Del., heads the women's rankings of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, announced for publication today. The ratings must be passed upon at the annual meeting of the U. S. L. T. A. Jan. 21 before becoming official.

The Teachers Union announced yesterday it had sent to Maximilian Moss, president of the Board of Education, and to Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, telegrams protesting Dr. Jansen's "whitewash" of Miss May Quinn, Brooklyn public school teacher.

Two museums add to the list of holiday attractions with special exhibitions. On Wednesday the Museum of Modern Art will present an important collection of paintings, drawings, and prints by Paul Klee. The largest exhibition of Klee's work ever held in this country, it will be composed of material loaned by the Klee Foundation in Berne, Switzerland, as well as from private collections.
The Christmas spirit is "sorely needed" in New York, the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken, pastor of the Riverside Church, said yesterday in his sermon.

One of the first hearers of Handel's "Messiah" in 1742 declared it "The finest composition of Musick that was ever heard." It still remains that, as all of the 2,700 listeners must have felt who gathered at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night to hear the 126th performance of the work by the Oratorio Society of New York.
HAVANA, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Claude Harmon of Mamaroneck, N. Y., shot a 2-under-par 70 today to win individual honors in the $10,000 Havana invitational golf tournament with a 72-hole total of 271.

In the wholesale garment market here last week activity centered on last-minute calls for holiday merchandise and orders for promotion priced coats, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Although "penance and reparation are sentiments rarely linked with Christmas, expiation of sin is the lesson of Bethlehem," the Very Rev. John Shields declared yesterday in his third Advent sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
ROME, Dec. 18 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration mission in Italy swung the whole of its authority today behind a wide agricultural reform to make land available to the peasants.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 Spokesmen for labor and management in ten industries will meet in Washington on Jan. 17 to plan to meet problems created by what they consider government policies that will lead to increasingly heavy competition from abroad.

Partisans and unbiased observers who have been insisting all along that the Dodgers have the best first baseman, the best shortsop, the best catcher and the best young pitcher will find confirmation of their views in the official National League fielding averages, released today.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 18 -- The greatest long-range problem of the Netherlands is, as jovial Foreign Minister Dirk U. Stikker puts it, one of optimism. There are too many babies. The population is growing too fast.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The National Labor Relations Board, in a ruling made public today, held that a labor union's threat to strike to force an individual employe to take part in the organization's activities violated the Taft-Hartley Labor Law.

The Ministerial Steering Committee of the European Marshall Plan Council meets in Paris tomorrow to ponder Mr. Hoffman's "considered request" that it work out a program for European economic integration as a step toward a long-range solution of Europe's economic problems and to assure continued Marshall Plan aid.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 18 -- The new Australian Cabinet was announced by Prime Minister-Elect Robert Gordon Menzies tonight, with fourteen, portfolios going to the Liberals and five to members of the Country party which ran with the Liberals to defeat Labor in the general elections.
Packages placed under Christmas trees will be at their gayest and gaudiest this year if gift wrappings being shown in stores are any indication.

Enzo Mascherini sang his first Rigoletto at the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday night and drew prolonged cheers from his admirers. The Italian baritone, who is 32 years old, made his debut with the company as Marcello in "La Boheme" ten days ago.

ALBANY, Dec. 18 -- Senator Thomas C. Desmond, Newburgh Republican, announced today he would introduce in the Legislature next month a bill aimed at "racketeering door-to-door vendors who are preying on housewives."

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- Grain markets continued to edge slowly upward on the Board of Trade last week, December and March wheat and March and May corn sold at new high prices for the year, with a lack of hedging pressure a factor, especially in wheat.

TOKYO, Dec. 18 -- Although business men are complaining about tight money, falling share prices, missed payrolls and mounting receivables and although the traditional year-end settlements promise to be settlements in name only, there is a strong undercurrent of hope for Japan's economic future.

HONG KONG, Dec. 18 -- Officially approved Soviet theories of heredity are to form the basis for teaching in the schools of Communist China, it was revealed in a recent issue of the Communist-controlled Shanghai daily, Ta Kung Pao.

MARGHANITA LASKI, who is probably tired of being introduced as the niece of her famous Uncle Harold, is a writer, too. But instead of writing ponderously of politics and enthusiastically of socialism she writes fiction. Miss Laski may share her uncle's opinions. Her "Toasted English," a satirical fantasy mocking the Conservatives, lends credence to such a sup position.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 18 -- Richard Todd, English actor who played the leading role in Warner Brothers' "The Hasty Heart," a British film, will make his American debut for Warners in "Lightning Strikes Twice," which Henry Blanke will produce and King Vidor will direct, starting early next year.
The Orchard Street area was more congested yesterday than usual in what the police called the heaviest shopping spree on the lower East Side in ten years.

BIG POCONO, Pa., Dec. 18 -- While not possessing the rugged mountains of New York State and New England, Pennsylvania, nevertheless, will match in ski enthusiasm any of its more northern neighbors. Starting less than ninety miles from New York City, this popular 400 mile square winter sports, playground has virtually everything to offer the ice and snow devotee.

ZURICH, Dec. 18 -- Through the growing influence of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation in liberalizing intra-European trade, the threat of another deadlock due to sterling devaluation has been averted. Anglo-Swiss deliberations in London about the exact meaning of the trade agreement of March 12, 1946, have ended in an arrangement accepted by both sides as workable until a new agreement can be drafted next month.
The New York Americans of the American Soccer League eliminated the Swedish Football Club of the National League, 5 -- 0, in a National Challenge Cup match at Sterling Oval, the Bronx, yesterday.
History will turn backward in a few days for New York's Liberty Bell, which has been rung at every triumph for freedom since colonial days.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 18 -- With the announcement of the Mexican Government's record-breaking 1950 budget, a backward look over the year shows that currency devaluation brought a remarkable recovery in foreign trade and the whole national economy. [The peso was pegged at 8.65 to the dollar in June.]

Take a breather from your busy shopping hours and look at the patterns illustrated here. They offer thought of quieter post-holiday hours. Here are dresses with many purposes, for their fabric interpretation will decide the uses to which you can put them.

The state executive committee of the American Labor party has adopted a resolution declaring that Jerusalem belongs to the State of Israel and calling upon the Security Council of the United Nations to reopen the question with a view to recognizing Israeli administration of the city.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations tomorrow opens its long-heralded "purge trials" of ten unions accused of hewing too closely to the Communist party line.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 18 (AP) -- All-star college players went through their first workouts today in preparation for the annual North-South Shrine football game in the Orange Bowl Dec. 26.

In the ten years they have been in this country, the South African baritone, Josef Marais, and his partner, Miranda, have developed a following, and at their recital last night at Town Hall 1,200 persons turned out to hear them and to call for favorite numbers when the program ended.

One healthy citizen of this city may attack Christmas dinner with little of the appetite this feast deserves. She is Mrs. Frances Foley Gannon, head of the Department of Markets' division of consumers' service and research, who already has eaten three Christmas meals.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- While the storage of water in many public reservoirs within 75 to 100 miles of New York City is far below the customary reserve at this season of the year, there is one reservoir, forty-two miles from New York, that is filled to overflowing.

The Department of Agriculture, through the Commodity Credit Corporation, is seeking offers for the fumigation of 11,500,000 bushels of surplus wheat, stored aboard forty-six Liberty-ships anchored in the Hudson River off Jones Point, N. Y.

The State Department's strong warning to American shipping to stay out of Shanghai is both a skilled political move in a delicate situation and a display of good common sense. The Department had previously called attention to the dangerous condition of those waters and had suggested thatships entering them did so at their own risk.

Direct wage losses by industrial employes in strikes since 1937 have amounted to $3,000,000,000, according to a study made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board. About 25,00,000 wage-earners shared the loss.
The shortage of teachers that has plagued New York's public elementary schools for the last ten years is virtually ended -- at least for a while.

GRANVILLE, Ohio, Dec. 18 -- Denison University, a liberal arts college with a student body of about 1,300 men and women, today explained a new program under which business concerns are asked to take an important part in the school's educational activities.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 18 -- The Harvard Crimson, under-graduate newspaper, says in an editorial that Harvard "can help American higher education to save its vitality" by demanding that the Navy exempt Naval Reserve Officers Training Corps students from the present loyalty tests.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Eagles marched through the mud and sailed through the air today to crush the Los Angeles Rams, 14 to 0, and win the National Football League Championship for the second straight year.
ROME, Dec. 18 -- The Pope said today that he would attempt to be as firm and fearless as his predecessor, Pius XI, in fighting those who sought to destroy the Roman Catholic faith.
Two young Canadian women who left Winnipeg two and a half years ago to work their way around the world arrived here yesterday from Southampton to begin the last lap of their trip.

The New York City Dance Theatre had itself a busy week-end at the City Center with three performances, some of them good, some of them not so good, and a number of novelties. Last night's was far and away the best even of the three, and contained the outstanding novelty in the form of Hanya Holm's "Ozark Suite."

VIENNA, Dec. 18 -- The Communist regimes of the Iron Curtain countries are beginning to copy the Nazi burners of books in their eagerness to comply with Moscow's recent order that "cos mopolitanism" must be rooted out wherever the Red flag flies.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 18 -- What he described as "a remarkably sustained enrollment" in the academic training of World War II veterans was cited here today by Dr. Raymond Walters, president of the University of Cincinnati, in his thirtieth annual survey of college and university enrollments.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- To the surprise and disappointment of financial London, the result of the Australian election failed to arouse any noticeable enthusiasm in the stock markets last week. For this seeming lack of interest, the explanation lies largely in the influence of year-end liquidation not already completed; consideration of the poor showing of national savings and the increasing competition of issues for new capital.

Human hopes to effectuate a utopian society based on science and reason were pictured as illusory by the Very Rev. Dr. Hughell E. W, Fosbroke, dean-emeritus of the General Theological Seminary, in a sermon yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

There are few things more filled with tradition, sentiment -- and inflammable pitch -- than Christmas trees. Few seasons of the year eclipse the Yuletide in the cornucopia of gifts, joys and harvests of a grimmer sort. This week the Fire Department issued its annual Christmas warning on fire hazards.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Chinese Communist press declared today that Mao Tze-tung's current mission to Moscow "spells disaster to the imperialist warmongers."

BOMBAY, India, Dec. 18 -- The Maharajah, or Gaekwar, of Baroda, who once was accused of squandering $10,000,000 in a six weeks' spending spree, is having trouble with his 250 servants. They have been on strike twenty-three days to enforce demands for recognition of their union and higher wages.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 18 (UP) -- A reporter for The San Francisco Chronicle, seeking first-hand information about New York's bathless Friday, telephoned the information desk at Grand Central Terminal last night.

Carols and the pleasant din of parties echoed through hotels, hospitals and homes yesterday as New Yorkers gave themselves wholeheartedly to the season to be jolly. Thousands of goody-stuffed youngsters, emerging from a chaos of candy canes and tissue paper, stickily clutched new toys provided by adults who had as much fun as their small guests did.
GENEVA, Dec. 18 -- Despite bitter winter weather and the increased vigilance of frontier controls, refugees from behind the Iron Curtain are pouring into Western Europe at a rate of 2,500 a month.

HONG KONG, Dec. 18 -- A complicating factor was injected into the Chinese airline snarl here today with the announcement by Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault and Whiting Willauer that they had purchased the Nationalist Government's interests in the China National Aviation Corporation and the Central Air Transport Corporation.

" The Bicycle Thief," the Italian-made drama set in post-war Rome produced and directed by Vittorio De Sica and released here by Mayer-Burstyn, which had its American premiere at the World Theatre on Dec. 12, has been voted the picture of the year in the twenty-fourth annual poll conducted by the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures, it was announced yesterday.

Christmas carols and Negro spirituals rang out from the carillon of St. Martin's Protestant Episcopal Church, Lenox Avenue and 122d Street, after dedication of the new bells yesterday afternoon by Bishop Charles K. Gilbert of the Diocese of New York.

Another link in the state parkway system on Long Island will be opened without fanfare today. The new road, which cost $3,000,000, extends Northern State Parkway for four and one-half miles from Plainview Road in Nassau County to the Amityville - Huntington Highway (Retire 110) at Melville in Suffolk County.

Pressure on the Canadian dollar lifted last week when oil companies re-entered the market and United States postal authorities bought their monthly quota resulting in a climb from 87.38 cents, on Monday, which incidentally is a new low since devaluation, to 88.62 cents, on Friday. The close was 88 cents, a gain of 5/16 cent over the previous week:
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 18 (UP) -A-/Agroup of Ku Klux Klan! leade/ said today after a meetiflg here that they wo/fid act as "the g0verning bodY" of the national Klan :organization.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Democratic party announced today that it planned two reports to the country on the work of the Eighty-first Congress -- the first dealing with what had been accomplished and the second with what still remained to be done.

Plans for the establishment of an information and advisory unit to assist foreign motion-picture producers have been approved by the Motion Picture Association of America, it was announced by John G. McCarthy, vice president in charge of international affairs.

Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, arrived here by plane from Ireland yesterday prepared to head his union's delegation at this morning's meeting with the Board of Transportation. Plans for the conference, arranged by Mayor O'Dwyer ten days ago, put off at least temporarily the threat of a slowdown on the city's subway lines.

At this moment the United States has a draft act which it isn't using. This measure, approved June 24, 1948, expires June 24, 1950. Why not drop it? Defense Secretary Louis Johnson, who has just asked the President and the Budget Bureau to endorse a three-year extension, explains why not.

The five lawyers who defended the eleven top Communist leaders at their recent trial were honored last night at a dinner given by the Civil Rights Congress of New York State at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- The prediction that in the next few years there are likely to be "several categories of warships of revolutionary type" was made today in the 1949-50 edition of Jane's Fighting Ships, British naval annual.

AMSTERDAM, Dec. 18 -- Financial circles in the Netherlands reject strongly the British accusation that Holland is mainly responsible for renewed pressure on the pound sterling. They admit, however, that Dutch traders are using existing loopholes for dealing in transferable sterling.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UP) -- Soft-coal supplies are slightly below normal but the nation "is a long way from a shortage," Federal labor experts reported today on the basis of Government and coal industry figures.

Cotton prices held to a narrow range during most of last week, with domestic market quotations decidedly firmer at the close. Active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange at the close last Saturday showed net gains for the week of 27 to 49 points.

Norman Secon, who appeared as a pianist at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon, displayed a commendable imagination in program making. Instead of warming up with the usual Busoni transcription of Bach, he gave us a Buxtehude prelude and fugue transcribed by Prokofieff -- and a very beautiful piece it turned out to be.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson has asked George F. Kennan, Counselor of the State Department, to spend most of the next six months reviewing United States foreign policy in Latin America and Africa, it was learned tonight.
A Christmas present in the form of reduced rents for veterans and their families in four public housing projects was announced yesterday.

WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 18 -- Champion Snow Boy of Fircot, 4 1/2-year-old white imported miniature poodle from the Blakeen Kennels of Stamford, Conn., went to best in show tonight in the Worcester County Kennel Club competition.
MADRID, Dec. 18 -- Increasing resentment in official circles over the United Nations refusal to change its stand on Spain is evident here.

The report of the American Civil Liberties Union on the Peekskill riot, on which you comment in your issue of Dec. 10, raises an interesting question as to the position of that respected organization.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- a four-engine Constellation of the Trans World Airline, landing at 8 o'clock this morning at Chicago Midway Airport after a nonstop flight from San Francisco, rolled off the end of the runway to crash through a wire fence, knock down two poles and hit a cafe building. None of the twenty-six on board was hurt.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 18 -- The main topic here late last week was the increases in the prices of steel. The increases had been expected in the trade. The changes in extras were indicated here two weeks ago.

A twenty-one-month agreement was concluded yesterday between 300 New York commercial printing companies and 4,500 workers that provides for no wage increase but sets up a contribution by employers of 1 1/2 per cent of earnings of union members to be paid into a pension fund.
TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- This Hudson River community decked itself with wreaths and holly today and played Santa Claus to 150 children of United Nations families.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 18 -- Deck officers of the American Merchant Marine today joined a campaign for a new system of figuring tolls at the Panama Canal.

ROME, Dec. 18 -- The Communist newspaper Unita this morning for the first time acknowledged the presence of Titoist ideas among the Communist rank-and-file by announcing the expulsion of a comrade guilty of "going over to the Titoist traitors."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UP) -- One local transit dispute was settled today but another threatened to force thousands of Government workers to walk the last leg of their daily trips to work.
One of the more moving among this year's beneficiaries of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund is No. 111, to judge by yesterday's response in the thirty-eighth annual appeal.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Dec. 18 -- The Bergen County Vocational School, known to its 750 apprentice students as "the big red schoolhouse," has been under construction for nearly two years and isn't completed yet.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Dec. 18 -- The American steel industry's shortage of manganese may be solved in Ungava, the wilderness of Northern Labrador and Quebec. For a large deposit of rich manganese ore has just been discovered adjacent to the rich iron ore bodies on the 14,000 square-mile concessions being explored by the Labrador Mining and Exploration Company.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 -- A general Christmas amnesty for men who served prison terms as conscientious objectors to military service in World War II was proposed to President Truman today in a letter signed by seventy persons, many of them eminent educators, clergymen, authors and scientists.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- State Department officials disclosed today that the United States soon would start training "important" Japanese diplomats as part of a policy of speeding the read- mission of Japan into the family of nations.

BOSTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Boston's last-place Bruins maintained their "hex" over the National Hockey League's second-place Canadiens tonight, defeating the Montreal club, 3 -- 1, as Sambo Bettio scored his first major league goal. A crowd of 10,742 Garden fans sat in in the rough proceedings in which three players suffered head bounds.

One hundred years ago today, in the coke-belt town of West Overton, Pa., a boy was born who announced at the age of 16 that he would "make more money than Grandpa Overholt," his maternal grandfather, whose modest fortune had come from the manufacture of "flour and Youghiogheny whiskey."
Citations for meritorious service were awarded yesterday to 177 members of the Police Department by Commissioner William P. O'Brien.

Mild weather and the Sunday holiday brought thousands of suburban motorists into the city yesterday for a look at the giant Christmas tree in Rockefeller Plaza. The result was one of the worst Fifth Avenue traffic jams in recent years.

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- French foreign commerce officials are making a strong bid for Far Eastern and Pacific markets. Exports are being pushed, particularly in the direction of India, Pakistan and Australia, although markets in Malaya, Burma, Ceylon, New Zealand and Japan also are slated for more thorough solicitation.

We are a mercenary people, our critics say. We pour out billions of American dollars trying to buy peace by investing in world prosperity and security. Our critics think we cannot do it; we believe we can. We believe one great contribution Americans can offer a world looking to us for leadership is our genius in demonstrating how much good dollars can accomplish.

The city's water storage reservoirs lost an additional 235,000,000 gallons of the precious fluid in the 24-hour period ended at 8 A. M. yesterday, leaving only 34.8 per cent of total capacity. Announcement of the drop was made a few hours before word came from Albany that Governor Dewey would discuss the city's critical water shortage this afternoon at a meeting there with the members and engineers of the State Water Power and Control Commission.
Fourteen new films comprise the holiday attractions arriving in first-run theatres this week and on Christmas Day. The programs follow:

TEL AVIV, Dec. 18 -- Israel's national airlines, El A1, today inaugurated weekly scheduled flights to Paris, Zurich and London with stops in Rome. Communications Minister David Remez said the service would be extended to the United States when additional aircraft were obtained.

ROME, Dec. 13 -- The foreign pilgrim who visits Rome during the Holy Year will find that both the Vatican and the Italian Government have taken measures designed to assist and guide him throughout his stay in Italy.

ALBANY, Dec. 18 -- Appointment of Dr. Ernest M. Gruenberg of the Yale University School of Medicine as executive secretary of the New York State Mental Health Commission was announced today by Dr. Frederick MacCurdy, State Commissioner of Mental Hygiene and chairman of the commission.

Four American journalists have received $5,000 fellowships for travel and study abroad next year from the Reid Foundation, established by the late Ogden Reid, editor of The New York Herald Tribune, it was announced yesterday.

Members of the State Water Power and Control Commission, reporting to Governor Dewey in Albany today, may be able to suggest new ways and means for meeting the current water crisis. Let us hope so. Meanwhile this city must face the future.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Eddie Lebaron, T-quarterback wizard of the College of the Pacific, will play with the Yankee squad in the Senior Bowl game here Jan. 7.
TOKYO, Dec. 18 -- Occupation authorities, who are disturbed by rumors, have clarified their plans for Japanese currency.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Dec. 18 -- Mrs. Wantha Davis, girl rider from the Western Plains country, defeated Johnny Longden today in their big betless match race, shading America's top jockey by a length and three quarters over the six-furlong distance.
CHICAGO, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Sales and net earnings of Swift Co., the nation's largest meat packer, were slightly lower in the 1949 fiscal year than in the preceding year, the company reported today.

In the pamphlet entitled "The Water Supply of the City of New York," issued by the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, and dated July, 1947, the following paragraph follows a general description of the meter rates and flat or frontage rates from which the major portion of the water revenues are derived:

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 18 -- Unexpectedly the United Nations Trusteeship Council canceled today its morning session set for 11 A. M. tomorrow, thus giving the twelve member nations a few more hours in which to crystallize their viewpoints on the Jerusalem issue.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- New obstacles lie before Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, and his assistants in their task of convincing Congress that the Marshall Plan is assisting the economic integration of Europe. There are ample signs that hope of ending the system of dual pricing, which is a euphemism for "gouging" one's neighbor, is about to be frustrated by the British who are subsidizing domestic coal prices at the expense of Continental buyers.

" The Strange Land," a novel by- Ned Calmer, will be issued by Scribner's on Feb. 6. It is a story dealing with twelve Americans who are involved in an offensive against the Siegfried Line, from the general in Paris to those on the front line.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18 -- A check for $3,000,000 as an advance contribution of the Jewish community here to the 1950 campaign of the United Jewish Appeal was presented this afternoon to Berl Locker of Jerusalem, chairman of the Jewish Agency for Palestine.

Regarding Dr. Sukarno, sworn in at Jogjakarta on Saturday as the first President of the Republic of Indonesia, The Associated Press has reported that "he likes to quote from Lincoln and Washington and to compare Indonesia's struggle for freedom with the American Revolution."
" Currency devaluation," observes R. C. Leffingwell in the January issue of Foreign Affairs, "is a symptom of a disease; it is not a cure."

TOKYO, Dec. 11 -- Japanese business circles, both through the Government of Premier Shigeru Yoshida and by independent efforts, increasingly are urging upon Allied headquarters the "advantages" of much enlarged trade between Japan and Communist China
Sites in the Horace Harding Boulevard area of Queens have been purchased by builders for improvement with taxpayers, according to John D. Connaughton, broker, who reported four deals in the section.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- One of the primary causes of today's water troubles in New York and other areas in the East is the pollution of surface water supplies by municipalities and industries, William Voigt Jr., executive director of the Izaak Walton League of America, declared here today.

MOSCOW. Dec. 18 -- Announcement was made today of the release of Nikita-Khrushchev, Politburo member, from his duties as Communist party secretary in the Ukraine and his election as a secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist party and first secretary of the Moscow Regional Committee of the party.

FLINT, Mich., Dec. 18 -- A new, advanced, high-compression engine designed to take advantage of the latest type of higher octane fuels recently made available by the petroleum industry will be offered on all Super Series models in the 1950 Buick line of cars. Ivan L. Wiles, general manager, Buick Division, and vice president of the General Motors Corporation, said today.
For some reason not clear to him, says the Old New Yorker who reaches for his snuff box instead of a cigarette, the region just west of Madison Square is ignored by our guidebook writers.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, Dec. 18 -- The Westinghouse Electric Appliance Division will introduce three new appliances for 1950: (1) the first fully automatic frost-free household refrigerator, (2) an electric range radically new in design, and (3) a new front-opening top- loading fully automatic dishwasher.

The enthronement of Archbishop Michael as head of the Greek Orthodox Church of North and South America took place yesterday afternoon at the Greek Cathedral, 319 East Seventy-fourth Street. He succeeded Athenagoras I, who became Patriarch of the Greek Orthodox Church last January in Istanbul after an eighteen-year tenure as its head in the Western Hemisphere.
Revenues of the city's Department of Marine and Aviation have reached a new high this year at $10,682,907, according to a report issued for publication today by Commissioner G. Joseph Minetti.

The writer of your editorial entitled "How Wilmington Does It" cannot have been aware of the background in the labor dispute between the Delaware Coach Company and Local 842 of the Amalgamated Association of Street, Electric Railway and Motor Coach Employes of America, AFL.

THE strength of a baseball club, they say, is down the middle -- meaning the batteries, the center fielder and the two fellows in between, the combination of the second baseman and the shortstop. If the New York Giants have done nothing else they have provided themselves With two guys in the vicinity of second who can make the double play, Eddie Stanky and Alvin Dark.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- The fate of Westchester County's pioneer cost-of-living bonus plan, which calls for a sliding scale of income for 2,600 employes, is at stake in a discussion that is growing in intensity.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Earle (Greasy) Neale, Eagle coach, who's been around a long time, said:
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 18 (UP) -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley urged Americans today to give maximum aid to Israel because it might become "a vital influence in the peace of the world."

Continuing its campaign to save water during the city's critical shortage, the Board of Education will make water conservation a definite part of classroom study and community effort in all parts of the public school system, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- Needham, Louis Brorby of Chicago has resigned the Pepsodent tooth powder and Rayve shampoo accounts of the Pepsodent division of Lever Brothers Company because of the impracticability of servicing the accounts from Chicago after the Pepsodent division moves from here to the Lever Brothers headquarters in New York on Jan. 3, it was announced today by Henry T. Woulfe, president of the Pepsodent division.

The annual Christmas message of the Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, was issued here yesterday by the National Council of the Church, 281 Fourth Avenue.

A new full-hour variety radio show entitled "The Show Goes On," featuring Robert Q. Lewis as master of ceremonies, will make its debut over the Columbia Broadcasting System network on Friday, Jan. 6, at 9:30 P. M.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 18 -- Marshall Tito and his principal Ministers are scheduled to make important statements on foreign and domestic policies during the course of the next session of Parliament, which will convene on Dec. 26.

Still exercising their spell over the New York Rangers, the Toronto Maple Leafs scored a 2-to-0 victory over the Blue Shirts at Madison Square Garden last night. With Turk Broda turning in a sensational performance in the nets, the Leafs extended their sway over the New Yorkers, who have yet to beat them in the current National Hockey League race.

The Moller Steamship Company, Inc., Operator of the Danish-flag Maersk Line, has increased its cargo-passenger service with the addition of two new runs to the Far East, Thorkil Host, president, announced yesterday. One of these will operate from Canadian ports and the other from Gulf ports in the United State.
HAMBURG, Germany, Dec. 18 (AP) -- A German shipyard director said today he was building a whaling fleet for a United States ship-owner.
The Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, in a "farewell" sermon yesterday pleaded for "sufficient and loyal support" for his successor.

Making large - type headline claims in advertising conform with small-type qualifications is urged on makers of antihistamine cold-treatment preparations as a major means of avoiding false impressions in such advertising.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 18 -- The award of seventy-six post- graduate and post-doctoral fellowships to forty-seven universities for the 1950-51 academic year was announced today by the Du Pont Company. An authorization of $224,000 was provided for the awards.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 18 -- West Germany is trying to get around the agreement between the Bonn Government and the Western occupying powers limiting the Germans to building cargo vessels with speeds of less than twelve knots, reports received in Stockholm diplomatic circles indicate.

Henry Goelet, operator, who took title to the two-story taxpayer building at 151-53 West 125th Street last summer, has resold it to Louis Denberg, according to an announcement made over the week-end by L. V. Hoffman Co., brokers.
PARIS, Dec. 18 -- France's battle of the budget, which has lasted for three weeks in committee, was to be resumed upon a full scale before the National Assembly Monday morning.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- Efforts were begun in London last week to liberalize and expand trade between Western Germany and the sterling area and to eliminate Britain's persistent deficit with the Western German Federal Republic. Trade and financial talks will continue in the New Year.

Rumors of imminent Government purchases of raw rubber for stockpiling jolted the rubber futures market here out of a three-day price decline on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. Prices advanced 25 to 60 points on the day.

In an editorial on freedom and labor THE NEW YORK TIMES asserts that the right to work is an accepted principle in liberal democratic countries. I beg to differ. We do not have a constitutional or legal right to work. To have a right one has a claim against somebody in the event that the "right" is violated.
CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Health Minister Sir Earle Page indicated today that one of the first measures of Australia's new government may be to implement a national health program.
SAIGON, Indo-China, Dec, 19 (Reuters) -- The Viet Nam Government of former Emperor Bao Dai of Annam will, on Dec. 30, formally take over power in French Indo-China.
ROME, Dec. 19 -- Myron C. Taylor, special representative of President Truman to the Vatican, is expected to resign on his return to the United States within the next few weeks, it was learned today.

The Maritime Commission reserved decision yesterday after hearing oral arguments in Washington on three complaints brought against steamship conference groups in the North Atlantic, a spokesman for the commission here announced.

A gathering of baseball players, executives and critics yesterday placed the stamp of approval on the motion pictures of the 1949 world series at a preview in Toots Shor's Restaurant, under the auspices of the American and National Leagues Motion Picture Division.

The program to get some sort of rational arms standardizing agreement among the United States, Canada and the United Kingdom has been called "the world's worst-kept military secret." The reason, perhaps, for the transparent veil is that this procedure is so logical that no one would be able to understand just why it was not being done. It is manifestly necessary, eminently sensible.
Despite the poor hunting conditions which prevailed during a good part of the fall, the New York deer kill set a new record on antlered deer, with 19,030 taken in the open season.

A 21-year-old man was arrested yesterday on charges of grand larceny, driving while intoxicated, leaving the scene of an accident and driving without a chauffeur's license after a truck he was driving, the police said, struck two automobiles and injured three policemen.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 19 -- This country "has not abandoned and will not abandon China or the other countries of Asia and the Far East," Philip C. Jessup, Ambassador-at-large, asserted today at a luncheon meeting here, held under the auspices of the World Affairs Council and the American Association for the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Protests from the Cotton Belt threatened today to intensify public disagreement between Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan and Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat, of New Mexico.
CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- Four railroad brotherhoods that voted a walkout against the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad in August canceled the vote today.
A full program has been prepared for the Senate subcommittee on the merchant marine for its investigation of the country's merchant fleet when Congress reconvenes next month.

STRASBOURG, France, Dec. 19 -- The General Affairs, or Political, Committee of the Council of Europe convened at the City Hall here today to begin work on a blueprint for the future structure of Western Europe.

There is no possibility of a decline in the basic cost of Scotch whisky in the "foreseeable" future, Harry L. Lourie, executive vice president of the National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers. Inc., declared yesterday.

"Disaster Through Air Power," by Marshall Andrews, an attack on the Air Force's reliance on the B-36, will be published on Jan. 23 by Rinehart. The author, a former major of infantry who now is military editor of The Washington Post, discusses the Department of Defense's attitude toward criticism and the "unvoiced" views of those who disagree with the theories of air radicals.

Gilbert A. Bogley of Chevy Chase, Md., tops the 1949 junior singles ranking recommendations of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, it was announced yesterday by the ranking committee. Approval of the junior rating as well as those for boys, girls and veterans will be officially submitted at the annual meeting of the organization in New York, Jan. 21.
A motion by Judith Coplon and Valentine A. Gubitchev, to dismiss the conspiracy count in their indictment on charges of espionage, was denied yesterday by Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Dec. 19 -- The commander of the Syrian Army, Brig. Gen. Sami Hinnawi, and some of his associates were arrested just after 6 o'clock this morning by troops who entered Damascus and surrounded his residence and several strategic points.

When it comes to telling children the truth about Santa Claus, better than a third of America's parents -- too tender-hearted to give out with the harsh facts -- would rather wait till the youngsters find out for themselves. Mothers and fathers who may have suspected this, judging by their own reluctance to break the news, received yesterday at a luncheon at Hampshire House statistical evidence that they were not alone in their indecision.

Unless American taxpayers wish to support Europe on a dole permanently we must import more European goods, lower our import tariffs and cut our prices on exports, Clinton S. Golden, labor adviser to the Economic Cooperation Administration, declared last night.
A strange story of a partly crippled woman who was "kidnapped" in an automobile by a man who did not know she was there was unfolded in Brooklyn yesterday.
PROVIDENCE, Dec. 19 -- The average subscriber to telephone service in Rhode Island will find a 25-cent increase in his bill next month and in future months.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Former Federal Judge Charles I. Dawson of Louisville, Ky., today sought a court order that would force John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, to allow him his place as trustee for the coal operators on the miners' welfare fund board.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- United States Ambassadors to other American republics will meet for policy conferences at Havana and Rio de Janeiro within the next several weeks, the State Department announced today.

Deposits in New York State savings banks rose $64,067,000 in November, against $43,138,000 in November, 1948, Perrin L. Babcock, president of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York, announced yesterday. The increase, he pointed out, maintained the trend which had continued for more than a year.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 19 (UP) -- Defying a veiled United States threat to curtail diplomatic relations, Bulgaria today rejected a State Department protest against the mention of the name of Donald Read Heath, United States Minister in Sofia, in the trial of former Bulgarian Deputy Premier Traicho Kostov.
LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Business generally was slow in the stock markets here today with price movements aimless. The undertone, however, remained firm.
ALBANY, Dec. 19 -- Governor Dewey indicated today that he did not intend to recommend any increase in the $25,000-a-year salary paid to the Governor by the state.
The steel price increase was the occasion for a demand by Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney for an investigation of United States Steel so that other companies may be deterred from raising prices.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- United States oil company representatives in Britain were perturbed and incensed today by what they termed the unilateral and arbitrary action of the British Government in ordering a drastic cut in British purchases of dollar oil.

Since the International Class sloops, leading racing group on Long Island Sound, were brought out in 1937, mere men skippers have governed their operations. It was different last night at the class bi-annual dinner meeting, in the New York Yacht Club.

STUART, Fla., Dec. 19 -- On the eve of his wedding, Mayor O'Dwyer today held a roadside press conference under a palm tree off of United States Highway No. 1, thirteen miles south of Stuart, and announced that he was "in a joyous and happy mood."
Lack of design talent in the mass dress market has been one of the principal reasons for poor business under highly competitive conditions, it was asserted yesterday by Tobe, fashion consultant.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was barely steady yesterday and prices declined 4 to 11 points.
At the Christmas season two years ago President Truman granted individual pardons to 1,523 conscientious objectors. This actually affected less than one quarter of the C. O.'s denied civil rights.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 19 (AP) -- The sensational riding of Apprentice Joe Culmone, 18-year-old native of Sicily, thrilled a crowd of 6,783 today as the meeting entered its third full week of competition.

A weekly series of radio concerts devoted to true American orchestral music, conducted by Dr. Karl Krueger, will be carried by the American Broadcasting Company on Tuesday evenings from 10 to 11 o'clock, beginning Feb. 7. For the experimental venture into the moods of American symphonic music, Dr. Krueger is integrating a new group to be known as the American Arts Orchestra, which for the first year will be held to thirty-five musicians.

The suggestion that public assistance budgets be more "realistic" and include a modest allowance for incidental needs was made yesterday by Alexander F. Handel, dean of the recently established Adelphi College Graduate School of Social Work.

Happiness, like the will-o'-the-wisp, we are never sure of, and most often find it where we least expect it. Alexandre Dumas seemed to have that in mind when he said, "We enjoy thoroughly only the pleasure that we give." Doubtless he was not thinking of sums of money, but happiness is tied up in the act of giving even small sums where they are needed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Treasury announced that the tenders for $900,000,000, or thereabouts, of ninety-one day Treasury bills to be dated Dec. 22, 1949, and to mature on March 23, 1950, which were offered on Dec. 16, last, were opened at the Federal Reserve Banks today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- A football player's suit for $4,100, seeking a test of the vital pro contract reserve clause, went to trial today in Federal Court after a directed verdict was denied.

A pair of rare portraits, painted in New York nearly 250 years ago, were recently presented to the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street, and will be exhibited tomorrow in the institution's entrance hall.

PARIS, Dec. 19 -- France's budget for 1950 was blocked again in the National Assembly today when the Finance Committee refused to re-examine it until after it had received definite proposals from the Government for correcting the deficit.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 19 -- As he packed tonight to go home tomorrow, President Truman looked back with satisfaction on three weeks of work, play, swimming and acquiring a tan -- and on one important neglect. He has done no Christmas shopping.
PIKESVILLE, Ky., Dec. 19 (UP) -- Coal miners in several Kentucky pits went back on a five-day week today following signing of union contracts during the week-end.

LONDON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The three nations, which form the core of the North Atlantic Pact, possess most of the military productive resources of the non-Communist world. Officials said that the decision to go ahead with a program of dovetailing their arms, equipment and training marked the At lantic Pact's biggest practical step forward.

The announcement that George F. Kennan, State Department Counselor, and Assistant Secretary of State Edward G. Miller Jr., who is in charge of Latin-American affairs, are going to make extended trips to our southern neighbors and will also be meeting United States Ambassadors in two regional conferences is a reminder of obligations and interest that are sometimes forgotten.

RICHARD CUMMINGS WAKEFIELD is the newest member of the New York Yankees, landing on the Stadium roster over the week-end in a straight player swap for Dick Kryhoski. But there is no sense in waiting until next April to meet the man. Introductions will be made immediately so that Yankee fans will know a little something about him. After all, this is the most intriguing and fascinating trade that has been made to date.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 19 -- Increasing popularity of wine has lifted average monthly consumption in the United States to more than 10,000,000 gallons, according to Part III of the thirteenth annual Wine Industry Statistical Survey, prepared by the wine industry for the wine advisory board.
Not long ago Peck Peck commissioned Carolyn Schnurer, one of the leading sportswear designers, to set out for Greece in search of fresh inspiration for a collection of resort fashions.

A six-point program for businessmen to combat the powerful forces in Washington, "which are driving ahead to socialize incomes and to displace our free market economy with administrative directives, edicts and controls," was advocated last night by Emerson P. Schmidt, economic director of the United States Chamber of Commerce.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The American Council of Education made public today its list of ten principles which it holds should prevail in the proposed Federal program of scholarships and fellowships.

The Temporary City Housing Rent Commission revoked yesterday an order of October, 1948, granting a 28 per cent increase in rents to the Albert Hotel, 65 University Place. The commission directed that refunds totaling $30,000 be made to 150 tenants.

A full-scale 196-day program is again on tap for New York race-goers in 1950, according to the schedule released by the State Racing Commission yesterday. As usual, the long season, the legal limit by the way, finds the opening at Jamaica on April 1.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 19 -- The six permanent members of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, the Big Five plus Canada, will receive new proposals for atomic control from Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, president of the Assembly, and Sir Benegal Rau, delegate of India, tomorrow morning.

A new collection of intricately veneered Swedish furniture that has a formal air of elegance, yet, in scale and multi-purpose use is admirably adapted to the limited space characteristic of rooms of today, was presented yesterday by Swedish Modern, 675 Fifth Avenue.

TOKYO, Dec. 19 -- The conservative Japanese Government moved today to solve a dangerous labor situation by submitting to the Diet a bill providing for payment of the traditional year-end bonuses to almost 1,000,000 public workers.

TRENTON, Dec. 20 -- A harmony caucus of the twenty-two Democratic assembly members-elect here this afternoon chose T. James Tumulty, of the Hudson delegation, to be minority floor leader in the 1950 session of the New Jersey Legislature.
BUFFALO, N. Y., Dec. 19 (AP) -- A strike of tug crews today left seventy grain ships in Buffalo harbor waiting to unload.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told the American Society of Foresters today that New York needed a few women to manage its water supply.
On the eve of her concert debut in this city, Margaret Truman made an open book yesterday of not one but two love affairs.

Traditional decorations formed a holiday decor for the annual Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball held last night in the Grand Ballroom and adjoining foyers, of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the New York Infirmary. One hundred and twenty young women, debutantes of this season, had subscribed to the ball, many of them making their formal debuts.
ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 19 -- Cornell came within 4 points of its all-time record high score in defeating Rutgers, 78 -- 46, in basketball tonight.

The steady decline in customs receipts at this port was reversed in November, and Collector Harry M. Durning's monthly report-showed an increase of $1,172,975 over the comparable period of last year. Total receipts were $20,044,906.

The Red Cross "Christmas Gift of Life" campaign was dramatized yesterday at the organization's blood center, 70 West Fortieth Street. Two tiny children, who must have frequent transfusions, were on hand to meet a priest and a young male student nurse, who had volunteered to provide the children's "gift of life."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- A broad program to step up construction of homes costing $8,500 to $10,000 was reported today to have clinched a high place on President Truman's legislative list for Congress next session.

BERLIN, Dec. 19 -- An increasing campaign to convert the education system in the East German state to the teachings of communism is highlighted today by Petrus Blatt, official organ of the Catholic archdiocese, which asserts pupils are being taught that Christ never existed.
SYDNEY, N. S., Dec. 19 -- Police Chief R. J. MacDonald filed a charge of murder today against Mayor Dan Jack MacLean following the death of Joseph Mackinnon, city registrar of voters.
A runaway delivery truck killed a Bronx woman and injured another yesterday on the northwest corner of 176th Street and University Avenue, the Bronx.
William Dennison Duble, former secretary-manager of the Cincinnati Clearing House "Association, pleaded guilty yesterday to two counts of an indictment alleging conspiracy to contrive a lottery.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture today extended the present grower price support program for wool through March 31. The support rate is designed to average 42.3 cents a pound nationally for shorn wool, grease basis.

One man was killed and another knocked unconscious yesterday in hold-ups of two stores of the New Yorker Delicatessen chain. These crimes were committed less than twelve hours after another store in the chain had been robbed without injury to anyone.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 19 -- India's Parliament voted today to consider a bill offered by Dr. B. R. Ambedkar, representative of the Untouchables, to reform the ancient Hindu code on marriage, caste, adoption, inheritance and other human relationships that govern lives of one-sixth of the world's population.

The Georgia Rug Company announced yesterday slight increases in wholesale prices of some items in its cotton rug line. William M. Brown, vice president of the company, a medium-size organization, did not give the amounts of the advances but emphasized the concern is confident that none of the retail prices of its products will be affected.

Bendix Home Appliances, Inc., will spend approximately $210,000 for a campaign in the first quarter of 1950 to be concentrated in newspapers in ninety-four cities, Parker Erickson, general sales manager, told the company's Eastern distributors at a meeting in the Park Sheraton Hotel yesterday.
SYRACUSE, Dec. 19 -- After a fairly even first half, Syracuse University's quintet drove to its fifth straight victory by halting Princeton, 80 -- 48, tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -Federal Judge Charles F. McLaughlin today ordered a two-day delay in National Labor Relations Board hearings on union representation in the electrical industry.

At a special meeting of the Coca-Cola Company yesterday in Wilmington, Del., common stockholders approved the directors' proposal to offer one share of common stock to Class A shareholders in exchange for three shares of Class A stock.
TRENTON, Dec. 19 -- A young man was wheeled into the active treatment ward at Trenton State Hospital here. He lay on the cot as though dead.

SALONIKA, Greece, Dec. 19 -- After nine years of war and disorder, civilian rail traffic between Athens and Salonika, Greece's second largest town and seaport and the principal administrative center of the whole northearn area, was resumed today.
VERDEN ON THE ALLER, Germany, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Former German Gen. Walter von Seydlitz, a prisoner-of-war in Russia since 1943, expects to be home by Christmas, his relatives here said tonight.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 19 -- Donald O. Hammemberg, State Milk Administrator, today directed Connecticut milk dealers to reduce by 2 cents a quart the price they pay Connecticut producers for Class 1 milk.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Music and advertising on radio-equipped streetcars and buses won official sanction here today.
A series of regulations governing city policemen in their contacts with delegates to the United Nations was issued yesterday by the Police Department.

Representatives of the American Bar Association and the American Institute of Accountants met yesterday at the Union League Club to revive the National Conference of Lawyers and Certified Public Accountants as a cooperative group to deal with problems arising between the two professions which affect the public interest.

A new development, known as Delmar Homes, has been opened in Creskill, N. J., where ranchstyle houses with baseboard hotwater heat are featured in the first section of thirty-seven buildings under construction. S. Grabowski and S. Yarosh are the builders and Percy Simon is the architect.

The twenty-seven-piece presentation that took place yesterday morning in the resort shop of Gunther Jaeckel in its newly equipped and decorated store on East Fifty-seventh Street was indicative of the well-styled merchandise that fills the racks and presses.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 19 (AP) -- The widow and other members of the family of jockey Charlie Kurtsinger filed suit in Federal Court here today against Warner Brothers, Inc., and Warner Brothers Pictures Distributing Corporation for $1,000,000 and net profits of the film, "The Story of Seabiscuit."

PARIS, Dec. 19 -- W. Averell Harriman, United States roving Ambassador for the Marshall Plan, was installed today for one year as chairman of the Economic and Financial Defense Committee, which directs financing of the North Atlantic Treaty.
