The thirtieth anniversary campaign of the Vocational Advisory Service will start in January, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Beardsley Ruml, the agency's president, after a meeting of the board of managers.

It is possible that in some pre-Christmas season a Postmaster General under an Administration that has been defeated at the polls in November -- and hence one to whom the wooing of votes no longer would appear to be a matter of transcendental importance -- might cause to be issued an order forbidding the acceptance at parcel post windows throughout the nation of packages wrapped by women and intended for Christmas delivery.

A plan to tap the Hudson River about fifteen miles below Poughkeepsie to provide an additional 100,000,000 daily gallons of water to bolster the city's reserves will be pushed "at once" by the Board of Water Supply, it was announced yesterday.
The spirit of the season struck the Federal Courthouse yesterday, bringing with it the reluctant present of a jail sentence to Richard T. Hackney, decorated war hero and former postal employe.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The State Department has decided to cut by two-thirds the size of United States military missions that are to go to Denmark and Norway to supervise United States arms shipments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Voice of America inaugurated broadcasts to Turkey today with a message from President Truman dedicating the programs to a strengthening of the "ties of friendship" between the peoples of that country and the United States.

Offering to the public of 400,000 shares of common stock of Lucky Stores, Inc., California retail food store enterprise, will be made today by an underwriting syndicate headed by Blair Co., Inc., and E. H. Rollins Sons, Inc. The stock is priced at $5.25 a share.
The Democratic minority in the State Legislature committed itself yesterday to an anti-discrimination program in housing that would bar a repetition of the Stuyvesant Town situation.

"Give Us This Day," which arrives at the Rialto, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The British-made adaptation of the Pierre Di Donato novel. "Christ in Concrete," stars Sam Wanamaker and the Italian actress, Lea Padovani.

OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 19 (AP) -Joe Louis, retired heavyweight champion, took another step in what many think will eventually lead to a comeback when he knocked out rangy Al Hoosman of Los Angeles in the fifth round of their scheduled ten-round exhibition boxing match at the Oakland Auditorium tonight.

The stock market followed an irregular course yesterday, although an attempt to move higher was checked in the afternoon by year-end tax sales. The day's performance was characterized mainly by the shifting of interest from one group to another while stocks of secondary importance found some speculative favor.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Republican National Committee plans to start a school Jan. 1 at national headquarters on how to win elections and influence voters.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Stockholders of the I. G. Farben industry proposed today that the German Government take over decartelization of the vast chemical and drug empire.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 19 -- A strong Brazilian confederation of commercial associations, with a membership said to be over 500,000, will open their own office in New York City early next year.

PATERSON, N. J., Dec. 19 -After more than half a century of producing some of the world's finest jacquard upholstery and drapery fabrics in Paterson, F. Ichumacher and Company wiU move its manufacturing operations to Lidland Park, N. J., next month.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Five high Nazi officials convicted at Nuremberg are among sixty German war criminals who will be freed on parole this week, the United States High Commissioner's officer announced tonight.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- One of the most precise operations of steel making -- the application of a vegetable oil coating to tin plate -- was explained by research technicians of Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation today in a description of a new method of measuring the extremely small quantities of oil used in the process.

A United States of Europe, or at least an economic union of the nations of western Europe, was warmly endorsed yesterday by a group of Dutch trade union leaders who have just finished a tour of industries in the United States.

VIENNA, Dec. 19 -- Two New York businessmen have found it necessary to enlist the aid of the United States legation here to keep the Austrian Government from shutting down a laundromat they established in Vienna two months ago.

Burlington Mills Corporation has filed suit for $250,000 against Lansburgh Bros., Inc., Washington, D. C., department store, for alleged damages caused by the unauthorized use of its trade-marks, it was announced yesterday. A complaint, consisting of two causes of action, was filed in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The State Department disclosed today a new warning from the Chinese Nationalist Government that United States and other foreign vessels stay out of Shanghai and all Communist-held ports.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 19 -- Counsel for Harry R. Bridges sought today to show at the longshore leader's perjury-conspiracy trial that a list of Communist National Committee members, purportedly prepared in 1939 by Earl Browder, former head of the party, bore neither the name of Mr. Bridges nor any of the aliases he allegedly had used.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- After a wait of ten months the Rev. Louis Robert Brassard, a Roman Catholic priest of Worcester, Mass., walked into the Soviet Embassy today and emerged within five minutes with a visa enabling him to go to Moscow.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- A tug of war is going on within the Labor party over the date for the general election, with Prime Minister Clement R. Attlee acting as arbiter between those favoring an appeal to the country as early as possible and those who would put it off until next summer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- During the first ten months of 1949 the Federal Government hired 5,200 physically handicapped persons, the Civil Service Commission said today. The total included more than 3,300 disabled veterans.

BUFFALO, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Nine employes of the Bell Aircraft Corporation, who were suspended as a result of indictments in strike violence cases, were ordered temporarily reinstated today by a state board of inquiry. Bell was directed to put five others back to work six weeks ago.

Sara Kaufman is a singer of remarkable imagination and more than ordinary vocal talent. These qualities were demonstrated in Town Hall last night, when the mezzo-soprano made her recital debut before a sizable and friendly audience.
The people of the United States have ultra-short memories. They remember the good things, but often forget the bad ones.

Establishment of a Center of Iranian Studies at Columbia University was announced last night at a dinner given by the university at its Men's Faculty Club, 400 West 117th Street, in honor of the Shah of Iran, Mohammed Reza Pahlevi.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 19 -Prospects for a special session of the General Assembly to consider extension of unemployment compensation benefits and a 75-cent hourly minimum wage were considerably dimmed tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UP) -- The Agriculture Department revealed today that insects had infested Government-owned wheat stored in fourteen Liberty ships in the Hudson River above New York City.

The expiration of the stand-by offering of 142,132 shares of new preferred stock of the Public Service Company of Indiana marks the end of an unusual public utility financing transaction. Award of the underwriting contract at public bidding was made by the company with the first purpose of offering a security to its stockholders which would yield 4 per cent.
ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 19 (AP) -- Cornell University today outlawed two student societies after the near-fatal outcome of a drinking initiation.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 19 -- One of the leaders of the Syrian military coup, Col. Adib al Shishikli, has been identified by Israeli sources as a commander of the Arab irregular forces that fought in northern Palestine in 1948. He is said to be friendly with the Moslem Brotherhood, a fanatical Islamic movement.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 19 -- In his annual report to the president and Fellows of Yale, Albert B. Crawford, director of the Student Appointment Bureau, disclosed today that students of the university received more than $1,500,000 in financial assistance during the 1948-1949 academic year.

Two other major producers of steel yesterday followed the lead taken last week by the United States Steel Corporation in raising prices on a wide range of key products by $4 a ton, or approximately 4 per cent. The increases were announced last night by the Republic Steel Corporation of Cleveland, the nation's third largest steel company, and by the Armco Steel Corporation of Middletown, Ohio, seventh ranking member of the industry.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 19 -- On the eve of leaving Sweden for Switzerland, Oscar R. Ewing, United States Federal security administrator and President Truman's emissary for the study of public health service conditions in Europe, said today that he doubted the American taxpayers' would "stand" for the additional assessments required if the proposed United States sickness insurance plan were to be made as broad as Sweden's program.

The Francis Lewis Apartments at 114-31 to 114-59 Francis Lewis Boulevard in St. Albans, Queens, have been sold by the Francis Lewis Apartments, Inc., to an investor, who resold the property through A. J. Clarke and Sigfrid Kaufman, brokers in the transaction.

TRENTON, Dec. 19 -- Federal Judge Phillip Forman turned down today the plea of a fugitive from a Georgia prison camp, who said he feared mistreatment if returned. The court said alleged conditions that gave rise to criticism of the Georgia penal system had been corrected.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 19 -- The United Nations Trusteeship Council called today upon its president, Roger Garreau of France, to join with Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, former United Nations Mediator for Palestine and at present director of the Trusteeship Division of the United Nations, and other Secretariat experts in drafting a new statute for internationalizing Jerusalem.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UP) -- The National Farmers Union tonight added its voice to a demand for Congress to divorce the Agriculture Department's Extension Service from the American Farm Bureau Federation.

Alger Hiss repeated yesterday his first-trial denial that he had ever passed secret State Department documents to Whittaker Chambers. He was testifying in his own defense at his second perjury trial in United States District Court.

STROUDSBURG, Pa., Dec. 19 -- Our extensive coverage of the ski-lands, to be resumed next weekend with the Hudson Valley, Catskills and Adirondacks, has resulted in a heavy backlog of pertinent information for the competitive and recreational enthusiast, so we'll plunge into the mountains of letters, news releases, etc.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Dec. 19 -- Mrs. J. Parnell Thomas announced today her withdrawal from the contest for the Republican nomination for Congress in the Seventh District. This left a three-way battle for the nomination in prospect at next month's special primary as the Bergen County organization faced its first challenge for leadership since 1946.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 2 per cent last week in comparison with the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 4 per cent.
UTICA, N. Y., Dec. 19 (AP) -- A State Supreme Court jury tonight acquitted all seven defendants in the Utica vote fraud trial.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture, in its final report of the year, today estimated this year's corn crop at 3,377,790,000 bushels and the wheat crop at 1,146,463,000 bushels.

Ira A. Schiller, formerly chief attorney in the lower Manhattan Office of Housing Expediter, and Julius Hoffman, president of First Terrace Gardens, Inc., owner of London Terrace Gardens, Twenty-third Street and Ninth Avenue, were indicted yesterday by a Federal Grand Jury on charges of conspiracy to defraud the Government.

MOSCOW, Dec. 18 -- Leonid Leonov, writing in Pravda, predicted today that "the practical revolutionary agenda or our century is far from being over." Eulogizing the formation of democratic republics and the emergence of a new revolutionary China, he wrote:

Following is the text of an analysis of twelve demands of the Transport Workers Union made yesterday by a special committee of the Board of Transportation. The analysis was based on an interim report of Deputy Commissioner John J. Woods, in charge of labor relations, submitted to the Board on Nov. 25:

The last shopping week before Christmas opened yesterday with umbrella-carrying crowds thronging the counters of midtown shops and department stores. Dolls and television sets were two of the biggest-selling items.
Willa Cotten, soprano, was heard at Times Hall yesterday evening in a program of lieder by Schubert and Brahms, a group of Italian folk songs and other songs in Italian, French and English.

ALBANY, Dec. 19 -- Governor Dewey and the Republican fiscal leaders of the Legislature met today in plans to telescope fund requests by state departments into a 1950-51 budget that can be financed without new or increased taxes. Results of the conferences will be announced tomorrow.
I trust that you will pardon my encroaching on your valuable space, but I write to you as I know your journal reaches every corner of the globe which Americans inhabit.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Federal Government intervened tonight in an effort to avert a possible strike against the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 19 -- The Government has entered into an agreement with two French concerns, the Banque Marocaine de Credit and the Societte de Produits Chimoues des Terres Rares, to set up a plant for processing monazite sands in India, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru told Parliament today.

In the six years that he has been performing here, Alexander Uninsky, Russian pianist, has made an especially favorable impression playing Chopin and Debussy. In consequence, considerable expectation was aroused last night when he gave a recital at Carnegie Hall devoted solely to those two masters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations today sued the United Office and Professional Workers to recover $18,700 lent to the union, which it has accused of pro-Communist tendencies.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UP) -- The commission said that in general the opponents had objected to the radio reception for the following reason:

YOKOHAMA, Dec. 19 -- Consul General Angus Ward today said he had been unable to gather important information regarding Chinese Communist or Soviet activities in Manchuria during his thirteen months' imprisonment after the Communist occupation of Mukden.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 19 -- In hopes of speeding negotiations for development of a modern $12,000,000 pier program here, Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll has asked representatives of the Port of New York Authority and Jersey City officials to meet with him in Trenton next week, it was announced today by Donald Spence, City Commissioner.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Pittsburgh Consolidation Coal Company plans to conclude a $6,000,000 deal tomorrow with its largest stockholder, M. A. Hanna Company of Cleveland.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- A triple challenge to state laws prohibiting peaceful union picketing where there is no direct dispute between employer and employe will be reviewed by the Supreme Court as a result of orders issued today.

Youngsters who sold their gifts of candy, held their own "antique show," or just saved their pennies to help less fortunate children, sent their contributions yesterday to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

PARIS, Dec. 19 -- The question of stronger political leadership for the European Marshall Plan Council, now mainly a body of expert permanent officials, will be discussed tomorrow by the Council's Ministerial Steering Committee, composed of the Finance and Foreign Ministers of eight nations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- A return of Federal personal income tax exemptions to $2,500 for a man and wife was proposed today as an aid in improving the position of low-income families by Reginald A. Johnson, field director for the National Urban League today. The present exemption is $1,200.

A nine-game football schedule, including four contests at the Polo Grounds, has been arranged for Fordham University for 1950, Jack Coffey, graduate athletic manager, announced yesterday. The Rams will meet Yale, San Francisco and Temple for the first time in their history, the West Coast Jesuit squad making its first New York appearance.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower won a round of applause from 350 Columbia University students at their Yule log party yesterday when he told them he wasn't going to talk politics. The recent utterances of the president of the university on social security and other matters of political interest have been criticized in the student publication, The Spectator.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The United States, Britain and Canada have worked out plans for an almost complete exchange of information about the military weapons and fighting methods each country develops.

ALBANY, Dec. 19 -- Modernization of obsolete municipal building codes can do more to lower housing costs than any program now in contemplation, Governor Dewey declared today following his first conference with the five members of the state's new Building Code Commission.

The New York Rangers were dealt another blow yesterday when it was announced that Frank Eddolls, star defense man, would shortly undergo an operation on his right elbow. Fearing infection, it was decided yesterday to go ahead with an operation.

While her 15-year-old son was running through a two-story house at 407 East 158th Street, the Bronx, early yesterday awakening members of the family and telling them the house was on fire, Mrs. Catherine Flanagan, 53 years old, was burned to death in the bathroom on the second floor.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 19 -- A plan to help solve the problem of mentally handicapped children was announced today by the University of Notre Dame.

The Office of Housing Expediter's interpretation of the rights of landlords to evict tenants in so-called decontrolled luxury apartments, without the sanction of the Temporary City Housing Rent Commission, received a setback yesterday in the Municipal Court.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -Growth of business in the Southeast, Southwest and Far West in 1944-49 period far outstripped the national average, the Department of Commerce reported today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 19 -- Nadia Gray, European stage and screen actress, has been signed to a term contract by Universal-International and will arrive in Hollywood in January to make her American debut as the leading woman in "Panther's Moon," the studio announced today.

The decision of the International Court of Justice that Albania must pay Britain over $2,000,000 in damages for the mining of two British destroyers in 1946 brings to a close -- so far as the Court is concerned -- the first case it has had to decide since its reconstitution under the Charter of the United Nations.

David E. Smucker and Hunter L. Delatour, trustees of the Long Island Rail Road, announced yesterday that the road had begun payment of current real estate taxes. Four checks totaling $13,869 were forwarded to four Suffolk County taxing districts that had made requested reductions in assessments on railroad property.

Fifty-one officers in the Volunteer Air Force Reserves received promotions last night at a ceremony at the High School of Needle Trades, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street. Thirty-four men were elevated from first lieutenants to captains and seventeen were promoted from captains to majors.

Even Bob Cratchit's wife had help with the bird; the baker cooked the goose for her and two younger Cratchit's fetched it just before dinner. With Dickens in mind, it may not be violating tradition too much to mention some establishments about town that will roast poultry -- especially turkey -- for home cooks too hurried to do it themselves on Christmas Day.
CAMDEN, N. J., Dec. 19 -- Santa Claus today traded his traditional roly-poly red jacket for the conservative gray of a postman.

HONG KONG, Dec. 19 -- Kunming, Yunnan provincial capital, was recaptured today by Nationalist troops from the forces of its Governor, Gen. Lu Han, who had defected to the Communists ten days ago. A Nationalist Central News Agency dispatch from Taipei said Nationalist troops had regained the city this afternoon after a twelve-hour battle.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Commander E. L. Robertson Jr. of Syracuse, N. Y., says the new 20,000-ton cruiser, the Salem, can discharge as much fire power as the mighty battleship Missouri.

HAMBURG, Germany, Dec. 19 -- A British military court found Nazi Field Marshal General Fritz Erich von Mannstein guilty today of war crimes and sentenced the 62-year-old World War II commander of German troops on the Russian front to eighteen years imprisonment.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 19 -- The consequences of devaluation of the pound were brought home to South Africans today when the price of gasoline rose approximately one and one-half cents a gallon, making a total increase of three and one-half cents since October.

The Public Service Commission's inquiry into Grand Central Terminal's loudspeaker "broadcasts" received publicity of a peculiarly appropriate sort yesterday. By order of E. B. Moor-house, manager, the "broadcasts themselves included this message:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Supreme Court held in effect today that automobile clubs were not exempt from Federal income and excess profits taxes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Robert N. Denham, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board today disclosed a policy of waiving the Taft-Hartley law's union-shop election requirement for the building industry.
Providence, R. I., announced yesterday that it will receive bids Jan. 4 on $2,500,000 of bonds. Dated Jan. 1, 1950, the bonds will come due from Jan. 1, 1952 to 1974.

First-nighters who had planned to take in the opening performance this evening of the Bernard Shaw comedy, "Caesar and Cleopatra," which co-stars Sir Cedric Hardwicke and Lilli Palmer, must wait until tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Alexander M. Campbell has resigned as assistant Attorney General to run for the Democratic Senatorial nomination in Indiana next year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Government need not pay a $3,520 freight bill for a lumber cargo lost when the steamship Gunvor was sunk by a German submarine, the Supreme Court ruled today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- An amended application was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Electric Bond and Share Company and its subsidiary, the American and Foreign Power Company, requesting permission for the parent company to transfer to its subsidiary $19,500,000 of Cuban Electric Company 6 per cent, twenty-year debenture bonds. Series A, due on May 1, 1948.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 19 -- Conservationists won a unique victory as President Truman announced today the prohibition of airplane flights into primeval areas of the Superior National Forest of Minnesota as a deterrent to easy assaults on its abounding wildlife.

An exhibit of arts and crafts that unfolded a story of courage and fortitude as graphically as it did of skills, opened yesterday in the Memorial Cancer Center, 444 East Sixty-eighth Street, the work of both patients and hospital staff.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 19 (AP) -- Ohio State's Rose Bowl football squad took its first two practices today, one of them in a driving rain.

Time was, before the Fascists imitated the Communists, the Nazis imitated the Fascists and the Communists began to imitate not only their own previous record but the Fascist and Nazis records, when a political frontier was not a frontier of ideas. A thought could travel without a passport around the world; a book, a magazine or a newspaper could also travel freely into most countries.
STORRS, Conn., Dec. 19 (AP) -- Manhattan College's fast-breaking, sharp-shooting basketball team staved off a second-half rally by the University of Connecticut tonight to gain a 71-56 victory.

CAIRO, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Egypt has tightened her already stiff censorship of foreign correspondents to prevent news of pre-election disorders being cabled abroad At least six persons have been killed during such disorders since Dec. 13.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Pittsburgh's music lovers can look forward to concerts in a "convertible" amphitheatre -- with the top lowered for clear weather and raised in a jiffy when rain clouds threaten.

Smart, alert and game in the face of an early 7-point deficit, Oklahoma University's basketball team rallied to conquer C. C. N. Y., 67 -- 63, before 16,000 fans at Madison Square Garden last night, leaving this city with only one major unbeaten quintet, St. John's.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Following is the text of a letter from Admiral Louis E. Denfeld to Secretary of the Navy Francis P. Matthews, made public here today:

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- The three-power announcement of a common policy on arms standardization among the United States, Britain and Canada has been worded with such extreme regard for security that it will probably mean little or nothing to the average person. However, it underscores the important fact that to date virtually no arms standardization has taken place, except on paper.

The Brown Shoe Company, in its seventy-first annual report issued yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31. announced that its net sales of $80.377.978 were only 5 per cent less than the record high volume of $84,404,361 the year before.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The State Department has turned to the comic book technique to tell non-Communist Asia about American heroes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -Edward L. Borger, president of the New York State Natural Gas Corporation, New York, said today that his company would be able to provide all the natural gas needed for a proposed expansion into six New York counties.

The United States liner Washington, renewing passenger service to Germany for the first time since mid-summer of 1939, received a "tremendous welcome" on her recent visit to Hamburg, according to Capt. Harold Milde, the master.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -The Federal Power Commission authorized today construction of pipeline facilities for natural gas service to the Harrisburg, Allentown, Bethlehem. Reading and Lancaster, Pa., areas.

Jacqueline Rheiner has purchased the three-story six-family apartment house at 687 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, from Marie Baumgarten. Coughlin Coughlin were the brokers. Title was insured by the Home Title Guaranty Company.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- The report of the Department of Agriculture estimating the corn crop at 20,000,000 bushels more than a month ago came as a surprise to the grain trade as many brokers had expected there would be a reduction. The report was construed as bearish.

COMPARED with the mountains of Kentucky and Tennessee the Ozarks have never loomed very large upon the American literary horizon. There have been scores, perhaps hundreds, of books about the hillbillies of the Eastern mountains and at least a dozen of them have been excellent. One of the best was published just last spring, Harriet Arnow's fine novel, "Hunter's Horn."
City Bank Farmers Trust Company has been appointed trustee, paying agent and registrar for an issue of $4,000,000 of Iowa Electric Light and Power Company's 3 1/2 per cent sinking fund debentures.
HONG, KONG, Dec. 19 -- Chinese Communist publicity organs are giving the greatest attention to Mao Tze-tung's meeting with Premier Stalin in Moscow.

A "whodunit" involving the new version of the two-minute rule now in use by collegians occupied the spotlight yesterday as the metropolitan basketball writers got together for their weekly conclave at Leone's. And, by the time the meeting was over, one thing appeared certain and that was that the current ruling is doomed.

Brig. Gen. Arthur Vincent McDermott performed with fairness, sympathy and administrative skill the major task of directing the Selective Service System of New York City during the Second World War. The magnitude of this operation is apparent in the figures.

PARIS, Dec. 19 -- Israel Jacobson, director of American Joint Distribution Committee activities in Hungary, who was arrested Thursday, was decorated with the Commander Cross for Merit by the Hungarian Government in September, 1948, Paris headquarters of the committee recalled today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 -- Caleb Foote, executive secretary of the Central Committee for Conscientious Objectors, said today that "second-class citizenship" was still the fate of thousands of persons who served prison terms because of religious or philosophical convictions.

In the first sale of the property since 1826, the three-story building at 48 and 50 Norfolk Street has been conveyed by Mary C. Daly and Virginia Gannon to Joseph Coopersmith and Hyman Munick. McDermott, Turner Hart were attorneys for the buyers.

OTTAWA, Dec. 19 (Canadian Press) -- A high Canadian source said today that there was "no major item of disagreement" between Canadian and American officials discussing difficulties arising from an air agreement the two countries signed more than six months ago.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumed in November included 771,833 bales of lint and 131,518 bales of linters.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Admiral Louis E. Denfeld, former Chief of Naval Operations, refused today to serve as commander of United States Naval Forces in Europe, with headquarters in London.

The Communist rulers of Bulgaria announce that they have rolled up no less than 97.66 per cent of the total vote cast in Sunday's election in favor of their so-called Fatherland Front, which is now the Russian Front. What the actual figures are is, of course, impossible to ascertain in a country whose Government uses fraud and terror as weapons of the class struggle and the cold war.
Deputy Police Commissioner Patrick J. Meehan, an intimate friend of Mayor O'Dwyer, was made eligible yesterday for a $6,000-a-year pension by the Board of Trustees of the Police Pension Fund.

First results of tests of new merchandising methods in tool sales prove that "impulse buying" is now being created by hardware dealers by "theft-proof" display methods, Ben T. Cowherd, vice president, Century Drill and Tool Works, Chicago, revealed here yesterday.

ALBANY, Dec. 19 -- New York City can add half a billion gallons a day to its present potable water supply by tapping Rondout Creek in Ulster County and taking water from the Hudson River just north of Beacon, Governor Dewey declared today after a meeting of the State Water Power and Control Commission.
Pan American World Airways announced last night that it would "seek the guidance of the United States Government with respect to the airline's interest in the China National Aviation Corporation."

The current set of twelve demands by the Transport Workers Union would cost the city an additional $70,865,000 a year for transit operation, William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation, declared yesterday at a negotiating session that ended abruptly one hour after it began.

For years the elevators in the plant of the Buenos Aires newspaper, Nacion, have been working satisfactorily. But because their gates lack safety plaques to prevent their being opened from the outside by anyone willing to push his fingers through the grill and fiddle with the electric switch, all of the elevators in the Nacion building have been shut down.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Free liquor and immoral women were effectively employed by Communists during the second World War to win converts among members of the United States armed forces and merchant marine, according to testimony released today by the Senate Judiciary Committee.

Increases in employment are being made by General Electric Company in order to boost output of household lines to meet active demand, C. E. Wilson, president, disclosed in a news conference at the company's executive offices last Monday night.

The Port of New York Authority moved yesterday to place its outstanding 3 per cent general and refunding bonds of the Fourth Series on a lower interest-cost basis by borrowing $54,000,000 on new serial obligations maturing from 1950 to 1964 at an interest cost of 1.532083 per cent.

The rubber futures market apparently decided yesterday that Monday's rumors of impending heavy Government purchases of raw rubber for stockpiling purposes was one of those ephemeral reports that emanate from Washington at frequent intervals.

A second liquidating dividend of $3 a share will be payable to stockholders of the Continental Bank Trust Company of New York on and after next Wednesday, John T. Seaman, president, has announced to stockholders in a letter being mailed out today.

ALBANY, Dec. 20 -- Three hundred and forty-three employees of the State Tax Department, with a combined total of 8,000 years in state service, received gold pins at a ceremony here today. The pins represented twenty and twenty-five years of continuous service.
STOCKKHOLM, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Viljo Heino, Finnish long-distance runner, took off today on a 7,000-mile flight to participate in a single race.

CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 20 (UP) -- The new Government of Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies, in its first administrative action, today increased the price of wheat and ordered a butter subsidy to ease the cost of living.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 20 -- The West German Government has asked the Western Allied High Commissioners to inform it officially what plans, if any, are being made by the North Atlantic pact powers to defend this country in case of an outbreak of war.

The city is awaiting action by the trustees of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road in its suit for reduction of tax assessments in Brooklyn and Queens, it became known yesterday. The trustees have filed similar actions in the Supreme Courts in the two boroughs, asking that tax valuations of its properties be reduced from a total of $107,978,806 to $37,958,832.

Mohammed Reza Pahlevi, Shah of Iran, dedicated yesterday a mansion purchased by Iranian business men for the work of Iranian groups promoting closer friendship between their country and the United States.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 20 -- The third coup d'etat in Syria this year, which overthrew yesterday the commander of the Army, Brig. Gen. Sami Hinnawi, and his friends, has much strengthened the somewhat revolutionary young officers group and the stormily nationalist political left wing, it became apparent today.

The short interest in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange showed a further increase on last Thursday, Dec. 15, the settlement date, and ran contrary to all predictions made in financial circles during the past three weeks. Due to the sustained advance by the stock market up until late last week, it had been predicted freely in Wall Street that the short position would decline because of covering operations.

German schools and universities are making "slow progress in reeducating that nation's youth, but are receiving a good deal of help from American colleges that accept exchange students, Dr. Edwin Redslob, rector of the Free University of Berlin, said here yesterday.

The stock market met its first serious setback of the month yesterday, as prices turned from an irregular course to a definite decline. The drop was an extension of the reaction that became noticeable last week for the first time and the losses of fractions to a point were the result of mild but persistent selling.
WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 20 (AP) -- More than 600 du Ponts will get together in this city on New Year's Day to celebrate the 150th anniversary of the family's arrival in the United States.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 20 -- A 75-year-old recluse who, before his death last Dec. 7, lived in a $4-a-week room, was found to have left a bank account, stocks, bonds, insurance policies and oil lands valued in excess of $150,000, the police announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Congressional demand for a tightening of Marshall Plan aid to Britain and for protection of the domestic petroleum industry were foreshadowed today in reaction to a British Government decision curbing dollar purchases of oil for Britain from the Middle East.

THE New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association has always prided itself on its utter lack of provincialism. Every year at its annual dinner it has awarded two plaques. One goes to the "Player of the Year" and the other is gaited for a longer period of time, going to the chap who has contributed heavily to the sport by meritorious service.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin today announced his intention to amend all prevailing wage rulings to require a minimum of 75 cents an hour for work on Government manufacturing and supply contracts.

STRASBOURG, France, Dec. 20 -- The General Affairs (political) Committee of the Council of Europe, now in session here, went on record today as favoring greater independence for the European Assembly with respect to the Committee of Ministers. [The Assembly and the Committee of Ministers compose the Council of Europe.]
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Government forecast today next year's winter wheat crop at 884,658,000 bushels -- only about 2 per cent less than this year's crop -- third largest on record.
Mrs. Ivan Obolensky was reconciled to the Roman Catholic Church about a month ago. This was confirmed yesterday by the Chancery Office of the Archdiocese of New York.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -Manufacturers' new orders have about equaled their sales in recent months, the Department of Commerce reported today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 20 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo told atomic control negotiators today that they ought to give top priority to drafting a short-term agreement before rapid technical advances in manufacturing atomic bombs made permanent settlement impossible.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- President Truman was reported tonight to be expecting a budget for the 1951 fiscal year of about $44,000,000,000 from Frank Pace Jr., Director of the Budget, and to be planning to pare this down to $42,000,000,000 or $43,000,000,000.
DETROIT, Wednesday, Dec. 21 (UP) -- An attempt was made early today to blow up the international headquarters of the CIO United Automobile Workers, police reported.

The Realty Associates Collateral Holding Corporation has sold 311 lots at Rosewood in Flushing, Queens, to Fresh Meadow Homes, Inc., represented by Morris Diamond, attorney. The new owners plan to construct 250 one-family dwellings on the property, which is assessed at $168,120.

Threatened loss of some $60,000,000 in American textile exports to the Philippines still overhung the industry here yesterday as the result of the import restrictions made effective by the Republic. Fresh cables received from the Islands failed to throw any new light on the course of developments.

A weekly television series with Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt is being planned for early presentation by the National Broadcasting Company, it was learned yesterday. It is expected that the program will have its debut around Feb. 1, possibly on Sunday afternoons from 4 to 4:30 P. M.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- In its second and final report the United Nations Economic Survey Mission for the Middle East has recommended that a remarkably modest beginning be made in development of the area. Its plans involve only $10,000,000 of outside financial aid in addition to $54,900,000 already voted by the United Nations to provide work relief for Palestine Arab refugees.

A suit to restrin Pan American Airways from operating passenger flights between the United States and Rome during the rest of this year and in 1950 was filed in the United States District Court yesterday by Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc.

Louis Schleifer, operator, has acquired another well-known hostelry. He purchased the Hotel Fourteen at 14 East Sixtieth Street, site of the Copacabana, famous supper club, from the Prudence Realization Corporation.

Persons who each year donate to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund sent in their gifts again yesterday from as widely scattered places as Paris, France, and Los Angeles, Calif. They were among the 531 donors who added $11,892.27 to this year's Christmas appeal for the fund.

Joseph Gayne Chenoweth, commercial artist of Jackson Heights, bought a cooperative apartment at Hudson View Gardens, 181st Street and Pinehurst Avenue, from Michael J. Shannon, through William A. White Sons and the Houghton Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Lieut. Col. Emil G. Beaudry, a pilot of the Military Air Transport Service, who rescued twelve stranded airmen from an icecap in Greenland today received the Mackay Trophy for the "most meritorious flight" of 1948. The award was presented to the 33-year-old airman by Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, chief of staff of the Air Force.
The growing roster of transatlantic shipping being accumulated for the expected record travel year in 1950 received the addition yesterday of the 24,000-ton Italian liner Conte Biancamano.

Last month an election was held in Syria to choose a Constituent Assembly. It was noted at the time that the voting was very apathetic. Only a small percentage of the eligible voters went to the polls, and only the women, casting their ballots for the first time in any Arab country, displayed a lively interest in the drafting of a new Constitution.

Frank L. Jones, who retired yesterday as president of the Greater New York Safety Council, reported to his fellow members at the organization's annual meeting in the Statler Hotel that the accidental death rate in New York City had decreased 4.57 per cent in the last ten months.
Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., accepted yesterday the chairmanship of the National Christian Committee of the United Jewish Appeal.
The United States Maritime Commission, in a reversal of previous policy, has approved the transfer of six tankers of the Standard Oil Company (N. J.) to a foreign flag, it was announced yesterday.

The Mayor's committee to evaluate the new $150,000,000 municipal hospital construction program agreed yesterday at its first meeting that expansion of clinics at five existing institutions was "an extremely necessary step" to save several thousand hospital beds.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Mr. Dodd said here that "it's quite possible I gave a party for the camp," but he denied that the camp was what Mr. Huber said it was.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Jack Kroll, director of the CIO's Political Action Committee, wrote today to Guy George Gabrielson, chairman of the Republican Committee, warning that efforts by the GOP to build a rival organization appealing to labor were doomed to failure.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Economist Frank E. Seidman returned today from a two-month trip to South Africa with a prediction that "American industry must adopt a new approach to the problem of foreign markets."

Raymond M. Hilliard, city Welfare Commissioner, asserted yesterday that the cuts in relief allotments that are to take effect on Jan. 16 reflected the decline in the cost of living and were based on sound policy.

The Empire Building at 507 Liberty Avenue, Pittsburgh, Pa., in the heart of the city's Golden Triangle, has been sold by the Tishman Realty Construction Company of New York to an investing syndicate headed by James D. Landauer Associates, Inc., of New York.

Fifty - two Customs inspectors who faced dismissal on Dec. 31 because they lacked civil service status have received a reprieve until March 31 at least, it was announced yesterday by Harry M. Durning, Collector of Customs.

Margaret Truman, who made her professional debut as a singer in a radio broadcast from Detroit a little more than two and a half years ago, sang in Carnegie Hall for the first time last night. She sang one short aria by Puccini and two Christmas carols in the course of a half-hour commercially sponsored broadcast originating from the hall.
HONG KONG, Dec. 20 -- Foreign observers who have studied the Formosan situation lately believe the Communist invasion of that island will not be attempted before next spring at the earliest.

The annual report of John Morrell Co., pork and beef packers, issued yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 29, showed a decline in net income to $84,065 or 10 cents a share from $2,587,741 or $3.23 a share earned in the preceding fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Soviet press was reported today to be hailing Premier Stalin on his seventieth birthday as 'inspirer of creation," "standard-bearer of peace," "hope and pride of laboring humanity," "best friend of Soviet art," etc., etc.

The National Association for American Composers and Conductors opened its season last night at Times Hall with a program in honor of the birthday of its founder, Henry Hadley, who was born Dec. 20, 1871, and died twelve years ago.
BATAVIA, Dec. 20 (UP) -- Radio Jogjakarta reported tonight that the new Government of the United States of Indonesia had seven major goals:

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 20 -- West Germany's first postwar aircraft was pronounced unflyable today by a United States Air Force officer. Capt. Edgar W. Gregory of Le Mars, Iowa, said he reached this opinion while inspecting the craft -- a helicopter built in a Frankfort garage.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The National Labor Relations Board, umpiring the struggle between the United Electrical Workers and the new International Union of Electrical Workers, CIO, changed its hearing rules at the demand of the UE, it was disclosed today.

The Univis Lens Company, maker of multivision lenses, has appointed Gerald F. Weis as general manager. A member of the organization since July, 1948, Mr. Weis' promotion is part of a program of expanded activity in its selling, advertising and operational fields.

A 26-year-old ex-convict facing trial in Brooklyn and in two New Jersey counties for grand larceny and burglary was promised yesterday by Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz in Kings County Court that he would get the opportunity to rehabilitate himself.

The White Cane Appeal of the Blind Self-Aiders, 1072 Bergen Street, Brooklyn, was started Monday night at the group's annual Christmas party, it was announced yesterday. The drive, designed to raise $50,000 to extend services to the blind, will end in March.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, which was the first of the major producers to settle the recent strike of its workers, announced yesterday that a special meeting of its stockholders has been called for Feb. 7, 1950, in Wilmington, Del., to vote on the increased pension benefits granted the workers in the agreement dated Oct. 31, 1949, between the company and the United Steelworkers of America, CIO.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 20 -- President Juan Peron pooh-poohed dollars and hard currencies generally last night, saying that the problem was not to devalue other monetary units but to "revalue gold" in terms of basic commodities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Beverly (Mass.) Gas and Electric Company had filed with it a registration statement covering 33,000 shares of $25 par value capital stock.

Organization of a New York State Liquor Advertising League was announced here yesterday by John M. Palmer, president of the Point of Purchase Advertising Institute, Inc. Formation of the group was described as a move to set up an industry-wide system of self-regulation of liquor advertising.

How many happy and alive today will be killed on the roads this holiday season? It is unfortunately true that, no matter what care you exercise, you may still be the victim of the drunken motorist. If the drunk at the wheel were a danger only to himself, you might feel, perhaps, the punishment fitted the crime. But this is not so.

Thirty agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation were added yesterday to the waiting list of pre-trial witnesses in the Coplon-Gubitchev spy case after it was disclosed in court that some of them had listened in on telephone conversations between Judith Coplon and her attorney, Archibald palmer.

Plans for a modern air-conditioned store and office building on the vacant plot at 288-90 Madison Avenue were disclosed yesterday in connection with the announcement of the sale of the property by the Chase National Bank to a syndicate headed by Theodore Ornstein. Berkeley-Judelson, Inc., was the broker.

November dollar volume of metropolitan area home furnishings stores increased 14.1 per cent compared with the corresponding month last year, James B. McMahon Jr., executive vice president, Associated Furniture Dealers of New York, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Maritime Commission asked for further information from its examiner today in the complaint of the Isbrandtsen Company against the North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference. Oral argument was ended yesterday.
Alger Hiss denied yesterday the pre-war Communist activity charged to him by Mrs. Hede Massing. He testified for the second successive day at his perjury trial before Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard.
MONTREAL, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A red hot three-man fight for individual scoring honors is offering an interesting sidelight to the National Hockey League race, official statistics revealed today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- Evening up in December grain and lard contracts, trading in which ceased at the close, combined with a bearish construction placed on a final Government estimate on the 1949 grain crops, resulted in nervous price changes on the Board of Trade here today.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Dec. 20 (UP) -- Mrs. Eugenie Anderson, first woman Ambassador in the history of the United States, arrived on the Jutlandia today and won the hearts of hundreds of cheering, flag-waving Danes and Americans.

The vast and varied assortment of scatter rugs now on the market gives homemakers an opportunity to brighten dull spots in the house. Moreover, it helps to assure their suitability for any place from the nursery to the spot in front of grandmother's rocking chair and for any type of decor.

A new series of essays by Andre Gide is being translated and prepared for early spring publication by the Philosophical Library. The essays, published in France recently under the title "Feuillets D'Automne," will be called "Autumn Leaves" here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The United States, in a stern note, called today for the immediate release of an American citizen held incommunicado in Hungary, and simultaneously barred further travel by Americans in that country.
Little if any notice has been given to a conference meeting in Turkey's distant capital of Ankara. It deserves attention.

California may be noted for its sunshine, oranges and movie stars, but pending San Francisco's appearance here tomorrow night the Golden State's basketball stock slumped severely last night at Madison Square Garden.
Travelers in Pennsylvania Railroad stations here and in Philadelphia yesterday afternoon and evening heard an unusual request broadcast over the loud-speaker system.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Ralph Ruthstrom, a fullback, not only lost his suit against the Washington Redskins today but was ordered to pay the club $241.80.

Agreement was reached yesterday between the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, and a committee representing East and Gulf Coast steamship operators on a union proposal for a pension and welfare fund, it was announced by Frank J. Taylor, chairman of the owners' group.
Mild weather yesterday belied the approach of Christmas, but many thousands of children in the city knew the holiday was at hand. Parties for them were numerous and there were gifts for all.

A comprehensive report of findings by the first British rayon weaving team to visit United States mills under the auspices of the Anglo-American Council of Productivity has been received by the Economic Cooperation Administration, it was learned yesterday.
WARSAW, Dec. 20 -- A German mining engineer pleaded guilty today before the Wroclaw Military Court to providing an alleged French intelligence network with information and misinformation.

New York City's water shortage points up threats not only to the city's economy and health but to the state's recreational program through reduction of the fish supply in up-state areas, Fairfield Osborn, president of the Conservation Foundation, warned yesterday.

Holding court in his Fifth Avenue headquarters yesterday, George Weiss, general manager of the Yankees, asserted that the world champions still are trying to swing a deal that would bring them a starting pitcher.

Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company has announced the promotion to vice president of Ernest Allen, Robert P. Furey and Fred P. McKenzie. The following were promoted to assistant vice president: William G. Allen, Thomas F. DeLaney, Paul J. Hanna, Seymour L. Johnson, Frederick J. Millett, and Paul A. Williams.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- White House sources said today that it was unlikely that J. Copeland Gray would be reappointed to the National Labor Relations Board, although the President has not decided the question yet.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 505, against 985 last week and 390 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 141 arrivals yesterday, compared with 398 last Tuesday.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- The Ministerial Steering Committee of the European Marshall Plan Council complied in part today with the urgent and repeated request of the Economic Cooperation Administration for closer participation in the Council's work by men of Cabinet rank.
LONDON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A vast hoard of tribute -- from Russian, from friend and from the conquered -- was piled up at the Kremlin tonight as birthday gifts to Premier Stalin.

STUART, Fla., Dec. 20 -- Mayor William O'Dwyer of New York and Miss Elizabeth Sloan Simpson, Texas-born former model, were married here this morning in the Roman Catholic ritual of their faith. Three hundred persons crowded the small, white-frame building of St. Joseph's Church for the wedding.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 20 -- By a 5 to 0 ballot, with seven countries abstaining, the United Nations Trusteeship Council voted today to authorize its president, Roger Garreau of France, to invite Israel to remove from Jerusalem governmental departments that recently were shifted to the Holy City from Tel Aviv.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 20 -- Major bituminous coal operators today forwarded their payments to the United Mine Workers controversial welfare fund on schedule. This was done as new reports indicated a more determined attitude by the union to whittle down coal stockpiles.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Clark Gable, film star, and the former Lady Ashley, widow of Douglas Fairbanks Sr., were married today at 3:15 P. M. (PST) on a ranch thirty miles north of here, with only a few close friends in attendance.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Following is the text of the United States note that Nathaniel P. Davis, the United States Minister, presented today to the Hungarian Foreign Office:

The present water shortage may be the most serious in the city's history, but it certainly isn't the first. This fact was illustrated yesterday by a man from Elberon, N. J., who seems to be a fine-print reader. He discovered that just fifty years ago this month -- less than two years after it had become part of the City of New York -- Brooklyn was short of water.

Many of the critical problems that trouble the New York public school system also were present in 1898, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, declared in his first annual report issued yesterday.
A net loss of $214,979 was sustained by the Graham-Paige Motors Corporation in the quarter ended on Sept. 30, last, the company's report revealed yesterday.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed unchanged to 6 points higher than on Monday.

There appears to be no end in sight to French Ministerial crises or near-crises, but not even French politicians can walk a razor's edge indefinitely. It is obvious now what an unhappy mistake was made early in October when the Government of Henri Queuille, which had balanced the budget and stabilized the franc, was overthrown for partisan reasons and without a clear alternative.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UP) -- American Overseas Airlines said today a Civil Aeronautics Board proposal for handling transatlantic Holy Year travel was financially unsound, contrary to the Civil Aeronautics Act and harmful to international relations.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 20 -- Jordan and Israel have agreed to open the historic road between Jerusalem and Bethlehem on Christmas Eve for exclusive use of the consular corps and United Nations personnel. Pilgrims will not be allowed to pass over this traditional short cut, which was closed during the hostilities in 1948.
A heavy volume of travel on the three-day Christmas holiday weekend is expected by railroads, air and bus lines with the peak looked for on Friday, it was said yesterday.

Last-minute Christmas shoppers and those still in search of gifts for the remaining persons on their lists will still find a diversified selection of accessories available in the stores. Complements for town, casual, evening or sport ensembles can be given as coordinated or separate presents.

" I do not intend to ask for any tax increase." When this declaration of policy is accompanied in these times by a determination to live within income, on a balanced budget, we find it so rare, on any level of government, as to be an almost startling departure. Governor Dewey is responsible for this bit of year-end cheer.

Responding to an invitation from the six permanent members of the Atomic Energy Commission, General Romulo, President of the adjourned Assembly of the United Nations, has submitted formal proposals to that group concerning his plan for a new approach to the problem of atomic bomb control.

ROME, Dec. 20 -- The possibility that the present coalition government may be replaced next month by a government composed exclusively of Christian Democrats grew more pronounced today as the result of strong opposition within that party to collaboration with any other party.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- A report has been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by its Division of Public Utilities, recommending that the agency approve a plan, now before it, providing for the reorganization of the $128,000,000 Pittsburgh Railways Company.

As the holiday season approaches its climax a spirit of excitement fills the crisp December air. Children are counting the hours; parents are hiding bulky objects in the closet; men and women everywhere are buying gifts, making plans, exchanging greetings, looking forward to that magic day when, for people of many races and many religions, the ties of home and friendship seem suddenly to be strengthened.

ALBANY, Dec. 20 -- Governor Dewey appointed today an advisory committee of nine state officials to make preliminary plans for New York State's participation in 1950 in a White House Conference on Child Welfare.

The day of the 30-ounce tip and the 16/0 reel seems to be passing, and many of those planning a Florida fishing trip this winter seem to consider a 6-9 outfit to be heavy enough for the fishing they will do.

ROME, Dec. 20 -- The intention of the Italian Communist party to sabotage the inauguration ceremonies of Holy Year was seen today in the announcement published by its official organ, Unita, that a mass meeting of agricultural workers would be held near the Colosseum at 10 o'clock Saturday morning.

Directors of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company declared yesterday an extra year-end dividend of $1 a share payable to common stockholders on Jan. 14. This will bring declarations this year to $6, including the $1.25 quarterly disbursements.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Dec. 21 -- Premier Stalin's seventieth birthday was marked today by the establishment of international Stalin peace prizes to be awarded annually to the citizens of any nation for strengthening the peace and the struggle against "warmongers."

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, predicted today that the AFL and the Congress of Industrial Organizations would join political forces in the next elections in the United States.

Your editorial favoring the career and salary survey of the city's civil service system, at a cost of $150,000, makes me wonder whether a broader survey of the city's finances would not, in the long run, accomplish much more.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Representative Ed Gossett, Democrat, of Texas, today called New York City "a haven for those who seek illegal entry into this country." His charge was made in a report on a three-day inspection that he made with another Representative.

The State of Washington designated yesterday Jan. 12 as the date for receiving bids on an issue of $70,000,000 of veterans' bonus bonds. Dated Jan. 1, 1950, the bonds will come due Jan. 1, 1951 to 1974.

We are always in favor of fact-finding, and the more facts that are spread on the record in the dispute between the Transport Workers Union and the city's Board of Transportation the better. For the first time in recent years the board has, itself, developed for public scrutiny a complete set of facts to lay alongside the union's demands.

ALBANY, Dec. 20 -- Governor Dewey said today that 1950-51 appropriations for state departments and agencies would be reduced $2,000,000 as a step toward a balanced budget involving neither new nor increased taxes.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 20 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has announced plans for a film dealing with the birth and establishment of the State of Israel, to be titled "The Road." Allan Marcus will be dispatched to Palestine to gather material for the film, which will deal thematically with the building of a road in the pioneer country.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 21 (UP) -- The Soviet delegate walked out of the Four Power Allied Council for Japan today rather than answer Gen. Douglas MacArthur's charge that Russia is forcing thousands of Japanese prisoners into forced labor in Siberia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- One more American convicted of being a traitor to his country during World War II was ordered to prison today. Herbert John Burgman, former United States Embassy clerk in Berlin, was sentenced to serve six to twenty years in the Federal penitentiary at Lewisburg, Pa. He was accused of broadcasting for the Nazis from Germany.

The Museum of Modern Art is opening to the public today an exhibition which should prove a peculiarly admirable attraction for the holiday season. It is the largest exhibition of work by Paul Klee ever held in this country, with more than two hundred oils, water colors and black-and-whites by the prolific Swiss artist who was one of the outstanding figures in the modern movement.

LONDON, Dec 20 -- Price movements were irregular in most sections of the stock markets here today, where trading was quiet. Leaders in the industrials group generally maintained or slightly improved on yesterday's prices, but variations were narrow.
BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Republicans outnumber the Federalists eleven to five in the Cabinet of the United States of Indonesia, it was announced today.

Pittsburgh's mighty young batsman, Ralph Kiner, is revealed as the slugging champion of the National League by the miscellaneous figures, released today. In view of Kiner's fifty-four home runs, this should surprise nobody.

" Samson and Delilah," produced and directed by Cecil B. De Mille for Paramount, will have a dual premiere tonight at 8:30 at both the Rivoli and Paramount Theatres. Victor Mature and Hedy Lamarr, who appear in the title roles, head the cast of the Biblical drama, which was filmed in Technicolor.

Judging by what veterans say about how they will use their 1950 insurance dividends and on what they did with the "windfalls" of 1947 and 1948, the effect on retail sales of the forthcoming $2,800,000,000 dividend to 16,000,000 veterans is likely to be diffused over a good many months.

With a few deft flourishes of the pastry tube and a wealth of imagination, bakers have captured the holiday spirit. They've fashioned confections for Christmas tables that are as delightfully ornamental as they are delectable. Cakes, cookies, ice cream and candy are one group of last-minute purchases for which it will be fun to shop.
George Mamroth, former milionaire banker of Berlin, Germany, started life anew at the age of 54 at 5:30 A. M. yesterday as counterman in a Brooklyn luncheonette.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury decided today whether it should indict John Maragon, who once had a White House pass and who now is accused of lying to Congress. However, the jury's verdict will not be made public until Jan. 3.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The National Federation of American Shipping launched an attack today against Brig. Gen. F. K. Newcomer, Governor of the Panama Canal, for his advocacy of increased tolls. The rates will increase by 10 per cent next April 1 unless President Truman intervenes or Congress passes new legislation.

EUGENE MANLOVE RHODES, who became a cowboy when he was 13 years old and remained one for twenty-five years, never used to carry a gun. He carried books instead and read them on horseback. The literary education he thus acquired shows in his writings. No man ever wrote about the West with more authentic personal information.

Mortimer Landsberg, vice chairman of the New York Curb Exchange, has been nominated for the chairmanship of the board of governors for a one-year term, it was announced yesterday by Francis Adams Truslow, president of the exchange.

The Board of Estimate will consider at its meeting tomorrow the establishment of positions that would make possible the appointment of two assistants for William Reid, the incoming Deputy Mayor, it was learned yesterday.
HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 20 -- Senator-designate William Benton of Southport, Conn., today announced the appointment of Penn T. Kimball of New Britain as his executive secretary.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- Despite the strong help extended to the weakened Cabinet of Premier Georges Bidault through the massive deblocking by the United States of Marshall Plan counterpart funds, the disputed French budget remained in deadlock today in the National Assembly.

A heavy last minute spurt in holiday liquor purchases has resulted in an "impossible" delivery situation in the trade, liquor wholesalers reported here yesterday. Due to excessive caution on the part of retailers, wholesalers are being besieged by a series of small orders, in many instances less than case lots, and are having trouble making deliveries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Glen R. Law, presiding examiner of the Federal Power Commission, urged the commission today to deny the application of New York State for a license to develop a power project on the St. Lawrence River, in the international rapids section, in cooperation with the Province of Ontario.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 -- Vincent Hallinan, chief defense attorney, startled the court room at the Harry Bridges perjury-conspiracy trial today with a charge that two key Government witnesses had committed "deliberate perjury."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 20 -- Edward F. Burke of Providence, R. I., president of the Harvard Student Council, said today that last night's action by that body in adopting a resolution to ban discrimination for "race, color or nationality" in all college organizations was in line with a project for rewriting the rules governing extracurricular activity.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 20 -- The New York, Chicago and St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad will pay $200,000 to relatives of its former president, the late John W. Davin, it was disclosed today.

Orders issued last night by G. Joseph Minetti, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, stipulated a series of water conservation measures that must be followed by all pier owners and pier operators to reduce "to the absolute minimum" consumption on the city's waterfront.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 (UP) -- A half-century of time trickled through the fingers of Connie Mack today and, with his 87th birthday coming up, baseball's grandest tradition said his golden anniversary as manager of the Philadelphia Athletics promised to be his roughest and toughest.
SEATTLE, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Puget Sound Sportswriters and Sportscasters Association voted today to ask the Pacific Coast Conference to eliminate or modify basketball's two-minute rule immediately.

The fourth round of post-war increases in steel prices became industry-wide yesterday as the Bethlehem Steel Corporation and five other leading companies raised their prices. This step was in accordance with the pattern set last week by the United States Steel Corporation, the country's largest producer of steel and traditional pace-setter on prices.

Delayed twenty-four hours to relieve the strain on Sir Cedric Hardwicke's voice, as well as to have things letter-perfect, "Caesar and Cleopatra" will have its postponed opening this evening at the National. First-nighters are cautioned by the management to be in their seats at 8 o'clock, since latecomers will not be seated during the first scene.

BOSTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Undefeated Holy Cross recorded its sixth consecutive basketball victory tonight, skimming by a fighting University of Kansas team, 57 -- 53, in a close, exciting battle in which the score was tied eleven times.

Amid all the excitement today as the faithful celebrate Joseph Stalin's seventieth birthday, do many of them reflect, we wonder, that the master of the Kremlin is a perfect example of the old bourgeois adage, Life Begins at Forty?
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 20 (AP) -- The South squad served notice today it will be ready to match the North in punting when the two teams meet in the annual Shrine charity football game here Dec. 26.
The Sanitation Department reported yesterday that its manpower and equipment were ready to tackle the season's first big snowfall -- but without the use of water.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Renown II, making his Florida debut, turned in a scintillating performance as he sped to victory in the feature at Tropical Park today.
DES MOINES, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Frank Leahy was named today as football's man of the year by the Football Writers Association of America.

President Truman's action in prohibiting airplane flights into the roadless areas of the Superior National Forest in northeastern Minnesota is a wise and significant move. It is a triumph both for the devoted individuals who have been struggling for many years to preserve in its primitive state this unique wilderness and for the embattled forces of conservation in general.

Harry Bloom, whose name appeared on ballots for the office of the sophomore class in last week's student elections at the City College School of Business and Civic Administration, lost the election by four votes, in spite of the fact that no such student exists.

Advertising interests will give greater stress to a states' rights argument against a bill banning interstate transportation and radio broadcasting of liquor advertising at Senate hearings scheduled Jan. 12-13, it was learned yesterday. The measure, known as the Lariger bill, vfould bar :interstate movement of every conceivable media, including 'films, records and mail, if they carried liquor, beer or wine ads.

Maurice (The Rocket) Richard probably will have to work overtime tonight when the second-place Montreal Canadiens move into Madison Square Garden to tackle the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League battle.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Creation of a big national scholarship and loan program to provide educational opportunity through colleges and technical schools to students from low-income families was proposed to Congress today by Dr. Dewey Anderson, executive director of the Public Affairs Institute.

Station WMCA announced yesterday that its frequency modulation affiliate, WMCA-FM, would suspend operation on Dec. 30 because it had represented a monthly loss of $4,000. WMCA-FM will be the first New York station employing the new form of high-fidelity transmission to leave the air.

The tanker Atlantic Voyager and the steamship Exemplar collided late last night six miles east of Sandy Hook near the entrance to New York harbor. The extent of damage was not made clear in early reports from the Coast Guard. No one was injured.
Cheating in examinations was the subject of discussion between student and faculty members at a forum session yesterday at New York University's School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance

Hospitals were urged yesterday by the Hospital Council of Greater New York to find more places on their staffs for physicians now without hospital connections. In this way, it was said, they can contribute toward raising the standards of medical care in the city.

The Borden Company plans to spend $15,600,000 in 1950 on modernization, expansion and replacement of equipment. Theodore G. Montague, president, told stockholders in a letter mailed yesterday. No important new building projects are included, he said.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 20 -In an order of the day to the Yugoslav armed forces, which coincided with the mobilization in Moscow on the eve of Premier Joseph Stalin's seventieth birthday of Communist leaders subservient to the Communist Information Bureau, Marshal Tito urged tonight greater military preparedness and fighting efficiency upon all officers and Soldiers.

The recent buoyancy in prices of long-term Government bonds is undiminished as market for gilt edge investments enter the year-end slowdown. In the dealers' market yesterday new high record levels for the year were registered by eight of the longer-term issues ineligible for commercial bank purchase.

The grant of $23,500,000 to the Dutch for expansion and modernization of the Royal Dutch Blast Furnaces and Steel Company will form part of a $47,000,000 project intended to increase coverage of domestic needs of Holland for steel products from 25 per cent to 50 per cent, it was reported here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The White House announced today the resignation of Sidney W. Souers as executive secretary of the National Security Council and his replacement on Jan. 15 by his present assistant, James Selden Lay Jr.

Members of the ski fraternity, whose hopes fluctuate with the antics of the elements, still are looking "ski-ward" for snow and freezing temperatures to provide recreation and sport for the coming holiday period. At the present time the outlook is rather damp and mild with nary a spot on our "ski-map" reporting good conditions.

The week's third college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden will present St. John's against San Francisco in the headline attraction tonight. C. C. N. Y. and California clash in the 8 o'clock curtain-raiser.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21 -- A run-off election Dec. 28-31, at which right-wing candidates will oppose left-wingers, will determine the four top officers of Local 10 of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO.

Mesh stockings, once thought of as strictly utilitarian, can now be compared with some of the sheerest nylon hose. Gotham Hosiery has perfected this nylon mesh so that at a distance it is hardly visible to the naked eye. These are available in the high fashion shades as well as neutrals and with reinforced or sheer heel and toes.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 21 -- The possibility of peace between Israel and Jordan has reached an impasse on two vital points, although both are struggling hard to overcome them. One is Jordan's insistence on an outlet to the sea, with sovereignty over any corridor granted.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed quiet, 2 to 4 points net lower.

Charles R. Cox, a leading figure in the steel industry for many years, has resigned as president of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, to become president of the Kennecott Copper Corporation of New York on Jan. 1, it was announced jointly by the companies yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, reported with moderate optimism today on the progress of the mutual defense program for the non-Communist West.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- United States corporations in November publicly reported cash dividend payments of $190,800,000, a decline of 7 per cent from the $205,100,000 distributed in November of last year, the Department of Commerce reported today.
LANDSBERG, Germany, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Five of Hitler's junior lieutenants, including a general and the boss of the Nazi foreign organization, were released from the Landsberg war crimes prison today.

GENEVA, Dec. 21 -- Jewish refugees from Communist Shanghai now in European waters will be able to complete their long voyage to Israel as a result of a decision announced here today by the American Joint Distribution Committee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Import Advisory Committee of the Department of Commerce has recommended a comprehensive program of customs reform, including legislative and administrative changes, as a means of narrowing the gap between the dollar volume of United States exports and imports.

THIS is the season of the year when various standout performers in various sports gain particular recognition in one sphere or another. One of the latest to be so honored is Slammin' Sammy Snead, who has just been nominated as golf's "Player of the Year." It's been so long in coming that folks were beginning to wonder if it ever would arrive.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 21 (AP) -- National Steel Corporation today joined the parade of steel producers raising prices with Board Chairman Ernest T. Weir defending his industry against what he called a "very vicious attack by a couple of fellows in politics."
The month of November saw an increase over October of 1,059 cases and 2,374 persons needing public assistance, Raymond M. Hilliard, City Commissioner of Welfare, reported yesterday to Mayor O'Dwyer.
The New York State Temporary Commission on Rents urged yesterday that New York State's rent control laws be extended one year.

An elderly woman picked her way slowly to a desk in The Times Building late yesterday afternoon and left $4,000 for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, the largest contribution made during the day. Asked if she wanted a receipt for the forty $100 bills she had given, she said quietly: "No thank you, God will know what I am doing."

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- Once again the gift season brings precious stones in new settings at the jewelers and intriguing novelties in the boutiques, those fascinating shops on the ground floor of couture houses.
