WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Middle South Utilities, Inc., New York, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 640,000 shares of no par value common stock that is to be offered at competitive bidding. The terms of the offering are to be filed by amendment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- President Truman asked American communities today to make "special efforts" this Christmas to extend friendship and hospitality to service men and women who were away from home.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The National Labor Relations Board found today that a union could legally make and enforce agreements not to handle "struck work" or "hot cargo."

The New York City Housing Authority received bids yesterday on $32,282,000 of temporary-loan notes intended to help to finance three state-aided housing projects and bearing tax-exempt interest. The best bids for the various series of notes ranged in interest from 0.78 per cent to 0.74 per cent.
On an old-fashioned "play or pay" basis the Weimeraner seems to have emerged on top in the shooting dog challenge issued by a local Weimeraner fancier more than two months ago.
PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 21 (AP) -The man who managed Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's Presidential campaign in Oregon last year said today that Mr. Dewey had written him he would not run again.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 21 -- An attempt by the Eastern German Democratic Republic and its Russian sponsors to force recognition of the Communist-dominated republic upon the Western powers and the Bonn Government is considered "most likely" by United States officials here.

The Squadron A Regulars, a 13-goal team, scored a 14-to-8 victory over the 15-goal New York Athletic Club trio last night at the Squadron A Armory. The Squadron A Yellows beat the West Point Officers by 12 to 3 in the opener of the polo double-header.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Coach Bill Jeffrey today named fifteen players to carry Penn State colors against unbeaten University of San Francisco in the nation's first soccer bowl game at St. Louis New Year's Day.

Despite slack demand for toiletries and fragrance products during the early part of the holiday shopping period, trade sources estimated unofficially yesterday that toilet goods volume for 1949, excluding soap products, will be close to, if not slightly more than, the $749,800,000 total for 1948.
BERLIN, Dec. 21 -- Anti-Communists braved an East Berlin rally in honor of Marshal Stalin's seventieth birthday to drop bitter greetings to the Soviet leader.

A vacant plot of land 100 by 210 feet at the southeast corner of Nostrand Avenue and Avenue X in Brooklyn has been sold by Leah Schuster to the Brubrad Realty Corporation. Lyons Davis were attorneys for the buyer. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 21 -- A conspiracy "to deprive us of our rights" was charged today at a National Labor Relations Board hearing by David Scribner, general counsel for the United Electrical Workers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -The Congress of Industrial Organizations urged Congress today to give a $3,000 income tax exemption to married couples plus a $600 exemption for each dependent.

Since Sir Cedric Hardwicke is seriously handicapped with laryngitis, it is not fair to judge his performance in Shaw's "Caesar and Cleopatra," which was put on at the National last evening. Although the production is gorgeous and the performance is sound, it lacks lightness and sparkle.

The Italian Government's gold "Medal of Military Valor" was presented yesterday at City Hall to Mr. and Mrs. Vincenzo Berardinucci of 299 Sixth Street, Brooklyn. It was awarded in memory of their son, Renato, who was executed by a German firing squad in the Italian village of Aquila on June 11, 1944.

Christmas retail toy sales this year are not reaching the levels of last year, a survey of large toy departments here disclosed yesterday. Certain lines such as dolls, however, were reported to be in heavy demand as are numerous other low priced, good quality toys.

The refugee commuters who confessed madness and anger before the State Public Service Commission yesterday in the hearing on Grand Central Terminal's loudspeaker system have our sympathy. A psychiatrist gravely warned that these musical-commercial broadcasts were "enough to drive you nuts."

An original and basic issue of the unification fight, the establishment of a controversial "Fourth Service" within the Defense Department -- a service of supply -- has been settled by a memorandum signed last month by Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense.

PARIS, Dec. 21 -- The long struggle over France's 1950 budget is expected to come to a head late tomorrow. Premier Georges Bidault announced today that he would ask the National Assembly for a vote of confidence.

In an investment deal involving a large property in the vicinity of the site for the proposed new $25,000,000 Madison Square Garden at Columbus Circle, K. B. Weissman has purchased the three sevenstory apartment houses at 400 to 406 West Fifty-seventh Street, southwest corner of Ninth Avenue. Sigmund I. Natanson and Arthur Goldman, brokers, arranged the sale for the Durfox Realty Company, Joseph Durst, president.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 21 -- Lieut. Gen. Otmar Kreatchitch, head of the political department of the Yugoslav Army, announced tonight at the meeting commemorating the eighth anniversary of the founding of the present army that 652 anti-Yugoslav frontier incidents had been perpetrated by troops of the Cominform states between June 28, 1948, and Dec. 1, 1949.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Dec. 21 -- The bill transferring sovereignty over the Netherlands East Indies to the Indonesians became law tonight when it received royal assent from Queen Juliana. Earlier today the Senate had approved the transfer act by 34 votes to 15.

A new film projection condenser system which increases screen illumination 55 per cent has been developed by Harry Rubin, supervisor of projection at the Paramount Theatre, and now is being used there.

The City Rent Commission's jurisdictional right to control rents of permanent guests who compose less than three-quarters of a hotel's occupants was sustained yesterday by Magistrate Charles E. Ramsgate.

The Government's forecast of the size of next year's winter wheat yield indicates another crop in excess of a billion bushels, despite the 15 per cent reduction in acreage. With farmers sowing their best lands to wheat, the indicated yield of 885,000,000 bushels from the winter crop, if weather is normal to harvest time, would mean a production substantially in excess of normal.

BOSTON, Dec. 21 -- Frederic C. Dumaine assumed today, for a second time, the presidency of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad following a meeting of the board of directors. He will continue to serve also as chairman of the board.

Confidence increased sharply in the fur industry yesterday that the 20 per cent Federal excise tax is likely to be eliminated or reduced in the coming year. This was predicated on the reported decision of President Truman to recommend repeal of certain wartime excise taxes, although the Chief Executive did not specifically mention the fur levy.

LONDON, Dec. 21 (Reuters) -The De Havilland Aircraft Company announced today that the Canadian Pacific Airlines Company of Montreal will buy two de Havilland jet Comet aircraft for use on its Vancouver to Hong Kong service.

The Ralston Purina Company, manufacturer of animal feeds and breakfast cereals, reported new high records for sales and earnings in its fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, in its annual statement issued yesterday.

In Moscow yesterday the Communist leaders celebrated the seventieth birthday of Josef Stalin by apotheosizing the Generalissimo of the Communist world revolution as omnipotent and infallible. They did so for one reason because they are Stalin's vassals, enjoying their own power and even their very lives only by grace of Stalin's will or whim.
Wirt H. Hatcher has been elected a director of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc. He succeeds J. E. Archbell, who has reached retirement age and will retire also as a director.

With their own Christmas packages still unopened under the tree, New York Girl Scouts already are making New Year's plans for sending gifts overseas in their International Friendship project for 1950.
Andrew W. Mulrain took over his duties yesterday as Commissioner of Sanitation. He succeeded William J. Powell, who retired after forty-three years of service in the department.

It usually happens on one of those peaceful days when there is a good book to be read, or music to be listened to, or a well-earned nap to be enjoyed. Someone suggests that the attic needs to be cleaned.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Dec. 21 -Army registered its second victory of the season today downing Ithaca College, 45 to 41, in a loosely played game in the Academy field house.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- In the hushed atmosphere of Arlington National Cemetery President Truman declared today that a strong national defense and alliance with democracies abroad would be our steadfast policy while the threat of aggression hung over the world.

The only book published today is an enlarged edition of "Old English Porcelain: A Handbook for Collectors," by W. B. Honey. The book, which has been out of print in the United States for several years, was originally published in England in 1928.

Christmas Eve mass as observed in the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem will be carried in a two hour "live" broadcast Saturday at 4:30 P. M. by WHOM. The program, originating on the site where Christ was born, will be relayed to WHOM here by the shortwave facilities of RCA Communications, Inc.

Another sizable part of last week's advance was surrendered yesterday by the stock market as prices repeated the approximate inroads of Tuesday with the composite index rate down 0.63 point further. The continued setback again was accomplished on moderate selling and any rallying attempt proved half-hearted and failed to follow through.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 21 -- A spokesman for the Israeli delegation said today his Government might challenge the right of the United Nations Trusteeship Council to ask Israel to remove from Jerusalem governmental departments recently shifted there from Tel Aviv.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Miami City Commissioners today found themselves with 1,000 tickets to the Orange Bowl football game between Kentucky and Santa Clara on Jan. 2 -- and turned them down.
Word must have got around last night that Augusta Romani was a pianist of uncommon merit for Town Hall was remarkable well filled for a debut recital.

The world's largest corporate enterprise, the $10,000,000,000 American Telephone and Telegraph Company, yesterday set in motion plans for raising $200,000,000 through a non convertible debenture offering scheduled for competitive bidding on Jan. 31, 1950.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 -- There is enough work yet to be done in mechanizing and electrifying farms to keep the country's economy running at top speed for years to come, Dr. P. D. Sanders, master of the Virginia State Grange, said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 21 -Dorothy Lamour today filed suit against RKO-Radio Pictures in the Federal Court here for declaratory release and judication of a contractural dispute arsing out of her suspension from salary by the studio last Oct. 17 because of approaching motherhood.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Hungary's Communist-led government demanded today that the United States return Hungarian goods that the Nazis allegedly looted in 1944.

PARIS, Dec. 21 -- Five years after France was freed from Nazi occupation, the Cabinet today approved a bill to amnesty, either automatically or by special decree, certain persons still serving prison terms for collaboration with the Germans. The bill must now be approved by Parliament.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, Dec. 21 -- The Labor party of William Alexander Bustamante suffered losses in a Parliamentary election of this British colony yesterday, but again is assured of a working majority.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 21 -- The development of an independent water supply system by Westchester County would not be economically advisable at this time, James C. Harding, county commissioner of public works and water works coordinator, said this afternoon.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Dec. 21 -- Pollution of Long Island Sound here should be ended in three years by a sanitation program to be started soon, Mayor Stanley W. Church said this afternoon.

On Dec. 17, 1949, THE NEW YORK TIMES reported that "Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, has personally rebuked Miss May A. Quinn, Brooklyn public school teacher, for making 'ill-considered statements' about Negroes. He cleared her, however, of any intention 'to offend the Negro people or to justify discrimination.'"

HARTSDALE, N. Y., Dec. 21 -So ill at her home here that no birthday celebration is being planned for her, Gen. Evangeline Cory Booth, retired international commander of the Salvation Army, gave hope to others today, when she said that she had faith in the peoples of the world "to know what is right and best."

Four films will arrive in midtown theatres today. At Loew's State the attraction is "East Side, West Side," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer romantic drama with Barbara Stanwyck, James Mason, Ava Gardner and Van Heflin. Mervyn LeRoy directed and Voldemar Vetluguin produced from an adaptation of the Marcia Davenport novel.

Federal Attorney Thomas F. Murphy brought out yesterday a discrepancy in the testimony of Alger. Hiss when he began cross-examination of the defendant on the twenty-third day of his second trial on two counts of perjury.

Piling up a three-goal lead before the first period ran out, the New York Rangers carved out a victory over the Canadiens of Montreal at Madison Square Garden last night. The Blue Shirts could tack only one more tally to their first period splurge, but this just proved more than enough.
The City Planning Commission approved yesterday an amendment to the Zoning Regulation permitting renting garage space in private dwellings to non-tenants if the space is not required by tenants.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 21 -- Frau Schmidt, given to reminiscing of the old days, could not help marveling at all the people in the shops and all the things for sale this Christmas season. It was really like the old days.

Proof of American competence in the field of jet engines is to be found in the disclosure of the new turbo-prop engine, XT40, developed for the United States Navy by the Allison Division of General Motors. With thrust equivalent to 5,500 horsepower, this new engine is of relatively small size and frontal area.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- Arrangements for the coming general election in Britain were discussed today by the chiefs of the Labor party at a meeting of the party's National Executive Committee. Prime Minister Attlee, who has the duty of deciding the election date, participated in the discussions.

DETROIT, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings went on a scoring spree tonight as they whipped the Toronto Maple Leafs, 7--1, in a National Hockey League game before 12,310 fans. Montreal's loss to New York increased Detroit's league lead to 10 points.
Directors of the Air Reduction Company approved yesterday a plan to simplify the corporate structure of the company in a move to consolidate activities and increase operating efficiency.

The resignation of Dr. Frank A. Calderone as director of the New York office of the World Health Organization to accept appointment as executive director of the New York City Cancer Committee was announced yesterday.

Senator Vandenberg has now thrown the weight of his authority behind the movement to send chiefs of diplomatic missions back to Madrid. The problem is simple enough, although not so simple as many Congressmen, Army generals and other interested parties seem to think.

TOKYO, Dec. 21 -- The Diet's all-powerful lower house tonight passed by a narrow margin the Administration bill calling for the payment to Government employes of heavily reduced year-end bonuses -- the focus of the recent labor unrest throughout Japan.

Jacques Stern, a retired French banker who was a member of the Chamber of Deputies for twenty-two years and served as a Cabinet member, died in a fall at 8:15 A. M. yesterday from a ninth-floor bedroom of his apartment at 941 Park Avenue.

LONDON, Dec. 21 (UP) -- The Committee for International Socialist Conferences tonight accused the Cominform of "openly fomenting war." The committee said the Soviet Union was using more of its resources for military purposes than any other country.
Merger of Blair Co., Inc., and E. H. Rollins Sons, Inc., two of the nation's oldest investment banking concerns, was agreed upon yesterday after several weeks of negotiations.

Warner Brothers Pictures confirmed yesterday reports that the company was working with the Department of Justice for a consent decree removing it from the Government's 11-year-old anti-trust suit against the motion picture industry.

DETROIT, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Outfielder Dick Wakefield, who was traded to the New York Yankees Saturday by the Detroit Tigers, today issued a three-page letter to the press in which he blamed himself for failure to live up to expectations during his career with the Tigers.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week increased 2,344,000 barrels, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. At the weekend they amounted to 108,490,000 barrels, compared with 106,146,000 a week earlier and 98,225,000 a year ago.

The 1950 budget on Van Heusen shirts will be increased over advertising expenditures for the current year of more than $1,000,000, Seymour J. Phillips, president of the Phillips-Jones Corporation, said yesterday at a luncheon session of the three-day sales convention the company is holding at the Statler Hotel.

In an interview published in THE TIMES on Dec. 8 the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, Senator McCarran, emphasized that "living conditions of the displaced persons are far better than living conditions of the average inhabitant of many areas in the United States."
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Public sales of 6,000 tickets to the Rose Bowl football game on Jan. 2 will begin at 12:45 P. M. (Eastern Standard Time) tomorrow at the Rose Bowl.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 14:

Coffee futures were active yesterday with prices moving erratically on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. In early dealings prices were steady to slightly higher on trade demand. Later, commission house selling, along with long liquidation from producer interests, found support lacking and prices declined the daily permissible limit of 200 points.

Two hundred boys and girls from the Society for Seamen's Children were entertained yesterday afternoon by the Maritime Association of the Port of New York at its annual Christmas party at the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street. Several professional entertainers were on hand, most of them through the courtesy of the Police Athletic League, to amuse the youngsters.

Judge Dorothy Kenyon is a shining example of the role qualified women can play in the United Nations organization. There are not enough women in the General Assembly or on the commissions which deal with broad human interests, and the lack is emphasized by the outstanding service performed by the few who are represented.
Ray J. Miller has been named manager of the research engineering department of the Dearborn Motors Corporation, national marketing organization for the Ford tractor and farm equipment.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 21 -Ecuador became the first Latin-American country today to formally ratify the United Nations Convention on Genocide, which outlaws as an international crime the mass extermination of racial, religious, ethnic and political groups.
HOBOKEN, Dec. 21 -- Completing her first trip on the Copenhagen-New York run, the motorship Erria of the East Asiatic Company, Ltd., arrived at the Eighth Street pier here late this afternoon.

Theme of the State Racing Commission's annual report, a 64-page recital of facts, figures and opinions released for publication today, is that the running-horse business in New York is burdened with excessive taxation.
CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins escaped the National Hockey League's basement tonight by defeating the Chicago Black Hawks, 4 to 1, before 11,212 fans.

The New York Produce Exchange has obtained a first mortgage loan of $1,000,000 at 3 3/4 per cent for ten years from the Equitable Life Assurance Society on its block-front property on Broadway between Stone and Beaver Streets and through to Broad Street, according to King Walker, brokers, who arranged the financing.

Plans for the redevelopment of Forty-second Street from First to Second Avenue as part of the East Side improvement of the United Nations area were announced yesterday by Borough President Hugo E. Rogers of Manhattan. The cost will be $1,848,000.

STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 21 -Hidden away in the hills of Connecticut a small, select group of eight student-priests is being prepared to carry the Gospel of Christ to fellow-Christians behind Europe's Iron Curtain.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- President Truman received today a report on the current economic situation and recommendations on what should be done about the national economy in 1950 as he continued conferences with officials in preparation for the opening of Congress on Jan. 3.

ROME, Dec. 21 -- Gay and apparently carefree crowds of shoppers throng the central streets of Rome as the most uninhibited Christmas spending spree of any year since the outbreak of World War II draws to its close.

Christmas is spoken in many languages in this melting-pot of a city. Yuletide may mean goose or dried cod, rice pudding or eel, pork pie or octopus. Everything must be as it has been before at family feasts, whether before was in Italy, Poland or Denmark.

That headline over a one-paragraph story in our news columns yesterday records the belated but commendable willingness of the taxpayers of Union School District 13 of South Huntington, L. I., to undertake the financial burden of a new elementary school. We comment on this action, taken at a special election, to complete the record on what had become, in a small way, a somewhat celebrated case.

Capt. Patrick Brennan, USNR, who retired last year as chief engineer of the America, the country's largest liner, has returned to the world of shipping to act as a consultant with the United States Lines and Gibbs Cox, naval architects and engineers, in the building of the new superliner.
MADRID, Dec. 21 -- The Spanish Cortes approved tonight the 1950 budget, which totals about 18,000,000,000 pesetas, with a prospective deficit of about 200,000,000 pesetas.
TOKYO, Dec. 21 (UP) -- Russian Lieut. Gen. Kuzma M. Derevyanko in a letter to Gen. Douglas MacArthur today charged him with permitting the Japanese to suppress democracy through "police club law."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 (AP) -The Philadelphia Athletics made it known today they have no intention of giving up Phil Marchildon to the New York Yankees if the one-time Canadian swifty's right arm is ready for baseball duty.

Charles Weidman's "Rose of Sharon" had its world premiere at the City Center last night in the New York City Dance Theatre's season, along with the only appearance of Eve Gentry in a pair of her own solos, and repetition of other choreographers' works from earlier programs in the series.

Hundreds of youngsters were entertained, stuffed with sweets and deluged with toys yesterday as the round of Christmas parties continued in scores of hospitals, schools, parks and other institutions and places.
ROME, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Italy has plans for building 170,000 tons of ships.
The conspiracy and espionage trial of Judith Coplon and Valentin A. Gubitchev, which had been set for next Tuesday, was postponed yesterday, probably until the new year.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 21 (AP) -- With Art Sullivan scoring three I goals in the final period, the Grand] Rapids Rockets defeated the To-I !lecTo Buckeyes 6---0, tonight in an Eastern Hockey League game be-I fore 3,000 fans.

A United States Maritime Commission Certificate of Merit was presented yesterday morning to Clarence D. Mercer, superintendent of the Hudson River Reserve Fleet, for perfecting a water blast method of scaling vessels' hulls that saved $230,000 in a year's operation.

An investor purchased from Westchester Realty Management, Inc., the two-story store and apartment building on plot 120 by 70 feet at 1 to 13 North Chatsworth Avenue, Larchmont, N. Y., in a deal negotiated by Byrne, Bowman and Forshay, brokers.

Garson Kanin, whose "Born Yesterday" is approaching the four-year mark on the Broadway stage, is the author of "The Rat Race," which makes its local debut this evening at 8 o'clock at the Barrymore Theatre.

A bill to provide for the planning and, in case of emergency, for the execution of civilian defense measures will be presented to the Legislature when it meets next month. This was announced yesterday by Assemblyman Frank J. Becker, Republican, of Lynbrook, L. I.

BOSTON, Dec. 21 -- Calling attention to a "reawakening of maritime ambition" by the Russians, Admiral Forrest P. Sherman, Chief of Naval Operations, asserted today that "our outstanding superiority over the Russian fleet lies in our carrier force."

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- Britain's Christmas shopping spree is almost over and weary shop girls are turning their thoughts to the three-and-a-half-day holiday that will descend on the nation Saturday afternoon.
The officials working the Georgie Kaplan-Duilio Spagnolo heavyweight battle last night at the St. Nicholas Arena must have been overcome with the true Christmas spirit.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 -- Coincident with retail coal price rises and reports of dwindling railroad stockpiles, the National Retail Coal Association, in the fifth of a series of messages to the White House, today told the President:

Governor Dewey again criticized the Democratic city administration yesterday "for delaying so long in taking any steps to meet the water emergency" and called a conference of state and city officials for this afternoon at 2:30 at the Roosevelt Hotel here.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The pre-holiday atmosphere brought a further contraction of business in the London stock markets today, and prices moved irregularly. Industrials were somewhat weaker than yesterday, but British Government securities improved.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -Rent controls were lifted today in six New York State areas.

A syndicate headed by Peter Feinberg has sold the one-story taxpayer building on a plot 75 by 00 feet at 3205-11 Bainbridge Avenue, near 206th Street, in the Bronx, to Max and Philip Marcus, builders of apartments in the borough for the past thirty years who now have acquired their first store property there.
Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson last night defied critics of his methods in carrying out the program for unification of the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, confident but still obviously in delicate health, called today for economy in the 1950 foreign aid budget, but emphasized that "the greatest of all economy in lives and dollars is to stop another war before it starts or to win it if it comes."

Christmas mail has set a record of more than $1,000,000 in stamp and postal card receipts for one day in New York post offices, Postmaster Albert Goldman reported yesterday. The record was established in the twenty-four-hour period ended at midnight Tuesday.
Rough play around second base is outlawed in the new official baseball rules adopted yesterday for the 1950 season after nine months of work.

In all the years that the St. Paul's School of Concord, N. H., has been playing its annual hockey game at Madison Square Garden, no opponent had tallied more than two goals in a game -- until yesterday.

TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 22 (AP) -Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today he had asked the United States Government to seek the aid of a neutral nation to investigate the condition of Japanese war prisoners held by the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Republican domestic policy leader of the Senate, asserted today that this country was now rich enough that for the first time it might be possible to "eliminate extreme hardship and poverty."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UP) -The Government's program for buying 1949-crop cottonseed to support prices will end on Feb. 15, instead of on Dec. 31, as originally scheduled, the Department of Agriculture announced today.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 21 -The Bogota newspapers Liberal and Tiempo, in editorial comments on the visit next month of George F. Kennan of the State Department and the meeting of the American diplomats accredited to other American countries, today foresaw a new era in relations between the United States and Latin America.

John W. Hooper, executive and ,trustee of the Lincoln Savings I Bank of Brooklyn has been named president and Fred Gretsch, formerly president, is to be chairman lof the board. Mr. Gretsch, a trus, tee for thirty-one years, had been president since 1940.

Helena Braun, who came to this country just to be with her husband, Ferdinand Frantz, while he made his debut last week at the Metropolitan Opera, made her own debut there last night. She sang in no less difficult a role than that of Bruennhilde in "Die Walkuere," and did so at four hours' notice.

MOSCOW, Dec. 21 -- In a special article written for Pravda on the occasion of Premier Stalin's seventieth birthday, Politburo member Georgi M. Malenkov today emphatically recalled Mr. Stalin's declaration that capitalism and socialism could live together peaceably for a lengthy time.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -The Government announced today that it will support producer prices of eggs in 1950 at a national average of 37 cents a dozen. This means, officials of the Department of Agriculture said, that consumer prices next year may average 8 to 10 cents a dozen less than this year's prices.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 -- General selling developed in all grains on the Board of Trade today and with stop-loss orders uncovered, the close was about the bottom. Wheat lost 2 1/8 to 2 1/2 cents a bushel, corn, 1 1/4 to 2 3/8 cents; oats, 1 1/4 to 1 7/8 cents; rye, 3 3/4 to 4 3/4 cents with May at a new low for the year, while soybeans broke 3 to 3 1/4 cents.

GENEVA, Dec. 21 -- The continuance of agricultural policies now in vogue in Europe and the United States will greatly worsen the already serious unbalance in the world economy in the opinion of a growing number of economists studying basic world economic trends.

Many dinner parties were given before the Post-Debutante ball in behalf of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. The event, arranged for debutantes of recent seasons, featured a waltz contest and a "Cavalcade of the Dance," illustrating the various steps that have been popular during the last twenty years.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- The French Parliament endorsed the Petersberg agreement on West Germany by a comfortable majority, and it is fair to say that this decision represents the broad sweep of French opinion.
VIENNA, Dec. 21 -- It seems likely that President Arpad Szakasits of Hungary will come close to winning the southeastern European championship for the oratorical deification of Soviet Premier Stalin.
OBERLIN, Ohio, Dec. 21 -Earl Newsom, New York public relations counsel, has been named a trustee of Oberlin College, William E. Stevenson, president, announced today.

WROCLAW (Breslau), Dec. 21 -- The Polish Government brought its case against the six defendants charged with espionage on behalf of the French intelligence to a climax today by presenting six witnesses who supported the main indictment.

The Constitution awards Congress the power to lay and collect taxes to provide for the general welfare of the United States. Therefore all promotions of general welfare must be for the benefit of all the people of the United States and our posterity. We cannot do it by non-uniform extortion from the producers to feed the drones, and I wonder how we can mysteriously promote a general welfare by injuring more people than are benefited.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Coach Wes Fesler of Ohio State had two matters of importance on his agenda today.

PARIS, Dec. 21 -- French housewives this week were crowding into Parisian shops and stores in the first Christmas shopping rush that has been seen under the auspices of abundance for the past ten years.

HONOLULU, Dec. 21 -- Twenty-six Hawaiian cane-sugar plantations and International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, reached an agreement today after ten months of negotiations on a new long-term contract. It will run until Aug. 31, 1951, and cover about 20,000 sugar workers in the territory.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Psychologists, pollsters, politicians, press men and just plain people are unusually active these days in search of a postulate which will fully account for the abiding Democratic successes in national elections since 1932. Some have concluded the answer is to be found in the personality of Franklin D. Roosevelt and its projection.

At least fifteen Roman Catholic schools in Jerusalem, Nazareth and other cities in Israel have introduced the teaching of Hebrew, it was announced yesterday by Benjamin G. Browdy, acting president of the Zionist Organization of America.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The Cunard Steamship Company, Ltd., announced today that it would soon take over Atlantic steamship operations now conducted by its wholly - owned subsidiary, Cunard White Star, Ltd. The move is described as a purely internal arrangement to simplify operations and accountancy and as having no bearing on dividend policy.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- Basic differences still exist between British and United States long-range policies on Germany's merchant marine, according to information now available here. These differences seem to have been accentuated in the last month since publication of the Anglo-American-French agreement giving the Germans wide latitude to build ships.

The American Velvet Company, owned and operated by A. Wimpfheimer Brothers, Inc., has distributed 30 per cent of annual profits to its 358 employes. The share is 26.25 per cent of annual earnings for every employe. Checks equaled 17.5 per cent of annual wages paid and 8.75 per cent of annual wages was deposited to a pension trust fund.

ALBANY, Dec. 21 -- Governor Dewey, in a Christmas message to the people of the state today, expressed hope that both children and adults would exercise unusual care to avoid accidents at home and on the highways.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21 -Testimony that Communist party leaders had cleared the way for expulsion of Harry Bridges in the fall of 1941, if he defied party orders, was offered by a Government witness and ridiculed by the defense at the longshore leader's perjury-conspiracy trial today.
Charming artificial trees, as well as aids and suggestions for lessening fire hazards from real ones, are plentiful this year to help preserve life, property and water.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Mrs. S. G. Steckler's Bashful Sun won the sixth race at Tropical Park today in one of the most exciting finishes seen at the meeting.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's address today at the dedication of the carillon at Arlington National Cemetery:

AN appeal to posterity is a tricky business at best, since posterity, sizzling in its own embroilments, seldom feels any overwhelming duty to do justice to the past. Yesterday's geniuses can turn out to be tomorrow's pains in the neck. And, as you know, the books that seemed pretty wonderful to you at the end of one decade may, at the end of another, spectacularly different, decade, fill you mainly with rugged disdain.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 21 -- Ambassador Loy W. Henderson, in his first important speech since returning from the United States, took the occasion tonight to talk on numerous Indian impressions of United States policy that have irritated him and other Americans here for some time.

The President's short speech at Arlington yesterday was appropriate to the occasion and to the setting. He had come to accept on the nation's behalf a carillon dedicated to our war dead, and in their presence he explained why it is that we, who so deeply desire peace, now arm ourselves again against the possibility of war.

DETROIT, Dec. 21 -- The Federal Government today stepped into the investigation of an attempt to blow up headquarters of the United Auto Workers, CIO. The union, seeking to "end a campaign of terror," raised to $245,000 the rewards offered for the dynamite plotters and for gunmen who have shot two top UAW officers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- David E. Lilienthal denied today that he would seek the Democratic Senatorial nomination in Wisconsin next year.

Consumer savings showed little change between 1946 and 1948, according to an analysis of post-war savings patterns, released yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board. Post-war fluctuations, it was found, arose primarily from differing amounts of income plowed back into unincorporated businesses and farms.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Western Europe will be looking to United States surpluses for about a third of its food requirements after 1952 despite a "dramatic improvement" in farm production and a prospective further increase of 15 per cent in the next two years.

TOKYO, Dec. 20 -- Allocation controls on sixty key industrial materials are due to go on Jan. 1, according to reports in Japanese circles here today. The move will virtually halve the list of controlled items.

Unit sales of men's clothing failed to show the hoped-for revival during the third quarter of this year, according to figures released jointly yesterday by the market planning service of the National Credit Office and the business information division of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The St. Louis Bombers treated 1,950 fans to an easy 75-to-52 victory over the New York Knickerbockers in the second game of a National Basketball Association doubleheader tonight.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Mayor of New York and his bride cruised through blue-green waters off Key Largo today on a leisurely yachting honeymoon.

HARTFORD, Dec. 21 -- Governor Chester Bowles tonight declared an "emergency" exists in the state on unemployment compensation and indicated he may call a special session of the General Assembly to extend the period of payments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Britain was informed officially today of the United States Government's concern over the projected British curb on dollar oil imports and its hope that some adjustment could be made to lessen the impact on United States oil companies that have been supplying Britain.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Drills and other training for Army Reserves, both enlisted and officer, will be curtailed sharply starting Jan. 1, it was learned today. A directive to this effect was approved by the Department of the Army Monday and is being sent to Reserve commanders throughout the country.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Because it needs more coal to carry on operations, the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad today decided upon the drastic step of confiscating coal in transit on its lines.
New York City's industrial users of water, both large and small, were asked yesterday to reduce their consumption some 200,000,000 gallons a day.

ROME, Dec. 22 -- The apparent Communist attempt to sabotage the inauguration of the Holy Year Saturday by holding a meeting of farm laborers at the Colosseum at the same time that Pope Pius XII is to open the Holy Door under the portico of Saint Peter's was countered today by the Italian Ministry of the Interior, which ordered Rome's police chief to ban the gathering.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad announced today that it would move the offices of some subsidiary companies to newly leased quarters in suburban Ardmore.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The United States has conceded Britain's right to send her own military equipment outside the North Atlantic treaty area while at the same time receiving United States arms for the common defense of the North Atlantic area, it was reliably reported here today.
LONDON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Antarctic whaling season opened today with more than 100 ships of six nations hunting for 16,000 blue whales.

Industrial buyers reported yesterday that the "tightest" market in bituminous coal in many months has appeared and executives in some plants are now "screaming for shipments." Coal in the hands of dealers was actively bought by railroads, utilities and steel companies.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 22 -- Gov. Forrest Smith said today that members of the Communications Workers of America, CIO, employed by the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company in Missouri, came under the state's King-Thompson act. It prohibits strikes against public utilities.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 22 -- Higher industrial production and a moderate increase in the volume of trade last week boosted the level of business in the Pittsburgh district to the best level since the end of May, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.
The Board of Estimate approved yesterday the creation of six new administrative positions and the promotion of 367 civil service employes, adding a total of $172,260 to the city's annual payroll.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- President Truman wound up a busy day today with a reception for about 300 members of the White House staff and then packed for an early departure tomorrow to spend Christmas in his home at Independence, Mo.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Maj. Gen. James B. Cress, commanding general of the Eightieth Airborne Division (Reserve), will take over the post of executive for Reserve and ROTC affairs of the Army on Jan. 1, succeeding Brig. Gen. Wendell Westover.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 22 -At noon today the Earl Carroll Theatre was sold at auction on a bid of $1,025,000 submitted by a corporation counting on the services of the producer, Gene Mann.

From all reports, the need for saving precious water will be a problem for homemakers for many months -- maybe even years -- to come. The luxury of washing clothes with huge quantities of water and mountains of suds will have to be postponed in every home.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The United Gas Corporation, Shreveport, La., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $25,000,000 of first-mortgage and collateral-trust bonds due on Jan. 1, 1970.
WASHINGTON, Dec, 22 (AP) -The Atomic Energy Commission has ordered a two-month examination of its security division, which protects the country's' atomic secrets and properties.

The Christmas spirit literally shines through the windows at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, From 168th Street west of Broadway snow men, Christmas angels and hand-painted Santa Clauses look down from many of the center's 8,000 windows, just as they do from many another hospital in the city.
Harvard's chess players, here for the annual meeting of the C. H. Y. P. College Chess League, were no match for the well-trained experts of Columbia at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Mrs. Eugenie Anderson, United States Ambassador, and her husband, John, are all set now for the diplomatic life in Denmark. They were received by the Royal Family today.

Your editorial of Dec. 17 on the occasion of the seventy-fifth birthday of Alvin Johnson, president emeritus of the New School for Social Research and its active director in 1922-45, is especially appreciated by me personally because of my long years of friendship with that great American and my awareness of the contribution he has made to the cause of liberal democracy.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Billie Bye of the University of Minnesota and Art Donovan of Boston College have been elected co-captains of the North team which plays in the all-star charity football game Dec. 26 in the Orange Bowl.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The formation of a Radiological Health branch of the Public Health Service to plan the control of radiation hazards was announced today by the Federal Security Agency.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration ruled today that it had a right to pay higher college tuition rates for veterans than colleges are legally permitted to charge.

MADRID, Dec. 22 -- Spain's highest authorities have promised special facilities to United States business men willing to bring capital into Spain, Col. Richmond Harris, United States trade expert, said today as he left Madrid for Rome after conferences with Generalissimo Francisco Franco and other Spanish leaders.

The shipping industry is concerned about a Brazilian decree, due to take effect on Jan. 1, which would put the carrying of cargo to that country on a freight collect basis and involve steamship lines in long exchange procedure before payment is actually made, it was learned yesterday

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 22 -Claudette Colbert will make her debut as a screen director next summer under a deal she has signed with Jack Skirball and Bruce Manning, independent producers at RKO, Skirball announced today.

The color that is soaring to fashion heights on the resort-wear scene is black. Singled out by the French couture and long a favorite of South American women famed for their style sense, it has cast its shadow on beach and play togs, on crisp linens and piques for day and night.

ALEXANDRIA. Va., Dec. 22 (UP) -- Erick Rios Bridoux, sole survivor of history's worst airplane crash, today disclaimed "any responsibility whatsoever" for the two-plane collision in which fifty-five persons were killed here Nov. 1.

A sensational second half, during which they better than doubled the opposition's point production, brought the Redmen of St. John's a 60-44 victory over San Francisco last night at Madison Square Garden. The slightly favored visiting Dons, having rallied from an early 8-point deficit to a 27-24 edge at the intermission, were run into the boards by the spectacular Brooklynites throughout the last twenty minutes.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 (AP) -The lean, lively old gent was talking on his favorite subject and there was a special glint in his eye, a sort of golden anniversary glint.

The performance of Richard Strauss' opera, "Elektra," given last night in concert form by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, with assisting soloists under Dimitri Mitropoulos, at Carnegie Hall must be recorded as one of the legendary musical events in the history of the city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- President Truman expressed optimism today over the business outlook as the year ends, but he would not go into details on this or on the preview of the State of the Union Message that he gave his Cabinet this morning.

PARIS, Dec. 21. (UP) -- The importance of curves and other Greek influences on women's fashions soon will be shown in the United States, Mrs. Henry Grady, wife of the United States Ambassador to Greece, has revealed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that the International Typographical Union, AFL, violated the Taft-Hartley act in its demands on twenty-two commercial printing shops in Baltimore.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Dec. 22 (AP) -- An Air Force B-50 Bomber, trailing sheets of flame, plummeted into an old rice paddy tonight, killing all eleven crewmen.

OTTAWA, Dec. 22 -- Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent issued today a proclamation making Canada's Supreme Court the final appeal tribunal of the land. Previously, Canada's final court of appeal in civil matters had been the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in London, supreme court of the British Empire.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Dec. 22 -- Nazem el Kodsi, deputy chief of the People's party and Foreign Minister of the present interim Government, has undertaken to form a new provisional Cabinet under the legislative and executive authority granted by Provisional President Hashem al-Atassi for the period of the debates in the Constituent Assembly on the new constitution.

WROCLAW (Breslau), Dec. 22 -- Defense lawyers asked a military court here today to pass mild sentences upon six defendants charged with conducting espionage for French intelligence, contending the trial had shown that they were only pawns in the service of Anglo-American imperialism.

The United Parents Associations was greatly interested in the story by Murray Illson in your newspaper, reporting that the Superintendent of Schools was able to find teachers to fill virtually all positions in the elementary school system provided in the budget, and to engage an adequate number of substitutes to fill day to day absences.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 22 -- A transit union strike was called early today and hundreds of thousands of residents were forced to walk, hitchhike or take taxis to work.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 22 -- The United Nations Commission on Korea today quietly told the Korean people that the doors of its headquarters and of its members homes still stood open to those who wished to get in touch with it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that a union of farm workers cannot be prosecuted under the Taft-Hartley Act because it is not a "labor organization" as defined by the law.

TOKYO, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Two hundred sad-eyed Japanese drifted away from their bonfires at the gates of the Soviet Embassy tonight without finding out what had happened to relatives captured by the Russians during the war.

A letter arrived yesterday at the home of Gilbert Pike, at 400 Eighth Street, Brooklyn, telling him to report today for his old job as a rigger at the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn. He had been laid off two months ago. But the 52-year-old father of eight children, 6 to 24, never learned of the letter.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., announced yesterday a proposed expansion of its present pension plan that would pay minimum benefits of $100 a month to its 75,000 employes on retirement at the age of 65.

Between 500 and 700 car washers will be laid off on Jan. 1 unless the ban on the use of water in that business is rescinded, the Metropolitan Garage Board of Trade told leaders of the Garage Washers and Polishers Local 272, AFL, yesterday.

Norman (Bud) Poile is beyond question the Bobo Newsom of the National Hockey League in the light of a trade that developed yesterday. The burly right-winger was sold by the New York Rangers to the Boston Bruins for an undisclosed amount of cash and the rights to a player still in the amateur ranks.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 22 -- Vladimir Dedijer, Director of Information, said today that the Yugoslav Government was preparing to take necessary action against the Hungarian Government for refusing to pay to Yugoslavia $70,000,000 in war reparations agreed upon in the Hungarian peace treaty.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The award of a commission to Kalervo Kallio, a Finnish sculptor, to execute a bronze memorial bust of the late James Forrestal, the first Secretary of Defense, was announced today. The bust will be placed at an entrance to the Pentagon.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 22 (AP) -Roving pickets today attempted to stop coal shipments into Pittsburgh by force.
Holiday travel began a slow rise yesterday toward a peak which is expected late this afternoon.

PARIS, Dec. 22 -- In an effort to end the French political conflict, Premier Georges Bidault interrupted debate on the 1950 budget tonight and demanded a vote of confidence in accordance with the constitution. The National Assembly then decided that a vote would be taken tomorrow night at one minute after midnight.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 22 -- Ending a three-year study of requests by women's clubs and civic groups for establishment of a university of Westchester, the county Board of Supervisors unanimously adopted a report this afternoon that rejected all proposals for county fiscal participation in such a project and urged that the state assume full responsibility.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The Federal Reserve Board announced tonight that department store sales for the week ended Dec. 17 were 1 per cent above those of the corresponding week last year. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:

The signing of a ten-year lease by the French Line for use of Pier 88, North River, at an annual basic rental of $269,534 was announced yesterday by G. Joseph Minetti, Commissioner of marine and aviation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- President Truman declared today that he does not regard General Dwight D. Eisenhower as a candidate for the Presidency.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 22 -- Arrangements for the purchase of the structural steel to be used in the permanent United Nations General Assembly building were completed today, but authoritative quarters confirmed that it would not be ready until about two years from now, too late for the 1951 session.

Two new films will open in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Roxy, the attraction is "Prince of Foxes," a Twentieth Century-Fox historical drama featuring Tyrone Power, Wanda Hendrix and Orson Welles. Henry King directed and Sol C. Siegel produced from the novel by Samuel Shellabarger and a screen play by Milton Krims, Everett Sloane, Marina Berti, Katina Paxinou and Felix Aylmer are among the principals in the offering which was filmed in Italy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner recommended today that the CAB and President Truman approve the proposed sale of American Overseas Airlines to Pan-American Airways for $17,450,000.

Starting with the Metropolitan A. A. U. open meet at the 102d Engineers Armory on Wednesday night, Jan. 4, there wil be at least one indoor track and field meet in New York each week until March 10. The complete local schedule, as announced yesterday by Pincus Sober, National A. A. U. track chairman, includes twelve meets.

Barney Balaban, president of Paramount Pictures, Inc., announced yesterday the names of the board of directors of Paramount Pictures Corporation. This is the concern organized to take over the production and distribution business of Paramount Pictures, Inc. as a result of divorcement of this department from the theatre operating division.

The relatively abrupt curtailment of the Army Reserve training program in the middle of its recruiting drive raises once more some of the basic issues in our military expenditure. Our budgetary outlay is already large, presumably fully as large as a healthy economy can sustain. It is the intention of the Defense Secretary and his associates to cut into our expenditures at every point at which a saving is possible.

Senora Carmen Vial de Senoret, who is engaged to be married to Olin Dows, a painter of Rhinebeck, N. Y., and who will be permanent Chilean delegate to the United Nations, was among 1,107 passengers who reached here last night on the French liner Ile de France, which docked at Pier 88, foot of West Forty-eighth Street.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 22 -- The silver nitrate is down the drain, and all's right with the 10-year-old boy who might have been poisoned by what a Philadelphia druggist had sold in error as a "car-sickness remedy."

The Joy Manufacturing Company, manufacturer of mining machinery and equipment, reported yesterday in its statement for the fiscal year ended with last September, net income of $3,890,813, or $4.41 a share on 881,638 shares outstanding. In the previous fiscal year the net was $6,958,925, or $8.14 each on 854,854 shares then outstanding.

Today John Marin is celebrating his eightieth birthday and art-lovers everywhere will wish to send congratulations to this Yankee artist who has become the "modern old master" whom many critics consider America's greatest painter.
Police Commissioner William P. O'Brien will appear as Santa Claus today to ninety-five members of the department at exercises in the line-up room at Police Headquarters.

Helena Braun, the young Wagnerian soprano who scored a vocal and histrionic success as a last-minute substitute Wednesday night in the exacting role of Bruennhilde in Wagner's "Die Walkuere" has received a contract until February with the Metropolitan Opera Company, it was learned yesterday.

Dr. Philip Jessup and his staff are setting out "on a slow boat to China." It is indeed a slow and baffling process for the United States to evolve a new policy toward the Far East through time-consuming research and on-the-spot study without in the meantime immediate and effective means to deal with the inexorable events momentarily unfolding in that area, culminating in the visit of Mao Tse-tung to Moscow.

TRENTON, Dec. 22 -- Three of the six defendants in the "Trenton six" case appealed to a Federal court today to halt their second trial for murder on the ground that the trial judge had barred the counsel of their choice.

The disputed block on Washington Square acquired by New York University for the erection of its Law Center will be cleared of all buildings by New Year's Day Dean Russell D. Niles of the School of Law said yesterday.

The Oriental Rug Importers Association will step up substantially next year its continuing drive to end misleading advertising of Oriental rugs by some retailers, Arsen Benneyan, outgoing president, declared yesterday. Interviewed following the group's annual meeting in the Martinique Hotel, he said the campaign this year was successful and led to greater volume by both dealers and importers of Oriental rugs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Santa Claus will play a leading role on the Voice of America broadcasts to the Russian people this Christmas season. The idea is to show the Russians what a fine season Christmas is in the land they are taught by their Government to hate and fear.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 22 -- Yugoslavia paid tribute today to the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund for its feeding and health programs among 600,000 Yugoslav children and nursing mothers during the past two years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UP) -The Department of Agriculture announced today that it would support wholesale prices of butter, cheese and other dairy products for the next fifteen months at about the same level they averaged this year. The new prices will go into effect Jan. 1, and will remain through March 1951.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 22 (AP) -- As if your money didn't go fast enough at a race track, the American Totalisator Company today announced development of a machine to take more.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 22 -- Water in the Boonton Reservoir of the Jersey City water system, which also serves Hoboken and Lyndhurst, is dropping at the rate of 10,000,000 gallons a day, Harold M. Ohland, municipal hydraulic engineer, said today. He estimated that the water supply would be exhausted here by Feb. 10 unless replenished by rainfall.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 22 -- Santa Claus came a little early this year or fifty-two United Nations chauffeurs, who have driven 305,000 passengers nearly 4,000,000 miles since 1946 without accident. Secretary General Trygve Lie and Adrian Pelt, former Assistant Secretary General in charge of the department of conference and g'eneral services, who was recently appointed United Nations Commissioner for Libya, presented a total of $2.550 and safe driving award certificates to the men today.

Some interesting ideas, including tapping the Hudson, were advanced at Governor Dewey's conference yesterday on the water emergency, but New Yorkers might as well face the fact that water-saving rather than water-finding is the only immediate salvation. No divining rod is equal to this situation, and any rabbits that are pulled out of the hat are bound to be small rabbits.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UP) -Senator John J. Sparkman, Democrat, of Aalabama, chairman of a Senate-House Economic subcommittee, urged Congress today to adopt a program to help underdeveloped areas of the United States.

Earning assets of New York City member banks dropped $364,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, and most types of loans were off sharply, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday. Total loans of the twenty-two weekly reporting banks were cut $509,000,000, net, and $505,000,000, gross.

Brock Pemberton is ready to go ahead with his second production of the season -- "Mr. Barry's Etchings." To prove it, he has signed Lee Tracy as the star of the "melodramatic comedy or vice versa" and Vicki Cummings in a featured role.
Robert T. Garrison has been elected a vice president in charge of manufacturing of Cluett Peabody Co. He succeeds the late Lawrence Parrish.

TOKYO, Dec. 22 -- Prompt action by Maj. Gen. Edward M. Almond, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's Chief of Staff, tonight kept Christmas relatively happy for eight American expectant mothers. The general countermanded orders which would have denied them Army facilities.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- A diplomatic note asking Britain not to prejudge Nationalist China's case before the United Nations by recognizing the Communist Government in Peiping was sent to the Foreign Office last night by the Chinese Embassy in London.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 (AP) -Doug Ratford of New York was fined $300 and suspended from the ring for three months today for what state officials called "inviting" a knockout last Thursday.

A bitter dispute over Superintendent of Schools William Jansen's handling of the case of Miss May A. Quinn, Brooklyn civics teacher accused of making anti-Negro remarks, erupted yesterday at a meeting of the Board of Education.
Two empty passenger trains of the Long Island Rail Road collided in Sunnyside, Queens, at 5:44 P. M. yesterday, killing two crewmen and injuring six others.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -President Clark Griffith disclosed today that a syndicate headed by John James Jachym, 31-year-old former newspaper reporter, had purchased approximately 39 per cent of the stock in the Washington Senators baseball club.

Long Island University, paced by its six-foot seven-inch center, Sherman White, romped to a 76-55 victory over the Ithaca College basketball team at the Brooklyn College Pharmacy gymnasium last night. White and Leroy Smith, the Blackbirds' left guard, accounted for 49 points, with the pivot man registering 25.

Shipments of holiday goods from overseas ports have been reaching the United States in increasing quantities and greater variety as the result of the recent devaluation of foreign currencies and the continued economic recovery abroad, it was noted yesterday by the American Merchant Marine Institute.
VIENNA, Dec. 22 -- At today's meetings of the Allied Council and of that body's executive council, the Soviet representatives repeated their charges that neo-Nazism was rife in Austria.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- President Truman reiterated today that he will take necessary action if the coal shortage reaches the emergency stage. He emphasized his readiness to act at his news conference today.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 22 -- Mexico's 3-year-old battle against the dread foot-and-mouth disease has been contained within this country's infected area, the Mexico-United States joint commission for eradication of the disease announced today.

Betty M. and Rhoda K. went to a Christmas party the other night at the Brooklyn Young Women's Christian Association. Apparently there is nothing extraordinary in that, yet to the YWCA and the Board of Education's Bureau for Children of Retarded Mental Development, the incident represents a real success for two clubs for girls that originated thirteen months ago.
ST. PAUL, Dec. 22 (UP) -- Nicholas Pastoret, 79 years old, whose hands had fashioned hundreds of American flags, wanted for years to become a citizen of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- President Truman today declared that the recent authoritative disclosures that Russia was building a big navy neither took us by surprise nor necessitated a change in the allocation of defense funds and missions. He answered a question on this topic today in his regular news conference.
A 46-year-old Swarthmore College professor has been named to succeed Roger N. Baldwin as director of the American Civil Liberties Union, it was announced yesterday.
Turkeys for the Christmas dinner are retailing at 24 cents a pound cheaper than last year, the markets department weekly food survey showed yesterday. The turkeys are in abundant supply.

George Kell's slide-rule victory over Ted Williams for the American League batting championship, indicated by unofficial computations at the end of the season, was confirmed with the release of the official records yesterday.

Modern wars with the scientific devices invented for more effective means of spreading death and destruction would have thrilled Ghengis Khan. Our devastation of cities with demolitions, the mass employment of incendiaries, and finally the atomic bombs, have caused deaths in a wholesale manner unknown to the Great Khan.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -The State Department took under fresh consideration today the issue of the World War II prisoners still held by the Soviet Union.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- The markets in grains did a right-about-face on the Board of Trade today, closing around the best levels of the day after being under pressure of scattered liquidation at the opening. General short covering developed on the break and prices climbed rapidly after May rye had sold at a new low for the year.
LONDON, Dec. 22 -- There was a firm undertone in nearly all markets on the Stock Exchange here today despite the drying up of business before the holidays.

Top sales executives of Calvert Distilling Corporation were told yesterday at a meeting in the Pierre Hotel that blended whiskies will continue to get their share of the business during 1950. Tubie Resnik, vice president and general sales manager of the company, told the executives to remember that retail inventories are extremely low and will have to be built up.

RUTLAND, Vt., Dec. 22 (UP) -Bernard J. Smith, 24 years old, of Fair Haven, the last of three war veteran jailed under Vermont's poor debtor law, will win his freedom through another of the state's archaic statutes.
Helen Laird, a 23-year-old dramatic soprano of Sheridan, Wyo., has won the first annual Blanche Thebom Christmas Scholarship Foundation Award, amounting to $1,500 for a two-year period.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The Commerce Department acted today to eliminate a loophole in its "voluntary" program to control the export to Russia and her satellites of technical but non-secret data, considered important to the national security.

Housing authorities of eight Massachusetts cities announced yesterday that they will receive bids until Dec. 29 on issues of temporary loan notes totaling $13,101,000 state-aided housing projects. Dated Jan. 9, 1950, the notes will come due on Jan. 9, 1951.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 22 -- The revival of German militarism and national socialism can and will be halted by the growth of responsibility and of expression on the part of the citizens of the West German State, United States High Commissioner John J. McCloy said today.

The Christmas tree is the glittering spot in the living room these days, of course, but at the dining table attention is drawn to a different highlight -- candelabra. Several new designs in metal have been introduced in time to grace holiday tables with a sophisticated sparkle.

Nowhere else, perhaps, is the term "cartel" regarded with the professed abhorrence that characterizes its status in American public opinion. Yet, we are periodically reminded at this time of year that our own Federal Government, acting in behalf of a small segment of American agriculture and a small segment of American industry, conducts one of the tightest and most monopolistic cartels to be found anywhere in the world.

BOSTON, Dec. 22 -- The Executive Council, called today into extraordinary session by Gov. Paul A. Dever, revoked a commutation of sentence granted yesterday by unanimous vote for a 52-year-old Chelsea, Mass., man with a criminal record dating back to 1915. The vote for reversal also was unanimous.

The pheasant preserve seems to have come into its own this season, for with short seasons and limited bags the average pheasant enthusiast has found it almost as cheap and much more certain to spend an occasional day in the abundant preserve covers.

GENEVA, Dec. 22 -- About 6,000,000 tons of steel capacity is now idle in Western European countries, according to the latest figures reaching the steel division of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

MADRID, Dec. 22 -- Almost a whole village became rich, by its standards, today when the fat main prize of 15,000,000 pesetas in the big Christmas lottery went to the village of Benavente on northwestern Spain. Four out of every five persons in the village had a share in the ticket, it was reported.

The minstrels of Manhattan have sung of spring, summer and autumn on this island but nothing about a sunny December day, particularly in midtown at noon. It is a splendid time. The shop windows glisten. The wind is brisk and clean.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 22 (AP)--Can't Trust won the sixth race for 2-year-olds at the Fair Grounds Race Track today. Mrs. Nellie M. Mikel's colt ran the six furlongs in 1:16 under Jockey John Brooks.
Thirty members of the Fire Department were promoted, and fifty-six new firemen were appointed yesterday at brief ceremonies in Engine Company 31 station, 87 Lafayette Street.

The use of secondary subscription rights, which was introduced into public-utility equity financing two years ago by the Southwestern Public Service Company, has just been extended successfully into financing without underwriting. The current instance is the successful outcome of the Florida Power Corporation's offering of 242,000 shares of new common stock to stockholders.

The railroads had their day yesterday before the Public Service Commission in the controversy over the canned music and commercials that are the newest feature of Grand Central Terminal. The roads produced their own psychiatrist to testify that only those already slightly "tetched" could be adversely affected, mentally or physically by the "broadcasts."

Advertising in newspapers of fifty-two cities during November totaled 207,908,984/ lines, a decrease of six-tenths of 1 per cent, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. For the first eleven months of the year, total linage was up 1.7 per cent over the comparable period of last year.

The December sunlight slanted with little warmth across the park whose leaves were too dead to answer any breeze. In the early day there were no sounds or smells or people. The stone tables marked with colored squares for chess or checkers had no audience and no players.

Twelve top men will retire from the F. W. Woolworth Company at the end of the year, it was announced yesterday. All have had long years of service with Woolworth and are being retired in accordance with the company's employe pension plan.
Horace Greeley's memorable phrase, "Go West, young man," might be appropriate for skiers in this part of the country since the skimpy snow reports promise anything but skiing.

Coffee futures were steady yesterday after early easiness. Scattered commission house selling in early dealings was absorbed by trade interests. This demand continued throughout the session and final prices were at the best levels of the day.
Two rival electrical unions began their battle yesterday before the National Labor Relations Board here for the right to represent 5,500 workers of the Sperry Gyroscope Company of Lake Success.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The impending departure of George V. Allen as Ambassador to Yugoslavia was made the occasion by President Truman today for reaffirming United States opposition to any aggression and to the subversion of any country's sovereignty.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Informed tips on what the President will say to Congress in his forthcoming message on the State of the Union, while they have uncovered only bits and fragments thus far, indicate that this document like the last one will reflect Mr. Truman's belief in the universality and benefit of change.
The term of the December Kings County grand jury was extended yesterday for three months to conduct an investigation into the operation of alleged organized gambling syndicates in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Dec. 17, 1949, totaled 639,723 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -The Government's support program for 1950 will seek to keep the national average farm price of eggs -- graded and ungraded -- from falling below 37 cents a dozen. By comparison, prices of all eggs -both graded and ungraded -- have averaged about 45 cents this year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- During the week ended Dec. 21, member bank reserve balances decreased $96,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture announced today that it would permit 7,500,000 short tons, raw value, of sugar to be sold in the domestic market in 1950. This is the same quantity permitted for sale this year.

The Metropolitan Opera gave its first performance of the season of Verdi's "La Traviata" last night. Licia Albanese as Violetta made her season's first appearance and Enzo Mascherini sang his first Giorgio Germont with the company.

The reconstruction of the United Palestine Appeal's board of directors which will now include representatives from twenty-four major communities and eight regions throughout the country was announced yesterday by Magistrate Morris Rothenberg, acting national chairman of the appeal.

The March of Dimes arranged yesterday for its 2 1/2-year-old 1950 poster boy to meet Santa Claus. Not one but six department store St. Nicks were on hand. Result: the child was frightened stiff, cried and refused to pose with the red-faced characters.

The stock market gave evidence yesterday that the traditional year-end rally, stifled by recent tax selling, might develop into a reality. Sustained by persistent bidding and with a minimum of pressure, prices on the New York Stock Exchange advanced over a broad front in the most ambitious push in three months and enabled the list to regain the year's peaks.

An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified yesterday that he did not know last May that the telephones of Judith Coplon and Valentin A. Gubitchev had been tapped, but admitted later that he had destroyed as early as February reports of conversations intercepted on their phones.

Your editorial "Changing West Point" brings to mind another change that should be made there. The monument to the "War Between the States" should be torn down and in its place should be erected a bronze monument to "The Four Chaplains" as an inspiration to all the young men who pass through on their way to become leaders in our military forces.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- Railroads will be compelled to make drastic cuts in train schedules within a few days unless something is done about the three-day work week imposed by John L. Lewis on the United Mine Workers and the coal operators, Wayne A. Johnston, president of the Illinois Central Railroad, wired Congress today.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Dec. 22 -- Paul Draper, the dancer, said today that he had sent to Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, a telegram denying that he was a Communist.

Friends often say to the members of the food news department that the nicest thing about working in it must be the sampling and sipping that go on. Well, that process has its points. But even pleasanter are the reader letters. Tasting sessions one becomes accustomed to, but the mail is always varied, often surprising.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Witnesses at a Civil Aeronautics Board inquiry into the crash of a Capital Airlines DC-3 near National Airport Dec. 12 today gave support to the theory that the aircraft stalled when its pilot attempted to pull up from the fog-shrouded field to attempt a new landing.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 22 (Reuters) -- Thailand today was taking measures to forestall any attempt by Communist Chinese armies on her northern borders to link with the country's Chinese community of 4,000,000.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- A foretaste of retail price increases on a long list of consumer products based on steel was given today by Alva W. Phelps, president of the Oliver Corporation, manufacturers of farm and industrial equipment.

BOSTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- A Federal judge, Francis J. W. Ford, ruled today that a radio station had the right to break a contract if it believed a proposed program did not best serve the public interest. He dismissed a civil suit brought by the Massachusetts Universalist Convention against Station WLAW of Lawrence.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -Leaders of Protestant, Catholic and Jewish agencies today presented a portrait plaque to President Truman for his work on behalf of Europe's displaced persons.

One of the most dramatic examples of water conservation yet to come out of the current campaign was discovered yesterday at the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn, where officials announced savings of more than 1,500,000 gallons a day since early this month.

Electronics products in 1950 will establish new sales records and over - all appliance manufacture should be 7 to 10 per cent greater than in 1949, it was announced here yesterday by executives in charge of two major departments of the General Electric Company.

A mark of the police state, unmistakable as the noose, is the flight of men and women in search of freedom. Along the devious trails of the underground, through barbed wire, across icy rivers, they slip over that dark frontier that divides two worlds. They leave behind them their possessions, they risk their lives, as they seek the liberty that the police state cannot brook.

OTTAWA, Dec. 22 -- Nothing has been agreed or decided in the talks this week between the United States and Canada that precludes the Canadian Air Transport Board from suspending the license of Colonial. Airlines to operate into Montreal, it was explained here today.
Sandra Lee Minyon, 4 years old, a cancer patient in Memorial Hospital, left yesterday for a date with Santa Claus at her home in McKeesport, Pa., but must return here Jan. 18 for further treatment.

Election of Raymond C. Johnson and Walter Weissinger as agency vice presidents of the New York Life Insurance Company, was announced by George L. Harrison, board chairman, following the directors' meeting yesterday.

ALBANY, Dec. 22 -- Senator Thomas C. Desmond, Republican, of Newburgh, said today that a survey of twenty-five up-state police chiefs revealed that a majority believed sex offenders should be examined and treated by psychiatrists and confined in prisons or hospitals until cured.
