WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- A plea to the incoming session of Congress for additional funds for Reserve and National Guard training is under consideration at the Department of Defense, it was learned today, although unofficial views of the armed services indicate that this will not be necessary to keep in a state of readiness the Reserve components needed for initial mobilization in an emergency.

Looking at New York from a wistful distance Garson Kanin has written an amiable and aimless rooming-house idyll, "The Rat Race," which opened at the Ethel Barrymore last evening. Nothing in "Born Yesterday," which Mr. Kanin wrote, is as charming as this free-hand sketch of a girl who has abandoned hope in New York and of a boy who is on tip-toe with hope and enthusiasm.

Many a New Yorker doffed his coat and hat yesterday on the first day of winter -- and with good reason. The Weather Bureau announced the shattering of a 74-year-old record when the temperature at 2:30 P. M. stood at 62.2 degrees eclipsing by more than five degrees the previous high for Dec. 22, set 1875.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 22 -- John M. Byergo, 29 years old, of 69 West Eleventh Street, New York, was killed at 2:30 A. M. today in an automobile accident on the Bronx River Parkway, north of the County Center. Mr. Byergo was an advertising salesman for The Daily News in New York and the husband of Mrs. Marthe Errolle Byergo, light opera soprano.

DETROIT, Dec. 22 -- As agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation began an investigation into the Tuesday-night attempt to dynamite the headquarters of the United Automobile Workers, CIO it was announced today that a threat of a bombing had been received by the Street Car and Bus Operators Union. AFL.

American Bemberg has raised the price of all types of Bemberg rayon yarn (cupramonnium) by 5 cents a pound, it was announced yesterday. The increase effective, it was said, on all orders entered beginning Dec. 22.

ASPEN, Colo., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Bob Sanderson of the University of Minnesota skied down the fifteen-gate slalom course in 1 minute 18.2 seconds today to take first place in the opening event of the four-way intercollegiate meet here.

The Indian Government has notified United States petroleum companies supplying oil products to India that starting next year they may sell no "dollar" fuel oil in that nation, the oil companies involved said here yesterday. The Indian Government said that the action was taken to conserve dollar exchange since an ample supply of "sterling" oil was now available.

Test operations of the CBS color system will be started on Jan. 2 in Washington and New York and at a later date in Philadelphia, the network announced yesterday. Fifteen sets will be installed in Washington to give the public a chance to express its opinion of the system.

PARIS, Dec. 22 -- The gaudy celebration of Soviet Premier Stalin's birthday focused the political spotlight directly upon the subsurface troubles, in Communism's orbit. Such human factors as discontent, dissension and rivalry obviously are stirring beneath the placid exterior that the world was permitted to see.

HONG KONG, Dec. 22 -- Nationalist Air Force headquarters at Taipei, Formosa, tonight announced that a heavy air attack had been made on Kumming, admitting by implication that earlier claims that Nationalist troops had captured the city were incorrect.

All over town, Christmas parties were held yesterday for underprivileged children. Thousands of sick, orphaned and poor boys and girls were stuffed with sweets, entertained, and showered with toys by welfare organizations and groups of private citizens.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Sparked by a 28-point scoring spree by Colin Anderson, Georgia Tech roared from behind in the second half for a 68-60 basketball victory over Michigan State here tonight.

TOKYO, Dec. 22 -- The Japanese Government has informed Parliament that Japan will not recognize the Yalta Agreement, which it regards as a pact between the Allied powers and not binding upon Japan, it was revealed today. Japan therefore has a legal claim to resume sovereignty over the Southern Kurile Islands, South Sakhalin, the Bonins, Okinawa and Iwo, in the view of the Conservative Administration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -The Collier Trophy for aviation's greatest achievement of the year demonstrated by actual use will be awarded to the Radio Technical Commission for Aeronautics for development of a bad-weather flight system.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Dinner Hour, under a feathery impost of 07 pounds, ran the fastest mile and a sixteenth of the Tropical Park meeting today in the Doncaster Purse. The son of Pilate collared the leaders leaving the far turn and prevailed by six lengths in 1:42 3-5, one-fifth of a second slower than the track mark.

Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., filed a brief with the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday, asking that Pan American Airways not be allowed to fly passengers into Rome during the coming Holy Year.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Leon Hart, All-America end, and two Notre Dame team-mates arrived today to bolster the East's football squad training at Santa Clara.

CHRISTINE, CARROLL, heroine of Francis Leary's first novel, "This Dark Monarchy,"* is one of the strangest girls to be met with on a year-long safari through the darkest jungles of current fiction. Proud, secretive, painfully sensitive and violently emotional, Christine found the long misery of her unhappy childhood and adolescence more than she could bear.

Three West Point cadets who wanted to make someone else's "Christmas a little brighter" took time out of their busy, disciplined lives to send their contribution yesterday to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- President Truman announced today that Charles S. Murphy, one of his administrative assistants, would succeed Clark M. Clifford as his special counsel on Feb. 1. Mr. Clifford's resignation to practice law here had previously been announced. He has been a right-hand man to the President in the formulation of high policy.

ALBANY, Dec. 22 -- Governor Dewey commuted today the life sentence of Louis Boy, 50 years old, Sing Sing convict who risked his life repeatedly in what the Governor described as "dangerous medical tests and experiments." He will leave prison tomorrow.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 1 to 11 points net yesterday.

Monte M. Wheeler has been named sales manager of the General Electric Company's automatic blanket and sun-lamp division, Bridgeport. He formerly was assistant manager of appliance sales in the north central district at Chicago.

In a three-hour conference at the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday Governor Dewey prodded city officials, including Acting Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri, to make all possible haste in pushing plans for tapping the Hudson River for 100,000,000 gallons of water daily.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -The United States turned to Britain today for help in freeing two American servicemen from more than fourteen months' captivity by the Chinese Communists.

Abandonment of the "destructive policy" of dual pricing by countries receiving European Recovery Program aid was urged yesterday by Curtis E. Calder, chairman of the National Association of Manufacturers' international relations committee, in a letter to the Ambassadors or other diplomatic representatives of Marshall Plan countries in Washington.

The Department of Justice announced the arrest yesterday of Andrew Overgaard, whom it described as "holder of many important Communist positions," on a deportation warrant. He is charged with being an alien member of an organization advocating overthrow of the United States Government by force and violence.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 22 -The Brussels newspaper Le Soir published a letter today from King George of Britain to King Leopold, sent two days before the Belgian capitulation, advising the King of the Belgians to head a new government-in-exile rather than become a prisoner of the Germans.

Arrangements have been made "looking toward" the purchase of control of Lament, Corliss Co., makers of Nestle's chocolate products and distributors of Pond's creams and toiletries, by the Swiss Nestle group through its Western Hemisphere company, Unilac, Inc., it was announced yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 22 -- The Duquesne University basketball team rolled up its highest point total of the season tonight to defeat the Fordham Rams, 75 to 61, on the Vocational High School gymnasium floor in near-by McKeesport.
BOSTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau tonight issued this report on winter sports conditions in New England:

The granting of amnesty to all conscientious objectors, as asked by the League for Peace and Freedom in a letter to your newspaper published Dec. 20, sounds like the forgive-and-forget attitude too frequently applied to those who were not willing to defend their country during the war and believe that they are entitled to a completely clean bill of health now that hostilities are over.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Dec. 23 -- Expansion plans for near-by Newark Airport include a new radio beam alignment that would take incoming planes away from midtown Elizabeth in all kinds of weather, it was disclosed today.
COCOA, Fla., Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Kentucky Wildcats went through a light conditioning workout today in preparation for their clash with Santa Clara in the Orange Bowl Jan. 2.
CLEVELAND. Dec. 23 -- The two-day-old strike on the city transit system and is paralyzing effect on transportation facilities for more than 1,300,000 Greater Clevelanders neared an end tonight.
GONZALES, Tex., Dec. 23 (U.P.) -- An airlift operation began today to give polio victims their best Christmas present -- a visit home.

You cannot buy happiness. You cannot go to the nearest grocery store and order a pound of happiness as you would a pound of butter. You cannot order a bouquet of happiness as you would a dozen roses from the florist. But, since happiness comes from within, you can buy a measure of happiness by your own acts.

WROCLAW (Breslau), Dec. 23 -- A military court here today found four French nationals, one Pole and a German guilty of spying for the French intelligence service and imposed prison sentences ranging up to nine years.

Mr. and Mrs. Byron C. Foy presented their daughter, Miss Cynthia Foy, to society last night at a dance in the ballroom of their home, 60 East Ninety-third Street, in a setting of flowering quince and camellia trees. There were ropes and wreaths of green in the supper room, and a tall Christmas tree in the entrance hall to give a holiday note to the party.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 23 -- The Security Council of the United Nations will meet on Tuesday afternoon to consider the dispute between India and Pakistan over the territory of Kashmir, it was announced here today.

An authority in public opinion research yesterday branded as scientifically inadequate a market research poll that had shown strong approval of canned music and commercials in Grand Central Terminal. He appeared before the Public Service Commission, which ended three days of hearings on the controversial "broadcasts."

By the time stores close their doors here this evening a good number of them will have completed the largest Christmas selling season in their histories. Although the average dollar volume will be slightly below last year. this can be accounted for by prices that are about 7 per cent below last Christmas.

Ten hold-ups were committed in various parts of the city yesterday that netted the thieves $50,000, with $40,000 of the total representing the loss of one fur dealer. Meanwhile a series of robberies during the last six weeks in drug stores, delicatessens and liquor stores appeared to be solved with the arrest of two brothers, both ex-convicts, who, according to the police, admitted twelve hold-ups.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -- The Republican party today announced a series of five national broadcasts during the next two weeks in a campaign to win grass-roots support for the 1950 election.

Bag manufacturers are cutting burlap consumption to stretch the available supply, it was learned yesterday. They are making greater use of both cotton and paper materials, awaiting the composition of monetary differences between the Governments of India and Pakistan which has cut down burlap production.

The six-story apartment house for twenty-four families at 228 East Fortieth Street was sold by St. Michael's Protestant Episcopal Church to the Norchester Corporation in a deal negotiated by Ruland Benjamin and Schimmer, Kerner Feder, brokers.
WASHINGTON. Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board proposed a temporary mail rate increase today to help All American Airways, which the board said was in "critical" financial condition.
MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Dec. 23 (AP) -- West Virginia University rolled easily to its sixth cage victory in seven starts here tonight by overwhelming an erratic-shooting Fordham quintet, 61 -- 37.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -- Police of the District of Columbia and of Maryland today recaptured four prisoners who noisily sawed their way out of the Fairfax County Jail in Virginia last night while the jailer, William Lowe, was sleeping near by.

The United Nations filmstrip, "The Universal Declaration of Human Rights," will be issued soon in book form by Ellner Co., 151 East Nineteenth Street. It will contain sixty-two halftone illustrations, enlarged from the film, accompanied by appropriate texts as well as the complete text of the Declaration as proclaimed by the United Nations last December.

Investors who contemplate establishing profits on securites for 1949 tax purposes, through sales made in the "regular way" of trading on the New York Stock Exchange have but one day left to do so -- Tuesday, Dec. 27. However, they may also establish taxable profits thereafter by means of "cash" transactions to and including Dec. 31.

BOSTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Squirming out of portholes and struggling through smoke-filled companion-ways, forty crewmen and two stewardesses escaped in night-clothes early today as explosions and flames wrecked the midship decks of the moored Norwegian freighter Fern Bay.

Early in the century a French politician boasted that he would put out the Star of Bethlehem. This year, in Moscow, they launch the annual campaign against Christmas and claim that the Red Star is now the light of the world. Yet today the name of Viviani is almost forgotten in France and thirty-odd crusades are not enough to make the Russian people forget Christmas.
ROME, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Following is the official English translation of the Pope's Christmas message today:

DETROIT. Dec. 23 -- State, county and city law enforcement agencies today organized for a concerted investigation to track down those responsible for what Gerald K. O'Brien, Wayne County Prosecutor, termed conspiracy to terrorize the United Automobile Workers Union, CIO.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 23 (AP) -- A coal operator played Santa Claus to his 600 miners today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- William McChesney Martin Jr., Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, was appointed today by President Truman to be United States executive director of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
ROME, Dec. 23 -- The Communists have again promised to make trouble during tomorrow's inauguration of the Roman Catholic Church's twenty-fifth Holy Year.
GREAT FALLS, Mont., Dec. 23 (AP) -- Pat Rafferty, "the stone man," plans a Happy Christmas although he has not moved a finger or turned his head for seventeen years.

Acting Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri signed yesterday, after a brief public hearing, the local law increasing the salaries of the members of the Board of Estimate and the City Council. The higher salaries become effective Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission today ruled unlawful the Bell Telephone System's restrictions against connecting its intercity television channels with similar facilities owned by others.

Abraham Morgenstern and Moses Adelson sold the six-story building at 83-09 Lefferts Boulevard, Kew Gardens, Queens, containing seven stores and thirty-seven apartments, to Louis Heller. Paul P. Zinner, Inc., was the broker.

Lumber production for the week ended Dec. 17 was 26.8 per cent above the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to The New York Times from trade associations. Shipments were up 43.4 per cent and orders 35.7 per cent.

A Roman Catholic priest who languished for a year in a Yugoslav prison while under "investigation,'' charged the Tito regime with responsibility for the death of 500 priests and 300,000 Roman Catholics in that country.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 23 -- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, pointing out that hundreds of war-destroyed Philippine schools are still in ruins, has flatly turned down a request to serve on a committee sponsoring an International Christian University in Japan.

ALBANY, Dec. 23 -- Gov. D. Sherman Adams of New Hampshire conferred for several hours here today with Hiland G. Batcheller, chairman of the board of the Allegany Ludlum Steel Company, on the possibility of establishing a steel mill center in New Hampshire.

Some startling figures have been assembled by the American Automobile Association with regard to the recklessness of drivers in the younger age brackets. The motor vehicle death rate in the age group 15-24 years has increased 86 per cent in the last twenty years. This is by far the largest rise for any age group.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -Ninety-eight thousand veterans still in hospitals won't be forgotten this Christmas. The Veterans Administration, local townsfolk and the patients themselves have been working on plans to make the Yuletide a merry one.
CHICAGO, Dec. 23 -- Officers of the American Retail Coal Association telegraphed to President Truman today that the coal crisis had reached the emergency stage under which he had promised to act.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The lowest death rate of record for this country was reported today for 1948 by the National Office of Vital Statistics. The rate was 9.9 deaths for each 1,000 population.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Foreign-owned gold in Federal Reserve Banks increased $63,938,765 during November to a total of $4,213,939,139, the Census Bureau reported today.
SEATTLE, Wash., Dec. 23 (UP) -- A cornered gunman exchanged shots with the police on a busy downtown street corner here today and escaped in a crowd of Christmas shoppers.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 23 -- A revolutionary income tax plan that would exempt an estimated 20,000,000 small wage-earners from any tax and increase the rates on the highest bracket incomes of both individuals and corporations has been endorsed by Gwilym A. Price, president of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

SOUTH PLAINFIELD, N. J., Dec. 23 -- Acquisition of a 250-acre tract for development as the largest privately owned airport in New Jersey was announced here today by Rickcliff Decker, operator of the Decker Flying Service at Hadley Airport, also in this borough.
Six new films will have local premieres over the week-end, thereby completing the Christmas influx. This morning's openings are:

A special meeting of stockholders of the Kansas Gas and Electric Company has been called for Jan. 24 to consider the issuance of 200,000 shares of $100 par value preferred stock carrying a dividend rate between 4 1/2 and 5 per cent.
WASHINGTON. Dec. 23 -- The General Services Administration announced today that it had sold four aluminum plants and a sinter (cinder) plant to the Reynolds Aluminum Company for $50,081,958.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- A Civil Aeronautics Board inquiry heard evidence today that a defect in the right engine of a Capital Airlines DC-3 which crashed here Dec. 12 had been reported days before the accidnet, but that apparently it had never been corrected.

One hundred and fourteen members of the Police Department received welcome Christmas presents yesterday at ceremonies in the line-up room at Police Headquarters. The presents were in the form of promotions and pay increases.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 23 -- The United States Government's declared opposition to aggression against Yugoslavia was conveyed today to the Yugoslav people in repeated broadcasts by the State Department's Voice of America.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan is expected to call upon farmers next week to reduce corn production about 12 per cent during 1950 to prevent a big surplus. The goal may be about 3,000,000,000 bushels, compared with 3,377,000,000 grown this year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- A letter written by President Truman to Rear Admiral Sidney W. Souers, who has resigned as Executive Director of the National Security Council, was made public today by the White House. It praised the Admiral for his "great work."

MOSCOW, Dec. 23 -- Foreign diplomats here are convinced that Premier Joseph Stalin believes the capitalist system is destined to exist for some years to come and that the world is large enough for both Communist and capitalist states to live and work in peaceful and businesslike relations.

Brooklyn College handed Wagner its first loss last night by defeating the Staten Island quintet, 71 -- 51, at the Brooklyn gym. The score was tied, 30 -- 30, at the half, but the Kingsmen broke the game wide open in the second half when three Wagner starters fouled out.

SCARBOROUGH, N. Y., Dec. 23 -- Several dinners were given in advance of the third annual Sleepy Hollow Assembly last night in the Sleepy Hollow Country Club, at which fourteen young women were presented to society. Each debutante danced the first dance with her father.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- A broad list of fruit and vegetable insecticides will go on trial here Jan. 17.
BOSTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -- The Boston Braves announced tonight they had signed William (Bucky) Walters, former Cincinnati Reds manager, to a contract as pitching coach.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- A $7,000,000 increase in capital stock of the Inland Waterways Corporation for the purpose of modernizing the Federal Barge Line is recommended by the Senate Commerce Committee. The proposal is in a report the committee has prepared to submit to the Senate next month.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 23 -- Success of a new method of causing rain that makes unnecessary the use of dry ice and airplanes was reported last night by the American Institute of Aerological Research, headed by Dr. Irving P. Krick.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Football's double wing is being shaped into a formidable attacking weapon which the West will use against the East in the big charity game here Dec. 31.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Dec. 23 (AP) -- George Stanich's basket from a fast break in the last five seconds tonight gave U. C. L. A. a 65-63 basketball victory over Illinois. It was the Illini's second defeat in seven starts.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Dec. 23 -- Dr. Tjoe Som Tjan, curator of the Sinological Institute at Leyden University, Holland, sailed for Rotterdam this afternoon aboard the motorship Noordam of the Holland-America Line after a two-month tour of American universities under a grant from the Rockefeller Foundation.

The Metropolitan used to give "Faust" so often in the decades of star singers and unlimited vocal glory the theatre was wittily designated by William J. Henderson as the "Faustspielhaus" at the time. Last night the Metropolitan restored it to the repertory after a lapse of three seasons.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Dec. 23 (UP) -- The Kent County Prosecutor, Roger McMahon, took up pistol practice today after receiving telephoned threats to "lay off or else" in his campaign against organized vice and gambling. The 38-year-old lawyer, a wartime gunnery instructor in the Army, said recent raids he ordered balked an attempt by "Chicago and Detroit gambling interests" to move in on Grand Rapids.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 23 -- There is less Christmas spirit in Jerusalem and fewer tourists than most people can recall over the years. The expected influx of pilgrims for the start of the Holy Year tomorrow night did not materialize.

DENVER, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers' forward, Vince Boryla, was in a hospital here this afternoon, but in spite of his absence they had little trouble defeating the Denver Nuggets, 83 -- 72, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

In the second large realty deal in the Times Square area this week, the twenty-four-story and penthouse Candler Building and the adjoining Harris Theatre at 218-26 West Forty-second Street through to 221-29 West Forty-first Street were sold by Emory University of Atlanta, Ga., to Thomas Moffa, operator.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Hungary's Roman Catholic Bishops today granted their priests permission to swear an oath of loyalty to the "Hungarian people's republic, its people and Constitution."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, has asked the Bureau of the Budget not to eliminate funds for medical care of dependents of members of the armed forces, it was said at the Pentagon today in reply to inquiries.

MITCHEL AIR FORCE BASE, L. I., Dec. 23 -- The assignment of Maj. Clement G. Slattery, staff air provost marshal of the First Air Force here for the last two and a half years, to the staff of the air provost marshal at the headquarters of the Fourth Air Force, Hamilton Air Force Base, Calif., was announced today. Major Slattery is a veteran of both World Wars.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture will not be "pressured" into "rushing" back-into the @ market to buy for price support, W. D. Termohlen, director of the Department's poultry branch, said today. He told a reporter the Government would let supply and demand set the price of eggs for a while.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 23 -Twentieth Century-Fox today suspended Lee J. Cobb from salary for refusing a role in "Where the Sidewalk Ends." an Otto Preminger production, which is scheduled to be made on location in New York.

SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., Dec. 23 -- Abe Stern, chief of the Ramapo Township Police Department and president of the New York State Chiefs of Police Association, was seriously injured at 1:30 this afternoon in an auto accident while responding to a fatal car crash in which a local high school boy was killed.
Service on the Long Island Raft Road was back to normal in time for the rush hours yesterday morning, according to a spokesman for the line.

Mistletoe, which is hidden by the verdure of spring and summer, and later by the colorful curtain of autumn leaves, comes into its own in winter. Then it flowers twice: Sentimentally during the Christmas and New Year holidays and in actuality a few weeks later.
LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Russia has indicted twelve Japanese Army officers on charges of plotting to use germ warfare in World War II, the Moscow radio said today.

Frank Eddolls, defense stalwart for the New York Rangers, will be lost to the team for three weeks, it, was disclosed yesterday. Officials of the National Hockey League sextet revealed that Eddolls underwent an operation for a bursitis condition in his left elbow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- President Truman and Pope Pius XII envisage the achievement of a lasting peace as the true goal of the world, the White House revealed through the release of an exchange of messages today.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 23 (AP) -- Coach Herman Hickman's Northern All Stars went through a bruising full-scale scrimmage today as Coach Andy Gustafson announced his hand-picked South squad would hereafter have only one workout a day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Dr. Earl James McGrath, United States Commissioner of Education, reported today a study of Europes' school systems had impressed him with the wisdom of Federal scholarships.
CHICAGO, Dec. 23 (AP) -- A proposal to unify three of Chicago's downtown railroad depots was rejected today as not "economically justified" by the fourteen lines operating from them.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 23 (AP) -- A big, rugged Yankee line had Southern coaches all but talking to themselves today even before practice starts for the Blue-Gray football game.

Four pictures that are on view in the Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street, in the annual exhibition of Contemporary American Painting were purchased by the institution for its permanent collection, it was announced yesterday.

The financial and commodity exchanges throughout the United States will be closed today and Monday in observance of the Christmas season. Canadian and European grain and stock markets also will close today and Monday.
The decorative interest and all-round utility value of ottomans -- or hassocks -- has earned for them a major role in today's furnishings.
Five new bronze doors at the Fifth Avenue entrance o St. Patrick's Cathedral were blessed yesterday afternoon by Cardinal Spellman at an hour-long liturgical ceremony witnessed by 1,600 persons.
ROME, Dec. 23 -- How the Ro- man Catholic Holy Year will open tomorrow:

BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 23 (AP) -- California's Bears plunged into the last two days of their home practice today with a drive that bodes ill for the Ohio State Buck-eyes when they meet in the Rose Bowl football classic Jan. 2.
The new Norwegian refrigerator ship Fruit Monarch is scheduled to arrive here Monday, Rohner, Gehrig and Co., agents for the vessel here, announced yesterday.

On the eve of Christmas The New York Times Neediest Case Fund received $21,727.46, the largest single day's contribution sent thus far this year. The donations were made by 668 contributors the greatest number to donate on any one day to the fund's thirty-eight annual appeal.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 23 -- Gov. Forrest Smith brought about a ten-day postponement of a telephone strike in six states today by threatening to invoke the King-Thompson Act, which provides severe penalties for utility strikes in Missouri.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 -- Grain prices here were at about the top level of the day when the markets on the Board of Trade closed today. Trading, however, was light and a large part of the strength came from short covering following an early decline.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 23 -- International affairs and economic questions will be considered by the conference of British Commonwealth foreign ministers, opening in Colombo, Ceylon, Jan. 9, the Indian External Affairs Ministry announced tonight.
Among the Christmas week exhibitions in metropolitan art galleries are several interesting group shows and one-man exhibitions of paintings and sculpture.

Edith Bown, American pianist, made her recital debut in Town Hall last night and showed herself a performer of talent. Her playing was apparently effortless, with easy, responsive fingers, but was carefully considered as to tempi and dynamics, and was especially effective in atmospheric selections.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 23 -- A general disinclination to assume civic responsibilities, ignorance of current politics and widespread political inertia are the main findings of a public opinion survey in the United States zone of Germany, the Information Services Division of the United States High Commissioner's Office announced today.

Broadway's longest running play, "Born Yesterday," will end its local engagement after the performance of Dec. 31, it was learned yesterday. By that time, according to statisticians, the Garson Kanin comedy about a boorish junk dealer and his lady friend who thirsts for knowledge will have registered 1,642 performances.
MOSCOW, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The news of an elaborate Kremlin reception honoring Premier Joseph Stalin on the occasion of his seventieth birthday was printed today in the Soviet press.

The New York Water Service Corporation announced yesterday plans for a ten-for-one common stock split and for refunding its first-mortgage debt. Financing is expected to be completed by May 1, provided the necessary approval is obtained from the Public Service Commission.
LONDON, Dec. 23 -- Operators on the stock exchange here were in a holiday mood today, and business was the smallest since the war.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- King Gustaf of Sweden, the Prince of Monaco, Gen. George Marshall, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Dr. Karl Renner, Federal President of Austria, and other world figures took part in a joint radio appeal tonight for funds for needy children.

PARIS, Dec. 23 -- United States and French officials attended the inauguration near Metz today of what will be the largest industrial project in Europe made possible by Marshall Plan funds, the Sollac hot and cold strip roiling mills.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -The men and women of the Army, Navy and Air Force, including 554,000 assigned overseas, will share in a typical American holiday feast built around roast tom turkey, the Defense Department announced today.

Retail sales here showed good increases during the week, according to estimates made here yesterday by trade observers. Department store sales were estimated to be between 10 and 15 per cent ahead of the week before Christmas last year.

It is necessary that the United States keep the question of the missing Japanese war prisoners continuously before the attention of the world. The Soviet Union declares that all but 10,000 of these Japanese have been repatriated. The best available Japanese records indicate that more than 376,000 are still unaccounted for.

By the time the city gets through with its program of executive pay increases and appointive transfers in key posts we believe the taxpayers have a right to expect something pretty good in the way of government for New York City. We took the lead in proposing some -- but not all -- of these pay rises. Some of the increases surpassed our recommendations.

]DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Martin Kurasch, attorney for the United Electrical Workers, said today that recent disaffiliation elections by union workers at five plants of the General Motors Corporation here were marked by "coercion, intimidation and company favoritism."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Seasonal drops in employment in some soft goods industries and the secondary effects of the steel strike nearly offset the return of striking coal and steel workers between mid-October and mid-November, according to Bureau of Labor Statistics estimates.

George McAneny, who turns 80 today, has not let the years dim his life-long vision for civic improvement. He has kept alive his happy combination of interests: preserving the best from the past in the life of the city and planning intelligently for coming generations of New Yorkers.

PARIS, Saturday, Dec. 24 -- Premier Georges Bidault, by a vote of 303 to 297, obtained a vote of confidence from the French National Assembly early today in favor of his Government's proposals for a compromise on the 1950 budget. The vote came just after 2 A. M., following a night of debate.

TOKYO, Dec. 23 -- Signaling Japan's gradual emergence from a completely managed economy, the Cabinet today approved a budget that not only slashes 79,640,000,000 yen from the 1949-50 total but increases the public bond retirements by 71,495,000,000.
JACKSON, Mich., Dec. 23 -- The gates of Southern Michigan Prison opened today for seventy-eight men who had served a total of 1,012 years. Their sentences had been commuted to time served.

TRENTON, Dec. 23 -- A vivid water-color hangs on the walls of the apartment of Mrs. Annette de Vol Trumbull, director of social service of the Trenton State Hospital. She is very fond of that painting, which was created by a former patient at a state hospital in Pennsylvania where she worked. He now has his own art studio.

Every week-day morning Dorothy B. Skinner visits the wholesale market where fresh fruits are sold. It's there she gathers first-hand material for her job, which is to stimulate interest in the wares of the New York Fruit Auction Company.
ERIE, Pa., Dec. 23 (U.P.) -- A small, private plane almost collided with a Capital Airlines DC-3 at Port Erie Airport during a sudden snow squall today.
William M. Yorio has been named piece boods buyer at Gimbels New York, effective about Jan. 4. He replaces Hyman Gelbcrunk.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Jockey Hal Keene booted home three winners for Owner W. H. Bishop today to keep the combination well in front for the Fair Grounds racing season.
SHALLMAR, Md., Dec. 23 (AP) -- A nation's sympathy has transformed this despair-haunted village into a community bright with Christmas well being.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent in the week ending Dec. 10, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 151 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.3 per cent below that of four weeks ago and 6.8 per cent below that of the comparable week of 1948.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 -- The Chicago office of the Department of Agriculture announced today that the Government has decided to continue selling its accumulation of more than 100,000,000 pounds of butter on the current price basis for at least two months, despite the lower price supports for 1950 butter announced yesterday.

MADRID, Dec. 23 -- A general change of United States policy to encourage economic relations with all countries while continuing to abide by United Nations decisions in diplomatic matters was predicted here today in one of a spate of articles prompted by keen official interest in the development of United States relations with Spain.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 23 (AP) -- Windsor Farms' Midchannel, under a rousing ride by Herb Lindberg, stormed her way to a head victory in the six-furlong sixth race at Tropical Park today in the fast time of 1:10 4/5. She paid $9.10 for $2 straight.

As rain drenched New York's Croton and Catskill watersheds yesterday, city officials expressed the hope that with continued public cooperation daily net losses of water from the reservoirs would stop within two weeks.

The news in scarves this season is in a new printing process as well as in their shapes and color combinations. Large coat scarves tell a story in their patterns. Smaller ones have been designed so that they can be worn as a dickey with a suit.

SCRANTON, Pa., Dec. 23 (AP) -- The parents of a 9-year-old Scranton girl, who has been in a coma for nearly two years because of sleeping sickness, today sued Montefiore Hospital, New York, for $100,000.

ROME, Dec. 23 -- Pope Pius XII called today upon all Protestant and Orthodox Christian churches to "return" to that of Rome and urged all Christians as well as Jews to support the Roman Catholic Church in the creation of a united front against militant atheism.

Felicitations of the Synagogue Council of America were extended yesterday to American Christians preparing to celebrate Christmas. The council is composed of representatives of rabbinical sand lay organizations of orthodox, reform and conservative Judaism.

Fred Wilt, National A. A. U. 5,000 and 10,000 meter and cross-country titleholder, will open his 1950 local track campaign in the invitation two-mile of the Metropolitan A. A. U. open meet at the 102d Engineers Armory Jan. 4. Wilt was a newcomer to New York when he won this event from scratch in the board-blazing time of 9:18.1 a year ago.

The commuters on the Long Island Rail Road are patient souls. They have a sporting interest in their railroad: they would like to see the bankrupt company make good. Yet Thursday night's accident in the Sunnyside yards -- a tragic accident in which two train-men were killed -- seems to have evoked more criticism among commuters than any other event since the great hiatus during the snowstorm of Dec. 26, 1947.

ATHENS, Ga., Dec. 23 (AP) -- Dean John E. Drewry of the University of Georgia School of Journalism and a friend, Miss Merriam Thurmond, were shot tonight by his divorced wife. The condition of both was reported serious.

Throughout the country thousands of youngsters are going to be speechless with happiness tomorrow morning when they tear the bright wrappings from the Shotgun or rifle that to them is the "one" Christmas gift.

PARIS, Dec 24 -- The Ministry of Finance announced today that by the end of the year France will have conformed with the recommendation made by European Marshall Plan Council on Nov. 1 that its members reduce import quotas on manufactured products, agricultural products and raw materials, each by 50 per cent.

BERLIN, Dec. 23 -- West Berliners will cash in on approximately 250,000,000 Deutsche marks ($59,525,000) as a result of authorization today by the three Western commandants of revaluation of old Reichsmark accounts blocked by the Russians on May 9, 1945.

OTTAWA, Dec. 23 (AP) -- A spokesman of the External Affairs Department said today that he would "be very surprised" If Canada's Air Transport Board took any action to cancel Colonial Airlines' license before the Canadian-American air agreement talks were concluded.
Julius Simon, American president of the Palestine Economic Corporation, described yesterday as "tommyrot" reports that the Israeli Government plans the nationalization of basic industries there.

The meaning of Christmas over the world and in America, as exemplified by the cosmopolitanism of the Washington Square neighborhood, is told in a Christmas message from Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the New York Methodist area, American co-president of the World Council of Churches.
The Italian liner Vulcania was delayed for more than three hours in the harbor as officials of the United States Public Health Service conferred.

Real winter weather rushed into the city yesterday with rain, sleet and gusts of wind up to thirty-five miles an hour that harassed last-minute shoppers, but assured New Yorkers of a seasonably cold Christmas. In one half-hour the mercury slid down twelve degrees.

The stock market pushed ahead yesterday to fresh highs since August, 1946, but lack of interest in the afternoon shaded peak gains on the Stock Exchange to an average net increase of 0.30 point on the day. Opinion in financial circles on the, immediate course of the share list was as confused as previously this week.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Dec. 23 (AP) -- A crater of marshy ooze, bits of metal and dirty water marked the death site today of an Air Force B-50 bomber and eleven airmen, including a son of Rogers Hornsby, veteran baseball player and manager.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 -- "Early construction" of four new 'round-the-world passenger-cargo liners, to cost an estimated $40,000,000, is planned by American President Lines, it was announced today by George Killion, the president.
CHICAGO, Dec. 23 (AP) -- A "Standing Room Only" sign went up at the Midwest Stock Exchange today. All 400 of its seats have been sold and its president, James E. Day, said no more were available.

When your youngster gets down to business with his new set of paints, you needn't feel called on to rave over the results. In fact, says Victor D'Amico, director of the department of education of the Museum of Modern Art, you shouldn't.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Ship captains who attempt to run the Nationalist blockade into Communist-held Chinese ports may have their masters' licenses revoked, the State Department warned today. It has classified the waters around Shanghai, for example, as a danger zone, although it has declined to acknowledge the validity of the Nationalist blockade.

In the case of Spain, the policy of ostracism retains a following. Your editorial, "Visitors to Spain," Dec. 17, offers fresh evidence of that. In the case of other countries we see the reasonableness of cultivating good relations with the Governments they have, and the value, for the peoples concerned, of a circulating flow of goods and services between them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Railroads with critical coal shortages were directed by the Interstate Commerce Commission today to take steps leading to seizure of coal from mines usually supplying them. The commission asserted that an emergency existed that required immediate action in all parts of the country.

FRANKFORT, Dec. 23 -- What the Lynds did for Muncie, Ind., in "Middletown," a group of Germans is attempting to do at Darmstadt, a typical German city of 85,000 persons that is 60 per cent destroyed by bombs, in the first such community survey ever attempted in Germany.

Eclipse Sleep Products, Inc., one of the largest local bedding manufacturers, will increase prices 3 to 5 per cent on some promotional items on Jan. 1, Irving Weisglas, president, disclosed yesterday. He said the advances are being made because of rising costs of materials, particularly steel.

The New York City Dance Theatre at the City Center last night touched the pinnacle of its achievement with its presentation of Jose Limon and his company in Doris Humphrey's "Day on Earth." This is surely one of the great masterpieces of our time, and the performance it received on this occasion was commensurate with its greatness.

The first analysis of the effects of steel price rises on costs of cap, machine and wood screws was received here yesterday from George P. Byrne, managing director of the United States Cap Screw Service Bureau, 53 Park Place.
The cotton futures market opened 1 to 5 points higher on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and closed 2 to 9 points higher.
EAST ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 23 -- Mrs. Ines Adrian Johns, wife of an Army captain, began her Christmas shopping today with a good reason for the late start.

A new comedy series, "That Wonderful Guy," will make its bow at 9:30 P. M. Wednesday, Jan. 4, over the ABC network's television facilities. Jack Lemmon will head the show's cast in the part of "a brash young lad from Kalamazoo" who serves as houseboy to a New York drama critic.

A new program to induce greater public cooperation in consumer research surveys by impressing individuals with the importance of their influence on such studies was announced yesterday by National Analysts, Inc., marketing research organization of Philadelphia.

The message of good-will that has attended the celebration of Christmas since the birth of Jesus in Bethlehem will be heard again in the churches today and tomorrow in carols, hymns and oratorios. Special sermons will be preached and gifts will be taken to many mangers for the poor.

Proposals to remove certain tax exemptions from farmers' cooperative selling and buying organizations are ill-advised because such action would adversely affect consumers. The so-called "profits" of the well-managed farm "co-ops" accumulated in reserves for working capital are essential to the expansion of a five-billion-dollar annual business which serves the public by improving the quality and reducing the cost of food products.
MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 23 (AP) -The present re-education program in Germany is characterized by "confusion rather than orderliness," a visiting expert to that country said today.

MANILA, Dec. 23 -- The Philippines Congress has become entangled in complicated mass charges against the government's import control office involving alleged control, evasions by favored importers, ghost entries and false quota allocations.

A great sweep of history lies behind the symbolic gesture with which Pope Pius XII will this morning break down the Holy Door of the basilica of St. Peter in Rome and inaugurate another Jubilee. The hopes that have been buried since the last Holy Year in 1933 will rise again, for mankind must always hope, especially in this season, that a door will at last be opened to peace and justice "for all humanity."

Coffee futures were firm in yesterday's abbreviated session of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The market opened higher on scattered commission house demand. The tempo of this demand increased later in the day and, along with some trade hedge covering, advanced prices in several delivery positions to the daily permissible limit of 200 points.

After two rounds of the women's tournament for the chess championship of the world, currently being contested in the concert hall of the Red Army Club in Moscow, Miss N. May Karff of Boston. Frieda Heemskerk of Holland and Olga Rubsova, one of the four Soviet competitors, share the lead with scores of 1 1/2 -- 1/2, according to a report from London.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -- President Truman approved today additional Federal loans totaling $15,286,600 to aid 118 cities draw up plans for public housing projects.

PARIS, Dec. 23 -- The insistence by United States officials that Britain should cooperate more closely with the European Continent under the Marshall Plan and in the Council of Europe has led to proposals that the British Commonwealth should tighten its ties with Europe.
Louis Boy came home to his family yesterday after spending eighteen years in Sing Sing.
ASPEN, Col., Dec. 23 (AP) -- Crosby Perry-Smith of Western (Col.) State took first place in both the cross-country and jumping events in an intercollegiate skiing meet today.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Dec. 23 -- With the cares and worries of the Presidency left behind in Washington, Harry S. Truman came home today to celebrate among his family and friends the festival of Christmas.

Physical chemistry is comparatively a young science, and it has not yet found its place among other branches of chemistry. Its educational status is not satisfactory. Only in a few institutions is it taught properly.

FREEDOM, Pa., Dec. 23 (AP) -- The nine-million-dollar Freedom-Valvoline Oil Company was sold today as the firm's president and board chairman lashed out with a bitter protest against present-day inheritance and income taxes.

Top leaders of Congress of Industrial Organizations unions, representing 500,000 members in New York, gave full backing yesterday to the Transport Workers Union in its drive for higher wages and shorter hours on the city transit system.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board said today that it would investigate complaints from persons in the New York area that nonscheduled air carriers had sold tickets and failed to deliver transportation.

TRENTON, Dec. 23 -- Three university professors were named today by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll as an arbitration board to break a wage deadlock between union employes and the Public Service Transportation companies. There are 4600 bus drivers and other workers involved in the contract dispute.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- New standards for "white collar" employes who are exempt from the Fair Labor Standards Act will go into effect on Jan. 25. That also is the effective date of the revised law.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 23 (AP) -- An entire Ohio town stepped out tonight for its biggest party of the year.
LONDON, Dec. 23 -- Because of the Hungarian Government's refusal to allow access to a British subject arrested in Budapest, the British Government has suspended trade negotiations with Hungary.
The Celotex Corporation, in a preliminary statement covering the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 last, reported yesterday a net income of $1,950,000 after all charges.
YONKERS, Dec. 23 -- Because of a storm of protests the Yonkers Common Council early this morning delayed action on the tentative 1950 municipal budget of $17,127,372.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- A basic difference of approach continues to exist between the United States and British governments over the role to be played in the North Atlantic treaty organization by the secretary general of the important Military Committee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Clark M. Clifford, special counsel to President Truman and one of the prominent figures of the Fair Deal Administration, will practice law in Washington with Edward H. Miller, another Missourian.

Seafarers and students from foreign lands, the aged who are alone and children whose stockings will hang tonight in hospital wards were caught yesterday in a swirl of parties that helped ease the sadness of not being home for Christmas.

Harry L. Lindquist, currently vice president of the organization, has been nominated as 1950 president of the New York Athletic Club. Following the formal elections on Jan. 10, he will succeed Theodore J. Van Twisk, who is retiring from office because of poor health, as top officer of the world's largest athletic club.
LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 24 -- United Nations delegates and staff workers left Lake Success headquarters closed and empty today as they scattered to celebrate their fourth Christmas in the United States.

DETROIT, Dec. 24 -- Police threw a protective ring today around top officials of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, to prevent a recurrence of a campaign of intimidation and to assure the union leaders a safe Christmas with their families.

THIS is the time of the year when artists and their managers are discussing whether or not they will stay with each other for 1950-51. The discussions have not all been amicable. Indeed some have been acrimonious.
AFTER one of my concerts in a Scandinavian country, a reputable critic wrote: "Isaac Stern has the technique of an American, but his musicality and soul are European."

Last week, when Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan announced his initial estimate of sugar consumption in this country for the coming year, industrial users and consumers hailed it as a victory in their battle to bring down prices.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Army was charged with "inept budgetary planning" by John P. Bracken, National president of the Reserve Officers Association, today. He was criticizing the Army's decision to cut back, starting Jan. 1, its paid drills for certain categories of reservists.
An 11-year-old boy arrived from France yesterday to spend the Christmas holidays with members of the Forest Hills Boys Club.

THE City Center's new modern dance project, the New York City Dance Theatre, closed its first season last night before a house sold out well in advance, and since last night was Christmas Eve and notoriously the poorest box-office night of the year, that was a significant accomplishment.

JERUSALEM, Sunday, Dec. 25 -- Chapel bells rang in Bethlehem, Jerusalem and Nazareth last night, while Christians throughout the length and breadth of the Holy Land raised their voices in prayer as midnight ushered in the birthday of Christ.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Possibly the busiest neck of these governmental woods nowadays is the west end of the dingy granite pile next door to the White House known as the old State Department Building. There, in the Bureau of the Budget, a compact staff of fiscal experts is getting ready to perform the annual task of "putting the book to bed."

William F. (Bill) Talbert of New York, who last week was ranked third nationally, subject to approval at the United States Lawn Tennis Association's meeting next month, has been placed at the head of the men's seedings in the East, it was announced yesterday.

Dr. Frank S. Hackett, founder of the Riverdale Country School, Riverdale-on-Hudson, was the guest of honor yesterday at a pre-Christmas breakfast party at the home of his son Robert, 13 Fox Meadow Road, Scarsdale, N. Y. It was Dr. Hackett's seventy-second birthday.

PARIS, Dec. 24 -- Since the days of the great Caesars and the conquering khans of Asia, there probably has never been such a massively organized tribute to a single man as the celebration of Generalissimo Stalin's seventieth birthday last Wednesday.

BEFORE every national holiday there are dire statistical predictions of disasters which will occur during the twenty-four-hour festival period. But the statisticians are unaware of the toll which will be taken today on this merriest of holidays due to the deceivingly innocent presence of art under the Christmas tree: art materials to tempt the amateur; art books; works of art; art works.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Several thousand Washington residents stood in the cold, crisp twilight on the south lawn of the White House today to witness the twenty-seventh annual tree-lighting ceremonies.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 24 -- The United States has informed the Netherlands Government that an agreement with Britain and France to lift the ban on foreign investments in Western Germany is expected "in the near future."

Little children broke into their piggy banks yesterday in behalf of the Neediest Cases and, also, sent money they had received as Christmas gifts. In labored lines written on paper torn from copy-books, they told of turning over their savings and gifts to help the unfortunate about whom they had read in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

MOSCOW, Dec. 23 -- In the windows of Moscow's big Mostorg department store on Petrovka Street today there is a green "yolka," bright with tinsel and gay decorations and beside it, with his knees deep in toys and playthings, stands "Deyd Moroz" smiling benignly in his red suit and fur-trimmed cap.

BOSTON, Dec. 24 -- Although the Christmas spirit pervaded most of New England this week, crowding out more mundane problems for the time being, two developments in Massachusetts were of more that passing interest.

AGAIN comes that happy occasion when this corner has its one big chance to say such nice things about the movies as it would regularly and always like to say. This is the old year's last Sunday, when custom obligingly decrees that we should make our selections of the best -- the "ten best" -- films of the year.

Death took its toll of many sports notables in 1949, including Marcel Cerdan, French boxing idol, and Rex Mays, veteran auto racer, who were cut down in tragic accidents. Cerdan, former world middleweight champion, died in a plane crash in the Azores, and Mays, thrown when his machine hit a chuck hole on a California track was killed when struck by another car in the race.

CHRISTMAS wouldn't be Christmas without eggnog, holly and -- it must be added with even more gravity -- "The Pickwick Papers." Mr. Dickens' first, brimmingly hilarious and wonderful masterpiece has been issued in a non-"Phiz" edition (Simon Schuster. $5) to help make this the felicitous holiday it should be.

The Yuletide Assembly, for debutantes, post-debutantes and their escorts, will be held tomorrow night in the grand ballroom of the Plaza. Several dinners will take place in advance of the dance, which is under the direction of Miss Bonnie May Murray and is one in a series of dances.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 24 -- City and transit officials tonight squared off for a showdown fight with union leadership after the American Federation of Labor transit union voted solidly to continue indefinitely a strike that has crippled Cleveland's transportation facilities.

It was a year of ups and downs in the world of sport for 1949. Enthusiasm ran high, but attendance marks along with their corresponding financial returns took some astonishing dips. Sounds a bit incongruous, but that's the way it went.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 24 -- India has suspended deliveries of coal to Pakistan in retaliation for the Moslem nation's alleged failure to deliver Indian jute purchases, K. C. Neogy, Minister of Commerce, announced in Parliament today.

COINCIDENT with its change of title from "Living-1949" to "Living-1950," NBC's documentary dramatic series will undertake an inventory of the twentieth century at mid-point. According to Thomas C. McCray, NBC's national program manager, the series will devote a three- month cycle of broadcasts to an interpretive treatment of social, political, economic and scientific aspects of contemporary culture, beginning with the program of Jan. 1 at 4 P. M.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 24 -- In view of the Germans' critical reaction to the end of the war-crimes trials with the conviction of former Field Marshal Gen. Fritz Erich von Mannstein last Monday, it may be useful to recall the original premises on which the trials were held.

I do not think J. E. Morpurgo in "'Darkest America' on the British Map" need be too ashamed of British ignorance of American history. Our record is probably just as bad on British history. Not one American in a thousand could name even one monarch in most of the grand divisions of British history from Boadicea to George VI.

ANY reader who likes birds will enjoy this little gem of nature writing because it has to do mainly with birds, is well written and is delightfully illustrated. It is the historical account of a war-weary officer of the British Army who is determined to have a little peace at last, and a few birds to go with it, because he always has been a keen ornithologist.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Disturbed by rumors of Congressional "salary kickbacks" and "payroll padding," two Senators today urged full public records on office payrolls of all Senators.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The provisional civil air transport agreement between the United States and Yugoslavia, announced in Belgrade today, was viewed at the State Department as a mildly encouraging step in the growing rapprochement between Marshal Tito and the Western nations.

OUR legation in London just before and during the Civil War was a quaintly tiny establishment. It consisted of the Minister -- first James Buchanan 1853-1856, then another Pennsylvanian, George Mifflin Dallas, till 1861, and then Charles Francis Adams -- with two secretaries and a clerk or two.
1949 was the year in which Russia made the bomb.

WHEN Cap'n Perkins can no longer get cargo for his Down-East schooner, he turns the Ella J. Perkins into a "sea-going dude ranch." Son Perk sails as a cabin boy, and his sister Lula, his friend Round-ears, and Ma Perkins also go along to help in the new venture.

DETROIT, Dec. 24 (UP) -- Replacement demand for cars and trucks is far greater today than at any time in the automobile industry's history. This is one of the reasons the nation's car makers expect production to remain higher than pre-war levels for many years to come.

IT seems fitting this morning, while most everyone is in the glow of unwrapped Christmas gifts, to observe that Peter Lawrence's contemplated production of "Peter Pan" appears more imminent than at any time in more than a year of preparation. This rosy-hued aspect may be attributed to the fact that Jean Arthur, apparently with the blessing of Paramount Pictures, has been signed for the leading role.

The New York premiere of the motion picture, "The Third Man," on the night of Jan. 18 at the Victoria Theatre will aid the work of the Lighthouse of the New York Association for the Blind. Mrs. George F. Baker is chairman of the benefit committee. Her co-chairman are Mrs. Howard S. Cullman, Mrs. Marshall Field and Mrs. Evander B. Schley.

BERLIN, Dec. 24 -- Through more than four years West Berliners have waited for a chance to celebrate again a traditional "Heiligen Abend" (Holy Evening). Tonight they have it -- their best Christmas since the end of the war.

General Electric Company is preparing a simple but comprehensive textbook on the "economic facts of life" for distribution to its 15,000 supervisors late in February, Lemuel C. Boulware, vice president in charge of employe relations, disclosed last week.

The Christmas shopping season ended yesterday after one of the largest buying waves in history, both in New York and throughout the country. A nation-wide survey indicated that Detroit was the only major exception.

CHRISTMAS and family fun are synonymous. The children are automatically the focus of attention and parents spend much of their time not only planning for the youngsters but also being with them -- enjoying gifts, playing games, singing songs. It is a time when father, mother and children share their fun on easiest terms.

Providing new incentives to encourage more students to enter medical schools "will only have the effect of lowering the standards of medical education," Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, dean of Columbia University's Faculty of Medicine, declared in his annual report, made public yesterday.

" No matter where his ship may be or how long it has been away from the home port every American seaman is likely to sit down to the traditional turkey dinner today, a dinner better in most cases than will be encountered by the average man ashore," says a Christmas Day gastronomical review issued by the American Merchant Marine Institute.

A guardedly hopeful picture of a democratic Germany in the future was painted yesterday by Dr. Charles D. Winning, acting director of the educational and cultural relations division of the Department of State.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Santa Anita's multi-million dollar merry-go-round begins a 50-day whirl Monday and once again the customers will be grabbing for the brass ring aboard man's most unpredictable friend, the race horse.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UP) -- The National Citizens Committee Against Forced Reading and Forced Listening started a new drive tonight against the broadcasting of advertising, news and music in street cars, buses and railroad stations.
The Christmas message of Pope Pius XII, as interpreted by Vatican circles, was sharply criticized yesterday in a sermon by Rabbi Louis I. Newman at Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street.

ON semi-postals released by the German Federal Republic is an inscription meaning "Help Free Charity to Mitigate Need." The designs are portraits of Elizabeth v. Thuringen on 8-pfennigs plus 2pf gray-violet, Paracelsus v. Hohenheim on 10pf plus 5pf green, Friedrich Wilhelm August Froebel on 20pf plus 10pf chestnut, Johann Hinrich Wichern on 30pf plus 15pf blue.

Case No. 1 in THE NEW YORK TIMES' Thirty-eighth Annual Appeal for New York's 100 Neediest Cases this Christmas is that of a 7-year-old boy who has been rejected by his divorced parents, and is now in a foster home awaiting adoption.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 24 -- A late upsurge in Christmas buying sent department store sales in the Ninth Federal Reserve District soaring over last year, the bank in Minneapolis reported this week. Figures for the four-week period ending Dec. 17 showed dollar volume of sales in the four major cities 101 per cent of the 1948 total, the first time last year's records have been surpassed in months.

The Christmas spirit, that rich rare compound of hope, joy, mystery and worship, sifted down through the crisp December skies and radiated warmly from the hearts of countless thousands of givers yesterday as the city bustled through its final preparations for the biggest day of all.

The bimonthly annotated list of additions to the collection of the Science and Technology Division of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, is now available in the November-December issue and may be purchased for 25 cents at the Inquiry Desk.

MATT WINTERS is not a real detective, but he does make a hobby of trying to figure out murder and other of the more noticeable crimes, and what's going on in the Margate family seems to him worthy of consideration.

FOR THIS WEEK: Water, about once every three weeks, outdoor window boxes filled with evergreen branches or plants. . . . When the ground is hard with frost, mulch newly planted evergreen and deciduous shrubs. . . . To protect trees planted during the past year from sun scald or other winter injury, wrap the trunks with strips of burlap. . . .

LONDON, Dec. 24 -- There was no question in anyone's mind tonight but that this was the happiest Christmas Eve the British people have had in ten years. From one end of the country to the other churches of every denomination began filling early as men, women and children came to give thanks for what they had -- but, above all, for peace.

Creation of a new international division is being considered by the National Retail Dry Goods Association, with its formation likely to be acted upon at the N. R. D. G. A. convention next month, it was learned here last week.

The anniversary of His birth, many thought, gave protection from evil spirits, from the miasma supposed to pollute the night air, from erratic heavenly bodies, wicked fairies and witches.
