Dr. Frank S. Hackett, founder of the Riverdale Country School, Riverdale-on-Hudson, was the guest of honor yesterday at a pre-Christmas breakfast party at the home of his son Robert, 13 Fox Meadow Road, Scarsdale, N. Y. It was Dr. Hackett's seventy-second birthday.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 24 -- Penn will start its 1950 November football games a half-hour earlier to avoid the 1949 practice of finishing in semi-darkness.

WE do not think enough about thinking, and much of our confusion is the result of current illusions in regard to it. Let us forget for the moment any impression we may have derived from the philosophers and see what seems to happen in ourselves.
LONDON, Dec. 24 (Reuters) -- Liverpool strengthened its position atop the English football league's first division with a 3-1 victory over Everton in a Christmas Eve match before 50,000 fans.

LAST week's announcement by WMCA that it was suspending operation of it frequency modulation affiliate, WMCA-FM, has focused attention on the growing economic crisis confronting FM radio. The reason for the suspension was simply that the station was unable to attract a large enough audience and was suffering a monthly loss of $4,000.

A NEW line of telephoto lenses, Kilfitt-Kilar, designed for ground glass focusing at eye-level on Leica and Contax cameras, is announced by Peerless Camera Stores, 138 East Forty-fourth Street, the importers. The lenses are available in 6-inch f/3.5 and 12-inch f/5.6, both coated and costing $249.50 and $279, respectively, for the Leica camera.

DURING the holiday season the lighted Christmas tree creates a center of warmth and interest in a room. Those who hate to relinquish its bright effect may obtain a similar result throughout the year by making lighting in the home decorative as well as functional.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 24 -- Mrs. O. L. Nyberg's Irisen won the featured $5,000 Christmas Handicap at Tropical Park today in a photo finish with Mrs. C. A. Cope's Bolo Mack.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti -- On the semicircular shore of La Gonave Bay, where a mile of Port-au-Prince's waterfront shacks have been cleared away, the gleaming white, extremely modern buildings of the International Exposition celebrating the city's 200th anniversary, stand in sharp contrast to the older architecture and even older customs and habits of the capital.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UP) -- Representative John Kee, Democrat, of West Virginia, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said tonight it would be "a catastrophe" for Congress to make a heavy cut in next year's Marshall Plan funds.

DESPITE its immediacy of appeal the work of Paul Klee is in many ways among the most baffling and paradoxical in the whole modern movement. Only Picasso's protean output rivals it in fertility and in diversity.

Seventy-five per cent of the nation's mentally retarded children can earn their own living and take care of themselves if proper training is provided, according to the Rev. James Smyth, Professor of Religion at the University of Notre Dame.

IN Finland as in America the best-seller lists have been topped this fall by "Sinuhe" ("The Egyptian"), Mika Waltari's foray into the age of the Pharaohs. Whatever its literary worth, this novel has proved its fiscal value to the sum of 92,000 copies sold in the author's homeland and well over 450,000 copies in the United States.

HERE we have man's old ally, the horse reduced nowadays mainly to playmate, presented through letterpress and pictures in various aspects. Colonel Lyon's book is a record of the animal's performance on course and field during the season 1947-1948 in England, with a side glance at Ireland, India and the United States.

GENEVA, Dec. 24 -- One of the first things the Western Allies promised themselves, and the people of liberated Europe, about the kind of world it would be after World War II was that looted property and property acquired by duress during the Nazi administration or occupation would be restored to the rightful owners or their heirs.
THE Tuscan-red Powhatan Arrow, fast Norfolk Western daylight streamliner between Norfolk and Cincinnati, is now operating with brand-new equipment, fresh from the shops of Pullman-Standard.
ROME, Dec. 24 -- Pope Plus XII opened the 1950 Holy Year today with a stately ceremony performed under the Portico and inside the Basilica of St. Peter's.

IN March, 1950, the theatres of the United States will stage a nation-wide demonstration of a fact sometimes forgotten in the alarums and excursions of day-to-day production: that the theatre is one of the most potent and dynamic vehicles for international understanding.
SONOMA, Calif., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Jane Maggard Dickson was shot and killed and a ranch worker critically wounded late today, the Sheriff's office said, when a ranch foreman went berserk.

ONE of radio's most successful, commercial formulas is the women's commentator type of program. Broadcast during daylight hours, and particularly in the mornings, it is designed to entertain, inform and inspire the housewife.
THE wisdom of Billy Rose haunts the Japanese stage. The redoubtable American showman visited Tokyo last spring and his remarks at that time epitomize the growing conflict gripping the Tokyo theatre.

Although Admiral Louis E. Denfeld's letter to Secretary of the Navy Francis P. Matthews last Monday threatened a new engagement in the Battle of the Pentagon, by yesterday the peace of the Christmas season descended on the combatants.

CHRISTMAS gifts undoubtedly come to bridge players the same as to other people, but the gifts they are likely to remember longest are not the ones they get on Christmas. The true addict thinks most fondly of the gifts he gets at the bridge table.

In the article on antihistamines and their use in blocking incipient colds which appeared on this page last week it was erroneously stated that coricidin was favored by the Navy. Capt. John M. Brewster was the naval medical officer who reported on the effectiveness of the antihistamines in colds, but coricidin was not one of the compounds that he tested with the results discussed in the January-February issue of the Naval Medical Bulletin.

DURING the past year, some new developments have become apparent in the art of flower arrangement -- a hobby that women all over the country find absorbing. These changes are not as marked as they were immediately following the war, but a-review of the year's shows does disclose several interesting trends.
LONDON, Dec. 24 (Reuters) -- The Moscow radio alleged today that Soviet prisoners of war had been used as human guinea pigs for experiments in bacteriological warfare by Japanese units in Manchuria.

The most serious water shortage in the history of New York City has finally caused most of its 8,000,000 residents to pay considerable attention to where all the water comes from and particularly to what happens to it every day.

ROME, Dec. 24 -- The Holy Year, or Jubilee, opened today in Rome for the twenty-fifth time in history. To Roman Catholics the celebration has primarily a spiritual significance, yet on this occasion a strong political undertone is present.

ATLANTA, Dec. 24 -- People in the Southeast were concerned mainly this week with Christmas activities, but among other events drawing wide attention was the launching in Georgia of a community interracial project to deal with the problem of providing equal school facilities for white and Negro children.

IF only because the creator of Natty Bumppo developed such a mania for litigation, there is strong logic in hiring a lawyer to make a new biographical appraisal. Doubly qualified, as both lawyer and man of letters, James Grossman has worked out a beautifully balanced and penetrating reinterpretation, at once terse and comprehensive.

Independence, Mo., (pop. 16,066) is celebrating Christmas in the characteristic fashion of a small American city. On the shopping streets the lamp-posts are hung with large plastic bells and heads of Santa Claus. The courthouse is outlined in colored lights, and Christmas trees stand at each of its four corners.
AN imposing brochure comes to hand: the fiftieth anniversary book -- "Fifty Years of Highlights with the Philadelphia Orchestra."

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 -- Department store sales here this week failed to maintain the pace set the week before and on a day-to-day comparison with a year ago were off 5 to 8 per cent, estimates indicated. However, on a weekly comparison with a year ago, when there were only five trading days, the increase was placed at 10 to 15 per cent.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 24 -- Robert Borden Reams, United States charge d'affaires, and Vladimir Popovitch, Yugoslav Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs, signed a provisional agreement here today granting American civil air transport planes the right to use Yugoslav civilian airfields and pass over Yugoslav territory en route to other points.

THE Norths have been meeting Murder -- in books, on the air, even on Broadway -- for a good many years now, and probably will for a good long time to come. On the present occasion -- as often in the past -- the encounter is of a coincidental nature.
The diplomatic immunity claimed by two United Nations employes proved no match for a policeman's nightstick in an early morning skirmish here yesterday.

Congressional plans to legislate a retroactive income tax on life insurance companies for 1947 and 1948, is likely to meet with sharp opposition from within the industry. Generally, it had been expected that the companies were resigned to such legislative action and would accept the proposed levy without resistance.

As is our custom on Christmas morning, we take note of the number and amount of the contributions to The Hundred Neediest Cases Fund. Since this, the thirty-eighth, annual appeal was opened, $243,161.50 in contributions has been received, and the contributors number 8,414.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 24 -- Westerners are increasingly hopeful a Rockefeller family "Christmas gift" of 33,500 acres of Jackson Hole lands to the Federal Government will permanently halt the long controversy over public-land use in the beautiful western Wyoming region.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- A Federal tax-enforcement and collection program of unsurpassed scope and intensity is under consideration here as a possible means of offsetting all or part of the revenue losses expected to result from a prospective reduction of excise taxes next year.

LADENTOWN, N. Y., Dec. 24 -- Residents of this rural hamlet, who consider such local persons as Paulette Goddard, Burgess Meredith, Waldo Peirce or colorful members of the Ramapo mountaineer colony just ordinary folk, learned today that the police chief of Ramapo Township, who is also president of the New York State Chiefs of Police Association, was known from the Canadian border to south Jersey.

During the visit of Prime Minister Nehru to this country several newspaper stories appeared indicating that a "barter deal" was in progress whereby the United States would sell one million tons of wheat to India in exchange for such raw materials as mica and manganese, which the United States needs.

The Christmas Scholarship Fund of Bonnie Brae Farm for Boys will be the beneficiary of a Christmas family dinner and square dance to be held at the Essex Fox and Hounds Club in Peapack, N. J., tomorrow night. Both adults and children have been invited to attend.

With the smaller college teams taking the Yuletide holiday seriously by remaining idle, the burden of carrying on the cage campaign will fall upon Gotham's bigger schools as they appear in three double-headers at Madison Square Garden within a four-day period.

A REAPPRAISAL of the entire philosophy of speed limits and controls to meet reasonable conditions is recommended by Lou E. Holland, president of the American Automobile Association, who bases his suggestions on studies of driver behavior under varying circumstances.

WHAT the Pitman Gallery, the British-produced series of picture books on art and artists, is a praiseworthy enterprise is reaffirmed by the four latest volumes. Each one contains ten color plates with critical remarks attached; each is opened with a short introduction by a reputable scholar in the field.

A HOLIDAY display of flowers in a small lean-to greenhouse may sound pleasant, but not quite practical. Yet it has been shown that red, pink and white poinsettias, cyclamen and camellias add a festive touch to the Rex hybrid begonias, fuchsias, lantanas and gardenias that usually bloom in winter.

While the days before Christmas have been notable in these parts for an absence of arctic weather, they have also been notable for the presence of an arctic visitor of another sort -- the snowy owl. This magnificent and valuable bird, with a five-foot wingspread, strays down to these latitudes every few years coincidentally with the periodic shortage in the Far North of lemmings, his favorite food.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Dec. 24 -- The pageant of the Nativity, staged here annually since 1914, was presented as a community event at 5:30 this evening by a cast of 100 townspeople on the lawn of Reformed Church of Pondfield Road opposite the civic center. A throng of about 5,000 persons witnessed the spectacle, in which representatives of all local religious and civic groups participated.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 24 -- Hungary rejected in a note today the United States' demand for the release of Robert A. Vogeler, and announced that the American communications executive had "confessed" that he was guilty of spying, economic sabotage and "criminal activities."

VITTORIO DE SICA director of "Shoeshine" and "The Bicycle Thief," is conducting a painstaking search for a leading man for his next picture, "I Poveri Disturbano" (The Poor Are Disturbing), which he hopes will turn up a young Chaplin and Harry Langdon combined.

THERE seems to be no doubt about it -- after almost fifty years of so-called modern music there are still thousands of well-intentioned music lovers who think it sounds peculiar. The only way I can get the full impact of what modern music must sound like to such people is to stand in front of Picasso's more controversial paintings -- the two-headed women, for example.

Mr. Truman speaking from Independence yesterday was not a President issuing a proclamation -- he was an American citizen, in many ways typical of countless Americans of his age and upbringing, telling what Christmas means to him. We all know that Presidents have secretaries who help them with their speeches, but we also know that the emotion and thought behind this speech came out of valued memories that stir many an American heart.

A FINAL pre-Christmas tour of the museums and galleries finds work by leading graphic artists of the past and of today much in evidence. On exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum are the latest purchases of prints and engravings, a choice group that shows the Print Room keeping its eyes widely and discriminatingly open.

Six contests with the Brooklyn Dodgers, their world series foe of last October, mark the 1950 spring training schedule of the New York Yankees. The ambitious program announced for the world champions yesterday calls for a total of thirty-nine games.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Government expects to order cuts in railroad passenger travel soon in order to conserve the country's shrinking coal supplies, according to J. Monroe Johnson, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission.
Two teen-agers from England and two from this country agreed yesterday that not enough young people were preparing themselves adequately for world citizenship.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- As a gesture of practical friendship for the United States of Indonesia which will come into official existence next Tuesday, the Economic Cooperation Administration has shipped to Indonesia $37,500,000 worth, of rice, textiles and other goods in the past six weeks, it was learned today.

ESTABLISHMENT last week by President Truman of an air-space reservation, above the million-acre Superior National Forest in the northeast corner of Minnesota on the Canadian border, marked a major victory for conservationists in their continuing battle to preserve the country's dwindling wilderness areas from invasion by aerial sportsmen.

LITTLE man, you've had a busy day, Yes. It's been a most busy year in sports and the time has come for the annual accounting. So we'll thumb through the calendar for a rather quick look at what's happened.

Fourteen of the nation's professional societies in economic and other social science fields will hold their annual meetings in New York this week from Tuesday through Friday. About 4,000 persons, including many of the leading social scientists, are expected to attend the sessions.

YOU can see in these simple but very expressive pictures how the very little dog grew by leaps and bounds (literally as well as figuratively). Every day he ate all his food and drank his milk. He took his naps and went to bed early and did all the things that a growing child should do, with very happy results.

BACK at the old stand with a third edition of his best-selling almanac, Mi. Kieran again serves up the latest facts on everything from baseball to the United Nations. This year the "extra" feature -- another book- within-a-book -- is a complete travel guide for the 1950 vacationist.

Pope Pius XII praised in a message yesterday the contribution that the Committee for American Remittances to Europe has made to European reconstruction. The message was received by Paul Comly French, director of CARE, from Msgr. G. B. Montini, the Vatican's acting Secretary of State.

America is undoubtedly dark on the British map, as J. E. Morpurgo contends. But, judged by his criteria, the same ignorance is almost as prevalent within the United States. With the aid of four friends I addressed some of his questions to Florida tourists of varied backgrounds from all over the country.

THE motion - picture industry in Hollywood in 1949 emerged from a state of panic and settled down to the production of films on a reasonable and by previous standards, a business-like basis. In the process labor suffered most, not in wage levels, but in the amount of employment.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 20 -- President Mariano Ospina Perez of Colombia told this correspondent in an interview that while the country generally was calm and the people were returning to work the "state of siege" cannot be lifted until the causes that brought it about had disappeared.

THIS short volume is two books in one, the story of two groups of men, one Mid-western, the other Rocky Mountain, who certainly earned the title of "desperate." One is the James boys -- Jesse and his followers -- and the other the crew known variously as the Wild Bunch, the Hole - in - the - Wall Gang, and the Robbers' Roost Outfit.

GENEVA, Dec. 24 -- What is believed to be the first open advocacy of international cartels as a means of preventing or frustrating integration of the European market, which is being demanded by the Economic Cooperation Administration as the price of further United States aid, is being examined with interest by antitrust experts here.

PARIS, Dec. 24 -- Wishing Christmas cheer to the nation in a broadcast, Premier Georges Bidault said tonight that political discords and budget troubles "should not make France lose hope in her destinies."

DEBATES over the place of religion in education and over the use of public funds to aid students in denominational schools call for re-examination of our religious freedom doctrine. For such study Professor Blau, who teaches the philosophy of religion at Columbia University, has provided the indispensable starting point: a book that reproduces basic documents on the subject.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The United States Army made public on Jan. 3, 1946, a report on bacteriological offensive and defensive efforts of the United States and other nations. The report was prepared by George W. Merck, head of a drug firm and a special biological consultant to the Secretary of War.

THE music of Charles E. Ives does not get performed much, and naturally it is seldom recorded. It is news, therefore, when a substantial composition of his becomes available in any form. The Walden String Quartet, consisting of Homer Schmitt, Bernard Goodman, Eugene Weigel and Robert Swenson, has made a recording of the String Quartet No. 2, and the newly organized company.

THESE seven books are reminders that the United States is still a country of great diversity. Despite the automobile, movies, singing commercials and other standardized blessings of the twentieth century, variety persists.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 24 (AP) -- The holiday spirit settled over the Rose Bowl camps of Ohio State and California today, affording the athletes a week-end respite from training for their encounter on Jan. 2.

THERE is delightful escape from the current winter in this English summertime fantasy. The story's setting is a quiet brook, the Folly, beside whose Oak Pool live three elderly gnomes. They are brothers, these tiny gray men with long beards, almost the last of their race in England.
The churches of New York joined last night in heralding the birth of Christ as thousands gathered to usher in another Christmas Day with song and prayer.

JOB BENSON is having trouble getting along with people -- especially with his schoolmate, Roscoe Turner -- when the two boys are thrown into a situation which makes them forget their quarrel. They sail from New York aboard an ocean-going salvage tug, bound for the Caribbean in search of a sunken diamond treasure.
World at Peace The first Christmas dawned on a world at peace. The Paz Romana had begun and was not to be broken for more than two hundred years.

THE twentieth century opened with Queen Victoria still on her throne. Already she had given her name to an era, and already men were beginning to pronounce that era the best, the most prosperous, and the most enlightened in history, forgetting or ignoring the poverty and misery, the cruelty, oppression and wars, that had stained its history.

Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., and Pan American Airways finished preparations yesterday for next week's court fight to determine whether Pan American will share with TWA the expected heavy air passenger traffic to Rome during the 1950 Holy Year.

An additional thick weather aid for ships' officers is now under service test aboard a C-3 type cargo liner of Moore-McCormack Lines, it was made known yesterday. It was described as an "anti-collision sound detector." Its purpose is to bring to the navigator in the pilot house visual and audible indications of sound signals that are too faint to be heard by the human ear.

The usual seasonal decline in business has not appeared and recovery from recent major strike setbacks is progressing more rapidly than originally estimated. These conclusions summarized general conditions as the year-end approached, as reported by the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, according to Chairman Robert C. Swanton, who is also director of purchases for Winchester Repeating Arms Corporation, division of Olin Industries, Inc., New Haven.
Believe it or not -- Santa Claus has a separate workshop on lower Fifth Avenue.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 24 -- The long drawn out process of preparing the basis for better trade relations between Argentina and the United States entered the final and decisive stage this morning when Ambassador Jeronimo Remorino, accompanied by Foreign Minister Hipolito Jesus Paz, placed the report of the joint commission in the hands of President Juan D. Peron.

A token of good-will in the form of two bank drafts for $200 to be used for the reconstruction of the ancient church of St. Mary's in Southampton, England, is a gift from the cadet midshipmen and alumni of the New York State Maritime College, Fort Schuyler, N. Y.

Thanks to Friday's rainfall in the watershed areas and the continued water conservation effort by the public, the city's reservoirs held yesterday at 8 A. M. 361,000,000 gallons more than at the same hour on Friday.

Surgical and medical supplies in increasing quantities have been distributed in the last year through the Roman Catholic Medical Mission Board, the Rev. Edward F. Garesche, president and director, reported yesterday for the year ended Nov. 30.

MORE than anything else, Elena wanted to leave her great-grandfather's house and the tiny village where her Spanish ancestors had lived and get a job in Pueblo, where her brother and that attractive Natan work. But when her grandmother broke her knee Elena had to stay home.

SINCE, as everyone is aware, Broadway is never quite orthodox about anything -- it even goes to sleep when others are awakening -- this department cannot indulge in a year-end report such as those you can discover elsewhere in these pages this morning.

In view of the coming plebiscite on whether Leopold should return to the Belgian throne, Foster Harley's "Belgium Debates a King's Destiny" is timely, but does not seem to bring out some of the main issues.

VIENNA, Dec. 24 -- In an effort to erase from the calendar all Christian feasts, the Hungarian Government has extended the celebration of Premier Joseph Stalin's birthday to cover Christmas Eve although Premier Stalin was born on Dec. 21.

The tree is young, a symbol both of youth and life enduring. It is green, with the green of life that no winter wholly banishes. It is bright with lights and decoration, and beneath it are placed, as at an altar to life and the Nativity, the gifts of this day and this season.

Under a new fellowship program to be introduced next fall at Dartmouth College, a small group of seniors will be permitted to pursue their own independent courses of study. The purpose of these fellowships, the college has announced, is to give promising students "all the freedom they are capable of using profitably with the framework, but not necessarily within the curriculum, of the four-year undergraduate college."
BRANFORD, Conn., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Flaming death came to a family of four early today as fire swept through their two-story frame cottage here.

THE totting-up season is upon us again. We took the occasion to glance back through the year's concert and recital programs from the city's major halls, trying to get an informal picture of the contemporary music situation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Officials planning the capital's 150th birthday party next year ordered an inquiry today into a promoter's reported proposal to obtain building contracts for 10 per cent of the net profits.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 24 (UP) -- Eight-year-old Mary Bailey lost her fight for life tonight despite the heroic efforts of a refugee and former German army officer who risked his own life in an effort to save hers.

The Maritime Commission's action last week in directing the broadening of the scope of its investigation into complaints against the exclusive patronage contract rate system of steamship conferences will probably have a far-reaching effect on the future activities of the conferences and water-borne commerce generally, local shipping men said yesterday.

ANATOLE LITVAK, who rated some justifiable plaudits for "The Snake Pit," will be examining things psychiatric again for Twentieth Century-Fox, the director revealed the other day. The company, he said, has assigned him to direct a biography of Sigmund Freud.
The American Association for the Advancement of Science and its 214 affiliated and federated societies, with more than a million members, will open its annual meeting here tomorrow.

MORE things and less dollars was the story of Christmas trade. The week just ended will show a bang-up dollar gain for the country, but this can be set down to the fact that there was one more business day.
PARIS, Dec. 24 -- Indications of the evolving character of the Marshall Plan became clearer than ever this week during negotiations in Paris, the European headquarters for the plan.

Unmistakeable evidence of pre-holiday influences left their imprint on financial markets last week. Trading on the New York Stock Exchange was at the slowest pace in more than a month. Selective gains were sufficient, however, to move stock prices slightly higher on balance.

PARTYING reaches a peak when the ladies have had just about all the cooking they can cope with. Which is why, in view of the kitchen hustling of the last few days, it is logical during Christmas week to let the gentlemen take over.

BOSTON, Dec. 24 -- As most items are slightly lower in price than they were at this time last year, the physical volume of Christmas trade in New England has run a little over the 1948 level. Actual results of the Christmas business this year were better than most merchants had looked for as recently as three months ago.

WITH only six days left in the year, it seems likely that 1949 will go out with a new safety record for the scheduled airlines of the United States. If there are no fatal accidents between now and Saturday, America's certificated airlines will post a new mark of only 1.2 fatalities for every 100,000,000 passenger-miles flown.

Although they showed a loss in dollar volume, textile and apparel sales in 1949 held their relative position in the competitive hid for the consumer dollar, it was pointed out last week. Clothing expenditures will exceed $16,000,000,000, it was predicted, even though the soft goods industry was faced with serious downward trend in prices which held well past the middle of the year.

AT Christmas the book with a religious theme has always had special interest, for its concern is the timeless, spiritual truth that lies at the heart of the Christmas story. This Christmas, as publishers, booksellers and the best-seller lists all bear witness, the religious book has been amazingly popular. It is not, however, a popularity limited to this season, or even to this year.

LIKE its author, St.-John Perse's great poem "Anabasis" has had a peculiar history. First published in France in 1924, it was translated six years later by T. S. Eliot for a British limited edition. After a leisurely fourteen-year percolation, it was brought out in America in 1938, but the first printing of this major work of modern poetry was sufficient for eight years of buyer demand.

The Truman Administration's top social security experts are planning a new approach to the $100 pension problem -- one that bears little resemblance to the clamor of many professional friends of the aged for universal pensions of $100 a month at the age of 65 years.

TREES and shrubs, while dormant or relatively inactive in growth, can withstand chemical applications that would severely injure them in the summer. This makes possible the use, during winter months, of much more potent materials, known as dormant sprays.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Senator Kenneth McKellar, Democrat, of Tennessee, chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, predicted today Congress would cut Government spending sharply next year.

With the successful marketing of more than $36,000,000 of new common stock of the Ohio Edison Company, the financial world is writing finis to a year of activity in underwriting and distributing public utility common stock in volume and variety unmatched since the twenties.

Melvin Lloyd Parnell, the stylish southpaw of the Boston Red Sox, carried off the major pitching honors of the American League, according to the official averages released yesterday. He topped the junior circuit in the earned run column, in complete games and in total victories.

PARIS, Dec. 24 Six of the seventeen nations represented in the European Marshall Plan Council have submitted lists of reductions in import quotas exceeding the 50 per cent recommended. Denmark's list failed to reduce her quotas by that amount.

AS this decade draws to a close, we are again reminded how time, in our conception of it, seems curiously to be contracting. I think we are more conscious of decades, as units in time, than people were before the century in which we live. Formerly the century was the unit, when generalizations were made about the temper of a period, the character of the literature that was produced within its boundaries.

AZOR was one of our favorite heroes of 1948. He was, you will remember, that independent small citizen of Marblehead who conversed freely with animals. In this new story, Azor decides to keep as a pet the haddock he has caught. No one else approves of that, least of all the haddock whose eyes registered every expression except happiness.

Encouraged by promise of good weather over Christmas, holiday travelers continued their treks into and away from the city in about equal proportions yesterday, although their numbers fell considerably below the peak figures set on Friday.

In several recent dispatches in THE NEW YORK TIMES from Germany Drew Middleton gives extensive figures showing the degree to which former Nazis are again being employed as teachers, especially in Bavaria. I do not challenge the accuracy of the figures Mr. Middleton quotes from anonymous American sources in Munich.

Last-minute Christmas shopping closed strong here. Department store sales for last week were estimated at 10 to 15 per cent above a year ago. An important factor in this percentage increase, however, was the extra selling day before Christmas, as contrasted with a year ago.

A NEW paper and process for making monochrome prints and enlargements directly from color transparencies is announced by the Gevaert Company of America, Inc. The product, Diaversal, signalizes this Belgian company's full-scale resumption of its pre-war rank as one of America's major sources of photographic paper and film.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 24 -- Over the objections of the Connecticut Highway Department, Gov. Chester Bowles signed a bill today directing the department to maintain and improve roads on the grounds of state institutions and in state parks and forests.

The last year of grace under which Britain is excused from making any payment on her $3,750,000,000 post-war loan from this country will run out on New Year's Eve. Starting with Jan. 1, 1950, the British must begin to accumulate some $140,000,000, including interest and principal to begin a year later the repayment of the sum advanced by the United States in 1945 to see our ally through the "post-war adjustment period."

A frankly experimental program to stimulate church attendance and greater spirituality among Americans by means of a national advertising campaign has produced such unexpected response that plans are now forming to make it a continuing project, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON. FOR those who are no longer children, Christmas, whether they enjoy it or not, must inevitably be a brief period of nostalgia -- and this is all the more to be savored in a foreign land whose habits at this season greatly resemble those one knew at home.

Activity in the wholesale apparel market here last week centered on last-minute orders for holiday merchandise, with some reorders for spring, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

IN a book review of S. E. Morison's "The Struggle for Guadalcanal, Vol. V, History of U. S. Naval Operations in World War II" (Book Review, Nov. 27) Mr. Ira Wolfert wonders what the fighting on Guadalcanal was all about.

TOKYO, Dec. 24 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida has decided to press for a quick amalgamation of Japan's conservative parties in expectation of peace treaty negotiations next year, Japanese political sources said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The United States Atomic Energy Commission announced today that John K. Gustafson would leave his post as manager of its raw-materials office on Jan. 1, having completed the two-year period he had agreed to serve. He will be succeeded by his deputy, Jesse C. Johnson.

The decision of the British Government last week to further restrict imports of oil into the United Kingdom generally is considered as another step by the nation to dominate the oil markets of the sterling area.

KEY LARGO, Fla., Dec. 24 -- On this day before Christmas, the honeymooning Mayor of New York and his bride lolled comfortably at the Key Largo Anglers Club and the bride weighed in a big fish she had caught.

Funds raised this year by New York newspapers for the aid of the sick, the needy, underprivileged children, disabled veterans and others amounted to $575,808.50. This was $15,634.90 less than the amount contributed in 1948.

ATHENS, Ga., Dec. 24 (AP) -- The divorced wife of a university professor ate dinner with him last night, then trailed him to the home of a pretty brunette secretary and shot and wounded them both.

AT THE THIRTY - EIGHTH PARALLEL, Korea, Dec 24 -- Not a rifle shot can be heard tonight on what is normally the cold war's hottest front. Instead, the music of "Silent Night, Holy Night" spreads from American loudspeakers to the entrenched troops on both sides of the line.

BETHLEHEM, Dec. 24 -- Christmas Eve was exceptionally quiet in Bethlehem thin year. The municipality said the number of visitors from Israel was 260, compared with totals of 10,000 to 20,000 from all countries in normal years.

THERE is nothing wrong with the egregious best-seller system that better books will not cure, let the grammarians' chips fall where they may. With that target to shoot at, the editors of this Review inaugurated the " -- And Bear in Mind" department a year or so ago.

America's young men and women continue to grow taller and heavier, Dr. Laurence B. Chenoweth, Professor of Hygiene and director of the University of Cincinnati's health service, reports. He finds that over the past thirty-three years, the height of Cincinnati freshmen has increased 2.74 inches and their weight 22.41 pounds, and that first-year women have added 1.24 inches and 4.33 pounds.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24 -- In view of the national publicity received by California this year because of lobbying activities before the Legislature, the West Coast this week watched with interest as legislators in special session took steps to control lobbyists.

PINE HILL, N. Y., Dec. 24 -- With a minimum amount of fanfare and a maximum amount of labor, the New York State Conservation Department is rapidly -- and this word is not used advisedly -- developing a top-notch ski area on imposing Belleayre Mountain, 140 miles away from Times Square.

PHILATELY'S expanding gallery has been enriched during 1949 with likenesses of ninety-four persons whose heads had not hitherto appeared on stamps. Forty-two Governments contributed to this panorama of portraiture.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 24 -- The University of Virginia has asked the National Collegiate Athletic Association that a record vote -- member by member -- be taken when the organization meets next month to consider the possible expulsion of seven institutions for "Sanity Code" violations.

FOR practically a century after his death in 1825 the work of Henry Fuseli, Swiss-born member of the British Royal Academy, was misunderstood and disregarded. "It has been reserved for our age," Mr. Ganz writes, "to understand Fuseli's art."

Few Christmas greetings will be more profoundly and beautifully moving than the message addressed to American Christians by the Synagogue Council of America, representing the religious forces of American Jewry. Speaking for the council, its president, Rabbi Bamberger, observed that the Christmas celebration was "marked by great outpouring of human warmth and brotherly sentiment."

ROME, Dec. 24 -- The Communists declared a general strike in Rome this morning a few minutes after the Pope and the three Cardinal legates had opened the Holy Doors in the four Patriarchal basilicas, thus beginning the Roman Catholic Church's twenty-fifth jubilee.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 24 (AP) -- A bone-jarring, earth-rocking battle of T-formations looms when two powerful all-star squads tangle in the Blue-Gray game Dec. 31. Even the rival coaches concede it can develop into a free-scoring duel beyond wildest expectations.

THE Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, area exactly 999 square miles, seemed until three months ago an out-of-the-way corner of Europe, tucked between Belgium, France and Germany but not necessarily on the road from anywhere to anywhere. Something has been added.

Men's and women's watches, men's sport shirts, novelty alarm clocks and umbrellas were featured in retail promotions here last week, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dee. 24 -- Bob Kiphuth, noted swimming authority who is recuperating from a serious illness at a hospital here, resigned today as director of athletics and chairman of the Board of Athletic Control at Yale.
HONG KONG, Dec. 24 -- Hong Kong street car workers began a protest demonstration today that may signalize the start of crippling strikes and agitations in all the basic utilities here.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Edward L. Schott, president and general manager of the Coney Island Company, today was named general manager of the Cincinnati Garden, which operates the Cincinnati team in the American Hockey League.

To prevent Germany's rehabilitated and fast-growing chemical industry from regaining its prewar dominant position in the world market, American manufacturers must combat the myth of superior quality of German goods and must establish competitive price schedules.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UP) -President Truman's budget for the fiscal year 1951 will earmark about $13,500,000,000 for national defense, with the Air Force down for the biggest share, informed quarters reported today.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 22 -Dr. Eduardo Santos, former Liberal President, told his correspondent in an interview at the office of the Liberal newspaper El Tiempo, of which he is publisher, that although he was Vice President of Colombia he was not permitted to express or publish his opinions under the present "state of siege."

Changes of leadership in two major sports groups have been made in the Amateur Athletic Union's national sports and administrative committees for 1950, it was announced yesterday by Albert F. Wheltle of Baltimore, newly elected A. A. U. president.
TOKYO, Dec. 25 (UP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced a Christmas amnesty today that will result in the immediate release of forty-six Japanese in prison for war crimes.

Fritz Reiner will conduct "Le Nozze di Figaro" for the first time with the Metropolitan Opera in the company seventh week, which begins Jan. 2, it was announced yesterday. The week also will see the first performance of the season of "Aida," while Kurt Baum will sing his first Samson in "Samson et Dalila."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 25 -- The Yugoslav Parliament is scheduled to convene tomorrow in a short session of five days to vote a new budget and hear important policy statements from leading members of the Government and the Communist party Politburo concerning the present status of the struggle with the Communist Information Bureau powers.

Wu, former Mayor of Shanghai, to be the Governor of Formosa is an indication that the Nationalist Government of China really wishes to do the right thing in Formosa and for the Formosans. Mr. Wu is a good administrator, liberal in his outlook, thoroughly "Western in his ideas of democracy.

Y., Dec. 25 -- If Rip Van Winkle were to return today to his native Catskill heath instead of hearing the legendary crash of tenpins against the mountainside he might be interested by the slashing of steel edges and wooden runners as thousands of skiers track up the woodlands and sweeping slopes.

Morse, director general of the International Labor Office.
CHICAGO, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Police captured a 19-year-old youth today who they said told them of shooting a whimpering 7-year-old girl during a South Side liquor store hold-up yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 25 -- The United Nations radio will mark the end of its third year of broadcasting to every part of the world on Tuesday with a special shortwave program from Batavia and The Hague to commemorate the official birth of the United States of Indonesia.

LONDON, Dec. 25 -- Christmas preoccupations have taken their usual toll of Stock Exchange business, which last week fell to the year's lowest point. Despite this lack of support the markets maintained a moderately firm front, largely because most of the yearend liquidation had already been completed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UP) -Senator Hugh Butler, Republican, of Nebraska, today called for a Congressional investigation of the Census Bureau's plan to ask every fifth American his income during the 1950 census.

No less a person than Palmiro Togliatti, leader of the Italian Communists, has stated that party members under his jurisdiction are free to adhere to any church or religion they chose. Nevertheless it is plain that the Communists consider the Holy Year ceremonies, which have begun with such impressive pageantry and popular enthusiasm, as a challenge.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- A Washington Baptist minister tonight denounced Santa Claus as a symbol of "heathenism rampant in our celebration of the Birth of Christ."
Christmas was brighter and warmer throughout the world yesterday than it had been since World War II started ten years ago. The only chill note blew out of "cold war" areas.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 25 (AP) -- Ponder, the Kentucky Derby winner, closes out his career as a 3-year-old tomorrow and co-stars with a $50,000 stake for California-bred 2-year-olds as Santa Anita opens its thirteenth annual winter meeting.
DES MOINES, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Six football players who had seen speedy Johnny Estes once race away from sprawling tacklers were never more proud of him today.

HONG KONG, Dec. 25 -- People in Communist China are being told through their newspapers that Japan is giving large-scale help to the Nationalists on Formosa, including the service of thousands of Japanese fighting men in the Nationalists' forces.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 25 -- Christmas Day in Cleveland lost none of its enjoyment or celebration today, although not a Transit System vehicle was moving, not even an old trolley car. The four-day-old transit strike failed to make any serious dent in the Yuletide activities of 1,300,000 Greater Clevelanders.

If we come into the presence of the Nativity as humble people, then God will shake our imaginations and allow us to see the "great truth," the Rev. Dr. Edgar Franklin Romig declared in his sermon yesterday at the West End Collegiate Church, West End Avenue and Seventy-seventh Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (NANA) -- A revolutionary ceramic material which contracts when heated and expands when cooled -- contrary to the general physical law -- now is being produced for the Air Force.

Eight or ten major legislative proposals bearing on the shipping industry will make the 1950 session of the Eighty-first Congress a decisive one for the merchant marine, according to a shipping survey issued for publication today by the Association of American Ship Owners, 80 Broad Street.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Dec. 25 -- With his official duties completely suspended, President Truman celebrated Christmas in the privacy of his home. He and Mrs. Truman and their daughter Margaret entertained eleven family guests, including three children, at an early afternoon turkey dinner.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture reported today that this year's world corn crop of 5,700,000,000 bushels appears to be the second largest in history -- about 300,000,000 bushels behind last year's record of 6,000,000,000 bushels.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 25 (AP) -- College all-star football players representing the North and the South held final loosening-up drills today and were pronounced ready for the Shrine charity game in the Orange Bowl tomorrow night before a crowd expected to exceed 40,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Representative Brooks Hays, Democrat, of Arkansas, who advocates a compromise on the controversial "civil rights" issue, sought today to dissuade Administration leaders from "forcing" legislation on a Fair Employment Practice Commission at the outset of the coming session of Congress.
The story of the Nativity was commemorated in song and prayer yesterday as worshipful thousands attended Christmas Day services throughout the city.
VIENNA, Dec. 25 (UP) -- Thirteen teen-age Austrians, believed to be members of a neo-Nazi terrorist gang, were arrested today in the United States zone of Austria, the Interior Ministry announced.
MOSCOW, Dec. 25 (AP) -- A group of Soviet academicians has been told that communism is making great strides in colonial and semi-colonial lands.

Fire at sea, considered by seamen one of the worst disasters that can befall a ship, proved a blessing in disguise yesterday to the crew of the United States Lines freighter American Inventor. A smoldering cargo of corn forced her to return to port and permitted the fifty-two officers and men and ten male passengers to spend Christmas day near land.

PENDLETON, Ore., Dec. 25. (UP) -- Planes from Pendleton, Baker and La Grande searched through heavy weather today for a private plane overdue on a Christmas Eve flight from Spokane to Ontario, Ore., with an army sergeant, his wife and their son aboard.

Our Government's conclusion of a civil air pact with Yugoslavia is another step toward the Yugoslav re-entry into the normal comity of nations. The acts and attitudes through which Tito divorced himself from such association were of his own making. The changes that are taking place in those acts and attitudes are not entirely so.

IT is to be presumed, of course, that you had a visitor yesterday, a stylish-stout gentleman whose name is Santa Claus. The presumption also is strong that the jolly old elf also visited various members of the sports fraternity. If you are wondering what he left under their Christmas trees, here are a few random guesses on the subject.

One-third of the visits by ailing New Yorkers in need of medical attention in 1948 were made to hospital out-patient departments and other clinics. Some of the city's leading health authorities believe that most of these facilities are giving "second rate" medical care and that improvements are in order.

Cotton prices in the domestic market last week held within a narrow trading range. At the close on Friday, active futures contract on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 1 to 10 points from the previous Saturday's close.
HYNDMAN, Pa., Dec. 25 -- A fire started in a Christmas tree burned out a large part of this southern Pennsylvania town of about 1,300 tonight.
PARIS, Dec. 25 -- The discussion of the budget, interrupted for the confidence vote narrowly accorded Premier Georges Bidault Saturday, will be resumed tomorrow by the National Assembly.

MADRID, Dec. 25 -- A decree for the release of Spanish prisoners in honor of the Holy Year of the Roman Catholic Church became effective today with publication in the Official Bulletin of orders to the military authorities on execution of the decree.
Doctors, nurses, service groups and volunteer workers throughout the city sacrificed some of their holiday yesterday to take the medicine of Christmas cheer to thousands of hospital patients.

I believe that your readers will be interested in knowing more about the Institutes of Applied Arts and Sciences, the philosophy of which was expressed in the letter of George Edmund Haynes recently published in THE TIMES.

DETROIT, Dec. 25 -- While Federal, state, county and city law enforcement agencies pressed their investigation today into the attempt to dynamite the headquarters of the United Automobile Workers union here last Tuesday. The UAW was hopefully awaiting its first clue through its "secret witness" plan.
Five new films, including importations from France and Italy, will open in midtown theatres to complete the year's roster. The programs follow:

Because of cold weather that checked the run-off from Friday's rainfall, the city's upstate reservoirs gained only 163,000,000 gallons in the twenty-four hour period ended at 8 A. M. yesterday. This compared with the 361,000,000-gallon gain in the previous twenty-four hours.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Five million dollars' worth of work has about been done to give Congress the first basic alterations in its legislative quarters since the middle of the last century.

ATHENS, Ga., Dec. 25 (UP) -Mrs. John E. Drewry spent Christmas in a jail cell today, while her former husband, dean of the University of Georgia's Journalism School, and another woman lay wounded in hospital beds.

BOSTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Harddriving Roy Conacher turned in the three-goal "hat trick" for the Chicago Black Hawks while they battled the Boston Bruins to a 4 -- 4 National Hockey League tie tonight before a 12,270 crowd at the Boston Garden.

A pair of goals within the short space of forty seconds gave the New York Rangers a victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The brace of tallies, coming in the third period, enabled the Blue Shirts to break a tie and go on to a 3-to-1 triumph.

WALTHAM, Mass., Dec. 25 -Brandeis University announced today that it has acquired the library of the late George A. Barton, who had been Professor of Semitic Languages and Comparative Religion at the University of Pennsylvania until his death in 1942.
Fearing that his business would be ruined, Gerard M. Radice, a Queens contractor, reluctantly brought his son into court yesterday on a burglary charge.

Twenty-three large seizures of narcotics, including a single fiftypound cache of opium and heroin with an estimated illicit market value of $1,000,000, and 200 smaller seizures of heroin, hashish and cocaine were made by customs enforcement officers aboard ships in the Port of New York this year.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 25 (UP) -Russia has secretly promised Communist-dominated Eastern Germany a separate peace treaty "before long," according to an East German official.

While most of the nation celebrated Christmas yesterday with the traditional mixture of reverence and festivity, the occasion was an unhappy one for friends and relatives of more than 350 persons who lost their lives in fires, auto accidents and other mishaps in the holiday period.

IT is more than three and a half years since a first startled look was taken in this space at the literary (or sub-literary?) phenomenon known as science fiction. Although science fiction can claim an honorable lineage and distinguished practitioners like Poe, Verne and H. G. Wells, it blooms most luxuriantly in such pulp magazines as Astounding Science Fiction and Thrilling Wonder Stories.

Principals of New York public schools will be required to sign "certificates of necessity" before maintenance and repair work will be authorized in the future, it was announced yesterday by Charles J. Bensley, chairman of the Board of Education's committee on buildings and sites.

LONDON, Monday, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Twelve Japanese indicted by Russia for preparation and use of bacteriological warfare pleaded guilty when their trials began Sunday at Khabarovsk, Siberia, the Moscow radio said today.

The new manager of the Five Hundred Room in the Berkshire Hotel has everything in his professional favor. Charles P. Ghirlanda -- proud, by the way, his name is a bit like the Italian Renaissance painter, Ghirlandajo -- comes to the restaurant (at 500 Madison Avenue) after managing the Hotel Negresco in Nice, teaching in the hotel school there and assisting the maitre d'hotel at the Colony Restaurant here in the city.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -Senator Francis J. Myers, Democrat, of Pennsylvania, expressed confidence today that more than 1,000,000 new homes would be started during 1950.

Increased sales of materials handling devices during the first six months of 1950 are being noted on expanding backlogs, and now a record half-year equal to 1949 total volume is foreseen, Howard L. Franks, director of sales for Merrill Brothers, forged product manufacturer of Maspeth, Queens, revealed here last week.

In a Manhattan investment deal on the lower West Side the six-story apartment house with self-service elevator at 125 Christopher Street has been sold by I. Stolz and I. Preussen, the builders, to a client of Paul P. Zinner, broker in the transaction.

The birth of Christ was linked yesterday to the advent of a new sense of freedom and individual worth by the Rev. Philip S. Watters in a sermon marking the start of his ministry at the Washington Square Methodist Church, 133 West Fourth Street.

The City College Midtown Business Center's Salesmanship Unit will put a new service into operation this week to provide individual companies and specific industries with "custom built" training programs, it was announced over the week-end.

As many as 1,500 workmen are swarming over the spacious decks, the interior and the huge hull of the Canadian Pacific liner Empress of Scotland at a Clyde shipyard, restoring the vessel to her pre-war luxury and preparing her for North Atlantic service, scheduled to begin on May 10.

ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 25 -- Findings of a survey of 183,000 farm families, recently released by the Cornell University Agricultural Experiment Station, will provide the basis for laboratory work in developing "more functional and better spaced homes" for rural dwellers, Prof. Glenn H. Beyer, project leader of the study, said today.

Under the European Recovery Plan each of the participating European countries has entered into a bilateral agreement with the United States under which it commits itself to the recognition of certain general principles of economic conduct.
Four members of the San Francisco Forty-niners and three from the champion Cleveland Browns have been chosen on the all-star team of the expiring All-America Football Conference announced yesterday.

MOSCOW, Dec. 25 -- The ancient story of Christmas was told once again in Moscow today at special services conducted at Spaso house, the residence of United States Ambassador Alan G. Kirk, for the small American colony and other members of the diplomatic corps.

The United Nations' economic survey mission to the Middle East, headed by Gordon R. Clapp, has now completed its three months' work. Although the final report has not yet been released here, Mr. Clapp has made public its general contents. The most striking feature lies in the modesty of the proposals, but presumably they represent all that seems politically and financially practicable at the present time.

A new novel by Robert W. Krepps, author of "The Field of Night," will be published on Jan. 26 by Rinehart. "The Courts of the Lion" deals with the experiences of two shipwrecked, treasure-seeking adventurers in the kingdom of the Zulu king, Tchaka, organizer of a military regime that conquered many tribes in Southeast Africa.

January will prove to be the crucial month for the coat and suit trade for spring business, it was pointed out last week. New York manufacturers indicated that they will make a two-pronged drive to salvage the season which up to the present time has not been going too well.

Shoe production this year has been maintained at the relatively high figure of 455,700,000 pairs, off only 1.4 per cent from the 1948 total of 462,320,000 pairs, according to estimates issued last week by the Tanners Council of America.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Guy G. Gabrielson, chairman of the Republican National Committee, today appointed a fifteen-member policy group to cooperate in drawing up a statement of party principles for the Congressional elections next year.

DETROIT, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings gave themselves a much-wanted Christmas present tonight as they defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 4 to 2, before 12,517 fans at Olympia. It was the first time in the National Hockey League campaign that the Red Wings were able to beat the Canadiens on Detroit ice.

ALBANY, Dec. 25 -- A public hearing on a tentative program to provide higher educational facilities for 151,000 additional students by 1966 will be conducted in Albany Jan. 4 by the Trustees of State University, President Alvin C. Eurich said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UP) -- Insurance Dividend checks, which thousands of veterans have already "spent," will start going out about the middle of next month, officials said today. Hopes that the first checks would be in the mails almost immediately after Christmas have been abandoned.

A woman accused of having fatally stabbed her husband while her two children watched was charged yesterday with homicide while she was in a hospital in critical condition from an overdose of sleeping pills.

It is gratifying that the Robert J. Collier Trophy, one of aviation's most coveted awards, should go this year to a development which holds promise for greatly increased safety in the air. The trophy for 1949 will be awarded next month by the President to a group of earnest workers in this field, the Radio Technical Commission for Aeronautics.

CHICAGO, Dec 25 -- Packers here sold beef loin for $1.25 a pound last week and loin of pork for 35 cents a pound. Nevertheless, observers in the industry felt that beef was about to gain on pork as a basic item in the American diet. The reason was a narrowing of the price spread between beef and pork

Women who apply make-up or men who shave in front of bathroom mirrors that reflect an uncomfortable -- often distorting -glare from bad lighting will be happy to know that the problem is being solved. Several leading lighting companies have put their engineers on the job and have come up with innovations worth noting.

LONDON, Dec. 25 -- King George VI told his subjects today that by carrying the spirit of Christmas through 1950 they could give strength to the British Commonwealth for the tasks of economic recovery and invigorating democracy.

For the first time since the war, it now seems certain, the production of wheat, cotton and corn will all be subject to production controls in 1950. The Secretary of Agriculture, as far back as July 14, ordered acreage allotments on wheat which would reduce plantings, all told, from eighty-three million acres to seventy-two millions.

The South Porto Rico Sugar Company reported over the weekend for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 a consolidated net income of $5,631,375 after charges and taxes, which was equal, after preferred dividend payments, to $7.01 each on the 745,734 common shares outstanding.
TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Three earthquakes shook Tokyo and east-central Honshu Island today. At least three Japanese were reported injured. Some buildings collapsed.

Many medium size and small British firms, which before the war were not generally concerned with exports in any direct way, are now joining Britain's dollar export drive, according to Sir Leonard Browett, director of the National Union of Manufacturers in the United Kingdom.

The idea that the first years of a person's life are really the crucial ones has become a dogma that aims to explain life in a too mechanical way and amounts almost to "a large step toward abolishing fathers," according to Dr. Fredric Wertham, director of psychiatric services at Queens General Hospital.

Phil Watson's New York Rovers concentrated most of their scoring in the second period in their battle with the Milwaukee Clarks at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon, but it wasn't enough to stop Jack Stover's club. As a result, the Clarks, making their first appareance at the Eighth Avenue arena, gained a well-deserved 4 -- all tie by caging two goals in the third chapter.

BOSTON, Dec. 25 -- An aftermath to the filing of an initiative petition to bar parochial school children from public school buses appeared today to have given Massachusetts Republicans the strong candidate they have been seeking in their campaign to recapture the Governorship next November.
Ivy League basketball teams hit the road this week with Columbia taking its squad clear to the Pacific Coast.
MOSCOW, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Newspaper photographs of the gala birthday receptions of the past two days indicate that Premier Stalin is bright and spry.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UP) -Many members of Congress will return to town this Christmas week prepared for a showdown fight over President Truman's Fair Deal program.

The Liberal party sent a letter to Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson yesterday, urging him to permit a public commission of inquiry to survey racial policy in the United States armed forces in Germany and to make its report public.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25 -- The upward trend in the grain markets came to a halt on the Board of Trade last week. Scattered liquidation resulted in a lower range of prices. The final estimate of the 1949 crops and a favorable start for the 1950 winter wheat crop combined to bring in fairly general selling, and in addition there was a feeling that some new incentive was needed to keep prices on the upgrade.
Christmas finally caught up yesterday with 70-year-old Thomas Brown of 906 Eagle Avenue, the Bronx. But for nearly twenty-four hours he didn't think it would. Here's the way it happened:
Verdi's "Simon Boccanegra" had its second performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House on Christmas Eve, with four singers taking their parts for the first time.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Dec. 25 -- The recorders of the Penguin and B Classes of the Manhasset Bay frostbite dinghy fleet announced today that Allan Clark and George Hinman won top honors in the fall series.
Numerous contributions were received by The New York Times Neediest Cases yesterday in memory of war heroes.

The Brookhattan-Galicia eleven defeated the Eintracht Sport Club, 4 -- 2, yesterday, in a National Soccer Cup match at Sterling Oval, the Bronx. The losers, who had an unbeaten record in the GermanAmerican Soccer League championship series, were eliminated after leading at halftime by 2 -- 1.

Two of the theatre's more venerable players, Grace George and Walter Hampden, return to the local boards tonight when "The Velvet Glove," by Rosemary Casey, opens at the Booth Theatre. Under the sponsorship of Guthrie McClintic, who also is credited with the direction, the play is advertised to send up its curtain at 8:20.

Mrs. Oksana Kasenkina, 54-year-old former Russian school teacher who leaped from a window of the Soviet consulate, escaped injury in a minor automobile mishap yesterday. She was driving alone near her home at 19-61 Eightieth Street, Astoria, Queens, when her automobile was in collision with another car at the intersection of Seventy-ninth Street and Twenty-first Avenue.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 25 (AP) -- Peace and calm was the theme today as the Ohio State football team spent an uneventful day before resuming practice chores for the Rose Bowl engagement with California on Jan 2.

Twenty boys and girls, a few from Columbia University, others home from colleges outside New York, assembled more or less on impulse on Christmas Eve outside the university president's home at Morningside Drive and 116th Street.

Several hours after three young armed thugs had escaped with $3,000 from the Penthouse Club, a restaurant at 30 Central Park South, two men were captured yesterday afternoon and identified by four employes of the club and the building.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UP) -The House Committee on Un-American Activities was praised today by two of its severest critics for its "restraint and regard for civil liberties" in the last year.

PARIS, Dec. 25 -- One of the most important events of last week was the recovery of French and foreign stocks on the Bourse. This movement follows a dull market that has lasted since the end of October.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 25 -Charles Coburn and Charlotte Greenwood have been signed by Universal-International to play the chief character roles in "Rose Queen," a photoplay by George Slavin and George W. George about the Pasadena Tournament of Roses.

Arch T. Hamilton, a consulting engineer of Beaver Falls, Pa., who spent most of yesterday at La Guardia Airport, hoping for a Christmas reunion with his 17-year-old son. Robert, left for home last night, alone.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25 -- Removal of hedges against sales of an estimated 47,000,000 pounds of lard to the Government gave that market on the Board of Trade a firm undertone most of last week, but as soon as the demand let up the market reacted and closing trades on futures were at net losses of 7 to 12 cents a 100 pounds.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 22 -Brazilian coffee supplies dropped below the 10,000,000-bag level this week -- the lowest point in thirty years -- and there was every sign that prices would remain high, and perhaps go even higher, barring a major drop in consumption during the next year.

It's a funny thing about Santa Claus. At Christmas time everybody loves the jolly and benevolent old gentleman who delights the heart of childhood. He is a popular and potent figure, held up as the embodiment of the most ingratiating human qualities. At Christmas time generosity is the great virtue.
Last week's foreign exchange market was a quiet affair, the scant turnover and steady array of rates being an aftermath of the holiday spirit which ruled from the opening to the close.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 25 (UP) -- John C. Ansengruber lay on a hospital bed tonight recovering from a dangerous ordeal which brought him the acclaim of the "bravest man I ever met" from a great surgeon. But his effort was in vain.

There is beauty on the hills when the first staying snow drops its cape over the land. The average countryman is not a scientific meteorologist, but when the waning moon is hazefuzzed for three successive nights, he feels certain that a storm is making. An interesting point about the first real snow of winter is that so often it starts in late afternoon or early evening.

San Francisco, last year's invitation tournament winner, which ran into a Tarter last Thursday when it was crushed by the red-hot St. John's quintet, will att pt to regain some of its lost prestige tonight. The Dons are slated to meet Long Island University in the feature half of a twin bill as another busy basketball week gets under way at Madison Square Garden.
Private and religious charitable organizations brought Christmas cheer at parties and dinners yesterday to needy men and women, to men away from home and to underprivileged children.
Relief for the needy aged is costing Federal, state and local taxpayers $250,000,000 more this year than it did in 1948.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 25 -- A warning of impending conflict in the tribal area of the Northwest Frontier Province between Pakistan and Afghanistan was sounded here by Sardar Najibullah Khan. Afghan Ambassador to India.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 25 -- The steel industry last week operated at a rate of 94.5 per cent of rated capacity, up one-half a point from the week before. It was said to be doubtful if that rate will be exceeded in the weeks to come as steel mills try to make up for the loss during the strike.
BETHLEHEM, Dec. 25 -- Sunlight broke through cloudy skies to reflect the peace of Bethlehem on this Christmas morning. In nearby Jerusalem, quietness pervaded the Holy City.

Because of the scarcity of the fleece, vicuna coats are made in a limited edition like a rare book. Only 200 coats of this precious fabric are fashioned in a year by Original Modes. The fabric is woven by S. Stroock Co.

Power failure caused by a grounded third-rail cable halted four BMT trains on Manhattan Bridge yesterday and stranded 450 passengers from thirty-five to eighty-two minutes. The mishap occurred at 10:20 A. M., and while there was no panic or disorder, the holiday travelers, many laden with packages, chafed at the delay.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UP) -Most of the nation's housewives will be able to buy yellow oleomargarine by next February for the same price as white oleo, Senators backing oleo tax repeal predicted today.

A radio premiere of unusual interest was presented on Saturday night. It was Peter Mennin's cantata; "The Christmas Story," sung by the Robert Shaw Chorale on WJZ and the American Broadcasting Company's network, with orchestra conducted by Mr. Shaw and solos by Yvonne Cionella and Blake Stern.
Need for new Government revenue to replace excise taxes, reported scheduled for repeal, will add new pressure for higher postal rates in the new Congress, advertising officials agree.

ROME, Dec. 25 -- Instructions have been issued to all members of Italian Catholic Action to begin a nation-wide crusade to make converts to Roman Catholicism among the atheist members of the Communist and anti-clerical parties and to persuade others who are still nominally Catholic to return to the Church's fold.
PARIS, Dec. 25 -- In Paris and throughout France a pre-war atmosphere of abundance and good cheer surrounded ceremonies and festivities of Christmas.
Christmas was characterized yesterday by the Right Rev. Stephen Charles Neill, associate general secretary of the World Council of Churches, as a challenge to false gods.
AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The 9-year-old stallion Suncap, holder of one of the Santa Anita track's fastest records, ran his last race today and won it easily.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- The Voice of America will inaugurate on New Year's Day a daily program of news, commentary and music to the Arabic world, the State Department announced today.

Excellent conditions of transmission resulted yesterday in the establishing of a new Christmas record for overseas telephone calls, it was announced last night by a spokesman for the Long Lines Division of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

DETROIT, Dec. 25 -- A number of layoffs in the fall in the automobile industry because of a combination of factors, including the steel strike, model changeovers and shut-downs for inventories, were blamed by business executives today for a 10 per cent decline in the Christmas business in Detroit and vicinity.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Dec. 25 (AP) -- Dr. Bert E. Young, Professor Emeritus of French at Indiana University and an internationally known scholar, died today of injuries received five days ago when he was hit by an automobile.

Practically everybody in these parts was convinced some time ago that little Phil Rizzuto of the Yankees not only was the best shortstop but the most valuable player in the American League, and backing for that belief is made official today with the release of the circuit's fielding figures.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 25 -From relief missions in Palestine and elsewhere in the Middle East, the United Nations has received a reassuring report that 517,440 destitute children and mothers, chiefly Arab refugees, are receiving at least a small measure of aid from abroad.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 16 -- The opening of a divinity school at Ankara University this fall is a notable sign of the changing attitude of the Turkish Republic's leaders toward Islam, the religion of 98 per cent of the people. The forward-looking nature of this experiment is indicated by the fact that the school is coeducational.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 25 (UP) -Cary Grant, screen star, today married Betsy Drake, the film actress, at a desert home twenty miles from this city. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Stanley M. Smith.

At the Regional Plan Association's annual meeting Paul Windels in his presidential report took stock of some of the changes that have taken place during the RPA's first twenty years, now completed. As a result of this and previous growth our metropolitan region is served by 20,000 miles of major traffic arteries, 2,000 miles of railroad and 74 airports.

Furniture manufacturing activity was higher in November than any previous month in 1949 and new orders booked by furniture factories that month registered the first substantial year-to-year gain, according to a monthly statement issued for publication today by Seidman Seidman, furniture industry accountants.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -The Air Force predicted today that the range of its 600-mile-an-hour Boeing B-47 jet bomber would be increased soon.

Am I alone in feeling sick at heart about the proposed remodeling of our beautiful Metropolitan Museum? The account in THE TIMES of Dec. 17 tells of the proposed removal of the front steps, installation of escalators, lowering of ceilings and general reshifting and rearranging of everything, so that nothing will be left of the stately building that it now is.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UP) -Administration leaders conceded today -- little more than a week before Congress returns -- that they have failed to find a solution to the religious controversy that has stymied the Federal-aid-to-education bill.

It's the day after Christmas. The excitement is over, both for the small fry and the grown-ups who have been generously showered with gifts. Now comes the housewife's turn, or the aftermath of the Christmas activities

BOSTON, Dec. 25 (UP) -- The Boston Braves today had added another sharp-eyed hitter to their revamped club after trodding the well-worn path to the players cupboard of the Brooklyn Dodgers for outfielder Luis Olmo, the star from Puerto Rico.

Both amateur and professional song writers will have a chance to display their talents on a new radio program featuring Guy Lombardo and his orchestra over the National Broadcasting Company's circuit. Each week a committee of musical experts will select four tunes for broadcasting, Lombardo to write special arrangements for them.
AMSTERDAM, Dec. 25 -- Beginning on Jan. 2 two-way traffic in Dutch certificates of United States securities again will be allowed in Amsterdam. One-way traffic only has ruled for nearly nine years.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, predicted today that business would enter 1950 thriving as it has for the last six months.
Why do students choose social work as a career? Chiefly because they want to work with people, and in so doing, to find personal and job satisfaction.

BUENOS AIRES, Dee. 25 (AP) -The Argentine Government barred publication today of the newspaper Intransigente, which has been critical of President Juan D. Peron. The Intransigente is published in the provincial capital of Salta in northwest Argentina.
Jean Michel Rallu of Ivry, France, was introduced yesterday to the old American custom of the heaping turkey dinner plate and found it to his liking.

Mr. and Mrs. John Ashley Merriman of 820 Fifth Avenue and Sedgwick, Me., gave a tea dance yesterday afternoon in the Crystal Room of the Ritz-Carlton for their debutante daughter, Miss Hildreth Anne Merriman, who received with her mother and grandmother, Mrs. Nicholas Frecknal-Joy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- heifer calves, known simply as SX-47 and SX-48, are getting a lot of attention at the Government's Beltsville, Md., farm these days.

"When we return the oleomargarine bill will be the first bill to be considered by the Senate." This statement, made by Senator Lucas, the Democratic leader, on the floor of the Senate in September, conveys the pledge of the Democratic Policy Committee given when that committee decided to shelve margarine legislation for the time being in order to get Congress out of Washington last fall.

HAWTHORNE, N. Y., Dec. 26 -- State troopers booked three New York boys on juvenile delinquency charges today asserting that they had broken into fifteen to twenty homes in Westchester and Putnam Counties, Greenwich, Conn., and Fort Lee, N. J.
