The chairman of the Republican National Committee has appointed a fifteen-member policy group to cooperate in drawing up a statement of party principles for next year's Congressional elections. According to our Washington dispatches this new group "has a strong 'Old Guard' element with views extremely critical of the program of the Truman Administration."

The Knickerbockers, gunning for their eighth straight triumph at home yesterday afternoon, were unable to stop sharpshooting Bob Davies, the former Seton Hall star. The result was that New York's entry in the National Basketball Association had to accept a disheartening 83-to-80 defeat at the hands of the Rochester Royals before 16,000 at Madison Square Garden.

St. John's University's quintet, undefeated in ten starts and boasting the best record among the local squads, will endeavor to keep its streak going tonight, when it tangles with Utah in the opening game of a collegiate twin bill at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The American Federation of Labor today published a list of 107 members of Congress whom it described as having "opposed the best inter ests of workers, farmers and small business men" this year.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 26 -- The Knesset, Israel's single-chamber legislature, which had been meeting in Tel Aviv since March, convened in Jerusalem today, fulfilling a decision it took three days after the United Nations General Assembly resolved to internationalize the Holy City.
LONDON, Dec. 26 -- Sir Stafford Cripps' extension of the Christmas holiday in Britain through Tuesday has resulted in two strikes and a considerable amount of confusion.
A steady improvement in the economic and industrial conditions of this country's Negro population was reported yesterday by the National Urban League in a year-end summary.

Today is the birthday of the United States of Indonesia. The transfer of sovereignty to this new federal republic is an act of great historic significance and consequence. It vindicates the declaration of Queen Wilhelmina in 1942 that the age of colonialism is dead.
New York's present water shortage is only a temporary situation, in the long-range view of scientists attending a meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science yesterday.

Who says it isn't the time, right now, to take down the Christmas tree? Do not bother to answer that, for there is no need. It is she who says so. It is she and all her sisters, and her mother and female cousins and her aunts who say so, and while her daughters and nieces do not speak too distinctly as yet, they soon will say so, too.

In the town of Salta in northwestern Argentina there is -- or was -- published a small daily newspaper called El Intransigente, which has attracted considerable attention because of its bitter opposition to the regime of President Juan. D. Peron. Its publisher, David Michel Torino, has been a leader of the anti-Peron Radical party and, at the time of the 1946 elections, was quoted as referring to Senor Peron as "the Nazi colonel."

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Dec. 26 -- Indonesian Premier Mohammed Hatta arrived here today to accept his nation's independence from Queen Juliana of the Netherlands. The ceremony transferring sovereignty will take place tomorrow at the Royal Palace in Amsterdam.
PENDLETON, Ore., Dec. 26 (AP) -- The snow-covered mountains of Eastern Oregon were scanned today for a plane in which Sgt. Frank Eaton and his wife and baby vanished on a flight home for Christmas.

For the first time, a national survey of smoke and "smog" prevention problems has been made by the foundry industry, according to a report just received from Raymond L. Collier, executive vice president of the Gray Iron Founder's Society, Inc., Cleveland.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 26 (Reuters) -- India hopes to stop all imports of food grains by the end of 1951. Announcing this target at a recent conference of agricultural officials from all parts of India, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said that food self-sufficiency must be achieved "what ever happens, whether there is a cyclone or an earthquake."

Biographies of five composers have been scheduled for publication in the first part of the new year. Philosophical Library will publish on Jan. 23 "Cesar Franck." by Norman Dcmuth. Composer and lecturer on music. The volume presents a picture of the composer and teacher, examining and analyzing his contemporaries, his time and his works.
BATAVIA, Dee. 26 (AP) -- The United States of Indonesia deployed troops tonight and maintained a state of siege in wide areas to prevent trouble when the country formally become free tomorrow.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Dec. 26 -- Closing the first of the long, cold-weather sailing series at the Larchmont Yacht Club, the Race committee revealed today that the Interclub winner was Bob De Coppet with his boat Zotom.
TOKYO, Dec. 26 -- An all-day series of earthquakes north of Tokyo today caused eight deaths and did widespread but comparatively minor damage.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 26 -- Odds makers continued today to make the Eastern football stars 7 1/2-point favorites over their Western rivals for the annual East-West charity game here on Saturday.

ROME, Dec. 26 -- Fifty-four displaced persons left Ciampino airport today for Pakistan aboard a special plane chartered by the International Refugee Organization. IRO officials described their departure as "an outstanding example of our efforts to resettle specialists."

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Following are the texts of speeches delivered here today by President Truman as he presented a statue of Andrew Jackson to Jackson County and as he unveiled a photograph of himself in the County Court House:

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 26 (UP) -- Churchmen today praised the Christmas message by Gov. James E. Folsom of Alabama calling for a "fair share of living" for Southern Negroes as based on the principles of Christianity.
A gain of $82,000,000 in regular deposits of the nation's 531 mutual savings banks in November was reported yesterday by the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.
HOLLYWOOD Calif., Dec. 26 (UP) -- Mrs. Joan Grunden sadly went her way again today and her former husband went his -- because he is paralyzed from the waist down and refuses to tie her to a cripple.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 26 -- With forty-one students from nineteen colleges competing, the biennial tournament for the individual championship of the Intercollegiate Chess League started today on the campus of Rutgers University.
LONDON, Dec. 26 (Reuters) -Heavy grounds and mounting injury lists are beginning to tell upon the eighty-eight major English soccer clubs in the gruelling Christmas period program.

PARIS, Dec. 26 -- The "Wolves of France," ostensibly a wartime resistance network and patriotic group, was accused by the French police today of being a conspiracy to obtain by false means the exoneration of persons accused of intelligence with the enemy during the German occupation of France.

The belief, recently expressed by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, that the AFL and the Congress of Industrial Organizations would soon be cooperating more closely, was voiced again yesterday by David Dubinsky and Matthew Woll, vice presidents of the AFL.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -- The International Refugee Organization announced today that 2,583 displaced persons would arrive in the United States this week just in time to begin a new life with the new year.

After directing labor negotiations for the painting industry here for more than half a century, Henry D. Moeller, trade commiteeman and director of the Master Painters and Decorators of New York City, will retire on Jan. 1.

ST. CLOUD, Minn., Dec. 26 (UP) -- Santa Claus triumphed over government red tape, with some high help from Washington, and managed to deliver two television sets to the St. Cloud Veterans Hospital for Christmas.

HYNDMAN, Pa., Dec. 26 -- Rain beat down today for hours on this tiny town, a large section of which was in ruins after a fire that Started in a Christmas tree. Three and a half blocks of the business district were laid waste.

LONDON, Dec. 26 -- Britain has extended a cautious helping hand to Premier Marshal Tito in his effort to resist Soviet pressure. The Board of Trade announced today the new trade agreements had been signed in Belgrade to increase trade with Britain and the sterling area and thus obtain some essential imports which Yugoslavia has been having difficulty in getting since the Cominform ordered satellite states to curtail their trade with her.
A collection taken up last summer among poverty-stricken Arab refugees in the desert of Gaza found its way yesterday as a contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 26 -- Milentije Popovitch, Minister of Foreign Trade and Acting Minister of Finance, presented the 1950 budget estimates at the opening of Parliament today. The estimates provided for an over-all expenditure of 173,746,000,000 dinars ($3,474,920,000) and defense appropriations totaling 28,000,000,000 dinars ($560,000,000).

Although the Senate has given unanimous consent to the International Safety of Life at Sea Convention of 1948, the United States has not completed formal ratification of the agreement. The document still lacks the signature of President Truman.

Emphasizing ''bigger inside and smaller outside" construction, the 1950 line of Dodge automobiles was presented yesterday by L. L. Colbert, vice president of the Chrysler Corporation and president of the Dodge division.

Freedom of the press no less than any other sort of freedom is indivisible. Thus discrimination against the press gives cause for concern even when it takes place in the freest and most democratic of countries. These thoughts prompt us to comment on an odd situation existing north of the border in a land bound to our own by the closest ties of sentiment and outlook.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 26 -- There should be no shortage of teachers by 1953 if the freshman class at the New Jersey College for Women, a unit of Rutgers University, is any indication.

In the last week before Christmas, activity in the wholesale garment market here centered on quick fillins for women's apparel and fashion accessories, according to the reports prepared especially leading resident buying offices. Orders for January sales merchandise are faimly heavy, it was said.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- The possibility that the American Educational Theatre Association would refuse to participate in the National Theatre Assembly -- proposed for Washington, D. C., early next year by the American National Theatre and Academy -- was raised today by Hubert Heffner of Stanford University, president of the organization.

Having won the Christophers' prize. Rosemary Casey's "The Velvet Glove" was put on at the Booth last evening, and Grace George and Walter Hampden are playing the leading parts in it. It is a mild, pleasant and thin little comedy about the skill with which a nun blackmails a Bishop by undermining his campaign to raise funds for a new seminary.

Mary Garden said last night that it was "shocking" that there was no opera house in the capital of the United States. The opinion was one of many that the famous opera singer expressed when she appeared at Town Hall for the final "talk" of her three-month tour of the United States.

The seventh annual national conclave of the deans and regents of the American Guild of Organists will be held in this city today, tomorrow and Thursday. It will include two pilgrimages to churches and organs.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 - Everybody is glad to see Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg back in his office on Capitol Hill, except those who know the most about the state of his health.

As one who has been mystified and dismayed at the totally inadequate response of this country to the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund, I was thankful indeed for Anne O'Hare McCormick's column of Dec. 14, which appeared under the heading "The Cry of Sixty Million Hungry Children."

"How Long Till Summer," a new drama by Sarett and Herbert Rudley, a husband and wife writing team will open tonight at the Playhouse. The curtain time for the premiere has been announced as 8:25 P. M. Leon J. Bronesky and Edward M. Gilbert are the co-producers.

The old theory that the oceans are boundless and will always produce an abundance of seafood despite the method and extent of the harvest is finally being abandoned, and a number of commercial fisheries as well as sports groups have awakened to the fact that unless something is done the harvest will be in danger.

Elimination of the formal dining room and the rise of informal eating have increased the popularity of table mats for small dinners and luncheons, for they have a quality of simplicity usually missing from sophisticated luxury versions.

Compared with other post-war years, the revival of European markets for platinum metals was outstanding in 1949, according to Dr. Charles Engelhard, president of Baker Co., Inc., dealer and refiner of platinum metals.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26 (UP) -- A former German soldier who risked his life in a futile experiment to save a dying child was told today that his heroism would help other sufferers of the disease that killed her.

Except for one player involved in an unfinished match, all the seeded entrants advanced without trouble as the Eastern junior championship tournament began yesterday on the New York Indoor Tennis Club's courts at the Third Engineers Group (Twenty-second Regiment) Armory.

A baby was burned fataly and nine other persons, including two small children and four firemen, were injured last night when flames swept the top floor of a three-story brick residence and store building at 630 Fifth Avenue, at Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn.

The American Musicological Society will open its fifteenth annual three-day conference at 1:30 this afternoon in the New York Public Library. The event will include musical programs and papers on subjects ranging from Gothic form to Afro-Cuban religious cult music.

A MAN may make few mistakes in life if he adheres closely to one rigid rule. It warns him to "mind his own business." It is when he starts butting into other people's affairs that he comes to grief. Yet human nature is such that it is extremely difficult to resist the temptation to barge into someone else's business and begin offering gratuitous advice.

Of all the doings of mankind, war is the most cruel and the most senseless. Yet, the wide difference between the ambitions and ways of thinking of the various nations make the outlawing of war one of the most difficult problems confronting our civilized world.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26 (AP) -- University of California at Los Ankeles toppled La Salle from the undefeated class with a 62-57 victory tonight before 5,399 fans in the second game of a Convention Hall college doubleheader. St. Joseph's of Philadelphia turned back Utah, 69-68, in the first game.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 26 -- King Abdullah, before he goes further with direct peace negotiations with Israel, will try to settle the differences that have been pushing the brother Hashemite regimes of Iraq and Jordan farther apart.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 26 (AP) -- The North's all-star football team, coached by Herman Hickman of Yale, tonight defeated the hand-selected all-stars from the South, 20 to 14, before 37,378 rain-drenched spectators in the Orange Bowl.
LONDON, Dec. 26 (UP) -- Prof. Arnold Toynbee predicted today the cold war with Russia would continue without becoming a shooting war until at least the year 2,000.
DETROIT, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Christmas-tree business turned into a grim one in Detroit this Yule holiday.

Recently you published an interview with Senator Pat McCarran, who had just returned from a prolonged trip to Europe, in which he made the statement: "I wish to state emphatically that living conditions of the displaced persons are far better than living conditions of the average inhabitant of many areas in the United States."

Plans for a shopping center containing six retail stores have been announced in connection with the leasing of a parcel of vacant land at 253-12 to 253-24 Union Turnpike, southeast corner of 254th Street, in the Bellerose section of Queens.
The Duke and Duchess of Windsor, the former Wallis Simpson, arrived here yesterday afternoon aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth for a four-month visit to the United States and Canada.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- For the first time in seven and a half years the number of Federal employes has dropped substantially below 2,000,000, the Civil Service Commission said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 26 -- Samuel Goldwyn has engaged Philip Yordan, who recently completed the script of "Edge of Doom" for him, to write a new photoplay, as yet untitled, as a prospective vehicle for Dana Andrews, Susan Hayward and Farley Granger.

AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 25 -- In another development in the Syrian political situation, which has created serious problems for the entire Levant area, Provisional President Atassi tendered his resignation today reportedly over the issue of civilian versus military rule.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Dec. 26 -- In a ceremony on the lawn of the court he served for ten years and where, he said, he first learned about government administration, President Truman today presented to Jackson County an equestrian statue of Andrew Jackson.
HONG KONG, Dec. 26 -- Information from Communist China emphasizes the fact that Manchuria is receiving first priority in the national program of industrialization and rehabilitation.

Albert Einstein, whose theory of relativity provided the formula that revealed the existence of atomic energy and offered mankind new visions of the material universe, has developed, after more than thirty years of arduous labors, a mathematical concept that is expected to lead to new and much deeper insights into the cosmos.

DETROIT,. Dec. 26 -- A former mental patient who had made boastful statements regarding the plot to dynamite the headquarters of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, and the attempts on the lives of Walter P. Reuther, UAW president, and Victor G. Reuther, UAW educational director, was sought today by police in their investigation into the terroristic campaign against the union.

The refusal of Andrew Duch, Director of Public Safety in Trenton, N. J., to permit a performance of John Wexley's play, "They Shall Not Die," was characterized yesterday by Arthur Garfield Hays, general counsel of the American Civil Liberties Union, as having exhibited "a shocking and complete disregard for the right of free speech and assembly."

Memphis, Tenn., was chosen yesterday as the winner among 3,762 entries in this year's National Fire Prevention Week contest. The National Board of Fire Underwriters sponsored the contest for the twenty-sixth year.
Our home economist comes up with a bright suggestion on a morning that is not so bright for most of us. A long holiday weekend results in blue-Monday depression on Tuesday.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 26 -- Dr. Charles R. Roberts, psychiatrist and director of the Child Guidance Clinic of the Oranges and Maplewood, which will open here next month, foresees not only a smoothly running clinic but a project in which the whole community will participate in the interests of its children.

PARIS, Dec. 26 -- A group of well-known intellectuals and political figures, many of whom have been identified with left-wing causes, called today for a plebiscite in Indo-China under the auspices of the United Nations to end the present fighting.

Mr. and Mrs. Juan T. Trippe of 10 Gracie Square and East Hampton, L. I., gave a large supper dance last night in the main ballroom of the Pierre to introduce to society in New York their daughter, Miss Betty S. Trippe. Stylized Venetian carnival figures in hues of orange, white and gold were used in the decorations.

BALBOA, C. Z., Dec. 26 -- No comment will be made for the present by Panama Canal authorities on a letter addressed to Gov. Francis K. Newcomer and released for publication Dec. 20 by F. A. Bailey, president of the National Federation of American Shipping The letter protested a proposed increase in tolls and alleged "a switch" in accounting methods.
ATHENS, Ga., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Miss Miriam Thurmond, felled by bullets fired from a pistol by a college professor's ex-wife, remained in a serious condition today.
ROME, Dec. 26 -- The Roman clergy, led by Pope Pius XII, paid a Jubilee visit to St. Peter's Basilica today.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Dec. 26 (AP) -- A friend of M. J. Stuart's telephoned the other day, saying his wife had suffered a heart attack, and the doctor gave the family just twenty-four hours to get moved to a lower altitude. Wouldn't Mr. Stuart like to have his collection of hamsters ?

Rain fell in the city early yesterday but there was none in the up-state watershed area for the twenty-four hours ending at 8 A.M. The lack of rain, combined with increased domestic consumption over the Christmas holiday, resulted in a net loss of 103,000,000 gallons in the reservoirs after two successive days of gains.
ALBANY, N. Y., Dec. 26 (AP) -New York's principal farm crops this year were worth about $372,051,000 to the farmers, or 8 percent less than last year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Charles E. Wilson, president of General Motors Corporation, predicted today that 1950 will be another year of business prosperity if nothing happens to "scare" American buyers.
BOSTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Outfielders Jim Russell and Ed Sauer of the Boston Braves were waived out of the major leagues today and shipped to the Brooklyn Dodgers' farm club at Montreal.

The American merchant marine, which felt the effects of war almost immediately after September, 1939, completed a ten-year cycle in 1949 and neared what may be its post-war position. Following a difficult reconversion and readjustment period since V-J Day, American shipping achieved some degree of stability in the year and looks forward in 1950 to making great progress in rebuilding its passenger fleet, the lone deficiency in a well-balanced fleet.

The report of the Montana Power Company issued for publication today shows a net income of $7,179,013 for the twelve months ended with last November. This is a gain of 9 per cent over the $6,601,767 net shown for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30, 1948.

Election of Robert F. Lenhart as secretary of the Committee for Economic Development was announced yesterday by W. Walter Williams, chairman. Associated with the CED since 1944, Mr. Lenhart has been secretary of its research and policy committee and administrative assistant on its research staff in Washington.
Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Marion Gentry of Manhasset, L. I., gave a dinner dance last night in the Terrace Room of the Plaza for their debutante daughter, Miss Courtenay Dewey Gentry.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The world's tin mines yielded 13,400 long tons last October or 200 tons more than in the preceding month, the International Tin Study Group in The Hague disclosed today.
CAMDEN, N. J., Dec. 26 (AP) -- A 17-year-old youth was arrested today and formally charged with the slaying of his nephew, 16.

For the season's third performance of Puccini's "Manon Lescaut," the management of the Metropolitan Opera changed the singers in the romantic leads and managed, nevertheless, to remain on the alkaline side. Licia Albanese was the new Manon and Richard Tucker the new Des Grieux who took over with little or no falling off in the effectiveness of the production.

BATAVIA, Dec. 26 (Reuters) -- Enthusiastic Indonesians tonight thronged the streets of this city, which changes is name to Jakarta and becomes the capital of the new United States of Indonesia when the Dutch hand over sovereignty tomorrow.

HONG KONG, Dec. 26 -- Chengtu, the Chinese Nationalists last mainland capital, was reliably reported tonight to have fallen to the Communists after a day of heavy fighting. Defending Gen. Hu Tsung-nan had flown suddenly to Hainan Island while the Communists had been reported attempting to storm Chengtu's south gate.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 26 -- Egypt, largest Arab power in the Middle East, warned Iraq and Jordan by implication today to keep hands off turbulent Syria.

Referring to the designee as "the heavyweight champion of the United States and outstanding contender for the world title," The Ring Magazine, in a copyrighted article appearing in its February issue, selects Ezzard Charles, Cincinnati Negro, as the "Fighter of the Year."

The winners in a nation-wide poll of fashion designers and fashion and society editors to select the ten best-dressed women of 1949 were made public yesterday by the New York Dress institute, which conducted the survey. Seven of the ten women on this year's list were similarly honored a year

PANAMA, Dec. 26 -- President-elect Laureano Gomez, a Conservative, will encourage investment of foreign capital in Colombia and will grant it all proper safeguards as a policy of his Administration, which will begin next August, he told this correspondent in a recent interview in Bogota.

Reporting on operations of the Gibson Refrigerator Company in the fiscal year ended with last Sept. 30, Charles J. Gibson, president, informed shareholders in the annual report just issued that the company enters 1950 with the largest backlog of firm orders in its history.

After completing a full day of work yesterday, Miss Rose Livingston, veteran social service worker known for many years as "the angel of Chinatown," finally found time last night to attend, one day late, a combined birthday and Christmas party in her honor.

BUFFALO, N. Y. Dec. 26 (AP) -- Western Kentucky's once-beaten basketball team gave Canisius its second defeat, 74 to 61, before 10,891 tonight in Memorial Auditorium. In the first game of a double-header. Temple downed the University of Buffalo, 66 to 48.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican, of Wisconsin, today demanded that Attorney General J. Howard McGrath investigate charges of an alleged "kickback" scheme involving the capital's forthcoming sesquicentennial celebration.

Syria has already experienced three military coups d'etat this year, and is at the moment completely without a Government following the resignation of both the President and the Cabinet. The issues which have led to this political chaos affect not only Syria but the whole Arab world.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 26 (AP) -The Santa Anita race track ushered in its thirteenth winter meeting today before a record-breaking opening-day crowd of 66,000 fans, who saw Your Host capture the $50,000 stake for California-foaled 2-year-olds and the Kentucky Derby champion, Ponder, finish out of the money in a co-feature.

GENEVA, Dec. 26 -- As a result of his current survey of medical insurance systems in European countries, Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, will recommend certain changes in the Administration bill, now before Congress, for compulsory health insurance.

Business in Broadway's first-run film theatres yesterday and over the Christmas holiday week-end was exceptional, with one house reporting a record, according to a canvass of representative showcases. The Radio City Music Hail, with the musical, "On the Town" as its attraction, played to about 100,000 persons from Thursday through Sunday, with yesterday's attendance estimated at 25,000 persons.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -- The American Federation of Labor announced tonight that its unions would seek "substantial" wage increases next year and strongly hinted that the final figure would be more than ten cents an hour.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. will conduct a nation-wide contest for paint retailers in 1950 as part of an advertising and promotion campaign to increase the distribution and sale of paint brushes made with nylon bristles. The contest will require answers to six true and false questions and a statement of twenty-five words or less from the retailer telling why he sells nylon paint brushes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The men of the Eighty-first Congress began returning today for its second session, a gathering certain to raise intense political heat and likely to leave unresolved for the 1950 campaigns many a capital legislative issue.

SLIDELL, Tex., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Two prominent West Texas chiropractors were found dead in the wreckage of a light plane near this northeast Texas town today. A third occupant was trapped in the fuselage for thirteen hours in freezing temperatures.
LONDON, Dec. 26 (Reuters) -- Gale warnings were in force in many areas around Britain tonight after the warmest Dec. 26 in sixty-seven years.

The three-day Christmas holiday drew to a close last night with railroad stations, bus terminals and airports jammed with travelers after a long week-end marked by a steadily mounting toll of accidental deaths.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Another committee of Republicans has been given the task of composing, in cooperation with their Congressional leaders, a set of "party principles" on which the Republicans can regain control of the Senate and the House in the elections of 1950.

Plans for the erection on the East Side of a twelve-story apartment building containing "luxury" suites have been announced by Brenner Lewis, Inc., brokers, who reported the sale of five buildings at 114 to 122 East Eighty- seventh Street By Lee Shubert to J. Goldfein and A. Hersch.

PARIS, Dec. 26 -- With only a shaky majority behind it, the Government of Premier Georges Bidault began today to guide the National Assembly through what is expected to be a long debate on the huge 1950 budget.

A logical first objective for industry in 1950 would be to match 1949's total output rather than that of the post-war boom years of 1947 and 1948, the National Association of Manufacturers declared yesterday in an analysis which found the national economy "strong and reassuring to an exceptional degree."

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 - About 12,070,000 tons of freight moved in barges over the Illinois Waterway in 1949, said a preliminary estimate made today by United States Army Engineers. The 1948 total was 12,109,250 tons. The waterway is maintained and operated by the Corps of Engineers.

The function of anti-Semitism, or any other form of group prejudice, is self-defense against one's own failures by projecting them on a weaker group, according to the conclusion of a comprehensive study of prejudice sponsored by the American Jewish Committee in cooperation with leading universities and colleges over the country.

A strapping, 71-year-old Indian, who has been harassing settlers in the plains of Flatbush since 1907 and having mighty little luck at it, ran afoul of a posse yesterday for the eighth time and wound up pitching his wigwam behind bars again.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Dec. 26 (UP) -- William Alexander Bustamante, leader of Jamaica's dominant Labor party, announced today that his new administration would concentrate on attracting foreign capital to this island colony.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 26 -- President Rafael Trujillo received blank-check power from Congress today to declare war against any Caribbean nation that knowingly harbored plotters of revolution aimed against the Dominican Republic.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -- Advocates of world government, who feel that their big task at this stage is educating and arousing public opinion, soon will have a chance to state their case before a highly respected sounding board.
The election of Norman Williams Jr., an attorney and zoning expert, as president of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council of New York, Inc., was announced yesterday.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 26 -- Common Pleas Judge Joseph A. Artl tonight directed the striking transit employes to resume their jobs by 2 P. M. tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts, the House Republican leader, asserted today that President Truman apparently intended to ask a "multi-billion-dollar" general tax rise as the price of repeal of the wartime excise taxes.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, announced yesterday that the Democratic legislative program for 1950 would give priority to establishment of a permanent State Commission on Aged Persons.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 26 -- The British and Yugoslav Governments signed tonight in Belgrade a five-year trade agreement for a volume of trade estimated at 220,000,000 ($616,000,000). The two Governments also signed an agreement on compensation for former British property in Yugoslavia.
Organized labor will fight for more substantial pensions in legislative halls and at the collective bargaining table next year.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 26 -- Harry N. Rosenfield, a member of the three-man United States Displaced Persons Commission, who left here today after a 1,300-mile tour of the country, said he was impressed by the manner in which Israel was absorbing immigrants, but felt there was a crying need for an orientation program at their points of departure.

Permanent pleating by the yard is now offered by many fabric shops and departments in the large stores. The service is available as an accommodation to customers. This means that a length of material of almost any kind can be processed with pleats that remain through dry cleaning and washing.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Jobstown carried the silks of F. H. Stark to victory in the featured Coral Gables Purse of $3,000 at Tropical Park today, reporting past the judges stand with a margin of two and a half lengths over W. Noble's Kay Gibson.

The number of television sets in the United States should reach 20,000,000 by the end of 1954, according to Brig. Gen. David Sarnoff, chairman of the board of the Radio Corporation of America. In his annual year-end statement, General Sarnoff predicted that in four years video's total audience would approximate 75,000,000 persons.

The city faces a $12,000,000 deficit in welfare costs for the fiscal year ending next June 30, and a sharp increase in expenditures for the next fiscal year to care for a steadily rising number of residents needing public assistance, it was reported yesterday by Raymond M. Hilliard, Commissioner of Welfare.

Originally planned as an economy measure, rural zoning in Wisconsin is providing a means of developing new sources of taxable wealth. The American Society of Planning Officials reported that the first rural zoning ordinance in Wisconsin was adopted sixteen years ago in an effort to solve the problem of tax-delinquent land, which comprises as much as one-third of the area of some counties.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Southern coaches lost two of their best backs today as practice continued for Saturday's Blue- Gray football game.

Failure to recognize the increasing importance of the clinic in the city's total medical program may be the reason why most hospital out-patient departments and other clinics are offering "second-rate" medical service to what may be one-third of the city's sick and ailing.

Dr. John Friend Mahoney, outstanding syphilologist who developed the use of penicillin to cure venereal disease, has been appointed director of the bureau of laboratories of the city Department of Health.

A world center for research in mental deficiency, to be set up at Letchworth Village, Thiels, N. Y., was called for yesterday by Dr. Edward J. Humphreys, deputy commissioner of the New Jersey State Department of Institutions and Agencies.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 26 -- According to information available in Amman, the United States and Britain are directly encouraging separate peace negotiations between Jordan and Israel. The replies from London and Washington to the Arab states' protest in late autumn against alleged Israeli breaches of the May 12 protocol arranged by the United Nations Conciliation Commission were interpreted in Amman as suggesting separate negotiations.
The letter of Lewis Mayers in criticism of the American Civil Liberties Union, published in your Dec. 19 issue calls for reply.
Mitchell C. Jossem has been appointed a senior partner and Larry Cohn a junior partner of Superba Cravats of Rochester, N. Y.

THE Siamese are a delightful people, hut their politics are unspeakable -- that is the principal conclusion to be drawn from Alexander MacDonald's "Bangkok Editor,"* a brisk and amusing volume, of hasty journalistic memoirs. Mr. MacDonald, who speaks and writes Japanese, has not yet had time to become fluent in Siamese. He makes no pretense to have written an intimate study of the thought and life of a peculiar and charming Oriental nation.

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Japan used United States prisoners of war as guinea pigs in experiments preparing for germ warfare against the United States and Britain, a witness testified at Russia's bacterial war trial, the Moscow Radio said today.

Champions by virtue of their success in last season's national invitation tournament, the Dons of San Francisco again failed to live up to their billing last night at Madison Square Garden, bowing to Long Island University, 56-48, before 16,000 fans.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Action to halt the "mysterious shopping" of contracts and concessions for the capital's 150th birthday party next year was announced by officials tonight.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Little Betty Lou Marbury, for whom many in the nation prayed, must have her right hand amputated.

This is the time of year when economists and business leaders throughout the country concertedly defy the time-honored adage that "prediction is the most gratuitous form of human folly." Within another fortnight or so, even the more casual newspaper reader or radio listener should have a fairly good idea of how the business and economic outlook for 1950 looks to these experts.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 27 -- Robert O. Loosley, secretary of Brown University since 1947, has resigned, effective Feb. 1, to become campaign director of the Greater New York Fund, which raises more than $5,000,000 annually for 423 metropolitan hospitals and health and welfare agencies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Miss Clarice Scott. designer of functional clothing for the Bureau of Human Nutrition and Home Economics. United States Department of Agriculture, today announced her new handi-coat. styled for the shopper who carries groceries home by street car or bus.

Polling and questionnaires that miss the "why" and "how" behind the "what" in their findings were the target of pointed criticism yesterday at opening of the American Marketing Association's two-day winter meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Add to the list of films opening this week a pair of French importations which will arrive at the Ambassador tomorrow. These are "Twilight," an adaptation of "Histoire Comique" by Anatole France, starring Micheline Presle and Louis Jourdan and directed by Marc Allegret, and "Counter Intelligence," a drama with Louis Salou, Jany Holt and Lucien Coedel. Jean Faurez directed. Both films are being released by Films International.

Fifty-three Long Island Rail Road trains were one to twenty-five minutes late yesterday morning. One train met such an obstacle that it did not run at all. Returning holiday visitors, some of whom were not used to travel on the Long Island, shared the confusion and delays with thousands of seasoned commuters.

Halted by the curfew on Monday after having taken the first set, third-seeded Donald Dockerill of Larchmont, N. Y., advanced to the second round by defeating Bernard Pustilnik, Bronx, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1, in the Eastern junior and boys tennis tournament on the indoor courts of the Third Engineers Group (Twenty-second Regiment) Armory yesterday.

We are in the midst of an agricultural revolution as a result of which the surface of the earth is being "stretched" to make possible a more abundant life for an increased population, Dr. Elvin C. Stakman, president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, declared yesterday. The University of Minnesota professor spoke at a symposium on trends of modern science at the Statler Hotel.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- The fight over management policies of National Enameling and Stamping Company, Milwaukee, was renewed today with charges that the election of Stevens Bennett as president of the company on Dec. 6 was announced to stockholders several hours before the election officially took place at a directors' meeting in Chicago.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Dec. 27 -- The Netherlands' long-held sovereignty over Indonesia was formally transferred to the new republic today in a brief ceremony during which Queen Juliana appealed to both Dutch and Indonesians to "cooperate loyally" in the new relationship between the two countries.

The apartment house at 35-35 Ninety-fourth Street in Jackson Heights, Queens, containing twenty suites, has been sold by A. Schuyler Clark and others to Daniel O'Neill and others. The property is assessed at $60,000.

It is "stupid" to force children with physical and emotional handi-caps to go to school, if nothing is done at the same time to help them with their special problems, Dr. Leona Baumgartner, associate chief of the United States Children's Bureau, said yesterday.

Western Germany's spectacular recovery, marked by an export boom recently, is not likely to last, economists warned yesterday in an appraisal of economic policy in Occupied Germany before the American Economic Association.

At the current meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science the Princeton University Press announced that its most distinguished author, Dr. Albert Einstein, has developed a new unified or generalized theory of relativity. Similar past attempts he rejected as inadequate.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Kenneth S. Wherry of Nebraska, Republican floor leader of the Senate, called today for an end to the bipartisan foreign policy as it is now known.

St. John's still is undefeated, but only because of the "skull" of an inexperienced Utah sophomore, whose inexcusable attempt to score a basket at a time when his team did not need one turned certain victory into a heart-breaking over time defeat last night at Madison Square Garden.

MONTREAL, Dec. 27 (UP) -- Ted Lindsay, Detroit Red Wings' star forward, led the National Hockey League's scoring parade for the sixth straight week, official statistics released by the league today showed.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Following is the text of Queen Juliana's speech today as she formally proclaimed independence for the United States of Indonesia:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The start of arms aid shipments to Western Europe has been delayed about a month to around Feb. 1.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Most Senators and all of their administrative assistants are watching an unusual Senate primary race in New Hampshire these days. The contestants are:

Plans for altering a property in the Beekman Hill section were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase by Lillian Tanzer of the four-story building on a lot 20 by 100 feet at 350 East Fifty-first Street in a deal negotiated by John H. Mautner, broker.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UP) -- The Government cannot possibly ferret out enough unpaid taxes with its present small staff of investigators to erase the Federal deficit, a high official said today.

IT happened at Tropical Park the day after Christmas. A 2-year-old filly named Jadeite finished last in the secondary feature and dropped dead. Perhaps it was sheer embarrassment that killed her. There was no other immediate explanation. The jockey, George McMullen, offered a formal statement which certainly must merit consideration as the quote-of-the-year. Said he: "She just dropped dead."

Pari-mutuel betting at harness racing tracks in the twelve states where such wagering is legal was up 10.5 per cent this year over 1948, according to figures released yesterday by the United States Trotting Association.
How much control should the Federal Government exercise over the private pension programs that are sprouting up in industry under the pressure of union drives for increased old-age security?

BOSTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics tonight continued their victory streak as they turned back the New York Knickerbockers, 97 -- 78, in a National Basketball Association game before 5,012 fans.

Light trading marked yesterday's session on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Transactions in coffee numbered 265 lots with prices off 5 to 19 points on the S contract and 31 to 46 points up on the D.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 27 -- Argosy Productions, the John Ford-Merian Cooper Company, will cease active operations as soon as Ford finishes editing "Wagon Master," it was learned today from an Argosy representative. All Argosy employes had been given notice, and they will begin leaving the company immediately after the first of the year.

VIENNA, Wednesday, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Austrian border guards said early today that Israel Jacobson, a United States citizen, had been expelled from Hungary and was being held by Russian troops just inside the Austrian border.
The seventeen-ship post-war construction program of Fearnley Eger and its co-partner, A. F. Klaveness Co., is rapidly nearing completion.

ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- In a novel attempt to keep in tune with the political views of his community, Assemblyman Fred W. Preller, Queens Republican, is polling several thousand of his constituents for advice on the stand he should take with regard to twenty-four questions likely to come before the Legislature next year.

The international market in blocked internal securities of Great Britain persists, with dealings at continued heavy discounts from the official rate of exchange. The blocked sterling proceeds from the sale of British Government bonds owned by non-Britishers are now selling at $1.63 to the pound, a discount of about 40 per cent from the official rate of $2.80 for current American account sterling.

Two tenants, once evicted from their Forty-eighth Street apartment to make room for the United Nations, will use the city's own Sharkey Rent Law to fight a second set of dispossess proceedings being brought by the city, it was learned yesterday.

An agreement between the Harbor Carriers of the Port of New York and Local 996, International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, which represents the captains of lighters throughout this port, was announced yesterday. The former is an industry association representing a large number of companies engaged in lighter work.
The long-rumored construction of an East Coast mill by the United States Steel Corporation moved closer to reality yesterday.

I wish to call attention to two news items appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 16. One, from Lake Success, reports the introduction of a resolution by France that the United Nations Trusteeship Council censure Israel for allegedly violating the U. N. Assembly's decision to internationalize Jerusalem.

The cliche expert had a going-over yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science and was pronounced a fairly reliable weather forecaster by a jury of scientific experts.

HONG KONG, Dec. 27 -- Informed sources here are doubtful of the ability of Nationalist leaders, either from the China mainland or Formosa and Hainan, to develop and control guerrilla warfare on an effective scale against the Chinese Communists.

Lily Pons made her first appearance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon as Lucia -- the role in which she made her debut there in January, 1931 -- in Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor." The Shah of Iran was in the audience that paid her tribute.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Dec. 27 -- Traffic north of here on the Albany Post Road, Route 6, the Taconic Parkway extension and approaches to Bear Mountain Bridge was being speeded today by a new $1,654,200 bridge that the State Department of Public Works has decided to put into service, although construction will not be completed until spring.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Dr. Corwin D. Edwards, director of the bureau of industrial economics of the Federal Trade Commission, recommended today that the agency reject a proposed compromise settlement of price-fixing charges against nearly 100 steel companies and the American Iron and Steel Institute.

PARIS, Wednesday, Dec. 28 -- Defeated by thirteen votes in the National Assembly, on its motion to discuss the tax compromise rejected by the Finance Committee yesterday, the Cabinet of Premier Georges Bidault early today was facing a probable failure to get its budget voted.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- The General Council of the Trades Union Congress issued as a formal document today the eight recommendations for the restraint of wages originally announced Nov. 24. This document, setting forth the views of organized labor on devaluation and its consequences, has been circulated to all affiliated unions representing 9,000,000 workers and will be acted upon at the conference of the Executive Committee in mid-January.

Although they arrived in New York with only 50 cents between them the O'Connells of Washington, D. C., decided to live in style and comfort. And so, with a careless elegance, they spent Dec. 9 to Dec. 23 in the Plaza Hotel, the Waldorf-Astoria and the Roosevelt, living in luxury and without paying their bills, totaling $389.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- An appeal to families and friends to visit the nation's "forgotten" men in veterans' mental hospitals was issued by the Veterans Administration today.

The State Athletic Commission's mass examination of fighters in advance of their Madison Square Garden engagements Friday night was accomplished yesterday for what was believed to be the first time in history, with only a single defection from the ranks.
LONDON, Dec. 27 (Reuters) -- Liverpool retained leadership of the football association's first division today, tying Chelsea, 2 -- 2, before 58,000 spectators.
Cardinal Spellman yesterday called on "freedom-loving people everywhere" to raise their voices in a "common bond of prayer" for Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, Roman Catholic Primate of Hungary.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Grandview Stables' mud-running Artist Life captured his third purse at the Tropical Park meeting today by sloshing to a rousing victory in the featured Craigmiller Purse.

Your editorial "Water Meters Are a Must" leaves one with the impression that you have determined upon the sole solution of New York's water shortage -- water metering. It isn't that easy by any means, at least not in the City of New York, with its 2,275,796 dwelling units, housing 8,005,000 people who have always used water freely and wastefully.

In the highly competitive North Atlantic passenger trade, steamship companies have used every possible device to lure the traveler to their own particular ocean greyhounds. They have stressed safety features, speed, size, luxury, service, but perhaps most of all they have emphasized cuisine.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The rainy season has forced a new relief problem upon Israeli agencies -- care for thousands of Jewish immigrants who have been living in leaky tents along the coastal strip.

Frederick V. Field, millionaire sympathizer with Communist causes, was married to the divorced wife of Dr. Raymond Boyer, Canadian scientist who received a two-year sentence for making available secret explosives to a Soviet atomic bomb spy ring, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The Pennsylvania Gas and Electric Corporation, Jersey City, N. J., received permission today from the Securities and Exchange Commission to put all of its system's gas transmission and distribution properties located in New York State under the ownership of one subsidiary confined in its operations to that state.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 27 -- John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, has informed Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West Germany's Chancellor, that unless the Federal Government acts on proposed legislation giving workers an economic voice in the management of factories, mines and other industrial installations he will withdraw the suspension on two state laws providing such prerogatives.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 27 (UP) -- The National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues today gave its fifty-nine minor league members another chance to repeal the controversial bonus rule.

Greeted by an advance sale of at least $130,000, a record thus far, the New York City Theatre Company, one of the cultural activities established at the City Center, ushers in its third term tonight with Oliver Goldsmith's celebrated mixture of farce and high comedy, "She Stoops to Conquer," not seen here since 1928. Inasmuch as an 8:15 curtain is advertised, the management would appreciate the cooperation of first-nighters.

Operations of Schenley Industries, Inc., in the quarter ended on Nov. 30, last, resulted in net earnings of $8,712,883, after all charges including $5,770,000 provision for income taxes, the report revealed yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- The American Educational Theatre Association today agreed to undertake a movement aimed at helping in the rehabilitation of patients in most of the 133 Veteran Administration hospitals throughout the country.
The Spelman Fund of New York made appropriations totaling $657,800 in 1947 and 1948 for the betterment of public administration, according to the fund's final report yesterday.
ENDICOTT, N. Y., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Thomas J. Watson, chairman of the board of the International Business Machine Corporation, said today that American business could expect "good results" in 1950.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 27 -- India will reject the McNaughton proposals for demilitarization of the Jammu and Kashmir area preparatory to a plebiscite in the dispute with Pakistan over the northern princely state, it was learned from authoritative quarters tonight.

ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- The combined municipal debts of the sixty-one other cities in the state is only 10 per cent of the total of New York City's outstanding obligations, Frank C. Moore, state controller, disclosed in a year-end report today.

IT is one of the affectations of intellectual and artistic snobbery to profess to find rare excellence in unlikely places. If a painter or a poet or a novelist is sufficiently mediocre so that there is good cause for his obscurity he need not despair. He still has a chance of becoming the object of the twittering admiration of a little coterie devoted to making silk purses out of sows' ears.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Empire Steel Corporation, owned by the Studebaker Corporation of South Bend, Ind., since December, 1947, today was sold to the Rema Company of Dover, Ohio. The price was reported unofficially as $5,000,000.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 27 -- President Juan Peron refused a promotion to the rank of major general voted today by the all-Peronista Senate. President Peron holds the rank of brigadier general.

Ernest Howard of the University of Toronto, seeded No. 5, eliminated third-seeded Thomas Ringe of Dartmouth, 17 -- 16, 15 -- 9, 10 -- 15, 17 -- 18, 15 -- 11, as play started yesterday in the annual intercollegiate squash racquets tournament at the University Club.

In his end-of-the-year interview in London Professor Arnold Toynbee did not predict that the cold war would last until the year 2000. What he actually said was that a shooting war was not inevitable within the next fifty years. This is a safer prophecy; the first premise of Western policy, indeed, is that the shooting stage can be prevented provided the necessary measures are taken how.

TOKYO, Dec. 27 -- Agriculture Minister Kotaro Mori today told the Cabinet that General MacArthur's headquarters had turned down the Japanese Government's plan to increase the official ration of staple foodstuffs by about 4 per cent during the current rice year.

Joseph Loftus' story in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 17 heralds a significant victory for the large numbers of migrant workers who yearly provide Americans with the products which make us the best-fed and best-clothed people in the world. The Federal Advisory Council to the Bureau of Employment should be commended for its courage and far-sightedness in recommending that no foreign labor be imported during the coming year.

PARIS, Dec. 27 -- By hard work and shrewd national instincts the German people have by the end of the fourth year of their occupation placed themselves in a position from which they may some day again be able to dominate Europe.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 27 -- The Israeli Government, which is now negotiating the ratification of the British-controlled Palestine Potash Company's concession to exploit Dead Sea minerals, is confronted with the problem of whether to share the royalties with neighboring Jordan in accordance with the current terms of the concession or to make unilateral arrangements.
Disagreement existed yesterday as to whether this New Year's Eve would be dismissed to the loud ring of cash registers that accompanied the 1948 finale.
GLOVERSVILLE, N. Y., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Sheriff F. Eugene Smith said tonight he had "a few leads" in his investigation of the stoning last night of a union leader's home.

Ohio's Ferguson Act forbids strikes by state or city employes and is almost identical, in vital passages, with New York's Condon-Wadlin Law. Therefore the strike in Cleveland which began last Thursday and paralyzed public transportation through the Christmas holiday until it ended yesterday has special points of interest for New York City, which also runs its own transit system.

Dictators are by the nature of their office uncontrollable and unpredictable. President Rafael Trujillo of the Dominican Republic asked -- and of course received -- authority from his Congress on Monday to declare war against any Caribbean nation that knowingly harbored plotters of revolution against his country.
PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 27 (UP) -- The unlisted telephone in the modest frame home of Albert Einstein rang constantly today.

Directors of American Asphalt Roof Corporation have declared an extra dividend of $1 and a quarterly dividend of 25 cents on the common stock, both payable on Jan. 15. A similar extra dividend was paid last January.

JAKARTA (Batavia), Java, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The 77,000,000 people of Indonesia snapped their colonial bond with the Netherlands today and took their place as a new nation in Communist - threatened southeast Asia.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Dec. 27 (AP) -- An unexpected $1,000,000 inheritance-tax payment from the estate of Edward S. Moore today bolstered Florida's depleted state general fund balance. It was one of the largest single estate-tax payments that the state ever had received.

CHARLESTON, S. C., Dec. 27 (UP) -- Historic Fort Moultrie off the South Carolina coast passes to new ownership tomorrow, and with it the controversy over its most famous occupant -- the long dead Indian Osceola.

The Collegiate Chorale, which is without the services of Robert Shaw, its founder, because he is taking a sabbatical, made its fifth annual Christmas festival concert at Carnegie Hall last night an exciting occasion, as usual. The program was built around fine and rarely heard works for chorus that suited the season, and the guest conductor was Alfredo Antonini, who directed with authority and musical perception.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Illinois won its sixth basketball game in eight tests and handed the Columbia University quintet its second loss in six games tonight, defeating the Lions, 58 to 46, in the first game of their cross-country tour before 4,760 fans.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 27 -- The educational benefits of the Fulbright Act were extended to Turkey under a cultural agreement signed in Ankara today by United States Ambassador George Wadsworth and Faik Zihni Akdur, secretary general of the Turkish Foreign Ministry.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 27 -- Vice Premier and Foreign Minister Edvard Kardelj announced today in Parliament that the Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) had agreed in principle to grant the Yugoslav Government a loan of $25,000,000.

MOSCOW, Dec. 27 (AP) -- It seems quite possible the Soviet Union will send a team to participate in the 1952 Olympic Games at Helsinki. If this happens, it will be the first time Russia will have taken part in this major international athletic event.
DETROIT, Dec. 27 -- Ypsilanti tonight called an emergency meeting to seek ways of easing the acute unemployment in the area around the industrial community, thirty miles west of Detroit.

You are probably swamped with similar complaints. Nevertheless I want to add one more voice to what must be a swelling chorus of protest against the weird noisemaking let loose upon helpless customers by the powers that control the loudspeaker system at Grand Central Station.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Dec. 27 -- Provisional President Hashem al-Atassi of Syria agreed this evening to withdraw his resignation after the Constituent Assembly this afternoon had unanimously rejected his resignation and had requested him to remain in office.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Dec. 27 -- President Truman drew his five-day "working holiday" toward a close tonight after a day chiefly devoted to routine state duties and talks with political leaders of his home state, and other oldtime associates.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 27 -- Eliot Hearst of Columbia, Fred Turim of Brooklyn College and Theodore Edelbaum of the Rensselaer Institute, with three straight victories, remain undefeated today after three rounds of the National Intercollegiate Chess League tournament for the H. Arthur Nabel trophy in progress in the library annex building on the Rutgers University campus.

The British Government has notified the Supreme Command of the Allied Powers in Japan that sterling balances built up by the Japanese may not be used for the purchase of oil from American oil concerns from "dollar" sources, according to cable messages received yesterday by United States oil companies from their representatives in Japan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The State Department in effect today restated its official opposition to the action of the Dominican Congress in giving President Rafael L. Trujillo the power to declare war. The Congress granted him authority to declare war against any Caribbean nations that knowingly harbored plotters of revolution against the Dominican Republic's Government.

Moppets who avidly follow the comic books are only aping their elders who seek escape from reality in this age of atom bombs, machines and confusing life situations, a psychologist told the American Association for the Advancement of Science yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 27 -- President Juan Perons libel suit against the newspapers Nacion and Prensa, which he announced Dec. 3, got under way this morning. Dr. Luis Mitre, 80-year-old director of Nacion, made a brief appearance before Federal Juge Miguel Vignola.

HAVANA, Ill., Dec. 27 -- Scott W. Lucas, majority leader of the United States Senate, announced his candidacy for a third term tonight, and pitched his campaign on a defense of foreign policy as conducted by the Democratic Administration.

A plot of land 300 by 105 feet on the east side of Nostrand Avenue, between Avenues T and U, in Brooklyn has been sold by Saul M. Siegel, operator and builder, to Joseph Levitt. The new owner plans to improve the parcel with a row of one-family houses.

SANTA ROSA, Calif., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Carl Schwartz, 39 years old, a ranch foreman accused of running amok with a gun, was charged today with the Christmas Eve murder of Jane Maggard Dickson, 30, a socially-prominent writer for the San Francisco Bay area newspapers.

PARIS, Dec. 27 -- The Office for Economic Affairs published today an extensive list of products import quotas on which France has consented to lift for member countries of the European Marshall Plan Council. At the same time, a tariff wall will be erected on many of them.
The Associated Press learns from a responsible source that King Farouk of Egypt may soon marry the 16-year-old daughter of an Egyptian civil servant. She is Miss Narriman Sadek.

LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 27 -- The Cunard White Star shipping company, owner of the Queen Elizabeth and Queen Mary, is planning to build a new express liner for its transatlantic fleet, according to press reports here today.
New rules issued yesterday will compel landlords who formerly painted and decorated apartments every two years to resume this schedule on Jan. 15.

Kling Factories will accept retailer orders on four bedroom suites at the opening of the Chicago home furnishings market Jan. 9 for delivery up to the middleof April olny, George Dudley, general sales manager, disclosed yesterday.

BERLIN, Dec. 27 (AP) -- A West Berlin Lutheran dean declared today that food and sanitary conditions in Russian zone concentration camps were better than in many West German refugee camps. Dean Heinrich Grueber was one of four churchmen who were permitted to hold Christmas services in the three biggest concentration camps in the East zone.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Syracuse University's undefeated basketball team tonight handed Brown its first setback of the season, 54 -- 52.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The United States Government has decided to extend de jure recognition to the Republic of the United States of Indonesia, a State Department spokesman said today. The formalities in connection with the recognition will be completed within the next twenty-four hours.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- A complaint was issued today by the Federal Trade Commission charging seventeen New York and New Jersey jobbers of automotive products and supplies with violation of the Clayton Anti-Trust Act by "inducing and receiving discriminations in price from suppliers."

Alger Hiss identified yesterday a friendly letter that he had written on May 7, 1948, to Noel Field, identified earlier in the Hiss perjury trial as the leader of a Russian underground organization in Washington in 1935.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 27 (UP) -- Attorneys for the CIO longshore leader, Harry Bridges, endeavored today to have two Government witnesses indicted for perjury, one of the charges on which Bridges is being tried.

The stock market gave evidence yesterday that it would generally follow a middle-of-the-road-course in the closing week of the year. While prices adhered to an irregular and mixed pattern during the morning, selling increased during the afternoon to leave final quotations on the lower side.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Rutgers University announced today a program of research to determine what causes social tensions and what sets off bobby sox crazes.
ALBANY, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Governor Dewey heard clemency pleas today for two men convicted of first degree murder and sentenced to die in Sing Sing's electric chair next month.
GENEVA, Dec. 27 -- Two Czechoslovak-Swiss agreements, one settling Swiss claims for property nationalized in Czechoslovakia and the other a five-year trade accord, were announced in Berne today.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Eleven foreign-bred racers from five different countries are among the sixty-two nominations for Hialeah's $25,000 McLennan at a mile and a quarter on Feb. 11, Racing Secretary Charles J. McLennan announced today.

Want to find out what to do for a baseball shoulder, a tennis elbow, a charley horse, a glass arm or a budding cauliflower ear? Go to the Hotel Piccadilly today or tomorrow and sit in at the first national convention of athletic trainers.

Clearance of children's and infants' wear stocks in two busy weeks prior to Christmas has induced early buying for spring, according to manufacturers at the Metropolitan Juvenile Style Mart showing in the New Yorker Hotel. Orders placed on the first day of a two-week showing, they said, indicate a willingness to buy by specialty shop owners in the Metropolitan area.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 27 -- The gift of a 467-year-old copy of the Pentateuch -- the first five books of the Old Testament of the Bible -- to the Hebrew Union College here was announced by Dr. Nelson Glueck, president of the Hebrew Union College, rabbinical seminary, at a dinner tonight.

The annual report of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, issued yesterday by Harvey S. Firestone Jr., chairman, disclosed the net income for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, last, at $17,823,621 after all charges, including $5,169,652 reserve to cover foreign earnings which could not now be remitted.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 27 -- A disorganized Yale quintet went down to its second defeat of the season tonight, dropping a 45-33 decision to Boston College. The Elis have won five games.

Charged with stabbing her husband to death on Christmas Day with two steak knives, Mrs. Camilla Failla, 32 years old, of 72 Lamport Place, the Bronx, was recommitted yesterday to Bellevue Hospital for further psychiatric observation.
DETROIT, Dec. 27 -- Appeals for unemployment benefits during the strike of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, against the Ford Motor Company last May have been won by about 300 Ford employes.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 27 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie today extended the congratulations of the United Nations to the peoples of Indonesia and the Netherlands on the establishment of the United States of Indonesia.

VIENNA, Dec. 27 -- The Austrian Laenderbank will dispense with New York representation in Marshall Plan transactions and thus with the services of Frederick Sunley, hitherto its New York representative, according to a report in the Communist newspaper Abend today.
Two tangible developments operated yesterday to confirm the belief that Governor Dewey would temporarily stop seeking public office at the end of his current term as Governor, on Dec. 31, 1950.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Raymond (Bear) Wolf, former head coach at Florida, becomes Tulane's football line coach next Sunday.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- In high spirits and seeming good health, Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin left here today on the first stage of his train-air-sea journey to the conference of Commonwealth Foreign Ministers and economic experts meeting in Colombo, Ceylon, on Jan. 9.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Robert Heller, chairman of the National Committee for Strengthening Congress, called today for the creation of a Congressional joint committee to frame further reforms in the legislative machinery.
ROME, Dec. 27 -- The Communists announced today another great campaign in favor of "peace," which they assert is threatened by the United States and other "imperialist" countries.

Nineteen symphony orchestras from various parts of the country will be featured over the radio network of the National Broadcasting Company, beginning Saturday, Jan. 7, from 3 to 4 P. M., when the "Orchestras of the Nation" series begins its sixth season.

With the presentation of the 1950 Buick automobile line yesterday came an announcement of cuts ranging from $67 to $326 in the New York delivered prices. The reductions affect models in the Roadmaster and Super series.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Small business concerns and distressed employment areas will hereafter be given the advantage in tie government bids, by order today of the General Services Administration.

PANAMA, Dec. 27 -- After a week in Bogota, talking with both Conservatives and Liberals and with foreign residents presumed to have an objective view, this correspondent agrees with President Mariano Ospina Perez that the present political situation is too complex and goes back too far for immediate evaluation.
A dense fog that reduced daytime visibility in the harbor to a low of 200 feet delayed the sailing of the French liner Ile de France for three hours and fifteen minutes yesterday.
PRINCESS ANNE COURT HOUSE, Va., Dec. 27 (UP) -- Robert (Buddy) Green was charged today with killing an Army lieutenant during a hold-up after a friend of the victim pleaded: "Don't shoot us, Buddy."

City housewives and househusbands, too, can congratulate themselves on the trend toward better eating among urban families. More enlightened meal planning on mother's part, implemented by enough money from father to buy the right food, have resulted in "significant gains in diet quality, particularly on the part of low-income groups."

A court-ordered revision of an appraisal of property in condemnation for the Sheepshead Bay Houses, a New York City Housing Authority project in Brooklyn, resulted in a savings of $78,716 to the city, it was disclosed yesterday.

A nation-wide campaign for public subscription of $500,000 to build a non-denominational chapel at the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, N. Y., will be conducted from Jan. 1 to Oct. 1, 1950, Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, chairman of the Maritime Commission, said yesterday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Prices of grains declined on the Board of Trade today, with closing deals at about the bottom.
Santa Claus, having been around for a long time, probably has grown accustomed to becoming a forgotten man soon after he has extricated himself from his last chimney on Christmas morning.

Scientists are not immune to error, visitors to the annual meeting of the American Assocation for the Advancement of Science at the Statler Hotel discovered yesterday. That conclusion was reached when scotch tape was found wound around an exhibit box on the eighteenth floor, where snakes, alligators, turtles and lizards are on view.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 27 -- The clang of trolley bells and honking of thousands of automobile horns tonight marked the end of Cleveland's six-day transit strike.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- About 2,500 military aircraft were built in the United States during 1949, it was estimated today by Admiral DeWitt C. Ramsey (retired), president of the Aircraft Industries Association. Official statistics are unavailable, for security reasons.

Another 1-cent drop in the retail price of a quart of milk by Sunday seemed probable yesterday, as the United States Department of Agriculture announced a cut of about 1 cent a quart in the minimum price dealers in the New York metropolitan area must pay to producers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The State Department notified relatives of two Navy enlisted men today that definite news had been received that they were alive and well, although in Communist custody outside Tsingtao, Manchuria. The men have been missing for more than a year.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation got from a tapped telephone wire on Feb. 27 its first tip-off that Judith Coplon, Department of Justice employe, planned to travel on March 4 from Washington to New York, it was disclosed yesterday in an FBI report read in Federal Court here.

An entire family in Vineyard Haven, Mass., "joined together" this year to send their contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, "to make a happy Christmas homecoming for Mrs. Irene R. in Case 6."

It takes all kinds to make up the sporting scene these days and some of the letters received from Northern shooters who just returned from Southern quail and turkey shooting come under the heading of "revelations."

A plan to relieve overcrowding at the Flushing bus terminal in Queens received the support yesterday of William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation, at a public hearing at the board's offices.

A variety of musical compositions of this century was offered by the League of Composers at McMillin Theatre yesterday evening to an audience consisting largely of composers, musicologists and others interested in the trend of contemporary music.
HYNDMAN, Pa., Dec. 27 -- The inhabitants of this burned-out mountain town began a community effort today to repair the damage wrought by a Christmas Eve fire that leveled most of its business center.

Your editorial "No Magic Wand on Water," like your earlier editorial comment on this pressing civic problem, as well as your daily news items publicizing the seriousness of the situation, bespeaks an intelligent grasp of basic needs. When it comes to method, however, is not THE TIMES a bit too impatient with city officials for apparent laxity in curbing business and industry, and with the public for insufficient savings in water consumption?
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday, and final prices were 4 points net higher to 2 points net lower than on Friday.
J. W. Brooks, formerly domestic sales manager of Scripto, Inc., mechanical writing instruments, has been named vice president and sales manager.

Christmas was not over yesterday for underprivileged youngsters in the city. Santa Claus was still handing out gifts and candy in police precinct stations, and his helpers wore blue uniforms and silver shields that looked as good to the youngsters as Santa's own white whiskers and red coat.

Pentti Lund, right winger, who has been on the sidelines with an abdominal injury since Dec. 4, will be back in action tonight when the New York Rangers skate against the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League battle at Madison Square Garden.

Rainfall in the twenty-four hours ended at 8 A. M. yesterday left in the up-state watersheds a potential run-off of 3,910,000,000 gallons of water, or more than four days' supply at the present rate of consumption.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 28 (UP) -- William J. Sebald, United States representative on the Allied Control Council, today described Russian reports on the germ warfare trial of twelve Japanese as a propaganda "smoke screen."

Decision on a motion by Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., to enjoin the Pan American World Airways from transporting Holy Year pilgrims from New York to Rome was reserved yesterday by Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe.

News that the American Economics Association is now meeting in this city reminds us that an economist we know -- an eminently practical fellow -- recently let us in on one of his treasured trade secrets: how he takes the economic temperature of the country and makes his business forecasts.

Uday Shankar, who delighted us all back in the Thirties with what was for most of us our first glimpse of the wonders of the Hindu dance arts, is back again after an absence of eleven years, and surely most of us feel pretty good about it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today that average weekly earnings of factory workers dropped to $54.45 in mid-November. This was 75 cents less than mid-October and reflected shortening of the average work week to 39.2 hours, about a half-hour below a month ago and a year ago.

Mayor O'Dwyer and his bride, the former Elizabeth Sloan Simpson, will return to the city tomorrow, it was announced yesterday at the Mayor's office in City Hall. They were married at Stuart, Fla., on Dec. 20 and have been on a honeymoon cruise in near - by waters.

OTTAWA, Dec. 27 (Canadian Press) -- A combine has operated for twenty years to fix prices and restrain competition in Canada's multi-million-dollar flat glass trade, F. A. McGregor, Canadian Combines Commissioner, charged in a report made public today.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 27 -- Among the currents running below the surface of German political life today is the development in both Bavaria and Austria of a movement for union of the two areas.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Pennsylvania's coal diggers today neared their best safety record in history.
