Two Boston Red Sox team-mates, Outfielder Ted Williams and Shortstop Vern (Junior) Stephens, batted in more runs in 1949 than ever before in their major league careers -- and neither could win the R.B.I. title.

The New York Film Critics yesterday voted "All the King's Men" the best picture of 1949, Olivia de Havilland as the best actress, Broderick Crawford as the best actor, Carol Reed of England as the best director, and an Italian drama. "The Bicycle Thief," the best foreign-language picture.

Although the theme is vital, the play does not poke beneath the surface. The theme is the life of the Negro in a white world. The play is "How Long Till Summer," which opened at the Playhouse last evening. Sarett and Herbert Rudley, authors, have tried to analyze color neuroses in a conventional problem drama about corrupt politics.

ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- William L. Pfeiffer, chairman of the Republican State Committee, declared today that nonpartisan plans for care of the aged were being jeopardized by the injection of "politics and confusion" into the subject by the Democratic party.

NEWARK, Dec. 27 -- Carl Holderman, president of the New Jersey State Congress of Industrial Organizations, today urged Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll and members of the city commission here to appeal from the recent decisions of the Board of Public Utility Commissioners approving the increase of bus and trolley fares for the Public Service Coordinated Transport and Independent Lines from 5 to 7 cents a zone.

For the second time in a week New York set a record for high winter temperatures yesterday. At both 3 and 4 in the afternoon the official thermometers read 62 degrees. The mercury fell to 59 by 6 o'clock but at 8:55 last night another new record was set with an official reading of 62.1 degrees.

Ross Roy, Inc., Detroit agency, has acquired an interest in the C. C. Fogarty Company, 4-A's Chicago agency, it was announced yesterday. Effective Jan. 1, the Chicago agency will be known as Ross Roy-Fogarty, Inc. Offices will continue to be located in the Bell Building, 307 North Michigan Avenue.

Favored by one extra shopping day, sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores rose 11 per cent above the corresponding week last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The Western World has taken two more steps over the Christmas holidays to contradict the Communist tenet that "capitalist" democracy is doomed because it breeds imperialism, colonialism, war and economic crises, and to demonstrate anew that the evils which the Communists ascribe to "capitalism" have become the evils of their own system.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 27 -- A comprehensive plan to redesign the Holy Sepulcher giving all sects now there separate churches around the present rotunda and including the Lutherans and Anglicans who are not represented in the basilica is about to be put forward by the Franciscan order, it was learned tonight.

TOKYO, Dec. 17 -- United States counterpart fund aid aggregating 8,600,000,000 yen (about $22,360,000) will be made available before March 31 to re-establish Japan's shipping industry, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.
LONDON, Dec. 27 -- Labor disputes and strikes continued today to disrupt the normal routine of the English post-Christmas holiday.

A fist fight among fifteen youths and a group of ushers at the Paramount Theatre, Broadway and Forty-third Street, yesterday afternoon was witnessed by about 500 patrons in the lobby waiting to be seated. One of the ushers was seriously injured. Eight of the assailants were arrested on charges of felonious assault.
Three new partners will be admitted next week to the investment banking firm of Lehman Brothers, it was announced yesterday. They include Francis A. Callery, Herman H. Kahn and Morris Natelson.
STATESVILLE, N. C., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Officers today were investigating the mysterious circumstances in the death of a retired grocer from Brooklyn, N. Y.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 28 -"Bedtime for Bonzo," a screen comedy by Raphael David Blau and Ted Berkman in which the center of attention is a monkey, has been acquired by Universal-International and assigned to Michel Kraike for production.

Nine chemical distributing companies have been named to market commercial uranium and eight new licenses for using the metal have been issued by the Atomic Energy Commission, the New York operations division revealed here yesterday.

CAMDEN, N. J., Dec. 28 -America today has a new figure for its Yuletide folklore, another 8-year-old girl to couple with Virginia O'Hanlon, whose query: "Is there a Santa Claus?" to a New York editor of the last century evoked a historic answer.

A novel approach to the water shortage was highlighted at a luncheon-symposium yesterday with a practical method and an equally practical suggestion. The method -- eating from paper plates. The suggestion -- to conserve with safety.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan was sworn into office for a third term yesterday in a brief ceremony at his office in the Criminal Courts Building, 100 Centre Street. It marked the first time in the history of New York County that a chief prosecutor had received three four-year terms.

The State of Maryland announced yesterday that it will receive bids on Jan. 9 on issues of school bonds totaling $9,650,000 and bearing tax-exempt interest. The bonds are to be dated Feb. 1, 1950, and will come due from Feb. 1, 1953 to 1965.

Long Island University will engage Western Kentucky and New York University will take on Yale in the basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight, but little was said about these attractions yesterday, when the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association met with the court coaches for lunch at Leone's.

One way to ring in the New Year is with "bells" of hard meringue heaped with ice cream. Though the combination is not original, having been endorsed by the French years ago, the style of presentation is. Serve the meringues as dessert for a New Year's Eve dinner or later in the evening with a sweet champagne or coffee au rhum.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 -- Walter E. Franklin, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, estimated today that the carrier's net income will be about $19,000,000 this year, compared with $34,430,000 in 1948 and $7,285,000 in 1947.

Unemployment insurance payments to jobless workers in this state were nearly two and a half times as large this year as last, according to preliminary estimates made public yesterday by the Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance of the State Labor Department.
George H. Lamb, chief of the Abandonment Bureau of the District Attorney's office in Queens County, has returned from California with his yearly catch of errant husbands.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Federal Government will stage, and gladly, a grand exit in a celebration to be held Dec. 31 by the farmers and ranchers of Texas.
From her farm in Newport, R. I., a 90-year-old woman sent her contribution yesterday to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

ALBANY Dec. 28 -- Physicians in the state outside New York City will be required to report cases of cerebral palsy beginning next Sunday under provisions of a law passed by the Legislature last winter, Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Health Commissioner, said today.

The Republics of Colombia and El Salvador announced yesterday that the time for holders of bonds to exchange their holdings for certain other securities, under current external debt readjustment plans, has been extended from Dec. 31, 1949, to Jan. 1, 1951.

The idea of permissiveness -- of letting a child do, within reason, what he pleases -- came up for spirited discussion yesterday at a symposium on "Permissiveness vs. Rigidity in Relation to Child Rearing, Personality and Culture," held at the New Yorker Hotel as part of the current meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
Robert W. Griggs has been appointed director of industrial relations of Standard Brands, Inc. He was formerly manager of the employe relations department.
The American Association for the Advancement of Science presented some of its top awards at its annual meeting at the Statler Hotel yesterday.

The letter of Frank E. Karelsen Jr. in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 22 does no service either to the solution of the problem of minorities or to the promotion of good-will and democracy among our citizens, particularly among the children of our schools.

The trouble with holidays is the lack of an automatic, built-in tidy-upper. Christmas, for example, comes without a self-serviced vacuum cleaner, and New Year's fails to dispose of its own streamers and paper hats.

Net earnings of the Pennsylvania Company for Banking and Trusts in the year ended Nov. 30 were $3,306,117, or $185,386 less than a year earlier, William F. Kurtz, president, disclosed in the Philadelphia bank's annual report mailed to stockholders yesterday.

Charles E. Brickley, Harvard football star who was an All-American choice for halfback from 1912 through 1914, died at 11:30 o'clock last night, apparently of a heart attack, in his room at the George Washington Hotel, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.

Top economists in business, government and the universities and colleges, at annual professional meetings here, were virtually unanimous yesterday in forecasting another year of extraordinarily high business activity for 1950.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- President Truman returned this afternoon from a five-day holiday among his kinfolk and friends in Independence, Mo., and went immediately to his White House desk.

TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 28 -- A new electronic method of measuring the distance of a star that takes only about ten minutes was explained to the American Astronomical Society here today by Dr. Olin J. Eggen of Lick Observatory of the University of California.

BERLIN, Dec. 28 -- Acceleration of a drive to purge the Eastern German Democratic Republic of all "unreliable elements" is indicated in a series of arrests of prominent men, especially of so-called bourgeois parties, during the last few days.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Dec. 28 -- Plans for a 400-acre regional shopping and residential development in the rolling woodland and meadows north of the Hawthorne traffic circle, near Pleasantville, were announced here tonight when the Mount Pleasant Town Board received an application to have part of the property re-zoned for business.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- William T. Faricy, president of the Association of American Railroads, said today next year's outlook was for more freight hauling business and a better chance to show improvements in post-war equipment. His forecast was made in a statement summarizing 1949 as one of outstanding operating performance but disappointing profits.

Attorneys for the eleven convicted Communist party leaders yesterday served on the United States Attorney's office a motion that if sustained by the Court of Appeals would delay hearing on the conviction appeals between six and eight months.

HONG KONG, Dec. 28 -- A Chinese Communist organization in Peiping in a telegram to Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India assailed as "disgraceful" the sentences recently passed on a group of Indians in Hyderabad for anti-Government activity.

Senators and Representatives returning to Washington for the second session of the Eighty-first Congress seem to be agreed (a) that it is unhealthy for the National Government to operate at a deficit, but (b) that it is out of the question to think of raising taxes in an election year.

Carrying a growing burden of installment payments on homes, automobiles and appliances, male wage earners in 1950 may be more than a little inclined to defer apparel purchases for themselves, according to Meyer Blackman, president of Brait's men's wear shops of Philadelphia.

Robert R. Nathan, economist, will serve as commentator for a series of radio programs produced by the Congress of Industrial Organizations over the ABC network each Tuesday evening at 10:45 o'clock, beginning next week. The program is part of a continuing labor-management series on Tuesday evenings for which ABC donates a half-hour time period.

The Gdynia America liners Batory and Sobieski, despite two trips fewer than in 1948, difficulties with Immigration authorities over the escape of Gerhart Eisler, Communist leader, last May and sporadic desertions by seamen, carried a total of 23,713 passengers to British, Baltic and Mediterranean ports in 1949.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- The British Government has sent fresh instructions to Ambassador Sir Oliver Franks in Washington that are expected to lead to the early signing of a bilateral arms treaty. Under the pending accord Britain is to receive American military equipment to help defend the North Atlantic treaty area.

Winston Churchill, statesman, soldier and writer, is described as the "man of the half-century" in a sixteen-page supplement, "The Half-Century," contained in the Jan. 2 issue of Time, the weekly magazine, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Government's chief mediator thinks capital and labor are getting along better all the time. He suggested today, in effect, that people ought to look at something besides strike headlines and strike statistics before judging the progress of industrial relations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- By many previous utterances and positions on foreign policy Senator Wherry of Nebraska, minority floor leader, invites the suspicion that, when he said yesterday he would no longer as a Senator let "bipartisan bigwigs" commit him to policies and programs made without any consultation with him, his real target was not the procedure of policy-making but the policy itself.

Carefully wrapped Christmas presents lay unopened under a gaily trimmed tree yesterday when a father and mother and their two young children were found dead in their three-room apartment at 428 East Seventy-first Street.

ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- Governor Dewey announced this evening the appointment of Charles D. Breitel, his counsel for the last seven years, as a Supreme Court Justice in the First District to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Justice Samuel Null earlier this month.

" The Crucible," the autobiography of Yay Panlilio, a Philippine - American newspaper woman who fled Japanese-held Manila to join the guerrillas, will be published on Jan. 31 by Macmillan. The book recounts her three years in the Luzon hills where, as "Colonel Yay," she worked with "Marking" (Marcos V. Agustin) to harass the Japanese.

Enforcement of laws against monopoly appear to be entering a stage of transition, Dr. Corwin Edwards, director of the Federal Trade Commission's Bureau of Industrial Economics, declared yesterday. He addressed more than fifty participants in the twenty-first annual meeting of the American Business Law Association.

Frank St. Leger and Earle R Lewis, assistant general managers of the Metropolitan Opera, will leave the company at the end of the season, it was learned yesterday. They have been the principal aides to Edward Johnson, general manager, who also is retiring on May 31, 1950.

Summer lines of members of the Fashion Originators Guild of America will be introduced during the week beginning Feb. 13, it was announced yesterday by Leonard Gendler, executive secretary. Pointing out the need for prompt placement of summer commitments by retailers, Mr. Gendler said that Guild companies would have favored bringing out their summer lines earlier if fabric and other considerations would have made it feasible.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- Although the Stock Exchange resumed trading quietly today after the holiday, dealers reported the underlying firmness of last week fully maintained. The only exception to the general dullness was the foreign bond section, where German and Japanese issues continued to advance.

The 13-goal Squadron A Regulars trounced a Long Island trio, 17 to 8, as Paul Miller, its No. 1, equaled a two-year individual mark with 13 goals in the second game of an indoor polo double-header last night at the Squadron A Armory.

Ethel Barrymore has agreed to appear in the latest edition, the third, of the "ANTA Album," the theatre industry's annual benefit for itself, which is to be held at the Ziegfeld Theatre on Sunday evening, Jan. 29.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Unbeaten Holy Cross came from behind in the second half tonight to beat Bowling Green, 71 to 70, for the Crusaders' eighth basketball victory of the season. The loss stopped a Bowling Green winning string at four and was the fourth setback for the Ohioans in twelve starts.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 28 (AP) -Betty Lou Marbury lost her right hand today, but her strong faith did not waver. The 10-year-old girl was described as "stoic and courageous" in the operating room.

Wages and salaries paid to employes in this state on or after Sunday will be subject to the temporary contribution under the Disability Benefits Law, Miss Mary Donlon, chairman of the State Workmen's Compensation Board, pointed out yesterday.

Personal consumption expenditures for all goods and services during 1950 could reach $188 billion, or $10 billion more than in 1949, it was estimated yesterday by Arno H. Johnson, vice president and director of media and research of the J. Walter Thompson Company.

HONG KONG, Dec. 28 -- A Christmas week-end demonstration by workers in Hong Kong street cars, marked by the operation of trolleys without collection of fares, developed into a complete stoppage of street-car services today.

Setbacks were suffered by both defense attorneys at yesterday's session of the Federal Court hearings to determine how much of the Government's espionage case against Judith Coplon and Valentin A. Gubitchev stems from information obtained illegally by wiretapping.

Aided by new high levels for newspapers, advertising this year is expected to equal, or top, the record 1948 total of more than $4,250,000,000, a check of key sources indicated yesterday. Expenditures in newspapers alone will reach an estimated total of $1,697,100,000, a gain of 3.7 per cent over 1948, it was learned.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 21:
The price of milk will go down 1 cent a quart on Sunday to the lowest point in two and a half years, it became certain yesterday.
John Stewart has resigned as president of the Donner Corporation, effective on Saturday. He has been president since the concern was incorporated in 1940.

Within ten years, and possibly sooner, all long-haul passenger travel will be by air, it was predicted last night by Ralph S. Damon, president of Transcontinental and Western Air. He addressed the American Legion Aviators Post at dinner at the Columbia University Club on "Jet Transports and Their Implications."

On the day after Christmas an airplane took off from an Italian field, bound for Pakistan. In the plane were fifty-four men and women of various nationalities, religions and professions. There were Latvians and Hungarians, Mohammedans and Protestants, doctors and at least "one entomologist of international reputation."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- David E. Lilienthal, retiring chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, said today that the "long-term" prospects of reaching an international agreement to control atomic energy were good.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Dec. 28 -- The Syrian political crisis ended today with the assumption of office by a Cabinet under Khaled el-Azem.

New demands for greater rent increases were indicated by landlords' groups yesterday after announcement that a two-year repainting schedule for apartments would be resumed in the metropolitan area as of Jan. 15.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The State Department announced today that the North Atlantic Council would meet for the third time on Jan. 6. The meeting will be held here, under the chairmanship of Dean Acheson, Secretary of State.
ROME, Dec. 28 -- The Pope today expressed the hope that the consolidation of peace, both in social and political fields, would be attained during the Holy Year.
ALBANY, N. Y., Dec. 28 (AP) -- New York State has realized $221,559,775 in taxes from flat and harness racing in the ten years since pari-mutuel betting was inaugurated.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Windsor Farms' Red Dawn marked his Florida campaign with a smashing victory in the featured Orange Bowl Purse at Tropical Park today.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was rather slow yesterday, and final prices were 1 to 6 points net lower.

A device by which it is hoped the totally deaf will be able to "hear" through their fingers was described here yesterday by Prof. Norbert Wiener of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, one of the world's most noted mathematicians.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation said today the wartime arrangement for pooling patents on synthetic rubber production has been ended.
Attorneys for Alger Hiss moved at his Federal perjury trial yesterday to unleash a double attack on the mentality of Whittaker Chambers, the Government's key witness against their client.

Dr. John E. Lovelock, 1936 Olympic track champion from New Zealand and recently a New York specialist in rehabilitation of the physically handicapped, was killed yesterday by a subway train in Brooklyn.

A raging Charlie Norkus from Bayonne, N. J., last night ended the winning streak of Rosario (Sonny) Parisi, promising young Brooklynite, at the St. Nicholas Arena in one of the most exciting heavyweight battles seen here in recent years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Egyptian Embassy denied today that King Farouk had broken up a romance between two of his subjects, but the denial said nothing about whether the youthful monarch was planning to marry the girl in question.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, has directed that all regular officers of the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marine Corps serve at least two years during their career with the National Guard or reserve units, it was announced today.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Harvard trounced Michigan State, 68 -- 57, and Ohio State downed Cornell, 43 -- 42, in a basketball double-header between the Western Conference and Ivy League teams witnessed by a crowd of 2,858 tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The United States Government extended de jure recognition to the Government of the United States of Indonesia today as H. Merle Cochran arrived in Jakarta (Batavia), the capital to present his credentials as first United States Ambassador.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon called on his fellow-Republicans today to defend the bipartisan foreign policy against attacks being made on it by members of the party's Midwestern wing.

Fifty-three Long Island, Pennsylvania and Lehigh Valley Railroad trains, carrying 40,000 commuters into the city, were delayed up to an hour yesterday morning when a rail inspection car broke down in a tunnel under the East River.

ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- Spencer E. Bates, president of the State Tax Commission, declared today that the Tax Department would insist on accuracy and completeness in the filing of tax returns by employers showing employe income for 1949.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Successful trials of antibiotics in canning, as a new method of food preservation, were announced today by the Department of Agriculture.
ALBANY, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The New York State Harness Racing Commission today granted a licence to the Yonkers Trotting Association to hold racing meets at the 45-year-old Empire City Track in Yonkers.

The General Electric Company notified the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers yesterday that it would not permit its contract with the union to renew itself automatically on its termination date, April 1, 1950.

Four new films will open in first-run theatres today. At the Palace, the attraction is "The Reckless Moment." a Columbia presentation starring James Mason and Joan Bennett. Max Opuls directed and Walter Wanger produced the drama from a screen play by Henry Garson and Robert W. Soderberg, an adaptation by Mel Dinelli and Robert E. Kent of "The Blank Wall," the story by Elizabeth Sanxay Holding. Geraldine Brooks, Henry, O Neill and Shepperd Strudwick.
The southern fishing seems to be reaching an early peak this season, for reports are coming in on the abundance of sailfish, snook and bonefish being taken at several Florida fishing resorts.

ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- The Public Service Commission extended for three months today the interim fares of eleven privately operated bus companies in New York City and one trolley company. The interim fares would have expired at midnight Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Eric H. Biddle of Philadelphia, was named today as consultant on civil defense planning for the National Security Resources Board.

WINSTON CHURCHILL'S celebrated remark about Russia -- "a riddle wrapped in a mystery inside an enigma" -- was as true 400 very odd years ago as it is today. That, at any rate, is an impression one gets from reading Hans von Eckardt's "Ivan the Terrible,"* translated by Catherine Alison Phillips, a murky portrait of a murky tyrant who was a contemporary of England's Great Elizabeth and Philip II of Spain.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Dec. 28 (AP) -- A 5 1/2-pound princess was born today to screen star Rita Hayworth and her husband of seven months, the Moslem Prince Aly Khan. Happily, Aly announced: "Yes, everybody is all right."

A runaway market for railroad issues dominated trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange and was primarily instrumental in raising the average of prices to the best in three years. While the gains in other principal divisions generally could be measured in fractions, the carriers spurted as much as 4 points, with the composite rate up 1.21 points.

Although "She Stoops to Conquer" is close to two centuries old, it still retains the warmth and good humor that made Oliver Goldsmith's friends love him. Those are endearing qualities of character in acting as well as playwriting, and they have been preserved in the performance put on at the City Center last evening.

With twenty-five seconds of the contest remaining, David Harrop of Deerfield Academy fired a long-range shot into the net and enabled his sextet to defeat the St. Mark's School, 4 -- 3, in their charity hockey game before 3,000 persons at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 28 (UP) -- George H. Love, spokesman for Northern and Western coal operators, declared tonight that John L. Lewis' attempts to get the mine owners to sign a "blank check" contract had caused a national coal crisis.

ATHENS, Dec. 28 -- Over the Athens radio tonight Queen Frederika of the Hellenes delivered an impassioned appeal for the return of 28,000 Greek children kidnapped by Communist-led guerrillas and still held behind the Iron Curtain in persistent defiance of the United Nations and Red Cross organizations' injunctions to repatriate them.

With business better in 1949 than many had anticipated, most New York business executives are optimistic about 1950, according to a survey of 336 companies by the Commerce and Industry. Association of New York, Inc., released yesterday.

LOS ALAMOS, N. M., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Efforts to get more water for the Atomic Energy Commission's Los Alamos community collided today with Indian rights dating back before Coronado. The project manager, Carrol L. Tyler, said growth of the Los Alamos research community made development of new water necessary by the summer of 1951.

Merger of the 240-bed Lebanon Hospital and the 320-bed Bronx Hospital was announced yesterday. The unification is the first step in a $5,000,000 development and expansion program "to provide the growing Bronx community with a far - reaching and comprehensive medical center for care, training and research," directors of the two hospitals said.

Skeptics who question the advisability of not rinsing the family wash, a water-conservation system now endorsed by at least two manufacturers of synthetic detergents, may have a chance next week to witness an actual demonstration.

Our society will be "within a very few generations as tolerant of premarital but postpubertal sexual relations as are the majority of the other peoples of the world," it was predicted yesterday by Dr. George Peter Murdock, Professor of Anthropology at Yale University.
The Liberal party, through its legislative committee, of which Leo J. Rosett is chairman, called yesterday for a $600,000,000 state bond issue for school construction.

Revival of foreign investment, private and public, through President Truman's Point Four Program should help to maintain high employment and production here while reducing the need for United States subsidies abroad, Dr. Walter S. Salant, Government economist, declared yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 28 -- Man has flown within a whisper of 2,000 miles an hour, according to The Los Angeles Times, which says it has learned from reliable informants that the X-1 rocket plane has reached a speed of 1,989 miles an hour high in the stratosphere above Edwards Air Force base at Muroc Dry Lake.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- The Cunard White Star Company announced tonight that it was not contemplating the placing of any orders for new tonnage at present. The company described as "misleading" a report that it was planning to build a 83,000-ton superliner for the North Atlantic run.

Rubber futures edged a little higher in moderate trading on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. December, 1949, delivery went off the board at noon, with the final price 18.10 cents a pound. Buying broadened somewhat in March, the new spot delivery, and the closing price of 18.2 cents recorded an advance of 15 points from Tuesday's levels.

Present prospects indicate "a high rate of steel production for some time to come," but the capacity of the steel industry should be adequate to meet all demands, Irving S. Olds, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, declared in a year-end statement issued yesterday.

DETROIT, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins, who had been beaten six straight times by the Detroit Red Wings, came from behind tonight to tie the National Hockey League leaders, 2 -- 2, before 13,445 fans at the Olympia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Individuals in the United States saved $1,700,000,000 in liquid form in the third quarter of 1949, the highest level of liquid savings since the third quarter of 1948 and $800,000,000 above the second quarter of this year, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

MILFORD, Mich., Dec. 28 -- Automatic transmissions are being offered for the first time by Chevrolet as optional equipment on its 1950 deluxe models, W. E. Fish, general sales manager announced today at the General Motors Proving Ground here. New models are to go on sale Jan. 7.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 28 -- The Yugoslav Parliament adjourned tonight after adopting unanimously the 1950 budget estimates of 173,746,000,000 dinars (about $3,475,000,000), an increase of 7.3 per cent over 1949.

The day of the bully and the rabble-rouser in the trade union movement is a thing of the past, in the opinion of Daniel J. Tobin, 73-year-old president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, largest union in the American Federation of Labor.

MILAN, Italy, Dec. 28 (UP) -- The world-famous La Scala Opera House faced another crisis today as angry Italian music fans and critics took turns in panning its season-opening production of Puccini's "La Boheme."

Railroad financing promises to play a prominent part in the market for new capital in January. Five equipment trust issues have been scheduled for sale thus far for a total of $39,465,000, which compares with nine issues totaling $36,495,000 marketed in January of 1949.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 28 -- Winning in 50 moves from Fred Turim of Brooklyn College, with whom he was tied, Eliot Hearst, Columbia varsity captain, assumed undisputed lead among forty competitors in the fourth round for the individual championship of the National Intercollegiate Chess League at Rutgers University today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UP) -- Seven New Jersey Democratic leaders made a bid at national party headquarters today to wrest patronage control from Frank Hague, Jersey City Democratic leader.

An idea abandoned as useless a half century ago was revived at the meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science yesterday with full agreement that it is at least a startling development in the scientific battle against cancer.

JAKARTA (Batavia), Java, Dec. 28 (AP) -- President Sukarno, welcomed by tumultous crowds that twice broke through police lines, returned to this capital of the new United States of Indonesia for a victory ride today and told citizens of the day-old republic the time had come for work and reconstruction.

Hallicrafters, Inc., introduced yesterday its 1950 television receiver line featuring the new black rectangular picture tube in all six 16-inch sets at a dealer meeting in the St. Moritz Hotel. The company claims it is the first manufacturer to market sets using the new tube.

Harry Sneden has been a telegrapher for sixty of his seventy-six years and has been a commuter all that time. But tomorrow afternoon, the train he usually catches hometo Hillsdale, N. J., wil take him into retirement.

This being the time of season when good will prevails on all fronts, it remained for the Yankees and Giants yesterday to put on a reciprocal act as they completed arrangements for the exchange of training camp sites. It's for one year only, but at least it shows on what an amicable plane our New York clubs move.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Reporting to the White House on his recent 15,000-mile tour of the United States to survey business conditions, Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, said today that the economic prospects for the immediate future were "good."

ROME, Dec. 28 -- Officials of the Italian Foreign Ministry read with great interest today references to Trieste made by Yugoslav Foreign Minister Edvard Kardelj to the Parliament in Belgrade yesterday. Dr. Kardelj said the Trieste problem could not be solved except in agreement with Yugoslavia.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 28 -- The Little Assembly of the United Nations will hold its first 1950 meeting on Jan. 16 to elect new officers and take up an agenda that includes Nationalist China's charges that the Soviet Union is violating the charter by aiding the Chinese Communists.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The United States Fidelity and Guaranty Company, Baltimore, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 300,000 shares of $10 par value capital stock.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The apartment-house troubles of Rear Admiral Joseph J. Clark were back in the news again today in connection with a $500,000 assault and battery suit brought against the admiral and his wife by Miss Selma Sinclair.

As Congress begins to reassemble in Washington it is becoming evident that to a larger degree even than in the past the principal issue before it will again be the foreign policy of the United States. This would be inevitable in any case, as a result of the upheavals of two world wars and the emergence of the United States as one of the world's strongest Powers.

Further gains in the reservoir supply led city officials to forecast yesterday that new restrictions in the use of water could be avoided. The prediction assumed that the present average daily consumption of 887,000,000 gallons would continue.

A five-member arbitration board completed yesterday hearings into a hiring dispute between the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, and a group of Atlantic and Gulf Coast ship operators. When the board would announce its decision was not reported.

As far back as Dec. 15 Joseph E. Moody, head of the Southern Coal Producers Association, addressed a plea to President Truman to take action in the "slow-down strike" which John L. Lewis has been conducting against that industry, except for one brief interval, for almost six months.

CORDOBA, Argentina, Dec. 28 (UP) -- iV[unicipal authorities today ordered the Catholic independent newspaper The Principios closed indefinitely. The order was issued two hours after a visit by public health inspectors who reported there were deficiencies in the building's sanitary system, the staff lacked Health Department cards and the painting was in bad condition. Only the business office remained open to permit another inspection by the Joint Congressional Committee Investigating AntiArgentine Activities.
The City Council, at its last meeting of the year, urged city and state officials yesterday to reconsider the cuts in relief allowances scheduled to go into effect here on Jan. 16.

MADRID, Dec. 28 -- Spain's trade mission to Argentina returned here today by air and the general belief in informed circles was that it had come back empty handed, thus presenting Spain with the prospect of a serious food crisis in the spring.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- New trends in theatre education were topics of discussion today at the opening session of the twenty-fourth annual convention of the American Educational Theatre Association, whose delegates represent teachers of theatre in high schools, colleges and universities in twenty-three states and the District of Columbia.

ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- The New York State Conference Board of Farm Organizations, representing eight major farm groups, urged the Legislature today to authorize a thorough study to determine how savings can be made in relief costs.

The city cannot have a balanced expense budget for 1950-51 if it grants general pay rises to its 157,000 civil service employes for the fiscal year starting July 1. Such was the clear implication of a letter sent by Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson to the heads of city departments and agencies and made public yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 28 -- One important strategic and economic consequence of the Communist conquest of China may well be to alleviate a shortage of tin in the Soviet Union. The southern Chinese tin mines should be of immense importance to the U.S.S.R. and probably will permit the stockpiling of that key metal for the first time since World War II.

Holding their heavy artillery until the closing minutes the New York Rangers defeated the Chicago Black Hawks in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The Windy City skaters had the edge over the local sextet by a goal with less than five minutes left, and all signs pointed to an upset triumph for the visitors.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Dec. 28 -- Joseph A. Suozzi, 28-year-old Italian-born lawyer, reputed to be the youngest man in the state to become a city judge, was sworn into office this morning by Supreme Court Justice Percy Stoddart in his chambers in the new court house at Mineola.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Southern coal operators took their contract fight with John L. Lewis before the National Labor Relations Board today. They urged the board to seek a court injunction to end the short work week in the mines.
Attention focused on the college girl, at home for the holidays, and the career girl at Saks Thirty-fourth Street yesterday afternoon.
JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Dec. 28 -A rare "first" edition of Handel's "Messiah" has been discovered at the Cambria Free Library here, Chief Librarian George V. Moreland disclosed tonight.

PARIS, Dec. 28 -- United States officials here expressed optimism today regarding their negotiations with European experts over the "clearing union" proposed by the Economic Cooperation Administration. American experts predicted that realization of the union would be a long step toward the full convertibility of currencies, which has been unattainable since the pound sterling went off the gold standard in 1931.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- During 1948 freight traffic on the 630-mile navigation channel of the Tennessee Valley Authority increased 21 per cent over the previous year, the agency told President Truman and Congress in its sixteenth annual report today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Naval Observatory, trying to keep the time accurate, is now conducting a survey designed to improve the usefulness of the moon as a means of determining and checking time independently of the rotation of the earth, the method of time measurement now used.

The shrinkage of the British Empire and the expansion of the Commonwealth are underlined by the departure of Foreign Secretary Bevin for the Commonwealth Conference in Ceylon. The Dominions are not only increased in number by the new status of India, Pakistan and Ceylon itself.

The young American violinist, Melvin Ritter, made his second Town Hall appearance yesterday evening, playing two relatively unfamiliar concertos by Haydn and Szymanowski, the Bach E major violin and clavier sonata, and a number of smaller pieces including first New York performances of works by William Kroll and Jack Schapiro.

Two civil anti-trust suits charging four corporations and eight persons with unlawful conspiracy to restrain trade in elastic top hosiery and to monopolize trade in machinery to produce this type of hosiery were filed in Federal court here yesterday.

Marilyn Meyer, Milwaukee pianist who gave three Town Hall recitals while she was in her teens, returned last night after an absence of nearly six years to give her first recital at Carnegie Hall. The event attracted an audience of 1,600.
HONG KONG, Dec. 28 -- Nationalist planes on Hainan Island made smashing raids today on boats being assembled by the Communists for the invasion of the island, Chinese press reports here maintained.
The country needs 10,000,000 amateur scientists, Dr. Edmund W. Sinnott, retiring president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, declared last night.

Dr John R. Dunning, scientific director of Columbia University, scored yesterday fear campaigns that overemphasize the dangers of radioactivity in connection with the use of atomic energy. This, he warned, was making Americans "ripe for overhysteria" in the event of war.

After four complete rounds of the tournament for the women's chess championship of the world at Moscow, Mrs. Gisela K. Gresser of New York was tied for first place with Olga Rubsova, U.S.S.R., according to a report received from London yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- Rafael Kubelik, 35-year-old Czech conductor, will become musical director of the Chicago Symphony next fall, it was announced today by Edward L. Ryerson, president of the orchestral association. At the same time Mr. Ryerson announced the resignation of Tauno Hannikainen as assistant conductor.

TORONTO, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs and Montreal Canadiens battled to a 1-1 National Hockey League tie before 14,252 fans tonight. The Leafs had to come from behind, scoring with less than four minutes of the play in the game.

John Dennison of Jackson Heights forged a lap ahead of the field yesterday in the Eastern junior indoor tennis championships. The husky New York University freshman, second-seeded entrant, gained the singles quarter-final round by defeating Paul Waldman of Brooklyn, a Columbia student, at the Third Engineer Group Armory.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 28 -- Finance authorities of the British High Commissioner's office are pressing for reorganization of the decentralized German banking system, which would re-create in another form big banks of the former German Reich, it was reliably reported here today.

PARIS, Dec. 28 -- Saly Mayer, an elderly Swiss business man who bluffed the Nazis into saving the lives of an estimated 230,000 Jews during the war, retired today as director of the American Joint Distribution Committee's activities in Switzerland, the committee's headquarters announced here.

Charles Pearson 2d, No. 2 on the seeded list, fell by the wayside as play in the annual University Club invitation intercollegiate squash racquets tournament reached the semi-final round on the club's courts yesterday.

Your editorial of Dec. 23 on the "Sugar Cartel" omits mention, except by implication, of the stultifying effect of the cartel on scientific and engineering progress in the sugar industry. The sugar producer is not greatly interested in lowering costs so long as he is assured on a percentage basis of a share of the sugar market at a fancy price.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- Short covering brought about a strong rally on the Board of Trade today after an early break under liquidation had carried soybeans off 3 1/4 cents a bushel. Wheat closed 1/4 cent higher to 3/4 cent lower, new-crop months showing the weakness.

The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit has reversed a district court decision in a major maritime legal action that will have a bearing on pending litigation involving numerous cases and many millions of dollars, it became known yesterday.
IOWA CITY, Iowa, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Wisconsin rolled through the Rutgers five by 68 -- 55 tonight before 10,986 fans in the University of Iowa fieldhouse.

An investigation into alleged discrimination by certain private, fee-charging employment agencies here was opened yesterday by the State Commission Against Discrimination in its offices at 270 Broadway.
MANILA, Thursday, Dec. 29 -- A sharp earthquake rocked Manila today, damaging at least three downtown buildings. There were no immediate reports of any casualties.

Dr. Mal Stevens, former Yale and New York University football coach who at present is connected with the Jersey City Medical Center, and Dr. Howard A. Rusk, professor and chairman of the N. Y. U. College of Medicine's Department of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation, were among the speakers at yesterday's session of the national convention of athletic trainers at the Hotel Piccadilly.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Living costs for families of moderate income edged upward 0.1 per cent, on the average, between mid-October and mid-November.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- A 25 per cent reduction in passenger service on coal-burning railroads is being considered by the Interstate Commerce Commission, it was reported tonight.

Willys-Overland Motors, Inc. and its subsidiaries, in the annual report for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, last, issued yesterday by Ward M. Canaday, chairman of the board, puts the net income at $3,423,711 after taxes and all charges.

If the people of the Anglo-Saxon world are astonished at the survival of nationalism in Germany, the reason can only be that most of the men who were in charge of formulating policies and of exercising control of Germany did not possess intimate knowledge of the German mentality.

If some of last night's hockey fans at Madison Square Garden thought they heard an unfamiliar chorus of cackling and crowing rising from beneath the ice, they were probably right. For in the basement exhibition hall was stationed a different breed of sportsmen -- the poultry fanciers -- and 5,000 squawking candidates for their All-American team.

VIENNA, Dec. 28 -- Israel Jacobson, head of the American Joint Distribution Committee's Hungarian office, who was arrested Dec. 15 on a charge of espionage and released and expelled yesterday afternoon in Budapest, told reporters on his arrival in Vienna today that he had been subjected to hardship but no physical cruelty by Hungarian political police.
The politico-military problem of German rearmament is fast becoming, as the year 1949 draws to an end, one of the "hottest" issues in a world-wide catalogue of hot issues.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 28 -- The United Nations Security Council will be asked to continue sponsorship of the intricate talks between India and Pakistan over the future of the princely state of Kashmir, it was reliably reported today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- A Reconstruction Finance Corporation official said today RFC lending to the Lustron Corporation of Ohio had been halted.

PARIS, Dec. 28 -- The French National Assembly will be asked to vote Friday morning on two proposals for new taxes in the 1950 budget, on whose acceptance Premier Georges Bidault today staked the existence of his Government.

Close ties linking strategically important Iran to this country have unquestionably been greatly strengthened of late, it was affirmed here yesterday by the 30-year-old Shah of Iran at a press conference on the eve of his departure for home by air this morning. The ruler of the ancient Eastern kingdom has been touring the United States officially and informally for six weeks.

Tests at the University of California Medical School have shown that chemical components of ACTH, the wonder hormone from the pituitary gland, possess the same power as the ACTH itself to relieve the crippling effects of rheumatoid arthritis.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Air Force said tonight that "recent reports of specific speeds" attained by the rocket plane X-1 were incorrect. According to the aviation editor of The Los Angeles Times, Marvin Miles, the plane had flown 1,989 miles an hour, three times the speed of sound.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The United States is considering the possibility of ruling Poland and Czechoslovakia out of bounds for American travelers, it was indicated today.

A $50 contribution sent from Brazil for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund arrived yesterday to help the fund's thirty-eighth annual Christmas appeal. The gift had been sent by a reader of THE TIMES from Sao Paulo on Dec. 21.

Charles D. Breitel has been in the public service for most of the last fifteen years and counsel to the Governor of New York since January, 1943. He now leaves that post, as Mr. Dewey appoints him to a Supreme Court vacancy, and we should like to say a word of appreciation for the contribution he has made to good state government.

"Frictional" unemployment, the kind that marked the post-war period, is likely to persist and may even increase if a full employment economy is maintained in the next decade, Ewan Clague, Commissioner of Labor Statistics, warned last night.

The $1,000 Red Badge Mystery Prize has been awarded by Dodd, Mead to Brandon Bird for a novel entitled "Death in Four Colors." The setting of the novel is one of the large slick paper magazines in New York. Brandon Bird is the pseudonym for a well-known color artist.

Free and open markets in the sale of electrical equipment may again be available to electrical manufacturers, distributors and architects and engineers, as a result of a recent change in union labor requirements for the use of labels, according to a statement by the National Electrical Manufacturers' Association received here yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Gardnar Mulloy advanced to the finals of the Sugar Bowl tennis tournament today. His opponent for the championship tomorrow will be fourth-seeded Herbert Flam of Los Angeles. Flam upset second-seeded Arthur Larsen of San Francisco, 6 -- 4, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 3 to gain the final.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Stuart Peabody, assistant vice president of the Borden Company in charge of advertising and public relations, was named today chairman of the advertising advisory committee of the Commerce Department.

From a practical as well as a traditional point of view, smoked ham is the logical selection for New Year's dinner. The City Department of Markets found in its weekly survey of food prices that stores generally were charging a moderate 53 cents a pound for it.

A radical new concept of dealing with traffic congestion in central Manhattan through the construction of an elevated crosstown toll highway has been placed before Mayor O'Dwyer, it was learned yesterday.

James Lees and Sons Company yesterday introduced what it claims is the first promotional device to effectively present simultaneously carpets of different colors, grades and price ranges for use in more than one room. The device, a point-of-purchase display arrangement, was shown at a press preview of the company's 1950 rug and carpet line in its New York offices and showrooms, 295 Fifth Avenue.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- In his annual message to the Legislature next week, Governor Dewey will propose that the Federal Government surrender its gasoline and amusement taxes, which produce $1,000,000,000 a year in revenue, to the states and that it reduce Federal grants to the states correspondingly.

Recovering most of the decline registered last week, business loans made by banks in this area rose $38,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday. According to the data covering the reporting New York City member banks, issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, expanded borrowings by oil companies, sales finance concerns and public utilities largely accounted for the increase, offsetting reductions by retail trade organizations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board reported tonight industrial production rose nearly 3 per cent in November and shows signs of making almost as great a gain this month.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- The Court of Appeals ruled unanimously today that the Sharkey eviction control law, enacted by the City Council in New York last Oct. 7, was inconsistent with the state's Civil Practice Act governing evictions and therefore was in violation of the home-rule amendment of the State Constitution.
The air of ridicule, gentle though it may have been, which tinged your editorial of Dec. 22, entitled "Grand Central Asylum," hardly becomes a great newspaper.

A 90-year-old British woman living in seclusion in the outskirts of Edinburgh, Scotland, has defied the British Government's claim for her dollar assets in this country, valued at more than $500,000, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Truman Administration offered a friendly hand to business today in a report of its Council of Economic Advisers which strongly urged the desirability of an ever-expanding, free, American economy in a divided world.

PARIS, Dec. 30 -- In connection with a growing campaign to bar manufacture and sale of Coca-Cola in France, United States Ambassador David K. E. Bruce has told Premier Georges Bidault that the United States Government would resist arbitrary discrimination against any American product, it was learned here today.

Three new films, two from Hollywood and one importation from Italy, will open in local theatres today. At the Strand is "The Inspector General," a Warner Brothers comedy with music, starring Danny Kaye. Henry Koster directed and Jerry Wald produced the offering, which was filmed in Technicolor.

Happy New Year may be a misnomer for night clubs here on New Year's Eve, a survey indicated yesterday. The tin horns and rattles will be on hand. But according to Broadway prophets the "tin horn sports" of yesteryears will be missing and there will be more noisemakers on tables than noise.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Obvious concern over the ill effects on foreign opinion of reports that King Farouk of Egypt would take as his wife the fiancee of another young man was shown today in efforts of the Egyptian Foreign Ministry and diplomatic missions to discredit the reports.
OTTAWA, Dec. 29 -- Tinofev Remizov, staff member of Tass, official Soviet news agency, tried to take his seat in the Ottawa Parliamentary press gallery today without having conformed to regulations.

Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey called yesterday for the redevelopment of "a working federalism" and a return to greater home rule in the states by reversing "the trend toward centralization" in the National Government.

Mrs. Ralph Pulitzer of 120 East End Avenue gave a supper dance last night in the St. Regis Roof to introduce to society her daughter, Miss Susan Pulitzer. The debutante, who received with her mother, wore a gown of white tulle, made with a fitted bodice and a bouffant skirt appliqued with silver leaves, and carried an old-fashioned bouquet of white camellias.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 29 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, expressed the hope today that the great powers, with the help of the smaller nations, would make 1950 "a true turning point on the difficult road to a secure peace."
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 29 -- Another independent newspaper is threatened with closing tomorrow through the activities of the Peron regime.

Organized labor's power bloc, called the most dominant one in the United States economy, is threatening the freedom of both the unions and private businesses, a joint session of four social science professional societies was told last night at the Commodore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Representative Robert L. Doughton, Democrat, of North Carolina, said today that Congress might be able to reduce excise taxes next session without increasing other tax rates to offset the resulting revenue losses.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- The Public Service Commission said today that it would allow the Staten Island Edison Corporation an annual increase in rates of $300,000 if the company would discontinue rate litigation going back several years.

Rabbi Abba Hillel Silver, Zionist leader, received the Benjamin N. Cardozo Award of Tau Epsilon Rho Fraternity at the thirtieth annual convention dinner of that national legal society at the Plaza Hotel last night.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Musa el-Alami, former member of the Palestine Arab Higher Committee, disclosed today that he had not been entirely successful in obtaining foreign currency to buy machinery for the construction of modern villages for refugees in Arab Palestine.
Transportation officials prepared yesterday for heavy passenger traffic during the three-day holiday week-end as crisp northwest winds brought fair and typical winter weather to the New York area.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that department stores sales in the week ended Dee. 24 were 14 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. This upsurge brought sales in the four weeks ended on the same date to equality with last year.

New York City's machinery to enforce the Sharkey Rent Control Law, held unconstitutional by the Court of Appeals, will be retained in the belief that the Legislature will validate it early in its session opening on Wednesday, it became known yesterday.

Dimitri Mitropoulos, who has shared the post of permanent conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra with Leopold Stokowski this season, will have the job all to himself next season, it was decided yesterday at a meeting of the board of directors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it would approve a plan of liquidation of the United Light and Railways Company and its subsidiary, the Continental Gas and Electric Corporation, both of Chicago, provided the plan was amended in certain respects.

After thirty-two years of air service, including participation in the tests made to support the late Gen. William Mitchell's views on the effectiveness of the air arm, Brig. Gen. Clifford C. Nutt, vice commander of the First Air Force, is to retire tomorrow, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- President Truman confided today that he had a "dream" project -- a vast system of ferries linking the United States mainland to the exotic islands of the Caribbean Sea.

Modernization of the port of San Pedro de Macoris, major sugar outlet of the Dominican Republic, has been virtually completed at a cost of $4,500,000, it was announced yesterday by the Dominican Republic Information Center, 6 West Fifty-first Street.

Bids submitted by ten companies for the installation, maintenance and operation of automatic drink-vending machines in the city transit system were opened yesterday at the offices of the Board of Transportation, 250 Hudson Street.

Teachers of mathematics must abandon "textbook instruction" and must strive to make their subject matter more appealing and realistic, 200 instructors decided here yesterday at the annual Eastern Section meeting of the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 29 -- Disagreement among Bible scholars on the age of Old Testament manuscripts found in 1947 in the Dead Sea area arose anew here today at a meeting of the Society of Biblical Literature and Exegesis. The meeting is being held at Hebrew Union College.

The New Jersey Turnpike Authority has worked out a plan with life insurance company investment managers for financing the state's projected $230,000,000 toll turnpike on a borrow-as-you-build plan. The deal is still in the discussion stage, with definite commitments not yet made, but the parties to the transaction expect to bring it to a close within the next sixty days.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Japan spent 10,000,000 yen a year on the top secret germ war Unit 731 of the Kwantung army, a witness testified at the Khabarovsk war crimes tribunal, the Moscow radio said today.

Sales of cooperative apartments were reported by Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers, as follows: in 10 Mitchell Place to Miss Betty Hitchcock; in 120 East Seventy-fifth Street to Mrs. Henry H. Williams and Miss Beatrice Kendall, and in 132 East Seventy-ninth Street to J. Joseph Lienhard Jr.

Shipments of structural steel in 1950 "should equal those of 1949 and perhaps exceed them by 5 to 10 per cent," N. R. Patterson, president of the American Institute of Steel Construction, declared in a year-end statement issued yesterday.

Time is running short for procrastinating theatregoers to purchase New Year's Eve tickets. For their convenience, all the box offices of the current Broadway shows, numbering twenty-six, were canvassed yesterday afternoon to ascertain what was still left for tomorrow's festive occasion, an event commemorated by a wholesale tilt in prices generally.

TOKYO, Dec. 29 -- Plans by Japanese officialdom and industry to reconstitute pre-war arrangements for cartels and business control associations have received a sharp setback. Edward C. Welsh, chief of the Occupation's Fair Trade Practices Division, revealed today that the Cabinet had been persuaded to order the elimination of 170 of 352 "advisory councils" established earlier in the year.

In a major move aimed at breaking down racial and religious discrimination in Greek-letter fraternities, Phi Sigma Delta, a national Jewish social fraternity with nearly 6,000 members and twenty-four college chapters, paved the way yesterday for the admission of Negro members.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Representative Charles A. Eaton, Republican, of New Jersey, announced today that he would seek a fourteenth term in Congress next year in the hope of helping to solve some of the difficult international problems expected to arise.
In the closing days of December, 1849, the New York City newspapers agreed that the year had been perhaps the most prosperous in America's history. Cotton, they reported, was up a few more cents.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- The Court of Appeals, in a unanimous decision, today nullified a decision of Lazarus Joseph, New York City Controller, fixing the prevailing rate of wage for building maintenance employes. The ruling orders the controller to make a new determination, taking into consideration additional factors.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission took a look at coal stocks today and found no need for cutting coal-burning passenger train service now.

A short-term low-cost method of helping problem children by conducting group therapy with their parents was described yesterday by Dr. Margaret C. L. Gildea of the Washington University School of Medicine, St. Louis. Dr. Gildea spoke at a meeting arranged by the National Committee for Parent Education as part of the annual conference of the National Council on Family Relations at the Park Sheraton Hotel.
BERLIN, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Communists took off the velvet gloves of collaboration with minor political parties in East Germany today and laid down a decree to "obey or disappear."
DENVER, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Columbia Lions, leading all the way, racked up a 63-59 basketball victory tonight over Denver.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The stock markets lost their firm undertone today when a little scattered selling caused fairly general weakness.

TURIN, N. Y., Dec. 29 -- The hospitable natives of this area at the edge of the Tug Hill Plateau and Black River Valley in northern New York are keeping fingers crossed in the hope that the forecast for snows tomorrow will materialize.

The outlook for the ship construction and vessel repair industry is not good and the work in sight will not be sufficient to keep plants operating to the extent necessary for national emergency, H. Gerrish Smith, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America, said yesterday.

A sharp upturn in credit extensions was reported here yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. The increase, which was estimated roughly between 5 and 10 per cent, was said to be caused largely by anticipation of the $2,800,000,000 veteran's insurance premium refund, scheduled to be paid next month.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- During the week ended Dec. 28, member bank reserve balances decreased $38,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

A program of three ten-round bouts will be presented at Madison Square-Garden tonight, with a pair of light-heavyweights, Dick Wagner of Toppenish, Wash., and Nick Barone of Syracuse, occupying the nominal feature spot. No very good reason has been offered by the International Boxing Club as to why this clash has been put on top, since it will be eclipsed in local interest by each of the other two battles.

A $1,000 fine and a six-month suspended sentence in the workhouse was imposed yesterday on a 55-year-old manager of a Manhattan apartment house who had admitted he had granted leases only on the condition he received a television set, motion-picture camera and liquor in return.

PARIS, Dec. 29 -- Premier Georges Bidault's chances of continued tenure still appeared uncertain late tonight on the eve of a National Assembly ballot for a vote of confidence tomorrow on two measures to raise budget funds by tax increases. With the probabilities slightly in his favor, estimates agreed that victory might depend on three to six now uncertain votes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- President Truman approved today a list of twenty-three naval officers for promotion to the rank of rear admirals of the line, as vacancies occur, and the list included the name of Capt. Arleigh A. Burke. There had been reports that Captain Burke's name had been stricken from the list because of his activities in support of the Navy's "revolt" last autumn before the House Armed Services Committee.

A wholesale price increase of between forty and fifty cents a case, depending on the size of the bottles, will be made on two popular brands of whisky Feb. 1 by the National Distilling Corporation. Retail prices will not be affected.
The cotton market on the New York Cotton Exchange firmed yesterday and prices rose 5 to 17 points net on the day.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- The Court of Appeals, in a five-to-two decision reversing the lower courts, held today that the Public Service Commission acted within its statutory powers in ordering a temporary 10 per cent reduction last January in the electric service charges of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Nineteen-forty-nine was the year John L. Lewis did not do it again.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 29 -- The Swedish Government has instructed its mission in Budapest to protest against socialization of Swedish enterprises in Hungary, the Foreign Office said tonight.

COLUMBUS, O., Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Lustron Corporation will seek a new loan on Jan. 4. The request, said President Carl G. Strandlund, will be sought on the basis of a stepped-up production program and a reorganization plan designed to pull the giant corporation out of the red. He said the new program would begin March 1.

ATHENS, Dec. 29 -- As Greece observed a day of mourning for those of her children now behind the Iron Curtain, Foreign Minister Constantin Tsaldaris warned today that communism intended to use these children in further attack against this country.

Making his debut in European chess circles, Larry Evans, 17- year-old player from the High School of Commerce, was the only winner yesterday in the opening round of the international masters tournament at Hastings, according to a report from England. His opponent was W. A. Winser, champion of the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club and also holder of the county title.

The Chemical Bank Trust Company has been appointed trustee, paying agent and registrar for $10,000,000 of New York State Electric Gas Corporation's first mortgage bonds, 2.80 per cent series due in 1979.
The spacious old rooms of Gracie Mansion were filled with flowers yesterday to greet the new Mrs. O'Dwyer.

Robert E. Kintner, executive vice president of the American Broadcasting Company, was elected yesterday president to succeed Mark Woods, who becomes vice chiarman of the company, according to the announcement of Edward J. Noble, board chairman.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 29 -- Greater responsibility for the West German Legislature and more frankness by the Bonn Government about its internal and external problems are recommended by both Americans and Germans here as weapons against the political apathy of the great mass of citizens of the German Federal Republic.

A huge scientific circus featuring animals ranging in size from the virus to the ocean-borne whale was held yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science in the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The United States warned Hungary today of almost certain retaliation unless the Communist - controlled Government takes steps to free Mr. Vogeler, an American citizen imprisoned in Budapest for nearly six weeks.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 29 -- The Peron regime's tax evasion case against the estate of multimillionaire Otto Sebastian Bemberg resulted Today in an all-time record fine for Argentine courts -- 97,257,254 pesos [more than $10,000,000].

Eight large projects, four entirely or nearly finished and four in various stages of completion, were cited yesterday by Manhattan Borough President Hugo E. Rogers in a report to Mayor O'Dwyer as outstanding accomplishments of Mr. Rogers' four-year stewardship.
LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 29 -- The United Nations Security Council held its last meeting of the year today and left the long controversy over the princely state of Kashmir open on the books.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- Prices of grains fluctuated in a nervous manner on the Board of Trade today, rallying after an early dip. Oats led the advance, rising 3/4 to 1 1/2 cents a bushel on reports that Holland was in the market for supplies, and there was some buying attributed to cash interests.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has advised the Lustron Corporation, of Columbus, Ohio, to get some substantial private capital into its prefabricated steel housing business and to stop asking the Government for financial aid.

TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 29 -- A meteor crater in Arizona, nearly a mile across and hundreds of feet deep, was caused by the impact of a giant meteorite thousands of years ago. Dr. H. H. Nininger, director of the American Meteorite Museum, believes that the cosmic missile burst into fragments that were strewn for miles over the landscape and then exploded after burying itself deeply in the earth's surface.

There are few unsold issues of corporate securities around Wall Street as the year approaches its end. Most of the year-end inventory consists of the float of newly issued railroad equipment-trust certificates. This now totals about $25,000,000, about half of the year's peak amount.
HEMLOCK, N. Y., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Four seminarians were drowned today as an outing ended in tragedy at Hemlock Lake.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Senator Tom Connally, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, appealed to all Congressional factions today to draw together in support of a continued bipartisan foreign policy.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- The French Government has invited Britain and other powers that administer colonial territories in Africa to send representatives to a conference in Paris in the middle of January to discuss questions of technical cooperation.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- A Widespread unofficial strike in the London docks was narrowly averted late tonight when the delegates of the tally clerks voted by a four vote margin to yield to the National Dock Labor Board and admit seventy recruits to their ranks.
MANILA, Friday, Dec. 30 -- President Elpidio Quirino embarked on a four-year term in office today, sharing inaugural ceremonies with Vice President Fernando Lopez.
ALBANY, Dec. 29 (AP) -- A program of special care for premature infants to increase their chances of survival will be started Jan. 1 by the State Health Department.

The American Chemical Society announced yesterday that Dr. W. Albert Noyes Jr., Professor of Physical Chemistry at the University of Rochester, would become editor of the Journal of the American Chemical Society next week.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29 -- The United States Government accused two women today of threatening to "frame" a major witness in the Harry Bridges perjury and conspiracy trial.
Connie Smythe, manager of the Toronto Maple Leafs, was the guest of honor at the luncheon of the New York Hockey Writers Association at Leone's yesterday.

Jake La Motta, middleweight champion of the world, was ordered yesterday by the State Athletic Commission to sign by Feb. 1 for a defense of his title within the following 60 days on pain of forfeiture of the crown.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- A five-year record of the Office of Vocational Rehabilitation, published today by the Federal Security Agency, showed that 220,000 disabled civilians had been restored to a self-supporting status at a cost to the Federal Treasury of $76,000,000.

A 150-apartment cooperative garden-type housing development for veterans will be built soon in Mount Vernon, according to plans announced yesterday by Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, and William Hart Hussey, Mayor of Mount Vernon.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 (AP) -- A field goal by Rene Herrerias, his only two points of the game, gave San Francisco University the margin of victory over La Salle, 46 to 44, in the second game of tonight's Convention Hall basketball doubleheader before 5,869 fans. Santa Clara routed Temple, 66 -- 41, in the opener.
MADRID, Dec. 29 -- Foreign Minister Alberto Martin Artajo arrived back in Madrid today after representing Spain at the inauguration of the Holy Year ceremonies in Rome.

TOKYO, Dec. 29 -- The Soviet declaration of war six days before the Japanese surrender saved China and other countries from widespread germ warfare plotted by the Kwantung Army, the Japanese Communist party asserted today.
Group Securities, Inc., a mutual fund represented by twenty-two classes of securities, announced in its sixteenth annual report yesterday that it had net assets of $67,651,000 on Nov. 30, 1949.
I wish to call your attention to certain facts and conditions in Greece which are too little understood.

Elliott V. Bell, retiring New York State Superintendent of Banks, in his annual report to be issued today, demands clarification of the Federal Open Market Committee's current policy on Government securities. The policy was initiated by the committee after an announcement on June 28.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Specific limits on speculation by large traders in eggs, soybeans, wool-tops and cottonseed oil were recommended as regulations for trading in futures by the Commodity Exchange Authority in its annual report released today.
In World War I, senior military officers were at a loss to know how to use the latest military device -- the airplane.

HAMBURG, Germany, Friday, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Spokesmen for West Germany's millions of homesick and ill-housed refugees served notice today that the refugees intended to get increased Federal attention for their problems in 1950.

Following the example of other Soviet puppet regimes, the Communist Government of Hungary has now extended its "socialization" program by seizing virtually all foreign-owned, including American, enterprises, and all Hungarian industries employing more than ten, and in some cases five, persons.

Vincent R. Impellitteri, President of the City Council, was sworn in for a second term at 3 P. M. yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Gavagan. Attending the ceremony in Mr. Impellitteri's office at City Hall were Mrs. Impellitteri and about 100 relatives and friends.
GEORGETOWN, S. C., Dec. 29 (UP) -- Bernard M. Baruch, 79-year-old elder statesman, said today the Social Security retirement age should be raised beyond 65.

With a sharp increase in use of public service advertising sponsored by the Advertising Council, business demonstrated in 1949 a growing interest in broad human problems, it was reported yesterday by T. S. Repplier, council president, in a year-end review.

Elizabetta Barbato, Italian soprano who made her debut with the Metropolitan Opera in the role of Tosca this season, last night undertook the less intensive part of Cio-Cio-San in "Madame Butterfly." The listener, admittedly, had to take the bad with the good, but the odds, last night, were in the young singer's favor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Department of Defense announced late today that the Navy would augment its Seventh Task Fleet, which operates in the Western Pacific, by two destroyers and an aircraft carrier of 27,000 tons displacement and carrying an air group, next month.

Sherman White scored 31 points and carried Long Island University to a notable 73-66 victory over Western Kentucky last night at Madison Square Garden. N. Y. U. overwhelmed Yale, 76 -- 62, in the opener so that it was an all-winning night before 18,000 fans for the local quintets.

Lack of a unified Department of Defense cost America literally billions of dollars in wastage in the last war, and that wastage represents a considerable part of our national debt today, Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War, declared yesterday.

A new dramatic series entitled "For the Living" will be presented by WNEW under the auspices of the American Cancer Society for a period of thirteen weeks, beginning Tuesday, from 9 to 9:15 P. M. With Edward G. Robinson as narrator, the cast will include Hollywood personalities.

"Broncho Charlie" Miller, a legendary figure in his own time, will complete next Sunday the first hundred years of an action-packed existence that has left him with deep Indian arrow scars, a flowing white mane reaching to his shoulders and a strong distaste for "drugstore cowboys."

By every measurable test the Tennessee Valley Authority continues to be a success. Its sixteenth annual report shows an annual production of nearly sixteen billion kilowatt-hours, or about ten times as much electricity as was available in its area in 1933. In 1933, 3 per cent of the farms in the area were electrified; now the proportion is 66 per cent and growing.
Those who have not had their fill of waterfowl shooting and want to get in one last fling before the season closes will have until Jan. 7 to complete the trip, and Rhode Island is the nearest point.
