Mrs. Alger Hiss testified in defense of her husband in his perjury trial in Federal Court yesterday and denied the main points of the Whittaker Chambers story on which the two-count indictment of Mr. Hiss is based.

The division of Paramount Pictures, Inc., into two companies, production and theatre circuit, was announced formally yesterday by top executives to nearly 5,000 employes in Canada and this country over an extensive telephone hookup.

Baseball hasn't run out of surprises in the waning hours of 1949. From Detroit yesterday came the announcement that Charlie Keller, who received his unconditional release from the Yankees less than a month ago, had been signed by the Tigers and would report next spring as an active player.

Reports reaching traders in the rubber futures market here yesterday indicated that Russia had again entered the crude rubber market in Singapore, contracting for the delivery of 10,000 tons a month through January, February and March of 1950.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 29 -- Warner Brothers today concluded a deal for John Garfield to star in "The Breaking Point," a photoplay by Ranald MacDougall which Michael Curtiz will direct and Jerry Wald will produce next month. The picture, which deals with the life of a tramp-fishing boat captain in Southern California waters, will be Garfield's first since 1945 for Warners, the company that brought him to Hollywood in 1938.

The Coplon-Gubitchev spy case bobbed yesterday upon uncharted legal seas as Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan conducted a hearing into the claim of Valentin A. Gubitchev, Soviet official and United Nations engineer, to diplomatic immunity from prosecution in the courts of this country.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- Full support of the proposal for a national theatre assembly to further the interests of a truly national theatre embracing the widest regional and local participation was unanimously adopted here today by the American Educational Theatre Association.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- The Public Service Commission, in a precedent-making decision, authorized the Rochester Telephone Corporation today to charge 10 cents instead of 5 cents for local coin box calls. It is the first increase in telephone coin box rates authorized by the commission since it was established in 1907.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 29 -- A sweeping nationalization decree affecting all trade and industry in Hungary still in private hands or financed by foreign capital was announced today. Major victims of this "significant step toward socialism' were American, British, Swiss, French and Dutch industrial holdings in this country.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Muskeeter, after missing the winner's circle in five previous starts, finally came through as he survived a stretch battle to capture the feature at Tropical Park today by a nose.
Admirers of oriental motifs will welcome the appearance of fresh design forms from the East that will blend equally well with cotemporary or traditional furnishings.

HONG KONG, Dec. 29 -- Nationalist headquarters on Hainan asserted today that their pilots had disrupted Communist preparations for an early invasion of the island in air and naval raids along the Kwangtung "invasion coast," begun yesterday and continued today.

In those nations where free government is nonexistent, or where an omnipotent state has assumed full responsibility for making the economic system work, the relationship between government and business is preordained, and therefore non-debatable. In this and other countries, however, where men are as united in their allegiance to free enterprise as they are to free government, the reverse holds true.

BOSTON, Dec. 29 -- Glyndon C. Van Deusen, professor of history at the University of Rochester, received the fourth annual Albert J. Beveridge memorial fellowship of the American Historical Association tonight.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 30 (AP) -- India today announced recognition of the Communist Chinese Government in Peiping.

A group of lawyers representing mainly the American Bar Association and the National Council on Family Relations will meet today at the Park Sheraton Hotel to consider reform of divorce laws. The objective will be to "eliminate grounds, thereby making divorce courts remedial rather than punitive," with nation-wide uniformity as a long-range goal.

LANCASTER, Pa., Dec. 29 (UP) -- A court today approved a bequest to Lafayette College from the estate of a former United States diplomat, who stipulated that the money could not be used for Catholics and Jews. A spokesman for the college, at Easton, said it would accept the bequest "although we don't like the strings attached that smack of religious discrimination."

JERUSALEM, Dec. 29 -- Although detailed plans for the proposed restoration of the Holy Sepulcher Basilica in Old Jerusalem were not available here, it was learned tonight that the recommendations called for a return to the original design, as planned and executed by St. Helena during the reign of Constantine, at the beginning of the fourth century.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Minute Maid Corporation of New York today filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 280,000 shares of its 10 cents par value common stock.
An indicated 50,000,000 gallon increase in water consumption on Wednesday caused city officials yesterday to warn that New York City's water situation was still critical.
Mackellar Gerbracht, in 50 Broad St; Lawrence A. Epter Associates Inc, in 225 Broadway; Ayerow Christian Projects Inc and Edwin F. O'Hanlon, in 39 Cortlandt St -- Brown, Harris, Stevens Inc, broker.
ROME, Dec. 29 -- A riot occurred in Milan today when police broke up an unauthorized demonstration of workers moving toward the center of the city.

GOFFSTOWN, N. H., Dec. 29 -- Dr. Hermann Sander, Manchester physician, was charged today with the first degree murder of a 59-year-old cancer patient, who died Dec. 4, in what Sheriff Thomas F. O'Brien termed a mercy killing.
GENEVA, Dec. 29 -- The United States will oppose the continued allocation of coal and European coke on the present basis by the Coal Committee of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

The three major Port of New York Authority airports here handled 29,909 plane movements last month, Walter P. Hedden, director of port development of the interstate agency, reported yesterday. Mr. Hedden was the speaker at a luncheon of transportation and utilities specialists of the American Economic Association at the Commodore Hotel.
LOS ANGELES, Calif., Dec. 29 -- Lilly Dache is quite emphatic about it -- women dress for men:

At a special session yesterday in the Statler Hotel members of the American Association for the Advancement of Science were assured that scientific progress will not be impeded by the current practice of making the results of some Government or privately sponsored research projects "classified" material to be withheld from general circulation.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Kentucky gave Villanova its first defeat of the year tonight, 57 -- 56, in an overtime period of the second game of the Sugar Bowl basketball tournament. Bradley won easily from Tulane, 78 -- 46, in the early game and meets Kentucky in the final tomorrow night.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 29 -- The Soviet Union brought the Chinese situation before the United Nations Security Council today by disputing the right of Nationalist China to hold a seat in the world organization's top political body.

A new organization, the Athletic Trainers' Association, Eastern Division, was formed yesterday at the Hotel Piccadilly, where the first national convention of sports trainers ended its three-day session.

A new overture by Philip Clapp, or at least an "Overture to a Comedy," by him, which has been played in many other cities, but was heard here for the first time, opened the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Dimitri Mitropoulos last night in Carnegie Hall.

When President Truman met with his defense and foreign affairs experts yesterday in Washington on what to do about China in general, and with Formosa in particular, a number of extremely stubborn facts and dilemmas faced him. Among these were the following:

There may be many fine things deep in the heart of Texas but weather is certainly not one of them, according to Sir Thomas Beecham, British conductor, who sailed for home yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth after a two-month lecture and concert tour of this country and Canada.

Irate Queens commuters on the Long Island Rail Road will go before the Public Service Commission on Jan. 6 to protest the road's petition to eliminate two stations, Albert L. Bontbellier, president of the Springfield Gardens Taxpayers and Citizens Association, Inc., asserted yesterday.

The nation's gasoline stocks increased 1,674,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 110,164,000 barrels, compared with 108,490,000 a week earlier and 100,286,000 a year ago.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 29 -- Paul G. Dietz of the University of Pittsburgh wrested the lead from Eliot Hearst in the tournament for the individual championship of the National Intercollegiate Chess League by defeating the Columbia captain in today's fifth round on the Rutgers campus. It was the Blue and White player's first setback.
Mayor O'Dwyer brought his bride, the former Miss Sloan Simpson, home to New York last night.

The Analin Corporation, Harry Forsyth, president, sold the one-story taxpayer building on the west side of Seventy-sixth Street, between Roosevelt Avenue and Thirty-seventh Road, in Jackson Heights, Queens, to Isidor Lagawitz.

MOSCOW, Dec. 29 -- In one of the sharpest criticisms to appear recently in the Soviet press, Pravda today charged the United States was trying to place in power in Japan the same type of war criminals as are now being tried in Khabarovsk on germ warfare charges and that the United States itself was conducting experiments in bacteriological weapons in preparation for a new war.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- Forty-six thousand applications have been received by the Veterans' Bonus Bureau in anticipation of the payment of bonuses to former residents of the state under a constitutional provision which becomes effective Sunday, Gerald E. Rowley, director of the bureau. said today.
In an effort to minimize the effects of the controversial two-minute rule, coaches of local college basketball teams yesterday decided to contest all future intracity games under a modified code.

The economy of the dictatorships ever since the First World War has been a source of enlightenment, but also of bewilderment to the experts. They used to be able to figure out the play of "orthodox" economic forces, but nowadays capricious political forces intervene and they are beyond calculation.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Santa Clara's football team and rooters rolled into town aboard a special train today, ready to go against favored Kentucky in the Orange Bowl classic Jan. 2.
The report of the Superior Oil Company of California, issued yesterday for the quarter ended on Nov. 30, last, disclosed the net profit at $1,831,053 after taxes and all charges.

Maurice A. FitzGerald, who will be sworn in as the Queens Borough President Sunday morning, announced yesterday the names of the fifteen persons who will be associated with him during the coming four years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Radio Station WHBI in Newark, N. J., has dropped a radio program of a Polish shipping line which was called Communist propaganda in a Senate report, Senator Herbert R. O'Conor, Democrat, of Maryland, said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Any who still believe that the laissez faire doctrine of the last century is feasible or even desirable as the base of American political economy in this century will turn impatiently and perhaps angrily away from the fourth annual report to the President by the Council of Economic Advisers, now bereft of its chairman, Dr. Nourse.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation will increase its television output next year by 75 per cent and to meet 1950 quotas will expand manufacturing facilities at its Sunbury (Pa.) plant by one-third, it was announced yesterday by F. M. Sloan, manager of the home radio division.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration today approved the General Electric J-47 turbo-jet engine for use in commercial transport planes.

Secretary of State Dean Acheson was asked yesterday by the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., to "direct" the Chinese Nationalist Government to assure safe conduct for its cargo liner Flying Arrow into and out of the Communist-held the port of Shanghai.

Mr. and Mrs. Barent Ten Eyck of 127 East Ninety-fourth Street and Mr. and Mrs. Dickerman Williams of 520 East Eighty-sixth Street gave a dinner dance last night at the Cosmopolitan Club to introduce their respective daughters, the Misses Catryna Ten Eyck and Joan Dickerman Williams.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The White House said today that President Truman would appear before a joint session of Congress next Wednesday to deliver his State of the Union message.

The cost of providing rail service, partly met by increases in freight rates, reached a new peak last year, A. T. Mercier, president of the Southern Pacific Company, said yesterday in a year-end statement. Despite the leveling-off of railroad revenues from the postwar high of 1948, he said, traffic remained far above the pre-war level.

Three thousand employes of Bloomingdale's were without legal union representation last night after a decision by the National Labor Relations Board setting aside a collective bargaining election held last March.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 29 (UP) -- A top secret official report has warned the Belgian Government that Russian infiltration into the interior of Africa constitutes an imminent threat to the security of the uranium-rich Belgian Congo, it was disclosed tonight.

Kenneth Carter of Plainfield, N. J., accounted for the only upset as singles competition in the Eastern junior and boys' indoor tennis championships progressed to the semi-final stage at the Third Engineers Group Armory, 168th Street and Fort Washington Avenue, yesterday.

The stock market put on another spurt yesterday with a good part of the initiative again supplied by the rails, but late selling reduced the top gains. The list followed closely the action of the carriers and when wavering tendencies developed, prices backed down. The close was mixed with gains predominating, and the composite rate rose 0.45 point.

DESPITE his reputation for parsimony, Branch Rickey is a most extravagant man. But he is shrewdly extravagant, not wastefully so. He had to count pennies and nurse nickels when he instituted the farm system for the St. Louis Cardinals and kept Sam Breadon solvent. In Brooklyn, however, he's had a lot more money to play with. So he's played with it.
BURLINGTON, Wis., Dec. 30 -- A fishing fib involving the demise of a Colorado trout today gave a fabricating Ohioan the title of "world champion liar."

In its first change of ownership since 1921, the old frame building at 2641 Broadway, northwest corner of West 100th Street, has been sold by the estate of Charles Frederick Hoffman to Wacht Rosenblatt. The little three-story structure, one of the few of its kind remaining on Broadway, occupies a lot 26 by 100 feet and was sold in a deal reported yesterday by Henry Shapiro Co., the brokers.

PARIS, Dec. 30 -- Premier Georges Bidault won a personal success today, obtaining a double vote of confidence by an eighteen-vote majority in the National Assembly. The votes were on key measures to introduce higher tax rates to balance the 1950 budget. It was on these measures that the Government had been most violently opposed.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Mackey MacDonald's long shot with two seconds remaining broke a 51-51 deadlock and gave the University of Miami's basketball team a 53-51 victory over the University of Pennsylvania tonight.

The new version of the two-minute rule adopted by the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Basketball Association for intracity games last Thursday had its first test last night at the DeGray Gymnasium, Brooklyn, as St. John's unbeaten Redmen took on Wagner College.

The Lawyers Mortgage Title Company has agreed to make mortgage loans totaling $1,000,000 on 150 residences in the $10,300 price class being erected by the Abbelow Construction Corporation in the Robinswood development in Valley Stream, L. I., where more than 75 per cent of the dwellings have been purchased.
The purchase of the new Panamanian-flag vessel George by the Zim Israel Navigation Company was announced here yesterday by the American-Israeli Shipping Company, New York, agents for Zim.
CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (UP) -- The National Safety Council estimated today that the nation's traffic deaths for 1949 would total 500 fewer than last year.

With the curve determined to some extent by the course pursued by the Federal Government, a general upward trend in business during 1950, at least in the first half, is predicted by leaders of American business. Their views are contained in the annual symposium of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., on the outlook for the new year, released yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday that he would make "a full examination of the facts" before arriving at any decision on the request that he appoint a fact-finding committee to consider the demands of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, for increased wages and improved working conditions for the employes of the municipal transit lines.

ROME, Dec. 30 -- The Federal Security Administrator, Oscar R. Ewing, appealed to the United States Congress during a press conference here today to help solve Italy's emigration problem. "Personally, I'd like to see Congress revise our immigration laws on a more numerous basis," he said.

Mayor and Mrs. O'Dwyer will be seen together on television for the first time tonight when they will make an appearance on the New Year's Eve Fund Raising program in behalf of the United Hospital Fund on Station WPIX. The pro gram, presenting stars of the stage, screen, radio and other entertain ment fields, will get under way at 7:30 P. M.

The Shah of Iran, Mohammed Reza Pahlevi, left here for home yesterday after pledging encouragement to private American investment and receiving President Truman's promise of economic and military aid. Iran borders on the Soviet Union.

Women's apparel manufacturers are looking forward to an improvement in business at the outset of the new year, according to a survey of the trade. The upturn will be immediately reflected, they said, in new orders for spring merchandise.

The Port Authority's union bus terminal will not be opened for at least one year, it became known yesterday when the agency disclosed that Governor Dewey and Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey had first rejected and later accepted a $9,194,759 contract for the superstructure, awarded to the second lowest bidder.

The De Laval Stem Turbine Company, Trenton, N. J., announced yesterday that James P. Stewart, formerly a vice president and manager of the commercial sales division, had been elected executive vice president. He will continue as manager of the commercial sales division.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 30 (UP) -- A Government spokesman accused the Soviet Union today of sending terrorist squads into Yugoslavia from Bulgaria.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday the last trading day of the year but closed somewhat irregular 8 points higher to 7 points net lower.

In his difficult post as Secretary General of the United Nations, Trygve Lie has carried out his responsibilities with tact and skill, but we think that he so phrased his New Year's statement published yesterday that an erroneous interpretation might easily be drawn from it.

TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 30 -- Theoretical evidence to support the growing belief among astronomers that extensive magnetic fields exist in space was presented today at the meeting of the American Astronomical Society by Dr. Jesse L. Greenstein of Mt. Wilson and Palomar Observatories and Prof. Leverett Davis Jr. of the Physics Department, California Institute of Technology.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 30 -- In one of the final acts of his administration today, Mayor James M. Curley of Boston locked himself in his office to avoid service of a court order restraining him from granting permits for two outdoor, drive-in motion-picture theatres.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- With an eye to Britain's coming general election the Labor party is beginning a new drive to capture the housewives' vote -- which, it is generally agreed, may prove a decisive factor in the result.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Dec. 30 -A public hearing on another proposed charter that would unite the twin villages of Tarrytown and North Tarrytown into a city -- the seventh community of city status in Westchester County -- was called today for the night of Jan. 10.

Negotiations which had gone on quietly here for two days between Pan American Airways and the Air Line Pilots Association (AFL) over the furlough of 146 Pan American pilots were adjourned for the long holiday week-end, it was learned yesterday.

Lumber production for the week ended Dec. 24 was 42.3 per cent above the comparable week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by trade associations. Shipments were up 27.4 per cent, and orders 14.6 per cent.

It will be a pretty pernickety reveler who can't find something acceptable in New York tonight to speed him into the New Year. From fruit juice to champagne, and from watch hour church services and midnight masses to sophisticated entertainment in night clubs and hotels, the city is prepared to kiss the Nineteen Forties goodby and head hopefully into the Nineteen Fifties.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 30 -- Gov. James H. Duff announced today that he would be a candidate for the Republican nomination for Senator in the May primary election, touching off what is expected to be a bitter fight for control of the party in Pennsylvania.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- Fifteen individuals and three organizations were named today on the honor roll of The Chicago Defender, a leading Negro newspaper, for "outstanding contributions in advancing the frontier of American democracy in 1949."

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Hamtramck, Mich., junior tennis team defeated Mexico City's team, four matches to three, today in an international contest staged in conjunction with the third annual Orange Bowl junior championships.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 30 -- Universal-International has concluded deals for leading ladies in two forthcoming films, it was learned today.

The Gramercy Theatre, which recently introduced a policy of showing single feature pictures accompanied by a program of short subjects, today will present a revival of "Major Barbara" as its second attraction under the new set-up.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 30 -- The Finance Ministers of France, Italy, the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg have scheduled a meeting in Paris for the second week of January to resume negotiations for a regional economic grouping called Finebel.

"AT the last stroke of midnight on New Year's Eve," Kim Carruthers, the benevolent bookman, said, "all books become one year older. It's an odd thing, but it's so." The evening promised to be a long one, and he was in a mood to be oracular.
A critical shortage of potash is developing throughout the country which may seriously interfere with sales of this chemical on "spot contracts" next spring, it was learned here yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Britain acted today to ease her currency controls somewhat. The Treasury gave assurance to foreign investors that the door, already open to approved investments, would remain open for the escape of their capital at any time. Hitherto it has been frozen for ten years.

Instructions to commanding officers of the Police Department in areas where various racial groups live to promote the friendship of leading citizens there for both as a check on police service and "in case of public disorder" were contained in the new Manual of Procedure, the contents of which are effective for department members and civilians affiliated with it at midnight tonight.

Mr. and Mrs. Lester W. Perrin of Far Hills, N. J., s[nd Aiken, S. C., gave a supper dance last night in the Starlight Roof of the; Waldorf-Astoria to introduce to society Mrs. Perrin's daughter, Miss Suzanne D. Kuser. The room wa decorated with cyhotium ferns, smilax and quince blossoms, which were arranged to simulate trees.

Food sales here this week are expected to exceed those during the Christmas week in a day-for-day comparison, according to reports received yesterday from food outlets throughout the city. Groceries are also preparing for more last-minute selling of food and beverages because of more home entertainment this year than last.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 30 -- An error of judgment by the pilot was reported officially today to have been the probable direct cause of the crash of the KLM (Royal Dutch Airlines) Constellation on a hillside near Bombay's Santa Cruz Airport last July 12.
DALLAS, Tex., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Navy cashed in on the free throws and Southern Methodist did not, so the midshipmen won, 53 -- 50, tonight in the opening game of the Cotton Bowl basketball tournament.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Dec. 30 -- Lieut. Harry L. Denham, 44 years old, of the Palisades Interstate Park Police, known to thousands of New Yorkers who frequent this resort, will be retired tomorrow after twenty-two years' service because of a physical disability.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UP) -- The Agriculture Department reported today that farm prices had dropped below parity, the so-called fair level, for the first time in eight years.

It is hard to estimate exactly how many strangers come to our big town during the holiday season. In some countries the figure could easily be had, for everybody would have to register with the police. In other countries there wouldn't be any figure, since strangers would not be encouraged to move around.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Dec. 30 -- The problem of nationalization of basic industries and proposals for worker participation in plant management will be taken up by the Western German Federal Republic in the coming year, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer declared today.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- Governor Dewey is expected to call upon the Legislature next week to expand the scope and functions of the joint legislative committee on problems of the aging so that an exhaustive study may be made of the economic problems of older persons.

On Dec. 22 the Board of Estimate, in Mayor O'Dwyer's absence, deferred action on a resolution to appropriate funds for a survey to reclassify titles and modernize pay schedules in our municipal civil service. The most vocal opponent of this career and pay plan study, Jack Bigel, president of a United Public Workers local, was present in the Board of Estimate chamber when the adjournment was announced.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 30 -- Dr. Merle A. Tuve of the Carnegie Institution, who helped to develop wartime radar, called tonight for a fresh recognition of esthetic and spiritual goals in higher education.

HONG KONG, Dec. 30 -- The possibilities that the Hong Kong street car strike may spread into a stoppage of most of the colony's utilities increased here today as the trolleys failed to operate for a third day. Bus, gas and telephone workers decided to press within the next few days wage demands similar to those being advanced by the trolley men on an ultimatum basis with a threat to strike.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 623,303 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 16,420 cars or 2.6 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 14,604 cars, or 2.4 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year and 23,949 cars, or 4 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Joint Chiefs of Staff will inspect United States forces in Japan next February, it was announced today at the Department of Defense. At the same time, Senator William E. Knowland, Republican, of California, just returned from the Far East, called for United States support for the Nationalist garrison of Formosa.

Hugo E. Rogers, outgoing Borough President of Manhattan and former leader of Tammany Hall, was appointed yesterday on the recommendation of Mayor O'Dwyer, to the $10,000-a-year post of special counsel to the Corporation Counsel.

With a thirteen-state police alarm broadcast for the apprehension of Louis Chazen, who disappeared Christmas night, the District Attorney's office announced yesterday that it was continuing its investigation into accounts maintained by Chazen as bookkeeper for the Publix Shirt Company.

TUSKEGEE, Ala., Dec. 30 -- Three lynchings were recorded in the South in 1949, a slight rise over the average number of the last five years, it was reported here today by F. D. Patterson, president of Tuskegee Institute.

Retail sales here again dropped below figures established last year, according to estimates made yesterday by trade observers. Department store sales were estimated to be about 8 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were 1 per cent above last year.

I Among the parties given yesterday for debutantes were tea dances Ifor the Misses Mary Coleman Dillon and Mary Leslie Guion Hewitt. Miss Dillon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Dillon of 447 East Fifty-seventh Street, was introduced to society at the party given for her in the Crystal Room of the Ritz-Carlton by her parents.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Dec. 30 -- The state of Viet Nam, which includes 40 per cent of the area and most of the population of Indo-China, took a new step today toward a limited dominion status in the French Union.

OLD FORGE, N. Y., Dec. 30 -- Since 1936 when 1,200 ski-conscious New Yorkers arrived on the first New York Central snow train to this central Adirondack winter playland, Old Forge has enjoyed an enviable reputation for its facilities.

The beginning of the new year will be marked by more than the usual number of worshipers at Christian churches tonight when Roman Catholics all over the world will attend masses in celebration of the opening of the Roman Catholic Jubilee Year of 1950.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A committee of Protestant clergymen replied today to the Christmas message of Pope Pius XII, which, they said, contained "a definite appeal for Protestants to enter the Roman Catholic Church."

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Concurrently with recognition of the Chinese Communist Government, Britain will establish relations with the regime of former Emperor Bao Dai in the State of Viet Nam, Indo-China, official quarters indicated today. A convention providing for the internal autonomy of Viet Nam within the French Union was signed in Saigon today.

BERLIN, Dec. 30 -- The circulation of newspapers and magazines in the territory of the Eastern German Democratic Republic passes out of private hands tomorrow and becomes exclusively a Government monopoly. This move completes a series of restrictive measures in the publications field that was begun last spring.

India's Prime Minister, Pandit Nehru, is both right and courageous in putting his Government solidly behind the so-called "Reform Bill" and in declaring that he is ready to take this issue to the country. The body of thought that Pandit Nehru represents has for years taken the position that India's Government must be secular.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals has upheld the conviction of a professed clergyman accused of preaching on a New York street without a permit and of denouncing the Catholic and Jewish faiths.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 30 -- India's recognition of the Communist Government of China made her the second nation outside the Iron Curtain countries -- Burma was first -- and the first of British Commonwealth Nations to do so.
BOSTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau tonight issued this report of winter sports conditions in New England:

Income tax liability suits against four telegraph companies were filed by the United States Attorney's office in Federal court yesterday. The suits coincided with the issuance of a show cause order by Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe restraining the Western Union Telegraph Company from making wire rental payments to stockholders of the defendant companies.

Eleven Japanese journalists arrived at the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, at 6:30 P. M. yesterday to attend a three-week American Press Institute seminar at Columbia University beginning next Tuesday. A twelfth member of the group will arrive next week.

Man may have a sixth sense that supplies to the brain information now attributed to "hunch" or "intuition," it was agreed at the meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science in the New Yorker Hotel yesterday.

A charge that the Federal Government was "out of control," in addition to being over-centralized, disorganized and "frightfully wasteful," was made yesterday by Dr. James K. Pollock, a member of the Hoover Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 30 (AP) -- George H. Sauer stalked out as head football coach of Navy today because the academy fired two of his assistants.

CAIRO, Dec. 30 -- The Arab News Agency said today that King Abdullah of Jordan had formally incorporated Jordanian-occupied Palestine into his kingdom. The dispatch was dated from Amman, Abdullah's capital.

Long-run trends are tending to produce an American economic structure characterized by high and more stable levels of employment and production, Prof. Sumner H. Slichter of Harvard University reported yesterday before the American Economic Association.

A plan for building a new "third stage" of the city's Delaware water project, making available an additional 285,000,000 gallons a day by 1960, was submitted yesterday to the Board of Estimate by the Board of Water Supply. The new third stage would cost about $140,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- President Truman reported today that he was preparing legislation to enable the United States to "assume its share" of the cost of a $54,900,000 Near East economic development and refugee-relief program propose by the United Nations.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Illinois rolled up its seventh basketball victory in nine starts by trimming Princeton, 68 -- 61, tonight.

EASTON, Pa., Dec. 30 -- Dr. Ralph C. Hutchison, president of Lafayette College, announced tonight that $13,506 from the estate of Frederick F. T. Dumont of Lancaster, Pa., left to the college, would be used for the college's general endowment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UP) -- The executive committee of the National Capital Sesquicentennial Commission recommended today that the Freedom Fair, scheduled to begin July 4, be postponed until the spring of 1951.
The winter cruise season, which got off to a rather slow start, is picking up momentum, according to a canvass of passenger traffic officials yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Eastern Air Lines today sued Capt. Erick Rios Bridoux, Bolivian pilot, for $500,000, declaring him solely responsible for the collision here Nov. 1 between its DC-4 and the P-38 he piloted. In the collision at the edge of National Airport, fifty-five persons, all aboard the liner, were killed.

Wagner's "Lohengrin" returned to the Metropolitan Opera last night after an absence of three years. Fritz Stiedry led the work for his first time with the company and the leading singers were Polyna Stoska as Elsa and Kurt Baum in the name role.

TORONTO, Dec. 30 (Canadian Press) -- The Mexican Light and Power Company, Ltd., announced today the "plan of arrangement" under which it is proposed to reorganize the capital structure of itself and two subsidiaries.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Kentucky won its third Sugar Bowl basketball championship tonight, 71 -- 66, over Bradley with a brilliant second-half charge which threatened to smother the Peoria, Ill., team.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Cleated football warriors, fresh from college gridiron triumphs, will clash here tomorrow in the greatest game of their respective careers. The twenty-four stars representing the East and a similar number wearing the colors of the West will battle it out in the twenty-fifth classic for the Shriners' Crippled Children's Hospital.

The Morlyn Realty Corporation represented by William L. Schwartz, attorney, has purchased the one-story taxpayer building at 311 Bruckner Boulevard, the Bronx, from the 311 Bruckner Boulevard Corporation. The building is on an irregular plot about 78 by 115 feet.

Members of the Richmond County Democratic Committee, of which Jeremiah A. Sullivan is chairman, expressed indignation last night when they learned that Borough President Cornelius A. Hall had reappointed the members of his cabinet during the day.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 30 -- Finishing with 6 1/2-1/2 after scoring again in the seventh and final round, Paul Luther Dietz of the University of Pittsburgh won the biennial tournament for the individual championship of the National Intercollegiate Chess League on the Rutgers campus today.

The League of Women Voters will open a new state-wide campaign for the adoption of permanent personal registration, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Edward M. Boyne, president of the League of Women Voters of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Government will begin pouring the $2,800,000,000 GI insurance refund into the hands of 16,000,000 veterans on Jan. 16. Announcing this today, the Veterans Administration said it hoped to get most of the checks to policyholders by June 30.

The Department of Agriculture has a good opportunity about this time of the year to appreciate the problem faced each January by the President's budget advisers in arriving at their initial estimates of federal receipts and expenditures for the coming fiscal twelve months.

Robert L. Joseph, co-sponsor of the Strindberg play, "The Father," announced yesterday the purchase of "Apple of Discord," a comedy written by Louis Kronenberger, better known for his professional appraisal of Broadway stage products.

United Aircraft Products, Inc., will double production of its spun aluminum seamless kitchenware line in 1950, John M. Meyers, president, disclosed yesterday. The company will change its method of distribution on Jan. 2 with a view toward insuring sales of additional production, he said.

What aptly might be termed the "great fishing contest season" is now getting under way in Florida, with the Metropolitan Miami Fishing Tournament initiating the catch-as-catch-can angling for the fifteenth consecutive year.

TRENTON, Dec. 30 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll started inquiries today into the high salaries of officials of the Port of New York Authority and into the seven-cent fare charged on bus lines in New Jersey.

HONG KONG, Saturday, Dec. 31 -- Ten American seamen aboard the Isbrandtsen freighter Flying Arrow cabled United States Secretary of State Dean Acheson today that they were being compelled "by force of arms" to sail the ship, loaded, they said, with chemicals, into Communist-occupied Shanghai despite Chinese Nationalist warships and mines.

Marginal producers in this Federal Reserve District were having a "more difficult" competitive struggle during the three months ended Nov. 30, according to reports by field representatives of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- Montgomery Ward Co. announced today that Morris Ginsburg, vice president in charge of the New York City office, has been "removed because of noncompliance with company rules and policies." Joseph C. Kracht, who has been with the company twelve years, was elected to replace him.
TRENTON, Dec. 30 -- J. Lindsay De Valliere, State Budget Director, reported today that New Jersey's revenue situation was not as bad as at first believed.

The water shortage in New York City and New Jersey may well be a blessing in disguise. For many year members of organizations such as the friends of the Land have been warning the people of this country about the urgent necessity for conserving our two basic resources -- land and water.

City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses was authorized yesterday by the Board of Estimate to apply to the Federal Government for an advance of $900,000 in planning funds for a midtown Manhattan expressway to connect the Lincoln and Queens Midtown Tunnels.

The venetian blind has come a long way since its introduction. Most recent developments, however, indicate that designers are still searching for the ideal method of screening large window areas and controlling light.

In the brief interval between Christmas and New Year's it is customary for leaders in industry and in public affairs to gaze into the coming months, and beyond, and to announce what they see there. Whether it is because forecasters are filled at this time with holiday spirit, or because men never lose hope that tomorrow will be better, their prophecies for the most part are cheering.

Pitted against Dr. Max Euwe, Amsterdam's chess-playing schoolmaster and holder of the world championship in 1935, Larry Evans, 17-year-old New Yorker, played convincingly to a draw in thirty-five moves in the second round of the international tournament at Hastings yesterday, according to a report from England.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Eight groups of Northern and Midwestern soft coal operators filed unfair labor practice charges today against John L. Lewis's United Mine Workers.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- Ownership of a manuscript does not include the right of publication, the Court of Appeals has ruled unanimously in a case involving a story written by Samuel L. Clemens under his pen-name, Mark Twain.

RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Favored North Carolina State found Penn State's zone defense troublesome for eighteen minutes tonight, but then began to roll for a 50-40 victory and top honors in the Dixie basketball classic.

The sizzling Rangers, beaten only twice in their last eleven games, tackle the Boston Bruins, who have a spurt of their own to protect, in the traditional New Year's Eve hockey game in Madison Square Garden tonight.

Discovery of the existence in green plants of a hitherto unknown force that enables them to utilize the energy of sunlight to create food with an efficiency four times greater than had been generally believed was announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

Being actively engaged in the garage field for the last thirty years throughout New York City, I am acutely aware of the parking situation throughout the Bronx, which is becoming progressively worse. Our largest shopping area -- Fordham Road -- is one of the biggest sufferers.
On Dec. 19 you published a letter from Lewis Mayers of New York City, who referred, during the course of a discussion of the American Civil Liberties Union, to the Bell Aircraft strike.

There probably will be little if any change in 1950 in the cost of building and total expenditures for new construction, as compared with 1949, according to James M. Ashley, president of the Producers Council, national organization of building product manufacturers.

Johnson Johnson, manufacturers of surgical dressings in New Brunswick, N. J., announced yesterday a new liberalized pension plan embracing 10,000 employes and paying, with Social Security benefits, up to 56 per cent of average annual earnings.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- President Truman read his message on the State of the Union to his Cabinet twice this morning. First he read it straight through to give the members the tone of it. Then he read the message analytically, line by line, to allow them to discuss its many proposals -- just about every Administration measure that Congress failed to act on at this year's session.

JAKARTA (Batavia), Indonesia, Dec. 30 (AP) -- H. Merle Cochran, who for eighteen months helped to hammer out Indonesian independence, handed his credentials today as first United States Ambassador to the new United States of Indonesia to President Sukarno.

A full-sized buying wave in the automotive issues lifted the stock market yesterday to new high levels since the summer of 1946. In the last five-hour trading session of 1949, traders staged another all-out bullish demonstration which raised prices 1 to 2 points and advanced the composite rate 0.84 point.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 30 (AP) -- A crowd of 9,030, largest weekday turnout of the meeting, visited Tropical Park today and saw the Palatine Stable's Dobodura capture the featured Brigantine Purse.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that the city would ask the 1950 Legislature for an early validation of the Sharkey rent-eviction control local law declared unconstitutional by the Court of Appeals last Thursday. The Mayor said Corporation Counsel John P. McGrath would draft the necessary bill for submission to the Legislature as soon as possible after it convenes at Albany next Wednesday.

Formation of seven committees to enlist the cooperation of industry and civic groups in preparing smoke control regulations for the city was announced yesterday by William H. Byrne, director of the Bureau of Smoke Control.

Pablo Eisenberg, top-seeded Millburn, N. J., player, and Roger Young, Hill School star who is rated No. 4, got through their semi-final singles matches yesterday in the Eastern indoor junior and boys' tennis tournament at the Third Engineers Group Armory.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Government today ordered sharp cuts in next year's corn and rice plantings in a move to prevent new surpluses.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 30 -- The possibility of the intervention of Iraq and Jordan in the Syrian crisis is seen by Israel as likely to hinder the efforts for peace between Israel and the Arab states. Diplomatic representatives of the big powers, including United States Ambassador James G. McDonald, have informed their respective Governments that this is Israel's position.

Plans for a conference of the International Bar Association in London next year, July 19-26, were made known yesterday. The association, which was formed on Feb. 17, 1947, is composed of bar associations of the principal nations of the world.

Mr. and Mrs. George T. Delacorte Jr. of New York and Old Greenwich, Conn., gave a dance last night in the Roof of the St. Regis to present to society their daughter. Miss Margarita Eugenia Delacorte. The debutante is a sister of the Misses Consuelo, Marianne and Victoria Delacorte, who were introduced to society together in 1947. _

HONG KONG, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Hong Kong Supreme Court tonight extended indefinitely the injunctions granted to the Chinese Nationalists and Communists in their dispute over ownership of two Chinese airlines. An early hearing was promised.

When florist shops reopened last Tuesday after the holiday week-end, evergreens and holly had disappeared as if by magic. Refrigerators and counters were filled with many flowers that were reminiscent of spring instead of winter.

The various specialists and agencies now trying to treat the ills of individuals and families must pool their knowledge and work together for the good of the "whole man," speakers emphasized yesterday at the annual meeting of the National Council on Family Relations.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 30 (AP) -- A battle of T-formations will take place in the Blue-Gray football game tomorrow, but the twentieth letter of the alphabet has a triple meaning.

DANBURY, Conn., Dec. 30 -- The fact that Representative J. Parnell Thomas of New Jersey, serving a six-to-eighteen-month sentence for padding his Congressional payroll, is hospitalized was confirmed late today by the warden of the Federal Correctional Institution here, but he added, "there is nothing wrong with him that is causing us any worry."

Coin-operated vending machines that may revolutionize the present method of home milk delivery to apartment houses and housing projects will be installed in selected parts of the city in the next two months. The machines have been developed and produced under the direction of the City Milk Company of Maspeth, Queens.

An 11-year-old French boy who arrived in this country on Christmas eve to be the guest of the Forest Hills, Queens, Boys Club, flew back to Paris yesterday from the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, wearing a ten-gallon hat.

The New York Stock and Curb Exchanges and other domestic security markets will be open for business two hours today, but will be closed on Monday. All domestic commodity markets will be closed both today and Monday. The Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges will be open today, but will be closed on Monday. The Winnepeg grain pit will be closed both today and Monday.
The heavy hand of near-tragedy hung over the boxing last night in Madison Square Garden.

Pillsbury Mills made public yesterday the recipe that won $50,000 for Mrs. Ralph E. Smafield of Detroit in a contest that wound up Dec. 12, when 100 finalists spent the day cooking in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 30 -- The Congressional commission headed by peronista Deputies struck out into a new field today with its numerous "interventions." A cultural institute in Rosario, whose purpose is to foster cultural relations between the United States and Argentina, was visited by the police, who took detailed photographs and asked to examine files of correspondence and business accounts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Michigan Associated Telephone Company, Lafayette, Ind., had filed a registration statement covering 50,000 shares of $50 par value cumulative preferred stock to be offered to the public.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Dec. 30 -- A delegation of residents of Jersey City attended the sailing today of the S. S. Exiria, an American Export Lines freighter for Naples and other Mediterranean ports, and witnessed the loading of an eleven-ton snowplow and auto truck, the $20,000 gift of Jersey City residents to the villagers of Capracotta, in the province of Campobasso, Italy.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 30 -- Dr. Ales Bebler of Yugoslavia came out to United Nations headquarters today to present his credentials as Belgrade's representative on the Security Council, and announced that he was highly pleased at the prospect of spending the next two years in the United States.

MANCHESTER, N. H., Dec. 30 -- Dr. Hermann N. Sander of Manchester, charged yesterday with first-degree murder in the alleged "mercy" death of a 59-year-old woman cancer patient, was released today in $25,000 bond, and said he hoped to resume his practice at once.

Archibald Palmer, attorney for Judith Coplon, resorted yesterday to an unusual procedure in his effort to win a retrial of the charges of theft of Government documents of which the former Department of Justice employe was convicted last June in Washington.

CHICAGO, Dec 31 (AP) -- Richard F. Uhlmann, president of the Chicago Board of Trade, predicted toContinued On Page 21, Column 4 day that domestic wheat and flour exports would not exceed 350,000,000 bushels during the current crop year. This would be 50,000,000 bushels less than the Government's goal.

Entries in the twenty-ninth annual exhibition of advertising and editorial art sponsored by the Art Directors Club of New York will be judged by the entire membership of the organization, forming an art jury of 415, it was announced yesterday. Entries for the show, scheduled April 19-29 at the club's headquarters, 115 East Fortieth Street, must be in by Wednesday, Jan. 25.

More detailed reports of Russian buying in the Far East brought a firmer tone to the rubber futures market on the Commodity Exchange in its brief session yesterday. The market which, opening at 10 A. M., closed for the holiday at noon, showed gains of 4 to 11 points, compared with Thursday's closing levels.
Twelve thousand workers who produce most of the furs manufactured in America will have their wages for the next six months cut by 11 per cent, it was announced yesterday.

A 9-year-old boy accidentally started a two-alarm fire yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of the Visitation of the Blessed Virgin Mary, a landmark in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn, when a taper became too hot and he dropped it into the creche in front of the altar.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- After a momentous year, spotlighted by the devaluation of the pound sterling, the stock markets here closed today, the last business day of the year, on an unsteady note.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- President Truman will send to Congress on Jan. 9 a thoroughly restyled budget of about $43,000,000,000, it was learned today, which will show the taxpayer exactly how his money will be spent.

LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 31 -- A Soviet military court sentenced twelve former Japanese Army officers to imprisonment ranging from two to twenty-five years on pleas of guilty to charges of having tried to wage war with germs, the Moscow radio said early today.

Changes in design plans calling for additional recreational and service improvements in the liners Independence and Constitution now under construction for American Export Lines at the Bethlehem Steel Company's Quincy, Mass., shipyard, have set back the delivery date of the ships four months, it was learned yesterday.

MADRID, Dec. 30 -- The Spanish Ambassador to Argentina has obtained release from his post after a year of trying, it was said here tonight by a generally reliable source. It was believed that Generalissimo Francisco Franco's brother Nicolas, now Ambassador to Lisbon, would replace him.
The warmest year in the recorded meteorological history of New York drew toward a close yesterday with the thermometer emphasizing its recent contrariety by recording a new low for the season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Pan American Airways told the Civil Aeronautics Board today that Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc. (Trans World) has used "smear tactics" in opposing Pan American's proposed charter service to Rome next summer at reduced fares.

HONG KONG, Dec. 30 -- The Chinese Communists announced in a broadcast heard here tonight that their conquest of southwest China was concluded except for the existence of a number of isolated units still resisting in Sikang and Yunnan Provinces.
NEGAUNEE, Mich., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Discovery of uranium ore, raw material of atomic energy, in Michigan's rugged north woods was revealed today. Its importance has not yet been determined.

PARIS, Dec. 30 -- As internal sovereignty over Viet Nam was formally handed over by France to Bao Dai today President Auriol sent a message of good wishes to the former Emperor of Annam and to the country over which he seeks to rule.

The young American pianist John Ranck appeared for the second time at Town Hall yesterday evening in a program which included first performances by Fred Werle and the late Charles Tomlinson Griffes, as well as sonatas by Beethoven, Hindemith and dello Joio, and smaller works by Bach and Schumann.
NEWARK, Dec. 30 -- The young couple who entered John Williams taxicab in Elizabeth at 2 A. M. and told him to drive north on Route 25, toward Newark, were pleasant at first.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- Grain markets were unsettled on the Board of Trade today, but on the whole showed considerable resistance to pressure and rallied quickly from breaks. Coarse grains were particularly strong as the result of further talk of export business, with corn gaining 1/8 to 1/2 cent a bushel, while oats were unchanged to 1 cent higher, the latter on the March delivery.

"The Illustrations from the Works of Andreas Vesalius," with introduction, annotations and translations by J. B. DeC. M. Saunders and Charles D. O'Malley, will be issued March 27 by the World Publishing Company in a $10 edition, with a prepublication prize of $8.50.

The Kinsey report, "Sexual Behavior in the Human Male," was both praised and denounced last night by speakers at a symposium session of the American Association for the Advancement of Science at the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Average primary market prices remained unchanged in the week ending Dec. 27, according to the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 151.1 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.2 per cent below four weeks ago and 6.7 per cent below the comparable week of 1948.
LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 30 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, called on the world tonight to have faith in the United Nations and not to despair.

With the idea in mind that quality is often to be preferred to mere quantity, the Yankees' vast baseball empire is about to undergo a major operation that in territorial domain will cut it down by exactly 20 per cent.
SEATTLE, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Huskies of the University of Washington outran Columbia's Lions tonight for a 60-56 basketball victory, their ninth in ten starts this season.

Premier Georges Bidault of France, who staggered successfully through two more votes of confidence yesterday, must feel a little like Christian in "The Pilgrim's Progress." During the forty-day budget debate in the National Assembly he has gone through the Valley of the Shadow of Death, the Slough of Despond and other obstacles, but ahead of him lie many more "Snares, Pits, Traps and Gins."

An orderly in a Bronx hospital collected the tips left to him by departing patients and donated them yesterday to The New York Times Neediest Cases. This anonymous contribution to the thirty-eighth annual appeal of the fund was sent so that "individuals interested in helping themselves" might have the chance to do so.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- An examiner of the Civil Aeronautics Board today recommended giving Eastern Air Lines a permit to fly between San Juan, Puerto Rico, and New York City. The permit would let the line carry passengers, cargo and mail.

MOSCOW, Dec. 30 -- The railroad newspaper Gudok announced today that a five-mile section of the planned extension of Moscow's subway system would open for use Jan. 1, in the latest expansion of the municipal transport system, which now is carrying more than 2,000,000,000 passengers annually.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 30. -- The solution to the race problem in the South is to be found in "ordinary hard work, Christian charity and courage applied in the right place at the right time," the Southern Regional Council declared today in its annual summary and report.

Two American high school seniors proposed world federation as the way to keep peace in the future. ALBANY, Dec.31 (AP)--Governor Dewey today appointed Harold F.Simons of Hamilton as Madison County District Attorney. Mr. Simons, a former special deputy Attorney General assigned to the State Agricultural Department, succeeds Howard E. Zeller. Mr. Zeller was elected to the State Supreme Court last fall.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Dec. 31 --Dr. Herman N. Sander, free in $25,000 bail on a first-degree murder charge involving the alleged "mercy" slaying of a woman cancer patient, calmly resumed his medical practice today.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 31-- A permit has been issued to Sheridan Gardens, Inc., for construction of an apartment development on Sheridan Avenue, between Alina and Virginia Streets, to cost 500,000 and to house 160 families. The development will include eight buildings of frame and masonry construction.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec.31--Pinhas Rosen, Israel Minister of Justice, proposed today the granting of a charter to the Zionist Organization. LONDON, Dec. 31 (Reuters)-- Liverpool blanked Arsenal by 2--0 today to maintain its pace-setting position in the English football league's first division. Manchester United, two points behind, also triumphed.

BONN, Germany, Dec.31 (UP)-- The Western Allies gave their blessing today to a German amnesty law opening the doors of prisons to many political offenders. Neither German nor Western Allied legal experts, however, could define the type of offender affected, or estimate how many would benefit.

WASHINGTON, Dec.31--Judith Coplon petitioned the Supreme Court today to set aside her conviction for espionage last June and to order the District Court here to accord her a new trial. She is now facing trial in New York, along with Valentin A. Gubitchev, for conspiracy and espionage.

WASHINGTON, Dec.31--The foreign and finance ministers of the principal Marshall Plan countries joined today with Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, in stressing the need of further economic integration if recovery gains to date were to be consolidated and Western Europe enabled to stand on its own feet after 1952.

ROME. THE thing which most pleases Vittorio De Sica, director of "The Bicycle Thief," about the success his film has achieved throughout Europe is the fact that much of the applause has come from Italy itself.

At the stroke of noon this Tuesday, Vice President Alber W. Barkley, as President of the Senate, and Sam Rayburn, as Speaker of the House, rap their gavels to call the Senate and the House of Representatives to order. The second session of the Eighty-first Congress will be under way.

MEXICO CITY, Dec.31 (AP)--The Mexican Treasury announced today it would put silver even into the new 25-centavo (three cent) pieces. Mexico, which produces 40 per cent of the world's silver, tries to use as much as possible in her coins.

JAKARTA (Batavia), Indonesia, Dec.31 (Reuters)--Dutch authorities here disclosed today that 630 Japanese war criminals had been embarked from Indonesia last Monday night, a few hours before Indonesian sovereignty was proclaimed.

A continued increase in professional and public interest in the rehabilitation of the disabled marked 1949. BUTTE, Mont., Dec. 31 (UP)--A 21-year-old miner's daughter tonight wiped out five members of her family, including herself. In a New Year's Eve rampage, Lorraine Knapp shot to death with a rifle her mother, two brothers and a sister and then fatally wounded herself.

Contracts guaranteeing the city a minimum annual revenue of $382,500 for the next five years were awarded yesterday for automatic drink vending privileges in the subway stations.

New York University's College of Engineering will hold its first annual art, show at University Heights from Tuesday to Friday. The exhibits will include a sixroom "dream house," oil paintings and cartoons. All are the work of students and faculty members.

The population of the five boroughs in New York now is about 8,200,000, a rise of 745,000, or 10 per cent, over the 1940 census, according to a survey made by Homer Hoyt Associates, land economists of Larchmont, N.Y., and McHugh McCrosby, city planning consultants here.

THE battle of the speeds was the big news of 1949 in the record field. As 1950 begins, it goes on. The record makers have been willing to leave it to the customer to fret his head over three-way changers or extra appliances to make the home apparatus usable in all three speeds.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Dec.31 (UP) --Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek today accused Russia of the "greatest crime in human history" and swore that he would fight "as long as the Soviet aggressor occupies one inch of our territory."
LONDON, Dec.31 (Reuters)--A number of clothing items for children will be exempted from sales tax from next Monday, the British Board of Trade announced today.
